View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne of Ms. Beat\u2019s guest bedrooms, where Ms. Vine was staying during her \u201cGolden Girlz\u201d run, is a homage to the 1976 Brian De Palma horror film, \u201cCarrie,\u201d with nearly 100 framed pieces of memorabilia, and a bedspread that supersizes a photo of the movie\u2019s stars, Piper Laurie and Sissy Spacek, in a familial embrace. Beneath a skull lamp on a bedside table, there is a small framed photo of the late Ms. Arthur (Ms. Beat refers to her as her \u201cspirit animal\u201d), the vestige of a \u201cGolden Girls\u201d-themed room that she had in her former home in Highland Park.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe kitchen features vintage cookie jars, two large graphic framed fruit prints and cabinetry lacquered in bright peacock blue. \u201cI love matchy matchy,\u201d Ms. Beat said, so the appliances and the flatware are that color, too, contrasting with a new set of dishes in Howard Johnson orange.\n\nThe first-floor bathroom is inspired by the \u201cPlanet of the Apes\u201d movies, which featured Brutalist architecture in their production design. A shower curtain reproduces an illustrated movie poster from the 1968 original with a shirtless Charlton Heston displaying his signature brand of hypermasculine anguish.\n\n\u201c\u2018Planet of the Apes\u2019 is very anti-glamour,\u201d Se\u00f1or Amor said. \u201cThe question became, how does that all fit into the home of someone who loves all things beautiful and refined?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIf there is any design regret in the new Chez Beat, it\u2019s the square-seated toilet chosen for the upstairs master bathroom (hidden by a sculptural midcentury modern room divider). It looks really cool, but it\u2019s not very comfortable, several who have experienced it have said.\n\nIn any room, Ms. Beat is an admitted control freak.\n\n\u201cIf you pick up a knickknack and admire it, she comes up behind you to make sure it\u2019s put back in exactly the same place,\u201d Ms. Bolding said. \u201cI\u2019m surprised she doesn\u2019t pull out a ruler.\u201d\n\n\u201cOne of my favorite things to do to drive her crazy is move a tchotchke,\u201d Mr. Diaz said. (Ms. Beat is relaxed enough, though, to live with two dogs: Chihuahua mixes named Miss Toni Home Perm and Darlin\u2019.)\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t want the place to look like the Madonna Inn,\u201d Ms. Beat said, referring to the wackadoodle themed-room hotel in San Luis Obispo, Calif. But she put any concerns about resale value out of her head. \u201cI would never tone down what I do to get more work, so I\u2019d never tone down my personal style to sell the place in the future,\u201d she said. \u201cThis home is not for other people. This place is for me.\u201d", "title": "The \u2018Weird Al Yankovic of Drag\u2019 Gets an Extreme Home Makeover", "authors": ["Frank Decaro"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "In October 2017, Oper Stuttgart presented his half-finished production of \u201cH\u00e4nsel und Gretel,\u201d transposed to Rwanda. Mr. Serebrennikov is also a welcome guest at Komische Oper Berlin. His most recent work there was a modern-day, social media-heavy staging of Rossini\u2019s \u201cIl Barbi\u00e8re di Siviglia\u201d in 2016, which is currently being revived. He was also set to direct Stravinsky\u2019s \u201cThe Rake\u2019s Progress\u201d in the 2019-20 season.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s with great sadness that we think about Kirill,\u201d Barrie Kosky, the Komische Oper\u2019s artistic director, said in an interview. \u201cWe\u2019re all waiting. That\u2019s the most frustrating and saddest thing about it.\u201d\n\nMr. Kosky said that he hoped Mr. Serebrennikov would soon be able to work again at the Komische Oper and elsewhere, but that he was anxious about what the Russian director might face first. \u201cI\u2019m fearing that it will be a bit of Russian grotesque with shades of Bulgakov,\u201d he said, referring to the Russian author of the satirical novel \u201cThe Master and Margarita.\u201d\n\nThe investigation against Mr. Serebrennikov began in May 2017. Prosecutors have so far presented little to support their claims, and they have dismissed striking evidence against them \u2014 multiple newspaper reviews, for instance, of a show they say was never staged. Mr. Serebrennikov has repeatedly protested innocence, most recently on Feb. 21.\n\nAt home and abroad, the outpouring of support for the director has been enormous. A Change.org petition initiated by Thomas Ostermeier, artistic director of the Schaub\u00fchne (another Berlin theater where the Gogol Center has performed in the past) has garnered more than 50,000 signatures. Among the most prominent artists lending their support are the actress Cate Blanchett, the filmmaker Lars von Trier and the Nobel Prize-winning novelist Elfriede Jelinek.\n\nAt a news conference at the Deutsches Theater on Monday, Mr. Serebrennikov\u2019s assistant, Anna Shalashova, urged the assembled journalists to read a campaigning website tracking the case. \u201cYou will see how Kafkaesque this whole trial is,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile expressing gratitude to the Deutsches Theater, whose collaboration also included a guest performance in Moscow this February, Ms. Shalashova said she doubted that the Gogol Center\u2019s visit to Germany would have much effect on Mr. Serebrennikov\u2019s legal position. \u201cWe just hope to present good productions, to show them to a German audience and to enter into dialogue with them,\u201d she said, speaking in Russian with a German translator.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince Mr. Serebrennikov\u2019s arrest, many have suggested that the director is being made an example of to discourage other Russian artists from voicing dissent in their work. Ms. Shalashova seemed to subscribe to this view. \u201cKirill is the emblematic figure of Russia\u2019s theatrical landscape,\u201d she said. \u201cBy now, he\u2019s Russia\u2019s most important director. Perhaps that\u2019s why he\u2019s been singled out.\u201d\n\nUlrich Khuon, the Deutsches Theater\u2019s artistic director, said the guest performances were \u201cpart of a larger movement of international solidarity.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAnd I think that it has a psychological and emotional effect on the work that the theater does and on Kirill,\u201d he added.\n\nBeyond mere symbolism, however, Mr. Khuon said he was more hopeful than Ms. Shalashova that artistic exchanges such as this one might influence the trial\u2019s outcome. \u201cI think that this wide publicity could be politically relevant for Putin\u2019s, or the court\u2019s, decision,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Khuon also sees the artistic exchange between his theater and Mr. Serebrennikov\u2019s as an opportunity to explore the role of the arts in society. \u201cIn Russia today, this is of course both tougher and more necessary\u201d than in Germany, he said, adding that the Deutsches Theater\u2019s program regularly examined the company\u2019s East German history.\n\nOdin Biron, an American actor in the Gogol Center\u2019s ensemble, said he was at a loss to explain what exactly had prompted the action against Mr. Serebrennikov.\n\n\u201cWhat I do know,\u201d he said, \u201cis that there\u2019s a definite line, very important for the current administration to frame the questions: What is Russian? What Is Russia? And one of the main columns that that understanding rests on is Russian literature. It\u2019s how you support the language, which, in essence, supports the country.\u201d\n\nMr. Serebrennikov\u2019s often-provocative productions of works by Russian masters from Alexander Pushkin to Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov, Mr. Biron said, might present a view of that culture not favored by the country\u2019s political class.\n\nMr. Putin, he said, stood for stability, while Mr. Serebrennikov\u2019s work reflected and was inspired by the turmoil of contemporary Russia.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cFor better or worse, art thrives when things are unstable,\u201d Mr. Biron added. \u201cThat is what art is supposed to do. Art cannot live on a steady foundation. And the theatrical and creative blood flows in Russia like in no place I\u2019ve ever been.\u201d", "title": "Theater Director Held in Russia Finds an Audience in Berlin", "authors": ["A.J. Goldmann"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "TULSA, Okla. \u2014 When she woke up one morning last week, Tiffany Bell, a teacher at Hamilton Elementary School here, had $35 in her bank account.\n\nOn take-home pay of $2,200 per month, she supports her husband, a veteran who went back to school, and their three children, all of whom qualify for the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program, a federal benefit for low-income families. The couple\u2019s 4-year-old twins attend a Head Start preschool \u2014 another antipoverty program.\n\nMoney is so tight for Ms. Bell, 26, that she had to think twice before spending $15 on Oreos for a class project, in which her third graders removed differing amounts of icing to display the phases of the moon.\n\nShe knew it would be hard to support a family on a teacher\u2019s salary. \u201cBut not this hard,\u201d she said.\n\nWhen West Virginia teachers mounted a statewide walkout last month, earning a modest raise, it seemed like an anomaly: a successful grass-roots labor uprising in a conservative state with weak public sector unions. But just a few weeks later, the West Virginia action looks like the potential beginning of a red-state rebellion.", "title": "Their Pay Has Stood Still. Now Oklahoma Teachers Could Be the Next to Walk.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The agency accused Ms. Holmes and the company of raising $700 million from investors by faking data, orchestrating tests and simply lying to investors and the media to cover up that they had no device that actually worked and were mainly using outside laboratories to assess blood samples.\n\nMs. Holmes, who did not admit or deny wrongdoing, will pay a $500,000 fine, which seems trivial given that the company was once valued at $9 billion, purportedly making her Silicon Valley\u2019s first self-made female billionaire. She\u2019s also barred from serving as an officer or director at any public company for 10 years, and she\u2019s returning 18.9 million shares. The penalties are small for such chicanery, but federal prosecutors are still conducting a criminal investigation.\n\nWe shouldn\u2019t be surprised by any biotech\u2019s failure. We should expect it. Biotechs by their nature offer the promise of disruptive breakthroughs and discoveries, but they\u2019re mostly all-in propositions, based on one molecule or one test. Fail in a Phase III clinical trial \u2014 and a majority do \u2014 and you\u2019re finished. It\u2019s a moonshot business; companies are going to blow up.\n\nStart-ups blow up in Silicon Valley all the time, too, but what\u2019s surprising is how long Ms. Holmes could peddle her disruption tale before regulators stepped in. The story was just too good to resist \u2014 a brainy 19-year-old drops out of Stanford and creates a device that can make blood testing vastly easier and more accessible. Her investors included Valley powerhouses such as Draper Fisher Jurvetson, health care players such as Walgreens and BlueCross BlueShield Venture Partners, the media tycoon Rupert Murdoch and Tako Ventures, founded by Oracle\u2019s Larry Ellison. She also assembled a brand-name board that included at one time or another two former secretaries of state, George Shultz and Henry Kissinger; former Senator Bill Frist (a physician); and the superlawyer David Boies, whose firm was involved in efforts to quiet a company whistle-blower and who reportedly tried to get The Wall Street Journal to kill an article that uncovered the fraud.\n\nIn 2013, Ms. Holmes added another heavyweight to the board, Jim Mattis, the general in charge of the United States Central Command. While in that command, Mr. Mattis, too, caught the Theranos fever and pushed to have the company\u2019s tests used in the field. Ms. Holmes had pushed the military story line even harder, telling Walgreens, which thought it was using its tests, that its analyzer was already aboard military helicopters. That was false. The Department of Defense is a regular investor in tech start-ups and like any venture capitalist is willing to suffer investment losses. But Theranos got red-flagged at some point by the F.D.A. and defense officials. Mr. Mattis would get green-flagged to a better gig after his time on the Theranos board: secretary of defense.", "title": "Opinion | Theranos\u2019s Fraud Tested the Limits of the Disruption Tale", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "It was a quiet day at Video Room, the 500-square-foot independent video store on 80th Street and Third Avenue. But that was nothing new.\n\nVideo Room is considered one of the first \u2014 and now one of the last \u2014 storefronts in the city that rents movies. (A few others remain, including We Deliver Videos, also on the Upper East Side, and Video Free Brooklyn, which closed its Cobble Hill address in 2016, but is supposed to reopen soon inside of the Alamo Drafthouse Downtown Brooklyn.)", "title": "There Are Still DVD Rental Stores in New York", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn the age of the #MeToo movement, the use of the term \u201cmansplaining\u201d \u2014 to point out patronizing explanations made by men to female counterparts \u2014 has become increasingly mainstream.\n\nSo mainstream that it\u2019s now been used by Britain\u2019s prime minister in the House of Commons.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May denounced comments by Jeremy Corbyn \u2014 the opposition leader who criticized her for meeting with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia ahead of International Women\u2019s Day \u2014 as \u201cmansplaining\u201d during a session on Wednesday.\n\n\u201cCan I thank the right honorable gentleman for telling me that it\u2019s International Women\u2019s Day tomorrow? I think that\u2019s what\u2019s called mansplaining,\u201d Mrs. May said, shooting a cold stare at Mr. Corbyn, before defending her meeting with Prince Mohammed during his visit to Britain. She said she planned to raise human rights concerns during the meeting.\n\nMrs. May followed up the comment with a message on Twitter directed at Mr. Corbyn that included a definition of the term from the Oxford Dictionary.\n\nEarlier, during time set aside for members to direct questions to the prime minister, Mr. Corbyn had criticized Mrs. May\u2019s decision to meet with the prince.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Corbyn began by saying that International Women\u2019s Day, observed on Thursday, was \u201ca chance to both celebrate how far we have come on equality for women, but also to reflect on how far we have to go.\u201d He then detailed Saudi human rights abuses, including those against women.", "title": "Theresa May Calls Out \u2018Mansplaining\u2019 in Parliament. But Was It?", "authors": ["Megan Specia"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "But it was not clear how strongly allies would rally to her side, and experts said that behind Mrs. May\u2019s tough talk lay relatively mild measures, aside from the headline-grabbing expulsion, which she described as the biggest one of Russian diplomats in more than 30 years. That, in turn, reflects Britain\u2019s weakened position in the world, as well as Russia\u2019s continuing success in sowing discord and division.\n\n\u201cI expected a stronger reaction,\u201d said Jonathan Eyal, international director at the Royal United Services Institute, a London-based defense and security research institute. He said Mrs. May might have calculated that in response to tougher measures, Russia would \u201cdecapitate the British Embassy in Moscow\u201d with its own expulsions.\n\nThere are a number of tougher measures that Britain could also take, like seizing any assets of questionable provenance belonging to Russians who have invested and settled in the country, changing laws that made it possible to hide the true ownership of assets, and calling on the international community to tighten economic restrictions on Russia.\n\n[Read more about Britain\u2019s options against Russia.]\n\nBritain\u2019s broadcast regulator has also hinted that it could revoke the license of RT, the Kremlin-controlled English-language news channel.\n\nBritain wants the support of its allies in taking action against Russia, but relations with those allies are shakier than they have been in generations, given Britain\u2019s pending divorce from the European Union and frictions with Mr. Trump.\n\nThe European alliance itself is being sorely tested, with the rise of far-right and anti-Europe movements in Italy and elsewhere, defiance from autocratic sounding governments in Poland and Hungary, and the long struggle in Germany to form a governing coalition.", "title": "Theresa May Expels Russian Diplomats. But Now Comes the Hard Part.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Prime Minister Theresa May on Friday made her opening bid for talks on British withdrawal from the European Union, outlining a plan that seemed designed more to unite warring lawmakers at home, than to win over her continental critics.\n\nStriking a note of realism for her domestic audience, Mrs. May accepted that Britain\u2019s departure, known as Brexit, would reduce trade with the European Union\u2019s giant single market, which she intends her country to quit.\n\n\u201cIn certain ways, our access to each other\u2019s markets will be less than it is now,\u201d Mrs. May told an invited audience in London, accepting that the European Union would never agree to a deal that allowed Britain \u201cto enjoy all the benefits without all of the obligations.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe reality is that we all need to face up to some hard facts,\u201d she added.\n\nHowever, Mrs. May said she hoped to gain some favorable treatment on trade by offering \u201cbinding commitments\u201d to stick to some European rules and regulations, while staying under the remit of European agencies that supervise sectors like pharmaceuticals \u2014 proposals that the hard Brexit faction might find difficult to swallow.", "title": "Theresa May Says U.K. Has to Face \u2018Hard Facts\u2019 on Brexit", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Montana has more than a dozen Native Americans running for the state House this year. Utah tribes are pushing the governor to make a seat for them in his cabinet. Five native people serve in the Minnesota Legislature, and four of them are women.\n\n\u201cAmerican Indians have been invisible for so long, in so many sectors in society,\u201d said Denise Juneau, who was among the first native women in the country to be elected to a statewide executive position when she became the Montana schools superintendent in 2009. In that role, she developed an Indian history curriculum that is being replicated across the American West. \u201cTo be able to make inroads in the political world,\u201d she said, \u201cis huge.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMany of these candidates are running on a liberal platform fueled by opposition to the Trump administration, as Ms. Haaland is. But others are Republicans who don\u2019t fit that mold at all.\n\nOne is Andria Tupola, a Native Hawaiian lawmaker running for governor of Hawaii on a promise of tax cuts and small government. Another is Sharon Clahchischilliage, who was a co-chairwoman of Mr. Trump\u2019s Native American coalition in 2016 and is running for re-election to the New Mexico House on a platform she calls \u201cfighting the environmentalists.\u201d\n\nMs. Clahchischilliage is a fierce advocate for a coal-fired power plant that employs many Navajo people. She is hoping Mr. Trump will halt the threatened closing of the plant. Keeping it open, she said, could save 1,600 jobs.\n\n\u201cWhat I love about Trump is that he understands,\u201d she said. \u201cHe gets it. He is asking: What regulations need to change?\u201d\n\nHere in Albuquerque, Ms. Haaland, a Democrat, recently won 35 percent of the vote in a six-candidate field at the state party convention. She is a \u201cstrong contender\u201d to win the June primary, said Joe Monahan, a longtime New Mexico political blogger. (Her district covers most of Albuquerque and has elected Democrats for a decade).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re seeing a new generation of Native Americans who have seen more opportunity in education starting to knock down the doors in politics,\u201d Mr. Monahan said. \u201cAnd it\u2019s not a loud movement, but it\u2019s a steady movement.\u201d\n\nMs. Haaland is a citizen of the Laguna Pueblo, a sovereign nation west of Albuquerque that is one the country\u2019s 573 federally recognized tribes. A child of military veterans, she attended 13 public schools before graduating from high school, then started a salsa company and worked as a cake decorator before putting herself through college and law school on a mix of food stamps and student loans.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe entered politics in 2008 as a volunteer for Barack Obama, then spent years crisscrossing the state to register native voters in some of the country\u2019s most remote corners. In 2015, she became the head of the state Democratic Party and helped to flip the New Mexico House of Representatives back to Democratic control.\n\nOn the campaign trail, she frequently cites her heritage, and she makes the argument that many of the issues affecting native communities \u2014 the ubiquity of low-wage jobs, violence against women \u2014 afflict other groups as well.\n\n\u201cI know what it\u2019s like to get my health care from the Indian Health Service, and hold a sick child in the waiting room for three hours until you have a chance to see a doctor,\u201d she said in an interview at her headquarters, a sparsely furnished office downtown splashed with political signs saying \u201cHealthcare Not Warfare\u201d and \u201c\u00a1Ob\u00e1manos Nuevo M\u00e9xico!\u201d\n\nHer priority in Congress, she said, would be to turn New Mexico into a solar energy powerhouse, a message with appeal in an impoverished state that has struggled to diversify an economy dependent on oil and gas.\n\nShe faces a field crowded with qualified candidates, including Antoinette Sedillo Lopez, a former law school dean who has spent a career building social justice programs.\n\nThe main criticism of Ms. Haaland is that she is concealing a lack of policy depth by focusing on the historic nature of her candidacy. \u201cThat as a single theme could leave her vulnerable,\u201d Mr. Monahan said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe United States did not grant native people full citizenship and the right to vote in federal elections until 1924, and for years they were mostly absent from federal government, according to Mark Trahant, a professor at the University of North Dakota who writes extensively about Native Americans in politics.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat began to change in the late 1950s, when Washington instituted a policy known as termination, abolishing tribal governments and taking Indian land.\n\nFacing existential threats, native leaders began to exhort fellow Indians to vote and run for office. Men began to make elective inroads, and in recent years women have followed. In 2001, the coalition of tribes known as the National Congress of American Indians began a voting project that continues today.\n\nTo be sure, Native Americans are just 2 percent of the population, and low voter turnout persists in many communities.\n\nBut that is changing in some corners, and American Indians have the potential to sway elections in states like Montana, where they make up 7 percent of the voting-age population; New Mexico, where they are more than 10 percent; and Alaska, where they are more than 17 percent.\n\nToday there are two native men in the United States House of Representatives, both Republicans from Oklahoma. (Elizabeth Warren, the senator from Massachusetts, has discussed having native heritage but is not enrolled in a tribe.)\n\nAmong the native women seeking office this year is Peggy Flanagan, a former director of a nonprofit organization who is running for lieutenant governor of Minnesota.\n\nIn an interview, Ms. Flanagan said that if she wins, she will oppose a proposed pipeline across historic Ojibwe land; send money meant to help native people to tribes rather than county governments; and bring attention to the country\u2019s many missing and murdered native women.\n\nBut Ms. Juneau, the Montana school superintendent, warned that the hardest part of winning an election as an Indian woman is proving that you can represent the entire state, not just its tribes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not like, as a person of color or as an American Indian woman, you can walk into a room and say: \u2018I\u2019m qualified,\u2019 and everybody looks at you like that,\u201d she said. \u201cYou have to prove it. And we will \u2014 eventually.\u201d", "title": "There\u2019s Never Been a Native American Congresswoman. That Could Change in 2018.", "authors": ["Julie Turkewitz"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Adam Ferguson was named Photographer of the Year in the 75th Pictures of the Year International competition, for work on assignment for The New York Times. Newspaper Photographer of the Year went to Magnus Wennman of Aftonbladet, a Swedish tabloid.\n\nMr. Ferguson\u2019s entry mainly consisted of three stories: a detention camp in Papua New Guinea for refugees seeking asylum in Australia; Nigerian girls that Boko Haram recruited as suicide bombers; and a road trip through Australia\u2019s outback, where he was born.\n\nLast year was pivotal to Mr. Ferguson\u2019s development as a photographer. Often photographers, particularly younger ones, \u201cemulate other photographers till they find their feet in the profession,\u201d he said.", "title": "These Are the Pictures of the Year From 2017", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "And it was truly exciting to begin to learn the intense and rigorous art of fact checking, which is like cross-examining sentences. I absorbed quickly and satisfyingly how to do another layer of reporting on the heels of the writer. I figured if I did good work and kept my head down, I\u2019d eventually be rewarded.\n\nBut, try as I did to avoid them, the affections and gifts and little notes continued from the older staff member \u2014 attentions that had begun during the interview process. One day he leaned in, suddenly, and kissed me in front of the Nat Sherman luxury cigarette store on Fifth Avenue. I didn\u2019t know whom to talk to about this or even if it was as weird as it felt.\n\nI\u2019ll be the first to admit that the themes of adultery and overt and detailed sexuality in Updike\u2019s stories sometimes made me slightly queasy. But there was nothing in them that ever smacked of the predatory; on the contrary, it was his fastidious honesty, his euphoric interest in sexuality, that rattled and embarrassed me.\n\nFrom Richard Ford I had learned an acerbic and more shrouded form of male sexuality, one that was, somehow, easier to take because less was there in black and white. Either way, these were stories; my best friends were Richard and Joan Maple and Frank Bascombe. No one had ever sat me down and told me what was wrong or right in a job or how to handle anything complicated with men in real life.\n\nAs the news of the Bill Clinton-Monica Lewinsky scandal broke, the staff member\u2019s flirtations intensified and began to feel controlling in their insistence. After weeks of insomnia, I finally broke down in a co-worker\u2019s office. I remember the smell of paperwhite narcissus through my salty tears more than anything; she was always forcing the little bulbs in large glass vases filled with turquoise marbles on her windowsill.\n\nThat night I called a lawyer friend of my father\u2019s, and the next day, using language the lawyer had advised me to, I confronted the man. That afternoon he brought over a bundle of thank you cards I\u2019d sent him during my quest for the job \u2014 a personal touch taught to me by a career counselor at Brown. He had tied them with a ribbon, like love letters. In front of two office mates, he ripped up the cards and threw them at my face and walked out. I remember scrambling to the floor to pick them up. A few days later he told me my freelance gig was over, and that I would not be hired on staff. I had been at the magazine only seven months.", "title": "These Days I Miss John Updike, a Remote and Noble Male Mentor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "NDONGA, Central African Republic \u2014 This remote village doesn\u2019t have an official school, and there\u2019s no functioning government to build one. So the villagers, desperate to improve their children\u2019s lives, used branches and leaves to construct their own dirt-floor schoolhouse.\n\nIt has no electricity, windows or desks, and it doesn\u2019t keep out rain or beetles, but it does imbue hope, discipline and dreams. The 90 pupils sitting on bamboo benches could tutor world leaders about the importance of education \u2014 even if the kids struggle with the most basic challenges.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard to learn without a paper or pen,\u201d Bertrand Golb\u00e9, a parent who turned himself into a teacher, acknowledged with a laugh. \u201cBut this is the way we have to do it.\n\n\u201cThey never have had breakfast when they arrive,\u201d Golb\u00e9 added. \u201cThey\u2019re hungry. It\u2019s difficult.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | These Kids Could Tutor World Leaders", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s kind of like when your little brother\u2019s trying to hit you and you put your hand on their forehead and they can\u2019t reach you.\n\nThey\u2019re not taking any chances.\n\nYou have to remember you\u2019re hunting things that are almost the same size as you that can potentially harm you. The prey have fangs that inject venom and silk that they can use to get you entangled.\n\nSpiders that hunt other spiders need to have some strategy toward getting around this, and it seems that this family has evolved the highly maneuverable chelicerae that are really long, and they attack at a distance, and that\u2019s the strategy they\u2019re using.\n\nAnd how do you get samples of these spiders when you\u2019re in the rain forest in Madagascar?\n\nYou collect the spiders that are in the vegetation either by walking around at night and just observing them, or you take a white sheet that is held stiff by pieces of wood. You take a stick and you beat vegetation, and the spiders fall out onto that.\n\nAnd then there are species that are very cryptic and live down in the leaf litter. I collect them by sifting litter. I have a tool called a litter-sifter that I shake, and I get concentrated leaf litter that I can spread out on a sheet and sort through by hand. Or I put it in another trap that dries the litter out, and the spiders fall down to the bottom.\n\nAnd do you use tweezers or do you grab them with your fingers?\n\nYou can\u2019t grab them with your fingers or a tweezer, because spiders are quite delicate. Arachnologists use an aspirator, and they actually suck them up. But there\u2019s a filter. So, you suck them up and then you blow them out into another tube.\n\nWhy is it important to look for new species in the field or even in museum collections?\n\nThis is basic research, where you\u2019re really just going out and discovering what\u2019s out there and then later, much later, is when you can make discoveries about venoms that can fight cancer or other things. This is really the first step. But I believe that these spiders are worth documenting just for their own sake, not for any sort of usefulness.", "title": "These Spiders Hunt Their Own Kind", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Crossword puzzles expect solvers to have a good grasp of general knowledge, but sometimes certain facts just aren\u2019t in our personal wheelhouses.\n\nThat\u2019s O.K. We\u2019re here to help you solve \u2026 and to help you expand those wheelhouses.\n\nFor our latest list of terms you should know to become a better solver, we\u2019ll be visiting a so-called \u201ccrossword aviary,\u201d taking a closer look at 12 birds that frequently show up in puzzles .\n\nWe\u2019ll also show you ways these terms might be clued, so you\u2019ll be able to recognize them the next time they come up. The clues that involve wordplay meant to trick you are bold, to make them easier to spot and so you can learn to think like the puzzle makers.\n\nThis is by no means an exhaustive list, but familiarity with these 12 birds will certainly help you out for future solving. After all, how else are you supposed to \u201cfly\u201d through a crossword without knowledge of our puzzles\u2019 favorite birds?", "title": "These Words Are for the Birds: A Crossword Aviary", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "But with three left-handed hitters \u2014 shortstop Didi Gregorius, first baseman Greg Bird and Gardner \u2014 in the lineup, using Judge in the leadoff spot will allow Boone to stack two right-handed hitters between each lefty, as he did on Friday when Bird batted third, Gregorius sixth and Gardner ninth. And batting the switch-hitter Neil Walker and Gardner in the Nos. 8 and 9 spots will allow Boone to have two high on-base hitters in front of Judge after his first trip to the plate.\n\n\u201cIf you have a lefty specialist, maybe they have one bullet in the middle of the game,\u201d Boone said. \u201cThey\u2019re not going to ride those three guys out. With your switch-hitters, you can kind of protect guys \u2014 and I don\u2019t think you would ever consider it if we didn\u2019t have as deep a lineup as we do. We\u2019re going to have guys at the bottom of the order with the capability of getting on base, so you feel like the top of the order is going to have good opportunities anyway.\u201d\n\nBoone added, \u201cI think there\u2019s a strong case to be made for it, but we\u2019ll kind of see.\u201d\n\nThough Boone never managed before this season, these are the types of decisions that he had to consider when he interviewed for the job.
