Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt gave me and my wife a community,\u201d he said. \u201cWe immediately had a support system.\u201d That is especially true in Los Angeles, he said, which isn\u2019t the most welcoming town. \u201cIt\u2019s such a hustle,\u201d he said. \u201cA lot of the time you have to sell yourself, your work. It\u2019s a competitive environment.\u201d\n\nBut saving souls is a business like any other. Pastors today who want to start a ministry for those 40 and under follow a well-traveled path. First, they lease an old theater or club. Next, they find great singers and backup musicians. A fog machine on stage is nice. A church should also have a catchy logo or catchphrase that can be stamped onto merchandise and branded \u2014 socks, knit hats, shoes and sweatshirts. (An online pop-up shop on Memorial Day sold $10,000 in merchandise its first hour, Mr. Veach said.) And lastly, churches need a money app \u2014 Zoe uses Pushpay \u2014 to make it easy for churchgoers to tithe with a swipe on their smartphones.\n\nMr. Veach said he modeled his church after Hillsong, with its vibrant youth community, and Church of the Highlands, whose pastor teaches other pastors how to start churches like his. He spent two days learning the basics at Highlands\u2019 headquarters in Birmingham, Ala., before Zoe opened for business.\n\n\u201dThere are lot of guys who aren\u2019t good orators that have really good churches because they are good managers,\u201d Mr. Veach said.", "title": "This Preacher Would Be Happy to Share Your Bowl of A\u00e7a\u00ed", "authors": ["Laura M. Holson"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "New TV shows, museum openings, film releases and concerts \u2014 it\u2019s a lot to keep track of. Let us help you. For the week of March 11, seven events in New York and elsewhere not to be missed:\n\nFilm: Al Pacino\u2019s Homecoming\n\nMarch 14-30; quadcinema.com.\n\nAl Pacino, the quintessential New York actor for many, will be the toast of his hometown with \u201cPacino\u2019s Way,\u201d a 16-day retrospective of more than 30 films starting Wednesday, March 14, at the Quad Cinema.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s particularly heartwarming because Greenwich Village, where the Quad is located, is the place where I went to live as a teenager and where I developed as a young actor,\u201d he said in a statement. \u201cIn a sense this is a homecoming for me.\u201d\n\nThe lineup includes his first leading role in 1971\u2019s \u201cThe Panic in Needle Park\u201d; his Oscar-nominated turns in \u201cThe Godfather,\u201d \u201cSerpico,\u201d \u201cDog Day Afternoon,\u201d \u201cDick Tracy\u201d and \u201cGlengarry Glen Ross\u201d; his winning one in \u201cScent of a Woman\u201d; and \u201cLooking for Richard,\u201d his 1996 directorial debut.", "title": "This Week: Al Pacino, Yo La Tengo, Meredith Monk\u2019s Multisensory Music", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Five clear, brightly colored dots tilting over a shadowy planet speckled with craters immediately light up the language centers of your brain: They look too clear and simple not to mean something equally clear and simple. But in fact they don\u2019t mean anything specific at all, so you are left with no object for your understanding except the process of understanding itself.\n\nTo put it another way, the drawing can make you hear yourself think \u2014 as can most of the 80 or so drawings and works on paper, from the 1980s to present, that comprise this thematically-organized retrospective. WILL HEINRICH\n\nPhoto\n\nDance: Jane Comfort Retrospective\n\nApril 5-8, lamama.org.\n\nOver the past four decades, the choreographer Jane Comfort has developed a frank, whimsical style of dance-theater, pointedly addressing social and political issues through pairings of movement and text. Her 1995 \u201cS/He\u201d played with reversals of gender and race to shed light on the Clarence Thomas and Anita Hill hearings of the early \u201990s. In \u201cDeportment\u201d (1991), she staged a satirical etiquette lesson to comment on learned behaviors of racism, sexism and homophobia in America. More recently, with \u201cAltiplano\u201d (2015), she has explored dancing on its own, untethered from words.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nExcerpts from these and other works, live and on video, will be part of Ms. Comfort\u2019s 40th anniversary retrospective at La MaMa, a celebration featuring over 20 current and former members of her company. Also on the program will be \u201cFour Screaming Women\u201d (1982), \u201cStreet Talk\u201d (1984) and \u201cAmazing Grace\u201d (2018), a reflection on our current political moment. Even the older works, though, may not seem so out of date. SIOBHAN BURKE\n\nPop: Caroline Rose Touring East Coast\n\nApril 3-7; carolinerosemusic.com.\n\n\u201cFloating around in a vacuum of space/Everything here, it all looks the same,\u201d Caroline Rose sings on \u201cMore of the Same.\u201d By the time she hits the chorus a few lines later, it\u2019s clear that this uncommonly catchy sketch of ennui is the kind of song you want to hear again as soon as it\u2019s finished.\n\nThere\u2019s more where that comes from on \u201cLoner,\u201d the New York songwriter\u2019s second album, released recently to strong reviews. \u201cCry!,\u201d an anxious inner monologue set to buoyant electro-pop, and the bitingly sarcastic \u201cSoul No. 5\u201d are among the other immediate standouts.\n\nMs. Rose\u2019s live appearances at the South by Southwest Music Festival in March were well-received. Hear \u201cMore of the Same\u201d and more when her tour swings back to the East Coast this week, with shows in Brooklyn (April 3, Rough Trade NYC), Boston (April 4), Philadelphia (April 5), New Haven (April 6) and Burlington, Vermont (April 7). SIMON VOZICK-LEVINSON\n\nFilm: Charlie Plummer in \u2018Lean on Pete\u2019\n\nApril 6.\n\nIt\u2019s a coldblooded human who doesn\u2019t love a warmhearted horse story. And \u201cLean on Pete,\u201d opening Friday, April 6, in New York and Los Angeles, starts out as just that: the tale of two misfits. Pete is a 5-year-old quarter horse at the end of his usefulness, and Charley (Charlie Plummer) is a gently scrappy 15-year-old trying to make something of his life by helping Pete\u2019s grizzled owner (Steve Buscemi) at a racetrack in Portland, Ore.\n\nTending to Pete and hanging with his jockey (Chlo\u00eb Sevigny) gives Charley a sense of purpose and connection sorely lacking in his itinerant existence with his carousing single father (Travis Fimmel). But when Charley learns that Pete is headed for slaughter, he and his newfound companion make a run for it through the American frontier on a quest for a place to call home. Andrew Haigh (\u201cWeekend,\u201d \u201c45 Years\u201d) directed this violence-tinged, startlingly bleak coming-of-age story, adapted from Willy Vlautin\u2019s novel, which earned Mr. Plummer the Marcello Mastroianni Award for best young actor at the Venice Film Festival last year. KATHRYN SHATTUCK\n\nClassical: Anna Thorvaldsdottir With Beethoven\n\nApril 4, 5 and 6; nyphil.org.\n\nA highlight of last season\u2019s New York Philharmonic programming was the local premiere of Anna Thorvaldsdottir\u2019s uncannily tactile \u201cAeriality,\u201d part of the composer\u2019s appointment as the orchestra\u2019s Kravis Emerging Composer. Observers tend to link Ms. Thorvaldsdottir\u2019s willfully craggy music to the surreal tectonics of her native Iceland. But her expansive works defy such national clich\u00e9s, and instead frequently channel abstract metaphysical concepts into acutely mysterious forms.\n\nThis week, the orchestra will give the world premiere of her \u201cMetacosmos,\u201d a Philharmonic commission that, as Ms. Thorvaldsdottir writes, is \u201cconstructed around the natural balance between beauty and chaos\u201d and inspired by \u201cthe speculative metaphor of falling into a black hole.\u201d It opens a program conducted by Esa-Pekka Salonen that includes Beethoven\u2019s \u201cEroica\u201d Symphony as well as the composer\u2019s Piano Concerto No. 3, featuring the distinguished young pianist Benjamin Grosvenor. WILLIAM ROBIN", "title": "This Week: Condola Rashad as \u2018Saint Joan\u2019; Planet Earth Is \u2018One Strange Rock\u2019", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Now \u201cTrust,\u201d an FX series from the \u201cSlumdog Millionaire\u201d team \u2014 the writer Simon Beaufoy and the director Danny Boyle \u2014 has Donald Sutherland as Granddad Getty. Starting Sunday, March 25, the 10-episode saga leans into longstanding speculation that the teenage Paul (Harris Dickinson), in hock to Italian criminals, helped stage his own abduction in the hope that his grandfather would fork over $17 million in exchange for his heir. He miscalculated, and in the process lost an ear.\n\nHilary Swank plays Gail Getty, left to negotiate her son\u2019s ransom even though she\u2019s broke. And Brendan Fraser is the elder Getty\u2019s fixer, hellbent on extracting the family dynasty, long thought cursed, from yet another terrible mess. KATHRYN SHATTUCK\n\nPhoto\n\nPop: The Black Keys\u2019 Dan Auerbach on Tour\n\nMarch 25-28; easyeyesound.com/tour.\n\nAs the leader of the Black Keys, Dan Auerbach has taken his efficiently re-engineered version of American blues-rock to festivals and sports arenas across the country. But his true passion is more modest in scale: Witness his recruitment of seasoned session players for the house band at Easy Eye Sound, the studio he runs in his adopted hometown Nashville. The music he makes there isn\u2019t about hits so much as history.\n\nThis spring, Mr. Auerbach is taking that philosophy on the road with the Easy Eye Sound Revue, featuring support from two of his recent collaborators: Shannon and the Clams, a charming Bay Area band that sounds like punks at a sock hop; and Robert Finley, a real-deal Louisiana soul singer in his 60s. The tour reaches the East Coast this week, with a Boston date (House of Blues, March 25) followed by two in the New York region (Brooklyn Steel, March 27; the Capitol Theater, in Port Chester, N.Y., March 28). It\u2019s an admirable effort by one of rock\u2019s bigger stars in recent years to think small. SIMON VOZICK-LEVINSON\n\nFilm: Zo\u00eb Kravitz and Lola Kirke in \u2018Gemini\u2019\n\nMarch 30.\n\nShe asked you to do what?\n\nCelebrity minders will surely snicker knowingly at \u201cGemini,\u201d Aaron Katz\u2019s neo-noir caper, in which Jill, a personal assistant to the Hollywood starlet Heather, navigates the murky abyss between loyalty and servitude. That is, until Heather is murdered with the handgun Jill lent her, and she\u2019s fingered as the prime suspect.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nZo\u00eb Kravitz plays Heather, the paparazzi-hounded actress who\u2019d rather croon karaoke and mingle with super fans than fulfill her contractual obligations. Lola Kirke is Jill, the Exeter-pedigreed handler with unwavering patience for doing Heather\u2019s dirty work while burying her own creative aspirations. And John Cho is the cop who chases Jill around glassy dwellings and Moroccan-style mansions \u2014 SoCal\u2019s golden rays subverted by a moody indigo glow \u2014 as he tries to figure out why Jill, or anyone else for that matter, would want Heather dead. But the better question might be: Who wouldn\u2019t?\n\n\u201cGemini\u201d opens Friday, March 30, in New York and Los Angeles, before a wider rollout. KATHRYN SHATTUCK\n\nPhoto\n\nDance: Remembering Arnie Zane in Manhattan\n\nMarch 25; newyorklivearts.com.\n\nIt was 30 years ago that Arnie Zane, just 39, died of AIDS-related lymphoma. On March 25, Mr. Zane will be honored in a daylong event \u2014 conceived and directed by Bill T. Jones \u2014 that explores his artistry, not only as a dancer and a choreographer but also as a photographer.\n\nThe co-founder of the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Company, Mr. Zane was a compelling choreographer whose love of repetition and precision lives on in works like \u201cContinuous Replay.\u201d Made up of 45 gestures, it\u2019s performed as an accumulation of movements. As part of the celebration, the former company member Jennifer Nugent will teach excerpts.\n\nBut how did Mr. Zane move? The critic Burt Supree wrote that Mr. Zane \u201creminds me sometimes of those star-shaped weapons ninjas and other baddies throw in 007 movies.\u201d It\u2019s not a surprise that he loved karate. An open class of the martial art is part of the event \u2014 an apt addition to this celebration of a ninja spirit. GIA KOURLAS\n\nPhoto\n\nClassical: Jennifer Koh in Brooklyn\n\nMar. 31; nationalsawdust.org.\n\nThe inquisitive violinist Jennifer Koh has a seemingly ever-expanding number of commissioning projects with an ever-expanding group of collaborators. So it is perhaps unsurprising that the latest of her attempts to introduce new works into the string repertory is titled \u201cLimitless.\u201d This new project focuses on duos that Ms. Koh performs alongside composers themselves, which on Mar. 31 at the venue National Sawdust will include an all-star lineup of musicians: Lisa Bielawa, Vijay Iyer, Nina Young, Tyshawn Sorey and the recent Pulitzer winner Du Yun. Notably, a principal component of \u201cLimitless\u201d is to foreground inclusivity in working with a diverse cohort of composers. As Koh told the National Sawdust Log, \u201cI am female and I am a minority. And I feel that there needs to be more equality in programming.\u201d WILLIAM ROBIN", "title": "This Week: C\u00e9zanne\u2019s Portraits, \u2018The Winter\u2019s Tale,\u2019 FX\u2019s Take on the Getty Kidnapping", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "New TV shows, museum openings, film releases and concerts \u2014 it\u2019s a lot to keep track of. Let us help you. For the week of March 18, seven cultural events not to be missed:\n\nDance: Stephen Petronio at the Joyce\n\nMarch 20-25; joyce.org.\n\nStephen Petronio made a bold move in 2015 when he unveiled \u201cBloodlines,\u201d an initiative to restage masterworks by pioneers of postmodern dance and present them alongside his own. The series uncovers gems that might otherwise be lost to history. It also sets a high bar for Mr. Petronio\u2019s choreography, inviting comparisons with artists he cites as some of his greatest influences.\n\nThe latest installment, opening on March 20 when the Stephen Petronio Company returns to the Joyce Theater, includes Merce Cunningham\u2019s rarely performed \u201cSignals,\u201d from 1970, and the premiere of Mr. Petronio\u2019s \u201cHardness 10.\u201d Inspired by diamonds and their many facets, the new work features costumes by Patricia Field, known for her work on \u201cSex and the City,\u201d and a score by Nico Muhly. Mr. Petronio also revisits his 2003 \u201cUnderland,\u201d bringing back a section of that characteristically high-velocity dance, \u201cWild Wild World.\u201d SIOBHAN BURKE", "title": "This Week: Justin Timberlake, Marion Cotillard, Diamond-Inspired Dance at the Joyce", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "A self-described tinkerer, she is not entirely dismayed by chaotic heaps. She grew up going to swap meets. Her parents would say, \u201cHere\u2019s 50 cents\u201d and she would scour for jeans. She gets lost in little things like vintage fabrics and brass doorknobs.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s always a reason to go to the salvage shop to look through boxes of junk because you might find something,\u201d she said. \u201cSame thing with the flea market. I can go to a vintage house or a flea market and love digging through a five-foot pile of jeans because at the bottom there might be one that makes me happy.\u201d\n\nWhen Ms. Haller isn\u2019t taking apart Levi\u2019s, she\u2019s taking apart houses.\n\nShe and her husband, Craig Ekedahl, a real estate agent, currently own a half-dozen houses in the area. Since 2012 they have renovated multiple others in nearby Echo Park and Boyle Heights, a business they began as a way for Mr. Ekedahl to transition out of the television industry. As a producer on \u201cBasketball Wives of Los Angeles,\u201d he was traveling six days a week and was concerned about saving for college \u2014 they have a 5-year-old daughter \u2014 and retirement.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe panicked a little bit,\u201d he said.\n\nStill, while many in their business make money flipping their properties, this couple prefers to rent them out. \u201cWe\u2019re not hard-core bottom-line investors,\u201d Mr. Ekedahl said. \u201cEach house becomes a part of our family and we want it to be right. We want to recognize what the house is and what it has been.\u201d\n\nIf he is the pragmatic one, Ms. Haller is the visionary, packing her Instagram account with shots of her newel posts, brass handle sets, salvaged tile and Victorian chandeliers.\n\nPhoto\n\nSometimes knobs are from the salvage store; sometimes they\u2019re from knobs.com. In the bathroom, new black octagon-shaped tiles cover the floor, but the claw-foot tub was unearthed at Olde Good Things, an architectural salvage shop in downtown Los Angeles, and refinished in black. The brass faucets and marble sink top were found at another local salvage shop, the ReUse People.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA tall wood Victorian mirror hung above the sink, donated by a man who sells her vintage Levi\u2019s. \u201cHe just hoards amazing stuff,\u201d Ms. Haller said. The sconces flanking the mirror were flea market scores, and Ms. Haller was thrilled to uncover 100-year-old brick in the driveway.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt the 1907 Craftsman home she and Mr. Ekedahl live in just around the corner (its 2016 renovation was also captured on Instagram), their buffet table is covered in vintage lamp parts. Ms. Haller recently taught herself how to rewire chandeliers by watching YouTube videos.\n\n\u201cIf I can have a glass of wine and tinker with lamps, I\u2019m so happy,\u201d she said.\n\nLater that day at the NSF loft in the fashion district, Ms. Haller toured her \u201cdenim archive,\u201d like a public library of jeans, with racks climbing up the walls and a ladder needed to reach the top.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use.
