View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cJust follow me into this hole back here,\u201d Ms. Haller said, disappearing behind a row of paint-splattered denim that she has collected for eight years.\n\nFor a moment it seemed as if she were heading into a John Malkovich-like portal, but then she appeared once again, her head popping up above the hues of faded blue.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis is where I come,\u201d she said. \u201cI crawl back here in this hole.\u201d\n\nIf Ms. Haller is painting one of her houses, she\u2019ll purposely let her clothes get messed up because it gives her inspiration or an idea for a new wash (often covered in paint). \u201cJust loaded them up,\u201d she said of cargo pants copied from a pair she wore after intensive work on a midcentury modern house in Glendale.\n\nTo her, such purposefully sloppy dungarees reflect not indifference, but care.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m always like, \u2018Is this emotional? Is someone going to want to pick it up off the rack?\u2019\u201d Ms. Haller said, tenderly picking up a bedraggled pair of pants. \u201cFirst it has to suit what I want. Then it has to suit my style. But for me, it needs to be special \u2014 always.\u201d", "title": "This Woman Makes a Living Destroying Jeans and Fixing Houses", "authors": ["Hayley Krischer"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "For all its moral seriousness and formal ingenuity, \u201cCourse of Empire\u201d never really rises above being a didactic machine. (And the otherwise splendid Met installation does it no favors by crowding it into a corner.) Dramatizing a similar message far more effectively is the single large 1836 painting titled \u201cView From Mount Holyoke, Northampton, Massachusetts, After a Thunderstorm (The Oxbow).\u201d From a God\u2019s-eye height we look down at the spot where the Connecticut River, flowing around an island-like land mass, creates a question-mark shape known as the \u201cOxbow.\u201d\n\nThe painting divides vertically into two atmospheric halves. To the left is a wild storm-soaked tangle of old trees and dense vegetation; to the right, far below, a flat terrain of treeless, square-cut fields running back to distant hills scarred by clear-cutting. The wilderness looks unkept and threatening, but seethes with life. The flat land, though cultivated and presumably fertile, feels as bare and bland as a tract-house town. And in the foreground of the picture is a tiny self-portrait of Cole at his easel. He turns away from his canvas and looks right at us, as if to say: Here are the alternatives; you choose.\n\nCole chose wilderness, and in doing so disappeared himself for more than a century. When he died suddenly, at 47, in 1848, he was widely mourned; pictorial tributes from fellow artists piled up, the most famous being Asher Brown Durand\u2019s 1849 \u201cKindred Spirits,\u201d which shows Cole and the nature-poet William Cullen Bryant sharing thoughts in a paradisal Catskill Mountain glen. (The picture is back in town for the first time since it was sold by the New York Public Library to the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Arkansas in 2005.)\n\nYet within a few years, Cole was all but forgotten. And the colonizing of Nature he so hated \u2014 hyped as Manifest Destiny \u2014 was being cheered on by artists who claimed to revere him, Durand among them.\n\nPhoto\n\nPolitically, Cole\u2019s art is conservative, but it\u2019s also work that challenges and complicates that term. And the Met show \u2014 organized by Elizabeth Kornhauser, curator of American painting and sculpture at the Met, and Tim Barringer, professor of art history at Yale University, with Chris Riopelle, a curator at the National Gallery, London \u2014 is precisely about complication. And just as Cole is most realistically and revealingly seen and judged against the background of his time, so is the exhibition, coming as it does in this confounding MAGA moment.", "title": "Thomas Cole, American Moralist", "authors": ["Holland Cotter"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "But improving endurance is not the same thing as improving health.\n\nSo when scientists and governmental regulators recently began planning a major update to the 2008 exercise guidelines, they decided, as part of their research, to gather the latest studies about exercise bouts and how long workouts should last in order to benefit health.\n\nSomewhat to their surprise, they found only a few relevant, large-scale, recent studies, and most of these relied on people\u2019s notoriously unreliable memories of how active they had been.\n\nSo, some of the scientists working on the new exercise guidelines decided that they would need to mount a major new study themselves.\n\nThey began by looking for reliable and objective data about ordinary people\u2019s exercise habits.\n\nThey found it in the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey, conducted annually for decades by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. It details the lifestyles and health of tens of thousands of American men and women.\n\nSince 2002, some of the participants in N.H.A.N.E.S. have worn accelerometers to precisely track how much and when they move throughout the day.\n\nFor the new study, which was published this month in the Journal of the American Heart Association, the scientists chose data about 4,840 men and women past the age of 40 who had worn activity trackers.\n\nUsing the accelerometer readouts, the scientists determined how many minutes per day, in total, each person had spent in moderate or vigorous physical activity. They defined moderate activity as, in essence, brisk walking, and vigorous activity, which was rare, as workouts similar to jogging.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe researchers also looked at how long each session of physical activity had continued. If a single session went on for more than five minutes, it was considered to be a \u201cbout\u201d of exercise. If it were shorter than five minutes, it was considered to be sporadic physical activity, such as walking down the hallway or up a brief flight of stairs.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n(Originally, the scientists had planned to focus on 10-minute exercise bouts, as currently recommended, but so few of the 4,840 people were active for 10 minutes at a time that the researchers lowered their definition of an exercise \u201cbout\u201d to five minutes.)\n\nFinally, they crosschecked death records to determine whether and when participants died through 2011.\n\nThe scientists found that moving strongly influenced longevity. The men and women who were the least physically active, exercising moderately for fewer than 20 minutes a day, were at the highest risk of premature death.\n\nThose who moved more often, especially if they managed about an hour in total of physical activity over the course of the day, cut their mortality risk in half, the researchers found.\n\nAnd it did not matter how they accumulated those minutes. If people walked continuously for five minutes or longer, meaning in exercise bouts, they lowered their risk of dying young.\n\nBut they gained the same benefit if they walked sporadically in short but repeated spurts, as long as they moved often.\n\n\u201cThe message is that all physical activity counts,\u201d says Dr. William Kraus, a professor at Duke University who conducted the study with researchers from the National Cancer Institute.\n\n\u201cThe little things that people do every day,\u201d like walking from their cars to the office or climbing a flight of stairs, \u201ccan and do add up and affect the risk for disease and death,\u201d he says.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOf course, this was an epidemiological study, meaning that it can show only that more physical activity is associated with a longer life, not that it directly causes people to live longer.\n\nThe study was also short, in terms of how long it followed people.\n\nBut the results, which will be considered as scientists and experts plan changes later this year to the formal exercise guidelines, are encouraging, Dr. Kraus says.\n\n\u201cIf you can\u2019t go for a long walk,\u201d he says, \u201ca few short walks are likely to be just as good for you.\u201d", "title": "Those 2-Minute Walk Breaks? They Add Up", "authors": ["Gretchen Reynolds", "Phys Ed"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cRight now, there\u2019s going to be a lot of appropriations dollars being sent to school districts without a lot of oversight,\u201d said Curtis S. Lavarello, executive director of the School Safety Advocacy Council, a training provider. \u201cThere are no national standards in terms of products for school safety.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nEach July, the group holds a conference and expo about school safety that normally draws about 80 exhibitors and 700 guests. This year, after Parkland, registration is on track to exceed 120 companies and 1,000 visitors.\n\nThe annual school safety conference hosted by the National Association of School Resource Officers drew 622 participants in 2011, then 733 in 2014 and 923 last year.\n\nSecurity options are manifold: palm scanners, mobile barricades, heat detectors, walkie-talkies, trauma kits, active shooter resistance training and more. In the fall, Florida Christian School in Miami began selling $120 ballistic panels for students to put in their backpacks. At a gun show in Tampa, Fla., last weekend, administrators and parents swarmed a booth offering similar panels for nearly $200 each.\n\nAfter shootings, schools wade through security options School safety products and technologies are proliferating, but their effectiveness is unclear. Here are some examples of the flood of services being pitched to campus administrators.\n\nThe civilian body armor market was valued at $72.2 million in 2016 and is expected to more than double by 2024, according to Grand View Research. Richard Soloway, the chief executive of Napco Security Technologies, which makes safety software systems, said in an investor call on Feb. 5 that campus safety was a \u201csignificant opportunity.\u201d\n\nThe vast and expanding array of security products can confuse school officials, said Stacie Dinse, the marketing director of Rauland, which has provided communications systems to schools for more than 75 years.\n\n\u201cTwenty years ago, school safety and security needs revolved around student fights, vandalism, weather-related emergencies and health-related emergencies such as a student asthma attack,\u201d she said. \u201cToday, there is much more focus on solutions to address emergency response and violence in their schools.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nNew companies are being formed to take advantage of the growing demand, people in the industry said. Businesses that had offered visitor management services and gunshot recognition software to hospitals and stadiums are now focusing more on schools. Military and law enforcement consultants are adding principals and superintendents to their rosters.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Heather L. Schwartz, who has studied safety technology for the RAND Corporation, said that research into what actually works is \u201creally thin.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s not a lot of evidence to help districts sort through the pile before investing in costly systems,\u201d she said. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot of hunger for some authoritative third-party source to go out and review these options.\u201d\n\nOften, schools react reflexively after high-profile school shootings, snapping up technologies and services as a symbolic gesture, Mr. Lavarello said.\n\n\u201cRight now, you feel sorry for these kids who have lost their lives, and you\u2019re searching for something fast, anything,\u201d he said. \u201cThe principal wants to tell the parents, \u2018Look, I have metal detectors and armed guards.\u2019\u201d\n\nBut products like a folding shield with straps called the Bodyguard Blanket and a remote-controlled pepper spray system are often far from infallible, Mr. Lavarello said.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe said his team had recently conducted a safety assessment at a school near Denver that had spent $600,000 fitting every window on campus with bulletproof film. Administrators had not realized that the film would prevent students trapped inside from breaking the glass to escape in an emergency.\n\nAdvocacy groups focused on school safety, many of them founded by relatives of shooting victims, increasingly try to offer guidance to school administrators in the form of checklists and updates on local programs. The National Institute of Justice, a government agency, administers a program to test the effectiveness of commercially available body armor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nErroll G. Southers, a public policy professor and the director of the Safe Communities Institute at the University of Southern California, said that all schools should at a minimum have their campuses assessed for safety risks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe even proposed that insurance companies reward schools that do safety assessments with a reduced premium.\n\n\u201cSchools should be treated like critical infrastructure,\u201d he said.\n\nSome campuses are starting to rely on outside help, taking donations from families, neighborhood businesses and local rotary clubs. One company pledged to donate proceeds from its bulletproof backpacks to Parkland victims and their families.\n\nSeveral bills seeking to fund school safety efforts are currently winding their way through Congress.\n\nPhoto\n\nSandy Hook was rebuilt in 2016 using a $50 million gift from the state of Connecticut. It has bullet-resistant windows adjacent to classroom doors, reinforced interior walls and landscaping that serves as a barrier outside the building. Other schools have raised money by issuing bonds and, in the case of Terry Shaw, the superintendent of the school district in Healdton, Okla., running a marathon to earn sponsorships from businesses.\n\nMr. Shaw\u2019s district, in the heart of tornado country, initially spent more than $100,000 installing seven shelters in the elementary school to protect students from windstorms.\n\nLast year, two more shelters were added to the middle school, where they are meant to double as hide-outs if there is a shooting. The district website links to a video in which Mr. Shaw tests a shelter by sitting inside while its exterior is pummeled by semiautomatic gunfire and explosives.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re left making those critical decisions on how best to protect our students,\u201d he said. \u201cEach school district\u2019s different, and there are so many issues you start getting into that it\u2019s hard to have a single set of guidelines.\u201d\n\nA few days after the shooting in Parkland, school officials one county over, in Miami-Dade, drew up a long wish list of campus security measures.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe school district, the fourth largest in the country, currently receives $9.5 million from Florida to keep its campuses safe. But now the superintendent, school board chairwoman, mayor and other leaders are asking for an additional $30 million for \u201cqualified human resources, artificial intelligence and technology based strategies,\u201d according to a letter sent to state lawmakers last month.\n\nMiami-Dade\u2019s plan includes video surveillance networks, automatically locking doors, digital floor plans, broad mass communications systems and ballistics-resistant windows. The county also wants more school resources officers and mental health services.\n\nOn Tuesday, Gov. Rick Scott of Florida, a Republican, spoke to reporters about the need to fund school safety programs.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve got to invest in metal detectors, we\u2019ve got to invest in bulletproof glass, we\u2019ve got to invest in steel doors, we\u2019ve got to invest in upgraded locks,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019ve got to do everything we can to make sure that somebody that wants to harm any one of our students can never do it again.\u201d", "title": "Threat of Shootings Turns School Security Into a Growth Industry", "authors": ["Tiffany Hsu"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTrump Resolute as G.O.P. Leaders Criticize Tariffs\u201d (front page, March 6):\n\nPeople fretting about President Trump\u2019s threat to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum are leaving a crucial factor out of their equation: a special election in Pennsylvania\u2019s 18th Congressional District next Tuesday. The district is in the state\u2019s steel and coal belt, including suburbs of Pittsburgh. By threatening the tariffs, Mr. Trump is hoping to swing enough votes to keep the district in his party\u2019s hands and avoid another humiliating off-cycle loss. Why aluminum? Alcoa is based in Pittsburgh.\n\nKey is that Mr. Trump is merely threatening the tariffs but hasn\u2019t enacted them. Late next week, after the votes are counted, he is highly likely to allow himself to be persuaded by his political allies to defer the tariffs indefinitely.\n\nTo rational people, it might make no sense to roil the stock market and upset our trading partners just to sway a few votes in southwestern Pennsylvania, but it\u2019s exactly the sort of narrow, petty con that has typified Mr. Trump\u2019s career and at which he excels.\n\nEDWARD GOODMAN\n\nWATERTOWN, CONN.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nAs an economist, I have no idea what it would look like for the United States to \u201cwin\u201d a trade war, and I\u2019ll bet a fair sum that President Trump doesn\u2019t either. The administration\u2019s proposals are likely to enrich certain shareholders and executives, while creating unemployment in industries that use imported solar panels, steel and aluminum. Consumer prices will increase. Trade wars create losers as well as winners, and if trade wars spread, the United States economy as a whole will suffer lower incomes and employment.", "title": "Opinion | Threatened Tariffs: The Motive, and the Fallout", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "The best long-term solutions, Goodell argues, involve working with nature rather than fighting to control it. One thing is certain: Rising sea levels will make it harder for governments to perform their essential function of keeping people safe.\n\nREPLENISH\n\nThe Virtuous Cycle of Water and Prosperity\n\nBy Sandra Postel\n\n323 pp. Island Press. $29.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the 20th century, societies dammed many rivers, depleted others and relentlessly pumped groundwater. The loss of habitats, especially wetlands, devastated fisheries and wildlife. Yet many water managers are embracing a new mind-set of working with nature rather than trying to conquer it.\n\nPostel tells a remarkable story of rejuvenation involving the Colorado Delta in Mexico. Upstream diversions dried up the delta decades ago. Yet in 2014, collaboration between the United States and Mexico, a binational team of scientists and conservationists, and several NGOs resulted in an agreement to turn the water back on.\n\nWatersheds, which Postel calls \u201cnature\u2019s water factories,\u201d are receiving special attention as cities try to make their water supplies more resilient. In 2010 the city of Denver joined the United States Forest Service to establish the Forest to Faucet Partnership, which underwrote a tree-thinning program to make forests more fire-resistant while enhancing water flow.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNew York City has a remarkable water supply in the Catskills, but the city faced a dilemma in the 1990s. Unless it took steps to protect the watershed surrounding its reservoirs, the city would need to build a water treatment plant. Rather than spend upward of $10 billion on the plant, it spent less than $4 billion protecting and restoring the watershed.\n\nThese and other stories \u2014 of cities conserving and reusing water, farmers engaging in \u201cconservation agriculture,\u201d and a dam-removal movement that is restoring thousands of miles of free-flowing rivers \u2014 give substance to the idea of replenishing.\n\nTHE SOURCE\n\nHow Rivers Made America and America Remade Its Rivers\n\nBy Martin Doyle\n\n349 pp. Norton. $26.95.\n\nPhoto\n\nDoyle\u2019s book tells the story of how rivers have shaped the United States from its founding, when cities were located astride rivers that served as transportation arteries for goods to move up- and downstream. As the new nation added lands, the federal government began to play an essential role in regulating rivers that crossed state boundaries, building dams for flood control and water supply, and overseeing the hydroelectric power they provided.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the latter half of the 20th century, environmental concerns prompted all levels of government to change course. Most notably, the Army Corps of Engineers, which has done more to straighten and confine rivers than any agency in the history of the world, remade itself into a force for restoring meanders in rivers, guarding endangered species and protecting wetlands.\n\nDoyle grafts his original ideas and research onto a big argument that doesn\u2019t quite hold up. To be sure, rivers shaped American society. But the federal government\u2019s authority, under the Commerce Clause of the Constitution and the 16th Amendment\u2019s power to generate revenue for federal projects, affected far more than rivers. It\u2019s a stretch to claim that the \u201cwhole economic history of the United States\u201d is the story of determining which level of government would provide water. Other economic historians place substantially more emphasis on railroads and the Interstate Highway System, for instance.\n\nStill, Doyle\u2019s historical perspective offers a poignant account of how financing the country\u2019s water and wastewater systems began at the local level, moved to the federal level, then, following the Reagan Revolution and the pulling back of federal funds, brought us to our current situation. Today, Washington provides almost no help to cash-strapped states and cities to rehabilitate their water systems.", "title": "Three Authors See Water, Water Everywhere, for Better and Worse", "authors": ["Robert Glennon"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Three images will rotate through each billboard. One points people to Ms. Sullivan\u2019s website, and says, across a picture of a man with a question mark over his chest, \u201cthe truth will be revealed.\u201d Another is a picture of Ms. Sullivan and says: \u201cMy rapist is protected by New York state law. I am not. Neither are you. Neither are your children.\u201d\n\nMs. Sullivan said the original design included Mr. Sargent\u2019s name and face, but that the company that owns the billboards would not allow her to use them, for fear of getting sued. Two billboard companies said they would not work with her at all.\n\nThe three billboards will be up for 28 days, Ms. Sullivan said, which will cost her $14,000. (She spent about another $2,000 on the website.) Once the billboards come down, Mr. Sargent\u2019s name and photograph will appear on her website.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Sargent did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nIn a statement, Emma Willard said, \u201cWe commend and support the survivors of sexual abuse who are committed to affecting change on this important issue.\u201d\n\nThe third graphic that will rotate through the billboards says \u201cNY Pass The Child Victims Act,\u201d a piece of proposed legislation in Albany that would give victims until age 28 to file criminal charges and allow them to sue until age 50. It would also create a one-year \u201clookback\u201d window, during which cases from any time could proceed in court. Today, the statutes of limitations in New York that govern the sexual abuse of children are among the most restrictive in the country. Most adult survivors had until they were 23 years old, at the latest, to bring a case.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nActivist groups have been pushing the Child Victims Act in Albany for more than 10 years, and have made an especially aggressive effort this year, targeting specific state senators. Ms. Sullivan moved to New York City last month from her home in Florida to help lobby for the measure.\n\nSupporters are trying to make the act part of the state budget, which is due April 1 \u2014 a tactic that would give Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who supports the bill, more leverage to negotiate with legislators. The Child Victims Act has support from the State Assembly, which is controlled by Democrats, but there is resistance to it in the Republican-controlled State Senate, which has blocked the bill for years. John J. Flanagan, the Senate majority leader, did not respond to questions about the legislation.\n\nA central sticking point is the lookback window. Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the archbishop of New York, said on Tuesday that any legislation that included it should be rejected and called the window \u201ctoxic\u201d for the Catholic Church. Representatives of the church have said it supports changing the statute of limitations, but fears a flurry of lawsuits and the financial hit a lookback window might deliver.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut proponents of the legislation have said that hasn\u2019t happened in states that have enacted similar legislation, and they call the window crucial. In addition to providing victims their day in court, they said the window serves a public-safety function by flushing out suspected abusers who are still in the community.\n\n\u201cThe lookback window will help identify abusers, many of whom still have contact with kids,\u201d said State Senator Brad Hoylman, Democrat of Manhattan, who sponsored the bill in the Senate. \u201cNew York has among the worst laws in the country on child sexual abuse. We are an outlier, so this fix is a long time coming.\u201d\n\nThe billboards strategy was used by activists in London pushing for arrests in the Grenfell Tower fire, which killed 71 people last year, who last month deployed three roving billboards to ask why there had been no arrests in the tragedy.\n\nMs. Sullivan said she was motivated by the frustration that Mr. Sargent has faced no major consequences.\n\n\u201cHe is free to teach, free to coach, free to be elected onto boards,\u201d she said. \u201cThere are no blemishes on his record.\u201d", "title": "Three Billboards Call Out Sexual Abuse", "authors": ["Elizabeth A. Harris"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "The bill was seen as a repudiation of Mr. Trump\u2019s budget requests. The president, for instance, had asked lawmakers to eliminate the advanced projects agency, saying that such research was best left to the private sector. But even Republicans balked.\n\nIf anything, that political fight obscured the magnitude of what happened. Tarak Shah, a former chief of staff to the under secretary for science and energy, pointed out that at the Paris climate conference in 2015, President Barack Obama set a goal of doubling federal investment in clean energy research. At the time, that seemed impossible. But during the Trump era, Congress has essentially put the country one-fifth of the way there.\n\nThe spending bill, Mr. Shah said, is \u201cabsolutely huge for energy innovation.\u201d (For more on why experts think such innovation is crucial for tackling climate change, see this article.)\n\nOne notable dynamic here: A number of Republicans who don\u2019t typically talk about global warming have nonetheless been eager to support clean energy research in recent years. \u201cThe one thing we do better than any country in the world is innovation through research,\u201d said Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee, at an advanced projects agency conference this month. \u201cWe must be careful not to lose this advantage.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s a story we\u2019ve seen repeatedly of late. When the solar and wind industries warned last year that the tax overhaul bill would cripple renewable energy investment, Republicans like Senator Rob Portman of Ohio stepped in. Mr. Portman\u2019s state is a major manufacturer of wind turbine components and has more than 100,000 jobs in clean energy industries.", "title": "Three Climate Updates You Might Have Missed (and One We Did, Too)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Die Motte\n\nDesigners: Astrid Schweitzer and Anel Rinat\n\nBarcelona, Spain\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s quite a cultural mix,\u201d says Astrid Schweitzer, 22, of Die Motte, the Barcelona-based jewelry label that she runs with her co-designer Anel Rinat, 27. Schweitzer, who is of Chilean, Peruvian and German descent, was raised in Barcelona\u2019s vibrant Poble Sec neighborhood, which overlooks the Mediterranean. Rinat is Kazakh, and grew up in Almaty, surrounded by the sagebrush steppe and snow-capped mountains of Central Asia; she was shaped by the city\u2019s Scythian and Soviet heritage. The two met in a jewelry arts school in Barcelona in 2016 and quickly became friends. \u201cWe connected by intuition,\u201d Schweitzer says.\n\nThe brand is an amalgamation of their distinct backgrounds, and the pair produces precious-metal wire pieces that are both delicate and evocative: gilded dove-shaped barrettes that recall Picasso\u2019s 1961 drawing \u201cLa Colombe Bleue,\u201d rings made from miniature handmade silver links and face-shaped hoop earrings with dangling chains that look like tears. The designers\u2019 process is instinctual, like their friendship: Ideas for new projects are formed during meandering walks through the foggy forests of Montseny or in their airy studio near Pla\u00e7a d\u2019Espanya, where they manipulate metals and sculpt. \u201cIt\u2019s like meditating,\u201d Rinat says. Their most recent collection comprises wisp-like earrings, brooches and rings inspired by the Swiss artist Alberto Giacometti. \u201cWe try to pull from our contrast and create a balance,\u201d Schweitzer says.", "title": "Three New Sculptural Jewelry Brands to Know", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nI Want Stand-Up Comedy\n\nAparna Nancherla on \u201cThe Standups.\u201d Saeed Adyani/Netflix\n\n\u2018The Standups\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Starting Tuesday, on\n\nStarting Tuesday, on Netflix Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nNetflix\u2019s stand-up hoard grows and grows, and this week the platform is adding six new half-hour specials. The standouts of the batch are from Kyle Kinane and Aparna Nancherla \u2014 he\u2019s blustery, she\u2019s more measured, but both have clear perspectives and masterly control of the crowd\u2019s energy during their sets.\n\nI Want Something Unnerving\n\nA scene from \u201cTabula Rasa.\u201d Caviar Films\n\n\u2018Tabula Rasa\u2019\n\nWhen to Watch: Now, on\n\nNow, on Netflix Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis Belgian series (in Flemish, with English subtitles) centers on a woman with amnesia who police believe is a key witness in a missing-persons case. The show has an intense ominousness and a real spooky streak, as well as an impressive \u2014 disquieting \u2014 visual style. It is sometimes downright frightening, but not in a slasher-gore way, more in a poisoned poem sort of way: arms that shatter like porcelain, a nightmarish magician, an over-present doll and a startling red sand that seems to appear out of nowhere. It\u2019s a little too freaky to make for a comfortable binge, so give yourself some time with the nine episodes instead.\n\nI Want Something Suspenseful\n\nLee Ingleby in \u201cInnocent.\u201d Steffan Hill/Sundance Now\n\n\u2018Innocent\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Starting Thursday, on Sundance Now.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nDavid has spent seven years in prison for killing his wife \u2014 a crime he says he didn\u2019t commit. Now he has been released on a legal technicality, and wouldn\u2019t you know it, lots of people involved with the case have dangerous secrets. There are only four episodes (they come out weekly), but there\u2019s still a lot of interpersonal thriller crammed in here; a lot of anxious, jangly phone-ringing and concerned pouting; and some juicy twists. As far as low-commitment mysteries go, this is a solid one.\n\nComings and Goings on Thursday\n\nThe new season of \u201cRuPaul\u2019s Drag Race\u201d starts at 8 p.m. on VH1.\n\nThe \u201cGrey\u2019s Anatomy\u201d spinoff \u201cStation 19,\u201d about Seattle firefighters, kicks off at 9 p.m. on ABC.\n\n\u201cPortlandia\u201d airs its series finale at 10 p.m. on IFC. Eight seasons is a lot of seasons!\n\nNeed Some Guidance on Picking Your Next Show?\n\nDo you have a particularly vexing TV conundrum? Are you trying to figure out what to watch next? (Or maybe what TV show to give up on completely?) We\u2019re here to help. Send your questions to our advice column: watching@nytimes.com.\n\n0", "title": "Three Shows to Watch This Week", "authors": ["Margaret Lyons"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Maharam\n\nThe textile giant Maharam, born from a Lower East Side pushcart at the turn of the 20th century, has long pursued collaborations with contemporary industrial designers, including Berlin-based Hella Jongerius and Munich\u2019s Konstantin Grcic. But perhaps its most fertile relationship in recent years has been with the Dutch husband-and-wife team of Stefan Scholten and Carole Baijings, both in their mid-40s, whose eponymous Amsterdam studio has designed fabrics for Maharam that speak to their love of soft yet bright colors, such as azure blue and cotton-candy pink, as well as grid-based patterns.\n\nImage Clockwise from top left: an antique darning sampler that inspired their designs for Maharam\u2019s upcoming fabric range; a mug from Maharam\u2019s first foray into housewares; dishware from the collection. Credit Courtesy of Scholten & Baijings\n\nNow, the couple and Maharam are uniting to introduce a line of housewares and accessories created in collaboration with several Japanese craftsmen. There is a stackable wooden stool manufactured by Karimoku New Standard, its seat upholstered in a variety of Maharam fabrics (three of them by Scholten & Baijings) and a five-piece collection of colorful, geometric porcelain dishware produced by the Japanese ceramics company 1616 / Arita Japan. \u201cConnecting Maharam with the level of work you find in Japan was incredibly satisfying,\u201d Scholten says.\n\nYet even as Maharam makes its first foray into housewares, the brand isn\u2019t neglecting its roots. Mary Murphy, the company\u2019s top design executive, recently introduced Scholten & Baijings to a bygone craft from Holland that was unfamiliar to them: composition paper-size patchwork darning samplers made by young girls in the 18th and 19th centuries, each featuring a dozen or so colorful, complicated stitch patterns originally intended to mend clothes. Scholten & Baijings, always ready to embrace a new idea (however old), reinterpreted these embroidered motifs for Maharam\u2019s latest textile range, to be released in July, elevating the homespun look with Mondrian-like flair.", "title": "Three Venerated Design Companies Look Back to Move Forward", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Taken together, these three books tell an alarming story about how difficult it is for women to access quality care; particularly those women suffering from poorly understood autoimmune disorders.\n\nThis is hardly breaking news. One member of the feminist collective that produced the 1971 women\u2019s health manual \u201cOur Bodies, Ourselves\u201d said that \u201ceveryone had a \u2018doctor story\u2019\u2014that is, a tale about male physicians who were sexist, paternalistic, judgmental or simply unable to provide the information women needed.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThese new \u201cdoctor stories\u201d cut deep, especially in a moment when \u201cbelieve women\u201d has become a rallying cry. They feel linked to other instances of women\u2019s voices being suppressed and belittled \u2014 in the accounts of assault and harassment emerging in the #MeToo moment, for example, or in the recent studies showing how frequently men interrupt women in meetings and how rarely women are quoted as experts. This is a crisis of authority, Dusenbery argues. Women are regarded as unreliable narrators who can\u2019t even be trusted to speak for themselves or to testify to their own pain.\n\nIn \u201cDoing Harm,\u201d this cultural distrust of women \u2014 ancient and ingrained \u2014 is shown to govern quality of care at every stage of treatment. Women with abdominal pain wait in emergency rooms for 65 minutes compared with 49 minutes for men , and young women are seven times more likely to be sent home from a hospital while in the middle of a heart attack. Doctors rarely communicate (or understand) how drugs from aspirin to antidepressants affect women and men differently. Autoimmune disorders have been understudied because, as Hirsch points out, three-fourths of the patients are women and it is considered a woman\u2019s ailment, never mind that 37 million people are afflicted, as estimated by the American Autoimmune Related Diseases Association. (In comparison, 15 million Americans have cancer.)\n\nWomen are consistently undertreated for pain, as one influential paper showed: Male patients are given pain relief while women, who are more likely to have their pain rated as \u201cemotional,\u201d are given sedatives. This also extends to children; a study of postoperative pain management found that boys were more likely to receive codeine and girls the gentler acetaminophen.\n\nFor women of color, especially black women, the situation is even more parlous. Black patients are 22 times less likely to get any kind of pain relief in emergency rooms. And Dusenbery reports on a disturbing 2016 study of more than 200 medical students who were presented absurd, made-up statements on race and medicine. Half gave credence to statements like: Black people have less sensitive nerve endings than white people.\n\nPhoto\n\nAddressing such entrenched inequities requires more than bringing more women doctors into the fold. As Norman learns the hard way in \u201cAsk Me About My Uterus,\u201d women doctors are not immune from implicit bias. Nor will a greater number of women doctors make up for the fact that, to this day, men are the default objects of study for research. A 2005 study found that almost 80 percent of animal pain studies used only males. A 1986 study on the influence of obesity on breast and uterine cancer infamously failed to enroll any women in the study.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAccording to Virginia Woolf, writing about the sick body (\u201cthis monster,\u201d \u201cthis miracle\u201d) requires the courage of a lion tamer and the spirit of a philosopher.\n\nNot all these books meet that exalted standard. But all three, despite their grim stories and projections, leave the reader galvanized, not despairing. Each of them ends on a similar note \u2014 calling for women to keep sharing their \u201cdoctor stories,\u201d keep putting pressure on medical professionals to study women\u2019s health and, in the meantime, for women themselves to learn how to advocate for their own care. Even as they recognize the burden that sick women must carry (Dusenbery: \u201cWomen should not be required to be more knowledgeable about women\u2019s health than their doctors are\u201d), they are each, in their own flawed, complicated way, the very intervention they seek.", "title": "Three Views of the Crisis in Women\u2019s Health", "authors": ["Parul Sehgal", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 Well, that threw everyone for a loop.\n\nNot the shows, nor even the snow (snow!) that covered Paris on Thursday morning but rather the news that Riccardo Tisci had been appointed chief creative officer of Burberry. In all the speculation about who would get the job after Christopher Bailey announced last October that he was stepping down, Mr. Tisci\u2019s name never came up (we were all thinking too local).\n\nAs the various fashion folk sat, checking their social feeds and waiting for the Chlo\u00e9 show to start, the surprise choice was all anyone could talk, or tweet, about.\n\nMostly, people were intrigued by what Mr. Tisci might make of the brand that Britishness built. After all, unexpected combinations are part of the guiding principle of fashion, whether you\u2019re talking about human resources or clothes.", "title": "Thrown for a Loop at Dries Van Noten and Chlo\u00e9", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "This past week, Panama\u2019s Public Ministry said it was looking into whether there had been any \u201cpunishable conduct\u201d in the dispute \u2014 which means that an arm of a foreign government finds itself in the extraordinary position of investigating a business owned by the American president.\n\nJust seven years ago, at the hotel\u2019s grand opening, the president of Panama at the time joined Mr. Trump in extolling the property. Panama City was then awash with international investors and a booming economy, earning it the nickname \u201cDubai of Latin America.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAlan Garten, the Trump Organization\u2019s chief legal officer, said President Trump had no role in the current dispute. \u201cThis has absolutely nothing to do with the president of the United States,\u201d he said. \u201cIt is purely a commercial dispute,\u201d adding that \u201cIt is simply getting more attention, obviously.\u201d\n\nAll indications point to business, not politics, as the source of the tensions, and at any other moment, the Trump Organization and its army of lawyers might have relished this sort of pitched battle.\n\n\n\nBut the Panamanian misadventure has become the family business\u2019s biggest headache at a time when its founder is in the White House and every move and woe is magnified across the planet. The business is also showing other signs of receding: The Trump Organization last year agreed to buyout deals that removed the Trump name from once-prized properties in New York and Toronto.\n\nWith those stresses and strains, the company is reluctant to walk away from the Panama property and possibly invite other partners to challenge their agreements, according to people close to the company who spoke on the condition of anonymity.\n\nThe Trumps also believe that the law is on their side, according to their lawyers, who argue that their management agreement prevents Mr. Fintiklis from terminating the contract without an arbitrator\u2019s order. The contract to manage the hotel extends through 2031, and the Trumps say they want to stand behind their employees, several of whom Mr. Fintiklis has sought to fire, for the duration of the deal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe dispute comes as the Trumps\u2019 property \u2014 like many Panamanian hotels \u2014 is struggling.\n\nThe hotel lost over $1 million last year, according to the hotel\u2019s confidential financial documents reviewed by The Times, after turning a gross operating profit of more than $800,000 in 2016. (The results are unaudited and may improve somewhat once they are finalized.)\n\nMr. Fintiklis, 39, declined to comment, but he has made several notable \u2014 and provocative \u2014 appearances at the hotel in recent days. On one evening, following a verbal confrontation with Trump employees, he and his entourage of about a dozen people retired to the lobby and had pizza delivered from a restaurant on the property. Then Mr. Fintiklis played music from \u201cZorba the Greek\u201d on the lobby\u2019s baby grand piano while his friends sang along.\n\nBorn in Cyprus, Mr. Fintiklis served as an officer in the country\u2019s military before studying law at Oxford University. He now lives in South Florida and runs his own investment firm, Ithaca Capital Partners.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s a very smart individual, and he worked with us for 10 years so he\u2019s very well trained,\u201d said Pierre Charalambides, a co-founder of Dolphin Capital Partners, a real estate private equity firm where Mr. Fintiklis previously worked. \u201cThis battle with Trump, it fits him perfectly.\u201d\n\nIn 2017, Mr. Fintiklis agreed to buy 202 of the hotel\u2019s 369 units for about $25 million, making him the controlling owner of the hotel. The 70-story tower also includes a casino and a separate condominium development, which are not part of the dispute between the Trumps and Mr. Fintiklis.\n\nThe Trumps say they blessed the transaction, on the condition that Mr. Fintiklis not interfere with their management of the hotel.\n\nWhen the purchase was finalized in August, the Trump-Fintiklis partnership initially seemed promising. Mr. Fintiklis hailed the hotel as \u201can iconic property\u201d and said he looked forward to working with the Trumps.\n\nBut soon after closing on the purchase, he tried to remove them.\n\nHis campaign began in earnest in October. He arranged for the hotel\u2019s unit owners to meet \u2014 the Trumps say he falsely portrayed the session as a \u201cmeet and greet\u201d \u2014 and they voted to declare the Trumps in default of their management agreement. The dispute soon spilled into the legal system, with Mr. Fintiklis seeking arbitration to remove the Trumps.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Trumps say that the rapid-fire nature of Mr. Fintiklis\u2019s legal efforts show that he never intended to cooperate, and that he had been planning an attack from the get-go.\n\n\u201cWe just want to run the hotel peacefully, and without interference,\u201d said Mr. Garten, the Trump Organization lawyer. \u201cBut I look forward to litigating this, and have no doubt we will prevail.\u201d\n\nThe president continues to own the company through a trust but has turned over day-to-day management to his eldest sons, Donald Jr. and Eric.\n\nPhoto\n\nMore than a decade ago \u2014 long before Mr. Fintiklis came into the picture \u2014 the Trumps began their foray into Panama when they teamed up with the developer Roger Khafif and his firm, Newland International Properties, as well as another partner.\n\nNewland signed an agreement with the Trump Organization, which would brand and manage the property. In a 2007 bond offering, Newland said the Trump name would be a boon to the project: \u201cWe benefit from the international prestige and name recognition associated with the Trump brand name.\u201d\n\nThe project united the Trumps with influential political figures, including Ricardo Martinelli, the president of Panama at the time. \u201cYou\u2019re my friend. Great honor,\u201d Mr. Trump said to the president at the grand opening in July 2011.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter his presidency, Mr. Martinelli fled to the United States in 2015 as Panamanian authorities opened an investigation into allegations of corruption and illegal surveillance. He is currently in the Federal Detention Center in Miami, fighting extradition.\n\nDuring the 2008 financial crisis, the project encountered financial difficulties during the development phase. Newland defaulted on its debt soon after the building opened and later filed for bankruptcy.\n\nWhen Mr. Fintiklis became majority owner last year, the hotel was struggling, a fact he soon blamed on the Trumps.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWithering in his criticism, he said in one court filing that \u201cabysmal management\u201d of the hotel, along with \u201cmaterial breaches\u201d of its management contract and fiduciary duties, had \u201cdramatically\u201d driven down profits and the condition of the building. \u201cThe hotel has been virtually empty,\u201d the filing said, a claim the Trumps dispute.\n\nThe Trump Organization declined to reveal the hotel\u2019s occupancy rates, but in a letter to hotel unit owners, the company argued that the hotel \u201ccontinues to outperform the market by a wide margin,\u201d despite a weakening hotel market in Panama. The Trumps say that Mr. Fintiklis was aware of the hotel\u2019s performance, and the broader hotel market woes, when he signed the deal.\n\nPhoto\n\nA hotel building boom over the past decade has tripled the number of hotel rooms in the country, according to Armando Rodr\u00edguez, president of the Panamanian Hotel Association. During the same period, however, occupancy rates have steadily fallen \u2014 to about 47 percent last year from about double that rate in 2008, Mr. Rodr\u00edguez said.\n\nAlgerd Monstavicius, who bought one of the hotel\u2019s penthouses as an investment in 2007, four years before the building opened, said he had seen revenues from his unit plummet in the past year. He attributes the falloff in part to President Trump\u2019s hard-line stance on immigration and antipathy toward him across much of Latin America.\n\n\u201cThe perception is: Trump is anti-Latino,\u201d said Mr. Monstavicius, 78, a retired pathologist living in Incline Village, Nev. \u201cAnd that\u2019s reflected in the occupancy.\u201d\n\nLawyers and executives from both sides of the dispute said the Panamanian government, at least so far, appeared to be showing no favoritism in either direction. At various times during the past week, delegations of government investigators and ministry officials, often accompanied by armed security forces, have spilled from the elevators into the hotel\u2019s elegant sky lobby, as perplexed hotel guests looked on.\n\nAs if the standoff were not bizarre enough, a number of apparent coincidences embellish the tale even further.\n\nFor one, Dolphin Capital Partners, where Mr. Fintiklis worked for 10 years, was founded in 2004 by a pair of investors who once worked at George Soros\u2019s real estate investment arm.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere is no evidence that Mr. Soros, a huge Democratic donor and critic of President Trump, played any role in the turmoil here, or that partisan American politics are a factor in the effort to remove the Trumps. Mr. Charalambides, the Dolphin co-founder, said his firm had no current business connection to Mr. Soros.\n\nIn addition, Mr. Fintiklis\u2019s New York lawyers operate out of 666 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, the financially troubled office tower owned by the family of Jared Kushner, President Trump\u2019s son-in-law and senior adviser.\n\nAnd Mr. Fintiklis filed the registration papers for his company, Ithaca Capital Partners, in Delaware on Nov. 9, 2016 \u2014 the day after President Trump won the election.", "title": "Thugs, Leeches, Shouting and Shoving at Trump Hotel in Panama", "authors": ["Kirk Semple", "Ben Protess", "Steve Eder"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBefore presenting the Oscars for documentary short and live-action short, Tiffany Haddish and Maya Rudolph drew laughs sending up the academy\u2019s progress in with representation of minorities, both among presenters and nominees.\n\nMs. Haddish and Ms. Rudolph assured the audience that if anybody was uncomfortable with the number of minorities on the awards show, there were plenty of Caucasians waiting backstage, both to appear on camera and work behind the scenes.\n\nTheir comedy wasn\u2019t the only hit on social media. Some eagled-eyed viewers spotted that Ms. Haddish was wearing the same dress she wore to promote \u201cGirls Trip\u201d and to host \u201cSaturday Night Live.\u201d\n\nAnd others decided they had spotted something else: future Oscar hosts.\n\nHere\u2019s what the two presenters said:\n\nTIFFANY HADDISH: We are so happy to be here but our feet hurt. MAYA RUDOLPH: Yeah. I had to take my shoes off. HADDISH: Girl, me too. I\u2019ve been wearing these shoes since 11 o\u2019clock this morning. How long you been wearing your shoes? RUDOLPH: Since the Critics\u2019 Choice Awards. HADDISH: Well, I got blisters bubbling up on the bottom of my foot. RUDOLPH: Girl, my pinkie toe fell off. HADDISH: Oh. RUDOLPH: We are so happy to be here, but a little nervous too, because a few years ago, people were saying that Oscars were so white. And since then, some real progress has been made. HADDISH: But when we came out together, we know some of you were thinking, \u201cAre the Oscars too black now?\u201d RUDOLPH: But we just want to say, don\u2019t worry. There are so many more white people to come tonight. HADDISH: So many. We just came from backstage, and there are tons of them back there. RUDOLPH: Tons of them. HADDISH: And not just movie stars, there are white people walking around with headsets, white people with clipboards. RUDOLPH: Oh yeah. HADDISH: Now, I\u2019m personally not a fan of white people with clipboards, because I\u2019m always wondering, what are they writing down about me? RUDOLPH: Oh yeah. When they\u2019re like, \u201cI\u2019m sorry, you\u2019re not on the list.\u201d And they didn\u2019t check all the pages. And I\u2019m like, \u201dHey white dude with the clipboard, check all the pages.\u201d HADDISH: Oh, oh, and what about when they\u2019re on the headset and you\u2019re like, \u201cWho are they talking to?\u201d Hold on one second. One moment. RUDOLPH: Are you talking to me? Oh, you\u2019re not talking to me. Oh, you want me to wait. I\u2019m sorry? HADDISH: O.K., Kim. O.K., Kim. RUDOLPH: Who is Kim? HADDISH: I don\u2019t know, but it feels like I\u2019m in a department store. RUDOLPH: Guys. Guys. enough about our personal issues. We are presenting two awards tonight, documentary short subject and live action short film. Here are the nominees for best documentary short subject. [NOMINEES ANNOUNCED] HADDISH: Hi, Meryl! I want you to be my mama one day. RUDOLPH: One day. Just one day. HADDISH: Let\u2019s get this money, girl. [BEFORE ANNOUNCING LIVE ACTION SHORT FILM] HADDISH: Yup. We\u2019re back. RUDOLPH: Tiffany, can I just say, when you peed off a zip line in \u201cGirls Trip,\u201d it was brilliant. HADDISH: Oh my God, Maya, when you took a dookie in the street in \u201cBridesmaids,\u201d it changed my life. It was inspiring. RUDOLPH: Thank you. Thank you, and look where we are now. HADDISH: Yeah. It was all worth it! RUDOLPH: It was worth it. [HADDISH STARTS DANCING] RUDOLPH: There she is.\n\n[ See a slide show from the red carpet | read about the after-parties]", "title": "Tiffany Haddish and Maya Rudolph, 2019 Oscar Hosts?", "authors": ["Sopan Deb"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "ORLANDO, Fla. \u2014 The pronouncement pierced the silence as soon as Tiger Woods made an 11-foot par putt to secure his third sub-70 in his last four rounds, a four-under-par 68 at Bay Hill on Thursday at the Arnold Palmer Invitational. \u201cTiger Woods \u2014 back!\u201d came the cry from a fan near the ninth green.\n\nWoods, fresh off a tie for second at the Valspar Championship, was making his first start in this tournament since he won for the eighth time here in 2013. His 68 on Thursday left him tied for seventh, four shots behind the leader, Henrik Stenson.\n\nAt this time last year, \u201cWoods \u2014 back\u201d was shorthand for a different narrative. He was a little more than a month away from having lower lumbar fusion surgery, which he starkly described last week as \u201cthe only option\u201d he had left, a \u201clast-case resort\u201d that would leave him in \u201cuncharted territory.\u201d\n\nWhen the PGA Tour\u2019s wraparound season began anew in October, Woods had not been cleared by his doctors to take full shots with all the clubs in his bag. He was not certain he would compete again, much less contend.", "title": "Tiger Woods Is Back in the Hunt, Thrilling Fans and Opponents", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Some brands had already bet on a Tiger Woods comeback, even when it looked unlikely. Bridgestone reached out to Mr. Woods about playing its golf ball in September 2016, shortly after Nike announced that it would no longer be selling golf equipment (though it would continue its Woods-branded clothing line). It hardly mattered that Mr. Woods had not appeared in a tournament in 13 months.\n\nPhoto\n\nAngel Ilagan, Bridgestone Golf\u2019s chief executive, said in a recent interview that the company had sent 12 dozen balls to Mr. Woods, hoping he would attach his name and endorsement to the product, which he eventually did, signing a multi-year contract in December of that year\n\n\u201cWe know Tiger\u2019s brand strength,\u201d Mr. Ilagan said. \u201cWhether he does play or not doesn\u2019t really matter. That\u2019s just icing on the cake.\u201d\n\nWith Mr. Woods apparently close to his previous form \u2014 he is the betting favorite to win his fifth green jacket at the Masters \u2014 that icing is already tasting sweet. Already in 2018, Bridgestone\u2019s sales of golf balls have increased 115 percent over the same period a year ago. Mr. Ilagan attributed that to Mr. Woods; Bridgestone has already begun to market a Woods edition golf ball, which it introduced on Wednesday.\n\nTaylorMade, which signed Mr. Woods to use its clubs in January last year, said it saw no need to build a marketing campaign around the star, because the mere fact that he plays with the clubs or talks about their performance in interviews does the selling job.\n\n\u201cWhen Tiger says something, the world takes notice,\u201d David Abeles, the company\u2019s chief executive, said. \u201cBecause it\u2019s true. We\u2019re excited just when he talks in his own words.\u201d\n\nMr. Ilagan suggested that Mr. Woods\u2019s rebound from the dramatic turn his career took in 2009 had made him more relatable and perhaps likable for fans. \u201cHis absence showed what was missing when he wasn\u2019t there,\u201d Mr. Ilagan said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMartin Buckley, global vice president and general manager of Nike Golf, which sells a full line of Woods-branded clothing, including shoes, shirts and sweaters, said that fans would be seeing a lot more of him in Nike advertisements this summer.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s a unique, integral part of the Nike family,\u201d Mr. Buckley wrote in an email, \u201cand we don\u2019t see that changing any time soon.\u201d\n\n\n\nBut while performance brands remain aligned with Mr. Woods, more mainstream companies have not yet jumped back on the bandwagon. Peter Land, a partner at Finsbury, the strategic communications firm, suspects a reason could be that Mr. Woods likely alienated women when news about his extramarital affairs surfaced.\n\n\u201cBrands with a strong female stakeholder base will continue to be a struggle for Tiger,\u201d said Mr. Land, who was with PepsiCo when Gatorade, which PepsiCo owns, decided to drop Mr. Woods. \u201cThere are so many other successful and charismatic global athletes to partner with \u2014 and they come with a lower risk profile.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe companies that might benefit most from Mr. Woods\u2019s resurgence could be the ones that got onboard a few years ago, seizing on a \u201cbuy low\u201d opportunity, said Mr. Carter, the University of Southern California professor.\n\nFull Swing Golf, which makes golf simulators, started a relationship with Mr. Woods in 2014, when he was rehabbing from injury. Its chief executive, Ryan Dotters, thought Mr. Woods could use the simulator to train indoors, and Mr. Woods was receptive.\n\n\u201cIt was definitely a strategic move,\u201d Mr. Dotters said. \u201cWe felt no matter what Tiger had gone through in the past, we knew his brand was extremely strong. We thought there was a big opportunity there.\u201d\n\nThe relationship has not always been easy. Last May, Mr. Woods was arrested and charged with driving under the influence after being found asleep behind the wheel of his Mercedes-Benz. A toxicology report found several powerful painkillers in his system that he said he was taking to cope with his fourth back surgery that spring.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Woods pleaded guilty to reckless driving and agreed to enter a diversion program, which included a year on probation and 50 hours of community service. He had already completed treatment at a clinic for help in dealing with his prescription medications.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis time, his sponsors stood by him.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t consider dropping him at all,\u201d Mr. Ilagan said. \u201cWe looked into the situation and ascertained that what he did was the right thing. People realized he was about as responsible as he could have been in that situation.\u201d\n\nBridgestone did conduct a survey after the arrest to gauge the public\u2019s reaction, Mr. Ilagan said. \u201cThe results were that the consumers were very supportive of him,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Abeles, TaylorMade\u2019s chief executive, said: \u201cWe\u2019re all human. We believed in Tiger, and we continue to believe in Tiger.\u201d\n\nMr. Carter said there would continue to be a certain amount of mistrust when it came to Mr. Woods and the brands he represented.\n\n\u201cRegardless of the circumstances, corporate partners don\u2019t want to see a mug shot,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s not surprising if it may take a little bit of time for mainstream brands to want to hitch their representation to his.\u201d\n\nWith that said, though, most fans assumed that Mr. Woods would never recover from his injuries. The golfer with 14 major championships has proved repeatedly throughout his career that it is never safe to count him out.\n\n\u201cI think people in this country are very quick to forgive and forget,\u201d Mr. Carter said. \u201cThey want to give people the benefit of the doubt and a second chance. And when you\u2019re a beloved figure like Tiger Woods, I think fans really want to see him come back. He still has this halo effect.\u201d", "title": "Tiger Woods Is Back. Will Sponsors Buy In?", "authors": ["Zach Schonbrun"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "After opening with a 76 on Thursday, Spieth walked through the scoring area looking shellshocked and made a beeline for the practice green, where he putted until darkness fell. On Friday morning, Spieth appeared relaxed. After his first-hole introduction, Spieth, who wore a winter beanie to ward off the 48-degree morning chill, tipped an imaginary bill to the throng of fans surrounding the tee box.\n\nAfter two solid shots, Spieth missed his six-foot birdie putt, capsulizing his recent putting woes. He said his struggles \u201cwere all about my own game.\u201d\n\nStill, it was hard to ignore the frenzy surrounding Woods, which at times made Stenson and Spieth seem invisible in plain sight. Woods said he was unaware that he ever had the lead to himself, because he never saw a leader board until he walked off his last green after his bogey. His focus was so fine-tuned that he didn\u2019t hear the running commentary of all the amateur analysts and play-by-play announcers in the gallery.\n\nThe crowd following the threesome had the size and timbre of a major championship Sunday. The volunteers at many holes became so caught up in watching Woods that they neglected to marshal the fans, who spilled inside the ropes and staked out spots behind tee boxes or within a few feet of the players so they could take sharper photographs with their smartphones.\n\n\u201cHe just has an extra following so the roars are a little louder,\u201d Spieth said. \u201cThere\u2019s certainly an energy about the gallery that you don\u2019t have anywhere else.\u201d\n\nSpieth, 24, is part of the generation that was inspired to take up golf by Woods\u2019s dominance. To this point, he and his peers have known Woods mostly as a mentor. At last year\u2019s Presidents Cup, Spieth was one of the players Woods oversaw as an assistant captain for the United States team.\n\nSnedeker, 37, who is old enough to have squared off against Woods when he was winning regularly, said of the younger Americans, \u201cI think it will be harder for them because they only know Tiger as a friend, and they don\u2019t know Tiger as the \u2018cut your head off on 18 and make that putt to win the tournament\u2019 kind of guy.\u201d\n\nCasey, 40, remembers that Woods well and was thrilled to be tied with him with 36 holes left.\n\n\u201cI want him to play brilliant golf, want him to win again because I want these kids to see what we dealt with for a long, long time,\u201d Casey said. \u201cI\u2019m not saying this in a nasty way. Officials said John F. Kelly, the chief of staff, had tried to warn Mr. Tillerson in a phone call days earlier by saying, cryptically, \u201cyou may get a tweet.\u201d White House officials also added that Mr. Tillerson had been on the toilet at the time of the call.\n\nMr. Tillerson will likely be remembered as among the least successful secretaries of state in recent history, having alienated much of the White House staff and most of his own department with an imperious style, skeletal leadership team and missteps on the international stage.\n\nJust as problematic were his frequent disagreements with Mr. Trump over key policy decisions, such as whether to remain in the Paris climate accord, how to broker the dispute between Saudi Arabia and Qatar and whether and when to engage in discussions with North Korea.\n\nOne of Mr. Tillerson\u2019s most difficult moments came over the summer, when NBC News revealed that he had called the president a \u201cmoron\u201d in a meeting with senior officials. Although he held a news conference that day to heap praise on Mr. Trump, Mr. Tillerson never denied making the remark, a refusal that rankled the president.\n\nIn his speech on Thursday, Mr. Tillerson hinted at a possible reason for his non-denial.\n\n\u201cNever lose sight of your most valuable asset, the most valuable asset you possess: your personal integrity,\u201d Mr. Tillerson said. He added: \u201cOnly you can relinquish it or allow it to be compromised. Once you\u2019ve done so, it is very very hard to regain it. So guard it as the most precious thing you possess.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Tillerson had frequently dismissed reports that his department was experiencing an exodus of top diplomatic talent \u2014 even though the State Department\u2019s personnel office issued data demonstrating that hundreds of officials were fleeing.\n\nThe most puzzling part of Mr. Tillerson\u2019s time at the State Department was the organizational chaos that defined his tenure.\n\nAs a former chief executive of Exxon Mobil, Mr. Tillerson\u2019s management chops were supposed to be his chief calling card. But he failed to get even half of his leadership team in place, a first in American history.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThose who did get top jobs were not allowed to make even small decisions without Mr. Tillerson\u2019s approval, leading to paralysis. In just one example, the State Department has yet to spend any of the $120 million that Congress allocated to counter Russia\u2019s election meddling.\n\nHe presided over a reorganization effort that spent millions of dollars on outside consultants and thousands of hours of staff consultations. At the end, however, the suggested changes were almost exactly the same as those given to him by managers on his first day in office. In his final weeks in office, Mr. Tillerson stopped mentioning the reorganization that he had once identified as his top priority.\n\nSince his firing, Mr. Tillerson has focused on ensuring a smooth transition, ordering a slew of memorandums by staff and waiting for a personal meeting with Mr. Pompeo.\n\nDespite his unpopularity with diplomats, Mr. Tillerson was credited by many observers with being a voice of moderation in an administration that has presided over deteriorating relations in almost every corner of the world.\n\n\u201cHis support for the Paris climate accord and the Iran nuclear deal, and his conception of having talks about talks with North Korea, I thought all of those were correct,\u201d said R. Nicholas Burns, a former career foreign service officer who was once Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice\u2019s right-hand man. \u201cBut he was a disastrous manager, and morale at the department plummeted.\u201d\n\n\u201cSo it\u2019s a complicated epitaph,\u201d Mr. Burns said.", "title": "Tillerson Says Goodbye to \u2018a Very Mean-Spirited Town\u2019", "authors": ["Gardiner Harris"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "In a news conference with Moussa Faki Mahamat, chairman of the African Union Commission, the men were asked by a reporter from the China Global Television Network about reports that Mr. Trump described Africa as filled with \u201cshithole countries,\u201d a remark the reporter said \u201cAfrica is still digesting.\u201d\n\nWearing the tight smile he used on a recent tour of Latin America, where he was asked to respond to similarly insulting remarks from Mr. Trump, or in Europe, where his reception was as chilly as the wintry weather, Mr. Tillerson said that relations between the United States and Africa remain strong.\n\n\u201cThe United States commitment to Africa is quite clear in terms of the importance we place on the relationship,\u201d he said.\n\nFor his part, Mr. Faki said, \u201cI believe this incident is of the past, and with the visit of Secretary of State Tillerson, and the evidence of the relations between Africa and the United States is personified through his visit.\u201d\n\nTo round out the global distancing that friendly nations are doing with the Trump administration, representatives from 11 countries \u2014 including Japan, Canada and Australia, close American allies \u2014 signed a trade pact in Santiago, Chile, on Thursday that President Trump had rejected in his first days in office.\n\nYet again Mr. Tillerson warned Thursday against Chinese investment. But with the Trump administration slashing assistance programs in Africa just as the Chinese are ramping up investments, he got as prickly a response in Ethiopia to his China-bashing as he had in South America.\n\nPhoto\n\nChina has invested $15 billion in Ethiopia in recent years compared to about $550 million by the United States. Besides the African Union\u2019s headquarters, China has built a light-rail system, a vast ring road and a host of other structures in Addis Ababa.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI think Africans are mature enough to engage in partnerships of their own volition,\u201d Mr. Faki said.\n\nMr. Tillerson also got trolled by Russian officials.\n\nSergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, was in Ethiopia at the same time as Mr. Tillerson and even stayed at the same hotel. The Russians insisted on social media that they had asked for a meeting between the two but had been rebuffed.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
