View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA taunting post on the Facebook page of the Russian Embassy in Washington said such a meeting \u201cwould be a great opportunity to discuss a range of accumulated issues on regional and global agenda not through the press but directly.\u201d\n\nIn a news conference, Mr. Tillerson dismissed the Russian taunts as \u201csilly,\u201d saying he had met with Mr. Lavrov more times than he could remember and that the two knew each other\u2019s phone numbers.\n\nMr. Tillerson\u2019s trip to Africa comes as the chaos in the administration appears to be increasing and his own place in it remains uncertain. Gary D. Cohn, the president\u2019s chief economic adviser, announced his resignation while Mr. Tillerson was in the air. And just after he landed in Ethiopia, Jared Kushner, the president\u2019s son-in-law and top adviser, was in Mexico for meetings with its president and foreign minister \u2014 meetings that excluded the American ambassador \u2014 Roberta S. Jacobson, who plans to resign in May.\n\nMr. Tillerson could hardly complain about her exclusion \u2014 since he has often refused to include ambassadors in his own meetings with top foreign officials. But Mr. Kushner\u2019s continued efforts to serve as the administration\u2019s intermediary in crucial foreign relations have undercut Mr. Tillerson\u2019s authority.\n\nMr. Tillerson is out of Washington just as South Korean officials fly in to brief their American counterparts about their talks with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un. The administration\u2019s pressure campaign against North Korea is one of Mr. Tillerson\u2019s signature efforts, something he mentions all the time.\n\nBut fence-mending was needed in Africa, where Mr. Tillerson is making a five-nation tour. He arrived in Ethiopia just as this country has plunged into political turmoil. A police state with a democratic veneer, Ethiopia is buffeted by violent clashes in diverse ethnic enclaves where activists are demanding political and economic reform. The government recently declared a state of emergency.\n\nAfter his meetings at the African Union, Mr. Tillerson rode by motorcade across town to meet Hailemariam Desalegn, Ethiopia\u2019s prime minister, and Workneh Gebeyehu, the foreign minister.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Desalegn announced weeks ago that he would resign, although he has remained in power while a successor is chosen.\n\nIn a news conference with Mr. Gebeyehu, Mr. Tillerson said that while North Korea had sent \u201cpotentially positive signals\u201d in talks with Seoul, Washington and Pyongyang remained \u201ca long ways from negotiations.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe first step is to have some kind of talks about talks,\u201d Mr. Tillerson said.", "title": "Tillerson, in Africa, Dodges Questions on Vulgarity and Trolling", "authors": ["Gardiner Harris"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cTillerson loathed by State Dept diplomats, but balanced & sensible in most areas of foreign policy,\u201d Ian Bremmer, president of the Eurasia Group, a political risk consultancy, said in a Twitter message. \u201cPompeo dramatically more hawkish on N Korea and Iran. Challenging day for the planet.\u201d\n\nDespite the way the announcement was handled, many conservatives viewed Mr. Pompeo\u2019s ascendance as an enormous opportunity.\n\n\u201cTillerson firing may open the floodgates for more conservatives to enter the admin,\u201d Jordan Schachtel, national security correspondent for The Conservative Review, wrote on Twitter. \u201cPeace Through Strength is making its grand return.\u201d\n\nHuman rights advocates, while never enamored with Mr. Tillerson, expressed alarm at Mr. Pompeo\u2019s elevation. They were even more alarmed that Mr. Pompeo\u2019s deputy at the C.I.A., Gina Haspel, had been named to replace him, given her role in coercive interrogations of terrorism suspects in the years after the Sept. 11 attacks.\n\nThe American Civil Liberties Union called Ms. Haspel the \u201ccentral figure in one of the most illegal and shameful chapters in modern American history.\u201d\n\nVincent Warren, the executive director of the Center for Constitutional Rights, said in a statement that \u201cGina Haspel should be prosecuted, not promoted.\u201d\n\nA conspicuous exception to the surprise was the reaction of the United States ambassador to the United Nations, Nikki R. Haley, whose antipathy for Mr. Tillerson had been an open secret. Foreign Policy magazine reported last week that she had not even hung the official portrait of Mr. Tillerson in the lobby of the United States Mission to the United Nations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWithout mentioning Mr. Tillerson by name, she posted an enthusiastic message on Twitter moments after Mr. Trump\u2019s announcement:\n\nThere was no immediate official reaction in Asia, partly because of the timing of Mr. Trump\u2019s announcement \u2014 late evening in China, Japan and the Korean Peninsula, where news of his intended meeting with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, is still sinking in.\n\nIn Iran, the official Islamic Republic News Agency\u2019s website posted an unflattering photo of Mr. Pompeo, who has made clear he considers the Tehran government more of a threat than Mr. Tillerson did.\n\nIn Europe, where disdain for the Trump administration is widespread, Enrico Letta, a former Italian prime minister, said of Mr. Tillerson\u2019s dismissal on Twitter: \u201cThis will make many laugh even more, as usually happens when one speaks of Trump. For me, he scares me more and more.\u201d\n\nMichael Roth, Germany\u2019s deputy foreign minister, tweeted: \u201cThe dismissal of Rex Tillerson does not help.\u201d\n\nThe firing was announced only hours after Mr. Tillerson delivered the administration\u2019s strongest and clearest statement to date on the March 4 poisoning of a Russian former spy in Salisbury, England, with a nerve agent.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve become extremely concerned about Russia,\u201d Mr. Tillerson told reporters while flying from Nigeria to Cape Verde, before returning to the United States. \u201cWe spent most of last year investing a lot into attempts to work together, to solve problems, to address differences. And quite frankly, after a year, we didn\u2019t get very far. Instead what we\u2019ve seen is a pivot on their part to be more aggressive.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Mr. Trump has avoided such criticism of Russia.\n\n\u201cToday Tillerson is fired as Secretary of State. While friction with Trump was months-old, the abrupt timing here is suspect,\u201d Beau Willimon, the creator of the television series \u201cHouse of Cards,\u201d said on Twitter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Russia, a Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, Maria Zakharova, expressed sarcasm about Mr. Tillerson\u2019s dismissal.\n\n\u201cHave they started blaming Russia yet for the Washington staff changes?\u201d she said.\n\nHowever, White House officials said the decision to fire Mr. Tillerson had been made earlier: The White House chief of staff, John Kelly, tried to call Mr. Tillerson on Friday and Saturday, apparently to warn him that if he did not step down, he would be dismissed.\n\nBill Kristol, a conservative commentator, questioned the style of the dismissal. \u201cHas Trump ever had the nerve to fire someone face to face?\u201d he asked on Twitter, noting that the former F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, learned that he was out of a job in May 2017, while on a trip to Los Angeles.\n\nJack Posobiec, a right-wing provocateur with a track record for disseminating false information, was one of a few prominent Trump supporters who embraced the decision.\n\n\u201cTillerson didn\u2019t want to name Jerusalem Israel\u2019s capital, wanted to stay in Paris climate agreement, and often undermined the President publicly and insulted him privately\u201d Mr. Posobiec said. \u201cNo surprise why this guy was fired.\u201d", "title": "Tillerson\u2019s Firing Had Been Expected, but It Still Stunned Observers", "authors": ["Rick Gladstone"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Tillerson has made safety a focus of his tenure, saying in nearly every speech to employees that he considers safety not just a policy but a value.\n\nThe bombing of the embassy here \u2014 and, on the same day, one in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania \u2014 showed that terrorist groups could target American facilities all over the world, even in countries deemed relatively secure.\n\n\u201cWe realized that our people weren\u2019t safe anywhere,\u201d said Bill A. Miller, who was acting assistant secretary for diplomatic security until last year.\n\nThe State Department now has 45,000 security employees, representing more than half of the department\u2019s 75,000 employees, Mr. Miller said. The security bureau\u2019s budget is more than $5.8 billion, with security construction costs adding another roughly $1.5 billion annually.\n\nMichael Evanoff, the current assistant secretary of state for diplomatic security, said Mr. Tillerson had never suggested he would cut the department\u2019s security budget. \u201cAt no time has he ever said to me he wants D.S. to look at cutting,\u201d Mr. Evanoff said, referring to the security bureau. \u201cHe\u2019s always been very supportive.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWithout cuts to the department\u2019s ballooning security expenses, Mr. Tillerson would need to look elsewhere.\n\nThe other major program that has grown since the 1990s is the President\u2019s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, known as Pepfar, which was begun in 2003. Along with a malaria program, Pepfar costs about $8 billion and has been widely credited with treating much of the African continent. In Kenya alone, the program costs about $1 billion and delivers antiretroviral drugs to 1.1 million people.\n\nMr. Tillerson, who has proposed some cuts to Pepfar, was due to visit an H.I.V./AIDS clinic on Saturday where a handful of young women were going to explain how vital the program is, but the visit was canceled because he was sick. In interviews, the women said they were deeply concerned about the proposed cutbacks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Wednesday, a group of more than 200 H.I.V. researchers, including Fran\u00e7oise Barr\u00e9-Sinoussi, a Nobel laureate who helped discover the H.I.V. virus, sent an open letter to the Trump administration denouncing the proposed cuts. Both Republican and Democratic lawmakers on Capitol Hill have vowed to preserve Pepfar\u2019s funding.\n\nSteve Goldstein, the under secretary for public diplomacy, said in an interview on Sunday that there were other places to cut the department\u2019s budget besides security programs and funding for H.I.V./AIDS programs. Mr. Tillerson has proposed cuts to a broad range of aid efforts, and has pushed out hundreds of experienced diplomats.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s easy to take two or three programs and add them up and say this is where the cuts are, but that\u2019s not really the fair way of looking at this,\u201d Mr. Goldstein said.\n\nBut the vast expansion of funding for security and anti-AIDS efforts since the last time the department had a budget similar to what Mr. Tillerson has proposed suggests that, if he cannot cut them, he then must make significant cuts in diplomatic staff, which even before Mr. Tillerson\u2019s tenure had been steadily shrinking since 2010, said Patrick Kennedy, the under secretary of state for management in two previous administration.\n\n\u201cIf Secretary Tillerson\u2019s budget cutting continues, the number of State Department people overseas will be significantly reduced,\u201d Mr. Kennedy said. \u201cAnd the department will end up becoming a landlord for other U.S. government agencies abroad rather than the diplomatic service this country needs.\u201d", "title": "Tillerson\u2019s Nairobi Visit Highlights Proposed Spending Cuts", "authors": ["Gardiner Harris"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "BRUSSELS \u2014 The operatic ouster of Rex Tillerson leaves a State Department angry and adrift, and a world even more confused about the management and direction of American foreign policy, hoping but not expecting that the change leads to greater coherence in Washington.\n\nThe angst is being felt especially acutely among European leaders. With the back-to-back resignation of Gary Cohn, Mr. Trump\u2019s top economic adviser, and the firing of Mr. Tillerson they fear the period of \u201cbenign neglect\u201d they have experienced so far from Mr. Trump is over.\n\nMr. Tillerson was roundly criticized by a much-demoralized diplomatic corps, accused of gutting budgets and staffing levels in a reflection of what many see as a long, downward trajectory of the State Department\u2019s influence.\n\nBut for allies, in particular, he was also seen as \u201cone of the grown-ups\u201d and a relative voice of reason, even comfort, in comparison with his boss\u2019s brash impulsiveness.", "title": "Tillerson\u2019s Ouster Has Allies Hoping for Coherence, but Fearing the Worst", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. \u2014 After the Mets\u2019 spring training game on Tuesday afternoon, outfielder Tim Tebow was summoned into the office of the new manager, Mickey Callaway. With the door shut, team officials informed Tebow, the most famous person in the organization, that his try at a baseball comeback would be moved from major league to minor league spring training.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not like it\u2019s a shock,\u201d Tebow said, laughing.\n\nTebow, 30, won the 2007 Heisman Trophy as the University of Florida\u2019s quarterback, but he returned to baseball in 2016 after not playing since high school. He had a taste of major league spring training games last year, and his improvement last year earned him an invitation to major league camp this year. With a swing he changed in the off-season, he still notched just one hit in 18 at-bats this spring. He was also bothered by an ankle sprain he sustained in late February when he tripped on a sprinkler head in the outfield at the Mets\u2019 spring training complex.\n\n\u201cUnfortunately, I couldn\u2019t do as much as I wanted to with my ankle, which is kind of disappointing,\u201d he said. \u201cBut I got to put in a lot of good work and I feel like I\u2019m improving.\u201d\n\nTebow played in seven spring games, but all as a designated hitter and saw no time in the field. Following a downswing of weight gain and OxyContin abuse, he has re-emerged as an in-demand producer.\n\nRecent credits include Sam Smith\u2019s emotive \u201cPray\u201d and collaborations with the rapper Ski Mask the Slump God. Most notably, he was a producer of four songs on Justin Timberlake\u2019s new album, \u201cMan of the Woods,\u201d including the singles \u201cFilthy\u201d and \u201cSay Something.\u201d\n\n\u201cI try to find all the youth,\u201d Timbaland said. \u201cThey crazy, but I love it. I\u2019m not 21, so I\u2019m like, God, they got so much energy. I stay in shape so I can keep up with them.\u201d\n\nTimbaland rose to prominence producing for 1990s R&B stars including Aaliyah and Ginuwine, and forays into hip-hop and pop cemented his legacy as a key architect of mainstream music over the last 20 years. More ringmaster than wordsmith, he released three studio albums as part of the duo Timbaland & Magoo, and three more as a solo artist, most recently in 2009.\n\nPhoto\n\nEven today, Timbaland\u2019s sonic signatures \u2014 stuttering percussion, menacing minor key synths and roboticized ad-libs \u2014 have aged elegantly. He discovered his trademark Middle Eastern inflections while exploring record shops in London. \u201cI heard the music and the singing and I was like, \u2018You hear that vibrato?\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cThe melodies touched my soul. It\u2019s not meant to be understood language-wise, but it\u2019s what you feel.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe divulged another influence after unearthing a $300 shirt for Nine Inch Nails\u2019 1989 \u201cPretty Hate Machine\u201d album. \u201cHis sound was so unique and so different,\u201d he said of Trent Reznor, the band\u2019s frontman and an industrial rock producer. \u201cBesides me and Pharrell, he was the guy to watch. Now, because of computers, you can manipulate so many different kinds of sounds. Back then, you had to really work to do it, and Trent was that dude.\u201d\n\nAfter nearly an hour of meandering down memory lane, and a quick spin through a Nick Atkins art show in another area of the boutique, Timbaland got down to business. He settled on a shirt for Jodeci\u2019s 1993\u2019s \u201cDiary of a Mad Band\u201d album, which had personal significance. Jodeci, a platinum-selling R&B group, had mentored him when he was in his early 20s, while he was part of a collective known as Swing Mob.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. But as the European Union prepares to introduce comprehensive new data protection regulation in May, European regulators have been stepping up investigations into tech industry data practices.\n\nMARCH 2011\n\nThe Federal Trade Commission for the first time requires a company to institute a comprehensive program to protect consumer data privacy\n\nGoogle reaches a settlement with the F.T.C., which charged the company with using deceptive tactics and violating its own privacy promises to consumers. Google had enrolled Gmail users in its social network, Buzz, without effective ways for them to opt out of the service or limit the sharing of their personal details, the agency said.\n\nNOVEMBER 2011\n\nThe F.T.C. goes after Facebook for exposing users\u2019 information\n\nFacebook agrees to settle charges by the F.T.C. that it deceived users by telling them that they could keep their profile information private and then repeatedly allowing it to be shared and made public.\n\nAUGUST 2012\n\nThe F.T.C. fines Google $22.5 million for Safari privacy violations\n\nGoogle agrees to pay $22.5 million to settle F.T.C. charges that the company misled people who used Apple\u2019s Safari browser by placing advertiser tracking codes, called cookies, on their computers after Google told them that they would be opted out of such tracking. But her true fascination is \u2014 everything.\n\n\u201cTheir death burst my bubble, \u2018Oh the world is not as clean as I thought it was or as simple,\u2019\u201d she said. I am still writing.\u201d", "title": "Times Scholarship Winners Excelled Through Adversity", "authors": ["Sarah Maslin Nir"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "In the days following the Grammy Awards in January, as the president of the Recording Academy, Neil Portnow, came under fire for saying that women in music should \u201cstep up\u201d to advance their careers, the academy announced the formation of a task force to examine its practices \u2014 but gave no details about who would run it, or what exactly it would do.\n\nOn Tuesday, the academy, which presents the Grammys, announced that Tina Tchen, who served as Michelle Obama\u2019s chief of staff, would be the chairwoman of the task force, and said that the effort would \u201cidentify the various barriers and unconscious biases faced by underrepresented communities throughout the music industry and, specifically, across Recording Academy operations and policies.\u201d\n\nA study released before the Grammys found that, in five top categories over the last six years, only 9 percent of nominees were women. Looking at the industry more broadly, the study, conducted by the University of Southern California\u2019s Annenberg Inclusion Initiative, found that for the most popular songs each year, women made up 22 percent of the performers, 12 percent of songwriters and just 2 percent of producers.\n\n\u201cThe music industry faces numerous challenges \u2014 from combating long-held biases to making sure women are represented and respected within the community,\u201d Ms. Tchen said in a statement. \u201cThis task force is an important initial step by the Recording Academy to demonstrate its commitment to tackling these challenges in a comprehensive way.\u201d", "title": "Time\u2019s Up Co-Founder Will Head Recording Academy Task Force on Diversity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I want to buy a lightweight laptop, but I need to use CDs and DVDs, which none of these models have anymore. Is there any way to still use discs with these tiny computers?\n\nA. When it comes to modern laptop design, many manufacturers have tossed disc drives onto the same pile with floppy drives, Ethernet jacks and other technology considered obsolete \u2014 thanks to cloud servers and wireless networks that have taken over a laptop\u2019s data storage and internet connection needs. The quest for smaller, lighter laptops with maximum space on the inside for a rechargeable battery has also pushed out these once-standard computer components.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nStill, as with adding back ports to these streamlined laptops, you can get external hardware to do the job. The ports on some newer laptop models may be limited to USB-C plugs only, so make sure you know what type of connectors work with the laptop you plan to buy. (If your preferred disc drive model does not have a connector that matches your laptop, you can get an adapter.)\n\nPhoto\n\nMajor hardware makers, including Apple and Dell, sell their own external disc drives designed to work with their laptops, but you can likely find less expensive hardware from other manufacturers. Some add-on drives can be a little too cheap, however, so be sure to read the reviews before buying.\n\nWirecutter, a product recommendation site owned by The New York Times, tested a variety of external disc drives and picked a $25 portable CD/DVD burner made by LG Electronics (the LG GP65NB60 model) as its top choice. For those who want Blu-ray disc compatibility along with CD and DVD playback and recording, the site recommends the Pioneer BDR-XD05B, which sells for around $90.", "title": "Tiny Laptop? Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Every once in a while, tucked into the stream of speedily made garments rushed into stores, designs with shockingly bad taste stand out: a shirt comparing women to dogs at Topman, symbols of the Holocaust on a top at Zara, a slogan that trivializes sexual consent on a piece at Forever 21, or words like \u201cslave\u201d and \u201cslut\u201d used as decorative details on T-shirts at ASOS and Missguided.\n\nBrands, even as they offer mea culpas, rarely explain how such blunders come to pass. But problematic designs seem to repeatedly slip past layers of buyers, designers, stylists, marketers and managers before being caught by consumers.\n\nRetail experts blame a heated competitive environment, where companies, many of them based in Europe, are spread thin trying to cater to a global customer base that is easily bored, is extremely demanding and can buy almost anything via e-commerce. Many brands develop a cavalier attitude: Churn out products now, ask forgiveness later.\n\nThe problem is not limited to fashion. On Monday, Heineken pulled a series of commercials for light beer with the tagline \u201csometimes, lighter is better,\u201d after an ad sparked criticism for being racist.", "title": "To Avoid More Racist Hoodies, Retailers Seek Diversity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "LAHORE, Pakistan \u2014 On Jan. 13, the police in Karachi, Pakistan, claimed to have killed four militants suspected of having links to the Islamic State. Rao Anwar, the officer leading the operation, said that the men had opened fire on the police and were killed in the gunfight.\n\nPictures of the dead circulated on social media and were broadcast on Pakistani television networks. Family members watching television news recognized one of the dead: Naqeebullah Mehsud, 27, from Waziristan, in the Federally Administered Tribal Areas on the border with Afghanistan. He had been arrested by the police 10 days earlier.\n\nMr. Mehsud, who is survived by his wife, a son and two daughters, had worked various jobs in the city and recently decided to set up a clothing store with help from his brother. He was also an aspiring fashion model, posing rakishly in bright clothes and sporting a manicured beard in photographs on his Facebook page.\n\nImage Naqeebullah Mehsud was an aspiring fashion model. Credit Agence France-Presse \u2014 Getty Images\n\nOn that night in January, a photograph of Mr. Mehsud\u2019s bloodied corpse in a bare room appeared on my Facebook feed. I shivered with a mixture of dread, anger and hopelessness. He wasn\u2019t very different from me: a young Pashtun man who had escaped the pitiless war consuming our home in Waziristan, a poor, isolated place that became an epicenter of the so-called war on terrorism and would be referred to as \u201cthe most dangerous place in the world.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | To Be Young and Pashtun in Pakistan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "But there has been limited past scientific scrutiny of the impacts of grunting. A 2014 study of college tennis players determined that grunting could indeed increase the power of players\u2019 groundstrokes and serves. And a study from 2010 found that such sounds can be distracting for others. In that study, participants watched videos of a tennis player striking the ball while a loud, grunt-like yell played or did not. The viewers pressed keys to indicate their snap judgments about which side of the court, right or left, the ball was heading toward. When the stroke coincided with the noise, the viewers were noticeably slower and more inaccurate in their picks.\n\nBut those studies could not determine whether the usefulness of grunting was confined only to tennis or how the ballistic squawks were affecting onlookers and opponents. Were the screams masking the sound of the racket striking the ball, making it difficult for people to judge the right trajectories? Or were the sounds more directly distracting people, drawing their attention away from the onrushing ball and befuddling their reactions?\n\nTo learn more, some of the same scientists decided, for the new experiment, which was published last month in PLOS One, to look closely at mixed martial arts and grunting.\n\nThey chose that sport for several reasons, the first being that, like tennis, it demands sudden, explosive movements, meaning punches and kicks, to which grunting conceivably could add power.\n\nPerhaps even more important, martial arts moves do not involve inherent noise, unlike the ping of a tennis racket meeting a ball. So if an onlooker proved to be worse at judging a fast-approaching kick when someone grunted, it would be because the yell had directly confused the watcher, not because it had masked some other noise.", "title": "To Boost Sports Performance (and Annoy Your Opponents), Grunt", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Many of the electric shock devices used by law enforcement are meant to be out of sight, but every once in a while comes a reminder that their use is widespread.\n\nThis time, it happened in Fort Worth. A conviction there was overturned last month because the judge had ordered the defendant to be electrically shocked by a device on his ankle three times during his trial, court documents show.\n\nThese devices have been referred to as stun belts, shock belts or stun cuffs. Some of the devices, which are used to restrain inmates, are strapped to the ankle and others around the torso. When triggered, the shock is comparable to that of a Taser; it is usually enough to knock a person to the ground, sometimes prompting involuntary defecation or urination.\n\nSupporters of the devices say they deter inmates from attempting violence or escape. Ideally, the devices are strapped on, the inmates behave and no jolts are needed.", "title": "To Control Inmates, Some Counties Try the Threat of Electric Shock", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 It looks as if President Trump is going to get his military parade after all. The last time our forces paraded across Washington was in 1991, to hail our triumph in the Gulf war. Unfortunately, there hasn\u2019t been much to celebrate in our foreign policy since \u2014 unless you count the 15-year anniversary, on Tuesday, of the start of the Iraq war.\n\nI don\u2019t.\n\nAs a veteran of Afghanistan, I wish this weren\u2019t the case. No patriot wants to see us fail. But America\u2019s approach to the world just isn\u2019t working to make us safer and more prosperous. And President Trump isn\u2019t helping. We need a more effective and realistic foreign policy.\n\nThe Iraq war is just the worst in a string of failures. They range from that destructive regime-change mission in Iraq and a later such effort in Libya to the ill-fated nation-building project in Afghanistan, and all the way back to the dangerous enlargement of NATO in the 1990s and 2000s to include countries on Russia\u2019s doorstep. In the process, nearly 7,000 American troops have been killed and tens of thousands wounded, and we\u2019ve spent trillions of dollars \u2014 all while failing to achieve our strategic objectives.\n\nUnderlying all of these failures is the view, endorsed by both parties, that we need an active military presence around the globe to shape what happens almost everywhere. But it doesn\u2019t matter how well funded our Pentagon, how brave our troops or how well intentioned our diplomats are. So long as we keep tinkering with this flawed operating system, we will continue to fail.", "title": "Opinion | To Defend America, Don\u2019t Overreach", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Both companies charged their fees, whether we made or lost money.\n\nAs the contest took off we enjoyed engaging conversations with our new friends at the bank, who educated us about investing, and their perks included free access to experts. When we had our wills and trust created, for example, the bank\u2019s attorney vetted the documents.\n\nAt the robo-adviser, on the other hand, there seemed to be no one who could answer a question. After our trust was created, it took days for us to get an email reply that said there was no way to move our account into the trust.\n\nIn about a year it was time for our beauty contest to hit the runway. The folks at the bank pulled out spreadsheets showing us how they outperformed various indexes, none of which we recognized \u2014 and all well below the returns of the Dow or S&P.\n\nThe results should not have surprised us. More than 80 percent of actively managed funds fail to perform as well as the market, according to a recent analysis, and it was going to be unlikely that a wealth manager would do better.\n\nThe algorithm outperformed the bank by about 50 percent, despite its maddening dearth of customer service.\n\nWith the robot\u2019s superior bottom line it would appear the results of our contest were cut and dry, but we were torn. We had a rapport with the bank, we trusted them, and they seemed to understand our needs.\n\nThat trust and personal touch was more important than just returns, and we were not alone feeling this way. Research by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology\u2019s AgeLab shows that when working with their financial advisers, investors value personalization over expertise.", "title": "To Find the Right Financial Adviser, \u2018Do a Beauty Contest\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "But it had not been studied in preschool age children, and there was reason to believe that they might be even more sensitive.\n\n\u201cWe were trying to simulate what would go on at home when you put a child to bed,\u201d said Dr. Monique LeBourgeois, an associate professor of integrative physiology at the University of Colorado, Boulder, and the director of the sleep and development lab; she was the senior author on the study. A child who is resisting being put to bed may come out of the dark bedroom and approach the parents in rooms where lights are on, she said, and \u201cthey get blasted with light. Just even a short exposure of bright light may suppress melatonin and shut down that sleep-promoting effect.\u201d\n\nThe average bedtime for the children in the study was 8:27 p.m., and in their dim-light \u201ccaves,\u201d with no bright light to interfere, the researchers found that the children began secreting melatonin, on average, at 7:47 p.m., marking the beginning of their \u201cbiological night.\u201d\n\nAnd then the next night they played on the light tables. \u201cWe found that the bright light exposure suppressed melatonin by almost 90 percent, and the effects persisted even after the kids returned to dim light,\u201d Dr. Akacem said. Fifty minutes after the light was gone, most of the children were still not back to 50 percent of the melatonin levels seen the day before.\n\nMelatonin secretion is usually low during the day, and then rises in the evening, causing the body clock to prepare for sleep. The melatonin comes from the pineal gland, located between the two hemispheres of the brain, which is neurologically connected to body clock central, the suprachiasmatic nucleus in the hypothalamus, which in turn is influenced by how much light gets through to the retina.", "title": "To Help Children Sleep, Go Dark", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Samsung\u2019s aim is for people to someday conduct their digital lives with equal ease from a fridge, a phone, a television or a car. Fed by data about you in the cloud \u2014 and with the help of a virtual assistant \u2014 all of the machines will operate in perfect synchrony to enable a maximally efficient domestic life.\n\nBosch is taking a more conservative approach. Its smart dishwashers, ovens and coffee machines, which range in price from about $1,300 to $3,100, look just like their disconnected counterparts and mostly use their internet connections for remote diagnostics. If a problem occurs, the appliance can automatically send an error code to Bosch\u2019s customer service team, which can help determine whether you should fix the problem yourself or schedule a repair.\n\n\u201cWhenever we talk to our customers, we get the feedback that they really appreciate technology when it makes their life simple, but they don\u2019t want to bother with additional complexity,\u201d said Anja Prescher, Bosch\u2019s director of brand marketing.\n\nWhirlpool emphasizes the use of smartphones as kitchen companions. The company last year acquired Yummly, a recipe site that developed an app for scanning items in a refrigerator or pantry. The app then comes up with suggestions for what to cook and walks the user through recipes.\n\nFor now, Amazon and Google are having some of the most notable successes in the kitchen, even though their devices are not specific to that room. Many people use Amazon\u2019s Echo speaker or Google Home, both of which are embedded with the companies\u2019 smart virtual assistants, for setting kitchen timers or looking up recipes.\n\nTo take advantage of the frequency with which these devices end up in kitchens, the companies are expanding on those products with voice-controlled smart screens. Last year, Amazon debuted Echo Show, which can load step-by-step recipes on the screen. Google this year unveiled Smart Display, a software system that it shares with manufacturers like Lenovo, which will release smart screens this year that feature Google Assistant and can run apps and play recipe videos.\n\nBut those devices have also raised privacy questions. The Amazon and Google screens constantly listen for voice commands, and they include cameras for placing video calls. Amazon and Google said they offer the ability to mute the microphones and turn the cameras off.", "title": "To Invade Homes, Tech Is Trying to Get in Your Kitchen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Canty, 52, started noticing Mr. Pirog, now 38, around town a few years ago, and inspiration began to flow upstream, back across the generations. \u201cHe was playing really wildly different things in every situation, so I couldn\u2019t quite understand who he was as a guitar player,\u201d Mr. Canty said. But the disorientation converted swiftly into fascination. \u201cI was attracted to that.\u201d\n\nMr. Lally, 54, had recently moved back to Washington from Italy, and the old confreres were looking to form a group. Mr. Canty suggested they give Mr. Pirog a shot; the trio began jamming at Mr. Canty\u2019s rehearsal space, and clicked immediately. The original idea was to play music Mr. Lally had written, but soon the elder musicians found themselves turning to Mr. Pirog for creative fuel. \u201cSeeing the kind of guitar player Anthony was didn\u2019t really make me want to play my music,\u201d Mr. Lally said of their first jam session, in fall 2016.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Pirog began bringing in tangled melodies and odd-metered patterns, and flinging them at the band at high speeds. \u201cIt\u2019s funny because Anthony was asking things of us that Fugazi asked of us, honestly,\u201d Mr. Canty said. \u201cIt feels like catching baseballs in a batting cage.\u201d\n\nThe record maintains the raw vibe of those early sessions: It was captured on basic equipment, the guitar and bass recorded straight from their amps, in Mr. Canty\u2019s rehearsal space above a Washington club.\n\nFugazi was never a band about virtuosity, exactly, but it wasn\u2019t opposed to the principle. Started in 1986, the quartet flew a flag of conviction in an insouciant era: First-generation indie rock was on the up, with bands like Dinosaur Jr. and Sonic Youth proposing abstention as rebellion. But Fugazi went for something direct and throttling; it played around with Jamaican dub, the loose-limbed punk coming from California, and drops of minimalism, arriving at a dark, stony, hard-bitten sound. Unlike past iterations of punk, the currency was its heft, not its speed.\n\nThe same could be said of \u201cThe Messthetics,\u201d though Mr. Pirog\u2019s playing here introduces something else. It can feel both misty and assertive, partly because of the way his effects pedals create something hot and threatening, as if he\u2019s immolating his own notes as soon as they arrive. The new album begins with \u201cMythomania,\u201d centered on a classic, low-boil bass line from Mr. Lally, cutting and quaking between two notes. Mr. Pirog plays snarled, overlapping guitar lines that seem to be shining through warped glass. Sometimes, he uses a pedal to play back his lines in reverse.\n\nThe track never rises into guitar heroics; there\u2019s a lot of heady downtime, the groove getting thicker, pulling you toward a foreboding stupor. Mr. Pirog offers a short guitar solo at the end, some unlikely mixture of John McLaughlin\u2019s Carnatic jazz fusion and Dick Dale\u2019s surf music, heightening the suspense but forgoing any big payoff.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLater on the album, after a couple of fast, mathy burners, Mr. Pirog drops things down for \u201cYour Own World\u201d and \u201cThe Inner Ocean.\u201d Both are slow and open-ended, their irresolution suggesting a cinematic expanse.\n\nWhether speeding and distorted or slow and ethereal, the Messthetics have a remarkable cohesion. And they see this as more than an intergenerational experiment; the band is already writing tunes for a second album.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s exciting to me because I know I can play with a certain intensity every night, and not second guess it or worry whether people will come with me,\u201d Mr. Pirog said. In a career that\u2019s quickly picking up steam, \u201cI want this to be the priority.\u201d", "title": "To Make the Messthetics, Mix a Reunion With One Virtuosic Newcomer", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Many of them are actually good. Quite good. And Lunardi has noticed.\n\n\u201cKnow and respect quite a few of them, and have tried to make myself available over the years,\u201d Lunardi wrote in an email. \u201cMany are super smart, smarter than I\u2019ve ever been, in terms of the analytics.\u201d\n\nIt might not come as a shock, then, that Bracket Matrix \u2014 using its own formula for accuracy based on teams picked correctly, teams seeded correctly, and teams predicted within one spot of their seed line \u2014 had Lunardi (with his 222,000 Twitter followers and almost round-the-clock ESPN appearances) ranked 75th this year among all the bracketologists on Phan\u2019s leaderboard.\n\nAnd over the course of the last five years, Lunardi\u2019s aggregate accuracy is not even in the top 35, making him the equivalent of a No. 9 seed in any bracket among bracketologists.\n\nThe top seed belongs to a man named Dave Ommen, who works in public relations for a hospital in southern Indiana, and, in his spare time, runs a site called Bracketville that received about 3,000 visitors a night last week.\n\nIn 2008, after getting tired of debating automatic bids and at-large selections with his friends, he started Bracketville. There is nothing amateur about his brackets, which also appear online at NBC Sports. This year, Ommen chose all but one team in the field correctly, with almost the full bracket (64 teams) seeded within one spot of the actual results. Yet this was still only good enough to tie for ninth on Bracket Matrix in 2018.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe. And LeBron vs. the Warriors. Go behind the N.B.A.\u2019s curtain with the league\u2019s foremost expert in a new basketball newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe last few years, maybe things have broken in the right way for me,\u201d said Ommen, 47. \u201cBut there\u2019s a lot of people who are equally knowledgeable, or more so, who have done this for just as long as I have.\u201d\n\nThe growth in interest in bracketology has picked up in recent years. Sixty prognosticators have joined the Bracket Matrix since 2015, a fact that has stunned Phan, who said he did not expect his website to maintain enough interest to last past its first season.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFew groups embody the young fan\u2019s interest in the hobby more than Delphi Bracketology, a club at Delphi Community High School, in Delphi, Ind., whose membership includes 10 students and three faculty members who meet between 7:15 a.m. and 8 a.m. on Thursday mornings throughout the fall and winter.\n\nOver breakfast, they break down the bracket for months before it is released.\n\n\u201cYou have to think outside the box, you have to analyze data, you have to make comparisons, and you have to have some debate skills,\u201d said Brian Tonsoni, the social studies teacher and basketball coach who founded the club in 2016. \u201cThey don\u2019t even know they\u2019re learning all that. They just think they\u2019re talking about Gonzaga and Wichita State and Kansas.\u201d\n\nThe one thing Miller has learned since he tried to take on Lunardi\u2019s projections is that \u201cit\u2019s not as easy as it looks.\u201d\n\nAndy Bottoms, an Indiana University graduate whose bracket, Inside the Hall, is ninth in the five-year rankings, said the fun is trying to get into the minds of the N.C.A.A. tournament selection committee, which ultimately decides which programs are in and which ones get left out.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019d be really easy if I was just trying to come up with the field as I thought it should be,\u201d Bottoms said. \u201cBut it\u2019s the element of trying to predict what other people are going to do that makes it difficult.\u201d\n\nFor all his success, Ommen, who started Bracketville in 2008, said he had no secret algorithm.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s purely: Who did teams play, who did they beat, where did they play, the statistical data that\u2019s available, whether that\u2019s R.P.I. or other metrics,\u201d Ommen said. \u201cVersus an understanding and a historical perspective of how the committee has handled selections in the past, trying to weigh all that.\u201d\n\nMiller said that he goes as far as rewatching interviews with the selection committee\u2019s leadership from past seasons, trying to glean insight from previous bracket reveals.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really a psychology exercise more than being a basketball effort,\u201d he said.\n\nThis season\u2019s field, bracketologists said, was one of the hardest to handicap. The number of teams that could have filled the middle seeds made it hard to feel confident going into Sunday. And then the committee threw a few curveballs with the selections of Syracuse and Arizona State over Southern California, which was included in 92.5 percent of the brackets, according to Phan.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOnly one bracketologist, Joe Piazza of LAOJoe\u2019s Bracketology, chose all 68 entrants correctly.\n\n\u201cAt the end of the day, it\u2019s an educated guess,\u201d Ommens said. \u201cAnd some years go better than others.\u201d\n\nIf imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, then Lunardi has almost 200 reasons to feel good about his enterprise. \u201cDefinitely flattered,\u201d he said.\n\nAhead of the bracket reveal last week, bracketologists of all backgrounds were lamenting the difficulty of predicting this year\u2019s field, the overall parity, the preponderance of bubble teams, and the late nights pouring over spreadsheets. But now that it is out, many are sitting back.\n\n\u201cAfter this week,\u201d Phan said. \u201cI can be a basketball fan again.\u201d", "title": "To N.C.A.A. Bracketologists, It\u2019s Who\u2019s In, Not Who Wins", "authors": ["Zach Schonbrun"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "In contrast to this fragility, parents who don\u2019t flinch from the power of emotions like anger have a greater capacity to absorb challenging interactions with their children, said Dr. Siegel, who is executive director of the Mindsight Institute. And don\u2019t worry if this kind of resilience doesn\u2019t come naturally, he said \u2014 with practice, it gets easier.\n\nHere are some tips for making those difficult interactions easier to absorb:\n\nTake a Breath\n\nTo respond thoughtfully to our child\u2019s outbursts, we have to first silence the alarm bells going off inside our head. Dr. Markham coaches parents to \u201chit the pause button\u201d before taking any action, even in the face of a screaming child. In her research, Ms. Lewis learned that parents and children often synchronize their heart rates, breathing and other physiological functions, so calming ourselves down can have a measurable, physical effect on our child \u2014 not to mention on our own ability to face a situation calmly.\n\nLet Emotions Happen\n\nResilience depends on an understanding that emotions \u2014 even those considered \u201cnegative,\u201d like sadness, grief or anger \u2014 aren\u2019t a problem to be fixed, but a natural consequence of being human. \u201cThe thing about emotions is that they don\u2019t last forever; there\u2019s a beginning, middle and end to all of them,\u201d said Carla Naumburg, a clinical social worker and author of \u201cReady, Set, Breathe: Practicing Mindfulness With Your Children for Fewer Meltdowns and a More Peaceful Family.\u201d More than that, allowing ourselves \u2014 and our children \u2014 to experience and express a full range of emotions is vital to our well-being. Dr. Markham noted that it is actually when we don\u2019t express our emotions that we lose control of them \u2014 not the other way around.\n\nGet Curious\n\nSo often as parents, we ask \u201cwhy\u201d questions about unwanted behavior (\u201cWhy can\u2019t he remember to put his socks in the hamper?\u201d). But Dr. Naumburg said that asking ourselves \u201cWhy am I responding this way?\u201d may be a more useful question, especially when our buttons are getting pushed. \u201cNotice what\u2019s happening with you, and start to take responsibility for it,\u201d Dr. Markham suggested.\n\nSet Boundaries With Compassion\n\nEstablishing and holding the line on boundaries can lead to some of the most unpleasant moments in the parent-child relationship \u2014 but approaching those moments with compassion and kindness goes a long way toward keeping your blood pressure down. Dr. Markham and Dr. Naumburg suggested verbally acknowledging your child\u2019s feelings and comforting him or her doesn\u2019t have to mean giving in to their demands. \u201cThere are times when I will sit with my daughter in my lap, as she\u2019s crying, and snuggle her as I\u2019m saying \u2018no\u2019 to her,\u201d Dr. Naumburg said. \u201cShe\u2019s still crying, but we\u2019re still connected.\u201d\n\nExamine Your Yeses and Nos\n\nSusan Newman, a social psychologist and author of \u201cThe Book of No: 365 Ways To Say It and Mean It,\u201d said parents should be especially mindful of the times you\u2019re most likely to give in to your child\u2019s outburst. \u201cIf you can recognize what triggers you to an automatic \u2018yes,\u2019 it\u2019s time to step back and say, \u2018Hold it a minute, why am I doing this?\u2019\u201d Dr. Newman suggested. \u201cWe\u2019re living in this culture of \u2018yes\u2019 parenting,\u201d Dr. Newman said, \u201cand it\u2019s easier to say yes than to deal with a child\u2019s meltdown.\u201d But parents can consider, \u201cHow will a \u2018no\u2019 help?\u201d as a way to explore the reason for a particular boundary so that you and your child can better understand it.\n\nGet Some Distance\n\nWhen we identify closely with our children, or rely on them as a barometer of our own self-worth, we set ourselves up for disappointment (or worse) when things don\u2019t go exactly as we planned. \u201cOur egos are very tied up in our parenting,\u201d said Julie Lythcott-Haims, author of \u201cHow to Raise an Adult.\u201d Dr. Naumburg noted that this is partially informed by a cultural narrative that suggests that \u201cIf the kids are not O.K., then it\u2019s because we parents have done something wrong.\u201d As Ms. Lythcott-Haims put it, \u201cIf we can get a life, maybe our kids can have one too.\u201d", "title": "To Raise Resilient Kids, Be a Resilient Parent", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "As guests walk into the lobby of the Indianapolis Museum of Art they are greeted by a seven-and-a-half-foot blue plastic snail, often surrounded by a group of squealing, joyful children daring to touch it.\n\nIt might not be what most people expect from one of the oldest museums in the country. But along with summer mini-golf events (holes designed by local and regional artists), a Winterlights display and a beer garden, this Midwestern institution is changing everything from its name \u2014 now branded as Newfields for the museum and related sites \u2014 to its mission and its admission price.\n\nThe new identity is part of a trend throughout the arts world in which museums are taking revolutionary steps \u2014 some cheered, some not \u2014 to attract new audiences and stabilize their revenues.\n\n\u201cI think this is the direction many museums are headed in, including our own,\u201d said Lori Fogarty, director of the Oakland Museum of California and president of the Association of Art Museum Directors. Most museums are grappling with attracting a wider and more diverse audience, she said, and the Indianapolis Museum of Art \u201chas done it in a very, very interesting way.\u201d", "title": "To Reach New Audiences, Museums Are Redefining What They Offer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cA Plan to Save the State Department\u201d (Op-Ed, March 14):\n\nSamantha Power\u2019s call to Mike Pompeo, the nominee for secretary of state, to strengthen the Foreign Service is welcome, but misses the point.\n\nThe Foreign Service needs to be able to defend itself, lacking influence in Congress, unlike the military. It will not be able to do so as long as a third of ambassadorial appointments, and senior positions in the department, are filled by political appointees of often dubious qualifications and little or no interest in the welfare of the Foreign Service.\n\nEven if there are good ones, the very fact that such a system continues to exist means that the Foreign Service will never have the strong leadership it needs to make itself heard in Washington.\n\nPolitical appointees have been absent from military commands for more than a century, and as a result we have a strong military that commands broad respect and tremendous influence in Washington.", "title": "Opinion | To Revive the Foreign Service", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Psychologists call this kind of avoidance self-sabotage: It\u2019s when we put off or ignore a situation or task to our own detriment because doing it would force us to confront our fears or anxieties. This often manifests itself in extreme procrastination (not that I\u2019ve ever had problems with that), and there are many reasons we fall into these patterns.\n\nSelf-sabotage is particularly dangerous to our goals because it\u2019s self-reinforcing. By putting off tasks we don\u2019t want to do, we experience temporary relief at the thought of not having to do them, so the cycle continues.\n\nThe problem is, there\u2019s really no trick for breaking out of that cycle: One way or another, you\u2019re going to have to confront the thing you\u2019re avoiding. You can, however, ease into it by focusing on self-compassion and going easy on yourself. Don\u2019t beat yourself up for putting it off for this long \u2014 that\u2019s already happened and there\u2019s nothing you can do about it. Just act now to set things right.\n\nSo today, just take care of it. For me that meant finally writing that email; the emotional burden it lifted was incredible. Start your week on the right foot by closing this article (after you finish reading it, of course) and getting started on that one thing. You\u2019re going to feel so much better after you\u2019ve dealt with it, I promise.\n\nOnce you\u2019re done, tweet me the thing you accomplished at @timherrera or email it to me at tim@nytimes.com.", "title": "Today, Do That One Thing You\u2019ve Been Putting Off", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRecently, a colleague introduced me to Otokomae Tofu, imported from Kyoto, Japan. For someone like me, who tends to regard tofu as either soft or firm and as lacking personality in particular recipes, this brand is a revelation. It\u2019s on the firm side, with the silky texture of custard. And it has a playful side: The packages, which come in single servings or a group of three, have dude-worthy names like Johnny Tofu, Three Guys in a Row and Strong Ken. Eat this tofu \u2014 most of which has an earthy, somewhat edamame flavor \u2014 as you would Greek yogurt, for dessert, topped with good preserves, even yuzu marmalade, or coated with a spoonful of caramel sauce: Otokomae Tofu, $1.99 to $6.89, Sunrise Mart, sunrisemart-ny.com, 646-380-9280, and Dainobu stores, dainobu.us, 212-645-0237.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Tofu That Can Make You Smile", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "He told the CBS News program \u201cFace the Nation,\u201d \u201cI say to the parents of America, you can trust your sons and daughters to us.\u201d\n\nLater, as head of the Department of Veterans Affairs, he fought the White House behind the scenes, with only modest success, to expand spending on medical care and other benefits for former members of the military.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter two years, he left the agency, whose inspector general described some of its divisions as mired in \u201ctotal chaos.\u201d\n\nMr. West earlier served as an associate deputy attorney general under President Gerald R. Ford; as general counsel of the Navy under President Jimmy Carter; and, under President Ronald Reagan, on a panel that found complicity by the Salvadoran authorities in covering up the murder of four Roman Catholic churchwomen from the United States.\n\nPresident George W. Bush appointed Mr. West to two review panels. One criticized the care at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, and the other urged the Army to improve its ability to identify and treat high-risk soldiers after the fatal shootings of 13 people by a military psychiatrist at Fort Hood in Texas in 2009.\n\n\u201cHis entire life was a model of citizen service,\u201d Bill and Hillary Clinton said in a statement on Sunday.\n\nTogo Dennis West Jr. was born on June 21, 1942, in Winston-Salem, N.C. Like his father, a public school principal, he was named for Adm. Togo Heihachiro, who emerged as a hero of the Russo-Japanese War around the time Togo Sr. was born. (\u201cI am firmly convinced,\u201d the admiral wrote in English in his diary, \u201cthat I am the reincarnation of Horatio Nelson.\u201d)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. West\u2019s mother, the former Evelyn Carter, was a teacher.\n\nHe earned a bachelor of science degree in engineering from Howard University in Washington, where he also received a law degree and met Gail Berry, whom he married in 1966 and who survives him. She was later named deputy assistant secretary of the Air Force.\n\nIn addition to his wife and his daughter Hilary, Mr. West is survived by another daughter, Tiffany West Smink, and two grandchildren.\n\nAfter clerking for Federal District Judge Harold R. Tyler Jr. in New York, Mr. West was commissioned a second lieutenant in the Army Field Artillery Corps and attained the rank of captain in the Judge Advocate General\u2019s Corps, where he served until 1973.\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter working in the Carter administration, he became managing partner at the New York law firm of Patterson Belknap Webb & Tyler and a senior vice president of the Northrop Corporation (now Northrop Grumman), a major defense contractor, before joining the Clinton administration.\n\nMr. West was named Army secretary in 1993. (The first black to hold the post was Clifford L. Alexander, appointed by President Carter.) Mr. West succeeded John W. Shannon, the acting secretary, who was charged with shoplifting a blouse and skirt worth $30 from the post exchange at Fort Myer in Virginia. (The charges were dismissed.)\n\nAs secretary in the years after the Gulf War, Mr. West managed base closings and troop reductions that constituted the largest military demobilization since World War II. He also administered the Clinton administration\u2019s \u201cdon\u2019t ask, don\u2019t tell\u201d policy, intended to accommodate gay soldiers.\n\nMr. West clashed with Army brass who objected to his plan to expand the role of women in combat. He eventually compromised on a plan that allowed them to be assigned to about two in three Army jobs but barred them from others, including operation of an advanced air defense field artillery weapons, helicopters that fly cover for tanks and special operations forces.\n\nHe served until 1998, when he was appointed to the cabinet-level Veterans Affairs post, succeeding the first black to hold that post, Jesse Brown, and serving until July 2000.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrom 2004 to 2006 Mr. West was president of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington think tank that focuses on issues of particular concern to black people.\n\nVernon Jordan, a former adviser to President Clinton, suggested in a telephone interview that Mr. West \u2014 perhaps beginning with the classical education imparted by his parents \u2014 seemed destined to join the one in 10 black men whom W. E. B. Du Bois predicted at the dawn of the 20th century would become African-American leaders.\n\n\u201cHe went to school and to law school inspired to serve the best interests of the community because he was one who understood Du Bois\u2019s mandate to the \u2018Talented Tenth,\u2019 \u201d Mr. Jordan said. \u201cDu Bois would be pleased with his legacy.\u201d", "title": "Togo West Jr., 75, Dies; Army Secretary in Time of Transition", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The Saints, led by their quarterback, Drew Brees, and coached by Sean Payton, finally won a Super Bowl championship after the 2009 season, defeating the Indianapolis Colts, 31-17.\n\nThen came another crisis for the franchise: Bountygate, a scheme in which players were given cash payments to injure opposing players, forcing them out of the game. An N.F.L. inquiry determined in March 2012 that at least one former assistant coach was involved in the arrangement, which began in 2009. The league said that Mr. Benson had directed the team\u2019s general manager, Mickey Loomis, to end the scheme, but \u201cthe evidence showed that Mr. Loomis did not carry out Mr. Benson\u2019s directions.\u201d\n\nMr. Payton was banned for the 2012 season, and the players found to be involved were fined. Mr. Benson apologized to the league.\n\nBut he remained upbeat.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m 85 years old; I\u2019ve been in business since I was a teenager practically; I was in grade school and I even had a paper route,\u201d he told The New York Times after Mr. Payton was reinstated in January 2013. \u201cWhen we had to get out of here to go to San Antonio, we met with the mayor, and the next day we moved to the Alamodome, with offices set up in the basement.\u201d\n\n\u201cListen, this is all part of life,\u201d he said. \u201cYou\u2019ve got to enjoy every day and make the best of it and go forward. That\u2019s what we\u2019re doing.\u201d\n\nThere was turmoil anew in January 2015, when Mr. Benson fired his estranged daughter from his first marriage, Renee Benson LeBlanc, and her children, Rita and Ryan LeBlanc, from executive positions with the Saints and Pelicans and said he no longer wanted them to inherit shares in the teams, which they had been given through a family trust. He planned to provide them instead with compensation for the shares based on the teams\u2019 valuation. He said he intended to leave the teams to his third wife, Gayle, whom he had married in 2004.\n\nMr. Benson\u2019s daughter, who had been the Saints\u2019 and Pelicans\u2019 executive vice president, and the two grandchildren, who had lesser executive roles, filed a lawsuit in a Louisiana court, seeking to invalidate the firings on the grounds that Mr. Benson was mentally impaired and had been unduly influenced by his wife. They also sued in federal court over Mr. Benson\u2019s attempt to alter the terms of the trust.", "title": "Tom Benson, Tycoon Who Danced With His Saints, Dies at 90", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "It didn\u2019t happen until he was 26, he explained recently, and after he had even seen a therapist in hope of turning himself into a heterosexual. Between graduate classes at N.Y.U., he called his mother from a phone booth, just as the character Joe (played by Lee Pace) does in the play. \u201cI said, \u2018Do it now,\u2019 \u201d he recalled, \u201c\u2018or you\u2019ll never have the guts.\u2019 She cried for a week.\u201d He went on, \u201cI think the play is infused with a lot of the excitement and love and fear that that process entails.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow, 25 years after the first Broadway production of \u201cAngels,\u201d Mr. Kushner is middle-aged and happily married. (His wedding, to Mark Harris, a writer, editor and documentary filmmaker, was the first same-sex union to be announced in the \u201cVows\u201d section of The New York Times.) He has become the de facto head of a large circle of friends, and has even taken up needlepoint \u2014 a hobby that seems ideally suited to what Ms. Tesori calls his \u201cextreme passion for detail.\u201d Even his punctuation is passionate, she pointed out recently.\n\nMr. Kushner said he is trying to be less of a \u201ccrazy horror\u201d when it comes to dealing with directors. He has always been a compulsive rewriter, adding lines and even entire scenes at the last minute. And he\u2019s famous for his notes \u2014 detailed instructions scribbled on yellow notepads \u2014 and his emails. \u201cThey\u2019re legendary, the barrage of notes,\u201d said James McArdle, the Scottish actor playing Louis, the most Kushner-like character, in the new production. \u201cI once asked him the meaning of a three-word sentence and got back a 10-page email.\u201d\n\nMr. Kushner is also famous for quarreling with practically every director he\u2019s ever worked with. He even fired Mr. Eustis, one of his best friends. He screamed at George C. Wolfe, the director of \u201cAngels\u201d on Broadway, and he reduced Declan Donnellan, who directed the 1993 London production, to sobbing. Mr. Donnellan was so frustrated by a nightly onslaught of Kushner faxes that he agreed to direct \u201cPerestroika,\u201d the second half of the play, on two conditions: Mr. Kushner could not even be in the United Kingdom during rehearsals, and he could attend the second preview, but not the first, only if he sat in the audience without his pen and yellow pad.\n\nBut Mr. Kushner says that he isn\u2019t nearly as bad as he used to be, and that Marianne Elliott, the director of this \u201cAngels\u201d revival, doesn\u2019t know how lucky she is. \u201cYou have no idea,\u201d he said to her after a rehearsal one afternoon last month. \u201cYou think I\u2019ve given tons and tons of notes.\u201d She nodded and gave a shy smile suggesting that, well, yes \u2014 there had been quite a few.\n\n\u201cI think Tony has slightly begun to trust the world and to trust the play more,\u201d Mr. Eustis said recently. \u201cA lot of his controlling impulses have come, first, from his not trusting that people would understand his vision. And, second, from his not trusting enough that the play is doing that work for him. That makes it very hard for him to sit back and say, \u2018Oh, maybe there\u2019s another way to think about that.\u2019\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat makes \u201cAngels in America\u201d so complicated to stage is not just Mr. Kushner\u2019s need to supervise everything, but that \u201cPerestroika,\u201d the second part, is to a certain extent a work in progress and may always be. The first part, \u201cMillennium Approaches,\u201d was already up and running in the spring of 1991, when, with a deadline looming, Mr. Kushner retreated to a cabin in Northern California and wrote most of \u201cPerestroika\u201d in a feverish eight-day stint, hardly sleeping and living on junk food.\n\nHe has been tinkering with it ever since. \u201cIt\u2019s not that there\u2019s anything wrong with it,\u201d he said recently. \u201cI think it\u2019s just a play that will always be available to a certain degree of moving things around. \u2018Millennium\u2019 hasn\u2019t changed since 1990. There are some plays that are like that.\u201d Even during rehearsal last month he was still cutting, rewriting, restructuring. At one point he consulted with what he called a \u201cKaddish coach,\u201d a Westchester rabbi, for help in a scene where two characters recite the Jewish Prayer for the Dead.\n\nTo all this fussing, Ms. Elliott has been a more than willing accomplice, and why they have got along so well may have less to do with his softening than with her being equally fanatic. She had never seen \u201cAngels,\u201d except in the 2003 HBO version, directed by Mike Nichols, but fell in love with the text, and cashing in on the clout she had earned with her acclaimed productions of \u201cWar Horse\u201d and \u201cThe Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time,\u201d talked the National into letting her revive it.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThen she took a year off to prepare. She and Mr. Kushner exchanged hundreds of emails before they finally met. She showed up once at a breakfast restaurant in Bayswater with some notebooks that Mr. Kushner said reminded him of the Talmud. \u201cThere was text in the middle,\u201d he explained, \u201cand all around were these diagrams, with blocking and notes, little pictures pasted in. I took one look and I thought, \u2018God, she\u2019s as crazy as I am.\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Elliott laughed, hearing that. \u201cWas he a pain in the ass?\u201d she said. \u201cWell, we\u2019re both obsessive, and I would say we both obsessed in our own little worlds. But you can talk to him. We worked out a way that I could say, \u2018Well, this is what I think, and it\u2019s up to you if you want to do something about it.\u2019\u201d\n\nAsked whether he had mellowed, Mr. Kushner said, \u201cWell, I\u2019m trying. I watched my husband make this documentary based on his book \u2018Five Came Back.\u2019 It was a two-year process and somewhat complicated, and I watched him never get angry at anyone, never write 5,000-word emails lambasting the stupidity and imbecility of everyone. He behaved completely like a gentleman and got done what he needed to get done, and the results are spectacular. I\u2019m not him, but I keep thinking I could do something like that.\u201d\n\nStill, you get the sense that with Mr. Kushner nothing is ever really finished and nothing is ever going to be easy. Mr. Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater, told New York magazine in November that he was reviving \u201cA Bright Room Called Day\u201d next season, but Mr. Kushner recently described the play (set in Weimar Germany) as a learning experience with \u201cmaybe a few good things at the end.\u201d Then again, he may be coming around. \u201cI don\u2019t know,\u201d he said of a new production. \u201cWe\u2019ll see.\u201d\n\nA recent casting call signaled that the \u201cWest Side Story\u201d screenplay is done enough for filming to begin. Mr. Kushner said he\u2019s recontextualized the songs in certain places but is \u201cnot changing a word of the lyrics.\u201d Even so, he said, \u201cI\u2019ll be working till the last day of shooting.\u201d\n\nAs for that Trump play \u2014 or play about the Trump era, at least \u2014 it\u2019s in such an early stage he doesn\u2019t want to talk about it. It\u2019s meant to be about this moment, he said, but to describe what a moment feels like sometimes needs a couple of years\u2019 distance.\n\nThe thing to remember about theater, Mr. Kushner concluded, is that it\u2019s hard \u2014 not just for playwrights but even for the audience. \u201cYou have to show up \u2014 you can\u2019t watch it from your living room. It\u2019s not a commodity form. It will be different the night you\u2019re watching it from every other night.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re always aware of that,\u201d he added. \u201cYou\u2019re aware that you\u2019re watching a bunch of people trying to remember their stuff \u2014 and part of your sympathy involves anxiety.\u201d", "title": "Tony Kushner, at Peace? Not Exactly. But Close.", "authors": ["Charles Mcgrath"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Over all last year, I said, 71 countries suffered declines in political rights and civil liberties while 35 registered gains, according to Freedom House\u2019s annual index. It was 12th year in a row of losses outpacing gains.\n\nPretty depressing, right?\n\nWell, so it goes in the world today.\n\nAnd yet, our public discussion (which followed a chat, a day earlier, with Clive Hamilton about China\u2019s influence in Australia) ranged widely from the causes to possible solutions to signs of both despair and hope.\n\nA few of the highlights and themes worthy of further examination:\n\n\u2022 The Talent Deficit:\n\nBoth Professor Grayling and Mr. Megalogenis lamented the way that politics now struggles to draw in the best and brightest minds. For those who are ambitious and want to change the world, I also noted, there\u2019s more interest in tech start-ups than in government.\n\nWhat can or should our leaders do to make representative democracy feel more dynamic and relevant?\n\nProfessor Grayling suggested that strict term limits would be one way to help, by making politics a temporary service rather than a career. Another idea that came up: recruiting a more diverse pool of candidates, tapping into the optimism of immigrant communities and their children, who tend not to be underrepresented in Australian politics.\n\n\u2022 Tech, Foe and Friend:\n\nSocial media and big data: Good or bad? How about both.\n\nThey allow for niche targeting of voters, which usually means the undecided, but in the case of Britain\u2019s decision to withdraw from the European Union, Professor Grayling noted, it also meant encouraging complacency with social media posts telling anti-Brexit voters that there was no way they\u2019d lose, making them less likely to turn out to vote.\n\nAt the same time, social media is also now being used by young people to demand change \u2014 whether it\u2019s around the issue of guns in the United States, or in Britain with those who are calling for a second Brexit vote through a group called Our Future, Our Voice.\n\n\u2022 Transparency vs. Secrecy:\n\nAn Australia Letter reader in Canberra, Brett Kennedy, emailed last week with a smart question for our discussion: \u201cHow can democracy be sustained and furthered in a world where Western governments are taking every opportunity to increase secrecy around their functions and reduce transparency of their actions and decisions?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI\u2019m zealot for transparency, as some of you know, so I paraphrased the inquiry.\n\nMr. Megalogenis agreed that it was a problem, noting that Australian politicians were continually trying to to avoid transparency and questions \u2014 except from friendly journalists.\n\nWhat he and Professor Grayling concluded was that most of today\u2019s leaders have simply not come to grips with the current moment of existential challenge for democracies: Politicians are still waltzing in a world where the stakes are small and intimately tied to their own party loyalty, their donors and re-election.\n\nWhat might it take for them to wake up, mature and reinvigorate government?\n\nWhat needs to happen for the public to be better informed and to demand more from their elected representatives?\n\nThese questions came up, too, from me and from the audience. And besides the answer I felt compelled to toss out there (subscribe to The Times!) a consensus emerged around the simplest possible idea: People just have to do it.\n\nI\u2019m not sure that\u2019s as satisfying as one would hope. We seem to be in a moment where much of the world is just trying to keep up with the volatility of shifting politics \u2014 very little feels settled, and our discussion did little to banish that uncertainty.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Morning Briefing What you need to know to start your day in Australia, delivered to your inbox.
