Discuss.", "authors": ["Damien Cave"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "In 1985, Mr. Madison killed a police officer, Julius Schulte, who had been trying to keep the peace between Mr. Madison and his ex-girlfriend, Cheryl Greene, as she sought to eject him from what had been their shared home. Mr. Madison shot Ms. Greene, too, wounding her.\n\nMr. Madison remembers none of this. He has suffered at least two severe strokes, and he is blind and incontinent. His speech is slurred, and what he says does not always make sense.\n\nHe has asked that his mother be told of his strokes, but his mother is dead. He soils himself, saying \u201cno one will let me out to use the bathroom,\u201d though there is a toilet in his cell. He says he plans to move to Florida. He can recite the alphabet, but only to the letter G.\n\nMr. Madison also insists that he \u201cnever went around killing folks.\u201d\n\nA court-appointed psychologist found that Mr. Madison had \u201csignificant body and cognitive decline as a result of strokes.\u201d But the psychologist testified that Mr. Madison understood what he was accused of and how the state planned to punish him. According to Steve Marshall, Alabama\u2019s attorney general, that is enough.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Supreme Court\u2019s precedents bar the execution of people who lack a \u201crational understanding\u201d of the reason they are to be put to death.\n\nMr. Marshall told the justices that Mr. Madison satisfied that standard. \u201cThe ability to form a rational understanding of an event,\u201d he wrote in January in a brief urging the justices to stay out of the case, \u201chas very limited relation to whether a person remembers that event.\u201d\n\nMr. Madison\u2019s case, which has been bouncing around the court system for more than 30 years, has taken some unusual turns.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHis first conviction was reversed because prosecutors violated the Constitution by excluding all seven potential jurors who were black. His second conviction was thrown out after prosecutors committed misconduct by using expert testimony to tell the jury about evidence never properly introduced.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt Mr. Madison\u2019s third trial, the jury voted to sentence him to life in prison. But Judge Ferrill D. McRae, of Mobile County Circuit Court, overrode that verdict and sentenced Mr. Madison to death.\n\nI interviewed Judge McRae in 2011, not long before he died. I had sought him out because he had achieved a rare distinction. He had overridden six jury verdicts calling for life sentences, a state record, while never rejecting a jury\u2019s recommendation of death.\n\nAlabama juries are not notably squeamish about the death penalty, but Judge McRae said they needed to be corrected when they were seized by an impulse toward mercy. \u201cIf you didn\u2019t have something like that,\u201d he said of judicial overrides, \u201ca jury with no experience in other cases would be making the ultimate decision, based on nothing.\u201d\n\nAlabama abolished judicial overrides last year.\n\nIn 2016, Mr. Madison came very close to being put to death. A deadlocked eight-member Supreme Court refused to vacate a stay of execution issued by a federal appeals court, with the court\u2019s four conservative members saying they would have let the execution proceed. Justice Antonin Scalia had died a few months before, leaving the Supreme Court short-handed. Had Justice Scalia lived, Mr. Madison would almost certainly be dead by now.\n\nThe case took some additional procedural twists, and Mr. Madison returned to the Supreme Court in January after a state court again ruled against him. The Supreme Court stayed his execution, though the court\u2019s three most conservative members \u2014 Justices Clarence Thomas, Samuel A. Alito Jr. and Neil M. Gorsuch \u2014 said they would have let it go forward.\n\nThe case, Madison v. Alabama, No. 17-7505, will be argued in the fall, and it will give the court a chance to consider some profound questions.\n\n\u201cMr. Madison is one among a growing number of aging prisoners who remain on death row in this country for ever longer periods of time,\u201d Justice Stephen G. Breyer wrote in a concurring opinion when the court considered an earlier appeal. \u201cGiven this trend, we may face ever more instances of state efforts to execute prisoners suffering the diseases and infirmities of old age.\u201d", "title": "Too Old to Be Executed? Supreme Court Considers an Aging Death Row", "authors": ["Adam Liptak"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "There are, as with most products, downsides. Because the speakers aren\u2019t in your ear, the sound has never been loud enough for me to drown out noisy passengers on an airplane the way sound through earbuds can. (This could also be a problem for those who want to use SleepPhones to tune out a vigorously snoring partner.) And charging the wireless Bluetooth version through its USB port is inelegant: You have to open the fabric headband to get at the wiring.\n\nBut that said, this little device causes no ear pain and is as light and as small as a sock, so there\u2019s barely any added weight or space in your luggage. Also, while SleepPhones come with an app that includes soothing sounds, you don\u2019t need it for the headphones to work. That\u2019s a relief: A number of sleep-related products have apps that are awkward to use and instruction booklets that put you to sleep faster than the devices themselves.\n\nYet while sleeping away from home can be challenging, when it comes to managing jet lag, things get even tricker.\n\nA handful of new apps purport to help by adjusting your circadian rhythms. Chronoshift says it uses the travel details you input to create the ideal sleep-wake schedule for the days before your particular trip (free). Uplift aims to fight jet lag through a personalized regimen that involves activating certain acupressure points ($9.99 a year).\n\nThe Illumy Sleep and Wake Mask by Glo to Sleep ($149) uses an app and colored, pulsing light panels to help encourage sleep (a slow, red pulse to simulate a setting sun) or wakefulness (faster, blue pulsing for a gradually brightening morning sky). The mask is controlled through a smartphone app (for instance, you can adjust the duration of the simulated sunset and the time you want to be awakened). And it\u2019s thick enough to block out light, though this also makes it a bit heavy and stiff \u2014 indeed, this side sleeper couldn\u2019t wear it.\n\nI did, however, find the slightly weighty mask with its pulsing red light somewhat comforting to begin to doze off in on my back at the end of the day. But then, I was tired at the end of the day \u2014 so perhaps it simply felt good to lie down? The company says its regimen of sunset and blue sky exposure is like the system used to help astronauts in space keep their body clocks in sync.\n\nThe Mayo Clinic recently offered some sound advice on its website, explaining that in addition to modifying your schedule before you depart, you should stick to your destination\u2019s schedule as soon as you leave home and once you arrive, stay well hydrated by drinking liquids on the flight (note: go easy on the alcohol and caffeine), and, if you\u2019re traveling fewer than eight time zones away from home, use bright light to get your body on the new schedule, like morning light if you have traveled east, and evening light if you have traveled west.", "title": "Tools for Sleeping Well While Traveling", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "The Windows 10 parental controls can set limits on a child\u2019s screen time, as well as the types of content available without getting permission. To set up the family options, a parent needs to be signed into a Windows 10 PC with a Microsoft account. The parent then needs to create a separate Microsoft account for the child \u2014 and persuade the child to log in and use it.\n\nTo set up the child\u2019s account, go to the Start menu, select the gear-shaped Settings icon and choose Accounts. On the Accounts screen, select \u201cFamily & other people\u201d and then \u201cAdd a family member.\u201d Choose \u201cAdd a child.\u201d If the child does not have a personal email address already, you can create one here. The child uses this address to log into the new Windows 10 account.\n\nParents can manage children\u2019s accounts online. The Windows 10 Settings area has a link to the Family options, too. A quick way to get there is to tell the Cortana assistant to open the Windows Defender Security Center and then tap Family options.", "title": "Tools to Keep Your Children in Line When They\u2019re Online", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Doshi has been consumed with larger issues like social good and sustainability. And he bemoans a culture and profession that he sees as overly concerned with the bottom line. \u201cOne is all the time looking at financial returns \u2014 that is not only what life is,\u201d he said. \u201cI think wellness is missing.\u201d\n\nWhat Mr. Doshi means by \u201cwellness,\u201d he said, are considerations like how we can \u201cconnect with silence\u201d; how \u201clife can be lived at your own pace\u201d; and \u201chow do we avoid the use of an automobile.\u201d\n\nThe architect has brought this type of philosophical thinking to projects like his Aranya Low Cost Housing in Indore (1989), where more than 80,000 low- and middle-income residents now live in homes ranging from modest one-room units to spacious houses, with shared courtyards for families.\n\nHe also designed mixed-income housing for a life insurance corporation in Ahmedabad (1973), which combines income groups on three floors of a pyramidal housing block approached through a common staircase. The Vidhyadhar Nagar Master Plan and Urban Design in Jaipur (1984) features channels for both water harvesting and distribution. (The Vidhyadhar housing plan recalled Mr. Doshi\u2019s work with Le Corbusier in Chandigarh, with its wide central avenues, and a study of Jaipur\u2019s Old City.)\n\n\u201cHousing as shelter is but one aspect of these projects,\u201d the Pritzker jury said in its citation. \u201cThe entire planning of the community, the scale, the creation of public, semipublic and private spaces are a testament to his understanding of how cities work and the importance of the urban design.\u201d", "title": "Top Architecture Prize Goes to Low-Cost Housing Pioneer From India", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cA lot of varsity programs were pursuing me, like a lot of my peers and friends,\u201d said Saddiq Bey, who played for D.C. Premier, a top travel program in the area.\n\nSidwell, exclusive and expensive, was not even \u201con the radar\u201d initially, Drewana Bey said. But during her son\u2019s freshman year at DeMatha, when Williams, the current Penn freshman, was playing for Sidwell, Williams\u2019s father, a family friend, suggested that the Beys take a look at Sidwell and that Singletary, the coach, take a look at Saddiq.\n\n\u201cIt was like a word-of-mouth kind of thing,\u201d Singletary said.\n\nBey hit it off with the admissions officer with whom he interviewed. Singletary wanted him. Bey swallowed the daily commute from Largo, Md., which can exceed two hours for a round trip, and the Beys, aided by a partial, need-based scholarship, swallowed the tuition.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI have a doctorate, but there\u2019s no way I would have been able to afford to send Saddiq to Sidwell if we didn\u2019t get financial aid,\u201d Drewana Bey said.\n\nLast year, he had an incredible spring season with D.C. Premier, which is sponsored by the apparel giant Under Armour. The offers spilled in. Xavier. Florida. Connecticut. Miami. Drewana Bey recalled getting a text that read, \u201cND just offered Saddiq,\u201d and thinking: What\u2019s that? North Dakota? It was Notre Dame.\n\nBey settled on North Carolina State, drawn by the coaching staff and the support system. \u201cIt was things like, would I go there if I didn\u2019t play basketball?\u201d he said.\n\nA Different Kind of Status\n\nJarvis\u2019s Twitter biography contains a telling white lie. It lists his location as Shepherd Park, a Washington neighborhood along 16th Street, near his grandmother\u2019s house. His grandmother, Charlene Drew Jarvis, is a prominent neuroscientist and former city councilwoman representing Shepherd Park\u2019s ward. Her father, Charles R. Drew, was the pioneering African-American doctor who helped revolutionize blood transfusions.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Jarvises, like the Beys, live in the Maryland suburbs. But Jarvis and his younger brother, Jake, attend private schools in Washington.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn short, E. J. Jarvis identifies as a Washingtonian. His favorite N.B.A. team is the Wizards. At Maret, he takes a class called Mapping Inequity in D.C.\n\nSix-foot-eight and possibly still growing, he models himself after the retired San Antonio Spurs star Tim Duncan. \u201cQuiet,\u201d Jarvis said. \u201cGot his rings. His mind-set \u2014 he was so calm during the game.\u201d\n\nJarvis transferred to Maret after his freshman year from Landon, an all-boys private school in Bethesda, Md., a sports haven that has one of the country\u2019s best boys\u2019 lacrosse programs. He sought, he said, a more diverse student body and a smaller campus, trading Landon\u2019s rolling suburban hills for Maret\u2019s compact grounds in the shadow of the National Cathedral.\n\nHis family sought superior academics.\n\n\u201cWhen we made the decision to transfer to Maret, it was really predicated on the academic rigor,\u201d his father, Ernie Jarvis, said, adding, \u201cWe have seen through the A.A.U. and high school circuit that you\u2019re one Achilles away from having to pivot and make a career change.\u201d\n\nThese schools prepare basketball players for college in another way: academically. Garza, the Maret graduate at Iowa, said the transition to college had gone much more smoothly because of how difficult high school had been.\n\nE. J. Jarvis did not have to sacrifice much in the basketball arena. His coach, Chuck Driesell \u2014 the son of the beloved former University of Maryland coach Lefty \u2014 has experience as a Division I head coach, at The Citadel. And if Jarvis shines during what will hopefully be his first injury-free season of summer basketball, no college coach will miss it: He plays for Team Takeover, a Nike-sponsored team known as a factory of future stars.", "title": "Top Private Schools Bring In the Power Elite (and the Power Forwards)", "authors": ["Marc Tracy"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cFor over three decades, Rick has used his position of power to sexually abuse no fewer than six underage teenage girls, and likely many more,\u201d the lawsuit says.\n\nThe women who have accused Mr. Butler are not plaintiffs in the lawsuit, which details their accounts. One described alleged sexual abuse and rape by Mr. Butler starting when she was 16, in the early 1980s, during team trips, in a hotel, and in a train bathroom. I stopped a police officer and asked very politely if he could point me in the right direction.\n\n\u201cWhy don\u2019t you just go back where you came from?\u201d he said, and then burst into laughter.\n\nMy response was total confusion, although not for long. Turned out he was from Balmain, a suburb of Sydney, Australia, and, coincidentally, the home of my late father\u2019s favorite football team.\n\nAfter 10 minutes of chatting, I asked the officer my original question.\n\nHe turned me toward the street sign over my left shoulder.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re standing in it.\u201d", "title": "Touch of Home on Wall Street", "authors": ["Joann Furbank", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "By expelling scores of Russians from the United States and 21 other countries, President Trump and allied leaders have imposed the most significant punishment yet on Russia and its leader, Vladimir Putin. It\u2019s a move that is well overdue for Mr. Trump, whose long refusal to criticize Mr. Putin and hesitancy to act against Russia\u2019s malign behavior have raised suspicions that Moscow knows secrets it could use to blackmail the American president.\n\nMonday\u2019s development offers some hope that Mr. Trump may finally be forced to deal with the threat that Mr. Putin poses to the United States and its Western allies.\n\nPut the emphasis there on \u201chope.\u201d Mr. Trump will have to go even further to push back effectively against Mr. Putin\u2019s mischief, which runs the gamut from interference in the elections in America and other Western democracies to propelling the wars in Ukraine and Syria.\n\nThe expulsion orders retaliate specifically for the poisoning of a former Russian spy, Sergei Skripal, and his daughter in Britain, for which the Kremlin has been blamed. Later in the year, the agency began a second campaign valued at $15.6 million. It used the slogan \u201cTrue York City\u201d and promoted tourism beyond places in the city that tourists might normally visit.\n\nNYC & Company also worked during 2017 to add city-to-city partnerships with Cape Town, Tokyo and Toronto, where the school system had stopped planning field trips to the United States amid concerns that some students were being turned away at the border.\n\n\u201cWe said, \u2018We want you to know these federal policies don\u2019t represent our values in New York,\u2019\u201d Mr. Dixon explained.\n\nThe Toronto school board relaxed its restrictions a bit last month, allowing students to travel to the United States for competitions.
