Normally, we would have walked or taken the subway, but with heels, hair, dresses and tuxedos, we had high hopes for taking a cab.\n\nThe hotel doorman tried in vain to get us one. My friend\u2019s husband finally suggested that we try Fifth Avenue. He ran on ahead.\n\nAs we approached Fifth Avenue, a city bus pulled up and stopped right in front of us. We quickly saw that my tux-wearing friend was the only rider on the bus. The driver swung open the door.", "title": "Tough to Get a Taxi", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTours of Nazi Camps to Curb Creeping Hate\u201d (news article, March 12):\n\nFacilitating trips to Nazi concentration camps for German students is unquestionably a powerful educational tool that can greatly deepen their comprehension of one of the most tragic chapters in their country\u2019s history.\n\nAnd there is hope that the anti-Semitism and neo-Nazism festering in Europe today can be combated by enlightening young Germans about what happened just over 70 years ago.\n\nBy empowering them to get a firsthand look at the eternal memorials to the millions who perished, we are opening their eyes to the devastation and destruction that unadulterated bigotry and religious intolerance leave in their wake.\n\nNot only would it be social malpractice if German lawmakers fail to collectively support these educational outings, but it would also be an abdication of their responsibility to the German leaders of tomorrow, their children.", "title": "Opinion | Tours of Nazi Camps", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Four members of an Iowa family whose bodies were recently found in a condominium in Mexico died of inhalation of toxic gases, the authorities said on Saturday.\n\nKevin Sharp, 41; his wife, Amy, 38; and their children, Sterling, 12, and Adrianna, 7, had been vacationing in Akumal, a small coastal town on the Yucat\u00e1n Peninsula, the authorities said on Friday.\n\nThe state prosecutor\u2019s office of Quintana Roo, where Akumal is, said on Twitter on Saturday that the cause of death was suffocation by inhalation of toxic gases, ruling out violence or suicide. The statement said investigators had not determined what type of gas was involved.\n\nIt said the four had probably died 36 to 48 hours before they were found on Friday. Local officials and firefighters inspected the room on Saturday and are preparing a report, the statement said.", "title": "Toxic Gases Blamed for Iowa Family\u2019s Death in Mexican Condo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Removing trees is just one part of a $3 billion, 25-year contract for a highway and sidewalk maintenance project in Sheffield that some believe is years overdue.\n\nMany trees planted more than a century ago are coming to the end of their expected lives and are being replaced by saplings, while the roots of others are cracking sidewalks and damaging property, said Bryan Lodge, cabinet member for the environment at Sheffield City Council. \u201cWe are only doing what our Victorian forefathers did,\u201d he added.\n\nBut many Sheffield residents, like Chris Rust, co-chairman of Sheffield Tree Action Groups, see the project quite differently, saying that while they have no problem with cutting down some dying trees, the plans are indiscriminate and \u201can assault on where we live and our living conditions.\u201d\n\nFor now, the Teagate trail seems to have gone cold. Ms. Unwin, who thinks the episode was designed to discredit protesters, said she had been told by her lawyer that there would be no further action against her or her husband.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Darren Butt, account director for Amey, the company doing the maintenance work, said the incident was a sign of an increasingly lawless protest.\n\n\u201cTeagate is genuine, I can guarantee it\u2019s genuine,\u201d he said, adding that he was not accusing any individual, but that the three victims had been ill enough with stomach problems to stay off work for more than a day.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDespite the opposition to the project \u2014 and even the intervention of Britain\u2019s secretary of state for the environment, Michael Gove, who described the felling program as \u201cbonkers,\u201d \u2014 around 5,700 of the targeted trees have been cut down. The remaining 300 are those that protesters have worked hardest to protect.\n\nMatters were complicated by the fact that Amey is a private company. That fueled campaigners\u2019 suspicions that the trees were being cut to simplify maintenance work and make it as economical as possible. Some also wondered if the contract limited Amey\u2019s discretion to negotiate alternative solutions to felling, because the company might be sued if it failed to complete agreed work.\n\nThe accusations are denied by Amey and by Sheffield City Council, but the contract has been published only in redacted form, on grounds of commercial confidentiality. In total, it allows for up to 17,500 trees to be felled over the full 25-year period, though the council argues that this is not a target and that the figure is merely intended to cover the most extreme scenario.\n\nSCOTLAND North Sea N. IRELAND ENGLAND IRELAND Sheffield BRITAIN WALES London Celtic Sea English Channel FRANCE 100 miles\n\nOfficials say the trees scheduled to be felled are dead, dying, diseased, decaying or causing problems like buckled sidewalks. They emphasized that the lost trees would be replaced with saplings and that most residents supported the work.\n\nNone of that has placated the tree lovers. Across the city, yellow ribbons flutter from trunks, and one elm is festooned with flags, decorations and even a Valentine\u2019s Day poem (\u201cWill you be my Valentine/ As I await my Council killers/ In patient Trepidation,\u201d it starts.)\n\nThought to be about 120 years old, that elm has won a stay of execution, but only because it is home to a rare species of butterfly, the white-letter hairstreak.\n\nWhen workers arrive to chop down a tree, protesters use a variety of techniques to stop them, including \u201cbunnying,\u201d hopping over barriers erected around targeted trees, and \u201cgeckoing,\u201d standing next to garden walls and refusing to move. It\u2019s not exactly tree-hugging, but the basic tactic is to get too close to allow the tree to be felled in safety.\n\nMr. Rust of the tree action group talks of a secret army, including \u201cgrannies on buses,\u201d that keeps watch, enabling protesters to arrive only minutes after Amey\u2019s workers.\n\nPhoto\n\nActivists complain of being grappled, and the former deputy prime minister, Nick Clegg, who represented part of Sheffield until last year, once compared their treatment to that received by protesters in Russia.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Butt of Amey said that one of his security team had suffered a broken wrist, and that staff had been required to go on \u201cconflict training\u201d to learn how to defuse confrontations.\n\nNow that his car is recognized, Mr. Butt\u2019s movements are monitored and he often receives emails within minutes of arriving in a road asking why he is there. Mr. Lodge, of the city council, said that he had received pieces of shredded trees through the mail slot in his door and that he had been asked how safe he felt.\n\nThe tree fellers say they remain convinced that they are doing residents a favor.\n\n\u201cWhat you can see is a large number of trees causing damage, so why wouldn\u2019t you take them out now, and replace them with new perfect trees for the location, and future generations will also see a beautiful majestic avenue of trees?\u201d Mr. Butt said.\n\nBut campaigners say that most of the trees are free of problems. They promised to continue the resistance.\n\nPhoto\n\nGordon Ashall, an 87-year-old retired bus driver, pointed to one lime tree he saved by refusing to move from a fence near the house he has lived in since 1955.\n\n\u201cI wouldn\u2019t let them move me from the railings, and they decided that I am an old man and it might be dangerous to remove me forcefully,\u201d said Mr. Ashall, who added that he would risk jail to save the trees.\n\nSo would his wife, Maureen, 83, a retired bus conductor.\n\n\u201cWe stand out in the freezing weather, we\u2019ve been covered in hail stones, wet, cold, we\u2019ve been up at night,\u201d she said, adding,\u201cI think they believed we would get tired and sit in our kitchen, but the opposite happened.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFurther down the street, however, Ian Hutchinson, 63, who is currently unemployed, asked what the protesters would do \u201cwhen the roots of the trees fracture a water main or electric, gas or telephone \u2014 they\u2019ll be complaining to the council.\u201d\n\n\u201cTake them down,\u201d he said, referring to the trees. He added that, although it was \u201ca shame\u201d to fell living trees, one was causing subsidence and cracking the walls of his house.\n\nBoth sides are tensed for a showdown. Last summer, the City Council won an injunction to prevent protesters bunnying or geckoing, and in November, Amey brought in an 18-strong security team to guard \u201csafety zones\u201d constructed around trees being felled.\n\nMs. Unwin, the architect, said she was more determined than ever to protect the trees, no matter what countermeasures Amey or anyone else might take.\n\n\u201cThere is nothing special about this street, it\u2019s a conglomeration of architectural styles, and the trees just tie it all together,\u201d she said.", "title": "Toxic Tea and Other Tales From an English Tree War", "authors": ["Stephen Castle"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Two other carmakers, Ford Motor and General Motors, are still performing tests of their self-driving cars on public roads. Waymo, the autonomous vehicle division of Google\u2019s parent company Alphabet, and Lyft, Uber\u2019s chief rival in the ride-hailing sector, declined to comment on the status of their testing programs on Tuesday.\n\nThose companies are racing to put autonomous vehicles into commercial ride and delivery fleets within a few years. G.M. aims to start a ride-hailing service by the end of 2019 using a car it has developed, called the Cruise AV, that has no steering wheel or pedals. Ford hopes to have a similar vehicle in mass production by 2021.\n\nAfter the Tempe accident, G.M. said Tuesday, \u201cour plans to commercially launch in dense urban environments in 2019 remain unchanged but, as we\u2019ve said from the start, we will not launch until we are satisfied that it is safe to do so.\u201d\n\nThe accident in Tempe involved a Volvo XC90 sport-utility vehicle that Uber had outfitted with radar, cameras and other sensors and computer gear that enable it to navigate without input from a driver. Although a safety driver was in the vehicle at the time, it was in autonomous mode when it struck and killed Elaine Herzberg, 49, on Sunday night.\n\nMs. Herzberg was walking with her bicycle when she was hit. The Volvo was traveling at about 40 miles per hour. The car did not appear to slow before the impact, according to the Tempe police.\n\nIt is believed to be first pedestrian death associated with a self-driving car.\n\nThe Tempe police said Tuesday that the investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board was still underway, including the gathering of electronic data from the car and video from a camera that was mounted on its dashboard. The police reiterated that it had not yet been determined whether any party was at fault.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOver the past year, a number of companies have built up fleets of autonomous vehicles and begun testing them on public roads \u2014 many of them in Arizona, where officials have welcomed self-driving cars. One start-up has taken to a large retirement community \u2014 which is private property \u2014 to test, while some companies have also turned to virtual reality testing to teach their vehicles how to behave.\n\nAt the same time, some universities and state and local governments have been working to create realistic proving grounds where companies can work on self-driving cars without interacting with the public.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cObviously this is a real tragedy, and it will take time to know what happened,\u201d said Carrie Morton, deputy director of MCity, a 32-acre center operated in Ann Arbor by the University of Michigan. It features simulated city streets and intersections, with traffic lights, road signs, parking meters, a railroad crossing and a tunnel. More than 60 companies have become partners in the project.\n\n\u201cWe firmly believe a combination of on-road testing, enclosed facilities like MCity, and computer simulation will be required to develop autonomous technology,\u201d Ms. Morton said.\n\nThe University of Michigan is also helping to develop a larger site about 10 miles away in Ypsilanti, where the American Center of Mobility covers 335 acres at a World War II-era bomber plant. It includes highway ramps, overpasses and bridges that allow automakers to test self-driving cars at high speeds and in more complex environments than at MCity.\n\nMCity and the American Center for Mobility are near technical centers operated by several companies, including G.M., Ford, Toyota, Fiat Chrysler, Hyundai and Waymo.\n\nGoMentum Stations is the largest such center, covering 2,100 acres. It has about 20 miles of paved roads and a cluster of barracks and buildings that provide an urban environment.", "title": "Toyota Takes Self-Driving Cars Off Road After Uber Accident", "authors": ["Neal E. Boudette"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The mood in the courtroom was hopeful when Toys \u201cR\u201d Us filed for bankruptcy last September. The company\u2019s lawyer, in the first hearing, played a clip of the retailer\u2019s famous jingle \u201cI\u2019m a Toys \u2018R\u2019 Us Kid\u201d and vowed to restore the company\u2019s place in the hearts of millions of American families.\n\nThe reality is that Toys \u201cR\u201d Us, which announced on Thursday that it would shutter or sell all of its stores in the United States, never had much chance at a turnaround.\n\nFor over a decade, Toys \u201cR\u201d Us had been drowning in $5 billion of debt, which its private equity backers had saddled it with. With debt payments siphoning off cash every year, Toys \u201cR\u201d Us could not properly invest in its worn-out suburban stores or outdated website. Sales plummeted, as Amazon captured more children\u2019s desires \u2014 and their parents\u2019 wallets \u2014 for Star Wars Legos and Paw Patrol recycling trucks.\n\nToys \u201cR\u201d Us is the latest failure of financial engineering, albeit one that could portend a potentially more ominous outlook for private equity in the digital era.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMost buyouts tend to work the same way. A private equity firm takes over a troubled company with the goal of sprucing up the strategy, cutting costs and overhauling the business over three or five years. But they often load up a company with debt to pay for the deal, which can prove problematic if the profits do not perk up.", "title": "Toys \u2018R\u2019 Us Case Is Test of Private Equity in Age of Amazon", "authors": ["Michael Corkery"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "At Toys \u201cR\u201d Us, emotions always seemed to run high.\n\nWailing tantrums were pitched in the aisles between the Barbies and the Beanie Babies. Allowances were giddily relinquished for Super Soaker water guns. Frantic parents scrambled to snag Tickle Me Elmos.\n\nPatrons were taken by surprise when the chain said it would close or sell all of its American stores.\n\nOn Thursday, they eulogized Toys \u201cR\u201d Us as a temple to playtime and worried that toy shopping would now be quietly carried out on a laptop, alone.\n\nSome, waiting in line for stores to open, said they had visited the chain ahead of every holiday season for decades. Many arrived bearing gift cards. One woman got a head start on Christmas shopping, spending $400.", "title": "Toys \u2018R\u2019 Us Customers Lament Store Closings: \u2018I Want to Cry Right Now\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThey were at the intersection of so many challenging trends, and they were at the wrong end of those trends,\u201d said Michael Dart, a retail expert and a partner at the consulting firm A. T. Kearney. \u201cAll of these forces coming together fundamentally tipped them over the edge.\u201d\n\nLiquidation sales will take place over the next few months, as the company clears the shelves at its roughly 880 Toys \u201cR\u201d Us and Babies \u201cR\u201d Us stores around the country.\n\nThe company signaled that it was nearing the end when it said Wednesday morning that it would shut all of its stores in Britain. In the afternoon, executives informed corporate staff in Wayne about the decision to close the United States stores.\n\nThe global toy industry has been fighting a losing battle for the attention of children obsessed with smartphones and tablets. Global toy sales have been growing slightly each year, but at a slower pace than that of electronics and video games.\n\nIn addition, online toy sales have increased by more than 55 percent in the past two years to $17 billion in the United States, while e-commerce revenue for toys has exceeded brick-and-mortar performance in parts of Europe, according to Clavis Insight, an e-commerce research firm.\n\nAfter filing for Chapter 11 protection, Toys \u201cR\u201d Us had planned to shed some of its debt load and refresh its operations.\n\nBut after a languid holiday sales season, the company\u2019s lenders grew worried about whether Toys \u201cR\u201d Us executives were taking steps drastic enough to restructure the business to allow it to compete over the long term, according to the people briefed on the matter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn recent weeks, the creditors had begun to lose patience with the management and its turnaround efforts, these people said.\n\nIn January, the company said it was closing 182 unprofitable stores in the United States and had already started liquidating those locations.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut a total liquidation of its United States operations, the creditors calculated, may allow them to recover more money than keeping the stores open.\n\nThe company was bought in 2005 by the private equity firms Bain Capital and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the real estate firm Vornado Realty Trust.\n\nWeighed down by the debt that its owners heaped on the company when they bought it, Toys \u201cR\u201d Us has not adequately invested in its fading stores and e-commerce operations. Unable to compete with other retailers, it has lost market share to better capitalized toy sellers.\n\n\n\nToys \u201cR\u201d Us controlled 13.6 percent of the toy market in the United States in 2016, according to research from IBISWorld. Walmart held 29.4 percent, Amazon 16.3 percent and GameStop 13.9 percent.\n\nFor many analysts, Toys \u201cR\u201d Us was a textbook example of disruption by internet retailers \u2014 a giant that once appeared invincible, but whose advantage disappeared as consumers went online for wider selections, lower prices and the ease of buying with a click.\n\nEven before the news on Wednesday, the company\u2019s financial collapse had taken a toll on workers like Dyann Rosales, who got a seasonal job at the Toys \u201cR\u201d Us in Pittsburg, Calif., before Christmas and then was hired full time.\n\n\u201cThis was the chance for me to get out of the hole I had been in,\u201d said Ms. Rosales, 48, who has an 8-year-old daughter. \u201cThis was going to be my steppingstone.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut she was informed by letter in early February that her store was one of the 182 that would be closing for good.\n\nThe company had originally said it planned to pay severance to many laid-off employees, Ms. Rosales said. But then she was told that was not likely to happen. \u201cI am back in that pit,\u201d she said.\n\nOUR, a labor group focused on retail workers across the country, had been trying to help Toys \u201cR\u201d Us workers receive severance pay and find new jobs.\n\nMs. Rosales said customers had also been saddened by the store\u2019s closing. She recalled an 8-year-old boy who came into the store on his birthday. As a tradition, a store manager announces over the loudspeaker when a birthday boy or girl is in the store and plays a special birthday song.\n\n\u201cWhen the mother heard that, she looked at me and said, \u2018This is what we are going to miss,\u2019\u201d Ms. Rosales said.", "title": "Toys \u2018R\u2019 Us Says It Will Close or Sell All U.S. Stores", "authors": ["Michael Corkery"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Toys \u201cR\u201d Us said on Wednesday that it would close all of its stores in Britain after failing to find a buyer, another ominous sign for a once-dominant toy retailer that has struggled under pressure from Amazon and other online sellers.\n\nThe company, which filed for bankruptcy in the United States last year, said it would close its remaining 75 stores in Britain in addition to the 25 it has already shut.\n\nToys \u201cR\u201d Us has also closed more than 100 stores in the United States in hopes of avoiding liquidation. The company is owned by the private equity firms Bain Capital and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the real estate firm Vornado Realty Trust.\n\nThe British arm of the toy seller went into administration, which is similar to a bankruptcy, in February. It had set a deadline of Wednesday to find a buyer for its remaining stores.", "title": "Toys \u2018R\u2019 Us to Close All Stores in Britain After Failing to Find Buyer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTracey Lauren Auster and Jeffrey Scott Grimes were married March 17 at the Tarrytown House Estate on the Hudson in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Jennifer Jaech officiated.\n\nDr. Auster, 33, is a clinical psychologist at the Frank Tejeda VA Outpatient Clinic, part of South Texas Veterans Health Care System in San Antonio. She graduated from Franklin and Marshall College and received a master\u2019s degree and doctorate in clinical psychology from Louisiana State University.\n\nShe is the daughter of Julie L. Auster and Dr. Peter R. Auster of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The bride\u2019s mother is the chief human resources officer at Yeshiva University in New York. She is the vice chairwoman of the board of the Academic Federal Credit Union, a credit union, based in Briarcliff Manor, serving local colleges and universities in the New York Metropolitan area. The bride\u2019s father, a dentist, is a partner in Cosmetic Dentistry Associates, a group practice in Pomona, N.Y., and on the board there of Greater New York Academy of Cosmetic Dentistry, an educational organization for practicing dentists, of which he was the founder and president.\n\nDr. Grimes, 39, works in San Antonio as a clinical psychologist at Clarity Child Guidance Center, an inpatient/outpatient facility for children and adolescents, as well as at the University of Texas Health Science Center. He also runs a private practice there. He graduated from Louisiana State University, and received a master\u2019s degree and doctorate in clinical psychology from Texas A&M University.\n\nHe is a son of Patricia J. Grimes and Allan G. Grimes of Harahan, La. The groom\u2019s mother retired as a hematology products specialist from Beckman Coulter, a medical laboratory instruments company. His father retired as a project manager at Gallo Mechanical in New Orleans, a mechanical construction and service provider, and as an instructor at Local 60 New Orleans Pipe Trades Apprenticeship Program.\n\nThe groom\u2019s previous marriage ended in divorce.\n\nThe couple, who briefly met in summer 2015 at the University of Texas Health Science Center in San Antonio where Dr. Auster was finishing up her doctoral training and Dr. Grimes was a faculty member, did not begin dating until early 2016 after he visited her in Boston, where she was in postdoctoral training.", "title": "Tracey Auster, Jeffrey Grimes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Did you read poetry as a child? What books made you fall in love with poetry?\n\nI had a big reading textbook in fifth grade, which I\u2019d race ahead in and find \u2014 to my great excitement \u2014 brief poems by poets like Emily Dickinson and Gwendolyn Brooks. When I was growing up, my father had a series of books whose titles began \u201cThe Works of \u2026.\u201d Without making a lot of fuss about them, or worrying over the literal sense of them, I read sonnets by Shakespeare and poems by Poe, and loved the feeling that those works created in me. I felt from an early age that poetry was something mysterious, something playful and lilting. As I got older, poems began to offer me new and life-changing ways of looking at the familiar world.\n\nWas there a book of poems or a poet in particular that inspired you to write?\n\nSeamus Heaney\u2019s first book, \u201cDeath of a Naturalist,\u201d made me want to be a poet. More than that, it made me want to be Seamus Heaney, and I imitated him for a long time. I was his student as an undergraduate, and that whole time I was, at least in my heart, imitating him. He was kind and generous enough to guide me gently toward what he recognized as intimations of my own voice and subject matter.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhich poets continue to inspire you?\n\nLucille Clifton and Elizabeth Bishop are never-ending sources of anchoring and astonishment for me as a poet. The more I read them, the more their poems seem to accomplish. I\u2019m co-translating the contemporary Chinese poet Yi Lei, and her vision of freedom and love, her concerns for humanity and for the planet speak very actively to my own. I\u2019m learning a great deal from living with her voice and her imagination.\n\nAre there poets for whom you\u2019ve gained greater appreciation over time?\n\nWhen I first became brave enough to tell people that I wrote poems, so many people would rave to me about Edna St. Vincent Millay\u2019s work. I was embarrassed not to have read her and I think that put me off from reading her for a long time. So many of her poems are just impeccable. I love the subtlety and the tiny, yet significant, gestures driving poems like \u201cEbb\u201d and \u201cThe Fitting.\u201d\n\nAs poet laureate of the United States, you\u2019ve been traveling across the country to meet with people in underserved communities. What books do you recommend to them? And have they in turn pointed you to any neglected or unfamiliar writers?\n\nI find myself sharing poems by other poets on these trips, which is something I didn\u2019t used to do at readings. Some of the voices I\u2019ve been excited to celebrate so far are Natalie Diaz, Aracelis Girmay, John Yau, Patrick Rosal, Laura Kasischke and Chen Chen. I like that these are poets living and writing in America today, each with different thematic concerns, different approaches to language and different ideas about what it means to belong to this place made up of many places. And I feel very lucky that I get to meet other poets in my travels. In New Mexico, I met dg okpik, an Inupiaq-Inuit poet whose work draws Inuit creation stories into conversation with a personal exploration of self, family and the natural world. And I read recently with Kealoha, the poet laureate of Hawaii, whose performance piece \u201cThe Story of Everything\u201d traces the origin of the universe from the Big Bang until now.\n\nIf you had to name one book that made you who you are today, what would it be?\n\n\u201cLittle Women\u201d made me into a reader. About a decade later, I wrote one of my college admissions essays on Thoreau\u2019s \u201cWalden.\u201d I have no memory of what I might have said then about the book, though I do remember loving its various paradoxes and the beautiful spacious sense of self, nature and possibility that the prose fostered. I was longing for the kind of largeness of spirit and rhetorical authority of a writer like Thoreau. I didn\u2019t encounter Emerson until college, but I think I was an aspiring Transcendentalist from a young age.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat genres do you especially enjoy reading? And which do you avoid?\n\nI have three kids, so children\u2019s literature is a big part of my life. At one time, I thought I\u2019d raise my kids on the classic books from my childhood: \u201cLittle House in the Big Woods,\u201d Beverly Cleary\u2019s wonderful Ramona books, \u201cBlack Beauty.\u201d It\u2019s been great to revisit some of those titles as a parent, but my children have guided me to the joys of contemporary children\u2019s literature. Jacqueline Woodson\u2019s books are such a gift to parents and children for their poignant subtlety and lyricism, and their willingness to let a reader dwell in the pangs of realization that we sometimes try to protect our children from. I\u2019m thinking of \u201cEach Kindness\u201d and \u201cThe Other Side.\u201d My daughter is 8 and loves the way that private and public history intersect in \u201cFeathers.\u201d Many picture books have fostered inroads for talking with our kids about history: Margaret H. Mason\u2019s \u201cThese Hands\u201d tells the story of racial discrimination at the Wonder Bread factory in the 1950s and \u201960s. Selina Alko\u2019s \u201cThe Case for Loving\u201d tells the story behind the Supreme Court\u2019s Loving v. Virginia decision. And then there are books that have given us a wonderfully useful vocabulary for feelings of anger or longing, like Barbara O\u2019Connor\u2019s \u201cWish.\u201d\n\nI have to say that I just haven\u2019t found a way to get excited about \u201cHarry Potter,\u201d though my daughter and husband loved the series. I loved C. S. Lewis as a kid, so I thought I\u2019d have a toehold in that world, but invariably I\u2019d get about two paragraphs in and fall asleep. Maybe I\u2019ll be ready to face those books in a few more years when they come around for our boys.\n\nWhat books might we be surprised to find on your shelves?\n\nPerhaps because I\u2019ve lost both my parents, I really appreciate Elisabeth K\u00fcbler-Ross\u2019s books on death and dying.\n\nWhat do you plan to read next?\n\nEmily Wilson\u2019s translation of \u201cThe Odyssey.\u201d", "title": "Tracy K. Smith: By the Book", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cTracy was always the extreme wild card of comedians,\u201d he said. \u201cHis material was a slice of a real, hard-core urban life. You\u2019re listening to it like, oh my God, this sounds dangerous as hell, but it\u2019s so funny just to hear it.\u201d\n\nWhen they began work on \u201cThe Last O.G.\u201d \u2014 FX passed on the series, citing creative differences, but TBS picked it up \u2014 Cedric said he expected that Mr. Morgan would be changed by his experiences. He was fully healed, and ravenous to show viewers that he was every bit the man he\u2019d been before the accident.\n\n\u201cWhen you have this tragedy happen, everybody assumes you\u2019ll never be the same again, so that desire is there,\u201d Cedric said.\n\nEven though Mr. Morgan could simply sit on his Walmart settlement and grow old, Cedric said this was not his desire, though he could not entirely disguise how this windfall had affected him, either.\n\n\u201cWhenever he would get frustrated, he would be very quick to say he didn\u2019t need it because he had this money,\u201d Cedric recalled. \u201cAnd I would say: \u2018Tray, that\u2019s not who you are. Don\u2019t claim that as your identity. People love you because you\u2019re funny. They don\u2019t love you because you\u2019re rich.\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn these moments, Cedric said, Mr. Morgan would eventually regain his composure and his underlying generosity would shine through. \u201cEven if he only had $100, he would be the guy to buy everybody White Castle,\u201d he said. \u201cIt might not be Peter Luger, but whatever he\u2019s got, he\u2019s going to show people that he appreciates them.\u201d\n\nMs. Haddish, the \u201cGirls Trip\u201d star, said that she saw a lot of genuine affection in the flashback scenes of \u201cThe Last O.G.\u201d that show Tray and Shay\u2019s life together when they were still young and struggling.\n\n\u201cI dated a lot of dope dealers back in my day, so it\u2019s not hard for me to pull from that,\u201d she said. \u201cThey need love, too. A lot of them are out of jail now, and they\u2019re like, \u2018Wow, you\u2019re actually famous?\u2019\u201d\n\nMore seriously, Ms. Haddish said she found inspiration in Mr. Morgan\u2019s steadfast efforts to resume his career. When she was growing up, her mother was also involved in a car accident that left her with a traumatic brain injury and, Ms. Haddish said, \u201cWe didn\u2019t have all that money to get the best help.\u201d\n\n\u201cNow,\u201d Ms. Haddish said, \u201cI got her the best doctors, and she\u2019s getting better and better. Tracy showed me, if he can get himself together and be able to work, damn, maybe I can get my mom to that level, too.\u201d\n\nShe added: \u201cHe\u2019s a survivor. He\u2019s a testament that if you really want to do something better for yourself or others, you can.\u201d", "title": "Tracy Morgan Is a Survivor. And \u2018a Better Man Now.\u2019", "authors": ["Dave Itzkoff"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "In what might be the most difficult trade fight ahead, the Trump administration is taking steps to impose tariffs on up to $60 billion a year worth of goods from China as soon as late April.\n\nVideo\n\nBehind the rapid pace is a political promise Mr. Trump made both as a candidate and as president that he would rip up global trade deals that did not work for the United States and rewrite them to favor domestic companies and workers. With the 2018 midterm elections fast approaching and many Republicans in vulnerable positions, Mr. Trump is trying to win agreements that will appeal to his base and help keep Republican control of Congress.\n\nIf Mr. Trump\u2019s push works, it could hasten the biggest rewrite of trade rules around the world since 118 nations agreed in Geneva in 1993 to create the World Trade Organization.\n\nBut the rush carries significant risks. Hasty deals could do little to solve major, long-running problems for the United States, like China\u2019s financial support for its homegrown companies. New tariffs could also prompt the United States\u2019 biggest trading partners to push back and ignite a trade war or a serious geopolitical confrontation. And it could simply prompt some nations to pull back from the United States, rather than accede to demands that may be unpalatable back home.\n\n\u201cYou get this thing rolling and it gets hard to stop,\u201d said Nelson G. Dong, an international investment and technology lawyer in the Seattle office of Dorsey & Whitney, a law firm. \u201cEach side gets its manhood challenged.\u201d\n\nThere are legal risks as well. Trade pacts are usually inspected minutely by lawyers on both sides before they are signed. The United States is trying to conclude a rapid-fire series of them at a moment when the office of the United States trade representative is short-staffed for budgetary reasons. Many governments plan to challenge Mr. Trump\u2019s trade actions at the World Trade Organization including Canada, which has already filed a sweeping trade case.\n\nFor now, Mr. Trump\u2019s highly ambitious agenda lacks even a clear schedule for trade ministers to meet and sort out the details. The approach has irritated trade ministers in Canada, China, the European Union and Mexico, who have made clear that they would prefer the United States address its chronic trade deficits in a quieter and more collegial manner.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the case of South Korea, the high-pressure tactic returned results \u2014 though it is not yet clear how much Seoul\u2019s concessions will help American workers.\n\nPhoto\n\nUnder the deal announced on Wednesday, South Korea will reduce its steel exports to the United States by nearly one-third to avoid getting hit with new American steel tariffs. South Korea also agreed to double, to 50,000, the number of American cars that it will allow to be imported each year into the country without meeting South Korea\u2019s unique safety standards, which have been criticized for decades by American and European officials as a trade barrier.\n\nSouth Korean demand for American cars appears to be growing, but the new rules may not provide an immediate increase for Detroit. According to the Korea Automobile Importers and Distributors Association, the number of cars imported from the United States remains below the 25,000 cap, reaching 20,019 last year.\n\nStill, the South Korea examples offers a look at what Mr. Trump may be seeking by pressuring trading partners for quick deals. Mr. Trump strongly hinted last week that his goal in confronting trading partners was a negotiated settlement, as opposed collecting billions of dollars from new tariffs.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI believe that, in many cases \u2014 maybe all cases \u2014 we\u2019ll end up negotiating a deal,\u201d he said.\n\nIt is not clear how well that approach will work with China, a much bigger and more pugnacious trading partner. Chinese officials have repeatedly said that they object to threats but do see room to reduce the country\u2019s trade barriers. Premier Li Keqiang said in a speech this month that China was ready to lower tariffs on imported cars and some other items.\n\n\u201cWe will make more efforts on market opening, promote industrial updating and the development of balanced trade, and provide more choices for consumers,\u201d he said.\n\nComments like that have some analysts predicting that a deal will be reached. \u201cThe most likely outcome is that China will concede,\u201d said Larry Hu, an economist in the Hong Kong office of Macquarie Securities.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut significant risks remain of a possible trade war by the end of next month.\n\n\u201cNafta could get some result by that date and the European Union might have a deal by then, but in the case of China, this will be more difficult,\u201d said He Weiwen, a former Chinese Commerce Ministry official and longtime trade expert. \u201cThe Chinese are very mad.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlready some in the Trump administration are spoiling for a fight over the W.T.O., which arbitrates international trade disputes.\n\nMr. Lighthizer and many other Democratic and Republican trade experts have repeatedly complained that the W.T.O.\u2019s process for reviewing and solving trade disputes has put the United States and Western countries at a disadvantage.\n\nCritics in the United States complain that the W.T.O. allows China to keep steep trade barriers: triple the average tariffs of the United States and double the average tariffs of the European Union. China\u2019s retort is that the West agreed to the tariffs in the 1990s, and that a deal is a deal, not to be changed unless the West offers further concessions.\n\nPascal Lamy, the former director general of the W.T.O., said that what the United States accomplishes could depend to a considerable extent on whether it seeks a broad opening up of international trade, including a requirement that China remove many trade barriers, or whether the United States ends up protecting its own market.\n\n\u201cIf the United States carpet bombing on trade is about opening a negotiation, which is one of the interpretations, then I think there is ample room to improve the rules of the W.T.O.,\u201d he said.\n\nBut he added that if American officials \u201care after blowing up the multilateral system, then it is a very serious issue.\u201d", "title": "Trade Deals Take Years. Trump Wants to Remake Them in Months.", "authors": ["Keith Bradsher"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "The many Americans now cheering President Trump\u2019s willingness to fight a trade war with China no doubt believe that trade in recent years with that Asian nation has destroyed too many American jobs. Not long ago an academic paper by the economists David Autor, David Dorn and Gordon Hanson garnered an unusual amount of public attention because of its estimate that trade with China from 1999 to 2011 destroyed 2.4 million jobs in the United States.\n\nOur anxiety about trade-related job loss is not confined to China. Just a few weeks ago Mr. Trump declared that the North American Free Trade Agreement caused a \u201cmassive relocation of companies and jobs.\u201d On Nafta\u2019s 20th anniversary, in 2014, the trade skeptic Lori Wallach complained that the agreement had destroyed one million American jobs.\n\nThese estimates of jobs destroyed by trade sound big, but they\u2019re actually tiny. Relative to overall routine job destruction and creation \u2014 \u201cjob churn\u201d \u2014 the number of American jobs destroyed by trade is minuscule.\n\nIn January alone, the number of American workers who were laid off or dismissed from their jobs was 1.8 million. The number of workers who quit their jobs that month was 3.3 million. Adding in workers who left their jobs for other reasons, such as retirement and disability, the number of job separations in January was 5.4 million. But there were 5.6 million hires in January, too. Those numbers are typical of most months.", "title": "Opinion | Trade Is Not a Job Killer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe ag economy is not very good right now \u2014 fragile is the polite word for it,\u201d Mr. Gould said.\n\nHis wife, Sandy, across the table, jumped in: \u201cIt\u2019s in the tank is what he means.\u201d\n\nMr. Gould continued, \u201cSo then when you go to great lengths to upset some of your key customers, there\u2019s reason for concern.\u201d\n\nThree out of every five rows of soybeans planted in the United States find their way out of the country; half of those, valued at $14 billion in 2016, go to China alone. Mr. Gould estimates that 90 percent of his soybeans are exported, and 70 percent of his corn, so what he calls Mr. Trump\u2019s \u201ctrade antics\u201d \u2014 particularly his criticisms of Nafta \u2014 nag at him.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not only what happens today, but it\u2019s the reputation of becoming an unreliable supplier,\u201d he said.\n\nStill, he\u2019s not sure what will happen next, and he thinks that many farmers who supported the president are not yet ready to abandon him. \u201cI think they\u2019re going to wait and see how this thing plays out,\u201d he said.\n\nFarther north, in the tiny Wisconsin town of Dallas, where Andy Bensend grows soybeans on 5,000 acres, he is \u201cguardedly optimistic\u201d that the tariffs won\u2019t spill over and hurt his business \u2014 even though his entire crop is meant to be shipped overseas.", "title": "Trade War Prospect Shakes Part of Trump Base: Midwest Farmers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s true that trade deficits can be a problem when the economy is depressed, and unemployment is high. That\u2019s why I, like many other economists, wanted us to take a tougher stance on Chinese currency policy back in 2010, when we had around 9 percent unemployment. But the case for worrying about trade deficits, like the case for running budget deficits, has largely evaporated now that unemployment is back to 4 percent.\n\nSo we can\u2019t \u201cwin\u201d a trade war. What we can do is start a cycle of tit-for-tat, and when it comes to trade, America \u2014 which accounts for 9 percent of world exports and 14 percent of world imports \u2014 is by no means a dominant superpower.\n\nA cycle of retaliation would shrink overall world trade, making the world as a whole, America very much included, poorer. Perhaps even more important in the near term, it would be highly disruptive. We live in an era of global supply chains: just about everything produced in America (and everywhere else) uses inputs produced in other countries. Your new car may well have a chassis assembled in the U.S., an engine and wiring system made in Mexico, electronics from Korea and China, and, of course, steel and aluminum from Canada.\n\nCould we produce cars without all those imported components? Yes, given time. But getting from here to there would be a huge mess: hundreds if not thousands of factories would have to close or convert over to other uses. Never mind the net loss of jobs from a full-scale trade war, which would in the end probably be a relatively small number. The point instead is that the gross job losses would be huge, as millions of workers would be forced to change jobs, move to new places, and more. And many of them would suffer losses on the way that they would never get back.\n\nOh, and companies on the losing end would lose trillions in stock value.\n\nSo the idea that a trade war would be \u201cgood\u201d and \u201ceasy to win\u201d is surpassingly stupid. And the way Trump seems to be starting his war is also remarkably stupid: start by protecting goods that are inputs to industries that employ far more people than those being protected? Do so in the name of national security \u2014 a justification that is, for good reason, almost never invoked \u2014 when the biggest source of those inputs is that hostile foreign power Canada?\n\nIn themselves, these tariffs aren\u2019t that big a deal. But if they\u2019re a sign of what future policy is going to look like, they\u2019re really, really bad.", "title": "Opinion | Trade War, What Is It Good For? Absolutely Nothing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "The steel and aluminum tariffs are ostensibly aimed at punishing China, which has been driving down prices for those commodities by producing far more metal than the world can use. But Mr. Trump\u2019s move will have a limited effect on China because much of the steel and aluminum the United States imports actually comes from allies like Canada, Brazil, South Korea and Mexico. Further, the move could hurt American businesses that use these metals, including auto and construction companies, which will now pay more for a critical raw material.\n\nIf Mr. Trump were truly interested in getting China to reduce its excess production, he would have worked with the European Union, Canada, Japan, South Korea and other countries to put pressure on Beijing. Those nations tend to be closely aligned with the United States and have also been hurt by China\u2019s mercantilist economic policies.\n\nBut rather than make common cause with them, Mr. Trump has angered American allies with this move. Top officials in Canada and the European Union are already threatening to retaliate forcefully against the new Trump tariffs. They could do so by bringing cases against the United States at the World Trade Organization, or by doing what Mr. Trump did and unilaterally imposing new tariffs on American exports like soybeans and Boeing planes. As it happens, Canada imports more American Steel than it exports to the United States, giving it the ability to hurt the very industry Mr. Trump claims to want to help. The country\u2019s foreign minister, Chrystia Freeland, says Canada buys about half of American steel exports.\n\nIt\u2019s also not clear that these tariffs will help Mr. Trump achieve his goal of increasing manufacturing employment in the United States. For example, businesses located in this country already produce about 70 percent of the steel used here. Experts say for every new job at a steel mill or aluminum smelter that is created by this trade decision, the country could lose as many or more jobs at businesses that use those metals, which will now cost more. This is one of the reasons that trade wars are, in fact, not easy to win.\n\nMr. Trump clearly sees trade as a zero-sum game. He and some of his most protectionist advisers, including Peter Navarro, think that if China and Mexico sell the United States more things than they import from America, they are winning. The president wants to turn the table on them with tariffs and other trade restrictions. But trade is much more complicated than that. Tariffs are blunt instruments that can hurt countries that use them, just as much as they can help.", "title": "Opinion | Trade Wars Are Destructive. Of Course Trump Wants One.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "That is, of course, a possibility. But it is not the only risk. The new tariffs will inflict damage on the American economy even absent retaliation from abroad. If history is any guide, Mr. Trump is proposing to protect the homeland by shooting it in the foot.\n\nThe closest parallel is the moment in 2002 when President George W. Bush decided that, for the umpteenth time, domestic steel makers deserved a hand and imposed tariffs of 8 to 30 percent on a variety of steel products from many countries.\n\nImports from the affected countries plummeted, of course. But others \u2014 in steel categories not covered by the safeguard and from excluded countries protected by preferential deals \u2014 surged. Overall steel imports increased 3 percent over the next 12 months. Employment in the American steel industry kept declining. And according to one study, by the time the tariffs were lifted in 2003, higher steel prices had cost 200,000 jobs in steel-using companies, more than all the jobs in the steel industry itself.\n\nUndeterred, President Barack Obama did roughly the same thing. After complaints about surging imports, he put tariffs on Chinese tires. Presumably nobody told him that American tire makers no longer produced the kind of low-grade tires exported by the Chinese. In any event, imports from other countries jumped 20 percent after the tariff was imposed. And the price of all imported tires rose by 18 percent, on average.\n\nGary Clyde Hufbauer and Sean Lowry at the Peterson Institute for International Economics calculated the additional cost to consumers at $1.1 billion \u2014 or about $900,000 per tire job saved. But the wages of workers whose jobs were saved amounted to about 5 percent of that.\n\nThe lesson is not that protectionism is porous. It is. And it can be gamed. Until a few years ago, Ford attached rear seats and rear windows to the Transit Connect vans it imported from its plant in Turkey. Once they had gone through customs \u2014 paying the 2.5 percent tariff on passenger vehicles instead of the heftier 25 percent levied on commercial vans \u2014 the seats and windows were ripped out and recycled.\n\nThe critical takeaway is that the distortions brought about by trade barriers impose a cost on the economy. It might not be easy to spot before the fact, but it tends to be more substantial than whatever fleeting gains protectionism can bring about to the protected.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThink of the multifiber agreement, which until its demise at the end of 2004 allowed the United States to impose individual quotas on thousands of pieces of apparel \u2014 cotton diapers from China, trousers from Guatemala. The rationale was to protect one of the lowest-wage industries in the country from lower wages in the developing world. A study by the United States International Trade Commission cited by the Dartmouth economist Douglas A. Irwin in his 2002 book, \u201cFree Trade Under Fire,\u201d concluded that it had raised apparel prices by 18 to 24 percent, imposing a particular burden on poor households.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSometimes the cost can squelch an industry. A 63 percent tariff on advanced flat-panel screens for laptop computers in 1991 helped drive a stake through the heart of the American laptop industry itself. Japan\u2019s Toshiba stopped making laptops in the United States. Apple moved production to Ireland. An IBM spokesman called the decision \u201can eviction notice from the U.S. government to the fastest-growing part of the U.S. computer industry.\u201d\n\nSimilarly, the ring of protection around the sugar industry almost killed it instead. Hoping to protect a price floor for sugar of 16.75 cents a pound even as world prices sank, in the 1980s Washington resorted to increasingly stringent import quotas that drove domestic sugar prices up to five times the world average.\n\nClever Canadian firms sent sugary cake mixes to the United States \u2014 where the sugar was extracted. Other countries grabbed on to the tactic. In 1985, Washington put emergency quotas on all imports of sweetened cocoa, cake mixes and edible preparations. South Korean noodles \u2014 with 0.002 percent sugar content \u2014 were snagged in the dragnet. So was kosher pizza from Israel.\n\nThen the unthinkable happened: Coke and Pepsi decided to replace expensive sugar with much cheaper high-fructose corn syrup. From 1980 to 1987, the share of sugar in American sweetener consumption, previously 65 percent, dropped to 47 percent.\n\n\u201cIn the longer term, this market reaction to the sugar program may indeed threaten the economic viability of the entire sugar industry in the United States,\u201d the economist Anne O. Krueger noted in an analysis of the sugar supports.\n\nSugar quotas are still around, nonetheless. Candy makers including Hershey and Ferrara have moved factories offshore. In 2006, the International Trade Administration concluded that for each sugar growing and harvesting job saved between 1997 and 2002, three confectionary manufacturing jobs were lost.\n\nSugar quotas even undermined American policy to counter narcotics trafficking. The Central Intelligence Agency concluded that falling sugar exports encouraged farmers in Jamaica and Belize to switch to marijuana.\n\nMr. Trump might look back fondly at that long-ago chicken tax. In the 1980s, Detroit did everything it could to fend off Japanese automakers. It persuaded the Reagan administration to force the Japanese into \u201cvoluntary\u201d export restraints on cars \u2014 raising car prices for American consumers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNothing was as successful as the chicken wall. It eroded over time. S.U.V.s were ultimately allowed into the United States as cars. Japanese automakers started making monster pickups and S.U.V.s in the United States, too. Still, fewer than a quarter of cars sold in the United States are made in America. The share for light trucks is 54 percent.\n\nBut there was a cost: more expensive pickup trucks, for starters, not to mention the discarded seats and windows from Ford\u2019s Transit Connects. The tariff also successfully kept smaller, low-margin trucks from competing with the less-efficient models made at home. Alongside low gasoline prices and easy fuel-economy standards, Detroit\u2019s love affair with trucks arguably gave the United States the least fuel-efficient fleet in the industrial world.\n\nIf gasoline prices were to rise \u2014 say, in an effort to combat climate change \u2014 a gas-guzzling domestic auto industry could prove a weak link in the nation\u2019s security.", "title": "Trade Wars Can Be a Game of Chicken. Sometimes, Literally.", "authors": ["Eduardo Porter", "Economic Scene"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Bad policies sometimes lead to interesting economics. For example, the disastrous turn toward austerity after 2009 was a kind of natural experiment that led to an upwelling of good work on the effects of fiscal policy.\n\nAnd I\u2019m starting to think that the Trumpian trade war, which finally seems to have arrived, will lead to some good work on international economic policy. Like the work on fiscal policy, it will of course be ignored by people in power. But still worth doing.\n\nIn this little essay I\u2019m going to offer some analysis and a few numbers based on a chain of thought that begins with Trump\u2019s evident disdain for Japan and ends up in Atlanta, New Orleans, and Buffalo. What? Bear with me if you have a taste for things wonkish.\n\nMy starting point is a peculiar aspect of Trump\u2019s climb-down on steel tariffs. The ostensible justification for these tariffs was national security; but as was widely noted from the start \u2013 although this probably came as news to the Trumpies \u2013 most U.S. steel imports come from American allies. And now Trump has granted exemptions to allies that largely vitiate the supposed point of the exercise.", "title": "Opinion | Trade and the Cities (Wonkish)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Brady Hill used his skills for buying and selling baseball cards to purchase his first car and to pay his way through Louisiana State University.\n\nNow that he\u2019s the chief executive of Greensource, one of the country\u2019s largest T-shirt printing companies, Mr. Hill is again devoting time and financial resources to his hobby.\n\n\u201cSeven or eight years ago, I went to see these cards I had in my safe deposit box that I was going to keep forever,\u201d said Mr. Hill, 47. \u201cI said, \u2018This is cool.\u2019 Then I looked on eBay and said, \u2018Wow, this is legit.\u2019\u201d\n\nPrices have certainly risen for collectible trading cards. Over the past decade, as the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index has roared back from the 2008 crash, an index of the top 500 baseball cards has done even better \u2014 beating it by more than double.", "title": "Trading Cards: A Hobby That Became a Multimillion-Dollar Investment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Are you now a cross-media star?\n\nI write things in the New Statesman. It\u2019s not mainstream news. I\u2019m not on TV. I\u2019m being played on the radio a bit at the moment. Ben and I have been lucky to evolve in different ways, which means we can carry on changing now. It\u2019s the result of having never let ourselves get too pinned-down.\n\nDon\u2019t all businesses encourage that?\n\nI think we had some kind of instinct that if we weren\u2019t careful at certain points we would get trapped. I started out in the Marine Girls, the archetypal indie band. I could see early on that could be limiting. There are loads of different boxes you can get put into. Sometimes the alternative box seems to be a route to freedom. But it often seemed narrow, with a lid on it like other boxes.\n\nWhat\u2019s more challenging these days, the music or writing business?\n\nI can\u2019t answer. I\u2019m making music from the position of someone who\u2019s had a long career. Same thing goes for writing. When I started making indie records I had the feeling that if you had a modicum of talent you could break into that scene. Nowadays my kids have friends who already are putting out their songs on SoundCloud. They\u2019re making music at a very sophisticated level because of the technology they use in their bedrooms, streets ahead of anything I could have achieved at their ages. But how they then distinguish themselves from all the other people who\u2019ve got access to the same technology, that\u2019s what makes it difficult.\n\n\u201cFace,\u201d a song on your new album, portrays your Twitter advocacy in reverse, addressing the incursion of the tech industry into romantic lives. Any secret to getting so much intersecting work accomplished?\n\nPeople sometimes identify Ben and me as very sensitive characters responding very sensitively to the world. That\u2019s a part of us. You can\u2019t defeat the mainstream music business. You just have to come to an accommodation with how you\u2019re going to work within its structure and still try and do what you want to do. If we were as sensitive as some people might imagine, I think Ben and I both might have been blown to pieces by our encounters with it.", "title": "Trading One Stage for Another", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cHow to Talk to Your Child\u2019s Doctor About Alternative Medicine\u201d (Here to Help, March 7) raises important issues but does so in a culturally insensitive manner that undermines the legitimacy of traditional medicine in modern life.\n\nThe writers, all doctors, encourage caution in the use of pseudoscientific treatments, and in doing so, don\u2019t acknowledge the role of traditional healers in the cultural life of many Americans.\n\nTraditional healing practices, like Ayurveda, Chinese medicine and Native American medicine, have existed for millenniums and provide health benefits. By suggesting caution in the case of \u201calternative\u201d treatments used largely by affluent white Americans, and ignoring traditional healing, the article underscores a larger issue in Western medicine: doctors\u2019 lack of cultural competence concerning indigenous and minority populations.\n\nIf Western medicine refuses to acknowledge the legitimacy of indigenous knowledge, then how can these populations learn to trust their health professionals?", "title": "Opinion | Traditional Medicine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "The director Eli Roth made his name with adults-only horror films like \u201cHostel,\u201d but he\u2019s setting out to scare a younger audience with \u201cThe House With a Clock in its Walls,\u201d which has just released its first trailer.\n\nAdapted by Eric Kripke (TV\u2019s \u201cSupernatural\u201d) from the young-adult novel by John Bellairs, the story follows an orphan, Lewis (Owen Vaccaro), who moves into the spooky titular abode with his uncle (Jack Black).\n\nAs if the unseen ticking timepiece weren\u2019t creepy enough, the home also features such haunted-house standbys as suits of armor, jack-o\u2019-lanterns and a tentacled monster that pops out of a closet. \u201cThat\u2019s safe?\u201d Lewis asks. His uncle reassures him, \u201cAs long as it\u2019s fed.\u201d\n\nMr. Black has enjoyed a lucrative run in family-oriented movies, from his 2003 breakout \u201cSchool of Rock\u201d to last year\u2019s smash \u201cJumanji: Welcome to the Jungle.\u201d His co-star, Cate Blanchett (as a bespectacled neighbor), also has experience in the genre, having played the evil stepmother in Disney\u2019s 2015 live-action remake of \u201cCinderella.\u201d", "title": "Trailer: \u2018The House With a Clock in Its Walls,\u2019 Starring Jack Black", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Brazil is a powerhouse when it comes to volleyball and the women\u2019s national team has twice won Olympic gold, in 2008 and 2012.\n\n\u201cJust like any other player, I\u2019d like to go to the Olympics,\u201d Ms. Abreu said in a postgame interview after greeting fans. \u201cBut I know it\u2019s not going to happen just because I\u2019m getting all this attention. I\u2019ve got to do my best as a player.\u201d\n\nMs. Abreu says she is trying to limit her media exposure after her success gave rise to widespread debate about whether male-to-female transitions give athletes an unfair advantage \u2014 an argument that has been going on at least since Ren\u00e9e Richards, a transgender woman professional tennis player, competed in the U.S. Open in 1977.\n\nAfter joining the women\u2019s professional league last year, Ms. Abreu\u2019s performance on the court quickly caught the nation\u2019s attention. In less than a month, she was scoring the highest number of points a game on average. And in January, she beat the record set by one of Brazil\u2019s Olympic stars, Tandara Caixeta, for total points scored in a single game: 39 (a record Ms. Caixeta has since matched).\n\nMs. Caixeta has helped fuel the debate about any edge transgender athletes may have.\n\n\u201cI really respect her and her history,\u201d Ms. Caixeta said in an interview given to sports journalists after her record was broken. \u201cBut I don\u2019t agree with her participating in the feminine Superliga. It\u2019s a very delicate issue and it\u2019s not homophobia. It\u2019s physiological.\u201d\n\nMs. Abreu began playing volleyball at the age of 17 and eventually made it to the men\u2019s professional leagues in Europe. Toward the end of her time there, she adopted the name Tifanny.\n\nIn 2012 she decided to begin her transition to a woman, even if it meant giving up volleyball.\n\n\u201cI knew I was a girl since I was a child,\u201d she said. \u201cI love volleyball, but it is just my job. The day I\u2019m no longer working, I\u2019ll still be happy because I am me, Tifanny, the person I always imagined.\u201d", "title": "Transgender Volleyball Star in Brazil Eyes Olympics and Stirs Debate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA young black transgender woman was shot dead in a Louisiana motel this week, becoming at least the seventh transgender woman known to have been killed in the United States this year, rights advocates said.\n\nThe woman, Amia Tyrae, 28, was killed Monday at about 1:15 a.m. at a motel on Airline Highway, according to the Baton Rouge Police Department.\n\nDr. William Clark, the East Baton Rouge Parish coroner, ruled Ms. Tyrae\u2019s death a homicide, caused by a gunshot wound to the chest.\n\nThe Police Department said Friday night that Dedrick Butler, 22, of Denham Springs, La., had been arrested in the killing. He was charged with second-degree murder, possession of a firearm by a convicted felon, and possession of a firearm with an obliterated serial number.\n\nBetween 25 to 28 transgender people were reported killed in the United States last year, the highest number in at least a decade, according to a report by the Human Rights Campaign and the Trans People of Color Coalition. The violence disproportionately affects transgender women of color.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe killing of Ms. Tyrae came less than a month after the shooting death of another transgender woman, Phylicia Mitchell, 46, outside her apartment in Cleveland on Feb. 23. But its reasoning could have influence elsewhere.\n\nAs it embraced a broad view of protections under Title VII, the court also rejected an expansive interpretation of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act.", "title": "Transgender Workers Gain New Protection Under Court Ruling", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Relatives recounted hauntingly similar stories of speaking by phone to loved ones trapped in the flames \u2014 but being unable to help them.\n\nPhoto\n\nAleksandr and Olga Lillevyali told Meduza.io, a news website, that their three daughters had been watching \u201cSherlock Gnomes\u201d when smoke began to fill the theater.\n\n\u201cMy daughter kept calling me,\u201d Mr. Lillevyali said, with tears in his eyes. \u201cI only shouted to her that she should try to get out of the hall, but I couldn\u2019t do anything. There was only fire in front of me.\u201d\n\nIgor Vostrikov, a local businessman, lost three children in the fire and also his wife, Yelena, and sister. They were all trapped in the theater.\n\n\u201cLena called from there,\u201d Mr. Vostrikov told Komsomolskaya Pravda. \u201cShe shouted, \u2018Help us, rescue us, we have been locked up.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe fire started around 5 p.m. on the fourth floor of the mall, which includes a three-screen cinema complex, a skating rink and an entertainment center for children.\n\nAmong those at the mall when the fire broke out were schoolchildren there to celebrate the beginning of the spring break. They were from Treshchyovsky, a little village 25 miles away from Kemerovo.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSix girls died in the fire. One of them, Vilena Chernikova, wrote, \u201cI love myself and my family,\u201d in her last message on a social media website.\n\nVideo\n\nVladimir Chernov, a deputy governor of the Kemerovo region, said the blaze had started in the children\u2019s entertainment room, where there was a trampoline with foam rubber that caught fire.\n\nVideos posted on social media showed black smoke billowing from the mall\u2019s roof and windows, and people jumping from upper floors to escape the flames, with nothing below to cushion their fall.\n\nVladimir Puchkov, the emergency situations minister, said that six people were still missing and 13 were hospitalized, including a teenager in grave condition.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. This past Thursday, board members of Oslo\u2019s Port Authority approved a pioneering trash-removal plan.\n\n\u201cWe will test out drones,\u201d said Svein Olav Lunde, the chief technical officer of the Oslo Port Authority, shortly after the meeting, explaining how these unmanned vessels will be used to help clear out underwater \u201cislands of trash.\u201d\n\nGeir Rognlien Elgvin, a board member, says he believes that Oslo\u2019s port will be the first in the world to try this sort of trash pickup. The drones will plunge into the depths of Oslo Fjord this spring. An electric-powered ship with a crane will join the cleanup fleet by next year.\n\nOslo is turning to drone technology partly because of a dead dolphin \u2014 bloodied, beached and ensnared in plastic. Gory images of the carcass, taken in January on a trash-strewn shore of Oslo Fjord, resonated on social media among Norwegians, who tend to see their jagged coastline as a paragon of untouched natural beauty.\n\nMr. Stubberud said that recent images of beached dolphins and whales have woken up Norway, but that \u201cplastic is the real problem.\u201d Politicians and the public have shown more interest in the cleanup campaign in the past two years, he said.", "title": "Trash in the Fjords? Norway Turns to Drones", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "For Lisa Christie, an architect in Portland, Ore., the idea of installing a dog shower came gradually. An outdoorsy client wanted a spot in the mudroom to rinse off his climbing gear. About a month into the project, he declared his intention to get a dog, so she raised the floor of the mini-shower to make it more comfortable for soaping and rinsing a pet, and added a towel rod.\n\n\u201cIf someone buys the house in the future and they don\u2019t have a dog, it\u2019s still a really useful thing,\u201d she said. Hayley Krischer\n\nBest Commute Ever\n\nBackyard work sheds flourish in the gig economy\n\nIn a cozy backyard in Chico, Calif., Hans Stullken, 35, an executive with a company that installs solar-electric equipment, built a 10-by-12-foot shed that functions as a detached work space \u2014 he and his wife call it their \u201ccasita.\u201d\n\nThe stucco-and-concrete exterior mirrors the look of the main house, and hovering over the desk inside is a 15-foot-high loft with a queen-size bed for guests. \u201cThe shed is a good way to compartmentalize work and home. You don\u2019t have any distractions, and you can leave your work there, not on the dining room table or bedroom,\u201d Mr. Stullken said.\n\nSheds, which have traditionally been used for stowing lawn mowers, tools and cobwebs, have become convenient garden domiciles, often designed without the headache of permits (height limits still apply). These micro-footprint extensions appeal to the increasing number of Americans who are working from home \u2014 43 percent of employees work remotely part of the time, according to a 2017 Gallup survey. Whether converted, constructed or prefabricated \u2014 sheds that are conceived and assembled offsite \u2014 the space must be outfitted for comfort. \u201cMost sheds aren\u2019t designed for human habitation,\u201d said Eric Enns, the owner of Modern Spaces and Sheds, which built the Stullkens\u2019 shed.", "title": "Trends in Design and Architecture", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Later he or the company adapted the elbow-grease concept to other uses, like powering flashlights and charging cellphones. And, Mr. Bunting said, Mr. Baylis\u2019s idea influenced others.\n\n\u201cAlthough the original clockwork technology was overtaken subsequently,\u201d he said by email, \u201cit triggered the idea that renewable technologies could be used to bring benefits in places where more conventional power sources were not available or too expensive.\u201d\n\nIn 2003 Mr. Baylis, partly because of the frustrations he had encountered, created Trevor Baylis Brands to help other inventors develop their ideas and, just as important, protect them.\n\n\u201cI want to make sure that when the money rolls in, he or she is not rolled out,\u201d he said in a 2012 interview. \u201cWe have to entice people to have a go.\u201d\n\nMr. Baylis was born on May 13, 1937, in Kilburn, a suburb of London. His father, Cecil, was an engineer, and his mother, Glad, was an artist.\n\nIn 1998 he told The Daily Mail that when he was 6 he was raped by a curate at his church.\n\n\u201cWhat happened made me arrogant and insular,\u201d he said. \u201cI am impervious to other people\u2019s opinions. It made me self-reliant and independent, and you need to be like that to be an inventor.\u201d\n\nThe family was not well off when he was young, so he did odd jobs to help out, including, at age 9, working a milk route with a horse and cart.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI remember that the horse, Gip, knew exactly where to drop off the milk,\u201d he told The Telegraph in 2015. \u201cShe was marvelous.\u201d\n\nHe left school, but while working in a soil mechanics laboratory in Southall as a teenager he began studying engineering part time at a local technical college. After serving in the Army, Mr. Baylis, an excellent swimmer, sold swimming pools, sometimes diving from 10 feet into shallow water as part of the sales pitch. He also worked in the Berlin Circus as an underwater escape artist.\n\nThe human-powered radio was far from his first invention. Earlier in his eclectic career he had a particular concern for the needs of people with disabilities, which inspired him to invent dozens of devices, like a bottle opener designed to be used with one hand.\n\nMr. Baylis said it took him only about a half-hour of fiddling in his workshop to come up with a working version of a hand-powered radio, but turning the idea into a product took a lot longer. None of the electronics manufacturers he wrote to were interested.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t until he told his story and spoke of his frustrations on the BBC series \u201cTomorrow\u2019s World\u201d in 1994 that an entrepreneur, Chris Staines, became involved, setting up a factory in South Africa under the name BayGen that was staffed by people with disabilities. A 1995 television program chronicled Mr. Baylis\u2019s introduction to that facility.\n\n\u201cTrevor burst into tears when he walked through the door,\u201d a reviewer for The Independent wrote, \u201cso that much of what he said subsequently was subject to sniffly interference, as if his own mainspring was winding down. You gathered that he was happy and proud \u2014 and justifiably so.\u201d\n\nLater that year Reuters reported that 60,000 of the radios had already been ordered by aid organizations operating in Rwanda, and BayGen said the radios would also soon be in use in Bosnia, which was then in the midst of a war. Today, renamed Freeplay Energy, the company has products aimed at the developing world, emergency preparedness providers and the outdoor leisure market.\n\nMr. Baylis, who leaves no immediate survivors, became a sought-after speaker. In his later years he put much of his effort into advising other inventors through Trevor Baylis Brands. His autobiography, \u201cClock This: My Life as an Inventor,\u201d was published in 1999.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2000, Mr. Baylis walked 100 miles across the Namib Desert \u2014 partly for a charitable cause, but also to demonstrate a new invention, electric shoes. A pouch on the side of the shoe held electronic gear that generated electricity from the walking motion.\n\nThe next year, though, a terrorist tried to blow up an American Airlines plane with a shoe bomb, and Mr. Baylis acknowledged that the incident had created a marketing problem for his electric shoe.\n\n\u201cThe only trouble is that having a pouch full of electronics on the side of the shoe invites you to have four bullets in the brain,\u201d he told TechWeekEurope, \u201cbecause they think you might be a shoe bomber. Try going to an airport wearing one of those!\u201d", "title": "Trevor Baylis, Inventor of a Radio Powered by Muscle, Dies at 80", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night\u2019s highlights that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy.
