View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Kabealo said the president\u2019s order could dramatically change the world of mergers and acquisitions and open the door to the possibility that more bankers and lawyers would use reviews by the foreign investment committee to block hostile takeovers on national security grounds.\n\nThe president said his decision to block Broadcom\u2019s bid had been based on the review by the foreign investment committee. The panel had said that the leadership of Qualcomm, which makes wireless chips and also licenses key wireless patents, was too important to let go of. The committee argued that economic leadership in next-generation high-speed mobile networks known as 5G, in which Qualcomm is a key player, was also a national security interest.\n\n\u201cChina would likely compete robustly to fill any void left by Qualcomm as a result of this hostile takeover,\u201d a United States Treasury official wrote in a letter to the companies last week.\n\nAs part of the presidential order, the United States also barred the 15 individuals who Broadcom had proposed for Qualcomm\u2019s board from running, saying they were \u201cdisqualified from standing for election as directors of Qualcomm.\u201d\n\nQualcomm acknowledged receiving the presidential order and said it had been told to reconvene its shareholder meeting at the earliest possible date, March 23.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA presidential action against foreign investment in an American company is rare and has only taken place four times in the past 30 years, according to the law firm Ropes & Gray. Scrutiny of foreign companies buying United States assets ramped up under President Barack Obama, including a presidential order barring a Chinese company from purchasing Aixtron, a German company with American assets, on national security grounds in 2016.\n\nUnder Mr. Trump, several deals involving foreign buyers have been squelched after a review by the foreign investment committee, including Moneygram\u2019s sale to an affiliate of the Alibaba Group and Lattice Semiconductor\u2019s sale to an investment firm with reported ties to the Chinese government. But the action against Broadcom was unusual because mergers are rarely killed before a publicly traded company\u2019s shareholders are given the chance to decide on the offer for themselves.\n\nThe decision was a blow to Broadcom, which under its chief executive, Hock Tan, has built itself up through several acquisitions. Mr. Tan had gone to great lengths to deflect concerns by American regulators and the Trump administration, including appearing in a televised speech at the White House with Mr. Trump last November, during which Mr. Tan promised to redomicile Broadcom in the United States.\n\nBroadcom had at one point in its negotiations with Qualcomm also offered to raise its offer to acquire the company. After the foreign investment committee announced its investigation into the Qualcomm bid this month, Broadcom hastened plans to move its headquarters to the United States and sent a letter to lawmakers promising it would not slow research and development in 5G networking technology if the merger were approved.", "title": "Trump Blocks Broadcom\u2019s Bid for Qualcomm", "authors": ["Cecilia Kang", "Alan Rappeport"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "A day after stunning markets, Republican lawmakers and even his own advisers by announcing stiff tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, President Trump doubled down on his approach on Friday, saying in an early morning tweet that \u201cTrade wars are good, and easy to win.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump appeared eager to defend his decision to levy sweeping tariffs on all imports of those metals, issuing a series of morning tweets explaining the need for tariffs. \u201cOur steel industry is in bad shape. IF YOU DON\u2019T HAVE STEEL, YOU DON\u2019T HAVE A COUNTRY!\u201d he said in one tweet.\n\nMarkets fell in response to Mr. Trump\u2019s announcement on Thursday that he would impose tariffs of 25 percent on steel and 10 percent on aluminum, effectively placing a tax on every foreign shipment of those metals into the United States. Mr. Trump, at a hastily arranged meeting with industry executives on Thursday, said he would formally sign the trade measures next week and promised they would be in effect \u201cfor a long period of time.\u201d\n\nOn Friday, he wrote that the measures would help to reduce the trade deficit, which is the gap between what the United States exports to other countries and what it imports. Mr. Trump has long lambasted the trade deficit as a sign of United States weakness.", "title": "Trump Calls Trade Wars \u2018Good\u2019 and \u2018Easy to Win\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "In the days after an \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d video exposed his own lewd comments about women during the final month of the campaign, Mr. Trump responded by showing up at his debate with Hillary Clinton with three women who had accused Bill Clinton of sexual improprieties.\n\nAs a candidate, and as president, Mr. Trump has eagerly attacked just about all of his enemies and accusers, often with colorful nicknames like \u201cLittle Rocket Man\u201d for the North Korean leader, \u201cCrazy Joe Biden\u201d or \u201cSloppy Steve\u201d Bannon.\n\nBut for now, it appears that the president is listening to \u2014 and accepting \u2014 his advisers\u2019 warnings on the dangers of speaking out about the women, much the way he followed the advice of his lawyers for a year not to attack Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel in the Russia inquiry.\n\nRecently, he has ditched that advice, attacking Mr. Mueller and his team directly on Twitter. That leaves only his alleged mistresses and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as people who are immune to Mr. Trump\u2019s Twitter trash-talk.\n\nRaj Shah, a deputy White House press secretary, declined to say \u201cwhat the president may or may not have seen\u201d on television Sunday night, though he said that Mr. Trump denies the allegations that Ms. Clifford made in the CBS interview.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ll just say that he\u2019s consistently denied these allegations,\u201d Mr. Shah said. \u201cThe president doesn\u2019t believe that any of the claims that Ms. Daniels made last night in the interview are accurate.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump dined at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida on Saturday evening with Michael D. Cohen, his lawyer and longtime aide who is at the center of the Clifford scandal, according to three people familiar with the get-together. The president scheduled the meeting himself, surprising his aides with it a short time before Mr. Cohen arrived, people familiar with the meeting said.", "title": "Trump Can\u2019t Stop Tweeting, but Goes Silent on Stormy Daniels", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "To understand why, one needs to understand exactly what sanctuary laws do. They draw their name from the sanctuary movement of the 1980s. During that period, Central American refugees were routinely denied asylum because the United States government supported the regimes from which they had fled. In the face of this injustice, some religious leaders took steps to actively prevent federal immigration officers from arresting and deporting these vulnerable immigrants. It was, at times, a form of civil disobedience.\n\nToday\u2019s sanctuary laws, while bearing the same name, are markedly different. California and the hundreds of other places across the country with such laws and policies have done nothing whatsoever to actively interfere with federal immigration enforcement efforts. Rather, the defining characteristic of these laws is their passivity. They do not direct state officers to take any steps to interfere with federal enforcement efforts. Instead, they dictate that the local police and state officers simply do not assist in the federal government\u2019s deportation agenda \u2014 that they do nothing.\n\nThis may sound like an overly formal distinction, since both efforts have made it harder for the federal government to deport people. To be sure, the decision of local and state officials not to lend their resources to immigration enforcement efforts means that either there will be fewer deportations or the deportations will be more expensive for the federal government. This is one reason these laws have so rankled Mr. Trump and Mr. Sessions.\n\nThe Justice Department lawsuit emphasizes that immigration is a federal matter, that we must have a uniform scheme to oversee it and that this scheme is being undermined by sanctuary laws. In most states, federal immigration authorities are able to leverage state and local criminal justice systems. The Justice Department is arguing that California\u2019s refusal to participate requires it to adapt and employ different enforcement strategies.\n\nIt is fair to ask whether states should have the power to abstain from federal law enforcement programs that they view as immoral or adverse to their local interests. It is not, however, a new question.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Can\u2019t Stop the Sanctuary Movement", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The news of the appointment competed with an exclusive interview on CNN of a former Playboy model, Karen McDougal, who described to Anderson Cooper what she said was a 10-month sexual relationship with Mr. Trump in 2006. Mr. Trump has denied the affair.\n\nIn his interview on Fox News, Mr. Bolton declined to discuss his views on Iran, Russia or North Korea, though he acknowledged his positions were hardly a mystery after years of writing and speaking. He described the job of national security adviser as making sure that the bureaucracy did not impede the decisions of the president.\n\nOfficials said that General McMaster\u2019s departure was a mutual decision and amicable, with little of the recrimination that marked Mr. Tillerson\u2019s exit. They said it was not related to a leak on Tuesday of briefing materials for Mr. Trump\u2019s phone call with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, which infuriated the president and did not help General McMaster\u2019s case. Mr. Bolton complained on Fox News that \u201ca munchkin in the executive branch\u201d was responsible for the leak and called it \u201ccompletely unacceptable.\u2019\u2019\n\nMr. Trump issued a statement that coincided with his tweet. \u201cH. R. McMaster has served his country with distinction for more than 30 years,\u201d the statement said. \u201cHe has won many battles and his bravery and toughness are legendary. General McMaster\u2019s leadership of the National Security Council staff has helped my administration accomplish great things to bolster America\u2019s national security.\u201d\n\nGeneral McMaster said in a telephone interview on Thursday that his departure had been under discussion for weeks, and, \u201creally, the only issue that had been left open is timing.\u201d He would have preferred to stay in the West Wing until the summer, but the timing was dictated by \u201cwhat was best for him and the country,\u201d he said, referring to the president.", "title": "Trump Chooses Bolton for 3rd Security Adviser as Shake-Up Continues", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "In the years ahead, it wants to emphasize more sophisticated goods like robotic arms and electric cars that count steel and aluminum only as ingredients.\n\nTake the Chengkouzhen plant. It is involved in the process of turning raw materials into raw aluminum, which will be hit by Mr. Trump\u2019s tariffs.\n\nBut the same owner operates another plant \u2014 and that plant is still humming. That plant, in the city of Zouping 90 miles away, takes raw aluminum and turns it into car parts. Most of those won\u2019t be affected by the tariffs.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cEvery day here, the factory is working as usual,\u201d said Geng Peiguo, a 67-year-old in a reflective yellow safety vest who cleans the street in front of the parts factory. A loud clanging emerged from the factory, which was the size of several football fields.\n\nEven before the tariffs, China\u2019s vast steel exports to the rest of the world were falling, stemmed by Beijing\u2019s efforts to shrink the industry as well as by improved demand at home. China\u2019s aluminum exports are rising, but at only a fraction of their earlier pace.\n\nChina will not give up its old ways overnight, as some local officials look to bolster local employment and short-term economic growth. Even as the Chengkouzhen factory lies dormant, more raw aluminum operations are set to open. Morgan Stanley, the American bank, estimates that Chinese aluminum companies are set to expand capacity by 11 percent, though it noted that the government might discourage some of those projects.\n\n\n\nLast year, Beijing propped up the publicly traded subsidiary of debt-laden Aluminum Corporation of China Limited, converting about $2 billion in loans into equity to be held by China\u2019s state-controlled firms. The move was part of a broader effort to keep debt from hobbling the economy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStill, China contends that it is addressing its wasteful factory problem and that American tariffs are unnecessary. Last week, the government-controlled association that oversees aluminum production called for retaliation against a wide variety of American products.\n\nChina accounts for only a small fraction of American aluminum and steel imports. As with the steel industry, aluminum manufacturers in the United States say China sends its cheap aluminum to other markets. That drives down global prices, and prompts producers elsewhere, notably Canada, to ship more to the United States instead.\n\nOther Shores China produces more than half of the world's steel and aluminum but exports only small amounts to the United States, thanks to strong demand at home, existing American tariffs and other reasons. Steel Aluminum 52% 25% Other countries 8 U.A.E. 9 Russia 6 European Union 41 5 21 18 Canada 11 China 3 China Canada European Union Russia U.A.E. Other countries Aluminum 11% 41 6 9 8 25 Steel 3 18 21 5 52\n\nThe two factories, in Chengkouzhen and Zouping, show how Chinese officials will help some factories even as they allow others to close.\n\nTheir owner, Qixing Group, employs about 12,000 people across Shandong Province in eastern China. Qixing ran out of money after it overextended itself into real estate and other businesses. Last year it looked as if it might close.\n\nThe two factories then met different fates.\n\nIn Zouping, after some workers demonstrated, local officials stepped in. They helped provide two-thirds pay for the workers and get the company partly back in operation, according to two people familiar with the payments who asked not to be identified because the local authorities consider the matter sensitive.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile it is not clear how many people Qixing employs in Zouping, the aluminum industry is a major presence. Factories owned by Qixing and others get power from a chain of huge coal-fired plants sporting 13 hourglass-shaped, 300-foot-tall cooling towers, about six times as many as a traditional coal plant. An overhead cobweb of ultra-high-voltage power lines connects the power stations to the city\u2019s voracious aluminum smelters.\n\nThe Zouping factory\u2019s workers are still nervous. They worry that the American tariffs will end up hitting the business, or that the government may decide to let the factory close after all. While the factory remains open, two of the four kilns at Qixing\u2019s smelter in Zouping have been shut down.\n\n\u201cIf Qixing goes bankrupt and my husband is laid off, how could we make a living?\u201d said Liu Guifang, a full-time mother whose husband and sister work for Qixing. \u201cI have a 13-year-old daughter and a 1-year-old son.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nZhang Hui, a Qixing electrician, criticized Mr. Trump\u2019s tariffs. But he was just certified as a master electrician and plans to look for a job at an electronic devices manufacturer if Qixing shuts down entirely.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI am very grateful to Qixing, which let me afford to buy an apartment and car and raise two sons,\u201d Mr. Zhang said. \u201cBut I don\u2019t feel appalled at Qixing\u2019s current situation. It was going to happen at some point.\u201d\n\nIn Chengkouzhen, local officials saw fewer reasons to keep the factory open.\n\nThe streets around the factory are silent. The factory, with its 15 hulking concrete silos as tall as eight-story buildings, used to import bauxite ore mined from West Africa and Australia. The factory would mix the ore with chemicals and heat it to separate alumina from the ore \u2014 the first step in producing raw aluminum.\n\nWhen Ms. Li and her husband moved to Chengkouzhen five years ago from a town a half-hour\u2019s drive inland, they thought that their new jobs would bring them firmly into China\u2019s increasingly prosperous class of heavy-industry workers.\n\nThen came the shutdown last spring. By late summer, with the equipment polished to a shine, maintenance duty became a mandatory holiday for all but a handful of workers. Autumn and then winter\u2019s snows arrived, and the kilns at the factory never turned back on.\n\nThe remaining workers subsist on partial pay, commonly disbursed with government assistance in China to stem unrest. Some are paid to keep the lights on.\n\n\u201cWe had heard the Qixing factory had good profits and offered high salaries,\u201d Ms. Li said. \u201cWho knew it would just collapse?\u201d", "title": "Trump Condemns Chinese Factories. China Is Already Closing Some.", "authors": ["Keith Bradsher", "Ailin Tang"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump, a senior official said, signed off on the sanctions and the harsh language in the administration\u2019s statements. But he was determined not to antagonize Mr. Putin, this person said, because he believes his leader-to-leader rapport is the only way to improve relations between the two countries.\n\nThat strategy has put Mr. Trump at odds with his own advisers: in preparing the president for the call, aides advised him to raise the nerve-agent attack and wrote on his briefing materials, \u201cDO NOT CONGRATULATE.\u201d The Washington Post first reported these details.\n\nA second official, however, said that while Mr. Trump\u2019s briefing cards did contain those suggestions, he spoke to his aides by phone and never saw the cards.\n\nThe White House also insisted that it was not the place of the United States to question how other countries conduct their elections \u2014 a contention that is at odds with years of critical statements about foreign elections by the United States, as well as recent statements by the Trump administration about elections in Venezuela and Iran.\n\n\u201cWhat we do know is that Putin has been elected in their country, and that\u2019s not something we can dictate to them how they operate,\u201d said the press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders. \u201cWe can only focus on the freeness and fairness of our elections, something we 100 percent fully support.\u201d\n\nEchoing the president, she went on to rail against the investigation of the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, into links between the Trump campaign and Russia.\n\n\u201cTo pretend like going through this absurd process for over a year would not bring frustration seems a little bit ridiculous,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Sanders noted that other foreign leaders, including Chancellor Angela Merkel, of Germany, had called Mr. Putin. Ms. Merkel\u2019s office released a terse account of their call, saying she had told the Russian president, \u201cToday, it is more important than ever to continue the dialogue with one another and to foster relations between our states and peoples.\u201d\n\nRepublican lawmakers, even those who have resisted criticizing Mr. Trump, faulted him for congratulating Mr. Putin.\n\n\u201cWhen I look at a Russian election, what I see is a lack of credibility in tallying the results,\u201d said the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky. \u201cCalling him wouldn\u2019t have been high on my list.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSenator John McCain of Arizona, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, was harsher.\n\n\u201cAn American president does not lead the free world by congratulating dictators on winning sham elections,\u201d he said in a statement. \u201cAnd by doing so with Vladimir Putin, President Trump insulted every Russian citizen who was denied the right to vote in a free and fair election to determine their country\u2019s future, including the countless Russian patriots who have risked so much to protest and resist Putin\u2019s regime.\u201d\n\nIn fact, both Presidents Barack Obama and George W. Bush called to congratulate Mr. Putin after previous election victories.\n\nIn Mr. Obama\u2019s case, said Michael A. McFaul, who served as ambassador to Moscow during the Obama administration, there was lively internal debate about whether, and when, the president should make that call. Mr. Obama waited several days after Mr. Putin\u2019s election in March 2012 before calling.\n\nAfter that election, the State Department issued a statement in which it said, \u201cThe United States congratulates the Russian people on the completion of the presidential elections, and looks forward to working with the president-elect after the results are certified and he is sworn in.\u201d\n\nThe language, Mr. McFaul said, was carefully chosen to applaud the Russian people for voting without praising Mr. Putin for winning. The statement also noted the reservations of outside observers about the \u201cpartisan use of government resources, and procedural irregularities on Election Day,\u201d though it credited the Russian authorities for reforms after a widely criticized parliamentary election the previous December.\n\nThe parliamentary election drew condemnation from Hillary Clinton, then the secretary of state, who said the Russian people, \u201clike people everywhere, deserve the right to have their voices heard and their votes counted.\u201d Her statement planted the seeds for the antipathy between her and Mr. Putin, who accused her of fomenting unrest in Russia.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis time, Mr. Putin prevailed with more than 76 percent of the vote. International observers said Russian electoral authorities counted the votes efficiently, but that several other factors prevented the contest from being fair.\n\n\u201cRestrictions on the fundamental freedoms of assembly, association and expression, as well as on candidate registration, have limited the space for political engagement and resulted in a lack of genuine competition,\u201d observers from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe said in a report.\n\nDuring their call on Tuesday, a senior official said, Mr. Trump told Mr. Putin he had been concerned by a recent speech in which Mr. Putin talked about Russia developing an \u201cinvincible\u201d intercontinental cruise missile and a nuclear torpedo that could outsmart all American defenses.\n\nMr. Putin\u2019s presentation included animated videos depicting multiple warheads aimed at Florida, where the president often stays at his Mar-a-Lago resort. Mr. Trump raised the nuclear threat in calls with Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain, President Emmanuel Macron of France and Ms. Merkel.\n\nMore recently, however, Mr. Trump noted that Mr. Putin had taken a more moderate tone, talking about the need to de-escalate the nuclear arms race between Russia and the United States.\n\nMr. Trump, this official said, told Mr. Putin that he welcomed the shift in tone. But Mr. Trump reminded Mr. Putin that his administration was spending $700 billion to upgrade the American military, and that the United States would win any arms race between the two.\n\n\u201cWe will never allow anybody to have anything even close to what we have,\u201d Mr. Trump told reporters.", "title": "Trump Congratulates Putin, but Doesn\u2019t Mention Meddling in U.S.", "authors": ["Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Update, March 22, 2018: John Dowd, the president\u2019s lead lawyer in the special counsel\u2019s investigation, has resigned. Read the latest, here.\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump\u2019s legal team was poised for a shake-up on Monday, according to two people briefed on the matter, as he openly discussed firing one of his lawyers, another considered resigning and a third \u2014 who pushed theories on television that Mr. Trump was framed by the F.B.I. \u2014 joined the roster.\n\nMr. Trump has weighed aloud in recent days to close associates whether to dismiss his lawyer Ty Cobb, who had pushed most strongly a strategy of cooperating fully with the special counsel investigation. The president reassured Mr. Cobb that he had no plans to fire him, according to a person who spoke with the president late Monday, in part to prevent a narrative that his team was in disarray after The New York Times began making inquiries.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s lead lawyer, John Dowd, has contemplated leaving his post because he has concluded that he has no control over the behavior of the president, the two people briefed on the matter said. Ignoring his lawyers\u2019 advice, Mr. Trump has reverted to a more aggressive strategy of publicly assailing the inquiry that he initially adopted in the weeks immediately after the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, was appointed. Flood, who represented President Bill Clinton during his impeachment process, had met with Mr. Trump in the Oval Office last week. It said that Mr. Trump had not made a final decision on whether to bring on Mr. Flood, who would help the White House manage its contacts with the Justice Department.\n\nThe Times said there had been signs in recent months that Mr. Trump might be looking to shake up his legal team as the special counsel inquiry stretches beyond the timeline given to him by Ty Cobb, the lawyer leading the Trump team\u2019s response to the investigation.", "title": "Trump Disputes Times Report on His Legal Team", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI don\u2019t think he came to the meeting with his mind made up,\u201d Ms. Henson said. \u201cI think there\u2019s more fact-finding to be done before anything is acted on.\u201d\n\nAs with his thoughts on gun restrictions, it remains unclear exactly what Mr. Trump thinks can be done on this issue, or what he truly believes. But he has a parent\u2019s insight on how young people encounter violent media. In a February round table he hosted with lawmakers on gun restrictions, the president said some content viewed by his 11-year-old son, Barron, had surprised him.\n\n\u201cThe video games, the movies, the internet stuff is so violent. It\u2019s so incredible. I see it,\u201d Mr. Trump said. \u201cI look at some of the things he\u2019s watching, and I say, \u2018How is that possible?\u2019 And this is what kids are watching. And I think you maybe have to take a look at it.\u201d\n\nThe administrations of President Bill Clinton and President Barack Obama had tried to understand the issue with wide-ranging initiatives and recommendations after massacres at Columbine High School in 1999 and Sandy Hook Elementary School in 2012. Mr. Clinton ordered an investigation into advertising practices used to sell violent entertainment. And in 2013, Mr. Obama asked Congress to provide $10 million to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to study the relationship between violence and video games. The funds were never allocated.\n\nPeople involved in listening tours during past administrations doubted that Mr. Trump\u2019s meeting would lead to productive policy. Mark DeLoura, who worked as a digital media adviser in the Obama White House, said that a similar meeting after Sandy Hook had been \u201cwell rounded,\u201d and that the recommendations that came out of that wide-ranging listening tour were concrete.", "title": "Trump Draws \u2018Lively\u2019 Opinions on Video Game Violence but Shrouds His Own", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "On their own, the tariffs appear unlikely to affect growth or inflation to a great degree, economists said. Mr. Trump\u2019s tariffs \u201cwould by themselves have only a small macroeconomic impact,\u201d said Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Moody\u2019s Analytics and a vocal critic of Mr. Trump\u2019s trade agenda during the campaign. Mr. Zandi said they were likely to add not quite 0.1 percentage points to inflation, which is currently hovering just under 2 percent, and to reduce economic growth by only a few hundredths of a percentage point.\n\nWhat worries many economists, particularly on Wall Street, is the prospect that Mr. Trump is set to launch a broader trade war. The national security grounds he is invoking as rationale for the tariffs could provoke swift retaliation from trading partners such as Canada, which will be affected far more by the measures than China will.\n\n\u201cThis is likely to escalate trade tensions,\u201d economists at Goldman Sachs wrote on Thursday, \u201cparticularly as it looks likely to apply to a broad group of countries including to some allies of the U.S. We expect further disruptive trade developments over the coming months.\u201d\n\nThe tariffs could also bring condemnation from the World Trade Organization \u2014 and a potentially dramatic showdown if the United States ignores rulings from the group, which has been marginalized by the Trump administration.\n\nIf such problems spiral worldwide, Mr. Zandi said, \u201ca particularly dark scenario could end in a global trade war. The economic fallout from such a war could be serious, ending in a global recession.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOther liberal economists caution that such a scenario remains unlikely. \u201cI\u2019d expect some counter-tariffs on our exports, maybe from China on food products\u201d as a result of the tariffs, said Jared Bernstein, a former Obama administration economist who is now at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities. \u201cYou always hear trade war at these moments. That doesn\u2019t mean that\u2019s always wrong, but it usually is.\u201d\n\nFrom the beginning of his insurgent 2016 presidential campaign, Mr. Trump has seen \u201cwinning\u201d on trade \u2014 measured by reducing bilateral trade deficits, particularly with China, the trading partner Mr. Trump is most concerned with \u2014 as critical for boosting the economy. Reducing trade deficits, he has argued, will work in tandem with lowering taxes and reducing federal regulations, to supercharge growth.\n\nMr. Trump took several steps last year to freeze or roll back regulations, and he signed a $1.5 trillion tax-cut bill in December. He also took initial steps to reorient trade policy, pulling out of the Trans-Pacific Partnership and embarking on a fractious renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement. But while economic growth accelerated, the trade deficit in goods and services widened to $566 billion for the year, the largest amount since 2008. The goods deficit with China hit $375 billion, a record.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe tariffs Mr. Trump announced Thursday were his boldest move yet on trade, and a sign of resurgent power in the White House for economic adviser Peter Navarro and Commerce Secretary Wilbur L. Ross Jr., who have long pushed Mr. Trump to act more aggressively on trade, which was a signature campaign issue. They were a reminder to the Republican establishment that Mr. Trump\u2019s theory of the economy is sometimes at odds with traditional free-market conservatism, for as much as they overlap.\n\nOn Thursday, the conservative Wall Street Journal editorial board called the tariffs the \u201cbiggest policy blunder of his Presidency.\u201d\n\nThe move is also at odds with a broad and bipartisan swath of previous top White House economists, going back several administrations, who urged Mr. Trump in a letter last year \u201cto avoid a policy that would likely incur greater economic and diplomatic costs than any conceivable national security gain.\u201d Jerome H. Powell, the new Federal Reserve chairman appointed by Mr. Trump, told Congress on Thursday that \u201cthe tariff approach is not the best approach\u201d for trade disputes.\n\nMr. Trump, though, casts himself as protecting an industry he sees as endangered; raw steel production in America remains higher than it was 25 years ago, but it is down dramatically from the 1970s. As he tweeted on Friday:\n\nSuch rhetoric will likely boost Mr. Trump in industrial states such as Ohio and Pennsylvania, which were both key to his 2016 victory. But in the event of a trade war, they could rebound to hurt many of his other base voters. Last year, researchers at the Brookings Metropolitan Policy Program reported that small, rural communities would be disproportionately hurt by a trade shock.\n\nThey compiled a list of the 10 metro areas most vulnerable to such a shock because of their economic reliance on exports. Those areas were in Indiana, Texas, Louisiana, South Carolina and Alabama \u2014 all states Mr. Trump carried.", "title": "Trump Embraces a Trade War, Which Could Undermine Growth", "authors": ["Jim Tankersley"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump said Tuesday that several thousand Liberians who have been living in the United States under a temporary immigrant status will have one year to return to their country or they will face deportation.\n\nThe president said in a memo to the secretary of state that he was formally ending a program that has allowed Liberian immigrants to remain in the United States and work legally since 1999, when President Bill Clinton established it in response to conditions in the country after a civil war.\n\nMore than 800,000 Liberians were displaced by the war and fled the country. Some sought refuge in the United States.\n\nThe program, known as Deferred Enforced Departure, has been renewed for Liberians since, giving the immigrants the ability to remain in the United States without fear of deportation. But in the memo, Mr. Trump cited the improved conditions in Liberia as evidence that the program was no longer needed.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Shear"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "A politically moderate former hospital executive who also served in the Obama administration, Dr. Shulkin had been one of Mr. Trump\u2019s most popular cabinet secretaries, both in the White House and on Capitol Hill. At a time when Mr. Trump was struggling to find legislative victories, Dr. Shulkin and Congress\u2019s veterans committees delivered a string of popular, bipartisan bills to the president\u2019s desk.\n\nAnd Mr. Trump has publicly showered Dr. Shulkin with praise. At a signing ceremony for one of those bills in June, Mr. Trump said his secretary did not have to worry about hearing the president\u2019s old reality-show catchphrase, \u201cYou\u2019re fired.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ll never have to use those words on our David,\u201d Mr. Trump said, pointing his finger at the secretary like a pistol. \u201cWe will never use those words on you, that\u2019s for sure.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat tenor began to change in recent months, as Dr. Shulkin increasingly butted heads with conservative Trump administration officials over one of the White House\u2019s top policy priorities for the department: the expansion of government-subsidized private health care for veterans, outside the government-run V.A. health system.\n\nThe conservatives came to feel that Dr. Shulkin, who advocated a moderate rewrite of the current private care programs, was an obstacle to their goal.\n\nThe dispute spilled into public over the last month, following a scathing report by department\u2019s inspector general on a business trip that Dr. Shulkin took to Britain and Denmark last year. The report found \u201cserious derelictions\u201d related to the trip and concluded that the secretary spent much of it sightseeing and improperly accepted a gift of Wimbledon tickets.\n\nThe report in hand, Dr. Shulkin\u2019s critics in the White House and the department \u2014 including his two top communications deputies \u2014 worked behind the scenes to try to hasten his ouster. Dr. Shulkin, who disputed the report\u2019s findings, went public with fears that appointees were \u201ctrying to undermine the department from within.\u201d He iced out those he viewed as a threat and essentially became his own one-person press office.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs recently as last week, after a series of meetings with John F. Kelly, the White House chief of staff, Dr. Shulkin publicly declared victory, hinting that he had the White House\u2019s support to remove officials battling him.\n\nThe secretary appeared to be regaining his footing. He sat at Mr. Trump\u2019s side during a cabinet meeting, and the two men together called Senator Johnny Isakson of Georgia, the chairman of the Veterans\u2019 Affairs Committee, to pledge their support for his more moderate health care legislation, according to a congressional aide briefed on the call. The secretary maintains the support of top Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill.\n\nBut top White House officials have only become more irked with the secretary\u2019s penchant for publicly discussing internal politics, and Mr. Trump has begun searching for a replacement.\n\nMr. Perry is seen as a more pliant figure for the veterans affairs position. Unlike Dr. Shulkin, who had run the department\u2019s health care system under President Barack Obama and spent a career in hospital administration, Mr. Perry has no background in health care delivery, but as Texas\u2019 governor, he showed a willingness to experiment.\n\nIf Mr. Trump were to make the move, possible replacements for Mr. Perry could include Ray Washburne, a Dallas entrepreneur and prominent Republican fund-raiser; J. Larry Nichols, the former chairman of Devon Energy; and T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, according to people who work closely with senior officials at the department and the White House.", "title": "Trump Eyes Replacing His Veterans Affairs Secretary With His Energy Chief", "authors": ["Maggie Haberman", "Nicholas Fandos"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cSchool shootings are a grave and preventable problem, but rescinding the school discipline guidance is not the answer,\u201d she said. \u201cRepealing the guidance will not stop the next school shooter, but it will ensure that thousands more students of color are unnecessarily ushered into the school-to-prison pipeline.\u201d\n\nThe issue of the Obama-era discipline guidance was raised formally by Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, who, after seeing a flurry of conservative news media reports, wrote a letter to Ms. DeVos and Attorney General Jeff Sessions questioning whether the guidance allowed the shooting suspect, Nikolas Cruz, to evade law enforcement and carry out the massacre at Stoneman Douglas High.\n\nIt was, on its face, an odd point: Mr. Cruz is white, and far from evading school disciplinary procedures, he had been expelled from Stoneman Douglas.\n\n\u201cThe overarching goals of the 2014 directive to mitigate the school-to-prison pipeline, reduce suspensions and expulsions, and to prevent racially biased discipline are laudable and should be explored,\u201d Mr. Rubio wrote, asking that the guidance be revised. \u201cHowever, any policy seeking to achieve these goals requires basic common sense and an understanding that failure to report troubled students, like Cruz, to law enforcement can have dangerous repercussions.\u201d\n\nBroward County educators and advocates saw Mr. Rubio\u2019s letter as an indictment of a program called Promise, which the county instituted in 2013 \u2014 one year before the Obama guidance was issued \u2014 and has guided its discipline reforms to reduce student-based arrests in Broward County, where Stoneman Douglas is.\n\nThe N.A.A.C.P. said that Mr. Rubio \u201cnotably backs away from raising the purchase age for assault-style rifles and restricting magazine capacity,\u201d and instead focuses on a system that once sent one million minority students to Florida jails for \u201csimple and routine discipline issues ranging from talking back to teachers to schoolyard scuffles.\u201d\n\nThe program was praised by former Secretary of Education Arne Duncan, and echoes the goals of the 2014 Obama guidance in discouraging schools from using law enforcement as a first line of defense for low-level offenses.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the days before making his request, Mr. Rubio released a proposal that he said would remedy lapses in the Promise program and the 2014 guidance.\n\nIn a tweet on Tuesday, Mr. Rubio noted that the gunman was not in the Promise program, but had displayed violent and threatening behavior.\n\n\u201cThe more we learn, the more it appears the problem is not the program or the DOE guidance itself, but the way it is being applied,\u201d Mr. Rubio said, referring to the Education Department. \u201cIt may have created a culture discourages referral to law enforcement even in egregious cases like the #Parkland shooter.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLong before the attack in Parkland, Fla., the 2014 discipline guidelines, which encouraged schools to examine their discipline disparities and to take stock of discriminatory policies, were already on Ms. DeVos\u2019s radar \u2014 but not because they were seen as a possible culprit in the next school shooting. Conservatives were using the Trump administration\u2019s effort to rein in federal overreach to reverse policies designed to protect against what the Obama administration had seen as discriminatory practices.\n\nThe \u201cRethink Discipline,\u201d package that Mr. Trump\u2019s commission will examine includes guidance that the Obama administration issued on the legal limitations on the use of restraints and seclusion, corporal punishment and equity for special education students.\n\nIn recent months, educators and policy experts from across the country have traveled to Washington to voice support for and opposition to the disciplinary guidance, in private meetings with officials at the Education Department and in a series of public forums.\n\nAt a briefing hosted by the United States Commission on Civil Rights, dozens of policy experts, researchers, educators and parents sounded off on the Obama-era discipline policy in a meeting that became so racially charged that some black attendees walked out.\n\nSince the discipline guidelines were issued, conservatives have blamed the document for creating unsafe educational environments by pressuring schools to keep suspension numbers down to meet racial quotas, even if it meant ignoring troubling and criminal behavior. Teachers who sought suspensions or expulsions of minority students were painted as racists, conservatives maintained.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEvidence is mounting that efforts to fight the school-to-prison pipeline is creating a school climate catastrophe and has if anything put at-risk students at greater risk,\u201d said Max Eden, a senior fellow at the conservative Manhattan Institute, who argued that teacher bias was not the driving force behind school discipline.\n\nBut proponents argued that racial bias was well documented.\n\nWhen the guidance was issued, federal data found that African-American students without disabilities were more than three times as likely as their white peers without disabilities to be expelled or suspended, and that more than 50 percent of students who were involved in school-related arrests or who were referred to law enforcement were Hispanic or African-American.\n\n\u201cChildren\u2019s safety also includes protection from oppression and bigotry and injustice,\u201d Daniel J. Losen, director of the Center for Civil Rights Remedies at the University of California at Los Angeles\u2019s Civil Rights Project, wrote in testimony to the Civil Rights Commission. \u201cFear-mongering and rhetoric that criminalizes youth of color, children from poor families and children with disabilities should not be tolerated.\u201d\n\nThe Education and Justice Departments wrote in a 2014 Dear Colleague letter that discipline disparities could be caused by a range of factors, but the statistics in the federal data \u201care not explained by more frequent or more serious misbehavior by students of color.\u201d The departments also noted that several civil rights investigations had verified that minority students were disciplined more harshly than their white peers for the same infractions.\n\n\u201cIn short, racial discrimination in school discipline is a real problem,\u201d the guidance said.\n\nIn recent months, Ms. DeVos has said change will be coming. She has already moved to rescind a regulation that protects against racial disparities in special education placements. Her goal, she said last month, was to be \u201csensitive to all of the parties involved.\u201d\n\nIn a bruising interview on \u201c60 Minutes\u201d on Sunday, Ms. DeVos said that the disproportionate discipline issue \u201ccomes down to individual kids.\u201d She declined to say whether she believed that black students disciplined more harshly for the same infraction were the victims of institutional racism.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re studying it carefully and are committed to making sure students have opportunity to learn in safe and nurturing environments,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. DeVos\u2019s office for civil rights also announced that it would scale back the scope of investigations, reversing an approach taken under the Obama administration to conduct exhaustive reviews of school districts\u2019 practices and data when a discrimination complaint was filed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Ms. DeVos\u2019s own administration has continued to find racial disparities. In November, the Education Department found that the Loleta Union Elementary School District in California doled out harsher treatment to Native American students than their white peers. For example, a Native American student received a one-day out-of-school suspension for slapping another student on the way to the bus, in what was that student\u2019s first disciplinary referral of the year. A white student received lunch detention for slapping two students on the same day \u2014 the student\u2019s fifth and sixth referrals that year.\n\nWhile Mr. Cruz was repeatedly kicked out of class and ultimately expelled, it is unclear whether he was ever referred to the police for his behavior in school. However, Mr. Cruz was known to law enforcement, which never found cause to arrest him, and a report of troublesome behavior to the F.B.I. went unheeded.\n\nThe Broward County superintendent, Robert Runcie, said that Mr. Rubio\u2019s effort to connect the district\u2019s discipline policies to the Stoneman Douglas shooting was misguided.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not going to dismantle a program that\u2019s been successful in the district because of false information that someone has put out there,\u201d Mr. Runcie said on Twitter. \u201cWe will neither manage nor lead by rumors.\u201d", "title": "Trump Finds Unlikely Culprit in School Shootings: Obama Discipline Policies", "authors": ["Erica L. Green"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "He added: \u201cReally, it was a different mind-set, a different thinking.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump announced his decision on Twitter.\n\nAt the State Department Tuesday afternoon, Mr. Tillerson said the president had called him from Air Force One just after noon \u2014 more than three hours after Mr. Trump had tweeted the news of his firing to his 49 million followers \u2014 to inform him personally of the dismissal. Mr. Tillerson said he planned to immediately step aside from his post, turning over all responsibilities by the end of the day to John J. Sullivan, the deputy secretary of state.\n\nDuring a short statement in a briefing room packed with reporters, Mr. Tillerson said he would end his service at midnight on March 31, but was encouraging his policy planning team and under secretaries and assistant secretaries \u201cto remain in their posts and continue in our mission at the State Department.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019ll now return to private life, as a private citizen, as a proud American, proud of the opportunity I had to serve my country,\u201d Mr. Tillerson said. He took no questions and left the briefing room.\n\nThe firing of Mr. Tillerson caught even the White House staff by surprise. Just the day before, a White House spokesman berated a reporter for suggesting there was any kind of split between Mr. Tillerson and the White House because of disparate comments on Russian responsibility for a poison attack in Britain.\n\nBut a senior administration official said that Mr. Trump decided to replace Mr. Tillerson now to have a new team in place before upcoming talks with Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader he plans to meet by May. The president also wanted a new chief diplomat for various ongoing trade negotiations.\n\nThe White House\u2019s purge extended to Mr. Tillerson\u2019s inner circle. The under secretary of state for public affairs, Steve Goldstein, was fired, and the status was unclear of Mr. Tillerson\u2019s chief of staff, Margaret Peterlin, and his deputy chief of staff, Christine Ciccone.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Tillerson was at the State Department on Tuesday and spoke to reporters, saying that he would surrender his authority at midnight and resign officially at the end of the month.\n\nAt the C.I.A., Mr. Pompeo will be replaced by the current deputy director, Gina Haspel, who will be the first woman to head the spy agency. Both she and Mr. Pompeo would need confirmation by the Senate to take the positions.\n\nMr. Tillerson has been out of favor with Mr. Trump for months but had resisted being pushed out. His distance from Mr. Trump\u2019s inner circle was clear last week when the president accepted an invitation to meet with Mr. Kim, to Mr. Tillerson\u2019s surprise.\n\nMr. Trump said Mr. Pompeo \u201chas earned the praise of members in both parties by strengthening our intelligence gathering, modernizing our defensive and offensive capabilities, and building close ties with our friends and allies in the international intelligence community.\u201d\n\n\u201cI have gotten to know Mike very well over the past 14 months, and I am confident he is the right person for the job at this critical juncture,\u201d the president continued, in a written statement distributed by the White House. \u201cHe will continue our program of restoring America\u2019s standing in the world, strengthening our alliances, confronting our adversaries, and seeking the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula.\u201d\n\nIn a Twitter post, Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the House Democratic leader, warned that the turnover at the top of the State Department had diminished the United States with foreign leaders.\n\nMr. Pompeo, a former congressman, has become a favorite of Mr. Trump\u2019s, impressing the president with his engaging approach during morning intelligence briefings. But he also, at times, has been at odds with the president \u2014 including agreeing with a C.I.A. assessment about Russia\u2019s interference in the 2016 elections.\n\nIn picking Ms. Haspel to succeed Mr. Pompeo at the C.I.A., Mr. Trump opted for continuity rather than bringing in an outsider. At one point last fall, Senator Tom Cotton of Arkansas, one of the president\u2019s closest Republican allies on Capitol Hill, had been tentatively tapped as the front-runner to run the agency if Mr. Pompeo moved up, but the idea later faded.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Tillerson, a former chief executive of the oil giant Exxon Mobil, had once been viewed as an intriguing, if unorthodox, cabinet choice. He had deep experience with Middle Eastern potentates, and knew President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia through Exxon\u2019s extensive efforts to explore for oil in Russia.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut the early enthusiasm for bringing a business sensibility to the State Department faded fast, as Mr. Tillerson seemed overwhelmed by the diplomatic challenges before him and isolated by career foreign service officers whom he often froze out of the most important debates.\n\nHis profound disagreements with the president on policy appeared to be his undoing: Mr. Tillerson wanted to remain part of the Paris climate accord; Mr. Trump decided to leave it. Mr. Tillerson supported the continuation of the Iran nuclear deal; Mr. Trump loathed the deal as \u201can embarrassment to the United States.\u201d And Mr. Tillerson believed in dialogue to resolve the North Korean nuclear crisis, but Mr. Trump repeatedly threatened military options.\n\nVeteran diplomats said they could not remember a time when a president so regularly undermined his secretary of state so brazenly in the midst of a tense situation. Richard N. Haass, the president of the Council on Foreign Relations, who served many Republican presidents, last fall urged Mr. Tillerson to quit.\n\n\u201cRex Tillerson has been dealt a bad hand by the Potus & has played it badly,\u201d Mr. Haass wrote in a post on Twitter, using the acronym for president of the United States. \u201cFor both reasons he cannot be effective SecState & should resign.\u201d\n\nCareer diplomats, who had seen in the gravelly voiced Mr. Tillerson a man of stature, experience and great wealth whom they hoped the president would respect and heed, eventually turned against him as he expressed more interest in shrinking the department than expanding American influence.\n\nWhile other cabinet officers made their goals plain, Mr. Tillerson never set clear diplomatic priorities other than to pursue Mr. Trump\u2019s slogan of \u201cAmerica First,\u201d a term he never really defined. In an odd admission more than eight months into the job, Mr. Tillerson told employees in September that his top priority was to make the State Department more efficient. Yet he never fully addressed what diplomats should be doing with that greater efficiency.\n\nCongress rebelled, declining to endorse his suggested 30 percent cuts in the State Department\u2019s budget. But the message of his tenure seemed clear: At a moment when money was being poured into the Pentagon and intelligence agencies, diplomacy seemed less valued than at any time in recent American history.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe turning point for Mr. Tillerson came when NBC News reported that he had called the president a \u201cmoron,\u201d leading him to take the extraordinary step of holding a news conference to affirm his support for Mr. Trump and insist that he had never considered resigning.\n\nDuring a trip to Beijing in September, Mr. Tillerson told reporters that he already had \u201ca couple, three\u201d lines into North Korea to get communication started with the United States. Mr. Trump erupted the next morning, and denigrated the effort on Twitter by saying Mr. Tillerson was \u201cwasting his time trying to negotiate with Little Rocket Man.\u201d\n\n\u201cSave your energy Rex,\u201d he added, \u201cwe\u2019ll do what has to be done!\u201d Mr. Trump later said he wished his secretary of state were tougher. The Chinese were left to wonder why Mr. Trump sent an emissary whose message the president did not believe in.\n\nPart of the reason for Mr. Trump\u2019s eruption then was that Mr. Tillerson\u2019s suggestion of secret talks with North Korea surprised President Moon Jae-in of South Korea, who called the White House to complain, according to people with knowledge of the exchange. That Mr. Tillerson failed to take into account Seoul\u2019s possible reaction was one of several embarrassing stumbles, arising from his own inexperience and decision to insulate himself from the department\u2019s diplomatic corps.\n\nWith his ousting, Mr. Tillerson joins a long list of Trump administration appointees who have left or been fired, including the president\u2019s first national security adviser, chief of staff, chief strategist, press secretary, two White House communications directors and secretary of health and human services.\n\nMr. Tillerson had some successes, including the growing international isolation of North Korea and improved ties between Saudi Arabia and Iraq. But he is likely to go down as among the least successful secretaries of state in history, and one big reason was his poor management of his relationship with Mr. Trump.\n\nAlthough Mr. Tillerson spent his first months on the job getting to know Mr. Trump at lunches, dinners and White House get-togethers, the two never established a comfortable rapport.\n\nOnce the head of the Boy Scouts of America, Mr. Tillerson was outraged when the president spoke to the Boy Scouts in July and turned it into a political event. When Mr. Trump declined to denounce white nationalists who paraded in Charlottesville in August, Mr. Tillerson made it clear that Mr. Trump \u201cspeaks for himself\u201d \u2014 not his secretary of state.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe growing distance between the men was on clear display during Mr. Trump\u2019s trip to Asia in November, when Mr. Tillerson visited the prison that once housed Senator John McCain, a Republican from Arizona who is a frequent critic of the president.\n\nBut perhaps the most puzzling part of Mr. Tillerson\u2019s tenure was his poor oversight of the State Department. As a former top business executive, his managerial skills were thought to be his chief asset.\n\nBut he failed to quickly pick a trusted team of leaders, left many critical departments without direction and all but paralyzed crucial decision making in the department.\n\nHe approved one global conclave in Washington just eight days before the event was to start, ensuring that few leaders from around the world were able to attend. He rarely sat for comprehensive briefings with many of his top diplomats and often failed to consult the State Department\u2019s experts on countries before visiting.\n\nForeign diplomats \u2014 starting with the British and the French \u2014 said Mr. Tillerson neither returned phone calls nor, with much advance warning, set up meetings with his counterparts. Strategic dialogues with many nations, including nuclear weapons powers like Pakistan, were ended without explanation.\n\nThe State Department\u2019s policymaking process devolved into conversations between Mr. Tillerson and a lone top aide, neither of whom had much experience or knowledge about many of the countries they discussed.\n\nMr. Tillerson became so isolated that even top administration officials like Mr. Pompeo and allies like Condoleezza Rice, the former secretary of state whose recommendation was crucial to his selection, had trouble penetrating a phalanx of staff to speak to him directly.\n\n\u201cThe relationship between top management and the bulk of the State Department was toxic,\u201d said Ambassador James F. Jeffrey, a former senior diplomat and fellow at the Washington Institute who once worked with Mr. Tillerson. \u201cAnd that was a total mystery because the people at the State Department would work for the devil if he is advancing American interests, which Mr. Tillerson was.\u201d", "title": "Trump Fires Rex Tillerson and Will Replace Him With C.I.A. Chief Pompeo", "authors": ["Peter Baker", "Gardiner Harris", "Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Several recent news articles, including three on the front page of The New York Times, have called attention to the overlap of Mr. Broidy\u2019s political advocacy and his business interests. They describe what appear to be his promises of access to the Trump administration or congressional Republicans as he sought lucrative contracts with various foreign governments.\n\nMost of those articles, including those in The Times, relied in part on copies of emails from Mr. Broidy\u2019s account that were provided to journalists by an anonymous group critical of his views about the Middle East.\n\nRepresentatives of Mr. Broidy immediately suspected Qatar of stealing his emails, in part because the private emails of at least one other high-profile foe of Qatar \u2014 Yousef al-Otaiba, the Emirati ambassador to Washington \u2014 have also been hacked and disseminated to journalists in a similar fashion. The hack required a level of resources and sophistication that suggested a state was responsible.\n\n\u201cThis is a case about a hostile intelligence operation undertaken by a foreign nation on the territory of the United States against successful, influential United States citizens,\u201d the lawyers for Mr. Broidy charged in a lawsuit filed in United States District Court for the Central District of California.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
