Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn a statement, a spokesman for Qatar said the suit was \u201cwithout merit or fact.\u201d The spokesman, Jassim al-Thani, of the Qatari Embassy in Washington, called Mr. Broidy\u2019s lawsuit \u201ca transparent attempt to divert attention from U.S. media reports about his activities.\u201d\n\nThe lawsuit charges that the attack began last Dec. 27, when Mr. Broidy\u2019s wife, Robin Rosenzweig, received an email that appeared to be a security alert from Google. She entered her password as the alert requested. It turned out to be a phishing attack, according to the lawsuit, and the information she provided was used to get access to her account, Mr. Broidy\u2019s and that of his company, Broidy Capital Management.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter the emails began appeared in the news media, Mr. Broidy retained a team of cyberforensic experts, including at least one former American intelligence official. According to the lawsuit, their initial analysis indicated that the attacks appeared to originate from computer servers in Britain and the Netherlands, but the researchers later concluded that the addresses of those servers had been used to mask another point of origin.\n\n\u201cA more thorough review of the server data\u201d showed that for a brief time on one day \u2014 Feb. 14, 2018 \u2014 \u201cproblems with the attackers obfuscation techniques\u201d had \u201crevealed that the attack originated in Qatar.\u201d\n\nThe lawsuit also claims that a Republican lobbyist, Nicolas D. Muzin of Stonington Strategies, conspired with Qatar to exploit the hacked emails to damage Mr. Broidy\u2019s reputation. Stonington Strategies is registered as a foreign agent of Qatar, and the lawsuit says that Qatar pays him $300,000 a month. Qatar spent nearly $5 million on Washington lobbyists and media relations during the six months that ended last October, according to the Center for Responsive Politics.\n\nMr. Muzin has reportedly courted Jewish leaders and others by offering them trips to Doha, the capital of Qatar. \u201cStarting last year, the State of Qatar, Muzin, and other foreign agents conspired in a strategic campaign to retaliate against and discredit Plaintiff Broidy,\u201d the lawsuit claims. It specifically accused Qatar of orchestrating the hacking after Mr. Muzin \u201cidentified Plaintiff Broidy as an individual who was opposing the State of Qatar\u2019s efforts to improve its image and relationships in Washington, D.C. and who was aligned with its regional rivals, the UAE and Saudi Arabia.\u201d\n\nIn a statement, Mr. Muzin said, \u201cMr. Broidy\u2019s lawsuit is an obvious attempt to draw attention away from his controversial work, and is as flimsy as the promises he reportedly made to his clients.\u201d", "title": "Trump Fund-Raiser Files Hacking Lawsuit Against Qatar", "authors": ["David D. Kirkpatrick"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt looks like we\u2019re going to have a good result on that,\u201d Peter Navarro, Mr. Trump\u2019s trade adviser, said of the South Korea deal on CNBC on Monday.\n\nIt remains to be seen whether the revised pact will be enough to satisfy lawmakers and industries that have been critical of South Korea\u2019s trading practices. Among the biggest concerns have been access to its markets for American exports of automobiles and agricultural products.\n\nThe reduction of trade deficits have been a priority for the United States; in 2016, it had a $17 billion trade deficit with South Korea.\n\nIn a statement published on Monday, the South Korean Trade Ministry said it had agreed to adhere to a quota of 2.68 million tons of steel exports to the United States a year, which it said was roughly equivalent to 70 percent of its annual average sent to the United States from 2015 to 2017. It also agreed to lower trade barriers to vehicles imported from the United States. Trump administration officials cited what they considered unfair barriers against American-made cars when they began last year to pressure South Korea to amend the trade pact.\n\nIn return, the Trade Ministry said, South Korea would be exempt from the steel tariffs.\n\nUnder the deal, the number of vehicles the United States can export to South Korea without meeting local safety requirements would double to 50,000.\n\nCars are a major reason for Seoul\u2019s trade surplus with Washington. Brands like Hyundai and Kia have found ready markets in the United States, but the big American automakers have complained that restrictions keep them from trying to make the same headway in South Korean. The agreement is also expected to allow the United States to extend the tariffs that it imposes on Korean pickup trucks to 2041. The tariffs are currently scheduled to be phased out in 2021.\n\nKim Hyun-chong, South Korea\u2019s trade minister, told journalists on Monday, however, that there would be no further opening of his country\u2019s agricultural markets, and no changes to tariffs that had already been lifted.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Trump administration suggested last week that the deal with South Korea was nearing completion as it unveiled the new tariffs targeting China.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTrade experts said that while the concessions were a win for the Trump administration, they would most likely do little to dent the trade deficit and that South Korea was probably happy to have the negotiations behind them after the United States briefly flirted with withdrawing from the pact.\n\nWashington and Seoul began negotiations in January on changes to the six-year-old trade agreement, one that Mr. Trump had previously called a \u201chorrible deal.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m happy that they can take this off the table as another trade policy irritant,\u201d said Dan Ikenson, a trade expert at the Cato Institute who argued that the administration\u2019s trade policies and focus on trade deficits are out of sync with economic reality. \u201cThis administration happens to believe, and it\u2019s a fairy tale, that bilateral trade accounts matter.\u201d\n\nSome labor groups and others who share Mr. Trump\u2019s general frustration with America\u2019s trade relationship with South Korea reacted coolly on Monday to the public details of the renegotiated deal, saying that the administration appeared to have achieved only modest progress and left some important issues out of the agreement. Several said the increased auto import numbers did not guarantee that automakers would be able to crack the Korean market, which is notoriously hostile to foreign cars.\n\nOthers expressed cautious optimism.\n\n\u201cAs with all trade agreements, the details are important, so I want to see the specific concessions we secured from Korea \u2014 especially on steel,\u201d said Senator Sherrod Brown, Democrat of Ohio. He added that it was \u201cgood news\u201d that Robert Lighthizer, the United States trade representative, \u201cappears to have taken steps to make the Korea agreement better for U.S. workers and auto companies while also getting the Koreans to limit their steel exports to the U.S.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s proposed tariffs \u2014 set in motion by a Commerce Department declaration that steel and aluminum imports posed a national security threat because they degraded the American industrial base \u2014 prompted American allies and trading partners including Australia, the European Union and Japan, as well as South Korea, to jostle for exemptions. But the impact of the tariffs may not be as great as expected, since most of the biggest suppliers of foreign metals have been granted at least temporary exemptions.\n\nSouth Korea was the third-biggest exporter of steel to the United States in 2016, after Canada and the European Union. Mr. Lighthizer said last week that those three trading partners, along with Argentina, Australia and Brazil, would initially receive a reprieve from the tariffs.\n\nMr. Trump pulled out of the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade pact last year and said that he would focus on negotiating new bilateral deals with countries around the world. The steel tariffs are speeding up that process, and Mr. Mnuchin signaled on Sunday that more deals were on the way.\n\n\u201cWhere we\u2019ve put a pause on tariffs, we\u2019re negotiating,\u201d he said.", "title": "Trump Gets First Major Trade Deal as South Korea Looks to Avoid Tariffs", "authors": ["Alan Rappeport", "Jim Tankersley"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Where did so many people originally get the idea that Trump was the right guy to fix our manifestly broken government? Not from Russian bots or targeted social media ad buys, but from a prime-time show that sold itself as real, and sold him as a business genius. Forget unhappy blue collar heartlanders; forget white nationalists and birthers: The core Trump demographic might just have been Republicans who watched \u201cThe Apprentice,\u201d who bought the fake news that his television program and its network sponsors gladly sold them.\n\nThat was step one in the Trump hack of television media. Step two was the use of his celebrity to turn news channels into infomercials for his campaign. Yes, his fame also boosted him on social media, but there you can partially blame algorithms and the unwisdom of crowds; with television news there were actual human beings, charged with exercising news judgment and inclined to posture as civic-minded actors when it suits them, making the decision to hand day after day of free coverage to Donald Trump\u2019s rallies, outrages, feuds and personal attacks.\n\nNothing that Cambridge Analytica did to help the Trump campaign target swing voters (and there\u2019s reason to think it didn\u2019t do as much as it claimed) had anything remotely like the impact of this #alwaysTrump tsunami, which probably added up to more than $2 billion in effective advertising for his campaign during the primary season, a flood that drowned all of his rivals\u2019 pathetic tens of millions. And as cynical as I believe the lords of Silicon Valley to be, the more important cynicism in 2016 belonged to those television execs who were fine with enabling the wild Trumpian takeover of the G.O.P., because after all Republicans deserved it and Hillary was sure to beat him in the end.\n\nExcept that she didn\u2019t beat him, in part because he also exploited the polarization that cable news, in particular, is designed to feed. In 2016 this polarization didn\u2019t just mean that Fox became steadily more pro-Trump as he dispatched his G.O.P. rivals; it also meant that a network like CNN, which thrives on Team Red vs. Team Blue conflict, felt compelled to turn airtime over to Trump surrogates like Jeffrey Lord and Corey Lewandowski and Kayleigh McEnany because their regular stable of conservative commentators (I was one of them) simply wasn\u2019t pro-Trump enough.\n\nThe depth and breadth of Trump skepticism among right-wing pundits was a pretty solid indicator of his unfitness for high office. But especially once he won the nomination this skepticism was often filtered out of cable coverage, because the important thing was to maintain the partisan shouting-match model. This in turn encouraged a sense that this was just a typical right-versus-left election, in which you should vote for Trump if you usually voted for Republicans \u2026 and in the end that\u2019s what most G.O.P. voters did.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Hacked the Media Right Before Our Eyes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIf you look across countries, there\u2019s no evidence that high tariffs reduce your trade deficit,\u201d said Joseph E. Gagnon, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, and a co-author of a 2017 book of policy recommendations on how to reduce trade imbalances.\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cThe trade deficit is a terrible metric for judging economic policy,\u201d said Lawrence H. Summers, a Harvard economist and former chairman of President Barack Obama\u2019s National Economic Council. Mr. Summers said tariffs would actually worsen deficits by making American companies that ship steel and aluminum overseas less competitive, and by inviting foreign retaliatory tariffs against other exports.\n\nA year ago, Mr. Trump signed an executive order directing the Commerce Department and the United States trade representative to conduct a 90-day review on the causes of America\u2019s persistent trade deficits. That review has not yet been released. The Bureau of Economic Analysis reported last month that the trade deficit grew to 2.9 percent of gross domestic product in 2017, up from 2.7 percent the year before.\n\nThe deficit in goods alone with China grew to $375 billion last year, an 8 percent increase from 2016.\n\nThe deficit in goods and services is on pace to reach about $330 billion, depending on fourth-quarter data that has not yet been reported, which would also be an increase from the year before.\n\nThe tangible source of America\u2019s persistent trade deficit with China is consumer goods: electronics, housewares and so much else that Americans buy regularly at Walmart or Costco. Those deficits have been exacerbated, economists generally agree, through concerted action by the Chinese government to prop up exports, by holding down the value of China\u2019s currency and directly subsidizing some exporting industries.\n\nWhen it was admitted to the World Trade Organization in 2001, China got access to markets around the world and in turn committed to opening its own markets to countries such as the United States, said Eswar S. Prasad, a trade economist at Cornell University. \u201cChina did not keep up its end of the bargain,\u201d Mr. Prasad said. \u201cIt did not provide easy access to its own markets. And for a long period after the Asian financial crisis \u2014 2000 until the end of that decade \u2014 they gave themselves a competitive advantage by holding down the value of their currency.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe United States actually runs a trade surplus in services with China, as it does with many other countries, in part by attracting Chinese students to study at American colleges, which counts as an export.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Prasad and most other trade experts say bilateral trade deficits are not a good measure of whether countries are living up to their promises on market access, or whether certain countries are better negotiators of trade agreements. They compare the global economy to a neighborhood. Consumers might spend a lot of money with a shopkeeper who never buys anything from their store in return, but they also receive money from other customers whose stores they never frequent.\n\n\u201cA bilateral balance doesn\u2019t really tell you anything about what the economy is doing,\u201d said Scott Lincicome, an adjunct fellow at the libertarian Cato Institute, \u201cjust like my bilateral deficit with my grocery store doesn\u2019t tell you anything about whether I\u2019m in debt.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s own Council of Economic Advisers, in a report last month, seemed to play down alarms over bilateral trade deficits. \u201cThe United States has a bilateral goods deficit and a services surplus with many of its major trading partners,\u201d council members wrote. \u201cOverall, the United States has a goods deficit and a services surplus with the world. The services surplus is consistent with the structure of the private sector, which has evolved during the last few decades toward more services output as a share of G.D.P.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEconomists who share Mr. Trump\u2019s concern with the overall trade deficit, or at least some degree of it, say there are better ways than tariffs to reduce it. Dean Baker, a liberal economist who writes frequently on trade policy, said targeting currency values is the best route; if other countries\u2019 currencies strengthen relative to the dollar, it becomes more attractive for their consumers to buy American exports.\n\nMr. Gagnon has a list of recommendations but said one dwarfs all others: reducing America\u2019s growing federal budget deficit, which is fueling foreign investment in the United States as the government turns to other nations to finance its spending.\n\n\u201cThere are things we could do,\u201d he said, \u201cbut I hate to recommend them when we\u2019re not doing the most important thing, which is bring down our massive fiscal deficit.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump, he noted, recently signed sweeping tax cuts that will add an estimated $1 trillion to federal deficits over the next 10 years, even after accounting for the faster growth it could bring.", "title": "Trump Hates the Trade Deficit. Most Economists Don\u2019t.", "authors": ["Jim Tankersley"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "After a week marked by persistent scandals and high-profile staff departures, policy was not at the forefront of the president\u2019s mind. Mr. Trump seemed intently focused on delivering his own progress report to supporters on a range of red-meat issues, including his zeal for improving border security, his promise to construct a border wall with Mexico, his administration\u2019s efforts to roll back what he called \u201cjob killing\u201d regulations and his thwarting of Democrats.\n\n\u201cReally, I have gotten done much more than I promised,\u201d Mr. Trump said. \u201cWe did a lot of things I didn\u2019t even promise.\u201d\n\nIn the driving rain, Mr. Trump made his way to the training center, where he had been scheduled to sell an ambitious plan that would try to leverage $200 billion in federal spending to generate $1.5 trillion in total spending on projects such as tunnels, bridges and highways. White House officials had framed the event as a ramp-up, but this conflicted with the president\u2019s decision to say he would push the plan to next year, declaring that he did not expect it to pass at least until after the November midterm elections.\n\nAlso curiously, Mr. Trump spent little time on the trade deal struck with South Korea this week, which had been a win for his administration. That continued a relatively muted celebration: The announcement of that agreement\u2019s details came not from Mr. Trump or his White House, but from South Korean officials; Trump administration officials unveiled the plan days later in a conference call with reporters.\n\nInstead, Mr. Trump disparaged a previous version of a South Korea trade agreement as a \u201chorror show\u201d and a \u201cHillary Clinton special.\u201d He mused to the crowd that he might hold up finalizing the deal while he pursues planned talks with North Korea.\n\n\u201cCertainly, the rhetoric has calmed down just a little bit, would you say?\u201d Mr. Trump asked the crowd. \u201cWe\u2019ll see how it all turns out.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump seemed to veer off script in other areas as well. At one point, he suggested that he planned to pull American troops out of Syria, where they have aided a military campaign that has recaptured the vast majority of the territory once controlled by the Islamic State, or ISIS. \u201cWe\u2019re knocking the hell out of ISIS,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019ll be coming out of Syria, like, very soon. Let the other people take care of it now.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs the crowd applauded, he added: \u201cVery soon, very soon we\u2019re coming out. We\u2019re going to have 100 percent of the caliphate, as they call it \u2014 sometimes referred to as \u2018land\u2019 \u2014 taking it all back quickly, quickly.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe comment seemed in conflict with plans by his national security team to keep a small force in place. As recently as Tuesday, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said that while American forces were no longer in \u201can offensive effort on the ground\u201d and had \u201cdrawn off slightly\u201d to avoid accidental conflict with Russian troops, they continued to play a role. \u201cWe continue the operations in Syria,\u201d he said.\n\nSome foreign policy specialists said a complete withdrawal of American troops from Syria would leave a dangerous void. \u201cIf we\u2019re pulling those troops out, we\u2019re ceding the remnants of Syria to the Russians and the Iranians and the other actors, which actually I would argue would be a big victory for Russia,\u201d said Jamie M. Fly, a Republican scholar at the German Marshall Fund of the United States.\n\nMr. Trump eventually focused on infrastructure on Thursday, zeroing in on his plan to speed up permitting. But the subject and timing of the president\u2019s focus on his plan, announced in February, are curious. Congressional Republicans have not shown much appetite for taking up the infrastructure package, and neither have Democrats, who prefer proposals with much more federal spending.\n\nMr. Trump acknowledged some of that reality in his remarks.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think you\u2019re going to get Democrat support very much,\u201d he said. \u201cYou\u2019re probably going to have to wait until after the election.\u201d\n\nAdministration officials have not mounted any sort of effort, in public or private, that matches the scale of the pressure campaign they employed before the passage of Mr. Trump\u2019s signature tax cut package last year. Perhaps the most prominent advocate of the infrastructure proposal, Gary D. Cohn, recently left his post as director of the National Economic Council. His successor, Larry Kudlow, is less enthusiastic about increases in federal infrastructure spending.\n\nThe administration envisions states, local governments and the private sector contributing the bulk of the funds, a recipe that experts doubt would result in anywhere close to the targeted level of investment.\n\nRichard Trumka, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which has lobbied for a large infrastructure bill, said he was skeptical that the president\u2019s visit would spur any action.\n\n\u201cHe and Congress didn\u2019t blink whenever they shelled out a trillion and a half dollars in tax giveaways for the rich,\u201d Mr. Trumka said, \u201cbut we haven\u2019t seen a nickel yet for infrastructure. He can talk about it forever, but he\u2019s got to do something.\u201d\n\nSenator Chuck Schumer of New York, the minority leader, echoed that sentiment on Thursday. \u201cDemocrats are eager to work with the administration on infrastructure,\u201d he said, \u201cbut there\u2019s been a lack of seriousness on this issue from the White House.\u201d", "title": "Trump Heralds South Korea Trade Deal, Then Says He Might Delay It", "authors": ["Katie Rogers", "Jim Tankersley"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nMANCHESTER, N.H. \u2014 President Trump hired the longtime Washington lawyer Joseph E. diGenova on Monday, adding an aggressive voice to his legal team who has pushed the theory on television that the F.B.I. and Justice Department framed Mr. Trump.\n\nMr. diGenova, a former United States attorney, is not expected to take a lead role. But he will serve as an outspoken player for the president as Mr. Trump has increased his attacks on the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III. Mr. Trump broke over the weekend from the longstanding advice of some of his lawyers that he refrain from directly criticizing Mr. Mueller, a sign of his growing unease with the investigation.\n\n\u201cFormer U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia Joe DiGenova will be joining our legal team later this week,\u201d said Jay Sekulow, one of the president\u2019s personal lawyers. \u201cI have worked with Joe for many years and have full confidence that he will be a great asset in our representation of the President.\u201d\n\nMr. diGenova has endorsed the notion that a secretive group of F.B.I. agents concocted the Russia investigation as a way to keep Mr. Trump from becoming president. \u201cThere was a brazen plot to illegally exonerate Hillary Clinton and, if she didn\u2019t win the election, to then frame Donald Trump with a falsely created crime,\u201d he said on Fox News in January. He added, \u201cMake no mistake about it: A group of F.B.I. and D.O.J. people were trying to frame Donald Trump of a falsely created crime.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLittle evidence has emerged to support that theory.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s legal team has been in tumult in recent weeks. On Saturday, Mr. Trump\u2019s personal lawyer, John Dowd, called on the Justice Department to end the special counsel investigation. Mr. Dowd said at the time that he was speaking for the president but later backtracked. According to two people briefed on the matter, he was in fact acting at the president\u2019s urging to call for an end to the inquiry.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Breaking News Emails Get the latest on the special counsel investigation \u2014 and other major news \u2014 delivered to your email inbox. Mr. Flood represented former President Bill Clinton during his impeachment proceedings.", "title": "Trump Hires Lawyer Who Has Pushed Theory That Justice Dept. Framed the President", "authors": ["Maggie Haberman", "Michael S. Schmidt"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe have one particular problem,\u201d the president said before signing an order that will impose tariffs on hundreds of Chinese products, from shoes and clothing to consumer electronics. \u201cWe have a tremendous intellectual property theft situation going on.\u201d\n\nThe sanctions reflect a shift in relations between the two economic giants, which for years engaged in highly structured dialogues to try to reach agreement on economic and security issues. But the White House now views those dialogues \u2014 and the agreements they produced \u2014 as largely hollow promises by the Chinese.\n\nRather than trying to draw China into the rules-based international economic order \u2014 a policy that dates back to Richard M. Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger \u2014 the United States now regards China as a strategic competitor, bent on eroding American security and prosperity.\n\nThe White House \u2014 along with many in the business community \u2014 believes the United States needs to strike back against China\u2019s exploitation of its intellectual property, even if many question whether tariffs are the best tactic.\n\n\u201cWe repeatedly aired our concerns about China,\u201d said Peter Navarro, director of the White House National Trade Council and a key architect of the measures. \u201cWhat the United States is doing is strategically defending itself from China\u2019s economic aggression.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump said that he respected China\u2019s president, Xi Jinping, and that China had been helpful in pressuring North Korea over its nuclear and missile programs. But the president declared that the United States would no longer tolerate running a trade deficit of nearly $400 billion with China, its second-largest trading partner, after the European Union.\n\nOn Thursday, the United States trade representative issued a lengthy report outlining a pattern of predatory behavior by the Chinese, including forcing American companies to transfer valuable technology and trade secrets, and \u201csystematic\u201d data theft by China through hacking of American computer systems.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn addition to the tariffs, the Treasury Department will restrict Chinese investment in American technology firms \u2014 a practice that officials said China uses to nurture its own \u201cnational champions\u201d in cutting-edge industries like artificial intelligence and autonomous vehicles.\n\nThe administration\u2019s increasing focus on punishing China was evident in its decision to exempt allies like the European Union, South Korea, Brazil, Canada and Mexico from what were supposed to be worldwide tariffs on steel and aluminum imports. The levies, which go into effect on Friday, will largely hit China.\n\nWhich Goods From China Could Be Affected President Trump announced that his administration would impose about $60 billion worth of annual tariffs on Chinese imports. A large share of electronics, apparel and other goods imported to the United States come from China. markets, with the stock prices for major exporters like Boeing and Caterpillar plunging more than 5 percent.\n\nThe Chinese Embassy in the United States issued a blunt statement, saying that \u201cChina does not want a trade war with anyone. But China is not afraid of and will not recoil from a trade war. China is confident and capable of facing any challenge. If a trade war were initiated by the U.S., China would fight to the end to defend its own legitimate interests with all necessary measures.\u201d\n\nUnder the proposed Chinese countermeasures, American-produced fresh fruit, nuts, wine, seamless steel pipes and other goods would be hit by 15 percent tariffs, while another group of goods, including pork, would attract 25 percent tariffs.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nChina would also \u201ctake legal action within the framework of the World Trade Organization,\u201d the Chinese Commerce Ministry said.\n\nInside the White House, there was little of the rancorous debate that erupted before Mr. Trump announced the steel and aluminum tariffs earlier this month. The president has steadily winnowed free-trade advocates from the ranks of his cabinet, and these measures are unlikely to draw the wall of opposition from Republicans that the metal tariffs did.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s announcement brought some clarity to a process that the White House has largely conducted in secret, since the president announced an investigation of China\u2019s trade practices last summer. But more will be revealed when the administration publishes the list of Chinese goods it will target for tariffs within the next 15 days.\n\n\u201cWe learned something today, but there\u2019s still tremendous uncertainty about what\u2019s going to happen,\u201d said Chad P. Bown, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics. \u201cSo in a sense, we didn\u2019t learn much.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAdministration officials said they were tailoring the list to minimize price increases for consumers, who buy large quantities of goods from China, and were focusing in part on strategic industries China is attempting to build up with state support. But Mr. Bown noted that the president\u2019s target for tariffs \u2014 $60 billion \u2014 represents more than 10 percent of America\u2019s annual imports from China.\n\n\u201cEventually they will feed into higher consumer prices,\u201d he said.\n\nThe United States trade representative, Robert Lighthizer, told the Senate Finance Committee that tariffs should be levied on Chinese products from all the advanced industries it has vowed to build up as part of its \u201cMade in China 2025\u201d plan. Those include electric vehicles, high-tech shipping and aerospace technology. He called them \u201cthe ones I care about.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Lighthizer and his colleague, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, faced a barrage of questions and criticism from lawmakers, several of whom worried about Chinese retaliation.\n\n\u201cA state like Iowa stands to lose,\u201d particularly if China targets soybean exports, said Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa. Senator Pat Roberts, Republican of Kansas, said, \u201cWe\u2019re in a dire fix.\u201d\n\nMr. Lighthizer acknowledged those concerns. \u201cEvery time we take a trade action, agriculture is in the cross hairs,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s something we\u2019re very sympathetic to.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s announcement was welcomed by a leading Democratic trade hawk in the Senate, Sherrod Brown of Ohio, who said the tariffs were a first step toward a comprehensive response to China that should also include increased screening of foreign investment in the United States to ensure it does not hurt American jobs.\n\n\u201cI applaud the president\u2019s aggressiveness in targeting tariffs on a country that is clearly cheating,\u201d Mr. Brown said.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s move comes at a time when he has enlisted Mr. Xi to help pressure North Korea over its nuclear and ballistic missile programs. Last year, Mr. Trump said he had decided not to designate China as a currency manipulator, in part because China was cooperating in the pressure campaign. His explicit linkage of trade and security raises questions about whether the tensions from these tariffs will spill over into the North Korea issue.\n\n\u201cThe end objective of this is to get China to modify its unfair trade practices,\u201d Everett Eissenstat, the deputy director of the National Economic Council, said in a telephone call with reporters.", "title": "Trump Hits China With Stiff Trade Measures", "authors": ["Mark Landler", "Jim Tankersley"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "The rally, which had been rescheduled after the deadly Parkland, Fla., shooting last month, capped a frenzied stretch of fund-raising and campaigning on behalf of Mr. Saccone, who is locked in a tight race with the Democratic nominee, Conor Lamb.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s an extraordinary person,\u201d Mr. Trump said of Mr. Saccone, dismissing Mr. Lamb as \u201cLamb the Sham.\u201d \u201cThe people of Pittsburgh cannot be conned by this guy Lamb, because he\u2019s not going to vote for us.\u201d\n\nIt was an opening for Mr. Trump not only to try to apply his political sway in the year\u2019s first special election \u2014 one being looked at as a bellwether for the November midterm elections \u2014 but also to seize the opportunity to promote his new tariffs before a steel-country base of supporters far more receptive than the officials and pundits in Washington.\n\n\u201cSteel is back,\u201d he proclaimed more than once. \u201cAluminum is back.\u201d\n\nHe also, after receiving some boos upon first mentioning Mr. Kim, the North Korean dictator, said that he thought the North Koreans \u201cwant peace.\u201d He said that his unprecedented meeting could go two very different ways: \u201cWe may leave fast,\u201d or strike one of history\u2019s greatest deals.\n\nWhile the rally was not specifically advertised as one for Mr. Saccone, a loss by him would mark the third time that Mr. Trump had thrown his political might behind a candidate without success. With his low poll numbers, Republican leaders and the White House are trying to determine how to handle his desire to campaign in the midterms.\n\nBut he was a hit with the crowd on Saturday. He retreated to fan favorites: reminiscing about his Electoral College victory, and saying that there is a \u201clot of evil in Washington\u201d and that he is \u201cgetting it out.\u201d To cheers and laughter, Mr. Trump hurled some old and new slurs and insults toward his opponents as he complained about his media coverage and perceived Democratic obstruction.\n\nHe embellished his derisive \u201cSleepy Eyes Chuck Todd\u201d nickname for the \u201cMeet the Press\u201d host by calling him a \u201csleeping son of a bitch.\u201d He said \u201cPocahontas\u201d \u2014 his name for Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts \u2014 would produce bad television ratings if she challenged him in 2020. On Wednesday, after news of Ms. Hicks\u2019s exit was announced, the New Yorker writer Jia Tolentino tweeted: \u201cGoodbye to Hope Hicks, an object lesson in the quickest way a woman can advance under misogyny: silence, beauty, and unconditional deference to men.\u201d\n\nIn Washington, however, Ms. Hicks\u2019s success was viewed as a product of other qualities, including her nuanced understanding of Mr. Trump\u2019s moods, her ability to subtly nudge him away from his coarser impulses and her skill as a liaison for some of the most prominent journalists in the country.\n\n\u201cWhen she tells you something, you know she is speaking to the president, because she is with him all the time,\u201d said Steve Scully, the senior executive producer at C-Span and coordinator of the network\u2019s White House coverage. \u201cIt was amazing how often he would turn to Hope and ask her questions and ask her point of view. You can really tell, seeing the two of them interact, that there\u2019s a trust between the two of them.\u201d\n\nMs. Hicks was a key point of contact for reporters, editors and executives at television networks and major newspapers. Often, she could single-handedly arrange time with the easily distracted president. At a Paley Center panel discussion on Wednesday, the NBC News anchor Lester Holt described Ms. Hicks as his first contact for coordinating his interview with Mr. Trump last May. \u201cShe was quite helpful,\u201d Mr. Holt said.\n\nAnd in an administration riven by infighting, Ms. Hicks\u2019s privileged position with the president meant that, for journalists, she was among the few officials whose information was deemed reliable, or at least not often compromised by personal squabbles.\n\nOf course, she always advocated for her boss, lamenting that reporters did not see the empathetic and charming Mr. Trump whom she said she knew.", "title": "Trump Is \u2018Losing a Limb\u2019 With the Departure of Hope Hicks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "GENEVA \u2014 The handsome stone edifice that serves as the headquarters for the World Trade Organization rises like a fortress over Lake Geneva, projecting an air of impregnability. But lately the institution looks vulnerable, sowing worries that global commerce itself may be in jeopardy.\n\nAs the United States accuses China of predatory trading practices while doling out unilateral punishment, the trade organization tasked with preserving the peace appears marginalized.\n\nThe latest indication came on Thursday, when President Trump effectively bypassed the trading organization in announcing plans to impose tariffs on as much as $60 billion worth of Chinese imports, from electronics to running shoes. By Friday morning, China was threatening to retaliate with tariffs on some $3 billion worth of imports from the United States.\n\nDiplomats and trade officials said the American action \u2014 if followed through \u2014 would flout W.T.O. rules, given that the United States would be imposing tariffs without first adjudicating its grievances. Chinese retaliation would similarly deviate from W.T.O. rules.", "title": "Trump Just Pushed the World Trade Organization Toward Irrelevance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Clifford\u2019s lawyer, Michael Avenatti, said that he did not consider the restraining order, dated Feb. 27, valid, and that his client would proceed with her lawsuit in open court. \u201cThis should be decided publicly,\u201d he said.\n\nImage The White House\u2019s spokeswoman, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, said on Wednesday that the president\u2019s lawyer had won an arbitration proceeding against the actress. Credit Doug Mills/The New York Times\n\nMs. Clifford\u2019s nondisclosure contract, made public through her lawsuit, calls for disagreements to be settled through confidential, binding arbitration. The lawsuit was filed a week after Mr. Cohen initiated arbitration proceedings, but the court papers did not say what was at issue or refer to the restraining order.\n\nThe contract gives Mr. Trump the right to seek financial penalties of more than $1 million in arbitration should Ms. Clifford break or threaten to break her agreement to stay silent. It also gives him the right to obtain an injunction barring her from speaking while disputes are considered in arbitration or open court. Those terms prompted Ms. Clifford to change her plans about going public, according to two people familiar with the situation who were not authorized to speak about it.\n\nMs. Clifford had suggested she was free to speak out after Mr. Cohen disclosed last month that he had arranged the payment, prompting her to claim that the contract had been breached.\n\nThe restraining order took her by surprise. A close friend of Ms. Clifford\u2019s, J. D. Barrale, said in an interview that she learned Mr. Cohen initiated arbitration proceedings when she landed on a flight from Los Angeles to Texas. \u201cShe was shocked,\u201d Mr. Barrale said.\n\nMr. Avenatti said Ms. Clifford had \u201cnever even been provided an opportunity to respond\u201d to Mr. Cohen\u2019s action in arbitration.\n\nA copy of the restraining order, obtained by The Times and first reported by NBC News, left open the possibility that it could be modified in the future. But Mr. Avenatti said he questioned its validity because it was brought on behalf of Mr. Cohen, not Mr. Trump.", "title": "Trump Lawyer Obtained Restraining Order to Silence Stormy Daniels", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Mueller probe should never have been started in that there was no collusion and there was no crime,\u201d he wrote. \u201cIt was based on fraudulent activities and a Fake Dossier paid for by Crooked Hillary and the DNC, and improperly used in FISA COURT for surveillance of my campaign.\u201d\n\nMr. Dowd, by contrast, did not name the special counsel in his statement, but the implication that he believed Mr. Mueller should be fired was unmistakable. Such a move could set off alarms among Republicans in Congress, who have largely stood by as the president repeatedly assailed the Justice Department and the F.B.I.\n\nMr. Dowd said at first that he was speaking on behalf of the president but later backed off that assertion. He did not elaborate on why he was calling for the end of the investigation, saying only: \u201cJust end it on the merits in light of recent revelations.\u201d\n\nPeople close to the president were skeptical that Mr. Dowd was acting on his own. Mr. Trump has a history of using advisers to publicly test a message, giving him some distance from it. And Mr. Dowd\u2019s comments came at a time when members of Mr. Trump\u2019s legal team are jockeying to stay in his favor.\n\nHours later, the president echoed Mr. Dowd\u2019s accusations of corruption in the theoretical \u201cdeep state\u201d that Mr. Trump has long cast as a boogeyman working to undermine him.\n\n\u201cThere was tremendous leaking, lying and corruption at the highest levels of the FBI, Justice & State,\u201d he wrote on Twitter.\n\nThe president\u2019s tweets, posted on a Saturday in which he remained inside the White House with no public schedule, came as Mr. Mueller is said to have sent questions to Mr. Trump\u2019s legal team as part of negotiations over an interview with the president. Mr. Mueller is seeking the interview, according to two people close to the White House, in order to ask follow-up questions, but put forward the list as a start.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Dowd\u2019s remarks about Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation represented an extraordinary shift in public strategy for the Trump legal team. Since taking over the case last summer, Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyers have urged a strategy of restraint, in which the president avoids discussing Mr. Mueller or criticizing him, and the lawyers had done nothing publicly until now that could agitate the special counsel\u2019s team.\n\nThe comments by both Mr. Trump and Mr. Dowd lent credence to Mr. McCabe\u2019s assertion that the president sees his firing as directly tied into Mr. Mueller\u2019s case. Mr. McCabe, who is a potential witness in the investigation, declared that his dismissal was an attempt to undermine it.\n\nMr. Sessions fired Mr. McCabe for failing to be forthcoming with the department\u2019s internal watchdog about a conversation he authorized between F.B.I. officials and a journalist.\n\nLike Mr. Comey, Mr. McCabe also kept contemporaneous memos about his interactions with the president and his conversations with Mr. Comey, a person close to Mr. McCabe said on Saturday.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe memos could support the account of Mr. Comey, who described in his memos and congressional testimony repeated requests from the president to clear his name. Mr. Comey said Mr. Trump also asked him to end an investigation into his former national security adviser, Michael T. Flynn. The special counsel is investigating both matters.\n\nMr. McCabe\u2019s memos were left at the F.B.I., which means that Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigators have access to them as they work to corroborate Mr. Comey\u2019s account.\n\nMr. McCabe\u2019s lawyers had no comment on Saturday, and Mr. Rosenstein has repeatedly defended the special counsel, including in an interview this month with USA Today, in which he said he had seen no need to fire Mr. Mueller.\n\nMr. Comey, who has a book scheduled to be published next month, weighed in himself.\n\n\u201cMr. President, the American people will hear my story very soon,\u201d he tweeted. \u201cAnd they can judge for themselves who is honorable and who is not.\u201d\n\nThe president\u2019s supporters have tried to undercut the investigation as part of a broader attempt to clear him of wrongdoing. This month, Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee \u2014 which is led by a close ally of the president, Representative Devin Nunes of California \u2014 concluded their own investigation into Russia\u2019s election meddling, saying they had determined the president did nothing wrong. Democrats on the panel accused Republicans of putting partisan politics ahead of fact finding.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump, who has repeatedly criticized Mr. McCabe\u2019s wife for accepting hundreds of thousands of dollars in donations from a political committee tied to Terry McAuliffe, a Hillary Clinton ally, for a Virginia State Senate race, praised Mr. McCabe\u2019s ouster again on Saturday.\n\n\u201cThe Fake News is beside themselves that McCabe was caught, called out and fired. How many hundreds of thousands of dollars was given to wife\u2019s campaign by Crooked H friend, Terry M, who was also under investigation?\u201d he tweeted. \u201cHow many lies? How many leaks? Comey knew it all, and much more!\u201d\n\nMr. Trump has increasingly expressed frustration as the special counsel investigation has shown more signs of accelerating rather than ending. His legal team has worked to keep him from firing Mr. Mueller in the past. To keep the president at bay, the lawyers \u2014 led by the White House lawyer Ty Cobb \u2014 told him that Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation would be over by last December and that they would ask Mr. Mueller to put out a statement saying the president was not a target of the investigation.\n\nBut instead, Mr. Trump was livid anew this week over the Times report that Mr. Mueller had subpoenaed his corporate records, including those related to Russia, according to one person close to the White House.\n\nThe president\u2019s lawyers appear to be feeling increasingly uneasy about where they stand. This month, Mr. Trump met with a veteran Washington lawyer, Emmet T. Flood, to discuss coming on board to take over the president\u2019s dealings with Mr. Mueller\u2019s office and possibly replacing Donald F. McGahn II as White House counsel. The president\u2019s personal lawyers, Mr. Dowd and Jay Sekulow, did not know about the meeting, prompting concerns that they could be pushed aside, and potentially making them less resistant to Mr. Trump\u2019s whims about handling the inquiry.\n\nLast June, Mr. Trump backed down from his demand that Mr. Mueller be fired after Mr. McGahn threatened to quit. A month later, Mr. Trump said in an interview with The Times that the special counsel would be crossing a red line if he looked into his family\u2019s finances beyond any relationship with Russia. After the Trump Organization subpoena was revealed on Thursday, Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyers privately tried to play it down, in part to keep the president and his family calm.\n\nMr. Dowd has been at the center of a string of embarrassing episodes in recent months. In December, he said he had written a tweet posted by the president that implied Mr. Trump knew that Mr. Flynn had lied to the F.B.I. when Mr. Trump fired him.\n\nMonths earlier, Mr. Dowd was overheard by a Times reporter discussing details of a dispute inside the president\u2019s legal team over lunch at a Washington steakhouse.\n\nDemocrats seized on Mr. Dowd\u2019s statement on Saturday. Senator Mark Warner of Virginia, the top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee, called on lawmakers of both parties to defend Mr. Mueller.", "title": "Trump Lawyer Says Special Counsel Inquiry Should Be Ended", "authors": ["Michael S. Schmidt", "Maggie Haberman"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "With over a full year under Mr. Trump\u2019s belt, and his unorthodox management style fully in evidence, I asked several experts to assess the president\u2019s abilities as a manager.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s much worse than I expected,\u201d said Jeffrey Pfeffer, professor of organizational behavior at Stanford University and the author of \u201cPower: Why Some People Have It and Others Don\u2019t.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe most important thing you need as a chief executive is the ability to hire and retain talent,\u201d Mr. Pfeffer said. \u201cTrump said he\u2019d get all these great people to work for him. But the rate of departures is unprecedented. Either he hired badly, or he hired well but couldn\u2019t retain them. Either way, this reflects badly on his leadership.\u201d\n\nAs Jeffrey T. Polzer, professor of human resource management at Harvard Business School, told me last year, the time-tested approach is \u201cto surround yourself with talented people who have the most expertise, who bring different perspectives to the issue at hand.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThen you foster debate and invite different points of view in order to reach a high-quality solution,\u201d Mr. Polzer said.\n\nHe added that it \u201crequires an openness to being challenged, and some self-awareness and even humility to acknowledge that there are areas where other people know more than you do.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump does appear to solicit and consider the opinions of others, but they are as likely to be random guests at Mar-a-Lago, or television pundits, as they are experts in the field, or even his own appointees.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe lack of attention to data drives me nuts,\u201d Mr. Pfeffer said. Mr. Trump, he said, \u201cseems to have no interest in science, social science or data,\u201d citing White House initiatives to repeal Obamacare and to rescue the coal industry as glaring examples.\n\nOthers pointed to his threats to pull out of the North American Free Trade Agreement with little understanding of the consequences for American businesses and farmers, and his decision to abandon the Paris climate accord despite scant familiarity with the science of climate change.\n\n\u201cNothing about the chaos and turnover in the White House surprises me,\u201d said Charles M. Elson, a professor and director of the John L. Weinberg Center for Corporate Governance at the University of Delaware.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cHe hasn\u2019t changed in 30 years,\u201d Mr. Elson added. \u201cHe isn\u2019t bound by any traditional norms of management.\u201d\n\nYet despite the well-documented disarray prevailing in the West Wing, Mr. Trump\u2019s first year has yielded some major accomplishments: business-friendly tax legislation, the appointment of a reliably conservative Supreme Court justice in Neil Gorsuch, the selection of Jerome Powell as chairman of the Federal Reserve and the dismantling of a regulatory regime viewed as overly burdensome by the business community.\n\n\u201cYou have to hand it to him: He has pulled some rabbits out of his hat,\u201d Mr. Elson said. \u201cHardly anyone thought he could pull off tax legislation after so many other people had tried and failed.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Mr. Pfeffer said those achievements had occurred despite the chaos, not because of it. For every success, Mr. Trump has had notable failures, starting with overhauling immigration policy and repealing Obamacare.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve long felt that if Trump didn\u2019t do well, it would be because of organizational issues,\u201d Mr. Pfeffer said. \u201cEven with Republicans in control of both houses of Congress, he hasn\u2019t been able to pass much. That speaks to chaos in the policy sphere.\u201d\n\nMr. Elson said Mr. Trump acted more like the typical entrepreneur than an experienced manager. \u201cA problem with entrepreneurs is that people get tired of it and they move on,\u201d he said. \u201cPeople just get worn out. At some point you need a real manager. A lot of entrepreneurs sell their businesses when they reach a certain size and they realize they can\u2019t manage them.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWould naming Mr. Cohn as chief of staff ameliorate the problem? Despite disenchantment with Mr. Kelly and his handling of the Porter situation, no one I interviewed thinks Mr. Cohn could fundamentally change the dynamic in the Trump White House any more than Mr. Kelly has.\n\nMr. Cohn is now basking in the afterglow of the tax legislation, which seems to be growing in popularity with the public. His supporters point to the first-rate team he assembled at the National Economic Council as evidence that he \u2014 perhaps alone among top White House officials \u2014 could attract and retain talent. He enjoys good relations with Congress.\n\nBut if Mr. Cohn became Mr. Trump\u2019s chief of staff, he would have to sublimate his own beliefs to the president\u2019s agenda. As one former White House official told me, \u201cHe can\u2019t pull another Charlottesville,\u201d referring to Mr. Cohn\u2019s efforts last summer to publicly distance himself from the president\u2019s racially charged comments while still working for him.\n\nThanks to that incident, Mr. Cohn has already fallen from favor once, and his current rehabilitation may not last. People like Mr. Trump \u201chave friends for a day,\u201d Mr. Elson said. \u201cThat\u2019s another quality of the entrepreneur. Like it or not, it\u2019s part of what makes them successful.\u201d\n\nWhile Mr. Cohn has influential supporters at the White House, talk of his possible elevation has prompted plenty of opposition, too, especially from representatives of Mr. Trump\u2019s populist base. Mr. Cohn is, after all, a longtime Manhattan Democrat.\n\nA White House spokesman declined to comment on behalf of Mr. Cohn.\n\nIn any event, Mr. Trump may be oblivious to the staff turnover and widespread vacancies in the executive branch, and indifferent to calls to replace Mr. Kelly.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think Trump thinks much about management philosophy,\u201d Mr. Pfeffer said. \u201cHe ran for president as a lark, and look at him now. For him it\u2019s all upside.\u201d", "title": "Trump Management Style, Year 2: See Year 1", "authors": ["James B. Stewart", "Common Sense"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "The relationship was further eroded when it was reported that last summer he called the president a \u201cmoron\u201d at a gathering of national security and cabinet officials and, after Mr. Trump spoke respectfully of white nationalists who demonstrated in Charlottesville, Va., Mr. Tillerson said Mr. Trump \u201cspeaks for himself.\u201d\n\nSo the president announced he would replace Mr. Tillerson with Mike Pompeo, the C.I.A. director and former Tea Party congressman, who has endeared himself to Mr. Trump with his engaging approach during morning intelligence briefings. Mr. Pompeo has also endeared himself to the climate-denying Koch brothers, who, along with their family, employees and affiliated groups donated $357,300 to his campaigns and political action committee, according to the McClatchy newspapers. Mr. Pompeo is unlikely to be sidelined in major policy debates, as Mr. Tillerson was regularly, even though he too, unlike Mr. Trump, supported his agency\u2019s conclusion that the Kremlin interfered in the 2016 elections. But his hawkish approach could do serious damage on major national security issues, including Iran and North Korea, on which he has expressed views at odds with his predecessor\u2019s.\n\nThe timing of Mr. Tillerson\u2019s ouster most likely hinges on the fact that Mr. Trump is facing his biggest foreign policy gamble, a decision to hold direct negotiations over North Korea\u2019s nuclear weapons program, starting with face-to-face talks with the country\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, supposedly in May. Tough trade talks are also looming.\n\nMr. Trump and Mr. Kim are expected to set the stage for negotiations and then let senior teams for the two sides do the detail work, which is likely to take months if not years. Before the shakeup, it was assumed Mr. Tillerson would lead the American team \u2014 one hobbled by a lack of North Korea expertise. Now, that role is likely to be filled by Mr. Pompeo, who has effectively pushed for regime change in North Korea and even alluded to assassinating Mr. Kim.\n\nMr. Pompeo will face other challenges in managing an increasingly aggressive China, as well as dealing with Europe and Afghanistan and turmoil in Syria and other parts of the Middle East.\n\nTo replace Mr. Pompeo, the president chose Gina Haspel, the deputy director of the C.I.A., to become the first woman to head the agency.", "title": "Opinion | Trump May Make America Miss Rex Tillerson", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPresident Trump on Friday nominated Jon Parrish Peede as chairman of the National Endowment of the Humanities, bringing to an end speculation about who would take the helm at an agency he has repeatedly targeted for elimination.\n\nMr. Peede, a scholar of Southern literature by training, was publisher of the Virginia Quarterly Review from 2011 to 2016, and has also worked in various capacities at the National Endowment for the Arts, the humanities endowment\u2019s sister agency. He has been serving as the agency\u2019s acting director since May, when William D. Adams, an Obama appointee, stepped down, citing personal reasons and a desire to let the transition go forward.\n\nIn a statement, Mr. Peede, who has already created a new set of N.E.H. grants focused on infrastructure needs at cultural institutions, summed up his mission as \u201censuring that all Americans have access to our country\u2019s cultural resources.\u201d\n\nThe N.E.H., along with the arts endowment, has been the site of ideological battles since the culture wars of the early 1990s, with conservatives often accusing it of pushing a left-wing agenda.\n\nWhile such overt conflict has largely died down, Mr. Trump last year proposed eliminating its roughly $150 million annual budget entirely, along with that of the National Endowment of the Arts. Congress rebuffed the attempt, and funding for both agencies was renewed. But in February, the administration released a budget for fiscal year 2019 that included $42 million for \u201corderly closure\u201d of the agency, as well as calling for closure of the arts endowment and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. In a speech at a community college here, he offered up more tough talk than he did specifics about his plan, or how he would pay for it.\n\nThe president said that most of the heroin in the country comes in from the southern border, \u201cwhere eventually the Democrats will agree with us and build the wall to keep the damn drugs out\u201d; he denounced so-called sanctuary cities, which he blamed for an uptick in overdoses; and he called for harsher penalties for drug dealers.\n\n\u201cIf we don\u2019t get tougher on drug dealers, we are wasting our time,\u201d Mr. Trump said, later adding, \u201cThat toughness includes the death penalty\u201d \u2014 a position that was at odds with what White House officials told reporters on Sunday.", "title": "Trump Offers Tough Talk but Few Details in Unveiling Plan to Combat Opioids", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "On Thursday, President Trump suggested that the United States could pull its approximately 2,000 troops out of Syria \u201cvery soon.\u201d The comments surprised Defense Department officials who have maintained that some kind of American presence in parts of Syria may be necessary to avoid recreating the conditions that led to the rise of the Islamic State \u2014 and also to avoid ceding influence in the country to Russia.\n\n\u201cVery soon, we\u2019re coming out,\u201d Mr. Trump said during a rally in Ohio. \u201cWe\u2019re going to have 100 percent of the caliphate, as they call it \u2014 sometimes referred to as \u2018land\u2019 \u2014 taking it all back quickly, quickly.\u201d\n\nThe suspension of funds for recovery efforts in Syria comes as the administration reassesses its role in the conflict there, a State Department official said on Friday. The freeze on funding was first reported by The Wall Street Journal.\n\n\u201cThere will be meetings on this next week,\u201d said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because a policy review was continuing. \u201cObviously, we, State, hope that this decision is reversed.\u201d\n\nA National Security Council official explained the White House\u2019s position: \u201cIn line with the president\u2019s guidance, the Department of State continually re-evaluates appropriate assistance levels and how best they might be utilized, which they do on an ongoing basis.\u201d\n\nSecretary of State Rex W. Tillerson had committed the aid in February in Kuwait at a meeting of countries who have joined together to defeat the Islamic State.\n\nPentagon officials in the past few months have said repeatedly that a complete withdrawal of American troops could leave a void.
