But he also has to protect the U.S. And he feels that many countries\u201d have engaged in unfair trade practices. Mr. Kudlow cited China as a prominent example, expressing a view that is widely held within the administration. The White House has taken a series of steps to curb China and is expected to announce tariffs on certain Chinese products in the coming weeks.\n\nMr. Kudlow has long espoused a traditional conservative embrace of free trade, but it remains to be seen how vocally he will push back on the growing ascendance of West Wing advisers who are trade skeptics and have urged Mr. Trump to adopt protectionist measures to protect American industry.\n\nStock markets, which have been rattled by the White House tariffs, did not react positively to news of Mr. Kudlow\u2019s appointment on Wednesday. The Dow Jones industrial average was down more than 200 points for most of the afternoon, once news media outlets began reporting Mr. Kudlow was the pick.\n\nMr. Kudlow is a radio and television commentator and an economics consultant. He was a zealous convert to the supply-side economic policies that swept the Republican Party in the late 1970s. He is a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of the supply-side economist Arthur Laffer, with whom Mr. Kudlow worked on Ronald Reagan\u2019s 1980 presidential campaign. Mr. Kudlow went on to serve in Mr. Reagan\u2019s Office of Management and Budget.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLike many past National Economic Council directors, he is not an academically trained economist \u2014 he studied for a master\u2019s degree at Princeton University but did not earn one \u2014 but he served as chief economist for Bear Stearns and made a name advising prominent conservative politicians. In the early 1990s, Mr. Kudlow took a leave from the firm to enter treatment for drug and alcohol addiction; his colleagues said he abused cocaine.\n\nMr. Kudlow has spoken frequently about his addiction and ensuing sobriety in the ensuing years.\n\nHe said Thursday that staying clean and sober for nearly 23 years \u201cis the center of my life\u201d and \u201cmy No. 1 job.\u201d\n\nAsked whether he thought the substance abuse could prove problematic for him as a White House staff nominee, he said, \u201cWe\u2019ll see how that plays out.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Kudlow was an early and enthusiastic supporter of Mr. Trump\u2019s run for the presidency, advising the neophyte candidate on economic issues and pushing him to go big on cutting taxes. The men agreed on their desire for growth-goosing tax cuts but disagreed on trade, on which Mr. Trump ran as a populist and Mr. Kudlow preached free-market principles.\n\nMr. Kudlow criticized the president after the emergence of the \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d tape in October 2016. He later re-endorsed him, but Mr. Trump, who nurses grudges, was angry for some time, according to people close to him.\n\n\n\nThe trade critique carried into Mr. Trump\u2019s tenure in the White House. Like Mr. Cohn, Mr. Kudlow had been publicly critical of Mr. Trump\u2019s push for stiff and sweeping tariffs on steel and aluminum imports. He jointly wrote a critical column urging the president to reconsider his plan to impose tariffs. \u201cTrump should also examine the historical record on tariffs,\u201d he and his co-authors wrote, \u201cbecause they have almost never worked as intended and almost always deliver an unhappy ending.\u201d\n\nMr. Kudlow said Wednesday that although he had little stomach for blanket tariffs, he was \u201cabsolutely delighted\u201d that Mr. Trump had softened his stance since first announcing global tariffs on steel and aluminum. \u201cWe talked a lot about that,\u201d Mr. Kudlow said, adding that Mr. Trump \u201cregards tariffs as a negotiating tool. And I think that\u2019s fair.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump indicated on Tuesday that he saw little disagreement with Mr. Kudlow on the issue of tariffs.\n\n\u201cI want to have a divergent opinion,\u201d Mr. Trump told reporters. \u201cWe agree on most. He now has come around to believing in tariffs as also a negotiating point. I\u2019m renegotiating trade deals and without tariffs we wouldn\u2019t do nearly as well. But Larry has been a friend of mine for a long time. He backed me very early in the campaign; I think the earliest; I think he was one of my original backers. He\u2019s a very, very talented man, a good man.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt remains to be seen whether Mr. Kudlow can navigate the chaos that has surrounded the White House and often clouded its message or if he can convince Mr. Trump to follow his advice. Mr. Kudlow said he plans to try.\n\n\u201cI expect to have a very disciplined process,\u201d he said, one that \u201cprovides the best policy advice possible to the president.\u201d\n\nStephen Moore, a longtime friend of Mr. Kudlow\u2019s and an informal adviser to Mr. Trump, said Mr. Kudlow would help with a pressing challenge: How to convince voters to credit the president, and his policies, for an improving economy. Surveys of businesses and voters show economic confidence is strong, but Mr. Trump\u2019s approval ratings are still hovering around 40 percent.\n\n\u201cThe communication of all these triumphs has not been fully communicated,\u201d said Mr. Moore, whom many expect to ultimately go to work with Mr. Kudlow at the N.E.C.\n\nAfter Republicans pushed a $1.5 trillion cut through Congress late last year, Mr. Kudlow praised it effusively, predicting it would usher in long-term annual growth of 3 percent to 4 percent \u2014 a more optimistic assessment than most independent economists have offered \u2014 and would help Republicans in this year\u2019s midterm elections.\n\nGene Sperling, a former N.E.C. director under President Bill Clinton and again under President Barack Obama, said Mr. Kudlow would have a difficult job \u2014 and that communicating happy economic news was the least of his tasks.\n\n\u201cThe fundamental job of the N.E.C. director is to ensure that the president is getting, in a fair way, the diverse advice of his economic cabinet, and to be the top economic person in the West Wing in advising the president on day by day and long term matters,\u201d Mr. Sperling said. \u201cHowever good Larry may be on TV, it would be very, very sad if the president looked at this job as fundamentally promoting with the media whatever the president\u2019s political interests are.\u201d", "title": "Trump Picks CNBC\u2019s Larry Kudlow as Top Economic Adviser", "authors": ["Maggie Haberman", "Kate Kelly", "Jim Tankersley"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "The effect of the China tariffs would be larger and more concentrated than the steel and aluminum measures and would have a bigger impact on United States consumers, who are heavy purchasers of electronics, clothing and other Chinese imports. The steel and aluminum tariffs would affect imports of roughly $33 billion, excluding Canada and Mexico, which are expected to be exempt from the measures, said Joseph Parilla of the Brookings Institution. The China moves would affect at least $50 billion a year in imports, officials said.\n\nChinese companies have also been placing big bets on American companies. New Chinese acquisition deals in the United States once totaled tens of billions of dollars annually, according to Rhodium Group, which tracks Chinese investments abroad, though last year they fell sharply to $8.7 billion as China cracked down on money leaving its borders.\n\nChinese companies have purchased many nonstrategic assets like movie theaters and the Waldorf Astoria hotel in New York. But they also sought out deals in cutting-edge areas like semiconductors and start-ups related to autonomous driving as China looked to upgrade its technological capabilities. China sees the American stranglehold on fundamental technologies as a long-term economic and security threat to its rise as a superpower.\n\nUnlike the metal tariffs, which caused bitter divisions within the Trump administration and were opposed by many Republican lawmakers and businesspeople, the technology moves against China are likely to be politically popular on Capitol Hill and throughout some industries.\n\n\u201cTheir theft costs us over $350 billion per year, so the bigger the better,\u201d said Daniel DiMicco, a steel executive and trade adviser to the Trump campaign, referring to the forced transfer of intellectual property and other unfair practices alleged by the administration.\n\nThe business community, which long defended trade with China despite accusations of theft of intellectual property, has grown more dissatisfied with adverse treatment in the Chinese economy. With the Chinese government and state-owned enterprises playing an ever-larger role in the market, the environment for American companies has steadily deteriorated.\n\nStill, American business groups expressed concern over the possibility that the United States tariffs would spur others around the world to raise their own trade barriers.", "title": "Trump Plans Stiff Trade Tariffs and Other Penalties on China", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump on Tuesday is to visit a barren stretch of scrubland in San Diego to view eight attempts at realizing his vision for a \u201cbig, beautiful wall.\u201d All the prototypes are big. None are beautiful.\n\nThe eight stolid slabs awaiting Mr. Trump inside the razor wire in the border neighborhood of Otay Mesa were chosen from numerous proposals (the Department of Homeland Security refused to say how many) submitted to the agency last year. In soliciting ideas, the department said that each prototype would be judged, along with its impenetrability, on \u201caesthetics and innovative design.\u201d\n\nInnovation they got. Among the unsuccessful bidders was Clayton Industries, a Pittsburgh-based outfit that envisioned a 30-foot wall reinforced by sensors, an electrified chain-link fence and a railroad track dumping nuclear waste into a 100-foot deep moat. The waste is used as a power source.", "title": "Trump Plans to View Wall Prototypes. Here Are Some He Won\u2019t See.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump appears to be taking advantage of the vacuum created by the resignation of Mr. Cohn, who was the plan\u2019s loudest opponent, to push the tariffs through. Mr. Cohn, who argued that tariffs would create a global trade war, found himself overshadowed by a group of more protectionist-minded advisers who have urged the president to follow through with the get-tough pledges he made during his campaign.\n\nThose advisers have been in ascendence, including Mr. Navarro, a trade skeptic who had been sidelined by Mr. Cohn. Mr. Navarro was recently promised a promotion and made the rounds on Sunday talk shows to promote Mr. Trump\u2019s trade policy. Mr. Ross succeeded in moving up last week\u2019s announcement, over the objections of Mr. Cohn. Robert Lighthizer, the United States trade representative who has pushed trading partners to accede to the country\u2019s demands, has become a trusted adviser to the president.\n\nThat group has a much more binary view of trade, seeing it as a zero-sum game in which the United States is losing. The advisers have pushed the president to withdraw from trade deals like Nafta and to carry out the type of stiff tariffs that Mr. Trump seems poised to impose on steel and aluminum imports. They see the United States\u2019 ballooning trade deficit, which hit a nine-year high on Wednesday, as evidence that more needs to be done to put the country on the winning end of global trade.\n\nThe rise of the populist faction is already fanning fears on Wall Street and among foreign officials that Mr. Trump could start and escalate a global trade war or take a more combative stance toward trading partners and international groups like the World Trade Organization. Foreign officials viewed Mr. Cohn as a reliable ally on global economic issues and as someone who could express their views to the president.\n\nThe prospect of approaching tariffs has set off furious lobbying from governments around the world, who have tried to sway the administration with offers of friendship and threats of retaliation. On Wednesday, the European Union released a list of American-made goods it would penalize if the tariffs went through.\n\nChina cautioned that it was prepared to \u201cmake an appropriate and necessary response\u201d should the United States impose the tariffs.\n\n\u201cChoosing a trade war is a mistaken prescription,\u201d China\u2019s foreign minister, Wang Yi, said during a news conference on Thursday in Beijing. \u201cIn the end, you will only hurt others and yourself.\u201d", "title": "Trump Prepares to Formalize Tariffs but Floats Exemptions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. \u2014 President Trump is pressing congressional Republicans to oppose funding for a new rail tunnel between New York and New Jersey, using the power of his office to block a key priority for the region and his Democratic rivals, according to several people with knowledge of his actions.\n\nMr. Trump urged Speaker Paul D. Ryan this week not to support funding for the $30 billion project, two people familiar with the conversation said.\n\nThe president\u2019s decision to weigh in forcefully against the so-called Gateway infrastructure project, which has been one of the United States\u2019 top transportation priorities for years, adds a significant obstacle to getting the project underway in the near future.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s opposition to the project is in part the result of his belief that it is important to Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, according to one person with knowledge of the president\u2019s thinking on the issue.", "title": "Trump Pushes Republicans in Congress to Oppose Funding Hudson Rail Tunnel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "From President Trump\u2019s order:\n\n(a) There is credible evidence that leads me to believe that Broadcom Limited, a limited company organized under the laws of Singapore (Broadcom), along with its partners, subsidiaries, or affiliates, including Broadcom Corporation, a California corporation, and Broadcom Cayman L.P., a Cayman Islands limited partnership, and their partners, subsidiaries, or affiliates (together, the Purchaser), through exercising control of Qualcomm Incorporated (Qualcomm), a Delaware corporation, might take action that threatens to impair the national security of the United States; and (b) Provisions of law, other than section 721 and the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (50 U.S.C. 1701 et seq.), do not, in my judgment, provide adequate and appropriate authority for me to protect the national security in this matter.\n\nFurther down\n\n(e) The Purchaser and Qualcomm shall immediately and permanently abandon the proposed takeover. Immediately upon completion of all steps necessary to terminate the proposed takeover of Qualcomm, the Purchaser and Qualcomm shall certify in writing to the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) that such termination has been effected in accordance with this order and that all steps necessary to fully and permanently abandon the proposed takeover of Qualcomm have been completed.\n\nPhoto\n\nCan Solomon get Goldman playing a new tune?\n\nMost C.E.O.s have to go to work each day and grind out better margins in highly competitive businesses that taxpayers won\u2019t bail out if they blow up.\n\nThis is now the fate that awaits the next C.E.O. of Goldman Sachs.\n\nIn apparently priming David M. Solomon for the job, Goldman seems to be signaling that, even if trading revenue revives after some difficult quarters, it intends to press on with its efforts to bolster its nontrading businesses, like lending to corporations and consumers. Mr. Solomon, after a successful run as the head of Goldman\u2019s powerful deal-making business, embodies in many ways the bank\u2019s hopes to be far more than a high-octane trading shop.\n\nOf course, if the Trump administration guts Wall Street regulations, particularly the Volcker Rule, Goldman may be tempted to pile back into trading. But the bank\u2019s recent track record in trading suggests that would not be a good idea.\n\nNot only does Goldman\u2019s business that trades bonds, derivatives, currencies and commodities bounce around too much for shareholders\u2019 tastes, it is opaque. Bank executives are often loath to talk in detail when it underperforms.\n\nGoldman also made strategic mistakes in this business in recent years. It focused too heavily on hedge fund clients, something it is trying to fix by reaching out to different types of customers. Its commodities business, which it clung to in the face of political pressure, has been a drawn out disappointment.\n\nAnd Wall Street traders ought not to get too excited about the prospects of deregulation. As some rules get loosened, others may get toughened up, like those that would liquidate a troubled Wall Street firm rather than bail it out. While the government may not be winding down any large banks anytime soon, the diminished likelihood of bailouts can force up the cost of borrowing for firms like Goldman. This, in turn, may steer them away from riskier businesses like trading.\n\nInvestors still seem to doubt Goldman\u2019s desire to adapt to a much more ordinary future. This is revealed in a comparison of Goldman and its rival, Morgan Stanley.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGoldman\u2019s return on shareholder equity, a closely watched metric that quantifies the profits generated on shareholders\u2019 money, has been higher than that of Morgan Stanley in recent years. But investors seem just as enthusiastic about the future of Morgan Stanley. Its stock trades at the same multiple to shareholders equity as Goldman\u2019s. Why? Morgan Stanley has arguably done more than Goldman to diversify away from trading to businesses, like wealth management, that are more stable.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nAnd then there was one.\n\nDavid M. Solomon is Goldman Sachs\u2019s heir apparent.\n\nThe Wall Street firm said Mr. Solomon would serve as its sole president and chief operating officer, setting him up as the potential successor to Lloyd C. Blankfein, the investment bank\u2019s longtime chief executive.\n\nContext\n\nMr. Solomon and Harvey M. Schwartz were seen as the favorites to eventually replace Mr. Blankfein when they were named co-chief operating officers and presidents in December 2016.\n\nBut, Mr. Schwartz, who previously served as the bank\u2019s chief financial officer and global co-head of the securities division, has decided to retire in April, Goldman said on Monday.\n\n\u201cHarvey has been a mentor to many, and his influence has made an indelible impact on generations of professionals at Goldman Sachs,\u201d Mr. Blankfein said in a news release. \u201cI want to thank Harvey for all he\u2019s done for the firm.\u201d\n\nMr. Solomon joined Goldman Sachs in 1999 and previously served as co-head of its investment banking division.\n\n\u2014 Chad Bray\n\nCritic\u2019s corner\n\nAnthony Currie of Breakingviews writes: \u201cIf Solomon does take the reins, it would end some 12 years of traders holding top positions at the Wall Street firm \u2013 and serve as another sign of Goldman\u2019s troubles in that business.\u201d\n\nCase in point:\n\n\u2022 Trading accounted for 53 percent of Goldman\u2019s revenue in 2012.\n\n\u2022 It made just over a third of the firm\u2019s revenue last year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMeanwhile, takings from merger advisory and stock-and-bond underwriting \u2013 Solomon\u2019s world \u2013 increased by half over the past six years. So positioning him as likely heir would look like a way of rewarding past success.\u201d\n\nGoldman\u2019s M&A business is off to slow start in 2018.\n\nGoldman\u2019s reputation for advising companies in mergers and acquisitions is well earned. Most years, it tops the rankings of advisers by deal volume known as the league tables.\n\nSo it was a bit surprising to see Goldman currently ranked fifth on both the global and the United States league tables. Here\u2019s a look:\n\nGlobal\n\nMorgan Stanley: $228.88 billion\n\nJPMorgan: $198.82 billion\n\nBank of America Merrill Lynch: $138.76 billion\n\nLazard: $134.39 billion\n\nGoldman Sachs: $131.56 billion\n\nUnited States\n\nMorgan Stanley: $132.36 billion\n\nLazard: $119.69 billion\n\nJPMorgan: $114.37 billion\n\nCenterview: $112.75 billion\n\nGoldman Sachs: $102.54 billion\n\nTwo points to note: 1) It is still early in the year and one big deal can reshuffle the rankings; 2) The value of transactions Goldman has advised on this year is up 31 percent from the same period a year ago.\n\nPhoto\n\nPresident Trump\u2019s new favorite to replace Gary Cohn...\n\nLarry Kudlow emerged Monday as the latest favorite in a changing rotation of potential replacements for Gary D. Cohn as the head the National Economic Council.\n\nThe job has not been formally offered to Mr. Kudlow, but the CNBC television commentator, who has informally advised President Trump on economic issues, is likely to interview him in the coming days.\n\nContext\n\nFrom the NYT\u2019s Maggie Haberman and Jim Tankersley:\n\nHeading into the weekend, the top contender to replace Mr. Cohn was Christopher Liddell, who is a special assistant to the president working with the Office of American Innovation on a team led by Jared Kushner, Mr. Trump\u2019s son-in-law and senior adviser. Mr. Liddell\u2019s previous experience as a chief financial officer for Microsoft had been seen as a selling point. But after The New York Times reported that Mr. Liddell was under consideration, Mr. Trump received pushback from people both inside and outside the White House, according to the people close to the president. On Monday, The Wall Street Journal\u2019s editorial board wrote a piece critical of Mr. Liddell\u2019s views on free trade. On Sunday, Mr. Trump again began discussing Mr. Kudlow as an option, the people close to the president said.\n\nPhoto\n\nDropbox looks to raise up to $648 million in its I.P.O.\n\nIn a revised prospectus filed this morning, the online storage company said that it planned to sell 36 million shares at $16 to $18 a share. At the midpoint of that range, Dropbox would be valued at about $7.5 billion, compared to the $10 billion of its most recent private fund-raising.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe big thought: The Dropbox offering \u2014 along with that of Spotify \u2014 could show how interested Wall Street investors are in the latest batch of Silicon Valley \u201cunicorns,\u201d or privately held companies worth at least $1 billion.\n\nThe man who made Dropbox: Meet Drew Houston, who created a multibillion-dollar business because he forgot to bring a USB flash drive one day while a student at M.I.T. His holdings could be worth nearly $1.7 billion\n\nCan Dropbox justify a $6.8 billion valuation?\n\nThe market for initial public offerings is on a tear, and, going by Dropbox\u2019s latest financial filing, it may be getting a little overheated.\n\nDropbox, a company that stores files on remote computers for consumers and businesses, on Monday said it aims to price its shares at between $16 and $18.\n\nThe midpoint of those two prices would value Dropbox at around $6.8 billion, excluding some shares that may be awarded to executives in the future.\n\nThat\u2019s a lot, though about 30 percent below the $10 billion valuation it received after its fundraising round in 2014.\n\nAt $6.8 billion, Dropbox would be trading at just over six times the $1.1 billion in sales it had for 2017. Companies in the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500 index trade at 2.3 times sales. Dropbox would also have a higher valuation than Box, another file storage company, whose market value is 5.6 times the revenue it generated in its last fiscal year, which ended in January.\n\nInvestors may, however, decide that Dropbox\u2019s higher valuation is not justified. True, its sales grew at an impressive 31 percent last year, but that is not materially faster than the 27 percent Box achieved in its latest fiscal year. (Revenue grew 6.3 percent at companies in the S.&P. 500, according to FactSet.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNeither company made a profit in their most recent fiscal year. Both are generating positive cash flows, though. And at $330 million last year, Dropbox\u2019s cash flows were more than five times those of Box\u2019s $62 million. If Dropbox went public at the $6.8 billion implied in Monday\u2019s filing, it would trade at 21 times its 2017 cash flows. That is pricey, but that is less than half of Box\u2019s cash flow multiple.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nIt\u2019s not quite Netflix, but...\n\nSpeculation has long swirled that Apple should buy Netflix. On Monday, the iPhone maker agreed to buy Texture, the \u201cNetflix of magazines.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe digital magazine app offers users a $10 a month subscription to read more than 200 magazines, including People, the New Yorker, Vanity Fair, and Vogue.\n\nThe deal is part of Apple\u2019s effort to bolster its services businesses. The WSJ reports:\n\nApple has set a goal of increasing total revenue from services to more than $40 billion by 2020. The company generated nearly $30 billion in services revenue in its fiscal year ended in September.\n\nThe Texture transaction follows Apple\u2019s deal for Shazam, the music recognition app, in December.\n\nTexture is owned by Next Issue Media, a joint-venture between Cond\u00e9 Nast, Hearst, Meredith, News Corp, Rogers Media and K.K.R.\n\nApple did not disclose the price.\n\n\n\nShort Netflix?\n\nShares of the video streaming company are down 3.4 percent Monday to about $320 after the short seller Andrew Left of Citron Research tweeted that he thinks the stock can be \u201dshorted back to $300.\u201d\n\nShares of Netflix close Friday at $331.44, up nearly 14 percent for March.\n\nPhoto\n\nBehind the scenes of a royal crackdown\n\nFrom the outside, the Saudi businessmen (including Prince Alwaleed bin Talal) who were corralled into Riyadh\u2019s Ritz-Carlton \u2014 in what Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman described as an anticorruption campaign \u2014 seemed to be in a gilded cage.\n\nThe reality was far more disturbing. Many were physically abused and one captive was killed, witnesses told the NYT. The Saudi government extracted billions of dollars of assets from detainees to set them free.\n\nMore from Ben Hubbard, David Kirkpatrick, Kate Kelly and Mark Mazzetti of the NYT:\n\nOne former detainee, forced to wear a tracking device, has sunk into depression as his business collapses. \u201cWe signed away everything,\u201d a relative of his said. \u201cEven the house I am in, I am not sure if it is still mine.\u201d\n\nThe net effect: Many outside investors, whom Saudi officials have hoped to woo to help transform the kingdom\u2019s economy, are now rattled by what they say was a lack of transparency.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOf note: The roles of the accounting company PWC and the law firm Clifford Chance in the Saudi government\u2019s takeover of MBC, a broadcaster.\n\nElsewhere in the kingdom: Aramco is more likely to go public next year than late this year as originally expected, Michael reported yesterday. Among the issues is that much of the work in pulling off the biggest I.P.O. in history has yet to be finished.\n\nPhoto\n\nParkland students thank businesses for support\n\nStudents of Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School took out a full-page ad in the NYT over the weekend to thank businesses \u201cwho acted on their consciences and took positive steps for change\u201d after the school shooting in Parkland, Fla. Among the companies thanked: BlackRock, Bumble, Delta, Dick\u2019s Sporting Goods, Gucci, Kroger, REI and Walmart.\n\nThe students are looking for GoFundMe donations for their March For Our Lives on March 24 in Washington.\n\nLots of big businesses weren\u2019t mentioned. Let us know if your company is changing its policies or donating to the march.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe downside of a trade war\n\nHistory hasn\u2019t been kind to those who seek victory in trade conflicts, though it remains unclear whether President Trump\u2019s tariffs will play out the same way.\n\nFarmers in the Midwest are fearful of a tit-for-tat response that could lose them customers. And investors are watching to see whether a full-blown global trade conflict will erupt.\n\nThe politics flyaround\n\n\u2022 Mr. Trump\u2019s unpredictability has helped cast China as a more stable superpower. And changes to the Chinese Constitution that allow President Xi Jinping to govern indefinitely could usher him into a global club of autocrats alongside leaders like Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore and Vladimir Putin of Russia.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Business are scrambling to address errors and ambiguities in the U.S. tax overhaul. Among them: Salle Yoo, Uber\u2019s longtime top lawyer, and Rachel Whetstone, the company\u2019s communications head, who have both since left the company.\n\nAnd then there was Bill Gurley of the investment firm Benchmark. According to the article:\n\nAs Gurley pondered his options, he received an email that kicked him in the gut. It was from Katrina Lake, C.E.O. of the apparel-shopping service Stitch Fix, one of Benchmark\u2019s other highly successful portfolio companies. Lake lambasted Gurley for not doing enough to fix Uber. She accused him of shirking his responsibility to make Silicon Valley a better place.\n\nElsewhere in Uber: How the company can still create its own reality distortion field for investors. How it plans to expand Uber Eats. Oh, and its brand chief, Bozoma St. John, has quietly been driving for Uber Pool.\n\nThe virtual currency corner: Bitcoin is at $9,882.73. Some investors are using the virtual currency as an indicator of when the stock market will drop. Some exchanges are reportedly charging up to $1 million for the listing of initial coin offerings on their platforms. And scammers made off with more than $2 million in digital money with a fake I.C.O.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 SoftBank is bringing together its Vision Fund and Fortress Investment to create an investing powerhouse. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Trump Puts an End to Broadcom\u2019s Bid for Qualcomm: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump \u2014 surrounded by his commerce secretary, Wilbur Ross, his trade adviser Peter Navarro and others \u2014 asked for a figure beyond $30 billion and for the plan to be officially announced in the coming weeks, according to two people familiar with the exchange.\n\nThe administration is devising the measure to broadly counter a Chinese strategy known as the Made in China 2025 plan. China introduced a comprehensive initiative in 2015 to upgrade Chinese industry over the next decade and dominate sectors of the future, including advanced information technology, new energy vehicles and aerospace equipment.\n\nUnlike the steel and aluminum measure, which divided the president\u2019s advisers and his own party, the idea of targeting China has broad support among a number of officials who believe China is cheating in global trade.\n\nGary D. Cohn, a top economic adviser who resigned over the steel and aluminum tariffs, had approved of action against China, the people familiar with the discussions said. Orrin G. Hatch, the chairman of the powerful Senate Finance Committee, and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, Republicans who criticized those tariffs, have also endorsed a tough approach toward China.\n\nCongress is also weighing legislation that would strengthen national security checks on Chinese investment. In a House hearing on Thursday, Heath P. Tarbert, an assistant secretary of the Treasury Department, said the current system for assessing investment is riddled with loopholes that allowed Chinese companies to evade such checks.\n\nConcern over China\u2019s practices picked up speed at the end of the Obama administration and has only increased since. Last year, a technology-focused unit in the Defense Department issued a report arguing that rising Chinese investment in Silicon Valley was giving China unprecedented access to the military technologies of the future, and increasing Chinese ownership of supply chains that service the United States military.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn recent months, China\u2019s political apparatus has exerted even greater control over the nation\u2019s economy. Business leaders and politicians of both parties now widely say that Washington\u2019s past strategy of offering Beijing economic incentives to liberalize its market has failed. On Sunday, China officially ended term limits on the presidency, clearing the way for President Xi Jinping to stay in power indefinitely.\n\nAdministration officials say that past failure to rein in China warrants a much tougher approach. Mr. Trump took one step toward this in his national security strategy, which identified China as an economic aggressor. When a top Chinese economic envoy visited in late February, the administration asked China to shave $100 billion off its $375.2 billion trade surplus with the United States, two people close to the talks said. And while the steel and aluminum tariffs will hit many countries, they are primarily aimed at combating overcapacity in Chinese metals, including those that are routed through other nations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe next step, advisers say, is to more aggressively focus on trade with China.\n\nThe United States is expected to impose tariffs on Chinese imports of high-technology goods specified in the Made in China 2025 plan, including semiconductors and new energy vehicles. But they could go beyond that to target more mundane products, including consumer electronics, apparel and even shoes. The breadth of the tariffs remains a contentious topic in the business sector and the White House, with some industries fretting about retaliation and increased costs to American companies and consumers.\n\nThomas J. Donohue, the president of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, said on Wednesday that while the administration was right to focus on China\u2019s unfair trade practices, his group strongly disagreed with sweeping tariffs.\n\n\u201cSimply put, tariffs are damaging taxes on American consumers,\u201d he said. \u201cTariffs of $30 billion a year would wipe out over a third of the savings American families received from the doubling of the standard deduction in tax reform.\u201d\n\nHun Quach, the vice president for international trade at the Retail Industry Leaders Association, said that tariffs on apparel, shoes and electronics would hit American families most. \u201cIs the best response to make American consumers pay for China\u2019s violations? We don\u2019t think so,\u201d she said.\n\nAlthough there is wide support for taking action against unfair trade practices by China, business groups and economists still say the measure could be risky. The United States and China maintain the world\u2019s largest trading relationship, and the tariffs could easily provoke a backlash.\n\n\u201cThey know our system inside out,\u201d said Jim McGregor, the chairman of the greater China region for APCO Worldwide. He added, referring to the House speaker and the Senate majority leader: \u201cThey know what companies are important to Paul Ryan. They know what companies are important to Mitch McConnell. They know which trade associations and political groups have a big voice in Washington.\u201d\n\nScott Kennedy, a China expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said that while China deserved a tough response, he feared the consequences of the administration\u2019s actions had not been well considered. \u201cYou really have to be smart,\u201d he said. \u201cThe Chinese aren\u2019t just going to fold over on this.\u201d\n\nMr. Kennedy compared China to a bully that had stolen America\u2019s lunch money. \"You want to teach them a lesson,\u201d he said. \u201cBut it\u2019s not as simple as going up in the playground and punching them on the nose.\u201d", "title": "Trump Readies Sweeping Tariffs and Investment Restrictions on China", "authors": ["Ana Swanson"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Inside the White House, the debate has pitted hard-liners like Peter Navarro, the president\u2019s trade adviser, and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross against more pro-trade voices, like Mr. Trump\u2019s chief economic adviser, Gary D. Cohn, who argue that the measure could disrupt international alliances and global supply chains.\n\nRepublican lawmakers have criticized tariffs as undercutting the $1.5 trillion tax cut that they worked in lock step to pass last year, saying tariffs are essentially a tax increase that would slow economic growth. On Monday, they floated the idea of congressional action to try to block tariffs, should the president impose them.\n\nRepresentative Kevin Brady, Republican of Texas and chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, circulated a letter Monday expressing concern over the tariffs. Senator Dan Sullivan, Republican of Alaska, said he spent the weekend speaking with members of Congress and \u201csenior administration officials\u201d about his opposition to the president\u2019s plan.\n\n\u201cAs you know the administration is split itself,\u201d Mr. Sullivan said from the annual CERAWeek energy conference in Houston, noting that details of the tariffs remain sparse.\n\nMr. Trump has heard all sides\u2019 arguments, but his view has remained steadfast, one White House official said.\n\nStill, the official said, the president is mindful enough of the arguments against potentially tanking the stock market that he has been somewhat open to a move to narrow the scope and effects of the tariffs while avoiding the perception that he was relenting. That would echo the approach the administration took to winding down the president\u2019s promises on the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, program, which has protected young immigrants brought illegally to the United States as children.\n\nThe unsettled nature of a final policy was magnified by a conversation on Sunday between Mr. Trump and Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain.", "title": "Trump Reaffirms Commitment to Tariffs but Opens Door to Compromise", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Donald Trump may be going to Korea! Also, to Moon Township, Pa.!\n\nWhile the president\u2019s plan to have direct talks with the North Koreans is fascinating, in a sort of unnerving way, right now we\u2019re going to look at the Moon Township angle. There\u2019s a special House election coming up on Tuesday, and it\u2019s perfectly possible that when it comes to international d\u00e9tente versus the 18th Congressional District, the White House\u2019s real fixation is western Pennsylvania.\n\nThe 18th C.D. is at the heart of the white, working-class vote that won Trump the Electoral College. It also has wildly gerrymandered borders aimed at guaranteeing Republican control unless the incumbent does something incredible, like championing anti-abortion legislation after hinting to his mistress that she ought to get an abortion if she\u2019s pregnant.\n\nWhoops. That was Representative Tim Murphy. Gone but not forgotten.\n\nSo there\u2019s this special election, which features Democrat Conor Lamb, a handsome young former federal prosecutor, versus Rick Saccone, a Republican state representative who is hanging onto Donald Trump like \u2014 um, we will not say Stormy Daniels. That would be totally tacky, and this is a serious political moment. We\u2019ll just say that Saccone says he wants to go to Washington and be the president\u2019s \u201cwingman.\u201d\n\nThe current district is going to vanish in November when new, less-outrageous boundary lines go into effect. So the only thing that\u2019s really at stake here is whether the voters are going to send an epic, albeit mainly symbolic, rejection letter to Trump. The president is obsessed. He\u2019s scheduled to appear at a rally there this weekend, and he\u2019s sending every possible White House warrior \u2014 from Kellyanne Conway to Donald Jr. \u2014 to the front lines.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Really Wants His Wingman", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump repeated on Thursday his false assertion that the United States runs a trade deficit with Canada, the morning after privately telling Republican donors that he had deliberately insisted on that claim in a meeting with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada without knowing whether it was true.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s private admission to having a loose grasp of the facts and his public refusal to back down from the incorrect statement \u2014 the United States has an overall surplus in trade with Canada \u2014 were vivid illustrations of the president\u2019s cavalier attitude about the truth, and a reminder of how that approach has taken hold at the White House.\n\nSarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, said Mr. Trump had chosen his figures selectively in the conversation with Mr. Trudeau and in a subsequent Twitter post that repeated the claim. The president was referring only to the trade of goods, Ms. Sanders said, which ignores the larger trade surplus in services the United States exports to Canada.\n\nAnd in a briefing with reporters, she acknowledged that Mr. Trump had fabricated an anecdote he told the donors about unfair trading practices \u2014 Japanese officials, he claimed, conduct a test on American cars by dropping a bowling ball on their hoods from 20 feet high, and those that dent are barred from being imported.", "title": "Trump Repeats False Claim About Canada After Admitting Uncertainty Over Figure", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPresident Trump made a personal phone call on Wednesday to a political supporter with a huge megaphone \u2014 Roseanne Barr.\n\nMr. Trump called Ms. Barr to congratulate her on the revival of her comedy, \u201cRoseanne,\u201d and to thank her for her support.\n\nThe call was confirmed by Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary.\n\nThe president, an obsessive about how TV shows perform, was enthralled by the \u201chuge\u201d ratings \u201cRoseanne\u201d had received, said a person familiar with the call. The show\u2019s first episode, broadcast Tuesday evening on ABC, averaged 18.2 million viewers.\n\n\u201cRoseanne,\u201d featuring a working-class family of five and assorted relatives, returned to the air this week more than two decades after it ended its run. The lead actress\u2019s character plays a backer of Mr. Trump. (Roseanne\u2019s TV sister, Jackie Harris, by contrast, supports Hillary Clinton, though ultimately voted for Jill Stein.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Barr herself has been a vocal defender of Mr. Trump.\n\nIn an interview with The New York Times published Tuesday, Ms. Barr said that she decided to turn her character, Roseanne Conner, into a Trump supporter because she felt it was an \u201caccurate portrayal\u201d of the political preferences of many working-class Americans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI just wanted to have that dialogue about families torn apart by the election and their political differences of opinion and how we handle it,\u201d she said. \u201cI thought that this was an important thing to say at this time.\u201d", "title": "Trump Rings Up Roseanne Barr After Her Show Is a Ratings Winner", "authors": ["Maggie Haberman", "Patrick Healy"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "More recently, the agency conducted a two-day inspection blitz involving gas leaks on offshore platforms, many of them owned by independent operators in shallow waters. Inspectors found that 17 percent of the 36 platforms and well operations they visited had \u201coil and gas accumulations,\u201d industry lingo for leaks that can lead to fires, agency records show. Eight facilities either lacked operating gas detectors or had other problems with their leak-detection systems.\n\n\u201cIt was quite concerning,\u201d said Jason Mathews, the agency\u2019s chief for safety management in the Gulf.\n\nA Native Son Leads the Charge\n\nThe Cajundome in Lafayette is well known as a venue for college basketball games, country music concerts and monster truck shows. But for Mr. Angelle, 56, it is associated with an enduring alliance he forged with the offshore oil and gas industry nearly eight years ago.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn July 2010, just three months after the Deepwater Horizon accident, Mr. Angelle, then lieutenant governor, stood in the arena before more than 10,000 locals, offshore workers and industry executives. He promised to pressure the Obama administration to end the moratorium on new offshore drilling, which had deeply angered communities that depended on it. The ban was lifted that October.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEnough is enough,\u201d he said with a thick Cajun accent in a rousing speech laced with rhymes and applause lines. \u201cAnd it\u2019s time to quit punishing innocent American workers to achieve some unrealistic political agenda.\u201d\n\nOne of nine children whose father owned a local Ford dealership before going into Louisiana politics himself, Mr. Angelle turned the arena on fire by ticking off the names of local families.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThis moratorium is not hurting the stockholders of BP, or Exxon or Chevron,\u201d he declared. \u201cThis moratorium is hurting the Cheramies, and the Calaises, and the Dupuises, and the Robins, and the Boudreauxs and the Thibodeauxs!\u201d\n\nMr. Angelle knew his audience well: After graduating from the University of Louisiana at Lafayette, he started his career by scouting for onshore drilling sites. He eventually went on to lead the state agency charged with regulating the oil and gas industry, and made a series of appeals to Interior Department officials \u2014 some at the safety agency he now runs \u2014 to press the federal government to soften its response to the Deepwater Horizon accident.\n\nHis ties to the industry are also financial. Mr. Angelle was paid $1 million to serve for four years on the board of directors at Sunoco Logistics, a pipeline company. And when he ran unsuccessfully for governor in 2015, he benefited from large contributions from the industry. One of these was a $1.25 million donation to Louisiana Rising, a political action committee that backed him, from a top executive at an oil and gas company that then had hundreds of Gulf platforms. Mr. Angelle promised voters that he was \u201cfighting for Louisiana\u2019s energy industry\u201d in one advertisement.\n\nAfter being appointed to his current post, Mr. Angelle made a return visit to the Cajundome last September as part of his outreach to oil and gas executives. Mr. Angelle, agency officials note, has sold off any industry stock assets to comply with federal conflict-of-interest rules.\n\nHis job was new, but his message was familiar: How can I help your companies thrive? In addition to safety enforcement, he made it clear that he viewed his role as helping the industry grow.\n\n\u201cOne of the things that we want to do is help unlock the next wave of investment into the Gulf of Mexico,\u201d he said at the time. \u201cThat is what we want to do.\u201d\n\nThe next day, at a meeting with executives in Houston, Mr. Angelle acknowledged that efforts to assist the industry could be hampered if safety problems persisted.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAt the end, we are only as strong as the weakest link,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd if we have someone who is a bad actor, you owe it to yourselves, you owe it to your families, you owe it to the industry, you owe it to America, to call them out.\u201d\n\nEven before this gathering, the Trump administration had signed off on the first rollback of industry regulations, including the one pertaining to the removal of unproductive offshore platforms. The lobbying effort on that rule was funded in part by companies, like Renaissance and Energy XXI, that were plagued by safety violations. It involved both Mr. Lott and his partner, John Breaux, a Democrat and former senator from Louisiana, according to a disclosure report.\n\nThe rule had taken effect late in the Obama administration after government auditors estimated that it would cost nearly $40 billion to remove the old wells, but determined that oil companies had issued just $2.9 billion worth of bonds to cover the expense.\n\nThe Obama administration\u2019s remedy was to require companies to buy more bonds, or provide other financial guarantees, to prove they had the capacity to pay for the removal of the wells. The industry\u2019s reaction was swift.\n\n\u201cThe Louisiana economy needs a kick start, not a kick in the teeth,\u201d Gifford Briggs, the top lobbyist and vice president at the Louisiana Oil and Gas Association, wrote in 2016.\n\nThe problems associated with the old platforms can be severe, as seen in an oil leak 12 miles off the Louisiana coast that has been spreading a sheen across the Gulf for more than a decade. The leak, from a collapsed platform once operated by the now defunct Taylor Energy Company, could continue for 100 years unless it is properly sealed, the safety agency has estimated.\n\nNext, the oil and gas companies pushed to unravel a major safety requirement known as the well-control rule, which regulates methods used to drill new oil and gas wells \u2014 and prevent explosions.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt took six years after the Deepwater Horizon accident to enact the rule, a process that involved thousands of hours of consultations with industry experts and public safety officials, according to Mr. Bromwich, the former federal prosecutor who helped start the process.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe new rule, which took effect in July 2016, required additional inspections of devices called blowout preventers, the equipment that failed during the Deepwater Horizon disaster. To prevent accidents, another provision required oil and gas platforms to shut down temporarily when so-called lift boats positioned themselves for repair work.\n\nAt a meeting Mr. Angelle called in September, industry officials detailed their objections while members of staff \u2014 some of whom helped write the rule \u2014 sat taking notes. Separately, Mr. Angelle held private meetings with representatives from the same companies, according to a copy of his calender, obtained through a public records request.\n\n\u201cIt is mostly knee-jerk reactions that came out of Washington,\u201d Craig Castille of Stone Energy said in prepared remarks that called for more than a dozen changes to the regulation. \u201cThe pendulum has swung way too far to the right.\u201d\n\nTwo days later, Mr. Angelle directed his top aides to prepare documents explaining how the agency had justified the requirement, according to emails obtained through the public records request.\n\n\u201cPlease highlight the sections around the drilling margin and any discussion on blowout preventer,\u201d Mr. Angelle wrote. \u201cThis will help inform me.\u201d\n\nIn late December, Mr. Angelle sent the White House a proposal to overhaul the well-control rule, estimating that oil companies would save $986 million in the coming decade. The proposal included many changes requested by the industry, such as loosening inspection requirements for blowout preventers and eliminating the need to shut down operations as lift boats approached.\n\n\u201cOil and natural gas operators raised concerns about certain regulatory provisions that impose undue burdens on their industry, but do not significantly enhance worker safety or environmental protection,\u201d said the confidential draft, a copy of which was obtained by The Times.\n\nThough the proposal is undergoing a review before the revisions are made public, the White House has made clear that it welcomes the effort. A White House spokeswoman declined to comment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlso in December, the safety bureau moved to ease requirements on the maintenance of offshore oil and gas platforms, cutting costs by an additional $228 million over the next decade.\n\nTo some longtime residents and activists, the changes, and the hundreds of millions of dollars they will save for companies, are not worth the possible trade-offs in safety and environmental protections.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s always the workers who pay,\u201d said Scott Eustis of the Gulf Restoration Network, an environmental group. \u201cAnd Gulf Coast workers will pay with their bodies, their lives, their children, who will grow up without fathers.\u201d\n\nMr. Bromwich, like other former officials who spent years drafting the safety rules, lamented the move to weaken them.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just a terrible signal to the industry as to who is in charge,\u201d Mr. Bromwich said. \u201cIt is classic swamp behavior.\u201d\n\nBut for offshore crews, the changes bring excitement and renewed optimism about work.\n\n\u201cIt affects from the lowest guy to the highest guy, regulations, all day long,\u201d said Don LeBoeuf, an Energy XXI crew worker here in Port Fourchon, before he boarded a boat to a platform 60 miles offshore.\n\nHuge drillships \u2014 with names like Deepwater Asgard, owned by Transocean, the same company that owned Deepwater Horizon \u2014 have been anchored in place 18 miles offshore for months at a time with their generators running and their crews on board, waiting for work.\n\nWhen a small boat with a reporter and photographer recently pulled up alongside Deepwater Asgard, workers peered over the side, wondering why they had visitors. Asked what they thought about the Trump administration\u2019s rollback of regulations in the Gulf, one of them yelled, \u201cDrill, baby, drill!\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSeveral weeks later, the ship actually did get a drilling contract, and is now back at work.", "title": "Trump Rollbacks Target Offshore Rules \u2018Written With Human Blood\u2019", "authors": ["Eric Lipton"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 In recent history as narrated by President Trump, the United States has been fleeced and humiliated by savvier nations unrestrained by na\u00efve notions like global trading rules. Predatory powers have exploited American weakness to steal factory jobs, sowing despair.\n\nThe primary villain in this narrative is China, the country that Mr. Trump has placed at the center of the combative trade policy he is advancing. Steep tariffs on steel and aluminum set to take effect this week are portrayed as targeting China, even as they mostly hit other powers. In a broadening of the battle to electronics and clothing, the Trump administration is readying at least $50 billion worth of tariffs and penalties on imported Chinese goods.\n\nIf these demonstrations of muscle are intended to strengthen the American position in grappling with China, trade experts increasingly fret that Mr. Trump\u2019s policies are doing the opposite: They potentially diminish the place of the United States in the world by alienating allies, undermining the potential for collective action among countries nursing shared grievances with China.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to be far more effective if they go together,\u201d said Meredith Crowley, an expert on international trade at the University of Cambridge in England. \u201cThe fact that the United States is doing all of this alone, it does seem to be weakening the U.S. position.\u201d", "title": "Trump Says Getting Tough on Chinese Trade Will Empower the U.S. He Risks the Opposite.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Michel Pronovost, a retired construction worker, said Mr. Trudeau was, by now, accustomed to Mr. Trump\u2019s creativity with the facts.\n\nImage Michel Pronovost Credit Jasmin Lavoie\n\n\u201cDo you really think he didn\u2019t know that Trump was lying to him?\u201d he asked. \u201cOf course, he knew.\u201d But he added that while Mr. Trump\u2019s protectionism was bad for Canada, he was \u201ctrying to protect his own people, just like China or any country would do.\u201d\n\nSome Americans denounced Mr. Trump\u2019s admission, including Bruce A. Heyman, the United States\u2019 ambassador to Canada under President Barack Obama, who spoke out in a series of posts on Twitter.\n\n\u201cCreating a crisis where none existed before is no way to run our country,\u201d Mr. Heyman posted. \u201cCanada is our best friend and don\u2019t ever forget it! We should never put the relationship at risk.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cWhen I left it was the best relationship the U.S.A. had in the world. The President is casually throwing Canada under the bus and this is just wrong.\u201d\n\nDetermining trade balances is not straightforward. According to the United States trade office, the United States had a $12.1 billion deficit in the trade in goods with Canada in 2016. But that was more than offset by a $24.6 billion surplus in the United States\u2019 favor in trade in services.\n\nIn a statement, the Canadian government noted the United States trade representative\u2019s finding of a surplus. Mr. Trudeau\u2019s office declined to comment.\n\nOn Thursday morning, Mr. Trump was not backing down. On Twitter he wrote: \u201cWe do have a Trade Deficit with Canada, as we do with almost all countries (some of them massive). P.M. The choice, he said, is not between gun rights and no gun rights.\n\n\u201cReasonable proposals that adhere to the Second Amendment but improve gun safety such as universal background checks, protective orders and a debate on the assault weapons ban are the way of the future,\u201d Mr. Schumer said.\n\nMr. Stevens retired from the Supreme Court in 2010. He wrote a major dissent about the Second Amendment in one of the court\u2019s hardest-fought decisions. Mr. Stevens argued that the amendment does not protect an individual\u2019s right to own firearms.\n\n\u201cThat decision \u2014 which I remain convinced was wrong and certainly was debatable \u2014 has provided the N.R.A. with a propaganda weapon of immense power,\u201d Mr. Stevens wrote on Tuesday, referring to the National Rifle Association, the powerful gun lobbying group. \u201cOverturning that decision via a constitutional amendment to get rid of the Second Amendment would be simple and would do more to weaken the N.R.A.\u2019s ability to stymie legislative debate and block constructive gun control legislation than any other available option.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
