Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, indicated the administration was not considering a repeal of the Second Amendment.\n\n\u201cThe president and the administration still fully support the Second Amendment,\u201d Ms. Sanders said on Tuesday in response to a question about Mr. Stevens\u2019s Op-Ed. \u201cWe think that the focus has to remain on removing weapons from dangerous individuals, not on blocking all Americans from their constitutional rights.\u201d\n\nIn his tweet, Mr. Trump also said that Democrats support repealing the Second Amendment, but that has not been the case in Congress, which is only considering modest policy changes on guns. In the 1990s, a Democratic congressman from New York introduced legislation for a repeal, but it did not get any traction. Mr. Trump\u2019s opponent in the 2016 election, Hillary Clinton, did not campaign to repeal the Second Amendment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe can uphold Second Amendment rights while preventing senseless gun violence,\u201d Mrs. Clinton tweeted in May 2016.\n\nMr. Trump had the support of the N.R.A. early in his campaign for president and has said he is \u201cthe biggest fan of the Second Amendment.\u201d After the deadly mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., last month, Mr. Trump proposed stricter controls on access to guns, particularly raising the age to purchase an assault weapon to 21 from 18. After a meeting with the N.R.A., Mr. Trump no longer advocated for an age increase.\n\nInstead, the White House \u2014 with the support of the N.R.A. \u2014 says appropriately trained teachers should be armed to respond to future mass shootings.\n\n\u201cGun free zones are proven targets of killers,\u201d Mr. Trump tweeted on March 1.\n\nArming teachers has been widely criticized, recently by people who gathered for marches for more gun control.\n\nAt a March for Our Lives demonstration in Anchorage, Alaska, on Saturday, Melanie Anderson, a 44-year-old middle schoolteacher, held up a sign that said \u201cteacher, not sharp shooter.\u201d", "title": "Trump Says Second Amendment \u2018Will Never Be Repealed\u2019", "authors": ["Eileen Sullivan"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "The political success of the trade agreement \u2014 and its ability to be replicated in other negotiations \u2014 is not guaranteed. Many countries have reacted coolly to Washington\u2019s pugilistic approach to trade, viewing the president\u2019s preference to punch first and negotiate later as counter to global interests.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron of France lashed out at the approach on Tuesday, saying he was frustrated by the seemingly coercive negotiation tactics coming from Washington.\n\n\u201cWe talk about everything, in principle, with a friendly country that respects the rules of the W.T.O.,\u201d Mr. Macron said. \u201cWe talk about nothing, in principle, when it is with a gun to our head.\u201d\n\nThe implications in the United States will depend on how well Mr. Trump and his allies are able to sell the deal\u2019s direct benefits to voters in midterm elections in the fall. They did not succeed in doing so in a recent special election in Pennsylvania, where a Democrat won in a district that should have been especially receptive to Mr. Trump\u2019s argument about trade and tariffs.\n\nStephen K. Bannon, Mr. Trump\u2019s former chief strategist, said the president\u2019s political team \u201cmust get on the ground and make sure working people understand the direct economic benefits that come from these measures \u2014 get it from being academic to simple.\u201d\n\nThe deal with South Korea, he said, \u201cis a big victory resulting from the president\u2019s smart tariff policies.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nThe agreement is also a victory for a president whose most ardent campaign supporters were animated in part by a promise that Mr. Trump would fight for them against an international free-trade establishment that they believe had robbed them of jobs and depressed their wages.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs a candidate, Mr. Trump had repeatedly threatened to withdraw from trade deals he said were unfair to the United States and its workers \u2014 or even rip them up. Even as recently as last September, associates of the president made it clear that he was willing to withdraw from trade negotiations with South Korea if he thought the result would be unfair.\n\nMr. Trump has also made clear his disdain for the multicountry trade agreements that the United States has long championed. One of his first moves as president was to pull out of what was then the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership, an agreement that President Barack Obama had helped solidify.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Tuesday, supporters of Mr. Trump\u2019s protectionist approach to trade cheered the new pact as a victory for American workers and the dawn of a new era in globalization.\n\n\u201cThe agreement with South Korea to better level the playing field on steel and autos is an encouraging sign that the administration\u2019s trade strategy is achieving results,\u201d said Scott N. Paul, the president of the Alliance for American Manufacturing. \u201cWe believe the deal\u2019s steel provision will be as effective as a tariff in achieving the goals of strengthening our domestic industry and ensuring it can supply America\u2019s security needs.\u201d\n\nThrough the agreement, South Korea \u2014 the third-biggest exporter of steel to the United States in 2016 \u2014 is permanently exempt from the White House\u2019s global tariffs of 25 percent on steel. In return, South Korea agreed to adhere to a quota of 2.68 million tons of steel exports to the United States a year, which it said was roughly equivalent to 70 percent of its annual average sent to the United States from 2015 to 2017.\n\nThe deal also doubles the number of vehicles the United States can export to South Korea without meeting local safety requirements to 50,000 per manufacturer. However, trade experts said that American companies had not come close to meeting their existing quota last year, and that American carmakers had not done enough to tailor their products for South Korean consumers, who prefer smaller vehicles. The revised agreement does ease environmental regulations that American carmakers face when selling vehicles in South Korea and makes American standards for auto parts compliant with South Korean regulations.\n\nImportantly for the Trump administration, the agreement extends tariffs on imported South Korean trucks by 20 years to 2041. Those tariffs were set to phase out in 2021, which officials said would have harmed American truck makers.\n\nThe deal will also establish a side agreement between the United States and South Korea that is intended to deter \u201ccompetitive devaluation\u201d of both countries\u2019 currencies \u2014 which can artificially lower the cost of imports bought by consumers \u2014 and to create more transparency on issues of monetary policy. Administration officials suggested that this new type of arrangement was likely to be replicated in other trade deals, though they acknowledged that it was not enforceable.\n\nSenior White House officials trumpeted the addition of the currency provision to the negotiations, which would seek to prevent South Korea from reducing the value of its currency to make its goods cheaper abroad and export more to the United States. In a report published in October, the Treasury Department declined to label South Korea a currency manipulator, but placed it on a \u201cmonitoring list\u201d for its currency practices and large trade surplus with the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHowever, the effect of the currency agreement may be mostly symbolic, since it was signed in a side deal to the pact to avoid a lengthy legislative approval process. Unlike other provisions of the official agreement, the currency provision is not enforceable through panels that typically settle disputes, or through officially sanctioned retaliation, the usual method for policing trade deals.\n\nThe Obama administration had fought for a similar currency provision to be included in the Trans-Pacific Partnership.\n\nOn automobiles, the biggest source of trade tensions between the countries, the negotiation delivered modest victories that were likely to be welcomed by American carmakers who have long sought to sell more cars in South Korea. It also smoothed customs and regulatory procedures that American businesses say have made it harder to sell goods in the country.", "title": "Trump Secures Trade Deal With South Korea Ahead of Nuclear Talks", "authors": ["Michael D. Shear", "Alan Rappeport"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "In a rambling and disjointed statement from the Diplomatic Reception Room, Mr. Trump called the process that yielded the legislation \u201cthis ridiculous situation,\u201d and he warned, \u201cI will never sign another bill like this again \u2014 I\u2019m not going to do it again.\u201d\n\nThe dramatic denouement for the spending bill, which drew fury from Mr. Trump\u2019s core supporters, left both political parties in Washington reeling and some of his own aides bewildered about the president\u2019s contradictory actions. Yet it was only the latest instance of Mr. Trump chafing against the advice of his advisers and throwing his own brand of chaos into the gears of the federal government.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s grudging embrace only highlighted the degree to which a president who portrays himself as the ultimate dealmaker has been sidelined by congressional leaders in both parties when it comes to striking compromises to fund the core functions of government. Instead, Mr. Trump has proved unable to find a way to negotiate victories on some of his highest priorities.\n\nArdent conservatives who are Mr. Trump\u2019s core backers were left wondering aloud whether the president\u2019s capitulation and failures would imperil Republicans\u2019 chances of keeping control of Congress in the midterm elections this fall. Amy Kremer, a Tea Party activist who helped founded Women for Trump, tweeted, \u201cI\u2019m done.\u201d\n\n\u201cDemocrats just won November #midterms. No point in wasting my time between now and then,\u201d Ms. Kremer wrote.\n\nMr. Trump said the spending plan was important because it includes hundreds of billions of dollars in military spending to ensure that the United States has \u201cby far the strongest military in the world.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe had no choice but to fund our military,\u201d Mr. Trump declared, reading aloud a series of military programs and weapons systems in the spending bill, including submarines, missile defense systems, tanks, helicopters and warships.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut in a bizarre version of the usually upbeat bill-signing ceremonies at the White House, Mr. Trump then went on to denigrate the legislation as \u201ccrazy.\u201d\n\n\u201cNobody read it,\u201d Mr. Trump said of the gargantuan funding measure drawn up by Republican and Democratic leaders in the House and the Senate. Echoing criticism from those who voted against it, Mr. Trump added, \u201cIt\u2019s only hours old.\u201d\n\nHe urged lawmakers to avoid passage of another so-called omnibus bill and to instead pass legislation giving him a line-item veto of spending measures, something that the Supreme Court has already ruled to be unconstitutional. He also called on the Senate to eliminate filibusters.\n\n\u201cI looked very seriously at the veto,\u201d Mr. Trump told reporters. \u201cI was thinking about doing the veto.\u201d\n\nIf he had, it would almost certainly have shut down the government at midnight, just as hundreds of thousands of teenagers and adults were scheduled to descend on Washington for a gun control march on Saturday. With Congress on spring recess for two weeks starting Monday, many lawmakers had already departed Washington and some were on their way out of the country as part of official congressional delegations.\n\nThe spending measure cleared Congress early Friday morning and, while Mr. Trump had made plain he was unhappy with some aspects of it, his senior advisers spent Thursday telling reporters that he would sign it. Then early Friday, on a morning when he watched a fierce backlash to the measure play out on Fox News, Mr. Trump seemed to hesitate, tweeting angrily about the lack of wall funding.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI am considering a VETO of the Omnibus Spending Bill based on the fact that the 800,000 plus DACA recipients have been totally abandoned by the Democrats (not even mentioned in Bill) and the BORDER WALL, which is desperately needed for our National Defense, is not fully funded,\u201d Mr. Trump wrote.\n\nHe was referring partly to the fact that he failed to reach a deal with Democrats to include provisions in the spending measure that would preserve Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, an Obama-era program that Mr. Trump rescinded last fall. The program allows undocumented immigrants brought to the United States as children to apply for permits to work legally and avoid deportation.\n\nBut the president was most angry about the lack of funding in the bill for an enormous wall across the nation\u2019s southern border that he has billed as the centerpiece of his crackdown on illegal immigration. The measure includes nearly $1.6 billion for border security, including new technology and repairs to existing barriers \u2014 but not Mr. Trump\u2019s wall, as he claimed on Twitter on Wednesday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt provides $641 million for about 33 miles of new fencing, but prohibits building a concrete structure or other prototypes the president has considered.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s morning tweet set off a scramble on Capitol Hill and at the White House. Speaker Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, phoned Mr. Trump and encouraged him to sign the measure, according to a source familiar with the call, citing all the \u201cwins\u201d contained in the bill, especially for the military.\n\nThe president\u2019s top advisers rushed to bring in Jim Mattis, the secretary of defense, to make the case to Mr. Trump that he must sign the legislation because of its robust military funding. Within hours, Mr. Mattis was in the Oval Office with Mr. Trump telling him the level of military spending was \u201chistoric,\u201d according to a senior White House official. Vice President Mike Pence, who had postponed a trip to deal with the crisis, also chimed in to make a case for signing the bill.\n\nThe president relented. In his remarks not long after, Mr. Trump expressed disappointment and said he was \u201cnot happy\u201d that the bill did not allocate the full $25 billion that the administration had requested for the wall. But he sought to claim some measure of victory, saying that $1.6 billion \u201cdoes start the wall\u201d and promising to \u201cmake that $1.6 billion go very, very far.\u201d\n\nThe political whiplash that he had put Washington through was reflected in Mr. Trump\u2019s own comments. At times, he seemed to direct blame for the spending bill on Republican lawmakers. But later, he praised them for doing their best in a tough situation.\n\n\u201cI just want to thank members of Congress for working so hard,\u201d he said. \u201cThere are a lot of strings pulling everyone in different directions.\u201d\n\nThe president\u2019s threat came as a surprise but hardly a shock to Republican leaders, who spent much of a snowy Wednesday privately imploring an agitated Mr. Trump to put aside his objections and back the measure, claiming it as a win.\n\nSensing a political advantage, Democrats were unperturbed by Mr. Trump\u2019s veto threat fire drill. Top Democratic aides said on Friday morning that they would not make concessions to Mr. Trump if he chose to reject the legislation, but lawmakers stayed silent until the president signed the bill. Then they cheered the measure as a disavowal of Mr. Trump\u2019s ideas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn sharp contrast to the devastating cuts called for in the Trump budget, the omnibus contains robust funding to combat homelessness, create new affordable housing and promote community development,\u201d Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California and the minority leader, said in a statement. She added, \u201cThe omnibus also rejects the Trump administration\u2019s cruel anti-immigrant agenda.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump said on Friday afternoon that it was Democrats who had balked at including an extension of DACA in the spending bill, claiming that Republicans wanted to protect immigrants from deportation but were blocked by Democrats.\n\nIn fact, over the weekend, the White House offered to extend protections for hundreds of thousands of current DACA recipients for two and a half years, with no guarantee beyond that time, in exchange for $25 billion for the border wall, according to congressional aides.\n\nDemocrats countered by saying they would agree to the full $25 billion only if the president agreed to a pathway to citizenship for a much broader population of young immigrants brought to the country illegally as children, well over a million people \u2014 a deal that was similar to an earlier offer from Mr. Trump.\n\nThe White House rejected the Democratic offer.", "title": "Trump Signs Spending Bill, Reversing Veto Threat and Avoiding Government Shutdown", "authors": ["Julie Hirschfeld Davis", "Michael D. Shear"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor some time now, President Trump has somehow resisted the impulse to open up his Twitter account and take potshots at \u201cSaturday Night Live,\u201d the NBC late-night comedy series on which he is frequently lampooned. (He has nonetheless found other online nemeses.)\n\nBut on Friday morning, Mr. Trump\u2019s wellspring of reserve was at last depleted, as he was lured into an electronic war of words with Alec Baldwin, the actor who has portrayed him on \u201cS.N.L.\u201d since the fall of 2016, saying it was \u201cagony for those who have been forced to watch.\u201d\n\nThis was in response to Mr. Baldwin\u2019s first salvo in this exchange, in an interview published Thursday by The Hollywood Reporter. Asked how much longer he could continue playing the president, Mr. Baldwin answered: \u201cEvery time I do it now, it\u2019s like agony. Agony. I can\u2019t.\u201d\n\nMr. Baldwin added: \u201cI could go out on the street, stand on any corner and tap 10 people on the shoulder. And all 10 of them, in all likelihood, would be more qualified \u2014 ethically, morally, intellectually and spiritually \u2014 than Trump. I\u2019ll vote for Mitt Romney. I don\u2019t care. Anybody over this guy. It doesn\u2019t matter. We have to get rid of him.\u201d", "title": "Trump Slings Twitter Insults With Alec Baldwin, His \u2018S.N.L.\u2019 Impersonator", "authors": ["Dave Itzkoff"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Tread lightly, the world warns\n\nThe contours of a trade war are already taking shape, with threats of retaliation pouring in from around the world and the president stoking a rhetorical battle of his own making.\n\nAfter the European Union threatened counter tariffs on goods like Harley-Davidson motorcycles, Kentucky bourbon and bluejeans, Mr. Trump said he was prepared to escalate the fight by imposing higher taxes on European cars. (China, in the meantime, has been fairly cautious in weighing in.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Ryan, a Republican and the speaker of the House, said he was \u201cextremely worried\u201d about a prospective trade war, but Mr. Trump continued to defend the tariffs, suggesting that they could help the United States negotiate better terms with two of its closest trading partners, Canada and Mexico.\n\nOn Thursday a group of 11 nations \u2014 including major United States allies like Canada \u2014 signed a broad trade deal that represents a direct challenge to Mr. Trump\u2019s embrace of protectionism.\n\nA potential threat to the economy\n\nExperts said that the announcement earlier this month not only threatened to undermine economic growth and inspire a trade war, but also underscored Mr. Trump\u2019s capriciousness and willingness to ignore his advisers, a reality they know all too well.\n\n\u201cWhat he has said, he has said. If he says something different, it\u2019ll be something different,\u201d Wilbur Ross, the secretary of commerce, said on NBC\u2019s \u201cMeet the Press.\u201d\n\nWhile the tariffs would benefit domestic steel and aluminum, industries that rely on the metals could suffer. Shares in Boeing and General Motors fell after the news, for example, while Anheuser-Busch and MillerCoors warned of potential job losses. (The tariffs, though, are unlikely to significantly affect the price of beer cans, which cost about 10 cents to produce.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSmall and midsize manufacturers that use steel and aluminum may be in for harder times, too: \u201cThere are more losers than winners,\u201d one economist said.\n\nFor American consumers, that means goods containing metals may well become more expensive, depending on whether businesses choose to pass on the higher costs. (The United States imports about a third of its steel and about 90 percent of its aluminum.)\n\nStill, even if many of the week\u2019s events have seemed to have ominous undertones, there is nothing inevitable about a trade war, The Upshot notes, saying that \u201cthe chances of a complete breakdown in the global trade system remain remote.\u201d", "title": "Trump Steel Tariffs: How They May Threaten Allies and Economic Growth", "authors": ["Niraj Chokshi"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Patrick Chappatte is an editorial cartoonist for The New York Times. He often sees aides who are subject to public criticism as extensions of himself, coming under fire because critics want to attack him, and he has described the Porter situation in those terms to some people, those briefed on the discussions said.\n\nThe president has told the advisers he has talked with that he knows he probably cannot bring Mr. Porter back. But he has made clear that he misses the staff structure that Mr. Porter had helped build and implement, a White House official said, speaking on background because advisers were not authorized to discuss the matter publicly. Mr. Porter also served as a de facto deputy chief of staff for policy, playing a key role on issues like tariffs, and Mr. Trump spent as much as two hours a day with him.", "title": "Trump Talks of Bringing Back Rob Porter, Aide Accused of Spousal Abuse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMS-13 is certainly a threat, just not the one the president is making it out to be,\u201d said Tom Manger, the police chief in Montgomery County, Md., a Washington suburb where the gang has one of its largest concentrations. Officials there dealt with four MS-13-related police incidents involving murder last year \u2014 for a total of five homicides \u2014 compared with zero in 2013.\n\n\u201cThey are a local public safety threat, but they are not a national security threat,\u201d Chief Manger said.\n\nFormed in central Los Angeles by Salvadoran refugees fleeing a civil war in the 1980s, the gang is believed to have 10,000 members in 40 states, according to the F.B.I. \u2014 but predominantly in just three metropolitan areas: Los Angeles, Long Island in New York and the region outside Washington. Most of its 30,000 other members live in Central America or Mexico, according to the authorities.\n\nIn his State of the Union speech in January, Mr. Trump said MS-13 members exploited immigration laws to move to Long Island and, ultimately, kill Kayla Cuevas, 16, and Nisa Mickens, 15. The girls were beaten with bats and sliced by machetes in a cul-de-sac near an elementary school parking lot in September 2016.\n\nMr. Trump brought their parents to the speech and asked them to stand, as if to exhibit the reason for his immigration crackdown.\n\nMS-13 operates in loose local cliques, sowing fear and violence. It is not a sophisticated global drug cartel, and many gang members are destitute.\n\nPhoto\n\nInterviews with dozens of law enforcement and intelligence officials, and a review of documents, indicate that the gang dabbles in small-time drug dealing, gun sales, prostitution and extortion, with some members receiving just enough money to get by.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn one case, the suspected leader of one the largest MS-13 cliques in Maryland recently canceled a drug deal because he did not have enough money to pay for gas to drive to the drop-off point, according to a law enforcement official in the state.\n\nThe Trump administration is not the first to target MS-13.\n\nPresident George W. Bush set up an F.B.I. task force to focus on MS-13 in 2004 and created the National Gang Intelligence Center in 2005. MS-13 became the first street gang to be designated by the government as a transnational criminal organization when President Barack Obama did so in 2012.\n\nMr. Sessions has compared MS-13 to Colombian drug cartels and the Mafia. The gang is now a top target of the Justice Department\u2019s Organized Crime Drug Enforcement Task Force, which has historically focused on major drug traffickers and money launderers with its annual $500 million budget. The department\u2019s budget proposal for next year also requests $400,000 for a \u201csensitive investigative unit\u201d to address transnational threats from El Salvador.\n\nThe United States and foreign allies have issued charges against 4,000 members of MS-13, Mr. Sessions said earlier this month. In December, he announced 40 new assistant United States attorney positions across the country to fight MS-13 and other gangs, including two on Long Island and three in Maryland.\n\nOne official at a United States attorney\u2019s office, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he was troubled by new pressure on MS-13 cases, given skyrocketing opioid crimes and a growing national human trafficking problem.\n\nEven so, the number of federal prosecutions against MS-13 in the United States is limited. Only 11 cases were brought between October 2016 and September 2017, according to data provided by the Justice Department. Since then, prosecutors have opened another 13 cases.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis week, Mr. Sessions told state attorneys general he wanted to work with them in local prosecutions against MS-13. \u201cWe\u2019re coming after MS-13. We want to hammer them,\u201d he said on Tuesday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMeanwhile, Immigration and Customs Enforcement investigators arrested 796 suspected members of MS-13 last year, up from 429 in 2016. The agency said it also deported about 5,300 suspected members of all gangs over that same period of time, up from 2,000. Over a three-month span last fall, an I.C.E. operation dubbed \u201cRaging Bull,\u201d swept up 214 MS-13 members nationwide and arrested an additional 53 in El Salvador.\n\nIn New York, F.B.I. agents have grumbled about having to focus on MS-13, according to a senior bureau official; there have been worries that agents have arrested members of Trinitario, a Dominican gang, but characterized them as MS-13 members to inflate their arrest totals to meet expectations, a senior state law enforcement official said. Neither official was authorized to speak publicly and both spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n\u201cAny claim that we are mischaracterizing gang members to inflate our arrest totals is false,\u201d an F.B.I. spokeswoman, Nora Scheland, said in a statement. The F.B.I. cracks down on all gang activity as part of its work to combat violent crime, she said.\n\nA $500,000 Justice Department grant promised in October to fight gang violence and gun crime in Suffolk County, N.Y., targeted not only MS-13 but also the Bloods and Crips in its crime analysis. The Long Island county, which applied for the grant, was one of 14 awarded for a total of $3.375 million. Officials say they have not yet received the grant.\n\nTimothy D. Sini, the Suffolk County district attorney and former police commissioner, said MS-13 \u201cconstitutes a significant public safety threat\u201d and was responsible for 17 murders in 15 months in that area of Long Island.\n\n\u201cWith that said,\u201d Mr. Sini said, \u201cthe No.1 public health and safety issue facing Suffolk County, as in other communities, is the drug epidemic. And this drug epidemic is a moving target.\u201d He said opioid overdoses killed more than 300 people in Suffolk County last year, compared with six deaths linked to MS-13.\n\nPhoto\n\nA two-year uptick in violent activity converged with the arrival of more than 4,700 school-age minors in Suffolk County since 2013. Many of the children were fleeing gang violence in their native El Salvador or Honduras, and, after entering the country, most often applied for asylum, or the protection known as Special Immigrant Juvenile Status.\n\nLast March, federal authorities charged 13 young adults \u2014 including four accused of involvement in the killings of Kayla Cuevas and Nisa Mickens \u2014 linked to MS-13 with racketeering and other crimes in Suffolk County. Of the 13, 10 were unauthorized immigrants, federal prosecutors said. Seven had come to the country as unaccompanied minors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Trump administration has repeatedly sought to show that immigration programs it is trying to eliminate have allowed MS-13 and other gangs to flourish. It has singled out the nation\u2019s diversity lottery system, immigration programs to allow unaccompanied minors to cross the border and deportation protections for people who were brought illegally to the United States as children.\n\nYet the latest numbers do not bear that out. According to Border Patrol apprehension statistics published in December, the number of MS-13 members caught at the border actually declined to 228 in 2017, from 437 in 2014.\n\nSome law enforcement officials privately fear that the Trump administration\u2019s push to eradicate crime by deporting illegal immigrants could backfire.\n\nImmigrants in communities where MS-13 is the strongest may be reluctant to come forward with information to help investigations, fearing deportation themselves. Some fear the government will use MS-13 cases to identify the gang members\u2019 relatives and deport them. And MS-13\u2019s victims are overwhelmingly immigrants themselves.\n\n\u201cThe administration is using MS-13 in Willy Horton-esque campaign ads and as cover to make a boogeyman out of immigration,\u201d said Kevin de Le\u00f3n, a California state senator. \u201cIt is using MS-13 as a pretext to go after hardworking immigrants.\u201d", "title": "Trump Targets MS-13, a Violent Menace, if Not the One He Portrays", "authors": ["Ron Nixon", "Liz Robbins", "Katie Benner"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Biden, speaking at a University of Miami rally to combat sexual assault, said, \u201cA guy who ended up becoming our national leader said, \u2018I can grab a woman anywhere and she likes it,\u2019 \u201d referring to an Access Hollywood audio recording in which Mr. Trump is heard boasting about kissing and groping women without their consent. Mr. Biden said when he was asked if he would like to debate Mr. Trump, he said, \u201cIf we were in high school, I\u2019d take him behind the gym and beat the hell out of him.\u201d\n\nThe back-and-forth blustering between two men in their 70s comes a day after Mr. Trump criticized two of his predecessors, Presidents Barack Obama and George W. Bush, for not being able to improve relations with Russia. And Mr. Trump is facing revived sexual misconduct accusations after a New York state judge ruled that a defamation lawsuit from a woman who has said Mr. Trump made unwanted sexual advances could go forward.\n\nMr. Biden, who has been a longtime advocate for anti-sexual assault policies, has been on the road lately, campaigning for Democrats.", "title": "Trump Threatens Joe Biden, Saying He \u2018Would Go Down Fast and Hard\u2019 if They Fought", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "In the wake of the horrific school shootings in Parkland, Fla., President Trump has called repeatedly for building or reopening mental institutions.\n\nStrangely, perhaps, he has echoed an argument made by some experts who study the mental health care system.\n\nIt\u2019s not that they believe that having more institutions would somehow prevent spree killings, as Mr. Trump apparently does. The majority of these murderers appear to be angry, antisocial individuals \u2014 with access to guns \u2014 whom the mental health system probably could not have spotted in advance.\n\nThe proposal to bring back asylums \u2014 in a modern, transparent form \u2014 is very much alive for other reasons among some policy experts, psychiatrists and bioethicists.", "title": "Trump Wants More Asylums \u2014 and Some Psychiatrists Agree", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "While the president was talking up armaments and bonuses for teachers who volunteer for weapons training, dispirited educators in West Virginia walked out of their schools, seeking what they say would be simply a living wage.\n\n\u201cDoesn\u2019t it get to be too much?\u201d said Brianne Solomon, a veteran West Virginia teacher who supplies food for her students\u2019 families, signs students\u2019 permission slips if parents can\u2019t and recently got one to the eye doctor. \u201cOn top of all the things we do, to have to remember when we\u2019re supposed to use a gun?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the Trump administration has elevated the issue to something of an educational mission. The president insisted that he personally would charge into a school, even unarmed, to challenge a gunman. Frank Brogan, a former Florida lieutenant governor who has been nominated for assistant secretary of elementary and secondary education, carries an unusual credential: When he was an assistant principal, Mr. Brogan chased down an armed teenager, talked him into lowering his weapon, then grabbed his arm and wrestled it away.\n\nBut even many educators who have faced off with a school gunman oppose the president\u2019s idea.\n\nEvery day for five and a half years, Jesse Wasmer said, he has thought about the moment that he tackled a student who had just fired a shotgun into the back of a classmate in the cafeteria of a suburban Baltimore high school.\n\n\u201cNever have I thought, \u2018I wish I\u2019d had a gun,\u2019\u201d Mr. Wasmer said.\n\nMr. Wasmer, who was a guidance counselor at Perry Hall High School when a student opened fire there in 2012, called the president\u2019s assertions \u201csimplistic and misguided.\u201d\n\n\u201cI think as educators we\u2019re trained to nurture kids and foster kids, and our first instinct is to not shoot or harm them,\u201d he said. \u201cWhat we need is more caring adults in these kids\u2019 lives, not more guns.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOfficials here in this town of 20,000 do not swagger.\n\n\u201cI agree with those folks who say teachers should teach and cops should be cops, but we got a mess on our hands,\u201d said Sheriff John Lenhart of Shelby County, who gave up his National Rifle Association membership in the 1990s. \u201cIf I have to wait on state officials, on the federal government, on psychologists to figure out why people hurt one another, we would have nothing in our school system.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince 2013, in response to the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., legislation in state capitals across the country has sought to arm school staff. At least 10 states allow staff members to possess or have access to a firearm on school grounds, according to an analysis by the Education Commission of the States. And local districts have varied their approach to arming educators \u2014 in Ohio, guns are kept in safes; in Texas, they can be worn in holsters or kept in safes within immediate reach.\n\nA Florida state legislative committee approved a $67 million \u201cschool marshal\u201d program this week to train and arm teachers \u2014 over the vocal opposition of Parkland residents.\n\nIn Texas, some public school systems have been quietly arming teachers and administrators for more than a decade. Teachers and other school personnel who volunteer to undergo specialized training receive approval to either carry a concealed firearm in school or have one within reach.\n\nPhoto\n\nLawmakers, educators and advocates for gun rights said Texas\u2019 school marshal and school guardian programs have eased fears of armed intruders and have not led to any firearm accidents or mishaps. The state\u2019s programs could serve as a model for schools around the country, advocates say.\n\nOne rural district, Harrold Independent School District, has been allowing armed personnel to carry concealed firearms on school grounds as part of its guardian program since 2007, one year after a shooting at an Amish school in Pennsylvania.\n\n\u201cThis clearly is the solution to the problem that we\u2019re seeing around the country, and I think the president has recognized that,\u201d said State Representative Jason Villalba, a Dallas Republican who wrote the law that established the school-marshal program.\n\nAt a meeting at the White House with other governors on Monday, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas, a Republican, told Mr. Trump that in more than 100 school districts in Texas, teachers and other personnel carry a weapon and are trained to respond to an attack.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cCandidly, some school districts, they promote it,\u201d the governor told the president. \u201cBecause they will have signs out front \u2014 a warning sign: \u2018Be aware, there are armed personnel on campus\u2019 \u2014 warning anybody coming on there that they \u2014 if they attempt to cause any harm, they\u2019re going to be in trouble.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Ohio, which allows local school boards to decide who can possess or have access to firearms on school grounds, Gov. John Kasich, a Republican, also supports arming teachers.\n\nOhio\u2019s teachers\u2019 unions have mobilized against the widespread arming of teachers in schools, arguing that gun control, not armed clashes, will protect students.\n\n\u201cWe appreciate that there are teachers that are willing to take this extra step. It comes from a good place,\u201d said Melissa Cropper, the president of the Ohio Federation of Teachers. \u201cBut when you start thinking about all that could go wrong in that situation, there are too many risks involved.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nLike many districts, Sidney City Schools was shaken by the slaughter of 20 first graders and six staff members at Sandy Hook in 2012. In the following days, Sheriff Lenhart presented Mr. Scheu with an equation: Every 17 seconds after the first shots are fired and the first 911 call is made, somebody gets hurt or dies.\n\n\u201cEven in the best-case scenario, we could get here in four to five minutes,\u201d Sheriff Lenhart said. \u201cYou do the math.\u201d\n\nWithin a year, Sheriff Lenhart had led what he calls a \u201clayered\u201d approach to school security and a \u201cconservative\u201d approach to arming teachers in the 3,400-student school district.\n\nThe district spent about $70,000 on safes, bulletproof vests, cameras, guns, radios and ammunition. Uniformed, armed officers cost $200,000 a year, and an insurance policy of $100,000 a year includes coverage for its staff with access to firearms. Those are negligible costs for a school district with a $36 million budget, the superintendent said.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re buying time, and it\u2019s of the essence,\u201d Mr. Scheu said.\n\nWindows and doors are numbered in the district\u2019s schools, and visitors have to be buzzed in. Each school has a panic button and security camera system that feeds to the sheriff\u2019s office. Every school has a uniformed, armed guard, mostly retired sheriff\u2019s deputies, every day from bell to bell. The high school has a specially trained officer and a bulletproof window between the secretary and visitors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd if all else fails, there\u2019s a secret group of 40 educators \u2014 teachers, principals, custodians, secretaries \u2014 called a \u201cfirst responder team\u201d that can retrieve firearms in under a minute.\n\nThe team was vetted by Mr. Scheu and Sheriff Lenhart, and completed a 16-hour training course that includes firearm safety, unarmed defensive tactics and basic gunshot first aid. Its members are required to attend a concealed weapons course, as well as additional monthly trainings at either the firing range where they practice marksmanship and in school-based simulations where they practice in the hallways, identifying threats and eliminating them with air guns.\n\nSince the team was created, it has responded to one incident, this past August when a student brought a gun to school in his backpack. It did not require a member to retrieve a gun.\n\nThe measures here met some opposition at first, from the town\u2019s teachers union and police chief, who were concerned about gun safety.\n\nBut Rick Cron, the armed guard at Sidney Middle School, said he would put members of his team up against any law enforcement officer in Ohio. The state requires that officers fire 25 bullets a year; his team members shoot at least 600.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the teacher\u2019s responsibility to protect the kids, no matter what, and they do it already,\u201d Mr. Cron said, \u201cbut without the tools.\u201d\n\nNicki New, the parent of three students in Sidney City Schools, said she felt safer dropping off her children knowing there were staff members equipped to respond to a parent\u2019s worst nightmare.\n\n\u201cGod forbid, if something would happen, knowing that not only a law enforcement officer is there, but there are teachers in that building who can give my child a fighting chance, is even more reassuring,\u201d Ms. New said.", "title": "Trump Wants to Arm Teachers. These Schools Already Do.", "authors": ["Erica L. Green", "Manny Fernandez"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "The departures of Rex Tillerson and H. R. McMaster, in particular, do not indicate a sudden swerve in policy: Mr. Tillerson a was a gamble from the beginning, a secretary of state with as little political experience as the president and no very tight ties to him. Mr. Tillerson\u2019s tenure at the State Department has been considered a success by no one. His exit was a matter of time.\n\nGeneral McMaster likewise has never developed a rapport with the president, who chose him as national security adviser only after Michael Flynn was forced to resign and Mr. Trump\u2019s second choice, Robert Harward, a retired vice admiral, declined the role. General McMaster was given a fair chance and allowed to remove from the National Security Council political holdovers from General Flynn\u2019s brief tenure. But his support for the Iran deal has been at odds with the president\u2019s commitment to ending or drastically renegotiating it. The president is determined on his course, and he understandably wants a national security adviser who shares his priorities.\n\nWere he not being replaced by the president, General McMaster would soon have found himself facing the same choice that Gary Cohn had to confront once Mr. Trump followed through on his promises of economic nationalism: to resign or implement a policy with which he firmly disagreed. Advisers are there to offer the president a menu of options, including those he might not find to his taste. Once the president has made up his mind, however, the responsibility of his aides is to see that his orders are carried out effectively. Policy differences have a proper place in an administration, but only before a decision is made.\n\nThere always has to be some trial and error involved in building an effective cabinet and White House team, and in Mr. Trump\u2019s case, coming from as far outside the policy world as he did, there was sure to be more turnover than in most administrations, as the president got a feel for personalities and policies. Has a year\u2019s experience now shown Mr. Trump who his real allies and most suitable colleagues are?\n\nThat\u2019s one theory for Mr. Pompeo\u2019s proposed elevation to secretary of state. And while Mr. Bolton and Mr. Kudlow have not served in the administration before, they have built strong relationships with the president. Then again, so did Steve Bannon, who proved not to be as close or indispensable to Mr. Trump as an avalanche of media coverage had made him seem. The man purported to be the power behind the throne didn\u2019t last a full eight months in this White House.\n\nThe next wave of national-security and economic advisers is not assured of lasting any longer. This is another reason fears of Mr. Trump\u2019s latest staff replacements are misplaced. An old joke attributed to Groucho Marx has a politician declaring: \u201cThese are my principles. If you don\u2019t like them, I have others.\u201d The same can be said about President Trump\u2019s personnel \u2014 if you don\u2019t like them, he has others.\n\nThe new personnel will not make the administration a monolith. Like those who came before them, they will find that the real key to policy lies not with them but with a single unchanging executive branch employee: Donald J. Trump. His great virtue is that he cannot be molded by his advisers; he resists all tutelage. He was elected because the people who do the molding in our politics have for too long led our country down a path of destruction, under Republicans and Democrats alike. The advice they give, sound in theory, is terrible in practice. One service President Trump has performed that even many of his detractors should applaud is to demolish the mystique of the policy elite. He can govern, and we can live, without them.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Was Elected to Govern Without These People", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "That is why some experts fear that by blocking the Broadcom-Qualcomm deal, Mr. Trump could further rattle the global economy and international norms. Other countries might now feel emboldened to block as a security threat inbound foreign investment that they consider significant, justifiably or not. France and other countries have a history of protecting companies they consider \u201cnational champions,\u201d but the United States has been reluctant to do so. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, which is made up of representatives from across the executive branch, looks at acquisitions that could represent a national security problem, but its reviews typically end up scuttling only a few deals annually, though the number has increased in recent years.\n\nBecause the committee does most of its work in secret, it is hard to know if it is making the right calls. But in this case, the ultimate outcome was correct because the potential takeover raised serious antitrust concerns.\n\nThere are good reasons to worry about the growing concentration of power \u2014 and lack of competition \u2014 in the semiconductor business, which supplies chips used in everything from phones and computers to cars and fighter jets. If the Broadcom-Qualcomm merger had gone through, just three companies \u2014 Samsung, Intel and Broadcom \u2014 would have controlled more than 36 percent of the global market for chips, according to Gartner. And the concentration would have been far greater in certain fields, like telecommunications.\n\nAs the number of players in the industry shrinks, innovation tends to decline because companies have less reason to worry about losing business to competitors. And they have a bigger incentive to milk profits by raising prices on existing products, which are often protected by patents that in the United States typically give inventors a 20-year monopoly over their creations. Such arguments would typically arise during antitrust reviews by the Department of Justice or the Federal Trade Commission, but they are also important to national security. That\u2019s because the government is heavily dependent on private companies like Qualcomm, which got its start in the 1980s by developing communications systems for the military.\n\nBroadcom being based in Singapore provided the Trump administration an easy way to block this deal. But even if it had been an American company, this acquisition would have been a hard sell.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Was Right to Block a Merger", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "But beyond that, Ms. Toensing is representing Mark Corallo, who was the spokesman for Mr. Trump\u2019s legal team in 2017 before they parted ways.\n\nMr. Corallo has told investigators that he was concerned that a close aide to Mr. Trump, Hope Hicks, may have been planning to obstruct justice during the drafting of a statement about a meeting between a Russian lawyer and Donald Trump Jr. during the campaign.\n\nMs. Hicks\u2019s lawyer has strongly denied that suggestion, and White House aides said Mr. Corallo\u2019s assertion had come up in discussions with the president as he weighed whether to go ahead with Mr. diGenova and Ms. Toensing.\n\nMr. diGenova had been expected to serve as an outspoken voice for the president as Mr. Trump has increased his attacks on Mr. Mueller. Schmidt", "Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "First and foremost, Iran most likely will move quickly, without any restraint, to enrich uranium, the fissile material needed for nuclear weapons. The Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, the leading edge of Iran\u2019s nefarious actions, will declare that the West can never be trusted and will use the decision to undermine the less hard-line president, Hassan Rouhani.\n\nThe destruction of the nuclear deal will also increase the Revolutionary Guards\u2019 malign activities in the Middle East, making the challenge to Israel\u2019s security and to America\u2019s other allies even more difficult. These activities, in turn, will increase American calls for military action against Iran as the only viable option, since no Iranian will be able to enter new negotiations with the United States any time soon.\n\nThe march to military conflict will be hard to stop, especially with Mr. Bolton leading the National Security Council.\n\nBeyond this horror show, the decision to destroy the Iran deal will also pound yet another nail into the coffin of the trans-Atlantic relationship. Mr. Trump has so far laid the task of \u201cfixing\u201d the deal at the feet of Britain, France and Germany, America\u2019s European partners in the nuclear negotiations. He has demanded that they agree to new language on Iran\u2019s ballistic missile development and inspections of Iranian military installations, and he has asked for a change in the timeline of the nuclear deal so that the restrictions on Iran will not expire. In essence, he has asked Europe for help changing the terms of the deal itself.\n\nThe Europeans\u2019 greatest objection is on the issue of the \u201csunset.\u201d They believe, accurately, that Iran has committed to never obtaining a nuclear weapon, is complying with the terms of the deal, and there are mechanisms in the deal to both review and sanction if it becomes necessary. European diplomats rightly feel that Mr. Trump is demanding that they solve a political problem he created by campaigning against the deal.", "title": "Opinion | Trump and Bolton\u2019s Plan to Isolate Allies and Encourage Enemies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTrump Seen Pressing Congress Not to Fund Hudson Rail Tunnel\u201d (front page, March 3):\n\nYou report that \u201cone person with knowledge of the president\u2019s thinking\u201d said \u201cMr. Trump has told Republicans that it makes no sense to give Mr. Schumer something that he covets \u2014 funding for the tunnels \u2014 at a time that Mr. Schumer is routinely blocking Mr. Trump\u2019s nominees and other parts of his agenda.\u201d\n\nSo much that is wrong with the Trump administration and President Trump himself is summed up in this characterization of the president. Senator Chuck Schumer of New York does not covet the Gateway tunnel \u2014 people who must commute in and out of New Jersey and New York need the tunnel.\n\nThis mass transit project is not about settling scores between Mr. Trump and his perceived enemies; it\u2019s about serving the needs of people who must commute. In his campaign, Mr. Trump promised to help working stiffs \u2014 well, those stiffs are not just in the coal mines. They are in both red and blue states \u2014 and they need to get where they need to go.\n\nJust once, it would be a nice gesture if the president acknowledged that he is the president of the entire United States and not just of the people who voted for him.", "title": "Opinion | Trump and Hudson Tunnel: Punishing Schumer, and Commuters", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTrump Attacks Obama, and His Own Attorney General, Over Russia Inquiry\u201d (news article, nytimes.com, Feb. 22):\n\nI noted with interest that after ample evidence that Russia will likely interfere in our midterm election, President Trump, instead of spearheading an effort to protect the election\u2019s reliability, has decided instead to blame our previous president for Russian meddling.\n\nI couldn\u2019t help thinking of Dwight D. Eisenhower\u2019s quote: \u201cThe search for a scapegoat is the easiest of all hunting expeditions.\u201d\n\nROLF WETZELL, DELRAY BEACH, FLA.", "title": "Opinion | Trump and Russia Meddling", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Yet they\u2019re not the only faction talking dangerous nonsense on international economics. The Trump administration has also become home to what we might call neo-goldbugs: people who think that a nation\u2019s strength can be measured by the strength of its currency, and refuse to see any downside in a strong dollar, never see any reason a weaker dollar might be needed.\n\nLike neo-mercantilism, or for that matter supply-side economics, this view has been debunked many times \u2014 I wrote about it in 1987! \u2014 yet keeps shambling along, because it appeals to the prejudices of wealthy and powerful people.\n\nUntil now, the most visible neo-goldbug in the administration has been David Malpass, the under secretary of Treasury for international affairs \u2014 normally a position of great policy influence, although under Trump, who knows? Malpass is the former chief economist of Bear Stearns, and a man with a Kudlow-like record of being wrong about everything. In particular, however, back in 2011 Malpass published an op-ed article declaring that what America needed to fix its economic ills was a stronger dollar (and higher interest rates).\n\nIt was a bizarre claim. After all, at the time the unemployment rate was still 9 percent \u2014 and a stronger dollar would have made things even worse. Why? Because it would have made U.S. products less competitive, increasing the trade deficit \u2014 and a situation of persistently high unemployment is the one situation in which trade deficits really are an unambiguously bad thing, reducing the demand for domestic goods and services.\n\nBut here\u2019s the thing: Kudlow appears to share Malpass\u2019s worldview. In fact, his first newsworthy statement after Trump announced his selection was a call for a higher dollar \u2014 something that would worsen the very trade deficit Trump sees as a sign of American weakness.\n\nWhy has Trump hired people with such conflicting notions about international economic policy? The answer, presumably, is that he doesn\u2019t understand the issues well enough to realize that the conflict exists. And what both sides in this dispute share is a general propensity for invincible ignorance, which makes them Trump\u2019s kind of people.\n\nAnyway, on international economics the Trump administration is now on track for a battle of the zombies \u2014 a fight between two sets of bad ideas that refuse to die. Pass the popcorn.", "title": "Opinion | Trump and Trade and Zombies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cToday\u2019s actions make the United States safer by reducing Russia\u2019s ability to spy on Americans and to conduct covert operations that threaten America\u2019s national security,\u201d the White House said in a statement.\n\nThe Kremlin has maintained that it had nothing to do with the poisoning.\n\nBritain\u2019s decision to expel 23 Russian diplomats over the poisoning initially raised tensions between the two countries to a level not seen since the heights of the Cold War. The government vowed to crack down on Russian spies, corrupt elites and ill-gotten wealth in Britain.\n\nOn March 15, the Trump administration imposed sanctions on a series of Russian organizations and individuals for interference in the 2016 presidential election and other \u201cmalicious cyberattacks,\u201d its most significant action against Moscow until Monday.\n\nThose sanctions came as the United States joined Britain, France and Germany in denouncing Russia for its apparent role in a nerve-gas attack on a former Russian spy and his daughter on British soil, calling it a \u201cclear violation\u201d of international law.\n\nWhite House officials called the nerve agent used against the Skripals \u201cmilitary grade,\u201d but declined to elaborate on the substance used.\n\nAmerican officials estimate there are currently more than 100 Russian intelligence officers in the United States.\n\nMr. Trump has said that, despite its denials, Russia was likely behind it. \u201cIt looks like it,\u201d he told reporters in the Oval Office on March 15, adding that he had spoken with Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe are in deep discussions,\u201d Mr. Trump continued. \u201cA very sad situation. The Polish foreign minister was expected to make an announcement later this afternoon.\n\nThe Polish foreign minister, Jacek Czaputowicz called the tragic incident in Britain an \u201cunprecedented attack on civilians with the use of chemical weapon,\u201d that had not been seen since World War II.\n\nMr. Czaputowicz said the Russian ambassador and three other diplomats were now considered \u201cpersona non grata,\u201d giving them until April 3 to leave the country.\n\nRussia\u2019s overall goal, Mr. Czaputowicz said, is to \u201cdisrupt international order and create a sense of danger.\u201d\n\nAny expulsion of Russian diplomats would be an unprecedented move on Warsaw\u2019s part, the first time they took diplomatic action against their neighbor due to Russian behavior outside of Poland.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince Poland broke from the Soviet bloc in the 1990s, it has expelled Russian diplomats only twice \u2014 and both times had to do with Russia\u2019s spying activities in Poland.\n\nGermany\u2019s move not only signaled solidarity with London, but it also suggested the incoming German foreign minister, Heiko Maas, may be more hawkish toward Moscow than his predecessor.\n\n\u201cThe attack in Salisbury shook us all in the European Union,\u201d Mr. Maas, said. \u201cFor the first time since the end of World War II a chemical war agent was used in the middle of Europe.\u201d\n\nMr. Maas said Germany did not take the decision \u201cflippantly.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut the fact and indications point to Russia. He actually seemed to boast about it.\n\nIn the furor that followed the disclosure of his remarks, attention focused on the impact on relations with Canada and whether the president was right or wrong in his assertion about trade. But the episode goes to the heart of a more fundamental debate about Mr. Trump: When does he know the things he says are false, and when is he simply misinformed?\n\nMr. Trump, after all, has made so many claims that stretch the bounds of accuracy that full-time fact-checkers struggle to keep up. Most Americans long ago concluded that he is dishonest, according to polls. While most presidents lie at times, Mr. Trump\u2019s speeches and Twitter posts are embedded with so many false, distorted, misleading or unsubstantiated claims that he has tested even the normally low standards of American politics.\n\n\u201cHis statement this week was another reminder of how cavalier he is with the truth,\u201d said Bill Adair, the founder of PolitiFact, the Pulitzer Prize-winning, nonpartisan fact-checking website owned by the Poynter Institute. \u201cHe seems so willing to say whatever suits him at that moment regardless of whether it\u2019s true. In all the time that I was editor of PolitiFact and in the time since when I\u2019ve worked with fact-checkers all over the world, I\u2019ve just never seen any political figure distort the truth so recklessly.\u201d", "title": "Trump and the Truth: A President Tests His Own Credibility", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump said on Thursday that he would impose stiff tariffs on imports of steel and aluminum, making good on a key campaign promise and rattling stock markets as the prospect of a global trade fight appeared imminent.\n\n(You can read more about Friday\u2019s developments here.)\n\nIn a hastily arranged meeting with industry executives that stunned many inside the West Wing, Mr. Trump said he would formally sign the trade measures next week and promised they would be in effect \u201cfor a long period of time.\u201d The action, which came against the wishes of Mr. Trump\u2019s pro-trade advisers, would impose tariffs of 25 percent on steel and 10 percent on aluminum, effectively placing a tax on every foreign shipment of those metals into the United States.\n\nThe president told more than a dozen executives that he wanted the tariffs to apply to all countries, one executive in attendance said. Mr. Trump argued that if one country was exempt, all other countries would line up to ask for similar treatment, and that metals could end up being shipped to the United States through exempted countries.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s authority to impose such sweeping tariffs stems from a Commerce Department investigation that concluded last month that imported metal threatened national security by degrading the American industrial base. The administration has said it wants to combat cheap metals flooding into the United States, particularly from China, but a broad set of tariffs would fall most heavily on allies, especially Canada, which supplies steel and aluminum to American companies as well as the military.", "title": "Trump to Impose Sweeping Steel and Aluminum Tariffs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPresident Trump will make the first visit of his presidency to Latin America next month, the White House said on Saturday, traveling to Peru for a summit meeting of Western Hemisphere nations where he will convene with a group of leaders who have criticized his statements and policies on immigration.\n\nThe president will also visit Colombia and meet with President Juan Manuel Santos, the White House said in a statement.\n\n\u201cThis travel demonstrates the president\u2019s resolve to deepen our historical ties with our partners in the region and to strengthen our joint commitment to improve security and prosperity for the people of the Americas,\u201d the statement said.\n\nThe statement pointed to the significance of establishing relationships with countries that \u201cshare our values and believe that the promise of a safe and prosperous future rests in strong democracies, fair and reciprocal trade, and secure borders.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs he has moved the United States toward a more protectionist stance on trade, Mr. Trump has abandoned the Trans-Pacific Partnership, which includes Mexico, Peru and Chile. Mueller III, and trigger a constitutional crisis.\n\nThe president certainly knows whether he is innocent or guilty of serious wrongdoing. If he knows that he has broken the law, then he may prefer to buy time and take his chances with the established constitutional mechanisms for removing or limiting the power of a president, rather than face the greater certainty that an unimpeded investigation by Mr. Mueller will reveal the truth.\n\nWhen you consider the failure of the House Intelligence Committee to fulfill its responsibility to conduct a nonpartisan, credible investigation, this may be the risky bet that the president is willing to make. Even so, it\u2019s a tough choice between dangerous options.\n\nIf, on the other hand, he knows that he is innocent, it is very hard to understand why he and his lawyers are ignoring the wise adage that when your client is innocent, act like it.", "title": "Opinion | Trump vs. Mueller: The Tension Builds", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump defended on Wednesday his decision to disregard the advice of his national security team and congratulate President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on his re-election, lashing out at the news media for reporting on how he diverged from his script and attacking his predecessors for failing to improve relations with Moscow.\n\nMr. Trump, enraged after officials leaked the contents of confidential notes he was given for the private phone call on Tuesday that exhorted him \u201cDO NOT CONGRATULATE\u201d Mr. Putin, argued in a pair of tweets on Wednesday afternoon that the conversation was part of his effort to foster better relations with Russia. He said such engagement could help the United States confront a host of national security challenges.\n\n\u201cI called President Putin of Russia to congratulate him on his election victory (in past, Obama called him also),\u201d Mr. Trump wrote on Twitter, referring to President Barack Obama\u2019s call to Mr. Putin in 2012. \u201cThe Fake News Media is crazed because they wanted me to excoriate him. They are wrong!\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Trump\u2019s handling of the call and his defense of it also pointed up his aversion to confronting Mr. Putin about Moscow\u2019s misdeeds, which has become a theme of his presidency even as a special counsel investigates Russia\u2019s efforts to sway the 2016 election in his favor.", "title": "Trump, Defending Call With Putin, Attacks \u2018Crazed\u2019 Media and His Predecessors", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "The reversal of fortunes for Mr. Shulkin, a rare holdover from the Obama administration, has been swift. For months, as Mr. Shulkin delivered a series of bipartisan legislative victories to a White House badly in need of them, Mr. Trump showered him in praise. At one such bill-signing ceremony in June, Mr. Trump teased that the secretary need never worry about hearing his \u201cApprentice\u201d-era catchphrase, \u201cYou\u2019re fired.\u201d\n\nBut that support began to erode in February, after the department\u2019s inspector general released a blistering report that found \u201cserious derelictions\u201d related to a business trip taken by the secretary to Britain and Denmark last year. It concluded that the secretary had spent much of the trip sightseeing and improperly accepted Wimbledon tickets as a gift.\n\nThe report provided ammunition for Mr. Shulkin\u2019s critics within the department, who had increasingly broken with the secretary over how to approach one of the White House\u2019s top policy priorities: the expansion of government-subsidized private health care for veterans. A handful of officials \u2014 including his two top communications deputies \u2014 worked behind the scenes to try to use the document to build support for his ouster.\n\nPerhaps more consequentially for Mr. Shulkin, Mr. Trump\u2019s advisers say White House officials began to believe that Mr. Shulkin misled them about what would be in the report, which ushered in a new round of negative news media reports on the president\u2019s cabinet. He made matters worse, they said, when he botched attempts to clean up the story and went public with fears about appointees \u201ctrying to undermine the department from within.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs stories about potential replacements began to circulate in mid-March, Mr. Trump summoned Mr. Shulkin to the Oval Office for what one person briefed on the discussion described as a tense meeting. An aide to Mr. Shulkin disputed that characterization.\n\nMr. Shulkin has played down speculation about his departure as he has testified about the department\u2019s budget request for the coming fiscal year and met privately with lawmakers to discuss pending legislation to remake the department\u2019s approach to private care. He was scheduled to host a regular meeting on Thursday with leaders of the nation\u2019s largest veterans groups.\n\nBut he has proceeded with a curtailed public profile. The secretary was not on hand for a veterans event at the White House on Friday, for instance, and he is now hurried in and out of events by a security detail without taking questions from the press. Those who have spoken with the secretary said he had made it clear that he wanted to continue in the department\u2019s top job, but was increasingly isolated.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAshleigh F. Barry, a spokeswoman for the secretary, said on Tuesday only that Mr. Shulkin was focused on the work of the department.\n\nThe speculation and mixed messages coming out of the White House have flummoxed key lawmakers in both parties, who continue to support the secretary, as well as many of the major veterans groups, which are congressionally chartered and largely apolitical. Organizations such as the Veterans of Foreign Wars and American Legion hold considerable sway over veterans policy in Washington, and they solidly back Mr. Shulkin.\n\nThough the groups were generally displeased with the findings turned up by the inspector general, they see the secretary as a pragmatic and effective leader who understands the challenges facing the department\u2019s sprawling health care system and has taken concrete steps to address them.\n\n\u201cWe are disappointed about all this speculation that is happening because we feel that the secretary has done a good job of leading the V.A. in a positive direction,\u201d said Garry Augustine, the executive director of Disabled American Veterans.\n\nThe groups and lawmakers on Capitol Hill are closely watching for candidates to replace Mr. Shulkin, many of them fearful that the White House might try to use the nomination to advance a long-held conservative goal of shifting more of the department\u2019s health care to private doctors. A nominee seen as too aggressive on privatization would likely face a difficult path to confirmation in the Senate, where Republicans have only the narrowest of majorities and several key Republicans have indicated an uneasiness with several of the names floated by people close to the White House.\n\nThose candidates include Jeff Miller, a former Florida congressman who led the House Veterans Affairs Committee and is now a lobbyist in Washington; Keith Kellogg, a retired three-star Army general who serves as the chief of staff of the National Security Council; and Leo Mackay Jr., a former deputy secretary at the department who is now an executive at Lockheed Martin. Mr. Trump has also discussed the job with Energy Secretary Rick Perry.\n\nAnother potential nominee, Pete Hegseth, is said to be uninterested in the nomination. Mr. Hegseth is a weekend co-host of \u201cFox & Friends\u201d who formerly ran Concerned Veterans for America, a conservative veterans advocacy group backed by the billionaire brothers Charles G. and David H. Koch. The group has led the push to let veterans use their government benefits at private doctors.\n\nIn the meantime, Mr. Shulkin may not be the only department official on his way out. Several high-ranking officials opposed to the secretary have indicated that they, too, intend to leave. Darin Selnick, an influential conservative voice on veterans issues within the administration, departed a position on the White House\u2019s Domestic Policy Council on Friday and has decided to leave the administration entirely. Others, including the department\u2019s assistant secretaries for communications and legislative affairs and its press secretary, have indicated to allies that they are searching for jobs elsewhere in the administration.", "title": "Trump, Famous for \u2018You\u2019re Fired,\u2019 Offers V.A. Chief Only Awkward Silence", "authors": ["Maggie Haberman", "Nicholas Fandos"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "As though Omarosa filling a top White House job between reality shows was not weird enough, The Times\u2019s Michael Grynbaum described a \u201chall-of-mirrors moment\u201d on Wednesday: Larry Kudlow, a chatterer plucked from CNBC to replace Gary Cohn as Trump\u2019s chief economic adviser, went on TV to describe the president telling Kudlow how \u201cvery handsome\u201d he looks on TV.\n\n\u201cSo Trumpian!\u201d Kudlow laughed.\n\nIt\u2019s the final Foxification of politics. Trump spends all his time watching Fox News, basing his opinions and tweets on it, and now he\u2019s simply becoming one with it. He is even willing to overlook his distaste for the yeti mustache of the warmongering John Bolton and consider the Fox News analyst as a replacement for McMaster.\n\nRoger Ailes would be so proud, if he were still alive and harassing women.\n\nTrump thinks he\u2019s a fabulously devious manager creating \u201cgreat energy,\u201d with great ratings coming from his talent for theatrical twists and turns. But he\u2019s really inhumane, playing people against one another and widely discussing successors for officials who haven\u2019t even been officially informed that they\u2019re walking the plank. And, far from the A-team he promised, he\u2019s hired a bunch of pathetic, disgusting swamp schnorrers who can\u2019t stop using taxpayer money to fund their office furniture or office redesign or luxury plane trips with their wives.\n\n\u201cI like conflict,\u201d Trump said this month at a press conference with the Swedish prime minister, smacking his fists together and adding, \u201cI like watching it, I like seeing it, and I think it\u2019s the best way to go.\u201d\n\nNever mind that a lot of the country \u2014 and the world \u2014 craves stability.\n\nWhile the president may appear unconstrained, intoxicated with escaping the net of those who displease him by telling him \u201cNo,\u201d he is getting ever more enmeshed in another net \u2014 Robert Mueller\u2019s.\n\n\u201cI think Trump is royally pissed about the Mueller subpoena of the Trump Organization records,\u201d Trump biographer Michael D\u2019Antonio says about the special counsel crossing the president\u2019s red line. \u201cHe fears the nakedness of his true business activities being revealed far more than the shame of \u2018Access Hollywood\u2019 or Stormy Daniels. Unlike the show of blank paper in file folders conducted when he supposedly stepped away from his businesses, this will require real documents, and I doubt he can count on people lying for him.\u201d\n\nIf you\u2019ve ever had a narcissistic boss, you know that they hate to hear any criticism and love to whack the naysayers and replace them with more compliant types. The circle of sycophants, who do not care about the boss, often spurs the leader\u2019s flameout.\n\nPresident Trump is doing it his way now. She added that the United States could cite the suspicious death of Mikhail Y. Lesin, a former Russian minister, in a Washington hotel in 2015, in taking joint action. Investigators concluded that he died from a drunken fall but many remain skeptical.\n\n\u201cFrankly, I believe we should have and could still do this in response to Russia\u2019s election interference in the United States and several other NATO countries,\u201d she said. \u201cWe certainly should craft additional sanctions together with the U.K. and the E.U. to address the assassinations.\u201d\n\nUntil Tuesday night, the White House had avoided pointing the finger at Russia for the attack, in which a former Russian spy was poisoned with a nerve agent near his home in southern England.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
