None at all. In fact, the economists (\u201ceconomists\u201d?) who currently have his ear seem to regard their job as being to confirm the wisdom of whatever he decides to do. Peter Navarro:\n\nMy function, really, as an economist is to try to provide the underlying analytics that confirm his intuition. And his intuition is always right in these matters.\n\nTranslation: Navarro sees his role as that of a propagandist, not a source of independent advice.\n\nBut the rest of us don\u2019t have to accept that Dear Leader is always right. And in fact, these tariffs are weirdly poorly considered even if all you want to do is create manufacturing jobs, leaving aside all the other ramifications.\n\nWhy? Because steel and aluminum aren\u2019t final goods \u2013 nobody directly consumes steel. Instead, they\u2019re intermediate goods, basically used as inputs to other U.S. manufacturing sectors. And while tariffs that raise primary metal prices may increase production of those metals, they make the rest of U.S. manufacturing less competitive.\n\nTrade economists used to talk about this kind of thing a lot. Back when most developing countries were trying to promote manufacturing with tariffs and import quotas, we used to talk about effective protection, which depended on the whole structure of tariffs. Sometimes effective rates of protection were very high: if you imposed, say, a modest tariff on cars but none on imported auto parts, the effective rate of protection for auto assembly could easily be in the hundreds of percent. Sometimes, however, rates were negative: if you put a tariff on parts but not on cars, you were actually discouraging auto assembly.\n\nClearly, we can apply this kind of analysis to the Trump tariffs. In fact, there are people out there trying to put numbers on it, although I wouldn\u2019t put too much weight on them, for reasons that will be clear in a minute.", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Negative Protection Racket (Wonkish)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 It has been practically a given that anyone nominated for a federal judgeship by a Republican president had to pass an unspoken litmus test \u2014 usually on abortion but often on any number of divisive social issues.\n\nThe Trump administration has a new litmus test: reining in what conservatives call \u201cthe administrative state.\u201d\n\nWith surprising frankness, the White House has laid out a plan to fill the courts with judges devoted to a legal doctrine that challenges the broad power federal agencies have to interpret laws and enforce regulations, often without being subject to judicial oversight. Those not on board with this agenda, the White House has said, are unlikely to be nominated by President Trump.\n\nThe criteria were first used last year in his Supreme Court selection of Neil M. Gorsuch, an appeals court judge who became something of a hero on the right for chastising his fellow jurists for being too deferential to government functionaries. And antipathy to regulations has been a factor in the selection of the dozens of judicial nominations since then.", "title": "Trump\u2019s New Judicial Litmus Test: Shrinking \u2018the Administrative State\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump\u2019s proposed budgets for 2017 and 2018 had requested pay increases of 1.6 percent and 2.1 percent \u2014 rates that were lower than the statutory formula, and that were ultimately ignored by Congress.\n\n\u201cFor the last eight years, deep defense cuts have undermined our national security. If you look at what\u2019s taken out, they\u2019ve hallowed our readiness as a military unit and put America at really grave risk.\u201d\n\nThis needs context.\n\nMr. Trump accurately noted that military officials had expressed concern about degraded troop readiness and delayed modernization of supplies. Both are what officials have described as consequences of protracted combat and budget restrictions, known as sequestration, that were imposed by Congress.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt\u2019s worth noting that military spending has decreased in recent years, after the United States withdrew combat troops from Iraq in 2011.\n\nAdjusted for inflation, total military spending swelled to more than $774 billion in the 2010 fiscal year from roughly $400 billion in the 2000 fiscal year, according to the Congressional Budget Office. That period was the peak of wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. As the wars wound down, so did military spending, which declined to $583 billion by the 2017 fiscal year.\n\nWar-related spending aside, the Pentagon base budget alone was still larger in 2017 than it was in 2007 or 1997. Over all, the United States spends more on its military than the next seven countries combined.\n\n\u201cI can tell you this, and I say this to DACA recipients that the Republicans are with you. They want to get your situation taken care of. The Democrats fought us. They just fought every single inch of the way. They did not want DACA in this bill.\u201d\n\nThis is misleading.\n\nIn September, Mr. Trump moved to end Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, a program began by President Barack Obama that shielded eligible young undocumented immigrants from deportation and gave them the right to work.\n\nIt is highly misleading to suggest that Democrats \u201cfought\u201d efforts to solidify the program into law. Democratic leaders have rejected Mr. Trump\u2019s demand to pair the program with funding for a border wall, but that is not nearly the same as not wanting a legislative solution at all.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDemocrats met with Mr. Trump and Republican lawmakers in January to discuss a deal, during which Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, suggested a \u201cclean DACA bill.\u201d At the meeting, Mr. Trump agreed.\n\nBut hours later, the White House said Mr. Trump\u2019s concept of a \u201cclean DACA bill\u201d included border security. Negotiations stalled, and weeks later, Democrats briefly shut down the government over the issue.\n\nIn February, Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the House Democratic leader, delivered an eight-hour speech about the plight of the young undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers. The Congressional Hispanic Caucus, in a letter dated Feb. 28, said Mr. Trump had \u201cthwarted every bipartisan, narrow agreement that seeks to provide relief for Dreamers\u201d and listed a few examples.\n\nAnd this week, several Democratic lawmakers who voted no on the spending bill said they did so because it did not contain protections for Dreamers.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Objections Require Some Corrections", "authors": ["Linda Qiu"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 After making good on tax cuts and regulatory rollbacks that business leaders wanted, President Trump has turned to a part of his economic agenda that many of them feared: tariffs.\n\nThose leaders worry that Mr. Trump, by imposing stiff and sweeping tariffs on steel and aluminum, will set off a trade war with other countries. The global tit-for-tat could hurt American exporters and raise costs for manufacturers that rely on a vast supply chain around the world.\n\nIf that happens, it will crimp economic growth, undermining the stimulative effects of Mr. Trump\u2019s deregulation push and his signature $1.5 trillion tax cut.\n\nThe odds of such an outcome now appear to be rising, prompting congressional Republicans to push Mr. Trump in public and in private to reconsider. \u201cIf the president goes through with this, it will kill American jobs \u2014 that\u2019s what every trade war ultimately does,\u201d Senator Ben Sasse, Republican of Nebraska, said on Friday. \u201cSo much losing.\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s Steel Tariffs Raise Fears of a Damaging Trade War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "The second conflict that Trump is hurtling toward is with Iran. Unless he chooses some face-saving compromise, it looks as if Trump will pull out of the Iran nuclear deal by May 12.\n\nThe risk is that Iran responds by restarting its nuclear program. This would lead to soaring tensions, the possibility of an Israeli strike on Iran, a risk of Saudi-Iranian conflict and a danger of war between the United States and Iran.\n\nMike Pompeo, the C.I.A. director, whom Trump has nominated to be secretary of state, is very smart \u2014 and very hawkish on Iran. Moreover, Trump is considering replacing his national security adviser, H. R. McMaster, with John Bolton, who is not a mere hawk so much as a pterosaur.\n\n(The last best hope for world peace may be Bolton\u2019s dramatic mustache, because it\u2019s so substantial that it might keep Trump from choosing its owner. Let\u2019s all pray that Bolton doesn\u2019t shave it.)\n\nThe final risk, of course, is a war with North Korea. We may have a reprieve for a couple of months if Trump\u2019s face-to-face with Kim Jong-un goes ahead, but I think Americans are too reassured by the prospect of a summit meeting.\n\nThe basic problem: There\u2019s almost no chance that North Korea will agree to the kind of verifiable denuclearization that Trump talks about. Then the danger is that if a summit collapses, there\u2019s no room to restart the process with lower-level diplomats. At that point, the risk of military conflict soars because all alternatives seem exhausted.\n\nMoreover, Trump\u2019s snap decision to accept Kim\u2019s invitation to meet underscores the risk of a mercurial president leaping into actions \u2014 which is one of the reasons we got into the mess in Iraq. The temptation to fire missiles at North Korea or Iran may also be particularly great for a president seeking to distract from a Russia investigation or an outspoken porn actress.\n\nThese fears of conflict aren\u2019t found just among Democrats but are broadly shared by many foreign policy analysts across the spectrum. Kori Schake, who worked in the Bush White House during the Iraq war, notes that Trump sometimes has spoken about North Korea the way Bush administration officials did about Iraq, and she adds: \u201cI worry that President Trump could lead to war on the Korean Peninsula or against Iran, or by miscalculation in a number of other places where adversaries misread his intent. The president considers his unpredictability advantageous, when it is more likely to have explosive consequences.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Talk Worries Me, Like the Talk Before the Iraq War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump\u2019s announcement that he planned to impose steep tariffs on imported steel and aluminum delighted some blue-collar industries he had championed. \u201cEnthusiastic and gratified are probably understatements,\u201d said Michael A. Bless, the president of Century Aluminum.\n\nBehemoth steel buyers like Boeing and General Motors weren\u2019t as pleased. Their shares fell on the news, and the most obvious aluminum dependents \u2014 the brewing giants Anheuser-Busch and MillerCoors \u2014 warned about the risk of job losses.\n\nBut it is people like H. O. Woltz III who feel most vulnerable.\n\nMr. Woltz is the chairman and chief executive of Insteel Industries, which operates 10 plants from Arizona to Pennsylvania producing steel wire products for concrete reinforcing. He has about 1,000 workers, most without college degrees.\n\n\u201cThe jobs that we have are good jobs,\u201d Mr. Woltz said. \u201cOur guys make a lot of money.\u201d\n\nNow his business calculus is being upended. A tariff on imports also allows domestic steel and aluminum producers to charge higher prices, affecting manufacturers across the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs industrial America sorts out the tariffs\u2019 prospective impact, one thing is clear: The divide between the metal producers and their customers slices directly through Mr. Trump\u2019s blue-collar constituency.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Tariff Plan Leaves Blue-Collar Winners and Losers", "authors": ["Natalie Kitroeff", "Ana Swanson"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "The St. Marys River, which separates the two communities, funnels Lake Superior, the largest of the Great Lakes, into Lake Huron.\n\nThe arrival of Europeans turned the Canadian city into a strategic fur trading post. Abundant and cheap hydropower from the river\u2019s rapids made it a pulp and paper producer. But it was the discovery of iron ore, and the founding of Algoma in 1901, that turned Sault Ste. Marie into one of the largest cities in this part of Ontario. (The city is informally known as the Soo, which is how \u201cSault\u201d is pronounced.)\n\nAs in the auto industry, distinctions between Canadian and American steel making blurred long ago. In recent years, Canada has bought about as much steel from the United States as it has exported there. Today, all of Algoma\u2019s steel starts as coal and iron ore imported from American mines. The American military uses armor plate made by Algoma. Many steel workers in both countries belong to the United Steelworkers, a union led since 2001 by a Canadian, Leo W. Gerard.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Tariff Threat Sends Fear Through a Canadian Steel Town", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump\u2019s flurry of trade moves this past week raised uncertainty and confusion among financial markets, trading partners, lawmakers and American industry, prompting many to ask what, exactly, his endgame might be.\n\nJust one day before stiff steel and aluminum tariffs were set to go into effect, Mr. Trump offered a temporary 11th-hour reprieve to several allies, including some of the biggest foreign suppliers of steel. Many of them had spent the previous two weeks frantically lobbying the administration for a permanent exemption, but the White House said late Thursday that those nations would have until May 1 to negotiate \u201csatisfactory alternative means\u201d to address the national security threat that America faced from a reliance on foreign metals.\n\nIn addition to the metals tariffs, the White House announced levies on up to $60 billion worth of Chinese imports, a move that provoked immediate promises of retaliation by China and sent stock markets into a tailspin. On Saturday morning, the Chinese vice premier for financial and industrial policy, Liu He, told Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin in a phone call that the United States\u2019 actions against China violate international trade rules and run counter to American, Chinese and global interests. He warned that China has the strength to defend its national interests.\n\nOn Friday, Mr. Trump boasted that his approach would produce better trade deals for the United States, including what he said was a breakthrough in negotiations with South Korea. \u201cSome tremendous trade deals are being made with various countries,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re negotiating very long, very hard, but very quickly.\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s Tariffs Keep Allies, Markets and Industry Guessing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "The tariffs rest on a little-used legal provision that allows Mr. Trump to restrict imports to try to bolster the American industrial base in the interest of national security. That power will face scrutiny by the World Trade Organization but, perhaps more significant, could prompt other countries to follow suit in using national security as a reason to wall off their markets.\n\nAmerican technology companies, agricultural producers and other industries could ultimately lose business abroad as nations seek to erect similar barriers.\n\nRobert L. Shanks, Ford Motor\u2019s chief financial officer, said commodities markets had already started to price in increases for steel and aluminum on the expectation that Mr. Trump would impose the tariffs. The effect on Ford, he said, is \u201cnot positive\u201d given the automaker uses those metals in the cars they produce.\n\nThe European Union detailed a three-step plan to penalize $3.5 billion of American trade \u2014 the same amount of European steel and aluminum the bloc estimates would be harmed by the planned tariffs. It proposed taxing American exports including bourbon, bluejeans, orange juice, cranberries, rice and motorcycles. The European Union could then take action to protect their own metal makers from a surge in imports, and bring a case against the United States at the World Trade Organization.\n\nA European Union official said that the bloc had been preparing for the announcement for months and that everything was in place for a swift, proportionate response.\n\nThe measures were intended to put pressure on politically sensitive areas, trade analysts said. Harley-Davidson motorcycles are made in the home district of Speaker Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin. Orange juice comes from the swing state of Florida. Restrictions on Kentucky bourbon could add pressure on the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, who is from the state.\n\nRetaliation could hit hardest in many of the rural communities that were strongholds for Mr. Trump. Farmers are among America\u2019s largest exporters, and often become a target in trade spats, said Darci Vetter, the former chief agricultural negotiator for the United States trade representative. She said the agricultural community was \u201crightly nervous\u201d about the prospect.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Tariffs Prompt Global Threats of Retaliation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "The rush started when Mr. Trump floated the potential for exclusions, saying that Canada and Mexico would be exempted from the 25 percent tariffs on steel and 10 percent tariffs on aluminum as the countries renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement. He also spoke warmly of Australia as an ally and trading partner, and said that other nations with close relationships to the United States might be exempted, too.\n\n\u201cThe dinner bell is ringing for the trade bar and associated lobbyists and consultants,\u201d said Chip Roh, a former partner at Weil, Gotshal & Manges. Lawyers and lobbyists are employed on both sides, arguing for and against exemptions, he said, adding, \u201cIt creates a fertile field.\u201d\n\nBut the Trump administration has yet to clarify what precisely will qualify trading partners for an exemption, other than a vague reference to protecting America\u2019s national security and reducing its trade deficit. That has led to a chaotic and anxious period as companies and countries try their best to meet unclear specifications, and the clock continues to tick toward tariffs that are expected to go into effect next Friday, wiping out valuable contracts and putting global supply chains at risk.\n\nRobert Lighthizer, the government\u2019s top trade negotiator, has been charged with helping decide which countries will be excluded, while Wilbur Ross, the commerce secretary, has been tasked with a parallel process for exempting imports of certain products that are not widely available in the United States. The Commerce Department has developed its procedures for such exclusions, but it has not yet released them publicly. Those will be issued by Sunday, a spokesman said.\n\nThe European Union commissioner for trade, Cecilia Malmstrom, speaking on Wednesday to the European Parliament, said she left a meeting with Mr. Lighthizer over the weekend in Brussels without \u201csufficient clarity\u201d about how countries would secure exclusions.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Tariffs Set Off Storm of Lobbying", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "By restricting the supply of foreign metals in the United States, the tariffs are meant to raise the domestic price of those metals, which will translate into profits for struggling American metal makers. But in the process, more cheap metal will be available in markets outside the United States. That will push down the global price of steel and aluminum and create a two-tiered market.\n\nAfter Mr. Trump announced his tariffs, trade unions and Canada\u2019s steel and aluminum industries warned Mr. Trudeau that, without its own measures, Canada could be flooded with cheap steel and aluminum from countries that export at artificially low prices.\n\nEuropean officials have also argued that, without protections, their companies could become collateral damage. Officials in Brussels have warned that they will take \u201csafeguard measures\u201d in the form of additional tariffs on steel products if an inquiry into the American tariffs shows there could be a significant surge in cheap steel imports.\n\n\u201cThe E.U. is more than an innocent bystander,\u201d said Fredrik Erixon, the director for the European Center for International Political Economy, a think tank based in Brussels.\n\nThe European Union already has \u201cantidumping\u201d tariffs on steel in place, mainly directed toward cheap Chinese imports. But the bloc\u2019s leaders have also made clear they are prepared to do more and to exert diplomatic pressure on Beijing, pushing China to reduce government subsidies for its steel sector, cut import tariffs and open its market to American and European steel.\n\nSome supporters of the tariffs see the moves as evidence that the Trump administration\u2019s strategy is working. But other trade experts see this chain reaction as the first in a damaging series of actions that will end up raising the price of metals globally and making markets around the world less free.\n\nEswar Prasad, a professor of trade policy at Cornell University, said that although Mr. Trump\u2019s approach appeared to be bearing fruit in the short term, it could ultimately hurt the trust of American trading partners and hamper the economy.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Tariffs Trigger Global Chain Reaction to Halt Imports", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "That\u2019s a difficult question for several reasons. One, no country like China (an enormous command economy but one reliant on foreign trade) existed in the 19th century. Two, Beijing itself has seemed uncertain about whether it wants to maintain or break the American-led order.\n\nChina joined the World Trade Organization in 2001 but has chafed against its rules. The country relies on American-imposed stability in parts of the world other than its own, but challenges that dominance in Asia.\n\nChinese companies need access to the enormous American market, and Chinese consumers rely on American products and services. But China also benefits from closing some markets that would otherwise be American-dominated, for instance on smartphone software, which gives Chinese firms space to grow their products.\n\nMaybe hardest to know is whether China\u2019s command economy is better- or worse-suited than the American free market economy to advance the national interest within a system of closed international trade.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Interpreter Newsletter Understand the world with sharp insight and commentary on the major news stories of the week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWe often hear comparisons to the Cold War, which supposedly proved that the American economic system prevailed over the Soviet-style command system. But the Soviet economy collapsed largely because it relied on commodity prices, a vulnerability that remained in place during Russia\u2019s catastrophic free-market 1990s and still today.\n\nAnd the American economy was more centralized during the Cold War than is widely remembered. Though Americans told themselves that their geopolitical advances sprang naturally from private enterprise, many came from state-led projects, such as those that developed the space program or the internet. The country also poured money into strategic industries such as automobiles and steel during a period, the 1950s and 1960s, when vast international markets were opening up.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYet now the United States is drifting into a strange place where it really does have the decentralized, unguided economy that it told itself it had during the Cold War, but it is now also closing access to the international trade that such a system requires.\n\nAnd China, long unwilling to choose between an open or a closed world, is being pushed toward the latter. The country certainly presents itself as economically self-sufficient, something that becomes more true as its middle class grows into a robust domestic market. And its ability to direct vast resources to state-led projects, such as solar power or artificial intelligence, do promise the sort of geopolitical gains once achieved in the United States.\n\nBut the modern Chinese economy really dates only to the early 1990s, and it has always relied on American-led free trade, particularly access to the United States itself. While many critics of Mr. Trump\u2019s tariffs argue that a self-imposed American decline will naturally aid China\u2019s rise, this is merely another version of Mr. Trump\u2019s zero-sum worldview. Maybe it\u2019s correct. But it\u2019s also possible that China, however tentatively, bought into the American-led order for a reason, and that the decline of this system will hurt Beijing, as well.\n\nThe safest bet, however, is almost always on the forces of the status quo. Mr. Bush\u2019s 2002 foray into protectionism also initially looked like an end to the then-much-younger era of Chinese buy-in to the liberal world order. It wasn\u2019t, and this might not be either. Time will tell.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Tariffs: Another Retreat From the Postwar World Order", "authors": ["Max Fisher", "The Interpreter"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "At the request of The New York Times, Ms. Packes compared the average price per square foot for Trump buildings with the average prices of similar condominiums built at roughly the same time.\n\n\u201cThe prices most Trump condos are now selling for no longer merit the luxury designation,\u201d the CityRealty report said. \u201cIn part, this is simply a function of the age of the buildings,\u201d as luxury buildings built over the past decade sell for more, the report said.\n\nBut, brokers say, the difference is about more than just age. The features, amenities and styles that define ultraluxury have changed drastically since Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue opened in 1983, or Trump World Tower opened in 2001, near the United Nations. And foreign buyers, who dominate the top of the residential market in New York, are gravitating to the latest buildings on the market.\n\n\u201cEverybody wants the newest, coolest apartment with the most amenities, the newest architect,\u201d said Dolly Lenz, a broker who represents high-end buyers and sellers. \u201cThe aesthetics have also changed. Back then, brass and gold was cool. Today, the aesthetic is much more minimalist. They show their status through art, so they need very high ceilings.\u201d\n\nAll this is a far cry from how the Trump brand was perceived in the 1980s and 1990s, when Mr. Trump was building his condominium portfolio.\n\nHe started building his first eponymous building in 1980, the Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue, between 56th and 57th Streets, when the city was emerging from a long period of economic and fiscal crisis. He was one of the rare developers at the time to build luxury condos. But he thought he had a great location and a hefty tax break to boot.\n\nEven before he sold the first condo at the Trump Tower, Mr. Trump told The New York Times in 1980 that projects with his name on them were \u201c25 percent more valuable.\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s Towers Pale Next to Ultraluxury Buildings, Studies Show", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere is a lot of concern among Republican senators that this could sort of metastasize into a larger trade war,\u201d Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader and Republican of Kentucky, told reporters at the Capitol on Tuesday. \u201cMany of our members are discussing with the administration just how broad, how sweeping, this might be.\u201d\n\nThe president has said there may be exceptions. On Monday, he floated the idea of exempting Canada and Mexico if the countries made concessions in a renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement.\n\nAt a news conference on Tuesday, the president said the European Union could be exempted if it removed some of the \u201chorrible barriers\u201d that prevent American products from entering its market. \u201cOtherwise, we\u2019re going to leave it as it is,\u201d Mr. Trump said, referring to the tariff plan.\n\nYet some trade advisers say the administration is unlikely to consider such an exemption for South Korea, which several officials in the White House see as one of biggest global culprits in trade.\n\nThat view has stunned the South Korean government, which is used to working closely with the United States on economic and security matters. The United States maintains a large military presence in Seoul, the capital, and it has been a partner on issues like the North Korean nuclear threat and balancing against China\u2019s rise in the Pacific.\n\nAgainst the advice of many economists, the Trump administration sees the trade deficit with South Korea as a sign that the United States is on the losing end of their economic relationship. That is the major reason American officials have started to renegotiate the United States Korea Free Trade Agreement.\n\nMs. Cutler said the proposed tariffs would make \u201cwhat was already a complicated negotiation extremely complicated.\u201d She said it would be \u201calmost politically impossible\u201d for the South to agree to the United States\u2019 demands if it is not treated like other allies, including Canada and Europe.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Trade Plan Threatens to Derail Korean Security Talks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Chinese leaders are judged in part on how they manage relations with the United States, and a damaging trade war, if handled poorly, might diminish Mr. Xi\u2019s political standing and test the wisdom of the highly centralized power structure that he has erected around himself. If he retreats and offers significant concessions, however, Mr. Xi risks looking weak and inviting criticism in a political system that has fanned nationalist and anti-American sentiment.\n\nShi Yinhong, a professor of international relations at Renmin University in Beijing, said that Chinese leaders had been so successful over the years in deflecting criticism of the country\u2019s trade practices in the United States that they may have been slow to realize the gravity of the confrontation brewing.\n\n\u201cPeople in the U.S. and China have for years said the wolf is coming, the wolf is coming, but the wolf hasn\u2019t come,\u201d he said. \u201cThis time, the wolf is coming. And how to deal with the wolf? I would say that there is still no consensus.\u201d\n\nAnalysts in Washington and Beijing say that Mr. Xi will want to demonstrate resolve by standing up to Mr. Trump while finding a way to steer the countries away from a broader confrontation that could slow China\u2019s rise and undermine its global ambitions.\n\n\u201cXi\u2019s done an excellent job walking the thin line between Trump\u2019s aggressive rhetoric and protecting his own strong nationalist image,\u201d said Cliff Kupchan, the Washington-based chairman of Eurasia Group, a consultancy.\n\nReferring to Mr. Xi and his advisers, he added: \u201cThe question has always been how skilled are these guys as policymakers. Now they are going to be tested. Can the \u2018helmsman\u2019 pull with both oars?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s determination to carry out pledges from his presidential campaign \u2014 in which he repeatedly accused China of \u201craping\u201d the United States and its workers \u2014 has frustrated Mr. Xi\u2019s team. They must now decide how to respond to a mercurial American president who heaps praise on Mr. Xi personally even as he rails against a trade relationship that they argue has benefited both nations \u2014 a view endorsed by Mr. Trump\u2019s predecessors and, until recently, by much of the American business establishment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA major reason for Mr. Xi\u2019s frustration, analysts said, is that Beijing feels it has already made concessions to Mr. Trump by tightening sanctions against North Korea over its nuclear program, and at considerable cost to Chinese companies. Chinese officials had assumed that would keep Mr. Trump from following through on his trade threats, as he had suggested more than once.\n\nWhen it became clear this year that cooperation on North Korea would not be enough to placate trade hawks in the Trump administration, Mr. Xi redoubled efforts to head off the tariffs, dispatching his senior economic adviser, Liu He, to Washington last month.\n\nThat mission ended, however, in a humiliating snub. Though Mr. Liu was acting as Mr. Xi\u2019s personal envoy, Mr. Trump declined to meet him. Instead, the White House announced tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, including from China, on the first day of his visit. In another sign of Mr. Xi\u2019s trust in him, Mr. Liu was promoted last week to vice premier overseeing the economy.\n\nMichael Pillsbury, director of the Center for Chinese Strategy at the Hudson Institute in Washington, said Mr. Xi had turned to respected veterans of diplomacy with the United States by elevating Mr. Liu, who studied at Seton Hall and Harvard, and Wang Qishan, the new vice president, who has longstanding ties with Wall Street.\n\nHe noted, however, that they had become Mr. Xi\u2019s point men on the relationship at a moment when their experience may be a poor guide to Washington, just as two decades of bipartisan American support for deeper trade with China is crumbling in favor of a more protectionist, \u201cAmerica First\u201d approach.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re having a hard time adjusting to the new owners,\u201d said Mr. Pillsbury, who served as an adviser to the Trump campaign.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nChina has warned that it will retaliate, tit-for-tat, against tariffs and other measures. Even before the announcement of punitive measures in Washington on Thursday, the Ministry of Commerce in Beijing issued a statement sharply criticizing the Trump administration.\n\n\u201cWe firmly oppose the unilateralism and trade protectionism of the United States,\u201d it said. \u201cChina will absolutely not sit back and watch as its legal rights and interests get hurt.\u201d\n\nHu Xijin, the editor in chief of Global Times, a state newspaper with a nationalist bent, signaled that the government would begin by raising barriers to American agricultural products, practically taunting American soybean farmers. \u201cSoybeans of Brazil, Argentina and Russia are good alternatives,\u201d he wrote on Twitter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe added that while a trade war would benefit no one, \u201cChina is far more resilient than the U.S. to the pain.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the past, the Chinese government has succeeded in blunting American complaints about its trade policies \u2014 and over the giant trade imbalance between the two countries \u2014 by enlisting the support of big business in the United States to head off calls for punitive measures while making relatively small concessions and dangling the prospect of further action.\n\nIn a news conference this week, Premier Li Keqiang struck a familiar, conciliatory tone, defending the global trading system and promising to take additional steps to open China\u2019s economy to American services and products.\n\n\u201cWhat we hope is that cool heads and rational actions will prevail, instead of emotions or impulses holding sway,\u201d he said.\n\nSuch words might have led to negotiations in the past, but Mr. Trump appears less interested in negotiations than the Chinese leadership is.\n\nIt is also unclear what exactly the Chinese government could do to mollify the Trump administration. Two people briefed on bilateral discussions said Chinese officials had asked for a to-do list they could work with, but the administration has not provided one.\n\nMr. Xi has made clear that he envisions China as a leading power on the world stage, able to dictate terms as the United States did for decades. And some of his supporters have argued that Mr. Trump\u2019s policies \u2014 especially his willingness to break with longstanding allies in Asia on trade \u2014 have presented China with an opportunity to make great strides toward that goal.\n\nBut a trade war that hurts the Chinese economy could slow Mr. Xi\u2019s agenda and roil Chinese politics in unpredictable ways.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Pillsbury, the author of \u201cThe Hundred-Year Marathon: China\u2019s Secret Strategy to Replace America as the Global Superpower,\u201d said there was a divide in the Chinese political establishment that mirrored the split in the United States between \u201cglobalists,\u201d who favor trade and a rules-based international order, and \u201cnationalists,\u201d who argue that those things are sapping American strength.\n\nIn China, he argued, a major confrontation over trade would be likely to strengthen those who believe the United States is seeking to block China\u2019s rise.\n\nHu Angang, an economist at the School of Public Policy and Management at Tsinghua University who advises the government, said that Mr. Trump\u2019s decision could begin a vicious cycle that would hurt America\u2019s reputation more than China\u2019s economy.\n\n\u201cI think Trump is not professional; he doesn\u2019t understand the global situation,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Hu added that China may be replacing the United States, with Mr. Xi picking up the banner of global cooperation on trade, climate and other issues that Mr. Trump\u2019s predecessors had carried.\n\n\u201cAfter 40 years of being students, learning from our teacher,\u201d he said, \u201cnow it is the time for the teacher to learn from its students.\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s Trade Threats Put China\u2019s Leader on the Spot", "authors": ["Steven Lee Myers"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "There\u2019s a short scene in the film \u201cRoxanne\u201d in which Steve Martin drops a quarter into a box to buy a local newspaper. He stares at the front page for about two and a half seconds before screaming hysterically at the atrocities he finds reported there. Then he reaches into his pocket for another quarter. Mr. Martin puts the paper back in the box, closes it, and then proceeds on his way, his sense of tranquillity restored.\n\nFollowing the news out of the White House these days is something like that \u2014 each week seems filled with so many things to make your hair stand on end that there are times that, like Mr. Martin, I find myself wanting to fish around in my pocket for an extra quarter just to make it all go away.\n\nThe last few days have been typical. On Thursday, H. R. McMaster, the national security adviser, resigned and was replaced by John Bolton (a man Donald Trump was originally reluctant to hire because he didn\u2019t like his mustache). On Friday morning, the president threatened to veto the $1.3 trillion spending package that Congress sent him in order to avoid a government shutdown, only to sign it later, after describing it as \u201cridiculous.\u201d Was it really just three days ago that he called President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to congratulate him on his victory in a rigged election, in spite of being specifically begged not to do so by his own staff?\n\nRight about now is when you might want to start fishing around for that additional quarter.\n\nSo you can be forgiven if, while all that was going on, you missed when Mr. Trump issued a new ban on transgender troops on Friday night, reversing an Obama-era policy and providing only minor tweaks to the ban he\u2019d already tried to put in place last year, before that policy was shut down by legal challenges.", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Trans Ban Shows Who He Really Is", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe abrupt decision on steel tariffs and now the summit with Kim Jong-un will inevitably raise questions in Tokyo and other allied capitals about how decisions are made by this administration that affect their interests,\u201d said Michael J. Green, a former Asia adviser to President George W. Bush who is now at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, and who met with Japanese officials in Tokyo on Friday.\n\nThe news that Mr. Trump wanted to meet with Mr. Kim did provide relief, at least in the short term, from months of growing fears that military conflict would break out on the Korean Peninsula.\n\n\u201cOn the one hand, we\u2019re buying time and Trump is not going to bomb in the spring,\u201d said Gordon Flake, chief executive of the Perth US-Asia Center at the University of Western Australia. \u201cThat\u2019s good.\u201d\n\nBut, Mr. Flake added, Mr. Trump \u201cdemonstrated extreme capriciousness on something like tariffs. This is why everyone in the region is having the same reaction: equal parts relief and alarm.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s seemingly unstoppable series of erratic moves has helped cast China as the more stable power in Asia. But it has also diverted attention from Chinese actions that would otherwise have raised much more alarm.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cOne of the most underreported consequences of the last 18 months is that China has gotten a free pass,\u201d said Mr. Flake, citing the country\u2019s military buildup on islands in the South China Sea, its economic punishment of South Korea for cooperating with the United States on a missile defense system and, most recently, President Xi Jinping\u2019s power grab, persuading the Communist Party to abolish limits on his time in office.\n\nUnder any other American administration, \u201cthe dominant narrative would have been Chinese overreach and internal crackdowns,\u201d Mr. Flake said. \u201cBut that narrative has been completely washed away by the chaos that is Trump.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe most recent announcements out of Washington, particularly the tariffs, could hurt China. Clearly, a trade war would be painful. And as Mr. Trump plans his meeting with Mr. Kim, Beijing is forced to sit on the sidelines awaiting the result.\n\n\u201cThe downside risk for them is that they are not in the room,\u201d said Mira Rapp-Hooper, a scholar of Asian security issues at Yale Law School. \u201cBeing completely cut out of a genuine relationship between the U.S. and North Korea is not in their interest.\u201d\n\nStill, lengthy talks between the United States and North Korea, even if they do not produce an agreement, would serve to delay some unpalatable decisions for China, analysts said.\n\nNorth Korea has become increasingly disgruntled with China since Mr. Kim took charge, particularly as Beijing has backed economic sanctions against it. That has complicated China\u2019s efforts to diminish American influence in the region.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cChina wants the nukes removed, but not at too high a geostrategic cost, in the form of North Korea becoming China\u2019s permanent enemy or falling into enormous domestic chaos or sliding into the American fold,\u201d said Shi Yinhong, a professor of international relations at Renmin University in Beijing.\n\nFrom China\u2019s perspective, the Trump-Kim talks, by cooling the bellicose rhetoric between the United States and North Korea, would reduce the need for intense cooperation between the United States, Japan and South Korea.\n\n\u201cIt suits China\u2019s long-term strategic interest perfectly, because what they don\u2019t want to see is pressure on North Korea leading to the strengthening of American alliances,\u201d said Mr. Green. \u201cChina\u2019s strategy is to start pulling apart those alliances incrementally.\u201d\n\nIncreasingly, Asian allies that once viewed the United States as an anchoring force in the region now worry about being played off against each other. Japan and South Korea in particular, whose relations have recently deteriorated over longstanding historical disputes, find themselves jockeying for Washington\u2019s favor.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Japan, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has worked hard to cultivate a warm relationship with Mr. Trump. So even as Mr. Trump withdrew from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a multilateral trade deal centered in Asia, and imposed the new steel and aluminum tariffs, government officials have tempered their criticism.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cJapan and the United States are allies, so the Japanese government doesn\u2019t want to be too negative towards the Trump government,\u201d said Kazuhiro Maeshima, a professor of politics at Sophia University in Tokyo.\n\nSouth Korea, meanwhile, lobbied for an exemption to the tariffs, citing the importance of the alliance. The envoys who visited the White House to brief Mr. Trump on their meeting with Mr. Kim made personal appeals to Defense Secretary Jim Mattis and the national security adviser, Gen. H.R. McMaster, on the tariff issue, according to Kim Eui-kyeom, a spokesman for President Moon Jae-in.\n\nThe tariffs prompted harsh words in some South Korean news outlets for the leader of the country\u2019s most important ally. \u201cHis style of governing, marked by disconnectedness and arrogance, is just mind-blowing,\u201d a liberal daily newspaper, Hankyoreh, said in a Saturday editorial.\n\nFor Asian allies, perhaps the most difficult task in dealing with Mr. Trump \u2014 one that is hardly unique to foreign governments \u2014 is scrambling to discern his true intentions.\n\nMr. Trump often \u201cis saying one thing in Japan and another thing in Seoul,\u201d said Yoshiki Mine, a former Japanese Foreign Ministry official who was involved in past talks between Japan and North Korea, and who now runs a think tank, the Institute of Peaceful Diplomacy.\n\nMr. Moon, after being sidelined by Washington in its approach to North Korea a few months ago, would now seem to be in favor, having effectively brokered Mr. Kim\u2019s invitation to Mr. Trump. But analysts warned that the talks could go in directions South Korea might not welcome.\n\n\u201cWe quickly get to the question of what is going to be talked about here,\u201d said Ms. Rapp-Hooper. \u201cKim Jong-un is clearly not ready to give up his nuclear weapons. If it gets to that, he will make extreme security demands, not only a security guarantee, but demanding that we end our alliance with South Korea and withdraw our troops from the peninsula.\u201d\n\nIf Mr. Trump offered to significantly reduce America\u2019s presence in South Korea in exchange for limits on the North\u2019s nuclear program, it would be a setback for South Korea and Japan and a long-term win for China.\n\nAmerican allies in the region, along with many developing countries in Southeast Asia, want the United States to maintain a strong presence, as much to counterbalance China as to promote democratic values, said Kristi Govella, an assistant professor of Asian studies at the University of Hawaii at Manoa.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMost countries would prefer not to be dominated by anybody \u2014 whether it is the U.S. or China or Japan,\u201d Ms. Govella said. \u201cEspecially for the smaller countries, they want to hedge a bit and have different options, and not be subject to the will of any particular country.\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s Unpredictability on Trade and North Korea Opens a Door for China", "authors": ["Motoko Rich"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Remember that bipartisan immigration get-together he held back in January? When he begged members of Congress to pass \u201ca bill of love\u201d that would take care of those very same Dreamers? It was a swell moment. After which, the alien floated away, Trump retracted everything and made the famous remark about people from \u201cshithole\u201d countries.\n\nDuring the spending negotiations, maybe the alien entity was taking Trump on a visit to other dimensions. That would explain why the president had absolutely no clue as to what had been going on during the meetings, which had been attended by members of his staff.\n\nWhen it came time for the threatened veto, Trump transformed again, announcing he had to sign the spending plan because it included desperately needed funds for the military. But to prevent anything this dreadful from ever happening in the future, Trump added that he was \u201ccalling on Congress to give me a line-item veto for all government spending bills.\u201d After members of the House and Senate finished rolling around on the floor laughing, the world moved forward.\n\nExcept for Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin, who told a Fox interviewer that he thought it would indeed be a good idea to allow the president to wipe out any pieces of the congressional budget that he didn\u2019t like. When informed that line-item veto power had been declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court, Mnuchin said, \u201cWell, again, Congress could pass a rule, O.K., that allows them to do it.\u201d\n\nThis is an administration that goes through high-ranking officials like Raisinettes at a movie. And yet Steve Mnuchin is still here.\n\nSo the spending negotiations were a disaster for the wall warriors. \u201cHow about going to Mexico and getting them to pay for it?\u201d said Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer cruelly.\n\nWe have listened to several conversations between Trump and the president of Mexico on this subject, all of which can be translated into:\n\nTrump: \u201cLook, all I\u2019m asking is that you just don\u2019t say you won\u2019t pay for it.\n\nPresident of Mexico: \u201cHahahaha. \u2026\u201d\n\nBut our chief executive does not give up! Trump came back with a stern tweet announcing that the Defense Department could build his wall, since, thanks to the new budget, \u201cour Military is again rich.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Visitor From Outer Space", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Welfare recipients forced off the rolls by the 1996 law were only slightly more likely to get jobs than people who continued to receive benefits, and the incentive effects of the work requirement dissipated over time, according to a University of Chicago study in 2005.\n\n\u201cThis all starts with the assumption that if you make people miserable enough, they will go out and find a job,\u201d said LaDonna Pavetti, the vice president for family income support policy at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a left-leaning think tank in Washington.\n\n\u201cThe reality of people\u2019s lives is much more complicated than that. It doesn\u2019t take into account the barriers they face, but also the color of their skin, their prison record, and barriers like education, transportation, child care and the lack of good-paying jobs where they live,\u201d she said. \u201cNone of these proposals have adequate resources to deal with any of those barriers.\u201d\n\nMr. Bremberg, in an interview, said: \u201cThe goal is not to kick people off support programs. The goal is to get people into productive jobs.\u201d He added that the president\u2019s main objective was matching millions of able-bodied potential workers with millions of jobs that remain unfilled because of the shortage of suitable workers.\n\nStill, the resources dedicated to increased work force development in Mr. Trump\u2019s 2019 budget, released last month, are relatively modest compared with the deep cuts proposed for safety net programs. And the work requirements come in addition to the administration\u2019s proposal to drastically cut domestic spending, including a plan to trim food aid by $213 billion over the next decade.\n\nThe Department of Housing and Urban Development, which is slated to absorb a $6 billion cut next year under the president\u2019s budget, has begun looking at ways to expand a small demonstration project centered on work requirements into its public housing and voucher programs.\n\nThe effort to impose work requirements on people who receive Medicaid is moving faster, in part, because the action is being initiated by a handful of governors in conservative states eager to shed the additional costs imposed on them by the gradual withdrawal of subsidies granted in the Affordable Care Act.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Vow on Welfare Faces an Uncertain Future", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe level of tension between the United States and its major trading partners is probably more tense than it has been at any time since the early 1980s,\u201d said Meredith Crowley, an international trade expert at the University of Cambridge in England.\n\nWhether Mr. Trump has begun a trade war or merely a skirmish will depend on what happens next \u2014 which countries win a reprieve from the tariffs, and which opt to retaliate.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s decision to back off from across-the-board tariffs came in the face of strident warnings from the American business world and leaders of his own Republican Party that such a course would damage the American economy and alienate allies.\n\nStill, Mr. Trump brushed aside talk that tariffs were a reckless provocation, appearing to relish his role as instigator. \u201cTrade wars are good and easy to win,\u201d he tweeted this month.\n\nMr. Trump maintains that Americans have been outwitted by savvier trading partners, with tariffs needed to force jobs to return to the United States.\n\nHistory has proved humbling for those inclined to seek victory through trade conflicts. Commerce has tended to plunge, with the working class suffering lost jobs and diminished livelihoods. Alliances have been frayed, heightening international tensions.\n\nMany economists and international-relations experts assume that Mr. Trump\u2019s tariffs could play out much the same way, isolating the United States while imperiling a global economic expansion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNot least, the tariffs seem likely to present the World Trade Organization with a potentially existential crisis.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe organization has been described as the referee for global commerce, settling disputes on the basis of rules adopted by consensus among its 164 members. Now, the referee may be on the verge of losing control of the game.\n\nIn justifying its tariffs as a response to a supposed threat to national security \u2014 a contention that has drawn derision from economists \u2014 the Trump administration has virtually ensured a challenge from the European Union via a complaint filed with the trade organization. That would put the institution in a predicament in which any course risks undermining its authority.\n\nThe trade organization could rule in favor of the United States, deferring to American sovereignty and its right to determine its national security policies. But that would hand every country on earth a template to break with the norms of international trade.\n\n\u201cThis would open the floodgates to everyone bringing in broad exceptions,\u201d said Ms. Crowley, the Cambridge expert.\n\nOr the body could rule against the United States, rejecting the argument that metal forged in Europe poses a mortal peril to Americans. The Trump administration might then ignore the ruling and carry on, forcing the W.T.O. to give countries the right to retaliate.\n\nHostilities would most likely expand well beyond steel and aluminum. Mr. Trump\u2019s pledge of tariffs has enraged and astounded American allies whose fortunes are tied to producing these metals, like Japan, South Korea, Germany and Taiwan.\n\nOn Wednesday, the European Union outlined plans to retaliate with tariffs on a variety of American goods, including motorcycles, rice and bourbon. If reprisals continued, Europe might limit exports of other American agricultural products, intensifying its push against genetically modified crops. In the most extreme case, Europe might even impede American investment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a real chance that everyone reacts very negatively,\u201d said Jennifer A. Hillman, an international trade expert at Georgetown Law Center in Washington.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFaced with a rebuke from the global trading body, Mr. Trump might pull the United States out of the institution.\n\nAs he addressed a delegation at the trading body\u2019s Geneva headquarters on Monday, W.T.O.\u2019s director general, Roberto Azev\u00eado, worried openly about a descent into a trade war.\n\n\u201cIt is clear that we now see a much higher and real risk of triggering an escalation of trade barriers across the globe,\u201d he said. \u201cOnce we start down this path, it will be very difficult to reverse direction. An eye for an eye will leave us all blind and the world in deep recession.\u201d\n\nTrade frictions are a constant in the global economy. Governments wield tariffs, import quotas and other instruments to protect sensitive industries. But a trade war is different, holding the potential to damage living standards on multiple continents.\n\n\u201cYou start viewing it as a conflict between nations,\u201d said Adam S. Posen, president of the Peterson Institute for International Economics, a research institution in Washington. \u201cYou put a premium on doing damage rather than deterring bad behavior.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Trump and his advisers appear to be calculating that, as the largest economy on earth, the United States possesses enough muscle to dictate the terms of world trade.\n\n\u201cThey are under the delusion that the United States has been screwed by the global system that it created,\u201d Mr. Posen said. \u201cThey apparently think that everyone else will fold if they stand up.\u201d\n\nThat idea, he added, is about to be exposed as wrong.\n\nAs the United States grappled with the Great Depression, a Republican-controlled Congress seized on protectionism as the fix, adopting the infamous Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 to wall off American farms and factories from foreign competition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe law sharply increased tariffs on hundreds of goods \u2014 from sugar to shoes to iron. American trading partners responded with their own tariffs, and commerce deteriorated, deepening the depression.\n\nAfter Democrats captured control of Congress and the White House in 1932, tariffs fell sharply, bolstering American trade. But Britain, France, Germany and other European powers maintained steep tariffs. Trade disintegrated, exacerbating nationalist animosities that exploded into World War II.\n\nThe last substantial outbreak of trade hostilities played out in the 1980s, as the United States grappled with the consequences of a rising Japan. The American auto industry \u2014 caught unprepared for the public\u2019s embrace of smaller, more fuel-efficient vehicles \u2014 lobbied Washington for tariffs to limit a surge of Japanese imports. President Ronald Reagan ultimately pressured Japan to voluntarily restrict auto exports to the United States.\n\nJapanese-made automobiles sold in the United States soared in price. Seeking to avoid tariffs while improving trust, Japanese car companies began setting up plants to make their vehicles in the United States, employing American workers.\n\nTrade advisers to Mr. Trump cite this history as an example of how an aggressive stance can set up fruitful trade negotiations. But major differences separate that episode from today.\n\nBack in the 1980s, auto plants needed to be built somewhere to serve swelling American demand for small cars. Japan was firmly dependent on good relations with Washington for its security, making it prone to avoid conflict.\n\nToday\u2019s primary American trade antagonist is China, ruled by the apparent president-for-life Xi Jinping, whose nationalist credo does not leave room for caving to pressure from Washington. The world faces a glut of steel, much of it made in China. Whatever tariffs the Trump administration maintains, foreign steel manufacturers are not likely to construct new plants in the United States.\n\nAmong proponents of liberalized trade, the most hopeful history may be the most recent chapter.\n\nIn 2002, President George W. Bush put tariffs on steel to protect American producers against imports. Then, as now, companies that make products using steel vastly outnumbered those that produce the metal. As automakers and other steel buyers confronted higher costs, the tariffs eliminated some 200,000 jobs, according to one study.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nForeign steel producers filed a challenge at the W.T.O., which ruled that the United States had acted without justification. Europe prepared a list of American goods to stick with retaliatory tariffs. Mr. Bush backed down.\n\nBut if the global trading apparatus successfully defused that crisis, the current situation presents a different challenge given the nature of the commander waging the attack.\n\n\u201cThe fundamental view of this administration seems to be, somewhat bizarrely, that the United States has not benefited from trade,\u201d Ms. Crowley said. \u201cIt seems like it\u2019s not really registering how damaging this could be.\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s Warning Shot on Trade Risks Igniting a Wider Conflict", "authors": ["Peter S. Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Character is fate. That\u2019s as true for a president as it is for anyone else, and so it\u2019s no surprise that the Trump presidency is engulfed in chaos.\n\nThe policy process is broken and incoherent, with the White House lurching from one position to another. Factions are warring. Top aides are embroiled in scandal and bailing out. President Trump is escalating his attacks on his own advisers, especially his attorney general, and is increasingly isolated and embittered.\n\nThe Republican Party is learning what should have been obvious from the outset: Mr. Trump\u2019s chaotic personality can\u2019t be contained. Indeed, combining it with the awesome power of the presidency virtually guaranteed he would become more volatile and transgressive. His presidency is infecting the entire party.\n\nIn the realm of policy, Mr. Trump is reshaping some traditional Republican views. A party that was once firmly in favor of free trade is now home to a president who just announced plans to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum and declared: \u201cTrade wars are good, and easy to win. Example, when we are down $100 billion with a certain country and they get cute, don\u2019t trade anymore \u2014 we win big. It\u2019s easy!\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s White House Is a Black Hole", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "After Aleppo, now comes the agony of Eastern Ghouta. This suburb of Damascus, the last rebel-held enclave close to the Syrian capital, is bombarded by Bashar al-Assad\u2019s forces for weeks on end, with Russian air support. More than 900 people, including many children, are killed. Hospitals are targeted in what Fran\u00e7ois Delattre, the French ambassador to the United Nations, has called \u201ca siege worthy of the Middle Ages.\u201d Pregnant women bleed to death. Some 400,000 people are trapped.\n\nFrance and Britain convene an emergency meeting of the Security Council and press for enforcement of last month\u2019s Resolution 2401, calling for an immediate cessation of hostilities. In this effort, the United States is nowhere, silent, AWOL, as President Vladimir Putin and his Syrian sidekick do their worst. The message to Moscow is clear: Donald Trump\u2019s America does not care about Syria, or war crimes, or human rights. Russian cynicism and American absence produce disaster.\n\nYes, it has come to this.\n\nEmmanuel Macron, the French president, calls Putin. He dispatches his foreign minister to Moscow and Tehran in an attempt to stop the slaughter. Trump, to whom moral indignation \u2014 indeed morality itself \u2014 is a stranger, does not care. His Middle East foreign policy has two components: Back Israel, bash Iran. With respect to Putin, he is compromised, or enamored, to the point of incapacity. Let Syria burn.\n\nYes, it has come to this.\n\nIn Hungary, a European Union country, committed by treaty to the Union\u2019s founding principles of \u201cthe rule of law and respect for human rights,\u201d Viktor Orban, the prime minister, declares that, \u201cWe do not want to be diverse and do not want to be mixed; we do not want our own color, traditions and national culture to be mixed with those of others.\u201d Now, what color, precisely, are Hungarians, and what color were the nearly 440,000 Jews deported by the Nazis, mostly to Auschwitz, in 1944 with the cooperation of Hungarian authorities?", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s World and the Retreat of Shame", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Since Mr. Christie canceled the ARC project, the need for a new tunnel has become more dire, transportation officials say. In 2012, Hurricane Sandy flooded the existing tunnels with salt water and the residue has been eating away at them from the inside ever since. If one of those tubes, which are owned and maintained by Amtrak, had to be taken out of service with no replacement, train service to and from New York City would be reduced by as much as 75 percent, Amtrak officials say.\n\n\u201cEvery day that goes by is a day we risk uncertainty, especially with mother nature,\u201d said Janna Chernetz, director of New Jersey policy for the Tri-State Transportation Campaign. \u201cThe next storm will not have to be as strong as Hurricane Sandy before the tunnel has to be taken out of service.\u201d\n\nKathryn S. Wylde, president and chief executive of the Partnership for New York City, a big-business group, says Mr. Trump knows how important Gateway is to the region and the country.\n\n\u201cPresident Trump travels frequently between New York and New Jersey and understands that Gateway is critical to connect the rest of the country with the center of the economy and the world financial capital in New York,\u201d Ms. Wylde said in an interview. \u201cI have no doubt that regardless of what he says, he knows the importance of this project and he does not want it to fail on his watch.\u201d\n\nMr. King said he did not understand what had changed since he attended a meeting with Mr. Trump and other elected officials at the White House in September. At the time Mr. Trump was telling the group that Gateway was \u201ceven more important than we were saying it was,\u201d Mr. King recalled. He said he came away believing that receiving substantial federal funding for the project was merely a matter of \u201ccrossing the t\u2019s and dotting the i\u2019s,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Christie and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, both of whom attended that meeting, had already pledged to cover half the cost of building Gateway. The Obama administration had ranked Gateway the No. 1 priority in transportation infrastructure and informally agreed to cover the other half.\n\nIn what was taken as a sign of continuing bipartisan support, Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, a Republican from New Jersey who leads the House Appropriations Committee, committed $900 million to the Gateway project last year. Mr. Christie, who had endorsed Mr. Trump for president, called the allocation \u201ca triumph for our region.\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s Yanked Support for Hudson Tunnel Angers Those Who Saw a Done Deal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "She was a college freshman when her parents came to tell her and her sister that their father had turned himself in to federal officials. Ms. Nolan promptly ran into the bathroom and threw up, she recalled in an interview. Until that point, she thought her parents had one of the better relationships out there; unlike most of her friends\u2019 parents, they were still together. But it was all a lie.\n\nFor three months after getting \u201cthrown into an emotional cyclone,\u201d as she put it, she hid in her apartment. She didn\u2019t go to class; she was afraid to see people. With failing grades, she dropped out of school. \u201cThe biggest thing to come to terms with was that my entire childhood was kind of bought with stolen money,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was an identity crisis. As I look back, I beat myself up for kind of not paying attention. What was the indicator that I missed out on over and over?\u201d\n\nTherapy has helped her try to make sense of it, although she hasn\u2019t seen her father in about two years.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not even mad about what he did to me, I\u2019m so mad at what he did to my mom,\u201d she said. \u201cShe\u2019s never hurt anybody in her entire life.\u201d\n\nMs. Franck struggled after her husband\u2019s crime. While she didn\u2019t have to file for bankruptcy, like Ms. Henry did, she did sell her Ford Thunderbird to pay off her daughter\u2019s college debt and some of her own legal fees after she was investigated by the F.B.I., and she had to get a second mortgage to cover debt left behind by her husband. She was also diagnosed with post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and not long after, had two bouts of colorectal cancer, which she said was in remission. \u201cThe doctor said it was stress-induced,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Franck and Ms. Henry divorced their husbands, something Ms. Lawler suggests all wives of white-collar criminals do. \u201cI\u2019m adamant about them divorcing to protect their assets so they are left with a fighting chance to recover their own losses as the first victims of a husband\u2019s financial crime,\u201d she said.\n\nStill, she is astounded by how many women try to make the marriage work.\n\n\u201cThe women want to live back in the safety of the bubble,\u201d Ms. Lawler said. \u201cMany of them defend their husbands: \u2018He\u2019s a good father, a good husband, a great member of the community.\u2019 I say, \u2018No, a good man protects his family and knows his place and role in society. Good guys don\u2019t toss themselves and their families over a cliff. Love and trust go hand in hand.\u2019\u201d", "title": "Trust Betrayed: Wives of White-Collar Criminals Tell Their Stories", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Clinton warned Palmieri otherwise. Before the race started, Clinton \u201cheld forth for more than an hour\u201d to recap each scandal, from the uproar in Arkansas when she resisted taking Bill Clinton\u2019s name to the White House and her doomed 2008 presidential campaign. \u201cShe was as bewildered as anyone by the phenomenon of \u2018Hillary Clinton,\u2019\u201d Palmieri writes.\n\nImage\n\nFlash forward to the day after the November election and Palmieri has started to see almost everything about the public\u2019s perception of Clinton through the prism of gender. She seethes at the supporters who ask her why Clinton couldn\u2019t have struck the emotional notes of her concession speech during the campaign. \u201c\u2018Yes, I\u2019m sure you loved her concession speech,\u2019 I thought. \u2018Because that\u2019s what you think is acceptable for a woman to do \u2014 concede.\u2019\u201d\n\nAmid a deluge of gossipy tell-alls by political operatives (or the reporters they vent to), Palmieri deserves credit for turning her story into something aimed at inspiring positive change \u2014 or at least making the perfect gift for the student-body president in your life. The book is rooted in the recent tradition of open letters by feminist authors, most notably Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie\u2019s \u201cDear Ijeawele, or A Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions.\u201d But Palmieri\u2019s bumper-sticker self-help can jolt the reader out of an otherwise enticing story.\n\nPalmieri has been at the center of pressure cookers from Whitewater to the Russian hacks and has picked up advice that could benefit any woman (even one without West Wing ambitions). She has plenty of vivid anecdotes: the time Obama encouraged her in an Oval Office meeting to stop stressing about \u201csome dumb Politico article,\u201d or the time Clinton insisted everyone have ice cream sundaes to cheer up her aide Huma Abedin after the F.B.I. found new emails on the computer of her estranged husband, Anthony Weiner. Why water these down with pablum like: \u201cTrust most what your own heart and head tell you to do,\u201d or \u201cIf you will yourself to fight on, you will never be defeated\u201d?\n\nPalmieri, who worked on John Edwards\u2019s presidential runs, devotes bittersweet time to redeeming his wife, Elizabeth Edwards. They bargain shop at T. J. Maxx and eat at a Sonic Drive-In. It\u2019s refreshing since Elizabeth Edwards, who died of cancer in 2010, had been skewered by the political press, with a particularly memorable turn in \u201cGame Change,\u201d the book about the 2008 campaign by Mark Halperin and John Heilemann.", "title": "Trust Your Own Heart, Write Your Own Story and Fight On", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "In his remarks, Mr. Carranza repeatedly echoed the mayor in speaking about equity \u2014 a byword of Mr. de Blasio\u2019s educational philosophy. \u201cThe equity agenda championed by our mayor is my equity agenda,\u201d Mr. Carranza said.\n\n\u201cThere is no daylight between Mayor de Blasio and myself, in terms of what we believe in, what our aspirations are for the children of New York City,\u201d he went on.\n\nMr. Carranza, no less than Mr. Carvalho, has an up-from-the-bottom story that appealed to Mr. de Blasio. His grandparents moved to the United States from Mexico, and he and his twin brother grew up speaking Spanish and did not learn English until they began school in Tucson. The boys\u2019 father was a sheet-metal worker and their mother was a hairdresser.\n\nAs a youth, Mr. Carranza learned to play the guitar and fell in love with mariachi music, a continuing theme in his life. He paid his way through college by playing mariachi gigs.\n\nHe eventually became a social studies teacher, then a principal and a school administrator. He spent seven years in San Francisco, first as deputy superintendent and then as superintendent, before moving to Houston in August 2016 to become superintendent.\n\nIn coming to New York \u2014 a city that he said he had little experience in \u2014 Mr. Carranza is taking on a much bigger system than anything he has managed in the past. New York City has about 1.1 million students in about 1,800 schools.\n\nHouston, the seventh-largest school district in the nation, has about 215,000 students in about 284 schools across 312 square miles.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Houston, 61 percent of students are Hispanic, 24 percent are black, 8 percent are white and 4 percent are Asian. Three out of four students are \u201ceconomically disadvantaged,\u201d according to information on the district\u2019s website.\n\nMr. Carranza might be coming to New York City with a sense of relief. He will inherit a school system where test scores and graduation rates have been improving, a trend that began under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and has continued under Mr. de Blasio.\n\nPhoto\n\nLike most major urban districts, Houston suffers from achievement gaps between low-income and wealthy students. Mr. Carranza and others have also argued that the district\u2019s current method of funding schools exacerbates inequality.\n\nHe had to grapple with daunting budget cuts. Hurricane Harvey struck the city in late August and caused major damage to the schools.\n\nIn an op-ed in The Houston Chronicle in January, Mr. Carranza said the Houston school district was in \u201ca financial storm unlike any the district has seen before.\u201d Damage from Hurricane Harvey could lower the area\u2019s property values, which would mean less money for the schools. Enrollment had fallen, he said, and was expected to continue its decline.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
