View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe was praised for his efforts after the storm to get the schools working again. About 80 percent of the city\u2019s schools opened after only a two-week delay. Mr. Carranza also secured donations from officials and philanthropists in San Francisco to help with the response, including a $1 million donation from the founder of Salesforce, Marc Benioff.\n\nIn recent months, Mr. Carranza has faced some turmoil in Houston, where he has proposed a new model of funding schools that he says is designed to create greater equity among the district\u2019s sharply segregated schools.\n\nJolanda Jones, the first vice president of the district\u2019s board of trustees, said there had been \u201ctremendous pushback\u201d to the proposal from people in affluent communities that have benefited from the current funding system, and their representatives on the board.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s really not going to leave a legacy of change or of anything positive,\u201d said Robert Sanborn, president of Children at Risk, a Texas-based research and advocacy nonprofit. \u201cIt\u2019s a legacy of: He hung out in Houston for a while and now he\u2019s leaving.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Sanborn said that Mr. Carranza found himself hamstrung by the school board. \u201cHe came in with a lot of great intentions,\u201d he said. \u201cIn the whole scheme of things, the biggest obstacle for Carranza was a school board that did not want to change.\u201d\n\nMr. Carranza\u2019s great strength, he added, is that he\u2019s personable. \u201cIn front of an audience, he\u2019s a guy that you love,\u201d he said.\n\nMany politicians and education officials in Houston complain that schools there are badly underfunded by the state.\n\n\u201cFrom a state perspective, it\u2019s a failure that we couldn\u2019t keep him, because he has a lot of talent,\u201d said Armando Walle, a Texas state representative whose district includes part of Houston. \u201cI hope this doesn\u2019t become a pattern where we get talented people to come in, and then they leave the district because we don\u2019t give them the tools they need.\u201d\n\nAfter restarting discussions with the mayor, Mr. Carranza flew to New York on Saturday and spent the weekend in intense conversations with Mr. de Blasio and other top staff members. Mr. de Blasio said that, sitting at a table in Gracie Mansion at 10 p.m. Sunday, he offered Mr. Carranza the job and Mr. Carranza said \u201cYes.\u201d\n\nHe will be paid $345,000, which the mayor said was his salary in Houston. Ms. Farina made $244,430, but after decades working in the city\u2019s school system she also collected a pension.\n\nThe speed of the announcement underscored Mr. de Blasio\u2019s need to find a replacement for Ms. Fari\u00f1a, 74, who seemed to already have one foot out the door. Her goodbye party at Tweed Courthouse, the Education Department\u2019s headquarters, was held on Friday, after which she flew to Florida, where she has a home. But at Monday\u2019s news conference, she suggested that she would be around for a while, saying that there would be two chancellors for a period. And she wants to continue to work on a high schools initiative even after Mr. Carranza takes over, she said.\n\nMs. Fari\u00f1a sent a valedictory email on Friday to the city\u2019s teachers, thanking them for their dedication and offering one last bit of advice.\n\n\u201cI want to remind you how strong our school system is, and that we must remain focused on the work ahead,\u201d she wrote. \u201cOur system is bigger than one single person; it is powerful because of our collective strength and belief that to reach all students, we must focus on each.\u201d", "title": "Trying Again, de Blasio Names a New Schools Chancellor", "authors": ["William Neuman", "Elizabeth A. Harris"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "There are differences between my story and Nakesha\u2019s, though. Nakesha had more friends who stuck by her and maintained an interest in helping her; I felt more alone. Many of my good friends \u2014 though certainly not all \u2014 acted toward me with an attitude like disgust, once it became clear that I needed help.\n\nI suffered from bipolar disorder, however, not some form of schizophrenia with paranoia, like Nakesha. I was able to accept help. I stayed in shelters almost every night \u2014 in two years I don\u2019t think I slept on the street once \u2014 and eventually was given housing by the Massachusetts Department of Mental Health. Nakesha, by contrast, feared psychiatric treatment and the assistance of social workers and state agencies. This is the curse of paranoid people, especially intelligent and perceptive ones. They are aware of the wretchedness of their situations, but are prevented, by their delusions, from engaging with forces that will heal them, shelter them or rescue them.\n\nThank you for turning Nakesha Williams back into a human being \u2014 and for doing it on the front page of The New York Times, where, maybe, Nakesha\u2019s story will reach and touch people who dehumanize and objectify the homeless.\n\nNICHOLAS N. FINKELSTEIN\n\nBOSTON\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nThe tragic saga of Nakesha Williams is an all too familiar story of the homeless mentally ill. The tragedy is not only the impact of her illness, likely schizophrenia, which robs a young adult of the promise and opportunity of having a normal life, but also of the failure of the health care system to find a way to treat her. The many individuals who befriended her while she lived on the street, who provided for some of her material needs, failed to get her into medical treatment, which almost certainly would have resulted in a profound reversal of the slide that her life had taken.\n\nAntipsychotic medications would have substantially reversed if not eliminated the paranoid ideas and fears that had crippled her capacity to realize her innate potential. Part of the difficulty in getting her treated was clearly her resistance, but this is the Catch-22 of schizophrenia. The illness itself obliterates an individual\u2019s capacity to have agency for one\u2019s own health. The question of whether she was a danger to herself in need of involuntary treatment was answered by the final chapter of her story.\n\nDANIEL R. WEINBERGER\n\nBALTIMORE\n\nThe writer is director of the Lieber Institute for Brain Development and a professor at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nThough we lost touch many years ago, I am fortunate to see my friend and former colleague Nakesha\u2019s bright light come shining through in this powerful and heartbreaking story. The evidence of her sojourn here will not be easily forgotten. Nakesha was a teacher, and it is amazing to see how her life is still teaching us all. She has given the invisibility of homelessness a name and a face. I am also struck by the many people who entered Nakesha\u2019s life to provide support along the way.", "title": "Opinion | Trying to Help a Homeless Woman", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "The change, and how quickly it came, took me by surprise. One minute we were in the heart of Tucson, Ariz., among the restaurants, coffee shops and businesses you\u2019d expect in a metro area of more than a million people. Scarcely 15 minutes later it was as if we were hundreds of miles from civilization. Surrounded by the muted bronze and sage colors of the desert, my cousin Melanie Kuhlman (and her three children) and I took in the silence, the desert brush and towering saguaro cactuses that stretched 20 or 30 feet into the air. One of the best things about Tucson, I discovered, is how easy it is to leave Tucson. That\u2019s not a knock against the city \u2014 I mean it in the most complimentary way possible.\n\nThe Old Pueblo, as the city is sometimes called, is a special place. Unlike many major urban centers, whose bragging rights are that you don\u2019t have to leave the city limits to find what you want, Tucson is a place that encourages you to explore. Yes, there is beautiful public art throughout, as well as a Unesco-recognized culinary scene. But within easy access are breathtaking mountainscapes, desert kitsch and outstanding wildlife-viewing opportunities. Tucson is worth a visit for any traveler, regardless of means, but I\u2019m happy to say I kept well within my modest budget when I visited last month.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a city that doesn\u2019t feel as big as it is,\u201d said my uncle Brian, an avid outdoorsman and decades-long resident (and Melanie\u2019s dad). Melanie compared the city to Phoenix, just two hours away: \u201cWe preserve our natural desert landscape,\u201d she said. \u201cIf you look around Phoenix, there are a lot of lawns. People have \u2026\u201d She paused. \u201cGrass.\u201d", "title": "Tucson Is a City That Encourages You to Explore", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "In this world, even the privileged are hyper-tense, constantly measuring themselves against their peers. On play dates, the mothers worry about how to hold their silverware: \u201cWhether she ought to cross, American-style, or keep her fork facing down, European-style.\u201d They worry about whether they overthanked the doorman \u2014 the richest moms always maintain an aloof, almost distracted separation from the help \u2014 and whether to dress their household staff in uniforms. They bully themselves into submission. \u201cWe deflected compliments,\u201d Macy writes, Greek-chorus style. \u201cWe made deprecating comments about how much we had eaten at the last meal and how lazy we were and how badly we sucked at tennis when in fact we were not at all lazy and we were very good tennis players.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMacy artfully observes the elite custom of seeming never to care about anything. Questions, she notes, are proffered only as segues into bragging: \u201cDo your children\u2026? Because we. \u2026\u201d As a Yale student trying to disguise his middle-class upbringing, John D. Curtis wears the hems of his jeans flamboyantly long so his loafers flatten them as he walks, a hallmark of slouchy, preppie indifference. And as the mothers watch another mother hugging and kissing her daughter after school, \u201ceach one of us remembered, in a depth of bumming-out, the moment, in preadolescence, when we had learned from either our parents or our peers that one had to pretend not to care.\u201d Even the marriages are chilly: \u201cA certain type of man needed a wife to help keep things impersonal, as if marriage were a barracks, and inspection from the outside could come at any time.\u201d Brrrr.\n\nMacy is well versed in the rigors of schadenfreude and social judgment. The descendant of an old-money family that had lost its fortune by her father\u2019s generation, she attended an East Coast boarding school, then went to Yale on scholarship. As she revealed in 2009 on the publication of her previous book, \u201cSpoiled,\u201d a story collection about class distinctions among the privileged, her husband had lost jobs at a bank and a hedge fund, and her older daughter had been rejected by all the private schools they applied to for kindergarten. (I\u2019m pretty sure things have turned out all right for them.)\n\nMacy has clearly observed the world of aspiration and failure up close, which is why \u201cMrs.\u201d has such a tonic air of authenticity. Within this novel, there\u2019s almost an entire treatise on the decorating habits of the wealthy \u2014 and not so wealthy. One mother can\u2019t be trusted to weigh in on another\u2019s apartment because her own home is \u201cfloor to ceiling Pottery Barn \u2014 giant clocks, lobster traps for coffee tables, apothecary shop for a kitchen.\u201d Minnie\u2019s kitchen is \u201cvast, suburban-size,\u201d glistening \u201clike an operating theater with menacing, hyper-clean appliances.\u201d One townhouse is so grand that its parlor floor makes the gathered parents look dumpy, \u201cas if the room had been made for a larger, more significant race, one that didn\u2019t have to stuff itself into pantyhose or pay through the nose for monthly highlights in a condescending salon on Madison.\u201d Even among wealthy people, there are levels of fabulousness.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe novel\u2019s attention to such interior detail makes you wonder if Macy is curating the scenery for an inevitable cable rendition, the way Liane Moriarty\u2019s novel \u201cBig Little Lies\u201d was adapted for HBO. In fact, the stories are similar: Both use the children\u2019s school as a stage, with the parents as the stars. \u201cMrs.\u201d is set among the Manhattan 1-percenters who count wine cellars and his-and-hers drivers as necessities, just as the TV version of \u201cBig Little Lies\u201d is set among the wealthy of Monterey. And as both stories unfold, the pursuit of luxurious lifestyles becomes incidental to survival, revenge and redemption.\n\nConsider a scene from \u201cMrs.\u201d that might as well have been directed by Jean-Marc Vall\u00e9e. Two mothers confront John D. Curtis and engage him in combat, eventually wresting from his wife an overdue debt. One takes off with her compensation (from an assignation-turned-assault during her \u201cBelle du Jour\u201d days), and as she strides away with her children, crisp hundred-dollar bills sail out of her pockets.\n\nThe remaining parents regard one another in stunned silence. Do they chase the money? Of course! Even masters of the capitalist universe and their flawless wives are soon scampering after the floating bills, stooping to the sidewalk, \u201cone with a stomp of the foot, the other on his knees, shooting out a hand.\u201d It\u2019s the children who look on, aghast.\n\nThe boldest thing about \u201cMrs.\u201d \u2014 as with \u201cBig Little Lies\u201d \u2014 is that it focuses on the depths of women\u2019s experiences as wives and mothers. Their clashes with one another are entertaining, sure, but they\u2019re a diversion from the more important conflict with their husbands and with male power. \u201cMrs.\u201d could easily have been a glossy, rushed novel about bitchy, bored housewives nursing social resentment. Plenty of those have been published, passing from memory as quickly as the pages fly under your fingers. But Macy hasn\u2019t written that kind of book. Although Philippa, Minnie and Gwen aren\u2019t smash-the-patriarchy crusaders for social justice, they recognize the violent, self-flattering, corrupt man in their midst and they deliver him, finally, to justice \u2014 even if it comes at the expense of other lives.", "title": "Turf Wars of the Ultra-Wealthy, Upper East Side Style", "authors": ["Alex Kuczynski", "Caitlin Macy"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "The fighting in Afrin is creating problems for the United States. The transfer of personnel from the Kurdish-led, American-backed militia known as the Syrian Democratic Forces, or S.D.F., is a blow to Washington\u2019s effort to stamp out the last vestiges of the Islamic State, also known as ISIS.\n\nOn the diplomatic front, the Americans have insisted that although they are allied with the S.D.F. in eastern Syria, they have no affiliation with the group in the northwest and will not aid any of its operations there. But with its Kurdish coalition allies now streaming to join the defenders in Afrin, that posture will be increasingly difficult to maintain. As a result, in Afrin, the Trump administration is finding itself awkwardly on the opposite side from Turkey.\n\nThe S.D.F. said in a statement on Tuesday that it had made a \u201cpainful decision\u201d to move the fighters from Deir al-Zour to Afrin, citing \u201cthe failure of the international community\u201d to pressure Turkey and \u201cstop its madness within our Syrian borders.\u201d\n\nThe role in Afrin of the Kurdish militia known as the People\u2019s Protection Units, or Y.P.G., which is the main component of the S.D.F., has raised tensions with Turkey, which considers the militia an extension of a separatist group that is active in Turkey and is listed as a terrorist group by both Ankara and Washington.\n\nFor six weeks, Turkey has mounted a campaign to wrest control of Afrin from the Y.P.G., an offensive that has displaced some 10,000 people and killed several hundred civilians and 41 Turkish soldiers. Mr. Erdogan said this week that 159 Syrians belonging to the Free Syrian Army, which is fighting alongside Turkish armed forces, had also died.\n\nThe Y.P.G. has responded with cross-border shelling, leading to civilian deaths in Turkey.\n\nAdding to the complications, the Y.P.G., which has carved out a zone of de facto autonomy from the Syrian government within Afrin and in a larger swath of northeastern Syria, last week allowed some pro-government militias to enter its territory to help the fight against Turkey.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe militias did not include formal army troops, but they flew the Syrian government flag. State television in Syria said the militias were aiding in the defense of the country\u2019s borders but made no reference to Kurdish aspirations.\n\nTurkey\u2019s incursion came soon after the United States said that it would continue to support the S.D.F. even after the fight against the Islamic State ends and that it would help the group form a border force to protect the long frontier its territory shares with Turkey.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow, the movement of troops away from Deir al-Zour threatens two American objectives there: preventing a resurgence of the Islamic State and curbing the growing influence of Iran, which sponsors militias that fight for the Syrian government.\n\nIn another crisis point in Syria, negotiations on Tuesday between the government and Jaish al-Islam, the rebel group that controls the northern and eastern parts of the Damascus suburb of eastern Ghouta, went nowhere. Despite mass civilian casualties and major territorial losses, the armed groups in the enclave refused to withdraw, according to antigovernment activists.\n\n\u201cThe result of the negotiations which Jaish al-Islam took part in yesterday is that the displacement and exit of the armed groups and civilians was refused completely,\u201d said Alaa al-Ahmad, an activist in eastern Ghouta, adding that rebel groups had \u201crefused a policy of displacement.\u201d\n\nVideos published by Syrian pro-government news media showed some residents of the town of Hammouriyeh taking to the streets Wednesday afternoon calling on the rebel fighters to leave. The videos, in which some people could be seen waving Syrian government flags, could not be independently verified.\n\nThe residents of eastern Ghouta have lived under a harsh government siege since 2013 and have borne the brunt of a heavy bombing campaign that has pounded the enclave for weeks, claiming the lives of over 800 civilians to date. The bombardment has continued despite a unanimously approved 30-day cease-fire agreed to by the United Nations Security Council that was intended to provide respite and an opportunity for civilians to evacuate.\n\nAfter the failed negotiations, about 700 fresh pro-government troops arrived on Wednesday, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported, in preparation for a push into the urban heart of the rebel-held enclave.\n\nSyrian and Russian authorities maintain that rebels have shelled the humanitarian corridor and prevented civilians from leaving. The Russian Ministry of Defense, in a briefing on Wednesday, maintained that only 17 people had thus far been able to evacuate through the corridor.\n\nSince the onslaught began less than a month ago, pro-government forces have seized about 40 percent of eastern Ghouta, mostly rural areas. Government forces have exploited loopholes in the cease-fire agreement to continue their advance.", "title": "Turkey Asks U.S. to Stop Kurds From Shifting Fighters to Western Syria", "authors": ["Anne Barnard"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 A Turkish court sentenced 24 journalists to prison on Friday, ruling that they were linked to a religious sect that the government calls a terrorist group and that has been blamed for a failed coup attempt in 2016.\n\nMost of the journalists worked for news organizations that are considered friendly to Fetullah Gulen, a cleric living in seclusion in a small town in Pennsylvania. The Turkish government claims that Mr. Gulen leads a shadowy, violent movement aiming to overthrow President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.\n\nMr. Erdogan has become increasingly authoritarian since the coup attempt. He has steadily tightened his control over the government, the military, the media, courts, schools and even the internet, fraying relations with Turkey\u2019s Western allies. He has purged tens of thousands of people suspected of disloyalty from the government and the military, and thousands more have been arrested and charged with supporting terrorism.\n\nIn the July 2016, elements of the military appeared to seize power, and aircraft bombed the Parliament building and presidential palace in Ankara, the capital. But the Y.P.G. has been an important ally of the United States in the fight against the Islamic State in Syria.", "title": "Turkish Warplanes Said to Kill 40 Pro-Government Fighters in Syria", "authors": ["Anne Barnard", "Hwaida Saad", "Carlotta Gall"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Imagine if prisons looked like the grounds of universities. Instead of languishing in cells, incarcerated people sat in classrooms and learned about climate science or poetry \u2014 just like college students. Or even with them.\n\nThis would be a boon to prisoners across the country, a vast majority of whom do not have a high school diploma. And it could help shrink our prison population. While racial disparities in arrests and convictions are alarming, education level is a far stronger predictor of future incarceration than race.\n\nThe idea is rooted in history. In the 1920s, Howard Belding Gill, a criminologist and a Harvard alumnus, developed a college-like community at the Norfolk State Prison Colony in Massachusetts, where he was the superintendent. Prisoners wore normal clothing, participated in cooperative self-government with staff, and took academic courses with instructors from Emerson, Boston University and Harvard. They ran a newspaper, radio show and jazz orchestra, and they had access to an extensive library.\n\nNorfolk had such a good reputation, Malcolm X asked to be transferred there from Charlestown State Prison in Boston so, as he wrote in his petition, he could use \u201cthe educational facilities that aren\u2019t in these other institutions.\u201d At Norfolk, \u201cthere are many things that I would like to learn that would be of use to me when I regain my freedom.\u201d After Malcolm X\u2019s request was granted, he joined the famous Norfolk Debate Society, through which inmates connected to students at Harvard and other universities.", "title": "Opinion | Turn Prisons Into Colleges", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The head of Turner Broadcasting on Wednesday pushed back against one of the central arguments of the government\u2019s case to block the AT&T and Time Warner merger, saying that his company\u2019s channels would not be used as a weapon against rivals if the deal went through.\n\nThe Justice Department has argued that Turner, which is owned by Time Warner, owns \u201cmust-have\u201d channels like CNN and TNT that the merged company would use as leverage in negotiations with other cable and satellite TV operators. But John Martin, the chief executive of Turner, told a federal court that his channels were not absolutely vital for a cable or satellite business.\n\n\u201cI believe we have must-have, as do other programmers,\u201d Mr. Martin said. \u201cMust-have is another way of saying we have popular programming.\u201d\n\nMuch of the Justice Department\u2019s argument in the trial, which started last week, has centered on the importance of Turner\u2019s exclusive sports rights, which include professional and college basketball games. Mr. Martin\u2019s testimony had been one of the most anticipated moments of the trial.", "title": "Turner Chief Pushes Back on Core Justice Dept. Argument", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "In remarks prepared for delivery to the Alaska Legislature last month, Senator Murkowski argued that \u201cfederal restrictions, including the roadless rule, are holding back timber, mining and renewable energy development.\u201d She added, \u201cI believe there is room and need for all of those alongside tourism and fisheries in a sustainable Southeast economy, and that is why I am pushing hard to restore balanced management.\u201d\n\nCritics of the roadless rule are wrong when they claim it blocks mining and renewable energy projects. The 1872 Mining Law guarantees reasonable and necessary access to explore and develop mineral claims in roadless areas, while the Federal Power Act allows for the construction of hydroelectric projects in roadless areas. The Forest Service reports that as of January it had approved 55 projects in roadless areas in Alaska, including 36 mining and 10 hydro or hydro-related projects, most winning approval within a month.\n\nThe days of litigation and controversy should be behind us. The regulation that protects roadless areas is more than 16 years old and has withstood multiple legal challenges. The roadless rule is an intensely conservative regulation. It saves taxpayers money and keeps our few remaining wild remote public lands intact. Most important, it maintains options for future generations.\n\nThe Tongass includes some of the most productive and valuable fish and wildlife habitat in the world. A report by Southeast Conference, a regional economic development organization, shows that Southeast Alaska\u2019s tourism industry supports 17 percent of all jobs while the seafood industry, mostly commercial fishing for salmon, accounts for 9 percent of jobs. The Tongass National Forest makes up 78 percent of the land base in Southeast Alaska and is the mainstay of the region\u2019s economy.\n\nThe targeting of the Tongass is the latest in Senator Murkowski\u2019s efforts to turn back longstanding protections of wild places in Alaska. She championed the lifting late last year of a decades-old ban on oil and gas drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in northeastern Alaska, as well as a land swap announced in January that will allow a road through environmentally important wetlands in the Izembek National Wildlife Refuge.\n\nWe should keep the Tongass as it is. Rather than passing amendments that micromanage the Forest Service and undo the progress that has been made, Congress should assist the agency on pressing issues like the spiraling cost of wilderness firefighting. To restart road building in Alaska\u2019s most pristine national forests will only repeat history, leading to more lawsuits and uncertainty while undercutting the region\u2019s economic bases of fishing and tourism.", "title": "Opinion | Turning Back the Clock on Protecting Alaska\u2019s Wild Lands", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Though Mr. Gaiman hasn\u2019t been directly involved in this new version \u2014 earlier this month he finished shooting a screen adaptation of his novel \u201cGood Omens,\u201d written with Terry Pratchett \u2014 Mr. Turnage and Mr. Mullarkey have had plenty to play with. The novel begins when little Coraline Jones discovers that a bricked-up door in the apartment she\u2019s just moved into is a portal to a nightmarish \u201cother world.\u201d Trapped behind the door, she finds a figure with black buttons for eyes who coos that she\u2019s Coraline\u2019s \u201cother mother\u201d and promises her anything she desires, if only she agrees to stay \u201cfor ever and always.\u201d Coraline\u2019s journey home to her real parents is not only a coming-of-age story; it also becomes a mythic quest.\n\nA powerful, self-determined heroine, Coraline is more than a match for operatic heroines like Leonore in Beethoven\u2019s \u201cFidelio\u201d or Rosina from Rossini\u2019s \u201cThe Barber of Seville.\u201d The role is shared in the new production by the sopranos Mary Bevan and Robyn Allegra Parton.\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s such a strong female character,\u201d Mr. Turnage said. \u201cShe\u2019s powerful; she\u2019s going to solve these things. I\u2019ve got a seven-year-old daughter. S he\u2019s too young to read the book, but she saw the film, and she was very taken with Coraline.\u201d\n\nAlthough the opera, like the novel, is aimed at young audiences \u2014 Mr. Turnage has dedicated it to his daughter and his youngest son \u2014 it goes to some genuinely disturbing places. The sense that evil lurks around every corner is palpable; there are heavy hints, too, of abuse in the plotline of parent-like figures who bribe a child to love them. While critics have often compared the book to Lewis Carroll, Mr. Gaiman\u2019s universe is arguably closer to David Lynch or Stephen King in its atmosphere of suspenseful, what-lies-beneath horror.\n\n\u201cI wanted to write about how people who have your best interests at heart may not always pay you the kind of attention that you\u2019d like,\u201d Mr. Gaiman said in a statement. \u201cAnd people who pay a lot of attention to you may not always have your best interests at heart.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Collins agreed that, despite its fairy-tale qualities, this narrative is not for the fainthearted. \u201cThe story is: You can have anything you want in the whole wide world, as long as you let me sew buttons into your eyes,\u201d she said.\n\nMr. Turnage clearly relishes the material\u2019s otherworldly side; the score, written for 15 musicians, is astringent and occasionally violent, bringing to mind early chamber pieces such as \u201cOn All Fours\u201d (1983) and \u201cBlood on the Floor\u201d (1996). But \u201cCoraline\u201d does allow audiences some moments of fun. The composer said he enjoyed coming up with Broadway-ish music for the character of Mr. Bobo, an eccentric old man who dwells in the apartment above Coraline and conducts the mouse orchestra. Two retired actresses who live in the apartment beneath, Miss Spink and Miss Forcible, are portrayed as divas of a certain age who issue Cassandra-like pronouncements about fate in high-voltage coloratura.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe fantasy element is so heightened,\u201d Mr. Turnage said. \u201cCompletely operatic.\u201d\n\nThe Royal Opera has staged eight new operas for young people and families in the last five years, among them Julian Philips\u2019s \u201cHow the Whale Became\u201d (2013), based on children\u2019s stories by Ted Hughes, and Adriano Adewale\u2019s \u201cHatch\u201d (2017), billed as a \u201csensory experience for children aged 2 to 5.\u201d The profusion indicates how seriously the company is trying to demolish the perceived barriers that surround the art form, and to attract new and more diverse audiences.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe company is under continual pressure to justify its annual governmental subsidy of around $33 million annually \u2014 the highest of any arts institution in Britain \u2014 and has invested in co-productions with theater and dance companies around the country. It also runs school workshops and outreach projects in towns outside London, including in some of the region\u2019s most deprived areas.\n\nMr. Turnage, who grew up in Essex, not far from London, and was the first member of his family to get a college education, said he hoped audiences for \u201cCoraline\u201d would come from all walks of life. The opera world sometimes wasn\u2019t as outward-facing as it should be, he suggested.\n\n\u201cA lot of opera directors are making opera for other opera directors, and quite a few opera composers are writing for their peer group,\u201d he said.\n\nAlthough \u201cCoraline\u201d has been in development for over four years, both he and Ms. Collins said that the theme of a young woman standing up for herself against the odds had acquired particular topicality in the context of the #MeToo and #TimesUp movements. The classical world has experienced plentiful rumors about sexual harassment, along with some high-profile firings \u2014 notably of the conductors Charles Dutoit and James Levine, who was pushed out of the Met earlier this month.\n\nMr. Turnage said that, while some things had improved over his years in the business, \u201cI\u2019m acutely aware of women working in the opera world and the way that they\u2019re marginalized, and how tough it is. Everybody knows this.\u201d\n\nHe added he was proud that, as well as having created a strong female lead, the production also has a largely female creative team, led by Ms. Collins and the conductor Sian Edwards. \u201cThe world is changing,\u201d Mr. Turnage said.\n\nHe added that he hoped \u201cCoraline\u201d offered a path forward, in its way. He was inspired by a quotation from G.K. Chesterton that Mr. Gaiman uses as the epigraph of the book: \u201cFairy tales are more than true: Not because they tell us that dragons exist, but because they tell us that dragons can be beaten.\u201d", "title": "Turning a Ghoulish Children\u2019s Book Into a Grand Opera", "authors": ["Andrew Dickson"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Jiang Zhi, the artist who produced the image, which has been interpreted as a criticism of the lack of property rights in China, said evicted families should be treated more humanely. He said he had displayed similar photos without issue for more than a decade and was puzzled that it would be considered controversial.\n\n\u201cWill the image of a bouquet of flowers, a gesture, a certain kind of smile, an umbrella, a hat and so on suddenly become forbidden?\u201d he said. \u201cDoes this not stem from a bizarre and ridiculous sort of fear?\u201d\n\nThe image was later restored.\n\nIn Beijing, a painter, Hua Yong, was briefly detained this winter after he posted dozens of videos online documenting the destruction and his conversations with aggrieved families. Mr. Hua\u2019s posts were later deleted on Chinese sites.\n\nMr. Hua said censorship was impossible to avoid. \u201cThe duty of artists is first to record and second, to ruminate,\u201d he said in an interview. \u201cI hope I can wake up more people.\u201d\n\nMr. Xi\u2019s government seems especially sensitive to art that uses the phrase \u201cdi duan ren kou,\u201d or \u201clow-end population,\u201d a derisive reference to migrants that is used by some officials. The phrase has become a rallying cry for critics of the government\u2019s mass expulsions, though censors now block it on the Chinese internet.\n\nA poem by Yu Xiuhua, who has been called China\u2019s Emily Dickinson, spoke bluntly about divisions in society and the plight of the \u201clow-end population\u201d:\n\nLeave the sunshine to the high-end population,\n\nLet\u2019s go my child, go with the Beijing wind,\n\nLeave the sunshine to the future. Leave it with the high-end to praise,\n\nLeave the happiness to the future. Leave it with the high-end to enjoy.\n\nThe poem was quickly deleted from social media sites. But that did not stop migrant workers from reciting it at protests and other gatherings this winter, as the rate of evictions in Beijing intensified.", "title": "Turning the Rubble of China\u2019s Mass Evictions Into Protest Art", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nThe sugar problem. If you live in the United States, you probably eat more sugar than is good for you. It\u2019s probably not your fault, either. Added sweeteners are infused into a shocking number of foods.\n\nAfter I wrote a year ago about my own efforts to eat less sugar, I heard from many readers who were interested in doing the same. So I have written a guide that The Times has just published.\n\nIf you follow its recommendations and want to tell me how it goes \u2014 or have your own ideas for how to eat less sugar \u2014 write me at Leonhardt@nytimes.com.", "title": "Opinion | Turnout Versus Persuasion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Three days later when they returned to the Shanghai airport, Ms. DeMaria was delighted to see Dr. Koehne, 60, looking her way again. By chance, they had also scheduled the same return flight, but as they waited, the flight was canceled. \u201cI was so attracted to him that when our flight was canceled, and we went upstairs to order food and wine and wait for a reassignment, I asked him to join us,\u201d she said.\n\nWhile they dined, Michele DeMaria began a conversation with Dr. Koehne, who was born and raised in Germany, and affiliated with Sloan Kettering for about 23 years. \u201cI asked what he was doing at the airport,\u201d she said. \u201cHe said he gives \u2018talks,\u2019 but I had to pull his profession out of him because he was so modest.\u201d\n\nMs. DeMaria, an expert in real estate communications, and also the founder of WorldWise PR Affiliates, a global network of independently owned public relations agencies, had been married for 30 years, with two other daughters and a stepdaughter; she had been separated for only four months when she met Dr. Koehne. She was clueless about how to handle her attraction to this stranger.\n\n\u201cI was not used to flirting,\u201d she said.\n\nAfter a polite conversation, their flights were called. She opted for a Los Angeles connection back to her home in Miami, while he planned to return to New York through Chicago. But neither asked the other for a name. \u201cOn the flight home I kept thinking about his eyes and how they have a quality of deepness like a caring priest,\u201d Ms. DeMaria said. \u201cThat made a huge impact on me, and I asked my daughter to find his contact information online.\u201d", "title": "Two Chance Meetings, and a Romance Takes Flight", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA gunman fatally shot two people at a Central Michigan University residence hall on Friday morning, sending police officers swarming to the campus and setting off a search for the suspect that ended early Saturday with an arrest.\n\nThe episode rattled nerves at Central Michigan, where details were released slowly and students were told to take shelter inside dorms and classrooms for much of the day.\n\nPolice officers said Friday that they were seeking James E. Davis Jr., 19 and a sophomore. They described him as a person of interest in the shooting and cautioned that he was \u201carmed and dangerous.\u201d The victims were identified as Mr. Davis\u2019s parents, James E. Davis Sr. and Diva J. Davis, both 47. An Illinois state legislator identified the elder Mr. Davis as a police officer in Bellwood, a Chicago suburb.\n\nJust before 1 a.m. Saturday, the university said the police had taken \u201cthe suspect in the shooting\u201d into custody after a search that grew to include more than 100 police officers from several Michigan agencies and the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe university did not name the suspect in its brief statement, saying only that the person had been \u201cseen and reported by an individual on a train passing through the north end of campus shortly after midnight.\u201d", "title": "Two Fatally Shot on Central Michigan University Campus", "authors": ["Mitch Smith"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Cielle experiences life the way most teenagers do \u2014 she\u2019s hyper-aware of her immediate world and detached from the larger scheme of things (her consciousness of the war in Europe is limited to the boys she knows who are going off to fight in it, and the rationing of food and gas). Though Kenny offers little exposition about the era, her austere landscapes and careful attention to color and light evoke the paintings of Andrew Wyeth or Edward Hopper, or the poetry of William Carlos Williams, suffusing the book with a midcentury mood throughout.\n\nLess placid is Kristin Hannah\u2019s \u201cThe Great Alone.\u201d Hannah has written more than 20 books since 1991, and her fan base has grown along with her oeuvre. Her most recent novel, \u201cThe Nightingale,\u201d topped the best-seller list for much of 2015, and a movie adaptation is in development. Her new novel has wasted no time catching up, having already been optioned for film rights as well. It\u2019s easy to see why: Like \u201cThe Nightingale,\u201d which was set in France during World War II, this novel features a camera-friendly backdrop \u2014 this time, Alaska \u2014 and a Hollywood-ready sentimentality.\n\nImage Credit Lis Xu\n\nIt\u2019s 1974 and the signs of the times flash vividly for 13-year-old Leni Allbright. In the first five pages alone she contemplates EST seminars, the I.R.A., Watergate, the Munich Olympics massacre, the kidnapping of Patty Hearst and, of course, Vietnam, where her father, Ernt, was a prisoner of war. He\u2019s been suffering from post-traumatic stress ever since, and Leni and her mother, Cora, suffer too as Ernt moves them from one home to another, trying to find peace in a chaotic world. When Ernt learns that a former war buddy has bequeathed him a cabin and land in Alaska, he believes this will be his salvation. Though Leni and Cora have misgivings about leaving their current home in Seattle, they share Ernt\u2019s hope for a restorative new life in the last frontier.\n\nThe family arrives on the picturesque, sparsely populated Kenai Peninsula, where they immediately meet the neighbors. Hannah, a former attorney, seems determined to prove beyond a doubt that what the locals lack in number they make up for in personality. First she presents the heavyset, middle-aged woman who owns the dry goods store: \u201cFolks call me Large Marge,\u201d she informs the newcomers. Shortly thereafter, we meet an elderly man, apparently somewhat unhinged, who offers, \u201cFolks call me Mad Earl.\u201d Folks don\u2019t just have descriptive nicknames in Hannah\u2019s Alaska; they have a tendency to use bumper-sticker-like slogans in everyday conversation. Within minutes of meeting the Allbrights, Large Marge issues a warning in a series of adages: \u201cTwo kinds of folks come up to Alaska, Cora. People running to something and people running away from something. The second kind \u2014 you want to keep your eye out for them. And it isn\u2019t just the people you need to watch out for, either. Alaska herself can be Sleeping Beauty one minute and a bitch with a sawed-off shotgun the next. There\u2019s a saying: Up here you can make one mistake. The second one will kill you.\u201d\n\nIn the very next chapter, Earl\u2019s daughter repeats Marge\u2019s admonition almost verbatim: \u201cIn Alaska you can make one mistake. One. The second one will kill you.\u201d And this is where I got excited, thinking the town might actually be a \u201cWestworld\u201d-like theme park where the locals are robots, programmed to talk like Alaskans of yore, repeating party lines in place of independent human communication. Sadly, I was wrong; Hannah\u2019s characters are just people who like to pepper-spray you with prepackaged plot points, like bitches with sawed-off shotguns.", "title": "Two Novels, United by Troubled Daughters of Damaged Fathers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "And its closet space was insufficient. \u201cI have so much stuff so we weren\u2019t going to torture ourselves with an apartment that didn\u2019t have enough closets,\u201d Mr. Dinzebach said. \u201cI have, like, 200 pairs of shoes.\u201d\n\nThey also found the building\u2019s size overwhelming. \u201cI didn\u2019t want to live in a building with 700 units with hundreds of people surrounding you,\u201d he said. \u201cThat for me was too much.\u201d\n\nThe couple kept returning to 363 Bond. Some units they saw had an extra half-bathroom or outdoor space. They decided against those. \u201cI just didn\u2019t think it was smart to pay $5,000 for a one-bedroom apartment,\u201d Mr. Dinzebach said.\n\nThey picked a garden-variety one-bedroom renting for around $3,800, with an incentive of six weeks free rent, and moved in last fall.\n\nMs. Townsend, always alert to design flaws, has found a few. In the bathroom, it\u2019s impossible to keep things on the back of the sink, because opening the medicine cabinet knocks them off.\n\nIn the kitchen, the cabinetry stops shy of the ceiling, leaving unused space. A weird indentation in one closet consumes much of the hanging space. Mr. Dinzebach, who collects hats as well as shoes, has to keep many of them at his workplace.\n\nBut there are perks that they both appreciate. The stacked washer-dryer is handy because \u201cwe both work out a lot and both have a lot of laundry,\u201d Ms. Townsend said. And they avail themselves of the free continental breakfast available every morning in the lounge, grabbing coffee on the way to work.", "title": "Two People. Two Dogs. And a One-Bedroom to Please Them All.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Painted quickly in 1634, when Rembrandt was burnishing his reputation as a portraitist to the wealthy in Amsterdam, each portrait depicts one half of a couple, their names unknown. A half-smile plays mildly on the woman\u2019s lips, and her face is ringed with intricate detail, like her frizzy curls, scratched into the paint, and the delicate lace of her collar, molded with calligraphic strokes over thick impasto. The man\u2019s gaze seems softer, with gentle light on one side of his face, which emerges below a wide-rimmed black hat and above the inky black robes of his dress.\n\nThe two paintings, which were given to the museum in 1893, are workhorse Rembrandts, long considered too important to the museum\u2019s narrative of Dutch art and the old masters to remove from the walls. So the Museum of Fine Arts approached the Executive Committee of the European Fine Art Foundation \u2014 or Tefaf \u2014 with a proposal they hoped would put some wind in their sails: If Tefaf could give the museum a grant to help restore the woman\u2019s portrait, the museum would commit to restoring the man\u2019s, as well.\n\n\u201cWe would never do just one,\u201d Ms. Baer said. \u201cThey should always be treated together.\u201d\n\nIn December, Tefaf announced that the museum had won a \u20ac25,000 grant, about $30,000, for the restoration of the painting of the woman (the Museu Nacional de Arte Antiga in Portugal was the other recipient of a similar grant, to restore tiles in a chapel on its premises).\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a very important painting,\u201d said Rachel Kaminsky, a longtime art dealer who is a member of the Tefaf panel that selected the grant recipients. By the end of the restoration, she said, the hope is to \u201chave two fantastic paintings that are on regular view at the museum that look their very best, and that they look as close as possible to what Rembrandt originally painted.\u201d\n\nRecently, the Rembrandt portraits came off the walls, bringing Ms. Baer a measure of relief.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think they look so great in the gallery,\u201d she said, and pointed to the particularly maddening problem on the man: \u201cJust walking by, because he has so much discolored in-painting on the side of his face, it always bothered me tremendously.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTime has been crueler to the man than the woman in part because of a crucial difference in the way their faces were depicted. It was customary at the time to paint women\u2019s faces with a bloom of light, which meant that for light-skinned subjects, a face would be rendered with more lead white paint, which proved sturdy over the centuries. The man\u2019s face, painted in shadow, was composed with umbers and ochers that had a higher oil content than the lead white.\n\n\u201cIt may change more over time naturally, and it\u2019s a little bit more vulnerable to cleaning, in previous centuries, when people didn\u2019t have the same techniques we have,\u201d said Rhona MacBeth, the museum\u2019s head of paintings conservation. \u201cMaybe someone cleaned a little more than they should have done and did some damage to the shadows.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow Ms. MacBeth, who has been assigned to execute the restoration, will get her turn.\n\nTechnical analyses of the paintings reveal the challenges ahead: Ultraviolet light shows multiple layers of uneven varnish, which have grayed and picked up dirt over the years, dulling the images. An infrared image shows secrets belied by the varnish, like buttons painted on the man\u2019s black clothes, or a sharp line in the folds that suggests that he may be wearing a cloak. And there are hints that Rembrandt may have made his own adjustments to the woman\u2019s hair.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe hair originally could have been a different style, or more of it,\u201d Ms. Baer said. \u201cOr we don\u2019t even know.\u201d\n\nThe restoration begins with a light \u201csurface cleaning,\u201d which is the conservator\u2019s equivalent of sweeping a floor before washing it. Ms. MacBeth swabs the surface of the paintings with a traditional cleaning fluid: saliva, which contains an enzyme that helps swipe grime away. She will use her own.\n\n\u201cNo spirits at lunch,\u201d Ms. MacBeth joked.\n\nNext, she develops a special combination of solvents that can be used to dissolve multiple layers of varnish on the paintings, including a natural resin and a synthetic varnish that was added to them during their last major restorations, in 1977. She will carefully remove the varnish and, with the help of a microscope, use a tiny ophthalmic scalpel to lift grime and varnish from the impasto, where the sculpted layers of paint have trapped grime over time.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m sort of cleaning a relief sculpture; that\u2019s what it feels like,\u201d Ms. MacBeth said. \u201cThe tiniest sculpture.\u201d\n\nThe old varnish has almost yellowed the white lace of the woman\u2019s collar and the man\u2019s ruff, dulling the pops of white and the light-reflecting texture Rembrandt used to render its exquisite detail.\n\nAs the varnish comes off, so too will much of the paint from previous restorations \u2014 including, Ms. MacBeth and Ms. Baer hope, the splotches on the man\u2019s face, and another section of retouching on the wall behind the woman.\n\n\u201cEven the background will come alive,\u201d Ms. Baer said.\n\nAny restoration brings risk. Ms. MacBeth must ensure that her solvents do not remove anything they are not supposed to. If she were to clean one painting more than the other, the two would be thrown off balance, so she will work carefully to ensure she does not make any part of either painting cleaner than she can get anything else.\n\nFinally, Ms. MacBeth will revarnish the paintings. And then, working closely with Ms. Baer, she will determine what she needs to retouch. She may put tiny dots of paint on a section of the man\u2019s robes where the paint has grown thin \u2014 but she will do it judiciously, knowing all too well that overzealous retouching can cause problems in the future.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not trying to make these look brand-new,\u201d Ms. MacBeth said. \u201cWe just want them to kind of, put their best foot forward, to look the best they possibly can with the understanding that things happen over time.\u201d", "title": "Two Rembrandts Get a Second Chance in Boston", "authors": ["Jess Bidgood"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "So while both of these artists operate under heavy clouds of suspicion and distaste, they are finding wide and dedicated audiences. However, even in spite of some high-profile acknowledgments \u2014 both Kendrick Lamar and the Weeknd have posted about XXXTentacion on social media, and Young Thug, Offset and A Boogie Wit Da Hoodie appear on \u201cDAY69\u201d \u2014 they haven\u2019t been fully publicly embraced by the music industry. Instead, it is operating in the shadows for both artists: Billboard has reported that XXXTentacion is signed to Caroline, a division of Capitol Music Group, and 6ix9ine is signed to the label of Elliot Grainge, who is the son of Lucian, the chairman and chief executive of Universal Music Group.\n\nImage \u201c?\u201d by XXXTentacion. Credit\n\nThis de facto exile has ended up embedded into their creative process, though, pushing these artists to the fringes, where they are less bound by hip-hop\u2019s conventions, or the needs of the music business. As a result, they have both made albums that break from the dominant sound in notable ways.\n\nXXXTentacion, messianic and immature, recorded \u201c?\u201d while on house arrest awaiting trial. It is a chaotic album, ping-ponging between bawdy, punchy rapping and tender, lonely singing \u2014 a blend that goes back to his days posting loose tracks on SoundCloud. The best songs here are the most vulnerable, like \u201cbefore I close my eyes,\u201d on which he croons, \u201cI hope it\u2019s not too late for me,\u201d embedding his public narrative into his creative identity.\n\nJust as the music operates at polar extremes, so does XXXTentacion\u2019s mood. Sometimes he is deeply petulant, like on the sticky \u201cSad!\u201d; elsewhere, as on \u201cNumb,\u201d he\u2019s self-lacerating. One song, \u201cHope,\u201d is dedicated to the survivors of the Parkland, Fla., school shooting.\n\nBoth he and 6ix9ine engage with rap-rock in a sidelong fashion. XXXTentacion harks back to the late-2000s Warped Tour, when melodic hardcore and screamo began flirting with hip-hop, in terms of cadences and also production textures. 6ix9ine, on the other hand, is often more reminiscent of New York hardcore than New York hip-hop. When he\u2019s at his most rap-adjacent, it\u2019s in the spirit of the early Ruff Ryders era, one of hip-hop\u2019s rowdiest and rawest moments. (He also nods to the fusion of the \u201cJudgment Night\u201d soundtrack and the horrorcore of the mid- to late 1990s \u2014 a one-man Family Values tour in the making.)\n\n6ix9ine is a brute-force screamer, and \u201cDAY69\u201d is a rough gauntlet of gun and sex talk, invigorating and also deadening. As a rapper, 6ix9ine is a boxer \u2014 he thrives on rasp and repetition, as if constantly looking to pick a fistfight. Occasionally he incorporates a touch of wordplay \u2014 \u201cI need all of mine, try to try me and it\u2019s Columbine/Let that Ruger fly, automatic poppin\u2019 at your guys/You gon\u2019 lose a guy, \u2019tato on the barrel, give \u2019em fries\u201d on \u201cCHOCOLAT\u00c9\u201d \u2014 but mostly he\u2019s landing one jab after the next.\n\nFor both artists, songs are short \u2014 around a 2:08 average for XXXTentacion (including interludes) and 2:28 for 6ix9ine \u2014 because their bursts of energy might not last another 90 seconds, and because there is little infrastructure in place to push them toward more conventional structures. (For what it\u2019s worth, most pop songs are only interesting for about two minutes.) Many of XXXTentacion\u2019s songs don\u2019t feel like much more than demos, experiments that under other circumstances might be thickened up for broader appeal.", "title": "Two SoundCloud Rap Outlaws Push Boundaries From the Fringes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 French and British theater-makers may be just a hop across the English Channel from each other, but in some ways, they live in different worlds. France has long leaned toward the kind of director-led, concept-driven stage fare that many in Britain, raised on the importance of text and naturalistic acting, find vexing.\n\nYet a few British directors have made the jump to Paris and gained a following there, most prominent among them Peter Brook and Declan Donnellan. Both debuted new productions in the French capital this month ahead of international tours; both have found ways to bridge the cultural gap, with work that combines storytelling and a strong directorial voice.\n\nMr. Brook returned to a theater he has long been associated with, the Th\u00e9\u00e2tre des Bouffes du Nord, to present \u201cThe Prisoner,\u201d a philosophical tale about punishment and redemption. While the 92-year-old director is beloved in Britain, where he started his career in the 1940s, he has now resided in France for nearly 50 years.\n\nIn 1974, he discovered the Bouffes du Nord, a dilapidated 19th-century music hall in a less-than-upscale area, which had been closed as a safety measure in 1952. Mr. Brook oversaw its renovation with his theater company, the International Centre for Theatre Research. They preserved its threadbare charm, and while Mr. Brook handed over the reins of his artistic home to Olivier Mantei and Olivier Poubelle in 2008, he has continued to show new work there.", "title": "Two Theater Worlds Collide in Paris", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think the way this team has been constructed is a masterpiece,\u201d said Stephanie Reid, a point guard. \u201cWe\u2019re so knowledgeable of each other and this quirkiness that we have. It\u2019s something that we love.\u201d\n\nCentral Michigan\u2019s roster is quite different, with all but one of its 16 players hailing from Michigan. The Chippewas also can score \u2014 their average of 82.7 points ranked seventh in the nation this season \u2014 even though Guevara plays a short bench, with the five starters averaging nearly 32 minutes a game. Tinara Moore, a forward, and Presley Hudson, a guard, power the offense; each averages more than 18 points a game.\n\nGuevara and Legette-Jack acknowledged the obvious: Their teams are underdogs. Again. But they do not see their teams as any less capable of reaching the next round, or even the Final Four.\n\n\u201cWe are not flukes, no way,\u201d Legette-Jack said. \u201cThis is the way the game is evolving: Good teams are everywhere. There is room for everybody at the top. You just have to keep working and trying to get there.\u201d\n\nBoth coaches know how long, and how difficult, the journey can be.\n\nGuevara, 63, is a link to the do-it-all early Title IX years of women\u2019s college athletics. In her first job, she served as the softball coach, assistant basketball coach and cheerleading coach at what is now Saginaw Valley State University in Michigan in 1978. She climbed the coaching ladder as an assistant at Ohio State, Ball State and Michigan State before getting her first head coaching job, at Michigan, in 1996.\n\nIt was there that Guevara met Legette-Jack, an assistant at Michigan State from 2000 to 2002.\n\nBut Guevara, one of the most successful coaches in Michigan women\u2019s basketball history, stepped down after a 3-13 Big Ten season in 2003. An assistant\u2019s job at Auburn led to her second chance as a head coach at Central Michigan. She has rebuilt the Chippewas into a team that won the MAC regular-season title in 2017 and the conference tournament this year.", "title": "Two Underdogs Join the Party, Linked by More Than a Conference", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Karl Lagerfeld turned the Grand Palais into an autumnal leaf-carpeted forest to close out Paris Fashion Week. At other shows too, a sense of wonder pervaded, and T\u2019s photographers captured it all: Comme des Gar\u00e7ons\u2019s joyful celebration of camp, Balenciaga\u2019s snowboarder paradise and Jacquemus\u2019s blissfully glamorous ode to \u201970s Marrakesh. Click through the slide show to see highlights from the week.", "title": "T\u2019s Best Photos from Paris Fashion Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Before I turned 17, my family had moved eight times. In Honolulu, we lived in my maternal grandparents\u2019 house, a wooden plantation-style 1940s bungalow shaded from the late-afternoon sun by a copse of pink and red torch ginger that had grown so tall and dense that its leaves poked through the sea-glass-green jalousies. In New York we lived in an apartment building overlooking the East River, where all the residents with children would leave their front doors open during the day, turning the floors into a honeycombed communal space for us kids to inhabit. In Texas, before we moved into a house, we lived in a one-bedroom apartment, my brother and I sleeping in the living room on soft cotton chairs that unfolded into futon-like mattresses.\n\nBecause we were so transitory, I grew up associating the idea of home less with a physical structure than with the objects that inhabited it: A place became ours, mine, only when the 19th-century pine chest was positioned in the living room, when the early American quilt with its worn calico squares was hung on the wall, when our books had been unpacked and placed on the shelves.\n\nThat was one ritual. The other was the leave-taking. And with each place we departed, we left something behind, some evidence that, yes, we had been there, and that for a short time, we had possessed that space. In Baltimore, we left dozens of parrot tulips that had been my father\u2019s pride; in Texas, a vegetable garden of wildly curling squash vines where once there had been only silt; in Irvine, Calif. \u2014 still, in the mid-\u201980s, rising from an empty stretch of clay \u2014 my brother\u2019s and my heights, notched into a white-painted door frame.\n\nThe instinct to mark the place one has occupied in the world is not particular to humans \u2014 animals create middens or nests made of saliva or dung or bits of straw \u2014 but it is, like the very act of collecting objects, one of the impulses from which culture is born and defined. None of us can resist announcing our presence, no matter how temporal or humble our dwelling might be; we write ourselves into walls as a way of protesting the relentlessness, the uncaringness, of time.\n\nSometimes, as in the case of Alfred Liechtenstein and his wife, Alice, that transcription becomes its own sort of decoration. The Austrian castle they live in with their children is both a puzzle and a palimpsest: The first of its 52 rooms were built in the 12th century; Alfred\u2019s family has inhabited it since the 19th. Throughout, proof of ghosts from the past can be seen \u2014 ancestors who have painted their portraits on its ceilings, who have etched their names into its surfaces. Now, the couple is leaving their own mark: a trippy Op Art-inspired elevator; a collection of furniture from contemporary designers. The castle is on loan to them from the generations that will succeed them, but for the moment, it\u2019s theirs.\n\nThen there\u2019s the Polish-French artist Marc Camille Chaimowicz, whose uncategorizable art \u2014 holistically conceived room-size works that smudge the line between decoration and installation \u2014 is inseparable from his own London apartments, one of which he is vacating after nearly 40 years. To see it now, unchanged and preserved since the 1970s, with its palette of eau de nil and peach, its glossy painted chairs and hand-drawn murals, is to wonder whether you are seeing one man\u2019s home ... or an artistic projection of an idea of home. But it is also a reminder of our eternal, collective search for someplace we can call our own, for the place we imagine when we shut our eyes \u2014 a yearning that takes on special meaning in our current age of refugees, who endure one of the great cruelties of the human experience: being forced to forsake their land for another. Chaimowicz\u2019s father, too, was a refugee, from a different era; it\u2019s perhaps not surprising that his very art is the recreation, again and again, of home. We say, with our spaces: We were here. Will you remember us? Memory is brief. But a house endures.", "title": "T\u2019s Design Issue: This Is Us", "authors": ["Hanya Yanagihara", "Letter The Editor"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "A sizable portion of your autobiography, \u201cRaw: My Journey Into the Wu-Tang,\u201d is about dealing drugs on Staten Island. I don\u2019t want to glorify that. Now I understand what happened and why. And I\u2019m kind of pissed off. I watched \u201cAmerican Made\u201d with Tom Cruise. A lot of my friends have not come home. Some people got 150 years.\n\nDo you mean in terms of how drugs were reportedly brought in to the U.S. from Central America by the C.I.A.? Yes. Like it was all a setup. But at the same time, it was a gold mine. It was a means of feeding my family.\n\nYou were arrested in the early \u201990s on a drug charge and spent some time behind bars. How hard was it for you to adapt when you got out? They put you in a halfway house, and then you go out in the streets again. Meanwhile, technology done sped up, your girl done left you, your mother-in-law died, your father might have died, you might not have no family left and you\u2019ve got to find your way. And the only thing that you knew before you went to jail is probably the crime that you committed, so you wind up doing the same [expletive].\n\nWhat was it like to be paroled right around the same time \u201cEnter the Wu-Tang (36 Chambers)\u201d was released in 1993? That promotion had us going up and down the East Coast in a van \u2014 nine people in a van. You had your bag, you probably had two sets of clothes \u2014 go to the shower with one, take the other one off, then let the other one dry, put the clean one on. Then we\u2019re off to the next race.", "title": "U-God Wishes He Had Sold Legal Drugs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Squeeze the Oligarchs\n\nThe British government has historically asked few questions about where wealthy foreigners\u2019 money comes from, helping make London a favorite place for people from other countries to invest.\n\nRussian \u00e9migr\u00e9s and investors in Britain include many of Mr. Putin\u2019s enemies, but also some of his closest allies. Transparency International, an anti-corruption group, says it has identified more than $6 billion in British real estate bought with possibly ill-gotten wealth, more than one-fifth of it owned by Russians.\n\nBut a law enacted last year allows British law enforcement to investigate where the money for big purchases came from, and to go to court to seize assets. Experts say that aggressive use of the new law could be the most effective way to inflict pain on Mr. Putin\u2019s inner circle.\n\nThe risk posed by such unilateral action is not just that Russia could respond, but that its retaliation would be aimed solely at Britain.\n\nShine Light Into Dark Corners\n\nBritish law makes it fairly simple to hide the ownership of assets through opaque shell corporations; the multimillion-dollar homes of wealthy expatriates are often bought by such companies.\n\nWatchdog groups say that it is too easy for people to create corporations for laundering illicit wealth, and that the government agency that tracks companies has neither the authority nor the resources to look deeply into what they do. They say that the registry of official companies is riddled with holes and inaccuracies.\n\n\u201cThe openness and attractiveness of London is particular to London,\u201d said James Nixey, head of the Russia and Eurasia program at Chatham House, a London think tank. \u201cThat is something the U.K. can change on its own.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKori N. Schake, deputy director of the International Institute of Strategic Studies, advocated taking transparency further.\n\n\u201cWe should publish Putin\u2019s bank details, what we know of his property and that of his kids,\u201d she said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nExpel the Spies \u2014 and Maybe Some Others\n\nRussia has, by some accounts, more spies in Britain than at the height of the Cold War, many of them operating under diplomatic cover. Lawmakers of all political stripes have called for the government to deport many of those people, though Russia would almost certainly respond by throwing out British diplomats and intelligence agents.\n\nIn addition to expelling suspected spies, Britain could re-examine some of the other Russians it has allowed to live in the country.\n\nLike many countries, Britain allows wealthy people to bypass the usual laborious process for getting a long-term residence visa. The deal is simple: Invest millions of dollars, and get a visa.\n\n\u201cThe whole idea that money gives you access to state protection is quite ridiculous, quite wrong,\u201d said Kadri Liik, a senior policy fellow at the European Council on Foreign Relations, based in London.\n\nCritics said for years that the program was too lax and required little in the way of background checks. In 2015, the government tightened the rules, and the number of people receiving investor visas dropped sharply.\n\nIn the past week, analysts have said that Britain could restrict the program more, revisit visas granted under the old rules, and revoke the residency of people with shady histories.\n\nCall on the International Community\n\nBritain can call on NATO, the European Union, the United Nations and the United States to help it take action against Russia, but each approach has drawbacks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince 2014, the European Union and the United States have imposed sanctions on Russia over its aggression in Ukraine, which have hurt the Russian economy, but have shown no signs of altering Russian conduct. And European countries, heavily dependent on Russian oil and gas exports, have not been eager to strain relations with Moscow further.\n\nNeither the allegations of Russian war crimes in Syria, nor Russia\u2019s meddling in other nations\u2019 elections, nor the downing of an airliner by pro-Russian forces in Ukraine, killing 298 people, prompted new sanctions from the European Union. Any such action in the Skripal case would require solidarity from the European Union at a time when Britain is leaving the bloc and relations with Brussels are uncertain.\n\nWhile European officials were quick to condemn the use of a nerve agent, and an attempted murder on British soil, President Trump, whose administration is enmeshed in investigations into Russian election manipulation, has made no public statement about it.\n\nSome diplomats and security analysts have said that Britain should invoke NATO\u2019s Article 4, which says that member nations \u201cwill consult together whenever, in the opinion of any of them, the territorial integrity, political independence or security of any of the parties is threatened.\u201d That consultation could be powerful symbolically but might not yield any substantive result.\n\nThe provision is usually interpreted as applying to actions on a far larger scale than attempted murder, said Adam Thomson, a former British ambassador to NATO and head of the European Leadership Network.", "title": "U.K. Has Weapons to Use Against Russia, All With Drawbacks", "authors": ["Richard P\u00e9rez-Pe\u00f1a"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 While Prime Minister Theresa May has united her warring Conservative Party by denouncing Russia over the poisoning of a former spy, things have not gone so smoothly for the opposition Labour Party. Among Labour lawmakers, familiar wounds have reopened over the more ambivalent stance of its left-wing leader, Jeremy Corbyn.\n\nTwice in Parliament this week, Mr. Corbyn, whose political views were forged in his leftist activism in the 1980s, has eschewed the supportive, cheerleading role that opposition leaders traditionally play to the prime minister when Britain is in conflict with a foreign power. At times, in his reluctance to criticize Moscow, he sounded like his ideological opposite, President Trump.\n\nWhile he condemned the attack in Salisbury, England, as an \u201cappalling act of violence,\u201d Mr. Corbyn has claimed that the Conservatives took donations from wealthy Russians, and he has highlighted cuts to the British Foreign Office and called for the Russian authorities to be \u201cheld to account on the basis of the evidence.\u201d\n\nOn Thursday, in an article in The Guardian, Mr. Corbyn added that criticism of Russia should not mean acceptance of \u201ca \u2018new cold war\u2019 of escalating arms spending, proxy conflicts across the globe and a McCarthyite intolerance of dissent.\u201d", "title": "U.K. Labour Leader\u2019s Stance on Russian Ex-Spy\u2019s Poisoning Splits Party", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 Britain should seek to postpone its exit from the European Union if talks drag on during the next few months, an influential committee of lawmakers concluded on Sunday.\n\nThe panel\u2019s recommendation split its members, some of whom disowned the document, and illustrated the growing concerns in Parliament over the pace of the negotiations.\n\nThe report came ahead of a summit meeting this week at which European Union leaders are expected to agree, in principle, on a standstill transition period of slightly less than two years to prevent Britain\u2019s economy from suffering the effects of a \u201ccliff edge\u201d departure from the bloc next March, when it is formally scheduled to quit.\n\nBut even that transition would be conditional on the success of broader discussions on the withdrawal, known as Brexit. The talks are due to end in the fall, but that deadline looks very difficult to meet, particularly because of the complexity of avoiding the introduction of a hard border in Ireland.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe House of Commons Select Committee on Exiting the European Union concluded that if \u201csubstantial aspects\u201d of the overall agreement were still left to be finalized in October, the British government should seek \u201ca limited extension\u201d of the time set out under Article 50. That is a section of the treaty invoked last year by Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain setting a two-year deadline for withdrawal from the bloc.", "title": "U.K. Lawmakers Say Britain Should Consider Delaying Brexit", "authors": ["Stephen Castle"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 British and European Union negotiators on Monday agreed on the terms of a 21-month transition period to keep Britain inside Europe\u2019s economic structures and to avoid an economically damaging \u201ccliff edge\u201d when the country formally departs the bloc next March.\n\nThe transition accord was announced on Monday at a news conference in Brussels by David Davis, Britain\u2019s main negotiator, and his European Union counterpart, Michel Barnier, who described it as a \u201cdecisive step\u201d toward an orderly withdrawal, or Brexit.\n\nThe deal, however, depends on a broader agreement on Britain\u2019s withdrawal, which is to be finalized this year but is by no means certain. One of the main sticking points in those talks has been the border between Northern Ireland, which is part of the United Kingdom, and Ireland, which will remain in the European Union.\n\nTo achieve the transition accord, the British government retreated from an earlier pledge and conceded that European Union citizens who arrived in Britain during the transition period would have the same rights as those already in the country. (Earlier this year, Prime Minister Theresa May insisted that the rights of those newcomers would be \u201cdifferent.\u201d)", "title": "U.K. Reaches Brexit Transition Deal With E.U.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "CALAIS, France \u2014 Serge Orlov, a 62-year-old Briton, likes to rail against what he calls the tyranny of the European Union. Like most supporters of his country\u2019s withdrawal from the bloc, he wants Britain to strike out on its own, a fully sovereign state unshackled from Europe\u2019s pettifogging rules and the Continent\u2019s overweening state.\n\nBut faced with excruciating pain and a seemingly endless wait for a knee replacement, Mr. Orlov temporarily shelved his euroskepticism to take advantage of a little known National Health Service program and jump to the head of the line \u2014 in France.\n\nAfter waiting a year just for the possibility of the knee replacement he badly needed, he turned to Calais Hospital in northern France, where in a matter of 10 days he found himself on the operating table for the three-hour procedure, he said in an interview. He plans to get his second knee replaced in a few weeks\u2019 time. Back home, it took him a year to receive a letter informing him when he might have the operation.\n\n\u201cWaiting, it\u2019s just miserable,\u201d he said, describing how he had been shuttled to five different hospitals in Britain over more than eight months.
