View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe rebuke from the governor is a reversal from what has been an open-arms policy by the state, heralding its lack of regulation as an asset to lure autonomous vehicle testing \u2014 and tech jobs. Waymo, the self-driving car company spun out from Google, and General Motors-owned Cruise are also testing cars in the state.", "title": "Uber Ordered to Take Its Self-Driving Cars Off Arizona Roads", "authors": ["Daisuke Wakabayashi"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Arizona\u2019s governor, Doug Ducey, ordered the company to suspend the testing of its autonomous vehicles on Monday, eight days after the crash, saying footage of the accident \u201craises many questions about the ability of Uber to continue testing in Arizona.\u201d\n\nUber said it withdrew its California application on Friday because it wouldn\u2019t have been able to respond to questions from the state\u2019s regulators until it had time to review the findings of the investigation in Arizona.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe proactively suspended our self-driving operations, including in California, immediately following the Tempe incident,\u201d said Sarah Abboud, an Uber spokeswoman. \u201cGiven this, we decided to not reapply for a California D.M.V. permit, with the understanding that our self-driving vehicles would not operate on public roads in the immediate future.\u201d\n\nUber initially applied to renew its permit a few days after the crash. When the D.M.V. opened the mailed application on Friday, it called the company to confirm, a department spokeswoman said, and Uber asked to withdraw the request. The D.M.V. asked for the withdrawal in writing, and it received an email on Saturday.\n\nUber has said it is cooperating with investigations by the Tempe police, the National Transportation Safety Board and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. None of the investigations have determined whether Uber was at fault in the crash.\n\nThe intense focus on the accident has also prompted Uber\u2019s suppliers to evaluate its technology. On Tuesday, a spokesman for Nvidia, a supplier of semiconductors and other computer hardware used in Uber\u2019s autonomous vehicles, said it was suspending its tests of self-driving cars on public roads in order to \u201clearn from the Uber incident.\u201d The price of Nvidia shares fell 8 percent on the news.\n\nUber has not said when it plans to resume testing its autonomous vehicles. The bulk of Uber\u2019s testing was in Arizona, but it was also driving autonomous vehicles on roads in San Francisco, Pittsburgh and Toronto. Alexis Campbell, a community relations manager for Pennsylvania\u2019s Department of Transportation, said it would work with Uber to ensure that safety was the top priority if tested was restarted in the state.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUber has had a rocky history with the California D.M.V. In 2016, Uber started testing its self-driving cars in San Francisco without a permit, arguing that one wasn\u2019t necessary because a safety driver was monitoring the vehicles.\n\nThe D.M.V. disagreed and ordered Uber to apply for a permit. When Uber refused, the department revoked the registrations for the 16 cars that Uber was testing in the city.\n\nAfter California revoked the registrations, Mr. Ducey said Arizona welcomed Uber\u2019s cars with \u201copen arms and wide open roads.\u201d In a public showing, Uber loaded its cars onto a truck and hauled them to Arizona. Uber eventually applied for a permit and resumed testing in San Francisco last March.", "title": "Uber Won\u2019t Renew Permit for Self-Driving Cars in California", "authors": ["Daisuke Wakabayashi"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Uber\u2019s exit from Southeast Asia, a region of more than 600 million people, also reflects the new direction the company is taking under Mr. Khosrowshahi, who replaced Travis Kalanick as chief executive last year.\n\nMr. Khosrowshahi has forsworn his predecessor\u2019s infamously pugnacious way of doing business. And with a mandate to take Uber public, he has set out to repair relations with regulators, fix a troubled workplace culture and calm Wall Street about the company\u2019s financial prospects. Uber said it lost $1.1 billion in the last three months of 2017, somewhat less than it lost in the preceding quarter.\n\n\u201cIt is fair to ask whether consolidation is now the strategy of the day,\u201d Mr. Khosrowshahi wrote in an email to staff. \u201cThe answer is no.\u201d\n\nHe continued: \u201cOne of the potential dangers of our global strategy is that we take on too many battles across too many fronts and with too many competitors. This transaction now puts us in a position to compete with real focus and weight in the core markets where we operate.\u201d\n\nGrab was introduced in 2012 and now operates in eight Southeast Asian countries: Cambodia, Indonesia, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam. And it has put up a tough fight.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWith passengers in nearly 200 cities across the region, the company is aiming to be more than just a transportation provider. It wants its digital wallet, GrabPay, to replace cash as a way to pay for things at offline shops and restaurants. And in a region where many people lack credit histories or even bank accounts, Grab is undertaking a venture to make loans to consumers and small businesses. Data collected through Grab\u2019s app, on users\u2019 movements and transactions, is used to assess their creditworthiness.\n\nGrab also offers a wide variety of ways for people to get around. In Singapore, you can hop on a GrabShuttle that, like a public bus, will take you between points along a fixed route. In jam-packed Jakarta, you can use Grab\u2019s app to hail a nearby motorbike taxi right off the street, forgoing the usual process of prebooking and waiting for the driver to arrive at your location.\n\nThe company is generally regarded as the market leader in Southeast Asia. But in Indonesia, the region\u2019s most populous country, it is taking on Go-Jek, a local rival whose apps offer services, such as massages on demand and motorbike parcel deliveries, that go beyond just rides. Go-Jek\u2019s investors include Google and Tencent, the Chinese internet conglomerate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn an interview, Ming Maa, Grab\u2019s president, said that the deal with Uber would help Grab move closer to profitability, although he declined to give specifics. One key benefit of combining with Uber, Mr. Maa said, is that it immediately expands Grab\u2019s food-delivery operations.\n\n\u201cThat has massive, massive benefits to our consumer base,\u201d he said, \u201cbut is also a key driver for our mobile payments business.\u201d\n\nFor Uber, ceding Southeast Asia still leaves it with plenty of challengers elsewhere in the world. Didi Chuxing, based in Beijing, invested alongside SoftBank in Grab last year. It recently raised money from SoftBank and other investors at a valuation of $56 billion \u2014 higher than the $48 billion at which Uber was valued as part of last year\u2019s stake sale to SoftBank.\n\nNow, Didi wants to go global. The company, whose full name is pronounced \u201cdee-dee choo-SHING,\u201d recently took control of 99, an Uber rival in Brazil, and is recruiting on LinkedIn ahead of a planned opening in Mexico.\n\nDidi is also aiming to expand soon into Japan \u2014 a market in which Uber, too, will make a big push this year, according to Mr. Khosrowshahi. SoftBank, despite being an investor in both Uber and Didi, announced recently that it would partner with Didi in Japan.", "title": "Uber to Sell Its Southeast Asia Business to Grab, a Regional Rival", "authors": ["Raymond Zhong"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "India is home to a raft of start-ups in e-commerce, mobile apps and other consumer internet businesses. But few of them have ventured beyond their home market successfully. Zomato, a restaurant review site similar to Yelp of the United States, expanded aggressively overseas a few years ago, only to scale back and focus more on India and a few countries like the United Arab Emirates. Paytm, India\u2019s leading digital-payments company, has targeted its services to Indian immigrants in Canada, primarily as an experiment geared toward learning how to operate in developed countries.\n\nFor Ola, Australia could be a compelling international opportunity.\n\nFor starters, the country offers room to grow. Fewer than one in five Australians who regularly buy things online used a ride-hailing service in the past year, according to June survey data analyzed by eMarketer, an American research firm. And the typical fares are much higher than in India, meaning Ola could potentially make more money per ride.\n\n\u201cIn the ride-sharing market currently, there are no real enemies,\u201d said Satish Meena, a senior forecast analyst with Forrester, a technology research firm. \u201cEveryone is willing to share the pie.\u201d\n\nAustralian laws also make it generally easy to set up a ride-share business. Taxify, an Estonian company, arrived in December.\n\n\u201cWe welcome competition because it keeps us focused on delivering the very best product,\u201d said David Rohrsheim, Uber\u2019s general manager for Australia and New Zealand.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Australia Letter Newsletter Damien Cave, our new Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nExperts say that Uber has another incentive: Australia has tough labor laws that could require the company to treat drivers as employees deserving of retirement and other benefits. If its drivers also drive for other services, Uber could more easily argue that they are free agents instead.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOla is mostly trying to win drivers over with a better deal.\n\nThe company takes only 7.5 percent of drivers\u2019 fares, with plans to increase that figure to 15 percent. Uber collects 20 to 25 percent. Drivers said that with Ola they could make 50 Australian dollars, or $39, an hour compared with only $30 Australian an hour with Uber.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a dramatic difference,\u201d said Cheri Gristwood, an Uber driver in Perth, who was an early adopter of Ola. \u201cI work my butt off, and with Ola I come home with a lot more.\u201d\n\nMr. Rohrsheim said that Uber had added incentives of its own last year, including paid wait time and a \u201cno thanks\u201d button that lets drivers refuse up to three rides in a row.\n\n\u201cUber isn\u2019t Uber without driver partners,\u201d he said, \u201cand our success depends on their success.\u201d\n\nOla\u2019s discounted commission has helped the company sign up 7,000 drivers so far. That is nowhere near the roughly 82,000 who drive for Uber, but more than double what Taxify started with in Sydney in December. Taxify did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nPhoto\n\nMany of the new Ola drivers help spread the word about the company. Cecilia Cornu, an Ola customer in Perth, first heard about the service when she asked an Uber driver about the two cellphones he had. One, he said, was for Ola.\n\n\u201cHe told me my ride would have been cheaper if I had booked it through Ola, as they were running a promotion with free rides,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cAs soon as I got to work,\u201d she added, \u201cI downloaded the Ola app.\u201d\n\nOla has not explicitly marketed itself to drivers or riders of Indian origin, but the company does expect that the awareness of its brand among Indians will help. About 1.9 percent of Australia\u2019s population of 24 million was born in India, according to 2016 census data; many more are the children of Indian immigrants.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Ola app still signals that connection: India sometimes shows up as the default country when someone in Australia signs up and adds his mobile phone number.\n\nOla\u2019s effort to shift from local to global remains imperfect. Some customers have reported problems with the app continuing to calculate rides after trips have ended. Mr. Ward, one of the Ola drivers in Sydney, said the company\u2019s registration process was less streamlined than Uber\u2019s.\n\nOla\u2019s expansion into Australia may also have a strategic goal beyond higher fares: protection against an unwanted takeover.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Japanese conglomerate SoftBank is Ola\u2019s largest outside shareholder, and one of the largest shareholders in Uber. It has also invested in other ride-hailing companies around the world.\n\nSoftBank executives have made it clear that they would like to see Uber\u2019s operations in some developing countries merge with local players to avoid a competitive blood bath, allowing the company to focus more intensively on higher-profit, developed markets.\n\nOla recently changed its articles of incorporation to defend against any large investor from forcing a sale of the company. Bhavish Aggarwal, a founder of Ola and its chief executive, is busy trying to raise money from other investors to reduce SoftBank\u2019s influence over his company\u2019s destiny.\n\nMr. Aggarwal declined several interview requests. \u201cWe are very excited about launching Ola in Australia and see immense potential for the ride-sharing ecosystem in a country which embraces new technology and innovation,\u201d he said in a statement.\n\nAt times, Uber has been a seller. It has left the ride-hailing business in China and Russia, selling its operations in those countries in exchange for stakes in the dominant local competitors.\n\nMr. Meena predicted that Ola and Uber would eventually reach a similar arrangement in India, with the Australian operations of each company possibly added to the mix. Developing a robust Australian business could give Ola a bargaining chip in negotiations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEveryone is looking at capturing market share,\u201d he said, \u201cand then doing a deal with Uber.\u201d", "title": "Uber\u2019s New Rival in Australia: An Indian Upstart", "authors": ["Damien Cave", "Vindu Goel"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Tech companies like Uber, Waymo and Lyft, as well as automakers like General Motors and Toyota, have spent billions developing self-driving cars in the belief that the market for them could one day be worth trillions of dollars.\n\nThe crash, which occurred Sunday night, was a major setback for Uber, which has been trying to improve its image since Mr. Khosrowshahi replaced Travis Kalanick as the company\u2019s chief executive in a messy transfer of power last August. In February, Uber also settled a longstanding legal fight with Waymo.\n\nOn Monday, Uber halted autonomous car tests in Arizona, Pittsburgh, San Francisco and Toronto. It is not clear when the company will revive them.\n\nThe Tempe Police Department said it was investigating the crash, and has not determined whether the car was at fault. A Volvo XC90 sport utility vehicle equipped with Uber\u2019s sensing technology struck Elaine Herzberg, 49, while it was going 40 miles an hour in a 45-mile-an-hour zone. According to the police, the car, with one safety driver and operating in autonomous mode, did not slow down before impact.\n\nA video shot from the vehicle\u2019s dashboard camera showed the safety driver looking down, away from the road. It also appeared that the driver\u2019s hands were not hovering above the steering wheel, which is what drivers are instructed to do so they can quickly retake control of the car. Ms. Herzberg, pushing a bicycle across the street, appeared in the camera right before she was hit.\n\n\u201cAs we develop self-driving technology, safety is our primary concern every step of the way,\u201d said Matt Kallman, an Uber spokesman. \u201cWe\u2019re heartbroken by what happened this week, and our cars remain grounded. We continue to assist investigators in any way we can.\u201d\n\nUber has been testing its self-driving cars in a regulatory vacuum in Arizona. There are few federal rules governing the testing of autonomous cars. Unlike California, where Uber had been testing since spring of 2017, Arizona state officials had taken a hands-off approach to autonomous vehicles and did not require companies to disclose how their cars were performing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWaymo and Cruise, a self-driving car company owned by GM, reported their \u201cintervention\u201d numbers to California regulators. Uber\u2019s goals in Arizona were mentioned in internal documents \u2014 Arizona does not have reporting requirements \u2014 and it has not been testing self-driving cars in California long enough to be required to report them.\n\nUber\u2019s first road tests in its self-driving car effort, code-named Project Roadrunner, were actually in Pittsburgh in September 2016. The Phoenix area was added a year ago, and quickly became the company\u2019s main testing ground, with 400 employees and more than 150 autonomous cars driving local roads because of \"favorable regulatory environment, favorable weather conditions,\u201d according to a company document.\n\nWhen Mr. Khosrowshahi took over as Uber\u2019s chief executive, he had considered shutting down the self-driving car operations, according to two other people familiar with Mr. Khosrowshahi\u2019s thinking.\n\nBut he became convinced that it was important to Uber\u2019s long-term prospects. His visit to Phoenix was seen by the Arizona team as a critical opportunity to demonstrate their progress, according to the people familiar with the company\u2019s operations in the Phoenix area. They wanted to take him on a ride without human interventions to demonstrate that the cars could handle so-called edge cases, tricky road situations that are hard to predict.\n\n\u201cWith autonomy, the edge cases kill you, so you\u2019ve got to build out for all the edge cases,\u201d Mr. Khosrowshahi said at a conference in November. \u201cWhich makes it a very, very difficult problem.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBy September 2017, Uber\u2019s autonomous cars had driven one million miles in a year nationwide. Uber tallied its second million in 100 days and added its next million at an even faster clip, according to company documents.\n\nEarly on in Phoenix, there were two groups of test drivers. A smaller group \u201cstressed\u201d the cars by putting them in challenging situations where, without human intervention, they would have crashed.\n\nA larger group of drivers was focused on picking up customers in the autonomous vehicles. Those drivers were expected to pay more attention to little details, often taking control to prevent a \u201cbad experience\u201d like hard braking, according to a company document.\n\nAround October, Uber merged the two groups to get to a point where it could offer a truly driverless car service to customers \u201cas quickly as possible.\u201d The customer pickup service was mostly dropped so drivers could focus on accumulating miles and gathering data to help the system become more reliable.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAround the same time, Uber moved from two employees in every car to one. The paired employees had been splitting duties \u2014 one ready to take over if the autonomous system failed, and another to keep an eye on what the computers were detecting. The second person was responsible for keeping track of system performance as well as labeling data on a laptop computer. Mr. Kallman, the Uber spokesman, said the second person was in the car for purely data related tasks, not safety.\n\nWaymo had also moved from two operators at all times to one in some situations in late 2015, said Johnny Luu, a Waymo spokesman. Waymo still uses two test drivers when it is adding new systems or moving to a new location.\n\nBut Uber\u2019s autonomous cars are not operating nearly as well as those of its competitors. Cruise reported to California regulators that it went more than 1,200 miles per intervention. After its strong California results, Waymo is now testing cars in Chandler, Ariz., a Phoenix suburb, with no safety drivers.\n\nMr. Kallman said miles per intervention was not a measure of safety but a rate of system improvement that could differ depending on where and how the cars were driven.\n\nWhen Uber moved to a single operator, some employees expressed safety concerns to managers, according to the two people familiar with Uber\u2019s operations. They were worried that going solo would make it harder to remain alert during hours of monotonous driving. Mr. Kallman said it delayed the start of its single-driver initiative to allow for more training and to make sure drivers felt comfortable for the new role.\n\nUber also developed an app, mounted on an iPad in the car\u2019s middle console, for drivers to alert engineers to problems. Drivers could use the app anytime without shifting the car out of autonomous mode. Often, drivers would annotate data at a traffic light or a stop, but many did so while the car was moving, said the two people familiar with Uber\u2019s operations. Mr. Kallman said it designed the app to meet government safety guidelines for in-car software to minimize distractions.\n\nWaymo had a different solution when it moved to a single safety driver. It added a button on the steering wheel for drivers to create an audio explanation when they took the car out of autonomous mode.\n\nNot all drivers followed Uber\u2019s training. One was fired after falling asleep at the wheel and being spotted by a colleague. Another was spotted air drumming as the autonomous car passed through an intersection, according to the two people familiar with Uber\u2019s operations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUber was planning to seek regulatory approval by December to start a self-driving car service in Arizona, according to company documents. Uber said the vehicles would have to be safer than human drivers before they would commercialize it. They would not operate around the clock and would stop for bad weather or traffic. And the service did not need to prove \u201clonger-term financial viability.\u201d\n\nAlready, one milestone will be missed. Mr. Khosrowshahi will not travel to Phoenix next month, because of scheduling problems that came up before the crash, Mr. Kallman said. But it is unclear how the crash will ultimately affect Uber\u2019s plans for autonomous vehicles.\n\n\u201cThe collection of bad news around Uber creates a reputation in people\u2019s minds,\u201d said Michael Ramsey, an automotive analyst at Gartner. \u201cEvery other company would get a black eye, too, but they might be forgiven. For Uber, it\u2019s going to be hard to shake.\u201d", "title": "Uber\u2019s Self-Driving Cars Were Struggling Before Arizona Crash", "authors": ["Daisuke Wakabayashi"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Uber launched Uber Freight, an app that matches truckers and trucking companies with loads to haul, in May 2017. In a business model that is similar to its ride-hailing service, Uber doesn\u2019t actually handle the deliveries but works behind the scenes to create a marketplace for truckers and shippers.\n\nThe company said it was working out of two primary transfer hubs in Arizona \u2014 one in Sanders near the border with New Mexico and another in Topock near the California border.\n\nUber isn\u2019t saying much about its self-driving trucks. It won\u2019t disclose how many trucks it is using, how many miles they\u2019ve driven or how often the human safety drivers had to intervene and assist the autonomous system. It is also not revealing many details about how the transfer hubs would work \u2014 including what they would look like, where they would be located and how the company planned to roll them out.\n\nWhen it comes to the politically sensitive question of whether Uber\u2019s technology will eventually eliminate trucking jobs, the company walks a fine line. For now, Uber said it believed the introduction of self-driving trucks would bring about more driving jobs, not fewer, in part because of greater demand as delivery costs fall. However, the nature of a trucker\u2019s job may change \u2014 becoming something akin to a parcel delivery driver, shuttling trailers between the hub and local destinations.\n\nWhile autonomous systems may one day be able to do everything a human truck driver does, Uber said it was not training its trucks to do it all, like back up to a loading dock or navigate around a busy industrial area.\n\n\u201cThat is beyond the window of what we\u2019re looking at,\u201d Mr. Woodrow said. Uber is choosing to \u201cfocus the development of our technology on the highway only.\u201d", "title": "Uber\u2019s Self-Driving Trucks Hit the Highway, but Not Local Roads", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The couple was married at Mar-a-Lago in November 2005. During the ceremony, guests including Bo Dietl, the police detective turned TV commentator, and Sophie Dahl, the model and author, were seated around a swimming pool.\n\nChristine Schott, who at the time worked as a model manager and publicist for Ms. Trump, was there, and staying at Mar-a-Lago. She spent at least some of the night helping the press keep straight which blond matron was the bride\u2019s mother and which was the groom\u2019s. \u201cThe paparazzi kept having to ask me who was who because Ivana looked so much like Vanessa\u2019s mother,\u201d she said. \u201cThey both were tall with big blond buns.\u201d\n\nMs. Schott recalled seeing the elder Mr. Trump and introducing herself as the bride\u2019s publicist. \u201cThe president said, \u2018Vanessa has a publicist?\u2019\u201d Ms. Schott said. \u201cHe was annoyed.\u201d\n\nMs. Schott, who is now starting a business to help the careers of beauty influencers, also recalled that it was a happy occasion for the new Ms. Trump. \u201cVanessa was very loving, she was very much in love with Donnie, she was excited to become a Trump,\u201d Ms. Schott said. \u201cShe told me at the wedding that she wanted five children. She was very specific about that. Not three, not four, but five.\u201d\n\nAbout a year and a half into the marriage, Ms. Trump gave birth to the couple\u2019s first child, a daughter named Kai. Four more children followed over the next seven years.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSince her marriage, Ms. Trump, who once actively sought the spotlight, has become less of a public figure. She is described as an involved, doting mother and is often seen at school for drop-offs and pickups.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the same time, her husband, who was something of a black sheep, became his father\u2019s most ardent supporter, including appearing on \u201cThe Apprentice,\u201d his father\u2019s television show. Because of his appearances on TV, Mr. Dietl said, women were \u201cthrowing themselves\u201d at the younger Mr. Trump. When his father ran for president, Mr. Trump emerged as a strident voice on social media and the campaign trail.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s never around,\u201d Mr. Dietl said. \u201cI definitely had that sense.\u201d\n\nThe pressure of being part of the first family has taken a toll on Ms. Trump, people who know her say. In February, she was understandably rattled when she opened a letter addressed to her husband that had been sent to her mother\u2019s rental apartment. White powder spilled out. Both Ms. Trump and her mother were taken to a hospital; the powder was later revealed to be cornstarch.\n\nMs. Schott said that early on, Ms. Trump was concerned about her husband\u2019s big-game hunting. \u201cI know she wasn\u2019t thrilled that he hunted as he did,\u201d Ms. Schott said. \u201cI know she wanted to keep it on the DL. She knew that was going to be a big issue, socially.\u201d\n\nMs. Trump appears to have been raised in a more liberal family than that of her estranged husband. Less than a month after President Trump was inaugurated, Ms. Haydon, Ms. Trump\u2019s mother, posted a story on Facebook headlined, \u201cI\u2019m an American living in Sweden. Here\u2019s why I came to embrace the higher taxes.\u201d Ms. Haydon\u2019s public Facebook is usually confined to family pictures and the occasional viral video, although in 2015 she reposted a meme from an account called Occupy Democrats that mocked American appetites for assault rifles \u2014 and another meme, from Daily Kos, that showed Republican politicians, including Speaker of the House Paul D. Ryan, with the text \u201cPeople without vaginas shouldn\u2019t be able to regulate them.\u201d\n\nEven so, Ms. Trump wasn\u2019t averse to appearing by the family\u2019s side, both in the flesh and on social media, throughout the campaign\u2019s various milestones.\n\nAs for Ms. Trump\u2019s future, Ms. Schott has high hopes. \u201cI think she could still have a nice career,\u201d she said. \u201cShe could be a mommy blogger and she could take on a cause. She is in a position to do something great.\u201d", "title": "Unbecoming a Trump: The Vanessa Trump Divorce", "authors": ["Katherine Rosman", "Jacob Bernstein"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "That means new kinds of detective work are needed for brands that still want the endorsements of the young and hip online. Dovetale said it uses more than 50 metrics to analyze the Instagram followers of popular accounts, including the language in the bios, the rate at which they hit \u201clike\u201d and \u201cfollow,\u201d and their country of origin. (An influencer with a high number of followers from Turkey, Brazil and China, for instance, can raise red flags for Dovetale, which has frequently seen fake followers come from those countries.)\n\nThe clues can be complex. Dovetale flagged one account that claimed to be someone named Meg Cragle because it was part of a group of profiles that had made one or two unrelated posts and contained similarly worded bios of exactly 99 characters that ended with ellipses. The discovery was reinforced by a Google search for phrases in the account\u2019s bio like \u201caward-winning bacon fanatic,\u201d which matched the terms in a now-deleted Twitter bio generator online.\n\nDovetale acknowledged that its methods were not foolproof, but they are valuable enough in a murky landscape that the agency 360i said it was now unlikely to hire influencers for campaigns if Dovetale\u2019s database said more than 2 to 3 percent of their followers were bots. Dovetale said that, on average, 16.4 percent of the followers on Instagram\u2019s top 20 accounts were fraudulent.\n\nSylo, which requires influencers to share access to their public and private post statistics, said it had rejected 77 percent of influencers who have tried to register on its platform after their accounts showed issues like abnormal spikes in engagement on posts or a large number of generic, emoji-laden comments that bots are known for.\n\n\u201cIn the absence of direct pressure on the platforms, it\u2019s a way for advertisers to take more control of their own spend and not be at the mercy of the platforms themselves,\u201d said Jeff Semones, head of social media at MediaCom, which has recommended Sylo to clients. While he said Instagram had removed many accounts that were flagrantly violating its terms and conditions, \u201ca lot of one-off activity goes unchecked.\u201d\n\nA spokeswoman for Instagram said that the platform\u2019s \u201cinternal estimates show that spam accounts make up a small fraction\u201d of Instagram\u2019s 800 million monthly users.\n\nSome believe that the new awareness around bots highlights the misguided expectations that marketers have for how many people they can reach through influencers.", "title": "Uncovering Instagram Bots With a New Kind of Detective Work", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "The investigations, known as \u201csecretary-initiated cases\u201d to indicate their importance, had been used in the past to set precedent and to put other localities and developers on notice.\n\nOne of the delayed investigations looked at an ordinance in Hesperia, Calif., that prevented the siting of neighborhood group homes for parolees and former offenders throughout the city\u2019s neighborhoods. HUD investigators saw the case as an important test of the federal resolve to rehabilitate low-level offenders, who often face housing and job discrimination when they are released, leaving them in need of government assistance.\n\nOther cases that were held up involved questions about the accessibility to the disabled of new dwellings built by a pair of large residential construction companies, Toll Brothers and Epcon Communities, in New York City and Ohio, according to a department official.\n\nOne high-profile case never made it to that stage.\n\nHUD had opened a case in late 2016 in response to a ProPublica article that said Facebook gives advertisers the ability to exclude specific groups it calls \u201cethnic affinities\u201d from seeing their ads when their social media habits identified them as black, Hispanic or Asian-American.\n\nBut even before Ms. Far\u00edas was appointed, Mr. Carson\u2019s aides ordered fair housing division officials to cancel a planned negotiating session with Facebook executives, leaving HUD to take Facebook at its word that the company\u2019s \u201cpolicies prohibit using our targeting options to discriminate.\u201d\n\nThen, after taking office, Ms. Far\u00edas sent a one-page letter to Facebook ordering, without explanation, the termination of a preliminary investigation into the company\u2019s advertising practices.\n\nFair housing groups filed a lawsuit on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan saying that Facebook continues to discriminate against certain groups \u2014 including women, veterans with disabilities and single mothers \u2014 in the way that it allows advertisers to target audiences for their ads.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Far\u00edas, an official at HUD in the George W. Bush administration, has not initiated any high-priority cases of her own, according to agency officials. And she has made it clear that she does not intend to aggressively pursue cases that are not instituted \u201cby my secretary,\u201d meaning Mr. Carson, according to an official who spoke with her last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cFor all intents and purposes, this administration is stopping the enforcement of civil rights and fair housing laws at the worst possible time,\u201d said Gustavo Velasquez, who served as assistant secretary for fair housing during the last three years of President Barack Obama\u2019s administration.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not just the lack of an agenda, which is what I thought we were dealing with for the first year or so, but an attempt to reverse all the advances we made through regulations and enforcement actions,\u201d said Mr. Velasquez, who now works for the Urban Institute, a nonpartisan progressive think tank in Washington.\n\nThis is not the first time critics have accused Mr. Carson, the only African-American man in President Trump\u2019s cabinet, of trying to stymie civil rights enforcement. Shortly after he was confirmed last year, Mr. Carson tried to reverse an Obama-era program that would make it easier for recipients of housing vouchers to use them in affluent neighborhoods.\n\nThe move was struck down by the courts, and Mr. Carson abandoned the effort.\n\nLast week, Mr. Carson told members of the Senate Banking Committee that he planned to delay another Obama-era rule that would have required local governments to create detailed plans to integrate racially divided neighborhoods.\n\nAnd a provision barring HUD from using federal funding to undertake such programs was stealthily inserted into the 2018 spending plan passed last week by Congress.\n\nDespite these moves, Mr. Brown, the HUD spokesman, said the department was merely \u201clooking to streamline\u201d its enforcement efforts and to focus on new, neglected areas of discrimination.\n\n\u201cThere is no mission shift. We are, in fact, putting more emphasis in sexual harassment\u201d complaints, Mr. Brown wrote in an email. \u201cIn addition, 60 percent of the fair housing complaints we receive are disability related, and the majority of those have to do with service animals.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe most significant fight over fair housing under Mr. Trump is taking place in Houston, a sprawling metropolis ranked in numerous studies as one of the United States\u2019 most segregated cities, where overt opposition to a housing development based on race and income has drawn the attention of career HUD investigators.\n\nIn January 2017, before Mr. Obama left office, HUD lawyers accused Houston officials of violating fair housing requirements cited in the 1964 Civil Rights Act. The city\u2019s mayor, Sylvester Turner, a Democrat, had killed a 233-unit mixed-income, mixed-race housing development slated for an affluent white area known for its high-end shopping and excellent schools.\n\nHUD told the city to undertake specific remedies as a condition of continued funding, including the approval of the development, known as the Fountain View Project, and the adoption of tough new zoning laws.\n\nIn a scathing letter, HUD officials accused Mr. Turner, who is African-American, of succumbing to \u201cracially motivated local opposition,\u201d claiming that he caved to protests by white business owners and residents.\n\nMr. Turner has denied the accusation, arguing that he opposed the development because only 23 apartments were set aside for low-income families. He also objected to the idea of forced integration, putting him in agreement with Mr. Carson.\n\n\u201cI have chosen to stay in the neighborhood where I grew up, and I will not tell children in similar communities they must live somewhere else,\u201d said Mr. Turner, who grew up in an all-black development.\n\nBut he might have had other reasons for opposing the project. In one meeting, Mr. Turner privately admitted that he hoped his position on the project would coax white Republican state legislators to support a bill needed to restructure Houston\u2019s ailing pension system, according to a former federal official who attended the meeting.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe mayor denied that account.\n\n\u201cHe never told anyone he opposed the Fountain View Project to win votes for his pension overhaul,\u201d said Mary Benton, a spokeswoman for Mr. Turner.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStill, few Democrats have done quite so well in negotiating with the Trump administration as Mr. Turner, who began pressing Mr. Carson to release the city from the order shortly after Mr. Carson was confirmed.\n\nMs. Far\u00edas, with Mr. Carson\u2019s blessing, began negotiating directly with Mr. Turner and other city officials. She largely excluded the career lawyers who had already begun drafting a tougher order \u2014 one that required the city to pay the Houston Housing Authority, Fountain View\u2019s developer, as much as $14 million if it insisted on blocking the deal, according to an official in Houston.\n\nBut Mr. Turner, who believes the case to be a distraction from his city\u2019s rebuilding effort, prevailed.\n\nThis month, Ms. Far\u00edas signed a new, less stringent agreement that other Houston officials eager to get federal money flowing into hard-hit neighborhoods \u2014 including Representative Al Green, a Democrat and harsh Carson critic \u2014 hailed as a victory.\n\nBut a coalition of local advocacy groups and national organizations are suing to block the disbursement of $5 billion in HUD recovery money unless the city abides by civil rights-era fair housing laws.\n\n\u201cIf this isn\u2019t a violation of Title VI of the 1964 Civil Rights Act, then damn it, I don\u2019t know what is,\u201d said John Henneberger, a director of Texas Housers, an advocacy group that filed a lawsuit last week in Federal District Court to enforce the original HUD letter.\n\n\u201cFountain View was kind of the last stand,\u201d he said. \u201cWe spent eight or nine years documenting systematic and pervasive racial discrimination in Houston \u2014 it is an open-and-shut case.\u201d\n\nMr. Brown, the HUD spokesman, said the agreement required the city to \u201cput in place new procedures for the building of affordable housing\u201d and a study on how to increase affordable housing in the city\u2019s Galleria district, where Fountain View was to be built.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere are other signs of change within HUD that could make it far less likely that similar cases would ever be pursued.\n\nMs. Far\u00edas, according to six current department officials, has told HUD managers that she intends to replace her top subordinate, Timothy Smyth, who played a central role in the Houston case. Bryan Greene, another senior manager, will be reassigned as part of the shake-up, the officials said.\n\nMr. Brown, in an email, said no one had been reassigned yet \u2014 but he added that it was \u201cwell within the assistant secretary\u2019s authority after 120 days to reassign senior-level personnel.\u201d\n\nMorale at the division is sinking. At a meeting this month of HUD regional housing directors in Atlanta, Ms. Far\u00edas \u2014 a former vice chairwoman of the Bexar County, Tex., Republicans and a Trump campaign supporter \u2014 told one of the directors that she preferred older HUD employees because they were more likely to have had experience working for Republican administrations.\n\nEarlier, according to two aides who requested anonymity for fear of retribution, she had told her staff that it was her intention to root out people she viewed as \u201cObama plants.\u201d\n\nMs. Far\u00edas, through a spokesman, denied making those statements.", "title": "Under Ben Carson, HUD Scales Back Fair Housing Enforcement", "authors": ["Glenn Thrush"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe\u2019ve had a very good chemistry right from the beginning,\u201d Mr. Trump told reporters at the White House on Tuesday morning as he described his relationship with Mr. Pompeo.\n\nChemistry is vital between any president and his chief global emissary. But the shift disrupts the delicate balance of power in the administration\u2019s national security team.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Tillerson and Jim Mattis, the defense secretary, had run something of a tag team to keep the president in check, finding common ground on policies from the Middle East to East Asia before stepping into the Situation Room. For the better part of a year, that put Mr. Trump in the position of having to overcome their unified advice, which also was sometimes aligned with the White House national security adviser, H. R. McMaster.\n\nOne senior administration official who often sat in the backbenches of those meetings last week described Mr. Trump\u2019s growing frustration at being hemmed in by his two principal national security cabinet members.\n\nThat seems particularly true on Iran, and Mr. Trump singled out that issue on Tuesday as he was preparing to leave for California. He said he and Mr. Tillerson \u201cdisagree on things.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhen you look at the Iran deal \u2014 I think it\u2019s terrible. I guess he thought it was O.K.,\u201d the president said, referring to Mr. Tillerson. \u201cI wanted to either break it or do something. And he felt a little bit differently.\u201d\n\nHis comments are certain to alarm European allies who have spent the last few days negotiating with Mr. Tillerson\u2019s closest aide, Brian Hook, on a way to add to the agreement that limited Iran\u2019s nuclear program, rather than reopen or scrap the deal. Those moves were intended to keep Mr. Trump from ditching the agreement in mid-May, when he faces a deadline over continued suspension of American nuclear-related sanctions on Iran.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe first Mr. Hook heard of Mr. Tillerson\u2019s ouster was when a reporter for The New York Times called him for comment on Tuesday morning, shortly after the secretary\u2019s 405-day tenure was ended by presidential tweet.\n\nMr. Tillerson\u2019s denouement seemed rife with the symbolism of the change to come. After Mr. Trump was revealed to have used a vulgarity to disparage several African nations, he dispatched Mr. Tillerson on a lengthy trip to the continent last week to make it up to them.\n\nBut while the secretary was away, Mr. Trump agreed to the meeting with Mr. Kim, catching Mr. Tillerson by surprise \u2014 even though he was the one who had long been arguing for opening up a diplomatic channel to North Korea. While in Africa, Mr. Tillerson took a day off to recover from what the State Department said was exhaustion from long nights catching up by phone with Washington.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThen he got food poisoning, cut his travels short, and was fired upon landing in the United States.\n\nIt was clear in recent months that Mr. Tillerson and Mr. Trump were barely talking. The frequent dinners the chief diplomat shared with the president last spring, when the two men were forming their views of how to approach the world, had ended.\n\nMr. Trump had hired Mr. Tillerson because he liked his record of profits and expansion at Exxon, and thought his mane of white hair gave him the look of a secretary of state. But more recently, the president told aides he thought Mr. Tillerson was \u201cweak\u201d \u2014 the ultimate insult in Mr. Trump\u2019s world. His affinity for Mr. Pompeo grew as the men bonded over intelligence warnings and authorizations for covert actions.\n\nMr. Pompeo\u2019s rise will solve one central problem in American diplomacy over the past year: When Mr. Tillerson spoke, few thought he was speaking on behalf of the president.\n\n\u201cIt creates the possibility that someone who is up to speed with the issues, and has a comfortable working relationship with the president, is now in the chair,\u201d said Richard Haass, who served several Republicans and Democrats in senior State Department and National Security Council positions.\n\nAmerica\u2019s interlocutors, Mr. Haass added, will now believe the secretary of state \u201cis speaking with the power and backing of the president.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe question is whether, when President Trump speaks, it sounds like he has consulted his secretary of state,\u201d Mr. Haass, now the president of the Council on Foreign Relations, said in a call from India.\n\nThe one arena where Mr. Pompeo\u2019s views are still a mystery is Russia. While serving in Congress, he was a critic of President Vladimir V. Putin. As C.I.A. director, Mr. Pompeo said he believed intelligence assessments that Mr. Putin was behind the effort to influence the 2016 election \u2014 even though Mr. Trump has dismissed those reports for fear it would undercut the legitimacy of his election.\n\nMr. Pompeo has not, however, gone the next step to describe what he thought the United States should do to counter Russia\u2019s actions.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn contrast, Mr. Tillerson had let known his increasing concern about Russia\u2019s activities, and even about Mr. Putin, who famously presented him with an award for his deals with Russia while at Exxon. On Monday, his last day as secretary of state, he agreed with the British government that Russia was most likely behind the nerve gas attack on a Russian living in England \u2014 while the White House has hedged about Russia\u2019s responsibilities. Mr. Pompeo\u2019s views are not known.\n\nBut perhaps the biggest unknown in the ascension of Mr. Pompeo is how it will affect any negotiations with North Korea.\n\nHe has warned many times, since last summer, that Mr. Kim is \u201ca few months\u201d away from acquiring the ability to strike the United States with a nuclear weapon. That is based on a calculation of how long it will take the North to solve the final problems of designing a warhead that can survive re-entry into the atmosphere atop an intercontinental missile.\n\nBut Mr. Pompeo has also been in charge of an active covert campaign against the North, which he has alluded to elliptically on several occasions. The question now is whether that covert effort \u2014 believed to include sabotage of North Korea\u2019s supply chain and renewed cyberattacks on its missile and nuclear programs \u2014 will buy Mr. Trump enough time, and leverage, to make a negotiation work.\n\nNo agency has been more skeptical about the chances of Mr. Kim\u2019s giving up his arsenal than the C.I.A. itself, under Mr. Pompeo.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a presentation last fall at George Washington University, one of the agency\u2019s top Korea analysts said that in the C.I.A.\u2019s view, no amount of sanctions pressure would persuade Mr. Kim that it was worth giving up the weapons that he believes are his only defense from having his country overrun by the United States and its allies.\n\nAssociates of Mr. Pompeo say he shares that view \u2014 which would suggest that while he may soon be running the North Korea negotiations, his expectations of success are limited.\n\nIn retrospect, Tuesday\u2019s shift could explain some comments Mr. Pompeo made over the weekend. In interviews on Fox and CBS, he said he had spent part of the weekend reviewing the C.I.A.\u2019s internal history of American negotiations with North Korea for the past quarter-century. That would have been an odd way for a C.I.A. director to spend his reading time; it makes a lot of sense for a future secretary of state.", "title": "Under Pompeo, a Foreign Policy That Fits the President\u2019s Worldview", "authors": ["David E. Sanger"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The United States military has carried out twice as many airstrikes against Islamic State militants in Libya since President Trump took office as it has publicly acknowledged, raising questions about whether the Pentagon has sought to obscure operations in the strife-torn North African nation.\n\nThe total number of strikes \u2014 eight since January 2017 \u2014 is relatively small. But the uptick points to the threat that the Trump administration believes Libya still poses, despite the president\u2019s focus on the American-led campaign against the Islamic State in Syria and Iraq that he has trumpeted as one of his administration\u2019s signature national security accomplishments.\n\nCounterterrorism specialists warn that the Islamic State and Al Qaeda also still pose formidable threats in places like Somalia, Yemen and West Africa. On Tuesday, Gen. Thomas D. Waldhauser, the head of the Africa Command, said in congressional testimony that \u201cwe are heavily involved in the counterterrorism piece\u201d in Libya.\n\nOn its website and in news releases, the Africa Command has acknowledged only four airstrikes in Libya in the last 14 months against the Islamic State, also called ISIS, ISIL or Daesh. All of the attacks have been carried out since September.", "title": "Under Trump, U.S. Launched 8 Airstrikes Against ISIS in Libya. It Disclosed 4.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nIn \u201c \u2018Millennial\u2019 Means Nothing\u201d (Op-Ed, March 7), John Quiggin suggests that the Pew Research Center would do better to eschew generational analysis altogether rather than tighten our definition of millennials. Yet he proceeds to give a number of important examples of the ways in which historical context can have an effect on the collective experiences and values of a generation.\n\nWe agree that when it comes to understanding people\u2019s values, behaviors and life outcomes, these generational signals often pale in comparison with other, more fundamental factors like race, class and gender.\n\nWe also agree that generational labels quickly become unproductive when they turn into overgeneralized caricatures. But the risk of overgeneralization does not justify ignoring that the social, political, economic and technological context in which one comes of age can have a meaningful effect worthy of studying.\n\nThe answer to the public\u2019s desire to understand generational signals is not to silence the conversation but to inform it.", "title": "Opinion | Understanding Millennials", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "SAM PRITCHARD, AMES, IOWA\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRobert Leonard concludes by stating, \u201cIf Democrats want to engage rural America culturally and politically, they need to understand us, and at least some of our ideals.\u201d What, though, if we do understand you, but still think that your attitudes toward guns \u2014 at least the more extreme attitudes \u2014 are unhealthy?\n\nI\u2019m a hunter myself and appreciate a nice shotgun as much as any farm boy. But when people\u2019s identities start to be defined by their AR-15s and Glocks, when they start to believe that their liberty is under perpetual threat from vague and sinister forces, and when their sense of self-worth is tightly tied to their ability to exert deadly force over others, I don\u2019t think they need understanding; I think they need therapy. Sometimes understanding a culture gives you reason to respect it less, not more.\n\nROB LEWIS, OAKVILLE, ONTARIO\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nMost of the people I know from the Midwest \u2014 where I was born, raised and educated \u2014 are better, smarter and more willing to engage in serious dialogue than the caricatures Robert Leonard describes.\n\nThey know that different views on how to reduce gun violence cannot be resolved by talk radio-style debates on human nature or the effects of \u201coriginal sin\u201d and that the real question is what can be done to reduce the incidence of gun violence in the future.\n\nMost small-town Americans also recognize that ignoring the evidence by dismissing it as \u201cthrowing around statistics\u201d is not likely to encourage a healthy dialogue, particularly when common sense suggests \u2014 and studies have confirmed \u2014 that restricting access to assault weapons reduces the incidence of mass murders.", "title": "Opinion | Understanding Rural America\u2019s Gun Culture", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Students across the country continue to attack and shut down speakers at a steady pace, from Christina Hoff Sommers to Jordan Peterson. I confess that I find their behavior awful. My gut reaction is that these student mobbists manage to combine snowflake fragility and lynch mob irrationalism into one perfectly poisonous cocktail.\n\nBut empathy is the essential character trait for our moment. So I thought it might be a good discipline to try to see things from the students\u2019 perspective \u2014 to not just condemn or psychoanalyze them but to try to understand where they are coming from. So here goes.\n\nI would begin my stab at understanding by acknowledging that I grew up in one era and they grew up in another. I came of age in the 1980s. In that time, there was an assumption that though the roots of human society were deep in tribalism, over the past 3,000 years we have developed a system of liberal democracy that gloriously transcended it, that put reason, compassion and compromise atop violence and brute force.\n\nThere was also an assumption that while we might disagree on the means, we all wanted basically the same things. For example, though America was plagued by economic divides we all wanted a society in which social mobility and equal opportunity were the rule. Though America is plagued by racism, we all wanted more integration and less bigotry, a place where talent and character mattered more than skin color and prejudice.", "title": "Opinion | Understanding Student Mobbists", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "British government officials had lobbied hard to persuade Unilever to maintain its London headquarters, in the hopes of avoiding the symbolic blow of a major company being seen to \u201cleave\u201d the country at a delicate time in its negotiations with European Union officials. Unilever officials said on Thursday that Brexit did not factor into the company\u2019s decision.\n\n\u201cThe proposed simplification will provide greater flexibility for strategic portfolio change and help drive long-term performance,\u201d Unilever said in a statement.\n\nIt said that it would continue to be listed in London, Amsterdam and New York, and that two of its three new divisions would remain based in London: beauty and personal care, and home care. The third division would be located in Rotterdam.\n\nPhoto\n\nUnilever employs about 7,300 people in Britain and 3,100 in the Netherlands; none are expected to be affected by the structural change. The company also said it would continue to spend 1 billion pounds, or about $1.4 billion, a year in Britain, including on research and development.\n\nDespite the company\u2019s insistence that it would keep its presence in the British capital, Rajesh Agrawal, the London deputy mayor for business, said the decision was \u201cclearly disappointing news\u201d for the city.\n\n\u201cIt brings into sharp focus the need for the government to secure a Brexit deal that secures London as Europe\u2019s leading business center,\u201d Mr. Agrawal added.\n\nUnilever\u2019s two headquarters mirrored its legal structure, in which the company maintained separate stock listings and corporate entities in both countries after its formation by the combination of the British soap maker Lever Brothers and the Dutch margarine producer Margarine Unie in 1930.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEach of the two operating companies technically has its own board, but the boards are made up of the same directors and senior management.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile unusual, the structure has been used by some of the largest companies with ties to both Britain and the Netherlands. The oil giant Royal Dutch Shell maintained a similar system until 2005, and RELX Group, the business information company that owns LexisNexis Legal and was formerly known as Reed Elsevier, dropped its dual structure this year.\n\nAs consumers have shied away from traditional brands in favor of products from smaller companies with more natural and organic ingredients, Unilever has tried to keep pace by buying companies like Schmidt\u2019s Naturals, Sundial Brands and Dollar Shave Club in recent years.\n\nNevertheless, simplifying its structure has been a topic at investor meetings for more than a decade.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the end, the unsolicited bid for Unilever by Kraft Heinz, the maker of Heinz ketchup and Oscar Mayer hot dogs, brought the topic to a head. Kraft Heinz withdrew its offer days later on friendly terms, but Unilever said soon after that it would review its structure.\n\nAs the company pursued a sale of its margarine and spreads business last year, Unilever said, \u201cit was apparent that our dual-headed legal structure adds complexity when undertaking such changes.\u201d\n\n\u201cUnilever\u2019s dual-headed legal structure does not technically impede its ability to issue equity or demerge assets, but it makes it significantly more complex,\u201d Pinar Ergun, a UBS analyst, said in a recent research note.\n\nThe consumer goods company said late last year that its board \u201cconsiders that unification with a single share class would be in the best interests of Unilever and its shareholders as a whole, providing greater ongoing strategic flexibility for value-creating portfolio change.\u201d\n\nUnilever had originally hoped to make a decision on its structure by the end of last year, but Paul Polman, its chief executive, told The Financial Times in November that the company had decided to delay it amid rising tensions in the negotiations between Britain and the European Union.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUncertainty about Britain\u2019s future relationship with the bloc has weighed heavily on decision-making by a number of companies as they try to determine how to continue to serve customers in Europe.\n\nFor example, a number of banks, including HSBC, have announced plans to move some employees to the Continent in order to be able to serve their European customers seamlessly when Britain is set to leave the bloc next year.\n\nOther companies have announced plans to stay and made new investments in their British operations. Toyota said this month that it would make the latest generation of its Auris automobile at its plant in Britain after announcing an investment of \u00a3240 million (about $335 million) in the Toyota Motors UK business last year.\n\n\u201cThe impact of Brexit may be felt in the future not only as a result of what happens in the U.K., but also as a result of the strong determination of governments of E.U. countries to make their markets more attractive and the new destination for foreign direct investment from multinationals based in the U.K.,\u201d said Carmen Stoian, a lecturer in international business at the Kent Business School at the University of Kent.", "title": "Unilever to Make the Netherlands Its Sole Headquarters, in Blow to Britain", "authors": ["Chad Bray"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Are humans the only creatures with individual DNA fingerprints? What about other species?\n\nA. Individual members of many species also have unique and identifiable genetic profiles. As with human beings, a large number of variations in a relatively short sequence of DNA can make it possible to identify an individual and to distinguish that animal from other members of the species.\n\nDNA fingerprinting is commercially available for dogs, for example, for purposes like identifying a lost or stolen pet or tracing a pedigree.\n\nThe approach is also used in wildlife research. It can determine whether an isolated population of wild birds has become too inbred for survival, for instance, so that some can be moved elsewhere.\n\nScientists at the University of Arizona and elsewhere also have turned to genetic fingerprinting to identify individual animals that have been poached or illegally trafficked, as well as to determine where imported animals came from.", "title": "Unique Identifiers in Animal DNA", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nUnited Airlines apologized on Tuesday after a dog died on a flight during which it was stored in a passenger\u2019s overhead compartment. A witness said that a flight attendant had ordered the pet owner to put the dog in the compartment before the plane took off.\n\nThe dog, a black French bulldog that was traveling in a pet carrier, was placed in the compartment shortly before United Flight 1284 left Houston for New York at around 6 p.m. Monday, said Maggie Gremminger, 30, who was seated behind the pet owner. She said the owner was instructed to put her dog there shortly after she boarded with two children, one of whom was an infant.\n\n\u201cThe pet owner was very adamant that she did not want to put the pet carrier up above,\u201d Ms. Gremminger said. \u201cShe was saying verbally, \u2018My dog is in here, no, this is my dog.\u2019 The flight attendant, in response, really just continued to ask her to put it above because it was a hazard where it was, it was a safety emergency, someone could trip.\u201d\n\nEventually, the pet owner, whom United declined to name, complied with the flight attendant. Ms. Gremminger said the owner was preoccupied by her infant during the flight and did not check on the pet, which fell eerily silent after barking during takeoff and as the plane ascended to its cruising altitude.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPutting animals in the overhead compartment is against the airline\u2019s policies, which say pets are required to travel in carriers that \u201cmust fit completely under the seat in front of the customer and remain there at all times.\u201d United said it was investigating who had put the dog in the overhead compartment and why.", "title": "United Airlines Apologizes After Dog Dies in Overhead Compartment", "authors": ["Liam Stack"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhen no one \u2018qualifies\u2019 because they called out sick due to the most awful flu in years, or sick children, or life \u2026 the company just makes more money for itself,\u201d she wrote. \u201cService is going to lack, on time departures won\u2019t be fought for and the company will suffer.\u201d\n\nOn Monday, the president of United Airlines, Scott Kirby, told employees that the company was rethinking the lottery program.\n\n\u201cOur intention was to introduce a better, more exciting program, but we misjudged how these changes would be received by many of you,\u201d he wrote. \u201cSo, we are pressing the pause button on these changes to review your feedback and consider the right way to move ahead.\u201d\n\nUnited, which has more than 80,000 employees, did not respond to specific questions about either the lottery program or the current bonus program.\n\nThat program rewards all eligible employees with up to $125 each month for on-time departures, on-time arrivals and other performance-related measures.\n\n\u201cThe employee group that would have been eligible for those bonuses was much larger\u201d than that of the lottery system, Taylor Garland, spokeswoman for the Association of Flight Attendants, said in a phone interview. The bonuses were given to not only United\u2019s 24,000 flight attendants but also its pilots and gate agents among others, she said.\n\nUnder the lottery system, just 1,361 employees would receive bonuses, according to the United Airlines memo, and only one would be chosen for the top cash prize of $100,000.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOther prizes included the Mercedes sedans (10 winners), a choice between a vacation package or $20,000 (20 winners), a similar choice at the $10,000 level (30 winners) and a variety of other cash prizes. The bonus that employees had the best chance of winning was $2,000 cash, which would have been given to 1,000 workers.\n\nIn February, Mr. Kirby lauded the company for finishing first among its competitors for on-time departures, \u201cmarking the seventh time in the past 10 months that we\u2019ve ranked in the top spot for mainline departures.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPaying out bonuses to both rank-and-file workers and executives costs the company tens of millions of dollars every year.\n\nAccording to United\u2019s latest earnings report, employees earned approximately $30 million in incentive payments for achieving operations performance goals in the fourth quarter ending in December, and approximately $87 million in earned bonuses in 2017. The report did not break out bonuses for executives and other workers.\n\nThe lottery system, with about $18 million in rewards per year available for rank-and-file workers, may have cost the company far less.\n\nIn response to the lottery plan, an online petition called \u201cMake United Airlines Great Again\u201d surfaced on Change.org last week, drawing more than 1,000 supporters, but it was closed a couple of days ago by the person who posted it, who is identified online only as \u201cN A.\u201d\n\nIt featured a letter addressed to the United Management Team written by Laurie Vesalo, a flight attendant, who referred to the lottery as a \u201cdeplorable new system that only rewards an elite few.\u201d\n\nMs. Vesalo told The New York Times that she did not create the petition and that her letter had been intended for internal company use \u2014 not a public complaint.\n\n\u201cI roll with the punches, but I also believe in standing up for what I believe,\u201d she said. \u201cI will still always do my job adequately, and I love my job.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMany of those who signed the petition chastised the company for treating its employees unfairly.\n\n\u201cYou have the opportunity to do the right thing. We feel like we\u2019re not being heard and the tension is palpable,\u201d one worker in Los Angeles wrote.\n\nA discussion on the airline\u2019s internal forum, obtained by the travel website The Points Guy, included hundreds of comments about the lottery.\n\n\u201cI haven\u2019t seen or heard one positive comment from a front line employee regarding this \u2018new and enhanced\u2019 program,\u201d one person wrote. \u201cUpper management is so out of touch with the front line, it would be funny if it weren\u2019t so sad.\u201d\n\nFor now, United\u2019s website still promotes the employee bonuses as a reason to come work for the company.\n\n\u201cOur employees are critical to our success,\u201d the web page said, \u201cso we reward them financially through profit-sharing, customer satisfaction bonuses and on-time arrival bonuses when the airline performs well.\u201d", "title": "United Airlines Pauses Lottery for Bonuses After Employees Rebel Online", "authors": ["Christina Caron"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMarch has been tough on dogs flying with United Airlines.\n\nLast week, a French bulldog died after being placed in an overhead bin on a flight from Houston to New York. A day later, a German shepherd headed from Oregon to Kansas wound up in Japan after being mixed up with a Great Dane during a connection in Denver. (The dog was flown back in a private jet.) Another dog, bound for Akron, Ohio, was mistakenly loaded onto a flight from Newark to St. Louis. The plane made an extra stop in Akron, where it was reunited with its family.\n\nOn Tuesday, the spate of missteps prompted United to suspend PetSafe, its program for transporting animals in the cargo holds of planes, while the airline moves to prevent more problems.\n\n\u201cWe know we need to improve, but we also know the best way to do that is to stop and take a look at this,\u201d said Charlie Hobart, a company spokesman.\n\nUnited said it was not planning to take new PetSafe bookings during the review, which is expected to be completed on May 1. The change will not affect animals permitted to travel in plane cabins or already booked reservations. Customers who want to cancel pets\u2019 travel during the review will be allowed to.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUnited recently announced in a separate move that it would impose stricter rules on emotional support animals flying in cabins, after one passenger tried to take a peacock onboard.", "title": "United Airlines Suspends Cargo Program for Animals After Spate of Missteps", "authors": ["Zach Wichter"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe United States men\u2019s national team continued trudging through the non-World Cup wilderness on Tuesday with its interim head coach and its rotating cast of young, unproven players managing a 1-0 victory in an exhibition against Paraguay.\n\nIn the Americans\u2019 third game since the October loss to Trinidad and Tobago that prevented them from qualifying for the World Cup, they deployed a starting lineup that included nine players age 25 or younger, one of which was making his first appearance with the national team \u2014 22-year-old Marky Delgado of Toronto F.C.\n\nDelgado helped provide the highlight of the night for the U.S. in the game\u2019s 43rd minute. He lofted a ball from 20 yards inside the Americans\u2019 half over the Paraguayan defense and into the path of 19-year-old Tyler Adams, who sprinted alone toward the goal before being brought down by Paraguay\u2019s goalkeeper, Gatito Fern\u00e1ndez, to draw a penalty kick. Bobby Wood, who has been struggling through the German league season with Hamburg, scoring just one goal in 20 league appearances, converted the penalty kick for the Americans. It was the team\u2019s first goal of 2018 and the lone scoring in the eventual victory.\n\n\u201cThe kids have got to start somewhere and this was a good game to get their feet wet,\u201d Dave Sarachan, the interim United States coach, said of his young roster.\n\nWood\u2019s goal punctuated an energetic performance from the young squad, which was facing a Paraguay team in a similar situation (having missed out on the World Cup and being led by an interim coach, Gustavo Mor\u00ednigo). It was the United States\u2019 first win since a 4-0 World Cup qualifying victory against Panama in October, a game that felt a world away from Tuesday night\u2019s matchup at Sahlen\u2019s Stadium in Cary, N.C.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmong the brighter points for the U.S. was Adams, who came up through the Red Bulls\u2019 youth academy and started 22 games for the club as an 18-year-old last season, scoring twice and recording four assists from defensive midfield.
