The Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, the industry trade group, rolled out an advertising campaign, \u201cShare the Savings,\u201d last year to make the case that by passing on the discounts, plans could significantly lower patients\u2019 out-of-pocket bills. The group called UnitedHealthcare\u2019s decision \u201ca step in the right direction.\u201d\n\nInsurers, including UnitedHealthcare, contend that they already use the money from discounts to lower premiums for all their customers, and argue the real issue is the high cost of so many drugs.\n\n\n\nBut UnitedHealthcare seems to have blinked, signaling what could be a coming shift away from the system of convoluted deals struck between the drug companies and these middlemen, said Adam J. Fein, president of Pembroke Consulting, a research firm. Although the new policy will only affect a fraction of the company\u2019s customers, \u201cit\u2019s one more step on the path of creating a more transparent pharmacy supply chain,\u201d Mr. Fein said.\n\nThe amount of rebates can vary widely, with some drugs, like Humira and Enbrel that treat rheumatoid arthritis, being deeply discounted. Others, like medicines for rare conditions where there is no significant competition, have little to no rebates. Patients, employers and the public have little information on what any one drug costs and whether the discounts ultimately flow back to customers.\n\n\u201cThe industry is taking criticism from a lot of different people,\u201d said Erik Gordon, a business professor at the University of Michigan. It is significant that UnitedHealthcare \u201cfelt compelled to do something,\u201d he said.\n\nThe Trump administration recently floated the idea of requiring private drug plans under Medicare to pass on the savings to consumers at the pharmacy counter. On Tuesday, Alex M. Azar II, a former executive at Eli Lilly and the new secretary of health and human services, called UnitedHealthcare\u2019s move \u201ca prime example of the type of movement toward transparency and lower drug prices for millions of patients that the Trump administration is championing.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut insurers have resisted the idea that they be forced to pass on the savings in Medicare drug plans, arguing that it would result in significantly higher premiums for everyone. Federal officials estimate that consumers buying the drugs would save, on average, from $45 to $132 a month under the proposal. But then premiums for all Medicare beneficiaries would increase anywhere from an estimated $14 to $44 a month.\n\nUnitedHealth Group, UnitedHealthcare\u2019s parent, opposes the Medicare proposal because it would raise premiums sharply for older people.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy contrast, the company\u2019s plans offered through private employers would have a minimal effect on premiums, Mr. Schumacher said. \u201cThe benefit to the individual is meaningful.\u201d\n\nEmployers who self-insure already have the option of passing the discounts onto customers, Mr. Schumacher said. CVS Health, a large pharmacy benefit manager, allows employers to share the discount with their workers and has offered rebates to its own employees since 2013. OptumRx also offers the option of sharing the discount directly with consumers.\n\nBut while some employers seem interested, it has not taken off, Mr. Schumacher said. \u201cWe have some customer interest,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s in the early innings.\u201d\n\nWhile some employers want to keep the savings, more are becoming concerned about how these large rebates affect people taking expensive medicines who are in high-deductible plans or pay a significant percentage of every prescription they fill, said Edward A. Kaplan, a senior vice president at Segal Consulting. The rebate \u201cis such a big number,\u201d he said.\n\nThe shift to choosing to share those savings with the employees filling these prescriptions \u201cis beginning to happen slowly,\u201d he said.", "title": "UnitedHealthcare Says It Will Pass On Rebates From Drug Companies to Consumers", "authors": ["Reed Abelson"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Hamilton and Mr. Chisolm met in March 2012 at an N.Y.U. School of Law dinner for admitted students. \u201cI sat in the back next to a guy in a chocolate brown suit who turned out to be Jordan,\u201d Ms. Hamilton said, laughing. \u201cHe looked like the C.E.O. of UPS, but he was cute.\u201d\n\nThey chatted briefly over wine, and Mr. Chisolm began amusing Ms. Hamilton, who is of Jamaican descent, by speaking in his best Patois accent.\n\n\u201cShe seemed entertained by my corny humor,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd I deployed the best of my nerdy charm.\u201d\n\nAs they teased each other and discussed some short-term plans (she was heading to a birthday party immediately after the dinner and he had to get up early for an interview), Mr. Chisolm caught a glimpse of Ms. Hamilton\u2019s thoughtful and caring personality.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI was intrigued by her insistence that I leave to prepare for my interview,\u201d he said. \u201cThough I was surprised she favored ending the night, her concern for my preparation was heartfelt.\u201d\n\nAt that point, their story gets a bit blurry, as Ms. Hamilton and Mr. Chisolm each have their own version of how they received the other\u2019s contact information.\n\n\u201cJordan said we should keep in touch, and I asked him how he would do that without my number,\u201d Ms. Hamilton said. \u201cSo he asked for it, and he hasn\u2019t left me alone not one day ever since. She made me look good, and feel even better. I quickly abandoned my plan to eschew any relationships in law school and made it official barely two months later.\u201d\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t know it then,\u201d Mr. Chisolm added, \u201cbut I hit the jackpot.\u201d\n\nWhen told that line, Ms. Hamilton laughed a little louder and said, \u201cWell, there\u2019s no disputing that.\u201d", "title": "Unreliable Witnesses to Their Own Meeting?", "authors": ["Vincent M. Mallozzi"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou can look at it with time as your metric and say, \u2018Wow, this is really long,\u2019\u201d said Jonathan Golub, chief United States equity strategist for Credit Suisse. \u201cOr you can look at output and say, \u2018It\u2019s actually surprisingly weak.\u2019\u201d\n\nSome parts of the country have experienced little recovery at all. And many families are still earning far less than they were before the recession. As a result, some economists, especially on the left, argue that policymakers should be less worried about the economy overheating than about the recovery ending too soon.\n\n\u201cYou just see a pervasive attitude in markets that says, \u2018Oh, no, workers are starting to get a piece of the pie, time to take it away,\u2019\u201d said Jared Bernstein, a former economic adviser to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. who is now with the liberal Center on Budget and Policy Priorities.\n\nLawrence H. Summers, the Harvard economist and former Treasury secretary, said there was evidence that the economy could keep growing without faster inflation. Even a little more inflation, Mr. Summers said, would not necessarily be a bad thing.\n\n\u201cA strong, fully employed economy \u2014 where firms looking for workers is a larger issue than workers looking for firms \u2014 is the best social program we know,\u201d he said. \u201cIt is shortages of labor that induce firms to figure out how to train felons, to move beyond their traditional prejudices, to figure out how to skill unskilled workers, to reach into distressed or depressed communities.\u201d\n\nThat argument puts economists like Mr. Summers and Mr. Bernstein in odd political company. Mr. Trump\u2019s economic advisers \u2014 including the incoming head of the National Economic Council, Larry Kudlow \u2014 have played down the threat of inflation, and Mr. Trump has indicated in the past that he would like the Fed to keep interest rates low. That could pay electoral dividends: If the Fed allows the economy to accelerate, it could bolster Mr. Trump\u2019s re-election chances, even if it raises the risk of a recession in his second term.\n\nSo far, the Fed does not seem inclined to cooperate. Jerome H. Powell, the newly appointed Fed chairman, has said he plans to continue the policy of gradual rate increases adopted by his predecessor, Janet L. Yellen. But Mr. Powell hinted in recent congressional testimony that the central bank could be forced to move more quickly if the economy continued to gain strength.", "title": "Up, Up, Up Goes the Economy. Here\u2019s What Could Knock It Down.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cPeople consuming the liquor, they are very scared,\u201d he said. \u201cThey think they are not doing the right thing, they think they are doing wrong.\u201d\n\nBut unlike consumption of alcohol, child marriage is socially accepted in parts of India, where there is a belief that marrying daughters off at a young age shields them from unwelcome sexual advances and consolidates families\u2019 status in a community.\n\nAt a police station near Madhura, Anoj Kumar, the head officer, said that this part of Bihar has evolved. Leaning over the criminal complaint lodged against Suresh Chaudhary, the father of Deepa Kumari, he noted that other villagers were against the union.\n\n\u201cEven Deepa\u2019s mother disagreed with the marriage,\u201d he said. \u201cSuresh said he was marrying her off because of poverty.\u201d\n\nA few miles away, in Madhura, Mr. Chaudhary told his side of the story through clenched teeth, balling a pink stole with his fist. \u201cNobody gave any money,\u201d he said. \u201cSociety said that we were marrying the girl off by force. Someone from the outside complained.\u201d\n\nWhen the police disrupted wedding preparations, on Feb. 5, Mr. Chaudhary avoided arrest by sprinting into a nearby cornfield and waiting out the night. He remained in hiding for two weeks.\n\nPressed about his daughter\u2019s age, Mr. Chaudhary said he shaved off two years on government documents to give her an advantage in school. As for Ms. Kumari\u2019s police statement that he tried to marry her against her will, Mr. Chaudhary posed a rhetorical question: \u201cNow, she is scared of the police. How can she say she wants to get married?\u201d", "title": "Uphill Battle Against Child Marriage Is Being Won in India, for Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHe has an encyclopedic knowledge of New York real estate,\u201d Mr. Kamel said. So when Mr. Wilpon urged the young family to consider an apartment at Philip House, a 1920s building on the Upper East Side that Cheshire Group was converting to condos, they decided to humor him \u2014 although they initially had no intention of moving uptown.\n\n\u201cI was like, \u2018I\u2019m not moving all the way up to 88th Street,\u2019\u201d Ms. Kamel said.\n\nBut when she saw the building\u2019s grand, raw spaces as construction was beginning, and visited a model apartment designed by Victoria Hagan, she changed her mind.\n\n\u201cIt was just bare bones, but I loved it,\u201d she said. \u201cIt had the kind of the flooring I would put in and the moldings I would do. It was not dissimilar to how I would renovate the space.\u201d\n\nShe and Mr. Kamel closed on a three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bathroom unit of roughly 2,100 square feet in October 2013, for about $4 million. Then they waited as construction on their new apartment dragged on \u2014 including the installation of custom bookshelves and cabinetry flanking the fireplace, and built-in speakers integrated within ceiling beams, which Ms. Kamel had designed and negotiated as part of the deal \u2014 before moving in a year later.\n\nThe wait gave Ms. Kamel time to concoct a furniture plan with enough of a young downtown feel to counter the building\u2019s uptown formality before the couple\u2019s second son, Miles, arrived in 2015.\n\nThe home now mixes furniture by some of her favorite European designers and American craftspeople. In the foyer, she paired a bench from the British company Pinch with a custom walnut console by the Hudson Valley-based Casey Dzierlenga. The dining area is anchored by a hefty table by the French designer Christian Liaigre and campaign-style chairs by the Long Island City-based designer Richard Wrightman.\n\nSome pieces took longer to find.\n\n\u201cThose coat hangers took a year,\u201d Mr. Kamel said, pointing to metal Afteroom wall hooks from Menu in the foyer.\n\nMs. Kamel explained that she merely needed to consider every option before committing.\n\nThen there was the living room rug. \u201cI\u2019m a proud Persian man; I need a Persian rug,\u201d said Mr. Kamel, who was born in Iran. \u201cBut we wanted something that wasn\u2019t very traditional Persian.\u201d", "title": "Uptown, With a Downtown Vibe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Recalling their work in Corumb\u00e1, in southwestern Brazil, Dr. Marvin said their job was to search for manganese to use in making steel. \u201cWhen the water was up, we traveled across country by dugout canoe (sometimes decked out in wild orchids),\u201d she said in the lecture.\n\nThey returned full time to the United States in 1958. After teaching mineralogy at Tufts for two years, she was offered a job researching meteorites at Harvard before joining the Smithsonian observatory in 1961.\n\nAt the time, Dr. Marvin knew nothing about meteorites. But with the space age accelerating, she gladly accepted. She received her doctorate from Harvard in 1969.\n\nAs her meteoritic expertise grew exponentially in the late 1970s, Dr. Marvin joined the first of her three expeditions to Antarctica to hunt for meteorites. She was the first woman on the American research teams that traveled there.\n\n\u201cTo search for Antarctic meteorites is an exhilarating adventure,\u201d she wrote in New Scientist magazine in 1983. She described riding a snowmobile over blue ice and drifting snow: \u201cThe glimpse of a dark object starts the heart pounding. Racing toward it, the excitement grows as one sees it is not a shadow, not a glacial cobble, but a meteorite \u2014 a piece of rock from another planet.\u201d\n\nIn 1982, she was part of the team that discovered a lunar meteorite.\n\n\u201cMany miles from camp,\u201d she wrote in New Scientist, they found a small specimen with a \u201cfrothy, greenish-tan crust\u201d that was unlike anything they had ever seen. When it was later analyzed in Washington, it was found to bear a great similarity to rocks that had been found by astronauts in the lunar highlands.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFollowing her trips to Antarctica, a small mountain on the ice sheet was named for her (Marvin Nunatak). And her meteorite studies earned her a similar honor in 1991, when the International Astronomical Union named an asteroid for her.\n\nDr. Marvin\u2019s interest in meteorites knew no geographic boundaries. When a six-pound meteorite ripped through the roof of a house in Wethersfield, Conn., in 1982, she and other scientists arrived to inspect it the next day. It was the second meteorite strike in Wethersfield in 11 years.\n\n\u201cMeteorites are always a dramatic occurrence,\u201d Dr. Marvin told The New York Times, \u201cbut to have two strike the same town is, well, almost incomprehensible.\u201d\n\nShe said the second meteorite, which had rolled to a stop under Wanda and Robert Donahue\u2019s dining room table, was probably from an asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter that she called a \u201csort of celestial rock garden.\u201d\n\nMore critically, she was part of a study, funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, that analyzed rocks and soil recovered by Apollo astronauts and Soviet robotic missions.\n\n\u201cWe compared rock types from different sites on the moon to work out its geological history,\u201d she said in the oral history. Her boss at the astrophysics center, John Wood, \u201cconcluded the moon must have had an early magma ocean,\u201d she said, adding, \u201cI think that idea still is the best explanation of how the lunar crust was formed.\u201d\n\nShe described her findings in an article for Science magazine in 1989. In all, she wrote more than 160 research papers and a book, \u201cContinental Drift: The Evolution of a Concept\u201d (1973).\n\nDr. Wood, a former associate director of the astrophysics center, said in a telephone interview: \u201cWe were a small group \u2014 just four of us and several technical assistants \u2014 that was very passionate about these samples. They were heady times, and Ursula was the mineralogical arm of the team.\u201d\n\nShe leaves no immediate survivors. Her husband died in 2012.\n\nAfter the Apollo 17 mission in 1972 \u2014 the crew included Harrison Schmitt, a geologist \u2014 Dr. Marvin was in Houston when a box of rocks the astronauts had collected was opened. It was the final Apollo mission.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere was so much of interest to study in the lunar samples,\u201d she said in 1997, \u201cthat I continued to do it until year before last.\u201d", "title": "Ursula Marvin, Geologist of the Extraterrestrial, Dies at 96", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Andrea L. Taylor, president and chief executive of the Birmingham Civil Rights Institute in Alabama, called the joint initiative between the Boston museum and the Brookline Police Department timely and appropriate. (The museum is planning to replicate the program with other Boston area police forces.)\n\n\u201cWe know that dialogue and appreciation of the cultural and historical context which people bring with them are critical to positive police-community relations,\u201d said Ms. Taylor, whose institution has engaged in similar programming, as have a number of the estimated 300 African-American history, heritage and cultural museums around the country.\n\nBirmingham Civil Rights Institute\n\nOver the last decade the institute and the F.B.I.\u2019s Birmingham division have partnered to stage an annual conference addressing topical issues related to race and law enforcement. The conference, which is open to the public, attracts about 150 to 200 participants, and features experts and panel sessions.\n\nIn May 2016, James B. Comey, then the F.B.I. director, was the keynote speaker for the conference. Mr. Comey \u201ctalked about the rather tortured and tense history between the African-American community and the F.B.I.,\u201d Ms. Taylor said. This year\u2019s conference, scheduled for June, will focus on human trafficking.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Goldsboro Museum\n\nSince its opening in 2011, the museum, in Sanford, Fla., has focused on the history of Goldsboro, which was the second all-black incorporated city in the United States. A few years after 17-year-old Trayvon Martin was shot and killed in Sanford in 2012, Francis Oliver, the founder, chairwoman and curator of the museum, began to rebuild strained relations with the local police department.\n\n\u201cMrs. Oliver welcomed me and the officers of the department, despite the many years of distrust, miscommunication and the events surrounding the Martin case,\u201d Cecil E. Smith, chief of the Sanford Police Department, wrote in an email.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt started with the department\u2019s donating sodas and snacks to a 2014 memorial for Mr. Martin at the museum, but the relationship has grown. Seventy new members of the 132-member police department have visited the museum, learning about the history of Goldsboro. It was founded in 1891 and existed as a separate community until 1911, when it was annexed by Sanford (\u201cstolen,\u201d Mrs. Oliver said).\n\n\u201cSome of the white police officers, especially the young ones, they knew nothing about that history, about the struggles,\u201d Mrs. Oliver said. \u201cThey\u2019re kind of amazed.\u201d\n\nNational Civil Rights Museum\n\nSince 2014, the museum, in Memphis, has welcomed new recruits from the city\u2019s police department. Typically, the group numbers about 60 to 65 officers in training. At first they simply toured the museum. \u201dIt has evolved,\u201d the museum\u2019s president, Terri Lee Freeman, said, \u201cinto being more of a conversation about what they see, and we are hoping to formalize that a bit more.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Freeman said the tours were not intended to provide only white police officers with a better understanding of the civil rights era. \u201cThis is important for all police officers, whether they\u2019re black or white,\u201d she said. \u201cUnderstanding the history of the relationships between law enforcement and communities of color is important, and it\u2019s just not well understood. I\u2019m talking about facts, not feelings.\u201d\n\nAnd what are the feelings of those officers who have learned more about black history through these museums?\n\nCarlos Crespo, a detective in the Brookline Police Department, visited the Boston museum in the spring of 2017 with a group of his colleagues. Crespo, who is Latino, said that he had grown up with African-Americans in the Roxbury section of Boston, but that he had known little about Frederick Douglass, the Underground Railroad or the role of Boston\u2019s black citizens in the abolitionist movement and the Civil War.\n\n\u201cIt was really interesting,\u201d he said of the tour. \u201cAnd it absolutely helped me to have a better understanding of that community.\u201d\n\nChief O\u2019Leary, who retired in January, said he hoped his successors would continue to visit the museum, and he was glad that he and his officers took the tour last year.\n\n\u201cThat poster took me by surprise and made me think,\u201d he said of the 19th-century warning to black citizens to avoid the authorities. \u201cI realized right there that we were doing this for a reason.\u201d", "title": "Using Art to Help the Police Understand Racism", "authors": ["John Hanc"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Two senior advisers to Prime Minister Theresa May might have conspired to bypass electoral spending laws when they were leading a campaign for Britain to leave the European Union, a former employee of their effort said this week, in an interview and in testimony he gave to the country\u2019s elections regulator.\n\nThe allegations led to a heated exchange, conducted in the British news media, involving allegations of hard feelings over an old romance and of the deliberate outing by the prime minister\u2019s office, No. 10 Downing Street, of the former employee as gay.\n\nThe former employee, Shahmir Sanni, said in the interview and in a witness statement submitted to the regulator, the Electoral Commission, that the two advisers had funneled more than $900,000 in campaign spending through a puppet organization that they had set up. They did so, he said, by paying the money to a digital advertising firm that was indirectly linked to the Trump campaign and also worked on the push to exit the European Union.\n\nMr. Sanni volunteered at Vote Leave, the main campaign led in part by the two advisers to the prime minister, and then at the organization that he now says was a puppet, called BeLeave. He spoke with The New York Times for a joint reporting project with The Observer of Britain.", "title": "Using Digital Firm, Brexit Campaigners Skirted Spending Laws, Ex-Employee Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "It is not a crime for parents to let their children play unsupervised in a park or walk home from school alone under a law signed by Utah\u2019s governor last week.\n\nThe law, which reflects a movement known as free-range parenting, goes into effect on May 8 and is the first of its kind in the nation. But its backers say lawmakers in several other states are considering introducing similar bills.\n\n\u201cThe fact that we need legislation for what was once considered common sense parenting a generation ago and is considered normal in every other country in the world is what surprises me,\u201d said Danielle Meitiv, the Silver Spring, Md., mother who made national headlines three years ago after she and her husband were charged with child neglect for letting their two children, ages 6 and 10, walk home from a park by themselves. \u201cI\u2019m glad Utah has put these protections in place after what I discovered when I tried to parent the way I was parented.\u201d\n\nState Senator Lincoln Fillmore, who introduced the Utah bill in January, said he was motivated by situations like Ms. Meitiv\u2019s. The bill specifies what constitutes child neglect in the state, and what does not. Under the law, neglect does not include \u201cpermitting a child, whose basic needs are met and who is of sufficient age and maturity to avoid harm or unreasonable risk of harm, to engage in independent activities\u201d such as going to and from school by walking, running or bicycling, going to nearby stores or recreational facilities and playing outside.", "title": "Utah Passes \u2018Free-Range\u2019 Parenting Law", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s hard to imagine what his works would have looked like without this source of inspiration,\u201d said Ms. Bakker, one of the exhibition\u2019s four curators, referring to the influence of Japanese prints. \u201cIt really helped him to find the style that we all know,\u201d she added. \u201cHe really chose that as the way to go.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe sprawling exhibition in Amsterdam \u2014 which is larger than a previous version that toured Tokyo, Sapporo and Kyoto \u2014 includes nearly all of the major van Gogh paintings that make either direct or indirect reference to Japanese art. These are hung near some 50 Japanese prints that played a role in the development of van Gogh\u2019s distinctive style, as well as Japanese lacquerwork and painted scrolls.\n\nVan Gogh first encountered Japanese prints in 1885 while he was working in the Belgian port city of Antwerp, whose docks he said were teeming with Japanese wares: They were \u201cfantastic, singular, strange,\u201d he wrote.\n\nThe Van Gogh Museum exhibition begins about a year later, when he moved into his brother\u2019s apartment in Paris and discovered that the German art dealer Siegfried Bing \u2014 who sold Japanese artworks and decorative objects \u2014 had an attic full of Japanese woodcut prints at very reasonable prices.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe immediately bought about 660 prints for just a few cents a piece. Ms. Bakker said that van Gogh originally held an exhibition trying to resell the prints, but it wasn\u2019t successful, and instead he hung onto them, tacked them to the walls of his studio and used them for inspiration. About 500 survive, and are now part of the Van Gogh Museum\u2019s permanent collection.\n\nAt first, van Gogh simply copied the works in both sketches and oil paintings: For example, in 1887 he traced in pencil and ink the cover of an issue of the magazine Paris Illustr\u00e9 devoted to Japan and also made a large-scale oil painting, \u201cCourtesan (After Eisen),\u201d based on the image.\n\nThe Japanese art he pinned to the walls of his studio also appears in the backgrounds of a number of his portraits, such as his \u201cPortrait of P\u00e8re Tanguy,\u201d who sits in front of a wall of prints. (This is the only major painting with Japanese influences that the Van Gogh Museum could not get for the exhibition; it belongs to the Mus\u00e9e Rodin in Paris, and according to Ms. Bakker was too fragile to travel.)\n\nPhoto\n\nBy the time the artist moved to Arles a year later, he was fully in the thrall of Japan. On the train from Paris, he repeatedly checked out the window, he wrote to his friend Paul Gauguin, \u201cto see \u2018if it was like Japan yet\u2019! Childish, isn\u2019t it?\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe first year in Arles, everything is Japan,\u201d said Bakker. \u201cLater, after his breakdown, that changes, and he still refers to it but it\u2019s less important. The nature of his admiration had changed. It has become integrated into his style but it\u2019s no longer his artistic model.\u201d\n\nThe impact was more subtle, more buried in his technique: For instance, he sometimes divided the canvas using diagonal lines, rather than using horizontal perspective planes, as was the norm in western painting, and he would streak his paintings with diagonal rain, as he had seen in Japanese prints.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Japanese dream was over, perhaps, but the fascination with Japan was not. Tsukasa Kodera, a Japanese curator who worked on the exhibition, has studied van Gogh\u2019s interest in his country for more than 30 years, and spent the last six researching the final phase of van Gogh\u2019s life.\n\nHe discovered that when van Gogh moved to the town of Auvers-sur-Oise, outside of Paris, in 1890, he pursued friendships with two artists with direct ties to Japan: Louis-Jules Dumoulin, a Frenchman who had traveled to the country, painting and taking photographs there, and Edmund Walpole Brooke, an Australian-born artist who had lived in Yokohama in his youth.\n\n\u201cHe didn\u2019t try to make contact with other painters in Auvers \u2014 only these two,\u201d said Mr. Kodera in a telephone interview. \u201cHis dream was broken but he still was interested in Japanese art,\u201d he added.\n\nFollowing van Gogh\u2019s death in 1890, Japanese artists and art-lovers read van Gogh\u2019s letters, which were translated into Japanese in 1915. They made pilgrimages to his grave in Auvers-sur-Oise in the 1920s and \u201930s. The home of van Gogh\u2019s friend Paul Gachet, who was also his doctor and sometime model, became a destination for these kindred souls; more than 140 Japanese names can be found in the guest books.\n\n\u201cHe was interested in our culture and that says something to Japanese people,\u201d said Mr. Kodera. Even though van Gogh\u2019s art wasn\u2019t widely reproduced and accessible in Japan until decades later, he added, \u201cThey had also Van Gogh visions, van Gogh dreams. Just as van Gogh imagined Japan as a country, they imagined him. It was a kind of two-way imaginary vision.\u201d", "title": "Van Gogh Never Visited Japan, but He Saw It Everywhere", "authors": ["Nina Siegal"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "He has stayed in close contact with his father, often defending the Trump administration on Twitter and in interviews on Fox News, and he recently campaigned in Pennsylvania for the Republican candidate in a special election.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. This is fitting, though, because Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon have dipped into an apropos subject with today\u2019s acrostic: language standards, and who gets to dictate how we say what we say.\n\nThis passage, from Steven Pinker\u2019s \u201cThe Language Instinct,\u201d is an excerpt from an argument actually directed at William Safire, \u201clanguage maven\u201d and 30-year columnist for The Times, as a representative of all the bossy bearers of language standards. (It should be noted that the choice of the word \u201cmaven,\u201d a Yiddish word that implies expertise, was intended by Mr. Safire, according to Mr. Safire, to be taken not completely seriously.)\n\nMr. Pinker takes umbrage with the \u201cprescriptive\u201d rules of language, commandments that include \u201cdon\u2019t split infinitives\u201d and \u201cdon\u2019t dangle participles,\u201d among many others. We may imagine these rules coming down from on high, he says, but in fact there\u2019s often no higher logic to them, and the evolution of language makes many fine points, like toes on whales, increasingly vestigial.\n\nAs far as the cluing went, I had to walk away from this puzzle a few times until some answers surfaced from the murky regions of my younger mind. (Do you ever feel as if you\u2019ve put some bait out but have to wait for a nibble? And that nibble just takes longer and longer to come?) I only started confidently with TAOISM, and E.M. FORSTER; I remembered KREBS, LONE STAR, ARCADIA and NATIVE SON; and guessed PEEKABOO and GELATO correctly. I also learned a new word for me, TRANSEPT.", "title": "Variety: Acrostic", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "VARIETY PUZZLE \u2014 As is so often the case, the duo of Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon have directed and produced a vehicle that perfectly captures today\u2019s zeitgeist. Or tonight\u2019s zeitgeist, if you\u2019re reading this on Sunday in a time zone where the Oscars are on in the evening.\n\nThe author of the passage today, Stella Adler, was a prolific theater actress but really made her name establishing Konstantin Stanislavski\u2019s system of acting in the United States. The acting school she established is still world-famous and her influence really can\u2019t be overstated; she trained an entire generation of great, influential performers \u2014 Marlon Brando, Robert De Niro, Anthony Quinn, Lauren Hutton, Holland Taylor, among them \u2014 and it\u2019s probable that most of the entertainment we watch now is rooted in method, natural or modern acting. The advice she gives in the passage kind of works for those of us who are just stars in our own movies too.\n\nI tried to find a nice timeline of this (Mary Pickford to Mary-Louise Parker) but instead I was entranced by these compilations of famous actors\u2019 auditions, many from when they were really young and adorable. Here\u2019s one. Warning: There is plenty of coarse language liberally and melodramatically sprinkled throughout. Acting!", "title": "Variety: Acrostic", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "VARIETY PUZZLE \u2014 It\u2019s fitting that our merry pranksters get cute today. I\u2019ll mention only a couple of things about my experience solving this backward creation: First, I\u2019m grateful that so many clues were straightforward (ha-ha), and second, I very specifically felt discomfort and distress at the exact same point I discovered those words in this passage. I don\u2019t know whether to chalk that up to suggestibility or if the Cox-Rathvon team made that happen somehow.\n\nYou see, you run this passage, from Moira Marsh\u2019s \u201cPractically Joking,\u201d backward from 176, the final square at the bottom right, to 1. You also read the attribution of the quote from V to A, in the clues, rather than regular alphabetical order.\n\nThe most disconcerting part about solving this puzzle for me was keeping the numbers straight. Whenever my mind deduced a word from near the beginning of the quote (\u201cdiscomfort but not necessarily distress\u201d) my writing hand rebelled at filling in the prescribed boxes because they were toward the end of the grid \u2014 I moved to the upper left rather than the lower right, if that makes sense. You may have had a completely different experience.\n\nThis acrostic made me think of palindromes. There\u2019s a 543-word phrase here that reads the same backward as it does forward, as well as dozens of other examples if you care to further your reverse reading.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs far as the cluing went, I got CATEGORIES and ASSOCIATES toward the end, mainly because they were more general clues. I know my Beatles and my NOISES OFF, and greatly appreciated some of the prankish winks like CUSTARD PIE and JAMES JOYCE. (James Joyce? He was a master craftsman of high- and low-brow wordplay.)\n\nMy favorite new fact gleaned here, however, was the existence of LOU REED spiders. They\u2019re quite incredible!", "title": "Variety: Acrostic", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "VARIETY PUZZLE \u2014 Cryptic crosswords are a unique form of punishment. If you like tricky clues in regular grids, though, you owe yourself to try them. At first, if it seems as if the rules are inscrutable, don\u2019t bail out; this is a very popular type of puzzle in other spheres, so there\u2019s great, detailed solving information available online (Deb Amlen recommends this guide \u2014 try using it as a road map today).\n\nI\u2019ve worked on cryptic puzzles for years, and have grown very fond of them. The experts say that the key to understanding each clue is recognizing its two parts; one is a standard definition or synonym, and the other is some form of paronomasia that adds a layer of interest and possibly leads you to an unusual solution. You definitely develop a knack for seeing the twist on each clue, but it also especially helps, in these puzzles, to recognize the fun in the journey and not beat yourself up for being unable to finish without an assist (especially from your fellow solvers in the comments).\n\nThe easiest clues for me are the anagrams; they\u2019re akin to multiple choice, as far as I\u2019m concerned, as the answer is there, just scrambled. There will usually be a tip that the scramble needs to happen in the clue: look for a word like \u201cdoctor\u201d (17D), \u201crocks\u201d (23A), or \u201cdeciphered\u201d (27A). Any word meaning disrupt, rearrange, or change can be a clue to what to do.\n\nFor example, the 27A: \u201cAcrostic deciphered: a country\u201d (5,4). First of all, as in most cryptics, you\u2019re given a hint in letter count that indicates more than one word, in this case a two-word phrase of five and then four letters. I look at the number of letters in each word; in this case, acrostic has eight letters, but if you add that \u201ca\u201d in \u201ca country,\u201d you get nine, so that\u2019s a good tip. If you rearrange the letters in \u201cacrostic,\u201d and add an a, with an eye to the information above, you arrive at COSTA RICA. Not bad, right? You can do this with those other two clues above \u2014 \u201cdoctor claimed,\u201d for 17A, to get MEDICAL, and \u201cpaper said rocks\u201d for the other, DISAPPEAR. The order of the words in a clue can sometimes be altered to further challenge the solver.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe anagram can also be one ingredient in a more complex recipe, like at 9A and 19A, among others. Let\u2019s look at 19A: \u201cMull liquor in blended tea\u201d (8). The anagram indicator is \u201cblended,\u201d so I guessed that \u201cliquor in,\u201d comprising eight letters, might be anagrammed for the answer, perhaps a synonym to \u201cmull.\u201d I came up empty, though, but the misdirection got me thinking of words like \u201cmull\u201d: ponder, consider, cogitate. \u2026 How about RUMINATE? If you work backward a bit, \u201crum\u201d is a synonym for liquor, \u201cin\u201d an anagram of tea: \u201cate.\u201d", "title": "Variety: Cryptic Crossword", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "This new weekend thing I\u2019m doing this year (writing up puzzles for your delectation and solving enrichment) is technically moonlighting. But I am occasionally in a position to double-dip a bit and do some solving when things are slow at my day job, which is basically getting pecked to death by ducks. I thought I could pop in and out of this 30-part puzzle, when I had a few minutes to spare, once I\u2019d learned the gist.\n\nYoung David Steinberg\u2019s game looks simple. He provides you with a first letter for a seven-letter word and a last letter for a seven-letter word; the missing six letters are the same, and in the same order, for both words, and he\u2019s given clues for both. So to start with 1.: A _ _ _ _ _ _ E, \u201cFitting\u201d and \u201cPop the question\u201d, the former is APROPOS and the latter is PROPOSE. The two seven-letter words share six letters \u2014 PROPOS.\n\nIt\u2019s a clever concept; after solving I spent a day or two occasionally trying to come up with a new one in my head and it\u2019s pretty hard, unless of course you cheat with an S at the end, which isn\u2019t very sporting. Most of the words used in this puzzle were common and the clues weren\u2019t too obscure either; I thought it was challenging enough, but with a natural flow to solving. Maybe EMERITI was a stretch, but really the only one I\u2019d call out.\n\nI liked PLANTER/LANTERN; WHARVES/HARVEST; CANAP\u00c9S/ANAPEST (ba da boom!); EMANATE/MANATEE; and MAILMEN/AILMENT. I skipped around a bit and got some momentum toward the end, then waited for a little inspiration to go back to my personal Waterloos at 2, 4, 12 and 18.", "title": "Variety: Six of One, Half a Dozen of the Other", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "A former president of the Vatican bank has been ordered to stand trial on charges of embezzlement and money laundering, the Vatican has said, making him the highest-ranking Holy See financial official to be indicted on charges tying him to losses of more than $61 million from real estate sales.\n\nA statement by the bank, officially known as the Institute for Works of Religion, said Angelo Caloia, 78, who was president of the I.O.R. from 1999 to 2009, was indicted on Friday, along with his lawyer Gabriele Liuzzo, "Photo\n\nLAS VEGAS \u2014 The Vegas Golden Knights chose to celebrate a monumental moment for the franchise by thinking back to how its inaugural season began \u2014 hoping the new hockey team could bring smiles to a city reeling from tragedy.\n\nShortly after Vegas became the first expansion team to clinch a playoff berth with a 4-1 win over the Colorado Avalanche on Monday night, the mantra in the locker room was the same as the one adopted shortly before the team\u2019s home opener:\n\n\u201cVegas Strong.\u201d\n\nThe team owner Bill Foley, the veteran goalie Marc-Andre Fleury and the leading scorer William Karlsson were among those who thought back Monday to the Oct. 1 mass shooting that killed 58 and injured hundreds more on the Las Vegas Strip.\n\n\u201cIt was a disaster that night, it was a terrible massacre, we changed our initial opening night ceremonies, I thought we really connected with the town \u2014 I\u2019m so proud of the whole team,\u201d Foley said. \u201cFrom then on, it was pretty unbelievable. We got off to that fast start. We\u2019ve survived a lot of challenges this year, besides being an expansion team who nobody picked to do anything.\u201d\n\nNo expansion team had ever made the playoffs since the league expanded for the 1967-68 season.\n\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t bring anybody back or we don\u2019t heal anybody,\u201d Fleury said. \u201cBut I hope that we\u2019ve changed people\u2019s mind a bit and get them to come here and have a good time at T-Mobile and be proud of their hometown team.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlex Tuch, Jonathan Marchessault, Shea Theodore and Karlsson each scored, while Fleury improved to 28-11-4 after stopping 28 shots.", "title": "Vegas Golden Knights Qualify for the Playoffs in Their First Season", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Rodr\u00edguez Torres, a confidant of former President Hugo Ch\u00e1vez, had been considered one of the earliest stalwarts of Mr. Ch\u00e1vez\u2019s political movement. He joined Mr. Ch\u00e1vez in a failed coup attempt in 1992 and spent two years in jail.\n\nHe served in Mr. Ch\u00e1vez\u2019s government as chief of the secret police, and under Mr. Maduro was the interior minister before being abruptly fired in 2014.\n\nRecently, Mr. Rodr\u00edguez Torres emerged as one of the most vocal critics to break with Mr. Maduro\u2019s leftist movement. A tipping point came during protests last year when hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets to demand that Mr. Maduro step down.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn an interview last year, Mr. Rodr\u00edguez Torres sided with the protesters.\n\n\u201cProtesting is a right,\u201d Mr. Rodr\u00edguez Torres said. \u201cWho is not angry in this country? Who doesn\u2019t have to skip work now because they have to go searching for medicine? Who doesn\u2019t skip work because the minimum wage doesn\u2019t allow them to buy their most basic food?\u201d\n\nAfter Mr. Maduro used force to quell the protests and created a new body that sidelined the country\u2019s Congress, Mr. Rodr\u00edguez Torres began appearing publicly with members of the opposition.\n\nOpposition politicians came to his defense on Tuesday.\n\n\u201cMiguel Rodr\u00edguez Torres also has human rights, and as a Venezuelan they\u2019re important to me, too,\u201d wrote Ram\u00f3n Guillermo Aveledo, the former secretary general of the coalition of opposition parties.\n\nAs Mr. Maduro consolidated power, few were as willing to go as far as Mr. Rodr\u00edguez Torres in their criticism. One exception was Luisa Ortega, the country\u2019s ousted attorney general, who tried to stop Mr. Maduro from using military courts to prosecute protesters. But Ms. Ortega fled the country shortly before the government charged her and her husband with criminal offenses.\n\nBy contrast, Mr. Rodr\u00edguez Torres stayed, continuing his criticism from within Venezuela\u2019s borders.\n\n\u201cThe government needs a president who is the head of state, one who can govern, and we don\u2019t have this here,\u201d he said in the interview last year. \u201cWe have so many problems that we can\u2019t assume coherent policies \u2014 we can\u2019t end our crime, we can\u2019t resolve our economic problems.\u201d", "title": "Venezuela Arrests Former Minister Who Became Vocal Government Critic", "authors": ["Ana Vanessa Herrero", "Nicholas Casey"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "MEDELL\u00cdN, Colombia \u2014 Venezuela\u2019s government said Thursday that it was postponing the presidential election until May 20, allowing an extra month before the country\u2019s snap vote but doing little to quell critics calling for a boycott.\n\nIn addition to announcing the new date, the government said that it would allow international observers to participate and that members of regional councils would be chosen by Venezuelans going to the polls in May as well.\n\nPresident Nicol\u00e1s Maduro is running for another six-year term after more than a year of crackdowns against opponents that have included jailing popular political rivals and using force to put down street protests.\n\nThough several minor opposition parties said Thursday that they would participate in the election, the main coalition representing opposition groups has said it would boycott the vote. It ended in carnage.\n\nOn Thursday, grieving families collected their dead after one of the worst prison fires in the country\u2019s history claimed the lives of 68 people. The relatives searched for answers, but also offered a chilling account of what they had learned so far: The fire began after gangs running a party in an overcrowded jail fought with the guards. A hostage was taken; a fire broke out.\n\nDozens perished in the smoke and flames, screaming for help.\n\nYet the pain didn\u2019t end there. Witnesses said that grieving relatives who had come were sprayed with tear gas by security forces who tried to disperse them.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve been living here 55 years, and it\u2019s the first time I\u2019ve seen something like this,\u201d said Mar\u00eda, whose home is near the prison, and who refused to give her last name for fear of reprisals by the police for describing the tear-gassing.\n\nThe scenes were shocking, even in Venezuela, where tragedy has become the norm.\n\nGrocery stores are short of food and hospitals are bereft of supplies as the country\u2019s economic meltdown hastens. Phil Scott, a Republican, has vowed to sign the measure. It represents a remarkable departure from the state\u2019s existing gun laws, which are some of the weakest in the country \u2014 and an about-face for Mr. Scott, who decided to consider new gun control measures only after a teenager was accused of plotting a school shooting in Vermont in the days after the violence in Parkland.\n\n\u201cNo state is immune to the risk of extreme violence,\u201d Mr. Scott said in a statement on Friday, adding, \u201cIf we are at a point when our kids are afraid to go to school and parents are afraid to put their kids on a bus, who are we?\u201d\n\nThe bill, which passed the Senate, 17 to 13, on Friday after clearing the House earlier in the week, would raise the minimum age to purchase a gun to 21 and ban bump stocks, which are devices that allow semiautomatic rifles to fire more rapidly. It also contains restrictions that go beyond those in the measure signed in Florida, like an expansion of background checks and a limit on the capacity of magazines that can be sold or possessed in the state.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe passage of the bill is likely to be hailed as a victory by activists pushing for tighter gun laws around the nation after the Parkland shootings. But the pressure for reform has ratcheted up since 2015, when a police video withheld by the city for more than a year showed an officer executing a black teenager named Laquan McDonald on the street \u2014 contradicting the official story that the young man had been killed while menacing officers with a knife. The officer was finally charged with murder \u2014 but only after a judge ordered the video released.\n\nA Justice Department investigation has since found that the police routinely used excessive force against black and Latino citizens. The effort to remake this deeply troubled agency entered a new phase last week when a coalition of community groups \u2014 one representing families of people killed by police officers \u2014 was granted a formal role in a process that could soon produce a sweeping, court-enforceable police reform agreement. By including community groups, the city and the Illinois State attorney general \u2014 which have primary responsibility for forging the agreement \u2014 might overcome deeply held public skepticism about the department\u2019s ability to change.\n\nThe Justice Department uncovered a number of cases, like the McDonald shooting, where the department accepted police versions of events that were later undercut by video. The investigation found that the city often failed to investigate cases.\n\nIf there was ever a police department that warranted federal supervision through a court-enforceable consent decree, this was it. Mayor Rahm Emanuel initially embraced that idea, but equivocated after the Trump administration made clear that it had no appetite for such agreements. In the antiseptic stare of the surveillance camera, even the most ordinary interactions are deformed, made weird only by what we know now. It is unnerving because it ends in the deadliest mass shooting in modern American history. It is unnerving because even with his every movement laid out, the grotesquely composed protagonist of this film gives away nothing.\n\nVideo\n\nThe faces of hotel guests and staff are blurred to preserve their privacy, reducing them to smudges that crisscross the screen at random. Mr. Paddock is the only person who appears throughout, the Waldo whose distinctive frame and faintly lopsided gait our eyes quickly learn to seek out in every frame. The clips begin when he appears and end after he leaves. The other people are little more than a backdrop.\n\nExcept that some of them may become his victims. And some are already his unwitting accomplices.\n\nOver and over in the clips, Mr. Paddock is seen leaving the Mandalay Bay for his home in Mesquite, returning with a dark minivan loaded with suitcases. Over and over, valets take his keys; over and over, bellhops stack his luggage on gold carts, helping him transport at least 21 bags over the course of seven days. As they take the service elevator upstairs, Mr. Paddock chats with them. He cracks a joke. He tips.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. Casino hosts greet him as a regular. Security cameras capture him with arms aloft, celebrating a $1,000 win.\n\nBut his movements are otherwise sedate, deliberate, unobtrusive, so much so that when he raises a hand to scratch his face in the elevator at one point, the extra movement registers as significant, even sinister.\n\nToward the end of the footage, two guests carrying shiny plastic inner tubes get off the elevator, padding out in flip-flops. The sheriff said that deputies had been trained on the use of nonlethal force, including during encounters with people who may have a mental illness.", "title": "Video Shows Unarmed Texas Man With Pants Down Before Fatal Police Shooting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "But in the realm of movies and literature, one might say creators have poetic license. Historical endeavors, such as the Ken Burns-Lynn Novick 2017 PBS documentary, or the Vietnam War exhibitions presented by the New-York Historical Society and the National Archives, would surely be different. They were not. All presented the Vietnam War along the same conventional trajectory that treats the Vietnamese perspective and experience as an aside.\n\nOut of the myriad photos, videos and oral histories compiled and presented by the historical society and the National Archives, the Vietnamese were granted minimal space. Certainly, there was no outright exclusion, which would have been ludicrous and damning. But one got the sense that the Vietnamese elements were perfunctory, added only to allow the exhibitions to claim inclusion. By contrast, painstaking care was devoted to showing the full range of the American experience, from the mundane and ordinary to the more pressing immediacy of war.\n\nWith respect to the PBS documentary, almost universally lauded as definitive, one might object to my characterization by pointing to the many South Vietnamese who were in fact interviewed for the series. The truth is, despite professed desires to include multiple perspectives, this series privileges the American perspective, whether it is supportive or critical of the American war effort.\n\nIt could have embarked on the worthwhile project of soothing American souls and healing divisions without sidelining the Vietnamese. The South Vietnamese were portrayed as incompetent and corrupt, their government bordering on illegitimate. This was done in a subtle and sophisticated way, not in the imperial manner of the past in which the West pontificates about the shortcomings of the native. South Vietnamese interviewees were allowed to express themselves in their own words.\n\nBut hovering above the cacophony is the seemingly more objective and reliable narrator, Peter Coyote, whose disembodied voice signaled omniscience. His narrative was peppered with adjectives like corrupt or weak or beleaguered when describing the South Vietnamese.\n\nAs a writer, I know that I write about a minor character differently from how I do my main character. The protagonist is carefully developed and infused with an active voice. By contrast, I might use my author\u2019s prerogative of description and prescription for minor characters. From tone to space to treatment, I know that the South Vietnamese is the minor character in the American historical exposition of the Vietnam War.\n\nIn the section of the PBS series about the Tet offensive of 1968, for example, there were hardly any South Vietnamese soldiers whose voices were included. Instead, their experiences were described and summarized. Even the postwar \u201cre-education camps\u201d and the suffering of the hundreds of thousands of \u201cboat people\u201d merited little time. They hardly mattered once American troops were pulled out and American P.O.W.s returned.", "title": "Opinion | Vietnam Wasn\u2019t Just an American War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "For most of the game, Villanova\u2019s offense could be summed up by a meeting at the rim between Konate and the Wildcats\u2019 Mikal Bridges early in the second half. Bridges soared majestically for a dunk with one hand, but Konate stuffed him with two. He then jogged back up court, tongue wagging.\n\nThe block, a highlight of the tournament, razzed the crowd and seemed to raise the hostility another notch. This is the Mountaineers\u2019 style, after all. They revel in making opponents uncomfortable, and they recruit players who have been overlooked, the theory being that they are hungrier and more unconventional.\n\n\u201cI have so much respect for the way West Virginia plays, how physical, how relentless they play, how mentally tough they are,\u201d Villanova Coach Jay Wright said. \u201cAnd to see our guys come out, to be able to compete with them physically and mentally, it was really impressive to me.\u201d\n\nTrue to form, West Virginia forced nine turnovers in the first half against a team that averages just 10.4 per game.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut the Mountaineers\u2019 aggressive approach was not entirely without consequence. They picked up 10 fouls in the first nine minutes of the second half, sending Villanova to the free-throw line early and often. West Virginia\u2019s leading scorer, Daxter Miles Jr., collected three quick fouls and went to the bench for about 10 minutes.\n\nWest Virginia Coach Bob Huggins was asked if the foul trouble had altered the game. \u201cSure, absolutely did,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m trying to say the right things. Yeah, it does. When the whistle keeps blowing, it really takes away your aggression, you know.\u201d\n\nWithout Miles, who scored 16 points, West Virginia was depleted on offense, and it shot just 30.8 percent in the second half. An 11-0 Villanova run midway through the half \u2014 capped by a putback slam by Omari Spellman \u2014 put the Wildcats ahead, 65-60, with nine minutes remaining, and they would not look back.\n\nWest Virginia went 18-0 this season when it held its opponent to fewer than 70 points.
