And security is not difficult to explain: The original bomb shelter has a 12-ton vault door, is eight feet underground and has a series of backup generators that would, well, protect your wine from Armageddon.\n\nBut Horse Ridge is two hours from New York, and proximity matters for many collectors. So Mr. Benedict said he was generally in and around New York every week for pickups and deliveries.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Schneur of Mana markets the convenience of his operation and its climate-controlled vans.\n\n\u201cIf you decide you want to get a bottle of wine and ship it from New Jersey to New York, it\u2019s illegal for you, but we have the licensing,\u201d he said. \u201cWe can pick it up for you. We can deliver it for you. We can do it in a rush if it\u2019s for tonight\u2019s dinner or tomorrow or next week.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDelivery fees vary. As with anything else, if you wait until the last minute, it will cost you more. Mana charges a minimum fee of $40 to deliver wine to Manhattan, whether one bottle or five cases, which Mr. Schneur said was reasonable.\n\n\u201cTo cross the tunnel, it\u2019s $15 for the toll,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re not nickeling and diming you.\u201d\n\nThere are other charges, too. Horse Ridge charges $40 an hour for additional services, like taking an inventory of wine or packing up a collection for shipment.\n\nStorage fees can be as low as $1.25 a month per case of wine, which holds 12 regular bottles or six magnums. Of course, wine collectors rarely store just one box, and they are not putting it there for just a month.\n\nMana has a monthly minimum of $45, which covers 20 cases of wine. That breaks down to 19 cents a bottle. For people who want their own \u201cwine cage\u201d \u2014 a space that holds 100 cases \u2014 the cost starts at $100 a month.\n\nBut for the serious collectors with hundreds of thousands of dollars or more in wine, these charges are of little matter. They know their wine will be secure for decades.", "title": "Want to Keep Your Wine Collection Safe? Store It in a Bomb Shelter", "authors": ["Paul Sullivan", "Wealth Matters"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIf you say something online, it has a different kind of permanence,\u201d Ms. Papacharissi cautioned. \u201cIt\u2019s always there to haunt you.\u201d\n\nSo over the last two months, I decided to do something different by trying to erase that permanence. Specifically, I used web tools to eradicate the vast majority of my Facebook and Twitter posts. Those turned out to be impractical and tedious to use \u2014 though automated, the programs were flawed and missed many posts after several attempts. The chore took about five hours, spread out over weeks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile I walked away from the ashes of my digital self feeling less haunted, I confess my methods may not be worth the trouble, though there are other, more practical solutions. Yet cleaning up your timeline is an exercise I recommend in moderation if you care about your privacy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHere\u2019s how I did it \u2014 and what I learned.\n\nTesting the Cleaners\n\nSince Facebook and Twitter offer no simple method for doing a mass purging of timelines, you will likely have to rely on third-party tools. I picked two well-reviewed programs: TweetDelete for cleaning up my Twitter account and Social Book Post Manager for handling my Facebook account.\n\nTweetDelete was simple to put to work. It\u2019s a web app you install by visiting the tool\u2019s website, tweetdelete.net, and authorizing the application to connect with your Twitter account.\n\nFrom there, you can choose to delete tweets that are more than a week old. The app takes a few minutes to delete large batches of your tweets. One major caveat: Because of a technical limitation, TweetDelete can delete only the last 3,200 tweets on your account. So to clear out roughly 14,000 tweets that were more than a year old, I had to run the app four times. (I\u2019ve had a lot to say on Twitter over the last decade, O.K.?)\n\nMy Facebook timeline was tougher to manage. After skimming my last 14 years\u2019 worth of Facebook posts, I concluded there was nothing worth keeping. So I opted to purge everything.\n\nI installed Social Book Post Manager, a free add-on for the Chrome web browser. This app was more rudimentary: It essentially scrolled through my timeline and clicked on the \u201cdelete\u201d button for each of my posts for me.\n\nSocial Book Post Manager lets you delete months\u2019 or years\u2019 worth of content \u2014 or everything, which I chose. The problem was, even after I used the app to scrub through my entire timeline six times, the tool missed about a dozen posts. There is a setting to adjust the speed at which the app deletes posts, and I had to choose the minimum speed to do a complete purge.\n\nVideo\n\nThe process was agonizing: I watched years of my youth play back in slow motion, including dated, satirical jokes and photos of myself wearing vintage clothing back when that was a fashion trend, before the tool deleted each post one at a time.\n\nIs It Worth the Effort?\n\nAfter I finished scrubbing my Facebook timeline, I concluded that my delete-everything approach was probably not worth most people\u2019s time. And even after all that time, my Facebook timeline was still decorated with posts that my friends had published about me \u2014 including photos from my 21st birthday (need I say more?) \u2014 because that content was not mine to delete.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGennie Gebhart, a researcher who follows privacy and surveillance issues for the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a digital-rights nonprofit, found a simpler approach. She connected her Facebook and Twitter accounts with the app Timehop.\n\nTo help people reminisce, Timehop every day surfaces photos and posts published from years past on Twitter and Facebook. Ms. Gebhart uses the tool to incrementally audit her timeline to see if there was something from the past she might not want lingering around.\n\nShe said that she rarely found posts worth deleting, but that most people might enjoy this light exercise for peace of mind \u2014 and to protect their public reputations.\n\nFacebook representatives said that based on feedback, the company recognized that people had different needs for managing their timelines. So it offers a privacy setting for people to limit the visibility of their older timeline posts. Similar to Timehop, Facebook also occasionally surfaces old memories from people\u2019s timelines to help them reminisce.\n\nTwitter did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nBeyond the technological difficulties of doing a social media purge, you may decide it\u2019s not right for you. Ms. Papacharissi, the communication professor, said people formed sentimental attachments to their memories on social media, as they do with clothing and old photographs.\n\n\u201cThey present a timeline of who we were, of who we are now and who we would like to be,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s like this always-on story. It\u2019s difficult to disconnect that.\u201d", "title": "Want to Purge Your Social Media Timelines? Can You Spare a Few Hours?", "authors": ["Brian X. Chen", "Tech Fix"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "At the same time, participation in the eurozone has required governments to forsake policy tools that their predecessors had used during times of economic crisis. Since 2010, eurozone membership can also demand acquiescence to the European Central Bank, which can essentially ask for and veto national economic legislation.\n\nThe result? Much of Europe has become nearly ungovernable. As voters across the Continent see their ability to influence policy taken away, they have lashed out, neutering the traditional center and giving rise to disruptive populists. Italy\u2019s election, in other words, says much about everything that\u2019s wrong with the European Union.\n\nThe center left has been hit especially hard. Germany\u2019s Social Democrats, France\u2019s Socialists and most recently, Italy\u2019s Democratic Party have lost millions of voters. Part of this is driven by a rejection of the immigration and refugee policies over which centrist governments have presided. In eurozone countries, voters have had extra reason to lose faith: Despite their rhetorical commitments to social welfare and redistribution, these parties have overseen cuts in welfare spending, loosened labor laws and reformed pensions. Over the past two decades, center-left parties have justified the elevation of a technocratic European ideal over the claims of both democracy and the actual, daily economic experience of millions of Europeans.\n\nItaly is the epicenter of the problems facing establishment European politicians for both recent and more historical reasons. The external immigration pressures that have roiled politics are especially acute in Italy, which is the first point of entry for migrants and refugees coming from North Africa. Consequently, the League surged from 4 percent of the vote in 2013 to about 18 percent this week, thanks in large part to the party\u2019s campaign slogan: \u201cItalians First.\u201d\n\nAbove all, though, have been Italy\u2019s particular tribulations with the euro, which have struck at the heart of the country\u2019s democracy. In the fall of 2011, the European Central Bank wrote to Mr. Berlusconi, then the prime minister, saying that its purchase of Italian bonds was conditional on legislative reforms. When Mr. Berlusconi refused to cut pensions, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany encouraged the Italian president at the time, Giorgio Napolitano, to end Mr. Berlusconi\u2019s premiership. Germany essentially strong-armed the president into appointing a cabinet of technocrats led by Mario Monti, a former European commissioner. Since then, Italy has not had an elected politician as minister of economy and finances. The role has been taken by Mr. Monti himself, a former central banker and former official at the International Monetary Fund.", "title": "Opinion | Want to Understand What Is Wrong With Europe? Look at Italy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Founded by students at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, it now has more than 1,400 employees and 65 retail stores in the United States and Canada.\n\nIts focus on design, customer service and a cultivated quirkiness have become a blueprint of sorts for other consumer brands. Harry\u2019s, the maker of grooming products, shares a co-founder with the eyewear company and was once known as the Warby Parker of shaving. Casper, the mattress seller, was once known as the Warby Parker of sleep.\n\nWarby Parker was also an early proponent of shifting beyond selling only online to opening brick-and-mortar stores. Figuring out how to balance e-commerce and physical retailing has become perhaps one of the biggest priorities for retailers around the world. Amazon has bought Whole Foods. Walmart, which has made online sales a priority, has acquired Jet and has devoted enormous resources to digital sales.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNeil Blumenthal, another of Warby Parker\u2019s co-founders, said the company hoped to focus on pleasing customers rather than sticking to a single way of selling glasses.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re experience-focused but medium-agnostic,\u201d he said.\n\nBut technology is a key part of its business. It has added apps that let customers get prescriptions through their smartphones or use the iPhone X\u2019s advanced front-facing camera to pick out which frames are most flattering on their faces. It has also set up an optical lab in Sloatsburg, N.Y., to help produce the lenses for its eyeglasses.\n\nThe company has also slowly worked toward attaining profitability. Mr. Gilboa said that 2018 will be the retailer\u2019s first full year of turning a profit.\n\nTo help finance its continued growth, however, Warby Parker turned to T. Rowe Price, which had already invested in the company.\n\nThat the new round was led by a mutual fund giant known for investing in companies on the verge of an initial public offering may raise questions about whether Warby Parker is finally headed toward the stock markets.\n\nMr. Blumenthal said an initial offering was a more likely future step than selling to some bigger company. But he said there were no immediate plans to pursue a public listing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOur objective is to build a brand that will have large-scale impact on the world, and we think being independent is important to that,\u201d he said. \u201cBut we don\u2019t have a timeline in place.\u201d", "title": "Warby Parker, the Eyewear Seller, Raises $75 Million", "authors": ["Michael J. De La Merced"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI had just looped my dog\u2019s leash over a hydrant and was about to go into the Mazzola Bakery on Union Street in Brooklyn. A cabby who had just double-parked met me at the door. I paused, indicating that he should go ahead of me. When he politely declined, I insisted.\n\nAfter we joined the line at the counter, he turned to me and told me how much he loved the bakery\u2019s fresh bread and how he would drive out of his way to get it, often finishing a whole loaf before his shift ended.\n\nHe got four loaves, I got a croissant and we both left the shop. I returned to walking my dog.\n\nI was halfway down the block when he pulled up, rolled down the window and offered me a ride.\n\n\u201cAre you going far?\u201d he asked.\n\n\u201cNo,\u201d I said, \u201cJust around the block.\u201d\n\n\u201cOh, O.K. Well, have a good day\u201d\n\n\u201cYou, too.\u201d\n\nAnd then he drove off, warm loaves of bread within reach on the front seat.", "title": "Warm Loaves of Bread", "authors": ["Russell Brockmann", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 Europe is pushing for more stringent vetting of foreign investments, with an eye on Beijing. Australia has been blocking bids by Chinese buyers for strategic assets. And in Canada, a Chinese takeover of a major contractor faces a national security test.\n\nAs China looks to spread its wealth and influence, the United States is not the only country seeking to shield its industries under the guise of national security. Governments around the world, and especially in Europe, are increasingly inclined to use such concerns as a litmus test for Chinese investments to protect their competitive edge.\n\nIt\u2019s a mixture of political posturing, national pride and outright paranoia. But China presents a difficult policy puzzle. Countries must balance safeguarding their strategic industries and preventing the loss of sensitive technologies, while still courting Chinese investors and improving trade with Beijing.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a general impression that China is rising on all fronts, and the question is how to deal with that,\u201d said Philippe Le Corre, a China specialist and senior fellow at the Harvard Kennedy School. \u201cMost countries don\u2019t know how to react.\u201d", "title": "Wary of China, Europe and Others Push Back on Foreign Takeovers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.\n\nIn pop music, there are oodles of heroes, and also more than a few misunderstood giants. From time to time on Popcast, we attempt to correct the historical record and give maligned artists their proper due.\n\nWhich is to say: As long promised, the Popcast presents the Ashlee Simpson edition, part one.\n\nPopcast Was Ashlee Simpson Underappreciated? Discuss In the mid-2000s, the pop singer had platinum albums and an MTV reality show. Hear the first of two conversations about Ms. Simpson\u2019s misunderstood career. Audio\n\nWere you aware that Ms. Simpson\u2019s debut album, \u201cAutobiography,\u201d went triple platinum? And that the follow-up, \u201cI Am Me,\u201d went platinum as well? Did you know that Ms. Simpson\u2019s third album, \u201cBittersweet World,\u201d was heavily produced by Timbaland? Did you know that Ms. Simpson even had a third album?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn this week\u2019s Popcast, the Ashlee Simpson enthusiasts of The New York Times \u2014 Mr. Caramanica, the pop music editor Caryn Ganz and the pop music reporter Joe Coscarelli \u2014 gather for the first of two episodes devoted to Ms. Simpson\u2019s career; this one focuses on her music, and the second will center on her television show and her run as a tabloid celebrity, and will also include a listener mailbag.\n\nEmail your questions, thoughts and ideas about what\u2019s happening in pop music to popcast@nytimes.com.", "title": "Was Ashlee Simpson Underappreciated? Discuss", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Some of these mutations might be responsible for the skeleton\u2019s bizarre form, causing a hereditary disorder never before documented in humans.\n\nAntonio Salas Ellacuriaga, a geneticist at the University of Santiago de Compostela in Spain who was not involved in the new study, called it \u201ca very beautiful example of how genomics can help to disentangle an anthropological and archaeological dilemma.\u201d\n\n\u201cDNA autopsies,\u201d as Dr. Ellacuriaga calls them, could help shed light on medical disorders \u201cby looking to the past to understand the present.\u201d\n\nThe research, published in the journal Genome Research, began in 2012, when Garry P. Nolan, an immunologist at Stanford University, got wind of the U.F.O. documentary, \u201cSirius,\u201d while it was still in production.\n\nDr. Nolan emailed the producers and offered to look for DNA in the mummy. The skeleton\u2019s owner agreed to X-ray images as well as bone marrow samples taken from the ribs and right humerus.\n\nOnce Dr. Nolan and his colleagues received the samples, they were able to retrieve fragments of DNA from bone marrow cells without much struggle. \u201cWe could tell this was human right away,\u201d said Atul Butte, a computational biologist at the University of California, San Francisco, and a co-author of the new study.\n\nThe scientists eventually managed to reconstruct much of Ata\u2019s genome. She was a girl, they found, most closely related to indigenous Chileans. But she also had a substantial amount of European ancestry.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe scientists have not carried out any precise dating of the skeleton, so they can\u2019t say exactly when Ata lived. But her European heritage suggested it was sometime after Chile was colonized in the 1500s.\n\nMore Reporting on Archaeology\n\nAfter death, DNA disintegrates into fragments, which become smaller over the centuries. Ata\u2019s DNA fragments are still large, another clue that she\u2019s less than 500 years old.\n\nWhile her elongated head was striking, it wasn\u2019t the strangest feature of Ata\u2019s skeleton. Despite being the size of a human fetus, about the length of a pen, her bones were as developed in some ways as those of a 6-year-old.\n\nRalph S. Lachman, an expert on hereditary bone diseases at Stanford University, examined her X-rays. He concluded that her constellation of symptoms did not match any known disease. The scientists reasoned that Ata might have had mutations for a disorder that had never before been described.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSanchita Bhattacharya, a researcher in Dr. Butte\u2019s lab, searched for mutations in Ata\u2019s DNA and identified 2.7 million variants throughout the genome. She whittled this list to 54 rare mutations that could potentially shut down the gene in which they were located.\n\n\u201cI was amazed by how much you can tell from the genetic blueprint,\u201d said Ms. Bhattacharya.\n\nMany of those genes, it turned out, are involved in building skeletons. Some have already been linked to conditions ranging from scoliosis to dwarfism to having an abnormal number of ribs.\n\nBut some of Ata\u2019s mutations are new to science. It\u2019s possible some caused her skeleton to mature quickly even while failing to grow to normal stature.\n\nMs. Bhattacharya speculates that such a disorder would have caused the child to be stillborn. And she stressed that these mutations are, for now, only theoretical candidates.\n\nOther experts concurred. \u201cThere is no single slam-dunk finding that explains the bizarre appearance of this individual,\u201d said Daniel G. MacArthur, a geneticist at the Broad Institute who was not involved in the study.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYet understanding what happened to Ata might shed light on skeletal deformities seen today. That may require engineering stem cells with each of the 54 mutations, growing them in a dish, and then looking for telling changes in their development.\n\nAnd Dr. Nolan has heard stories about similar skeletons in other parts of the world. If he were able to examine them, he might discover some of these mutations in their DNA, as well.\n\nEven more direct confirmation might be possible if researchers paid closer attention to stillbirths.\n\nAlthough there are 24,000 stillbirths in the United States alone each year, doctors generally don\u2019t record the features of the fetuses, let alone study their DNA. With so little data, there\u2019s no way to know if Ata was unique.\n\n\u201cThis could be a trigger to look into more such cases,\u201d said Albert Zink, an anthropologist at the European Research Academy in Bolzano, Italy, who was not involved in the new study.\n\nWhile Dr. Nolan began the project as \u201ca lark,\u201d he believes the evidence now requires that the mummy be returned to Chile for proper treatment as human remains.\n\n\u201cOne has to respect these things,\u201d he said.", "title": "Was a Tiny Mummy in the Atacama an Alien? No, but the Real Story Is Almost as Strange", "authors": ["Carl Zimmer"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "In the meantime comes \u201cRussian Roulette,\u201d a new book by two veterans of Washington political journalism, Michael Isikoff and David Corn, whose subtitle promises to reveal \u201cthe inside story of Putin\u2019s war on America and the election of Donald Trump.\u201d\n\nAlas, it does not \u2014 at least so far as offering foolproof evidence of Putin\u2019s involvement, or his motives. \u201cFor all the public controversy,\u201d they write two pages before the end of their book, \u201cthere was still much about Putin\u2019s cyberattacks that was cloaked in mystery, especially what had happened in Russia.\u201d\n\n\u201cRussian Roulette\u201d is, thus, not an investigative breakthrough as much as a new contribution to that well-worn genre: the granular, source-on-the-wall election diary. On that score, they have produced the most thorough and riveting account so far \u2014 riveting, that is, as long as you don\u2019t mind falling into paroxysms of political outrage and dismay.\n\nAlthough the authors make their view clear from the start, referring to Russian help as the perceived \u201coriginal sin\u201d of Trump\u2019s presidency, it is to their credit that they present both campaigns in an unfavorable light. The book will surely infuriate readers on either side of what should be the most urgent question facing the nation today: the vulnerability of our democratic institutions to Russian manipulation.\n\nFor aggrieved Clinton supporters, reading \u201cRussian Roulette\u201d will be like reliving a nightmare. Trump supporters, too, should wince at the cringe-worthy embarrassments that would have derailed any other candidate.\n\nIn one scene inside Trump Tower, the candidate\u2019s aides debate how to respond to the infamous \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d tape in which the future president boasts about grabbing women by their genitals. According to the authors, Trump\u2019s daughter Ivanka, her face reddening and eyes filling with tears, urged her father to make a full-throated apology. He did not. He simply dismissed what he said as \u201clocker room banter\u201d without denying anything he did.\n\nIt should have been a moment for Team Clinton to celebrate a knockout blow to Trump\u2019s insurgency \u2014 except that the video landed on an inauspicious day for them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBarely an hour earlier, the director of national intelligence and secretary of homeland security issued a statement saying that the intelligence community was \u201cconfident that the Russian government directed\u201d the hacking of the Democratic National Committee\u2019s email system. The subsequent leak of thousands of emails was a tactic \u201cconsistent with the methods and motivations of Russian-directed efforts.\u201d\n\nThis was the Watergate burglary of the internet age, yet the revelation was all but drowned out by the release of the tape. \u201cThe Clinton staffers hit the phones, calling reporters they had worked with, urging them to give more attention to the Russia story. They weren\u2019t having much luck.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd still to come was the third October surprise of the day. WikiLeaks announced that it would begin dribbling out thousands of emails to and from John Podesta, the Clinton campaign chairman, that proved hugely embarrassing to the candidate.\n\nThat day \u2014 Oct. 7 \u2014 may prove to be a turning point in American history. It was, by some unearthly coincidence, also Vladimir Putin\u2019s 64th birthday.\n\n\u201cRussian Roulette\u201d is best when describing how the country\u2019s intelligence agencies were slow to recognize Russia\u2019s effort and the frustration among Clinton\u2019s supporters of the failure of the administration, the F.B.I. and the media to trumpet it for what it was. (Some reporters did, in fact, including Corn and Isikoff, but much more became clear only after Trump\u2019s victory.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt was President Obama, however, who set the administration\u2019s tone: He did not want to be seen as trying to tip the scales of the election by suggesting a foreign leader was intervening in support of one side. \u201cWe were wearing self-imposed handcuffs,\u201d one agonized aide tells the authors.\n\nA disclosure is required here: The book describes an article that a colleague, Eric Lichtblau, and I wrote for The New York Times. In it we reported on the F.B.I.\u2019s inability to substantiate what appeared to be ties between the Trump Organization and a private Russian bank, Alfa, even as its agents were following an array of other leads. Some of them were detailed in the \u201cdossier\u201d of Christopher Steele, the former British agent hired to conduct opposition research.\n\nWhile evidence of many accusations remains unclear, the authors argue that the article and headline wrongly focused on the absence of proof rather than the main point, which was that there was an investigation into \u201cpossible links between the Russian government and the Republican presidential candidate.\u201d\n\nThere are, in the end, no heroes in \u201cRussian Roulette.\u201d The bureau\u2019s director, James B. Comey, deserves significant scrutiny (and he has his own book coming). During the investigation into her private email server, Clinton and her staff were so suspicious of the bureau that when agents first came to the Brooklyn headquarters to inform them of the Russian hacking, the campaign manager, Robby Mook, refused to meet them, fearing they were there to ask about Clinton\u2019s emails.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe suspicions boiled over when Comey made an 11th-hour statement that the bureau was reviewing \u201cnew\u201d emails found in a separate investigation, into Anthony Weiner, the disgraced husband of Clinton\u2019s close aide Huma Abedin. By doing so, Comey hurled a thunderbolt into the election only days before the vote \u2014 something aides quoted anonymously claim he wanted to avoid.\n\nHistorians may long debate who had a bigger influence on the outcome: the F.B.I. director or the Russian leader.\n\nFor anyone who believes in the better angels of American politics, \u201cRussian Roulette\u201d is a depressing book. The Russian hacking, it is now clear, simply exploited the vulgarity already plaguing American political campaigns, which churn on spin and strategy (and money) far more than vision or values.\n\nThe book does have its flaws. The simplistic vilification of Russia \u2014 without evidence or better context \u2014 reinforces the view of some thoughtful Russians that Americans have become irrationally hostile toward the country and even the culture. The sourcing is also sloppy in places. The authors are respected journalists, and one can trust their use of anonymous sources or not, but in the span of four pages describing the Miss Universe pageant in Moscow in 2013, for example, they quote four different ones. There is \u201ca Miss Universe associate\u201d (whatever that means), \u201ca Miss Universe official,\u201d \u201ca Miss Universe staffer\u201d and \u201canother Miss Universe staffer.\u201d\n\nThe \u201cMiss Universe official\u201d states that only Putin could have approved holding the pageant in Moscow, which is absurd. Putin controls much in Russia, but only in the fevered imagination of a pageant official does he dictate the location of beauty contests. The \u201canother Miss Universe staffer\u201d suggests Trump winnowed the finalists in his pageants by rejecting dark-skinned contestants and those who \u201csnubbed his advances.\u201d That is an explosive accusation to attribute to a single source among a muddle of them.\n\nStill another anonymous source reveals one of the book\u2019s most significant revelations. A Russian insider had been providing the American Embassy in Moscow with unconfirmed but what turned out to be prescient information about Putin\u2019s inner circle around the same time Trump was presiding over the pageant. Among the disclosures was the racially tinged disdain senior Russians felt for Barack Obama, all dutifully reported back to Washington in top-secret cables.\n\nThis source \u2014 described not as an intelligence asset but as a sympathetic political insider, who as a young man had been \u201cheartened by Ronald Reagan\u2019s anti-Soviet rhetoric\u201d \u2014 told his interlocutor as early as 2014 that the Kremlin was planning to undermine democracy in the West. It was, the authors suggest, one of many missed signals of what was coming.\n\n\u201cAnybody who had any doubt about Putin\u2019s intentions,\u201d the source\u2019s American interlocutor is quoted as saying, \u201cjust wasn\u2019t reading what we reported.\u201d", "title": "Was the 2016 Election a Game of \u2018Russian Roulette\u2019?", "authors": ["Steven Lee Myers", "Michael Isikoff", "David Corn"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Two weeks before his speech, Johnson had received an unusual C.I.A. study examining the likely implications of a Communist victory in Vietnam. The 33-page report, a distillation of the opinions of more than 30 C.I.A. officers, concluded that a failure in Vietnam would not open the way to devastating setbacks, much less lead to a major war. On the contrary, the study asserted, \u201csuch risks are probably more limited and controllable than most previous argument had indicated.\u201d\n\nRichard Helms, the director of central intelligence, knew this conclusion would not sit well with a president who had ordered American forces into combat two and a half years earlier and steadily increased the American commitment ever since. In a covering note, Helms assured Johnson that the C.I.A. was not arguing that the United States should end the war any time soon. \u201cWe are not defeatist out here,\u201d he wrote from his office in Langley, Va. Yet the report plainly suggested that the scale of America\u2019s involvement in Vietnam was out of line with that country\u2019s actual importance to the United States.\n\nThe study, titled \u201cImplications of an Unfavorable Outcome in Vietnam,\u201d acknowledged that a Communist victory would amount to \u201ca rather dramatic demonstration that there are certain limits on U.S. power, a discovery that would be unexpected for many, disconcerting for some, and encouraging to others.\u201d But none of this, Johnson was told, would amount to a disastrous blow to American security. For one thing, the report said, it would hardly come as a surprise that a highly motivated and well-supplied guerrilla movement could defeat a militarily superior power. \u201cThis is not a novel discovery,\u201d the C.I.A. pointed out.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMore important, the report added, defeat in Vietnam would do nothing to undermine the \u201cessential strength\u201d of the United States, which would clearly remain the \u201cweightiest single factor\u201d in global affairs as long as it gave fresh indications of its determination to play its accustomed role. To reinforce the point, the C.I.A. looked to the past: \u201cHistorically, great powers have repeatedly absorbed setbacks without permanent diminution of the role which they subsequently played\u201d in international affairs.\n\nThe report also questioned the contention that defeat in Vietnam would cause governments around the world to doubt the willingness of the United States to live up to its international commitments. Since the Eisenhower years, leaders had justified their decisions to escalate American involvement in Vietnam in part on the supposition that its alliances could unravel \u2014 and Communist challenges to American interests could multiply \u2014 if other nations had reason to question Washington\u2019s resolve when it confronted challenges.\n\nIn fact, the C.I.A. study asserted that damage to national credibility would be limited and temporary. The Soviets would continue to act with \u201ctheir usual caution\u201d and would pull back in the face of new indications of American strength, according to the report. It even speculated that willingness to accept defeat in Vietnam might improve the reputation of the United States with its NATO allies, who might view Washington\u2019s willingness to cut its losses in a region of secondary importance as a sign of maturity rather than unreliability.\n\nA secretary\u2019s notation on the document, which was declassified in 1993, indicates that Johnson read the study, but there is no record of his reaction. None of his aides could recall speaking with him about it. It\u2019s not difficult, though, to imagine why he would have ignored it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMost obviously, he might have dismissed the document as irrelevant, since he remained convinced that the United States was on course to achieve its basic objectives in Vietnam. That, after all, would be the central theme of a major effort undertaken by the administration later in the year to re-energize the nation\u2019s commitment to the war.\n\nPolitical calculations may also have played a role. Just as in earlier years, Johnson feared that backing down in Vietnam would jeopardize his re-election in 1968 and the prospects of the Democratic Party more broadly. The party had already suffered setbacks in the 1966 congressional elections, and bigger disasters loomed if Republicans could paint their rivals as irresolute cold warriors. Closely related, perhaps, was Johnson\u2019s concern for his own reputation and legacy. A man of towering ambitions, he shuddered at the thought of becoming the first president to lose a war.\n\nOr it may be that Johnson simply could not see past pervasive assumptions about the monumental stakes of the war. To be sure, he had occasionally questioned the importance of Vietnam during private conversations with aides and was well aware that many prominent Americans in and out of government had long doubted the need to fight there.\n\nBut he was also steeped in a Cold War mind-set that assumed a defeat anywhere in the world could unleash domino effects, irrevocably damage American credibility, and invite larger wars. To defy this conventional wisdom, particularly at a time when thousands of Americans had already died to uphold it, would have required exceptional intellectual and political courage.\n\nIt also, though, might have been the right thing to do. Instead of seriously reckoning with the issues raised in the report, Johnson continued to insist that core American interests demanded success in Vietnam, even after events forced him in 1968 to open negotiations. His successor, Richard Nixon, was even more adamant about the dangers to American power internationally if the Communists won, and 20,000 more Americans died in the failed effort to prevent that outcome after Johnson left office.\n\nOnly after 1975 would Americans see what the C.I.A. had pointed to eight years earlier: Defeat in Vietnam, whatever the political and social traumas it produced for the United States, brought no geopolitical disaster.", "title": "Was the Vietnam War Necessary?", "authors": ["Mark Atwood Lawrence"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Residents of Washington State are getting so-called net neutrality rules back, with the nation\u2019s first state law that prevents internet service providers from blocking and slowing down content online.\n\nThe law, signed on Monday by Gov. Jay Inslee, a Democrat, is the most sweeping state action so far against new federal rules that strip away regulations on how high-speed internet providers handle digital data. The dismantling of the nationwide rules, approved by the Federal Communications Commission last year, set off a fierce outcry from consumers and tech companies.\n\nOpponents of the change in the federal regulations fear that without strong rules, internet service providers will create faster and slower lanes online to extract fees for better service. The F.C.C. said it got rid of the rules because they restrained broadband providers like Verizon and Comcast from experimenting with new business models and investing in new technologies.\n\nThe Washington State law, which goes into effect June 6, bars internet service providers from blocking websites or charging more for faster delivery of certain sites in a way that benefits the broadband company and partner websites.", "title": "Washington Governor Signs First State Net Neutrality Bill", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "The M Shop\u2019s challenges were summed up this week by a watchdog group, Citizens Against Government Waste. \u201cFailing D.C. Metrorail Opens Absurd Swag Shop,\u201d the group wrote on its website, noting that the crisis-plagued system \u201chas been labeled \u2018the worst in the world,\u2019 and its financial situation has been characterized as a \u2018death spiral.\u2019\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Twitter account @UnsuckDCMetro, a gathering place for Metro malcontents, lit up. \u201cWhen you dropping the \u2018Sorry for the Inconvenience, We\u2019ll Be Moving Momentarily\u2019 crewneck sweatshirt?\u201d one wrote.\n\nMetro serves the second-highest number of passengers in the nation, after New York. When it opened in 1976, \u201cit was really \u2018The Jetsons\u2019 \u2014 a futuristic system,\u201d said Jack Evans, a District of Columbia council member and chairman of the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority board, which oversees the system. \u201cNow everything\u2019s 40 years old and it\u2019s really falling apart.\u201d\n\nSome of Metro\u2019s 1970s railcars are still in use. Long-deferred network maintenance has led to breakdowns, track deterioration and multiple disasters, including a 2009 collision that killed nine people. The busiest route, the Red Line, \u201cleaks like a sieve, and whenever it rains, you get puddles and the wires fall into the puddles and they catch fire and you get smoke incidents,\u201d Mr. Evans said. \u201cNobody wants to hear that.\u201d\n\nThere have been some improvements. In 2017, Metro wrapped up a yearlong, $150 million maintenance blitz aimed at bringing its infrastructure back from the brink of collapse. Metro officials say the program, SafeTrack, was successful, and has made the system significantly less dangerous and more reliable.\n\nStill, Metro\u2019s general manager, Paul Wiedefeld, told the board of directors last year that the system needed $15.5 billion in long-term funding just to maintain the subpar status quo.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re on the right track now, but it\u2019s going to take a lot of work and a lot of money,\u201d Mr. Evans said, adding that the District, Maryland and Virginia are nearing a deal to supply $500 million annually in funding to Metro, which is what the transit authority says it needs to improve reliability and safety. Metro\u2019s modest ambitions are summed up by a new slogan: \u201cBack2Good.\u201d Ads trumpeting new railcars say, \u201cThey smell better.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOther city subways sell branded merchandise. But Washington\u2019s subway lacks the history, though not the electrical fires, of New York\u2019s. It can\u2019t boast the \u201cMind the Gap\u201d panache, or the 99 percent on-time rate of London\u2019s Tube, whose former chairman, Tony Ridley, called Metro \u201cso sad.\u201d It can\u2019t top the socialist-realist glamour of Moscow\u2019s Metro, whose \u201cM\u201d logo resembles Washington\u2019s but whose working escalators do not.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSurly commuters heralded the M Shop grand opening with a stream of invective. The Washington Post\u2019s commuter newspaper, Express, had an entire column trolling the M Shop. Caption for the cuff links: \u201cBe careful not to lose these cuff links \u2014 if a stray one falls onto a track, it could cause rippling delays throughout the system.\u201d\n\nOne critic tweeted a photo of the sparsely attended opening with the caption, \u201cCan I buy some of this standing room to take on the train?\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJawauna Greene, Metro\u2019s marketing director, tweeted back, \u201cThanks haters!!! We are making money.\u201d\n\nMaking matters worse, M Shop customers must stand in a queue that leads to a gate that leads to a row of ticket windows behind bulletproof glass. Shoppers make choices from a 35-page catalog, but they learned that items on half of the pages were available only online. A staff member relayed the order to other workers in a storage area, who schlepped the goods to the ticket windows, where payment was made through a slot and a feedback-prone intercom. Purchases, packed in a shiny Pop Art shopping bag, were delivered through a door in the barrier.\n\n\u201cI appreciate the sense of humor\u201d of the venture, said Arielle, a 27-year-old federal employee who declined to give her last name because she was shopping during work hours. She laughed at the yoga pants printed with \u201cFoggy Bottom,\u201d a Metro stop near the State Department, but said, \u201cI\u2019m not sure it\u2019s a brilliant idea to walk around D.C. with that on your pants.\u201d Instead she chose a \u201cStress Reliever,\u201d a squeezable foam replica of a railcar, for $6.95. \u201cThose aren\u2019t available,\u201d the clerk told her.\n\nArielle rolled her eyes: \u201cThat is so Metro, to be out of stress relievers.\u201d\n\nMr. Evans insisted the shop\u2019s detractors were simply more vocal and that some people were pleased. On his rounds through the city, he said, he had heard from a few satisfied customers \u2014 along with the people who say, \u201c\u2018I got caught in a tunnel and the train caught fire.\u2019\u201d", "title": "Washington\u2019s Unloved Subway Opens a Swag Shop. Riders Aren\u2019t Rushing the Doors.", "authors": ["Elizabeth Williamson"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Drip some water onto it, the glue dissolves and the fruit violently splits in half.\n\nWith ultrahigh speed video \u2014 up to 20,000 frames a second \u2014 Dr. Whitaker and his students slowed down the action, watching as hooks in the fruit accelerated the seeds to speeds more than 30 miles per hour, similar to how the curved scoops used in the sport of jai alai can accelerate a ball to well over 100 m.p.h.\n\n\u201cIt just looks like this gentle, beautiful motion,\u201d Dr. Whitaker said.\n\nImage Seeds still nestled in the jagged stalks that help propel the hairyflower wild petunia's seeds. Credit Erin Tripp\n\nWhen they did the calculations, they were stunned to find that some of the seeds were spinning at a rate of more than 1,600 revolutions a second. The discs were oriented vertically, spinning like a bicycle wheel headed backward. Those at the top of the fruit tended to fly the farthest, while those at the bottom of the fruit tended to wobble \u2014 \u201cfloppers,\u201d the researchers call them \u2014 and land closer to where they started.\n\nNext, they wondered why. Why the vertical orientation? Why backspin? Why do the seeds spin so fast?\n\nFor that, they turned to an obsolete piece of 20th century technology: the compact disc. Carolyn Cross, who graduated from Pomona in 2013, cannibalized a boom box and built a disc-launching apparatus.\n\nShe also performed more prosaic experiments: flinging CDs down a hallway or off the roof of a campus building.\n\nNo matter how she launched the CDs, the spinning discs would invariably tip over to a vertical orientation, always with back spin, not top spin.\n\nThe aerodynamics of a flat disc are fundamentally different from a Frisbee, Dr. Whitaker said. The Frisbee\u2019s lip creates a stabilizing turbulence that keeps it flying horizontally (at least when properly thrown).\n\nEric Cooper, a senior at the college, worked out the mathematics of the seed\u2019s flat disc. The back spin keeps the seed oriented so that it slices through the air with minimal drag. He also showed how the forces on a horizontally spinning seed tip it over to vertical, similar to the wobbling motion of a spinning top.", "title": "Watch the High-Flying Physics of a Plant\u2019s Exploding Fruits", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cVerr\u00fcckt\u201d is German for \u201ccrazy\u201d or \u201cinsane,\u201d and the slide was built to thrill.\n\nRiders climbed 264 steps to the top before sitting in a raft that plummeted from a high point of about 17 stories and then soared over a crest on their way to a runoff pool at the bottom. Netting covering the length of the slide, supported by metal poles, was meant to keep riders from falling off.\n\nThe indictment portrayed a company that ignored its own warnings and hurried to construct a towering water slide in an effort to impress the producers of a Travel Channel show, \u201cXtreme Waterparks,\u201d which featured the slide in an episode.\n\nIn that pursuit, Schlitterbahn rushed to build a prototype without proper testing, did not involve engineers in all phases of its design and opened the slide to riders of all ages despite concerns about weight limits, the authorities said.\n\nMr. Henry, who was also one of the water slide\u2019s designers, expressed concerns before the slide opened that he could be hurt or killed riding it, according to records obtained by investigators.\n\n\u201cIt is a seriously dangerous piece of equipment today because there are things we don\u2019t know about it,\u201d the indictment quoted him as saying.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Henry and another designer of the water slide, John T. Schooley, were mentioned in last week\u2019s indictment of Mr. Miles, but Mr. Miles was the only person charged in that document. One of his lawyers, Tricia Bath, said on Sunday that Mr. Miles denied the state\u2019s allegations.\n\n\u201cNot only had Tyler ridden the slide numerous times, but, as the state is aware, he had scheduled his wife to ride it on the day of the accident,\u201d Ms. Bath said in an email. \u201cThese are not the actions of someone who believed the ride to be dangerous.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSchlitterbahn Waterparks and Resorts, which is based in Texas, said it planned to contest the charges against the company and Mr. Henry.\n\n\u201cOur staff, since we opened Schlitterbahn Kansas City, has demonstrated the highest dedication to safety, from the training of our lifeguards and ride operators, to ensuring all rides have operated in accordance with our strict protocols,\u201d the company said in a statement.\n\nIn addition to the rushed design and construction phases of Verr\u00fcckt, problems persisted after it opened, the authorities said.\n\nInvestigators said park employees ignored serious problems: The passenger restraints were too weak and the rafts were poorly designed and tended to go airborne at the crest, putting riders\u2019 heads in dangerous proximity to the netting and the poles. Park officials \u201cobviously ignored\u201d a consultant\u2019s warning that the ride was unsafe, the indictment said.\n\nAs investigators were looking into the death of the boy, Caleb Schwab, in August 2016, Mr. Miles, then the operations director, hid or destroyed documents detailing injuries sustained by riders, the indictment said.\n\nCaleb\u2019s family received a settlement of nearly $20 million last year from Schlitterbahn and other companies involved in the slide, The Kansas City Star reported. Caleb was the son of Scott Schwab, a member of the Kansas House of Representatives.\n\nTwo other people who were in Caleb\u2019s raft \u2014 Hannah Barnes and Matraca Baetz, sisters who sustained facial injuries and bone fractures \u2014 also received settlements from the park.\n\nSome riders who were hurt complained of neck pain and bruises while others had more serious injuries, including concussions and broken bones.\n\nTwo days before Caleb died, another rider, Donald Slaughter, who was 42 at the time, was in a raft that went airborne on the second hill, causing his head to jerk, the indictment said. Nearly two years later, Mr. Slaughter has pain and struggles to perform daily activities, he told investigators.", "title": "Water Slide That Decapitated Boy Violated Basic Design Standards, Indictment Says", "authors": ["Jacey Fortin", "Matthew Haag"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Among Mexican voters, there is \u201ca great dissatisfaction with the traditional partisan system and the states\u2019 lack of ability to respond to citizens\u2019 demands,\u201d said Alejandro Poir\u00e9, secretary of the interior in the administration of President Felipe Calder\u00f3n, whose term ended in 2012. \u201cA growing number of citizens,\u201d he added, are \u201ctrying to partake in this system through alternative channels.\u201d\n\nFor instance, 16 members of Wikipol\u00edtica, a leftist youth movement founded in 2013, have qualified to run as independent candidates for federal and state races. Many are under 30, and they include Mr. Kumamoto.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe share a common principle, and that is if you don\u2019t get yourself involved in politics, someone else will come and do it for you,\u201d Mr. Kumamoto said, describing the goals of Wikipol\u00edtica, whose name, a play on Wikipedia, is meant to suggest grass-roots politics.\n\nThe political establishment, as embodied by the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, which held power uninterrupted from 1929 to 2000, is perceived by many Mexicans as inclined to corruption and graft.\n\n\u201cTo be born and grow up in a country ruled by the PRI meant you thought that there was one way of doing politics,\u201d said Roberto Castillo, 27, a founding member of Wikipol\u00edtica, who is now running for a seat in Mexico City\u2019s state-level Congress. \u201cThis meant patronage politics over merit, knowledge or leadership, and we were made to believe that was morally acceptable,\u201d he said. \u201cBut that is changing.\u201d\n\nCarlos Brito is another youth activist looking to enter and change the political system.\n\nAn earthquake in September left thousands of people homeless in his small hometown, Jojutla, in the south-central state of Morelos, and local leaders were accused of hoarding aid for the victims. Mr. Brito, 30, said he could not bear the outrage, so he decided to run for mayor, leaving a successful digital start-up in Mexico City and moving back to Jojutla.\n\nBoth Mr. Kumamoto and Mr. Brito said one of the biggest challenges facing independent candidates is overcoming voter skepticism that the political status quo can be challenged.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe have been convinced by this lunatic idea that nothing will ever change,\u201d Mr. Kumamoto said. \u201cThat is what I call the anticipated defeat, and we must realize that is simply not true.\u201d\n\nMr. Brito is a former member of a student movement that emerged in 2012 to protest media manipulation during the campaign of President Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto, who took office in December of that year.\n\nReflecting on the Pe\u00f1a Nieto administration, which has been tainted by corruption scandals, spiraling violence and human rights violations, Mr. Brito said the most valuable lesson for young activists is \u201cto train yourself against frustration.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Brito expressed confidence that the surge of independent candidates would begin to have an effect. \u201cWe are witnessing the demise of the political establishment,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd we should be happy about that.\u201d\n\nBut in a political system that favors established parties \u2014 Mexican law, for example, guarantees parties funding and media access during campaigns \u2014 the electoral performance of most of the independents in the coming election is expected to be marginal, experts say.\n\n\u201cThere is a political oligopoly designed with high entry barriers and enforced by restrictive laws that prevent us from having more Kumamotos,\u201d Mr. Poir\u00e9 said.\n\nWhile many of the independents may struggle to win their elections, Mr. Kumamoto has established himself as a rising force, at least in Jalisco.\n\nThe great-grandson of Japanese immigrants, Mr. Kumamoto said his activism began when he joined a sit-in at age 19 to halt the removal of hundreds of trees for a highway overpass. He later became president of the student council at his college.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNow Kuma, as he is known among his peers, enjoys a kind of celebrity in Guadalajara. People of all ages stop him in the streets for selfies, and passing cars honk and drivers raise their fists in support.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt his campaign headquarters in Guadalajara, a group of young people were organizing crowdfunding efforts, rallies and media campaigns.\n\nSitting among them was Susana Ochoa, 27, an activist who served as the communications manager in Kumamoto\u2019s campaign two years ago. With a passion for politics and feminism, Ms. Ochoa said she felt it was time to step on the stage herself and run for a seat in Jalisco\u2019s Congress.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI decided to do it to redefine what it means to be a woman and a woman in politics in Mexico, and so that girls of future generations find it easier to raise their hand, not only in politics, but in every aspect of their lives,\u201d Ms. Ochoa said.\n\nShe said she viewed the rise in independent candidacies not as a \u201cpanacea\u201d for all that ails Mexico, but rather as a \u201ctool to open cracks with.\u201d\n\nAs a lawmaker, Mr. Kumamoto sees one crack to open: He says he wants to show that politics can mean something other than corruption and theft, and he\u2019s donated 70 percent of his salary to a fund focused on political participation.\n\nLanding in the state Congress at age 25, he knew it was important to show he could be effective, despite his inexperience.\n\nHe garnered multiparty support to pass legislation in which political parties gave up much of their public funding. Called \u201cNo Money Without Votes,\u201d the state law cuts funds assigned to the parties by more than half, and calculates future funding based on the votes each party wins in the previous election.\n\nHe won passage of another initiative to end protection from prosecution for Jalisco\u2019s elected officials. Early criticism of his lack of experience and political na\u00efvet\u00e9 was quickly silenced.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut opponents argue his popularity is overblown and fueled by a media frenzy over his age, independent status and campaign, which broke with the norm of patronage politics.\n\n\u201cHis legislative triumphs speak more about the favorable circumstances of the political climate here than of his true leadership,\u201d said M\u00f3nica Almeida L\u00f3pez, a state representative from the leftist Party of the Democratic Revolution, who opposed the \u201cNo Money Without Votes\u201d initiative, claiming it would damage smaller parties.\n\nPhoto\n\nAmong his political inspirations, Mr. Kumamoto said, are the leftist former president of Uruguay, Jos\u00e9 Mujica, and movements like Occupy Wall Street. Now, he has begun to inspire others.\n\nAt a small rally in the center of Guadalajara, a banner read: \u201cWe will replace them.\u201d Nine young candidates running for the Jalisco Congress had collected the signatures they needed to run and were celebrating.\n\nAmong them was Alejandra Vargas, 29, a political novice with a degree in industrial engineering, who said she was flabbergasted when Mr. Kumamoto suggested she run.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t even know what a congressional representative did,\u201d Mrs. Vargas said. \u201cBut when I thought about it, I told myself I had no excuses for turning it down as I had always preached about civic participation being the backbone of democracy.\u201d\n\nMr. Kumamoto stood in the back of the crowd that was cheering the new independent candidates. \u201cThis is what it is all about, to pass along the baton,\u201d he said.\n\nA gray-haired man walking by stopped at the sight of the rally.\n\n\u201cHe is not a politician, he is one of us,\u201d said Jorge Gonz\u00e1lez, 63, referring to Mr. Kumamoto. \u201cHe is a normal person and that is what makes him so great.\n\nMr. Gonz\u00e1lez noted that a typical Mexican politician does not ride a bike or wear tennis shoes, as Mr. Kumamoto is known to do.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI just trust him, he said. \u201cHe has my vote.\u201d", "title": "Wave of Independent Politicians Seek to \u2018Open Cracks\u2019 in Mexico\u2019s Status Quo", "authors": ["Paulina Villegas"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMembers of the public will be able to take our cars anywhere in our service area,\u201d Mr. Krafcik said. \u201cWe will be driving everywhere \u2014 dense, urban centers, high-speed roads, low-speed roads, suburbs. There\u2019s every driving scenario to be imagined.\u201d\n\nThe company said it planned to buy as many as 20,000 electric cars from Jaguar Land Rover and outfit them with the radars, cameras and sensors it has developed to enable the vehicles to drive themselves on public roads. The deal could be worth $1 billion.\n\nIt\u2019s an audacious vision that goes far beyond even the most optimistic plans of its rivals. General Motors, for example, also intends to start a ride service that uses robotic cars that have no driver. But G.M. says its service won\u2019t get off the ground until late 2019 \u2014 a time when Waymo said its fleet would be providing as many as one million rides a day.\n\nMike Ramsey, an analyst at Gartner who tracks autonomous-vehicle development, said it would not surprise him if Waymo achieved its ambitious timetable. But he added, \u201cI anticipate a rollout that will be less than perfect and at times will be a bit slow and clunky.\u201d\n\nWaymo\u2019s aggressive plans are all the more striking given the setback to another contender in the driverless push, the ride-hailing service Uber. One of Uber\u2019s self-driving vehicles struck and killed a woman last week in Tempe, Ariz., in what is believed to be the first pedestrian death involving autonomous driving. As a result, its road testing has been halted in Arizona, California, Pittsburgh and Toronto.", "title": "Waymo, a Google Spinoff, Ramps Up Its Driverless-Car Effort", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "There are few items in our homes that didn\u2019t originate as disparate components in faraway supply plants, touched by many hands in multiple countries. But whose hands actually make and order the assembling of the products, from the B-24 builders in Ypsilanti, Mich., whose goods flew into combat during World War II, to the corporate owners who erected three million square meters of yellow netting to prevent overworked Chinese Foxconn workers from jumping to their deaths in 2010?\n\nFreeman tells us who both the makers and the corporate owners are, and, more impressively, he shows us how, over a relatively short period of time, their stories come to be entangled. He wants us to leave his book grappling with the question: How should human beings balance economic good with environmental harm, need with greed?\n\nPhoto\n\nHe is more concerned with the building up of factories than the tearing down, chronicling the pros and cons of factory work with a scholar\u2019s even gaze. When a developing country embraces manufacturing to propel itself away from agrarian subsistence, the work is invariably rote and exploitive and often even life-threatening. But, over all, life expectancy climbs and poverty and disease plummet.\n\nThat was as true in the wake of the Industrial Revolution in Western Europe \u2014 before which only half of French children, plagued by hunger and disease, lived to see the age of 20 \u2014 as it is now in Ethiopia, where the producers of Ivanka Trump\u2019s shoes recently relocated from Dongguan, China, chasing a more desperate work force content to work for a pittance (roughly $30 a month) rather than paying the rising wages of their predecessors in China ($560).\n\nCapitalism, naturally, takes advantage of such increasingly swift and secretive moves. It was the striving capitalists, after all, who pioneered the world\u2019s initial giant factories \u2014 first among them a British wigmaker named Richard Arkwright who patented his spinning machine in 1768, then created an empire of steam-powered cotton mills. Arkwright knew he had arrived when he was able to lend the Duchess of Devonshire 5,000 pounds to pay down her gambling debts, even if he and his fellow mill owners used laborers as young as 7 years old.\n\nFreeman dips into a delicious expanse of source material from Charles Dickens to Karl Marx to Tim Cook, from Bloomberg Businessweek to The National Rip-Saw. In roughly chronological order, British silk mill owners give way to the Boston barons who developed the factory town of Lowell, Mass., in 1822, building dorm-style housing for the out-of-town farmers\u2019 daughters they hired and innovating a standardized production process that bested the British and would \u201cmorally uplift\u201d via such utopian amenities as company-sponsored libraries and potted plants.\n\nThe wealthy Boston merchant Francis Cabot Lowell not only figured out how to churn out white sheeting more efficiently \u2014 the fabric used to make slaves\u2019 clothing \u2014 but he was also the brains behind the radical innovation of the stockholder corporation. Before Lowell, that model was rare, usually reserved for public works, not the accumulation of private wealth.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFreeman loops around the globe nimbly, drawing parallels between the farmers\u2019 daughters who sent money home from Lowell and the Chinese migrants who do the same from Guangdong almost two centuries later. Though I wish he would have lingered longer on the workers\u2019 lives, he has a sharp eye for the raw, gut-kicking detail. A riveter in the Urals freezes to death on a scaffolding. Middle managers in Michigan have to learn the words for \u201churry up\u201d in English, German, Polish and Italian to keep Henry Ford\u2019s assembly line humming along.\n\nAs he does with Diego Rivera\u2019s industry-worshiping murals in Detroit, Freeman\u2019s mini-portrait of the photographer Margaret Bourke-White shows how the public came to view manufacturing through her factory-fanatic lens, from Ford\u2019s River Rouge plant in Dearborn, Mich., to Stalin\u2019s giant tractor factory in a former melon field. With Henry Ford\u2019s top architect, Albert Kahn, as their consultant, the Soviets squeezed wealth out of the countryside on the road to creating a socialist society after an initial epic fail. \u201cThe Russians have no more idea how to use the conveyor than a group of schoolchildren,\u201d Freeman quotes Bourke-White saying. \u201cOne Russian is screwing in a tiny bolt and 20 other Russians are standing around him watching, talking it over, smoking cigarettes, arguing.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the Russians eventually figured out how to make manufacturing advance both their socialist culture and their economy, inspiring the East Europeans, all of whom later inspire Taiwanese and Hong Kong businessmen setting up Chinese government-backed shops in Shenzhen and Guangdong.\n\nFreeman\u2019s final chapter, \u201cFoxconn City,\u201d is the finest and most searing profile of wealth-makers in the bunch, revealing the sheer drudgery of overworked people who make sneakers and iPhones but can\u2019t afford to buy them and the quiet deal-making machinations fueling Silicon Valley\u2019s billionaire class.\n\nQuoting the Apple executive Tim Cook, the mastermind behind offshoring production to Taiwanese-owned contractors in China before his ascent to chief executive, Freeman shows how just-in-time production flourishes on the backs of poorly paid workers who are shifted from one factory to another in an entirely different region practically at the stroke of his keyboard. When it comes to inventory, Cook said, \u201cyou kind of want to manage it like you\u2019re in the dairy business. If it gets past its freshness date, you have a problem.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen wages rise because of retention problems or labor unrest, the Chinese government is happy to help Apple and others by handing out tax breaks and transportation projects to spur new, lower-paying factories in China\u2019s hinterlands. No such help is on tap for a worker, trained with a specialized skill, stuck in a country that no longer supports the industry she works in and living in places like Flint, Mich., which can\u2019t even guarantee the water is safe.\n\nFor the displaced, Freeman writes, \u201cthe future has already come and gone, perhaps leaving them with sneakers and a smartphone, but with little hope\u201d for forging a post-factory life that is both sustainable and ecologically sound.\n\nThough he never states it outright, Freeman\u2019s inclusion of poetry by a Foxconn worker who committed suicide in 2014 telegraphs where his allegiances lie:\n\nThey\u2019ve trained me to become docile\n\nDon\u2019t know how to shout or rebel\n\nHow to complain or denounce\n\nOnly how to silently suffer exhaustion.\n\n\u201cBehemoth\u201d is contextually thin in places, especially Freeman\u2019s take on deindustrialization. He doesn\u2019t mention that, as life expectancy in East Asia climbed, mortality rates rose in America, or that drug dealers, not farm girls seeking sewing jobs, now flock to Lowell \u2014 a distribution hub for heroin.\n\nFreeman only cursorily explores the aftermath of globalization, automation and unfettered free trade, and he doesn\u2019t ask what the government owes the people still living in America\u2019s former mill and mining towns. More robust retraining and access to need-based college financial aid? Incentives to resettle elsewhere? A New Deal for the displaced and drug-addicted?\n\nPerhaps it\u2019s beyond the purview of a historian to wrestle with such questions. Perhaps it is enough that this thoroughly researched history makes us question our own accumulation of the stuff in front of us and our complicity in the truth we dare not see.", "title": "We Are What We Manufacture", "authors": ["Beth Macy", "Joshua B. Freeman"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "The play is not supposed to depart from \u201cthe spirit of the novel\u201d nor \u201calter its characters.\u201d What does that mean for the playwright\u2019s ability to interpret and change source material?\n\nThe language of the contract that is at issue \u2014 \u201cthe play shall not derogate or depart in any manner from the spirit of the novel nor alter its characters\u201d (emphasis added) \u2014 could be interpreted in a limiting manner in the Lee estate\u2019s favor, but the underlying concepts \u201cspirit of the novel\u201d and what it means to \u201calter\u201d a character are themselves ambiguous. Interpreting this provision strictly arguably could bar the addition of a new major character, which the letter seems to allege has taken place, but it also could be interpreted more broadly to allow for changes that are consistent with the spirit of the novel and meaning that existing characters\u2019 natures cannot be changed. It is quite possible that the parties had different understandings and it is no wonder that a dispute has turned to litigation.\n\n\u2014 Cheryl Davis, general counsel of the Authors Guild\n\nDoes \u201cspirit\u201d have a definite and precise meaning, or could there be a difference of opinion as to what is \u201cthe spirit\u201d of the novel? I do not think that a dictionary definition of \u201cspirit\u201d will resolve that question. Similarly, the contract states that the characters should not be altered. In its pre-action letter, Harper Lee\u2019s estate repeatedly states that the characters \u201cwould never have\u201d and \u201cwould not have\u201d done numerous things; unless as a matter of historical fact the characters would not have done something (because it had not yet occurred at the time when the novel takes place or when it was written), who is to say what a creature of fiction \u201cwould never have\u201d or \u201cwould not have\u201d done? The person who created those characters, Harper Lee, is dead.\n\n\u2014 Jordan Greenberger, intellectual property lawyer\n\nMy own sense, having read the complaint, is that it includes a mix of valid concerns about anachronism and character arcs with highly contestable interpretations, ones we have no real way to know whether Lee would have shared. One might disagree, for example, about exactly how black men and women who \u201cknew their place\u201d (as the letter describes both Calpurnia and Tom) would behave and speak in light of that knowledge, especially where the audience is not having its experience filtered through the perceptions of a young white girl. [\u201cTo Kill a Mockingbird\u201d is narrated by Atticus\u2019s daughter, Scout.]\n\n\u2014 Rebecca Tushnet, professor of First Amendment law, Harvard Law School", "title": "We Asked 7 Lawyers to Untangle the Broadway Fight Over \u2018To Kill a Mockingbird\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nSince sexual harassment accusations against Harvey Weinstein roiled Hollywood last fall, questions have swirled about how the Oscars would handle this #MeToo moment. On the red carpet before the ceremony on Sunday, I asked stars and other Oscar-goers for their thoughts. Here\u2019s a roundup of their reactions.\n\n\n\nThe actress Viola Davis said speaking out should be routine:\n\nLakeith Stanfield, a star of \u201cGet Out,\u201d took the long view:\n\nAgn\u00e8s Varda, who has been making films since the 1950s, had her own perspective on history:\n\nTarana Burke, who coined the #MeToo hashtag, was concerned that not enough attention has been given to women outside Hollywood:\n\nEva Marie Saint, the star of classic films like \u201cOn the Waterfront,\u201d was optimistic.\n\nDoug Jones, who plays the fish man in \u201cThe Shape of Water,\u201d confessed he didn\u2019t know how pervasive sexual harassment was:\n\nTiffany Haddish, the breakout star of \u201cGirls Trip\u201d last year, came at the issue from a different angle:\n\nCommon, who\u2019s nominated for his song for \u201cMudbound,\u201d said sexual harassment was one of many issues facing Americans:\n\nAnd Danny Glover turned the question to the larger topic of how Hollywood can make a difference:", "title": "We Asked Oscar Stars About #MeToo. Here\u2019s What They Said.", "authors": ["Cara Buckley"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "The tiger recovery in Manas is working because intensive efforts have been brought to bear there to stop poaching and to disrupt the illegal wildlife supply chain.\n\nRemote camera traps placed covertly throughout the park capture images of passers-by and relay these photos in real time to law enforcement officials, who use the photos and other intelligence to identify wildlife poachers. This enables limited resources to be deployed efficiently: Specially trained rangers can pinpoint the poachers\u2019 exact locations to set up ambushes and arrest them, while local aid groups focus on training community members in skills like farming, food preparation and weaving to reduce their dependence on forest products, an approach that\u2019s proved effective in discouraging wood-gathering, fishing and other illegal activities in the park.\n\nThese strategies are succeeding in some of the world\u2019s most heavily poached landscapes. Tiger populations are recovering at key sites in Nepal, Thailand and Indonesia, and there is now hope for critically endangered lions in West Africa, where the poaching of their prey is one of the biggest threats.\n\nBig cats are resilient, but so are the criminals poaching them. In Bolivia, where jaguar hunting has been outlawed since the 1975 treaty on the international trade in endangered species banned the global trade of the animals\u2019 coveted pelts, reports of a resurgence in jaguar killings have recently emerged. The journal Nature has reported that between August 2014 and February 2015, Bolivian authorities confiscated 186 jaguar fangs from packages bound for Asia. Radio ads broadcast in parts of the country offer $100 to $150 for jaguar fangs, most likely for necklaces to be sold as trinkets. Experts worry that as tiger parts become harder to obtain, a new illicit trade in jaguar parts will take hold.\n\nConservation teams stationed in poaching hot spots are best positioned to anticipate emerging threats like these and respond quickly.
