Front line officers are striving to stay one step ahead of the criminals with counterintelligence; elite ranger training; and advanced technology borrowed from police and the military like night vision equipment, thermal drones and forensic genetics.\n\nDespite the insatiable and ever-changing demand for big cats and their parts, conservation groups and law enforcement agencies working together across the entire illegal supply chain \u2014 from source to transit to destination \u2014 have proved that they can disrupt the criminal networks that lie behind these serious crimes. Arrests, prosecutions and convictions of poachers are on the rise, and big cat populations \u2014 where diligently protected \u2014 are on the rebound.\n\nAs the results in Manas show, a focused effort on locking down key tiger sites can increase tiger populations. A 2010 study by some of the world\u2019s leading tiger experts suggested that it is relatively inexpensive to protect tiger sites effectively. Adjusted for current conditions \u2014 and excluding the investment already being made by governments, particularly India, as well as by international donors and nongovernmental organizations \u2014 it would take about another $50 million a year to secure the 50 or so remaining recoverable tiger sites across Asia.", "title": "Opinion | We Can Stop the Poaching of Big Cats. Here\u2019s How.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. King passionately believed that a commitment to God is a commitment to bettering humanity, that the spiritual practices of prayer and worship must be translated into concern for the poor and vulnerable. Dr. King would want us to live his specific faith: work to defeat racism, speak out in principled opposition to war and combat poverty with enlightened and compassionate public policy.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn his lifetime, he was disappointed in the complacency of both black and white churches. He would be as disappointed today. The white church largely remains a bastion of indifference to the plight of black people. White evangelicals continue to focus on personal piety as the measure of true Christianity, while neglecting the Social Gospel that enlivens Jesus\u2019 words for the masses. Dr. King saw faith as an urgent call to service, a selfless ethic of concern that, he said, quoting the Hebrew prophet Amos, made \u201cjustice roll down like waters and righteousness like a mighty stream.\u201d\n\nToday, in the midst of resurgent bigotry and deep divisions in this country, faith is too often viewed as an oasis of retreat, a paradise of political disengagement. On this Easter Sunday, as we mark 50 years since Dr. King\u2019s death, it is a perfect and necessary time to remember his faith \u2014 and rekindle its urgency.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. King often declared his preacher\u2019s vocation by citing something like a biblical genealogy of black sacred rhetoric that traced through his family: \u201cI grew up in the church. My father is a preacher, my grandfather was a preacher, my great-grandfather was a preacher, my only brother is a preacher. My daddy\u2019s brother is a preacher. So I didn\u2019t have much choice.\u201d\n\nBut Dr. King\u2019s faith underwent significant change. At first, he was discouraged from the ministry by a strain of black preaching that was long on emotion and short on reason. Then, at Morehouse College, his encounter with preachers like the school\u2019s president Benjamin Mays convinced him that the ministry was intellectually respectable.\n\nA midnight kitchen experience over a cup of coffee after he received phone calls threatening to blow out his brains and blow up his house during the Montgomery bus boycott gave the fear-stricken Dr. King a sense of God\u2019s unshakable presence. He said that instead of inherited faith, he had to forge the terms of his own relationship to the Almighty.\n\n\u201cI had to know God for myself,\u201d he explained. \u201cI could hear an inner voice saying to me, \u2018Martin Luther, stand up for righteousness, stand up for justice, stand up for truth. And lo, I will be with you, even until the end of the world.\u2019\u201d\n\nFor the rest of his life Dr. King did just that. His faith propelled him to fight Jim Crow, the ugly hatred it bred in the white soul and the haunting inferiority it left in black minds. It led him to speak valiantly against the lynching, bombing and shooting of black people who merely wanted what white people took for granted: a cup of coffee at any lunch counter, a room at any hotel they could afford, a drink at any water fountain they passed, a seat on a bus wherever they pleased and a desk in the nearest schoolhouse.\n\nDr. King\u2019s faith put him at odds with white Christians who believed it was their mission to keep separate the races \u2014 the same people whose forebears believed it was their duty to enslave Africans and punish blacks who sought to escape their hardship. Dr. King realized that he wasn\u2019t simply in battle against a society built on legal apartheid, but that he also had to fight against a racist culture that derived theological support from white Christianity.\n\nWhite evangelicals were opposed to Dr. King because they conveniently divided body and soul: Race was a social issue that should be determined by rules in society and laws generated by government. Such a view meant that the racist status quo was sacred. The point of religion was to save the souls of black folk by preaching a gospel of repentance for personal sin, even as segregation often found a white biblical mandate. After Dr. King spoke at the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary in 1961, the most prominent institution of the nation\u2019s largest Protestant denomination, many white churches in the South withheld financial contributions to the school.\n\nIf rabid racists were a clear threat to black well-being, it was the white moderates who claimed to support civil rights but who urged caution in the pursuit of justice who proved to be a special plague. In 1963, eight white Alabama clergymen issued a statement pleading for black leaders to slow their aggressive campaign against segregation in Birmingham, Ala. The clergymen cited \u201coutsiders\u201d who had come to Birmingham to lead demonstrations that were \u201cunwise and untimely.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe white clergymen blamed the black protests for inciting hatred and violence through their \u201cextreme measures,\u201d arguing that their cause \u201cshould be pressed in the courts and in negotiations among local leaders, and not in the streets.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Opinion Today Newsletter Every weekday, get thought-provoking commentary from Op-Ed columnists, the Times editorial board and contributing writers from around the world. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTheir statement led Dr. King, imprisoned for his protests against injustice, to draft his well-known \u201cLetter From Birmingham Jail,\u201d in which he \u201calmost reached the regrettable conclusion that the Negro\u2019s great stumbling block in the stride toward freedom is not the White Citizens\u2019 Council-er or the Ku Klux Klanner, but the white moderate who is more devoted to \u2018order\u2019 than to justice.\u201d It was the same white moderates who led Dr. King near the end of his life to conclude that \u201cmost Americans are unconscious racists.\u201d\n\nIt wasn\u2019t only the white church Dr. King had to combat. In 1961 he joined other black ministers who were dissatisfied with the conservative leadership of the National Baptist Convention to form a rival body, the Progressive National Baptist Convention. Dr. King reserved some of his harshest criticism for the black church. Less than two months before he perished, Dr. King and his Southern Christian Leadership Conference organization convened a meeting of ministers in Miami.\n\n\u201cWe didn\u2019t come to Miami to play,\u201d Dr. King warned his listeners in an address titled \u201cTo Minister to the Valley.\u201d And he didn\u2019t. \u201cLet us admit that even the black church has often been a taillight rather than a headlight,\u201d Dr. King preached. As social injustice roared, these ministers kept silent \u201cbehind the safe security of stained-glass windows.\u201d As their members struggled with poverty, they mouthed \u201cpious irrelevancies and sanctimonious trivialities.\u201d\n\nThen Dr. King came in for the kill: \u201cLet us honestly admit that all too often we\u2019ve been more concerned about the size of the wheelbase on our automobiles, and the amount of money we get in our anniversaries, than we\u2019ve been concerned about the problems of the people who made it possible for us to get these things.\u201d Dr. King argued that \u201cthe great tragedy is that Christianity failed to see that it had the revolutionary edge.\u201d\n\nChristianity is again failing to see that edge.\n\nWhile black bodies are punished or disappear into oblivion, under the repressive reign of police brutality, many white churches remain silent. Instead, an overwhelming number of white evangelicals line up in support of a president who has evinced even less of a public embrace of religion than Ronald Reagan did. Yet President Trump has been prayed for by white evangelicals as his administration and his words have preyed on black people, immigrants, transgender people and the poor. There are some brave contrarians among Southern Baptists, like the Trump critic Russell Moore, who have dared to dissent. But their voices are too few.\n\nThe black church\u2019s behavior has been shameful as well. With a few notable exceptions, black churches have often been chronically indifferent to the fight against white supremacy. . On this Easter Sunday, many ministers will dutifully preach about a crucified God without dwelling on the death in Sacramento of 22-year-old Stephon Clark in a police shooting that even the city\u2019s mayor, Darrell Steinberg, said was \u201cplain wrong.\u201d\n\nInstead, black churches have been invested in personal prosperity and upward climbing at the expense of the Social Gospel that Dr. King preached. For every progressive pastor like Frederick Douglass Haynes in Dallas, there are hundreds more who turn their dire warnings about sin into bigger cars and more cash for their lucrative pastoral anniversaries. For every preacher of the virtue of social conscience, like Gina Stewart in Memphis, there are so many more pastors who use the Bible only to reprimand fornicators and backsliders.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome black ministers have even frowned on Dr. King for his moral failures as an excuse to avoid the message that he trumpeted as an itinerant preacher for social justice. To Dr. King\u2019s credit, he acknowledged his flaws and warned people against making him a saint.\n\nMartin Luther King Jr. was a man of faith who didn\u2019t mind making trouble for God. He believed his purpose in life was to bring justice to as many of God\u2019s children as possible while proclaiming the revolutionary power of belief. And that wasn\u2019t a mere metaphor: He believed that America must undergo a \u201crevolution of values\u201d so that it might begin to fulfill the mandate of the Gospel to look after those who needed God\u2019s help the most.\n\n\u201cGod didn\u2019t call America to do what she\u2019s doing in the world now,\u201d Dr. King said in his famous \u201cDrum Major Instinct\u201d sermon, delivered from his home pulpit at Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta two months before his assassination. \u201cGod has a way of even putting nations in their place. The God that I worship has a way of saying, \u2018Don\u2019t play with me.\u2019\u201d\n\nAs America in its present incarnation, with its present leadership, teeters toward an arrogance, isolationism and self-importance that are the portals of moral decline and political self-destruction, the nation must recall the faith of Martin Luther King Jr. He saw faith as a tool for change, a constant source of inspiration to remake the world in the just and redemptive image of God. On this holy day, instead of shrinking into the safety of faith, we should, as Dr. King did, bear the burdens of the less fortunate and rise again to serve humanity.", "title": "We Forgot What Dr. King Believed In", "authors": ["Michael Eric Dyson"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "What we could really use from Hollywood is about 100 years of phase cancellation.\n\nWe need new work that actively challenges and counterbalances old assumptions, that offers radical models for how to conceive of ourselves and how to treat each other. We need artists and studios fighting for diverse work made by diverse creators for diverse audiences because it\u2019s the right thing to do, not just because \u201cBlack Panther\u201d is hurtling toward a possible billion-dollar worldwide box-office take. Capitalism won\u2019t germinate that kind of pure morality on its own, but we can choose it. If we really want to have this #MeToo reckoning \u2014 if we want to fix what\u2019s broken \u2014 those choices are part of it. The movement can\u2019t just disrupt the culture; it has to become the culture.\n\nOne of the most breathtaking things about #MeToo \u2014 just behind the iron-jawed fury of its deponents \u2014 is how swiftly and decisively it pulled conversations about sexual predation from the conceptual to the concrete. After decades of debates and doubts and dissertations and settlements and nondisclosure agreements and whisper networks and stasis and silence, all of a sudden, in one great gust, powerful men are toppling. Talk has become action. The seemingly untouchable have lost jobs, reputations and legacies overnight. Choices have consequences, even if you are Harvey Weinstein. This is new.\n\nBut in the rush of catharsis, it\u2019s important not to lose track of some of those old conceptual conversations, because we never came close to finishing them. We are not done talking about why so many men feel entitled to space, power and other people\u2019s bodies. We are not done talking about our culture\u2019s hostility toward women\u2019s sexual pleasure. We are not done talking about how to get justice for \u201cimperfect\u201d victims, and how to let go of perpetrators we love. We are not done talking about how to decide which abusers deserve a path to redemption, and what that path might look like. We are not done talking about the legal system. We are not done talking about sex. We are not done talking about race.\n\nUnseating a couple (or a score, or even a generation) of powerful abusers is a start, but it\u2019s not an end, unless we also radically change the power structure that selects their replacements and the shared values that remain even when the movement wanes. Art didn\u2019t invent oppressive gender roles, racial stereotyping or rape culture, but it reflects, polishes and sells them back to us every moment of our waking lives. We make art, and it simultaneously makes us. Shouldn\u2019t it follow, then, that we can change ourselves by changing the art we make?", "title": "Opinion | We Got Rid of Some Bad Men. Now Let\u2019s Get Rid of Bad Movies.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "The diversion from the daily grind was probably welcomed by Mr. Cuomo, who has been ensconced behind closed doors since Sunday as the negotiations over the budget have continued to drag on. Lawmakers had returned to the Capitol over the weekend, hopeful of a possible deal in advance of the April 1 deadline, which coincides with Easter.\n\nMr. Cuomo, a second-term Democrat, did answer a few questions about Mr. Percoco, who had spent 68 days making hundreds of phone calls in the governor\u2019s executive offices during 2014 when he was serving as a campaign manager, and not a state employee, according to evidence admitted at his trial. On Wednesday, Mr. Cuomo said he knew that was a violation of state law barring use of state resources, but insisted that he was \u201cnot aware of him violating any rules or using any equipment for nongovernment purposes.\u201d\n\nMr. Cuomo has previously called Mr. Percoco\u2019s presence in the office as campaign manager \u2014 over nearly eight months, before he returned to the governor\u2019s office \u2014 \u201ctransition work,\u201d and he stuck to his explanation on Wednesday.\n\n\u201cComing back and forth, to be part of a transition, and help, that is fine,\u201d he said.\n\nAll in all, however, Mr. Cuomo seemed more happy making wisecracks about other legal matters, namely his services on a reporter\u2019s behalf.\n\n", "title": "We Interrupt These Budget Talks for a Reporter\u2019s Arrest and a Coyote", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Adults are supposed to take care of children \u2014 not only keep them safe, but make them feel safe. Schools are essentially an extension of the home, in that sense, providing sanctuaries of learning, of nurturing and care. But after years of attacks by people with weapons of war, students cannot feel safe and are demanding that adults end years of complaisance and act. They are not asking for their schools to become armed garrisons. Rather, they want those weapons to be brought under control. And unlike too many adults, the young people leading Wednesday\u2019s walkout at schools around the country \u2014 inspired by angry, motivated students from Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, in Parkland, Fla., where 17 people were killed by a former student with an assault weapon \u2014 have had the courage to take on the industry responsible for blocking every reasonable measure to limit access to guns, including those that make it all too easy to commit mass murder.\n\nAs Stoneman Douglas junior Florence Yared said in front of the Florida State Capitol late last month, \u201cYou adults have failed us by not creating a safer place for your children to go to school. So we, the next generation, will not fail our own kids. We will make this change happen. If not today, then tomorrow, and if not tomorrow, next year. Take it from us. You created a mess for us, but we will make this world safer for our children.\u201d\n\nWith Wednesday\u2019s demonstration, and their March for Our Lives movement on March 24 in Washington, young voices are being heard. How will the nation\u2019s adults respond? Hopefully, by amplifying their demand: Never again.\n\n\u201cNo kid should be afraid to go to school, no kid should be afraid to walk outside, and no kid should have to worry about being shot. Now that\u2019s why I\u2019m marching.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Alfonso Calder\u00f3n, Junior\n\n\u201cThe \u2018children\u2019 you pissed off will not forget this in the voting booth. Don\u2019t doubt the power of the younger generation, because we are a force to be reckoned with.\u201d\n\n\u2014Aly Sheehy, Senior\n\n\u201cMaybe the adults have gotten used to saying \u2018it is what it is,\u2019 but if us students have learned anything, it\u2019s that if you don\u2019t study, you will fail. And in this case if you actively do nothing, people continually end up dead, so it\u2019s time to start doing something. We are going to be the kids you read about in textbooks. Not because we\u2019re going to be another statistic about mass shooting in America, but because...we are going to be the last mass shooting.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Emma Gonz\u00e1lez, Senior\n\n\u201cHigh schools shouldn\u2019t be hashtags every other day\u201d\n\n\u2014Jaclyn Corin, Junior\n\n\u201cMore prayer, Jesus, god, and compassion won\u2019t bring back the victims that sadly lost their lives. It won\u2019t bring back the sense of security that my fellow peers and I lost. The only way to get that back is through gun control starting now.\u201d\n\n\u2014Jose Iglesias, Senior", "title": "Opinion | We Stand With the Students", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Now, Lindsey Underwood, the editor of The Edit, and other journalists at The Times are busy reading through the mountain of applications, and making plans for the newsletter\u2019s relaunch.\n\nAs a millennial member of the Reader Center, I sat down with Lindsey to talk about the viral response to our call for contributors and The Times\u2019s efforts to reach new audiences. (The application was open to anyone of any age, but we were especially interested in hearing from college students and recent graduates.)\n\nHow did The Edit start, and how do you plan to use it as a platform?\n\nThe Edit launched a few years ago and began as a curated list of Times stories that we thought would interest college students.\n\nA lot of those readers sent us feedback saying they wanted to see more of their voices represented in The Times. Based on that, we decided that we should relaunch The Edit and find a way to incorporate their perspectives.\n\nOnce we choose our contributors from the applications we received, we will feature their stories and voices in the newsletter.\n\nThe relaunch of The Edit is part of a larger effort by The Times to engage with college students and recent graduates. Why is The Times focusing more on these readers, and how are we changing to appeal to them?\n\nI don\u2019t think it was surprising for any of us to hear that readers say they sometimes don\u2019t see themselves represented in The Times. If we\u2019re leaving out such a large part of the population in our report, that must mean our coverage is missing something.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow did you react when you saw thousands of applications coming in?\n\nMaybe we were being na\u00efve, but we initially thought we might get a couple of hundred applications. But soon after the post went up, it went viral and the responses started pouring in. We were blown away by the excitement and quickly realized we were in for something much bigger. (I also had to adjust my email settings.)\n\nMost people found the application on social media, where they shared it with their friends. We ended up extending the deadline because there were so many people who wanted to apply.\n\nWhat was the application process?\n\nWe asked applicants to write a few sentences about themselves and then choose one of four prompts to answer.\n\nWhat are some of the themes you\u2019re seeing in the responses?\n\nGoing through the applications has been really fun. I\u2019m glad the questions we asked allowed people to go in a lot of directions with their responses. One prompt was \u201cWhat\u2019s your biggest pet peeve about the way that people write about your generation?\u201d There are only so many stereotypes that we all know about millennials and Gen Z, so a lot of the answers draw upon the same themes. But with that question, you can see how strong of a writer an applicant is and how compelling of an argument he or she can make.\n\nFor another prompt, we asked applicants to write about something they\u2019re obsessed with. This question led to the widest range of responses. Some people wrote fun odes to mozzarella sticks and cold showers. Others took on weightier issues like climate change and housing reform. There\u2019s no right answer to a question like this, so it\u2019s great to see how people chose to respond.\n\nWhere did candidates send applications from?\n\nWe\u2019ve heard from people all over the world, from West Virginia to West Africa. I\u2019ve really been surprised by the number and diversity of international applicants. It\u2019s also great to see that people wrote to us from across the United States. I\u2019m glad we were able to get such a wide range of applicants, and hope our contributors will reflect that diversity in their work for The Edit.\n\nWhat qualities does the ideal candidate have? Is a background in journalism important?\n\nThe most important thing is that the applicants have ideas. When college students and recent graduates say they don\u2019t see themselves in The Times, then the next question is, What do you want to see? If they can come up with ideas for improving our coverage and topics that will interest their peers, that\u2019s the real sweet spot. The applications that excite me most have ideas that I never would have come up with, or that touch on something I didn\u2019t even know existed.\n\nA strong foundation in writing is a plus, of course, but we\u2019re not necessarily looking for journalists. This isn\u2019t a traditional media position.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWho's reading the applications, and what\u2019s the process for reviewing them?\n\nWe have a team of editors and others from around The Times, mostly from our newsroom. We\u2019re dividing up all the applications and closely reading each and every one.\n\nWe\u2019re doing the first round right now and will be in touch with people who are moving on to the second stage. We aren\u2019t sure how many rounds there will be yet.\n\nHow many people will you choose? When will they be announced?\n\nWe initially planned to select five contributors. Because of the huge response we got, we are probably going to increase that number.\n\nI\u2019ve gotten a ton of emails and messages on social media from people wondering when they\u2019ll find out about their applications. Since we\u2019re still reviewing them and planning the relaunch of The Edit, all I can promise is that we\u2019ll be in touch as soon as we have news. That should be in the coming months, if not the coming weeks.\n\nWhat are some of the subjects that the contributors will write about? What form will their stories take?\n\nWe have an awesome opportunity to feature a mix of stories.\n\nIn the weeks since the school shooting in Parkland, Fla., you can\u2019t help but notice the many high schoolers who are speaking up about gun violence, and see a need for more opportunities for students to share their views on real issues. I think there\u2019s also room to approach topics that you wouldn\u2019t find elsewhere in The Times. Maybe that\u2019s a meme or a YouTuber who wouldn\u2019t normally have a place in the report. This is a great chance to shed light on some of those things, too.\n\nWe\u2019re also really open to different story formats, like reported articles and personal essays. It will just depend on what the story is and how we think it\u2019s best told. I would love to incorporate video and other media.\n\nHow frequently will the contributors write?\n\nThat\u2019s a bit up in the air right now. There was so much excitement about the application that we\u2019re thinking about increasing the frequency of the newsletter, which comes out every other week right now. However that shakes out, we\u2019ll work with the writers to figure out a cadence that makes sense for them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow long will these first contributing positions last?\n\nWe said that we were looking for people to work with us this year. This is a new program, so depending on where we are and where they are toward the end of that period, the positions could last longer.\n\nWill there be another application for the next group of contributors?\n\nI hope the relaunch is a huge success and that we\u2019ll be able to do another callout relatively soon. There\u2019s clearly a lot of interest from college students and recent graduates to work with The Times.\n\nWill there be other opportunities for applicants who aren\u2019t chosen as contributors?\n\nDefinitely! We\u2019re thinking a lot about how we can offer other ways to get involved. We\u2019ll be in touch with applicants in the coming months about some of those opportunities.", "title": "We Want to Elevate the Voices of College Students and Recent Graduates. 20,000 Responded.", "authors": ["Lara Takenaga"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Weijia Jiang and Travis Luther Lowe were married March 17 at Casa de Monte Vista, an events space in Palm Springs, Calif. Jim Obergefell, who became a deputy commissioner for marriage in Riverside County, Calif., for the occasion, led a ceremony incorporating a Chinese tea ceremony.\n\nThe couple met at the College of William & Mary, from which each graduated.\n\nMs. Jiang, 34, is a Washington correspondent for CBS News, where she covers the White House and Capitol Hill primarily for Newspath, the CBS News news service affiliate servicing about 200 stations and affiliates worldwide; she also fills in on the anchor desk for the CBS Morning News. She is on the board of the Newhouse 44 at the S. I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse, from which she received a master\u2019s degree in broadcast journalism.\n\nMs. Jiang is the daughter of Liya Wei and Huade Jiang. Her parents, who are retired, owned and operated Chinatown Restaurant in Buckhannon, W.Va.\n\nMr. Lowe, 35, who goes by Luther, works in Washington as the global vice president for public policy at Yelp, the website and mobile application for which consumers write reviews of local businesses and services. He oversees public policy initiatives, including competition policy, consumer free speech and open data.", "title": "Weijia Jiang, Luther Lowe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNo one should be afraid to speak out or coerced to stay quiet,\u201d the company said, going on to thank \u201cthe courageous individuals who have already come forward.\u201d\n\n\u201cYour voices have inspired a movement for change across the country and around the world,\u201d the company added. \u201cThe company regrets that it cannot undo the damage Harvey Weinstein caused, but hopes that today\u2019s events will mark a new beginning.\u201d\n\nIn a statement of his own, Mr. Schneiderman called the company\u2019s decision to release any victims and witnesses from nondisclosure agreements \u201ca watershed moment for efforts to address the corrosive effects of sexual misconduct in the workplace.\u201d Mr. Schneiderman added that he welcomed \u201cthe parties\u2019 efforts to preserve jobs and pursue justice for victims.\u201d\n\nSpokeswomen for Mr. Weinstein have denied that he ever engaged in \u201cnonconsensual sex.\u201d He has spent recent months seeking treatment for sex addiction and anger management, according to his representatives.\n\nMr. Weinstein, who is now a Hollywood pariah, has an array of legal problems that are separate from the bankruptcy case. Prosecutors in New York, Los Angeles and London are pursuing possible criminal cases against him. A lawsuit filed last month by Mr. Schneiderman will continue. Mr. Weinstein also faces additional civil suits, including one filed by the British actress Kadian Noble, who is suing him for sex trafficking.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut the bankruptcy filing does halt an array of lawsuits against the company, including those filed by women who contend that the studio facilitated misconduct by Mr. Weinstein. Those women will now have to line up behind the studio\u2019s secured creditors \u2014 who themselves are likely to be paid pennies on the dollar, according to bankruptcy lawyers.\n\nThe upshot is that women alleging abuse may now have a harder time recovering damages.\n\nThe filing, which was expected, ended a chaotic five-month effort to keep the Weinstein Company afloat.\n\nIn the fall, after The New York Times and The New Yorker revealed allegations of sexual harassment and rape, Mr. Weinstein\u2019s younger brother and partner in the studio, Bob Weinstein, unsuccessfully scrambled to line up bridge loans to keep the company operating. He then sold \u201cPaddington 2\u201d rights to Warner Bros., which bought time but resulted in a lawsuit.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy early February, to the disbelief of many in the film industry, it seemed as if the Weinstein Company had found a way forward. A group of investors, including the billionaire Ron Burkle and Lantern Capital, had made an offer to buy most of the studio\u2019s assets, which include the TV series \u201cProject Runway\u201d and the rights to \u201cLion,\u201d \u201cDjango Unchained\u201d and about 275 other films.\n\nThe investor group, managed by Maria Contreras-Sweet, who ran the Small Business Administration under President Barack Obama, had offered to pay off what it believed was the Weinstein Company\u2019s debt \u2014 about $225 million. In return, it would receive most of the studio\u2019s assets, which Ms. Contreras-Sweet planned to use to start a new, female-led film company.\n\nBut then Mr. Schneiderman threw the brakes on a sale, filing a lawsuit alleging that the studio and the Weinstein brothers had violated various state and city laws. He also said the proposed sale to Ms. Contreras-Sweet\u2019s group was unacceptable because it did not adequately compensate victims, protect employees and ensure that those who enabled or perpetuated Mr. Weinstein\u2019s conduct would not be rewarded.\n\nThe Weinstein Company and the investor group moved to address those concerns, but the studio\u2019s board announced on Feb. 25 that it would file for bankruptcy because Ms. Contreras-Sweet had not delivered on a promise to fund the studio\u2019s operations until a transaction was completed.\n\nMr. Schneiderman was able to get the deal back on track earlier this month, when he hosted a meeting between the two sides at his offices. He did so after the buyers and sellers had committed to various terms, including establishing a victims\u2019 fund worth up to $90 million. The Weinstein brothers, who jointly own about 42 percent of the studio, would receive no cash from the sale.\n\nBut the sale collapsed a few days later after the investor group discovered that the studio had an additional $55 million to $65 million in debt.", "title": "Weinstein Company Files for Bankruptcy and Revokes Nondisclosure Agreements", "authors": ["Brooks Barnes"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Hardy Green, author of \u201cThe Company Town: The Industrial Edens and Satanic Mills That Shaped the American Economy,\u201d said that the tech companies had been reviving elements of the company town in the United States for years now.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe free meals, nap pods, concierge services, yoga classes, on-site laundry and haircuts are a perk but also a modern way of slowing down the mill clock so the workers can spend more time working. But in a society where government is increasingly ineffective, company towns are nevertheless likely to be welcomed, or at least tolerated.\n\n\u201cIt may be the best option for many, just as a benevolent dictatorship can be O.K. for as long as the benevolence lasts,\u201d Mr. Green said.\n\nNo Free Wi-Fi\n\nOnly seven years ago, Silicon Valley had a very different attitude about building housing for workers, much less the community. A gaunt Steve Jobs, in what would turn out to be his last public appearance, made his case before the Cupertino City Council for a new Apple headquarters.\n\nMr. Jobs told council members how great the new doughnut-shaped headquarters was going to be. It would have a lot of trees, a theater, curved windows. Architecture students would come from all over to study it.\n\nCity Council member Kris Wang had a question: How could the 60,000 Cupertino residents benefit from this new campus?\n\n\u201cWe\u2019d like to continue to stay here and pay taxes,\u201d Mr. Jobs said. \u201cIf we can\u2019t, we\u2019d have to go somewhere like Mountain View.\u201d\n\nMs. Wang, a former Cupertino mayor, persisted. \u201cDo we get free Wi-Fi or something like that?\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a simpleton,\u201d Mr. Jobs replied. \u201cI always had this view that we pay taxes and the city should do those things. That\u2019s why we pay taxes. If we can get out of paying taxes I\u2019d be glad to put up a Wi-Fi network.\u201d\n\nSince that June 2011 meeting, the number of hours commuters in Silicon Valley lose every day to congestion has doubled to 66,000. About 300,000 new jobs have been created, pushing the median apartment rental rate up 37 percent and the median cost of a home to $968,000.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMeanwhile, the big companies \u2014 not only Apple but Amazon, which has an increasingly large presence in Silicon Valley, as well as Facebook and Google \u2014 are much wealthier.\n\nApple built a $5 billion campus that, for all its splendor, is not readily accessible by mass transit. That problem was compounded by the company\u2019s apparent lack of interest in where its new employees would live. Decisions like these are no longer acceptable from a public relations point of view, and would not be smart for the companies in any case. If Silicon Valley continues choking on its traffic, the companies will find hiring not merely difficult but impossible. Even for a tech programmer, a $2 million house is a hurdle.\n\nSo the virtual companies are being forced to grapple with the most intractable physical issues.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think Google, for instance, thought they were going to have to get into the transportation business,\u201d said Allison Arieff, editorial director of San Francisco Bay Area Planning and Urban Research Association, a research organization. \u201cBut they now have a giant swath of the company devoted to getting people around. Housing seems the next step. No one bats an eye if universities build housing for students, grad students and tenured professors.\u201d\n\n\u2018Money in Every Problem\u2019\n\nWhen the tech companies played a much smaller role in Silicon Valley 25 years ago, even the working class could afford to live here. So could Stanford University students. Traffic flowed naturally.\n\nHowever enticing this past might seem, efforts to put the brakes on growth have had limited success.\n\nMeasure M, a 2014 effort to restrict development in Menlo Park\u2019s downtown, was soundly defeated by voters. Patti Fry, a former chairwoman of the Menlo Park City Planning Commission and an architect of the measure, said she is wary of Facebook\u2019s increasing size and power.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re doing more than most companies, but most of what they do serves them,\u201d she said. \u201cI do not expect a company to have as a priority providing community services that a real community needs. They\u2019re in business to be in business.\u201d\n\nDrew Combs is a former journalist who became a member of the Menlo Park Planning Commission and then ran for City Council in 2014. He was loosely associated with Measure M and when it failed, so did his bid. He is now chairman of the planning commission, which reviews the use permits required for large projects.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think in a lot of cases this is a good-versus-evil battle,\u201d Mr. Combs said. \u201cThis is a negotiation between different stakeholders.\u201d", "title": "Welcome to Zucktown. Where Everything Is Just Zucky.", "authors": ["David Streitfeld"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Derek Jeter\u2019s first inning as chief executive of the Miami Marlins did not quite go as planned.\n\nJose Urena threw the first pitch of the 2018 baseball season. It was a four-seam fastball at 95 miles an hour. Ian Happ of the Cubs sent it in the other direction, for a home run to right.\n\nAnd it kind of got worse after that.", "title": "Welcome to the Bigs, Derek Jeter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "In 1813, not long before the end of his reign, Napoleon Bonaparte told the Austrian foreign minister, Count Metternich, the downside of being a strongman. \u201cMy reign will not outlast the day I have ceased to be strong and therefore to be feared,\u201d Napoleon said. \u201cYour sovereigns, who were born to the throne, can allow themselves to be defeated 20 times and will always return to their capitals.\u201d\n\nNapoleon knew better than anyone the difficulties of remaining in power forever, particularly if you weren\u2019t born to the throne. Years later, democratic institutions would resolve this problem by making it possible for a defeated leader to return by way of the ballot box. Electoral democracy made clear that the throne is never owned, only leased.\n\nBut the spirit of democracy was hardly limited to the idea that the will of the people is expressed through free and fair elections. That rulers should not be encouraged to outstay their welcomes and that their power must always be constrained played an instrumental role in the modern understanding of liberal democracy as well.\n\nBut this consensus, forged over centuries, is now being called into question.\n\nToday some of the leaders of the world\u2019s most powerful countries, democracies and non-democracies alike, are fashioning themselves as modern-day emperors. They are concentrating power in their own hands with no plans to leave office in their lifetime. In their view it does not matter whether a country is a democracy or an autocracy; what matters is the quality of its leader. And they have a lot of support: At a time when mistrust of politicians is high, many people see strongman leaders as preferable to a corrupt political establishment.", "title": "Opinion | Welcome to the Era of Presidents for Life", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Looking around the room I was struck by the eclectic mix of people, a reflection of Jiva\u2019s history as well as Australia\u2019s.\n\nFor one thing, a lot of us had been refugees from civil wars who resettled here, back in the days when the country\u2019s refugee policy was not so hard-line: Iraq, Bosnia, Sri Lanka \u2014 where Jiva and his family hailed from \u2014 and Vietnam, in my family\u2019s case.\n\nThe rest were different kinds of migrants, like Anglo-Australians a few generations in and people like Sonal from the United Kingdom \u2014 though her Gujarati family had fled Uganda under Idi Amin.\n\nI saw a young woman wearing tortoise shell glasses and I couldn\u2019t place her yet she looked familiar \u2014 until I realized I\u2019d actually taken a photo of her and posted it to Instagram last month.\n\nI\u2019d seen her speaking about illustrating a picture book at Lost in Books, a multilingual kids\u2019 bookshop in Fairfield. She was collaborating with a writer I knew, Zarlasht, whose parents had come to Australia in the '70s from Afghanistan as Colombo Plan scholars.", "title": "Welcome to the Neighborhood", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "As an artist in residence on the palliative care floor of the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, I visit with dying patients and their caregivers. These 12 rooms are sacred spaces, and I open the doors carefully to see if art might help.\n\nPhoto\n\nMy work is sponsored by a nonprofit organization called Collage: The Art for Cancer Network, founded by an oncologist, Dr. Jennifer Wheler. She was inspired by Georgia O\u2019Keeffe, who said, \u201cI found I could say things with colors and shapes that I couldn\u2019t say any other way, things I had no words for.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nRecently I talked to a man in his 60s who grew up in a small coastal town near Houston. He loved the Texas coast and its beaches. I asked him, as I usually do, if he had an image in his mind that had meaning for him. He had been thinking about a raindrop he had seen at home before he had been admitted. He talked about how far it had traveled, how it had gone through a storm and it had endured to be a unique drop at this moment on his windowpane.\n\nPhoto\n\nI thought about the image. The drop would dissolve and be absorbed into the earth, like all of us. I drew what he was describing: a window looking out on subtle shapes of trees and bushes, a narrow path obscured by slanting lines of rain, and in the center of the pane, a raindrop. He took the drawing and held it closely. There was his raindrop, a small oval shape on a piece of white paper. He looked at me as if we had discovered the universe.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI ask patients to talk about what they love, what has meaning to them. Often the responses are about loved ones, spouses and children, fishing in the bay. Sometimes the patient wants to create an artwork with his or her own hands. Sometimes I create a collage of images: children, horses, flowers, sunsets and sunrises, the beach, a dog, a sport. I\u2019ve drawn the Texas A&M football stadium and Mickey Mouse with an angel because they meant something to a patient.\n\nPhoto\n\nI connected with MD Anderson because my husband was a patient there. He died in 2000, and losing him was the most difficult experience of my life. I felt flayed. It took me a long time and many paintings to deal with the raw grief.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe first moments when I enter a patient\u2019s room are fragile and tender. Some patients are very beautiful in repose and seem at peace. Their partners or family members want me to draw them like that. Once a woman whose husband had just died asked their nurse if I would come to their room and draw them lying together.\n\nPhoto\n\nRecently I saw a young woman who was so ill she could barely talk. When I told her I was an artist, she perked up a little. She was bald, her skin was sallow, and a palm-sized bandage covered the port on her chest through which her chemotherapy had flowed for months.", "title": "Well Illustrated: Visions at the End of Life", "authors": ["Lynn Randolph"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "When a bank receives a fraud claim or detects suspicious activity, it typically assigns an investigator to piece together what happened. If the bank determines that the customer was an innocent victim, it will usually help him or her try to recover the missing money. But if the bank finds signs that the customer has engaged in illegal activities, like money laundering or fraud, it is supposed to report the issue to law enforcement and close the customer\u2019s accounts.\n\nMany Wells Fargo customers, however, have complained that the bank was too quick to freeze or close accounts after signs of fraud \u2014 even if they themselves reported the suspicious activity. The consumer bureau\u2019s complaints database contains dozens of reports from aggrieved customers who said their accounts had been shut down after they were victimized. Some customers who unknowingly deposited fake checks, for instance, said their accounts had then been terminated, often with little warning or explanation. That can temporarily block customers\u2019 access to their funds \u2014 and make it more difficult to recover any money they lost.\n\nWells Fargo said it was working with regulators on the matter.\n\n\u201cAs always, our goal is to protect our customers and the bank from fraud, and we want to do so in ways that minimize the risk and impact on our customers,\u201d Mr. Seitz, the bank spokesman, said.\n\nTimothy J. Sloan, Wells Fargo\u2019s chief executive, said at an investor conference in December that the bank was reviewing its procedures for handling accounts with signs of suspicious activity.\n\nAccording to Mr. Valles\u2019s lawsuit, it was standard practice at Wells\u2019s Portland office to close customer accounts rather than investigate the suspicious activity.\n\nInstead of looking into fraud claims, the bank would instead \u201csave money by simply closing accounts under the pretext of a \u2018business decision,\u2019\u201d Mr. Valles said in his complaint, filed in Oregon\u2019s Multnomah County Circuit Court.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cImproperly closing customer accounts in this manner ensured that customers, not Wells Fargo, were left to absorb the costs of fraudulent activities and unauthorized withdrawals from their checking and savings accounts,\u201d Mr. Valles\u2019s complaint said.\n\nMr. Valles, 30, worked at Wells Fargo for seven years, mostly in the fraud department in Salt Lake City, and transferred to the Portland office in 2014. He said he had first complained to the company\u2019s management about the account closings the next year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast month, Wells Fargo fired him, saying he had violated a security policy by leaving his notebook, which contained internal case numbers, on his desk overnight. It was the last in a string of reprimands that Mr. Valles said he had received from the bank after he complained \u2014 a response that he said constituted retaliation.\n\nDespite the acrimony surrounding his departure from the bank, Mr. Valles said Wells Fargo had shown signs of progress in recent months.\n\nSoon after the bank\u2019s disclosure of the consumer bureau\u2019s investigation, a new group of people arrived to the Portland office, he said. They set up new computers and put up an \u201cAudit Department\u201d sign over their section of the office.\n\nAfter that, employees stopped using the blanket \u201cbusiness decision\u201d justification for closing accounts and began conducting more thorough investigations, Mr. Valles said. If they did decide that an account had to be closed, he said, they cited more specific evidence of fraudulent acts, such as a counterfeit check or an unauthorized electronic deposit.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re working on fixing the problems,\u201d Mr. Valles said. \u201cA lot needed to be done.\u201d\n\nBut those changes will not help customers whose accounts have already been affected, like Michael and Mary Ellen Mervis, a couple who had accounts with Wells Fargo for decades.\n\nIn 2015, they discovered that one of their accountants had removed a six-figure sum from their checking account without their consent over the course of several years. The Mervises filed a police report in Milwaukee, where they lived at the time, and alerted the bank. Soon after, Wells Fargo told them that it was closing their checking and brokerage accounts and would not let them open new deposit accounts with the bank.\n\nThe Mervises protested. The bank responded by noting its \u201cresponsibilities to oversee and manage risks in its banking operations,\u201d and said the decision was final. That forced them to seek out a new bank and move over their assets, and still left them on their own to pursue their missing money. The accountant was eventually convicted of theft and ordered to pay restitution, but they still haven\u2019t been made whole.\n\n\u201cWe got a hold of a lady in the fraud department, and she said this happened to a lot of people who filed fraud complaints,\u201d Mr. Mervis said. \u201cWe were horrified. The bank had this attitude that if something went wrong, instead of trying to fix it, they were just going to run you over with the stagecoach and be done with you.\u201d", "title": "Wells Fargo Accused of Harming Fraud Victims by Closing Accounts", "authors": ["Emily Flitter", "Stacy Cowley"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "After an outcry, Chief Manley clarified his position in a television interview on Thursday. He explained that his characterization of Mr. Conditt\u2019s recording had been meant to be descriptive, not empathetic. \u201cMy opinion is that he created terror in our community by his actions and he stole lives from our community,\u201d the chief said.\n\nThe way Mr. Conditt\u2019s story has been handled by the police and the press has reignited the debate over who should be considered a terrorist. It is playing out against a backdrop of shootings and white supremacist rallies that have shaken the nation, and at a time when the country is questioning whether citizens of different races, religions and genders receive equal treatment under the law and in their communities.\n\nThe two people Mr. Conditt killed were black, but the police have said they have no reason to suspect that the attacks were racially motivated.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe law defines terrorism as violent, criminal acts that are intended to intimidate or coerce civilians and governments for an ideological, political or religious purpose.\n\nLaw enforcement officials called Tashfeen Malik and Syed Rizwan Farook, who killed 14 people in San Bernardino, Calif., and Omar Mateen, who killed 49 people at a nightclub in Orlando, terrorists. Dylann Roof, who murdered nine African-American people at a historically black church in Charleston, S.C.; Stephen Paddock, who killed 58 people at a concert in Las Vegas, and Mr. Conditt were not.\n\nSome legal experts say that the word \u201cterrorism\u201d is being applied too broadly today, both under the law and by people who want to emphasize the horror of the crime.\n\n\u201cAfter 9/11, the definition expanded and continues to lose its coherence and continuity,\u201d said Jonathan Turley, a constitutional law expert at George Washington University who has served as counsel in a number of national security and terrorism cases. The notion of terrorism \u201chas almost become an exclamation point for criminal cases,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf someone like Mr. Paddock, the Las Vegas shooter, is considered a terrorist, \u201cthen every serial killer in history would be a terrorist,\u201d Mr. Turley said. \u201cIf everybody is a terrorist, then the actual crime loses its definition and meaning.\u201d And ultimately, he said, there could be an expansion of the government\u2019s power to investigate, as well as tougher sentencing.\n\nThe news media often wrestles with this issue as well. For the most part, journalists tend to follow the lead of law enforcement on whether to call a crime an act of terrorism. The New York Times called the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing an act of terror, but not the 2002 Washington-area sniper attacks.\n\nMajor news outlets did not label the Austin bombings as terrorism. The editorial board of the Austin American-Statesman disagreed with that decision. \u201cThere is no mistaking the fear these attacks inflicted on an entire city,\u201d the board wrote. \u201cThat makes this terrorism.\u201d\n\nAttorney General Jeff Sessions has used the term \u201cdomestic terrorism\u201d to describe some incidents, like the killing of Heather Heyer at a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Va. But people cannot be charged with the federal crime of domestic terrorism as they can be charged with international terrorism.\n\nThis is one reason killers who support designated international terrorist groups are referred to as terrorists by law enforcement officials.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Mateen could be charged with terrorism after the Pulse nightclub shooting because he expressed support for the Islamic State. \u201cThe government pointed to the fact that he had made statements that suggested he was trying to advance the goals of a foreign terrorist organization,\u201d said Faiza Patel, a director of the liberty and national security program at the Brennan Center for Justice.\n\nPeople found guilty of terrorism can receive tougher sentences.\n\nEven though there are plenty of crimes with which killers can be charged, it is still important to treat domestic terrorism as the crime that it is, Mary McCord, a professor at Georgetown University Law School and a former national security official at the Justice Department, wrote after the Charlottesville rally.\n\n\u201cIt is time that our federal criminal laws recognize domestic terrorism for what it is: the moral equivalent of international terrorism,\u201d she wrote.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere is also a perceived bias against people who are not white or Christian when it comes to deciding on who is a terrorist, said Victor Asal, a professor and a director of the Project on Violent Conflict at the University of Albany who focuses on terrorists and insurgents. \u201cThe distinction between what is terrorism and what is not matters a whole heck of a lot,\u201d he said. \u201cWe think of serial killers and terrorists in very different ways.\u201d\n\n\u201cAs a country, we need to be more aware that if you are killing people for a political or ideological purpose, regardless of what the perpetrator looks like, they have to be thought of as terrorists,\u201d Professor Asal added.\n\nThis belief is one of the reasons the debate over how we define terrorism is so charged and brings up sensitive issues around race and religion.\n\nThere have been several instances where law enforcement and the media did not give nonwhite suspects \u2014 or even victims \u2014 the same consideration. Eddie S. Glaude, the chair of the center for African-American studies at Princeton, said those decisions became \u201cmarkers in the culture that signal which people are valued more than others.\u201d\n\nBy eschewing the word \u201cterrorist\u201d in favor of \u201ctroubled,\u201d law enforcement made Mr. Conditt more empathetic, Professor Glaude said.\n\n\u201cIf I describe this as an act of a person who has suffered, it orients the listener differently than if I say it\u2019s the act of a terrorist or a madman,\u201d Professor Glaude said. \u201cThe language we use carries a moral and ethical weight. It mobilizes passions. And it can cut short or activate empathy.\u201d", "title": "Were the Austin Bombings Acts of Terrorism? Why Law Enforcement Says No", "authors": ["Katie Benner", "Serge F. Kovaleski"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere\u2019s not a chance on this planet that\u2019s going to be the case,\u201d Mr. Justice said. \u201cWe have cash in the balances in Medicaid that will absolutely backstop any cuts whatsoever from Medicaid.\u201d\n\nThe strike ground the state\u2019s public schools to a halt for nine days, a remarkable show of defiance by the teachers in a state where the power of organized labor, once led by strong mining unions, has greatly diminished. Along the way, the teachers disregarded union leaders\u2019 advice to return to work when the governor first promised them the raise last week, deciding in meetings at malls and union halls and in Facebook groups that they would stay out until their raise was enacted in law.\n\n\u201cMaybe our voices are being heard, finally,\u201d said Danielle Harris, a third-grade teacher from Fayette County, whose eyes filled with tears after Mr. Justice announced the deal on Tuesday. \u201cThese strikes aren\u2019t for nothing.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDale Lee, the president of the West Virginia Education Association, one of the teachers\u2019 unions, said the pay raise was probably sufficient to get teachers back to the classroom. School systems in some of the state\u2019s 55 counties, including Kanawha and Putnam, announced even before Mr. Justice signed the pay raise bill that they would reopen on Wednesday.\n\n\u201cIt appears the strike will end,\u201d Mr. Lee said after the deal was announced.\n\nThe pay raise was the main point of contention in the final days of the strike, but the teachers have also demanded some relief from sharply rising health insurance costs. The governor has promised to address that issue through a state task force. Both union leaders and rank-and-file teachers have welcomed that move.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
