Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s a step in the right direction,\u201d said Kerry Guerini, a teacher from Fayette County, who stood in the Capitol on Tuesday with a sign that said, \u201cWill teach for insurance.\u201d\n\n\u201cA 5 percent raise isn\u2019t going to feel like very much when we have so much coming out for insurance,\u201d Ms. Guerini said. Nevertheless, she added, \u201cI\u2019m ready to go back.\u201d\n\nMr. Carmichael, whose resistance to the raises had made him a key antagonist for the striking teachers, insisted on Tuesday that he did not want to pass anything \u201cjust to appease a special-interest group.\u201d The deal came about, he said, because lawmakers decided to offset the cost of the raises with budget cuts, rather than rely on optimistic revenue estimates the governor had offered.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe raises for state workers were expected to cost the state treasury a total of about $110 million a year. Some of the money for the raises would be redirected from amounts the governor had requested for tourism promotion and the state Department of Commerce, but lawmakers in the Senate said additional spending cuts would probably be required. Mr. Blair, the Republican who heads the Senate\u2019s Finance Committee, said in a meeting that some of the money could be taken from Medicaid.\n\nMr. Carmichael told reporters that the scale of Medicaid cuts was \u201cnot absolutely determined,\u201d because lawmakers were still \u201cscouring the budget\u201d for more places to cut.\n\nThe prospect nevertheless alarmed some Democratic lawmakers.\n\n\u201cI want to make sure there\u2019s not a back-room deal here that\u2019s punishing people who are too poor to go to the doctor,\u201d Michael A. Woelfel, a Democrat, said on the Senate floor. \u201cDon\u2019t do this on the backs of the Medicaid recipients.\u201d\n\nThe teachers, who do not have a labor contract with the state, are among the lowest paid in the nation, on average, and had not had an across-the-board raise in four years. They walked off the job Feb. 22, saying they had been pushed to the brink by low pay and rising costs in their health insurance plan.\n\n\u201cTeachers across the state came together for one goal,\u201d said Renita Benson, 54, a remedial reading teacher from Calhoun County, who stood near the Capitol\u2019s soaring rotunda on Thursday. \u201cIt\u2019s not the raise, as much as it is having the respect that we deserve from the government, and I think that was proven today.\u201d", "title": "West Virginia Raises Teachers\u2019 Pay to End Statewide Strike", "authors": ["Jess Bidgood"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "CHARLESTON, W.Va. \u2014 A statewide teacher strike in West Virginia entered its seventh day on Friday, with teachers defying efforts by the state\u2019s governor and union leaders to end the walkout with a deal to raise pay.\n\nEarlier this week, James C. Justice, the governor, announced a plan to raise teachers\u2019 salaries by 5 percent, and state union leaders said teachers would return to work on Thursday. But teachers across the state have refused, saying they will not return until the State Legislature completes the deal, and counties across the state have kept schools closed.\n\nWearing red T-shirts, often emblazoned with the names of their counties, the teachers filled the chambers of the State Senate on Friday morning and filled the hallways and rotunda of the Capitol, chanting, \u201cWe\u2019re not leaving.\u201d\n\n\u201cAt this point everybody\u2019s still prepared to be out for the long haul,\u201d said Julie Alderman, 35, a first-grade teacher in Logan County, in the state\u2019s southern section, who was waiting for a babysitter to arrive so she could head to Charleston, the capital. \u201cWe\u2019re starting to kind of say, \u2018Wow, this really may last a while.\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe walkout began last Thursday after months of simmering tension over myriad issues, including proposed changes to teachers\u2019 health insurance plans that would have raised monthly premiums for many.", "title": "West Virginia Teacher Strike Enters Its Seventh Day", "authors": ["Campbell Robertson", "Jess Bidgood"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI have two children; I live paycheck to paycheck,\u201d Ms. Endicott told The Times. \u201cWhen I realized that they were taking hundreds of dollars and then they tried to tell me they were giving me a pay raise of 1 percent, I knew I can\u2019t just sit back.\u201d\n\nFirst she joined hundreds of teachers who flooded the state Capitol on Feb. 2 as legislators considered legislation with the 1 percent raise. It passed the Senate 33-0.\n\n\u201cWe were just walking silently from the Capitol,\u201d Ms. Endicott related, \u201cand one teacher said, \u2018Guys, we\u2019re really going to have to strike.\u2019 At that point, I knew.\u201d\n\nUnion battles have a deeper role in the history of West Virginia than that of perhaps any other state. Coal miners there fought bloody battles with mine owners who cared little for the sacrifice of life and limb that workers made to haul their coal from the earth. But unions have been broken there as they have throughout the country. Fewer than 5 percent of miners are represented by unions, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.\n\nPublic-sector unions have been the last bastion of worker strength.\n\nDespite Justice Alito\u2019s hand-wringing over the right to free speech, the effect of the decision that is expected from the court would be to silence workers and sap their power. The West Virginia teachers are having none of that. While it looked as if the strike was settled this week when the governor agreed to 5 percent raises, the Legislature had not committed to that, and how much workers would pay for health care was still unsettled. So the teachers stayed out.", "title": "Opinion | West Virginia Teachers Give a Lesson in Union Power", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Experts say the West Virginia teachers may foreshadow the future of organized labor, especially in the public sector, at a time when its power has been eroded in much of the country by anti-union legislation and by court challenges like the Janus case, now before the Supreme Court, which threatens the financial viability of collective bargaining.\n\nPublic employees in other states have taken notice. Teachers in Oklahoma have been talking about mounting a West Virginia-style statewide walkout in early April if the Legislature does not raise their pay by then. In Kentucky, a pending bill to reduce pensions for retired teachers has prompted protests and talk of strikes.\n\n\u201cUnions have tended throughout most of their histories to be forces that seek stability, not unrest,\u201d said Joseph A. McCartin, a labor historian at Georgetown University. \u201cWhen they are weakened, we\u2019re more likely to see the re-emergence of instability and militancy, and the kind of model that we\u2019re seeing happen in West Virginia.\u201d\n\nThat model, driven by grass-roots anger, can flummox politicians. Mitch Carmichael, the Republican president of the West Virginia Senate, opposes collective bargaining for public employees, but he acknowledged that the decentralized aspects of the strike made it difficult to reach a settlement that would satisfy the teachers.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re not negotiating with a particular, a unique set of participants,\u201d Mr. Carmichael said. \u201cThere\u2019s just this organic sort of \u2014 I don\u2019t know what to call it. More like an uprising.\u201d\n\nNational union leaders said the situation in West Virginia revealed the pitfalls of government policies intended to hobble them.\n\n\u201cIf the right wing gets what it wants and tries to eliminate collective bargaining in the public sector, then politics \u2014 this kind of political activism at the ballot box, in the State House \u2014 will be the only avenue,\u201d said Randi Weingarten, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, a national teachers\u2019 union.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe West Virginia teachers found ways to organize and act outside the usual parameters of traditional unionism. Teachers and service workers across the state aired their frustrations in an enormous Facebook group, and their walkout ultimately included members of three different unions and many people who did not belong to any union. When they defied union leaders\u2019 calls to end the strike on March 1, the strikers redoubled the pressure on lawmakers to deliver on their pay raise.\n\nThe lesson, experts said, is that undermining public sector unions, as the Janus case seeks to do, will not guarantee labor peace.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhat it does show is that this Janus decision will force workers to look at other strategies,\u201d said Ken Fones-Wolf, a professor of history at West Virginia University. \u201cWithout this institutional voice, it does make it harder to sort of organize this kind of thing. But when conditions do get bad enough, workers will take action without an organization.\u201d\n\nIndeed, some teachers who went to the meeting at the mall in Morgantown said their lack of collective bargaining rights left them no choice but to continue their strike.\n\n\u201cIt we can\u2019t negotiate with the people that we\u2019re supposed to negotiate with, then we\u2019re really just sticking out our necks and saying, this is what we\u2019re fighting for,\u201d said Lindsay Smalls, a sixth-grade science teacher. \u201cWe\u2019re just going to stick up for ourselves.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWildcat strikes led by rank-and-file workers are rare these days, but they recall the big miners\u2019 strikes that racked West Virginia\u2019s coal country in the early part of the 20th century. That pattern of labor activism changed with the passage of the National Labor Relations Act of 1935, sometimes called the Wagner Act, giving most workers a federally protected right to form unions and engage in collective bargaining.\n\nThe Wagner Act does not cover public employees, though, and some states, like West Virginia, do not give public employees the right to bargain collectively. For that reason, the state\u2019s two teachers\u2019 unions, the West Virginia Education Association and the state branch of the American Federation of Teachers, do not function as those in other states might, although they do lobby for teachers and help with grievances. Membership is voluntary and far from universal.\n\nEven so, they were quick to respond as frustration built over rising health insurance costs and other issues earlier this year. It was the unions that started the long walkout by conducting a vote and calling for the statewide work stoppage, which began on Feb. 22.\n\n\u201cIt started off with the membership following their state leaders,\u201d said Gary Price, the superintendent of schools in Marion County, who, like his colleagues around the state, kept schools closed during the walkout. \u201cBut when the state leaders made a decision that the employees didn\u2019t like, they took it in a different direction.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt that point, the course of the strike was in the hands of teachers in each of the state\u2019s 55 counties making their own separate decisions about what to do, though they monitored the mood elsewhere over social media. In Mr. Price\u2019s county, teachers gathered for a heated meeting at a high school, where people stood up and cried out every time they heard that another county\u2019s schools would be closed the next day.\n\n\u201cOnce they started to all fall, we were going to fall in line with the rest of our state,\u201d said Allyson Perry, president of the Marion County Education Association. \u201cThat\u2019s been the theme of this the whole time.\u201d\n\nEarlier in the day, teachers and bus drivers from Boone County had huddled informally at the Capitol to make their decision. \u201cNone of our union reps were over there,\u201d Robin Muncy, a bus driver, said afterward. \u201cWe just did it as a whole, because we felt we were being lied to.\u201d\n\nWill Lawrence, 53, a cook at an elementary school in Charleston who is not a member of any union, said, \u201cWe had to drag our leaders kicking and screaming \u2014 that\u2019s why it seems so disorganized.\u201d\n\nAnd in Morgantown, it was Anna Simmons, 26, who called the meeting at the mall, intending to talk over the idea of defying the union leadership and staying out with some of her colleagues at the elementary school where she works as a counselor. She was stunned when so many teachers from other schools showed up.\n\n\u201cI think our reps realized change needed to happen,\u201d Ms. Simmons said. \u201cThey ended up with a forest fire, and once it was lit, they didn\u2019t know how to contain it.\u201d\n\nWest Virginia\u2019s strike is over now, but the problems and the activism that drove it are not. In Oklahoma on Wednesday, the state\u2019s largest teachers\u2019 union announced it was accelerating its timeline for a statewide walkout, catching up with the fast-moving plans of activist teachers who had already been organizing a work stoppage in protest of low pay \u2014 on average, the lowest in the nation.\n\n\u201cWe have proven this was long overdue,\u201d said Larry Cagle, an English teacher in Tulsa who has been one of the main grass-roots organizers of a walkout. \u201cThe union, they don\u2019t know how to do this.\u201d", "title": "West Virginia Walkouts a Lesson in the Power of a Crowd-Sourced Strike", "authors": ["Jess Bidgood", "Campbell Robertson"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "In the film \u201cBlack Panther,\u201d the mythical African nation of Wakanda, known to outsiders as a small and mostly agrarian country, is protected by a holographic camouflage, which shields its advanced society from the rest of the world. Among the many great things about the film is its emphasis on Wakanda\u2019s technological gems, along with showcasing the landscape of the modern country. However, to the casual filmgoer, there is a lot that can be left to the imagination.\n\nThe Travel Desk would like to solicit your ideas of what an actual Wakanda trip would look like. Do you see Wakanda as a series of magical neighborhoods floating in midair? Would the magnetic levitation subway in Wakanda travel around its capital city like a graceful roller coaster? Maybe you might see the Wakanda countryside as a collection of broad valleys and lakes, with the glimmer of the distant metropolis as a backdrop? What kinds of things would you do in Wakanda? Would there be an abundance of infinity pools and virtual reality bowling alleys? The possibilities are truly endless.\n\nIn a future Travel issue, we will feature 10 of the most innovative submissions, so start brainstorming and have fun!\n\nShare your ideas on our Facebook page or as a comment on this article.", "title": "We\u2019d Like to Know: Where Would You Go in Wakanda?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Among them:\n\nLaura Kipnis, a feminist film-studies professor at Northwestern who wrote an essay for The Chronicle of Higher Education about how there are too many Title IX sexual misconduct investigations on campuses \u2014 and then had two graduate students file a Title IX complaint against her, on the grounds that her article created a \u201chostile environment.\u201d\n\nOr Ayaan Hirsi Ali, a Somali-born former Muslim and feminist who the Southern Poverty Law Center insists is in fact a \u201cpropagandist\u201d who is \u201cfar outside the political mainstream.\u201d\n\nOr Mary Beard, the celebrated Cambridge classicist and self-described \u201cbloody lefty\u201d who recently published a book-length manifesto denouncing the world\u2019s long history of misogyny. Last month, Ms. Beard commented on a scandal gripping Britain: Oxfam workers in Haiti after the 2010 earthquake are accused of hiring prostitutes, including, reportedly, underage girls. \u201cOf course one can\u2019t condone the (alleged) behavior of Oxfam staff in Haiti and elsewhere,\u201d she wrote. \u201cBut I do wonder how hard it must be to sustain \u2018civilized\u2019 values in a disaster zone.\u201d\n\nFor expressing the thought that people in lawless places often behave in terrible ways, Ms. Beard was torn apart on social media as an \u201cabsolute monster\u201d who was somehow excusing the exploitation of vulnerable women and girls. Her Cambridge colleague, Priyamvada Gopal joined in, accusing her of \u201cpatrician white \u2018feminist\u2019 racism.\u201d\n\nWhy are so many demonstrably non-fascist people being accused of fascism?\n\nPartly, this phenomenon is driven by our current political moment, in which millions of Americans \u2014 and not just those who identify as liberals or progressives \u2014 are horrified by the policies and the rhetoric oozing out of the White House. When the shadow of genuine chaos and extremism looms, people tend to get jumpy.\n\nPartly, as the writer David French and others have pointed out, this ritual we keep witnessing of an in-group wielding its power against a perceived heretic seems to come from a deep human desire for a sense of belonging and purpose. Organized religion may be anathema on the political left, but the need for the things religion provides \u2014 moral fervor, meaning, a sense of community \u2014 are not.\n\nPartly, too, it is the result of a lack of political proportion and priority. It\u2019s instructive that students at the University of Chicago spent their energy a few years back protesting Dan Savage, the progressive sex columnist who used the word \u201ctranny\u201d in a talk that included a discussion about reclaiming words, while ignoring a lecture the very same week by former Senator Rick Santorum, the Pennsylvania Republican who has compared gay relationships to bestiality. Freud called this the narcissism of small differences.", "title": "Opinion | We\u2019re All Fascists Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Progressives and even conscientious bureaucrats who are used to a place in the power structure are being frozen out. Many people find this disorienting, especially those who are used to being heard. But as a black American, I see a pattern of oppression that\u2019s awfully familiar, part of a historical continuum.\n\nThe ruthless othering practiced by Mr. Trump started long ago in the institution of slavery and perfected over hundreds of years. After the civil-rights movement, it morphed and hardened into a general indifference toward racial crises, crises represented most vividly by inner cities.\n\nMr. Trump simply extends this same reflexive indifference to other crises, and to those who care about them. He thinks most movements for social good are a waste of time. They\u2019re bad for business and television ratings, to say nothing of white male dominance, and so he relegates them to the shadows.\n\nMany constituencies in this country have been steadily ghettoized in this way; we\u2019ve just failed to notice. On so many critical issues, like the Iraq war, abortion rights and gun control, the majority popular opinion has gone ignored, especially by Republicans. As the party has increasingly kowtowed to donors and to a small but influential voter base, the will of the rest of the people has become an inconvenience. It\u2019s a metaphorical eyesore, a neighborhood to drive through with the windows up.\n\nWhite people don\u2019t frame this kind of negligence as racial, but they should. Blacks do because they\u2019ve lived the negligence, and still live it. (We live in a hypocrisy, not a democracy, as Malcolm X once said). Blacks have always known that America is very good at ghettoizing, at separating influencers from losers. It\u2019s in our DNA to keep certain folks at the margins.", "title": "Opinion | We\u2019re All in the Ghetto Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "My final stop will be proud and scenic Saguenay, where many manufacturing jobs have been lost because of globalization. Who are the local characters I should meet? This could be everyone from the resident historian to cultural figures, community leaders or the resident clown. (The more interesting, dynamic and fun, the better.)\n\nWhat places, both known and off-the-beaten-track, should I visit? Which neighborhoods should I go to?
