Tell Us Where to Go, S\u2019il Vous Pla\u00eet.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Age: 86\n\nOccupation: Journalist and author\n\nWhat brings you here today?\n\nI\u2019m an antique, a walking antique among the antiques. I grew up with the printed word and I\u2019m still part of the printed word. I don\u2019t own a cellphone. I don\u2019t do anything in the digital realm. I\u2019m in the spirit of this place.\n\nYou\u2019re famously dapper. Where\u2019s your suit from?\n\nThis suit was made in Paris. My father was an Italian tailor. He trained under a famous uncle of his. This is a Cristiani suit: Rue de la Paix. I must have a hundred suits.\n\nIt\u2019s a winter wool.\n\nIt\u2019s distinguished by the pinstripe. If you were standing on my head, you\u2019d see these lines go perfect. I like the precision.", "title": "What 7 Book Lovers Wore to the Antiquarian Fair", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Are there things you enjoy doing that are so exhilarating or challenging that you find yourself feeling stronger, more alert or happier? What activities make you feel more alive?\n\nIn \u201cAlone at Sea,\u201d Elizabeth Weil writes about Aleksander Doba, who kayaked across the Atlantic Ocean (for the third time) at age 70:\n\nOcean kayaking is catastrophically monotonous. The primary challenge is not physical. Doba describes the tedium as a form of dementia: \u201cHundreds, thousands, maybe millions of repetitions. The brain is removed from the process.\u201d Alone at sea without his hearing aids, Doba joked, he grew so disoriented that he started shouting at himself \u201cso that I could hear.\u201d (Doba is fairly deaf but didn\u2019t bring the aids along because they\u2019re expensive and not waterproof, and there was no one to talk to anyway.) He intended to keep muscle tone in his legs by swimming, but he had to abort that plan because his body in the water attracted sharks. He was assaulted by hailstorms of flying fish. \u201cDo you know how fast they go?\u201d he said. \u201cThis does not feel good.\u201d When he couldn\u2019t sleep, because of the unrelenting stuffiness of his cabin and the waves crashing through the portal onto his head, Doba thought about his wife, children and his young granddaughter. He thought about his dead parents. He communed with the turtles, whose shells he tapped while they swam alongside him to make sure they were alive, and the birds, who landed on Olo for a rest and often entered his cabin and did not want to leave. He did have a satellite phone, and he texted with Arminski, who, as his trip navigator, sent a regular forecast for wind and weather. Doba also called his wife, twice. But after she got the bill for $500, she says, \u201cthe desire to talk\u201d decreased. Doba rotated through three kinds of freeze-dried porridge for breakfast, four kinds of freeze-dried soup for lunch and an assortment of a dozen freeze-dried entrees. (He ate all the meat options first.) He also snacked on dried fruit and his wife\u2019s plum jam, but he ran out of that halfway across the ocean. Every time he closed his eyes, Doba told me, \u201cI dreamed I was paddling in the winter in Poland.\u201d He lost 45 pounds. Still, the trip was perfect. Ninety-nine days after leaving Senegal, Doba arrived in Brazil. He was greeted by one journalist and the Polish ambassador. Nobody cares if you cross the Atlantic in a kayak. The fact that Doba knows this is clear in his eyes. In photos from the ends of his trips, he looks ecstatic and feral, in the best possible sense, intrinsically wild and free.\n\nStudents: Read the article up to the close-up photo of Mr. Doba in a white tank top, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Can you understand why Mr. Doba looked as if he were feeling \u201cecstatic and feral, in the best possible sense, intrinsically wild and free\u201d while kayaking? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 What activities do you do that give you a feeling of being more alive? Why do they make you feel that way?\n\n\u2014 What activities can you see yourself doing when you reach Mr. Doba\u2019s age, so you still feel \u201cwild and free\u201d? Explain why.", "title": "What Activities Make You Feel Most Alive?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "British TV host, model and fashion designer Alexa Chung has made a career out of her dynamic sense of style. She\u2019s currently creative director of her eponymous fashion label , alexachung.\n\nMs. Chung lived in New York for seven years before moving back to England in 2016 to start her business. She\u2019s a frequent traveler and Paris is one of her favorite places. She has an affinity for one hotel there. \u201cA year ago, I went to stay in Le Bristol. There\u2019s this particular attic room and it has a straight shot to the Eiffel Tower, and it\u2019s so beautiful and cottage-y and gorgeous, and when you\u2019re in there, it just doesn\u2019t look real. Like, if it was in a movie, you\u2019d be like, \u2018That\u2019s a bit much.\u2019 About two years ago, I\u2019d lost my favorite shirt and I would always go on about it \u2014 but I opened the cupboard this stay, and they\u2019d kept my shirt from two years ago, waiting for me to revisit. I thought, that was great service. So, Le Bristol, hat\u2019s off, you\u2019ll always be my favorite hotel. That, and they have a pet cat.\u201d\n\nShe calls Tokyo \u201cthe best place ever. It\u2019s such a strange cultural shock when you get there, because everything looks so different. I always have regrets whenever I go there because you walk into a shop and it\u2019s like being inundated with so much strangeness, but you can\u2019t pick out a single item to buy. And then when you get home you\u2019re like, even if I had just bought that weird fried egg magnet, that would have been cool to have with me now.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s what she packs on every trip.", "title": "What Alexa Chung Can\u2019t Travel Without", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "But there\u2019s a strong case to be made that no factor has contributed more to the normalizing of sports gambling \u2014 in America, at least \u2014 than the four-decade rise of fantasy sports. Fantasy, in its broadest and most benign form, has been a godsend for major sports leagues, providing a (mostly) harmless way to keep fans engaged in a world of growing entertainment options.\n\nWhatever the catalyst, Americans are now betting more than $150 billion annually on professional and college contests. (All but $250 million of it is illegal, which is why definitive figures are hard to come by.) By comparison, the non-betting sports industry \u2014 ticket sales, media rights, advertising revenue \u2014 is expected to reach around $74 billion next year.\n\nGambling does not represent any kind of new threat to American sports. On the contrary, it\u2019s a homecoming of sorts to sports\u2019 roots.\n\nThere\u2019s no record of it, but it\u2019s almost a certainty that as soon as the first pair of crook-wielding Scottish shepherds decided to see who could knock dried sheep dung closest to a rabbit hole \u2014 golf! \u2014 so, too, did a couple of nearby highland lads agree to wager on the outcome. Ancient Olympics, scholars believe, had betting scandals, involving bribetaking athletes throwing a wrestling match or foot race.\n\nMore relevant and recent is the close connection between betting and two of the world\u2019s oldest and most popular organized sports, cricket and baseball \u2014 both, it should be noted, invented in England.\n\nUntil the mid-17th century, cricket was played almost exclusively by children, what with working people (who included teenagers back then) having little leisure time for much besides eating, sleeping and creating more little cricketers. But the twin engines of the English Civil War (1642-51) and the Industrial Revolution (about 1760-1840) gave working-class Britons their first taste of individual liberty and free time \u2014 the men, at least. That brought grown-ups to the cricket pitch. And they, in turn, brought the gamblers.\n\nBetting was so integral to cricket\u2019s modern provenance that the first rules books were concerned almost entirely with the adjudication of betting disagreements. Likewise, the earliest newspaper accounts of cricket matches focused a little on runs tallied and a lot on amounts wagered. Landed gentry and other moneyed types were especially fond of the new hobby.", "title": "Opinion | What Americans Really Think About Sports Betting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The documents show that the Border Patrol identified what it called 902 \u201ccapability gaps,\u201d or vulnerabilities, on the Southwest border. The word \u201cwall\u201d was suggested as a possible solution for just three of those gaps.\n\nAgents mentioned a \u201cfence\u201d or \u201cfencing\u201d as a possible solution 34 times \u2014 less than 4 percent of the 902 vulnerabilities identified, the report found.\n\nCustoms and Border Protection officials said Border Patrol agents were asked to identify \u201cgaps\u201d in border security, not to propose solutions. They said that Border Patrol sector chiefs, from San Diego to the Rio Grande Valley in Texas, have voiced support for a border wall.\n\nDays after his inauguration last year, Mr. Trump ordered construction to begin immediately on a border wall. Customs and Border Protection then created a process to help decide where a wall was most needed on the border, and for how many miles.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe U.S. Border Patrol has been very clear that a border wall is essential to gaining operational control of the Southwest border,\u201d said Benjamine Huffman, the chief of the Border Patrol\u2019s strategic plan and analysis directorate. \u201cThe fact is, when it comes to border security, the border walls system works. Suggestions that the Border Patrol believes otherwise are false.\u201d\n\nThe Senate Democrats\u2019 report comes as Mr. Trump is stepping up his calls for building a border wall. On Monday in New Hampshire, where he outlined plans to fight opioid abuse, the president again said that building a wall would block drugs from entering the United States. \u201cWe\u2019ll build the wall to keep the damn drugs out,\u201d he said.\n\nLast year, Customs and Border Protection spent $20 million on border wall prototypes near San Diego. Agency officials said they have been testing the mock-ups to decide which best curbed illegal immigration and drug trafficking.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCongressional Democrats and some Republicans, including Representative Will Hurd of Texas, have questioned the need for a wall and instead called for more technology along the border, such as sensors and surveillance equipment. A February 2017 study by the Government Accountability Office found that Customs and Border Protection had not shown the extent to which fencing and walls have secured the border.\n\nThe House on Thursday approved spending money on border fencing, but not a border wall. The bill would fund nearly $1.6 billion for border security, including technology and repairs to existing barriers. That includes $641 million for about 33 miles of new border fencing in the Rio Grande Valley.\n\nThe administration wants to spend $18 billion over the next 10 years to build a wall on nearly 900 miles of the Southwest border. Currently, there are nearly 700 miles of wall and fences on the border.\n\nThe Democratic report concluded that funding requests for a wall far exceeded proposed spending on border technology and personnel, which border agents identified as critically needed.\n\nThe president\u2019s budget request for the 2019 fiscal year includes $43 million for remote video surveillance systems along the border and more funding for other security technology.\n\nIt also includes $255 million to hire and retain agents at the Border Patrol, which has been shedding personnel faster than it can hire. Agency documents indicate the Border Patrol must recruit 133 applicants to fill a single agent\u2019s position. Mr. Trump wants to hire 5,000 new agents.\n\nA program to detect drug tunnels beneath the southern border \u2014 another security priority cited by agents \u2014 was not funded in Mr. Trump\u2019s budget request, the Democratic report noted.", "title": "What Border Agents Say They Want (It\u2019s Not a Wall)", "authors": ["Ron Nixon"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Oliver, a 32-year-old software engineer, has spent roughly $200 on Relationship Hero, with coaching sessions that have lasted between three and 46 minutes. (He requested his last name be withheld, because he worried women might have an \u201cuncharitable\u201d opinion of a man who was paying a coach to analyze their conversations and texts. \u201cThey might think, \u2018What a loser,\u2019\u201d he said.)\n\nLast fall, Oliver contacted Relationship Hero after an especially bad Tinder date. He told his coach that the woman had seemed normal in her texts, but in person she turned out to be obsessed with status. He asked how to avoid meeting women like this in the future, and if he did end up on another bad date, how to leave early without seeming rude.\n\n\u201cOh boy. lol,\u201d the coach wrote. \u201cso would you say you are often drawn to women by their looks first? Because you will have to dive a bit deeper \u2026 you know what Im sarying?\u201d\n\nAt the end of the chat, the coach suggested that Oliver write down his expectations before his next date and then compare them with his postdate notes. \u201cGood advice but also thanks for listening,\u201d Oliver wrote. The coach signed off with a smiley face.\n\nOliver doesn\u2019t consider his coach\u2019s typos or colloquialisms unprofessional. \u201cIt\u2019s just a conversation,\u201d he said. \u201cNot a formal document.\u201d He found the coach clear and helpful. \u201cYou just want someone to hear you,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s like a two-minute therapy session.\u201d\n\nNot a Therapy Substitute\n\nRelationship Hero, which has 20 coaches and has raised $620,000 in funding, emphasizes it provides \u201ctactical relationship advice,\u201d not therapy. \u201cWe won\u2019t tell you to search your emotions, but give you advice that we think is most proven to get results in the situation,\u201d Mr. Shapira said. Though some coaches are psychologists, the company\u2019s co-founder Lior Gotesman, who is also a lead coach, says he often rejects candidates with graduate degrees, \u201cbecause they\u2019re not as much in tune with their intuition.\u201d\n\nBut neither intuition nor expertise can solve every problem. Hunt Ethridge, another lead coach, says clients frequently want help winning back their exes. \u201cShould that not work out, we\u2019ll help set you up for the next thing,\u201d he said. \u201cWe can\u2019t do magic.\u201d", "title": "What Can an Online Dating Coach Do for You?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Q. What causes canker sores? Why would I have a sudden outbreak of canker sores in the mouth?\n\nA. There are several theories about what leads to canker sores, those painful ulcers that form inside the mouth, on the tongue or inside the cheek or lips, though medical experts say they don\u2019t know the precise cause. They are distinct from cold sores, which form on the outer lip and are caused by infections with the herpes simplex virus.\n\nAnyone can get a canker sore, though they occur more often in teens and young adults and may be more common in people with underlying medical conditions that cause inflammation or weaken the immune system.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just one of those things where the exact cause has yet to be determined,\u201d said Dr. Sally Cram, a dentist and spokeswoman for the American Dental Association.\n\nAmong the possible culprits are viruses, bacterial infections, food allergies, poor nutrition, a weakened immune system, an injury or trauma to the mouth and stress. Hereditary factors may also play a role.", "title": "What Causes Canker Sores?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTo some, free speech on college campuses appears to be under attack, but what do the students themselves think? A study released on Monday offers some answers based on a survey of more than 3,000 of them.\n\nThe survey, a collaboration among five groups, finds that college students feel increasingly stifled on campus and online, and while they equally value free speech and inclusivity, they wrestle with how best to balance the two.\n\n\u201cWhat you see is a generation that\u2019s struggling with really deep questions about how to be a pluralistic society and a pluralistic campus and how to be an open society and an open campus,\u201d said Sam Gill, vice president of communities and learning at the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, which led the effort with Gallup, the polling company.\n\nStudents differed widely on how to strike that balance. Here\u2019s a look at some of the findings of the survey, which was co-sponsored by the American Council on Education, the Charles Koch Foundation and the Stanton Foundation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTension between free expression and inclusion\n\nCollege students believe about equally in free expression and pluralism, with nearly 90 percent saying that free speech protections are very or extremely important to American democracy and more than 80 percent saying the same of promoting an inclusive and diverse society.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen forced to choose, a majority of students said that diversity and inclusivity were more important than free speech, though opinions differed widely by demographic.\n\nInclusivity is more important than speech, majority of students say When forced to choose, a small majority of college students say inclusivity is more important than free speech, though they widely believe in the importance of both to democracy. Diverse and inclusive society Protecting free speech rights All Men Women Whites Blacks At historically black institutions Democrats Independents Republicans 53% 46 39 61 64 35 47 52 68 31 53 46 66 34 49 50 30 69 Diverse and inclusive society Protecting free speech All Men Women Whites Blacks At historically black institutions Democrats Independents Republicans 53% 46 39 61 64 35 47 52 68 31 53 46 66 34 49 50 30 69\n\nThose who belong to groups historically or currently in positions of power \u2014 white students, men or Republicans \u2014 tended to favor free speech, while nearly two in three students who were black, women or Democrats favored inclusivity. That gap was widest along partisan lines, with 66 percent of Democrats saying inclusivity was more important and 69 percent of Republicans saying the same of free speech.", "title": "What College Students Really Think About Free Speech", "authors": ["Niraj Chokshi"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI have two words to leave with you tonight, ladies and gentlemen: inclusion rider,\u201d Frances McDormand said Sunday night at the end of a rousing acceptance speech for the best actress Oscar in which she urged all other female nominees to stand up and reminded the audience that every woman standing had stories to tell and projects that needed financing.\n\nSo what is an inclusion rider? As Stacy Smith, who researches gender equality in film and television at the University of Southern California, has put it, it\u2019s the idea that A-list actors have the ability to stipulate in their contracts that diversity be reflected both onscreen and in \u201cbelow the line\u201d positions, where women, people of color, and members of L.G.B.T. communities are traditionally underrepresented.", "title": "What Did Frances McDormand Mean by an \u2018Inclusion Rider\u2019 at the Oscars?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "What is hard about being a teacher or school administrator today? What do you wish your students, their parents and the general public understood better?\n\nWhat unique stresses and challenges do you and your colleagues experience, and how would you explain those to people who have never worked in a school \u2014 or who retired long ago?\n\nBut ask yourself, too, what\u2019s positive about being an educator today? What do you think may make the experience better for those in the profession today than it was in the past? Why?\n\nIn general, what can you tell people who haven\u2019t been in school in years about what life there is like now? Why is it important for them to understand?", "title": "What Do You Wish More People Knew About What It\u2019s Like to Be a Teacher in 2018?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "What is hard about being a student today? What do you wish your parents and teachers understood better? What unique stresses and challenges is your generation experiencing, and how would you explain those to someone older?\n\nBut ask yourself, too, what\u2019s positive about being a student today? What do you think may make school and learning better for you than it was for other generations? Why?\n\nIn general, what can you tell people who haven\u2019t been in school in years about what life is like? Why is it important for them to understand?\n\nIf you\u2019re a student who is at least 13 years old, this is your chance to make your voice heard, and to spotlight details large and small. Your answer could appear in print in a new Times section devoted to education that will be published on Sunday, April 8.", "title": "What Do You Wish More People Understood About What It\u2019s Like to Be a Student in 2018?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Emma Gonz\u00e1lez spoke for just under two minutes on Saturday before tens of thousands of demonstrators at the March for Our Lives rally in Washington, describing the effects of gun violence in emotional detail and reciting the names of classmates who had been killed.\n\nThen she said nothing for four minutes and 26 seconds.\n\nMs. Gonz\u00e1lez, a senior at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., has emerged as one of the most prominent faces among the student activists who have mobilized against gun violence after a shooting at their school last month that left 17 dead.\n\nTheir facility with social media has added urgency to demands for more gun control. Ms. Gonz\u00e1lez, who has more than 1.3 million followers on Twitter, has spent much of the last month urging her audience to turn out for Saturday\u2019s marches.", "title": "What Emma Gonz\u00e1lez Said Without Words at the March for Our Lives Rally", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "The failure of systems used to store frozen eggs and embryos at two fertility clinics has rattled people who count on such clinics to help them realize their hopes of having children. But the breakdowns at clinics in Cleveland and San Francisco, each apparently involving the temperature or level of liquid nitrogen in one storage tank, have damaged at least some eggs and embryos belonging to potentially hundreds of people.\n\nAt a time when egg freezing is increasing swiftly \u2014 some Silicon Valley companies now tout it as a perk for their employees \u2014 the incidents raise questions about what to look for and ask if you are considering taking that step. Here is a basic guide:\n\nHow likely are storage failures?\n\nSeveral doctors with years of experience in the fertility industry say the recent incidents in San Francisco and Cleveland appear to be unusual. \u201cI\u2019m not aware of any other instances,\u201d said Catherine Racowsky, the director of the IVF lab at Brigham and Women\u2019s Hospital in Boston, who has served on several professional and government oversight committees.\n\nDr. Racowsky and others said that fertility clinics \u2014 there are about 450 to 500 in the United States \u2014 tend to have backup systems to handle technical failures and make sure frozen tissue stays frozen. \u201cIt\u2019s every clinic\u2019s nightmare,\u201d said Dr. Julie Lamb, director of fertility preservation at Pacific NW Fertility in Seattle. She has been fielding questions this week from concerned patients, assuring them that the clinic has multiple backup storage tanks, freezers checked by staff members twice daily, and a \u201cspecialized alarm system that monitors tanks, monitors the temperature in the nitrogen level and is connected to a whole phone system with multiple layers of alarms.\u201d\n\nJake Anderson, a founder of Fertility IQ, a website that provides assessments of fertility doctors and clinics, noted that both the Cleveland and San Francisco clinics are \u201clarge, reputable, subject to oversight,\u201d and they both quickly acknowledged the failures publicly. But he said he worried about smaller, private clinics that have no affiliation with a university or hospital and whether some would be less inclined to disclose a problem. \u201cIf this happens in other places that are private, people would take this to the grave and they would never breathe a word of this,\u201d Mr. Anderson said. \u201cTo think that only the well-run places that have boards and clinical oversight \u2014 they\u2019re the only ones having this problem? I believe the opposite.\u201d", "title": "What Fertility Patients Should Know About Egg Freezing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "But the Bulls had other ideas. Their backcourt of Jeremy Harris and Wes Clark combined for 48 points. It was Buffalo\u2019s first N.C.A.A. tournament win. And it could hardly have been more unexpected.\n\nFor most of the first day of what has been billed as the most wide-open tournament in years, fans had been left wondering: What happened to the upsets?\n\nAfter the higher seeds Kansas, Duke, Gonzaga and Tennessee all advanced in the early afternoon \u2014 some of them expending a little more perspiration than others \u2014 it was hardly the dramatic, roiling, bracket-busting start to a tournament that is designed to fuel unpredictability.\n\nWhen there was finally a buzzer-beater shot by a midmajor underdog \u2014 Loyola-Chicago, a No. 11 seed, stunned Miami \u2014 it was greeted exuberantly by fans on social media, even though the outcome had not been entirely unforeseen. The Ramblers, making their first tournament appearance since 1985, were considered a favorite sleeper, and their win kept plenty of brackets intact.\n\nYet the higher seeds won seven of the first eight games. Many of winners emerged from major conferences, and they quickly snuffed out the smaller programs that have historically given the tournament its March Madness mystique.\n\nThe day\u2019s first seven games were decided by an average of more than 11 points.\n\n\u2014-\n\nWant exclusive sports news, highlights and analysis from a rotating cast of New York Times journalists, delivered to your inbox once a week? Click here to receive our weekly Sports newsletter.\n\n\u2014-\n\nHere\u2019s what happened on Thursday:\n\nNo. 4 Arizona Falls to No. 13 Buffalo\n\nWes Clark scored 25 points, Jeremy Harris added 23 and No. 13 seed Buffalo pulled off the biggest upset of the N.C.A.A. tournament\u2019s opening round, rolling over No. 4 seed Arizona 89-68 in the South Region.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe smaller Bulls (27-8) used their quickness to zip around the Wildcats (27-8), scoring at the rim and on kickout 3-pointers.\n\nDefensively, Buffalo neutralized Arizona\u2019s size inside by collapsing on the paint, forcing the Wildcats to shoot from the perimeter. Arizona went 2 for 18 from beyond the 3-point arc, while the Bulls knocked down 15 of 30. Superstar freshman Deandre Ayton was held to a quiet 14 points.\n\nCJ Massinburg had 19 points and Buffalo shredded Arizona\u2019s defense at a 55-percent clip for the program\u2019s first N.C.A.A. tournament win.\n\nThe Bulls move on to face Kentucky in Saturday\u2019s round of 32.\n\nPhoto\n\nLoyola-Chicago Scores Tournament\u2019s First Upset\n\nThe N.C.A.A. tournament is about buzzer-beaters, and the first one in this year\u2019s event came from No. 11 Loyola of Chicago.\n\nIt was a close game throughout, but Miami took the lead late, and Lonnie Walker IV went to the line with his team up by 1 and 9 seconds left.\n\nHe missed, and Loyola raced down court to try to take the lead. Donte Ingram fired from 3-point range, and with .3 seconds left, it swished in, giving Loyola the first upset of the tournament, 64-62.\n\nCelebrating the win was Sister Jean Dolores-Schmidt, the 98-year-old nun who serves as the team chaplain for Loyola.\n\nThe 11th-seeded Ramblers (29-5) matched the school record for wins from their 1963 national championship team in their first N.C.A.A. trip since losing to Patrick Ewing and Georgetown in the Round of 16 in 1985. They advanced to face third-seeded Tennessee on Saturday. Next up for Loyola is Tennessee.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe sixth-seeded Hurricanes (22-10) led most of the second half in their third straight trip to the tournament but couldn\u2019t pull away in the final minutes and lost in the first round for the second straight year.\n\nAmong those selecting 11th-seeded Loyola over sixth-seeded Miami was former President Barack Obama.\n\nBuffalo shot 54.8 percent from the field, but its defense was what stood out, holding Ayton to a quiet 14 points, as he was double- and even triple-teamed on almost every possession.\n\nMichigan\u2019s Defense Stifles Montana\n\nA suffocating defensive performance lifted Michigan past Montana, 61-47, in the final game of what wound up being an eventful first night.\n\nOpening the game with a 10-0 lead, the Grizzlies were quicker and more energetic than the Wolverines, who looked to be shaking off some rust after an extra week off following the early Big Ten tournament this year.\n\nBut by halftime, Michigan was back in shape. And in the second half, they held Montana more than 10 minutes without a field goal. The Grizzlies finished with only seven field goals in the entire second half.\n\nThe No. 4 seed Wolverines would never be confused with an offensive juggernaut, but their defense has been terrific of late. Thursday night was just the latest example.\n\nPhoto\n\nRob Gray\u2019s 39 Points Keep Houston Alive\n\nAn up-and-under scoop layup through traffic by Rob Gray with 1.1 seconds remaining beat San Diego State, 67-65, and sent No. 6 Houston to the second round.\n\nThe Aztecs\u2019 Trey Kell had a look at a buzzer-beating 3-pointer, after a pass the length of the court found him surprisingly open. But it clanged out.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt had been an amazing comeback by the Aztecs, who trailed by 13 early in the second half. The No. 11 seed found a way to tie it with 1:08 remaining on a 3-pointer by Devin Watson.\n\nThen Gray answered with a 3-pointer to go back ahead. Then it was Watson again, from the corner, to tie the game a second time.\n\nBut Gray, the senior guard, was not going to be denied. He wove his way through traffic and somehow flipped a layup through for his 39th point. It was all the Cougars needed.\n\nTexas Tech Avoids Big Upset\n\nIt looked like it would be the biggest upset of the day, but No. 3 Texas Tech found a way to get past No. 14 Stephen F. Austin, fighting off a hot team to advance with a 70-60 victory on Thursday.\n\nThe Red Raiders had lost five of the team\u2019s last seven games going into the tournament but were still deemed 11-point favorites by most sportsbooks despite Stephen F. Austin having been on a roll with 10 wins in 11 games.\n\nKeenan Evans led Texas Tech with 23 points, while Ivan Canete led Stephen F. Austin with 17.\n\nWhile the Lumberjacks flirted with an upset all game, the Texas Tech defense ranked No. 4 in the nation by KenPom.com \u2014 locked things down in the second half, not allowing a field goal in the last 5 minutes and 24 seconds of the game. That plus an offensive surge led by Evans, who scored 19 of his 23 in the second half, sealed Stephen F. Austin\u2019s fate.\n\nTexas Tech will now advance to face the winner of Thursday\u2019s matchup between No. 11 St. Bonaventure and No. 6 Florida.\n\nPhoto\n\nKentucky Holds Off a Scrappy Davidson Team\n\nThey looked shaky at times in the second half, but No. 5 Kentucky managed to hold on against No. 12 Davidson to advance, 78-73.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGive the young \u2019Cats credit. They made the plays down the stretch, while Davidson went cold.\n\nIt was tied, 54-54, with just over seven minutes remaining, after Davidson rebounded from a 10-point halftime deficit. But then they went dry: 1 of 12 from the field down the stretch, while Shea Gilgeous-Alexander (15 points) and Kevin Knox (21 points) hit their shots. Not many people gave this freshmen-led Kentucky team much of a chance when they lost four in a row in early February. But they\u2019ve now won 9 of their last 10.\n\nIt was the first time since Nov. 1988 that Kentucky won a game despite not making a single 3-pointer, breaking the longest streak in Division I history, according to Stats, Inc.\n\nPhoto\n\nSeton Hall Advances by Beating N.C. State\n\nNo metropolitan New York City team had won an N.C.A.A. tournament game since 2004. That streak ends, with No. 8 Seton Hall evading No. 9 N.C. State, 94-83.\n\nIt\u2019s the first win in three tournament tries for the Pirates\u2019 seniors Angel Delgado, Kadeem Carrington, and Desi Rodriguez. They combined for 59 points and now get to prepare to take on top seeded Kansas on Saturday.\n\nCarrington scored 26 points, Rodriguez added 20, Myles Powell had 19 and Angel Delgado scored 13 for the Pirates (22-11), who led the entire way a year after a late meltdown cost them an early exit against Arkansas.\n\nAllerik Freeman hit six 3-pointers and had 36 points to lead the No. 9 Wolfpack (21-12), who returned to the tournament under first-year coach Kevin Keatts for the first time in three years. Torin Dorn added 18 points and 12 rebounds, and Lennard Freeman contributed 13 points.\n\nThe only thing that slowed down the high-scoring, up-and-down matchup was the whistles. The teams combined for 53 fouls, resulting in 66 total free throws. Seton Hall had two players foul out \u2014 Delgado was one of them \u2014 and the Wolfpack had three players relegated to the bench.\n\nPhoto\n\nOhio State Avoids Dreaded 12-5 Upset\n\nWith the game tied at 70, a four-point play by Kam Williams with 1 minute 36 seconds remaining gave Ohio State what it needed to outlast No. 12-seeded South Dakota State and avoid the dreaded 12-5 upset.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSouth Dakota State made a late run at the Buckeyes, scoring 10 straight points to tie it at 70-all.\n\nWilliams answered \u2014 by being fouled on a pair of 3-pointers. He finished off the four-point play for a 74-70 lead and made all three free throws on the second, making it 77-70 with 64 seconds left.\n\nMike Daum likely ends his career with the Jackrabbits with 27 points and six rebounds, while three Buckeyes scored at least 20 points, led by Keita Bates-Diop (24 points, 12 rebounds).\n\nOhio State was one of college basketball\u2019s biggest surprises in coach Chris Holtmann\u2019s first season. He didn\u2019t take over the program until June and the Buckeyes were picked to finish 11th in the in Big Ten.\n\nYet behind Bates-Diop, the Big Ten player of the year, Ohio State finished second in the conference behind Michigan State to earn its first NCAA Tournament berth since 2015.\n\nPhoto\n\nKansas Stumbles Early, but Holds Off Penn\n\nAfter sending a few shivers down the spines of fans all across Kansas, Penn, the No. 16 seed in the Midwest region, isn\u2019t going to wind up in the history books.\n\nA poised Quakers team took it to the top-seeded Jayhawks early, looking like a team that truly believed it had a chance to pull off the unthinkable: a No. 16 seed beating a No. 1.\n\nBut, as has happened 133 times before in the N.C.A.A. tournament, Kansas held on for a 76-60 victory. The Jayhawks could not turn it into the blowout that usually results in these first-round matchups; credit Penn for hanging tough throughout the second half. But Kansas\u2019 star guard Devonte Graham (29 points, 6 rebounds, 6 assists) led a late first-half turnaround that was ultimately the difference.\n\nIf it wasn\u2019t for six straight points from Graham to spark that run, perhaps this would be a different story. Penn, winners of the Ivy League tournament, had a 21-13 lead, momentum and the look of a team that wasn\u2019t intimidated by the Big 12 conference champions. As it turned out, it was just a slow start for the Jayhawks, who shot 46 percent from the field in the second half and hit 15 of 17 free throws.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDuke Routs Iona to Advance\n\nMike Krzyzewski keeps wringing his hands about his team\u2019s youth. And then Duke and its roster of N.B.A.-bound freshmen get on the floor against a more experienced opponent and the Hall of Fame coach\u2019s fears largely vanish.\n\nHaving Marvin Bagley III certainly helps.\n\nThe Atlantic Coast Conference Player of the Year did whatever he wanted against game but overmatched Iona, pouring in 22 points to go with seven rebounds in his N.C.A.A. Tournament debut as the Blue Devils pulled away for an 89-67 victory on Thursday. The 6-foot-11 freshman forward made 10 of 14 shots in 32 minutes \u2014 even making his lone 3-point attempt \u2014 as Duke rolled into a second-round Midwest Region matchup with seven-seeded Rhode Island on Saturday. The Rams held off Oklahoma in overtime in the opening game of the tournament.\n\n\u201c(This is) what we\u2019ve had to go through the whole year, you know, the first road game, the first conference game, the \u2014 you know, the first 10:00 of game, you know, all of those things,\u201d Krzyzewski said. \u201cSo this is a first for them.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nNo. 4 Gonzaga Outlasts U.N.C.-Greensboro\n\nWell, that got interesting.\n\nA 3-pointer by redshirt freshman Zach Norvell Jr. with 20.8 seconds remaining was the difference for No. 4-seeded Gonzaga, which just sneaks past a pesky No. 13 U.N.C.-Greensboro that fought valiantly in the second half.\n\nThe Bulldogs allowed the Spartans to keep hanging around because they could not make free throws. They were an abysmal 12 of 23 from the stripe, including four straight misses down the stretch. The Spartans kept up the full-court pressure, happy to let Gonzaga shoot from 3-point range (4 of 22 before Norvell\u2019s clutch shot) or fouling when the Bulldogs tried to move it inside.\n\nFor a while, that strategy seemed to be working. A Greensboro putback by Jordy Kuiper gave the Spartans the lead for the first time since the first half with 1 minute, 46 seconds left.\n\nBut junior guard Josh Perkins answered with a jumper with 56 seconds remaining. After a wild miss by Federico Alonso, Norvell pulled up from 3 and drilled it for the go-ahead shot in Gonzaga\u2019s 68-64 win in Boise.\n\nPhoto\n\nRhode Island Knocks Out Trae Young and Oklahoma\n\nTrae Young was the best player on the floor, as expected. But Rhode Island was better than Oklahoma in a tightly contested opener to the N.C.A.A. tournament, winning 83-78 in overtime.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere was more attention than usual on the game because of Young, and Oklahoma\u2019s strange season. The freshman led the nation in points and assists. And, unfortunately, turnovers. Oklahoma had looked like one of the best teams in the country but by March only barely squeaked into the tournament.\n\nNeither team could pull away in this game. No. 10 Oklahoma led by 4 at the half, behind 4-for-4 shooting by Young. In the second half he ramped up his point total and finished with 28 and seven assists.\n\nRhode Island was the team with a chance to win it in regulation however. After Young made two free throws to tie it at 69-69, Rhode Island missed a jumper by Jeff Dowtin and a Stanford Robinson putback.\n\nIn overtime, Rhode Island was the better team, winning, 83-78. The extra period included two long, long 3 point tries by Young, both with Oklahoma leading and both of which missed. A 3 by E.C. Matthews was the killer that won it for Rhode Island. Young finished with a game-high 28 and seven assists, and Matthews had 16 for Rhode Island.\n\n\u2022 Meanwhile, no problems for Tennessee against Wright State; the final score was 73-47. Lamonte Turner scored 19 points off the bench.", "title": "What Happened in the NCAA Tournament First Round", "authors": ["Zach Schonbrun", "Victor Mather", "Benjamin Hoffman"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Early in his presidency, Donald Trump knew exactly whom to blame for the chemical weapons used in Syria, and what to do about it. The \u201cheinous\u201d sarin gas attacks by President Bashar al-Assad on the Syrian town of Khan Sheikhoun last April happened because President Barack Obama \u201cdid nothing\u201d to enforce his red line against the banned arms after an attack near Damascus in August 2013, Mr. Trump said.\n\nSo Mr. Trump ordered the launch of 59 cruise missiles against a Syrian airfield where the April chemical attack originated. Invoking the horror of \u201cinnocent babies\u201d choked by poison gas, he said military action would \u201cdeter the spread and use of deadly chemical weapons.\u201d\n\nOnly it didn\u2019t.\n\nIn the 11 months since then, there have been many such attacks, including at least six this year, which American officials and human rights groups blamed on Mr. Assad. Rather than the more lethal sarin agent used in April, recent attacks reportedly have involved chlorine.\n\nThe use of poison gas, a war crime under international law, has been integral to Mr. Assad\u2019s scorched-earth drive to regain control of the last rebel-held areas near Damascus. By bombing civilians and depriving them of food and medical care, he has killed more than 700 people in the past several weeks, on top of nearly 500,000 killed since the civil war began in 2011.", "title": "Opinion | What Happened to Trump\u2019s Red Line on Chemical Weapons?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Smoot-Hawley \u201cwas such a disaster that it\u2019s held sway over American trade policy for over 80 years,\u201d said Joshua Meltzer, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution who also teaches international trade law at Johns Hopkins University. \u201cNo one wants to repeat it.\u201d\n\nHe called Mr. Trump\u2019s comments on trade wars \u201ca dramatic departure\u201d from economic orthodoxy.\n\nOn the question of who wins, \u201cthe easy answer is to say that no one wins a trade war,\u201d said Marc-William Palen, a professor of history at the University of Exeter in Britain and the author of \u201cThe \u2018Conspiracy\u2019 of Free Trade,\u201d which examines trade rivalry between the United States and the British Empire in the 19th century. \u201cBut the more I reflect on it, it seems the winners are those nations that don\u2019t take part.\u201d\n\nProfessor Palen cited the late-19th-century trade wars between Canada and the United States, which caused a precipitous drop in Canadian exports to America and led Canada to seek export markets in Britain. \u201cThe British Empire was the winner,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnother \u201cbig winner\u201d from a trade war it was not involved in, Professor Palen said, was Soviet Russia, which was largely shunned by Western trading partners after the 1917 revolution and the rise of communism, and was desperate for hard currency. The Smoot-Hawley tariffs, Professor Palen said, caused countries like Italy to abandon American imports and resume trading with the Soviets, forging trade links that persist today.\n\nA textbook case of one country\u2019s \u201cwinning\u201d a trade war occurred during the late 19th century when a newly unified Italy imposed steep tariffs on imports from France in order to spur domestic industrialization. France, which was much richer and stronger, retaliated with tariffs against Italy, and Italian exports to France collapsed. Even after Italy abandoned its tariffs, France continued to punish Italy for years with high tariffs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cFrance won in the sense that the trade war was brutal for the Italians,\u201d said John Conybeare, emeritus professor of political science at the University of Iowa, and the author of the book \u201cTrade Wars.\u201d\n\nProfessor Conybeare said an enduring lesson from that trade conflict was that if there is a wide disparity in economic strength between two countries, the stronger country will probably prevail. \u201cTrump must be thinking that the large size of the U.S. domestic market gives it a lot of bargaining power in any trade dispute,\u201d he said.\n\nWhile that may be true with much smaller, weaker countries, it is not the case with trading partners of equal or even larger size, such as the European Union and China. \u201cWithout that large disparity in economic strength, both sides lose,\u201d Professor Conybeare said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe cited what have become known as the \u201cchicken wars\u201d of the early 1960s, a trade dispute set off when Germany and France imposed tariffs on American chicken. The United States retaliated by imposing tariffs on an array of goods, including French brandy, light trucks and Volkswagen buses. The United States even threatened to reduce its troop presence in Europe. Despite those pressures, the newly formed European Economic Community did not back down, and in that sense the United States \u201clost\u201d the war.\n\nThe biggest losers, though, were American and European consumers deprived of choices in the marketplace and forced to pay higher prices for what was available.\n\nThere were also unintended consequences. American automakers, insulated from foreign competition by the tariffs, failed to modernize, improve quality or reduce costs, setting the stage for a decades-long decline, which for Chrysler and General Motors ended in bankruptcy.\n\nPhoto\n\nMuch the same can be said of the United States steel industry, which since World War II has probably received more protection from tariffs and quotas than any other industry. \u201cThey just used the protection to raise prices, fatten profits, pay their executives more and avoid automating and reducing costs,\u201d Professor Conybeare said. \u201cThey didn\u2019t use the breathing space they gained to modernize. So much of the U.S. steel industry is using obsolete technology, which is why they can\u2019t compete.\u201d\n\nDecades of tariff protection have done little to stem the industry\u2019s decline. Domestic steel employment dropped from 135,000 in 2000 to 83,600 in 2016, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.\n\nMuch like Mr. Trump, President George W. Bush veered from Republican free trade orthodoxy in 2002 when he imposed tariffs of up to 30 percent on certain steel products to counter what he claimed was a surge of imports (Canada, Mexico and a number of developing countries were exempted). Although the tariffs were loudly condemned by many Republicans, politicians from steel-producing states supported the move and protectionist Democrats like Representative Richard Gephardt of Missouri argued that the measures did not go far enough.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe European Union filed charges with the World Trade Organization, which ruled that the tariffs were illegal and discriminatory and authorized up to $2 billion in retaliatory measures. The E.U. threatened tariffs on a variety of American products, including autos and Florida oranges.\n\nMr. Bush abandoned the tariffs in December 2003. He claimed that they had served their purpose, but subsequent studies suggested that they had little impact on employment in the industry and led to a loss of hundreds of thousands of jobs in industries that use steel as a raw material.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s pronouncements on trade this week \u201csound like a very archaic, 19th-century argument,\u201d Professor Palen said, referring to a time when protectionism was Republican orthodoxy and Representative William McKinley of Ohio, who later became president, was successfully promoting his Tariff Act of 1890, which raised the average duty on imports to nearly 50 percent.\n\nThe act is widely considered by historians to have been a disaster that led to higher consumer prices and inflation and provoked a voter backlash. Republicans lost their House majority in 1890 and lost the White House and both houses of Congress in 1892. The act was repealed in 1894.\n\nIn any trade war, as that example suggests, \u201cthe big losers are consumers, who are the vast majority of people,\u201d Professor Palen said. \u201cA few industries may benefit, but there are way more losers than winners. And the poor are the biggest losers of all. People like Trump may not care that much about paying a few extra dollars. But a lot of people don\u2019t have that luxury.\u201d", "title": "What History Has to Say About the \u2018Winners\u2019 in Trade Wars", "authors": ["James B. Stewart", "Common Sense"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "One of my favorites of these lab reports is Walt Whitman\u2019s essay \u201cDemocratic Vistas,\u201d published in 1871. The purpose of democracy, Whitman wrote, is not wealth, or even equality; it is the full flowering of individuals. By dispersing responsibility to all adults, democracy \u201csupplies a training school for making first class men.\u201d It is \u201clife\u2019s gymnasium.\u201d It forges \u201cfreedom\u2019s athletes\u201d \u2014 strong and equal women, courageous men, deep-souled people capable of governing themselves.\n\nWhitman had hoped that the end of the Civil War and Lincoln\u2019s sacrificial death would bring the nation together. But instead there was corruption, division, demoralization and inequality. For Whitman, America\u2019s great foe was feudalism, the caste structure of Europe that Americans had rebelled against, but that always threatened to grow back: \u201cOf all dangers to a nation, as things exist in our day, there can be no greater one than having certain portions of the people set off from the rest by a line drawn \u2014 they not privileged as others, but degraded, humiliated, made of no account.\u201d\n\nWhitman feared economic and social feudalism, but above all he detested cultural and moral feudalism. He believed that writers, artists, musicians, poets and preachers were the real legislators of mankind, and in America they were detached from the nitty-gritty American experience. They still looked back to Europe \u2014 to the parlor, the perfumed courtier and the spirit of gentility \u2014 for their models of character, manners and education. They looked down on America\u2019s democratic mass.\n\nThat left a spiritual vacuum, he believed. Americans had no way to see how their daily exertions contributed to a common spiritual cause. They saw no way to achieve individual salvation through community effort.\n\nAmerica has created a brilliant political constitution, Whitman wrote. It has amassed untold wealth. But it has not created a democratic culture that captures, celebrates and ennobles the way average Americans live day to day.\n\n\u201cThe problem of humanity all over the civilized world is social and religious, and is to be finally met and treated by literature.\u201d When there is no common sense of mystical purpose, you end up with alienation, division, distrust, \u201cuniversal ennui,\u201d a loss of faith in the American project. \u201cNever was there, perhaps, more hollowness at heart than at present, and here in the United States,\u201d he observed.", "title": "Opinion | What Holds America Together", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLook carefully at the map that tracks the Northwest Passage, above.\n\nHow difficult would the ocean passage be, do you imagine? What special challenges might sailors face, and why?\n\nIn \u201cThe Northwest Passage That Might Have Been,\u201d Brian Castner writes:\n\nIn the summer of 1789, a young fur trader named Alexander Mackenzie led an expedition in search of a Northwest Passage. He and his voyageurs and Chipewyan guides were attempting, 14 years before Lewis and Clark, to cross North America, paddling birch bark canoes down a river they hoped would pierce the Rocky Mountains. Mackenzie was a businessman who wanted to speed the pace of trade by connecting New York and China via an interior passage through the continent. He did find such a route, without knowing it. Mackenzie died thinking he was a failure, when he was really just 200 years early. Some ideas are fantastically ahead of their time. In 1636, Ren\u00e9 Descartes created contact lenses, using glass tubes filled with water; unfortunately, the wearer was unable to blink. Charles Babbage invented digital \u201cdifference engines\u201d \u2014 essentially modern programmable computers but powered by steam \u2014 in the 1820s. And Kodak developed digital cameras in 1974 but discarded the product idea because it thought no one wanted to look at photos on televisions. In a particularly ill-timed episode, Giovanni Caselli invented the fax machine in 1856. Letter writers could scribble a message onto electrically charged foil, and the portions covered by ink would block the flow of current. The stylus of Caselli\u2019s device then scanned each line of text, transmitting the signal via telegraph lines to a second machine, which would scrawl out a \u201cfac simile\u201d of the letter.\n\nHe continues:\n\nLike the fax machine and computer, Alexander Mackenzie\u2019s Northwest Passage was too forward-looking to be practical or useful. Today the melting Northwest Passage \u2014 along the North Slope of Alaska, through the maze of Canadian Arctic islands, then back down along Greenland\u2019s west coast, to the Atlantic \u2014 is regularly in the news. A holy grail for generations of explorers is now finally open, because of climate change. Giant cargo and oil tankers regularly ply those seas, and even the Crystal Serenity cruise ship, with 1,700 people onboard (many in black tie), has made the journey the past two summers.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 What was your reaction to the story about the long search for the Northwest Passage, and the fact it is now a reality because of climate change?\n\n\u2014 What other ideas can you think of that were fantastically ahead of their time, only to become a reality at some point after they were dreamed up?\n\n\u2014 Do you agree with the author that, \u201cIdeas do not exist only on their own merits. Timing matters.\u201d Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 What idea do you have that is ahead of its time? What made you think of it, and do you expect it will one day come to fruition? Why or why not?", "title": "What Idea Do You Have That Is Ahead of Its Time?", "authors": ["Caroline Crosson Gilpin", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "POTOMAC, Md. \u2014 On a Friday evening in March, 10 studio musicians, most from Nashville, were tightly clustered in a living room here, tuning their instruments and waiting for Lynda Carter, the actress best known for playing Wonder Woman in the 1970s TV series of the same name.\n\nAfter a few minutes, Ms. Carter entered the room, huddled with her band and apologized for the delay. She explained that she had just gotten off the phone with Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, and her husband, Paul.\n\n\u201cThey called to say congratulations on the new album and they\u2019re sorry they can\u2019t be with us this time around,\u201d said Ms. Carter, 66, wearing not leotard, high red boots and gold cuffs but a navy blazer, black pants and slip-on sneakers, her hair in a high ponytail, earlobes dripping with diamonds. \u201cThey\u2019re at the Houston rodeo with the family. Isn\u2019t that nice?\u201d\n\nFor over three decades, this onetime beauty queen turned actress and singer has cut a glamorous figure in this well-heeled suburb of Washington, D.C. The following evening, Ms. Carter and her band would be performing at the Kennedy Center, after which they were hitting the road for a brief tour, stopping in Los Angeles, New York and Nashville to celebrate the release of her fourth studio album, \u201cRed Rock n\u2019 Blues.\u201d", "title": "What Is Former Wonder Woman Lynda Carter Doing These Days?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cCan There Be Good Porn?,\u201d by Stoya (Op-Ed, March 5):\n\nYes, there can be good porn. As a theater professional I have seen porn actors who have explored the human body\u2019s limits bravely, openly, nearing the edge of recklessness. I have also viewed porn where the human spirit, removed from standard religious and moral constraints, howls in glee.\n\nThere are times I think that a particular porn actor shames the often puritanical stars of Hollywood. Of course, I have also viewed porn that is atrociously dishonest, meaning that the performances are forced or, at times, cruel. All of this, it seems clear to me, reflects the human condition.\n\nAnd finally, I often see porn on the nightly news, in the headlines coming out of Washington, in the lies told on TV commercials, and in our endless push toward more wars \u2014 all of which are is more harmful than viewing sexual adventurers performing for us.\n\nRICH QUATRONE, SPRING LAKE, N.J.", "title": "Opinion | What Is Porn?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor the latest on the winter storm, read Wednesday\u2019s live updates.\n\nJohn Schwartz, a New York Times reporter who covers climate change and the environment, is answering reader questions about the winter storm in the Northeast United States, the second to hit the region in less than a week. Ask your questions about the causes of dangerous winter storms by emailing storms@nytimes.com.\n\nIf it\u2019s cold, how can there be climate change?\n\nThat\u2019s a common question \u2014 one asked, in various ways, by the president of the United States. But it\u2019s based on a fallacy.\n\nWeather is not climate. Weather refers to day-to-day conditions; climate is about long-term trends. And the long-term trends show a planet that is warming, especially in the Northern Hemisphere. Even with occasional Arctic blasts of bitter cold, which we\u2019ve seen in much of the United States in recent years, 2017 had the second-highest surface temperatures ever recorded, surpassed only by 2016 \u2014 which was the third \u201chottest year\u201d in a row. The trends are clear, even if you can make a snowball in March in Central Park.\n\nReally, though \u2014 is there some connection between climate change and this cold weather?\n\nScientists have been looking at phenomena like cold spells, which occur when air from the Arctic dips south. After all, the Arctic is warming as a result of climate change, and that appears to be weakening the jet stream, which tends to hold that cold air up toward the top of the world. As Marlene Kretschmer, a researcher at the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research in Germany, told The Times in January, the connection is not yet fully established. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot of agreement that the Arctic plays a role, it\u2019s just not known exactly how much,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s a very complex system.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat is thundersnow?\n\nOn Wednesday, parts of New York shook with a thunderclap. In a snowstorm. The phenomenon goes by the portmanteau \u201cthundersnow,\u201d because, after all, that is an awesome word. And people get excited about it. Just watch Jim Cantore\u2019s reaction to it on The Weather Channel.\n\nWe expect snowstorms to envelop our world in silence. But as this NASA essay shows, thundersnow booms through a mechanism that appears to be similar to what causes thunder in conventional storms: electrically charged particles circulating in the cloud and building up static until something goes BOOM.", "title": "What Is Thundersnow? We Answer Your Questions About the Storm", "authors": ["John Schwartz"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nAmid a cultural reckoning over misconduct in the workplace, we spoke to more than 60 restaurant servers and bartenders, who shared stories of having to endure crude comments and even groping from customers \u2014 all to ensure a good tip.\n\nGoing to a restaurant is a near-universal experience, but one that can be vastly different for servers and customers. For example, do you tend to like painting, sculpture, photography, ceramics, textiles or other kinds of art? Why?\n\nLook through the images of art in this article and pick your favorites.What do you like about them?\n\nIn \u201c30 Must-See Artists at the Armory Show,\u201d Martha Schwendener writes:\n\nThe Armory Show, one of the city\u2019s top fairs for 20th- and 21st-century art, had a shake-up in the last year: one director replaced following accusations of sexual harassment, and a shift in focus under its new director, Nicole Berry. There is a notable drive toward streamlining, with fewer galleries this year \u2014 a total of 198 from 31 countries at Piers 92/94, the contiguous exhibition space. The timeline is being tightened, as well, to create less of a divide between the past and the present, between post-World War II art (usually found on the sleepier Pier 92) and newer work. It\u2019s a smart move, since much \u201chistorical\u201d art from the 1950s, \u201960s and \u201970s is now being shown in contemporary galleries anyway. The impulse is toward slow looking and away from flashier displays. There are live discussions with artists: Carolee Schneemann at 1 p.m. on Saturday, and JR with the gallerist Jeffrey Deitch at 2:30 p.m. on Sunday. There is plenty of historical work here that has not been seen before \u2014 or seen much \u2014 as well as commissioned projects and a very good mix of international, emerging and blue-chip galleries. Here are some currents I saw running through the fair. Fiber and Textile There has been a strong interest in fiber and textile art in the last half-decade, circling back to the \u201950s and \u201960s, as well as newer work. Textiles also honor traditions outside or alongside the Western painting canon. Jeffrey Gibson is a painter, but he also makes ceremonial-style garments, inspired by Native American Ghost Dance shirts. Several wonderful examples, presented by the gallery Kavi Gupta (Booth 611) and Roberts Projects (Booth 714), are suspended from the ceiling in Pier 94.\n\nShe continues:\n\nDigital A range of digital art and video, both historical and recent, is here. A small survey of Nam June Paik at Gagosian (800) has a 2005 television sculpture with lions and Merce Cunningham dancing on the screens, as well as never-before-seen drawings by Paik. Another Korean video artist, Hyun-Ki Park, is on view at Gallery Hyundai (519, F14), with an installation of televisions nestled amid boulders and photographs of Mr. Park hefting a television.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Have you ever been \u201cwowed\u201d by a piece of art or an exhibit?
