I am a native New Yorker, but somehow I fell in love with Austin: with the open sky and the people I worked with, with my fellow Longhorns, with Torchy\u2019s breakfast tacos, queso and good margaritas.\n\nI bought a house and thought I might stay for five years. I lived there for eight, the longest I have lived anywhere at a stretch.\n\nI left in 2013 for a lot of reasons. I started to realize that in a place like Texas, you needed kin, but I lost mine. In the space of two years, I lost both my parents, one to suicide, the other to cancer. In my grief, I tried to write through it, but it was more than I could power through alone.\n\nAnd in Austin, I felt a loneliness that was hard to explain. I wasn\u2019t just a New Yorker in Texas. I was a tall, dark-skinned black woman with natural hair. I was an outsider in a place that is supposed to value weirdness, but I never felt like the right kind of weird.", "title": "Opinion | What It\u2019s Like to Be Black in Austin", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "The composer John Luther Adams won the Pulitzer Prize in 2014 for \u201cBecome Ocean,\u201d a lushly tidal, terrifyingly immersive evocation of nature. \u201cThe music is not only a description of the sea \u2014 it behaves like it,\u201d Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim wrote in The New York Times. The music submerged the listener \u201cin a swirling, churning wash of sound.\u201d\n\nIts sequel, \u201cBecome Desert,\u201d will be given its premiere on Thursday, March 29, by Ludovic Morlot and the Seattle Symphony, the orchestra that also commissioned \u201cBecome Ocean.\u201d \u201cDesert\u201d features five different ensembles, moving at five different tempos and stationed around the audience. Voices sing a single word, \u201cluz\u201d (Spanish for \u201clight\u201d), inspired by a quotation from Octavio Paz: \u201cClose your eyes and listen to the singing of the light.\u201d\n\nHere Mr. Adams gives a sense of what the experience of hearing \u201cBecome Desert\u201d will be like.\n\nFrom the stillness around you a high glassy sound descends, like first light. Each new sound seems to breathe \u2014 emerging from and receding back into the stillness \u2014 and the glint of bells, like desert plants, here and there.\n\nAlmost imperceptibly the music swells and continues falling in pitch.\n\nFrom somewhere above \u2014 like a gleam of metal, like sunlight emerging from behind a ridgeline \u2014 comes the sound of flutes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou are in a strange landscape. You don\u2019t know how to read the weather or the light. You are unsure how long you will be here, or how challenging the journey may be.", "title": "What It\u2019s Like to Hear the Desert in Music", "authors": ["John Luther Adams"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Whatever you think about adult film, it is one of the most consumed forms of media in the world. Pornhub, the popular pornography website, draws 80 million visitors a day. Exact figures for the size of the industry are scarce, but experts put total sales around a billion dollars a year. Plus, studies show that adult film has become a form of sex education for young people around the world.\n\nIt is also, now, a regular subject in the news. A top adult film star, Jessica Drake, is one of the women who has accused President Donald J. Trump of sexual assault (he has denied the allegations). And of course, Stormy Daniels, whom I profiled with two colleagues, Matt Flegenheimer and Rebecca R. Ruiz, in a front-page story yesterday, is suing Mr. Trump, with whom she claimed she had a consensual affair, in order to be released from a nondisclosure agreement signed shortly before the 2016 election.\n\nBut gradually, the subject of adult film is getting a closer look. In 2014, scholars founded the academic journal \u201cPorn Studies.\u201d In 2015, the actress Rashida Jones produced a documentary, \u201cHot Girls Wanted,\u201d on the amateur porn scene in South Florida. The film later became a Netflix series of the same name and remains a major subject of conversation in adult film circles. Recently, a New York Times Magazine cover story, \u201cWhat Teenagers Are Learning From Online Porn,\u201d explored how much pornography teens consume and what effects it is having on their personal lives.\n\nStill, the industry remains shrouded in mystery, and very little has been written about the companies who make adult film. For example: Who owns them? When were they founded? How do they make money? Is it true that one company owns most of the content produced on the web? (Yes \u2014 MindGeek.) How hard was it for Ms. Clifford to become a top adult film performer and director?\n\nTo learn as much as possible, I traveled to industry conferences like XBIZ Miami, AVN in Las Vegas and Exxxotica New Jersey to meet industry leaders and understand their careers. I interviewed dozens of performers, agents, lawyers, producers, webcam models, website hosts and even executives from billing companies about how their jobs have evolved with changing technology.", "title": "What It\u2019s Like to Report About the Porn Industry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "With his power at home secure and the country\u2019s nuclear program (perhaps) completed, Mr. Kim appears to have the confidence to emerge as a recognized, if not yet respected player on the international scene, a crowning achievement for an ambitious young leader.\n\nBefriending a fading ally\n\nChina has long been North Korea\u2019s ally and patron, a lifeline keeping its struggling economy afloat. Relations between the two, though, have become increasingly strained, and Mr. Kim\u2019s government needs Beijing\u2019s help in emerging from its international isolation.\n\nChina, evidently frustrated by the provocative behavior of its junior partner, has joined the United States and others in tightening sanctions, imposed in response to the North\u2019s nuclear and missile tests. Mr. Kim has yet to meet his Chinese counterpart, and as he heads into direct talks with the United States and South Korea, he could use all the diplomatic support he can get.\n\nAt a minimum, Mr. Kim cannot afford to deliver a diplomatic snub to an increasingly assertive and confident Mr. Xi by bypassing him during the coming talks with Seoul and Washington.\n\nMaking Beijing a player again\n\nChina, which initiated the visit, had been left on the sidelines in the recent diplomatic breakthroughs.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIf talks progress, Chinese officials would certainly want to reclaim a central role in the diplomatic maneuvering to protect the country\u2019s own strategic interests on the Korean Peninsula.\n\n\u201cChina worries about being bypassed by North Korea and Trump,\u201d said Shen Zhihua, a prominent historian in China. \u201cChina fears some collusion and fears its interests being disregarded.\u201d\n\nPlaying world powers against each other\n\nWith increasing signs that the sanctions have begun to hurt in North Korea, Mr. Kim may have realized that he cannot survive a sustained economic squeeze.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA high-profile diplomatic foray \u2014 coupled with a suspension of provocative statements and new weapons tests \u2014 should at a minimum avoid new sanctions and buy time for the economy.\n\nMr. Kim could also seek an easing of sanctions as a concession for continuing talks. China and Russia, as previous negotiations have shown, may be less willing than the United States to punish the North if it commits to diplomacy.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s playing one superpower against another,\u201d said Xia Yafeng, a historian at Long Island University.\n\nStrengthening his grip at home\n\nOne of the first things Mr. Kim promised to his people when he took power was not to force them to \u201ctighten their belts again.\u201d\n\nNow that he claims he has nuclear missiles capable of hitting their country\u2019s archenemy, the United States, he needs to focus on rebuilding the economy, and for that he needs the help of China and its vast market.\n\n\u201cTo the North Koreans, improving ties with South Korea is important, but more important and urgent is improving ties with China,\u201d said Cheong Seong-chang, a senior analyst at the Sejong Institute, a South Korean research organization.", "title": "What Kim Jong-un May Get in Reaching Out to China", "authors": ["Steven Lee Myers", "Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Rather than teaching the government a lesson, sanctions have provided it with a useful talking point. Officials say sanctions benefit the Russian economy by encouraging the production of local goods. (Whether that\u2019s true is another story.) Polls have found that most Russians believe the government should pursue its current foreign policy despite the sanctions.\n\nThe closest the president came to outlining his foreign policy program was two and a half weeks before the vote. On March 1, during an address to the Federal Assembly, he spent about a third of his time talking about defense and foreign policy.\n\nHe boasted that Russia is testing a new line of nuclear-capable weapons that, he said, can easily overcome American antimissile defenses. According to the president, this is a response to the decision by the United States in 2001 to leave the Antiballistic Missile Treaty signed in 1972 with the Soviet Union. \u201cYou didn\u2019t listen to our country then,\u201d Mr. Putin said. \u201cListen to us now.\u201d And although quite a few experts doubt that these new missiles are anywhere near operational, most ordinary citizens were impressed.\n\nWhat does all of this mean for the future of Russia\u2019s foreign policy as the country prepares for Mr. Putin\u2019s fourth and probably final term?\n\nIn the coming years, the Kremlin will continue to pursue what it sees as its rightful interests in Ukraine, Syria and elsewhere in whatever way it sees fit and no matter what others think. But at the same time, as Mr. Putin begins to look ahead, he has signaled that he is ready to negotiate with the rest of the world \u2014 so long as it is on \u201cequal\u201d terms.\n\nThe president sent this message last weekend, for example, in a long interview with Megyn Kelly of NBC, in which he indicated that Russia is ready to consider a prolongation of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty or even a new agreement with further reductions. He also repeated several times that Moscow is interested in signing a treaty with the United States on cyber issues.\n\nIt is clear that Mr. Putin is more interested in foreign affairs than he is in domestic policy. Anyone who has watched him speak at a news conference or in a public speech can see where his enthusiasm is.\n\nSo far, his adventurous foreign policy has worked for him, both domestically and internationally. As he eyes the eventual exit, he may be looking to leave a more august legacy, one that includes real and durable achievements. The problem is that in recent years, what Russia sees as victory too often means a loss for someone else.", "title": "Opinion | What Makes Putin So Popular at Home? His Reputation Abroad", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Every day is a curly hair day for sheep. Those curls and kinks are part of what makes woolen sweaters so cozy \u2014 the maze of fibers helps trap warm air, keeping it close to the body. But wrapped up in those curls may also be answers to a longstanding mystery: exactly how a strand of hair winds itself into a curl on the cellular level.\n\nFor many years, there were two competing theories to explain what makes hairs curl in sheep. Research by scientists in New Zealand and Japan published Thursday in the Journal of Experimental Biology finds that neither theory is exactly correct. But it remains likely that differences between certain cells on a hair may explain what makes a sheep\u2019s wool curly. And while human hair has some crucial differences from wool, understanding why curls happen in one mammal\u2019s hair could eventually shed light on others, including ours.\n\nAt first, the cells that will make up a strand of hair are soft and squishy, like little round bags of fluid. But as they grow longer and get extruded through a hair follicle, they get thinner, harder and full of keratin, a protein.\n\nIn human hairs, the cells end up winding around one another in complex tangles, which makes it difficult to draw conclusions about how they contribute to curl. So researchers led by Duane Harland, a scientist at AgResearch in New Zealand, clipped samples from six New Zealand merino sheep, whose wool cells are much more tidy.", "title": "What Makes Some Hair Curly? Not Quite What Scientists Thought", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Before reading the article, draw an effective leader. In your drawing, include the appearance, qualities and behaviors of a leader.\n\nHeather Murphy writes in \u201cPicture a Leader. Is She a Woman?\u201d:\n\nThis series of images emerged from a simple prompt: \u201cDraw an effective leader.\u201d Tina Kiefer, a professor of organizational behavior at the University of Warwick in the United Kingdom, fell upon the exercise accidentally, while leading a workshop full of executives who did not speak much English. Since then it has been adopted by organizational psychologists across the world. In terms of gender, the results are almost always the same. Both men and women almost always draw men. \u201cEven when the drawings are gender neutral,\u201d which is uncommon, Dr. Kiefer said in an email, \u201cthe majority of groups present the drawing using language that indicates male (he) rather than neutral or female.\u201d And yet, her clients often insisted that what they meant by \u201che\u201d is actually \u201cboth.\u201d Several researchers in organizational psychology who have had a similar experience with this exercise decided to investigate further. How might holding unconscious assumptions about gender affect people\u2019s abilities to recognize emerging leadership? What they found, in a study posted by the Academy of Management Journal, seems to confirm what many women have long suspected: getting noticed as a leader in the workplace is more difficult for women than for men. Even when a man and a woman were reading the same words off a script, only the man\u2019s leadership potential was recognized.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 What similarities and differences do you notice between your drawing and the ones from the article? Do these illustrations surprise you? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 Who is someone in your own life or from public life you consider to be a great leader and why?\n\n\u2014 In your opinion, what makes a person a great leader? What qualities does she or he have? How does she or he act? Given this criteria, do you think women and men can be equally effective leaders? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 Have your leadership abilities ever been overlooked, or have you ever underestimated someone else\u2019s leadership abilities, because of gender \u2014 whether in class, group projects, sports teams, clubs or other group activities? If so, what was that experience like?", "title": "What Makes Someone a Great Leader?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "What the heck is the American Songbook at this point? The annual Lincoln Center series bearing that name may not be clarifying matters. The 2018 season started back in January with the country-folk rocker John Paul White, formerly of the Civil Wars, then went on to feature the disparate likes of the Broadway heartthrob Aaron Tveit, Rachel Bloom and Adam Schlesinger of television\u2019s \u201cCrazy Ex-Girlfriend,\u201d the Blind Boys of Alabama, and Rosanne Cash, who wrapped things up on Tuesday \u2014 with, perhaps tellingly, a set incorporating songs from her forthcoming musical based on the film \u201cNorma Rae.\u201d\n\nWhat connects these dots? And if the American Songbook is everything, is it anything?\n\nThe series\u2019 debut slate, in 1999, consisted of two programs focusing on classic composers. The first was dedicated to Harold Arlen (\u201cOver the Rainbow,\u201d \u201cStormy Weather\u201d) and the second honored Richard Rodgers (\u201cMy Funny Valentine,\u201d \u201cSome Enchanted Evening\u201d). The interpreters were drawn mostly from the cabaret and Broadway ranks: Barbara Cook, Faith Prince, Audra McDonald \u2014 names familiar to people who spend quality time ensconced in red-velvet seats. Clearly the American Songbook (many people qualify it as \u201cGreat\u201d) consisted of songs from Broadway and Tin Pan Alley, blessedly untouched by rock \u2019n\u2019 roll or singer-songwriter confessionals.\n\nNearly two decades later, the definition has gotten a little muddled \u2014 which is not a bad thing at all. Guests have ranged far and wide, and included Thurston Moore; the rapper Talib Kweli (though hip-hop has, overall, not been featured nearly enough); the Magnetic Fields performing all of their \u201c69 Love Songs\u201d; and Joey Arias pulling off full Billie Holiday realness, gardenia in his hair.\n\nOn the surface, little connects the last three shows in the 2018 edition: Justin Vivian Bond singing the Carpenters; an evening exploring the catalog of Scott Frankel and Michael Korie, the team behind such musicals as \u201cGrey Gardens\u201d and \u201cWar Paint\u201d; and Ms. Cash, a literate Americana writer and performer who has stepped outside of her father\u2019s long shadow. And yet, all three programs felt very much part of a continuum \u2014 and not just because the audience always sat politely, the performers had dressed up for the occasion, and nobody ever broke a sweat.", "title": "What Makes a Songbook American? Justin Vivian Bond and Rosanne Cash Have a Few Answers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Over the same period, \u201cfeeling thermometer\u201d ratings of the opposition candidate fell sharply, from 56.2 in 1968 to 25.1 in 2012. In 2016, the ratings of the opposition candidate plummeted to 12.2.\n\nDespite the public\u2019s increasingly adverse views of political parties, party loyalty in voting has now reached record levels, according to the two authors. Partisanship currently \u201chas a stronger influence on vote choice than at any time since the 1950s.\u201d\n\nHow can these conflicting trends be reconciled? Voters dislike the parties and are dissatisfied with their candidates, even as they cast straight-ticket ballots. This may sound inconsistent, but it\u2019s not that hard to understand.\n\nAccording to Abramowitz and Webster, in 2016, \u201clarge majorities of Democrats and Republicans truly despised the opposing party\u2019s nominee.\u201d Voters were motivated to go to the polls to cast ballots against the opposition\u2019s nominee much more than to support their own party\u2019s choice. The key factor \u201cin predicting party loyalty in the 2016 presidential election was how voters felt about the opposing party\u2019s presidential candidate.\u201d\n\nIn fact, Abramowitz and Webster found that \u201cthis measure was twice as important in predicting loyalty as feelings toward the candidate from one\u2019s own party.\u201d Partisan loyalty remained \u201cvery high because both Democratic and Republican identifiers overwhelmingly viewed the opposing party\u2019s candidate with deep hostility.\u201d\n\nIn the 1970s, about a quarter of all voters split their tickets, voting for presidential and congressional candidates of different parties. Now, not even one in 10 does so. The result:\n\nIn 2016, all 34 Senate elections and 400 of 435 U.S. House elections were won by the party winning the presidential election in the state or district.\n\nIn their analysis of negative partisanship, Iyengar and Krupenkin argue that voting on the basis of hostility has an unexpected consequence: It lessens pressure on the winner to be accountable to his or her supporters, effectively freeing winners to thumb their noses at many of the voters who put them in office:\n\nWhen citizens\u2019 support for a candidate stems primarily from their strong dislike for the opposing candidate, they are less subject to the logic of accountability. Their psychic satisfaction comes more from defeating and humiliating the out-group, and less from any performance or policy benefits that might accrue from the victory of the in-party. For this group of voters, candidates have every incentive to inflame partisan negativity, further entrenching affective polarization.\n\nBy this logic, Iyengar and Krupenkin argue that\n\nIf partisans care less about their own party\u2019s performance and instead focus on their distrust of the opposition party, elected officials no longer need campaign on their own merits; instead, they have good reason to try even harder to denigrate the opposition.\n\nIn other words, Trump critics who anticipate a collapse of support when he fails to deliver on campaign promises are likely to be disappointed. According to Iyengar and Krupenkin,\n\nThe primal sense of \u201cus against them\u201d makes partisans fixate on the goal of defeating and even humiliating the opposition at all costs. This negativity bias in voting behavior undermines traditional theories of electoral accountability that rest on incumbents\u2019 ability to deliver policy and performance benefits.\n\nCandidates and incumbents, Iyengar and Krupenkin continue, \u201care less likely to be sanctioned for demonstrating incompetence, dishonesty and unethical behavior.\u201d\n\nTo make their point, the authors cite Roy Moore, the Republican candidate for Senate in Alabama last December, pointing out that under partisan conditions \u201ca candidate accused of molesting teenage children is able to attract 91 percent of the vote from his copartisans.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | What Motivates Voters More Than Loyalty? Loathing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI believe it gave hope to teams that they can beat UConn as well,\u201d William said on Saturday. \u201cOver the years, people have been complaining that UConn\u2019s too good, they just dominate everyone. I feel like there\u2019s programs out there that can get the job done.\u201d\n\nBy Saturday morning, William had not yet contacted Ogunbowale, but she said she would probably tell her before Sunday\u2019s tip-off: \u201cYou\u2019re an all-American. You\u2019re supposed to do that. I\u2019m proud of you.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut William drew a distinction between her shot and Ogunbowale\u2019s. Her own shot had stopped UConn\u2019s record winning streak, providing both an epic upset and cathartic redemption after the Bulldogs had lost by 60 points to the Huskies in the 2016 N.C.A.A. tournament.\n\nBoth shots were great, William said, but she added, \u201cFor us to hit that shot and beat them, I just won\u2019t compare it.\u201d\n\nIn retrospect, perhaps it was inevitable that William effectively ran out of gas in the 2017 championship game.\n\nShe had scored 41 points to help defeat Baylor in overtime in the final of the Oklahoma City Regional. The 66-64 victory over UConn also extended into extra time. William did not get to bed after the game until 4 a.m., when the celebration and interviews and adrenaline finally ebbed. Then she was up early the next morning for more interviews, practice and an autograph session.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cBeating UConn takes so much out of you,\u201d said Kara Lawson, an ESPN commentator who played in three Final Fours at Tennessee. \u201cI don\u2019t think they had any juice left. Think about it. You hit that huge shot, your Twitter is blowing up, your Instagram, your phone. You\u2019re not in bed till late. The next day, you\u2019re playing for the national championship. I think that all hit her.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe day after the championship game, William went to the gym at Mississippi State and practiced her shooting. \u201cMy safe haven,\u201d she called it. She did not complain about being benched and has not complained this season about sharing more playing time with her fellow point guard Jazzmun Holmes. Coach Vic Schaefer does not owe her an explanation, she said.\n\nHe has said repeatedly that he will play the point guard with the most energy and the hottest hand.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t really know a player in college basketball who\u2019s been complaining to the coaches,\u201d William said. \u201cLet me know if you find one and see if they\u2019re on the team next week.\u201d\n\nThose who have known her the longest say that she has always been this way, stoic, even-keeled. She has spent her career disproving those who said she was too short. She has had to overcome the loss of her stepfather, who put a basketball in her hands when she was 3 years old and died of a heart attack when she was a senior in high school.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s just a positive kid,\u201d said Andy Landers, a former coach at Georgia whose summer camp William attended. He joked, \u201cShe thinks the glass is half full because her height won\u2019t let her see the other half.\u201d\n\nThis season, William\u2019s scoring is less urgent. It is her job to facilitate the dominance of the 6-7 center Teaira McCowan (21 points, 25 rebounds in Friday\u2019s semifinal win over Louisville) and the perimeter shooting of forward Victoria Vivians (25 points in the semifinals).\n\nBut Dionnah Jackson-Durrett, an assistant coach at Mississippi State, has implored William to be ready to take over when others languish. In the fourth quarter on Friday, William blocked a layup attempt by a Louisville player who is a foot taller. Then she assisted on a 3-point shot that forced overtime.\n\nWith 46 seconds remaining in the extra period and Mississippi State holding a 1-point lead, William hit two free throws. Then, with her back to the basket, she intercepted a long pass. That essentially put the game beyond reach for Louisville, which finally succumbed, 73-63.\n\n\u201cShe is a tough, competitive cuss,\u201d Schaefer said.\n\nAsked if she would prefer to hit another game-winning shot on Sunday, William smiled and said, no, she would prefer a comfortable lead.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s nice to hit a buzzer beater,\u201d she said, \u201cbut no one wants it to come down to that.\u201d", "title": "What N.C.A.A. Women\u2019s Finalists Share: Big Shots That Felled a Giant", "authors": ["Jer\u00e9 Longman"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "The Second Amendment to the Constitution reads:\n\nA well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed.\n\nThe Library of Congress writes, \u201cThe meaning of this sentence is not self-evident, and has given rise to much commentary but relatively few Supreme Court decisions.\u201d\n\nWhat do you think the words of the Second Amendment mean? What relevance should they have for the national debate about gun laws?\n\nThen read these four excerpts from Opinion pieces published this month in The Times \u2014 or follow the links to read the complete Op-Ed \u2014 and decide: What do you think lawmakers should do about guns and gun violence?\n\nExcerpt 1: In \u201cJohn Paul Stevens: Repeal the Second Amendment,\u201d John Paul Stevens, a retired associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, writes:\n\nRarely in my lifetime have I seen the type of civic engagement schoolchildren and their supporters demonstrated in Washington and other major cities throughout the country this past Saturday. These demonstrations demand our respect. They reveal the broad public support for legislation to minimize the risk of mass killings of schoolchildren and others in our society. That support is a clear sign to lawmakers to enact legislation prohibiting civilian ownership of semiautomatic weapons, increasing the minimum age to buy a gun from 18 to 21 years old, and establishing more comprehensive background checks on all purchasers of firearms. But the demonstrators should seek more effective and more lasting reform. They should demand a repeal of the Second Amendment.\n\n_________\n\nExcerpt 2: In \u201cAfter the March, Follow This Gun Reform Battle Plan,\u201d Steve Israel, a Democratic representative from Long Island from 2001 to 2017, writes:\n\nIt has been 38 days since the mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla.; 174 days since the shooting at a concert in Las Vegas; 1,011 days since the killings at a church in Charleston, S.C.; and 1,926 since the tragedy at Sandy Hook Elementary School. Ten days ago, students organized a nationwide school walkout to demonstrate their outrage about these and other shootings. On Saturday they plan to amass in Washington to pressure a Congress that has done nothing meaningful to protect American children in classrooms, movie theaters, churches, malls \u2014 because, thanks to the National Rifle Association, many of their elected representatives are too busy protecting their re-election. My advice to the students? When you finish marching on the mall, march into the specific congressional districts where you can actually make a difference.\n\nHe continues:\n\nYou can stage marches and school walkouts, but then walk into the swing congressional districts that matter. In the end it\u2019s not about standing up to be heard. It\u2019s about changing who sits in Congress.\n\n_________\n\nExcerpt 3: In \u201cStop Shielding Gun Makers,\u201d Brad S. Karp, the chairman of the law firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, and H. Christopher Boehning, a partner there, write:\n\nSenator Charles Schumer has proposed three measures to reduce gun violence: expanded background checks, protective orders to disarm individuals at risk of violence or self-harm, and an assault weapons ban. These proposals are critically important. But there is another effective response that has been largely ignored: repeal of a law that prevents suits against the gun industry. A bedrock principle of the American legal system is accountability for wrongdoing. Businesses that cause harm may be held legally responsible in a court of law. Through the imposition of financial liability, our legal system encourages businesses to reduce harm to consumers by making their products safer and disclosing the risks associated with their use. Thanks in part to the accountability imposed by lawsuits, society knows more about the dangers of smoking, and tobacco companies market their products more responsibly. Automakers continually develop and install new safety features, and these innovations deliver results: From 1975 to 2016, the rate of motor vehicle deaths decreased by nearly half. While motor vehicle deaths have declined over the last two decades, firearm deaths have not: According to the most recent statistics from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, more people now die from firearms than motor vehicle accidents.\n\n_________\n\nExcerpt 4: In \u201cWhy Gun Culture Is So Strong in Rural America,\u201d Robert Leonard, the news director for the radio stations KNIA and KRLS, writes:\n\nIt\u2019s been many years since I hunted squirrels and rabbits with my Grandpa Leonard. I grew up around guns and remember the pride I had when I completed my N.R.A.-sponsored gun safety training in Boy Scouts, back when the N.R.A. was a group primarily known for teaching gun appreciation and safety rather than lobbying. I have come to understand and appreciate arguments for more gun control. But guns are important to the culture in my conservative community in Iowa, and people around here reject most gun control legislation. So I do my best to understand where they are coming from. One morning after the mass shootings in Parkland, Fla., I spoke about them with a police-officer friend. He has led active-shooter trainings in our schools. He believes that better background checks might help prevent some gun violence, and that people need to do a better job securing their firearms (especially from suicidal teenagers). But he doesn\u2019t believe that significant gun control measures will ever meet approval in rural America, including a ban on AR-15-style semiautomatic rifles. He confided that many conservative police officers do not want more gun control and that other officers have told him that should they ever have to start taking guns away from people, they will quit their jobs. Like most rural conservatives, he truly believes that taking guns away from law-abiding citizens will never solve America\u2019s gun problems, including mass shootings. He says gun control has never stopped criminals from getting guns, and never will.\n\n_________\n\n\n\nStudents: After reading the four excerpts above, tell us:\n\n\u2014 Why does this topic interest you? How have your own experiences shaped your opinions? What questions or concerns does this topic raise for you?", "title": "What Should Lawmakers Do About Guns and Gun Violence?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Historical data of this kind is sparse, but in Iowa the Democrats have never enjoyed a turnout advantage over 30 years of comparable data. In the last 15 years of data in North Carolina general elections, it barely happened once.\n\nThe fact that something hasn\u2019t happened before doesn\u2019t mean it can\u2019t happen in November. The growing affluence and educational attainment of white Democrats might give them a much better chance of earning a turnout advantage than in the past.\n\nBut so far, Democrats have not been able to sustain the same advantage in higher-turnout elections, such as in the general elections in New Jersey and Virginia, or in the special congressional election in Georgia\u2019s Sixth District.\n\nIn Virginia, Democrats still appeared to have a turnout advantage compared with all registered voters, but not a big one. The Republicans had an advantage in the Georgia Sixth runoff election between Jon Ossoff and Karen Handel, the highest-profile race of all. And while Democrats fared well over all in these elections, the party\u2019s showing was not especially impressive compared with what they have often pulled off in lower-turnout elections.\n\nThe relatively unimpressive Democratic performance in Virginia and New Jersey is particularly noteworthy: The two elections are usually entirely omitted from analysis of recent races, even though more votes were cast in those two elections than in all of the special elections combined.\n\nThe Democrats could still fare extremely well even if their turnout advantage is diminished. Indeed, they did well in the special election in Pennsylvania\u2019s 18th District and in the Alabama Senate race. Turnout was quite high for both sides in the two races. On the other hand, one could argue that these races aren\u2019t an easily replicable model for Democratic success.\n\nThere isn\u2019t enough data to definitively resolve this question. But if, on average, Democrats are benefiting from unsustainable turnout, it seems reasonable to suppose that they might still fare a bit worse in the general election than in the broad set of special elections. The results in Georgia, Virginia and New Jersey at least suggest it\u2019s a possibility.", "title": "What Special Elections Can\u2019t Tell Us About a Democratic Wave", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "The Reader Center is one way we in the newsroom are trying to connect with you, by highlighting your perspectives and experiences and offering insight into how we work.\n\nThere\u2019s an app for that, but I\u2019m not sure anyone cares anymore. That thought was stuck in my head when I pitched the idea for Tech We\u2019re Using, a column about how New York Times journalists use tech in their jobs and personal lives.\n\nOver the last decade, smartphones have become the center of how we consume and create media. Apps used to be a novelty; there was a period of time when smartphones were young and we were excited about finding new apps to download.\n\nBut by now, there are millions of apps for smartphones, and people have found and settled on the tools that are the most useful to them. So what are people doing with tech now that it\u2019s become such a personalized commodity tailored to their lives?", "title": "What Topics Should the \u2018Tech We\u2019re Using\u2019 Column Tackle Next?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "SINGAPORE \u2014 Days before winning the election in 2016, Donald Trump stood on a stage and directed an accusation at a tiny country halfway across the world: Singapore, he said, was stealing American jobs.\n\nSingapore is now on the tip of Mr. Trump\u2019s tongue again \u2014 but this time, he\u2019s expressing admiration for its death penalty for drug trafficking. He has reportedly invited government representatives to brief the White House on their approach to drug trafficking, including their use of capital punishment. Mr. Trump seems to believe he can learn a thing or two from Singapore.\n\nThis is convenient for the Singapore government, which has been using the global opioid crisis as an argument for the retention of capital punishment. While the American media reported Mr. Trump\u2019s praise for Singapore\u2019s \u201czero tolerance\u201d stance, the country hanged a 39-year-old Ghanaian named Billy Agbozo on March 9, and a 56-year-old Singaporean, Hishamrudin bin Mohd, on March 16. Both had been convicted of drug trafficking. These are the first two executions of 2018, as far as we know; information about imminent executions is not made available, and the prison service announces the number of hangings only in its annual report.\n\nBut the borrowing of ideas hasn\u2019t been a one-way street: the government here has taken a page out of Mr. Trump\u2019s book. The new Select Committee on Deliberate Online Falsehoods is holding public hearings to explore measures for tackling \u201cfake news.\u201d The committee is meant to examine a range of options, but there are strong hints that new restrictions on the media are on the way, not least because the law minister, who is also a member of the committee, has already said that legislation is a \u201cno-brainer.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | What Trump Is Learning From Singapore \u2014 and Vice Versa", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Because there must be something very important in them that he wants to keep hidden. Maybe it\u2019s just the embarrassment that he is not as rich as he claims, or, maybe, it\u2019s something more fundamental \u2014 like how dependent he is on Russian oligarchs for financing, so much so that Putin has leverage on him. Whatever the reason, though, when Trump saw he could get away with hiding them, he knew he could break any rule, tell any lie and violate any presidential norm \u2014 and he\u2019s done just that.\n\nPutin\u2019s turkey was even more serious. It was the shooting down of that Malaysian civilian airliner, Flight MH17, over Ukraine on July 17, 2014, killing all 298 people onboard.\n\nRemember the story? A Dutch-led international investigation \u2014 relying on, among other things, 150,000 intercepted phone calls \u2014 found that Putin\u2019s proxies in eastern Ukraine had requested that Russia send them an SA-11 surface-to-air missile launcher. And it was trucked over the Russian border into Ukraine, where it shot down that Malaysian airliner (probably mistaking it for a Ukrainian military plane) and then was trucked back to Russia hours later.\n\nPutin\u2019s military was up to its neck in this. Putin did not push the button on that missile, but he created the conditions for it to shoot down that plane \u2014 and he walked away from it as if the plane were brought down by lightning, making up one implausible story after another. He got slapped on the wrist with a few sanctions, but his complicity faded away into a mist of baldfaced lies.\n\nWho wanted to confront Russia, with all its gas exports to Europe and all its oligarchs throwing money around London or buying condos in places like \u2026 Trump Tower in New York? Putin surely also said to himself, \u201cCan you believe I got away with that? Why not poison a former Russian spy in London with a banned military nerve agent or perpetrate genocide in Syria? Who\u2019s going to stop me?\u201d\n\nTrump and Putin are cut from the same cloth. Their strategy is: keep pushing, keep grabbing, keep lying, keep denying, no matter how implausible the denials \u2014 and never apologize. Because when you lie on an industrial scale, it overwhelms everyone else. Normal people just don\u2019t behave that way, and the sheer shamelessness eventually exhausts them.\n\nThe lesson that the Bedouin chief was trying to teach his sons is that he could live his life without that turkey \u2014 but he couldn\u2019t live his life with what the stealing of his turkey with impunity implied: that when people keep eroding the norms of society, stealing \u2014 turkeys or the truth \u2014 eventually becomes the norm.", "title": "Opinion | What Trump and Putin Have in Common", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Television personality, producer, entrepreneur and former model Tyra Banks has a lengthy resume, but is probably best known these days for instructing aspiring models to \u201csmize\u201d (smile with their eyes) on \u201cAmerica\u2019s Next Top Model,\u201d a fashion reality TV series she created and hosts. It\u2019s currently in its 24th season. Her book \u201cPerfect Is Boring: 10 Things My Crazy, Fierce Mama Taught Me About Beauty, Booty, and Being a Boss\u201d will be published in April.\n\nWhile Ms. Banks mostly travels for work, she describes herself as \u201ca master at tacking on pleasure,\u201d commonly adding on vacation days to weeks of intensive shooting abroad. \u201cAmerica\u2019s Next Top Model\u201d has taken contestants around the world, but her favorite was Morocco. \u201cWhat I love about Marrakesh is the people, and the earth, and the architecture are like the same color. It\u2019s just that beautiful terracotta color and it just all blends, it\u2019s just beautiful. The whole town is like a makeup base foundation,\u201d she said.\n\nShe describes herself as obsessed with hotels, even going so far as to model her own bedroom after a room in the Four Seasons New York. \u201cI used to stay there when I was a Victoria\u2019s Secret model, actually, and I studied that room. I don\u2019t think I took pictures back then, but I talked to the interior designer, and I made it as close to that Four Seasons as possible, including the bathtub that fills up in like 60 seconds.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s what she can\u2019t travel without.", "title": "What Tyra Banks Can\u2019t Travel Without", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Moreover, critics argued, the primary roots of opposition to the American-backed government in Saigon were indigenous and deep rooted, not just in North Vietnam, but throughout the South.\n\nIndeed, from the late 1950s through the mid-1960s the bulk of Communist-led fighting was carried out by southern guerrillas of the National Liberation Front, known to its enemies as the Vietcong. Only after the war was well underway did large units from North Vietnam arrive on the southern front. Antiwar opponents also challenged the claim that South Vietnam was an \u201cindependent nation\u201d established by the Geneva Accords of 1954. Those agreements called for a temporary partition of Vietnam to be shortly followed by a nationwide election to choose a single leader for a unified Vietnam. When it became clear to both Saigon and Washington that the Communist leader Ho Chi Minh would be the overwhelming victor, the South Vietnamese government of Ngo Dinh Diem, with American support, decided to cancel the election.\n\nThus began a two-decade failed effort to build a permanent country called \u201cSouth Vietnam.\u201d The government in Saigon was never a malleable puppet of the United States, but it was nonetheless wholly dependent on American military and economic support to survive against its enemies, including many non-Communist parties and factions in the South.\n\nArmed with these criticisms, many opponents of American policy in the 1960s described Vietnam as a civil war \u2014 not like the relatively clear-cut North-South division of the American Civil War, but a nationwide struggle of Communist-led forces of the South and North against the American-backed government in the South. By 1966, this analysis was even embraced by some mainstream politicians, including Senator William Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and Senator Eugene McCarthy, who ran as an antiwar presidential candidate in 1968. Both men called attention to the \u201cSouth Vietnamese civil war\u201d to emphasize the strength of the southern insurgency and the failure of the Saigon government to gain the broad support of its own people.\n\nBy 1972, the idea that Vietnam posed a threat to Cold War America was so discredited, it sometimes sounded as if America\u2019s only remaining war aim was to get back its P.O.W.s (President Richard Nixon bizarrely claimed that Hanoi was using them as \u201cnegotiating pawns\u201d). Even more mind-boggling were Nixon\u2019s historic 1972 trips to Beijing and Moscow. Many Americans wondered how Nixon could offer toasts of peace to Mao Zedong and Leonid Brezhnev while still waging war in Vietnam. As the journalist Jonathan Schell put it, \u201cIf these great powers were not, after all, the true foe,\u201d then the war in Vietnam \u201creally was a civil war in a small country, as its opponents had always said, and the United States had no business taking part in it.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut alongside the \u201ccivil war\u201d interpretation, a more radical critique developed \u2014 the view that America\u2019s enemy in Vietnam was engaged in a long-term war for national liberation and independence, first from the French and then the United States. According to this position, the war was best understood not as a Cold War struggle between East and West, or a Vietnamese civil war, but as an anticolonial struggle, similar to dozens of others that erupted throughout the Third World in the wake of World War II. When the French were defeated by Vietnamese revolutionaries (despite enormous American support), the United States stepped in directly to wage a counterrevolutionary war against an enemy determined to achieve full and final independence from foreign control.\n\nThis interpretation was shared by many on the antiwar left, including Daniel Ellsberg, the once-hawkish defense analyst who turned so strongly against the war that he was willing to sabotage his career by making public 7,000 pages of classified documents about the history of the Vietnam War, the so-called Pentagon Papers. Ellsberg made his argument most succinctly in the 1974 documentary \u201cHearts and Minds.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe name for a conflict in which you are opposing a revolution is counterrevolution,\u201d he said. \u201cA war in which one side is entirely financed and equipped and supported by foreigners is not a civil war.\u201d The question used to be, he added, \u201cmight it be possible that we were on the wrong side in the Vietnamese war. We weren\u2019t on the wrong side; we are the wrong side.\u201d\n\nIn the decades since 1975, all three major interpretations have persisted. Some writers and historians have embraced President Ronald Reagan\u2019s view that the war was a \u201cnoble cause\u201d that might have been won. That position has failed to persuade most specialists in the field, in large part because it greatly exaggerates the military and political virtues and success of the United States and the government of South Vietnam. It also falls short because it depends on counterfactual claims that victory would have been achieved if only the United States had extended its support for Diem (instead of greenlighting his overthrow), or tried a different military strategy, or done a better job winning hearts and minds. However, the war as it was actually conducted by the United States and its allies was a disaster by every measure.\n\nIn recent decades, a number of historians \u2014 particularly younger scholars trained in Vietnamese and other languages \u2014 have developed various versions of the civil war interpretation. Some of them view the period after the French defeat in 1954 as \u201cpost-colonial,\u201d a time in which long-brewing internal conflicts between competing versions of Vietnamese nationalism came to a head. As the historian Jessica Chapman of Williams College puts it, \u201cThe Vietnam War was, at its core, a civil war greatly exacerbated by foreign intervention.\u201d Others have described it as a civil war that became \u201cinternationalized.\u201d\n\nWhile these scholars have greatly enhanced our knowledge of the complexity and conflict in Vietnamese history, politics and culture, they don\u2019t, in my view, assign enough responsibility to the United States for causing and expanding the war as a neocolonial power.\n\nLet\u2019s try a thought experiment. What if our own Civil War bore some resemblance to the Vietnamese \u201ccivil war\u201d? For starters, we would have to imagine that in 1860 a global superpower \u2014 say Britain \u2014 had strongly promoted Southern secession, provided virtually all of the funding for the ensuing war and dedicated its vast military to the battle. We must also imagine that in every Southern state, local, pro-Union forces took up arms against the Confederacy. Despite enormous British support, Union forces prevailed. What would Americans call such a war? Most, I think, would remember it as the Second War of Independence. Perhaps African-Americans would call it the First War of Liberation. Only former Confederates and the British might recall it as a \u201ccivil war.\u201d\n\nI would reverse Chapman\u2019s formula and say that the Vietnam War was, at its core, an American war that exacerbated Vietnamese divisions and internationalized the conflict. It is true, of course, that many Vietnamese opposed the Communist path to national liberation, but no other nationalist party or faction proved capable of gaining enough support to hold power. Without American intervention, it is hard to imagine that South Vietnam would have come into being or, if it did, that it would have endured for long.\n\nMoreover, no other foreign nation deployed millions of troops to South Vietnam (although the United States did pressure or pay a handful of other nations, Australia and South Korea most notably, to send smaller military forces). And no other foreign nation or opponent dropped bombs (eight million tons!) on South and North Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos. The introduction of that staggering lethality was the primary driver of a war that cost three million lives, half of them civilians.\n\nIf we continue to excuse American conduct in Vietnam as a well-intentioned, if tragic, intervention rather than a purposeful assertion of imperial power, we are less likely to challenge current war managers who have again mired us in apparently endless wars based on false or deeply misleading pretexts. Just as in the Vietnam era, American leaders have ordered troops to distant lands based on boundless abstractions (\u201cthe global war on terror\u201d instead of the global threat of \u201cinternational Communism\u201d). And once again, their mission is to prop up governments that demonstrate no capacity to gain the necessary support of their people. Once again, the United States has waged brutal counterinsurgencies guaranteed to maim, kill or displace countless civilians. It has exacerbated international violence and provoked violent retaliation.\n\nOur leaders, then and now, have insisted that the United States is \u201cthe greatest force for good in the world\u201d that wants nothing for itself, only to defeat \u201cterror\u201d and bring peace, stability and self-determination to other lands. The evidence does not support such a claim. We need a new, cleareyed vision of our global conduct. A more critical appraisal of the past is one place to start.", "title": "What Was the Vietnam War About?", "authors": ["Christian G. Appy"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Insulin sensitivity didn\u2019t make a difference. People who secreted more or less insulin lost no more or less weight in general on either a low-fat or low-carbohydrate diet. Genetics didn\u2019t make a difference either. People who had genes that might indicate that they would do better on one diet or the other didn\u2019t.\n\nIn fact, when you look at how every single participant in this study fared on the diet to which he or she was assigned, it\u2019s remarkable how both diets yielded an almost identical, curving range of responses \u2014 from lots of weight lost to a little gained. It wasn\u2019t just the averages.\n\nSome have taken this study to prove that avoiding processed foods, eating more whole foods, and cooking at home leads to weight loss. While I\u2019d like that to be true \u2014 I have advocated this healthful approach in my Upshot article on food recommendations and in a recent book \u2014 that\u2019s not what this study showed. Although that advice was given to all participants, there was no control group in which that advice was omitted, and so no conclusions can be made as to the efficacy of these instructions.\n\nOthers have taken this study as evidence debunking the idea that counting calories is the key to weight loss. While that wasn\u2019t the main thrust of this study, nor the instructions given, participants did reduce their intake by an average of 500-600 calories a day (even if they didn\u2019t count them). This study didn\u2019t prove the unimportance of calories.\n\nThe researchers also asked everyone, not just those in the low-carb group, to avoid \u201cadded sugars.\u201d Therefore, we can\u2019t really say anything new about added sugars and weight loss.\n\nWhat this study does show is that people who have staked a claim on one diet\u2019s superiority over another don\u2019t have as strong a case as they think. It\u2019s hard to overstate how similarly these two diets performed, even at an individual level.\n\nIt shows us that the many people, and the many studies, suggesting that we can tell which diets are best for you based on genetics or based on insulin levels might not be right either. Almost all of the studies that backed up such ideas were smaller, of shorter duration or less robust in design than this one. Granted, it\u2019s still possible that there might be some gene discovered in the future that makes a difference, but those who think they\u2019ve found it already might want to check their enthusiasm.", "title": "What We Know (and Don\u2019t Know) About How to Lose Weight", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "This isn\u2019t a minor debate. The misattribution obscures the organizational nature of the firm, which is partly what makes the building significant. Corporate clients such as Union Carbide chose Skidmore precisely because it married the architectural language of European modernism with American business ethics; crucially, the architect remained invisible. This made it seem as if the building had arranged itself around the corporation\u2019s internal drives. The corporation was de facto the architect.\n\nIt\u2019s true that architectural guidebooks usually list Bunshaft as the architect of Union Carbide, along with other midtown Manhattan landmarks as Lever House, Manhattan House and the Pepsi-Cola building. But in a 1989 oral history conducted by the Art Institute of Chicago, he evades this attribution for those buildings. He depicts himself as the conduit through which a corporation\u2019s mission was translated into architectural form. He credits his administrative partners, who headed up research specific to each commission and oversaw logistics, and the designers who produced drawings and thus helped to work out various kinks in the design.\n\nBunshaft always put the corporation first. But he also makes clear that he set the architectural parameters and, just as important, sold them to progressive chief executives, whom he wonderfully equates with Renaissance princes: \u201cThey were the new Medicis, and there were many of them.\u201d\n\nToday, the Seagram Building, a few blocks north of Union Carbide on Park Avenue, designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, is universally acclaimed as the pinnacle of postwar modernism. But when it was completed in 1958, another architect, Louis Kahn, criticized it as stunning but somehow false. \u201cShe is a beautiful bronze lady but she is all corseted inside,\u201d Kahn said. \u201cShe is not true.\u201d Set 50 feet back in an isolated plaza framed on either side by green marble monoliths, it asked to be admired, but refused to participate in the everyday life of the avenue.\n\nUnion Carbide, by contrast, fills its entire site. The base of the block, however, is dematerialized with a glazed ground story: it looks as if the tower miraculously rests on thin planes of glass. Twin escalators lift you into a double-height, glass-walled atrium. The sensation is one of levity, suspension and translucence, yet the building remains human-scaled. The energy of the city\u2019s grid is carried right up onto the building\u2019s facade by the I-beams, which rise almost from street level. The architectural language is similar to Seagram, but Union Carbide\u2019s looser syntax results in a totally different, much more pragmatic compositional effect.\n\nAlong with Wallace Harrison\u2019s Time & Life Building, from 1957, and Eero Saarinen\u2019s CBS skyscraper, from 1964, which face each other on Sixth Avenue, Union Carbide and the Seagram Building exemplify the post-World War II cultural narrative: the United States\u2019 vision of itself as a savior of Western civilization and heir to the great traditions of antiquity.\n\nThis narrative was imparted through an aesthetic of massed shimmer. The totemic majesty of ancient monolithic architecture was joined with the limpidity of the glass curtain wall. These skyscraper colossi positioned postwar American corporations as gateways to the world\u2019s boundless resources and cultural treasures, which existed to be exploited, just as the buildings exploited the possibilities of epic form. Their noble, classicizing piers and temple-like porticos, which recall Greek and Roman architecture, and the soaring romantic I-beams, which recall the intricate ribbing of Gothic cathedrals, proclaimed that a democratic, capitalist country like the United States could carry on the traditions of a great civilization \u2014 \u201cAmerica\u2019s humanistic nationalism,\u201d as the religious scholar Martin E. Marty said at the time.\n\nWhen corporations or governments say they need to demolish an architecturally or historically significant building, it is almost always under the guise of needing more space. But there is also always an underlying ideological cause. The nature of capital, and its place in American culture, has changed. The Union Carbide tower will no doubt be replaced by an even more transparent, yet paradoxically completely opaque skyscraper of inhuman proportions that better represents the menacing ethics and aesthetics, and vague nature, of global finance.", "title": "Opinion | What We Will Lose When the Union Carbide Building Falls", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Face Up\n\nFrom ON THE MEDIA/GUARDIAN US: This fast-paced, 50-minute documentary-like program collects the thoughts of the country\u2019s best minds on race. It doesn\u2019t just dive into the recent role of the media, it also charts the origin of enduring myths on race. To hammer the theme home, there are two interactive quizzes. One is on extreme ideas that have found their way into national policy. The second is simply titled, \u201cWho said it: An elder statesman? It\u2019s a close look at Xi Jinping\u2019s rhetoric, which essentially says that\u2019s he\u2019s the man \u2014 the man, the one and only, to save China from whatever it is that\u2019s troubling the country. Sign up here.\n\n\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Race Issue\n\nFrom National Geographic: It\u2019s a rare thing indeed for an authoritative publication to turn its gaze so honestly and critically on itself, but National Geographic did just that in an article unequivocally titled \u201cFor Decades Our Coverage Was Racist.\u201d For an analysis of its record, the magazine enlisted John Edwin Mason, a historian of both photography and Africa. On the whole, NatGeo didn\u2019t do so well, but Mason did find some strengths. \u201cIt\u2019s possible to say that a magazine can open people\u2019s eyes at the same time it closes them,\u201d he said. \u2014 Jina Moore, East Africa bureau chief\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\nHeads Up\n\nFrom IEEE Spectrum: Small experimental satellites went to space in January aboard a rocket launched by India\u2019s space agency. But there was a problem: The company that built them didn\u2019t appear to have approval from United States government regulators to go into orbit. That\u2019s apparently never happened before, and this article looks at what happened and what the implications could be for the future. \u2014 Michael Roston, senior staff editor, Science\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\nA Kind Legacy\n\nFrom BuzzFeed: We all talk about the need for more empathy, but very few of us actually show it. That\u2019s what makes Maya Wiley\u2019s unexpected compassion toward a clearly troubled Trump aide, Sam Nunberg, all the more remarkable. Wiley, a professor at the New School and a lawyer, appeared alongside Nunberg during his bizarre blitz of television interviews, when he declared he would defy the special counsel Robert Mueller. Wiley advised him to rethink his plan.
