While the unpredictability of a meeting between these two unconventional leaders provides unique opportunities to end the decades-old conflict, its failure could also push the two countries to the brink of war.\n\nThe South Korean national security adviser, who had met with Mr. Kim in North Korea on Monday, made the announcement at the White House after meeting with Mr. Trump. He said that the North would consider denuclearization, agree to cease weapons testing for now and accept the start of the annual United States-South Korea military exercises this spring.\n\nAfter more than a year of heated rhetoric between the two leaders, and several North Korean missile tests, the United States and North Korea appeared headed for a collision course in the run-up to the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, last month. Vice President Mike Pence\u2019s cold shoulder to the visiting North Korean dignitaries at the Games presaged for many that the temporary respite of sports diplomacy would give way to a dangerous military crisis. The temperature on the Korean Peninsula seems to have been lowered for now.\n\nWhile the South Korean government deserves credit for turning an impending crisis into an opportunity, there is no denying that Pyongyang\u2019s apparent change of heart stems partially from the economic bite of Mr. Trump\u2019s global sanctions, his so-called \u201cmaximum pressure\u201d campaign. The North Koreans were probably also startled by reports earlier this year that the Trump administration was considering military options. But Mr. Kim also probably calculated that a pause in his country\u2019s weapons testing now would not significantly erode Pyongyang\u2019s ability to advance its nuclear program.", "title": "Opinion | What Will Trump Give Up for Peace with North Korea?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMONDAY PUZZLE \u2014 A nice, smooth opener to the week by Lynn Lempel, wherein she tells us how to dress for the solve.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nMs. Lempel offers us a simple set of two-word common phrases clued to their surface definitions (e.g., not as puns), and the second word in each phrase is an article of clothing.\n\nFor example, at 17A, we have the \u201cOpposite of a country bumpkin,\u201d which would be a CITY SLICKER. Slickers are another name for raincoats. Similarly, we have a STUFFED SHIRT at 43A, clued as \u201cPompous person.\u201d\n\nThis was such a fun set that I almost wish that the clues had been puns to heighten the sense of fun even further, but that might have booted this puzzle out of Monday territory.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTricky Clues\n\nSometimes the crossword stars align, and we can give our solvers even more help than usual. At the very moment that I am writing this, the assistant puzzles editor, Sam Ezersky, is putting together our \u201cCrossword Aviary,\u201d which is a list of 12 birds that you need to know to raise your solving game. Three of those birds are in today\u2019s puzzle, so if you\u2019d like to learn more about these tougher entries, take a gander (sorry) at Mr. Ezersky\u2019s aviary.", "title": "What You Might Come Across", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "The legacy of the Vietnam War still shapes America, even if most of us are too young to remember it. The Opinion section has been shining light on the conflict and its repercussions in a special series. Read the final installment, by a veteran writing about his scarred generation.\n\nImage Credit Angie Wang\n\nIn an essay last weekend, David Reich, a geneticist at Harvard, argued that science is changing how we think about \u201crace\u201d and urged a candid discussion of the findings. Many readers left comments, some worrying that the results could be misinterpreted or nefariously applied. Read his responses to some of the comments.", "title": "Opinion | What You Might Have Missed: 10 Weekend Reads From Opinion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "The human heart of song and story is a changeable, if not fickle, thing. But in one crucial sense, the organ has been seen as immutable. Scientists long thought that mammalian hearts stop producing most of their new cells shortly after birth, and that when they grow bigger, they do so primarily because the size of their existing cells increases. A recent study in The Journal of Physiology, however, confirms that exercise can substantially increase the number of cells in the hearts of young lab rats \u2014 and it also indicates, for the first time, that these additional cells are still present in mature hearts.\n\nResearchers in Australia took young, healthy male rats and kept some of them sedentary while making others run on treadmills. This active cohort was divided into three groups, each of which began exercising at a different stage of life. In human terms, these starting points corresponded to childhood, adolescence and adulthood. After the rats were put through a month of daily hourlong workouts at a moderate pace, the hearts of some of them were examined microscopically. Exercise was then curtailed for the rest of the rats, which spent the next several months (roughly equivalent to 10 human years) inactive. Once they reached full adulthood, their hearts were also scrutinized.\n\nThe treadmillers had bigger hearts than their inactive counterparts, a finding expected by the researchers. Exercise makes hearts larger, more efficient and healthier. But the pathways to this change differed greatly depending on the rats\u2019 ages when they started running. Those that began exercising as adults had bigger cardiac-muscle cells but not more of them. The hearts of the childhood runners, though, teemed with about 20 million additional cardiomyocytes \u2014 the type of heart cell that contracts \u2014 compared with the hearts of the sedentary rats of the same age. The adolescent runners also showed small increases in the number of cardiomyocytes, but many fewer than the youngest runners gained. Perhaps most interesting, the extra heart cells found in both young and adolescent rats remained in their hearts after they reached adulthood, despite the cessation of exercise.\n\nThe study involved rodents, not people, so the findings shouldn\u2019t be overhyped, cautions Glenn Wadley, an associate professor in the Institute for Physical Activity and Nutrition at Deakin University, who conducted the experiment with a graduate student, Yasmin Asif, and colleagues from the University of Melbourne and Monash University. But even so, the results do hint at human implications. A heart attack kills tens of millions of cells in an instant; a reserve of cardiac-muscle cells built up during childhood could conceivably affect the likelihood of surviving an attack as an adult, as well as influence how well a heart functions over the course of a lifetime. \u201cExercise is beneficial for the heart at any age,\u201d Wadley says. His study provides \u201ca new reason\u201d for people to be active when their hearts are still young and unburdened.", "title": "What Young Rats\u2019 Workouts Could Tell Us About the Human Heart", "authors": ["Gretchen Reynolds"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "But blaming Mr. Walker alone \u2014 as gratifying as that might be \u2014 would miss a larger point.\n\nLike many political reporters, I\u2019ve spent months reflecting on the arc of 2016, pondering where my coverage might have missed the mark and why.\n\nMany of the conventional explanations have been shallow and unsatisfying. It\u2019s not the case, for instance, that the news media didn\u2019t cover President Trump\u2019s supporters or listen to their voices, or that reporters failed to visit the middle of the country. Scores of reporters have the datelines and airline receipts to prove it.\n\nFor me at least, the real problem of 2016 was a failure of imagination.\n\nMuch of campaign reporting is an exercise in imagination, informed by experience. You travel the country and talk to voters and activists and local officials, and you form a theory of what the electorate wants. You study public opinion and recent history to gauge which outcomes are possible and which are not. You meet candidates and size them up, on and off the record, assessing how knowledgeable, intellectually agile, and comfortable with criticism and combat they are.\n\nAnd you ask yourself: Can I imagine this person scrapping their way through a debate? Or negotiating with hardheaded legislators? Or empathizing with constituents who don\u2019t look like them?\n\nSometimes you misread a person. In the winter after President Barack Obama\u2019s first election, I crossed paths with a member of the Republican National Committee who was fiercely supporting Michael Steele\u2019s bid for chairman. Over breakfast, he came across as a blunt, unsmiling party foot soldier. There was nothing, at the time, that suggested Mike Pompeo, the man sipping coffee, could be nominated for secretary of state inside of a decade.", "title": "What a Times Political Reporter Learned From the 2016 Election", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "For a counterexample of how a time of intense political bitterness can start to tear this country apart, look back exactly half a century to 1968. In that chaotic year, America slashed and clawed at itself amid the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the riots that followed; the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy as he ran for president; swelling antiwar demonstrations on college campuses amid growing recognition that the government had been lying about the course of the Vietnam War; and the police beatings of protesters in Chicago outside the Democratic National Convention.\n\nFactors like the draft and the race relations of the period made that tumultuous year a particular historical moment. But one difference between then and now is salient: Arguably, there was little reason to believe that the November 1968 election was likely to provide immediate relief.\n\nWe are lucky that so far 2018 does not look like a new 1968. But the relative calm may be like an unexploded bomb, its volatility not so much defused as contained by the thought that Trump Republicans will be punished in the Nov. 6 midterm elections. These expectations are widespread. After the big Democratic special election victories in places handily carried by Mr. Trump in 2016, from Virginia and Alabama to Wisconsin, Republican lawmakers in purple districts are retiring to avoid ending their careers in humiliating defeats.\n\nDemocrats, meanwhile, relish visions of a new congressional majority wielding its subpoena power to flay the Trump administration with oversight investigations. They can see it now: Making public Mr. Trump\u2019s hidden tax returns and otherwise laying bare any financial dealings between foreign governments and his businesses. Inviting the women who have accused him of sexual misconduct to testify at a televised hearing. Unearthing what his appointees have been doing in places like the Environmental Protection Agency, where collection of fines from polluters has plummeted.\n\nAlmost taking a House flip for granted, Democrats whisper that a tsunami-level wave would also flip the Senate and stop Mr. Trump\u2019s assembly line for turning conservative lawyers into life-tenured federal judges. Some even fantasize about impeachment.\n\nSuch vivid anticipation steers those sputtering at Mr. Trump's presidency to take deep breaths and bide their time until Nov. 6, which draws closer every day: The 2018 campaign cycle formally starts this week with primary voting in Texas.\n\nBut a significant Democratic wave may not materialize. Good economic news, for example, tends to blunt anti-incumbent sentiments. The country is still mostly using House districts that were redrawn after the 2010 census, just as Republicans\u2019 big 2010 midterm wave victory gave them an unusual degree of control over state legislatures. Beyond deliberate partisan gerrymandering, the impact of a Democratic turnout surge would be partly diluted by their voters\u2019 disproportionate concentration in cities, piling up extra votes in districts Republicans would have lost anyway.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut inevitably, many eyes would turn to Russia. It appears to still be covertly spreading disinformation and amplifying tensions on American social media with the intention of having \u201can impact on the next election cycle,\u201d Mike Pompeo, the Central Intelligence Agency director, told Congress last month.\n\nAnother poll-defying election night surprise, like 2016\u2019s, would further fuel suspicions of unseen manipulation. After all, the public only later found out \u2014 apparently thanks to the National Security Agency contractor Reality Winner, whom the Justice Department is prosecuting for leaking \u2014 that shortly before the 2016 election, Russian hackers infiltrated the servers of an elections systems software supplier and tried to trick 122 state elections officials into downloading malware. While there is no evidence that Russian hackers tampered with Election Day results last time, the government has disclosed that it thinks they probed elections systems in 21 states and penetrated several.\n\n\u201cThere should be no doubt that Russia perceives its past efforts as successful and views the 2018 U.S. midterm elections as a potential target for Russian influence operations,\u201d Dan Coats, the director of national intelligence, recently testified. \u201cThroughout the entire community, we have not seen any evidence of any significant change from last year.\u201d\n\nAgainst that backdrop, disappointed Trump opponents will be primed to believe the worst: that Russia rigged two elections in a row for Republicans. And if their anticipatory catharsis and faith in the democratic process evaporates, the anger could seek a different outlet \u2014 in turn risking a backlash from Trump supporters and a downward spiral.\n\nThe White House\u2019s approach to issues raised by Russian election meddling has been backward-looking, minimizing the problem in a way that seems to preclude focusing on protecting the country from future threats. Preoccupied with defending the legitimacy of the 2016 results, Mr. Trump repeatedly insists not only that his campaign did not collude with Moscow, but also that Russia\u2019s effort to torque that election was either \u201ca made-up story\u201d or had no impact on the outcome. Asked recently whether Mr. Trump has specifically directed the Federal Bureau of Investigation or the N.S.A. to take actions to confront and blunt continuing Russian influence operations, their respective directors testified that the president has not done so.\n\nIntelligence community leaders say their agencies are nevertheless trying to mitigate the risk, helping states strengthen cyberdefenses and hinting at other, classified steps. Such efforts to bolster the credibility of the election system are crucial, but may prove insufficient if there is another expectation-defying result.\n\nThree days after the directors\u2019 testimony, the Justice Department announced that a grand jury had indicted a group of Russians accused of running the social media manipulation operation. The unsealed indictment quoted internal Russian documents obtained by Robert Mueller, the special counsel. In them, the Russians were said to have described the original stated goal of what they called \u201cinformation warfare against the United States of America,\u201d before it morphed into helping Mr. Trump win, as spreading mistrust toward \u201cthe American political system in general.\u201d\n\nThis November, if the wave turns out to be a mere trickle, we could see the accomplishment of that goal take hold.", "title": "What if Republicans Win the Midterms?", "authors": ["Charlie Savage"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "14A: Like a lot of people from my era, I filled in John SMITH before John ROLFE, because I had my story about Pocahontas wrong. Her life was hardly a Disney story.\n\n34D: \u201cIn a pickle\u201d can mean in trouble, but today we are thinking of edible pickles, and the answer is DILL. Yum.\n\n35D: Interesting historical side note: In previous New York Times crosswords, the phrase VIOLET RAY has been used twice, once in 1963 and once in 1954. (This one was by the eventual third New York Times crossword editor, Eugene T. Maleska, and was edited by the first crossword editor, Margaret Farrar.) Both used the clue \u201cPart of the spectrum,\u201d which wouldn\u2019t have worked here, because it would have given away the fact that the theme involves the color spectrum.\n\n39D: Note that capital B in \u201cHome of the Braves: Abbr.\u201d We are thinking of the ATLanta Braves.\n\nMichael Wiesenberg: The idea for the puzzle first came to me in 2007. I tried unsuccessfully to fit seven entries that had all the colors of the rainbow, plus RAINBOW as the reveal. I looked at the puzzle from time to time, but couldn\u2019t manage to get eight entries into one puzzle. I concluded it couldn\u2019t be done, but then I was trying to fit all entries horizontally. I revisited the idea and came up with something I could make work by making two of the entries vertical. I had had four unthemed puzzles published in The New York Times by this time, but no themed ones, although I\u2019ve had many themed puzzles published elsewhere. My efforts were an inconsistent mix of easy and difficult entries and clues.\n\nI contacted Andrea Carla Michaels because I felt I needed help from someone who has a lot of experience with devising an early-week puzzle. In a lengthy exchange of approximately 70 emails, we honed the puzzle until we got something we felt was worth submitting. We considered ROY G. BIV as the reveal (\u201cMnemonic for remembering a list of seven of which the starred entries all contain elements\u201d), but went back to RAINBOW.\n\nFor what it\u2019s worth, we think the final version contains a minimum of difficult entries.\n\nAndrea Carla Michaels: Although Michael Wiesenberg and I have yet to meet in person, I have a soft spot for him because my father\u2019s name was Michael Eisenberg, so I felt an instant kinship.\n\nWe have been corresponding for almost 10 years since meeting virtually on cruciverb.com. (I cannot underestimate the value of these sites that have brought us all together and helped us form a community!)\n\nMichael has had his share of rejections, but is probably the most tenacious partner with whom I\u2019ve ever worked. I reviewed some of his back burner ideas to see if there were ones that were salvageable or would complement our disparate styles and strengths. I\u2019m super proud of this effort.\n\nI was in awe that Michael could get eight theme entries into a Monday! (I warned him that regardless of how difficult we thought this was, it would be slotted for a Monday.) That necessitated many iterations, to keep the fill \u201csimple.\u201d\n\nHow nice at the end of all this to see a rainbow!", "title": "What the Clues Constitute", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "One challenge in every social justice movement is making sure it\u2019s not dominated by a single voice. At the beginning, I was surprised to be criticized by fellow activists because I was not a Mexican immigrant. I did not have to walk across the border; my family came to this country from Ecuador on an airplane, with a tourist visa. My parents bought an apartment before we arrived. Because I was more privileged than many others, I tried to put them front and center when reporters came to talk to us. Learning to give up your seat so others can have a voice helps legitimize and strengthen your movement.\n\nThis is very important for the Parkland teenagers, many of whom are white and well off \u2014 the kind of kids the news media typically pays the most attention to. They have met with students from Chicago, where young people have long been speaking out about gun violence without much national attention. But they can and ought to do more.\n\nAt the same time, as a woman, I also knew I had to speak out, because my voice was often ignored. One day, two male reporters asked me, \u201cWhere are the students who are walking?\u201d\n\nI smiled and said, \u201cI am one of them, how can I help you?\u201d\n\nThey looked at me and said, \u201cNo, the people who are walking, where are the boys?\u201d\n\nThis kept on happening. Maybe they didn\u2019t think a woman could walk 18 miles a day, or maybe they thought that because I was overweight, I couldn\u2019t possibly do this. After a CNN interview during which I had to force myself into the conversation, I shared what I had been experiencing with my fellow walkers. They decided that from then on, I would be the first person to speak at events.\n\nPerhaps the hardest thing about being part of a youth movement is transitioning out of it. I am now 33. It\u2019s been 17 years since the introduction of the Dream Act, and still it has not passed. Part of me feels like I have failed.\n\nI am still involved, but not at the forefront of the fight. I realized I could no longer go days without sleep, working on strategy and giving interviews. I needed a succession plan. And I wanted to help mentor other smart and motivated young people. Perhaps the Parkland students will be luckier than we were, and will see stricter gun control enacted before they hit their 30s. But if not, they will have to pass on the baton. This is important not just for the continuity of a movement but also for the sanity of the individuals within it.", "title": "Opinion | What the Dreamers Can Teach the Parkland Kids", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "SPECIAL POST \u2014 Good morning! You have to get up pretty early to fool most crossword solvers, but this week there was an entry in the Friday, March 9, puzzle by Neville Fogarty and Doug Peterson that sent a lot of people running to the dictionary.\n\nThe answer to the clue at 2-Down, \u201cPoem greeting the dawn,\u201d was AUBADE. An AUBADE can also be a musical composition about the morning.\n\nAn AUBADE\u2019s counterpart, a poem or song about the evening, is called a \u201cnocturne.\u201d\n\nThe word was first used in 1678 and was adopted by the French from the Spanish word \u201calba,\u201d meaning sunrise. Ben Zimmer, the language columnist for The Wall Street Journal, says that \u201cA skim of Google Books shows that AUBADE appeared chiefly in French sources, or French-English dictionaries, until the early 19th century.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAn example of an AUBADE would be John Donne\u2019s \u201cThe Sun Rising,\u201d which, if nothing else, shows that Mr. Donne was clearly not a morning person.\n\nBesides \u201cPoem greeting the dawn,\u201d some of the ways crossword solvers might see AUBADE clued are \u201cMorning music,\u201d \u201cMorning song\u201d and \u201cSunrise song.\u201d\n\nAnd with that, we wish you a wonderful start to your day.", "title": "What the Heck Is That?: AUBADE", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "SPECIAL POST \u2014 If it looks like a goose and it honks like a goose, it should just be a goose, right? The NENE, however, is special. Not only is it the Hawaiian state bird, but it is the world\u2019s rarest goose and its webbed feet have adapted to living on hardened lava. That\u2019s one tough bird.\n\nDespite their tough feet, they are weak fliers. Once hunted nearly to extinction, conservation efforts have succeeded in bolstering the nene population, and today they live exclusively on the islands of Hawaii, Maui, Moloka\u02bbi, and Kaua\u02bbI.\n\nAnother reason to know your nenes is because they come up quite a bit in crossword puzzles, most recently in the Monday, Mar. 12 puzzle by John R. O\u2019Brien. NENE has been an entry in The New York Times Crossword a total of 295 times since 1944. They may be rare in Hawaii, but they have hidden nests in your puzzle.\n\nBrush up on the nene and other birds that appear in The New York Times Crossword in our Crossword Aviary.", "title": "What the Heck Is That?: NENE", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "SPECIAL POST \u2014 It has only appeared in The New York Times Crossword three times over the past few years, most recently in the Friday, March 2 celebrity puzzle co-constructed by MSNBC host Rachel Maddow and veteran constructor Joe DiPietro. Perhaps that just means that the 180 year old rye and bitters based Sazerac cocktail is finally getting its due, at least in crosswords, where SAZERAC was one of the most revealed entries of the past week.\n\nEven if you don\u2019t imbibe, it\u2019s certainly a fun name to say.\n\nThe story of the Sazerac cocktail begins in mid-19th century New Orleans, where apothecary owner Antoine Amedie Peychaud treated his friends to brandy toddies containing Sazerac French brandy and a dash of the bitters made from a secret family recipe. By 1850, the Sazerac Cocktail became the first \u201cbranded\u201d cocktail, and in 1873, the French brandy was replaced by American Rye Whiskey, with a dash of absinthe. Over the years, Herbsaint, another anise-flavored pastis, has been used in place of absinthe and the \u201cofficial\u201d Sazerac Cocktail recipe was modified to use Sazerac Kentucky Straight Rye Whiskey.\n\nIf you\u2019d rather use absinthe, there\u2019s always former \u201cDrinks\u201d columnist Rosie Schaap\u2019s recipe from New York Times Cooking.\n\nHow It Might Be Clued\n\n\u201cCocktail with rye whiskey,\u201d \u201cNew Orleans cocktail,\u201d \u201cOfficial cocktail of New Orleans\u201d\n\nLaissez les bon temps rouler!", "title": "What the Heck Is That?: SAZERAC", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "SPECIAL POST \u2014 Torii are familiar to people outside of Japan as a symbol of the land of the rising sun, but many solvers were unsure of the word when it appeared in the Tuesday, Mar. 20 crossword puzzle by Andrew Zhou. It has appeared 63 times in The New York Times Crossword.\n\nThese gates, which have a traditional shape and structure, are closely related to the Shinto religion. Typically located at the entrance of Shinto shrines or in spots that hold special religious significance, they signal to worshipers a transition from the profane world to the sacred. By walking through the torii, one has entered the world of the Kami, or Shinto gods.\n\nThe earliest documentation of the torii in Japan dates back to the mid-Heian period in 922 A.D.\n\nThe structure of the torii has variations, but the most important parts are the pillars (hashira), the lintel placed on the two pillars (kasagi), and a tie-beam that keeps the structure together (nuki).\n\nHow It Might Be Clued\n\nEarly week: \u201cTraditional Japanese gate,\u201d \u201cShinto temple gateway,\u201d \u201cShinto gateway,\u201d Mid-to-late week: \u201cShinto shrine entrance,\u201d \u201cTraditional Japantown feature,\u201d \u201cDecorative gateway in Japan,\u201d \u201cJapanese portal\u201d\n\nWere there any entries you had trouble with?", "title": "What the Heck Is That?: TORII", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "BEIRUT, Lebanon \u2014 In the beginning there was just an insult, sparked by a trivial squabble in a street of a working-class neighborhood of Beirut. A surly-looking man on a balcony splashes some water on a foreman below who has come to fix a defective pipe; the foreman curses back. Such is the starting point of \u201cThe Insult,\u201d a film by Ziad Doueiri, which is up for an Academy Award in the foreign-language category on Sunday.\n\nMatters could have ended there. After all, as Freud supposedly said, \u201cThe first human who hurled an insult instead of a stone was the founder of civilization.\u201d But not in the Lebanon of \u201cThe Insult\u201d \u2014 where the insult turns into a fight, then a court case and finally a state affair. And not in the real Lebanon either: Some weeks back, just a few months before the next general election is expected to be held, another insult set the country ablaze.\n\nIn late January a video appeared online showing Gebran Bassil, the foreign minister (and the president\u2019s son-in-law), calling Nabih Berri, the speaker of the National Assembly, a \u201cthug.\u201d Some streets of Beirut broke out into scenes that could have been lifted from the movie: angry youth, blocked roads, burning tires \u2014 as ever, the specter of civil strife. Mr. Bassil (like his father-in-law) is a Maronite Christian; Mr. Berri is a Shiite. And the whole of Lebanese politics plays the sectarian chord.\n\nHere, a single insult can rekindle badly healed wounds, and nudged by just a few excesses from the media or the public, push Lebanon to the brink. (Freud might have called this, too, the \u201creturn of the repressed.\u201d) Resentment runs deep in this tiny country, this house of many mansions, home to so many communities with so many narratives forged over so many decades of frustration. Fear of a conflagration remains after a long history of deadly fratricidal clashes, for example in 1845, 1860, 1958 and, of course, 1975\u201390.", "title": "Opinion | What the Unspoken in \u2018The Insult\u2019 Says About Lebanon\u2019s Politics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "However, over the past five years, the pace of reform has slowed, in large part because the party has feared losing control. The 13th National People\u2019s Congress has promised to accelerate the reform program once more, with a renewed commitment to put \u201cthe market\u201d at the center of the economy. We will see.\n\nPerhaps the greatest analytical error across the West has been the view that Xi Jinping would want to continue to sustain the liberal, international rules-based order once its economic power began to rival that of the United States. Again, this hope goes against the well-known facts: China has long said that it sees the existing order as one invented by the victors of the last world war, one in which China did not have a seat at the table.\n\nChina has never shared the West\u2019s view of human rights. It has long sought to weaken the powers of the United Nations Human Rights Commission. China has at best had an ambivalent attitude to free trade \u2014 just look at its qualified support for the World Trade Organization, its opposition to the Trans-Pacific Partnership and its own long history of mercantilism.\n\nAnd as for the global security order, China has never changed its hostility to the global system of American military alliances, in particular those in the Asia Pacific, which it has long attacked as legacies of the Cold War. That\u2019s in addition to China\u2019s assertion of its territorial claims in the South China Sea.\n\nFor these reasons, Mr. Xi has explicitly called for \u201ca new type of great power relations,\u201d \u201ca new type of international system\u201d emerging out of the \u201ccurrent struggle for the international order\u201d and a new type of activist Chinese diplomacy that puts to bed Deng Xiaoping\u2019s dictum of \u201chide your strength, bide your time, and never take the lead.\u201d Hence its efforts to foster an alternative multilateral system with the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, the Shanghai Cooperation Organization and the Belt and Road Initiative.\n\nOver time Mr. Xi would like to turn the page on the liberal Western order and write a new chapter in world history. If China in the next decade becomes the largest economy in the world with Mr. Xi still likely its leader, the country\u2019s economic success would be based on a form of state capitalism that rejects the notion that rising income parallels broader economic liberalization and political democracy.\n\nNone of us knows how much Mr. Xi will seek to apply the principles of this \u201cChina model\u201d to the wider international order. There will be tensions here. But we should be very clear about what Mr. Xi wants for China itself, rather than seeing it through the rose-colored glasses of the West, still shaped by the images of Deng Xiaoping\u2019s China, a quarter of a century ago. Xi Jinping\u2019s China is radically different.", "title": "Opinion | What the West Doesn\u2019t Get About Xi Jinping", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning! A week ago, I was on a skiff in Everglades humidity, deep into the park, up the Lostmans River near where Edgar Watson kept his claim, raised suspicions and met his fate. I was casting to snook and tarpon, eating almonds, swatting at bugs. Spring seemed possible, and my spirit rose, stayed up even when I shrugged into a jacket in New York and returned to work. There was a softness to the air, a promise of rebirth. I looked for buds in the trees.\n\nYou know what happened, what always does: Winter storms continue all winter, all the way to the end, demand of us close attention and a lot of Jamaican oxtail stew (above), sustenance to monitor floods and wind gusts, not to mention the chaotic drumbeats of news from Washington, from Albany, from abroad.\n\nIt can be hard to come out of that and cook again on a Monday night, when all you want to do, really, is go to bed and wake up just once in sunshine and grace. If that\u2019s you and not just me: Don\u2019t cook tonight, or at least don\u2019t cook in a big way. But do make great food all the same.\n\nHere\u2019s how: Make rice. Make it in a rice cooker if you have one or according to our instructions if you don\u2019t, and when it\u2019s done just fluff it into a bowl, pat sweet butter onto it and hit it with soy sauce. There\u2019s still plenty good cooking you can get up to at the tail end of winter, indoors.\n\nLike, for instance, you could dig deep into Tejal Rao\u2019s primer on cooking rice, then make one of her new recipes as part of your dinner tonight: coconut rice, arroz verde or khichdi. We lost an hour last night in the tick of a second, and while most will be fine by tomorrow, some of us this morning are playing the Thane of Fife, coming on strong to Macbeth, growling:\n\nDespair thy charm,\n\nAnd let the angel whom thou still hast served\n\nTell thee, Macduff was from his mother\u2019s womb\n\nUntimely ripped.\n\nOur bed\u2019s a womb, see? They\u2019ve got the time, are in the mood. They may want today to go a little more hard in the paint, as the expression goes, and lay in good eating for tonight and the rest of the week.\n\nLike, for instance, you could make this great Ottolenghi chocolate cake this afternoon. It\u2019ll leave you feeling like you\u2019re fancy and deserving, like you live in Islington, in London, and have a house account at Yotam\u2019s shop on Upper Street. Go take a look at them, and save the ones you like to your recipe box, so you can organize them later and put them to good use. Send yourself a few shopping lists. And then use them. Cooking more often is a reward in itself, the kind of habit that leads to an increased sense of self-worth rather than the self-loathing that can accompany a Domino\u2019s order. Real talk.\n\nBut if something goes wrong no one here is going to judge you, either in your ordering takeout or your relationship with our technology. We may even be able to help. The case has never been solved. I like this collection of books about or inspired by the crime.\n\nFinally, if you haven\u2019t gotten one already, I\u2019d urge you to subscribe to NYT Cooking today. It is a good and vibrant community we\u2019re building here, filled with smart and interesting people who cook both more and less than you do, and we\u2019d like you to be a part of it.\n\nSo join us! Teenage Wrist will play us off: \u201cDweeb.\u201d See you tomorrow!", "title": "What to Cook This Week", "authors": ["Sam Sifton", "What To Cook", "Melissa Clark", "Alison Roman"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning. Tejal Rao has a beautiful riff about dried beans in The New York Times Magazine right now, about how she traffics beans home from her travels around the world, \u201cauntie-style, rolled up in old plastic bags, concealed between the folded clothes in my suitcase.\u201d\n\nThe essay conspires to make obvious a great plan for this weekend, the last before Easter and the start of Passover, too. Cook beans and then either make Tejal\u2019s new recipe for beans and garlic toast in broth (above) or the old one that exists in her memory and prose: red beans \u201ccooked simply with crushed tomatoes and a mash of ginger, garlic and green chiles, with a glug of cream added somewhere near the far end of cooking and a pile of chopped cilantro on top.\u201d\n\nPut that on rice and leave me alone. That\u2019s my Saturday night right there. Me and Dua Lipa: \u201cNew Rules.\u201d\n\nThough maybe we\u2019ll get some grill time going this weekend as well, first of the season for us in New York: chicken wings bathed in oak or apple smoke, maybe a spice-rubbed fillet of salmon as well, alongside grilled broccoli, a couple of grilled leeks. Maybe not, but it\u2019d be nice to think that spring is really coming and not just here on the calendar, a seasonal shift that will move us toward shorts and flip-flops and dinner before dusk. (So maybe yes after all, even if it\u2019s brisk out?)", "title": "What to Cook This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Also on Sunday, you could make West Indian lamb curry, eat it with rice made with coconut milk in place of half the water, with a can of drained butter beans fluffed into it at the end. Also with mango chutney and a bunch of quartered limes. And hot sauce: Matouk\u2019s if you can get it.\n\nThen, while it simmers, pull out the stand mixer and make pizza dough, so you can cold-proof it in the fridge for a few days and have a stellar pizza party on Tuesday or Wednesday night.\n\nSee how all this weekend planning pays dividends? That\u2019s the NYT Cooking lifestyle for you. We ought to sell merch!\n\nMany thousands more recipes to think about cooking this week are at NYT Cooking. Go browse around there a while and save whatever recipes intrigue to your recipe box, so you can organize them later and put them to good use. (Take a look at my recipe box, if you want an example.) Then send yourself a shopping list for those recipes you want to make.\n\nAnd cook them! We\u2019re all excited to know how it turns out. Post pictures of your food on social media. (Use the hashtag #NYTCooking.) Or send word via Twitter or Facebook. You can write me at foodeditor@nytimes.com.", "title": "What to Cook This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning. I\u2019m just back from Florida, where I spoke to chefs in Miami, caught a huge tarpon in Everglades National Park and spent a perfect evening on the southwest coast cooking my in-laws chicken shawarma in the Ronco rotisserie oven that they drag out of storage when I visit because rotisserie is really the best way to make shawarma, every time. It was an epic few days.\n\nDid you have fun with Tejal Rao while I was gone? Isn\u2019t she a great writer? She\u2019s also a fantastic cook, and you can spend some more time with her in coming days and weeks as you make your way through her terrific new educational blockbuster for NYT Cooking, \u201cHow to Cook Rice.\u201d\n\nThis weekend, in addition to making rice, I think you should try putting together this incredible house salad (above) that the pizza mystic Mark Iacono serves sometimes, when he feels like it, at his candlelit restaurant, Lucali, in Brooklyn. I wrote about it for The Times this week, in an \u201cEat\u201d column with the headline \u201cMost House Salads Are Terrible. Make Yours Shockingly Superb.\u201d It\u2019s what Iacono calls a \u201cbottom of the bowl\u201d salad, the dressing reminiscent of what\u2019s left after a long dinner with family and there are just a few slices of tomato left alongside an olive or two, a slice of red onion, all of it marinating in red-wine vinegar and oil.\n\nAt the restaurant, he layers the tomatoes above and below cold, crisp lettuce, adds a final drizzle of dressing and serves the salad with a meatball on top. But the salad goes as well plain alongside a pizza or under sausage that\u2019s been simmered in sauce, with stuffed shells or lasagna or eggplant Parm. You don\u2019t need fancy tomatoes or lettuce with bona fides, just strong vinaigrette and enough time to allow the tomatoes to bleed out in it before you assemble the salad and serve.", "title": "What to Cook This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning! Pale and freckled some of us, dark-haired, blue-eyed, red-cheeked, too, the cynics, the idealists, the poets, the swains. Together we proclaim: This weekend puts us one week out from St. Patrick\u2019s Day. It is time to corn the beef.\n\nYou can simmer the result with vegetables next Saturday or make Irish tacos (above) instead. It\u2019s an easy business to do the corning, and the process will deliver far better meat than you may recall from past holidays or meals at McGillicuddy\u2019s. Give corning beef a try this weekend: a big hunk of brisket and a couple hours of work, and, by next Saturday, it\u2019ll be ruddy and ready, and you\u2019ll be in clover sure. (Cue: Dropkick Murphys covering The Cars, \u201cJust What I Needed,\u201d March 17, 2016.)\n\nCook something impressive this weekend anyway, if only because it is a fun and healthy thing to do, while others stare at screens. It is Matthew B. Crawford\u2019s \u201cShop Class as Soulcraft\u201d moved into the kitchen: \u201c \u2026dwelling on a task for a long time and going deeply into in, because you want to get it right.\u201d\n\nYou could scare up a dried chipotle, soak it in hot water to make a kind of tea, use the softened flesh to bring smoke and heat alike to some whipped chicken livers, then spread the mixture on toast, marveling at the intensity of the pepper, so different from the more common canned variety.", "title": "What to Cook This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGood morning. For a lot of us this will be a big weekend for cooking, what with Passover getting underway tonight, and Easter following on Sunday. So good luck with your legs of lamb, your big smoked hams, your brisket and matzo brei. Here\u2019s hoping your hard-boiled eggs are perfect, your haroseth truffles beautiful, your lemon sweet rolls with cream-cheese icing sun-kissed and soft. We are here for all who need us at NYT Cooking, and offer recipes appropriate to whatever faith you have, including none, as some among us celebrate the rise and promise of spring.\n\nBut you don\u2019t need cook out of the paschal playbook, if you don\u2019t want to.\n\nSamin Nosrat, for instance, has a new recipe I think you\u2019ll want to try, based partly on Hawaiian butter mochi, but also on her experience making canel\u00e9s, those wee little caramelized pastries from Bordeaux with a gooey center. Samin calls her sweets brown-butter mochi cakes (above), and wrote about the process of discovering them in The Times this week. Brown-butter mochi cakes prove to be the best kind of recipe, the sort that leaves you wondering how something so complex and delicious turns out to be so simple to make.\n\nAnd Sunday isn\u2019t just Easter, remember. It\u2019s also April Fools\u2019 Day, and the best day of the year to make and serve and yap about Rozanne Gold\u2019s insane and actually delicious recipe for a cherry cola-chocolate-mayonnaise-sauerkraut cake. (Read the notes that follow the recipe! People dig this one!)\n\nIf I weren\u2019t smoking lamb on Sunday and making like the Canlis brothers with their Lake Union salad, I might have turned toward shrimp burgers for dinner \u2014 maybe you could in my place. Or maybe Korean grilled beef lettuce wraps? Or a Russian salmon pie!\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThousands of recipes to consider cooking this weekend are anyway at NYT Cooking. Go browse among them, the way people did in the age of malls. You\u2019ll need to sign up for a subscription to do so, yes. But I think you\u2019ll find that worth your while.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. And we will get back to you.", "title": "What to Cook This Weekend", "authors": ["Sam Sifton", "What To Cook", "Joan Nathan", "Samin Nosrat", "Melissa Clark", "Pete Wells"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "In 2015, it was a tossup between \u201cBoyhood\u201d and the eventual winner, \u201cBirdman.\u201d In 2016, with lots of experts betting on \u201cThe Revenant\u201d or \u201cThe Big Short,\u201d the prize went to \u201cSpotlight.\u201d Last year, nearly all the forecasters declared \u201cLa La Land\u201d the presumptive winner, and for two and a half minutes, they were correct, before an envelope snafu was revealed and the rightful winner, \u201cMoonlight,\u201d was crowned.\n\nThis year, awards watchers are unequally divided between \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri,\u201d the favorite, and, \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d (which is the Bagger\u2019s prediction), with a few forecasting a Hail Mary win for \u201cGet Out.\u201d\n\nBut all of those films have historical Oscar-voting patterns against them. \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d has 13 nominations, more than any other film, and was also named the year\u2019s best by the producers\u2019 and directors\u2019 guilds. Yet it was not nominated for a Screen Actors Guild Award for best ensemble; and no film has won best picture without previously landing at least the actors\u2019 nomination since \u201cBraveheart,\u201d in 1996. This year, the best ensemble SAG ended up going to \u201cThree Billboards,\u201d which is significant because actors make up the academy\u2019s largest branch; that film, while divisive, also won the best drama Golden Globe and the Bafta. But its filmmaker, Martin McDonagh, was not nominated for best director, and apart from \u201cArgo,\u201d movies that land best picture without also earning best director nominations are few and far between.\n\nMeanwhile, many viewers feel that the year\u2019s best film was \u201cGet Out.\u201d While the academy\u2019s influx of younger, more diverse members might have helped the film secure nominations for best picture, director, actor and original screenplay, no film has won best picture with fewer than five total nominations since \u201cCavalcade,\u201d from 1933, according to the movie maven Kristopher Tapley at Variety.\n\nEclipsed by all of this is Christopher Nolan\u2019s \u201cDunkirk,\u201d which, in terms of worldwide box-office receipts, blew away the rest of the best picture nominee field. It earned $525.6 million worldwide; \u201cGet Out\u201d accounted for the next best haul, with $255 million. (The lowest earner of the bunch was \u201cCall Me by Your Name,\u201d which took in $29 million globally.)\n\n\u201cDunkirk\u201d ought to have been a coup for Mr. Nolan. It was his most Oscar-minded film, told a historically pivotal story, was beautifully shot, and clocked in, mercifully, at two hours. But it didn\u2019t have acting nominations, and on the awards circuit Mr. Nolan, who received his first directing nomination for this picture, could not outshine the jovial favorite, Guillermo del Toro, who showed up to at least one party toting a case of tequila. When Mr. Nolan\u2019s \u201cThe Dark Knight\u201d was snubbed in the best picture and director categories in 2009, that outrage led the academy to expand the top prize to 10 nominees, from five; but it looks like Mr. Nolan\u2019s Oscar dreams will, yet again, be deferred.\n\nAnd while the acting categories are pretty much sewn up by baby boomers \u2014 Frances McDormand, Gary Oldman and Allison Janney \u2014 and one Gen-Xer, Sam Rockwell, this year\u2019s nominations made winners out of a new generation of actors, bringing to the world\u2019s attention the talents of Daniel Kaluuya (\u201cGet Out\u201d), who went on to star in \u201cBlack Panther,\u201d and Timoth\u00e9e Chalamet, the young lead of \u201cCall My by Your Name\u201d who, by several accounts, gave the best performance of 2017. Margot Robbie\u2019s nomination cements her graduation from the ing\u00e9nue holding pen, not that really she needed it; she is starring as Elizabeth I in the forthcoming \u201cMary Queen of Scots,\u201d across from her fellow best actress nominee, Saoirse Ronan, who, at 23, is already considered a great.", "title": "What to Expect (and Not Expect) at the Oscars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Here\u2019s a look at what economists and money managers are expecting:\n\nJan Hatzius, Goldman Sachs: \u201cPublic remarks by Fed officials suggest a broad shift in the committee\u2019s outlook towards a potentially faster pace of tightening, and we expect the median dot to show four hikes in 2018, up from three at the December meeting. Additional hawkish changes\u2014a move to three hikes in 2019 or an increase in the longer-run funds rate estimates\u2014are also possible but not our base case.\u201d\n\nMichelle Meyer, Bank of America Merrill Lynch: Ms. Meyer says she expects the Fed raise rates this meeting, but \u201cunlike December where there were two dissents, we expect this decision to be unanimous given the shift in voters this year in the hawkish direction. The focus will be on the evolution of the dots: we look for the median to hold at three hikes for this year, but to shift up from two to three hikes in 2019. We also think the long-run dot will edge up to 2.875%. This would show a Fed that is more confident about its ability to deliver rate hikes, but without an urgency to front-load the tightening.\u201d\n\nIan Shepherdson, Pantheon Macroeconomics: Mr. Powell \u201cis bound to be faced with questions along the lines of \u201cWhy are you not raising the dots in the wake of the substantial, unfunded fiscal easing?\u201d. His reply, we suspect, will be something like: \u201cIt\u2019s not our job to tell Congress how to conduct fiscal policy, and it\u2019s too soon to assess the impact of the tax cuts and spending increases. Much of the easing of policy could be saved rather than spent, and there are encouraging signs that productivity is picking up, so any upturn in wage growth as a result of fiscal loosening need not necessarily generate higher inflation. In any event, with inflation well below target, gradual normalization is the best way to balance the risks of both future inflation and the premature ending of the cycle via excessive tightening.\u201d\n\nStephen Stanley, Amherst Pierpont: \u201cThe bulk of the interest in this week\u2019s F.O.M.C. meeting will come from the updated dot and economic projections as well as any meaningful tweaks to the key elements of the F.O.M.C. statement. Any changes to the dots and statement language are likely to be in the hawkish direction, though I would expect that the new information will be more evolutionary than a radically different.\u201d\n\nSteve Rick, CUNA Mutual Group: There is \u201ca very strong case for not only raising rates this week, but potentially doing so in a more aggressive manner than previously forecasted at the end of 2017. I think we could see projections get updated to call for four hikes instead of three, with plans for lifting rates more in coming years as well.\u201d\n\nChris Zaccarelli, Independent Advisor Alliance: \u201cWhether we have 3 or 4 rate hikes this year shouldn\u2019t be that big of a difference to the economy, but it WILL have a big impact on market prices and market psychology. Every statement \u2013 whether spoken or written \u2013 will be highly scrutinized looking for clues as to whether the Fed Funds rate will be 1% higher (or only 75 bps) a year from now.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTrump, tariffs and the G20\n\nPresident Trump\u2019s plan to hit countries around the world with stiff tariffs on imports of steel and aluminum has dominated a gathering of world economic leaders amid fears that the United States is on the cusp of starting an international trade war.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Monday, Steven Mnuchin, the United States Treasury secretary, was peppered with requests from several countries for exemptions from the tariffs, which are being imposed in the name of national security.\n\nIn an interview on the sidelines of the meeting, Mr. Mnuchin suggested exemptions to the tariffs could be announced \u201crelatively quickly.\u201d\n\nMr. Mnuchin said:\n\n\u201cI think we\u2019ve been very transparent in describing our positions; I don\u2019t think anything should be a surprise. This is all about free and fair and reciprocal trade.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump has already said he would exempt Canada and Mexico from the tariffs upon a successful renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement, and he has indicated that other countries could also get exemptions. But the United States has yet to detail exactly what would qualify a country for an exemption, other than a vague reference to protecting the United States\u2019 national security and reducing bilateral trade deficits.\n\nCountries including France, Argentina and South Korea pressed Mr. Mnuchin on Monday about being freed from the metals tariffs, arguing that, as United States allies, they should not be penalized on national security grounds. Mr. Mnuchin said that decisions were being made on a case-by-case basis and that there was not a one-size-fits-all approach to deciding which countries would be exempt. The tariffs go into effect on Friday.\n\n\u2014 Alan Rappeport\n\nPhoto\n\nPressure continues to mount on Facebook.\n\nThe Federal Trade Commission has opened an investigation into whether Facebook violated an agreement with the agency on data privacy, reports Cecilia Kang of the NYT.\n\nThe probe comes after reports that information on 50 million users was improperly obtained by the political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica, according to a person with knowledge of the inquiry.\n\nThe investigation, started in recent days, adds to the mounting pressureagainst Facebook in the United States and in the United Kingdom about its handling of the data. Cambridge Analytica used the information to help President Trump\u2019s presidential campaign profile voters during the 2016 election.\n\nThe F.T.C. and Facebook reached a settlement in 2011 after the agency accused the company of deceiving customers \u201cby telling them they could keep their information on Facebook private, and then repeatedly allowing it to be shared and made public,\u201d according to a statement at the time.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFacebook could face fines of thousands of dollars a day per violation if the commission finds Facebook violated terms of the settlement, Bloomberg reports.\n\nShares of Facebook are down 2.5 percent in early trading.\n\nFacebook\u2019s worst day in ages\n\nExhibit A: Its stock closed down nearly 7 percent, its worst performance in four years.\n\nExhibit B: Its chief security officer, Alex Stamos, plans to leave after disagreements about how much the company should share about misuse of its platform. (He favored disclosure.)\n\nThe overall problem: Reports about how the data firm Cambridge Analytica improperly harvested information from 50 million Facebook users are highlighting just how much governments itch to regulate the tech giant.\n\nAnd Facebook\u2019s previous laissez-faire attitude toward data collection by apps has gone from feature to bug, Kevin Roose writes in his latest column.\n\nPeter Eavis\u2019s take: Mark Zuckerberg\u2019s unusually powerful position at the company may have played a role:\n\nThrough his holding of special voting shares, Mr. Zuckerberg has an especially powerful position at Facebook that might shield him from the normal forces of accountability. C.E.O.s without that protection might do more to tackle a big problem because it more directly threatens their job security.\n\nMore on Cambridge Analytica: An undercover investigation by Channel 4 News of Britain captured the firm\u2019s C.E.O., Alexander Nix, suggesting the entrapment of a potential client\u2019s political opponents with women and bribes. Britain\u2019s information commissioner is now seeking a warrant to examine the firm\u2019s data. And Facebook has hired a forensics firm to audit it.\n\nCritics\u2019 corner\n\n\u2022 Jeff Goldfarb of Breakingviews writes, \u201cTen years ago, Zuckerberg hired Sheryl Sandberg to help turn his start-up into a serious corporation. It may be time for more adult supervision.\u201d\n\n\u2022 The academic Zeynep Tufekci writes, \u201cThis wasn\u2019t informed consent. This was the exploitation of user data and user trust.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Cass Sunstein of Bloomberg View writes, \u201cIt would be a mistake to take the fiasco as a reason to keep treasure troves of information out of the hands of people who can provide immensely valuable services with it.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Dan Gallagher of Heard on the Street writes, \u201cFacebook\u2019s immense scale also has made it virtually impossible for alternatives to catch on. That, in turn, makes abuse of the platform more urgent for lawmakers.\u201d\n\nPublic service announcements: How to protect yourself on Facebook. Oxford Analytica, an advisory group, wants you to know it\u2019s not like that. And a little joke for those steeped in the British university system:\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nA death that could set back self-driving cars\n\nUber has suspended its autonomous vehicle testing in four cities after a car in self-driving mode struck and killed a woman in Tempe, Ariz. Until now, regulators had been increasingly open to testing: Just this month, California said it would start letting self-driving cars operate without anyone behind the wheel. Arizona already had.\n\nThe head of Carnegie Mellon\u2019s self-driving car lab has urged a halt to testing, telling Axios, \u201cThe technology is not there yet.\u201d\n\nThe virtual currencies corner: The White House banned Venezuela\u2019s virtual currency in a new round of sanctions. Morgan Stanley analysts said Bitcoin looked like the dot-com boom and bust, only way faster. How Zug, Switzerland, became a hotbed for digital money. And the Hong Kong and Australia stock exchanges are working to share blockchain information.\n\nOracle\u2019s slowing cloud growth.\n\nShares of Oracle are down 9.3 percent this morning\n\nThe reason? The software giant reported that its sales missed Wall Street expectations and its guidance disappointed after the close Monday. The lackluster results led analysts to downgrade the stock.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nAlwaleed bin Talal speaks out about his detention\n\nBloomberg interviewed the Saudi royal shortly after his release from the Ritz-Carlton, where Saudi Arabia detained hundreds of businessmen in the name of an anti-corruption campaign.\n\nMr. bin Talal wouldn\u2019t comment on the deal for his release, but said that he has \u201cforgiven and forgotten\u201d the process, and continues to talk with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the cousin who jailed him. More from the interview:\n\nYou have to wonder how comfortable CEOs will be investing in Saudi Arabia after seeing the Ritz-Carlton method of dealing with disputes. They have to decide that. But I can speak on my own behalf, and I can tell you it\u2019s business as usual: We\u2019re going to invest in Saudi Arabia.\n\nElsewhere in Saudi Arabia: Behind the bromance between Jared Kushner and the crown prince. Aramco looks increasingly likely to postpone an international listing, focusing on an I.P.O. on its home stock market, the WSJ says. And why the kingdom wants to enrich its own uranium.\n\nPhoto\n\nTronc\u2019s chairman resigns ahead of misconduct allegations\n\nMichael Ferro, who is also the media company\u2019s biggest shareholder, stepped down hours before Fortune published an article in which two women accused him of inappropriate advances. Neither worked for him, but both said they had been interacting with him professionally. Mr. Ferro declined to comment on the allegations.\n\nA recap of his tenure: Tribune became \u201cTronc.\u201d Management opposed a newsroom unionization effort. The company sold its crown jewel, The L.A. Times, after controversies led to the replacement of senior executives.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWeinstein Company news: The troubled film studio finally filed for bankruptcy protection. And New York state is looking into how the Manhattan district attorney handled 2015 assault allegations against Harvey Weinstein.\n\nElsewhere in misconduct: A loose coalition of Silicon Valley companies like Airbnb, Dropbox and Stitch Fix are pressuring venture capital firms to diversify their ranks. Female employees at Nike circulated a survey about improper conduct by male colleagues. And a former employee of the celebrity chef Mike Isabella sued him for sexual harassment.\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 The Long-Term Stock Exchange and IEX took a step to spread new standards for I.P.O.s. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Cheddar, the CNBC for the Snapchat generation, has raised $22 million from Raine Ventures, Liberty Global and the C.E.O. of the N.Y.S.E.\u2019s parent company. (WSJ)\n\nRevolving door\n\n\u2022 Greenhill & Company has hired Neil Augustine from Rothschild as vice chairman and co-head of its of North American financing advisory & restructuring. (Greenhill)\n\n\u2022 Germany has named J\u00f6rg Kukies, the co-head of Goldman Sachs\u2019s operations in Germany and Austria, as its deputy finance minister. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Paul Fishman, the former U.S. attorney for New Jersey, has joined the law firm Arnold & Porter as a partner and the head of its crisis management practice. (Arnold & Porter)\n\nThe speed read\n\n\u2022 The S.E.C.\u2019s chairman pressed exchanges to end a standoff that has delayed a massive database of stock and options trading. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "What to Expect From Powell\u2019s First Fed Meeting: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Some states require home inspectors to have certifications. For those that don\u2019t, membership in organizations like the American Society of Home Inspectors can give you some assurance about an inspector\u2019s professionalism.\n\nInterview potential inspectors before hiring one. Ask about their experience and whether they\u2019re familiar with the type of home you\u2019re buying. Find out what will be included in the inspection and report.\n\nWhat the Inspector Should Look At\n\nDuring a home inspection, the inspector should thoroughly evaluate the physical structure of the home as well as critical internal systems. You should make sure the examination includes the following:\n\n\u25cf Electrical system\n\n\u25cf Plumbing system\n\n\u25cf Heating and cooling systems\n\n\u25cf Radon detection equipment, if applicable\n\n\u25cf Walls, ceiling and flooring\n\n\u25cf Windows and doors\n\n\u25cf Roofing\n\n\u25cf Foundation\n\n\u25cf Basement\n\n\u25cf Attic\n\n\u25cf Insulation\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile an inspection will give you an idea of a house\u2019s overall condition, it might not uncover hidden problems such as pests, mold or asbestos. It also won\u2019t turn up flaws in areas that are below ground or otherwise inaccessible to the inspector, like wells and septic tanks. To identify those types of problems, you\u2019re going to need additional inspections.\n\nFor example, a Wood Destroying Insect Inspection can identify termites, carpenter ants and other pests. \u201cMore than 30 states require a pest inspection before a home loan can close,\u201d Leslie Wyman, the owner of Epcon Lane, a pest control company said. \u201cBut even if you live in a state where it\u2019s optional, it\u2019s a really important safeguard.\u201d\n\nWhat Should You Do During the Inspection?\n\nYou should make every effort to be present when the inspection is taking place. You can follow the inspector around the house and ask questions so you can learn more about your potential new home. If you can\u2019t make it for the inspection, you should meet with the inspector to go over the report in detail.\n\nIf you have questions about potential issues or how to take care of parts of the home, feel free to ask the evaluator. Take care, however, not to get in the inspector\u2019s way. Don\u2019t start inspecting the home yourself, either. If you test a sink while the inspector is testing a shower, for example, you might alter the results.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s also important to remember that \u201can inspection is only a snapshot in time on the day of the inspection,\u201d said John Bodrozic, a co-founder of HomeZada. So if you\u2019re buying a house in the middle of summer, try to consider how the home might perform in different conditions, like the winter or fall.\n\nA Home\u2019s Report Card\n\nOnce the inspector completes an evaluation, you will receive a report with the inspector\u2019s findings. Don\u2019t be alarmed if you see a lot of deficiencies noted. Home inspections are detailed, so reports often include between 50 and 100 issues, most of which are relatively small.\n\nThe report should include information about how severe each listed problem is, plus estimates on how much it would cost to fix each problem. Ask the inspector for clarifications on this if necessary.\n\nIf the inspection finds more problems than you\u2019re comfortable dealing with, you can choose to back out of the sale or try to negotiate to have the seller make the repairs or lower the price. If you\u2019re satisfied with the condition of the home or the shape it will be in after the seller meets the arrangements of your negotiations, you can move into your new home with more peace of mind.", "title": "What to Expect From a Home Inspection", "authors": ["Megan Wild"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Most directly, the law reduces how much mortgage debt will benefit from tax-deductible interest payments; that number was previously $1 million and is now $750,000. Also, property taxes previously had no limits in being deductible against federal income tax, but now the deduction of property and other state and local taxes is capped at $10,000.\n\nBoth provisions will most affect upper- and upper-middle-income families in states with relatively high housing prices and high state and local taxes: Think Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Maryland and California.\n\nFor example, a married couple in Connecticut with a $300,000 annual income aiming to borrow $1 million toward a $1.2 million house would be able to deduct about $33,000 in mortgage interest in the first year of their loan, compared with about $44,000 under the previous law. Because they would be in the 24 percent federal marginal tax bracket, buying that house would cost them about $2,650 more in the first year of the mortgage after taxes than under previous law.\n\nMoreover, that family\u2019s state income tax obligations would push them over the $10,000 deductibility limit on their own, meaning the family would effectively lose the ability to deduct property taxes of around $22,000 a year, depending on the jurisdiction. That represents another reduction of this family\u2019s tax advantage from homeownership by about $5,000 a year.\n\n(Our hypothetical family may not be losing out as much as those numbers suggest because they would have faced the alternative minimum tax under the old tax system \u2014 evidence of just how complex these calculations can be.)\n\nEven people whose mortgages are well below $750,000, or who are in lower-tax states, may find the tax law could shift the incentives for buying compared with renting. The new law roughly doubles the standard deduction that all households can take, to $24,000 for a married couple, which means that more households will find that they get no net tax savings from taking on a mortgage. They are better off just taking the larger standard deduction whether they buy or rent.\n\nOver all, Moody\u2019s Analytics estimates that the tax law will reduce home transaction prices by 4 percent, a number that reflects both the direct impact of tax changes and higher interest rates caused by larger deficits.", "title": "What to Expect From the Housing Market This Spring", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "As you go from trekking the Coast-to-Coast Walkway to a night of theater on the waterfront of this multifaceted New Zealand city, you\u2019ll want to be equally prepared for indoor and outdoor adventures. Here are some recommendations from Wirecutter, The New York Times\u2019s product review site.\n\nRia Misra, an editor at Wirecutter, suggests that you remember the shifting weather while packing for your time in this stylish, but casual, city: Days spent on and off boats, beaches, and ferries means that you\u2019ll also want to be ready for bright, breezy, or even damp conditions. Having a windbreaker, sunglasses, sunscreen, and a base-layer top at the ready will help keep you comfortable as you move between activities.\n\nHere are some more of Ms. Misra\u2019s suggestions for what to take on your trip, including recommendations from Wirecutter\u2019s experts.\n\nDon\u2019t forget your:", "title": "What to Pack for 36 Hours in Auckland", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Whether you\u2019re planning a trip to Memphis, Tenn., for the National Civil Rights Museum\u2019s commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King\u2019s assassination; to take in musical history at Graceland; enjoy some of the country\u2019s best barbecue; or all of the above, here\u2019s what you\u2019ll need.\n\nWe\u2019ve shared packing essentials for any 36-hour trip in previous lists, so when Elaine Glusac, our travel columnist, recently returned from Memphis, we asked her to share a few specific things she was glad she brought with her \u2014 or wished she had taken.\n\nThen we turned to Ria Misra, an editor at Wirecutter, for the best items to fill those needs \u2014 and her expert suggestions for other things to pack to make the most of your trip. Here are their picks.\n\nDon\u2019t forget your:\n\nCollapsible travel tote. \u201cI wish I had a magical bag like Hermione Granger in the Harry Potter stories to swallow up all the gear I need to travel with. Catching live music is a vital part of visiting Memphis and it\u2019s hard to dance with a giant tote,\u201d Ms. Glusac said. Since we can\u2019t magic away the inconvenience of carrying a bag around, the next best thing is a convertible bag that\u2019s flexible enough for different needs. Ms. Misra suggests the Patagonia Lightweight Travel Tote, which transforms into a backpack to carry a change of clothes and water bottle if you\u2019ll be out all day, converts back into a tote for walking between shops and restaurants, and (while Ms. Misra notes that doesn\u2019t come with a vanishing spell) it can be packed down into its own pocket when empty.\n\nSun protection. \u201cA hat with a bill to shade your face is essential,\u201d noted Ms. Glusac. Wirecutter recommends the Tilley LTM6 Airflow Hat, which will protect both your neck and your face from the sun. It\u2019s comfortable and stylish, too. Even with sun protection baked into the hat\u2019s fabric, though, you\u2019ll still want to apply a good sunscreen and use it correctly.\n\nTravel umbrella. We just mentioned sun protection, but keep in mind the weather can change quickly in Memphis. That means you\u2019ll also want a small umbrella. This Lewis N. Clark Travel Umbrella is small and lightweight enough to tuck into a bag to protect you on days that rain, but not take up too much space on sunny days. Plus, if the wind kicks up, it\u2019s sturdy enough to weather a sudden thunderstorm without buckling or breaking.", "title": "What to Pack for 36 Hours in Memphis", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "A city steeped in culture, both ancient and modern, Oaxaca has a lot to offer. From a rich culinary scene and boutique hotels to traditional crafts, art and culture, there\u2019s plenty to enjoy.\n\nWe\u2019ve shared packing essentials for any 36-hour trip in previous lists, so we asked Freda Moon, our travel columnist who recently visited Oaxaca, to share a few specific things she was glad she brought with her \u2014 or wished she had taken.\n\nThen we asked Ria Misra, an editor at Wirecutter, for the best items to fill those needs \u2014 and her expert suggestions for other things to pack to make the most of your trip. Here are their picks.\n\nTravel umbrella. \u201cOaxaca is in the semi-tropics,\u201d Ms. Moon said, \u201cso unexpected two-hour downpours aren\u2019t uncommon.\u201d Don\u2019t skimp on the umbrella, either. Spending a little more on a good one means you won\u2019t have to replace it every time the wind picks up.\n\nA packable daypack. \u201cOaxaca will make you want to shop,\u201d Ms. Moon said, and considering the wealth of local crafts and art, you\u2019ll have plenty to take home. She also noted that store hours can be unpredictable, so \u201cwhen you see something you like, buy it.\u201d This day pack from Matador is not only waterproof (in case you do get caught in a shower) but incredibly light. Plus it packs down to about the size of a smartphone, so it won\u2019t take up much space in your carry-on \u2014 when it\u2019s empty, that is.\n\nA protective bottle pouch. Speaking of luggage, Ms. Moon suggests packing something to protect the bottle of mezcal you\u2019ll probably be bringing home (for yourself, for your dog sitter, for whoever). She used this inflatable bottle pouch from Kohl\u2019s.\n\nFeminine products. \u201cIn a lot of places in Latin America, it\u2019s hard to find tampons or options are very limited,\u201d Ms. Moon notes. So, if you think you may need tampons (Ms. Misra pointed us to Wirecutter\u2019s applicator and applicator-free suggestions) while traveling, or have brand, type or style preferences, make sure to bring your own.\n\nA good, portable camera. We recommend a camera for virtually every destination, but Oaxaca\u2019s natural beauty and art scene really call for one. Shooting with a mirrorless camera, like the Olympus OM-D E-M10 Mark II, means that you\u2019ll get quality images with a fairly compact device. It comes with a nice lens, but if you do want to upgrade to better capture the architecture and street life the city is known for, Ms. Misra recommends a fast prime such as this Panasonic Lumix G 25mm f/1.7.", "title": "What to Pack for 36 Hours in Oaxaca", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "So you have a few days to spare in one of Brazil\u2019s largest, most beautiful cities. Whether you plan to roam through Vila Madalena\u2019s market or take in the art at IMS Paulista, the first thing you\u2019ll need is comfortable walking shoes. Beyond that, here are some other essentials, with the help of Wirecutter, The New York Times\u2019s product review site.\n\nRia Misra, an editor at Wirecutter, offers a few reminders: First, pickpockets target tourists, so aim to blend in. Keep your camera secured with a strap, your shopping in a tote or messenger bag (not a backpack) that zips shut securely, and any cash or cards tucked out of sight in a not easily accessible wallet.\n\nRegardless of the weather, you\u2019ll probably find that your light jacket gets much more of a workout than your sunglasses. The skies are often overcast, but weather conditions fluctuate by the week, the day and even the hour, Ms. Misra noted. Dressing simply and casually in light, sheddable layers will help you stay comfortable in a variety of both temperatures and situations, from morning walking tours of the city\u2019s vivid street art through an evening of cocktails and live music.\n\nWith the basics out of the way, here are Ms. Misra\u2019s packing suggestions, complete with specific recommendations from Wirecutter experts.", "title": "What to Pack for 36 Hours in S\u00e3o Paulo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Resting along the Danube, with the Hungarian Parliament Building on one bank and the Fisherman\u2019s Bastion standing watch over the other, Budapest is a city of art, architecture, history, and of course, luxurious thermal baths. If you want to visit, you\u2019ll need to prepare. Here\u2019s what to bring.\n\nWe\u2019ve shared packing essentials for any 36-hour trip in previous lists, so I asked Evan Rail, our travel columnist who\u2019s been to Budapest several times, to name a few items he thinks any tourist would be glad they packed.\n\nThen we turned to Ria Misra, an editor at Wirecutter, for the best products to fill those needs \u2014 and her expert suggestions for other things to pack to make the most of your trip. Here are their picks.\n\nDon\u2019t Forget Your:\n\nComfortable, Quality Sleep Mask. For the already jet-lagged traveler, Budapest\u2019s late-night scene can be as much a challenge as a charm \u2014 especially since, as Mr. Rail notes, \u201chotel curtains rarely seem to be designed with the city\u2019s night life in mind.\u201d I can vouch for this, having once slept in a hotel room looking out at the Budapest Eye, which was always beautiful and quite colorful, but bright even at night. Bring a good sleep mask, like the Nidra Deep Rest. Ms. Misra offered a helpful reminder: Pack it in your carry-on for the flight so that you get some rest on the way. (For best results, combine it with a good pair of ear plugs and the Travelrest Ultimate Memory Foam Travel Pillow.)\n\nSwimsuit and Towel. For the thermal pools at the Rudas Baths, you\u2019ll want your swimsuit and a quick-drying towel. The Packtowl Personal, collapses down into its own little pouch, has a loop for hanging between soaks, and is made of a fast-drying microfiber, so you won\u2019t need to worry about pulling a sopping towel from the bottom of your pack at the end of the day.\n\nLightweight Daypack. \u201cBudapest is the kind of place where you can find wonderful souvenirs: storied antiques, Communist-era tchotchkes, and stuff from the city\u2019s surprisingly cool contemporary design scene,\u201d Mr. Rail said. A lightweight, durable daypack, like L.L.Bean\u2019s Stowaway Day Pack \u2014 which you can stuff into its own pocket until you need it \u2014 will be incredibly useful.\n\nSun Protection. \u201cEven in the winter, the sunlight there can be startlingly bright, especially compared to grayer destinations in Central Europe,\u201d Mr. Rail said.
