Bring sunscreen (and use it correctly!) and a pair of sunglasses, like these Kent Wangs.", "title": "What to Pack for a Trip to Budapest", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nIt\u2019s \u201cAtlanta\u201d season. Donald Glover, the multitalented creator of that surreal dramedy from FX, kept a relatively low profile last year after wrapping up the show\u2019s Emmy-winning first season and releasing an acclaimed album under his musical alias, Childish Gambino. Now, he\u2019s finally back with 10 new episodes, collectively titled \u201cAtlanta Robbin\u2019 Season.\u201d\n\n\u2018Atlanta\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: FX, Hulu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn his New York Times review, the critic James Poniewozik compares Season 2 with its predecessor. \u201cAlong with its new title, \u2018Atlanta Robbin\u2019 Season\u2019 has a different, more serial structure from the impressionistic first season,\u201d he writes. \u201cWhat\u2019s blessedly the same: the dry sense of humor, the luscious visual style established by the frequent director Hiro Murai and the writers\u2019 effortless fluency with social media\u2019s language and quirks.\u201d If Thursday\u2019s alligator-crazy premiere has you itching to read more about \u201cRobbin\u2019 Season,\u201d our list of the best recent writing on \u201cAtlanta\u201d \u2014 including a few standout recaps to bookmark \u2014 is an excellent place to start.\n\nInterviews\n\n\u2018The Cast of \u201cAtlanta\u201d on Trump, Race and Fame\u2019 [The New York Times]\n\nIn a round-table interview with The Times\u2019s Joe Coscarelli and the show\u2019s stars, Stephen Glover, a lead writer of \u201cAtlanta\u201d and Donald\u2019s younger brother, explained the inspiration behind the second season\u2019s theme: \u201cThe concept of \u2018Robbin\u2019 Season\u2019 just felt cool because we\u2019d done a lot of summer stuff in the first season \u2014 it felt really hot,\u201d Glover recalled. \u201cI started to remember what it\u2019s like to live there during the winter time; the city just has a vibe that\u2019s very dark. People think it\u2019s a party city, but there\u2019s this side where there\u2019s a lot of crime and grittiness. I think that goes with the Trump vibe, too. People were just feeling a little less optimistic at the time.\u201d\n\n\u2018Donald Glover Can\u2019t Save You\u2019 [The New Yorker]\n\nThe creator of \u201cAtlanta\u201d gets the New Yorker profile treatment in this extraordinary piece of long-form journalism by Tad Friend, who touches on Glover\u2019s wildest artistic ambitions, his conception of reality as an algorithm to be figured out, the experience of making \u201cblack\u201d art in America and much more. \u201cI tell stories because that\u2019s the best way of spreading information,\u201d Glover tells Friend in a typically high-minded exchange. \u201cWe\u2019re all tricking and toying and playing with each other\u2019s senses to affect this thing hidden inside our skulls.\u201d\n\n0\n\nEssays\n\n\u2018\u201cAtlanta\u201d\u2019s Second Season Interrogates the Value of Money\u2019 [Jezebel]\n\nAs Clover Hope sees it, Season 2 is an exploration of the characters\u2019 frustrating lives within a capitalist economy. She writes that every episode \u201cinvolves a theft of some sort, not just physical but institutional,\u201d adding: \u201cThere\u2019s a sense that as these young black men go about trying to make their friend Paper Boi popular (or whatever success looks like to them), at a thrilling yet painstaking pace, there\u2019s a crime-like societal setup in place. They\u2019re having things stripped from them in the process, whether it\u2019s their culture, stature, or actual possessions.\u201d\n\n\u2018\u201cAtlanta\u201d and the Anxiety of Fame\u2019 [The Atlantic]\n\nSophie Gilbert observes that, in the new episodes, \u201cEarn\u2019s mounting anxiety as he intuits that everyone he meets is trying to take something from him begins to feel oppressive.\u201d She continues, \u201cIt\u2019s hard not to interpret these moments as an allegory for Glover\u2019s own altered relationship with the world, his obligatory suspicions about what people want him to do, or to be.\u201d\n\nThe Music of \u2018Atlanta\u2019\n\n\u2018Following a Feeling: How \u201cAtlanta\u201d Got Its Authentic Sound\u2019 [Pigeons & Planes]\n\nBefore the season premiere, the show\u2019s music supervisors, Jen Malone and Fam Rothstein, sat for an interview with Eric Skelton of Pigeons & Planes. Asked whether there was a significant difference between the last season\u2019s soundtrack and the music in the new episodes, Rothstein said: \u201cThe tone of the overall season changed. It\u2019s a lot darker in general. So I think there are certain flavors and notes that we make sure have some sort of connection to the identity of each episode. But for the most part, you can see parallels between Season 1 and Season 2 and the identity that we\u2019re forging with the show over all.\u201d\n\n\u2018What Does Atlanta Hip-Hop Think of \u201cAtlanta\u201d the Show?\u2019 [Pitchfork]\n\n\u201cAtlanta\u201d loves to spotlight local rappers, but do people working in Atlanta\u2019s music industry find the show realistic? Christina Lee poses that question to a handful of the city\u2019s artists and behind-the-scenes figures, and gets a different type of answer from everyone she asks.\n\nRecaps\n\n\u2018\u201cAtlanta\u201d Season 2 Premiere: It\u2019s Robbin\u2019 Season\u2019 [The New York Times]\n\nIn her recap for The Times, Leigh-Ann Jackson notes that the \u201cAtlanta\u201d premiere raises plenty of questions. \u201cThe writers returned from their protracted break offering up more questions than answers,\u201d she writes. \u201cIt\u2019s not clear how much time has transpired since we last left the core trio. No one knows why Darius and Al have beef at the top of the episode. Who are Uncle Jarvis and Damon, and what did Willy do to Earn\u2019s mom that\u2019s left him carrying a grudge? Will the teens in the opening robbery be relevant down the road?\u201d\n\n\u2018\u201cAtlanta\u201d Season 2 Is Off to a Weird, Perfect Start\u2019 [The Ringer]\n\n\u201cIf Season 1 ended on a note of fragile optimism,\u201d writes Micah Peters, \u201cthe premiere of \u2018Robbin\u2019 Season\u2019 feels defined by a simmering panic, like the anxiety that stampedes back in once a high wears off, like the dread of knowing you\u2019ll have to either make decisions or have them made for you soon.\u201d This Peters\u2019s recap is devoted largely to the beleaguered comedian Katt Williams\u2019s triumphant guest appearance as Earn\u2019s uncle.\n\n\u2018\u201cAtlanta Robbin\u2019 Season\u201d Premiere Recap: You Good?\u2019 [Vulture]\n\nBryan Washington muses that \u201ca thing from this premiere that I think is worth noting, the one thing that\u2019ll stick with me the longest, is how often we see black people just quiet and thinking on camera.\u201d He urges readers to \u201cwatch it again and count,\u201d continuing: \u201cHow often have you seen that, really? No music. Just thinking, onscreen.\u201d", "title": "What to Read About \u2018Atlanta\u2019 Season 2", "authors": ["Judy Berman"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Painters often find their styles by setting narrow limits on their work. But things usually get really interesting when they start working against their own rules. Sarah Crowner, known over the last decade for stitching together cutout shapes of plain or painted canvas to form rectilinear abstract paintings, is sticking to first principles. Yet she\u2019s messing with them so vigorously that \u201cWeeds,\u201d her fifth solo gallery show in New York, has the feeling of a breakthrough.\n\nMs. Crowner has complicated her compositions, strewing them with tipsy curves, ellipses and parts of circles suggestive of orange sections. Her arrangements borrow from the history of abstraction without accruing too great a debt. Matisse\u2019s cutouts and Ellsworth Kelly\u2019s signature curves, which were often kissing, or stacked like those in the letter B, are repeatedly folded into the flux.", "title": "What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "The Brazilian artist Erika Verzutti is in her late 40s, but her work exudes the exploratory energy of youth, mellowed by older, wiser emotional warmth, especially in her unusual combination of materials. In \u201cEx Gurus,\u201d her first commercial gallery solo in New York, Ms. Verzutti uses raw bronze, gold in color, as canvas; combines papier-m\u00e2ch\u00e9 with concrete; and in \u201cCemetery Inline,\u201d makes a bumpy Carl Andre floor piece resembling a ragtag row of tombstones from chunks of cobblestone, unbaked clay and papier-m\u00e2ch\u00e9 with color added. More subtly, Ms. Verzutti pits the translucence of oil paint against the implacable opacity of acrylic.\n\nThis contrast is especially evident in \u201cFloral,\u201d where the shapes of a wilting flower and perhaps a beehive carved into the surface of raw bronze, are veiled in blue or yellow; dots of acrylic jump all around them like bees. Ms. Verzutti usually creates a specific physical place for color in her bronze surfaces (see the extremely satisfying \u201cAstrology\u201d). Except when she doesn\u2019t: In \u201cHomeopatia,\u201d arguably the show\u2019s star, lozenge-shaped indentations of brilliant color dot the raw bronze surface while other lozenges are painted flat on the surface, which creates strange spatial ambiguities. It resembles a painter\u2019s palette and an entomologist\u2019s beetle collection.\n\nDespite Ms. Verzutti\u2019s love of color, her mind seems alive with sculpture. Past works have referred to Robert Gober and Jeff Koons. \u201cDias da Semana\u201d evokes some of Brancusi\u2019s sexier sculptures while also \u2014 seen from a certain angle \u2014 recalling her penchant for casting fruits and vegetables. In two dark bronze reliefs named \u201cWitch\u201d and \u201cPilates\u201d she drags little stones or clumps of bronze down the surface, creating deep ruts and leaving the forming implements in place. They\u2019re mini-earthworks that pay tribute to the Italian artist Lucio Fontana. Combined with the show\u2019s title, the works\u2019 names suggest paths to health that Ms. Verzutti has tried and discarded. They also suggest an artist who leaves no stone unturned.", "title": "What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "HOLLAND COTTER\n\nEdith Schloss\n\nThrough March 30. Meredith Ward Fine Art, 44 East 74th Street, Suite G, Manhattan; 212-744-7306, meredithwardfineart.com.\n\nThis show brings the painter Edith Schloss (1919-2011) one step closer to the small but definite niche that is her due. Following a larger, somewhat confusing retrospective at the Sundaram Tagore Gallery in 2015, this show, \u201cBy the Sea,\u201d zeros in on her best work: a group of small, delightful still lifes from the 1960s and \u201970s. They were made in Italy, to which Schloss decamped for good in 1964, after about 18 years of marriage to the photographer/filmmaker Rudy Burckhardt and active participation in the nascent downtown New York art scene.\n\nThese paintings make good on Schloss\u2019s longtime interest in still life, partly by taking cues from the painters Cy Twombly and Giorgio Morandi, both of whom she knew in Italy. The canvases feature a set cast of vases, pitchers and occasional toys (her son\u2019s) that Schloss was never without, even when traveling. She would fill the vessels with blooms \u2014 thick circles in hearty shades of blue, orange or red balanced by whites and pinks and sometimes by patches of bare canvas. Especially in paintings from 1967 and \u201968 titled \u201cRignalla\u201d and \u201cOn the Ledge\u201d from 1976, she lines up the vases on a high horizon, giving them a personable lean and monumental scale reminiscent of Philip Guston\u2019s late works. In others, the bouquets line the bottom edge of the canvas or paper, as if on a windowsill overlooking a beach or the sea stretching beyond. At this point in her life, Schloss painted with consummate ease and abundant charm, sketching in her subjects and then applying color as needed. But don\u2019t be fooled. Her best works are primers on the shortest route to a good, original painting.\n\nROBERTA SMITH\n\nThomas Demand\n\nThrough April 7. Matthew Marks, 523 West 24th Street, Manhattan; 212-243-0200, matthewmarks.com.\n\nPhoto\n\nThomas Demand is a hybrid photographer. He trained as a sculptor and is best known for making cardboard and paper models of momentous events and politically charged sites \u2014 the meager kitchen in Saddam Hussein\u2019s last hide-out in Iraq or the nuclear power plant in Fukushima, Japan \u2014 and photographing them to look deceptively realistic. In his current show at Matthew Marks, however, Mr. Demand shifts his primary focus to recreating photographs taken with his cellphone.\n\nIn the front gallery the walls are covered with gray wallpaper depicting school or workplace lockers (overtones, perhaps inadvertently, of American school shootings). Two videos shown on monitors suspended from the ceiling and a handful of photographs reproduce saccharine or banal subjects that Mr. Demand photographed with his cellphone: a red bow tied to a fence; a box with electrical wiring; blinking stoplights and balloons attached to a plastic clip. In the rear gallery are three large photographs in Mr. Demand\u2019s recognizable style, depicting the ruins of an unidentified bombardment, the interior of a barracks tent and the warmly lit workshop of a Bavarian violin maker \u2014 all near-perfectly sculpted in cardboard and paper and photographed.\n\nThe cellphone-derived works, titled \u201cDailies,\u201d are not as dramatic or captivating as the historical scenes. And yet, they accurately depict the present, merging Mr. Demand\u2019s anesthetized aesthetic with a world in which people are attached to their smartphones, capturing images they will never look at again. In this sense, Mr. Demand memorializes the banal and the forgotten with the same painstaking care he gives to more charged moments in history and suffuses the \u201cDailies\u201d with an uncanny absurdity and pathos.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMARTHA SCHWENDENER\n\nCarissa Rodriguez\n\nThrough April 2. SculptureCenter, 44-19 Purves Street, Long Island City, Queens; 718-361-1750, sculpture-center.org.\n\nPhoto\n\nConstantin Brancusi made an iconic, egg-shaped marble head, which he called \u201cLe Nouveau N\u00e9\u201d (\u201cThe Newborn\u201d), in 1915. In 1993, Sherrie Levine made a mold of the piece for a show at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, which owns it, and subsequently cast versions in foggy white crystal and black sandblasted glass. Carissa Rodriguez\u2019s new video, \u201cThe Maid,\u201d on view in the middle of SculptureCenter\u2019s main gallery, visits several of these casts in the richly appointed collectors\u2019 homes and the sterile white warehouses on both coasts where they\u2019ve ended up. No people are visible, except for the gloved hands of two preparators and a cleaning woman seen through a window, and the only sound is minimal electronic music. In New York, the weather is snowy and dark; in Los Angeles, staggeringly bright.\n\nIf Ms. Levine\u2019s appropriation was a one-to-one critique of the male artist-hero mythos that congealed around Brancusi, Ms. Rodriguez\u2019s reframing would seem to be a critique of the old-fashioned matrix of money and power in which even Ms. Levine\u2019s feminist reversal was still inextricably embedded. But what makes the video not merely effective but strangely moving is its air of scientific detachment. Taking in both Ms. Levine\u2019s casts themselves and the tokens of wealth and access with which they\u2019re surrounded \u2014 Warhols, sports cars, snapshots of the Clintons \u2014 with the same impartial attention, Ms. Rodriguez makes the entire complex social phenomenon of art making and collecting seem as blindly mechanical as evolution. If there is a critique, it\u2019s in the suggestion that we could have dissolved our idols already just by looking at them more closely.\n\nWILL HEINRICH", "title": "What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week", "authors": ["Roberta Smith", "Holland Cotter", "Martha Schwendener", "Will Heinrich"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "The stated mission of this new TriBeCa project space, founded by a former partner at David Zwirner, is to exhibit artists who\u2019ve had significant foreign impact but little exposure in the United States. Its inaugural show certainly qualifies: This is the first American solo outing for Michel Parmentier (1938-2000), one of the most undeviating abstract painters of postwar France, whose radically simple paintings fused minimalism, performance and institutional critique.\n\nMr. Parmentier is best known as one-quarter of the swashbuckling but short-lived group known as B.M.P.T. (The letters stand for the last names of the artists Daniel Buren, Olivier Mosset, Mr. Parmentier and Niele Toroni.) I n 1967, its members voiced their intolerance for gestural abstraction by painting ultra-minimal canvases at a Paris salon \u2014 in Mr. Parmentier\u2019s case, horizontal stripes exactly 38 centimeters wide, done with spray paint \u2014 and then quickly withdrawing them from view. Four paintings here feature his trademark stripes, in blue or silver or red or black, spanning the unstretched canvas and bulging out from the wall; you can see the creases where he folded the canvas and the punctures where staples held it to his studio wall.\n\nMr. Parmentier broke from B.M.P.T. just a year after the group\u2019s debut; he gave up painting from 1968 to 1983. His second phase also comprises horizontal stripes on unstretched supports, but now he has used delicate paper rather than thick canvas, and composed the stripes with dense freehand marks in pastel, paintstick or pencil. These fragile later works are as dispassionate and skeptical of gesture as his early striped canvases, though instead of the extreme authorial abnegation of spray paint, here the handmade marks marry restraint and repetition with subtle individuality.\n\nFrench abstract painting of the 1960s, dismissed at the time by chauvinistic American critics, is having quite a moment in New York: Elsewhere in town now are exhibitions by Martin Barr\u00e9 and Fran\u00e7ois Morellet. But there is a particular satisfaction, in today\u2019s snapping and yapping New York art world, in rediscovering this most stringent painter of all.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJASON FARAGO\n\nMadeline Hollander\n\nSaturdays from 2 to 6 p.m. through March 24. The Artist\u2019s Institute at Hunter College, 132 East 65th Street, Manhattan; theartistsinstitute.org.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe project notes for Madeline Hollander\u2019s \u201cNew Max\u201d are probably the best way to describe her current installation at the Artist\u2019s Institute at Hunter College. \u201cPerformance begins at 65 degrees Fahrenheit, and dancers continuously hit a new maximum temperature each round.\u201d Lower on the page are directions for the four dancers to pause (\u201cdancers rest\u201d) before performing another of the 16 cycles in the work as the temperature in the room, controlled by four air-conditioning units, four heat sensors and four light panels, rises from a low of 65 degrees to a high of 85.\n\nIf \u201cNew Max,\u201d which clearly descended from 1960s systems-based artwork, sounds dry, it is not. The four young dancers, clad in stylish silver boxing shorts, specially designed black chemises and Keds sneakers, perform a series of movements choreographed by Ms. Hollander that fall somewhere between an Yvonne Rainer sequence and stuff you\u2019d do in an exercise class. (Many dancers make their living teaching various types of Pilates-Yoga-Gyrotonics, which inevitably surface in their choreography.) The overall impression is of a 21st-century version of the graces in Botticelli\u2019s \u201cPrimavera\u201d (1477-1482), but here dancing is a form of mechanized labor rather than a lyric pleasure.\n\nThe performance-installation gains further heft from a smart essay by A. E. Benenson, printed for visitors on thermal paper, as if it were a long drugstore receipt. The essay touches on the history of air-conditioners, climate change and the alt-surrealist Georges Bataille\u2019s musings on energy and consumption. \u201cHeat is the universe\u2019s choreography,\u201d the essay states, concluding that \u201cwe have built a kind of planetary-scale air-conditioner. It\u2019s just stuck facing wrong-side-out,\u201d with greenhouse gas trapped with us inside. Meanwhile, Ms. Hollander\u2019s graces dance silently before you in the slowly rising heat of the room.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMARTHA SCHWENDENER\n\n\u2018Prison Nation\u2019\n\nThrough March 7. Aperture Foundation, 547 West 27th Street, fourth floor, Manhattan; 212-505-5555, aperture.org.\n\nAperture Foundation often produces exhibitions to complement issues of its photography quarterly, Aperture magazine. Such is the case with \u201cPrison Nation,\u201d a stirring show about mass incarceration in the United States, with the historian Nicole R. Fleetwood doing double duty as curator and issue editor.\n\nBetween what\u2019s on the wall and what\u2019s in print there\u2019s a lot of history. In the magazine, the lawyer Bryan Stevenson, founder of the Equal Justice Initiative in Montgomery, Ala., and author of the 2014 memoir \u201cJust Mercy,\u201d traces the disproportionate degree of African-American incarceration back to 18th-century slavery, when American citizenship was restricted to property-owning white men. And in photographs in the show from the 1960s and \u201970s by the folklorist Bruce Jackson, we see 20th-century East Texas prison farms that were, in effect, cotton plantations that used racially segregated forced labor.\n\nFar from being coolly documentary, though, many of the images in the show are personal. The artist Jamel Shabazz, renowned for his images of contemporary black street fashion, and his fellow New York photographer Lorenzo Steele Jr., both worked as correction officers on Rikers Island in the 1980s. Their on-the-job pictures of colleagues offer a counterweight to the usually negative view of prison staff.\n\nAnd, in general, the show gives a warmer image of prison life than we\u2019re accustomed to seeing: in Jack Lueders-Booth\u2019s beautiful 1970s color portraits of inmates at the Massachusetts Correctional Institution-Framingham, one of the oldest women\u2019s prisons in the country; in Lucas Foglia\u2019s images of prisoners tending to Rikers Island flower gardens; in the artwork created from soap bars and newsprint photographs by a former inmate, Jesse Krimes; and in Deborah Luster\u2019s extraordinary, monumental 2013 portraits of prisoners dressed for roles in an Easter passion play in the Louisiana State Penitentiary at Angola.\n\nThe humanizing perspective of \u201cPrison Nation\u201d is deeply moving and long overdue. It\u2019s crucial to remember, though, the unforgiving realities of incarceration. A majority of the prisoners at Angola, which is built on the site of several former slave plantations, are serving life sentences, either by judicial decision or by default. According to a text accompanying Ms. Luster\u2019s photographs, some 90 percent of inmates who enter Angola, at whatever age, for whatever crime, are expected to die there.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHOLLAND COTTER", "title": "What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week", "authors": ["Roberta Smith", "Will Heinrich", "Jason Farago", "Martha Schwendener", "Holland Cotter"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "That coalition ran with the anti-Europe, anti-immigrant party League, formerly the Northern League, whose leader, Matteo Salvini, has tried to broaden its appeal to the southern regions it once disparaged as hotbeds of crime and corruption; with Fratelli d\u2019Italia, or Brothers of Italy, the most recent postwar mutation of Mussolini\u2019s fascist party; and with a smaller centrist party.\n\nThe League gained about 18 percent of votes, according to preliminary results.\n\nThe center-left coalition is anchored by the Democratic Party, which has been losing support in opinion polls since its leader, Matteo Renzi, stepped down a year ago after unsuccessfully lobbying to overhaul the Constitution.\n\nThe Democrats formed a coalition with three centrist and center-left movements: Civica Popolare, Insieme (an alliance of the Green Party and the Socialists) and Pi\u00f9 Europa (More Europe), the pro-Europe party headed by the Radical Party leader Emma Bonino.\n\nThe Five Star Movement, founded by a comic, Beppe Grillo, and by the-now deceased Gianroberto Casaleggio, whose son Davide has emerged as the party\u2019s shadow puppeteer, had been expected to garner the most votes, according to polls. The anti-establishment and populist movement has capitalized on widespread disaffection for Italy\u2019s traditional parties.\n\nThe main issues and promises\n\nPhoto\n\nThough Italy has one of the lowest percentages of migrants per capita in Europe, immigration emerged as the campaign\u2019s major theme. The issue was highlighted by an act of violence last month: the shooting of six African migrants by a right-wing sympathizer who ran with the League in a local election.\n\nCandidates across the political spectrum have played up fears of immigrants in Italy, a country that has struggled with a wave of people arriving by the Mediterranean in search of a better life. Recent polls indicated that 70 percent of Italians were concerned about safety, partly because of fears of undocumented migrants.\n\nAnother major concern was the economy. Even as Italy has seen a slight uptick in growth over the past year, the national debt is at 130 percent of the gross domestic product, the second-highest level in the euro area, after Greece. But campaign speeches had mostly steered clear of any belt-tightening measures that might be required to lower that debt.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFiscal promises, nevertheless, blossomed during the campaign, including in the League and Forza Italia\u2019s proposal for a single income and corporate tax rate of 23 percent, the Democrats\u2019 tax breaks for families and Five Star\u2019s guaranteed minimum income for millions of Italians.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome Italians see the European Union\u2019s budget deficit limit of 3 percent of G.D.P. as one of the major factors dragging down the economy, since it affects spending. Support in for the bloc\u2019s common currency is among the lowest in Europe, and there is a lingering nostalgia for the lira, which some parties, including Forza Italia, have considered reintroducing.\n\nThe turnout\n\nPhoto\n\nItalians generally vote in large numbers, but the turnout on Sunday \u2014 a little over 71 percent, according to the Italian Interior Ministry \u2014 was a decrease from the 75 percent turnout in 2013 and 80 percent in 2008.\n\nPolls had suggested there would be higher abstention rates on Sunday than in previous elections, except among those who back the Five Star Movement. The number of undecided voters has reached a record high, estimated at 30 percent to 40 percent, with many women among them.\n\nVoters cast ballots for a candidate, a party or a coalition. The vote will determine the 945 members of Parliament, as well as the party or coalition that will run the country for the next five years.\n\nWhat happens after the election\n\nPhoto\n\nPreliminary results based on exit polls will be released on national television and news websites. Official results will be available on Monday.\n\nBut it will take weeks before the next Italian government is sworn in. The new Parliament will hold its first session on March 23 and will vote to elect the speakers of the Lower House and the Senate, a first litmus test to gauge the political majority.\n\nAfter that, Italy\u2019s president, Sergio Mattarella, will start consultations to see which party or grouping in Parliament has the consensus to win a confidence vote.\n\nAfter hearing from the parties, Mr. Mattarella will ask a lawmaker to try to form a government.\n\nIf no clear winner, with a certain majority, emerges from the election, Mr. Mattarella could confer an \u201cexploratory mandate\u201d to a lawmaker, or even the speakers of the two houses, to see if a broad coalition might be possible.\n\nIn case of a stalemate, the president could envision a nonelected person chosen on the basis of expertise in forming a government. That cabinet would still need to win a vote of confidence in Parliament.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOnce the president has nominated a prime minister, the new government can be sworn in and face a vote of confidence in both houses.", "title": "What to Watch For in Italy\u2019s Election on Sunday", "authors": ["Gaia Pianigiani", "Elisabetta Povoledo"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "A rate increase this month would make clear the Fed\u2019s gathering confidence in the economy as well as its focus on the potential for inflation, which has remained persistently muted throughout the expansion.\n\n\u201cWe think Fed officials will view the growth and inflation data in recent months as encouraging,\u201d analysts at Goldman Sachs wrote in a research note ahead of the meeting, \u201cparticularly with tax cuts now implemented and with an additional fiscal boost from federal spending arriving this year.\u201d\n\nHow Many Increases?\n\nFed officials indicated in December that they expected to raise rates three times in 2018. Now some analysts say a short-term economic stimulus from Congress \u2014 in the form of a $1.5 trillion tax cut and federal spending increases \u2014 could push the Fed to add a fourth rate move. On Wednesday, the Fed\u2019s intentions will be reflected in the so-called \u201cdot plot,\u201d which charts the expectations for future rate increases from every member of the Federal Open Market Committee.\n\nA potential fourth increase would be motivated by rising concerns about an overheating economy, with such low unemployment that it sets off an inflationary spiral as companies lift wages to compete for scarce workers and increase prices to pay for those higher salaries. A portion of the voting membership of the committee rotates every year among the Fed\u2019s regional bank presidents. The new members tend to worry more about inflation than those they replaced. Even some members who have fretted more about growth than inflation appear to be shifting their calculus.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLael Brainard, a Fed governor who has been less hawkish than many of her colleagues, said in a speech this month that in many ways, \u201ctoday is the mirror image of the environment we confronted a couple of years ago.\u201d\n\n\u201cIn the earlier period, strong headwinds sapped the momentum of the recovery and weighed down the path of policy,\u201d she added. \u201cToday, with headwinds shifting to tailwinds, the reverse could hold true.\u201d\n\nA Case for Caution\n\nIf the Fed sticks to three planned rate increases this year, analysts will point to lingering uncertainties in the recovery, including structural issues like a ballooning debt load and trade barriers that could turn the economy\u2019s tailwinds back into headwinds.\n\nRecent data suggest that economic growth is falling short of expectations for the first quarter. Wage growth appears to be improving, but the signs are mixed. Markets have been rattled in recent weeks by Mr. Trump\u2019s tariff plans and embrace of a potential trade war. The Fed seems unlikely to react strongly to any one of those factors, but taken together, they could prod officials into pushing any additional rate move into 2019.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPowell\u2019s Big Performance\n\nThough this will be his first news conference as Fed chairman, Mr. Powell has already faced tough questioning during two days of congressional hearings in February and March. He struck a careful tone in those appearances, saying he had upgraded his own economic outlook but saw no evidence yet of overheating in the economy.\n\nMr. Powell also offered only gentle criticism of Mr. Trump\u2019s planned tariffs on imported steel and aluminum. He praised free trade in general, while acknowledging that it had hurt some workers by shifting jobs overseas, and added, \u201cThe best approach is to deal directly with the people who are affected rather than falling back on tariffs.\u201d\n\nReporters are likely to push Mr. Powell more on that subject, especially with Mr. Trump\u2019s tariffs scheduled to take hold this week and the administration readying a round of trade penalties aimed directly at China. Analysts expect him not to rock markets with any surprise opinions, in line with his performance in front of Congress.\n\n\u201cHe came off fairly polished in that, as if he wasn\u2019t nervous about being there,\u201d said Tim Duy, a University of Oregon economist who writes the Fed Watch blog. \u201cI would expect him to be similar in this news conference. He\u2019s not going to drop any bombshells.\u201d", "title": "What to Watch for in Fed\u2019s Rate Decision", "authors": ["Jim Tankersley"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nAmong the nine best-picture Oscar nominees this year, we have three based on real events, two that are explicitly topical, two coming-of-age tales and two very unusual love stories. All of the films have been informed \u2014 directly or indirectly \u2014 by other movies throughout history. Many of those are available to stream.\n\n\u2018Call Me by Your Name\u2019\n\nTimoth\u00e9e Chalamet, left, and Armie Hammer in \u201cCall Me by Your Name.\u201d Sony Pictures Classics\n\nFans of independent and international cinema may recognize some of the cinematic traditions to which this film belongs: the European poeticism, the thematic daring, the suffusion of vintage sound and color. Here are several wonderful films for context.\n\n\u2018Edge of Seventeen\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d is set in Italy in 1983; this comedy-drama from 1999 by David Moreton is set in Sandusky, Ohio, in 1984, and similarly concerns a teenage boy\u2019s evolving understanding of his sexual identity. But the two films don\u2019t share only those surface similarities; like Elio, the young protagonist in \u201cCall Me,\u201d Eric, from \u201cSeventeen,\u201d finds himself unexpectedly stirred by a smooth, confident older man, which complicates his dalliance with a kind young woman \u2014 who, herself, is only starting to find her way and is doomed for heartbreak. But most of all, \u201cSeventeen\u201d beautifully captures the feeling of being young, aching for love and discovering its complications and implications.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018\u00c0 nos Amours\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: FilmStruck\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe novel \u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d is set in 1987, but the film switches that date to 1983 \u2014 the year the French filmmaker Maurice Pialat released this challenging drama. Guadagnino, who is Italian, has pinpointed \u201cAmours\u201d as one of his primary influences, calling it the one coming-of-age movie \u201cthat was dear to me,\u201d because Pialat\u2019s films \u201cavoid the traps of a narrative and to be at the center of his characters.\u201d In \u201cAmour,\u201d Pialat is at the center of Suzanne (Sandrine Bonnaire), a teenage girl whose sexual awakening is a good deal more tempestuous than Elio\u2019s (and with a significant divergence in familial support). But the films share a freewheeling, languorous vibe, propelled less by plot and structure than by mood and emotion.\n\n0\n\nClick to read about four other complementary movies.\n\n\u2018Darkest Hour\u2019\n\nGary Oldman as Winston Churchill in \u201cDarkest Hour.\u201d Jack English/Focus Features\n\nThrough a wondrous serendipity, Joe Wright\u2019s \u201cDarkest Hour\u201d appeared in theaters a few months after Christopher Nolan\u2019s \u201cDunkirk,\u201d serving as a natural companion piece. \u201cDunkirk\u201d is only the most obvious film to compare it with, though, and their similarities end mostly with the subject matter. If you liked \u201cDarkest Hour,\u201d these streamable films provide great complements as well.\n\n\u2018Atonement\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix, Amazon, iTunes\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe worlds of \u201cDarkest Hour\u201d and Wright\u2019s 2007 drama, \u201cAtonement,\u201d intersect on the beaches of Dunkirk, which the earlier film renders in one celebrated tracking shot that captures the chaos, misery, surreality and defiant hope of British soldiers awaiting an evacuation that may never come. The scene pays homage to the nationalist grit expressed through Churchill\u2019s speech to the House of Commons \u2014 \u201cWe shall go on to the end,\u201d and so on \u2014 but it also keys into the experience of an individual soldier (James McAvoy), who can think only about getting back to the woman he loves (Keira Knightley). Based the novel by Ian McEwan, \u201cAtonement\u201d has the elegance and sweep of a classic wartime romance, in which the emotion intensifies with each falling bomb. But it\u2019s also a literate period piece about the tragic ramifications of one falsely witnessed moment.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018The Gathering Storm\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon Prime, HBO\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cDarkest Hour\u201d opens as Churchill succeeds Neville Chamberlain as British prime minister, amid fierce debate over whether to seek a treaty with Nazi Germany. Produced for HBO and the BBC, \u201cThe Gathering Storm\u201d catches up with Churchill six years earlier, when he was plugging away on a biography on the Duke of Marlborough at his home in Chartwell, in rural Kent.\n\nAs the title suggests, the film is about Churchill\u2019s growing alarm over German rearmament under Adolf Hitler and his difficult return to relevance, aided by government officials like Ralph Wigram (Linus Roache) who share his concerns and reject the appeasement policies of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin (Derek Jacobi). Albert Finney won an Emmy for his dyspeptic Churchill \u2014 as did Brendan Gleeson\u2019s Churchill in the lesser 2009 sequel, \u201cInto the Storm\u201d\u2014 and Vanessa Redgrave lends fine support as his wife, Clemmie, whose faith in her husband sometimes wavers dramatically.\n\nClick to read about four other complementary movies.\n\n\u2018Dunkirk\u2019\n\nA scene from \u201cDunkirk.\u201d Warner Bros. Pictures\n\nChristopher Nolan\u2019s World War II film \u201cDunkirk\u201d is one of the most critically lauded of this year\u2019s Academy Awards nominees, racking up nominations not only for best picture but also for cinematography, editing, production design and director (Nolan\u2019s first). If you value \u201cDunkirk\u201d as much as the Academy does, here are a few streamable films that are bound to resonate, whether in story or aesthetic.\n\n\u2018Dunkirk\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nNolan\u2019s \u201cDunkirk\u201d is not a remake of this 1958 British film from director Leslie Norman, though it bears the same title and portrays the same event. Norman\u2019s version is a far more conventional telling of the Dunkirk evacuation, done in a traditional style, with none of the shifting time frames of Nolan\u2019s interpretation. It is, however, a tightly crafted, hard-nosed war picture, told mostly through the eyes of two protagonists: one a British soldier (John Mills) awaiting evacuation from Dunkirk beach, the other a British reporter (Bernard Lee), who covers the events and then leads the charge of civilian boats assisting the rescue. It may not be as formally flamboyant as Nolan\u2019s telling, but it\u2019s a brilliant antecedent.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Battle of Britain\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Vudu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBarely a month after the Dunkirk Evacuation, the Royal Air Force\u2019s extended defense of Britain from German Luftwaffe began. That campaign, which lasted nearly four months, is the basis of this 1969 war film from director Guy Hamilton. Hamilton was best known for such classic Bond films as \u201cGoldfinger\u201d and \u201cDiamonds Are Forever,\u201d and his work here is less winking but just as technically impressive; the large-scale flying and battle sequences are spectacular, their scale, scope and intensity not unlike those in Nolan\u2019s \u201cDunkirk.\u201d\n\nBut Hamilton pays just as much attention to his human interactions. The all-star cast (which includes Laurence Olivier, Michael Caine, Trevor Howard, Christopher Plummer, Susannah York and Robert Shaw) shines, and the film takes great pains to include the perspective of German soldiers and officers, rather than paint them as background cartoon villains. That choice lends \u201cBattle of Britain\u201d a moral complexity that helps it transcend the usual war movie conventions \u2014 much as \u201cDunkirk\u201d does.\n\n0\n\nClick here to read about four other complementary movies.\n\n\u2018Get Out\u2019\n\nAllison Williams and Daniel Kaluuya in \u201cGet Out.\u201d Justin Lubin/Universal Pictures\n\nAhead of this film\u2019s release last year, director Jordan Peele programmed a retrospective in Brooklyn titled \u201cThe Art of the Social Thriller,\u201d which offered fans rare and direct insight into the films that influenced him. Here\u2019s where to stream some of those films now.\n\n\u2018Night of the Living Dead\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon Prime, iTunes\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe low-budget 1968 movie that launched zombies into the horror movie pantheon tells the story of a group of people holed up in a house \u2014 including a single black protagonist (Duane Jones) \u2014 who try to fend off a zombie attack. Peele told The New York Times that the movie resonated with him in an extra way. \u201cYou could write an interesting essay about how the lead in \u2018Night of the Living Dead\u2019 is a man living in fear every day,\u201d he said, \u201cso this is a challenge he is more equipped to take on than the white women living in the house.\u201d\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Guess Who\u2019s Coming to Dinner\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nA Civil Rights Era film with a social message, \u201cGuess Who\u2019s Coming to Dinner\u201d follows a young doctor (Sidney Poitier) as he meets his white girlfriend\u2019s liberal parents (Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy) for the first time. Peele explained to GQ how the movie, released in 1967, influenced the awkward scenes in his film. One of the great things about \u201cGuess Who\u2019s Coming to Dinner,\u201d he noted, was that \u201canybody can relate to is the uncomfortableness of meeting your in-laws for the first time and being at a party where you\u2019re the outsider.\n\n\u201cSo the layer of race that enriches and complicates that tension\u201d in \u201cGet Out,\u201d he continued, \u201cbecomes relatable. It\u2019s made to be an inclusive movie.\u201d\n\nClick to read about five other complementary movies.\n\n\u2018Lady Bird\u2019\n\nSaoirse Ronan and Lucas Hedges in \u201cLady Bird.\u201d Merie Wallace/A24\n\n\u201cLady Bird\u201d is up for five Academy Awards, including best picture, best actress (for Saoirse Ronan) and best director for Gerwig \u2014 only the fifth time in Oscar history that a female director has earned an Oscar nomination. As refreshing as \u201cLady Bird\u201d is, the film comes from a long line of movies about headstrong young women.\n\n\u2018The Edge of Seventeen\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Showtime, Amazon, iTunes\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe most important love story in \u201cLady Bird\u201d is the tense relationship between Christine, who calls herself Lady Bird, and her mother, Marion (Laurie Metcalf, who was nominated for best supporting actress). Likewise in \u201cThe Edge of Seventeen,\u201d it\u2019s the troubled relationship between Nadine (Hailee Steinfeld) and her mom (Kyra Sedgwick). As in \u201cLady Bird,\u201d the drama doesn\u2019t stop at home, as Nadine struggles through an also awkward adolescent romance and a broken friendship. Meanwhile, her mother either can\u2019t or refuses to understand her daughter\u2019s behavior: The two of them fight, bicker and snipe at each other in almost every shared moment. In one scene, Nadine even steals her mom\u2019s car to escape an argument. Luckily, that\u2019s not the last word in a movie full of warm supporting characters like her caring teacher (Woody Harrelson) and a cute boyfriend (Hayden Szeto).\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Pariah\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix, Amazon, iTunes\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nNothing says growing up like rebelling against your parents, and in the case of \u201cPariah,\u201d rebellion is practically a necessity. Alike (Adepero Oduye) is a 17-year-old black poet discovering her sexuality. Her much more conservative mother pushes Alike to hang out with a friend from church, with whom Alike finds more comfort in her identity as a lesbian. Despite her tenuous relationship with her mom, Alike bonds easily with her dad, who\u2019s much more lenient about her choice to wear men\u2019s clothes or spend time with friends her mom does not like. Although, he writes off Alike\u2019s behavior as a phase instead of her sexual identity, which causes problems later. Dee Rees, who more recently directed the Oscar-nominated \u201cMudbound,\u201d made her narrative debut with this powerful drama about family and acceptance.\n\nClick to read about four other complementary movies.\n\n\u2018Phantom Thread\u2019\n\nVicky Krieps and Daniel Day-Lewis in \u201cPhantom Thread.\u201d Focus Features\n\nA focused, meticulously art-directed romantic drama set in postwar England, \u201cPhantom Thread\u201d matches the pathologically fastidious couturier Reynolds Woodcock (Daniel Day-Lewis) with a young woman known only as Alma (Vicky Krieps), a canny waitress of mysterious origin. Satisfy your hunger for more high-fashion pathos and difficult love with one of these streamable films.\n\n\u2018Abuse of Weakness\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Filmstruck, Amazon, Vudu, YouTube, iTunes\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cPhantom Thread\u201d is, essentially, the tale of a romance with very unusual power dynamics. This kind of strange, obsessive love story is a specialty of the European art house, particularly of the French actress Isabelle Huppert, who brings crucial specificity to the complicated masochists she plays in movies like \u201cThe Piano Teacher\u201d and \u201cElle.\u201d Less famous but equally captivating is her performance in \u201cAbuse of Weakness,\u201d a 2014 film from the French auteur Catherine Breillat. Huppert plays a director recovering from a stroke, who casts a famous con man (Kool Shen) in her new project, gets sucked into his mind games. The film is based on a similar event from Breillat\u2019s life, and the chemistry between the leads sells its story of a smart woman who gets scammed by a man she always knew was a scammer.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\n\u2018Dior and I\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix, Amazon Prime\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cWe decided early on that Reynolds Woodcock wasn\u2019t the greatest couturier in the world,\u201d Mark Bridges, who designed the Oscar-nominated costumes for \u201cPhantom Thread,\u201d explained to Vogue. But you don\u2019t have to love his every creation to appreciate the film\u2019s stunning recreation of his atelier and the psychologically rich portraits of his wealthy clients. If the House of Woodcock\u2019s all-night sewing marathons and enervating fashion shows piqued your curiosity, consider educating yourself about contemporary couture with this behind-the-scenes documentary that follows Raf Simons\u2019s frenzied first season as the artistic director of Dior.\n\nClick to read about five other complementary movies.\n\n\u2018The Post\u2019\n\nTom Hanks and Meryl Streep in \u201cThe Post.\u201d Niko Tavernise/20th Century Fox\n\nHistorical docudrama, timely political allegory, quicksilver newspaper comedy \u2014 Steven Spielberg\u2019s \u201cThe Post\u201d is a movie that has it all, all at once. And the intersection of germane history and snappy newsroom banter offers up plenty of comparisons for related viewing.\n\n\u2018The Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Kanopy\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cThe Post\u201d is mostly concerned with the \u201chow\u201d and \u201cwhy\u201d of the Pentagon Papers, the massive study detailing the history of American involvement in Vietnam. Spielberg\u2019s film does, however, delve briefly into the \u201cwhat\u201d of the document dump in the film\u2019s early passages. If you want more about the study\u2019s contents, you can\u2019t do better than this Peabody Award-winning and Oscar-nominated feature by Judie Ehrlich and Rick Goldsmith, which takes the form of a documentary but runs with the speed and intrigue of a good political thriller. Ehrlich and Goldsmith aren\u2019t only preoccupied with the specifics of the Papers (though they certainly cover those bases). Their film also has the insight and sensitivity of a character study, probing the personal and political journey of Mr. Ellsberg, whose deep dive into the Vietnam conflict turned him from a hawk into an antiwar activist.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018His Girl Friday\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon Prime, FilmStruck\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cThe Post\u201d fits the tradition of the \u201cnewspaper picture\u201d best defined by Pauline Kael: \u201ca tough modern talkie,\u201d in most cases \u201ca melodrama with crime and political corruption and suspense and comedy and romance\u201d \u2014 often with snappy titles like \u201cScandal Sheet\u201d and \u201cLibeled Lady.\u201d And the best of those movies, or at least their screwball comedy subset, is this 1940 barnburner from Howard Hawks. A gender-swapped rewrite of the earlier film and play \u201cThe Front Page,\u201d it features Cary Grant in top form as a ruthless newspaper editor who will tell any fib and pull any string to get his star reporter (the peerless Rosalind Russell), who is also his ex-wife, to cover one last story rather than quit her job and disappear with her fianc\u00e9 (a wonderfully dopey Ralph Bellamy). Grant and Russell\u2019s mile-a-minute, love-hate banter is priceless, but don\u2019t undervalue the snappy, wiseacre dialogue of the supporting players, a crew of seen-it-all newsmen who talk shop and swap lingo with growling, offhand wit.\n\nClick to read about five other complementary movies.\n\n\u2018The Shape of Water\u2019\n\nSally Hawkins with Doug Jones, as the Asset, in \u201cThe Shape of Water.\u201d Fox Searchlight Pictures\n\nGuillermo del Toro isn\u2019t simply one of our most imaginative and innovative filmmakers; he\u2019s also an enthusiastic film historian and collector, so his films often function as both absorbing narratives and carefully curated exhibitions. These are some of the likely influences for his latest film, which earned a season-high 13 Academy Award nominations.\n\n\u2018The Creature From the Black Lagoon\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Starz, Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, YouTube, Vudu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe most obvious influence on \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d is this 1954 monster movie (originally released in 3D), from which del Toro seems to borrow heaviest in creating the look of his aquatic monster \u2014 which his characters call the Asset (Doug Jones). Advances in technology allow him to add a few notable bells and whistles, including moving gills and lights under his merman\u2019s skin, but the basic shape and face of the Asset is unmistakably close to the Gill Man\u2019s from \u201cBlack Lagoon.\u201d (The filmmaker said this about the Gill Man: \u201cI can only tell you I drew that monster all my childhood. It\u2019s the most beautiful monster, one of the top three ever made.\u201d) \u201cCreature\u201d also contains the seeds for the primary conflict in del Toro\u2019s film: the question of whether to preserve and study the aquatic creature (in the interest of science), or kill it (in the interest of safety and survival).\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Swamp Thing\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes, Google Play, Vudu, YouTube\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nLike \u201cWater,\u201d Wes Craven\u2019s 1982 adaptation of the \u201cSwamp Thing\u201d series from DC Comics gives us government scientists working on top-secret projects, a creature from the deep, the beautiful woman who loves him and a winking sense of homage and self-awareness. It\u2019s also an awfully good monster movie, for which Craven eschews the grisly tone of some of his better-known efforts, like \u201cThe Last House on the Left\u201d and \u201cNightmare on Elm Street,\u201d and instead embraces the childlike, gee-whiz enthusiasm of the \u201850s comic books that inspired it.\n\nClick to read about five other complementary movies.\n\n\u2018Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u2019\n\nFrances McDormand in \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri.\u201d Fox Searchlight Pictures\n\nAs with most of Martin McDonagh\u2019s work, \u201cThree Billboards\u201d is ultimately about posturing, as the grieving mother and the local cops in the film back themselves into separate corners over the unsolved murder of a teenage girl. Brilliant to some, maddening to others, the film has become a lightning rod for its depiction of American life. If you\u2019re looking for cinematic context, there are six great films you can stream right now.\n\n0\n\n\u2018Le Corbeau\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: FilmStruck\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe \u201cThree Billboards\u201d of the title refer to the giant outdoor messages that Mildred Hayes (McDormand) buys along the road into town that, read in succession, accuse Chief Bill Willoughby (Harrelson) of dereliction of duty for failing to catch the person who raped and murdered her daughter. The billboards rile her neighbors, reopening old wounds and exposing grim secrets. This idea of a citizen who blurts out uncomfortable truths about her small-town community recalls the \u201cpoison pen\u201d letters in the French melodrama \u201cLe Corbeau\u201d by Henri-Georges Clouzot, in which an anonymous whistle-blower nicknamed the Raven exposes local secrets including extramarital affairs and illegal abortions. Civic harmony is a fragile thing, whether in a World War II-era European village or in 21st-century Middle America. And it is often held together by a thin net of shared lies.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Winter\u2019s Bone\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Hulu, Amazon, iTunes\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIt\u2019s never made entirely clear, but Ebbing appears to be the kind of quaint little mountain town that might derive a lot of its income from visitors \u2014 tourists who are passing through to hunt, fish and camp. In other words, it\u2019s a cleaned-up version of the hardscrabble Missouri Ozarks community where Ree Dolly dwells in the magnificent rural noir \u201cWinter\u2019s Bone,\u201d directed by Debra Granik (who also helped write the screenplay). Jennifer Lawrence earned a best-actress Oscar nomination for her portrayal of Ree, who, like Mildred Hayes, is a woman wronged by the law. In Ree\u2019s case, she\u2019s on a mission to find her druggie deadbeat dad and save her family\u2019s land from being seized by the state, racing urgently around the county, from the hillside shacks to the antiseptic suburbs of Middle America.\n\nClick to read about four other complementary movies.", "title": "What to Watch if You Loved the Best-Picture Nominees", "authors": ["Watching Staff"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The study, published Thursday in Science, represents the first large-scale search of electronic health records for hidden Mendelian diseases. But Dr. Joshua C. Denny, a biomedical informatics researcher at the Vanderbilt University School of Medicine and co-author of the new study, suspected that it only revealed the tip of a genetic iceberg. Much larger databases including DNA and records for hundreds of thousands of people are being built, and searching them may uncover many more hidden mutations.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m sure there\u2019s a whole bunch else out there that we will discover,\u201d Dr. Denny said.\n\nHe and his colleagues gathered data from Vanderbilt\u2019s massive electronic health records system, which includes more than two million patients. More than 225,000 have signed up as volunteers for genetic research, allowing scientists to analyze their DNA.\n\nThe researchers picked out 21,701 patients from the database and surveyed all the symptoms recorded for each one. They then compared the symptoms to those seen in 1,204 Mendelian diseases.\n\nIt was a difficult task. These disorders can produce a number of symptoms, and each patient may have a different combination of them.\n\nAnd some symptoms linked to a Mendelian disease may also be signs of other diseases. Cystic fibrosis can cause asthma and recurrent infections, for instance \u2014 but those symptoms alone aren\u2019t enough to diagnose the disease.\n\nDr. Denny and his colleagues developed a scoring system to determine how likely it was that each patient in their study suffered each Mendelian disease. If a patient had a rare symptom linked to a disease, she scored a lot of points. A common symptom earned her far fewer points.\n\nThe researchers identified groups of people with symptoms strongly suggesting they shared a Mendelian disease. The researchers went on to examine the DNA of these patients to see if they also shared a mutation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Denny would have been happy just to find a few undiagnosed patients. Instead, the team found 807 patients carrying mutations in genes linked to 17 different diseases, such as cystic fibrosis or hemochromatosis, a disorder that causes iron to build up in the blood.\n\nPhoto\n\nOnly eight of these patients had gotten a test that revealed the mutation. In other cases, doctors had tested for the wrong disease and gotten a negative result. Many times, the doctors hadn\u2019t ordered any genetic tests at all.\n\nTypically, these disorders can be passed down in one of two ways. A dominant disease, like Huntington\u2019s, requires inheriting just one defective copy of a gene from a parent. Recessive diseases, such as sickle cell anemia, usually require two defective copies of the same gene.\n\nThe mutations that the scientists discovered often didn\u2019t fit the standard profile for the diseases. Many of the patients had conditions that are considered recessive, yet they carried a just single defective copy of the gene.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA single defective copy may cause milder versions of Mendelian diseases, Dr. Denny suspects.\n\nThe researchers identified 36 people, for example, who carried only one defective version of a gene called AGXT. Two copies of the gene cause a disease known as primary hyperoxaluria, which can result in kidney failure in toddlers. The patients identified in the new study also suffered kidney problems \u2014 but not in the first few years of life.\n\nOne patient who turned up in their search had kidney stones at age 15. That\u2019s unusual \u2014 but apparently not enough to lead the patient\u2019s doctors to suspect primary hyperoxaluria.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not as simple as what we learned in high school genetics,\u201d Dr. Denny said.\n\nThese results are all the more surprising given how modest Dr. Denny\u2019s search was. He only looked for a limited number of mutations in a relatively small group of people, all of whom were of European descent. (Much of what is known about gene variants that cause disease was discovered by researching predominantly white populations.)\n\n\u201cI\u2019m kind of surprised we found anything. The fact that we did means there\u2019s maybe a lot out there that we don\u2019t know,\u201d Dr. Denny said.\n\nHeidi L. Rehm, a molecular geneticist at Brigham and Women\u2019s Hospital who was not involved in the study, said many doctors do not suspect that their patients are suffering from a Mendelian disorder unless they suffer severe textbook symptoms.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey simply never order any genetic testing, and then you never develop an understanding that it\u2019s genetic to begin with,\u201d she said.\n\nOverlooking the genetic causes of diseases can seriously harm patients. \u201cThere are people here who had kidney and liver transplants that could potentially have been avoided,\u201d Dr. Denny said.\n\nUndiagnosed hemochromatosis, for example, can lead to liver failure. Of the 40 people Dr. Denny and his colleagues identified with hemochromatosis, four needed liver transplants.\n\nYet hemochromatosis can be readily treated by having patients donate blood on a regular basis, which helps rid them of excess iron.\n\nThe strategy employed by the research team was startlingly effective at identifying potential causes of disease. In the long run, Dr. Denny and Dr. Rehm agreed, the best solution might be to sequence the entire genome of every patient \u2014 in childhood, or even at birth.\n\nBut such a policy would create an unmanageable glut of genetic data.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think we\u2019re ready to do that,\u201d Dr. Denny said.", "title": "What\u2019s Behind Many Mystery Ailments? Genetic Mutations, Study Finds", "authors": ["Carl Zimmer"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Kat Kinsman, the senior food and drinks editor of the website Extra Crispy, devoted a column to what she saw as the inherent sexism in the egg-spoon attacks. If Francis Mallmann, the subject of a recent Esquire profile titled \u201cIs Francis Mallmann the Most Interesting Chef in the World?,\u201d had cooked an egg with a spoon instead of roasting a lamb on a wooden cross near blazing wood, he\u2019d be a hero, she wrote. (Ms. Waters, incidentally, has given Mr. Mallmann one of her own beloved egg spoons.)\n\nThe new round of criticism also struck a nerve with Samin Nosrat, a cookbook author and New York Times Magazine columnist. Cooking an egg in an iron spoon over open fire is really no more precious and probably a lot less elitist than cooking an egg in $300 sous-vide machine, she said in a recent interview \u2014 except that women tend to do the former and men the latter.\n\n\u201cIs it any more practical to sous-vide an egg? No,\u201d she said. \u201cBut it\u2019s this amazing thing because a man is using it.\u201d Consider the chef Dan Barber of Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Pocantico Hills, N.Y. When he celebrates these same ideals, she said, \u201che gets a hagiographic \u2018Chef\u2019s Table\u2019 episode. It pisses me off.\u201d\n\nAnd now, the latest salvo: In Slow Food\u2019s version of an in-your-face move, Alice Waters\u2019s daughter, Fanny Singer, has introduced an egg spoon for sale through her website Permanent Collection.\n\nThe 16-inch iron spoon is hand-forged to Ms. Waters\u2019s specifications by Shawn Lovell, whom Ms. Singer described in an email as \u201can incredible female blacksmith in Alameda, CA.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s Cooking in That Egg Spoon? A Bite-Size Culture War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "3. After you have posted, try reading back to see what others have said, then respond to someone else by posting another comment. Use the \u201cReply\u201d button or the @ symbol to address that student directly.\n\nOn Tuesday, March 13, our collaborator, the American Statistical Association, will facilitate a discussion from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern Time by paraphrasing comments and linking to responses to help students\u2019 understanding go deeper. You might use their responses as models for your own.\n\n4. On Thursday afternoon, March 15, we will reveal at the bottom of this post more information about the graphs. How does the original New York Times article and the moderators\u2019 additional questions help you see these graphs differently? You can incorporate the statistical terms defined in Stat Nuggets in your response.\n\n_________\n\nMore?\n\n\u2022 Read our introductory post, which includes information about using the \u201cNotice and Wonder\u201d teaching strategy.\n\n\u2022 Go to the A.S.A. K-12 website, which includes This is Statistics, resources, professional development, student competitions, curriculum, courses and careers.\n\n_________\n\nUpdated: March 15, 2018\n\nWith a series of high-profile mass shootings (defined as indiscriminate, multiple killings by one shooter), researchers have been digging into data to see if they can find associations between number of mass shootings and some variable. Here, by country, we see the association between mass shootings and the number of guns for countries around the world. But, we could have also looked for associations between number of mass shootings and measures of violence, crime, racial divisions, mental health care, video games or strength of gun legislation. Statisticians have the tools to analyze all of these variables, if they have accurate data. Since 1996, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which monitors public health threats such as diseases, auto and food safety, and much more, has seen cuts to its funding for research into gun violence as a public health issue. Data for the United States is not complete and the same is probably true for other countries.\n\nAcknowledging these limitations, the two graphs come from the New York Times article \u201cWhat Explains U. S. Mass Shootings? International Comparisons Suggest an Answer\u201d and was published on November 8, 2017. It uses data from the annual Small Arms Survey, an independent research project of the Graduate Institute of International and Development Studies in Geneva (Switzerland).\n\nSome of you said that you did not have enough information. Tommy of NJ wanted to see more countries represented. Rachel from Jackson wanted to know the year of the data. Many wanted all data points labeled.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHenry of Detroit noticed when he removed the United States outlier data point, there seems to be no association between guns and mass shooters. For example, in Graph B, France, Canada, and Iraq all seem to have about the same number of guns per 100 people, but very different mass shooters per 100 million people. He wondered if there is no association. This is counter to most other responses. Before we come to any conclusion on association, we need to dig deeper into the data to investigate what we wonder. I would suggest getting a copy of the cited report by Alan Lankford and looking at the Small Arms Survey.\n\nHere are some questions you may want to think about critically.\n\n\u2022 Why were there two graphs? What additional insight did we gain with Graph B?\n\n\u2022 Statisticians are careful to note that just because there is an association between two variables, it does not mean that changes in one variable are causing the value of the other variable to change. Do you think it is possible to say that having more guns is the cause of increased mass shootings? Or, are there other factors that may cause increased mass shootings? What could be the other factors?\n\n\u2022 The United States is an outlier (defined below) in both graphs. How do you interpret its being an outlier?\n\n\u2022 Other than the United States, none of the countries that are identified on Graph A are identified on Graph B. Even without this identification, what might you know about these countries regarding their rate of gun ownership and mass shooters?\n\n\u2022 In Graph A, what do the identified countries have in common? How about for Graph B?\n\nBelow in Stat Nuggets, we define and explain scatterplot, total and per capita data, and outlier. Look into the archives to see past Stat Nuggets terms.\n\nThank you for participating in \u201cWhat\u2019s Going On in This Graph?\u201d, which is intended to have you think more critically about graphs and the underlying data in a news story. Critical thinking is an essential element of statistics, the science of learning from data. Data visualizations, like this graph, are an important part of statistics. They help us to understand and communicate about data.\n\nKeep noticing and wondering. Come up with conjectures based on the graphs. We continue to welcome more responses.\n\nSee you next month on Tuesday, April 10, for our next \u201cWhat\u2019s Going On in This Graph?\n\n_________\n\nStat Nuggets for \u201cWhat Explains U. S. Mass Shootings?\u201d\n\nSCATTERPLOT\n\nA scatterplot is an x-y graph that is used to investigate the relationship between two quantitative variables, one on each axis.\n\nScatterplots can be described in terms of direction (+ or upward, - or downward, or neither), form (linear, curved, scattered, etc.), unusual data points that are out of the pattern, and strength (strong to moderate to weak, based on how \u201ctight\u201d the form is).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn \u201cWhat Explains U. S. Mass Shootings,\u201d the number of mass shooters (vertical y-axis) is plotted against the number of guns (horizontal x-axis). The direction is neither positive nor negative. The form is scattered with no association for the countries\u2019 data points in the lower left corner. The most unusual countries are the United States and Yemen in the per capita graph. They are outliers, as explained below. Ignoring the outliers, there is at best a very weak association between the number of guns and the number of mass shooters.\n\nTOTAL vs. PER CAPITA DATA\n\nSome quantitative variables count the number of times something occurs for a group. To calculate a per capita (\u201cper person\u201d) rate, simply divide the number by the total number of people in the group.\n\nIn \u201cWhat Explains U. S. Mass Shootings,\u201d Graph A shows countries in terms of their number of guns and number of mass shooters without regard to their population size. In contrast, Graph B shows these values as a proportion of the country\u2019s population. Note that the rate is multiplied by a larger number \u2014 100 people for guns and 100 million people for mass shooters, to avoid decimals, which can be hard to comprehend in rates. This scaling of the data does not change the order of the countries; it just makes the values more understandable.\n\nOUTLIER\n\nAn outlier is a data point that is out of pattern by being distant from other points.\n\nIn \u201cWhat Explains U. S. Mass Shootings,\u201d the United States is an outlier in both graphs and Yemen is an outlier only in Graph B. For both countries, the number of guns per 100 people and the number of mass shooters per 100 million people are unusually large compared to the other countries.\n\n_________\n\nThe graphs for \u201cWhat\u2019s Going On in This Graph?\u201d are selected in partnership with Sharon Hessney, the Statistics Content Director at Mass Insight Education. In addition, Ms. Hessney and Annie Fetter, a math educator formerly at the Math Forum who has worked to popularize \u201cWhat do you notice? What do you wonder?\u201d, moderated the Tuesday comments and wrote this week\u2019s \u201creveal\u201d and Stat Nuggets section.", "title": "What\u2019s Going On in This Graph? | March 13, 2018", "authors": ["The Learning Network", "What'S Going On In This Graph"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Updated: March 29, 2018\n\nNote: Our next \u201cWhat\u2019s Going On in This Picture?\u201d will publish on April 9. There will be no new image on April 2.\n\n_________\n\nStudents\n\n1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:\n\n\u2022 What is going on in this picture?\n\n\u2022 What do you see that makes you say that?\n\n\u2022 What more can you find?\n\n2. Next, join the conversation by clicking on the comment button and posting in the box that opens on the right. (Students 13 and older are invited to comment, although teachers of younger students are welcome to post what their students have to say.)\n\n3. After you have posted, try reading back to see what others have said, then respond to someone else by posting another comment.
