After you have posted, try reading back to see what others have said, then respond to someone else by posting another comment. Use the \u201cReply\u201d button or the @ symbol to address that student directly.\n\nEach Monday, our collaborator, Visual Thinking Strategies, will facilitate a discussion from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern time by paraphrasing comments and linking to responses to help students\u2019 understanding go deeper. You might use their responses as models for your own.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n4. On Thursday afternoons, we will reveal at the bottom of this post more information about the photo. How does reading the caption and learning its back story help you see the image differently?", "title": "What\u2019s Going On in This Picture? | March 5, 2018", "authors": ["The Learning Network", "What S Going On In This Picture"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSCOTTSDALE, Ariz. \u2014 Jake Arrieta has taken his beard and his breaking balls from the North Side of Chicago to South Philadelphia. The old Miami Marlins outfield has scattered to the Bronx (Giancarlo Stanton), Milwaukee (Christian Yelich) and St. Louis (Marcell Ozuna). And if you\u2019re sitting in the Green Monster seats at Fenway Park, look out, because a guy nicknamed Just Dingers \u2014 J. D. Martinez \u2014 has come to town.\n\nBut the most celebrated newcomer of 2018, at least for nostalgic fans over 40, can be found in the bullpens at Chase Field in Phoenix. They are E-Z-Go golf carts, with an outer shell made to look like a baseball with a black Arizona Diamondbacks cap on top. Yes, the bullpen cart, that charming vestige of the 1970s, is back.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve never thought of being driven into a game, so it\u2019s a little weird concept, but I think it\u2019s pretty cool,\u201d said Archie Bradley, the Diamondbacks\u2019 ace reliever. \u201cWe have some creative minds out in the bullpen. We\u2019re already talking about tricking this thing out \u2014 subwoofers, underglow lights. And I definitely want to drive guys in. That would be sick.\u201d\n\nAlas, the Diamondbacks have hired four game-day staffers to drive the cart, and so far, the only add-ons are logos for OnTrac, a shipping company based in Chandler, Ariz., that signed a six-figure sponsorship deal. Derrick Hall, the Diamondbacks\u2019 president, said pitchers would have the choice to be driven from the bullpen or trot in, as usual.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou know how superstitious baseball players are,\u201d said T. J. McFarland, a Diamondbacks left-hander. \u201cThe first guy who goes out there in a cart and ends up having a really bad outing, is he going to do it again? I don\u2019t know.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMike Fetters, the Arizona bullpen coach, pitched for the Milwaukee Brewers in 1995, believed to be the last time a team used a vehicle to transport relievers. In the Brewers\u2019 case, it was a Harley-Davidson motorcycle with a sidecar for the pitcher \u2014 or, at least, the pitcher\u2019s warm-up jacket.", "title": "What\u2019s New in 2018? Something Old: The Bullpen Cart", "authors": ["Tyler Kepner"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Her large black-and-white photographs, in which she appears in costume, bring to mind the work of the Samoan-born photographer Shigeyuki Kihara, who also stages self-portraits in the pose of native women in the Pacific islands, reprising how they were depicted in studios decorated with ethnic props by 19th-century photographers.\n\nUnlike Ms. Kihara, who is particularly interested in gender, Ms. Syjuco is more concerned with capitalist commodities, and is a student of how Western manufacturers both appropriated and created \u201cprimitive\u201d designs.\n\nShe purchased all the ethnic materials that she wears in her photographs at chain stores in a mall in Omaha, where she was living at the time. The clothes conspicuously retain store labels. (She returned them for credit after the shoots.)\n\nPhoto\n\nLike the fabrics, the backdrops in the photographs are intensely patterned, in the manner of the \u201cdazzle camouflage\u201d painted on British warships as protection from airplane bombers during World War I. \u201cIt was used not to hide the battleships but to confuse enemy aim by making it unclear what you are looking at,\u201d she explained in a phone interview.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn addition to the portraits, which come from a series she calls \u201cCargo Cult,\u201d Ms. Syjuco has included in the exhibition a series of passport-style self-portraits (taken with her cellphone) with her face obscured, alluding to the anxiety presently felt in immigrant communities in this country.\n\nPhoto\n\nPaul Mpagi Sepuya, 35, also critiques photography portraiture, from a vantage point that is more formally inventive and politically oblique than Ms. Syjuco\u2019s. Black and gay, with an interest in investigating his racial and sexual identities, Mr. Sepuya uses collages and mirror shards to fragment the image; and he raises out of their customary invisibility the black cloths and tripods of a photographer\u2019s studio. His photographs were included in the recent \u201cTrigger: Gender as a Tool and a Weapon\u201d at the New Museum and the current \u201cTag: Proposals on Queer Play and the Ways Forward\u201d at the Institute of Contemporary Art, Philadelphia.\n\nAlong with large inkjet prints on the wall, in the MoMA show he has a table with found objects, both photographs and books, to provide context (a presentation style associated with Wolfgang Tillmans). Mr. Sepuya is a postmodern portrait photographer, but one who chooses to reshuffle real material rather than compose on Photoshop. \u201cThere\u2019s a codedness,\u201d he said, describing his work. \u201cI\u2019m interested when someone can piece together another layer of meaning from a fragment of a body or the location of a room.\u201d\n\nAnd he relates his formal strategy to his sexual orientation. \u201cThere is a history of queer social spaces inhabiting the back room,\u201d he said. \u201cIn these darkroom portraits, I\u2019m thinking that being under the black cloth is like being in the back room.\u201d It is a space \u201cof creative friendship and sexual exchange all happening in the same places.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAlthough photographers have always been acutely conscious of what lies just outside the edges of their pictures, the viewer may overlook this central fact. Mr. Sepuya is not alone in wanting to highlight what usually goes unseen. Andrzej Steinbach, 34, a Polish-born photographer based in Berlin, photographed three young people together, as if in a fashion shoot, and then displayed the portraits as a sequence, where a person who is mostly out of the frame in one picture becomes the central figure in the next. \u201cThey switch places and they switch clothing,\u201d Ms. Gallun said. \u201cIt\u2019s unsettling.\u201d\n\nMatthew Connors, 42, likens his position as a photographer to the unreliable narrator in contemporary fiction. The body of work he is showing comes from five trips he made to North Korea between 2013 and 2016. Earlier, he took pictures in Egypt during the street demonstrations that culminated in the fall of President Mohamed Morsi. If that job description makes him sound like a photojournalist, he quickly dispels the notion. \u201cI would be a terrible photojournalist, because I\u2019m very slow and I\u2019m not always training myself on the event that\u2019s unfolding,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn many of his photographs of North Korea, where he was invariably accompanied by a couple of handlers, he emphasizes how partial his images are. He photographs electronic billboards in which the image is incomplete because some of the lights are out. He depicts a dark cave decorated for tourists with projected patches of colored lights \u2014 a stand-in for the cave in Plato\u2019s allegory, where only the shadows of outside life are visible to those chained within. Both the photographer and his subjects see each other indistinctly, a fact that the sharpness of Mr. Connors\u2019s digital images doesn\u2019t deny.\n\nWe are a long way from MoMA\u2019s most famous photography exhibition, Edward Steichen\u2019s \u201cThe Family of Man\u201d of 1955, which presented people from all around the world as being more alike than not. Some of the most striking of Mr. Connors\u2019s photographs are portraits of North Koreans: three schoolgirls as frozen as waxworks, one young man affectionately touching another at a public swimming pool. The pictures are compelling but resist easy understanding. The emblematic photograph in Mr. Connors\u2019s contribution to the show appears in a print twice the size and separate from the North Korea pictures: a mask held in a fist at a New York anti-Trump rally. Because of the positioning of the tape and the eyeholes, what we see looks like a crude rendition of a face, but it is actually the back of the mask.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome of Mr. Connors\u2019s images \u2014 the geometric reflections in a nighttime swimming pool, the rushing cascades in a water park \u2014 are reminders of the pleasures that photography can provide when practiced by a technically skilled artist. Even more daringly retrograde in the embrace of tradition is Sam Contis, 35, who sometimes shoots with film and a vintage view camera (as well as a digital one). She has made repeated visits over the last five years to photograph the students at Deep Springs College, a small, all-male institution in a remote valley in eastern California. The breadth of her ambition is discernible in the exhibition, and even more so in her impressive book, \u201cDeep Springs.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s New in Photography? Humanism, MoMA Says", "authors": ["Arthur Lubow"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Evan Strong has earned every title in adaptive snowboarding. He has a gold medal from the 2014 Sochi Paralympics, a silver medal from the 2018 Pyeongchang Paralympics, several World Cup titles, world championship titles, and a handful of X Game medals, too.\n\nWhat more can a Paralympian accomplish?\n\nWell, the Olympics.\n\nThe 30-year-old Strong, who just finished competing in Pyeongchang, has spent the past six years working to become the first Paralympic snowboarder to compete against able-bodied athletes in the Winter Olympics, something he hopes to accomplish at the 2022 Beijing Games.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s all in the works,\u201d he said before the 2018 Paralympics. \u201cAfter this Games I\u2019m going to focus full time on able-bodied racing and step away from adaptive racing for a couple years.\u201d\n\nStrong grew up on Maui and was well on his way to becoming a professional skateboarder when, at 17, he was riding his motorcycle and was hit head-on by a drunken driver. His left leg was partially amputated.", "title": "What\u2019s Next After Paralympic Gold? The Olympics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Time is \u2018accelerating.\u2019\n\nIt took centuries, even thousands of years, for us to reap the rewards of decisions made by our forebears, for example, growing wheat that led to the agricultural revolution. Not anymore.\n\n\u201cTime is accelerating,\u201d Mr. Harari said. The long term may no longer be defined in centuries or millenniums \u2014 but in terms of 20 years. \u201cIt\u2019s the first time in history when we\u2019ll have no idea how human society will be like in a couple of decades,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re in an unprecedented situation in history in the sense that nobody knows what the basics about how the world will look like in 20 or 30 years. Not just the basics of geopolitics but what the job market would look like, what kind of skills people will need, what family structures will look like, what gender relations will look like. This means that for the first time in history we have no idea what to teach in schools.\u201d\n\nLeaders focus on the past because they lack a meaningful vision of the future.\n\nLeaders and political parties are still stuck in the 20th century, in the ideological battles pitting the right against the left, capitalism versus socialism. They don\u2019t even have realistic ideas of what the job market looks like in a mere two decades, Mr. Harari said, \u201cbecause they can\u2019t see.\u201d\n\n\u201cInstead of formulating meaningful visions for where humankind will be in 2050, they repackage nostalgic fantasies about the past,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd there\u2019s a kind of competition: who can look back further. Trump wants to go back to the 1950s; Putin basically wants to go back to the Czarist Empire, and you have the Islamic State that wants to go back to seventh-century Arabia. Israel \u2014 they beat everybody. They want to go back 2,500 years to the age of the Bible, so we win. We have the longest-term vision backwards.\u201d\n\n\u2018There is no predetermined history.\u2019\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re now living with the collapse of the last story of inevitability,\u201d he said. The 1990s weres flush with ideas that history was over, that the great ideological battle of the 20th century was won by liberal democracy and free-market capitalism.\n\nThis now seems extremely na\u00efve, he said. \u201cThe moment we are in now is a moment of extreme disillusionment and bewilderment because we have no idea where things will go from here. It\u2019s very important to be aware of the downside, of the dangerous scenarios of new technologies. The corporations, the engineers, the people in labs naturally focus on the enormous benefits that these technologies might bring us, and it falls to historians, to philosophers and social scientists who think about all of the ways that things could go wrong.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s Next for Humanity: Automation, New Morality and a \u2018Global Useless Class\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Just as the Trump administration has stepped back from quickly imposing the steel and aluminum tariffs, it may soften its stance if China suggests that its open to negotiations. The world could relax.\n\nBut China may not budge. As our colleague Steven Lee Myers reports, President Xi Jinping has so far managed to navigate Mr. Trump\u2019s rhetoric while maintaining a strong nationalist image at home. Yet Mr. Trump\u2019s tariff announcement, along with moves perceived by the Chinese as humiliating, may prompt China to retaliate with force.\n\nInvestors would then scramble to quantify the economic repercussions. They might not be terrible.\n\nSome American companies, like computer chip makers, get substantial revenue from China. But on average, companies in the S.&P. 500 index derive a small share of their sales from the country.\n\nAnd some investors may take a long view, believing that U.S. companies have long been treated unfairly in China. A trade fight that eventually relaxes some of those disadvantageous conditions could bolster the long-term prospects of those firms. And if the U.S. is able to recruit other countries to its cause, China may relent.\n\nStill, much could go wrong. A true test of investor sentiment will come if China fights back. Markets could fall further, creating a financial chain reaction that dampens the wider economy. A lot would depend on how Mr. Trump responds to Chinese actions. Would he up the ante?\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s genuinely hard to predict how this will turn out,\u201d said Scott Kennedy, an expert in Chinese trade at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, \u201cwhether one side will back down or whether it will spiral into a trade war.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nDropbox has priced its I.P.O.\n\nHere are the details:\n\n\u2022 The data-storage and collaboration company sold 36 million shares at $21 apiece, its expected range of $18 to $20 a share.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 At that price, the offering raised $756 million.\n\n\u2022 At $21 a share, the company has a market value of gave Dropbox a market value of $9.2 billion.\n\nThe context\n\nThe demand for Dropbox\u2019s shares suggests investors overcame any concern about daunting competition from the likes of Microsoft, Google and Amazon, all of which provide cloud storage services. A successful debut could pave the way for other unicorns to soon go public.\n\nPhoto\n\nTrump on tariffs: \u201cIf they charge us, we charge them.\u201d\n\nPresident Trump said he would impose about $60 billion worth of annual tariffs on Chinese imports as the White House moved to punish China for what it says is a pattern of co-opting American technology and trade secrets and robbing companies of jobs and billions of dollars in revenue.\n\nThe tariffs will target 1,300 lines of Chinese goods \u2014 everything from shoes and clothing to electronics \u2014 the NYT reports administration officials said.\n\nMr. Trump, the officials added, will also direct the Treasury Department to impose restrictions on Chinese investment in American technology companies, a practice that they said the Chinese government uses to develop its own \u201cnational champions\u201d in cutting-edge industries like A.I. and autonomous vehicles.\n\n\u201cThe end objective of this is to get China to modify its unfair trade practices,\u201d Everett Eissenstat, the deputy director of the National Economic Council, told reporters.\n\nPeter Navarro, the director of the White House National Trade Council and an architect of the measures, cast the tariffs as part of a seminal shift in how the U.S. views China. Rather than trying to draw it into the rules-based international economic order \u2014 a policy that dates back to Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger \u2014 the U.S. now regards China as a strategic competitor, bent on eroding American security and prosperity.\n\n\u2014 Mark Landler and Jim Tankersley\n\nPhoto\n\nThe stock market is proving Gary Cohn right\n\nBefore he said he was leaving his White House position earlier this month, Mr. Cohn reportedly warned that protectionist trade policies could jeopardize the stock rally that has taken place since Donald Trump became president. After Mr. Trump announced tariffs on steel and aluminum, the stock market slid, but soon recovered those losses, reassuring the president that his decision to introduce tariffs was right.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Thursday, the Trump administration announced trade restrictions against China. The news appeared to weigh on markets. So, how have stocks done since important dates in the trade skirmish?\n\nOne important milestone was the Commerce Department\u2019s announcement last month that suggested the Trump administration was serious about introducing steel and aluminum tariffs. The S.&P. 500 index is down 2.3 percent since the day before that announcement. Mr. Trump actually announced plans for those tariffs on March 1. The S.&P. 500 is down 1.7 percent since Feb. 28.\n\nThe Dow Jones industrial average has done a lot worse, however. It is down 3.7 percent since the Commerce Department\u2019s announcement, and 3.1 percent since Mr. Trump announced his intentions. The decline encapsulated how trade tension might hurt specific businesses, in particular, Boeing\u2019s.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nBlame Boeing\n\nMuch of the Dow\u2019s underperformance can be traced to the aircraft maker\u2019s stock.\n\nThe Trump administration\u2019s trade policies have hit Boeing, the most-heavily weighted stock in the Dow, particularly hard.\n\nAluminum makes up about 80 percent of the weight of most commercial aircrafts, according to Brooke Sutherland and David Fickling of Gadfly. That means tariffs on imported aluminum would likely raise Boeing\u2019s costs more than its competitors. Boeing also views China, the main target of the Trump administration\u2019s protectionist trade policies, as an important growth market. The country is set to overtake the U.S. as the biggest aviation market by 2022, Ms. Sutherland and Mr. Fickling write.\n\nChina could target Boeing if the country decides to retaliate against the U.S.\n\nBoeing is down 3.6 percent today, shaving more than 80 points off the blue-chip index. Since the Commerce Department released its report calling for tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, the stock is down 8.7 percent, worth more than 200 points off the Dow.\n\nBoeing drove the Dow higher for much of Mr. Trump\u2019s presidency, more than doubling during his first 12 months in office.\n\nBoeing\u2019s climb has had an outsized impact on the Dow. The index is price-weighted, meaning that the higher priced stocks have a bigger pull on the index.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMoneyBeat\u2019s Ben Eisen noted that at the end of January, the stock accounted for 9.4 percent of Dow, up from 6 percent a year earlier. By comparison, Boeing makes up just 0.8 percent of the market capitalization weighted S.&P. 500.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt\u2019s not just Boeing that is falling on trade tensions\n\nChinese tech stocks are also tumbling.\n\nShares of Alibaba are off 4.2 percent, Tencent 5 percent and Baidu 4.3 percent in the wake of the Trump administration\u2019s plan to impose about $60 billion worth of annual tariffs on Chinese imports.\n\nThat is much worse than their American counterparts. Amazon, Facebook and Google\u2019s parent Alphabet are down between 1.2 percent and 2.2 percent by comparison.\n\nShares of Baidu, Alibaba and Tencent \u2014 collectively known as BAT \u2014 have soared over the past year, pushing their combined market value above $1 trillion.\n\nAs these companies have grown, so have their ambitions. All three have moved to expand beyond their core business and home market and have aggressively invested in Americantech start-ups to help them do so.\n\nChina\u2019s largest internet companies \u2014 the BAT plus the e-commerce company JD.com \u2014 have invested $5.6 billion in 48 tech deals in the United States over the past two years, according to CBI Insights data via CNBC.\n\nSuch investments have raised concerns in the United States. The Trump administration officials said the Chinese government uses these investments to develop its own \u201cnational champions\u201d in cutting-edge industries like A.I. and autonomous vehicles. As part of the China tariffs, the Trump administration plans to place restrictions on Chinese investment in American technology companies.\n\nThe Bank of England stays firm amid other banks\u2019 rate hikes\n\nShrugging off hikes by the Federal Reserve and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority this week, the Bank of England maintained its key interest rate at 0.5 percent today.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTwo members of the central bank\u2019s monetary policy committee called for an immediate rate increase, but the majority of the committee did not see the need for a hike at this time. Most economists expect the Bank of England to raise rates in May, when it releases its latest quarterly projection for inflation.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the minutes from the committee\u2019s latest meeting, the central bank said that there had been \u201cfew surprises\u201d in recent economic data and its February projections for inflation appeared \u201cbroadly on track.\u201d The bank said that the May inflation report would allow the committee to \u201cundertake a fuller assessment of the underlying momentum in the economy, the degree of slack remaining and the extent of domestic inflationary pressures.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Chad Bray\n\nPhoto\n\nMark Zuckerberg has finally spoken\n\nAfter days of questions and criticism about his silence, the Facebook co-founder and C.E.O. posted a statement and gave a series of interviews. (Sheryl Sandberg offered a statement, too.)\n\nWhat he promised: to investigate apps that had access to large amounts of Facebook data, to restrict developers\u2019 data access and to show users how to revoke app permissions.\n\nHighlights from his interviews:\n\n\u2022 To CNN: \u201cI\u2019m not sure we shouldn\u2019t be regulated,\u201d Zuckerberg said. \u201cThere are things like ad transparency regulation that I would love to see.\u201d (He also made ad transparency promises to Wired.)\n\n\u2022 To the NYT, about Facebook\u2019s business model: \u201cI don\u2019t think the ad model is going to go away, because I think fundamentally, it\u2019s important to have a service like this that everyone in the world can use, and the only way to do that is to have it be very cheap or free.\u201d\n\n\u2022 On why it took so long for him to respond, compared with other tech C.E.O.s: \u201cI know that there was a lot of pressure to speak sooner, but my assessment was that it was more important that what we said was fully accurate.\u201d\n\n\u2022 On #DeleteFacebook: \u201cI don\u2019t think we\u2019ve seen a meaningful number of people act on that, but, you know, it\u2019s not good.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPeter Eavis\u2019s take: Missing from his response was a full explanation of why Facebook took so long to disclose the Cambridge Analytica misuse of data. The company found out in 2015. Why wasn\u2019t the abuse disclosed then?\n\nElsewhere in the Facebook orbit: A guide to deleting your account; idealistic reasons not to. Why former employees feel emboldened to criticize. And Cambridge Analytica is being accused of receiving a foreign leader\u2019s private emails, perhaps from Israeli hackers. (It says it didn\u2019t.)\n\nPhoto\n\nWill this spending deal pass Congress (and Trump)?\n\nIt\u2019s here. A $1.3 trillion, 2,232-page pact between Republicans and Democrats that needs to be signed into law by midnight Friday to avoid another government shutdown. But can Congress pass the bill \u2014 and will President Trump support it?\n\nWhat\u2019s in there:\n\n\u2022 A patch for the \u201cgrain glitch\u201d in the recent tax overhaul that hurt corporate farms and helped farming co-ops\n\n\u2022 A pathway to funding for the New York Gateway project, something Mr. Trump has opposed\n\n\u2022 $1.6 billion, with strings attached, for a border wall with Mexico\n\n\u2022 Nothing to protect Dreamers or to shore up the Affordable Care Act\n\nRepublicans like the senators Rand Paul and John Kennedy are unhappy. So too is the president, who wanted far more for his wall. (He\u2019s on board for now.)\n\nThe politics flyaround\n\n\u2022 How George Nader, now a cooperating witness in Robert Mueller\u2019s investigation, sought to influence a top Republican fund-raiser on behalf of Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Among the companies lined up to meet the Saudi delegation in the U.S.: Boeing, JPMorgan Chase, and Apple. (Bloomberg)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The F.B.I. investigated Jeff Sessions for perjury last year. Andrew McCabe, now fired, authorized it. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Reince Priebus, Don McGahn and Ivanka Trump supported a White House push for nondisclosure agreements, some while knowing they would be unenforceable. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 John Kelly was furious over leaks about Mr. Trump\u2019s briefing materials for his call after President Vladimir Putin\u2019s election victory, which included the admonition \u201cDO NOT CONGRATULATE.\u201d (Politico)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Fed raised rates again. The harder bit\u2019s coming up.\n\nAdding a quarter of a percentage point to the benchmark interest rate, as expected, Jay Powell said, \u201cThere is no sense in the data that we\u2019re on the cusp of an acceleration of inflation.\u201d\n\nThe Fed is now expected to raise rates three times this year, three times next year and twice in 2020. But there\u2019s a bigger issue, as Neil Irwin of The Upshot points out:\n\nThose economic projections signal that Mr. Powell and his colleagues believe they can keep running the economy a little hot with mainly good results. But they seem to believe that a more aggressive shift toward higher interest rates will be needed to keep that benign future intact.\n\nCritics\u2019 corner: Justin Lahart of Heard on the Street writes about inflation, \u201cThe Fed\u2019s view doesn\u2019t jibe with the recent hopes and dreams of some investors.\u201d And Tom Buerkle of Breakingviews writes, \u201cThe big questions are yet to come. Powell is smart to want maximum flexibility to address them.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nVideo of the Uber self-driving fatality has emerged\n\nIt shows the vehicle in Tempe, Ariz. didn\u2019t try to swerve from a woman walking her bike across the street, the WSJ says. And the human behind the wheel was looking down for about 5 seconds before it hit her.\n\nMore from Greg Bensinger and Tim Higgins of the WSJ:\n\n\u201cThis video is damning for Uber,\u201d said Todd Humphreys, an associate professor at the University of Texas at Austin whose research area is robot-perception systems. \u201cThis appears to have been a serious failure of the Uber perception system.\u201d\n\nThe stakes for Uber remain high, as Goldman Sachs analysts recently pointed out, since self-driving cars were part of its route to profits. And car insurers are watching closely, too.\n\nElsewhere in Uber: The company withdrew an offer to make Assaf Ronen its new product head, after discovering he had left Amazon earlier than he said. Wall Street is fighting to get into Uber\u2019s big debt deal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nElsewhere in tech: Tesla shareholders approved a $2.6 billion stock options grant to Elon Musk. The Senate passed a sex-trafficking bill opposed by some tech companies. And Dropbox raised its I.P.O. price range.\n\nPhoto\n\nPfizer\u2019s consumer division is Glaxo\u2019s to lose\n\nThe winning bid in the auction for the unit could amount to as much as $20 billion. Gaining brands such as Advil and Centrum multivitamins would be a big success for GlaxoSmithKline\u2019s C.E.O. of nearly a year, Emma Walmlsey, who has favored a diverse product lineup.\n\nReckitt Benckiser withdrew from the fray yesterday, with its C.E.O. saying, \u201cAn acquisition for the whole Pfizer consumer health business did not fit our acquisition criteria.\u201d\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Meredith plans to sell Time, Sports Illustrated, Fortune and Money. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Steve Wynn intends to sell some or all of his 12 percent stake in Wynn Resorts. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Matillion, a cloud data software maker, has raised $20 million in a new round from investors like Sapphire Ventures and Scale Venture Partners, the company tells us.\n\n\u2022 Elliott Management is reportedly considering backing a spinoff of Telecom Italia\u2019s fixed-line network. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 As others have fled, Sycamore Partners has dived profitably into traditional retail. (WSJ)\n\nPhoto\n\nTaxes on cryptocurrency: \u2018I\u2019ve lost sleep over it\u2019\n\nNewly minted virtual currency moguls are worried about the I.R.S. as the April 17 tax deadline looms. Many are libertarians who don\u2019t like having a central government, let alone paying taxes to one. Others are simply newbies who didn\u2019t realize that you have to pay taxes on capital gains, even on digital money.\n\nMore from Kevin Roose\u2019s latest column:\n\nMs. Walter said she had seen clients with cryptocurrency gains as large as $400,000 who did not withhold taxes during the year and subsequently lost money trading. \u201cNow they\u2019re stuck with these huge tax bills, and they don\u2019t have the capital to pay it.\u201d\n\nElsewhere in crypto: Bitcoin is at $8,999. Some blockchains are better than others. And Britain has formed a task force to study cryptocurrencies.\n\nPhoto\n\nRevolving door\n\n\u2022 Jimmy Iovine is formally stepping down as the head of Apple\u2019s music division. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Twitter\u2019s chief information security officer, Michael Coates, is leaving. (The Verge)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The Noble Group\u2019s founder and chairman, Richard Elman, is retiring, leaving the commodity trader with a battered stock price and high amounts of debt. (WSJ)\n\nThe speed read\n\n\u2022 Swiss prosecutors have opened a criminal investigation into the taxes of the French luxury group Kering, part of a case that started in Italy. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Abu Dhabi is consolidating two of its leading sovereign wealth funds into a $200 billion vehicle. (FT)\n\n\u2022 What Bill Voge disclosed before his sudden departure as chair of Latham & Watkins: sexually explicit messages to a woman he approached on behalf of a Christian men\u2019s group, and threats to her husband to have her thrown in jail. (Law360)\n\n\u2022 Gary Barber was fired from MGM after a disagreement over how to compete with Netflix, unnamed sources said. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Jamie Dimon earned 364 times as much as the median JPMorgan employee last year. (WSJ)\n\n.\n\nWe\u2019d love your feedback. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "What\u2019s Next for Stocks After the China Tariffs: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWhy Is U.S. Health Care So Expensive? Some of the Reasons You\u2019ve Heard Turn Out to Be Myths\u201d (The Upshot, March 13):\n\nIt\u2019s true that \u201canalysts are fond of describing the system as wasteful, with too many patients getting too many services.\u201d But those of us on the front lines know that large segments of the population have no real access to quality medical care, and even those with \u201cgood insurance\u201d struggle through a maze of barriers and increased costs.\n\nThe United States has some of the highest administrative costs in the world because of our fractured, multipayer, profit-based system. Private insurers add zero value but drive up costs through administrative waste and profiteering, and require hospitals and doctors to maintain complex billing and cost-tracking bureaucracies.\n\nWhile no system is perfect, we have an excellent solution in the form of Medicare. A single-payer plan like H.R. 676, \u201cMedicare for All,\u201d could save an estimated $617 billion a year by slashing administrative waste in the private insurance industry ($504 billion) and bargaining down drug prices ($113 billion), freeing up money for universal coverage without any net increase in health spending.\n\nERIC SALK, TORRINGTON, CONN.\n\nThe writer is medical director of emergency medicine at the Charlotte Hungerford Hospital.", "title": "Opinion | What\u2019s So Good About Health Care?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Issues Down Under\n\nColin McCahon is the star of the Gow Langsford Gallery (Auckland, New Zealand) booth. Postwar abstract Australasian paintings by Mr. McCahon (1919-87) address life, death, spirituality and the land, but they also touch on Maori and settler politics. The artist grew up in a tiny New Zealand town, was influenced by the Abstract Expressionists and went on to enormous pieces on unstretched canvas. \u201cThe Urewera Triptych\u201d (1975), his most important work, makes a special appearance here.\n\nEven for Sydney galleries like Roslyn Oxley9, diversity is a central topic. In the Discoveries sector, the indigenous artist Nyapanyapa Yunupingu will be showing her \u201cGana (self),\u201d a sculpture-installation that includes totemic bark paintings. In the Galleries sector, there are Anglo-Australians who focus on indigenous culture, like Tracey Moffatt, a Brisbane-born photographer and videographer.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile some New Zealanders call for a new isolationism, the Auckland gallery Michael Lett reflects on the country\u2019s encounters with the effects of refugee crises, rising sea levels and other 21st-century phenomena. The Berlin-based, Auckland-born Zac Langdon-Pole offers an unusual interpretation of passports \u2014 nine small sculptures made of paper nautilus shells.\n\nNo Boundaries\n\nDon\u2019t tell the Chinese artist Tan Ping that a painting is supposed to stop where the canvas does. \u201cIt goes beyond the canvas and right onto the wall,\u201d Carrie Shen of the Leo Gallery in Hong Kong explained. \u201cThe result of this process is different every time, from one location to another.\u201d The technique is called overspreading, and the project that introduced it is called \u201cThe Certainty of Uncertainty.\u201d When Tan Ping\u2019s acrylics are hung in their new spot in Hong Kong, he will make a second creation there, influenced by the space, the environment and his mental state that day.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDon\u2019t tell Ulla von Brandenburg, whose work celebrates the theater world, that audiences are supposed to stay in front of \u201c7 Curtains.\u201d \u201cLe rideau a deux c\u00f4t\u00e9s,\u201d the Paris-based artist told Le Figaro in 2014. \u201cThe curtain has two sides.\u201d The idea in her installation is to step behind the curtains and find yourself in the wings, a performer by position if not by action. Pilar Corrias of London is a co-presenter with Meyer Riegger, which is in Karlsruhe, Germany, the artist\u2019s hometown.\n\nAnd apparently no one told Chou Yu-Cheng that there should be limits to installation titles. The Edouard Malingue Gallery of Hong Kong is showing his \u201cRefresh, Sacrifice, New Hygiene, Infection, Clean, Robot, Air, Housekeeping, www.ayibang.com, Cigarette, Dyson, Modern People.\u201d One of the installation\u2019s collections consists of gleaming white plates and bowls the size of bookcases and giant white chopsticks that could function as battering rams. The artist, who lives and works in Taipei, Taiwan, is also blurring boundaries between formalism and free verse, preparation and presentation, the poetic and the mundane.\n\nA Changing Subcontinent\n\nSome Indian galleries at the fair seem to lament changing times. Subodh Gupta misses the old days when delivery men known as dabbawallas used wheelbarrows to take home-cooked lunches in tiffin boxes to work sites (and most workers didn\u2019t order from restaurants online). His installation, \u201cStart. Stop.,\u201d shown by the Arario Gallery of Seoul, South Korea, is a slowly moving sushi conveyor belt bearing pots and tiffin containers.\n\nPhoto\n\nVivek Vilasini misses clean air. Some studies have concluded that the toxic smog in New Delhi is the equivalent of smoking as many as 45 cigarettes a day. An Indian-born conceptual artist, Mr. Vilasini responded with \u201cCity \u2014 Fifth Investigation,\u201d leaving 31 thin sheets of Tibetan rice paper in a roof garden atop a three-story building downtown, removing one per day and using a fixative to preserve the buildup. Mr. Vilasini, shown by the Sakshi Gallery of Mumbai, is the same artist who painted \u201cLast Supper Gaza\u201d (2009).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOthers are looking at future, present and past. Visitors will see an android-like Rorschach blot and a robot pointer hand in the project from Galleryske of Bangalore. The Mumbai gallery TARQ is presenting the urban-architecture-influenced work of Vishwa Shroff, including pieces from her \u201cPartywall\u201d series (gold leaf and ink on paper). And Jhaveri Contemporary is showing the Pakistani artist Ali Kazim\u2019s landscapes, near Lahore, a city founded well before A.D. 1000.", "title": "What\u2019s Trending at Art Basel Hong Kong", "authors": ["Anita Gates"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "The New York Times asked members of the RedBar watch clubs in London and New York for their advice to new collectors.\n\nThe No. 1 tip? Buy what you love.\n\nHere\u2019s a sampling of their replies, which were edited and condensed:\n\nThere is no point in getting a watch as an investment piece if you don\u2019t really fancy it; you will soon find that, same as with every other hobby, the interest tends to fade away if certain choices do not express your taste.\n\nARISTEIDIS PARASKEVOPOULOS, London\n\nTake your time. You\u2019ve painstakingly saved up enough money to buy a watch, yet you may want to hold back on buying one. The internet offers a plethora of watch resources, so take time to learn and understand about the options available to you. Studying the heritage and DNA behind the watches you like generates a lot of valuable anticipation and excitement, to the extent that your relationship with the watch of choice goes far beyond the blue book value. For me, this process only adds to the pleasure of collecting and wearing your timepieces.\n\nROWAN WRIGHT, London\n\n[MORE: Thinking about starting a watch collection? Experts answer your top six questions.]", "title": "What\u2019s Your Best Tip for a New Watch Collector?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "GEVGELIJA, Macedonia \u2014 From the time he was a high school student and made his first discovery \u2014 graves dating to the Iron Age and coins 3,000 years old \u2014 Emil Slamkov said he wanted to be an archaeologist.\n\n\u201cFor me, it is a chance to discover what the earth is hiding,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd then to try and find a way to bring it back to life and give meaning to what came before.\u201d\n\nIn the Balkans, however, giving meaning to the past can be a fraught business.\n\nIn recent years, Mr. Slamkov, 52, has found his skills in demand as the government has poured money into excavating ancient sites with a single goal: finding connections to ancient Macedonia to add legitimacy to its claim on the name.\n\nIt is not an academic question. For more than two decades, this country of just two million people has been fighting with its southern neighbor Greece over the right to have Macedonia in its name.", "title": "What\u2019s in a Name? For Macedonia, the Key to Peace and Security", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNeil Patrick Harris returns to villainy in \u201cA Series of Unfortunate Events.\u201d And a new Netflix movie follows a fierce Brooklyn underdog.\n\n\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nA SERIES OF UNFORTUNATE EVENTS on Netflix. The delightfully dire (and alliteration-filled) series returns, with adaptations of books five through nine of this children\u2019s series by Daniel Handler. Neil Patrick Harris couldn\u2019t be more in his element as the preening and venomous Count Olaf, who, with pantomime and eye-rolling disguises, torments the three Baudelaire orphans. The series doesn\u2019t break the fourth wall so much as continually smash it with a hammer and a chain saw; the presumed author of the series, Lemony Snicket, has a central role. And look out for Lucy Punch as a delightful Cruella De Vil-style villain.\n\nPhoto\n\nFIRST MATCH on Netflix. Mike Tyson fought his way out of the Brownsville area of Brooklyn in the \u201970s. Forty-some years later, a fictional teenager named Monique (Elvire Emanuelle) tries to do the same. Olivia Newman\u2019s film follows a foster child from a broken home who becomes the first female wrestler on her high school\u2019s team and hits the mat to forge a future. But she struggles to reconcile the advice of her father (Yahya Abdul-Mateen II), just out of jail, and her school coach (Colman Domingo).\n\nRAPTURE on Netflix. This documentary series, created by the hip-hop media company Mass Appeal, delves into the lives of eight rappers as they discuss their history and craft. They include Nas, who reminisces on a past era of lyricism while mentoring a younger New York rapper, Dave East; Rapsody, who earned a Grammy nomination this year; and Logic, a high school dropout who is one of the genre\u2019s most popular stars.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nPhoto\n\nN.C.A.A. WOMEN\u2019S BASKETBALL Will anyone beat the Huskies? It\u2019s Final Four time, with each No. 1 seed still standing. Louisville and Mississippi State have both dominated throughout the tournament; they face off at 7 p.m. on ESPN2. Notre Dame has been ravaged by injuries but pulled off a win against Oregon with only six players. Unfortunately, they have to face Connecticut, at 9:30 on ESPN2, who is coming off a well-rounded 30-point rout as the college makes its 11th consecutive Final Four.\n\nTHE STELLAR AWARDS 9 p.m. on TV One. Snoop Dogg has embraced many guises over his storied career, from rapper to rasta to football coach to TV co-host with Martha Stewart. This month he unveiled his latest iteration: gospel singer, with an album that was received with much praise. He performed at this awards show, which honors the best of gospel music; it took place last weekend and airs on Friday. The newly reunited sister duo Mary Mary also perform; JJ Hairston, the sonorous and acrobatic singer, was the top winner of the night, with six awards. Women\u2019s Final Four", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "A familiar story is back in a different furry body. And a documentary explores Adderall addiction in the United States.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nBENJI on Netflix. We live in an era of reboots and also an era of canine obsession. Put those two together and you get this remake of 1974\u2019s \u201cBenji,\u201d starring a very smart and adorable mutt with droopy, shaggy ears; he is adopted by two children and their disapproving mother. But when the children are kidnapped, it\u2019s up to the pup to crack the case and bring them home. \u201cAs cute animal movies go, \u2018Benji\u2019 is adult-watchable, and most likely child catnip,\u201d Glenn Kenny wrote in his Streaming column in The New York Times.\n\nTAKE YOUR PILLS on Netflix. Two years ago, in The New York Times Magazine, Casey Schwartz wrote about a phenomenon she termed Generation Adderall and recounted her experience with the medication: Initially it caused euphoria and laser focus but soon led to addiction and panic attacks. \u201cI lived a paradox, believing that the drug was indispensable to my very survival while also knowing that it was nothing short of toxic,\u201d she wrote. This special delves into the prevalence of Adderall and other cognitive-enhancement drugs and their effects on college campuses and American culture, as they earn billions of dollars for the pharmaceutical industry.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Friday: \u2018Benji\u2019 and \u2018Jane the Virgin\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "LOVE on Netflix. Judd Apatow has a history with characters that fit the \u201cnice guy\u201d and \u201cmanic pixie dream girl\u201d tropes, as seen in movies like \u201cThe 40-Year-Old Virgin\u201d and \u201cSuperbad.\u201d But \u201cLove,\u201d which he helped create, sets up the archetypes only to knock them down. It follows the nebbish Gus (Paul Rust) and the impulsive, beautiful Mickey (Gillian Jacobs), who begin dating and quickly realize the other is far more damaged and complex than their caricature would suggest. \u201c\u2018Love\u2019 is a funny, winning version of the format, and the casting is spot on,\u201d James Poniewozik wrote in his Times review. The show\u2019s third and final season, in which Gus and Mickey once again try an honest, adult relationship, arrives on Friday.\n\nMY NEXT GUEST NEEDS NO INTRODUCTION on Netflix. David Letterman is very much in his comfort zone on his new Netflix talk show; he\u2019s stripped back the snark that long drove his persona in favor of a warm empathy for his distinguished guests. In this episode, a day after International Women\u2019s Day, he welcomes the young activist Malala Yousafzai to the stage.\n\nSNEAKY PETE on Amazon Prime. In this series, a long-lost grandson named Pete returns to his family in Bridgeport, Conn., after several decades, and they live happily ever after. Except that the man isn\u2019t really Pete, and the family\u2019s troubles are just beginning. Giovanni Ribisi plays a con man who gets out of jail and assumes the identity of Pete, his former cellmate, in order to hide from a violent New York gambler played by Bryan Cranston. Season 1 followed the mind games between the con man and the gambler; Season 2, which streams Friday, focuses more on Pete\u2019s family, including a memorable turn from the character actress Margo Martindale.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Friday: \u2018Collateral\u2019 and \u2018Love\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMorgan Freeman once again lends gravitas to a penguin documentary. And Neil Young turns to acting in a new movie by Daryl Hannah.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nMARCH OF THE PENGUINS 2: THE NEXT STEP on Hulu. Moviegoers flocked to theaters in 2005 to see penguins flock across the tundra; the $8 million documentary made $127 million worldwide. There\u2019s no big-screen release for this sequel, but audiences can still watch these lovable flippered birds trek across \u201cunforgiving yet mesmerizing landscapes,\u201d as Morgan Freeman intones. Once again, the focus is on the relationship between penguin fathers and their young \u2014 dads must cradle the eggs, watch the babies while the moms are out gathering food, and protect them from carrion birds and bitter storms.\n\nPARADOX on Netflix. Neil Young is an Oscar nominee, but not for his work on camera \u2014 his song in Jonathan Demme\u2019s \u201cPhiladelphia\u201d was recognized in 1994. He has acted sparingly over the years, though, and returns to the trade in this new film written and directed by Daryl Hannah. The film follows a band of outlaws hiding in the mountains, with Mr. Young playing the man in the black hat. He also provides original music along with the band Promise of the Real, which includes Willie Nelson\u2019s sons.\n\nPhoto\n\nROXANNE ROXANNE on Netflix. Before Cardi B, before Missy Elliott, before Queen Latifah, there was Roxanne Shante. In 1984, the M.C. recorded \u201cRoxanne\u2019s Revenge\u201d when she was 14 and living in Queens. But while the song took off like a rocket on boomboxes across the country, her career did not. This biopic traces her rise and stagnation, as she was taken advantage of by managers and other men in the music industry. \u201cI was actually able to sit back and say, \u2018Wow, something good came out of all of this,\u2019\u201d Ms. Shante said in a Times interview about the film, which stars Chant\u00e9 Adams and also includes performances by Mahershala Ali and Nia Long.\n\nPhoto\n\nGAME OVER, MAN! on Netflix. Playing the help at a hotel, they spring into action when terrorists storm the building and take hostages.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nN.C.A.A. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMasterChef Junior\u201d returns with Gordon Ramsay on his best behavior. And a documentary exploring crime in Flint, Mich., comes to Netflix.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nMASTERCHEF JUNIOR 8 p.m. on Fox. Gordon Ramsay has built an empire partly based on his scathing verbal lashings of the adults in his kitchens. He\u2019s far kinder to the youngsters on this show, who take on cooking challenges with brio and sass. The sixth season starts with a two-hour special, as 40 children ages 8 to 13 arrive with the goal of nabbing the $100,000 prize.\n\nFRONTLINE 9 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). It\u2019s been five months since The New York Times published accusations of sexual harassment against Harvey Weinstein, but the saga is by no means over: New accusations and details of misconduct have continued to emerge. This hourlong special captures his downfall up to this point, with interviews with former colleagues, victims and the reporters who broke the story, including The Times\u2019s Megan Twohey. The documentary examines how Mr. Weinstein used lawyers and private detectives to help him suppress sexual harassment allegations, and investigates who around him knew what, and when.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Friday: \u2018MasterChef Junior\u2019 and \u2018Flint Town\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTwo documentaries shine a light on the lives of celebrated writers: the groundbreaking playwright Arthur Miller and the inimitable film critic Roger Ebert.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nARTHUR MILLER: WRITER (2018) 8 p.m. on HBO; also on HBO streaming platforms. The director Rebecca Miller first started shooting videotapes of her father, the playwright Arthur Miller, when she was just 21. More than 30 years later, Ms. Miller has woven that footage with intimate interviews and decades\u2019 worth of archival gems for this new documentary. \u201cI realize, you know, that this is my sixth film, but it\u2019s also my first film,\u201d she said in an interview with The New York Times. \u201cI spent 18 months cutting it. It was quite an emotional process for me.\u201d The portrait covers the traumatic events that affected the writer early on, his relationship with Marilyn Monroe and his 40-year marriage to the Magnum photographer Inge Morath.\n\nPhoto\n\nEPIC WARRIOR WOMEN 8 p.m. on Smithsonian. Television\u2019s first Wonder Woman, Lynda Carter, narrates this documentary series on storied female fighters who came well before DC Comics\u2019 Diana Prince. This premiere revolves around the horse-riding Amazon warriors who roamed the Eurasian grasslands and protected their vast territory from the powers of Greece, China and Persia.\n\nTHE VOICE 8 p.m. on NBC. The Season 14 battle rounds begin. Carson Daly hosts as contestants team up for duets.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSILICON VALLEY: THE UNTOLD STORY 8 p.m. on Science. Discover how Silicon Valley spawned technological breakthroughs in three back-to-back episodes of this documentary series. Some of today\u2019s biggest innovators weigh in on the industry\u2019s history, including its failures.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nLIFE ITSELF (2014) on iTunes, Amazon and Hulu. When Steve James started this documentary, he originally envisioned an adaptation of the 2011 memoir by the Pulitzer Prize-winning film critic Roger Ebert. That plan changed when Mr. Ebert, who had cancer, died five months into production. The result, \u201cLife Itself,\u201d juxtaposes scenes of an indefatigable Mr. Ebert in his final moments with clips from his earlier years as a leading voice in American cinema \u2014 a critic for The Chicago Sun-Times and co-host of \u201cAt the Movies.\u201d Writing in The Times, Geoffrey O\u2019Brien named the film a Critic\u2019s Pick.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018Arthur Miller: Writer\u2019 and \u2018Life Itself\u2019", "authors": ["Sara Aridi"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Brett Morgen\u2019s documentary about the British scientist Jane Goodall is on National Geographic. And Oprah Winfrey appears with the \u201cA Wrinkle in Time\u201d co-stars Mindy Kaling and Reese Witherspoon on \u201cThe Late Late Show.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nJANE (2017) 8 p.m. on National Geographic and Nat Geo Wild. When Jane Goodall journeyed into the forests of East Africa to research chimpanzees, it was the early 1960s, she was 26 and had no scientific degree. But, despite her lack of traditional training, Ms. Goodall\u2019s quiet observations of primate interactions would help significantly deepen human understanding of chimps and our connections to them. Brett Morgen (\u201cKurt Cobain: Montage of Heck\u201d) directs this documentary, which consists primarily of historical footage of Ms. Goodall taken by the wildlife photographer Hugo van Lawick, Ms. Goodall\u2019s first husband. In his review for The New York Times, Ben Kenigsberg wrote that the film \u201cis such an absorbing account of her experiences at a reserve in what is now Tanzania that you may not pause to think about how its imagery was captured.\u201d It has a score by Philip Glass, and includes a present-day interview with Ms. Goodall. Now in her 80s, she has spent her career pursuing her research and living as an outspoken conservationist. \u201cIt is a jolly tough way to live,\u201d she told The Times in 2010, \u201cbut it\u2019s worthwhile.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018Jane,\u2019 and Oprah on \u2018The Late Late Show\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA new documentary offers a behind-the-scenes look at the comic Garry Shandling, who died in 2016. And AMC dramatizes a doomed 19th-century expedition in \u201cThe Terror.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nTHE ZEN DIARIES OF GARRY SHANDLING 8 p.m. on HBO; also on HBO streaming platforms. The filmmaker and producer Judd Apatow pays tribute to his longtime mentor, the comedian Garry Shandling, in this two-part documentary. Mr. Shandling made a name for himself in the stand-up world as a guest host of \u201cThe Tonight Show\u201d before starring in \u201cIt\u2019s Garry Shandling\u2019s Show\u201d and \u201cThe Larry Sanders Show.\u201d The first part of this portrait chronicles Mr. Shandling\u2019s upbringing in Tucson, the near-death experience that motivated him to keep introspective journals and the early stages of his relationship with the actress Linda Doucett. \u201cI wanted to do right by Garry,\u201d Mr. Apatow said in an interview with The New York Times. \u201cBut right by Garry doesn\u2019t mean making Garry look great. It means getting to the truth, because that\u2019s all he ever cared about.\u201d Part 2 is on Tuesday at 8 p.m.\n\nTEYANA & IMAN 9 p.m. on VH1. This new reality show stars the newlyweds Teyana Taylor, the singer, rapper and dancer, and Iman Shumpert, the shooting guard for the Sacramento Kings, as they adjust to married life with their toddler, Junie.\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE TERROR 9 p.m. on AMC. In 1848, after three years at sea, an expedition team braving the Arctic in search of the Northwest Passage, led by the British explorer John Franklin, disappeared. Numerous search parties tried to find the crew of 129 men, but not until 2014 was a first ship, the Erebus, located. The Terror was found two years later. This new thriller series starring Jared Harris, Tobias Menzies and Ciaran Hinds reimagines that perilous journey, beginning with an accident at sea that damages one of the ships.\n\nTHE GOOD DOCTOR 10 p.m. on ABC. This heart-wrenching medical drama by David Shore, creator of \u201cHouse,\u201d quickly became one of the most watched shows on television when it began last fall. Freddie Highmore stars as Dr. Shaun Murphy, a young, exceptional surgeon with autism and savant syndrome who works at a prestigious hospital. Some of Shaun\u2019s colleagues worry his disorder is a liability, even though his talent in the surgical unit speaks for itself. In this season finale, hospital staff members race to discover the cause of a patient\u2019s injuries, and a distraction during a procedure could cost Shaun his job.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nFROWNLAND (2008) on FilmStruck. Set in uninviting rooms and on obscure New York streets, this divisive directorial debut by Ronald Bronstein is a character study of Keith Sontag (Dore Mann), a hapless, chain-smoking coupon salesman in his late 20s. Keith is by no means likable; it\u2019s his moments of despair, brought on by cringe-worthy setbacks, that make a raw spectacle. In her review, Manohla Dargis named \u201cFrownland\u201d a critic\u2019s pick and wrote, \u201cThis is personal cinema at its most uncompromising and fierce.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018The Zen Diaries of Garry Shandling\u2019 and \u2018The Terror\u2019", "authors": ["Sara Aridi"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "ATOMIC BLONDE (2017) 8 p.m. on HBO. What happens when you reimagine James Bond as a blond, female spy? According to the The Times\u2019s Manohla Dargis, you get \u201clavishly violent, inventively choreographed fights that have been glued together by nonsense and Charlize Theron.\u201d Ms. Theron stars as Lorraine Broughton, a British secret service spy who is on an assignment in Berlin shortly before the fall of the Berlin Wall, with a cast that includes James McAvoy and John Goodman.\n\nPACIFIC RIM (2013) 8 p.m. on F.X. If you\u2019re planning on seeing \u201cPacific Rim: Uprising,\u201d (and you might want to, our critic writes), this first installment directed by Guillermo del Toro will get you acquainted with the robots-versus-monsters story. \u201cIf you walk in expecting subtlety, or even novelty, you may find yourself more tormented than entertained,\u201d the Times\u2019s A. O. Scott wrote. \u201cBut \u2018Pacific Rim\u2019 is also a reminder \u2014 either just in time or much too late \u2014 that this kind of movie can and should be fun.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: \u2018Hope & Fury\u2019 and the \u2018Kids\u2019 Choice Awards\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Greta Gerwig\u2019s coming-of-age story is streaming. And Rachel Weisz plays a mysterious widow in an adaptation of a Daphne du Maurier novel.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nLADY BIRD (2017) on iTunes and Amazon. \u201cWhat is \u2018Boyhood,\u2019 but for a girl? What is \u2018The 400 Blows,\u2019 but for a girl? What is personhood for young women?\u201d That\u2019s Greta Gerwig speaking about her film \u201cLady Bird\u201d at the New York Film Festival. Set in Sacramento in the early aughts, the movie stars Saoirse Ronan as the titular character, whose nickname is self-assigned. In the waning days of her Catholic high school career, Lady Bird navigates college applications, the limitations of her family\u2019s economic situation and the tension between platonic relationships and romantic ones. \u201cI wish I could convey to you just how thrilling this movie is,\u201d A. O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times. \u201cI\u2019m tempted to catalog the six different ways the ending can make you cry.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: \u2018Lady Bird\u2019 and \u2018My Cousin Rachel\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA young woman seeks comfort after a breakup in \u201cLover for a Day.\u201d And the true crime documentary \u201cOperation Odessa\u201d arrives on Showtime.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nLOVER FOR A DAY (2018) on Mubi. The latest meditation on love by the French director Philippe Garrel revolves around a seemingly functioning triangle. After a devastating breakup, 23-year-old Jeanne (Esther Garrel, the director\u2019s daughter), moves in with her father, Giles (Eric Caravaca), and his new 23-year-old girlfriend, Ariane (Louise Chevillotte). Shot in 35-millimeter black-and-white film and set in Giles\u2019s crowded Paris apartment, \u201cLover for a Day\u201d follows Jeanne\u2019s rocky transition while revealing each character\u2019s anxieties and convictions about intimacy and romance. In her review for The New York Times, Manohla Dargis wrote that the film \u201clooks like a dream,\u201d adding that Mr. Garrel is \u201ca master of near-perfection, of dazzlingly lit and shot wisps of hair and tear-streaked cheeks.\u201d The director\u2019s earlier drama, \u201cIn the Shadow of Women,\u201d streams on Mubi on Sunday.\n\nFRANK (2014) on iTunes, Amazon, Hulu and Sundance Now. Domhnall Gleeson plays Jon, an aspiring rock star who joins a band led by a brilliant keyboardist, Frank (Michael Fassbender). Among Frank\u2019s many quirks is the large papier-m\u00e2ch\u00e9 head he refuses to take off. As the group records an album, Frank\u2019s experimentalism inspires Jon in new ways, and tensions rise between Jon and his feisty bandmate Clara (Maggie Gyllenhaal).\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nPhoto\n\nOPERATION ODESSA 9 p.m. on Showtime. In the 1990s, Ludwig (Tarzan) Fainberg, a Russian mobster and Miami strip club owner; Juan Almeida, a Cuban luxury car dealer; and Nelson (Tony) Yester, an international drug trafficker, were accused of combining their skills to sell a Soviet submarine to a Colombian cartel to distribute cocaine in the former Soviet Union and North America. An interagency task force, \u201cOperation Odessa,\u201d uncovered the plot after a three-year investigation. In this new documentary, the director Tiller Russell interviews Mr. Fainberg and Mr. Almeida (Mr. Yester is still on the run), and the law enforcement agents who exposed the unbelievable scheme.\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE X-FILES 11 a.m. on BBC America. It could be said that this cult paranormal drama has had three lives. Starring David Duchovny and Gillian Anderson as F.B.I. agents investigating the supernatural, the series first aired in 1993; returned for a six-episode 10th season in 2016; and resolved a major cliffhanger in its 11th season, which wrapped up on March 21. Fans were mostly pleased with the latest episodes, yet many feel that the show has run out of juice. (Ms. Anderson has hinted that she, too, has had enough.) For those who prefer its earlier days, BBC America is airing this back-to-back marathon of the first two seasons through 6 a.m. Tuesday, with a break for the season finale of Top Gear on Sunday at 8 p.m. All the original episodes are streaming on iTunes, Amazon and Hulu.\n\n48 HOURS: LIVE TO TELL 10 p.m. on CBS. A former sex trafficking victim chronicles her traumatic experience in this short-run series. Ashton Kutcher discusses his efforts in identifying potential victims and abusers through his nonprofit organization, Thorn.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: \u2018Lover for a Day\u2019 and \u2018Operation Odessa\u2019", "authors": ["Sara Aridi"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCatch the Oscar contender \u201cMudbound\u201d on Netflix. Or watch Matt LeBlanc talk cars and burn rubber in the new season of \u201cTop Gear.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nMUDBOUND (2017) on Netflix. Set in the Mississippi Delta in the years after World War II, this drama by the director Dee Rees revolves around the Jacksons, black tenant farmers, and the McAllans, a white family that owns the land the Jacksons work. The plot twists and turns, but the heart of the story is the relationship between Jamie McAllan (Garrett Hedlund) and Ronsel Jackson (Jason Mitchell), combat veterans who return home only to be reminded that their friendship doesn\u2019t bode well in the Jim Crow era. Adapted from the 2008 novel by Hillary Jordan, the film earned four Oscar nominations and broke new ground when Rachel Morrison, the director of photography, became the first woman to be nominated for best cinematography. In his review, A. O. Scott named the movie a Critic\u2019s Pick and wrote, \u201cIt\u2019s a work of historical imagination that lands in the present with disquieting, illuminating force.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n1984 (1984) on iTunes, Amazon and Hulu. If you haven\u2019t read the classic dystopian novel by George Orwell, stop what you\u2019re doing and find a copy. Soak it all in, then come back to this column. The story of a totalitarian state ruled by Big Brother made a strong comeback last year for its prescient themes. And this film adaptation by Michael Radford is just as enduring. John Hurt plays a government worker who rewrites history to align with the Inner Party\u2019s policies. His dreary routine is shaken up by a brief love affair with another government worker (Suzanna Hamilton), but their rebellious romance is no match for Big Brother\u2019s Thought Police. \u201cThis \u20181984\u2019 is not an easy film to watch,\u201d Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times, \u201cbut it exerts a fascination that demands attention even as you want to turn away from it.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nPhoto\n\nTOP GEAR 10:30 p.m. on BBC America. The last couple of years have been bumpy for this popular car show. Its longtime host, Jeremy Clarkson, was suspended in 2015 after \u201ca fracas\u201d with a BBC producer. Unable to save the program from low ratings, Mr. Clarkson\u2019s successor, Chris Evans, stepped down in 2016. \u201cTop Gear\u201d then welcomed its first American co-host: Matt LeBlanc, who holds the show\u2019s record for fastest celebrity lap. Mr. LeBlanc returns in this season premiere alongside the British journalists Chris Harris and Rory Reid. The second episode will air in its regular weekly slot, 8 p.m. on Sunday.\n\nSATURDAY STACK: CLASSIC SOUL 1 p.m. on AXS TV. Settle in for a marathon of programming on soul artists, beginning with the documentary \u201cThe Story of James Brown.\u201d\n\nROCKY MOUNTAIN ANIMAL RESCUE 10 p.m. on Nat Geo Wild. This new series follows members of the nonprofit Humane Society of the Pikes Peak Region as they save animals across Southern Colorado. This premiere surrounds a mission to rescue an endangered duck.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: \u2018Mudbound\u2019 and \u2018Top Gear\u2019", "authors": ["Sara Aridi"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Christiane Amanpour identifies universal aspects of relationships in a new series. And the lustful melodrama \u201cThe Beguiled\u201d arrives on HBO.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nCHRISTIANE AMANPOUR: SEX & LOVE AROUND THE WORLD 10 p.m. on CNN. Christiane Amanpour, CNN\u2019s chief international correspondent and the anchor of the global affairs program \u201cAmanpour,\u201d takes a turn toward the intimate in this new six-part series. Each episode brings her to a different country in Asia, Europe and Africa to explore carnal taboos and norms. Her first stop is Tokyo, where she gasps at 17th-century erotic art, interviews a hotel health worker and attends a host club that offers \u201cprivate hospitality\u201d to women. Given that Anthony Bourdain is among the show\u2019s executive producers, it\u2019s no surprise that the style is reminiscent of \u201cParts Unknown\u201d \u2014 with a sensual twist.\n\nNYC ST.
