A green sea of New Yorkers washes over Fifth Avenue to celebrate the city\u2019s 257th parade.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: \u2018Sex & Love Around the World\u2019 and \u2018The Beguiled\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Who will win at the Oscars tonight? And what will Alec Baldwin say on his new talk show?\n\nWhat\u2019s On TV\n\n90TH ACADEMY AWARDS 8 p.m. on ABC. \u201cI promise I\u2019ll never come back; good night!\u201d were Jimmy Kimmel\u2019s final words at last year\u2019s Oscars, shortly after an envelope mixup sent an otherwise docile night into absurdist chaos. Well, he\u2019s back as host this year, and will surely reference the debacle early and often. And he may mention the #MeToo and Time\u2019s Up movements. Like last year, the best picture race is a tossup, with \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d and \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d neck and neck \u2014 although the cultural phenomenon \u201cGet Out\u201d lurks as a dark horse candidate. Just as intriguing is the live music, which might just rival the Grammys: Mary J. Blige, Common, Sufjan Stevens and Miguel will all perform. The red carpet starts at 5 p.m. on E!\n\nSTARTALK 11 p.m. on National Geographic. Last year, Neil deGrasse Tyson became the first American scientist to take home the Stephen Hawking Medal. On Sunday, Mr. Tyson interviews the man himself, in the Season 4 finale of \u201cStarTalk.\u201d Mr. Hawking is a spry and good-natured interviewee; here, he answers questions about his theories about the origins of the universe, the possibility of time travel, and what he would ask Isaac Newton if given the chance.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Sunday: The Oscars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAmerican Idol\u201d is back, with three new judges. And \u201cTimeless\u201d visits Marie Curie and the French front in World War I.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nAMERICAN IDOL 8 p.m. on ABC. You didn\u2019t really think \u201cAmerican Idol\u201d was going away, did you? Two years after Fox announced the cultural behemoth would come to a close after 15 seasons, here it is back again on ABC. Ryan Seacrest is still around despite a swirl of controversy, but the judges box looks decidedly different, with Katy Perry, Lionel Richie and Luke Bryan calling the shots. Ms. Perry will bring bursts of zaniness, while Mr. Richie will bring the sage perspective of an older generation. \u201cFor two days a week, Professor Richie is going to talk about the reality of what it takes to be an artist,\u201d he said in an interview with The New York Times.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Sunday: \u2018American Idol\u2019 and \u2018Timeless\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Bill Hader stars as a hit man yearning for a new life in \u201cBarry.\u201d And Stormy Daniels breaks her silence on \u201c60 Minutes.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nBARRY 10:30 p.m. on HBO. One week removed from a triumphant return to \u201cSaturday Night Live,\u201d Bill Hader kick-starts a new era of his career with \u201cBarry.\u201d He plays a weary and tightly wound hit man who learned the skills of the trade in Afghanistan. But when he digs into the life of his next mark, an aspiring actor, he finds a passion for acting bubbling to the surface, and begins to take classes, much to the chagrin of his handler. \u201cYou don\u2019t expect this comedy to find its target in the way it does,\u201d James Poniewozik wrote about this series in his New York Times review; he named it a Critic\u2019s Pick.\n\nGREAT PERFORMANCES AT THE MET 12 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). Last fall, the Met Opera was besieged by live sheep, ghostly violins, slamming doors and shattering dishes in Thomas Ad\u00e8s\u2019s \u201cThe Exterminating Angel.\u201d \u201cThis riveting, breathless, score \u2014 full of quick-cutting shifts, pointillist bursts, and episodes of ballistic intensity \u2014 may be his best work,\u201d Anthony Tommasini wrote in his Times review. The opera, inspired by the classic Luis Bu\u00f1uel film of the same name, follows a hellish dinner party, where the guests find themselves unable to leave; the opera includes the highest note ever sung at the Met.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Sunday: \u2018Barry\u2019 and Stormy Daniels on \u201860 Minutes\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAlan Cumming leads a new drama on CBS. And \u201cBrooklyn Nine-Nine\u201d returns.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nINSTINCT 8 p.m. on CBS. Don\u2019t put Alan Cumming in a box: He\u2019s spent his career ricocheting from theater (he\u2019s a Tony winner) to television to cabaret to owning a gay bar. And even when he\u2019s taking on more conventional roles, like this one, he\u2019s still breaking boundaries: He will play the first gay lead of an hourlong network drama. \u201cThe fact that has taken so long is awful,\u201d Mr. Cumming said in an interview with The New York Times. \u201cBut the character\u2019s gayness is like the fifth most interesting thing about him, and the way it\u2019s handled is very non-sensational.\u201d He plays Dr. Dylan Reinhart, a former C.I.A. operative turned washed-out psychology professor who gets drawn into a murder investigation.\n\nHAWKING (2013) 7 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). This intimate documentary tells the story of Stephen Hawking\u2019s life through his own words, as he continued to work at the University of Cambridge late in his life. The film includes archival footage; computer-generated imagery illustrating some of his discoveries; and interviews with his former wife Jane Hawking, the astronaut Buzz Aldrin, and others.\n\nPhoto\n\nBROOKLYN NINE-NINE 8:30 p.m. on Fox. At the merciless \u201cRoast of James Franco\u201d in 2013, Jonah Hill targeted Andy Samberg\u2019s new cop show, predicting that it would be canceled after five episodes and that Mr. Samberg would have to resort to phone commercials. But here we are five years later, with Mr. Samberg still leading the zany and diverse sitcom through high jinks all over Brooklyn. In this new episode, the crew works to protect Captain Holt\u2019s husband from kidnapping by resorting to lots of feints, wigs and identical rolling carts.\n\nGENIUS JUNIOR 9 p.m. on NBC. He can host awards shows, star in sitcoms and films, and even win a Tony. But Neil Patrick Harris will never escape the long shadow of Doogie Houser, the prodigal teenage doctor he played for four seasons on \u201cDoogie Howser, M.D.\u201d So for his next hosting gig, Mr. Harris is leaning into his roots, as he presides over extremely smart kids in this game show. They will be quizzed on spelling, math and memory, with each round tougher than the last. And LITTLE BIG SHOTS, a kids\u2019 talent show hosted by Steve Harvey, leads in with episodes at 7 and 8.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nLEONARD COHEN: I\u2019M YOUR MAN (2005) on Hulu. In the year since his death, Leonard Cohen has become something of a secular saint in his hometown, Montreal, with bars, murals and museums celebrating his work. If you can\u2019t make the trip, you can still join in on Cohen Mania with this documentary, which combines pieces of an extended interview with footage from a tribute concert. He reflects on his relationship with Judaism and his reputation as a Casanova, flashing his distinct gallows humor.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Sunday: \u2018Instinct\u2019 and \u2018Brooklyn Nine-Nine\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "N.C.A.A. MEN\u2019S BASKETBALL TOURNAMENT You better have those brackets filled out, because the first large batch of March Madness games arrives on Thursday. Oklahoma has sputtered as of late, but anything is possible with the freshman phenom Trae Young\u2019s sharpshooting prowess from all over the floor; his team plays Rhode Island at 12:15 p.m. on CBS. An intriguing No. 8- and No. 9-seeded matchup pits Alabama, with the ferocious point guard Collin Sexton, against Virginia Tech at 9:15 p.m. on TNT. And Deandre Ayton, a potential top N.B.A. prospect, hopes to dominate Buffalo at 9:40 p.m. on CBS.\n\nFURIOUS 7 (2015) 7 p.m. on FX or on Netflix. The seventh installment of the unassailable \u201cFast & Furious\u201d franchise serves as both a brisk action flick and a touching tribute to Paul Walker, in his last role filmed before his death. Before the cast members say their farewells in the final moments, cars are driven out of airplanes, come-ons are exchanged and Dwayne Johnson brawls with Jason Statham. \u201c\u2018Furious 7\u2019 is an early favorite to win the prize for most picture,\u201d A. O. Scott wrote in his review in The New York Times. And look for footage of Gal Gadot, two years before she would become a superstar in her own right with \u201cWonder Woman\u201d \u2014 which in on HBO2 at 9:45 p.m.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Thursday: March Madness and \u2018How to Get Away With Murder\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDonald Glover\u2019s \u201cAtlanta\u201d returns with grittier plotlines. Or watch the breezy, dance-filled \u201cAn American in Paris.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nATLANTA 10 p.m. on FX. With its stinging social commentary, hazy musical reveries, fake commercials, invisible cars and a black Justin Bieber parody, the first season of \u201cAtlanta\u201d was unlike anything else on TV in 2016. Its creator, Donald Glover, took some time off to chase other dreams (being a pop star, appearing in \u201cStar Wars\u201d), but he\u2019s back with the show\u2019s second season. While the rap career of Paper Boi (Brian Tyree Henry) begins to take off, Earn (Glover) flounders in a teeming city. \u201cWe wanted to show character development in people having their backs against the wall,\u201d Mr. Glover said in an interview with The New York Times. The new season meanders through the city\u2019s streets, with fast-food robberies, alligator standoffs, tense studio sessions and late nights at a strip club with a mixture of absurdity and gravitas. (\u201cStraight Outta Compton,\u201d another unflinching portrait of a hip-hop hub, leads in at 7 p.m.)\n\nAN AMERICAN IN PARIS (1951) 8 p.m. on TCM or streaming on FilmStruck. This Gershwin musical won best picture at the 1952 Oscars, but not for the plot, in this film set in post-World War II Paris. It remains enchanting for its kinetic energy and visual splendor, which include lavish dance sequences, bright costuming and the magnetism of its stars, Gene Kelly and Leslie Caron. Kelly acted, sang, danced, and choreographed; he even directed several musical sequences, including the one set to the unforgettable torch ballad \u201cEmbraceable You.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nGOTHAM 8 p.m. on Fox. This Batman origin story-turned-procedural returns. Jim Gordon (Ben McKenzie) contends with the usual host of the city\u2019s campy criminals, like the Toy Maker, Edward Nygma and Poison Ivy.\n\nMUSIC CITY 10 p.m. on CMT. Musicians can spend years in Nashville as cogs in the city\u2019s singer-songwriter machine, gigging and writing hits while remaining in the shadows. In this reality series, five performers hope to take a shortcut to stardom. The docu-series tracks their studio sessions, concerts, and professional and personal relationships.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nLOGAN (2017) on HBO and iTunes. \u201cBlack Panther\u201d has stormed through box offices all over the world and set all kinds of records. But \u201cLogan,\u201d released about a year earlier, set a different kind of precedent: It\u2019s the first live-action superhero film to receive an Oscar screenplay nomination. \u201c\u2018Logan\u2019 is good enough that you might forget it\u2019s a comic-book movie,\u201d Manohla Dargis wrote in her Times review. The movie focuses on the familial and fiercely protective relationship that forms between an aging Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) and a young mutant named Laura (Dafne Keen).", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Thursday: \u2018Atlanta\u2019 and \u2018Gotham\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "LADIES FIRST on Netflix. Deepika Kumari grew up in poverty in rural India, where social norms dictated that women remain in domestic life. Instead, she took up archery and discovered her extraordinary talent. In just three to four years she mastered the sport, eventually becoming the world\u2019s top ranked archer at the age of 18 and appearing in the Olympics in London and Rio. This short documentary navigates her improbable rise and continued success (she\u2019s still just 23).\n\nTHE OATH on Crackle. O.K., so it turns out 50 Cent didn\u2019t actually invest in Bitcoin. But he\u2019s had real success in his television ventures, most notably as executive producer and star in the hit show \u201cPower.\u201d Now he\u2019s throwing his weight behind \u201cThe Oath,\u201d which explores police gangs. The show was created by Joe Halpin, a former undercover cop in the South Central section of Los Angeles. Sean Bean stars, bringing the same brooding intensity to street fights that he displayed in the fantasy worlds of \u201cLord of the Rings\u201d and \u201cGame of Thrones.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Thursday: \u2018Jessica Jones\u2019 and \u2018Atlanta\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "A dangerous mermaid washes ashore in \u201cSiren.\u201d And Bill Gates shows up on \u201cThe Big Bang Theory.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nSIREN 8 p.m. on Freeform. When ABC Family changed its name to Freeform in 2015, it hoped to distance itself from its innocent-sounding moniker. And so while \u201cSiren,\u201d the channel\u2019s newest addition, is about a mermaid, she\u2019s nothing like Ariel. The show takes on the darker hues and themes of teenage dramas like \u201cPretty Little Liars\u201d and \u201cThe Vampire Diaries\u201d to tell the story of Ryn (Eline Powell), a sea creature who wreaks havoc on a town while befriending its inhabitants. The show has small-town mystery elements, frenetic action sequences, and of course, homages to \u201cJaws.\u201d\n\nTHE BIG BANG THEORY 8 p.m. on CBS. This sitcom has had cameos from myriad brainy superstars, like Stephen Hawking, Steve Wozniak and Bill Nye. In this episode, the illustrious guest geek is Bill Gates, who s partners with Penny\u2019s (Kaley Cuoco) pharmaceutical company. And an actor who played one of television\u2019s most celebrated jerks appears on YOUNG SHELDON at 8:30: Jason Alexander (George Costanza on \u201cSeinfeld\u201d) will play the protagonist\u2019s hammy drama teacher.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Thursday: \u2018Siren\u2019 and \u2018Atlanta\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA spinoff of \u201cGrey\u2019s Anatomy\u201d focuses on firefighters. And \u201cPortlandia\u201d comes to a close.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nSTATION 19 9 p.m. on ABC. \u201cHow to Get Away With Murder\u201d finished up its season last week, but Shonda night rolls on with this new spinoff of \u201cGrey\u2019s Anatomy.\u201d Stacy McKee, a longtime writer and executive producer on \u201cGrey\u2019s,\u201d leads this series (with Shonda Rhimes as executive producer) about Seattle firefighters stationed a few blocks from Grey Sloan Memorial Hospital. Jaina Lee Ortiz plays Andy Herrera, a firefighter who happens to be the daughter of her station\u2019s captain.\n\nN.C.A.A. MEN\u2019S BASKETBALL TOURNAMENT What new insanity lies in store for your brackets in the Sweet 16? There will be no No. 1 or 2 seeds in play on Thursday as eight teams square off. No. 7 Nevada and No. 11 Loyola-Chicago both entered the tournament as heavy underdogs, yet will face off at 7:07 p.m. on CBS. Michigan, which escaped its last game on a winning three-pointer by Jordan Poole, faces Texas A&M at 7:37 on TBS. Kansas State took out the Cinderella story U.M.B.C.; it faces a taller challenge against a defensive-minded, John Calipari-led Kentucky squad at 9:37 on CBS. And two experienced teams, Gonzaga and Florida State, compete at 9:59 on TBS.\n\nPhoto\n\nPORTLANDIA 10 p.m. on IFC. It\u2019s time to bid farewell to this sketch comedy series, which has grown and mutated with the city itself across eight zany seasons. In the purported finale (you never really know these days, given the frequency of reboots and revivals), Portland\u2019s mayor (Kyle MacLachlan) cuts deals all over town to secure the perfect route for the Portland Marathon. Fred Armisen and Carrie Brownstein, playing characters with the same names, decide to run.\n\nLIP SYNC BATTLE 10 p.m. on Paramount Network. Michael Bolton has re-entered the zeitgeist over the last decade for his wry, unblinking self-parody. He\u2019ll get to do it again when he lip syncs Coolio\u2019s \u201cGangsta\u2019s Paradise.\u201d His competition is the comedian Pete Davidson, fresh off his latest \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d appearance, in which he addressed his mental health issues.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nON MY BLOCK on Netflix. The current golden age of teen TV only grows stronger with the arrival of this comedy-drama, in which four friends in South Central enter high school and find their social worlds irrevocably shifted. This diverse and earnest show tackles politics, discrimination and poverty, ebulliently portraying a neighborhood in which a gang is not a haunting menace but merely a fact of life.\n\nINNOCENT on Sundance Now. This new British drama focuses on a man who has spent seven years in jail for the murder of his wife. But when David Collins (Lee Ingleby) is suddenly released on a technicality, he returns home to a community that ranges from suspicious to downright hostile. And a new set of breakout comics performs in the second season of \u201cThe Standups.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nADAM RUINS EVERYTHING PRESENTS: REANIMATED HISTORY 10:30 p.m. on truTV. An animated Adam Conover debunks historical myths in this midseason premiere of his sketch-comedy show. The lives of seemingly unrelated strangers intertwine over the course of 36 hours in this directorial debut by Paul Haggis. Set in Los Angeles, the film is a meditation on race told through a horizontal narrative with one too many characters. It boasts a star-studded cast, led by Terrence Howard, Matt Dillon and Don Cheadle, and won three Oscars, including best picture. But not everyone is a fan of its moralistic themes. In his review, A. O. Scott wrote that \u201cCrash\u201d is \u201ca frustrating movie: full of heart and devoid of life; crudely manipulative when it tries hardest to be subtle; and profoundly complacent in spite of its intention to unsettle and disturb.\u201d\n\nBLOCHIN on MHz Choice. Fans of \u201cTrue Detective\u201d and \u201cHouse of Cards\u201d would find hints of those series in this gritty German crime drama. The title character, played by J\u00fcrgen Vogel, is a former criminal-turned-detective who uses his illicit past to help crack cases alongside his brother-in-law in a Berlin homicide division.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Tuesday: \u2018Mister Rogers: It\u2019s You I Like\u2019 and \u2018Gad Elmaleh: American Dream\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRicky Gervais examines his own ability to generate controversy in a new Netflix special. And \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d is streaming.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nRICKY GERVAIS: HUMANITY on Netflix. \u201cI don\u2019t know why I called it that, I\u2019m not a big fan,\u201d the British comedian Ricky Gervais says of the title of his new Netflix special. Mr. Gervais, a seasoned stand-up comic, is known to American audiences both as a sharp-tongued Golden Globes host and as a creator and star of shows including \u201cExtras,\u201d \u201cLife\u2019s Too Short\u201d and the British version of \u201cThe Office.\u201d In the special, he takes on issues including Twitter, wigs and his own brushes with controversy.\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE SHAPE OF WATER (2017) on iTunes and Amazon. Accepting the Academy Award for best director this month, Guillermo del Toro expressed surprise and delight that, when he pitched the idea for this film, his distributor thought that \u201ca fairy tale about an amphibian god and mute woman done in the style of Douglas Sirk\u201d was a sure bet. The movie stars Sally Hawkins as Elisa, a mute janitor in a government research lab in the 1960s. When a mermanlike creature (Doug Jones) is brought into the lab, Elisa develops a connection to him that blossoms into a romance. The cast also includes Richard Jenkins, Octavia Spencer, Michael Shannon and Michael Stuhlbarg, and the film also won the Academy Awards for best picture, production design and score. In his review for The New York Times, A. O. Scott wrote that \u201cthe most welcome and notable thing about \u2018The Shape of Water\u2019 is its generosity of spirit.\u201d\n\nICARUS (2017) on Netflix. For another Academy-lauded film, see Bryan Fogel\u2019s sports doping documentary, which won best documentary this year. Initially conceived as a film about steroid use, the movie begins with Mr. Fogel by injecting himself with performance-enhancing drugs to see how hard it would be to not get caught. This brings him into contact with Dr. Grigory Rodchenkov, a Russian doctor who, we now know, helped operate a state-run Olympic doping program. When Dr. Rodchenkov comes under investigation, Mr. Fogel shifts the focus from doping itself to the doctor, who flees Russia out of fear for his own safety. \u201cMr. Fogel could be considered either daring or foolhardy for his initial plan,\u201d Ken Jaworowski wrote in his review for The Times. \u201cBut his work with Dr. Rodchenkov is levelheaded, and his documentary illuminating.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE PIZZA SHOW 7 p.m. on Viceland. Across the lake and down the highway from the toppings-in-the-middle deep-dish pizzas of Chicago, Detroit pizza has a crunchy crust and a distinctive rectangular shape. In this episode of Viceland\u2019s pizza-focused travel show, the host and pizza connoisseur Frank Pinello (who also owns Best Pizza in Brooklyn) scours the Motor City for the best slices.\n\nTHIS IS US 9 p.m. on NBC. When this drama series began in 2016, James Poniewozik of The Times likened the experience of watching it to \u201cgetting beaten up with a pillow soaked in tears.\u201d You may be able to expect some happy tears from the Pearson family in this second-season finale, which concludes with a wedding.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Tuesday: \u2018Ricky Gervais: Humanity\u2019 and \u2018The Shape of Water\u2019", "authors": ["Gabe Cohn"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTwo series debut on ABC: the return of \u201cRoseanne\u201d and the family comedy \u201cSplitting Up Together.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nROSEANNE 8 p.m. on ABC. Recent resurrections of shows like \u201cWill & Grace\u201d and \u201cTwin Peaks\u201d prove that \u201990s television is thriving. So it\u2019s no surprise that the family sitcom \u201cRoseanne\u201d gets a comeback. The original series, which ran for nine seasons, brought a relatable aspect of American life to the small screen with its depiction of the Conners, a working-class family in fictional Lanford, Ill. This revival\u2019s premiere quickly sets the show in the present, as Roseanne (Roseanne Barr) and her sister, Jackie (Laurie Metcalf), bump heads over Roseanne\u2019s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 election. (Ms. Barr has been an outspoken supporter of President Trump.) In his review, James Poniewozik welcomed the show\u2019s return, writing, \u201cLike that old couch you can\u2019t throw out, it may just have a good year or two left in it.\u201d Need a refresher? The original episodes are streaming on Amazon Prime Video.\n\nFOOD EXPOSED WITH NELUFAR HEDAYAT 8 p.m. on Fusion. The Fusion correspondent Nelufar Hedayat investigates the global food chain to reveal the human and environmental costs of modern appetites in this new documentary series. In the premiere, Ms. Hedayat explores food waste in New York, Los Angeles and Guatemala.\n\nPhoto\n\nSPLITTING UP TOGETHER 9:30 p.m. on ABC. Jenna Fischer (\u201cThe Office\u201d) and Oliver Hudson (\u201cScream Queens\u201d) play a newly divorced couple who (sort of) live under the same roof for the sake of their children in this new comedy. Each week, they rotate roles: The \u201con-duty\u201d parent stays in the house to look after the children, while the \u201coff-duty\u201d parent lounges in the garage. The pilot opens with the couple breaking the news of the divorce to their friends and family, and dealing with the aftermath. Ellen DeGeneres is an executive producer of the show, which is adapted from a Danish series.\n\nTHE JIM JEFFERIES SHOW 10:30 p.m. on Comedy Central. Jim Jefferies tackles gun violence and reform in this Season 2 premiere of his politically charged late-night talk show. The 10th season premiere of \u201cTosh.0\u201d leads in at 10 p.m.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE LITTLE HOURS (2017) on iTunes, Amazon and Hulu. Alison Brie, Aubrey Plaza and Kate Micucci play irreverent nuns in a 14th-century Italian convent in this loose adaptation of Giovanni Boccaccio\u2019s \u201cThe Decameron.\u201d Directed by Jeff Baena, the film picks up when a hunky groundskeeper (Dave Franco), who\u2019s introduced to the wild girls as a deaf mute to keep them at bay, arrives on the premises. Naturally, desires are unleashed and chaos ensues. Some critics have applauded the movie\u2019s screwball comedy and overly salacious scenes, but others weren\u2019t impressed. In her review for The New York Times, Jeannette Catsoulis wrote, \u201cBoccaccio might have had medieval audiences rolling in the aisles, but Mr. Baena squanders an R rating and a roster of household names while managing to raise little more than a smile.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Tuesday: \u2018Roseanne\u2019 and \u2018Splitting Up Together\u2019", "authors": ["Sara Aridi"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cThe X-Files\u201d wraps up its season. And watch a Superman origin story without Superman.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nKRYPTON 10 p.m. on Syfy. These days we\u2019re going so deep into superhero origin stories that the actual superheroes aren\u2019t even in them. This new series is set on Krypton, but the man who becomes Clark Kent is nowhere to be found; instead, it follows his grandfather, Seg-El (Cameron Cuffe), some 200 years before Superman\u2019s birth. The show is not a procedural, like another DC origin story, \u201cGotham,\u201d but rather a sociopolitical drama examining a world being divided into classes. The El family has been ostracized, and Seg-El must fight to redeem his family\u2019s honor and save his planet from obliteration.\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE X-FILES 8 p.m. on Fox. Barring yet another surprise, it sure seems like this will be the last episode of this stunningly resilient show, which has transitioned into the new millennium with grace. Mulder (David Duchovny) and Scully (Gillian Anderson) contemplate aging and their tenuous relationship as they rush to find an on-the-run William; the Cigarette Smoking Man pushes forward with his ultimate plan.\n\nO BROTHER, WHERE ART THOU? (2000) 8 p.m. on CMT. In 1999, George Clooney hung up his \u201cER\u201d scrubs; in 2001, he donned his nattiest suit for \u201cOcean\u2019s Eleven.\u201d In between, he played one of his strangest and scrappiest roles, as an ex-convict wandering the dusty roads of Depression-era Mississippi. He and his companions flee from a cyclops, sirens and the Ku Klux Klan, making some great music along the way. The Coen brothers wrote and directed the film, in which their \u201cwhiz-kid inventiveness\u201d reaches \u201cnew heights of whimsy,\u201d A. O. Scott wrote in his review in The New York Times. T he cinematography is courtesy of Roger Deakins, who finally won his first Oscar this month on his 14th try.\n\nAMERICAN CRIME STORY 10 p.m. on FX. The hunt for Andrew Cunanan, after his murder of Gianni Versace, comes to a frantic end.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nBEAR GRYLLS: FACE THE WILD on Facebook Watch. The survival expert Bear Grylls is relentless in his pursuit of thrills. You can bet that while you\u2019re reading this, he\u2019s clambering up a the face of a cliff, jumping out of a helicopter or stepping on the neck of an alligator. But while he has spent the past few years putting celebrities like Kate Winslet and Michael B. Jordan through brutal physical and psychological wilderness challenges, he now turns his focus to everyday people he found on Facebook. In this new show he embarks on adventures with Jonathon Blank, who lost his legs in Afghanistan; a woman with failing eyesight; and others.\n\nMISTER ROGERS\u2019 NEIGHBORHOOD on Twitch. The gentle and deeply kind show hosted by Fred Rogers received a celebratory special on PBS for its 50th anniversary this year. Now, Twitch is streaming a complete run of the show\u2019s 856 episodes, 24 hours a day, until April 8. Tune in around the clock for glimpses of Mr. Rogers learning from astronauts, hanging out with Koko the gorilla or taking on divorce.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Wednesday: \u2018Krypton\u2019 and \u2018The X-Files\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Lucy Hale stars in a new series on the CW. And a Hulu series draws inspiration from a David Bowie song.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nLIFE SENTENCE 9 p.m. on the CW. In many films and television shows, a character\u2019s life is thrown into chaos after a cancer diagnosis. \u201cLife Sentence\u201d explores the opposite scenario. After living with terminal cancer for eight years, Stella (Lucy Hale of \u201cPretty Little Liars\u201d) finds out she has been cured. Suddenly all her live-in-the-moment clich\u00e9s start to ring hollow; her family, which had invested its time and money in sending her off with love, starts to fray. \u201cThe show has a perky earnestness, buoyant enough to float over the genuine agonies of cancer while still acknowledging some of the emotional fallout,\u201d Margaret Lyons wrote in The New York Times. (\u201cRiverdale\u201d leads in at 8 with a trip to the Lodges\u2019 lake house.)\n\nTHE MEN WHO BUILT AMERICA: FRONTIERSMEN 9 p.m. on History. Six years ago, the History Channel ran an iteration of this series that focused on American businessmen and included an interview with none other than Donald J. Trump. This new mini-series jumps back in time to cover more rugged adventurers from the country\u2019s first 75 years; the lives of Daniel Boone, Lewis and Clark, and Davy Crockett will be explored through dramatizations and interviews with experts. Leonardo DiCaprio, who played a frontier trapper in \u201cThe Revenant,\u201d produced the series.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Wednesday: \u2018Life Sentence\u2019 and \u2018Hard Sun\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Americans\u201d returns for a final season. And a docuseries on YouTube follows the international pop stars BTS on tour.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nTHE AMERICANS 10 p.m. on FX. Talk to any television critic long enough and you\u2019ll probably hear griping about how \u201cThe Americans\u201d doesn\u2019t get its due. The show never acquired the cultural capital or ratings of \u201cBreaking Bad\u201d or \u201cThe Sopranos,\u201d but it has received rave reviews and taken on shocking relevance as headlines involving the phrases \u201cRussian tampering\u201d and \u201cundercover operatives\u201d blare. Keri Russell and Matthew Rhys are back for a final season as Elizabeth and Philip Jennings, K.G.B. spies and assassins at the dusk of the Cold War. But their marriage crumbles as their roles shift and their daughter, Paige (Holly Taylor), learns the skills of the family business. \u201cIt\u2019s that melancholy intimacy that makes \u2018The Americans\u2019 more than the sum of its wigs, stabbings and spot-on period-music choices,\u201d James Poniewozik wrote in his review in The New York Times.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Wednesday: \u2018The Americans\u2019 and a Tribute to Andrew Lloyd Webber", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA filmmaker spends time in Yellowstone with mountain lions. And watch the terrifying \u201cThe Babadook.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nTHE MOUNTAIN LION AND ME 8 p.m. on Smithsonian. Some filmmakers travel far to nab footage of animals in their natural habitats. But the Montana-based Casey Anderson started this project in his backyard, where he found footprints belonging to a family of mountain lions. He followed the animals through the rugged terrain of Yellowstone National Park and set up cameras in their cave to provide an intimate look as a mother and her three kittens face predators and a bitter winter.\n\nPhoto\n\nSPEECHLESS 8 p.m. on ABC. The history of sitcoms is littered with characters trying to weasel their way out of jury duty, whether it\u2019s Liz Lemon donning Princess Leia buns or Larry David resorting to straight-up racism. But for Maya, the frantically busy mother of the DiMeo clan, jury duty is practically a vacation \u2014 until she runs into a familiar face in the courthouse. Back at home, JJ, her teenage son with cerebral palsy, lies about his disabilities on an online dating site.\n\nTHE BABADOOK (2014) 8 p.m. on TMC or on Netflix. If you knew the Babadook only from social media, you might think he was a benign and proudly gay creature; you might not realize he lords over a terrifying movie that helped usher in the golden age of horror. The Babadook jumps out of a picture book and torments a mother and son already reeling from a death. The pair must confront their troubled bond as well as the monster. \u201cI came home from the screening, went to bed and woke up in the throes of the kind of nightmare that was the reason I had shunned those books in the first place,\u201d A. O. Scott wrote in his review in The New York Times.\n\nDESIGNATED SURVIVOR 10 p.m. on ABC. Tom Kirkman\u2019s White House has hit another rocky patch, and so has \u201cDesignated Survivor,\u201d which hit a series low in ratings two weeks ago. In this episode, President Kirkman (Kiefer Sutherland) tries to right the ship after a devastating tragedy, but runs into a P.R. crisis when a video of him visiting a prison is leaked to the news media.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nANOMALISA (2015) on Amazon Prime. Charlie Kaufman is known for his unorthodox storytelling devices, whether it\u2019s the tunnel vision of \u201cBeing John Malkovich\u201d or the disorienting fragmentation of \u201cEternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.\u201d In this film he uses stop-motion puppets to depict loneliness, love and despair. \u201cAnomalisa\u201d follows Michael, an author voiced by David Thewlis, through a series of deeply uncomfortable encounters during a trip to Ohio. \u201cMr. Kaufman\u2019s gift for quotidian horror remains startling; he\u2019s a whiz at minor miseries,\u201d Manohla Dargis wrote in her review in The Times. She named the film a Critic\u2019s Pick.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Wednesday: \u2018The Mountain Lion and Me\u2019 and \u2018Speechless\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "FULL ENGLISH Long ago, the mystery writer Elizabeth George \u2014 inspired by John Steinbeck\u2019s \u201cJournal of a Novel,\u201d a collection of letters he wrote to his editor while working on \u201cEast of Eden\u201d \u2014 began to keep a diary, jotting down ideas, research issues, plot problems and the like. \u201cActually, I used to keep two journals,\u201d she admits, \u201cone about the book I was working on, which I wrote every morning, and one more personal, which I wrote every night, about the struggles I was dealing with in my own life. But the two have merged.\u201d Even today \u2014 she\u2019s just published her 20th Inspector Lynley novel, \u201cThe Punishment She Deserves,\u201d which debuts on the hardcover fiction list at No. 2 \u2014 she still finds journaling useful.\n\nThe first Lynley book, \u201cA Great Deliverance,\u201d came out in 1988. The series has gone on for so long, George says, that \u201cit can be a delicate dance\u201d to introduce new readers to her characters. \u201cI don\u2019t want to give out every single detail about their pasts, which would be tedious for faithful readers,\u201d she says, \u201cso at this point I only repeat the information that\u2019s relevant to the current book.\u201d The other big challenge of writing a series? While she doesn\u2019t have any problems recalling the details of her characters\u2019 lives, \u201csometimes I have to double-check the names and places in their pasts. For example, Daidre Trahair\u201d \u2014 Lynley\u2019s love interest \u2014 \u201chas a brother and sister with very unusual Cornish names, so I usually have to leaf through a past book and make sure I\u2019ve got it right.\u201d\n\nGeorge, a meticulous researcher, visits England multiple times to investigate her settings. \u201cSeeing the place is really helpful in developing the plot, because if I don\u2019t go, there are things I simply won\u2019t know,\u201d she explains. \u201cFor example, for the new book I went to Ludlow, and when I visited the police station, it was closed. There was an intercom and video-camera setup at the building which connected people with the police and emergency services. That became a hugely important plot point in the book.\u201d\n\nGeorge\u2019s knowledge about the inner workings of New Scotland Yard is so exhaustive \u2014 and her understanding of class issues in British society so finely tuned \u2014 that some readers profess surprise when they learn she is American. How, they ask, can she turn out novels with such a distinctly British flavor? \u201cThe reality is very simple. I set my novels in England because I like to write about England,\u201d she says on her website. \u201cWhy on earth do people find it so weird that I write about England? It worked well enough for Henry James.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s the Connection Between John Steinbeck and Elizabeth George?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "These demonstrations gave birth to a small generation of anti-authoritarian, left-wing and nonpartisan militants, who kept protesting for subsequent years over all kinds of issues. They have been dismissed as thugs, vandals, political pawns or simply ineffectual. (That last accusation may not be completely inaccurate.) But now, they are also being held accountable for the right wing\u2019s advance in Brazilian politics and for the impeachment of the former President Dilma Rousseff.\n\n\u201cWe were hasty in thinking that 2013 was democratic,\u201d Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva, the popular former president and an icon of the Brazilian left, said last year. \u201cI sincerely believe that Ms. Rousseff\u2019s impeachment would not have occurred were it not for the June Journeys,\u201d wrote Fernando Haddad, the former mayor of S\u00e3o Paulo and a prominent figure in Mr. da Silva\u2019s Workers\u2019 Party. \u201cIn my opinion, it was when the coup started,\u201d Mr. da Silva tweeted in January.\n\nWhy do these left-wing politicians see the decidedly left-wing protesters as agents of the right? Well, in part because it\u2019s easy to feel anxious about an uncontrollable, leaderless, movement with pluralistic demands. But there\u2019s another reason. After June 2013, some people protested against political corruption as a whole, including the Workers\u2019 Party, which was in power at the time. This eventually resulted in five big right-wing street demonstrations demanding the ouster of Ms. Rousseff, the elected president who came from the Workers Party. The right-wing demonstrators got their wish in August 2016.\n\nBut there\u2019s no straight line that runs from the 2013 protests to the 2016 impeachment. The street rallies weren\u2019t the golden opportunity they were all waiting for to take down Ms. Rousseff, nor were they the main factor that finally enabled them to seize power. After all, many on the right worked with the Rousseff administration. (Remember that President Michel Temer was Ms. Rousseff\u2019s vice president.) Nor did the right \u201chijack\u201d an intrinsically anarchic movement, considering the fact that many other people have kept on holding their own progressive rallies, small but pretty inconvenient. (See, for example, the demonstrations against the 2014 World Cup. Back then, criticizing the event for any reason was considered an affront to the governing left.)\n\nThat view is simplistic and only serves to evade the burden of responsibility. In 13 years of Workers\u2019 Party rule, the traditional left missed many crucial opportunities to effectively change Brazil. Now they need someone else to blame for their losses. And the current scapegoat seems to be the protesters of the far left \u2014 those who dared to criticize the Workers\u2019 Party\u2019s decisions in the past.", "title": "Opinion | What\u2019s the Use of Protesting?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "TEMA, Ghana \u2014 As recently as the 1980s, the West African nation of Ghana was in crisis, crippled by hunger after a series of military coups. But it has held peaceful elections since 1992, and its economic outlook turned considerably brighter about a decade ago, with the discovery of major offshore oil deposits.\n\nNow, as oil prices rise again and the country\u2019s oil production rapidly expands, Ghana is on track to make a remarkable claim for a country mired in poverty not long ago: It is likely to have one of the world\u2019s fastest-growing economies this year, according to the World Bank, the African Development Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the Brookings Institution.\n\nIts projected growth in 2018, between 8.3 and 8.9 percent, might outpace even India, with its booming tech sector, and Ethiopia, which over the last decade has been one of Africa\u2019s fastest-growing economies thanks to expanding agricultural production and coffee exports.\n\nAccording to the I.M.F.\u2019s projections, only Bhutan, with a minuscule economy, and Libya, whose war-ravaged economy plunged in recent years, may have a higher rate of growth this year.", "title": "What\u2019s the World\u2019s Fastest-Growing Economy? Ghana Contends for the Crown", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "I am scratching my mother\u2019s head. Her hair is quite thin now and I no longer bother to make an appointment in the nursing home\u2019s \u201csalon\u201d for a cut. It is just another trauma to her, as is taking a shower. When the aides give her a shower I can hear her screaming all the way down the hall, shrieking like a feral cat.\n\nI am scratching the head of the woman who more than once told me she would cut off my arm and beat me with the bloody stump when, as a child, I angered her about something. Now she leans back into my hand like the cat she has become, almost purring, after the horror of the shower and the indignity of being dressed and put into her wheelchair for the day. Most days she just gets a sponge bath which elicits protests, often biting, and always my mother finding the most tender spot on a caregiver\u2019s upper arm and pinching it hard.\n\nAt lunch I pull apart small pieces of a peanut butter sandwich and my mother lets me feed it to her. With her terrible teeth, which used to be gorgeous and white, she rolls the tiny morsel of food around in her mouth until it seems to be gone. Sometimes when I offer another bite she shakes her head. Sometimes she opens her mouth. Then we have cake. She likes cake.\n\nLater I stroke the inside of her arm, the smooth, soft part that seems to be connected directly to the brain. She closes her eyes and I sit in a chair next to her wheelchair whose wheels I have locked down so she cannot roll away, and I stroke her arm. Once upon a time when things were good, which they sometimes were, I would sit down next to my mother and hold out my arm, inside part up, and she would almost unconsciously stroke it. She did this when I had my first panic attack at 15. Now, when I am anxious on an airplane or cannot sleep, my husband tickles me gently there and my breathing slows, my heart quiets.", "title": "When Alzheimer\u2019s Makes Room for Love", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "But bondsmen have extraordinary powers that most lenders do not. They are supposed to return their clients to jail if they skip court or do something illegal. But some states give them broad latitude to arrest their clients for any reason \u2014 or none at all. A credit card company cannot jail someone for missing a payment. A bondsman, in many instances, can.\n\nUsing that leverage, bond agents can charge steep fees, some of which are illegal, with impunity, according to interviews and a review of court records and complaint data. They can also go far beyond the demands of other creditors by requiring their clients to check in regularly, keep a curfew, allow searches of their car or home at any time, and open their medical, Social Security and phone records to inspection.\n\nThey keep a close eye on their clients, but in many places, no one is keeping a close eye on them.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a consumer protection issue,\u201d said Judge Lee V. Coffee, a criminal court judge in Memphis. Before recent changes to the rules there, he said, defendants frequently complained of shakedowns in which bondsmen demanded extra payments. \u201cThey\u2019re living under a constant daily threat that \u2018if you don\u2019t bring more money, we\u2019re going to put you in jail.\u2019\u201d The pressure, the judge said, \u201cwould actually encourage people to go out and commit more crimes.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUnlike payday lenders, the bail bond industry deals with potential criminals whose very involvement with the law raises questions about their trustworthiness. But in the United States criminal justice system, the Supreme Court has affirmed, liberty before trial is supposed to be the norm, not the exception \u2014 the system is intended to allow defendants to stay out of jail.\n\nSome bail bond practices have drawn the ire of judges who complain that payment plans are too lenient on people accused of serious crimes, allowing them to get out for just a few hundred dollars or even no money down. Those judges say it should be more difficult for the accused to walk free.\n\nOther judges see some bondsmen as trampling the rights of defendants. One judge in Lafayette, La., Jules Edwards III, held in contempt two bondsmen who were brothers for intercepting a defendant on his way to court and sending him, instead, to jail.\n\nThe judge said the commercial bail industry had put its financial interests above justice and public safety. \u201cIf he\u2019s not in compliance with the contract, sue him. How do you get to snatch his body and hold him hostage?\u201d Judge Edwards said in a phone interview.\n\nHe added that defendants do not have to go with their bondsmen unless there is a warrant out for their arrest, but many of them do not know that. \u201cWhat they\u2019re doing is intimidating and coercing and lying,\u201d he said. The brothers declined to comment.\n\nIn both Mr. Egana\u2019s case and this one, the bondsmen would not have been on the hook for the defendants\u2019 failure to appear, because they diverted the defendants from court dates for unrelated cases, not the ones for which they had bailed them out.\n\nThe bond agency, Blair\u2019s Bail Bonds, stopped Mr. Egana, who had prior felony convictions, from going to court on charges of fleeing an officer, but had bailed him out in June 2016 after he was arrested on charges of possession of marijuana, a firearm and stolen property.\n\nHad Mr. Egana been wealthier, he might have been able to post his full bail of $26,000, then gotten it back when he returned for court. But like most defendants, Mr. Egana had to turn to a commercial bail bond agent that charges a nonrefundable fee for the service of guaranteeing the bond.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNot only could Mr. Egana not afford the full bail, he could not afford the fee, $3,275. He arranged to pay it in installments. After his release, he said, Blair\u2019s informed him that on top of the premium, he would have to pay $10 a day for an ankle monitor, though the judge had not ordered one. Guilty or innocent, Mr. Egana would never see any of that money again. Blair\u2019s has denied any wrongdoing in the matter.\n\nSome customers feel they have no choice but to pay bond agents\u2019 fees \u2014 no matter how outrageous they seem. When a home health care aide wanted to bail her son out of Rikers Island in New York City, she was charged $1,000 to have a courier walk her money a few blocks to the courthouse.\n\nA defendant in a serious domestic violence case in Santa Clara, Calif., suffering from a dangerous heart condition, had to have his ankle monitor removed each time he went to the hospital, and was forced to pay $300 to have it put back on afterward.\n\nA woman in Des Moines woke one morning to find that her 2001 Pontiac Grand Prix had been repossessed during the night. Had she put up her car as collateral in a typical loan, she would have been notified that she had fallen behind and given 20 days to pay.\n\nBut instead, the car was collateral for a bail bond for her child\u2019s father. She owed $700 to the bail agents. They not only took the car, but turned the father over to the jail. Ultimately the misdemeanor assault charges against him were dismissed.\n\nThe bond agents in the Lafayette, New York, Santa Clara and Des Moines cases declined to comment. But Jeffrey J. Clayton, the executive director of the American Bail Coalition, an industry group, said that credit bonds, as the payment plans are called, should be more tightly regulated and require at least a minimum down payment. However, he said, any rules should preserve the benefit to the customer, namely, \u201cIf you have the ability to pay it, just not right now, you can get out right now.\u201d\n\nBond companies fall into a sort of regulatory gulf between criminal courts and state insurance departments, which are supposed to regulate them but seldom impose sanctions. With rare exception, defense lawyers and prosecutors are too busy with their caseloads to keep bond companies in line. Further complicating things, it is often unclear whether consumer protection laws apply, and insurance departments say they lack the resources to investigate complaints.\n\nIn the case of Mr. Egana, who worked as a carpenter, it did not take long for him to fall behind on his payments. But he thought that since he was routinely showing up to court, he would be fine.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe was wrong. The bond company detained him several more times, according to court records. At one point, two men with guns and bulletproof vests came to the home where he was working as a contractor and forced him into a car. Each time, they demanded that his mother pay more money.\n\nJeffrey Orey, a spokesman for Blair\u2019s Bail Bonds, while denying any wrongdoing, declined to comment on the specifics of Mr. Egana\u2019s lawsuit. He said the company had never charged interest or assessed penalties for late payment. The lawsuit, brought by the Southern Poverty Law Center on behalf of Mr. Egana and alleging violation of consumer lending laws, says Mr. Egana\u2019s mother paid at least $5,450 \u2014 or almost two times the original premium \u2014 to keep her son out of jail. Some of her money, the lawsuit says, was applied to older debts that Mr. Egana still owed.\n\n\u201cIt was kidnapping,\u201d Mr. Egana said. \u201cThey saw the love that my mom has for me, and they used that to their advantage.\u201d\n\nIn May, Blair\u2019s decided it no longer wanted Mr. Egana as a customer and handed him over to the jail.\n\nSiphoning Millions From Poor", "title": "When Bail Feels Less Like Freedom, More Like Extortion", "authors": ["Jessica Silver-Greenberg", "Shaila Dewan"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Erich Ely, the facilities manager at Columbia University, said he started hearing from Big Ten programs four months ago, when the conference wanted to declare Levien Gymnasium as its \u201cofficial practice home\u201d for the week. The problem? Columbia\u2019s men\u2019s basketball team was still trying to win the Ivy League, and the home team obviously gets priority.\n\nEly still managed to squeeze in practice time for Michigan, Iowa and Penn State last week, and then DePaul, Georgetown and Xavier this week. He took care to make sure that there were at least 15 minutes between sessions for the teams, who could wind up facing each other in their tournaments.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t want to have a Jets-and-Sharks moment when they\u2019re passing each other in the hallway,\u201d Ely joked.\n\nDan McDermott, the director of basketball operations for Boston College, said the top priority was finding a court not too far from the hotel where the team was staying. Spending hours trying to fight midday traffic for a 90-minute practice is less than ideal.\n\n\u201cThat can kill the whole afternoon,\u201d McDermott said.\n\nBut teams also want a certain amount of privacy. That can be hard for some gyms to deliver. Chelsea Piers, the indoor sports and entertainment complex on Manhattan\u2019s West Side, reached out to McDermott about hosting the Eagles last year, he said. But he had concerns about the intimacy.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not sure that was actually private,\u201d he said. \u201cI think they would section it off.\u201d\n\nThe gym at John Jay, known as the Doghouse, includes a balcony for spectators during games, but it is kept restricted during the times when visiting teams are practicing. The college, part of the City University of New York system, charges up to $300 per hour for teams to rent the space. Columbia has charged $500 in the past, but Ely said that practice had largely gone by the wayside.\n\n\u201cWe sort of try to be an open, friendly place,\u201d Ely said. \u201cWe like having them here.\u201d\n\nPaul Brazeau, a senior associate commissioner for the A.C.C., said the league made the court at Barclays Center in Brooklyn, where the tournament is being held, available on Monday for the 11 teams that had games Tuesday and Wednesday.", "title": "When College Basketball Teams Invade New York, an Empty Gym Is Hard to Find", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "What did the Mark Grotjahn painting above the couch say to you?\n\nCOHEN I\u2019m so proud of this. He had made these butterfly paintings. I started going from show to show, and I would see them in different variations, different colors. This one came up for auction at Christie\u2019s. I was very lucky. Now they\u2019re in the millions, and you can\u2019t get them.\n\nSomehow, I\u2019ve been really lucky in picking pieces that have appreciated. From the beginning, I not only wanted to have the best artists. I wanted to have the best representations. Really having the best work of a top artist is even more of a coup. I can say it proudly of this work.\n\nThrough Galerie and your own efforts, what have you learned about how to live with art?\n\nCOHEN If you\u2019re lucky enough, you start with the right pieces that really bring the sentiment and the feeling to the space. Then you design around it. Originally, I had the de Kooning on this wall. No offense to Bill de Kooning, but when I saw this Grotjahn piece, I thought, wow, this will tie it all in. The butterfly central spiral brings everything together in the room.\n\nWhat\u2019s the feeling after you buy a piece?\n\nCOHEN It\u2019s certainly a high. To have a great master painter in your own home elevates you. It just makes you feel so different about the space. When I look at them, I can\u2019t believe I\u2019m living with these incredibly talented artistic people.\n\nIs there a blank wall waiting to be filled? And if so, by what?\n\nCOHEN Well, I\u2019d love to have a Picasso. One of the hardest things about being an art collector is when you start to run low on wall space. There just aren\u2019t enough walls.", "title": "When Contemporary Art Speaks to This Collector, She Listens", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "The researchers then used this data set to test several genetic and historical hypotheses, showing \u201cyou can harness the hard work of so many people around the globe just documenting their own family history, and learn something about humanity,\u201d said Yaniv Erlich, the chief science officer of MyHeritage, the parent company of Geni.com, and senior author of the paper.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very impressive as a data collection and harmonization effort, and of course they have only scratched the surface of what it might have to offer,\u201d said Philip Cohen, a sociology professor at the University of Maryland, who was not involved in the research.\n\nThe study is the latest example of scientists using big, crowdsourced data collected by private companies to do research. Last year, one study spearheaded by Ancestry.com mapped North American migrations. There have also been efforts to track food poisoning via Yelp reviews and drug usage via Instagram.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe trend raises new questions for researchers to think about, such as how representative such data are of populations at large, and whether commercial entities like Geni.com have vested interests, said Emily Klancher Merchant, a science and technology studies professor at the University of California, Davis.\n\n\u201cWhen private companies control the data and fund the research, they\u2019re the ones gatekeeping what kind of science gets done,\u201d she said. A DNA testing company might be more interested, for instance, in financing studies that discover sellable genetic markers rather than open-ended, basic research.\n\nWhat\u2019s interesting about genealogies, however, is that there aren\u2019t much better ways to get data currently. In the past, researchers had to laboriously cobble together church records or local birth and death certificates to construct large family trees.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWith crowdsourced genealogy, \u201cwe have the ability to connect a much more vast network of individuals and locations around the world, in a faster, cheaper way,\u201d said Dr. Erlich, who is also a computer science professor at Columbia University.\n\nGeni.com has millions of users worldwide, and the website allows its members to merge trees, in an effort to create a single, massive family tree for the world.\n\nDr. Erlich and his collaborators took steps to validate the company\u2019s trees, then reported several new findings from the data, such as a lower heritability of life span than others have reported, and a greater likelihood of mothers to migrate than fathers.\n\nBut with all of their findings, it\u2019s important to consider that not everyone is represented equally.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like reading a Jane Austen novel \u2014 it gives you lots of great insights, but you have to be careful about generalizing to society as a whole,\u201d Dr. Cohen said.\n\nIn addition to likely underreporting infant mortalities and people who never bore children, genealogy data skews toward families that have the privilege of accessing and maintaining a detailed history, Dr. Merchant said. Sites like Geni.com require a paid membership to access all features. And families that were forced to migrate, through the slave trade or to flee persecution, are probably not as well-represented in their databases.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile these studies have limitations, they also offer opportunities. Biomedical research that marries family trees with genetic and health information could lead to new discoveries about heritable disease risk. In social sciences, genealogies merged with census and tax records could yield findings on things like inequality.\n\n\u201cAs soon as you start linking these things, your analytical power goes way up \u2014 as do privacy risks,\u201d Dr. Cohen said.\n\nWith any of these efforts, he added, it\u2019s important to insist \u201cthat the norms of science, as far as transparency and openness, still apply.\u201d", "title": "When Did Americans Stop Marrying Their Cousins? Ask the World\u2019s Largest Family Tree", "authors": ["Steph Yin"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "This quirky bit of medical history opens Abby Norman\u2019s vivid memoir, \u201cAsk Me About My Uterus.\u201d But the focus of the book is really in the subtitle: \u201cA Quest to Make Doctors Believe in Women\u2019s Pain.\u201d She builds a convincing case that women describing discomfort are more likely than men to be dismissed by physicians, but along the way tells a story that will resonate with anyone (man or woman) who has ever experienced pain.\n\nImage Credit Alessandra Montalto/The New York Times\n\nNorman suffers from endometriosis \u2014 a chronic and debilitating illness triggered by uterine-like cells growing outside of the womb. Women with the disorder have heavy, agonizing periods along with a litany of other symptoms depending on where the rogue cells lurk. If they congregate near the bladder, urinating hurts; near the sciatic nerve, pain can shoot down the legs; inside the lung (a rare event), breathing can be stifled.\n\nAfter one bout \u2014 \u201cas sudden as a thunderclap. A stabbing pain in my middle\u201d \u2014 Norman eventually got to an emergency room, where she was handed the typical 1-10 pain scorecard. She was still aching, but not in the original horrors of it all. So she didn\u2019t know how to assign a number to it: \u201cBad enough that I couldn\u2019t ignore it, which made it definitely higher than a four or five.\u201d She questioned whether she was a six or higher and whether the doctor would believe her anyhow.\n\nNorman repeatedly told doctors that sexual intercourse ached \u201clike a dull pinch, that resonated to my pelvis.\u201d No one paid attention until her boyfriend accompanied her and mentioned his frustration. \u201cBecoming a disappointment to a man,\u201d she writes, \u201cseemed to do the trick.\u201d\n\nNorman is a terrific storyteller with a gift for weaving memorable anecdotes, some drawn from medical history, others from recent scientific debates and most plucked from her own travails. We learn about Sigmund Freud and his views of his \u201chysterical\u201d female clients. We read about baby monkeys who grew up with emotional issues because their real cuddly moms were removed at birth and replaced with pretend wire-doll monkey-mothers. We learn of recent ideas challenging long-held notions about the origins of endometriosis. Many experts no longer believe the disease is triggered by uterine cells that escaped the womb, but rather by uterine-like cells that originated outside of it.\n\nNorman\u2019s life is much more than a disease. She emancipated herself from her family at the age of 16 and sought solace in books, particularly scientific literature, to understand her symptoms. Many doctors chalked up her distress to physical expressions of a psychic trauma.", "title": "When Doctors Don\u2019t Listen to Women", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "For fans of the series, the book offers a chance to revisit six fascinating lives. Its ensemble cast includes Helen Moses, 91, who falls in love with her neighbor, Howie, at a Bronx nursing home; Fred Jones, 88, who struggles to reach his third-floor walk-up apartment after gangrene claimed parts of two toes; Ping Wong, 90, originally from Hong Kong, who lucked into subsidized housing and fills her days with mah-jongg; Ruth Willig, 91, who must readjust after an unwanted move from one assisted-living facility to another; Jonas Mekas, 92, a Lithuanian-born filmmaker who dedicates his life to art; and the sad-eyed but dignified Sorensen, who has longed to die ever since Walter, his partner of 60 years, passed away in 2009.\n\nTheir stories are appealingly diverse, but therein lies Leland\u2019s greatest challenge. How does a columnist knit together a series of free-ranging articles \u2014 a sequence of portraits captured in real time, featuring disparate topics and voices? Some publish collections. Others add connective tissue. Leland chose to do the latter, grafting in material from many origins. He cites research findings. He quotes sages ranging from Seneca, the Stoic philosopher, to James Brown and Jack Kerouac. (Leland is also the author of \u201cWhy Kerouac Matters: The Lessons of \u2018On the Road\u2019\u201d and \u201cHip: The History.\u201d) He embeds his own struggles \u2014 relating to an aging mother, starting over after a divorce \u2014 as a quiet throughline. But mostly Leland adds self-help, sprung from a single axiom: \u201cIf you want to be happy, learn to think like an old person.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThat choice is disappointing. Americans spend $1 billion on self-help books each year. \u201cHappiness Is a Choice You Make\u201d feels like part of that hard sell: a relentless process of extrusion. The morals of the story, forced from the raw material of human lives, quickly overshadow the action and characters. \u201cThe good news about getting old is that there is good news,\u201d Leland announces. \u201cWhat the elders had discovered, I began to see, was not just a preparation for death but a prescription for life at any age.\u201d\n\nThe author has a flair for showmanship, treating this \u201cprescription\u201d like a powerful elixir that he has tested, with salubrious results, on his own life. He laments not finding it sooner, urges readers to take a taste. \u201cContentment had been there for the grasping, if only I had recognized it,\u201d he writes. \u201cProbably it\u2019s there for you.\u201d\n\nUnfortunately, the \u201clessons\u201d on offer aren\u2019t as compelling as the raw experiences from which they\u2019re derived. They are a slurry of positive-psychology platitudes, with occasional dashes of Buddhism and even EST.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLive in the present. Focus on the good things. Find your purpose. Love unconditionally. Accept adversity. Feel gratitude. Acknowledge that \u201cproblems were only problems if you thought about them that way. Otherwise they were life \u2014 and yours for the living.\u201d\n\nThe book even goes so far as to suggest a positive side to cognitive decline: \u201clearning how to use memory loss as an advantage,\u201d a tool for wiping away bad experiences to attain greater happiness.\n\nMany of these conclusions come early in the book. As a result, when Leland sets off on his journey to find meaning from the elders\u2019 lives, there are few surprises. The stories feel like beams supporting a house to which he\u2019s already revealed the blueprint.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI found myself wondering how the elders felt about having their experiences strip-mined for lessons. The author explains how \u201cFred\u2019s found fulfillment in the present, because the future might not come,\u201d while \u201cPing kept her spirits up by accepting her pains as a part of life.\u201d When, late in the book, he shrugs off a woman\u2019s suggestion that \u201cI was reading too much into things,\u201d it\u2019s hard not to laugh. She\u2019s got his number \u2014 he is old-splaining.\n\nAs it turns out, you don\u2019t need sugar to make lemonade. Remember Sorensen, who spoke so candidly about wanting to die? Even he becomes a case study in gladness. \u201cThe lesson of John Sorensen was that to accept death was to accept life, and to accept life was to live in joy, however dire the circumstances around you,\u201d the book explains.\n\nBut actions speak louder than anything and, in that sense, Sorensen got the final word when he died last year. Fittingly, Leland wrote about it. The headline read: \u201cSomewhere John Sorensen Is Smiling.\u201d", "title": "When Growing Old Is a Blessing", "authors": ["Jessica Bruder", "John Leland"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "My family in Haiti, where I was born and raised, was captivated by the smart and educated character played by Sidney Poitier in \u201cGuess Who\u2019s Coming to Dinner.\u201d He made us feel proud. The powerful message was that this black man and his white fianc\u00e9e were facing her family (and the world) and saying that was O.K. I think it was the first time I thought to myself: Love trumps color, race, culture, and even fear.\n\n\u2014 Vanessa Ricot, project manager, marketing\n\nMy mother was American and my father Colombian, and Lucy and Ricky on \u201cI love Lucy\u201d were the first ethnically mixed, semi-bilingual couple I had seen on TV. The show, which I saw reruns of as a child in the 1980s, introduced ideas like culture clash; it lightly made fun of American cluelessness about other countries, in the figures of Fred and Ethel.\n\nA comic genius, Lucy used slapstick and crocodile tears to combat her husband\u2019s machismo \u2014 and when you look at how Latina actors in her position are still forced to play stereotypes of the docile wife or the sexy spitfire, that still looks radical today.\n\n\u2014 Annie Correal, reporter, metropolitan news\n\nI am not athletic, British or Indian. But Parminder Nagra, who played Jess Bhamra in \u201cBend it Like Beckham,\u201d was close enough. She loved her traditional brown family, but she was fiercely independent and a talented soccer player. She even nabbed the hot (white) boyfriend over the Keira Knightley character. She was everything the tween in me wanted the chance to be.\n\n\u2014 Fahima Haque, editor, social media\n\nI didn\u2019t see myself in someone who looked particularly like me, but rather in someone who matched my passion for the performing arts. I fell in love with the movie \u201cSelena\u201d because of the singing and dancing. It was one of the first movies I saw with a leading Latina actress.", "title": "When Hollywood Is Our Mirror", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "The film industry\u2019s historic lack of representation prompted us at Race/Related to ask: When was the first time you saw yourself represented on the silver screen?\n\nWe published our responses in an article, \u201cWhen Hollywood Is Our Mirror.\u201d Then we asked for your answers to the same question. About 100 readers responded. Here are a selection of them, lightly edited for clarity and length.\n\n\u201cThe Brothers Garcia\u201d on Nickelodeon. It was my happiest TV day ever! The family on TV looked and acted very much like mine, and everybody at school loved it! The show gave me the \u201cendorsement\u201d I had been craving all my (short) life.\n\n\u2014 Alex Gonzalez\n\nThe first time I saw myself on the big screen was when \u201cGone With the Wind\u201d came out and had Hattie McDaniel as the maid. I am 74 years old and I have seen a lot of racism in my life but \u201cGone With the Wind\u201d was the worst. It depicted a black women as a slave, who at the same time had power. At the time of the film I didn\u2019t really understand a lot about racism and the fact that I was a second-class person. A lot has changed, but a lot has not.", "title": "When Hollywood Is Your Mirror", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Advisers, Ms. Iarussi said, may spot red flags that idealistic funders may miss. \u201cWe want to see the best in everyone,\u201d she said, adding that \u201cyou need a little bit more objectivity, or you can get carried away.\u201d\n\nTo help ensure their philanthropy is being used effectively, donors are increasingly seeking the help of professionals.\n\n\u201cPhilanthropic advising has grown as philanthropy has become more complex,\u201d said Una Osili, associate dean for research and international programs at the Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy.\n\nA family foundation may be overwhelmed with funding requests and need help vetting programs, evaluating proposals and monitoring grants. Services offered by philanthropic advisers vary, but often involve helping funders identify causes they are passionate about supporting and map out a giving strategy.\n\nPhoto\n\nAdvisers typically work with donors to help them find specific groups that will make good use of their contributions, assess financial and operating information, and help establish a system for measuring results. Many offer administrative or back-office support, handling tasks like soliciting proposals and mailing checks. They can also serve as gatekeepers, buffering donors from excessive grant requests. Some charge fees based on an hourly estimate, or on a group\u2019s grant-making capacity; others charge annual subscription fees.\n\n\u201cOur mission is to help funders increase the effectiveness of their philanthropy,\u201d said Leslie Pine, managing partner with the Philanthropic Initiative, a Boston-based advisory firm.\n\nMs. Iarussi said her family began working with the Philanthropic Initiative when her family\u2019s foundation was established 15 years ago. She and her relatives had seen other families struggle to identify funding priorities. \u201cWe knew others who were winging it,\u201d she said, and sought a more formal structure.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWorking with the group, she and her family, including two uncles who are also trustees, soon agreed on areas of emphasis, and a process for deciding what to fund. The foundation focuses on helping children in poverty, particularly those affected by the incarceration of a family member, as well as community building and environmental justice, which seeks to protect the poor and powerless from adverse environmental conditions. It gave away about $2 million in 2016.\n\nShe credits the Philanthropic Initiative with helping her family learn how to conduct in-person assessments of charities. \u201cI\u2019m a big fan of site visits,\u201d she said. Once, she showed up to meet with leaders of a small nonprofit and quickly realized that the group had not told her that it was being evicted from its offices; boxes of files were stacked for relocation. The foundation still funded the group, she said, but the visit prompted a conversation about transparency.\n\nDonors can do very basic early sleuthing themselves because of digital information. An essential first step, for instance, is verifying that a potential grant recipient is qualified as tax exempt. Eligibility can be verified instantly online, through GuideStar\u2019s nonprofit tracker, Charity Check.\n\nAdvisers typically dig deeper into the details of the group\u2019s financial reports; talk to their contacts in the field, as well as the group\u2019s leaders and existing donors; and arrange site visits.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIf you really want to have an impact, it takes some work,\u201d said Henry L. Berman, chief executive of Exponent Philanthropy, a nonprofit that guides and educates a membership network of small, sparsely staffed foundations. \u201cDon\u2019t just Google \u2018middle school arts programs in New York City\u2019 and write a check.\u2019\u201d\n\nCautionary signs when assessing a charity, he said, include revenue that is decreasing; a deficit that is increasing, particularly over several years; unexplained variances from the proposed budget; and missing documents. Such findings are not necessarily deal breakers, he said, but warrant further inquiries.\n\nDonors may also be wary of a group\u2019s overhead \u2014 the spending for staff, office space and support services \u2014 or the amount it spends fund-raising. Some online nonprofit watchdogs, like Charity Navigator, rate charities based on the proportion of funds spent on administration and fund-raising. While such spending is a consideration, many advisers say, they caution donors that it must be considered in context.\n\n\u201cYou have to keep in mind what\u2019s required for the staff to actually achieve their mission,\u201d said Betsy Brill, president of Strategic Philanthropy, an advisory firm in Chicago. A nonprofit providing mental health services, for instance, likely needs doctors, lawyers and psychiatrists, and such professionals tend to receive higher salaries.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSimilarly, a group\u2019s financial statements cannot be read in isolation, Ms. Brill said. Expecting a small nonprofit to maintain, say, a reserve of two years of operating expenses may be unrealistic.\n\nAnd while a group running a deficit is a concern, it also needs to be evaluated with additional information. \u201cIs it an ongoing issue?\u201d she said. \u201cOr is it a one-time problem?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nNeil Gobioff, president of the Gobioff Foundation, a private grant maker in Tampa, Fla., that supports the arts and social justice causes, said the foundation\u2019s grants are relatively small \u2014 $6,000 on average. But that amount can be significant for small arts groups, so it is important that the funds are used wisely. The foundation ran into at least one problem, he said, when a grant recipient did not use funds as specified.\n\nThat led to some changes, Mr. Gobioff said, with the help of Foundation Source, which provides advice and back-office services to foundations. Previously, the Gobioff Foundation would mail checks to recipients with letters stating terms of the grant; cashing the check meant the recipient agreed to the rules as outlined. But in this case, the recipient claimed that the person responsible for the grant was never made aware of its requirements. So the foundation changed its approach. \u201cNow we require a signed letter\u201d acknowledging acceptance of the grant terms, he said, before any checks are presented.\n\nSome donors avoid fledgling organizations, in favor of more established, high-performing nonprofits that may be seen as less risky. But Janis A. Reischmann, executive director of the Hau\u2019oli Mau Loa Foundation in Honolulu, said her organization was willing to back groups at early stages.In 2009, she recalled, the foundation funded an organization that had $500 in the bank and a new executive director. \u201cThere was a lot of risk in that,\u201d she said. But the foundation had faith in the director and the group\u2019s board. \u201cWe felt if anybody could make it happen, they could.\u201d\n\nThat bet paid off.
