The group, she said, was on sounder financial footing within five years.", "title": "When It Comes to Donating Money, Whom Do You Trust?", "authors": ["Ann Carrns"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Upstairs, they added dormers and skylights. Downstairs, they ripped out the addition and extended the central foyer by 12 feet for extra living space and a larger kitchen. The back porch was enclosed for a dining area with insulated windows overlooking the water.\n\nNearing the end of her work, Ms. Doermann went to inspect the house. All that remained were final decisions on the interior paint colors and spots to be patched on the siding and roof. Lightning rods lay on the living room floor, ready to be installed.\n\nAnd so they remained the next day, when lightning hit. \u201cIf the barn had caught, the fire would have spread to the whole town,\u201d Mr. Cogan said. The bucket brigade saved it and the century-old one-room schoolhouse next door, but not Chapin House. The top floor was incinerated and water ruined the rest.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe couple discussed remodeling again. \u201cBut nobody could guarantee that we would get rid of the burnt smell,\u201d Mr. Cogan said. Anyway, it would have been just as costly to salvage the remains as to knock them down and rebuild. This time, they started from scratch.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe couple decided the 2,500-square-foot replacement home would be a replica of the destroyed one. \u201cContext was important,\u201d Ms. Allen said. A modern building would have clashed with the nearby gabled stone town hall and 19th-century Congregational church. So a new Chapin House rose on the old stone foundation.\n\nTo save time, even mainlanders on the construction team lived on Isle au Haut on and off from August 2009 through June 2010.\u201cDuring the winter, it was hard enough to get materials to the island and get waste off it,\u201d Ms. Doermann said, never mind the workers. The mail boat that ferried between the mainland and town dock could transport small loads, but large barges were needed for lumber and Dumpsters and were often delayed by tides and weather.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cPerhaps that\u2019s why islanders don\u2019t get rid of things and reuse what\u2019s there,\u201d Ms. Doermann said. \u201cMany houses have pieces from other houses because of that ingrained mentality of recycling.\u201d\n\nIndeed, Bill Stevens, the roads commissioner-turned-contractor who did the septic site work, gathered Chapin House\u2019s charred but usable frame and windows to build a painting studio for his wife.\n\nMs. Doermann turned her energies to reclamation, as well. Pine beams from a Boston warehouse were milled for the new house\u2019s main-level flooring (now with radiant heat), while the hand-hewn floorboards upstairs came from a Nova Scotia barn.", "title": "When Lightning Strikes Back", "authors": ["Zahid Sardar"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "The Teams\n\nLoyola\u2019s integrated team was the Midwest\u2019s best, in the top 5 nationally all season and 19-2 heading into the tournament. Point guard Jerry Harkness was the star, an All-American who went on to play for the Knicks. Les Hunter and Vic Rouse dominated the boards.\n\nPhoto\n\nMississippi State, led by Leland Mitchell, was also a top 10 team. But while Loyola played a geographically diverse schedule, Mississippi State stayed in the South, playing only teams without black players. Indeed, Mississippi State had won the two previous Southeastern Conference titles, but it had turned down invitations to the N.C.A.A. tournament because of the probability of facing a team with black players.\n\nBefore the Game\n\nBy the end of the 1962-63 regular season, things were changing. Mississippi State\u2019s players and coaches wanted no more of the \u201cunwritten law\u201d and planned to prove themselves in the N.C.A.A. tournament. The university president, D.W. Colvard, announced that this time the team was in.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLoyola won its preliminary game, 111-42, over Tennessee Tech, still the biggest margin ever in a tournament game. That set up the match against Mississippi State in the round of 16 in East Lansing, Mich.\n\nYet there were still plenty of people who did not want the game played. One of them was Mississippi\u2019s governor, Ross R. Barnett. In 1960, he had said of integrated sports: \u201cIf there were a half-dozen Negroes on the team, where are they going to eat? Are they going to want to go to the dance later and want to dance with our girls?\u201d\n\nA special meeting of the state college board was called. It voted, 8-3, to let the team play. Segregationists turned to the courts and won an injunction, but it was overturned by a state Supreme Court judge a day before the game.\n\nBut the team was still concerned about further legal action, to the point that it turned to subterfuge. The second string was sent to the Starkville airport first, as decoys, to draw out any lawyers wielding further injunctions. Had one arrived, the first team, hiding in their dormitory, would have been spirited away by some other method.\n\nBut when the coast was determined to be clear, the team flew to Michigan together. Coach Babe McCarthy had been sent out of state, to Nashville, and joined the team when its plane stopped there.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt was cloak-and-dagger stuff,\u201d said Mitchell, who died in 2013. \u201cIt was almost like cops and robbers.\u201d\n\nThe Game\n\nAfter the intrigue that preceded it, the game was free of trouble. There were friendly handshakes before and after. Loyola got 20 points on 7-of-11 shooting by its star, Harkness, and 19 rebounds from Rouse to win by 61-51.\n\n\u201cThere wasn\u2019t one incident,\u201d Mitchell said, \u201cand not because we weren\u2019t trying or trying to be nice.\u201d\n\nAftermath\n\nLoyola kept it up, beating Illinois and then Duke at the Final Four in Louisville. In the championship game, its opponent was formidable: the two-time defending champion, Cincinnati, which had been No. 1 all year. Loyola, using only five players the whole game, rallied to tie the score on a last-second shot by Harkness. Rouse scored off a missed shot to win it in overtime, 60-58.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLegacy\n\nIn 1965, Mississippi State admitted its first black student, Richard Holmes.\n\nCollege basketball continued to integrate, although slowly in some places. In 1966, a Texas Western team with five black starters beat an all-white Kentucky team in the N.C.A.A. final, a game immortalized in the 2006 film \u201cGlory Road.\u201d The SEC did not get its first black basketball player until 1967.\n\n\u201cThe recruiting of Negro athletes isn\u2019t as good as recruiting Negro brains would be,\u201d said Leslie W. Dunbar of the Southern Regional Council in 1963, \u201cbut it may be a start.\u201d\n\nLoyola\u2019s championship team was inducted in the College Basketball Hall of Fame in 2013, the only team so honored. It also remains the only team from Illinois to win the N.C.A.A. tournament.\n\nToday\n\nLoyola returned to the tournament in three of the next five years, but times have been tough since. An appearance in 1985 was followed by a 33-year drought that ended this season with the Final Four surprise.\n\nMississippi State did not return to the N.C.A.A. tournament until 1991, and made a run to the Final Four in 1996. It has not been back in the field since 2009, but made this year\u2019s NIT semifinal.\n\nAs in 1963, Loyola continues to have a mix of white and black players. The once segregated Mississippi State had more than a dozen black players on its roster.", "title": "When Loyola-Chicago Broke a Racial Barrier 55 Years Ago", "authors": ["Victor Mather"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Here is a look at the events that led to the hearings, and their aftermath.\n\nSafety advocates express alarm\n\nViolent video games began drawing the attention of the authorities shortly after they started showing up in arcades. In the 1970s, a game called Death Race, which required players to simulate hit-and-run killings from behind the wheel, was described by the National Safety Council as \u201csick, sick, sick.\u201d\n\nIn the 1980s, Dr. C. Everett Koop, the United States surgeon general, voiced concerns that video games might be detrimental to young people, who he said could become addicted to them \u201cbody and soul.\u201d\n\nBut by the early 1990s, concern had morphed into panic. Rhetoric about an epidemic of violence ran rampant, fueled by fears of teenage gangs and murderers. On Dec. 7, 1993, a gunman killed six people on a crowded Long Island Rail Road train during rush hour.\n\nNot long before, the intensely popular and extremely bloody arcade game Mortal Kombat had become available for home gaming systems. Players squared off against opponents in one-on-one fights; the victor could employ a character-specific \u201cfatality\u201d that allowed the winning avatar to tear out the loser\u2019s heart or execute some other coup de gr\u00e2ce.\n\nMortal Kombat\u2019s first iteration featured weapons, but no firearms.\n\nCongressional hearings, then a ratings system\n\nThe brutal game became a favorite target for critics of violence marketed to children, along with a more obscure game called Night Trap, whose premise involved a surveillance agent protecting teenage girls from blood-craving monsters.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Lieberman led the charge in denouncing such games as desensitizing young players. The same month as the Long Island train massacre, he spearheaded a series of congressional hearings into the influence of video games on real-world violence.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re talking about video games that glorify violence and teach children to enjoy inflicting the most gruesome forms of cruelty imaginable,\u201d he said at a news conference that December.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmid the growing concern, MTV ran a special called \u201cGeneration Under the Gun,\u201d in which teenagers discussed their relationships with firearms. Toys \u201cR\u201d Us vowed to stop selling Night Trap. The gaming industry formed its first trade group, which is now known as the Entertainment Software Association.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTo head off lawmakers\u2019 threats to form a federal commission to oversee video games, the organization quickly created a regulatory body known as the Entertainment Software Ratings Board. The board\u2019s rating system, largely modeled after the one used by the movie industry, assigned letter grades to video games based on their content, with the most violent games reserved for players 17 or older.\n\nThe industry promised the new system would be in place in time for the 1994 holiday buying season.\n\nA persistent political debate\n\nBut politicians and lobbyists from both sides of the aisle would continue to point to video games as a possible culprit in mass shootings.\n\nThe two teenage gunmen who killed 12 fellow students and a teacher at Columbine High School in 1999 were said to have played the first-person shooter game Doom, which led Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, to accuse Hollywood and computerized games as having \u201cundermined the core values of civility.\u201d\n\nA few months after the shooting, President Bill Clinton asked the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission to investigate how violent media, including video games, was being marketed to children.\n\nRegulatory efforts were stymied in 2011, when the Supreme Court blocked a California law that sought to ban the sale of violent video games to young people.\n\nBut in the aftermath of the deadly shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School the next year, President Barack Obama asked Congress for funds to research the effects of violence in video games.\n\nA generation grown up with violent games\n\nNearly 25 years have passed since the 1993 hearings, and video games are vastly more realistic and social, with gamers capable of participating in 100-person \u201cBattle Royale\u201d-style death matches.\n\nThe ratings system is generally considered to have been effective in keeping children from directly acquiring violent games, although many still find ways to get hold of them.\n\nAnd the prospect of legislative action seems to have faded.\n\n\u201cNow, there are very few legislators under 60 who don\u2019t have kids who play video games or who don\u2019t play themselves,\u201d said Michael Pachter, a video games analyst with Wedbush Securities. \u201cIt\u2019s just a different society now.\u201d", "title": "When Mortal Kombat Came Under Congressional Scrutiny", "authors": ["Tiffany Hsu"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQ. The city recently rolled out its organics pickup program in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where I live. It\u2019s a pain to lug my organics down to the green market, so I was excited to be able to dispose of organic waste as I do my trash or recycling. The management of my large luxury rental, however, has not signed up for the program. My neighbors and I have been trying to engage management for months, with no luck. Is there anything I can do to persuade them, or will I just have to hope that the city eventually makes the organics program compulsory?\n\nA. Five years ago, the city unveiled an organics collection program, starting with 3,000 households on Staten Island. Now, more than 3.3 million residents in parts of all five boroughs have access to curbside organics pickup. By year\u2019s end, all New Yorkers may have access to curbside or neighborhood drop-off, according to the Department of Sanitation, which operates the program.\n\nAsk Real Estate Submit your questions, share your stories and tell us what topics interest you most. Post a comment or email us at realestateqa@nytimes.com.\n\nFor this ambitious program to work, New Yorkers have to save their food scraps, and buildings have to accommodate and maintain collection containers. As of March 1, 1,183 apartment buildings were participating in the program. But many building owners are reluctant to start composting.\n\n\u201cThere is work involved \u2014 you have to find the space,\u201d said Dan Wurtzel, the president of FirstService Residential New York, which manages properties in New York. \u201cThe staff isn\u2019t set up to do this.\u201d Buildings that do participate tend to be condos and co-ops because residents who own their apartments and want to compost can set up a committee to make it happen, while renters don\u2019t have that power, Mr. Wurtzel said.\n\nIs the fight over? Not all. Instead, you and your neighbors should try to persuade your landlord to see the program as an asset, not just a chore. Such a program could attract new renters who want to live in an environmentally responsible building. Organize your neighbors. Talk to them in the elevator and halls, post a flier on the bulletin board. With a group of supporters, try to persuade the landlord. Is management worried about rodents? The city has an answer for that: \u201cThis program can actually help keep our four-legged friends away,\u201d said Belinda Mager, a Sanitation Department spokeswoman. If the building is concerned about where to place the bins, Sanitation Department outreach staff members can provide training and help with setup. \u201cThey don\u2019t go it alone,\u201d Ms. Mager said.", "title": "When Organic Waste Pickup Gets a No From Your Landlord", "authors": ["Ronda Kaysen", "Ask Real Estate"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Last school year, however, the school began using Family Playlists in the sixth grade, and teachers and school administrators were amazed that 91 percent of families participated in the activities \u2014 more than triple the engagement rate that they usually see.\n\n\u201cMany parents in our community haven\u2019t had the educational background and struggle with the math and they\u2019ve been honest about that,\u201d said Flanagan. \u201cBut this is changing the conversation about what homework is for. It\u2019s not just the parent saying, \u2018Is it done?\u2019 It\u2019s about students trying to figure out the best way to explain something. It\u2019s more about conversation than about completion, and they\u2019re having fun together.\u201d\n\nThe fundamental premise behind Family Playlists, which teachers assign as homework intermittently \u2014 typically at the end of a unit \u2014 is that when students are asked to teach something, they learn it at a deeper level and strengthen their sense of self-reliance. That was my experience as a child, and it appeared to be shared by the eight sixth graders from South Bronx Prep I recently interviewed.\n\nJesmari Cruz, 11, was surprised to discover that her father, Luis, was good at math. However, she found that he had forgotten some things, like how to calculate perimeter. \u201cSo I had to teach him,\u201d she said. \u201cFirst I explained it and gave him his own shape and let him do whatever work he understood, but then I had to explain it more to him, and help him break it down.\u201d\n\nMadison Toro, 12, had a similar experience teaching her father, Eugene. \u201cWhen we did polygons and shapes, I made mistakes and he corrected me,\u201d she said. \u201cBut I taught him about dividing fractions and how to make an improper fraction and a mixed number.\u201d\n\nThe students found that after having led parents and other relatives through a number of lessons, their parents started reminding them less often to do their homework \u2014 reflecting, perhaps, increased trust and confidence. Their biggest difficulty was having to translate math concepts for parents who weren\u2019t fluent in English. And their most common complaint was about parents being too busy with work and caring for younger siblings \u2014 and too distracted by cellphones \u2014 to give them their full attention. (Some children confiscated their parents\u2019 phones until the homework was done!)\n\nThe two fathers I interviewed were unabashedly enthusiastic. Luis Cruz, 36, who works as a housing certification agent, said of his daughter, Jesmari, \u201cI love that she\u2019s bringing me back to my childhood because I don\u2019t remember that many things from school.\u201d He added: \u201cSince she was little she\u2019s been smart, but she\u2019s shy and she used to hold herself back. I\u2019ve seen a big change. She\u2019s opened up a lot. She\u2019s grown and she\u2019s got a big smile on her face. I like that.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | When Parents Teach Children (and Vice Versa)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Teachers in Oklahoma, who are threatening a walkout on April 2, have expressed similar frustrations, as have adjunct faculty members at a college in Florida and the recently unionized staff of The Los Angeles Times.\n\nRobert Bruno, a professor of labor relations at the University of Illinois, said that while compensation and job security were often core concerns, \u201cwhat really generates this explosion of resistance among professional workers is when they feel they\u2019re the last line of defense between the public they serve and others who would threaten the professionalism of their work.\u201d\n\nSome professions, like law and medicine, began to take their modern form in the late 19th century and early 20th century, as science became more rigorous and knowledge became more specialized. Other occupations, like journalism, became more professionalized later in the 20th century by developing an agreed-upon set of norms and best practices.\n\nIn most cases, said Tracey Adams, a sociologist who studies professions at the University of Western Ontario, the workers tended to be driven by a sense that they were improving society, not just adding to the bottom line. In return, the public and government officials often deferred to them in the areas where they asserted authority. This netted them the resources to do their jobs, the independence to exercise their judgment and widespread public esteem.\n\nThat has changed in the past few decades, however. \u201cI think that most professions would find that there are a number of forces chipping away at a lot of those tangible and less tangible benefits,\u201d Professor Adams said. \u201cIncreasingly people say, \u2018I\u2019m not sure I trust you more than the next person.\u2019\u201d", "title": "When Professionals Rise Up, More Than Money Is at Stake", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "John R. Bolton, chosen by President Trump to be his new national security adviser, does not need the Senate\u2019s endorsement to succeed H. R. McMaster in the job. But in 2005, the extraordinary refusal to confirm his nomination to be President George W. Bush\u2019s ambassador to the United Nations by a Republican-controlled committee is worth revisiting for what it revealed about Mr. Bolton and what it may portend for our national security.\n\nOne moment singularly derailed his nomination. Testifying before the usually staid Senate Foreign Relations Committee in April 2005, Carl W. Ford Jr. \u2014 the former assistant secretary of state for intelligence and research \u2014 called Mr. Bolton a \u201ckiss-up, kick-down sort of guy\u201d and a \u201cserial abuser\u201d of people beneath him in the chain of command. Mr. Ford \u2014 a self-described conservative Republican and Bush supporter \u2014 made vivid an emerging portrait of Mr. Bolton as a bully who repeatedly sought retribution against career intelligence analysts with the temerity to contradict him.\n\nBack then, I served as the Democratic staff director of the Foreign Relations Committee. Under the leadership of its Republican chairman, Richard Lugar of Indiana, and its ranking member, Joe Biden of Delaware, a Democrat, the committee was an oasis of comity in an increasingly rabid Washington. Even my Republican colleagues were surprised at Mr. Bolton\u2019s nomination. After all, this was a man who had famously declared: \u201cThere\u2019s no such thing as the United Nations,\u201d adding that if the United Nations building in New York \u201clost 10 stories, it wouldn\u2019t make a bit of difference.\u201d\n\nMr. Bolton, President Bush\u2019s under secretary of state for arms control and international security, had a general disdain for diplomacy that rankled several Republican members of the committee, including George Voinovich of Ohio and Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island. Mr. Lugar had quietly counseled the administration not to nominate him.", "title": "Opinion | When Republicans Rejected John Bolton", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "A car wends its way through a line of taxis in the Las Vegas rain, carefully steering around a tangle of sedans vying for passengers. As the black Lincoln MKZ gets closer, the steering wheel saws back and forth, but there\u2019s no one in the front seat. In fact, there\u2019s no one in the car at all.\n\nIt\u2019s disquieting to be picked up by an empty car, and it\u2019s something of a milestone: Inside most autonomous research vehicles cruising public streets, there\u2019s a minder to keep a watchful eye and take control should things go awry. But with the MKZ, there was no human custodian. At least not one within view.\n\nHundreds of miles away, Ben Shukman, a software engineer for Phantom Auto, was sitting in front of a phalanx of video screens in Mountain View, Calif. Using a live, two-way video connection along with the kind of steering wheel and pedals usually reserved for video games, he was driving the MKZ.\n\nWhile major technology and car companies are teaching cars to drive themselves, Phantom Auto is working on remote control systems, often referred to as teleoperation, that many see as a necessary safety feature for the autonomous cars of the future. And that future is closer than you might think: California will allow companies to test autonomous vehicles without a safety driver \u2014 as long as the car can be operated remotely \u2014 starting next month.", "title": "When Self-Driving Cars Can\u2019t Help Themselves, Who Takes the Wheel?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "#SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at@nytimes.", "title": "When Shakers Were Movers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "On Monday afternoon, Jerry Saltz, the longtime art critic at New York Magazine, went to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where he has gone nearly once a week for three decades. After two hours of taking in \u201cGolden Kingdoms: Luxury and Legacy in the Ancient Americas,\u201d he left and headed toward the fountain on the northern end of the plaza out front, which bears the name of its benefactor, David H. Koch. Mr. Saltz was carrying a long strip of paper that had been printed to blend in with the granite used for the fountain. The words on it matched the typeface of the fountain\u2019s inscription. Mr. Saltz then attached his sign to the fountain, so that it no longer read \u201cDavid H. Koch Plaza.\u201d Instead it declared, \u201cClimate Change Denier Plaza.\u201d\n\nPeople cheered and clapped and took out their phones. Mr. Saltz, who is married to the co-chief art critic of The New York Times, Roberta Smith, picked up the scraps of tape he had used that had fallen to the ground \u2014 he did not want to litter \u2014 and shared a picture of his act of guerrilla resistance with his 502,000 followers on Twitter. The Met removed the sign quickly and offered no comment when I called its spokesman to ask how the gesture was received. Had the museum banned him from going back, Mr. Saltz told me, he would have prostrated himself before its executives and begged to be readmitted. \u201cI can\u2019t live if living is without the Met,\u2019\u2019 he said. \u201cI know the act is riddled with protest, but it was a guttural response. I\u2019d walked by so many times and seeing the name David Koch had bothered me for such a long time.\u2019\u2019\n\nIn the fall of 2014, the plaza in front of the museum, which runs along Fifth Avenue for four city blocks, opened to the public after a two-year reconstruction that cost $65 million, the entire sum of which was supplied by Mr. Koch, the famous backer of right-wing causes and work in climate-change skepticism in particular. Among the many recipients of the family\u2019s largess is, for instance, the Competitive Enterprise institute, a nonprofit libertarian think tank that published a blog post several years ago comparing a prominent Penn State climate scientist, Michael Mann, to the former football coach and pedophile Jerry Sandusky, arguing that Mr. Mann had \u201cmolested and tortured data in the service of politicized science.\u201d\n\nThe Trump presidency has, in many ways, been like a tuning fork applied to the city\u2019s soul, causing it to vibrate again after years in which it had seemed incapable \u2014 dulled and flattened by the growing presence of Rite Aid and meal kits and complacency and billionaire dormitories. On a Friday evening last month, a dozen activists stood up in Clyde Frazier\u2019s, a Midtown restaurant, chanting, \u201cNo justice, no bread,\u2019\u2019 in protest of Tom Cat Bakery, a major supplier, that has attracted the antagonisms of the group Rise and Resist for its treatment of immigrants. In January, protesters lined up in front of the Museum of Natural History to call for Rebekah Mercer, another influential conservative philanthropist who has supported climate-science denial, to step down from the museum\u2019s board.", "title": "When Should Cultural Institutions Say No to Tainted Funding?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.\n\nRecently you advised a reader who has eight years to go until retirement and is trying to decide whether to stick with an unhappy job or look for something new. (\u201cIs a Late-Career Change Worth It?,\u201d March 3, 2018.) I wish you had offered the thought that first this person should petition for less travel (since travel seemed to be the main source of dissatisfaction). I find many teams are willing to work around an individual collaborator\u2019s inability to travel a lot. This could encourage the worker to consider options within the current company, which might prove beneficial. ANONYMOUS\n\nYour reader who is eight years from retirement and hates her job might do well to look into what is often called \u201cjob crafting.\u201d Perhaps there is some way to remake the job or remake how the person thinks about his job, and end up feeling more fulfilled. Even if that doesn\u2019t work, the person might still use some of those approaches to craft the next job, to make it as fulfilling as possible. A positive psychology career coach (I am one) can help with this. GAYLE SCROGGS, EASTON, MD.\n\nThat column inspired quite a few responses. And I think the idea expressed in these two replies \u2014 to make this less of a binary stay-or-go decision, and instead try to reshape the job at hand \u2014 deserves further exploration. In fact, I was curious enough about Gayle Scroggs\u2019s positive-psychology take on job crafting that I gave her a call, and then explored academic research on the subject.\n\nBut before I get to that, it\u2019s worth briefly sharing some of the other feedback I received. The column argued for thinking hard about exploring new options with an open mind, suggesting that one would most likely regret giving in to the idea that there\u2019s no choice but to ride out those unhappy years until retirement.\n\nAnd indeed a number of readers offered their own anecdotes of late-career-change success stories. One quit Wall Street for a public sector job in Rhode Island, and called the move \u201cvery rewarding.\u201d Another described two years working (and networking) her way toward escaping a \u201ctoxic boss\u201d and unhappy work culture.\n\n\u201cAt 59, I switched jobs last year and have never been happier,\u201d she wrote. \u201cMake a plan, set yourself a deadline, and do the work.\u201d", "title": "When Small Steps Can Change Your Life", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Stewart has since retired from the ring, having replicated himself a dozen times over on every channel, each copy smugger than the last. But Mr. Carlson, too, has triumphed. He now hosts one of the top-rated shows on Fox News, where he has become a shouty populist version of his former mini William F. Buckley Jr. persona \u2014 much closer to the trollish partisan Mr. Stewart accused him of being than he ever was in his \u201cCrossfire\u201d days.\n\nAnd the rest of the movement has evolved \u2014 or devolved \u2014 alongside him, from the organizers of the Conservative Political Action Conference who invited Marion Le Pen and Sheriff David Clarke, to the campus conservatives who\u2019ve doubled down on their strategy of inviting Ann Coulter and her spiritual descendants to speak to the very audiences likely to be most outraged by them. For many campus conservatives, the invitations are driven by a sincere desire to give their values an airing and set off debate. It is, of course, also fun to annoy people who disagree with you.\n\nIronically, or perhaps predictably, tonal tensions are escalating at a time when actual policymaking has ground nearly to a halt, with budgets and major legislative packages hopelessly stalled in Congress after Congress. The attempt to find common ground over the \u201cDreamers\u201d \u2014 the group of undocumented immigrants who came to the United States as children \u2014 for instance, ultimately involved a brief shutdown of the federal government and a near miss of one. The left labeled the right racist; the right accused the left of hating America. No substantive policy change resulted.\n\nSo maybe it makes sense that political squabbling across much of America has become increasingly aesthetics-focused and content devoid: It\u2019s no coincidence that at the moment the alt-right leader Richard Spencer was sucker-punched on camera, he was explaining the elaborate in-joke signaled by his Pepe the Frog lapel pin. Nor that when Russians allegedly tried to meddle in the last presidential election, they chose to do it in meme form, with Facebook ads featuring Jesus and the Devil arm wrestling over the prospect of a Hillary Clinton victory, or promoting \u201cBuff Bernie\u201d pro-L.G.B.T. coloring books. Differences remain as fundamental as ever, but the way we talk about them is so superficial as to have become incoherent.\n\nBut that has done little to restrain the all-consuming ferocity of the fighting. Nor have the consequences been restricted to the internet. The tonal differences go all the way to the top: If Barack Obama\u2019s \u201ccling to guns or religion\u201d statement was a perfect distillation of the smug style in liberal politics, Donald Trump is impeccably suited to an increasingly post-ideological Republican landscape where the point-scoring is the prize.\n\nOne of the primary reactions to this new framing of the political debate has been exactly what you\u2019d expect: Many sane, self-respecting people no longer want anything to do with either side. Barely half of the respondents to the last round of Gallup\u2019s long-running question about partisan affiliation could bring themselves to pick a party at all, with just 28 percent identifying as Republicans and 27 percent as Democrats. (Happy start of midterm season!) And even when Gallup tried to force people into bicolor boxes, by asking the 46 percent identifying as independents which way they lean, the totals still come only to 46 percent on team red and 44 percent on team blue.\n\nIt is from the reluctant partisans and the remaining 10 percent of stalwart independents that hope must spring. The notion that there are sensible political coalitions to be had outside of partisan paradigms is a cherished American idea. Some of the people abandoning standard labels are liable to make things worse by racing to the bottom \u2014 think \u201cthe dirtbag left\u201d of the \u201cChapo Trap House\u201d podcast or even the alt-right. But there are other longstanding principled transpartisan coalitions that might be due for reconsideration: Think cosmopolitan libertarianism or Blue Dog Democrats. These coalitions can form, however, only if they can find a space outside of mainstream politics\u2019 compulsive, addictive, downward rhetorical spiral.\n\nIn the meantime, \u201cDon\u2019t feed the trolls\u201d is a sound piece of advice \u2014 and one that is nearly impossible to follow.", "title": "Opinion | When Smug Liberals Met Conservative Trolls", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "One morning \u2014 a few weeks after the so-called \u201cbomb cyclone\u201d in January had thrown record-low temperatures, high winds and thick ocean waves onto Rockaway Beach in Queens \u2014 the conditions remained gnarly. It was 35 degrees, snowing, the Atlantic Ocean was colder than normal at 38 degrees, and the winds were whipping.\n\nJoe Falcone looked past the snow-covered sand to the surf and saw a fleet of humans bobbing up and down on boards. Dozens of them. His blood pumped hot with frustration.\n\n\u201cThere were at least 50 guys just in my eyesight,\u201d Mr. Falcone said, describing the scene as \u201cmayhem.\u201d He believes that surfing should be like a meditation. \u201cBut it\u2019s hard when you\u2019re sitting shoulder to shoulder with someone you don\u2019t know. Out goes the intimacy between man and Mother Nature.\u201d", "title": "When Surfing Rockaway, It\u2019s Watch Out or Wipeout", "authors": ["Lisa M. Collins"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "For the first year of the Trump administration the story was one of containment and constraint. President Trump was constrained ideologically by Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell, pursuing a conventional Republican agenda on health care and taxes and letting his populist promises hang fire. But more important he was constrained institutionally, in roughly the ways that Republican politicians had promised that he would be \u2014 surrounded by a conventional Republican cabinet and (after a while) a conventional White House that essentially governed for him, letting him play the authoritarian on Twitter while the business of the presidency was conducted elsewhere.\n\nThe problem with this arrangement is that unlike other out-of-the-loop presidents \u2014 Richard Nixon at his nadir, Woodrow Wilson after his stroke, Ronald Reagan with a bullet in him \u2014 Trump was not actually incapacitated or about to be impeached. He was just, well, Donald Trump: a septuagenarian cable-TV addict ill-suited for the responsibilities of his office but still fully capable of attempting to exercise its powers. Which meant that the containment game had to last, not weeks or months, but three more long years to work.\n\nAnd it may not last that long. From his exciting new steel tariffs to his promised summit meeting with Kim Jong-un, Trump has been acting lately like a man less inclined to listen to his handlers \u2014 and now those handlers have begun to disappear. The firing of Rex Tillerson, on the heels of Gary Cohn\u2019s departure about a week ago, evokes the wildly chaotic atmosphere that characterized Trump\u2019s first few months in office. But as my colleague Maggie Haberman tweeted, this time it seems less like something happening to Trump and more like chaos orchestrated from the Oval Office: \u201cThe narrative of Trump unglued is not totally wrong but misses the reason why \u2014 he was terrified of the job the first six months, and now feels like he has a command of it. So now he is basically saying, \u2018I\u2019ve got this, I can make the changes I want.\u2019\u201d\n\nIn other words, Trump knows that he\u2019s been constrained and tamed \u2014 for all I know he might have read my columns, or at least the headlines, saying so \u2014 and doesn\u2019t want to play the incapacitated Twitter president anymore. He wants to actually use the office, and not just occupy it \u2014 and since he is the president, nobody can stop him from trying.", "title": "Opinion | When Trump Takes Charge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "The other, \u201cLast Week Tonight With John Oliver Presents a Day in the Life of Marlon Bundo,\u201d is a gay romance between two bunnies that was the brainchild of the HBO comedy host John Oliver.\n\nSo far, that is the more popular of the two.\n\nMr. Oliver revealed the book, which was written by Jill Twiss and credits the titular bunny as a co-author, on his weekly late-night show on Sunday. He sat her down on cushions and she arranged the brown wrap that covered what remained of her legs.\n\nIt was a warm October afternoon and I was in Noorzia and her father\u2019s temporary house in Nangarhar Province, in eastern Afghanistan. Just three months earlier, she had been gathering firewood on a hill above her home village when her life changed forever. The summer before, her village had been overrun by Islamic State militants; her family fled and then returned in the fall once government forces drove them out. But the Islamic State left behind some surprises.\n\n\u201cI climbed this little mound,\u201d Noorzia said. \u201cI couldn\u2019t see the mine and I stepped on it.\u201d The explosive device, planted by the militants, took both of her legs.", "title": "Opinion | When War Is More Dangerous for Civilians Than Soldiers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Kim\u2019s Confident Debut\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile the Chinese news media published less flattering images of Mr. Kim, the North Korean media made sure he came across at home as charismatic, showing him smiling and offering a forceful handshake to Mr. Xi.\n\nThe state-run media showed photos of Mr. Kim\u2019s extensive motorcade as well as Mr. Xi appearing to offer a toast to Mr. Kim. Those images did not appear in the Chinese media.\n\nMr. Kim, making his debut on the global stage, was most likely eager to show he was a respected figure who could hold his own with one of the world\u2019s most powerful leaders. In North Korea he was depicted, without exception, as strong and in charge.\n\nIdeological Brethren\n\nPhoto\n\nMao Zedong once said China and North Korea, longtime Communist allies, were as \u201cclose as lips and teeth.\u201d\n\nBut relations between the two countries have been strained in recent decades. However, there was no hint of that tension in the coverage of Mr. Kim\u2019s visit this week.\n\nThe Chinese and the North Korean news media portrayed the two countries as ideological comrades. Mr. Kim was welcomed in the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, as a military band played. News reports said he and Mr. Xi watched an art performance together, joined by their wives.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
