View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOrville Schell, director of the Center on U.S.-China Relations at Asia Society in New York, described the pageantry as a \u201crenaissance of the old socialist-style, big-leader rituals.\u201d\n\n\u201cThey certainly didn\u2019t just sneak him in the back door,\u201d he said of Mr. Kim. \u201cIt looked like he got pretty close to the full monty.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPersonal Chemistry\n\nPhoto\n\nBoth men seemed eager to convey that they have a renewed commitment to working together, and a personal chemistry that will unite them.\n\nMr. Xi showed considerable warmth toward Mr. Kim, smiling widely and offering affectionate embraces. Mr. Kim returned the fondness, waving enthusiastically as he departed.\n\nThe budding alliance between the two leaders may put new pressure on President Trump, who is expected to meet with Mr. Kim in the coming weeks. While the location for a meeting has not yet been decided, some analysts say that Mr. Xi may be angling to have it in Beijing.\n\n\u201cThat would make Trump like the three-wheel bicycle,\u201d Mr. Schell said. \u201cHe would have to go to Beijing again, and almost be the supplicant to these old allies that have patched up their marriage.\u201d", "title": "When Xi Met Kim: How China and North Korea Depicted It", "authors": ["Javier C. Hern\u00e1ndez"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Since then, Mr. Xi has cast himself as a decisive, unwavering leader with a long-term plan to make China a prosperous and respected great power. On Sunday, the legislature, the National People\u2019s Congress, passed a constitutional amendment erasing a limit of two presidential terms and setting Mr. Xi on course to run China for at least another decade.\n\nMr. Xi began his second five-year term as president after a unanimous vote by legislators on Saturday. Officials have said that extending Mr. Xi\u2019s time in office beyond this term will assure stable policies for decades. The swift, secretive way in which Mr. Xi secured his extended reign let officials know that Mr. Xi would bulldoze past any resistance to get his way.\n\n\u201cXi effectively is signaling to opponents of his policy agenda that they cannot wait him out and that they need to get on board with his agenda,\u201d said Ryan Hass, a former director for China at the National Security Council who is now a fellow at the Brookings Institution. \u201cHe wouldn\u2019t take this step, and expose himself to such risk, unless he felt it was needed to bust through opposition to his agenda.\u201d\n\nMr. Xi has already established sweeping authority, through his anticorruption drive, and by creating a plethora of new powers and leadership groups that channel decisions to him. His overhaul of the military also demonstrated a willingness to take on entrenched bureaucracies.\n\nA reorganization of ministries and agencies revealed at the congress on Tuesday may let Mr. Xi and other leaders better steer bureaucracies. And a new government lineup, to be announced on Monday, is likely to put Mr. Xi\u2019s close allies atop his administration, making it easier to communicate and refine orders. One such ally, Wang Qishan, became vice president on Saturday.\n\nBut Mr. Xi\u2019s centralization of power over the sprawling bureaucracy can also create confusion and overshooting.\n\nPhoto\n\nOfficials are often reluctant to risk making decisions that draw suspicion of corruption or political disloyalty, a Beijing think tank said last year. But when ordered to act, cadres are often eager to avoid suspicion of sloth. The outcome, several experts said, can be a confounding mix of overreaction to orders and reluctance to act on one\u2019s own initiative.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThings are shot out of the top of the party, and they\u2019re unworkable when they\u2019re implemented,\u201d said James McGregor, the chairman of greater China for APCO Worldwide, who advises companies dealing with Chinese officialdom. \u201cIt\u2019s very hard to get an official to make decisions these days, because they\u2019re all scared of doing the wrong thing.\u201d\n\nChina\u2019s top-down system has long been prone to overshooting. But several factors may magnify such problems in Mr. Xi\u2019s next term.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn recent years, he has installed officials loyal to him across most provinces and ministries, and ardent supporters have sworn unquestioning obedience. Their awed obedience can encourage rigid enforcement of even vague or conflicting policies. Officials rarely suffer serious punishment for over-eagerly imposing Mr. Xi\u2019s orders.\n\n\u201cUnless loyalty is absolute, it is absolute disloyalty,\u201d Li Hongzhong, one of the avid loyalists promoted by Mr. Xi into the party\u2019s top ranks, said in 2016.\n\nMr. Xi\u2019s efforts to break down walls between the party and government bureaucracies may discourage midlevel technocrats from improving policies. And Mr. Xi\u2019s crackdown on rights lawyers, rights advocates, independent-minded journalists and online debate has silenced many voices who could question misguided government decisions.\n\nNobody sees such overreach producing anything as calamitous as Mao\u2019s Great Leap Forward and subsequent famine. But Sun Liping, a well-known sociologist at Tsinghua University in Beijing, has warned against a mobilized bureaucracy stoking excessive zeal among subordinates.\n\n\u201cThis mobilizing form of government sometimes evolves into a race between officials. \u2018If you\u2019re tough, then I\u2019ll be even tougher. If you go to extremes, I\u2019ll go further,\u2019\u201d Professor Sun wrote about recent cases of official overreach in an essay that spread on China\u2019s internet last month before being censored.\n\n\u201cEverything in one fell blow, thunderous bombast, magnified down layer after layer, and then after the task is completed, just chicken feathers everywhere,\u201d Professor Sun wrote, using a slang phrase for scant accomplishments.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLate last summer, to cut coal use in northern China and replace it with cleaner natural gas, officials tore out coal stoves and suspended coal deliveries. But when cold weather arrived, natural gas supplies fell short because planned pipelines had not all been finished.\n\nMr. Xi had ordered Beijing to reduce its population at least as early as 2014. But the effort progressed fitfully until last year, when Mr. Xi\u2019s prot\u00e9g\u00e9, Cai Qi, apparently eager to make his mark as the new party chief in Beijing, seized on a deadly apartment building fire to push mass demolitions. Tens of thousands ended up scrambling for shelter after losing their homes.\n\nOfficials are also racing to turn Mr. Xi\u2019s biggest visions into reality, including Xiong\u2019an New Area, the new model city planned for a stretch of land 80 miles south of Beijing. Mr. Xi began vocally promoting the idea about a year ago.\n\nNot all of Mr. Xi\u2019s policies appear prone to waves of excess zeal. Since destabilizing policy gyrations in 2015, financial policy has settled down, said Barry Naughton, a professor at the University of California, San Diego, who studies Chinese economic policymaking. But if China\u2019s economy hits a rough patch, presenting difficult choices between shoring up growth and reining in debt, that stability may not last.\n\n\u201cIt seems to me that bandwagoning, sycophancy, toadying are all becoming much more fundamental,\u201d Professor Naughton said. \u201cThat\u2019s got to change the way the system functions as a whole.\u201d", "title": "When Xi Speaks, Chinese Officials Jump. Maybe Too High.", "authors": ["Chris Buckley", "Keith Bradsher"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "The University of Texas had a problem \u2014 its undergraduates liked bright-lights, biggish-city Austin so much they didn\u2019t want to leave. Or that\u2019s the optimistic take on it. Many students were simply struggling to finish their degrees. Barely half of each class was graduating in four years.\n\nMost universities are in the same boat. Today just 40 percent of college students earn a degree in four years. This phenomenon is so common that educators now use six years, by which time 59 percent of undergraduates receive their diplomas, as the new normal.\n\nThat\u2019s bad news. The extra time slows many students\u2019 progress toward an advanced degree or a good job. When students stay for an additional year, it costs them or their parents as much as $40,000, and at public institutions, taxpayers foot part of the tab. And with undergraduates lingering, there is also less room for other students to enroll. Most important, the longer it takes students to graduate, the more likely they are to drop out.\n\nDavid Laude, a former senior vice provost in charge of student success at U.T., told me the school\u2019s culture was opposed to four-year graduation rates. But after a Texas-size donnybrook that pitted Gov. Rick Perry, who was fixated on cost-cutting, against the president at the time, William Powers, a deal emerged in 2013. The Texas Board of Regents approved a tuition increase, gave the university $12 million and agreed to invest in programs to help students succeed. The university had already begun drawing up plans to graduate more students on schedule, but Mr. Powers raised the stakes by pledging that 70 percent of the Class of 2017 would graduate in four years.", "title": "Opinion | When Your College Has Your Back", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Did Washington Irving Sleep Here?\n\nThe bronze plaque with the words \u201cThis house was once the home of Washington Irving\u201d had always intrigued Dan Critchett when he walked past 122 East 17th Street (it has the alternate address 49 Irving Place), a three-story brick Italianate-style townhouse and former single-family residence that has been cut up into rental apartments.\n\nFour years ago, an alcove studio on the parlor floor became available, \u201cand I thought it was cool,\u201d said Mr. Critchett, 61, a real estate agent at Stribling and Associates. \u201cI thought, \u2018This is a historic house and it will be something fun to tell my friends.\u2019 \u201d\n\nSomething fun, sure, but, as it turned out, pure fiction.\n\nThe author of \u201cThe Legend of Sleepy Hollow\u201d and \u201cRip Van Winkle\u201d apparently never crossed the threshold, according to a New York Times Streetscapes column from 1994 with the headline: \u201cThe \u2018Washington Irving\u2019 House; Why the Legend of Irving Place Is but a Myth.\u201d\n\nMr. Critchett doesn\u2019t know how long the plaque has been affixed to the building; who put it there is another mystery. But after settling in, he learned that he had plenty to dine out on without an assist from the creator of the headless horseman. The townhouse had once been the residence of Elsie de Wolfe, often called America\u2019s first interior decorator, and her companion, Elisabeth Marbury, a literary agent and theater producer whose clients included Oscar Wilde and George Bernard Shaw. And there is reason to believe that Sarah Bernhardt, the architect Stanford White and assorted Astors, Morgans and Vanderbilts, might have turned up at the couple\u2019s Sunday salons.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m getting a lot of mileage telling people about the house,\u201d said Mr. Critchett, who lives in what was once the de Wolfe-Marbury living room.\n\nLearning of a house\u2019s past can turn residents into amateur historians and scholars. Ms. Johnson, for instance, began hunting for pictures of Rambova and Valentino, unearthing several of the pair doing the tango, and is planning an evening of Valentino movies for residents at the Hotel des Artistes some time next year. For his part, Mr. Critchett read \u201cLadies and Not-So-Gentle Women\u201d a group biography of, among others, de Wolfe and Marbury, as well as de Wolfe\u2019s design book \u201cThe House in Good Taste.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere was a chapter on this house because it was her home,\u201d Mr. Critchett said. \u201cMy sofa is where her writing table was. She looked out the same windows I look out. And I imagine people of that era arriving for grand dinner parties here and looking at Elsie\u2019s d\u00e9cor.\u201d", "title": "When Your Home Has a History", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The report\u2019s author, senior researcher Gretchen M. Livingston, floated the idea that the reason may have to do with increasing life spans. \u201cPeople realize they have many more years to live and want to find fulfillment in that extra time,\u201d she wrote.\n\nBut the likelihood of remarrying couples in that age bracket staying fulfilled may depend on how carefully they planned their finances before walking down the aisle.\n\n[READ MORE: Here\u2019s How to Maintain Peace Among Your Heirs]\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s all very tricky and sometimes difficult to understand,\u201d said Hyman G. Darling, president of the National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys, of the money-related factors that can affect older remarrying couples. \u201cWe\u2019ve definitely broken up some marriages\u201d when advising couples on the financial intricacies of combining resources in their golden years, he said.\n\nRisks attached to later-in-life marriages include the potential loss of government benefits like Medicaid and Supplemental Security Income. Income and estate tax increases, the loss of pensions or alimony and the taking on of a new spouse\u2019s debt are also possible with the signing of a marriage certificate. Long-term health care costs and whether a new spouse is legally bound to pick up the tab for them are big issues, Mr. Darling said.\n\nBut according to Mr. Darling and Lina Guillen, an attorney and co-author of the 2017 book \u201cLiving Together: A Legal Guide for Unmarried Couples,\u201d the problem older couples wring their hands over most when considering remarriage is how their decision will affect their adult children.\n\n\u201cA common reason older partners choose to remain single is that they want to leave their property to their children,\u201d Ms. Guillen said. \u201cChildren may have expectations for a coming inheritance. Things can get sensitive when a new spouse comes along.\u201d\n\nThe Anastasios are living proof \u2014 although they wish they weren\u2019t. Mrs. Anastasio tried to reassure her daughter that Mr. Anastasio had no designs on her property and hadn\u2019t even considered the possibility of outliving her. The daughter, Laura, however, was said to be unconvinced. (The Anastasios declined to give her last name to protect her privacy).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. and Mrs. Anastasio married for love but also for practicality. Mrs. Anastasio is British. Before she and Mr. Anastasio married, her visits to the United States were limited to three-month stretches on a visa. Although the couple loves to travel, going back and forth so frequently was stressful. \u201cAt our age, going through security at the airport is not much fun,\u201d Mr. Anastasio said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThey wed in a small ceremony without consulting a lawyer or an estate planner, which they acknowledged may have been behind the daughter\u2019s unease.\n\n\u201cWe were always treated like a married couple. And we started to think, the only reason we\u2019re not married is to satisfy Tina\u2019s daughter,\u201d Mr. Anastasio said. \u201cWe had talked about putting something in writing, saying, whatever happens she keeps her things and I keep mine and never the twain shall meet. But we decided it\u2019s time for us to worry about us, not the kids. We have plans to put something in writing\u201d eventually, he said, but they chose not to before the wedding.\n\n\u201cIf a couple remains unmarried and one dies without a will, generally speaking the unmarried partner will get nothing,\u201d Ms. Guillen said. \u201cThe property will go to blood relatives, with children being first in line.\u201d\n\nRemarrying couples like Mr. and Mrs. Anastasio, on the other hand, have to plan ahead. What Ms. Guillen called the \u201cgold standard\u201d for such couples is signing both a will and a prenuptial agreement. Only then can they feel reasonably sure their grown children\u2019s inheritance will not be contested or otherwise tampered with, she said.\n\nMrs. Anastasio, now on her third marriage after being divorced and widowed, said practical factors beyond citizenship convinced her to marry Mr. Anastasio. One was a health scare a few years ago. Navigating hospital rules after Mr. Anastasio was admitted would have been easier if they were legally married, she said. But if citizenship and health care proxy issues had not been factors, she would have preferred to remain Mr. Anastasio\u2019s live-in partner rather than his wife. \u201cI didn\u2019t want to upset my daughter,\u201d she said.\n\nMr. and Mrs. Anastasio are outliers; many people over 55 remarry for moral or religious reasons. \u201cThere are people who say, I\u2019m not going to live with someone without being married no matter what,\u201d Mr. Darling said.\n\nIn addition to a clear conscience, benefits for such couples include money saved by joining households and, in some cases, depending on the state and the combined income, lower taxes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut for many couples the minuses of remarrying often outweigh the pluses. That might be a reason, according to Pew, that the number of people over 50 who cohabit with a partner rather than marry jumped 75 percent from 2007 to 2016.\n\nAnd some couples are finding ways to skirt the system.", "title": "When Your Parents Remarry, Everyone Is Happy, Right?", "authors": ["Tammy La Gorce"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "AS A CHILD in Bologna, the curator Alice Stori Liechtenstein was enchanted by a scene in Luchino Visconti\u2019s 1963 film, \u201cThe Leopard,\u201d in which the young nobleman Tancredi is asked how many rooms are in his family\u2019s castle. \u201cNo one knows, not even Uncle,\u201d he responds. \u201cHe says a palace in which one knows every room isn\u2019t worth living in.\u201d Twenty years later, in the early aughts, she posed the same question to her future husband, Alfred Liechtenstein, when they first visited his ancestral home, Schloss Hollenegg, in the east Austrian hills. \u201cI don\u2019t think I\u2019ve been in them all,\u201d he replied, even though he had inherited the castle, which has been in his family for nearly two centuries, when he was 26. (There are 52 rooms total, for the record.)\n\nAlfred, now 45, always knew Schloss Hollenegg was a magical place \u2014 like Disneyland, only real \u2014 with its Renaissance-style courtyard built by Abel von Hollenegg and renovated in 1550, its magnificent ballroom painted by Philipp Carl Laubmann in 1750 and its Baroque chapel open to local residents on Sundays. Portraits of his ancestors line the hallways, and a fresco of a family tree stretching back about 30 generations covers the library\u2019s vaulted ceiling. For Alfred, who grew up near the palace, Hollenegg was inexorably linked to his family; not to care for it as an adult would have been an unthinkable breach of duty.\n\nBut his 39-year-old wife, as she says, \u201cfought against this place for 11 years.\u201d Before they relocated to the rural castle in 2014, her life was unquestionably metropolitan; after attending boarding school in England and university in Milan, she began creating exhibitions for the city\u2019s annual Furniture Fair, eventually counting as clients the Milanese studio Atelier Biagetti, the online retailer Yoox and La Triennale di Milano. When she met Alfred, she was in graduate school in Barcelona, renting a one-bedroom apartment. \u201cLiving in a castle in the countryside was not the plan,\u201d she says, so the couple compromised by moving to Graz, 50 minutes from Hollenegg, which has an international airport. At first, she thought the castle would be a weekend getaway, but trying to manage her career throughout Europe, three young children and two homes quickly became untenable; and so, after a decade or so in Graz, the castle became the family\u2019s main residence.\n\nLike many very large old houses \u2014 and especially the hundreds of privately owned, inhabitable castles in Austria \u2014 Schloss Hollenegg was in a state of neglect; it hadn\u2019t been modernized since Alfred\u2019s grandmother died in 1974. The couple had to install proper bathrooms (previously, there were old toilets hidden behind screens in the hallways) and build an internal staircase. (The only access to the third-floor bedrooms was through the outdoor arcades.) Today, the family inhabits less than half of the 21,500-square-foot property, and apart from the early 18th-century Chinese wallpaper and the 18th-century kachelofen (German wood-burning clay stoves), the private quarters are contemporarily quotidian: the kids\u2019 rooms scattered with plastic toys; there\u2019s a projector mounted in the living room for movie nights; and the simple kitchen crowded with stainless steel appliances is smallish by American standards. But many of the largely unused spaces, from the staterooms with their 17th-century silk-covered walls, to the sumptuous \u201cgreen room\u201d with its original coffered ceiling, lack heat or electricity, which helps preserve their finishes in near-perfect condition. Despite the fact that the castle hadn\u2019t been fully occupied since 1991, when Alfred\u2019s grandfather died, all of its rooms require constant upkeep, even the uninhabited ones: There is silver to be polished, plaster to be patched, floors to be waxed. A significant portion of the income Alfred derives from his family\u2019s timber business \u2014 the grounds are thicketed with larches and spruces \u2014 goes toward property maintenance.\n\nThere is, after all, 900 years of history to maintain. The first records of the castle begin in 1163, but the structure is a palimpsest of a near-millennium of architectural trends: The worn limestone of the Renaissance-style stairway dates from 1577 and the bedrooms, with their Flemish tapestries and four-poster beds, from the late 18th century. The couple tried to restore the house with as many historically correct materials as they could \u2014 lime plaster to repair the delicate ceiling details, reclaimed wood to mend damaged parquet \u2014 but decided that any new additions would be unapologetically modern: their way of adding their names to the house\u2019s lineage and writing themselves, and their era, onto its walls. Upon entering the residence, you\u2019re struck with the first of these contributions, a trippy wallpapered and mirrored elevator by the German designer Markus Benesch, who covered the walls and floors with a disorienting pattern of Op Art Dalmatian spots. \u201cIt was a bit of shock the first time I saw it,\u201d Alfred says.\n\nVideo\n\nDESPITE THESE NEVER-ENDING renovations, Alice never quite felt she possessed the castle; something about it always frustrated her attempts to make it as much hers as her husband\u2019s. Then, in 2015 (around the time she reoriented her freelance business from exhibition design to personal curatorial projects), she decided that instead of the house merely being her dependent, it would become her partner. First, she conceived a showcase in Graz, inviting 23 designers whose work straddled art and design, including, among others, the Scottish designer Dean Brown and Peter Mabeo from Gaborone, Botswana, whose furniture fuses African craftsmanship with European influences. After being \u201csurprised when nearly everyone said yes,\u201d she says, Alice had a more ambitious idea: If Hollenegg was far from the world of contemporary design, why not bring that world to Hollenegg? In 2016, she asked Brown, along with the Viennese studio Mischer\u2019Traxler, known for conceptual pieces that blend handicraft with technology, and the Italian duo Dossofiorito, whose work often includes plants, to be her first designers-in-residence. They each spent a few weeks living at the castle, collaborating with Alice to create a site-specific work that would remain in Hollenegg\u2019s permanent collection, residing alongside the centuries-old furnishings. Brown installed a multidimensional \u00e9tag\u00e8re in a passageway overlooking one of the two courtyards to showcase various treasures collected over the years, such as an urn by Hilda Hellstrom and a collection of vases by Studio Furthermore. Dossofiorito created glass vases inspired by antique ceramics to hold bulbs, an homage to Alfred\u2019s grandmother, Princess Ludmilla, who loved gardening.\n\nPhoto\n\nAlice now chooses a few residents annually; with these designers, she is alternately nurturing and stern, encouraging them to draw on the history of the Schloss, to \u201cexplore all the rooms and open all the drawers,\u201d but not to get so lost that they don\u2019t finish their projects. Last fall, the Viennese design studio BreadedEscalope encountered in their wanderings the 19th-century diaries of Alfred\u2019s ancestor Heinrich Liechtenstein, an adventurer who hunted buffalo with U.S. President Ulysses S. Grant and brought back redwood saplings from California, which now tower over the castle\u2019s walls. Alice let them cut down one of the trees to carve into a table and pair of stools.\n\nThe residents\u2019 pieces debut each May at a group show installed throughout Hollenegg, along with items from about 20 other visiting international designers whom Alice invites to present work. Last year\u2019s exhibition was titled \u201cMorphosis,\u201d referencing gradual but important adaptations that often go unnoticed. The opening night drew guests from Europe and the Middle East who danced to music played by a D.J. from Ibiza, injecting youth and life into rooms that are normally shuttered and silent. Alice opened the castle to the public for the following month, attracting curious locals who had lived in Hollenegg\u2019s shadow their whole lives yet had never seen its interiors. This year\u2019s theme is \u201cLegacy,\u201d prompting designers to explore the personal and collective importance of heritage, which has captivated Alice since hosting Hollenegg\u2019s first show, \u201cSlow,\u201d three years ago. Then as now, inspired by the pace of her more remote life, she wanted to re-examine the negative connotations that slowness has taken on in a culture that values the technological, the futuristic and the fast above all else. Indeed, now that Alice has embraced her countryside castle, she\u2019s developed a broader sense of family and community, but also of time itself. \u201cWhen you live in the city it\u2019s all about me: my apartment, my job,\u201d she says. \u201cNow, I see life on a larger scale \u2014 it\u2019s not about the next generation, but the next three generations. The trees Alfred plants today will be cut by our grandchildren.\u201d", "title": "When a 21st-Century Family Moves Into a 12th-Century Castle", "authors": ["Tom Delavan"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in the West Village. Every morning, the superintendent, or another worker, mops the entryway with powerful cleaning products. Once a week, workers sprinkle a potent powder on the hallway rugs to vacuum. Since I work from home, I am constantly exposed to these toxic products. I have complained to the super and building management, to no avail. (The super even told me the owner hopes that I will move out because my lease is rent-stabilized.) I have read about the health hazards of cleaning products. Imagine what it\u2019s like being forced to inhale these fumes daily! What can be done to protect my health?\n\nA. Many household cleaning products (even some that are marketed as environmentally friendly) contain ingredients that can harm your health. Such products can irritate your eyes or throat and cause headaches or other health problems.\n\nSome people are more sensitive to chemicals than others, particularly those with conditions like asthma. \u201cThese things are irritants, but everybody\u2019s threshold is a little different,\u201d said Dr. Louis DePalo, a pulmonology professor at Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai.", "title": "When a Building\u2019s Cleaning Products Make a Tenant Miserable", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "The freezing, black water enters the helicopter from all sides, instantly flooding the cabin as it flips upside down. Passengers who have barely had time for a last gasp of air before submerging are trapped, unable to see or breathe.\n\nQuickly losing sensation in their frigid fingers, their best hope is to free a small blade from a shoulder strap and slash their way out of a complicated harness system designed to keep them safe in an airborne flying machine with no doors.\n\nThis was the nightmarish scenario that followed the crash of a chartered helicopter in the East River on Sunday night. None of the five passengers on board succeeded in escaping, and all died.\n\nThe helicopter that crashed was owned by Liberty Helicopters and flown by FlyNYON, a company that specializes in doors-off helicopter photo tours. The company promoted its safety standards on its website and singled out its \u201cproprietary eight-point Safety Harness System\u201d worn by passengers. It is a complicated system of straps, carabiners and an emergency blade for cutting it off in case of trouble.", "title": "When a Device Meant for Helicopter Safety Becomes a Death Grip", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.\n\nA few months ago, I joined a new company, and began working with a friend whom I really value outside work. The trouble is that at the office, she is driving me crazy. And she\u2019s possibly jeopardizing my good standing. It turns out my friend is deeply insecure in her job. She throws tantrums several times a week, threatening to quit over minor things (and expecting me to walk her back from the cliff). Worse, she undermines me, sometimes in front of bosses. Once she \u201cpulled rank\u201d on me, even though she has only been at the company a month longer than I have. She speaks up about projects that are in my area, not hers, but doesn\u2019t actually help out. At a recent meeting with supervisors, she even presented my ideas as her own. On days when she is not in, I\u2019m happy and productive. This is wearing on me. I need to disconnect from her professionally while maintaining our friendship if possible. Our boss is very hands-off, and I feel there is no chance she would be helpful here. Please help. ANONYMOUS\n\nWhile you need to have some kind of talk with your friend, this does not have to be a relationship-wrecking confrontation, if you frame things carefully.\n\nFirst, make some distinctions in your own mind between behaviors that are annoying (tantrums, the random butting-in) and those that are really potentially damaging (undermining you in front of your boss, stealing your ideas).\n\nThe latter you should address directly, just as you would with any colleague. Take on such problems as they arise, don\u2019t let them slide \u2014 or, worse, pile up. Start with a frank response that lets her off the hook somewhat, but sends a clear message: \u201cYou presented my perpetual-motion machine concept as if it were yours \u2014 why did you do that?\u201d If such habits persist, be more blunt: \u201cMaybe you don\u2019t mean it this way, but when you say X to our boss, that causes me problem Z.\u201d Be civilized but firm, leaving out any \u201cI know we\u2019re friends, but \u2026\u201d caveats. (And if you feel clarifying, for instance, the ownership of an idea with your manager is useful, do so.)\n\nPolicing these more substantial offenses might make your work relationship more tolerable in general. If not, you still have room to draw some boundaries \u2014 and you might find the most effective way to do so is to position this as a reflection of your preferences, not her limitations.", "title": "When a Good Friend Becomes a Terrible Colleague", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Ghandour said he had paid a premium to have a near hospital-grade HEPA air-filtration system installed since his 13-year-old daughter was born with special needs that include respiratory problems. The system was supposed to keep unfiltered outside air from entering the home.\n\nMore frequently, whenever it rains, Mr. Ghandour said there are several rooms that have water leaks, including an HVAC room with sensitive electronic equipment. The house, which is divided into three separate structures, includes a building that was designed to hold a sauna, steam room and showers. Mr. Ghandour said the leaking is so bad in that building that it sits unfinished and entirely empty.\n\nBack in 2009, when planning for the project began, Mr. Ghandour, the founder of a Los Angeles-based venture capital firm, said he interviewed four contractors and ultimately decided to take the unusual step of hiring a commercial builder after being approached by a well-known company. He said they sold him on the idea that they would be perfect for the job because a home as large as his wouldn\u2019t be like building a typical single-family house. So why hire a typical homebuilder? Plus, the exterior his architect designed would have more in common with an office building or commercial space.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe company he hired was Lendlease, best known for its construction work on high-profile projects like the National September 11 Memorial & Museum at the World Trade Center, the Sydney Opera House in Australia and the Petronas Twin Towers skyscrapers in Malaysia. \u201cLendlease sold me on that they\u2019d be able to translate that experience into high-end homes,\u201d Mr. Ghandour said.\n\nThough representatives of Lendlease told him they hadn\u2019t yet built any comparable luxury homes, Mr. Ghandour said he was assured that his project would get special attention because it would be their first. \u201cThey said, \u2018We\u2019ll start a new line of business and this will be the showcase, the showpiece,\u2019\u201d he said.\n\nLendlease declined to comment on Mr. Ghandour\u2019s characterization of its proposal or confirm whether the company had previously built any luxury homes of that scale. A spokeswoman said the company has built more than 400 residential projects, mostly in military master-planned sustainable communities for the Department of Defense.\n\nMr. Ghandour said he pleaded with Lendlease to get its subcontractors to fix various problems along the way. At one point, he said, Lendlease stopped responding, so he hired a high-profile construction lawyer, Robert Mann, to pursue a legal claim against Lendlease in 2016. He wants the company to pay for the necessary repairs he has made, plus other damage he still needs to fix. \u201cWhat I was hoping for them from the beginning was that they\u2019d just do a good job,\u201d Mr. Ghandour said. \u201cAnd if they didn\u2019t do that, then they\u2019d fix whatever wasn\u2019t done right.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRepresentatives from Lendlease said they were unable to comment on any of Mr. Ghandour\u2019s claims because the case is now in binding arbitration. \u201cWe disagree with Mr. Ghandour\u2019s claims and regret that the matter has gone this far without resolution,\u201d the company said in a statement.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Ghandour said the company did attempt to fix some issues, to no avail. An exterior stucco wall, for example, was meant to look smooth but instead has the look of crumpled paper that has been somewhat flattened. Mr. Ghandour said Lendlease\u2019s subcontractor unsuccessfully attempted to fix it four times.\n\nOther areas of the house could be even harder to repair. A large room at the top of the stairs was framed crookedly, six inches out of square, said Mr. Mann, the lawyer. Mr. Ghandour said he didn\u2019t notice the error until the room\u2019s hardwood floors had been laid down and there was a gap that required an awkward triangular piece to fill.\n\nNow \u201cit basically can\u2019t be fixed\u201d without reframing the building, Mr. Mann said. He also said the home\u2019s drywall was of a low-quality finish more commonly found in tract homes or lower-end commercial buildings. Replacing it would be extremely costly and would likely require Mr. Ghandour and his family to move out for several months.\n\nMr. Ghandour said the toll on his family life has been \u201cdevastating.\u201d During construction, he moved his family four times, signing short-term leases after receiving assurances that he would be able to move into his home soon. By the time the property was cleared for occupancy, his oldest daughter had gone away to college. He said the stress of the project also took a toll on his marriage. \u201cWe\u2019re still patching it back together,\u201d he said.\n\nJason Kellogg, a South Florida-based construction litigation lawyer who isn\u2019t involved in Mr. Ghandour\u2019s case, said the recent boom in mega-mansion building has prompted a growing number of inexperienced builders to try to get into the business.\n\nThough very large homes are in some ways similar to commercial structures, he said, mega-mansions are still best handled by contractors who have experience building large residences. Because \u201conce problems start,\u201d he said, \u201cthey become immensely costly.\u201d", "title": "When a Mega-Mansion Runs Over Budget", "authors": ["Candace Jackson"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nI\u2019m one of those head-in-the-sand people who would rather not know about guns and violence and how terrible bombings and shootings can be.\n\nIn 2013, I was at the Boston Marathon when the bombs went off. I grabbed my family, and we rushed out of that city. But I had to return the next day to report on the victims and their injuries. It was unbearably sad and even though I ran the marathon the next year; even though was supposed to be a celebration of resilience, I did not feel that way at all. I remembered too well what had happened to those bombing victims.\n\nSo, of course, I read the minimum about the Parkland shooting. I knew the basics. A teenager went into a Florida high school on Valentine\u2019s Day, armed with a military style weapon, and began shooting. In six minutes he killed 14 students and three staff members and injured many others.\n\nThen my editors asked me to write about assault-style weapons like the AR-15 used in Parkland and what they do to the human body. My big concern was that the story had to be compelling enough that someone like me \u2014 who would rather not know \u2014 would start it and read it to the end. That meant, as always, writing for an audience of one \u2014 me. And I did not want to be polemical. This was not the place to rail about gun laws. It was going to be a story about the destruction assault type weapons can wreak.\n\nIt began as a solo project. But my editor, Celia Dugger, ultimately suggested bringing in C.J. Chivers. At the start, I knew nothing about guns; C.J., on the other hand, is a Pulitzer-Prize winning reporter who modestly says he has \u201csome seeming fluency here from a lot of years of writing about weapons, and from being in the infantry.\u201d His tweaks to my language describing weapons and bullets made such a difference that it was only right to share the byline with him.\n\nAs for the reporting, I began by finding trauma surgeons who had been in the military and cared for shooting victims. I knew a few, because I had written about Representative Steve Scalise, who was shot while practicing baseball last summer and spent months recovering from a bullet that cracked his bones and rended his internal organs. One surgeon, who said he cannot speak on the record, connected me with others who could.\n\nStill, was I just going to get the same story over and over about trying to repair wounds? Could a surgeon explain more than just how to repair an injury? And was a military assault weapon, the M16, pretty much the same as an AR-15, the gun the shooter used, in terms of the damage they could inflict?\n\nThe effects of the weapons\u2019 bullets, I soon discovered, were pretty much equivalent. Through the eyes of each surgeon, however, I saw a different picture.\n\nOne told me about the nature of the wounds. He\u2019d see a little hole where the bullet entered and think it was not so bad. Then he\u2019d turn the patient over, and see an exit wound that could be a foot wide.\n\nAnother told me what it looks like when a victim arrives at the operating room, bones shattered, organs shredded: \u201cIt\u2019s like a bomb went off.\u201d\n\nFor me, it found that it reading about these horrors was different than reporting on them. It\u2019s hard to explain why; perhaps it\u2019s something like the experience of those who tend to the wounded, that detachment they wear like shields.\n\nWhen I thought I was done with the story, I was put in touch with Dr. Lillian Liao, a surgeon who cared for children shot with an AR-15 in the November Sutherland Springs church shooting. Dr. Liao was professional; she seemed almost dispassionate as she described grievous injuries. But when I asked her if it affected her, she told me two things.\n\nDr. Liao was focused on getting the children stable enough to return home \u2014 although they faced many operations and are still being treated at her hospital, University Hospital and UT Health in San Antonio. She knew they would need rehabilitation to help them learn to walk or use their arms again. She knew they were seeing psychiatrists to help with the trauma.\n\nThen, about two weeks later, she began to think about what had happened \u2014 these children\u2019s lives would never be the same.\n\nShe went on, putting the horror behind her. Until the Parkland shootings, at which point she could no longer forget.", "title": "When a Reporter Borrows the Eyes of Trauma Surgeons", "authors": ["Gina Kolata"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Erectile dysfunction is a factor for some men, especially over the age of 40. Other men may have low testosterone (although there is a lot of dispute in this area). There is also the possibility that one partner in a heterosexual relationship is gay.\n\nNew love is intoxicating, and I\u2019m not being metaphorical. A functional MRI study suggests that new love activates the reward centers of the brain and, like opioids, increases pain tolerance. I wonder how much the drug that is new love affects libido? If some men and women are simply on a lower libido spectrum in everyday life, might they revert to that once this \u201clove drug\u201d subsides, leaving those with a higher libido frustrated?\n\nI want women to know that if they are on the wanting end for sex, they are not alone. If you love the person you\u2019re with, then the sooner you speak up, the better. You can try what I did \u2014 sleeping naked and scheduling sex \u2014 because the more you have sex, the more you may want to have it, if you\u2019re doing it right and it feels good. However, if things are not changing in the way you want, you may need help from a couples counselor, a sex therapist, a clinical psychologist or a medical doctor, depending on the situation.\n\nWaiting until months or even years have passed can weaponize the bedroom. It will add so much more complexity because resentment compounds like a high-interest credit card.\n\nSexuality and relationships are complex, and there are no easy answers. It\u2019s not good or bad to have a high, a medium or a low libido. You like what you like, but if you don\u2019t speak up about what you want, you can\u2019t expect the other person to know.\n\nOur society seems almost built on the erroneous idea that all men want sex all the time, so I imagine it would be hard for men to admit to a lower libido, even anonymously. I have lied about my weight on many forms. That doesn\u2019t make me a broken person; it just proves that a cloak of invisibility doesn\u2019t hide you from yourself. The most damaging lies are the ones we tell ourselves.", "title": "When the Cause of a Sexless Relationship Is \u2014 Surprise! \u2014 the Man", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "EATON, N.Y. \u2014 Fred Morgan was already deep in debt from rebuilding his milking barn after a fire when milk prices plunged in 2015, setting off an economic drought that is now entering its fourth year \u2014 the worst in recent memory for dairy farmers in New York State.\n\nMr. Morgan, 50, saw no way to save the dairy farm in central New York State that he took over as a teenager from his ailing father and ran with his wife, Judy, and their son, Cody.\n\nWith the farm operating at a loss and facing foreclosure, Mr. Morgan believed his only solution was his $150,000 life insurance policy. He said he planned on killing himself so his family could receive the payout.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d sacrifice my life so my family could keep the farm,\u201d Mr. Morgan said. His wife persuaded him otherwise.", "title": "When the Death of a Family Farm Leads to Suicide", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cPeople knew Connecticut because of Sandy Hook,\u201d said Mr. Bennett, who has had several relatives become victims of gun violence. \u201cBut me and so many other pastors have to do too many funerals, deal with too many mothers who have to pick up the pieces after their children die, and see too many family members killed because of illegal guns.\u201d\n\nRather than pressing for outright divestment, the campaign\u2019s strategy depends on staying engaged with the industry, government customers and investors. The campaign is convening a group in the coming weeks to develop a set of guiding principles for investors, akin to the Sullivan Principles, a code of corporate conduct developed in the 1970s in the fight against apartheid.\n\nThe recent moves by retailers and N.R.A. corporate sponsors have reaffirmed their commitment to leverage purchasing and investor power, even if manufacturers seem reluctant or if the gun lobby blows the dog-whistle of \u201cEuropean-style socialism.\u201d Every reaction, for good or bad, dictates their next action.\n\n\u201cCorporations can play such a big role,\u201d Rabbi Mosbacher said. \u201cThey have power well beyond what a few imams, rabbis and ministers have. And they can use their power without any more laws being passed.\u201d\n\nBut, as some officials have asked, will it prevent the next mass shooting, given that there are already enough weapons out there to arm every American?\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t promise that,\u201d he said. \u201cNot with 300 million guns in this country. There is no magic solution, but does that mean we shouldn\u2019t try to turn the tide?\u201d\n\nRabbi Mosbacher has come a long way since that day when a gun ended his father\u2019s life. And while he speaks with urgency about the need to continue pressing for change, one feeling has stayed constant.\n\n\u201cI, like most people hopefully, have learned from the joyous and challenging moments in my life,\u201d he said. \u201cThat said, I would give everything back \u2014 all that growth I found \u2014 to have my father back.\u201d", "title": "When the Dollar Is Mightier Than the Gun", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "But economists do not necessarily agree.\n\nThose who study immigration and labor patterns have questioned the wisdom of restricting family-based immigration, a crucial source of low-skilled workers, many of whom hail from countries like Mexico and the Philippines, where Ms. Mangayan, 47, is from.\n\n\u201cIn any plausible future scenario, the U.S. needs far more new low-skilled workers than high-skilled workers,\u201d said Michael Clemens, an economist at the Center for Global Development, a Washington think tank, \u201cso many that it will be impossible for native labor to fill all those jobs, even if native workers wanted to.\u201d\n\nAccording to a Bureau of Labor Statistics analysis, among the 10 occupations expected to grow the most through 2026, only three require university degrees, all of them digital or data-focused: software developers, statisticians and mathematicians.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe two that will require the most new workers: personal care and home health aides, with 1.2 million new positions between them.\n\nAbout 10,000 baby boomers turn 65 every day, and more than half will need long-term care, according to the Pew Research Center. Already, home-care agencies and elderly-care facilities are struggling to recruit.\n\n\u201cIf one of our aides is sick or has an emergency, it\u2019s very difficult to find a backup,\u201d said Kevin Smith, the president of Best of Care in the Boston area, who taps into the large Haitian and Brazilian communities in Massachusetts.\n\nIn 2017, 26 percent of personal care aides and home health aides were foreign born, a high, according to an analysis of official data by Brian Schaitkin, a senior economist at the Conference Board. In New York, 62 percent of home aides were foreign born. In California, Massachusetts and New Jersey, foreigners represented nearly half of them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLupe Mercado, a Mexican immigrant who works for an agency called 24Hr HomeCare in Los Angeles, has endeared herself to clients with dementia who initially cursed and flung food at her. One of them recently died holding her hand, Ms. Mercado noted, brandishing a picture of the woman on her cellphone.\n\nOn a recent afternoon, she doted on Olive Tanaka, 92. \u201cI\u2019m spoiled by her,\u201d said Ms. Tanaka, a line dancer in her day who is now widowed, blind in one eye and needs round-the-clock care since suffering a fall.\n\nHaving entered the United States illegally, Ms. Mercado benefited from a 1986 amnesty law signed by President Ronald Reagan, obtaining a green card and eventually becoming a citizen.\n\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t pay so much, but I love my job,\u201d said Ms. Mercado, who earns $12 an hour and supplements her pay by taking private clients on her days off.\n\nProponents of restricting immigration say the low wages in her field \u2014 and in other workplaces where immigrants have a foothold, like construction, farms, and restaurant kitchens \u2014 are a prime reason immigrants have begun to supplant American workers in the jobs.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists.
