Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSome of those other professions, too, face worker shortages. A survey in September by the Associated General Contractors of America found that 70 percent of construction firms were having difficulty finding bricklayers, roofers and electricians, among others. Last August, the restaurant and accommodation sector had 742,000 vacancies, a historic high, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.\n\nStemming the flow of low-skilled immigrants could pressure employers to raise wages, compelling many Americans, including millions who are chronically unemployed, to get back to work. \u201cIt may draw all these people, or some fraction of these people, into the labor force,\u201d posited Steven Camarota, research director of the Center for Immigration Studies, which supports curbs on immigration.\n\nIndeed, more people would do blue-collar work they now shun if wages were higher \u2014 but not enough of them would, according to Chris Tilly, a labor economist at the University of California, Los Angeles.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWage is not the main issue,\u201d he said. \u201cThere are also expectations and status. Not everybody wants to work with their hands touching people; not everybody will do dirty work.\u201d\n\nSupporters of an immigration overhaul cite other reasons the country should be choosier about whom it lets in. The Trump administration has also framed it as a national security issue, noting several cases in which terror suspects came to the United States through family connections. Immigrants are also more likely to use welfare programs than native-born Americans, owing largely to their comparatively low skill levels upon arrival, the Center for Immigration Studies says, citing Census Bureau data.\n\nUnder a Senate bill introduced by the Republicans Tom Cotton of Arkansas and David Perdue of Georgia, and supported by the White House, citizens and permanent residents, or green card holders, could continue to bring spouses and children under 18 into the United States. But they would no longer be able to sponsor parents, adult children, siblings, nephews and nieces.\n\nThe bill would also create a point system for admission based on factors including education, English skills and job offers in the United States, and it would cut the overall number of green cards awarded each year by half, to 500,000.\n\nEmployers who rely on immigrant labor are anxious about what will happen in Washington. Senior-care agencies in particular are worried because many are dependent on Medicaid and Medicare and so cannot, they say, easily raise wages to make their jobs more attractive to native-born workers.\n\nIf Congress makes it harder for relatives to immigrate, \u201cWhere are all these workers going to come from?\u201d asked Patricia Will, the founder of Belmont Village, a Houston-based network of upscale facilities that employs 4,000 people in several states.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Mangayan, who makes $29,000 a year plus benefits at Belmont Village in Burbank, came to the United States in 1997 after marrying an American citizen, and she is now a citizen herself. She would have been able to immigrate under the proposed rules, though many of her co-workers would not.\n\nMs. Mangayan and her husband, a customer-service representative at the airport, earn enough to afford a $1,200-a-month two-bedroom apartment, their 23-year-old son\u2019s college tuition and occasional travel to the Philippines. Ms. Mangayan cuts hair on the side to make extra money.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Mangayan, who also has a 14-year-old daughter, said that one day, \u201cI would like to have at least a condo.\u201d\n\nNot long after arriving for her 3 p.m. to 11 p.m. shift one recent afternoon, she was already darting from room to room.\n\nIn Room 411, she improvised sign language to communicate with Bernard Bragg, an 89-year-old who achieved fame decades ago as a deaf actor.\n\nMr. Bragg, asked what he thought of Ms. Mangayan, pointed to her, placed his hands over his heart and smiled lovingly. He then flapped his arms to suggest she was an angel.\n\nVelma Vincent, in Room 406, credited Ms. Mangayan with restoring her will to live and ability to walk after her husband died.\n\n\u201cI was a goner,\u201d recalled Ms. Vincent, 88, who was resplendent in a bright-red blouse and white slacks with matching red necklace, earrings and nail polish. \u201cIrma came in and encouraged me.\u201d\n\nMs. Mangayan had coaxed Ms. Vincent to get out of her wheelchair, practice baby steps down the hall, going farther and farther each time. Soon, Ms. Vincent was mobile \u2014 and independent \u2014 with her walker, playing blackjack and Bingo, attending church and visiting Belmont Village\u2019s beauty salon.\n\n\u201cMy family will be forever grateful,\u201d said her son, Bob Vincent. \u201cthat Irma emigrated from the Philippines to the United States, giving my mom a quality of life that she would not enjoy were it not for Irma.\u201d", "title": "When the Elderly Call for Help, a \u2018Chain\u2019 Immigrant Often Answers", "authors": ["Miriam Jordan"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Foreign policy experts are betting on a fantasy, one mostly confined to the Acela Express. Those experts who seek to shape public opinion, to judge by their columns, interviews and tweets, have faced this responsibility only halfway. The president could not be luckier. Little short of catastrophe will vindicate his critics. Mr. Trump can clear their low bar by being unspectacularly awful. More important, the current debate does nothing to forge a future foreign policy that improves on what preceded Mr. Trump\u2019s election. Far from devising alternatives, experts are shutting down needed debate by collapsing America\u2019s interests into an abstract \u201corder.\u201d They increasingly resemble the \u201cglobalists\u201d whom candidate Trump derided.\n\nThe irony is, Mr. Trump was wrong. Policymakers have always put American interests first, adjusting (or defying) the rules accordingly. In 1945, Harry Truman met Winston Churchill and Josef Stalin in war-torn Potsdam, Germany. If this was the moment of creation of the \u201cliberal international order,\u201d as today\u2019s commentators maintain, Truman did not know it. (Neither he nor his advisers used the phrase.) The frustrated president wrote to his wife, Bess, \u201cI have to make it perfectly plain to them at least once a day that so far as this President is concerned Santa Claus is dead and that my first interest is U.S.A.\u201d\n\nTruman understood what Mr. Trump\u2019s critics implicitly deny: the possibility that American power can come at the expense of others. The foreign policy establishment clings to the fiction that what\u2019s good for America is necessarily good for the world. They condemn Mr. Trump\u2019s tariffs as an unthinkable breach even though the United States has employed protectionist measures throughout history. They pretend that Mr. Trump, having vowed to take things from the world, must be diminishing American power when he seeks to expand it. Mr. Trump\u2019s actions may not have their intended effect, but the most logical and cutting response isn\u2019t that he is weakening America but that he\u2019s trying to strengthen it in a way we should not want. His outpouring of militarism and chauvinism may or may not reduce the United States\u2019 influence. It does, however, threaten to turn the world\u2019s sole superpower into an unabashed purveyor of violence and exploitation.\n\nLet\u2019s call Mr. Trump\u2019s vision what it is: radical American imperialism. He does not so much break with tradition as bring forward some of its most retrograde but persistent elements. Recognizing this is the start of an honest conversation about the Trump administration and America\u2019s role in a changing world. So far, however, the right has come closer to grasping this point than the left or the center. Mr. Trump and his supporters do identify a conflict (indeed, almost endless conflict) between America\u2019s interests and the world\u2019s. As Rush Limbaugh recently put it, Mr. Trump wants to restore the \u201cprimacy of the United States,\u201d whereas his critics think \u201cAmerican leadership should preside over the weakening of America.\u201d The point is perverse, but it is coherent. Fearing decline, the Trumpian right seeks to get tough with the world and take all it can.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s challenge can be met. As distributional conflicts surge in domestic politics, they are surging in foreign policy, too \u2014 and those who ignore them lose out to those who inflate them. Citizens seeking a better foreign policy ought to be engaged, not ignored. But recent events cast doubt on whether our current crop of experts is up to the job.\n\nDemocracy requires experts but it also requires something from them: that they facilitate public debate and respect the ultimate power of the electorate to set the aims of the nation. By rallying behind the lowest common denominator of \u201canything but Trump,\u201d they are disengaging the public\u2019s discontent, pulling up the drawbridge until the next election. In that sense, Donald Trump is not the only one who might be called an isolationist.", "title": "Opinion | When the Leader of the Free World Is an Ugly American", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt was all about propaganda and P.R.,\u201d said Jonathan Bikker, the curator of the Rijksmuseum exhibition. \u201cI think that\u2019s why the monarchy and the high nobility had such a strong hold on that format. They made it associated with them and them alone.\u201d\n\nThe nobility would often use the full-length portrait to celebrate the union of two influential families. Such was the case with Henry IV, duke of Saxony, and his bride, Catherine of Mecklenburg, whose 1514 portraits by the German artist Lucas Cranach the Elder were opulently adorned in the colors of their coats of arms. The continuation of a powerful dynasty could also by emphasized by the inclusion of children.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe association of the nobility attracted the Dutch bourgeoisie to the format in the 17th century. Having gained wealth and power, they used their portraits to claim a comparable importance. Those who could afford such lavish works of art hung them in the entrance halls of their canalside houses to show visitors that they were members of an exclusive club. \u201cOnly 20 of these portraits that were made in Amsterdam between 1618 and \u201939 have survived, and they\u2019re all of the city elite,\u201d said Mr. Bikker.\n\nArtists had a variety of methods to highlight their clients\u2019 status. Rembrandt, for example, used his masterful skill in depicting texture and fabric to draw attention to the wealth of the prominent Amsterdam citizens Marten Soolmans and his bride, Oopjen Coppit, in their portraits. It is a common misconception that the Dutch of that era wore black out of puritan self-restraint \u2014 as the Rijksmuseum\u2019s curator of costume, Bianca du Mortier, explained, that could not be further from the truth.\n\n\u201cBlack was very expensive because it involved a complex dyeing process,\u201d she said. Wearing it was a sign of status, particularly when it was elaborately embellished, as in the Rembrandt example.\n\nPhoto\n\nDuring the 18th century, when the full-length portrait was at its peak in Britain, two very different social groups took advantage of its promotional opportunities. Aristocratic women, like Jane Fleming, would flaunt their beauty and elegance with help from masters of the genre such as Joshua Reynolds, while aristocratic men would show off their personal or professional accomplishments. The intention was the same: to enhance their reputation in society.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the other group were the growing ranks of professional actors and actresses whose successes had made them independently wealthy. They commissioned portraits in their most admired roles as a form of self-promotion. Both groups benefited from the creation of the Royal Academy, Britain\u2019s first combined art school and exhibition space, where many portraits were first exhibited, giving them unrivaled public exposure.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Belle \u00c9poque, the period of optimism and economic prosperity in Europe from 1871 to 1914, was the heyday for this most sumptuous of portrait formats. In the aftermath of the French, American and Industrial Revolutions, a newly rich clientele clamored for the ultimate drawing room accessory to emphasize their entry into high society.\n\nFor women like Virginie Gautreau, a noted Paris beauty who prided herself on pale skin that she maintained by drinking arsenic, \u201cit was important to be painted at full-length because it really showed that you belonged\u201d to the elite, Mr. Bikker said. However, for Madame Gautreau, it backfired spectacularly. Her deathly pallor and daringly low-cut dress caused a major scandal when the portrait was exhibited at the Paris Salon in 1884. Madame Gautreau was humiliated, and the portraitist, the American painter John Singer Sargent, fled to England. The work (not included in the exhibition) became known as \u201cMadame X.\u201d\n\nIt is doubtful if such a thing would have bothered Marchesa Luisa Casati, a woman who wore live snakes as jewelry and paraded around her hometown, Venice, with a pair of cheetahs on leashes. The marchesa was painted in her prime by Giovanni Boldini in 1908; the bold brush strokes, confident pose and penetrating gaze perfectly sum up a woman whose aim in life was to be nothing less than a work of art.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe striking images created of her and of others like her were drawing attention from fashion designers who realized that having a celebrated sitter dressed in one of their creations was an opportunity for mutual publicity. At the request of Les Modes, a French fashion magazine, Boldini\u2019s painting of the marchesa was exhibited at the couturier Jacques Doucet\u2019s fashion house in Paris, with his creations displayed around it.\n\nIt was an early indicator of the link between personality and commerce that gathered momentum as the century progressed. In the aftermath of World War I, the extravagance of the full-length portrait came to be seen as excessive and the formal society that the portrait relied on began to disintegrate.\n\nA new breed of celebrity turned to news releases and magazine covers to shape their image. But while those ephemeral means are soon forgotten, the full-length portrait will dazzle for centuries to come.", "title": "When the Old Masters Were the P.R. Agents of the Rich and Powerful", "authors": ["Cath Pound"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Q. My condo in Murray Hill overlooks the patio of an apartment in a rental building across the street. The residents of that apartment throw fraternity-style parties that include beer pong. I don\u2019t really mind the parties, but I do mind the hundreds of beer cans and plastic cups strewn all over their balcony, which create quite a mess and are an eyesore. They leave the mess there for weeks at a time. Does this run afoul of any New York City laws since the mess is on their balcony?\n\nA. Watching someone else\u2019s game of beer pong from afar is a rather unpleasant experience (who really wants to think about those juvenile college days after you\u2019re all grown up?). But being forced to stare at the aftermath for weeks is simply gross. I can understand why you\u2019d want your neighbors to get a broom and a trash bag and clean up.\n\nYou can nudge them along. The city\u2019s Housing Maintenance Code sets minimum standards for things like health and safety, fire protection, cleanliness and building maintenance. According to the code, owners and residents are required to keep roofs, yards and other open spaces clean and free from dirt, filth, garbage and offensive material. All that trash on their balcony is not only unsightly, it also poses a safety hazard. For example, if the balcony is an escape route, it could impede a safe exit.\n\nAsk Real Estate Submit your questions, share your stories and tell us what topics interest you most. Post a comment or email us at realestateqa@nytimes.com.\n\n\u201cIt is very likely that the failure to clean up this outdoor space amounts to a violation of the offending tenants\u2019 lease,\u201d said Debra J. Guzov, a lawyer in Manhattan.\n\nFigure out what company manages the property. Some buildings have a placard at the entrance with the name of the managing agent. You could also ask the doorman or superintendent for the name. Write the managing agent a letter explaining the situation and asking management to address it. This might be enough to solve the problem. However, if the trash problem continues, call 311 and report the issue to the city. If an inspector finds that the state of the balcony violates city rules, the building will receive a violation. No landlord wants to pay a fine for someone else\u2019s trash. \u201cSo the pressure will surely be exerted over the tenants to start cleaning up after themselves,\u201d Ms. Guzov said.", "title": "When the Party\u2019s Over, but the Beer Cans Remain", "authors": ["Ronda Kaysen", "Ask Real Estate"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "It has been seven years since the Securities and Exchange Commission first advised public companies to tell investors if they had suffered a cyberattack deemed to be material. But even with the rising number of severe hacks, only a few companies report incidents each year to the S.E.C.\n\nNow the S.E.C. has issued updated cybersecurity guidance. Again, it warned public companies to make \u201ctimely\u201d disclosure, recognizing the \u201cgrave threat\u201d that cybercrime poses to investors and the capital markets.\n\nYet, the S.E.C.\u2019s new guidance doesn\u2019t confront the practical quandary facing public companies victimized by a cyberattack: Going public with news of a cyberattack isn\u2019t always an easy call. Doing so can risk tipping off the bad guys and imperil investigations. Law enforcement often encourages, or even demands, that the incident not be disclosed. At the same time, companies know they have a duty to their investors to provide prompt information about any real risks to their businesses.\n\nThis tension between the need for discreet cooperation with law enforcement and the obligation to inform investors and the markets creates a dilemma for public companies. Unfortunately, the commission\u2019s updated guidance provides little direction to corporate leaders confronting these conflicting demands. While the guidance acknowledges that it will often take time to \u201cdiscern the implications\u201d of a breach and that it \u201cmay be necessary to cooperate\u201d with law enforcement, it concludes that an active investigation would not \u201con its own\u201d be a reason to avoid disclosure of a material cybersecurity incident.", "title": "When to Report a Cyberattack? For Companies, That\u2019s Still a Dilemma", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Grant Snider is a cartoonist and illustrator, and the author, most recently, of \u201cThe Shape of Ideas.\u201d\n\nFollow New York Times Books on Facebook and Twitter, sign up for our newsletter or our literary calendar. And listen to us on the Book Review podcast.", "title": "Whenever, Wherever", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Our recent article \u201cThe Yorkie\u2019s Dominance: We Analyzed Every Dog Registration in New York\u201d told the story of the city\u2019s changing neighborhoods through the dogs that live in them, noting the curious phenomenon of how smaller dogs seem to predominate in areas where prices are rising.\n\nThe inverse, of course, isn\u2019t usually true: The appearance of larger dogs doesn\u2019t mean prices are falling. But if you own one of those big dogs, where are you likely to live?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis week, we dug into New York\u2019s dog registration database again, analyzing 583,841 dog registrations between 2012 and 2016, to determine where big dogs are most popular \u2014 or, to be precise, which boroughs have the highest percentage of dogs that weigh more than 50 pounds.\n\nStaten Island came out on top, with some 18 percent of its registrations (or 10,147) for large dogs. With plenty of backyards and outdoor space, that seemed to make sense. Densely populated Manhattan had close to the smallest share \u2014 also fairly predictable \u2014 with just under 14 percent of its registrations for dogs over 50 pounds.\n\nDogs Over 50 Pounds Staten Island 18% large dogs 10,147 large dogs out of 57,136 Queens 14% large dogs 16,935 of 120,245 Brooklyn 14% large dogs 19,520 of 139,535 Manhattan 14% large dogs 26,922 of 195,321 Bronx 10% large dogs 6,590 large dogs of 63,772 Borough Unknown: 14.5% large dogs, 1,138 of 7,832 Staten Island 18% large dogs 10,147 large dogs out of 57,136 Queens 14% large dogs 16,935 of 120,245 Brooklyn 14% large dogs 19,520 of 139,535 Manhattan 14% large dogs 26,922 of 195,321 Bronx 10% large dogs 6,590 large dogs of 63,772 Borough Unknown: 14.50% large dogs, 1,138 of 7,832\n\nAt the neighborhood level, it was less predictable. The highest rates of large dogs, it turns out, can be found not just in Stapleton, on Staten Island, but in Manhattan\u2019s cramped SoHo/Greenwich Village area, where an impressive 19 percent of the registrations were for big dogs.", "title": "Where Are All the Big Dogs?", "authors": ["Michael Kolomatsky"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "SYDNEY, Australia \u2014 One day in April 2016, Kate Brandis opened a weathered envelope, mailed to her from suburban Sydney. Instead of a letter inside, she found the feathers of an Australian white ibis. A day or so later, another envelope arrived, stuffed with more feathers. In the days following, more began to come.\n\nSoon, Dr. Brandis, who is a research fellow at the University of New South Wales\u2019s Center for Ecosystem Science, was receiving three to four envelopes a day containing the feathers of birds from across Australia, including those of pelicans, wood ducks, cormorants, herons and spoonbills.\n\n\u201cIt was really exciting,\u201d Dr. Brandis said, sitting in her office at the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organization in Sydney in January. Two years before, she had put out a call to the public to send her fallen feathers of wetland birds so she could analyze where they came from, in an effort to map how the birds are moving between the country\u2019s disappearing wetlands.", "title": "Where Do Birds Flock Together? Australians Are Mailing In Feathers to Help Find Out", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump announced on Tuesday that he would nominate Mike Pompeo, the director of the C.I.A., to be the next secretary of state now that Rex Tillerson has been pushed out. This is bad news for the country and the world.\n\nIf confirmed, Mr. Pompeo will bring to the job not the discretion and objectivity of a former intelligence chief, but instead the habits of a fierce ideologue, which is precisely what he continued to be as C.I.A. director, typically a nonpartisan position. He has been the most political head of the agency since William Casey in the 1980s. Mr. Pompeo has repeatedly stepped out of the proper role of an intelligence director to be an advocate for hawkish policies. The ruthless partisanship he displayed as a congressman foreshadows how he will perform at the State Department.\n\nMr. Pompeo is a staunch defender of Mr. Trump and echoes his preferences on major national security and foreign policy matters. That\u2019s likely the main reason he was given Mr. Tillerson\u2019s job as the United States\u2019 top diplomat. As secretary of state, Mr. Pompeo would reinforce Mr. Trump\u2019s more destructive inclinations on several key issues:\n\nIran. In commenting to reporters on the appointment, Mr. Trump singled out the Iran nuclear agreement as an issue on which he disagreed with Mr. Tillerson, saying, \u201cI think it\u2019s terrible; I guess he thought it was O.K.\u201d But with Mr. Pompeo, continued the president, \u201cwe have a very similar thought process.\u201d\n\nMr. Pompeo has indeed been a fervent foe of the 2015 nuclear agreement. While in Congress, he pursued every possible avenue to discredit and undermine it. He talked of imaginary \u201csecret side deals\u201d that the Obama administration had allegedly made with Iran and has played down the costs of bombing Iran. As director of the C.I.A., Mr. Pompeo has likened Iran to the Islamic State and has tried to make a case that Iran is allied with Al Qaeda, even ordering another dive into already-exploited documents captured in the raid that killed Osama bin Laden, and then taking the highly irregular step of furnishing a cherry-picked result to an advocacy group that opposes the nuclear agreement.", "title": "Opinion | Where Does Mike Pompeo Stand on the Issues? Too Close to Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "For nearly a decade, the photographer John Moore has traversed the Mexico-United States border, covering the story of immigration from all sides \u2014 American, Mexican, immigrant and border agent.\n\nHis depiction of the border is both literal and figurative.", "title": "Where Fear and Hope Collide: Images From Mexican Border, and Beyond", "authors": ["Azam Ahmed"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "DUNEDIN, Fla. \u2014 Of course, Kevin Pillar remembers his triple last season. How could he forget? Pillar, the Toronto Blue Jays\u2019 center fielder, smoked a deep drive into the right-field corner at Busch Stadium in St. Louis. The Cardinals\u2019 Stephen Piscotty leapt and smashed into the fence, never touching the ball, which caromed hard off the padding and skipped far away.\n\nPillar pulled into third with the triple \u2014 but that wasn\u2019t what made the play memorable. The runner ahead of him, Chris Coghlan, vaulted his way into an eternal video highlight, launching his body over catcher Yadier Molina to score. The oddity of Pillar\u2019s feat, alas, was an afterthought.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s definitely a huge thrill to hit a triple,\u201d Pillar said. \u201cBut that\u2019s usually one of the only times you\u2019ll see a triple now, when a guy leaves his feet and the ball gets by him. To hit a ball in the gap and just flat out outrun the defender and the ball to third base is something you don\u2019t see very often.\u201d\n\nLast season, the Blue Jays did it less often than any other team in major league history. They hit five triples in 2017 \u2014 yes, five, a record low by a team in a season, including strike years. The Blue Jays\u2019 hitters were in no hurry to see Luis Rivera, their third-base coach, unless they were slapping his hand on a home run trot. At least Rivera didn\u2019t take it personally.", "title": "Where Have All the Triples Gone? (Don\u2019t Look for Them in Toronto)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "It might be an awkward setting for Mr. Trump, though, who would be wary of not being seen as a supplicant. And North Korea might want to give Mr. Trump, who has expressed an interest in military parades, a display of its own.\n\nWhen Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright visited Pyongyang in 2000 in an attempt to convince Kim Jong-il, Kim Jong-un\u2019s father, to halt his ballistic missile program, she attended a mass propaganda performance that included an image of the very missile she was trying to get North Korea to curtail.\n\nJeju Island, South Korea\n\nThe governor of the South Korean island of Jeju has proposed holding the meeting there. The island, south of the Korean Peninsula, is a tourist destination, and its relatively small size and population could make security easier than in a large city like Seoul, the South\u2019s capital.\n\nWashington\n\nPhoto\n\nWashington would also be a potential spot, although Mr. Kim would most likely be wary of making the American capital his first trip abroad as North Korea\u2019s leader.\n\nA meeting there would also be awkward for the White House, which would be wary of the propaganda value it could give the North. When Marshal Jo Myong-rok, a high-level North Korean military official, visited Washington in 2000 to invite Mr. Clinton to Pyongyang, he first met with Dr. Albright while wearing a business suit. He then changed into a medal-festooned military uniform and high-brimmed hat to meet with Mr. Clinton, creating an uncomfortable image for the White House.\n\nBeijing\n\nChina is North Korea\u2019s only significant ally, although their relationship has hardly been close in recent years. Still, China was one of the few countries Kim Jong-il traveled to as North Korea\u2019s leader.\n\nChina has also played an active role in promoting negotiations among all sides and was a host to the so-called six-party talks a decade ago. Geng Shuang, a Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman, said Friday that China welcomed the meeting and would \u201ccontinue to make unremitting efforts\u201d for a \u201cpeaceful settlement of the nuclear issue.\u201d But he did not directly answer a question about whether Beijing would be host.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGeneva\n\nPhoto\n\nGeneva, the city in neutral Switzerland, has hosted high-level meetings between rivals, like between President Ronald Reagan and the Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev in 1985. And Kim Jong-un would have more familiarity with the country, where he studied in the late 1990s, than most other places.\n\nMoscow\n\nLike China, Russia has been an occasional destination for North Korean leaders. Mr. Kim himself has not gone as leader, though. He canceled plans to travel to Moscow in 2015 for events to mark the 70th anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany in World War II. A visit to Moscow might not look good for Mr. Trump, either, given the charges that Russians tried to interfere in the 2016 election to help his campaign.\n\nStockholm\n\nSweden has long been a key intermediary between the United States and North Korea. The United States does not have an embassy in the North, and Sweden is the so-called protecting power that provides consular services for Americans, including meeting with citizens who are imprisoned there. Sweden has also been the site of talks between North Korean officials and experts from the United States, South Korea and elsewhere. And last week a Swedish newspaper, Dagens Nyheter, reported that Ri Yong-ho, the North Korean foreign minister, would visit Sweden soon, fueling speculation about a possible meeting location.\n\nUlan Bator, Mongolia\n\nPhoto\n\nMongolia, which shares borders with Russia and China, has pursued a policy of neutrality in recent years and has good relations with both the United States and North Korea. Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj, a former Mongolian president, tweeted in support of a meeting in Ulan Bator, saying: \u201cHere is an offer: US President Trump and NK leader Kim meet in UB. Mongolia is the most suitable, neutral territory.\u201d", "title": "Where Might Trump and Kim Jong-un Meet? Here Are Some Possibilities", "authors": ["Austin Ramzy"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "VILNIUS, Lithuania \u2014 During the Holocaust, many Lithuanian Jews were not killed in Nazi death camps, but by their neighbors, usually shot or even beaten to death. In all, 90 percent of an estimated 250,000 Jews perished, wiping out a community that had been part of Lithuanian life for five centuries.\n\nSo it may come as a surprise that in Vilnius, the country\u2019s capital, there is a thriving Jewish community center (including a cafe serving bagels), an expanded new Jewish Museum and fully functioning synagogue \u2014 beneficiaries of a Western-looking government that encourages Litvak Jews to return and has proposed to declare 2019 \u201cThe Year of the Jew.\u201d\n\nIn the Ponary neighborhood, on the outskirts of town, there is a memorial, which eventually included the 70,000 Jews who were stripped naked and shot to death in the forest there. And in the city, there is a huge Museum of Genocide Victims.\n\nThat, however, is where the glowing picture suddenly becomes murky.\n\nUntil recent years, the museum, in what was once the headquarters for the Nazi S.S. and later the K.G.B., the Soviet secret police and intelligence apparatus, did not even mention the Holocaust, in which the German Nazis used Lithuanian partisans and police to round up and kill the country\u2019s Jews.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore Jews were killed in Lithuania, in actual numbers as well as percentages, than German Jews who died in far more populous Germany.", "title": "Where the Genocide Museum Is (Mostly) Mum on the Fate of Jews", "authors": ["Rod Nordland"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "FRIDAY PUZZLE \u2014 By the time you read this, I will be packed and ready to go to the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, which runs this weekend at the Marriott Hotel in Stamford, Conn. Attendance is booming, I\u2019m told, but if you want to pay a walk-in fee and compete or even just observe, I\u2019m sure the tournament host, Will Shortz, will be happy to squeeze you in.\n\nStandings will be posted throughout the weekend as we have time, but you can also follow the puzzle-by-puzzle proceedings on the A.C.P.T. rankings page. Wordplay daily columns will continue through the weekend (the amazingly dangerous Caitlin Lovinger will be here to make sure you don\u2019t have any loud parties while I\u2019m away), and I will be linking early next week to an article I\u2019m writing for the Metro section about the joys of gathering for this pastime of ours.\n\nSpeaking of puzzles, I came away from today\u2019s crossword by Erik Agard with my hair mussed and having broken a light sweat. That\u2019s a good thing, by the way \u2014 a Friday puzzle should make you struggle a bit.\n\nIt\u2019s not just the entries that did that, although there are quite a lot of beauties here. Mr. Agard debuts a total of 11 words and phrases, although one is a scene in a play with a Roman numeral, but you can\u2019t win \u2019em all. The ones that really stood out to me were POLICE BOX (because I am a devoted \u201cDoctor Who\u201d fan who wished for a TARDIS when other kids were wishing for a jet pack); KISS ON THE CHEEK (awww \u2026); MAKEUP TUTORIAL (these are tremendously popular on YouTube and have also become a large part of the ASMR video boom, which focuses on personal care activities to help viewers relax and fall asleep); AFROPUNK; and JANET MOCK, the creator of the #girlslikeus campaign and transgender rights activist. Also, bonus points for debuting the plural ZAMBONIS, which, to me, is one of the funniest words around.", "title": "Where to Get Down From", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The serene snip, snip, snip of scissors is the only sound that breaks the genteel silence at Paul Mol\u00e9 Barber Shop, which, at 105 years old, claims to be the city\u2019s oldest destination for a shave and a haircut.\n\nThe second-story business, a fixture on Lexington Avenue between 73rd and 74th Streets since it opened in 1913, has catered to generations of men.\n\n\u201cAnd some ladies, too,\u201d said Adrian Wood, the owner, a silver-haired Englishman and barber who wears dress shirts monogrammed at the cuffs.", "title": "Where to Go for a Gentleman\u2019s Haircut", "authors": ["Nancy A. Ruhling", "Neighborhood Joint"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHONG KONG \u2014 This city\u2019s creative scene has transformed in the decade since an annual art fair was introduced. Galleries, museums, design spaces and alternative fairs have cropped up, in some cases reviving abandoned complexes and industrial neighborhoods. Here\u2019s a guide on where to see the best art in town \u2014 and, just as important in one of the world\u2019s great food cities, what to eat while you\u2019re there.\n\n[READ MORE: A Worldwide Focus on Hong Kong for Art Basel]\n\nThe Alternative Fair\n\nWHAT TO SEE Art Central Hong Kong (through April 1), Art Basel\u2019s rival fair, boasts over 100 galleries; about three-quarters of them are from the Asia-Pacific region, and 30 are first-time exhibitors. It has a younger, more local vibe than Art Basel, not least because it is in a giant circus tent on a fairgrounds.\n\nThe Hong Kong curator Ying Kwok has chosen six large-scale projects for the fair, including Zhang Xiaodong\u2019s \u201cDream of the Red Chamber\u201d (2017), a work inspired by the classic Chinese novel of the same name, is a contemporary installation crafted from an ancient technique called accordion-dragon scale binding. Also look out for \u201cProgress: The Game of Leaders\u201d by the Singaporean artist Samantha Lo, which is built from giant Jenga blocks marked with terms like \u201cstronger currency\u201d and\u201d \u201cimproved military.\u201d Another work with a political edge is \u201cPavilion for Our Living\u201d by the Hong Kong artists Sampson Wong and Lam Chi Fai, which simulates the micro-apartments where many poor residents live.\n\nWHAT TO EAT There is one formal restaurant on site at Art Central, Le March\u00e9. But if the weather\u2019s nice, most of the crowd heads to the picnic tables on The Terrace, for burgers, roast chicken, Thai barbecue, Vietnamese dishes and French crepes.\n\n\n\nPhoto\n\nUrban Sculpture Park\n\nWHAT TO SEE Twenty-one sculptures were unveiled at public spaces across downtown in February, as part of the Harbor Arts Sculpture Park (until April 11). A majority of the large-scale installations are set in the expansive lawns of Tamar, just outside Art Central. On a recent Sunday afternoon, the park was crowded with art lovers, families, migrant workers on their day off and even newlyweds, all taking selfies with the new installations. Children ran excitedly around one of Yayoi Kusama\u2019s big orange pumpkins, then treated Rasheed Araeen\u2019s \u201cHong Kong Blues\u201d and \u201cAsteroids & Comets\u201d by the Hong Kong artist Kacey Wong like jungle gyms.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWHAT TO EAT There are some food trucks in this area, which rotate among snacks like coconut-milk ice cream and Hong Kong-style dim sum.", "title": "Where to Play (and Eat) in Hong Kong", "authors": ["Joyce Lau"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "A verdant expanse of misty hills punctuated with tiny, preserved-in-amber towns, Central Maui goes largely ignored by sunbathers and surfers congregating on the island\u2019s western towns of Wailea, Lahaina and Kapalua. Sitting as high as 3,600 feet, Upcountry, as this 200-square-mile area by Haleakala Volcano is called, has cooler temperatures (at night it can approach freezing) and more eucalyptus trees than coconut palms. It became an agricultural center in the late 1700s, when a British naval captain gave Hawaii\u2019s King Kamehameha I a herd of longhorn cattle that spawned an entire ranching industry. There aren\u2019t as many paniolos (Hawaiian cowboys) today as there were in the 19th century, but several big ranches remain, as does a general appreciation for living off the land: In addition to the ranches, there are coffee farms, lavender fields and scenic hiking loops through forest reserves.\n\nMany of Upcountry\u2019s 38,000 residents (less than one-fourth of Maui\u2019s overall population) live in and around its small, historic towns, which include Haiku, Pukalani and Makawao, former pineapple plantations and ranch communities established in the 1800s. As industrialization forced plantation owners to downsize post-World War II, the families of the primarily Hawaiian, Chinese, Portuguese and Japanese workers who remained were joined in the 1960s and \u201970s by a wave of mainland hippies looking to get off the grid. (Willie Nelson and Mick Fleetwood have homes nearby.) Over the past decade or so, the area\u2019s relatively cheap housing and temperate climate have attracted all sorts of wanderers, dropouts and seekers, including jewelry makers, woodworkers and glassblowers, as well as a new generation of farmers growing organic produce (poha berries, lilikoi) for local restaurants. (The cuisine here leans more toward Proven\u00e7al than taco truck.) And so, these days, Upcountry is worth more than just a drive-through on the way to the rocky, rust-colored terrain of the island\u2019s most spectacular national attraction: Haleakala Crater, 10,023 feet above sea level and best experienced at sunrise, when the ghostly fog lifts to reveal peaks and valleys all around. You may even realize you don\u2019t need a beach after all.", "title": "Where to Stay (and What to Eat) in Maui\u2019s Upcountry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nWhat was the Academy thinking? There\u2019s no other way to guess than to watch the winners, many of which are available to stream. The big winner for best picture and director, Guillermo del Toro\u2019s \u201cThe Shape of Water,\u201d isn\u2019t up for rental until March 13 \u2014 along with \u201cCall Me By Your Name\u201d (best adapted screenplay, James Ivory) and \u201cI, Tonya\u201d (best supporting actress, Allison Janney). But most of the others, including the shorts, are ready to watch from home now.\n\n\u2018Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u2019\n\nSam Rockwell, left, and Frances McDormand in \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri.\u201d Merrick Morton/Fox Searchlight Pictures\n\nWon for: best actress in a leading role, best supporting actor\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAs a grieving mother who pressures the local sheriff to investigate her daughter\u2019s murder, Frances McDormand gives a performance that both complements and stands in contrast with her Oscar-winning role as Marge Gunderson in \u201cFargo.\u201d The two share a Middle American candor and clarity of mission, but McDormand takes her \u201cThree Billboards\u201d character down a wayward path that edges this salty film into disturbing moral terrain. Ditto Sam Rockwell, whose supporting role as an outwardly vile cop possesses hidden dimensions, though the character nonetheless falls short of redemption.\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes, Vudu\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Darkest Hour\u2019\n\nGary Oldman as Winston Churchill in \u201cDarkest Hour.\u201d Jack English/Focus Features\n\nWon for: best actor in a leading role, best makeup and hairstyling\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe two Oscars for \u201cDarkest Hour\u201d go hand-in-glove \u2014 or rather, face-in-latex. For four hours a day, Gary Oldman and his prosthetic artisans, Kazuhiro Tsuji and Lucy Sibbick, immersed themselves in the task of getting Oldman into his role as Winston Churchill during the Battle of Dunkirk. As Churchill, Oldman projects the bellicosity and rhetoric necessary to bend the political establishment to his will and rouse the British people for the long fight against the Nazis. Yet buried under all that bluster (and makeup), there\u2019s the distinct uncertainty of a man who could, in fact, be making an historically consequential mistake.\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Dunkirk\u2019\n\nMark Rylance, left, and Cillian Murphy in \u201cDunkirk.\u201d Warner Bros. Pictures\n\nWon for: best sound editing, best sound mixing, best editing\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAlthough Christopher Nolan\u2019s large-scale re-creation of the Dunkirk evacuation was shut out in all the major categories, the technical awards the film did collect suggest its unique strengths. Rather than put the dialogue first, Nolan and his team of editors and sound mixers instead reduce it to oft-unintelligible murmurs amid the chaos of war, creating a multipronged symphony of combat, weaving together three story strands across three different timelines until they converge into one. Nolan broke through on a virtue of complicated puzzle pictures like \u201cMemento\u201d and \u201cThe Prestige,\u201d but \u201cDunkirk\u201d carries that sophistication into pure visual language \u2014 it\u2019s minimalist storytelling on a maximalist stage.\n\n0\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Get Out\u2019\n\nDaniel Kaluuya in \u201cGet Out.\u201d Justin Lubin/Universal Pictures\n\nWon for: best original screenplay\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn one of the most competitive categories of the night, Jordan Peele\u2019s original script won an Oscar for upending horror conventions and for reminding audiences that two-term presidency of Barack Obama did not, as many had hoped, signify the dawn of a \u201cpost-racial\u201d America. With debts to the screen versions of Ira Levin\u2019s \u201cThe Stepford Wives\u201d and to \u201cRosemary\u2019s Baby,\u201d Peele takes a weekend in which a young black man (Daniel Kaluuya, nominated for best actor) meets his white girlfriend\u2019s family and imagines it as a surreal and satirical nightmare of wicked conspiracies and sublimated racism.\n\nWhere to watch: HBO\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Blade Runner 2049\u2019\n\nAna de Armas and Ryan Gosling in \"Blade Runner 2049.\" Warner Bros.\n\nWon for: best visual effects, best cinematography\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nUntil now, the cinematographer Roger A. Deakins was the Susan Lucci of famous Oscar also-rans, with 13 nominations for films like \u201cThe Shawshank Redemption,\u201d \u201cFargo\u201d and \u201cSkyfall,\u201d but nothing to show for it. But Deakins\u2019s artistry on \u201cBlade Runner 2049\u201d was not to be denied: More than merely replicating the future-noir ambience of the original film, Deakins extended it with startling bursts of color and light, no doubt aided by the Oscar-winning visual effects team. The palette alone puts enough of a distance between the two films to keep \u201cBlade Runner 2049\u201d from seeming like a retread.\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Icarus\u2019\n\nBryan Fogel in \u201cIcarus.\u201d Netflix\n\nWon for: best documentary feature\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThere were more subtle and more artfully crafted nominees for best documentary, but it\u2019s exceedingly rare for a documentary to have the real-world impact of a film like \u201cIcarus.\u201d In the midst of \u201cSuper Size Me\u201d-like stunt to dope himself up into becoming a winning amateur cyclist, director Bryan Fogel stumbled onto a major international scandal when Grigory Rodchenkov, the head of the Russian antidoping agency, confessed to leading a sweeping program to enhance the country\u2019s Olympic prospects through banned substances. Rodchenkov\u2019s whistle-blowing \u2014 which has since landed him in the witness protection program \u2014 is astonishing to see on camera.\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Coco\u2019\n\nHector (voiced by Gael Garc\u00eda Bernal) and Miguel (Anthony Gonzalez) in a scene from \u201cCoco.\u201d Disney \u2014 Pixar\n\nWon for: best animated feature, best original song\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nPixar has spent so much energy lately cashing in on old hits that \u201cCoco\u201d was a reminder of how audacious its original films could be. After all, this is an animated feature about death, following a young boy who crosses into the Land of the Dead to pursue his dream of becoming a musician. Rich in color and song, the film also immerses itself in Mexican cultural traditions without the once-over-lightly treatment of lesser works like \u201cThe Book of Life.\u201d\n\nWhere to watch: iTunes, Vudu\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Heaven Is a Traffic Jam on the 405\u2019\n\nA scene from \u201cHeaven Is a Traffic Jam on the 405.\u201d ShortsTV\n\nWon for: best documentary short\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAcross 40 minutes, this intimate documentary from Frank Stiefel examines the life and work of Mindy Alper, a Los Angeles-based artist whose lifelong struggle with mental illness is reflected in her line drawings and sculptures. Now in her 50s, Alper still communicates two or three times a day with her mother, who has been steadfast in her support, and she still takes a cocktail of medications for obsessive-compulsive disorder, depression, anxiety and psychosis. Her mother notwithstanding, Alper\u2019s artwork serves as her lifeline, a place where she can manage her abundant fears through creative expression.\n\nWhere to watch: YouTube\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018The Silent Child\u2019\n\nMaisie Sly in \u201cThe Silent Child.\u201d Slick Films\n\nWon for: best live action short\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nRachel Shenton writes and stars in this short from Chris Overton about a social worker who finds a 4-year-old deaf girl who is receptive to learning sign language, but she has trouble convincing her parents it\u2019s worth the bother. A nice bond develops between Shenton\u2019s social worker and the girl, touchingly played by Maisie Sly, but \u201cThe Silent Child\u201d takes more of a message-first approach in advocating for neglected children.\n\nWhere to watch: YouTube\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Dear Basketball\u2019\n\nA scene from \u201cDear Basketball.\u201d Glen Keane Productions\n\nWon for: best animated short\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWritten and narrated by Kobe Bryant, \u201cDear Basketball\u201d is a retirement-year tribute to the game that made him a star, sketching his journey from a moony-eyed 6-year-old to a professional whose body is finally breaking down. Told with absolute sincerity and handcrafted simplicity, it\u2019s like a cross between \u201cThe Giving Tree\u201d and a post on The Players\u2019 Tribune.\n\nWhere to watch: Go90\n\n\u2014", "title": "Where to Stream the 2018 Oscar Winning Movies", "authors": ["Scott Tobias"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "But rather than finish the program and take part in intensive outpatient sessions, Mr. Weinstein has, for the most part, seemingly whiled away much of his time in Arizona, dabbling in outpatient classes at a related facility and dealing with his legal challenges, said three people who have heard from Mr. Weinstein in recent months. And through his presence, he has provoked the ire of Scottsdale and neighboring Paradise Valley\u2019s retirees and vacationers, some of who have been complaining about their famous neighbor on social media.\n\nMr. Weinstein has lost weight. He still works his Rolodex \u2014 or at least tries to. But in the Hollywood caste system, the publicists-for-hire, the striving producers, the up-and-coming directors who used to endure his verbal lashings and entertain his every whim now mostly don\u2019t pick up, according to several such people who said they avoid his calls.\n\nThe man behind \u201cPulp Fiction\u201d and \u201cShakespeare in Love\u201d has already made some efforts to produce his most challenging film yet, these people say: a documentary designed to pave the way for a comeback. So far, no one will touch it. A representative for Mr. Weinstein said a \u201clong list\u201d of producers and others have reached out to him about how to best tell his side and story.\n\nBefore Gwyneth Paltrow, Angelina Jolie, Kate Beckinsale and dozens more women came forward with accusations against Mr. Weinstein, his net worth was estimated at $300 million. But paying his legal teams, led by Blair Berk in Hollywood and Benjamin Brafman in Manhattan, and his ongoing divorce, have chipped away at that fortune, said several people close to Mr. Weinstein.\n\nLast week, the Weinstein Company, once a crown jewel of moviemaking, said that it would file for bankruptcy, after the collapse of sale talks with an investor group.\n\nThe failed deal followed a lawsuit filed last month by Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, intended to block the fire sale of Weinstein Company. The suit includes new details about the studio\u2019s \u201ctoxic environment for women\u201d and Mr. Weinstein\u2019s \u201cunlawful conduct,\u201d including using female employees to help him pursue sexual targets and to procure and administer erectile dysfunction medication.", "title": "Where\u2019s Harvey?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Adam Schiff (@RepAdamSchiff), a Democrat from California, is the ranking member of the House Intelligence Committee.\n\nFollow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter (@NYTopinion), and sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter.\n\n", "title": "Opinion | While Putin Meddles, Trump Congratulates Him", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThat change is statistically significant,\u201d said Gregory A. Smith, Pew\u2019s associate director of research, who also noted a nine-point drop among evangelical men. \u201cBoth groups have become less approving over time.\u201d\n\nIf that drop in support translates into a lack of enthusiasm among core Trump supporters in the midterm elections in November, as it did for many of President Barack Obama\u2019s voters in 2010, the Republican Party could be more vulnerable in its efforts to maintain control of Congress. In 2020, it would also possibly open a lane for a primary challenger to the president.\n\nThe women in suburban Dallas all conceded they have cringed sometimes at Mr. Trump, citing his pettiness, impulsiveness, profanity and name calling. Still, they defended him because he delivered on issues they cared most about, such as the appointment of Justice Neil M. Gorsuch to the Supreme Court.\n\n\u201cCertainly we are all embarrassed, but for the most part he represents what we stand for,\u201d said Ms. Leonhart, who is active in the women\u2019s ministry at her church.\n\nA clear majority of white evangelical women, even in the face of the #MeToo movement and renewed claims of marital infidelity against the president, continue, along with white evangelical men, to form Mr. Trump\u2019s most cohesive block of support.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s ability to connect so strongly with evangelical voters was among the most notable surprises of the 2016 campaign. Since his election, he has courted evangelical leaders aggressively and, more important, has delivered on promises to appoint conservatives like Justice Gorsuch to federal courts. Men who see themselves as leaders of religious conservatives, such as Franklin Graham, Jerry Falwell Jr. and Tony Perkins, the president of the Family Research Council, have remained doggedly supportive.\n\nAnd the majority of evangelical women remain in his corner.\n\nBut it has not been easy.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know any evangelical woman who is going to defend the character of the president,\u201d said Carmen Fowler LaBerge, host of \u201cThe Reconnect,\u201d an evangelical-centered radio show.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMany things the president says and does are things that many evangelicals use as examples with our kids of what we should not do,\u201d added Ms. LaBerge, who did not support Mr. Trump in 2016. \u201cThis is not who we are as evangelicals. This is not how we treat people.\u201d\n\nSome evangelical women simply keep their views private. Gathered at a well-appointed home in Falls Church, Va., last week, eight Christian women agreed to talk about their feelings about the president, on one condition: that they not be identified.\n\nThey feared reprisal in the workplace, at their children\u2019s schools, even at their church. They meet in secret and have a private Facebook group, which its organizer said has about 160 members, to talk about their support for Mr. Trump.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThey said that Christian voters who backed Trump had been derided as unthinking, unsophisticated hypocrites, but for many of them that only affirmed their resolve. One of the women said that her parents had come to the United States illegally from El Salvador and that she was born a short time later. Her father is now a citizen. She supports Mr. Trump and his hard-line plans on immigration.\n\n\u201cI would say that this year has only made me more of a certain supporter,\u201d said another of the women, Joanna, who agreed to be identified only by her first name. \u201cI\u2019ve been really excited to see him come through with his promises, one by one, against incredible odds.\u201d\n\nStill, there is a tension among evangelical women. They said they largely cast their votes against Hillary Clinton more than for Mr. Trump.\n\n\u201cAt least in my experience, it was more of an anti-Hillary vote than a pro-Trump vote,\u201d Ms. LaBerge said.\n\nKaren Swallow Prior, a professor at Liberty University who opposed Mr. Trump and voted for a third-party candidate, said, \u201cNow that Trump is in office and we are evaluating his performance then, I am glad to see that people are less in lock step and thinking critically about him as a leader, and it doesn\u2019t surprise me that his overall support would decline from 80 percent.\u201d\n\n\u201cI was one of those culture war evangelicals in the \u201980s and \u201990s,\u201d Ms. Swallow Prior said. \u201cI was appalled by the candidacy and presidency of Bill Clinton. It was hammered into my mind that character mattered, and that did change when Trump came along. In some ways, I felt betrayed by my evangelical peers who taught me and cemented in me the idea that character matters. I didn\u2019t abandon that belief. I feel like some evangelicals did.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHer outspoken criticism is all the more notable given that the president of Liberty University, Mr. Falwell, remains one of the president\u2019s most vocal defenders.\n\nEvangelical voters, often portrayed as a monolith, are becoming increasingly difficult to define. The support for Mr. Trump reflects a growing pragmatism among evangelical voters who are willing to accept a less than ideal model of Christian faith in exchange for policies that they endorse.\n\n\u201cI think they\u2019ve become experienced and very practical,\u201d said Frances FitzGerald, the author of the recent book \u201cThe Evangelicals: The Struggle to Shape America.\u201d \u201cBy large majorities they used to believe that to be elected, you had to be of good character. No longer. It\u2019s \u2018We want a president to do what we want him to do, and he\u2019s going to do it if we turn out and vote.\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. Trump also appeals to white evangelicals in other ways with his strong language, disruptive view of presidential norms and his policies on taxes. \u201cReligious right rhetoric has always been very martial \u2014 isolationist and martial at the same time,\u201d Ms. FitzGerald said.\n\nIn surveys conducted by LifeWay Research in Nashville, evangelical voters in 2016 cited the economy (30 percent) and national security (26 percent) as their top two issues. Abortion was cited by just 4 percent, said Scott McConnell, the company\u2019s executive director.\n\nEvangelical voters began to emerge as a political force with their support for Ronald Reagan in 1980 and became a more coherent movement with the 1988 presidential campaign of the religious broadcaster Pat Robertson and the rise of Christian Coalition. But there are now few obvious leaders of religious conservatism, and voters have become more conventional in their assessment of candidates.\n\nAnd even among religious conservatives, the Pew poll suggests tolerance for Mr. Trump has its limits.\n\n\u201cIt may simply be that there\u2019s not a single breaking point as much as a tipping point, the \u2018Oh Lord, I can\u2019t stand another one of these,\u2019\u201d said William Martin, a scholar at the Baker Institute for Public Policy at Rice University and author of \u201cWith God on Our Side,\u201d which charted the political rise of the religious right.", "title": "White Evangelical Women, Core Supporters of Trump, Begin Tiptoeing Away", "authors": ["Michael Tackett"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Over the past 14 months there have been at least eight complaints against White House officials for potential violations of the statute, according to a review by the agency charged with enforcing it. That number has put the Trump White House on a pace to far surpass the complaints against the staff of his predecessor.\n\nA handful of high-profile violations and the increased number of complaints suggest that, more than a year after taking office, Mr. Trump \u2014 who has openly defied many norms of government ethics and transparency \u2014 is surrounded by aides who blur the line between their roles as partisans and public servants, sometimes skirting or disregarding altogether decades-old standards that govern the behavior of senior White House officials.\n\n\u201cThis is an overall attitude this White House has about these rules, that they are just not all that important or they do not apply,\u201d said Lawrence M. Noble, the senior director and general counsel of the Campaign Legal Center, the nonpartisan ethics watchdog group that filed the complaints against Ms. Conway. \u201cThere are clearly gray areas, but it\u2019s not like occasionally they stumble into the gray areas; this seems to be willful ignoring of the rules.\u201d\n\nThe Office of Special Counsel, the federal agency which enforces the Hatch Act, has an email inbox and telephone hotline devoted to fielding complaints, and, according to one official, has heard about more potential violations since Mr. Trump was sworn in than is typical, particularly three years before a general election campaign. Over the eight years of Barack Obama\u2019s presidency, for example, the office received a total of six complaints about conduct by White House officials \u2014 a number Mr. Trump\u2019s administration has already surpassed.\n\nNot every complaint has led to a finding of a violation, and Mr. Trump\u2019s aides argue that many are meritless claims by political opponents looking for ways to undercut the president. They also point to the increase in the use of Twitter and other platforms that make it more difficult to maintain a bright line between the official and the political.", "title": "White House Aides Blur the Legal Lines Between Partisans and Public Servants", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cCommunications Chief to Leave White House\u201d (news article, March 1), about the planned departure of Hope Hicks, reveals the dysfunction at the White House, with the prominence of staff members who lack political experience. I was struck Wednesday night by the coverage on cable TV news, which at times appeared to be having too much fun covering what many regard as a reality show.\n\nThis is not funny, as we live in a very dangerous world. Beyond the headlines are many ominous warnings of countries, including our own, preparing for a war that can easily go nuclear \u2014 that is, if we do not have steady and wise leadership.\n\nI would encourage people to treat what many describe as a circuslike atmosphere in government with less amusement and more of the gravity it deserves. Everyone needs comic relief, and that can be obtained in late-night entertainment talk shows and elsewhere, but not in the news.\n\nJEFFREY B. FREEDMAN, NEW YORK", "title": "Opinion | White House Dysfunction: It\u2019s Chaos, Not Comedy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump proposed an additional $59 million next fiscal year to make up for the loss of the emergency spending in the C.D.C.\u2019s Global Health Security Agenda activities. But that amount would fall far short of the emergency supplement, and even that sum would be drawn from other global health programs at the agency.\n\nOver all, Mr. Trump\u2019s February budget proposal offered the C.D.C., the United States Agency for International Development and the Defense Department\u2019s health security programs about the same funding those agencies received between 2006 and the Ebola crisis, \u201cobjectively inadequate for the agencies\u2019 activities\u201d since the outbreak, said Jennifer Kates, who studies global health policy at the Kaiser Family Foundation.\n\nWithout more funding, the C.D.C. would have to cut its health security fieldwork by 80 percent, according to its plan reported by The Wall Street Journal. The new priority list would exclude nations like the Democratic Republic of Congo, Haiti and Sierra Leone, where past outbreaks of diseases like cholera and Ebola have rampaged.\n\nAdministration officials said their commitment to disease management should not be judged by budget numbers.\n\n\u201cCountering biological threats, infectious diseases, and pandemics is a priority of the administration \u2014 a key pillar of our national security strategy,\u201d Rear Adm. R. Timothy Ziemer, the director for global health security and biothreats at the National Security Council, said in an interview on Monday. \u201cA budget line is not the only indicator of commitment. Budgets come and go.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. Last year, Mr. Trump and Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson, who was ousted on Tuesday, publicly endorsed the initiative, and Mr. Tillerson vowed that the American commitment \u201cwill remain constant.\u201d\n\nAt the initiative\u2019s summit meeting in Uganda last October, Admiral Ziemer and Dr. Brenda Fitzgerald, the head of the C.D.C. at the time, gave speeches urging the global community to extend the initiative until 2024 \u2014 but suggested no financial support to do so.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince then, the language from the administration has changed. He said additional C.D.C. funding \u201cdoesn\u2019t seem \u2014 in a time of scarce resources \u2014 a wise use of resources.\u201d\n\nIn 2016, an independent panel convened to assess the government\u2019s Ebola response concluded that the Department of Health and Human Services, the C.D.C.\u2019s parent agency, needed an ongoing contingency fund to prepare for future outbreaks.\n\nDr. Thomas Inglesby, the head of the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security, who testified during the January hearing, said that neglecting such programs would jeopardize national security.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s true that we have shouldered responsibilities,\u201d he said in an interview. \u201cBut it is in our own interest. If other countries are vulnerable to epidemics, that makes our country, too. We saw only a glimpse of it with Ebola, a few patients here. But had it been more contagious \u2014 we were lucky.\u201d\n\nEarlier this year, several coalitions representing over 200 health security groups sent a letter to Alex M. Azar II, the health secretary, expressing concerns over the C.D.C.\u2019s fieldwork cutbacks.
