Minnesota Confronts a National Quandary", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Other changes make life much easier for the largest players and encourage regulatory shenanigans. Dodd-Frank introduced more \u201cstress tests\u201d \u2014 fire-drill-like exercises that ensure the banks can handle a major downturn. The Crapo bill reduces their frequency for all the major players\u2019 internal tests, from Citigroup to JPMorgan Chase on down.\n\nThe Crapo bill will introduce a one-word change from \u201cmay\u201d to \u201cshall\u201d that will pave the way for the biggest, most politically connected financial firms to argue that regulations should be tailored to be weaker for themselves, creating a race-to-the-bottom dynamic in what has been, so far, fair rules written for all banks to follow together. It allows community banks to violate the Volcker Rule, introduced in Dodd-Frank to prevent banks from engaging in hedge-fund-like gambling with their own funds.\n\nForeign banks that pose major risks, such as the Trump-friendly Deutsche Bank, will see their United States subsidiaries deregulated with the bill. It attacks the supplemental leverage ratio \u2014 an essential reform that provides a clear, straightforward funding rule to ensure banks are stable \u2014 by watering it down for two of the largest eight banks. Reporting shows other large banks like Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase are fighting to expand this further. This starts the rule down a path of not being informative or useful for regulators and capital markets. This is why the Congressional Budget Office not only assumes that it is 50 percent likely these megabanks will abuse this loophole, but also that this bill increases the chance and cost of a financial crisis overall. Given the sheer opportunity to abuse porous rules introduced by the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, it is overkill to give finance even more rules to abuse for its own profit.\n\nModerate Democrats could fight for a narrower bill that would benefit small banks \u2014 with the understanding that community banks aren\u2019t actually suffering. According to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, community banks had $6 billion in profits in the fall of 2017, a rise of 9.4 percent over the previous year. Furthermore, since Dodd-Frank, several waves of deregulation bills for small banks have already passed.\n\nCommunities must have banks that can meet their needs. By rolling back requirements for medium-size banks, the Crapo proposal will accelerate mergers and consolidations rather than postpone them. This could cause even fewer community banks and more concentration in the long run. If we are concerned about a top-heavy financial sector, the way to handle that is with breaking up the banks and structural reforms for the biggest players, not by removing basic rules at the bottom.\n\nThis bill also hurts consumers. It removes protections on mobile homes and appraisal requirements in rural areas, while getting rid of the requirement that smaller banks prove that borrowers can repay subprime loans they make and keep on their own books. All of these read as if they were written to appease a specific lobbying group, rather than out of a concern for consumer security.\n\nThe most serious consumer protection rollback involves banks reporting on the mortgages they offer. The Crapo bill will exempt banks that make fewer than 500 mortgages \u2014 which includes nearly 85 percent of banks \u2014 from reporting important mortgage data. This data is used to ensure that discriminatory or other abusive practices aren\u2019t happening. This exposes minority communities and rural areas, voters Democrats need to win over to gain viability, to increased predation.", "title": "Opinion | Why Are Democrats Helping Trump Dismantle Dodd-Frank?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI give great thanks to the government that now we have a chance to save these memories,\u201d she said.\n\nAfter more than two years in power, the Law and Justice party and its leader, Jaroslaw Kaczynski, have reshaped the judicial system in ways that critics say undermines the rule of law. The government has seized control of the state news media, ousting opponents; moved to curb public gatherings; and passed a controversial law making it illegal to claim that the Polish nation was responsible for the Holocaust.\n\nCritics worry that the party is using the tools of democracy to undermine that very democracy. But for all the international hand-wringing, the party itself is more popular than ever where it counts \u2014 with the voters.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile the main opposition remains badly divided, with polls showing them mired in the teens, Law and Justice has been consistently scoring between 40 and 45 percent.\n\nMuch of that support has been built on populist and patriotic themes, placing as much importance on shaping memories of the past as building for the future. Poland\u2019s tragic history, along with the need to overcome centuries of occupation and stand up to outsiders, remains an important part of Mr. Kaczynski\u2019s appeal.\n\nThat populist message and promises to restore traditional values have resonated deeply in the vast countryside, where many rural voters long for a sense of stability and security in a fast-changing Europe.\n\nMr. Kaczynski has struck upon a potent mix of populist social programs, patriotic swagger and selective historical remembrance to build support. He has spoken about a 20-year project to reshape Poland, and in places like Podgorze, voters seem inclined to give him time.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere are so many areas that in our reality need not just modernization but outright plowing,\u201d he recently told the right-wing weekly, Gazeta Polska. \u201cIn order to turn Poland into a modern state, free from the burden of the past, friendly to its citizens, one needs not two, but at least three terms.\u201d\n\nHe ran promising that Poland would no longer find itself on its knees, living in fear of Russia to the east and subservient to Germany in the west.\n\nMs. Klosinska said she was pained that foreigners do not understand her country and its history. But this only stiffened her resolve. \u201cPoland will not take a step back,\u201d she said.\n\nPeople here work the fields. They live on farms, erect shrines to the Virgin Mary and dutifully go to church every Sunday. It is not always an easy life.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe previous party talked a lot about helping these people but did nothing,\u201d said Marek Adam Komorowski, 58, a local councilman.\n\nThe first thing Law and Justice did was deliver a real benefit: a stipend of 500 zlotys, or around $148, a month for every child after the first child for every family in the country. The party also reversed a deeply unpopular decision to raise the retirement age to 67, reducing it to 60 for women and 65 for men. It has provided new housing subsidies and worked to reopen shut state factories.\n\nWhile the opposition called these spendthrift policies that could not be afforded, the economy is thriving, and the government has lowered both the budget deficit and unemployment (with no small amount of help from European Union subsidies).\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLaw and Justice \u201crealized the electorate outside the cities could be mobilized, that there was a political vacuum,\u201d said Slawomir Debski, the director of the Polish Institute of International Affairs in Warsaw. \u201cThe money was important as a psychological signal to the society.\u201d\n\nBut despite the warnings of cataclysm from the opposition, the deficit has not soared. Poland\u2019s economy continues to boom. Unemployment, even in the countryside, is at historic lows, hovering around 6 percent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince 1991, when it completed its transition from communism, Poland\u2019s economy has been growing on average 4 percent annually \u2014 without a single year of negative growth. The average income has risen from $2,300 to more than $13,000.\n\nPoland has also benefited from its membership in the European Union, with subsidies for things like road construction and farming touching every corner of the country.\n\nBut if leaders in Western Europe think Poland should simply be grateful, say thank you and follow their lead, they misread the mood here, Mr. Komorowski said.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want people to think people here are just backward peasants who go and vote where they are told to,\u201d he said. \u201cPeople here have suffered a lot, and this is shaping their views.\u201d\n\nMore than anything, he said, the ruling party allowed people to feel proud again.\n\n\u201cThe government is helping us restore our pride and dignity,\u201d he said. \u201cYou cannot take freedom for granted. Dignity and freedom are something to fight for. You need to protect it, just as you need to protect national identity.\u201d\n\nAsked to define Poland\u2019s national identity, he thought for a moment. \u201cChristian values,\u201d he said. \u201cDevotion to fatherland. And tradition.\u201d\n\nMs. Klosinska, the librarian, values the government\u2019s emphasis on national pride in education. \u201cI was always aware that there was a lack of patriotic education, even when I was a little girl,\u201d she said.\n\nAround 17 years ago, she petitioned the government to organize a contest for patriotic poems. It told her no. Now, this government has encouraged her project.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe has received grant money to hold a conference on those who were sent to Siberia and another grant for an essay contest that asks \u201cpeople to write about what it means to live in a sovereign country.\u201d There is also new money for a \u201cpatriotic festival.\u201d\n\nThis year marks 100 years since President Woodrow Wilson called for the establishment of a free and independent Polish state, and the ruling party has been preparing for this anniversary for more than two years, she said.\n\nShe took visitors outside the library to view the new memorial to the deported.\n\n\u201cIn memory of the Sybiracy, deported to an inhuman land,\u201d the memorial reads. \u201cLet good God care for the martyrs of Siberia, those tortured and murdered in the Golgotha of the east and those who had been deported and found a home under a foreign sky.\u201d\n\nPosing proudly by the monument, Ms. Klosinska said: \u201cFinally we have a government that allows us to celebrate our history.\u201d", "title": "Why Are Poland\u2019s Nationalists So Popular? Ask a Local Librarian", "authors": ["Marc Santora", "Steven Erlanger"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "There is a philosophically problematic presupposition that also figures in widespread surprise at the very idea of violence perpetrated by Buddhists \u2014 that there is a straightforward relationship between the beliefs people hold and the likelihood that they will behave in corresponding ways.\n\nEven if we suppose that most Buddhists, or members of any other religious group, really do hold beliefs that are pacifist and tolerant, we have no reason to expect that they will really be pacifist and tolerant. As Immanuel Kant well understood, we are not transparent to ourselves and can never exhaustively know why we do what we do. We can never be certain whether or to what extent we have acted for the reasons we think we did (whether because, for example, \u201cit was the right thing to do\u201d), or whether we are under the sway of psychological, neurophysiological or socioeconomic causes that are altogether opaque to us.\n\nThat doesn\u2019t mean that we should (or can) jettison all reference to our stated beliefs, reasons, rationality; indeed, Kant also cogently argued that despite the efforts of all manner of determinists, we cannot coherently explain these away (for any attempt to explain away our rationality would itself represent a use of that faculty). But it does mean that we cannot infer from, say, a society\u2019s widely held belief in toleration and peace that the actions of people in that society will be strictly guided by those beliefs.\n\nWe should thus be wary of any narrative on which historical events are straightforwardly explained by the fact that the people in any society hold whatever religious beliefs they do. It just doesn\u2019t follow from the fact that someone is admirable \u2014 or for that matter, that she is vile \u2014 that it is because of her beliefs that she is so. Given this, we should expect that even in societies where virtuous beliefs are widely held, we will find pretty much the same range of human failings evident throughout history. Buddhist societies are no different in this respect than others.\n\nMany of history\u2019s great Buddhist philosophers would themselves acknowledge as much. Buddhist thinkers have typically emphasized that there is a profound difference between merely assenting to a belief (for example, that all sentient beings deserve compassion) and actually living in ways informed by that belief. To be really changed by a belief regarding one\u2019s relationship to all other beings, one must cultivate that belief \u2014 one must come to experience it as vividly real \u2014 through the disciplined practices of the Buddhist path.\n\nThe reason this is necessary, Buddhist philosophers recognized, is that all of us \u2014 even those who are Buddhists \u2014 are deeply habituated to self-centered ways of being. Indeed, if that weren\u2019t the case, there would be no need for Buddhist practice; it is just because people everywhere (even in Tibet, Myanmar and Japan) are generally self-centered that it takes so much work \u2014 innumerable lifetimes of it, according to many Buddhists \u2014 to overcome the habituated dispositions that typically run riot over our stated beliefs.\n\nThe basic Buddhist analysis of the human predicament makes sense, as well, of the irony of colonialist conceptions of Buddhism and of the misguidedness of colonial attempts to exploit religious identities. According to a Buddhist analysis, we go through life thinking we\u2019re advancing our own interests, while actually producing ever more suffering because we misunderstand ourselves.", "title": "Opinion | Why Are We Surprised When Buddhists Are Violent?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Spending $7 million for no real impact may sound expensive, but other recent economic development offers are staggering, even for those of us who think we have seen everything. The State of Wisconsin is offering Foxconn $3 billion for electrical-component manufacturing operations. The price tag for Amazon HQ2 is unknown, but the offers will most likely be in the billions for many locations.\n\nWhat is troubling is that these giant incentives may also be setting a new benchmark for companies. In Wisconsin, Gov. Scott Walker is offering Kimberly-Clark, the maker of paper-based products, a Foxconn-size deal (in cost per job) simply to help keep an existing business from closing shop \u2014 in essence, to do nothing.\n\nThe chairman of JPMorgan Chase, Jamie Dimon, recently said that he will be pushing for the same deal received by Amazon. And this is even before any announcement of where Amazon is investing and what is being offered. Mr. Dimon would like to pre-order some Amazon incentives.\n\nPolitical pandering is behind this explosion. But there is also some of what Brink Lindsey of the Niskanen Center and the political scientist Steven Teles call the \u201ccaptured economy.\u201d In between these politicians and corporations are economic incentive consultants, tax professionals and lobbyists all providing ways for businesses to maximize their take, and getting a percentage of these incentives in return. Some consultancies are clearly offering valuable services to governments and companies attempting to manage the complex decisions and operations across various locations in the country.\n\nOthers are experts at extracting as many incentives from governments as possible, in some cases moving businesses a few miles away, say, from Kansas City, Mo., to Kansas City, Kan., to qualify them as new investments.\n\nWhat is to be done? One call is to push for more transparency in these policies, requiring governments to provide details on the support they are offering business. If the Amazon HQ2 competition is any guide, many governments will use creative ways to avoid disclosing their bids. Contact your city government and ask whether it sent a proposal to Amazon. I bet the answer will be something like, \u201cWe offered some details but the actual proposal was sent by X, which isn\u2019t a government agency. We don\u2019t have a copy of the final proposal.\u201d\n\nThe best hope is bipartisan reform of these programs. On the left, critics of economic development programs don\u2019t like \u201ccorporate welfare\u201d or the use of taxpayer money to reduce the taxes of select businesses; on the right, numerous groups have rallied against \u201cgovernments picking winners and losers.\u201d\n\nThere is a role for government in economic development. State and local governments can help businesses without access to finance survive and expand, provide worker training that is valuable to residents and companies, and invest in traditional education from pre-K to college. There are certainly worthy investments that can be made. But $7 million for Carrier, $3 billion for Foxconn and billions for Amazon is just using the public coffers for political theater.", "title": "Opinion | Why Are Your State Tax Dollars Subsidizing Corporations?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou have to be pretty sophisticated,\u201d said Dr. Arthur L. Caplan, a bioethicist at New York University who has been working with companies, including Johnson & Johnson, to develop better early-access programs. But the bill passed this week, he said, \u201cdoes somewhere between nothing and absolutely nothing to help you.\u201d\n\nThe bill\u2019s passage represented a victory for proponents of \u201cright to try,\u201d a campaign championed by Vice President Mike Pence and initiated by the Goldwater Institute, a libertarian think tank that favors limiting the scope of the F.D.A. At least 38 states have passed local versions of right-to-try laws, which allow patients to sidestep F.D.A. approval once they have received permission from a company.\n\nThe right-to-try measures are opposed by a broad coalition of groups, which contend the bill will not help patients and will undermine the authority of the primary regulatory agency, the F.D.A. Four former F.D.A. commissioners, including two each from Democratic and Republican administrations, oppose the bills, as do dozens of patient groups, including the American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network and the American Lung Association.\n\nThe pharmaceutical industry, while not taking a position on the issue, has been circumspect. A spokesman for its main lobbying group, the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, said on Friday, \u201cWe believe any legislation must truly benefit and protect patients and not disrupt the future of clinical trials, U.S. Food and Drug Administration oversight and the research and approval of new medicines.\u201d\n\nThe bill\u2019s future is unclear. On Thursday, Senator Ron Johnson, Republican of Wisconsin, failed to secure unanimous consent in the Senate to pass the House version of the bill after it was blocked by Senator Chuck Schumer, the Democratic leader from New York. Mr. Schumer said that the Senate had already passed its version and that he wanted to work on a compromise bill.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a statement, Senator Johnson said the next step would be to persuade the House to pass his version.\n\n\u201cPatients and their families are running out of time,\u201d Mr. Johnson said in the statement. \u201cI promise to continue to work tirelessly on behalf of desperate patients for their right to try \u2014 their right to hope.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSupporters say that right-to-try measures will eliminate an unnecessary layer of bureaucracy \u2014 obtaining approval from the F.D.A. The legislation includes incentives they say could encourage companies to participate, such as shielding them from lawsuits and preventing the F.D.A. from considering the experiences of patients on the drugs in their eventual decisions about whether to approve them.\n\n\u201cAll we\u2019re trying to do with Right to Try is open up another avenue for patients who need it and aren\u2019t served by existing programs,\u201d said Starlee Coleman, a senior policy adviser at the Goldwater Institute.\n\nThe F.D.A. already approves 99 percent of such applications, and the agency has streamlined the approval process. Drug companies also have many other reasons to bar access \u2014 often, companies do not have enough extra product to give to patients, or they worry that the logistical work of granting access could slow efforts to get the drug approved, when it would become available to any patient who needed it.\n\nThere is also the possibility that the drug does not work \u2014 many experimental products fail in late-stage trials.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u201ds not going to fix the problem because there are still a lot of reasons why the companies will choose not to share their drugs,\u201d said Nancy Goodman, the founder and executive director of Kids v Cancer, an advocacy group that helps connect patients with companies offering early access to treatment. Ms. Goodman\u2019s son, Jacob, died in 2009 at age 10 of cancer, and she said she asked eight companies for access to their experimental therapies and was turned down every time.\n\nMs. Goodman said that dying patients do need better access to drugs during what she described as the \u201cuncomfortable\u201d period between when there is consensus that a drug works and when it reaches the market.\n\nStill, she said of the companies, \u201cI can understand why they say no, even though my heart was broken so many times.\u201d\n\nSome companies said they would continue to seek F.D.A. permission, even if a right-to-try bill becomes law.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIn our view, the F.D.A. plays a really important role,\u201d Dr. Joanne Waldstreicher, the chief medical officer of Johnson & Johnson, said in an interview Thursday. Johnson & Johnson initiated a program in 2015 that delegates decisions about early access to a program set up by Dr. Caplan. The F.D.A., Dr. Waldstreicher said, has \u201cinformation that we don\u2019t have necessarily; they see safety and efficacy information on products that may be similar.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt is not always clear which patients would benefit under such a law, including those whose names are included in the bills\u2019 title. Both the House and Senate versions carry the name of Jordan McLinn, an Indiana boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy, a degenerative and ultimately fatal disease with no cure. Jordan and his mother, Laura McLinn, have campaigned with Mr. Pence in favor of a law, and a video about them is featured on the Goldwater Institute website.\n\nIn the video, Ms. McLinn discusses an unnamed medicine that she said she believed would allow her son to live a \u201clong, productive life.\u201d But in separate remarks at a public event in February, Ms. McLinn said that her son was in a clinical trial for an experimental drug.\n\nIn an email message Thursday, she said, \u201cOur journey has evolved over time with right To try,\u201d adding, \u201cThere is not a drug that we are presently trying to access.\u201d\n\nShe said she still supported the measure because \u201cwe should have that option if it is a pathway that makes sense and works for a treatment we may want to access in the future.\u201d\n\nMs. Coleman, of the Goldwater Institute, said the video about the McLinns was three years old, \u201cand all of Laura\u2019s statements were accurate at the time and are still reflective of the situation many patients experience.\u201d\n\nIn recent years, more companies have developed formal policies on what is often called \u201ccompassionate use\u201d in the wake of high-profile campaigns by dying patients and their families.\n\nIn 2014, executives at the biotechnology company Chimerix received death threats after refusing to give an experimental drug to a 7-year-old boy, Josh Hardy of Virginia, who was dying from a viral infection. The company ultimately provided the drug to the boy, but the episode led to the departure of the chief executive, Kenneth I. Moch, who has since become a proponent of granting fairer access to experimental drugs. (In 2016, Josh died at age 10 of complications from a rare cancer.)\n\nBefore the Hardy family made its request, Mr. Moch said he and his company had been flooded with pleas, ranging from longtime friends to a billionaire, seeking access to the drug, brincidofovir, which still has not been approved by the F.D.A.\n\n\u201cYou get these requests and you have to make your judgment,\u201d he said.\n\nSince the episode, he said dozens of companies had contacted him for advice. In addition to Ms. Goodman\u2019s group, another organization, the Reagan-Udall Foundation, also provides information about company programs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Moch and others who oppose the legislation acknowledged that it has served a positive purpose.\n\n\u201cThe only good thing I see coming out of the right-to-try legislation is the increased awareness within the medical community about expanded access,\u201d he said.", "title": "Why Can\u2019t Dying Patients Get the Drugs They Want?", "authors": ["Katie Thomas"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMy wonderful boyfriend (of one year) won\u2019t let me pay for anything! We\u2019re in our mid-20s. He refuses to split checks and never lets me treat him. He makes more money than I do, but I can afford to pay half. It feels old-fashioned and weirdly paternalistic that he\u2019s so insistent about paying. But what bothers me most is that I feel indebted. When I bring it up, he laughs and tells me \u201cnot to take it that way.\u201d I don\u2019t push these conversations very hard, but I\u2019m getting annoyed. What do I do?\n\nGIRLFRIEND\n\nPush harder! And I write this knowing \u2014 in fact, battle scarred by my knowledge \u2014 that few subjects elicit angrier responses from some readers than suggesting that women can also pay for dates. (\u201cI would never go out with him again,\u201d they write. \u201cCheapskate!\u201d) But readers, Girlfriend wants to pay. And Boyfriend\u2019s generosity, which denies reciprocation, sounds like control to me.\n\nThe solution here is not finding a gesture that Boyfriend can tolerate. It is getting him to acknowledge that Girlfriend deserves an equal say in setting the terms of their partnership. Tell him: \u201cI get that paying means a lot to you. It means a lot to me, too: independence and equal footing. So, please don\u2019t laugh it off. I want to pay my share \u2014 except on my birthday or when we dine out with your parents, in which case, knock yourself out. But I expect to pay full freight on your birthday, too. Agreed?\u201d\n\nWhen he hears the structural importance of your plea, it will be telling to hear how he responds. Frankly, if you were writing about a member of the greatest generation or a baby boomer, I would be more forgiving about how your request may conflict with the message of his upbringing. But a millennial should be able to recognize the importance of his partner\u2019s autonomy. (Finally, to all the couples who have found other arrangements that work for them: Good for you!)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSeated in the iPad Section\n\nMy roommate and I headed to our favorite neighborhood bistro. The only table available was next to a couple with two preschool children. No problem! But the younger boy was playing with an iPad at full volume. (No headphones in sight.) I asked the ma\u00eetre d\u2019 to make sure they had headphones before we took the table. He said he didn\u2019t feel comfortable asking them, but I was welcome to. I didn\u2019t feel it was my responsibility, so we left. Did I overreact?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. As between an employee of the restaurant and a stranger fresh off the street, the employee was much better situated to speak with the parents about a blaring iPad. And bonus: It\u2019s his job! The parents may have produced headphones, and you could have sat down \u2014 though why the child wasn\u2019t wearing them to begin with is a mystery for another day.", "title": "Why Can\u2019t a Modern Woman Pay (at Least) Half?", "authors": ["Philip Galanes", "Social Q S"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "SAN ANTONIO \u2014 Long before a 98-year-old nun became the biggest star of the 2018 N.C.A.A. men\u2019s basketball tournament, Immaculata, a small Catholic college outside Philadelphia, won the first three de facto national women\u2019s basketball championships.\n\nThe Mighty Macs\u2019 titles in the early 1970s, Bill Russell\u2019s breakout success at the University of San Francisco in the 1950s and the presence of Villanova and Loyola-Chicago at this weekend\u2019s Final Four are just three data points among many that prove an undeniable fact: In college basketball, Catholic schools have long punched well above their weight. The reasons stretch back a century \u2014 and, some would argue, to the New Testament itself.\n\n\u201cIt is a real thing,\u201d said Julie E. Byrne, a professor of religion at Hofstra University who studies American Catholicism.\n\nAs the Final Four coincides with Easter weekend, this phenomenon is as real as ever. Half the No. 1 seeds in this tournament were Catholic teams, as were eight of the 64 teams that made the bracket. Loyola is named for St. Ignatius of Loyola, the founder of the Jesuits, and has Sister Jean Dolores Schmidt as its chaplain and unofficial scout. Villanova is associated with the Augustinian Order. Both are still playing.", "title": "Why Catholic Colleges Excel at Basketball", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 In a tit-for-tat trade battle with the United States, China\u2019s response has so far been restrained.\n\nBut that is with good reason: As it waits to see how far President Trump plans to go in imposing sweeping tariffs on China, Beijing knows that it has more effective weapons in its arsenal.\n\nChina\u2019s Ministry of Commerce said on Friday that it would impose tariffs on $3 billion worth of American-produced fruit, pork, wine, seamless steel pipes and more than 100 other products. The move was in response to the Trump administration\u2019s announcements that it would apply tariffs on Chinese steel and aluminum, and came hours after Mr. Trump said he would impose tariffs on about $60 billion worth of Chinese-made products.\n\nBeijing said it would challenge the penalties at the World Trade Organization, and would carry out its trade restrictions in accordance with W.T.O. rules.", "title": "Why China\u2019s Response to Trump\u2019s Tariffs Is So Muted", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Companies still have room to influence 5G technology because it has not yet been deployed. As of now, a group called 3GPP \u2014 staffed by engineers from many companies \u2014 has been defining the specifications so that devices that operate with 5G technology can \u201ctalk\u201d to one another. The group delivered its first major set of standards in December.\n\nMike Thelander, an analyst with Signals Research Group, predicted that American carriers will have some 5G services operating in late 2018 but that smartphones that use the technology won\u2019t be ready until 2019.\n\nQualcomm has long been one of the most active contributors of cellular technology, playing a particularly influential role in 3G technology as well as current 4G networks. Yet the effort to develop 5G standards has brought many new players to the fore, including Huawei, a relative newcomer to the field.\n\nHuawei, which makes gear like cellular base stations and other key equipment to operate 5G networks, has been largely blackballed from the United States on national security grounds. But the Chinese company\u2019s sales have surged elsewhere, such as Europe, and Huawei has taken a leading role in submitting technology for inclusion in 5G technical standards.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Cfius letter estimated that Huawei owned 10 percent of the patents essential for 5G networks. A Huawei spokesman said it had been working on 5G since 2009, having spent $600 million on related research already and committing $800 million more in 2018 alone.\n\nMany American carriers also buy cellular equipment from Sweden\u2019s Ericsson, which has long helped set cellular standards and estimates that it has been working on 5G for a decade. Erik Ekudden, the company\u2019s chief technology officer, said its technical contributions had topped those of any other company.\n\nOther major contributors include South Korea\u2019s Samsung Electronics, Finland\u2019s Nokia and several companies in Japan. Intel, which has been determined to reduce Qualcomm\u2019s market dominance in wireless chips, has also significantly stepped up efforts to influence 5G standards.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOfficials appointed by President Trump have pointed to regulatory barriers that have kept the United States behind nations like China, which has a national plan for 5G networks using technology by Huawei and other Chinese companies like ZTE.\n\nLast month, Brendan Carr, a Republican member of the Federal Communications Commission, announced a regulatory plan that would allow wireless carriers to bypass environmental assessments for the construction of 5G wireless infrastructure.\n\n\u201cThe rest of the world is very conscious of our leadership in 4G, and they are questioning whether we will have the resolve to take the deregulatory steps necessary to extend our leadership into 5G,\u201d Mr. Carr said.\n\nAjit Pai, the commission\u2019s chairman, said last week in a speech to global telecommunications executives and regulators that the agency was prepared to make more spectrum available for those networks. The airwaves would need to be approved by Congress before companies could use them.\n\nAt last week\u2019s Mobile World Congress, which is one of the biggest wireless trade shows, companies were quick to provide evidence of their leadership in 5G. Huawei, for example, demonstrated the first cellular base station that complies with the new 3GPP specifications, said Will Townsend, an analyst at Moor Insights and Strategy, a research firm.\n\nStill, others at the event, which was held in Barcelona, Spain, said it was hard to top Qualcomm\u2019s presence. The San Diego company, which gets much of its profits from licensing patents rather than selling chips, listed a string of technologies that it has shaped for 5G, with obscure descriptions like \u201cMassive Mimo,\u201d \u201cflexible slot-based framework\u201d and \u201cscalable O.F.D.M.-based air interface.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf you walked through Qualcomm\u2019s booth at Mobile World Congress, it is an amazing thing, in terms of the breadth of the technology they show and the quality of people they have staffing it,\u201d said Robert DiFazio, a vice president in the research arm of InterDigital, another company that contributes to cellular standards.", "title": "Why Companies and Countries Are Battling for Ascendancy in 5G", "authors": ["Don Clark", "Cecilia Kang"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI moved here because I want the moonlight, the stars and the Northern Lights,\u201d he said.\n\nIn that low-tech spirit, our group \u2014 Mr. Olafsson; his wife, Karitas; my wife, Melinda; and I \u2014 hatched a plan to cook at the local geyser oven, a feature of many rural Icelandic towns. A short drive from the restaurant, it sits on a rise with a hundred-mile vista to the south and east, a panorama of big rivers and lava fields. In the distance, Hekla, an active volcano, hulks over the plain. In medieval times it was said that the birds that circle the sleeping volcano were the souls of sinners queuing up for the descent into hell.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe water we are drinking fell as rain and snow on that glacier 700 years ago,\u201d Sigfusson said, pointing west to the mountains of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, which rise up from the North Atlantic rift that marks the separation of Eurasia from North America.\n\nWe were standing on the hill above Reykholt, where the town\u2019s geyser has been capped with a roughly finished housing of concrete, topped by a ramshackle smokestack. From that source, the village channels steam and hot water that supply part of the heat and power needs of the modern community.\n\nSome of the hot vapor is also diverted to the village\u2019s communal oven, where Mr. Sigfusson proposed to cook our meal. It\u2019s a much safer way to cook in geothermal heat than tiptoeing around boiling geysers.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe opened the geyser oven, propping it up with a fence post so that I could peer in safely. The escaping steam was as hot as a sauna and, at the bottom of the oven, a good deal hotter (about 200 degrees Fahrenheit, or 93 degrees Celsius). It smelled a bit sulfurous, too, but that comes with the territory when tapping the heat of the Earth\u2019s core.\n\nWe agreed to meet the following morning to cook a menu of local fare, including trout from the nearby Tungufljot River and grass-fed Icelandic lamb, a hardy local breed that has the same salty succulence of the famous French agneau de pr\u00e9-sal\u00e9, lamb raised in salt-marsh meadows.\n\nFor dessert, Mr. Sigfusson suggested abrystir, made from the first milk (nutrient-dense colostrum) produced by a nursing cow. \u201cWhenever one of our cows gave birth, my grandma would take some of the milk and put it in a teakettle set into a pan of hot water,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was so rich that pretty soon it had set into a cr\u00e8me br\u00fbl\u00e9e all on its own \u2014 no eggs.\u201d\n\nThe next day broke bluebird-bright, with cotton-candy clouds and a light breeze. \u201cFirst we forage,\u201d Mr. Sigfusson said when we met. \u201cWild herbs are everywhere.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOur small group ranged along the hillside. The ground was carpeted by wild thyme, with purple flowers the size of a gumdrop nestled among tender flavorful leaves. In the lusher folds and hollows, we found angelica, a plant with a floral, almost verbena note and just a touch of bitterness \u2014 well suited to contain the broad flavors of the unctuous lamb.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Sigfusson lopped off two stalks of wild hops to season the broth, a new use \u2014 at least to me \u2014 of the brewmaster\u2019s mainstay.\n\nAs we prepped the meal, he offered us cold beers and appetizers: smoked ptarmigan and cured salmon on rye crackers, with tomato jams and chutneys from the restaurant and, as with just about everything one eats in Iceland, cold fresh butter.\n\nThe ptarmigan had been smoked over dried smoldering sheep dung, which is pretty much the only thing you can use for smoking in this relatively treeless landscape, where a 15-foot fir tree towers like a sequoia.\n\nPhoto\n\nWith the tailgate of his truck serving as our work surface, we separated some greenhouse romanesco into florets and tossed them into a Dutch oven. We cubed baby kohlrabi, did the same with the smoky brined lamb shoulder, then added the herbs, the hops and a half-dozen glugs of cream. As we worked, the geyser would blow its top every seven minutes, and we had to pause, retreating beyond the reach of its warm, misty spray.\n\nNext, we poured the colostrum into ramekins that we set into our bain-marie \u2014 a roasting pan half-filled with water. Then Mr. Sigfusson brought out a two-pound brown trout he had caught himself (\u201con a Hairy Mary salmon fly,\u201d he reported with pride). We stuffed the brightly spotted trout with sorrel, angelica and green onions, folded it up in parchment paper (en papillote is an ideal way to cook in a steam oven) and placed it in with the rest of our feast.\n\nWe left the oven to work its magic and, a few hours later, returned to unburden it of our meal. The bread, Jon\u2019s own variation on this Viking staple, could have easily sufficed for the whole meal had we not exercised some restraint. The trout was flaky and herbaceous. The milk pudding, topped with a jam of green tomatoes, ginger, and honey was super-creamy.\n\nBut the star of the show was the lamb braise. The meat was salty and smoky, the creamy gravy enriched with the captured juices of lamb, romanesco and kohlrabi, and everything suffused with wild thyme, angelica and hops \u2014 which brought the sweetness-enhancing quality of fresh tarragon. I made a note to try it under the skin of my next roast chicken.\n\nThe breeze was gentle, and the ground was soft and dry enough to lie or sit on without getting damp. Late afternoon sun lit up the landscape formed by long ago by lava flows. It looked like pale-green velvet rippled by the breeze.\n\nI\u2019ll admit to a tingle of schadenfreude as I looked over at Hekla to see to see if the soul of anyone on my hit list was plunging into hellfire, but I didn\u2019t dwell on it. The day was too lovely, the natural world too congenial and the food too satisfying to yield to uncharitable fantasies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Why Cook Over an Icelandic Geyser? Because You Can", "authors": ["Peter Kaminsky", "Jason Epstein"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "We can run tests for months, but we\u2019re most likely to experience failure when we\u2019re getting off the launchpad: We can\u2019t feel comfortable with our planning until we get the first round of votes live.\n\nEven with the preparation, things do go wrong. In previous years, the sheer amount of traffic has caused error pages. And of course, in 2016, our models indicated Hillary Clinton was favored to win the presidential race, a prediction that changed when the live results began flowing in. But we\u2019ve avoided many of the most embarrassing errors, like calling the race for the wrong candidate.\n\nOnce we\u2019re live, we\u2019re monitoring how we\u2019re doing in real time. How many readers are on the page? How much faster do we have the latest update than our competition? What does our model say is happening? Has CNN projected a winner yet?\n\nElection night is also when our competitors introduce new tools. On the night of the 2017 general election, the TV in our conference room had our pages and the Matrix-like scrolling logs for our election data. But it also had a web browser with tabs open to Axios, CNN, Politico, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post.\n\nWe also communicate with other news outlets. In 2015, 2016 and 2017, we shared a private Slack channel with The A.P.\u2019s election developers, along with those from NPR, Politico, The Los Angeles Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post, so that we could discuss problems we saw in the data feed and solutions we might need to apply. The Times poured resources into an open-source software library called Elex that any organization could use to get real-time election results from The A.P.\n\nBut for all the competition around who has the fastest results or the most interesting visual presentation, the single most discussed element is still who has the best dinner. At The Times, we prefer tacos (my favorite: lengua), Sichuan (I hold out for the dan-dan noodles and mapo tofu) and Greek (lamb slices and those fantastic lemony potatoes), though we\u2019ve been known to have the occasional barbecue platter.\n\nLast year might have been an off-year for national elections. But New York City elected a mayor, and The Times had a knockout spread of street tacos. My only regret: Everyone in our cramped conference room smelled like cilantro and onions until we turned everything off and went home around 1 a.m. It was a small price to pay to hold our position in the increasingly competitive dinner wars of election night.", "title": "Why Data Nerds Embrace Election Night Jitters", "authors": ["Jeremy Bowers"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "The research is especially timely as American students consider whether to participate in the National School Walkout planned for Wednesday.\n\nIn the aftermath of the killing of 17 students and teachers in Parkland, Fla., teenagers around the country are planning to leave their school buildings on Wednesday at 10 a.m. for 17 minutes, a demonstration meant to honor the victims and advocate for gun control. Taking part in a single event \u2014 whether this one or another that matches the child\u2019s political leanings \u2014 may not, by itself, alter the trajectory of an adolescent\u2019s development. But the study\u2019s authors suggest that positive, lasting outcomes may result if organized civic engagement helps young people galvanize their belief in their personal efficacy, connect to empowering social networks or cultivate professional skills.\n\nIndeed, the teenage survivors of the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School shooting are already making a difference: Gov. Rick Scott of Florida credited them with inspiring new gun control legislation he signed last week.\n\nFor teenagers who intend to participate in the National School Walkout, this same study comes with an interesting caveat: Not all forms of political and social action confer equal benefits on young people. Though voting and volunteering both forecast lower levels of depression and smarter health choices down the line, activism does not.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cActivism,\u201d Dr. Ballard said, \u201cis usually a different social experience than other forms of civic engagement.\u201d While casting ballots and serving others both enjoy broad cultural support and are reliably gratifying, \u201cactivism tends to be more controversial. Activism can be empowering. But it can also be experienced as difficult and stressful.\u201d\n\nIndeed, the youth who engaged in activism \u2014 defined by the researchers as participating in a march or rally \u2014 enjoyed the positive benefits of greater educational attainment and larger incomes as they aged. But unlike those who only voted or volunteered, they also went on to engage in higher levels of risky health behaviors such as eating fast food, smoking cigarettes, using marijuana or binge drinking when they were between the ages of 24 and 32.\n\nThe study\u2019s authors propose two possible explanations for this.\n\nFirst, activists have, historically, often been members of counterculture groups where risk-taking may already have been the norm. Second, activists might become discouraged by the glacial pace of social change and turn to poor health habits to manage their frustration.\n\n\u201cWe can help young people reframe their expectations from big ideas to small wins,\u201d Dr. Ballard said. \u201cThe expectation shouldn\u2019t be changing federal policy right away, but getting news coverage and raising awareness.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAccording to Dr. Ballard, adults can also help teenagers feel that their activism is effective by making it about connection: \u201cconnecting with others, connecting with a cause and connecting with what\u2019s already going on.\u201d While most teenagers are too young to express their opinions by voting, participating in rallies is a way to make their voices heard. Those who want to join the effort to end school shootings can look to the student-led March for Our Lives movement to learn about the global rallies scheduled for March 24 \u2014 a Saturday, so there is no conflict with classroom time.\n\nOf course the decision about whether to support or disapprove of a teenager\u2019s activism is as personal as any in family life. Some adults will cheer on students who wish to participate in the walkout while others may oppose them or worry about the potential safety hazards, educational costs or disciplinary consequences of joining in. While some schools have threatened to suspend students who participate, legal scholars say students have the right to demonstrate unless they are disruptive. And dozens of colleges and universities said that any disciplinary actions against those participating in the protests would not affect their admissions decisions.\n\nLooking at the issue from a social science perspective, adults should nurture adolescents\u2019 efforts to catalyze political and social change because civic engagement can help teenagers grow. America has a long history of benefiting from the activism of young people; it\u2019s good to know that the young people usually benefit, too.", "title": "Why Demonstrating Is Good for Kids", "authors": ["Lisa Damour"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Such willful ignorance isn\u2019t unique to the Oscars, however. This kind of attitude is also partly to blame for the lack of progress for African-Americans in rates of homeownership, incarceration and employment over the past 50 years. The Economic Policy Institute recently released a study showing that the black homeownership rate stayed about the same from 1968 to 2015. But during that time, the black incarceration rate nearly tripled, and it\u2019s now more than six times the white incarceration rate. And the unemployment rate among blacks is worse than in 1968, and now twice the rate of white unemployment.\n\nThis news comes amid massive civil rights rollbacks by the Trump administration, and not long after a post-racial narrative that took hold during the Obama era: By electing a black president, the idea goes, America had at least partially moved past race. But both approaches ignore the project of improving life for black Americans.\n\nIt\u2019s clear that America prefers its black people to remain invisible \u2014 in underfunded schools, in segregated neighborhoods, behind bars. Black people can live and work, and pay taxes if we do so quietly. But we\u2019re not supposed to talk about inequality or discrimination. If we do, we\u2019re \u201cplaying the race card.\u201d\n\nBy now I hope this isn\u2019t a spoiler, but just in case, you\u2019ve been warned: What makes \u201cGet Out\u201d a horror film is that the Armitage family, with its surgeon father and psychiatrist mother, puts white brains into black bodies and leaves the leftover black brains in the \u201csunken place,\u201d where the black host can think but can\u2019t act. The sunken place illustrates the invisibility that many black people are forced into in real life \u2014 a state where they are looked at but not seen, heard but not listened to. At the same time, the use of the sunken place draws attention to the overrepresentation of black people among the physically missing.\n\nThe Armitage family\u2019s black servants have all undergone the surgery, so when Chris, the black protagonist, asks them how they\u2019re treated, they fawn over their subservient jobs. Logan King, who is kidnapped and subjected to the procedure at the beginning of the movie, appears at the Armitages\u2019 party and says to his white girlfriend, \u201cChris was just telling me how much more comfortable he felt with my being here,\u201d signaling to Chris that it\u2019s inappropriate to draw attention to their blackness.", "title": "Opinion | Why Didn\u2019t \u2018Get Out\u2019 Win Best Picture?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "In some households, cracking your knuckles is a declaration of war. Whether you\u2019re in the camp that can\u2019t stand the sound or the one that can\u2019t see what the fuss is about, you might be surprised to learn that where exactly the sound is coming from \u2014 what precisely in the knuckle produces it \u2014 is still a subject of scientific research.\n\nFor more than 50 years people have been publishing scholarly papers about what is going on in your finger as you pull it. Lately an older theory, that the sound arises from the popping of a bubble in the joint, has been challenged by one that holds that the formation of the bubble itself is responsible. On Thursday in the journal Scientific Reports, the saga continued: A pair of researchers at the \u00c9cole Polytechnique in France reveal a mathematical model of a cracking knuckle and suggest that the old theory could accurately explain the sound.\n\nThe first thing to understand about the knuckle is that it is full of fluid. Where the two bones of the finger meet, a little lake of synovial fluid keeps them from grinding on each other. There is gas dissolved in the synovial fluid, mostly carbon dioxide, and it usually stays there. However, when the bones are pulled away from each other, there\u2019s a sudden drop in pressure in the middle of the joint. Lower pressure allows the gases to come together, forming bubbles. Earlier work had suggested the collapse of such structures was behind the noise.\n\nIn 2015, however, Greg Kawchuk of University of Alberta and collaborators used an M.R.I. scanner to record what was happening in the finger of a volunteer who was a frequent knuckle-cracker. In the images, you can see the sudden appearance of a bulge in the knuckle as it is cracked.\n\nThis is the result, Dr. Kawchuk and colleagues wrote, of the formation of a bubble, which persisted for some time afterward, and whose creation might be responsible for the cracking noise. They posited that the bubble generated a pressure wave in the fluid, producing a sound. However, it was not clear how that wave could be powerful enough to make the distinctive crack.\n\nMore Reporting on Mathematics\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAbdul Barakat, a professor of biomechanics at the \u00c9cole Polytechnique in France, and Vineeth Suja, then a master\u2019s student, came across the 2015 paper as they grew interested in knuckle-cracking themselves. To see whether even the old theory could produce a sound of that magnitude, they created a simplified mathematical model of a joint with a bubble in it and ran simulations, comparing the theoretical sounds of the bubble collapsing in the model with recordings of Mr. Suja, who is now a doctoral student at Stanford University, and others cracking their knuckles.\n\n", "title": "Why Do Cracking Knuckles Make That Noise? You Might Need a Calculator", "authors": ["Veronique Greenwood"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Elsewhere in the world, a mile of subway track typically costs $500 million or less.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s fantastic that people are really paying attention to this issue,\u201d said Dani Simons, a spokeswoman for the Regional Plan Association, a research and advocacy group that released its own report on high transit construction costs last month. \u201cWe\u2019re very excited that they\u2019re doing this study.\u201d\n\nA spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs the subways, said the authority was already acting to reduce construction costs.\n\n\u201cThe M.T.A. under new leadership is aggressively tackling these issues through working groups dedicated to procurement reform and containing construction costs,\u201d said the spokesman, Jon Weinstein. \u201cWe are implementing new processes and procedures to streamline work, stop customization and reduce change orders \u2014 all of which will help us drive down costs.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe federal inquiry is a milestone in more than a year of stop-and-start efforts in Washington to address the costs of transit construction. The Senate inserted the request for the Government Accountability Office study in its spending plan last year, but it was stripped out in negotiations with the House.\n\nThis year, amid a crisis of delays on the New York subway system, an amended version of the provision calling for the study survived the final budget negotiations and made it into the spending bill.\n\n\u201cNot later than 9 months after the enactment of this act, the G.A.O. shall report to the House and Senate Committees on Appropriations regarding the construction costs of transit capital projects in the United States in comparison to other developed G-20 nations, such as South Korea, Japan, Spain, France, Italy and Germany,\u201d the provision states.\n\nAll those countries have completed major construction projects in the last decade that cost far less than American projects. The extension of the 14 Line in Paris, for example, was very similar to the Second Avenue subway project in length, depth, soil type, environmental issues and regulations, but it cost just $450 million per track mile. In Madrid, a project to extend the 2 Line, completed in 2011, cost just $100 million per track mile.\n\nAmerican transit construction generally is more expensive than work completed abroad, but recent projects in New York have cost far more than elsewhere in the country. In San Francisco, for example, the 1.7-mile central subway is being built for about $1 billion per track mile. The University Link project in Seattle cost around $500 million per track mile.\n\nThe Times investigation found that the high costs were the result, in part, of generous contracts, excessive staffing and archaic work rules.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne member of the M.T.A. board, Charles G. Moerdler, summarized the problems: \u201cIs it rigged? Yes. I don\u2019t think it\u2019s corrupt. But I think people like doing business with people they know, and so a few companies get all the work, and they can charge whatever they want.\u201d", "title": "Why Does Subway Construction Cost So Much? Congress Wants to Find Out", "authors": ["Brian M. Rosenthal"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "In most areas, he said, drivers pay the same premium whether they drive 90 miles round-trip to work each day, or if they take public transit and drive their car only on the weekends.\n\nTo conduct its analysis, researchers obtained quotes for basic liability coverage from Allstate, Farmers, Geico, Progressive and State Farm, using the same hypothetical driver with a clean driving record, but varying the number of miles driven annually. Researchers sought five different quotes for miles driven each year, from 2,500 miles to 22,500 miles. (The cities tested were Atlanta; Baltimore; Boston; Charlotte, N.C.; Chicago; Cleveland; Houston; Los Angeles; Minneapolis; Oklahoma City; Rochester; and Tampa, Fla.)\n\nThe report found that outside California, given drivers with similar characteristics, Progressive and Farmers usually quote the same rates to someone who drives just 2,500 miles a year that they do someone who drives 22,500 a year. (Progressive referred an inquiry to the Property Casualty Insurers Association, an industry group. Farmers didn\u2019t immediately respond to a request for comment.)\n\nGeico offered a small price reduction, the analysis found, while Allstate\u2019s and State Farm\u2019s quotes for the lowest-mileage drivers averaged savings of 11 percent and 13 percent, respectively, compared with the highest-mileage drivers.\n\nDrivers in Los Angeles saw consistent savings for fewer miles driven, the analysis found. Premiums dropped nearly 9 percent on average for every reduction of 5,000 miles driven per year, and very low-mileage drivers were quoted rates of about 30 percent less than very high-mileage drivers. California law requires auto insurers to give mileage driven the second-greatest weight when setting premiums, after the consumer\u2019s driving record, researchers said.\n\nQuotes for drivers in other cities saw average savings of less than 2 percent for every 5,000-mile reduction in annual mileage, or less than $3 in savings per month.\n\nThe Property Casualty Insurers Association said in a statement that the federation\u2019s latest report was \u201cflawed\u201d and showed a \u201cfundamental misunderstanding of auto insurance underwriting and rating.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInsurers use multiple factors that have proved to be effective in predicting the likelihood of someone filing an insurance claim, the association said. \u201cBy using a variety of rating factors, insurers are able to develop a more complete picture of a driver\u2019s potential for filing a claim and in this way more accurately price the policy.\u201d\n\nAs the report itself says, insurers do consider mileage driven as a factor, the association said, but \u201cas one would expect in a competitive market, it is done so differently among insurers.\u201d\n\nSome insurers, the report noted, have said they don\u2019t emphasize mileage in setting rates because customers often wrongly estimate how much they drive. The researchers suggested, however, that there are ways to verify the accuracy of mileage estimates, like recording odometer readings at the time of policy purchase or renewal, or after accident claims.\n\nHere are some questions and answers about auto insurance premiums:\n\nShould I tell my insurance company if I\u2019m driving less?\n\nYes. \u201cIt\u2019s always worth talking to your agent and saying, \u2018Do you know how much I drive?\u2019\u201d said Doug Heller, a federation researcher who conducted the study with another researcher, Michelle Styczynski. Retirees, in particular, should check in with their agents. They may be charged the same rate as they had previously been, even though they are no longer commuting to work.\n\nHow can I lower my insurance premium?\n\nMargot Gilman, money editor at Consumer Reports, said one of the best ways to make sure you\u2019re getting the lowest rate possible is to comparison shop at least every few years. \u201cCast a wide net,\u201d she said: Get quotes from a dozen insurers, not just two or three. She recommends trying the online quote comparison tool the thezebra.com. (But also check an insurer\u2019s reputation. A rock-bottom premium won\u2019t help much if the insurer gives you too low an estimate on repairs. Consumer Reports offers customer satisfaction ratings on many insurers, though you have to be a member.)\n\nA start-up, Metromile, offers pay-by-the-mile insurance, but is currently available in just a half-dozen cities.\n\nWhat other discounts might be available?\n\nDiscounts may be offered to student drivers for maintaining good grades, for drivers who take a \u201cdefensive driving\u201d class or to customers who bundle various insurance policies (like auto, homeowners and life) with the same insurer. Ask your agent.", "title": "Why Driving Fewer Miles May Not Lead to Lower Auto Premiums", "authors": ["Ann Carrns", "Your Money Adviser"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 On Nov. 9, 2016, when we Europeans woke up to the news of Donald Trump\u2019s election as president of the United States, most of us understood that it would have a significant impact on world politics. What we did not realize at the time was how much that event would alter the basic fabric of international relations.\n\nOver the past 16 months, we have been through roughly three stages in dealing with the fact that our first ally, the United States of America, is ruled by such an unorthodox president. We began by betting on human wisdom and political realism: Soon enough, Donald Trump, the nationalist, populist candidate, would wise up and become President Trump. Maverick politicians tend to do this in democratic societies.\n\nThen came the \u201cadults in the room\u201d stage. When it became clear that there was no wising up in the Oval Office, we were led to believe that fortunately, the celebrated checks and balances of the American system were functioning. The toxic Steve Bannon would soon be on his way out. Some experienced, reliable generals were taking over; their advice would prevail. How would official Washington have reacted if generals were appointed to key posts in a French or German government? Not warmly, one suspects. But these being no ordinary times, Europeans went along with the idea.\n\nFor those who still bought it, the \u201cadults in the room\u201d theory took a serious beating last month at the Munich Security Conference, an annual gathering of top dogs in foreign and defense policy. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis came, but surprisingly did not take the floor. Gen. H. R. McMaster, the national security adviser, did speak but was very publicly chided a few hours later by a presidential tweet because he \u201cforgot\u201d to say that Russian interference had no impact on Mr. Trump\u2019s election.", "title": "Opinion | Why Europe Is Giving Up on Trump\u2019s America", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "If Mr. Lamb, a Marine veteran and a former federal prosecutor, defeats State Representative Rick Saccone, a Republican, in a district that the president carried by 20 points, the alarm bells will be audible across the country. The Democrats will have shown that they can breach the Republican hold on the blue-collar white voters who helped deliver Mr. Trump the presidency.\n\n\u201cIf the Democrats were to prevail in western Pennsylvania, that would be quite an earthquake, let\u2019s face it,\u201d said Representative Charlie Dent, a Republican who represents a district in the eastern part of the state. \u201cIf a strong pro-Trump district like this goes the other way, it would send a bad signal around the country in districts far more competitive than this one.\u201d\n\nWhat is so remarkable about the Republican intervention is the ephemeral impact of its outcome. The lawmaker who held the seat \u2014 a married man and an opponent of abortion \u2014 fled Congress after his mistress let it be known that he had pressed her to have an abortion. Since then, the State Supreme Court has redrawn Pennsylvania\u2019s congressional lines, and Mr. Lamb will live in another district come November.\n\nWin or lose, he will probably be running against another Republican lawmaker in a more Democrat-friendly district slightly to the north.\n\nYet Republican officials, who believe that Mr. Saccone is a pedestrian candidate, say they could not simply abandon such a red-tinted region, especially with the White House unveiling tariffs aimed at bolstering the steel industry and eager to keep its grip on the crucial industrial Midwest this year and in 2020.\n\nNow, with Mr. Lamb gaining ground, they are doing everything they can to push Mr. Saccone over the finish line, including a bit of political gamesmanship. The Congressional Leadership Fund, the leading House Republican \u201csuper PAC,\u201d is sending mail to Democratic households depicting Mr. Lamb firing an assault rifle and noting that he supports gun rights \u2014 part of an attempt to dilute his support among more liberal voters.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe group has also put together a deceptive digital ad made to look like a cable television news report that portrays Mr. Lamb as reaching a \u201cboiling point\u201d with the labor unions, a pillar of his support.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cDemocrat abandons PA Unions,\u201d the ad says, noting that he opposes raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour. While Mr. Lamb does oppose such an increase, he enjoys overwhelming support from unions.\n\nIn an interview, Mr. Lamb said that he was running in part because he was \u201cupset we weren\u2019t competing everywhere,\u201d and he argued that his success, in the wake of the West Virginia teachers\u2019 strike, could help reinvigorate the beleaguered union movement.\n\n\u201cIt could send a message that we have rebuilt and reconnected our link with organized labor,\u201d he said. \u201cThey\u2019re at the top of our agenda.\u201d\n\nThis appeal, along with Mr. Lamb\u2019s unapologetic opposition to Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, has offered other Rust Belt Democrats something of a model for how to run in the Trump era.\n\nIf that gives Ms. Pelosi, who is eyeing a return to the speakership, pause, it troubles Mr. Trump and his allies even more as they aim to hold together their 2016 coalition. The president will have visited the district twice by Tuesday, and other administration officials have come for their own events.\n\nRonna McDaniel, the Republican National Committee chairwoman, noted that Mr. Lamb is \u201crunning like a Republican,\u201d pointing out not just his opposition to gun control but also his support for the president\u2019s tariffs.\n\nBut Ms. McDaniel said that the overarching reason the party and the White House are competing so aggressively is they know Democrats are energized and history suggests they could make big gains this fall.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
