In the Senate race, Mr. Renacci, 59, has staked his campaign on his relationship with the president and attacked Mr. Brown for opposing Mr. Trump\u2019s tax cuts. Both he and the president, Mr. Renacci said in an interview, \u201cwant to make sure Ohio is great again.\u201d\n\nBut the tangled lines of populist politics could complicate that blunt partisan argument: Where Mr. Brown endorsed the Trump tariffs, Mr. Renacci has been more equivocal, calling them a work in progress.\n\nAt a union hall in Dayton last month, Mr. Brown found an audience seemingly friendly both to Mr. Trump and his own campaign. Addressing a Teamsters local about the union\u2019s pension crisis, Mr. Brown was introduced by a pair of labor activists who borrowed from the president\u2019s message to suggest Washington had overlooked them in favor of other vulnerable groups. \u201cWe\u2019re dreamers, too,\u201d declared Rita Lewis, a prominent Teamsters activist who is close to Mr. Brown. \u201cWe\u2019re not illegal aliens. We\u2019re American citizens.\u201d\n\nMr. Brown addressed the group in a confiding tone, hunched over a lectern and upbraiding Washington for siding too often with banks over workers. As Mr. Brown worked the crowd afterward, Greg Thompson, a Teamsters member from Akron, explained that he voted for Mr. Trump because of his stance on trade, but these days considered Mr. Brown a more reliable ally.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know what to think of the president,\u201d said Mr. Thompson, 69. \u201cHe talks out of both sides of his mouth.\u201d\n\nAs for Mr. Brown, Mr. Thompson said, \u201cWe\u2019re 100 percent behind him.\u201d", "title": "Why Joe Biden and Elizabeth Warren Are Eyeing Ohio in 2018", "authors": ["Alexander Burns"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Edward E. Curtis IV, the author of \u201cBlack Muslim Religion in the Nation of Islam,\u201d said that while estimates ranged wildly about how many bona fide members belonged to the Nation, he believes that there were tens of thousands of members in the 1960s and early 1970s. But he said that millions of others sympathized with the movement\u2019s anticolonial stance and were inspired by its most famous member, Muhammad Ali.\n\nWho is Louis Farrakhan?\n\nBorn Louis Eugene Walcott in New York in 1933, Mr. Farrakhan joined the Nation of Islam in the mid-1950s and rose quickly within the organization, becoming close to Malcolm X. After the assassination of Malcolm X in 1965, he became one of the most powerful members of the Nation and its chief spokesman, the position that Malcolm X had held.\n\nThe Nation of Islam had gained followers around the nation in the 1940s and \u201950s by providing something of a religious answer to antiblack racism. It was not widely recognized as an anti-Jewish organization during its early years (its early literature, though, focused on \u201cthe white man\u201d as \u201cthe white devil\u201d). But in 1967, it became outspokenly and flagrantly anti-Zionist, in an expression of solidarity with Palestinians. That political position became a vehicle for Mr. Farrakhan to express his anti-Semitism. (Among his more infamous comments is his 1984 description of Adolf Hitler as \u201ca very great man.\u201d)\n\nIn 1975, when Elijah Muhammad died, the Nation split into two factions. The faction reconstituted under Mr. Farrakhan in the late 1970s retained the original name, though not the influence or support that it had when its leaders were Malcolm X, Muhammad Ali and Elijah Muhammad. Mr. Curtis said that today the membership could be in the thousands, and there could even be as many as 10,000 followers.\n\nMr. Farrakhan, whose name, the Anti-Defamation League wrote after the February event, is \u201cvirtually synonymous with anti-Semitism,\u201d then drew national attention in 1984, when he exhorted his followers to support Jesse Jackson\u2019s bid for the Democratic presidential nomination.\n\nIn a radio address, he urged listeners to \u201cmake an example\u201d of a Washington Post reporter who had reported that Mr. Jackson had used anti-Semitic terms in private. Mr. Jackson repudiated Mr. Farrakhan, but the minister\u2019s support proved troublesome to his 1988 campaign as well.\n\nHe was back in the news in 1995 when he organized what became known as the \u201cMillion Man March,\u201d a political and religious revival event in Washington.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhy were Tamika Mallory and Danny Davis reluctant to denounce him?\n\nMs. Mallory, who declined to comment for this article, did not respond to calls to condemn Mr. Farrakhan, for whom she had expressed admiration in the past.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn March 3, she said on Twitter that someone had brought to her attention that she had yet to tweet \u201cmy absolute position on how wrong anti-Semitism is.\u201d A day later, she said that she was \u201ccommitted to ending anti-black racism, anti-Semitism, homophobia & transphobia,\u201d but did not mention Mr. Farrakhan.\n\nIn an essay posted Wednesday, she said that she had been attending Saviour\u2019s Day celebrations for over 30 years.\n\n\u201cIn that most difficult period of my life, it was the women of the Nation of Islam who supported me and I have always held them close to my heart for that reason,\u201d she said. The essay did not mention Mr. Farrakhan.\n\nAsked what the appeal of Mr. Farrakhan\u2019s views might be to people like Ms. Mallory, religious scholars emphasized that the Nation of Islam is a religion and can provide comfort and aid to its adherents.\n\n\u201cFor those who find it appealing, it is a form of radical black self love that is willing to challenge any potential impediment to black freedom,\u201d Mr. Curtis said.\n\nYvonne Chireau, a professor of religion at Swarthmore who called Mr. Farrakhan\u2019s remarks about Jews \u201cunbelievably vile,\u201d emphasized that his fundamentalism was comparable to the fundamentalist views found in other religions.\n\nCoincidentally, the photo of Mr. Farrakhan and Mr. Obama had been published by the Trice Edney News Wire in January. The News Wire reported that the picture had been taken by the photojournalist Askia Muhammad during a 2005 meeting of the Congressional Black Caucus and that Mr. Muhammad kept the photo under wraps so as not to hurt Mr. Obama\u2019s candidacy.\n\n(Mr. Muhammad, in a 2012 blog post, said that he was an admirer of Mr. Farrakhan and that the minister was not an anti-Semite. He reaffirmed that he admired Mr. Farrakhan in an interview on Friday, though he said that the things the minister says about Jewish people \u201csometimes make me shudder.\u201d)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKatie Hill, a spokeswoman for Mr. Obama, said on Friday: \u201cPresident Obama has denounced racism and anti-Semitism his entire life. That includes his public and repeated repudiations of Louis Farrakhan\u2019s views over the years. Today is no different \u2014 he still rejects the harmful and divisive views Farrakhan continues to espouse.\u201d\n\nRepresentative Davis, who was interviewed by The Daily Caller, a conservative news site, after the photo emerged, called Mr. Farrakhan an \u201coutstanding human being,\u201d and later said he was not bothered by the leader\u2019s position on \u201cThe Jewish Question.\u201d\n\nAfter a monthlong backlash about that interview, largely in conservative media, Mr. Davis said in a statement to Forward on Thursday that \u201cI reject, condemn and oppose Minister Farrakhan\u2019s views and remarks regarding the Jewish people and the Jewish religion.\u201d", "title": "Why Louis Farrakhan Is Back in the News", "authors": ["Jonah Engel Bromwich"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "This attitude was reinforced by the opinions of people he valued. The Senate Democratic leadership on foreign policy \u2014 J. William Fulbright, Russell and Mike Mansfield, the majority leader \u2014 privately warned him in 1964 and \u201965 against Americanizing the war. Allied leaders abroad did the same, as did prominent voices in the press.\n\nHis own vice president, Hubert H. Humphrey, a savvy politician who needed no reminder of the risks of \u201closing\u201d a nation to Communism, insisted, in a memo in mid-February 1965, that the risks of escalation were far greater.\n\n\u201cIf we find ourselves leading from frustration to escalation and end up short of a war with China but embroiled deeper in fighting in Vietnam over the next few months,\u201d Humphrey warned, \u201cpolitical opposition will steadily mount,\u201d because Americans had not been persuaded that a major war on behalf of an ineffectual Saigon government was justified.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt the same time, no senior military leader in 1965 offered the White House even a chance of rapid victory in Vietnam. Five years, 500,000 troops, was the general estimate Johnson heard. Where would that put the president in early 1968, as his campaign for re-election began in earnest? Right where he found himself as he sat down to deliver his announcement on March 31: in a protracted war with no end in sight.\n\nSo why did he go in? Part of the answer, surely, is that escalation, if done quietly, gradually and without putting the nation on full war footing, offered Johnson the path of least immediate resistance (always a tempting option for a policymaker), especially in domestic political terms. Given his repeated public affirmations of Vietnam\u2019s importance to American security, it made sense that he would remain steadfast, in the hope that the new military measures would succeed, lest he face accusations of backing down, of going soft.\n\nMore than that, Johnson made the leap because for him, \u201cretreat\u201d from the struggle was inconceivable. He personalized the war, saw attacks on the policy as attacks on himself, and failed to see that his landslide victory in 1964 and the international and domestic context in early 1965 gave him considerable freedom of action \u2014 a point Humphrey cogently underscored in his February memo.\n\nFrom Day 1 to the end, Johnson was a hawk on Vietnam, which proves again that doubting warriors can be committed warriors. He always framed his options in such a way that standing firm appeared the only reasonable choice \u2014 it was full retreat, bomb the hell out of China, or stay the course. Never did he fully explore imaginative ways out of the conflict; for him, extrication without victory signified humiliation and defeat.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis didn\u2019t mean Johnson rejected all talk of negotiations. After mid-1965 he pressed Under Secretary of State George Ball for new diplomatic ideas \u2014 although, as Ball later remarked, \u201che really meant merely new channels and procedures.\u201d\n\nWhen negotiations with North Vietnam at last began in Paris in May 1968, Johnson took a firm line. He also continued the bombing and indeed increased it below the 19th Parallel and in Laos. In the 10 months from March 1 to Dec. 31, 1968, the Pentagon dropped a greater tonnage of bombs on Indochina than had been expended in the three years prior. This expanded bombing, Daniel Ellsberg hauntingly concludes in his memoir of the war, was \u201cobediently carried out\u201d by men from Secretary of Defense Clark Clifford \u201con down to flight crews, who believed it served no national purpose whatever.\u201d\n\nHumphrey won the Democratic nomination in 1968, yet Johnson was reluctant to throw his full support behind him, privately accusing the vice president of being cowardly and disloyal whenever he expressed a desire to move policy even modestly in a dovish direction. Some part of Johnson preferred to see Richard Nixon as his successor, expecting, with reason, that the Republican would be more resolute than Humphrey in pursuing the war.\n\nAnd so it ended, the saga of Lyndon Johnson\u2019s presidency, its denouement having been anticipated by him at the beginning. He was a man who dreamed big dreams for the Great Society, who hoped that his prodigious efforts on civil rights, voting rights, education and Medicare would earn him a place alongside Abraham Lincoln and Franklin Roosevelt \u2014 and who anticipated from the start that Vietnam would ruin it all.\n\nIt bears all the markings of tragedy, but of a certain kind, more Shakespearean than Greek, more Macbeth than Agamemnon. Whereas for the Greek playwrights the universe tends to be deterministic, the hero at the mercy of forces beyond his control, for Shakespeare the tragedy lies in the very choices the protagonist makes. His Macbeth is no mere victim; he contributes to his own demise. The same must be said of Lyndon Johnson.\n\nFor those seeking symbols there is, finally, this: On Jan. 22, 1973, Johnson died at his Texas ranch, two days after hearing Nixon, in his second inaugural address, hint at cuts to the Great Society and remind Americans how far they had come from that bleak time in 1968, when they faced \u201cthe prospect of seemingly endless war abroad and of destructive conflict at home.\u201d The next day, Nixon announced a deal had been reached in Paris to end the war and \u201cbring peace with honor.\u201d", "title": "Why Lyndon Johnson Dropped Out", "authors": ["Fredrik Logevall"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "In the history of nuclear weapons there has been only one country that voluntarily gave up its weapons and the program that produced them, and that is South Africa. That should tell us something about how hard it will be to persuade North Korea to dismantle its large and very sophisticated weapons program.\n\nThe South African program was unusual in several ways. It used a method of enriching uranium that had never been tried on an industrial scale, injecting hexafluoride gas at very high velocity into a tube to separate out the fissile bomb-making isotope, uranium 235. What\u2019s more, only white Afrikaners \u2014 no mixed-race or black or Asian South Africans \u2014 were allowed to work on the program.\n\nSouth Africa had managed to manufacture six bombs and had one under construction when, in 1989, it turned its entire weapons program over to the International Atomic Energy Agency for a variety of reasons, including a desire to end its international isolation. None of these devices were ever tested.\n\nThree former Soviet republics \u2014 Belarus, Kazakhstan and Ukraine \u2014 also gave up nuclear arms in the 1990s. But those countries had not produced the weapons: They were made by the Soviet Union and simply stored in the republics. So they were not abandoning actual nuclear weapons programs.", "title": "Opinion | Why Making North Korea Nuclear-Free Will Be So Hard", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Far from damaging Mr. Putin, with just days to go before Russia\u2019s presidential election, the accusations leveled at Moscow by Britain only reinforce Mr. Putin\u2019s position that Russia is a besieged fortress under constant threat from enemies within and outside its borders.\n\n[ Read more about the clash escalating between Britain and Russia.]\n\nWhile steadfastly denying any involvement in the attack, the Kremlin has added the episode to a daily diet of news on state news media outlets that showcase what Mr. Putin, in a recent state of the nation address in Moscow, described as Russia\u2019s invincible might and its readiness to strike back at enemies wherever they are.\n\nPhoto\n\nLike the new missile systems unveiled by Mr. Putin in that speech, the attack on Mr. Skripal has only added to the president\u2019s stature, at least among his base at home, as a fearless defender of the nation ready to do anything, no matter how risky, to assert Russia\u2019s status as a great power to be feared.\n\nRather than bow to British demands for an explanation of how a Russian-made military nerve agent ended up in Salisbury, Moscow went on the offensive. Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov on Tuesday dismissed British accusations as \u201cnonsense\u201d and demanded that Britain hand over the nerve agent used against Mr. Skripal and his daughter. Russia, he added, had so far \u201creceived an incoherent response, which amounts to a rejection of our legitimate demands.\u201d\n\nJust as Britain did earlier to Russia\u2019s ambassador in London, the Kremlin on Tuesday summoned the British ambassador to Moscow to demand an explanation.\n\nVladislav Inozemtsev, a Russia scholar currently at the Polish Institute of Advanced Studies in Warsaw, said the nerve-agent episode showed that \u201ctalking to Mr. Putin has become senseless.\u201d The Russian president and his senior officials, he said, would \u201cnever assume responsibility,\u201d whatever the facts were, and would only gloat over the suffering of a traitorous former spy \u2014 still unconscious and in critical condition \u2014 while blaming Britain for it.\n\n\u201cThey will stick to the thesis that Westerners kill agents they do not need anymore and then blame Russia,\u201d Mr. Inozemtsev said.\n\nPhoto\n\nRussia under Mr. Putin, said Mr. Galeotti, an expert on Russia\u2019s security services, \u201chas given up on winning respect through soft power and is pursuing what I call \u2018dark power.\u2019 \u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis approach, which involves Russia throwing its weight around and then reveling in the outrage this causes, Mr. Galeotti added in a telephone interview, \u201cplays into Putin\u2019s own natural instincts that a great power is one that is feared. It is better and much easier to be feared than loved.\u201d\n\nOf all the virtues in which Mr. Putin takes pride, none has more importance to the Russian leader \u2014 a veteran of a Soviet security apparatus built around a cult of loyalty to the state \u2014 than his commitment to the idea that nobody, especially not spies who defy their vows, can escape punishment for betrayal.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnswering questions from citizens in a 2010 phone-in program, Mr. Putin praised intelligence officers as \u201cpeople who lay their whole lives on the altar of the Fatherland\u201d and denounced those who betrayed this mission as \u201cpigs\u201d whose fate would be so miserable that they would \u201cregret a thousand times\u201d their treachery.\n\nMr. Skripal, who was convicted of high treason in Russia in 2004 and then allowed to settle in Britain after a 2010 spy swap, was a case study of all that Mr. Putin loathes.\n\nMr. Skripal almost certainly had no more Russian secrets to betray when he was attacked with a nerve agent identified as one of a Russian-produced class of chemicals known as Novichok. But he still represented an affront to the principle that betrayal must never go unpunished: He was alive and living comfortably in a pleasant English cathedral town.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs happened after accusations that Russia was responsible for the 2006 murder in London by radioactive poisoning of another intelligence turncoat, Alexander V. Litvinenko, the downing of a Malaysian passenger aircraft over Ukraine in 2014 and meddling in America\u2019s 2016 presidential election, officials and state news media outlets in Moscow responded with a barrage of denials and mockery to the latest outrage. They have scoffed at the idea Russia could possibly have had any role in the attack on Mr. Skripal and even suggested that the whole episode might have been fabricated.\n\nThe Russian Embassy in London, in sneering statements on its website and Twitter feed, refers to the \u201cSergei Skripal Case,\u201d using quotation marks to suggest it does not believe there really is such a case.\n\nRussia has yet to address in any detail the main piece of evidence pointing to a Russian hand \u2014 that Novichok agents have been produced only in Russia \u2014 and has instead developed conspiracy theories involving Ukraine, British revenge for past athletic defeats ahead of this year\u2019s World Cup soccer tournament in Russia and other far-fetched explanations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMoscow has been exasperated that its denials are not taken seriously and have been mocked relentlessly under a Twitter hashtag, #Russiadenies, even though officials have in the past acknowledged what they had earlier denied.\n\nMr. Putin and his lieutenants, for example, denied for weeks that Russian soldiers were involved in the seizure of Ukrainian military bases and government offices in Crimea in March 2014. The action, they insisted, was entirely the work of local \u201cself-defense units.\u201d The following month, however, Mr. Putin made a sharp U-turn, declaring, \u201cOf course our troops stood behind Crimea\u2019s self-defense forces.\u201d\n\nMaria V. Zakharova, the Russian Foreign Ministry\u2019s spokeswoman, mocked Mrs. May\u2019s statement to Parliament in London as a \u201ccircus show,\u201d adopting a sneering and decidedly undiplomatic tone now in vogue among Russian diplomats and commentators.\n\nBut in an earlier comment, soon after news of the nerve gas attack in Salisbury broke, the evening news host on the state-controlled Channel One gave voice to what, under Mr. Putin, is the Russian state\u2019s view of traitors.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t wish death on anyone, but for purely educational purposes, I have a warning for anyone who dreams of such a career,\u201d the newscaster Kirill Kleimenov told viewers. \u201cThe profession of a traitor is one of the most dangerous in the world.\u201d", "title": "Why Moscow Will Never Apologize for Attack on Ex-Spy", "authors": ["Andrew Higgins"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "But wind power is not a practical option for most individual households, said Michael Welch, a senior editor for Home Power magazine.\n\nFor a wind turbine to make economic sense, average wind speeds need to be higher than they are in most places. The Department of Energy recommends a minimum average wind speed of 10 miles an hour for a grid-connected wind turbine.\n\nThe majority of American cities fall short by that measure. Average annual wind speeds in New York City are about 9 m.p.h. In Los Angeles, they\u2019re about 7.5 m.p.h. You can find wind speeds for where you are by asking independent site assessors, or even checking with a nearby airport.\n\nBut even if you live in a particularly wind-swept part of the world, surrounding structures or geographical features \u2014 like buildings, trees or hillsides \u2014 can easily rob the wind of its energy. That means places like hilltops, plains and oceanfronts make good sites for wind turbines. Forests, valleys, cities and suburbs do not.\n\nStill determined to get a wind turbine? You\u2019ll also need a really tall tower \u2014 typically 80 to 120 feet tall, Mr. Welch said. And you\u2019ll need to be prepared to shimmy up that tower for regular maintenance, unless you get a tilt-up turbine that is easier to access from the ground.", "title": "Why Not Get Your Own Wind Turbine? Many Reasons", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Wolitzer started very young. She sold her first story, about a child who enters a box-top cereal contest that requires her to eat a great deal of cereal, to a children\u2019s magazine when she was 11; won a slew of writing competitions; got the same internship at Mademoiselle magazine that Sylvia Plath wrote about in \u201cThe Bell Jar,\u201d and sold her first book while a student, at Brown. (She transferred from Smith after her sophomore year.)\n\nNow she has reached the age when you can vividly remember your youth while also realizing you are no longer precocious. But the years are weighing lightly on her. \u201cYou don\u2019t want to look at your life like biography: \u2018How many novels did she write; in her West Side years she became more ambitious,\u2019\u201d she said. \u201cBut when I was young, I had the desire to do a lot, and now I have a desire to do a lot because I\u2019m 58. Work is the anti-death. It\u2019s hard for me to feel bad when I\u2019m writing well.\u201d\n\nMs. Wolitzer is on the writing faculty at Stony Brook Southampton, and occasionally sings with Suzzy Roche, from the folk trio the Roches. But what she really likes to do is to write. She has to work hard not to be distracted by the noise swirling outside in the air, she said.\n\n\u201cEverybody talks about that thing, what\u2019s it called, Freedom?\u201d she said, referring to the app that shuts off access to the internet for a set amount of time. \u201cThe danger is that you try to work on a paragraph that you care about, and you take a break and you find yourself in some political hellscape, or you\u2019re looking at a list of the Top 10 colleges. Why? I don\u2019t even have a kid in college now.\u201d (She has two boys in their 20s.)\n\nMs. Wolitzer began \u201cThe Female Persuasion\u201d three years ago. It was a slower time, before #MeToo and the exhilarating, bewildering avalanche of developments in the feminist movement.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a moment where everything\u2019s just being shaken up, realigning and changing really fast, like in a snow globe,\u201d she said. \u201cThere\u2019s such heat around everything, and it\u2019s really hard, at least for me personally, to work in that kind of state.\u201d\n\nShe continued: \u201cBut as a novelist, I feel lucky that I can traffic in nuance. I\u2019m more interested in looking at how things change over time, at how people try and sometimes fail to make meaning out of their lives.\u201d\n\nDo not rush her. \u201cIn this moment of the hot take, I\u2019m the master of the warm take,\u201d she said.", "title": "Why Now May (Finally) Be Meg Wolitzer\u2019s Moment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "For many counties, this makes migration especially important for population stability and growth. Counties in the Northeast and Midwest that have traditionally lost residents to the South and West are having a harder time propping up their population numbers.\n\nSome maintain their numbers because of immigration, but American immigration policy is now a subject of debate, and a smaller number of immigrants would put more pressure on counties facing population loss.\n\nThe nation\u2019s sprawling growth pattern has taken its share of criticism; it\u2019s associated with long-distance commuting, environmental degradation and urban decay. But population stagnation in places that had been growing will most likely bring its own sets of problems, including pressures on real estate values and eventual shrinking of political representation.\n\nAnd it starts with babies. The estimated lifetime births per woman is down 16 percent from a recent peak in 2007.\n\nNew Census Bureau projections say that Americans over 65 will outnumber children under 18 for the first time in U.S. history by 2030, and that \u201ca rising number of deaths will increasingly offset how much births are able to contribute to population growth.\u201d\n\nMigration dropped significantly during the recession, Mr. Johnson said, but has returned to pre-recession patterns, albeit at a slower pace. Florida, Texas and Arizona have all seen population inflows resume, for example, while states in the North east and Midwest that were losing residents to migration have resumed losing them.\n\nBirths, on the other hand, have not returned to pre-recession patterns. They\u2019ve instead skewed sharply in a negative direction.", "title": "Why Outer Suburbs in the East and Midwest Have Stopped Booming", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Italians are more practiced at such tumult. Over the past 25 years, Italy has changed prime ministers 13 times. It has swung this way and that. At this point it\u2019s more or less dangling: The nascent, renegade party that got the most votes in the recent election, the Five Star Movement, lacks a majority, not to mention a workable agenda, and doesn\u2019t have a coalition partner.\n\nThere\u2019s no clear national purpose, no steady national trajectory, no sturdy sense of control. Italians wait, somewhat helplessly, to see what happens next.\n\nBut their rituals, their families and their food \u2014 these are governable and protectable across time. They\u2019re the engines of stability. They\u2019re the agents of solace. Italians cling to them more fiercely, and with greater pride, than we Americans embrace our kin and our ways.\n\nI used to view this with a mixture of admiration and ridicule. When I lived in Rome, I often groused about how many restaurants had almost identical menus and how inviolable the rules and rhythm of Italian meals could be. Cappuccino at breakfast but never after dinner. Beer with pizza but not with pasta.\n\nOn return trips to the Eternal City, I occasionally rolled my eyes at the changelessness of it all. Here a carbonara, there a gricia, everywhere a cacio e pepe. Italians, I decided, wanted for imagination. They lacked daring.\n\nMaybe so. But this time around I felt only respect and gratitude for what they do have: the discernment to recognize a sweet spot \u2014 or rather, a fatty, salty one \u2014 when they find it and the wisdom not to abandon it on the unsupported chance that there\u2019s better around the bend.\n\nAnd so I kept happily to routine. I walked the Roman paths that were most familiar and dearest to me, lingered in the Roman piazzas that had given me pleasure before and supped not just on the classics but on one classic in particular: gricia. It was my link to a calmer past and my thread through a turbulent present.\n\nI can\u2019t predict where, politically, Italy or America is headed. I can\u2019t inoculate myself against Trump\u2019s coming tweets. But I can count on what happens when pork cheek meets pecorino. I can plant myself at that juncture. And I can stand still.", "title": "Opinion | Why Pasta Is the Answer to Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Still, Amazon cannot quietly hope that such criticism just fades away. Amazon\u2019s rapid growth, immense bargaining power, eye-catching initiatives and estimated 44 percent share of U.S. e-commerce sales make the company vulnerable to accusations that it is too powerful.\n\nBut if the Trump administration pursues ways to curtail the company, it would meet sizable obstacles.\n\nAmazon accounts for only 4 percent of all retail sales in the United States, a recent survey estimated. Its revenue is a third of Walmart\u2019s and, even after its acquisition of Whole Foods, Amazon\u2019s footing in the grocery business is still small.\n\nAll in all, it would be hard to show that Amazon is pushing prices higher for consumers.\n\nAmazon also has a loyal customer base \u2014 it has an estimated 90 million Prime members \u2014 and the public views it relatively favorably. When the Department of Justice\u2019s antitrust lawyers went after the proposed merger of Time Warner and AT&T, it was not targeting companies that were particularly popular with the public.\n\nStill, some Amazon critics see a possible, though small, opening. In theory, an antitrust case could focus on the firms that supply Amazon with goods, according to Christopher L. Sagers, a law professor at Cleveland State University. If a company consistently uses its power to demand a good from suppliers at too low a price, the public could still get hurt. That\u2019s because the supply of the good could decline, its quality degrade, and there may be less innovation in the sector that produces the good, Mr. Sagers said.\n\nBut anyone bringing that against Amazon would have to explain why Walmart would not be a target, too.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nPublic pension fund wants changes to Facebook\u2019s board.\n\nThe investment adviser to New York City\u2019s pension funds is calling for changes to Facebook\u2019s board to address the fallout from Cambridge Analytica\u2019s improper harvesting of information from 50 million users of the social network.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNew York City\u2019s comptroller, Scott M. Stringer, wrote in a letter addressed to Dr. Susan Desmond-Hellmann, an independent director at Facebook and the chief executive of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation:\n\n\u201cFacebook is now among the most valuable and, given the immense power and reach of its platform, most influential companies in the world. The very data collection and sharing practices that made its extraordinary growth possible, and that are the basis of the company\u2019s business model, are now facing potential regulation in numerous jurisdictions around the world.\u201d\n\nNew York City\u2019s pension funds, which have more than $193 billion in assets under management, own $895 million of Facebook\u2019s shares, according to the letter. Even with the recent tumble in its shares, Facebook is valued at more than $450 billion.\n\nIn his letter, Mr. Stringer calls on Facebook\u2019s independent directors to take four steps to help restore investor confidence.\n\nHere are the proposed changes:\n\n1) Add at least three new independent directors to improve the board\u2019s ability to oversee the evolving risks Facebook faces.\n\n2) Name an independent director as chairman, allowing Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook\u2019s chief executive and chairman, to focus on running the company.\n\n3) Create a committee of independent directors to oversee the company\u2019s data privacy policies and risks.\n\n4) Institute a clawback policy so that the board can \u201crecoup executive pay in the event of violations of law, regulation or company policy.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTrump tweets Amazon does not pay enough taxes.\n\nPresident Trump spoke out against Amazon on Thursday, saying that the online behemoth does not pay enough taxes and uses the United States postal system \u201cas their Delivery Boy.\u201d\n\nThe president\u2019s commentary, made in a Twitter post, comes amid reports that Mr. Trump has expressed an interest in reining in the e-commerce business.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmazon and the company\u2019s founder, Jeff Bezos, are among Mr. Trump\u2019s regular Twitter targets. In December, Mr. Trump questioned whether the United States Post Office charges Amazon enough for package deliveries. And in August, Mr. Trump said Amazon hurts taxpaying businesses.\n\nAmazon, however, does pay taxes \u2014 $412 million in 2016, for instance, according to the company\u2019s report to the Securities and Exchange Commission.\n\nAxios reported on Wednesday that Mr. Trump has wondered aloud whether Amazon could be vulnerable to antitrust or competition laws.\n\n\u201cTrump\u2019s wealthy friends tell him Amazon is destroying their businesses. His real estate buddies tell him \u2014 and he agrees \u2014 that Amazon is killing shopping malls and brick-and-mortar retailers.\u201d\n\nAmazon shares fell more than 7 percent following that Axios article but recovered some of those losses after a White House official told Reuters that the company faced no particular policy changes. But the administration is always looking at its options, the official added. The stock closed down 4.4 percent Wednesday.\n\nShares were down nearly 2 percent in early trading.\n\nShould shareholders worry? The GBH Insights analyst Daniel Ives told Bloomberg that this regulatory threat was unlikely to change Amazon\u2019s business model, but it was still \u201cthe last thing nervous tech investors wanted to see today.\u201d\n\nRetailers, at least, already have some reason to be cheerful.\n\nAnd Amazon has another target market for expansion: housekeeping.\n\nFirst quarter profits are going to be big.\n\nCorporate American will start reporting first-quarter results in less than two weeks, and earnings are expected to be big.\n\nAnalysts estimate that profits at companies in the S.&P. 500 grew 17.3 percent this quarter, according to FactSet. If the forecasts prove accurate that would be highest earnings growth rate since the first quarter of 2011.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPerhaps most surprising, is that analysts have grown more optimistic on corporate earnings as the quarter progressed. The earnings forecast for the index rose 5.4 percent from the start of the quarter to the end. Typically, analysts lower their expectations as the quarter progresses. On average, the profit estimates for the index fall 3.7 percent from the start of the quarter to the end.\n\nBut there are reasons for investors to temper their enthusiasm. Analysts have not been as optimistic about the abilities of companies to increase sales. Revenue is expected to have grown 7.3 percent in the first quarter, up from a 7 percent rate at the start of the quarter.\n\nThat suggests analysts are not raising estimates because of increased sales. So why are they? Taxes. And the impact tax reform will have on bottom lines should moderate in the coming quarters.\n\nThat may already be happening. BofA Merrill Lynch\u2019s earnings revision ratio for the S.&P. 500 fell in March for the first time in three months. Of course, the pullback comes after the ratio hits the highest level on record in February, but it does suggest that earnings lift from tax reform has begun to wane.\n\nPhoto\n\nAre we witnessing the end of a tech boom?\n\nInvestors, always willing to believe in technology companies, spent the last three years piling into their shares with abandon. Now the intellectual underpinnings of that rally are being tested.\n\nExhibit A: Facebook, down 20 percent from its recent high.\n\nExhibit B: Nvidia, off 12 percent from its recent high.\n\nExhibit C: Tesla, not a tech stock but in the FANG+ index.\n\nConcerns about Tesla\u2019s ability to fund itself can also be seen in the trading of its debt.\n\nThe WSJ\u2019s Charley Grant explains:\n\nTesla can\u2019t simply cut spending to solve its cash challenge if it hopes to ramp up production. The company has racked up about $10 billion in long-term debt and has $23 billion in total liabilities. To survive long term, Tesla needs to stop overpromising and to scale back its ambitions to goals it actually can achieve. Right now, though, it just needs more money.\n\nPeter Eavis notes that the latest problems for tech giants have raised deeper doubts:\n\nAfter the Uber incident in Arizona, those companies may take a more realistic look at what they have to spend to create a technology that is efficient and safe, and conclude that they have to pull out of the race or pare back. Users of social media and regulators may prevent social media companies from sharing so much of their data with advertisers, and that could restrain revenue growth. And if the passion for two or three big tech companies wanes, the cooling may spread.\n\nPhoto\n\nBarclays pays $2 billion to settle mortgage securities suit.\n\nBarclays said on Thursday that it agreed to pay $2 billion to settle a lawsuit by United States authorities that accused the British bank of fraudulently misleading the public in the sale of tens of billions of dollars in securities backed by home mortgages.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Justice Department sued the bank in December 2016 after the two sides failed to reach a settlement despite months of talks. The settlement is the latest by a European lender related to residential mortgage-backed securities sold ahead of the financial crisis and follows agreements reached by Credit Suisse and Deutsche Bank in late 2016.\n\n\u201cI am pleased that we have been able to reach a fair and proportionate settlement with the Department of Justice,\u201d James E. Staley, the Barclays chief executive, said in a news release. \u201cIt has been a priority for this management team from the start to resolve these historic issues in a timely and appropriate manner wherever possible.\u201d\n\nTwo former Barclays executives who were sued along with the bank also have reached settlements, agreeing to pay a combined $2 million, the Justice Department said in a news release.\n\nTheir lawyers separately said the government\u2019s claims were baseless and each agreed to settle the case without admitting wrongdoing.\n\n- Chad Bray\n\nGoldman banker to join Morgan Stanley\n\nTammy Kiely is leaving Goldman Sachs to join Morgan Stanley as global head of semiconductor and auto technology investment banking, according to an internal memo seen by The New York Times.\n\nMs. Kiely, who will be based in Menlo Park, Calif., joined Goldman in 1999 and had headed its semiconductor investment banking team since 2006, becoming a partner in 2014. Before Goldman, she worked at KPMG as a certified public accountant in its information, communications and entertainment practice.\n\nShe has a bachelor\u2019s degree in business administration from the California Polytechnic State University and an M.B.A. from the Stanford University Graduate School of Business.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Amid the scandal over Facebook data, it\u2019s thinking again.\n\nBut the group\u2019s executive, Scott McDonald, said that advertisers cared more about whether the data tech companies offered was accurate than whether they should have collected it.\n\nFacebook, for its part, promised yesterday to stop advertisers targeting ads using data from third-party brokers, and to put its user privacy settings in one place, rather than about 20. It\u2019s also rethinking privacy safeguards for forthcoming devices, The Information says.\n\nTim Cook of Apple is calling for privacy regulation: \u201cTo me, it\u2019s creepy when I look at something and all of a sudden it\u2019s chasing me all across the web.\u201d\n\nAnd our Kevin Roose considers how to save social media: Facebook could become more of a collective enterprise, social networks could become more like email or users could put an expiry date on information.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Expect more deals from SoftBank\u2019s Vision Fund.
