View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 Capital Economics: \u201cWe suspected that the flu epidemic and the unseasonably cold weather in January had depressed payrolls, but even we were caught out by the strength. Illness and weather also affected the earnings and hours worked data in January, with those effects unwinding in February.\u201d\n\nSenator Elizabeth Warren has some questions for Apollo and Citi.\n\nSpecifically, Ms. Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, is interested in the loans Apollo and Citigroup extended to Jared Kushner\u2019s family real estate firm, reports Politico\u2019s Playbook.\n\nMs. Warren, along with Representative Elijah Cummings, Democrat of Maryland, Senator Tom Carper, Democrat of Delaware, and Senator Gary Peters, Democrat of Michigan, sent letters to Apollo (the letter) and Citigroup (the letter) asking:\n\n\u201cFor the dates the loans were offered, conditions of the loan and a description of the process by which the Kushner Companies got the loans. It asks for ALL MEETINGS between the two firms and Kushner, and various details about those meetings. They request ALL DOCUMENTS from the loan process and whether any of the loans included foreign financing.\u201d\n\nContext\n\nThe New York Times reported last week that:\n\n\u2022 Josh Harris, a founder of Apollo Global Management, was advising Trump administration on infrastructure policy last year and met with Mr. Kushner several times. Among other things, the two men discussed a possible White House job for Mr. Harris, which never materialized. In November, Apollo lent $184 million to Kushner Companies. The loan was to refinance the mortgage on a Chicago skyscraper\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Michael Corbat, Citigroup\u2019s C.E.O., met with Mr. Kushner in the spring, and shortly afterward the bank lent Kushner Companies $325 million.\n\nPhoto\n\nMartin Shkreli is sentenced to seven years in prison for fraud.\n\nStephanie Clifford of the NYT reported:\n\nMartin Shkreli, a former pharmaceutical executive notorious for sharply increasing drug prices, mounting sneering defenses of his actions and even issuing a bounty for one of Hillary Clinton\u2019s hairs, was sentenced on Friday to seven years in prison after being convicted of fraud last year.\n\nLast summer, a jury convicted Mr. Shkreli, nicknamed Pharma Bro, on three of eight counts , concluding that he had lied to investors about, among other things, how the hedge funds were managed, what they invested in and how much money they had. The jury found that he had also secretly controlled a huge number of Retrophin shares.\n\nProsecutors had sought a sentence of at least 15 years; the defense had pushed for 12 to 18 months.\n\nHow much is Martin Shkreli\u2019s Wu-Tang album worth?\n\nBen Sisario of the NYT writes:\n\nWhen Martin Shkreli, the disgraced former pharmaceuticals executive, is sentenced for securities fraud in Brooklyn on Friday, the government will have its pick of a number of his assets to satisfy the $7.36 million judgmentagainst him. There is a brokerage account with $5 million in cash, shares in his company Vyera Pharmaceuticals, even a Picasso. And then there is an item that has been the subject of worldwide intrigue: the sole copy of the Wu-Tang Clan album \u201cOnce Upon a Time in Shaolin,\u201dpackaged in a custom silver-and-nickel case and accompanied by a 174-page leather-bound book. It may be the most famous album ever kept in the possession of just one person. But what is it worth?\n\nThe answer? It is complicated, though experts all doubt that the album could yield anywhere near the $2 million Mr. Shkreli apparently paid for the album at auction three years ago.\n\nThe tariffs already have carveouts\n\nPresident Trump authorized tariffs on imported steel and aluminum yesterday, defying allies and Republicans alike. But as Peter Eavis notes, the presence of exemptions for Canada and Mexico show more wiggle room than expected:\n\nCommerce Secretary Wilbur Ross has leeway to exempt certain steel and aluminum imports from the restrictions if he determines that the United States lacks the capacity to produce them. There is also a national security exemption, notable since national security concerns are the legal basis for the tariffs.\n\nAnd Neil Irwin of the Upshot reckons that while we\u2019re seeing a trade skirmish, it won\u2019t necessarily become a trade war. (He also thinks it\u2019s partly a negotiating tactic in the Nafta talks.) That hasn\u2019t stopped trade partners protesting. And in its lead editorial, The Economist wrote, \u201cNot since its inception at the end of the second world war has the global trading system faced such danger.\u201d\n\nThe other China trade story: Mr. Trump tweeted that he has asked Beijing to reduce its trade deficit with the U.S. by $1 billion, adding, \u201cWe must act soon!\u201d Elon Musk subsequently beseeched him on Twitter to tackle China\u2019s restrictions on auto imports.\n\nThe trade flyaround\n\n\u2022 U.S. allies like Canada and Japan signed what was long known as the Trans-Pacific Partnership, thumbing their noses at the White House. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 History belies Mr. Trump\u2019s assertion that \u201ctrade wars are good, and easy to win,\u201d Jim Stewart says. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Maybe we should worry less about the tariffs and more about the White House\u2019s inquiry into Chinese intellectual property policy. (Breakingviews)\n\nPhoto\n\nCould Peter Navarro replace Gary Cohn?\n\nThe policy adviser who pushed the tariffs wants to become the new national economic adviser \u2014 scarily for pro-free-trade business leaders and Mr. Cohn\u2019s dwindling cohort in the Trump administration.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore from Jonathan Swan of Axios:\n\nTrump loves Navarro, and Navarro reflects the president\u2019s hard-wired beliefs on trade far more closely than Cohn ever did, or did any of the other top officials involved in the trade debate besides Wilbur Ross.\n\nMr. Navarro isn\u2019t in the lead \u2014 other candidates include a top lieutenant to Mr. Cohn, Shahira Knight \u2014 but can\u2019t be counted out.\n\nThe politics flyaround\n\n\u2022 The president has threatened to veto a spending bill if it funds the Gateway tunnel between New York and New Jersey that he opposes, potentially leading to another government shutdown, unnamed sources say. (Politico)\n\n\u2022 The recent tax overhaul won\u2019t pay for itself, according to Harvard economists. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 The lawsuit against President Trump by the adult-film actress Stormy Daniels raises the possibility of the president needing to testify and could show evidence of campaign finance violations. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Elizabeth Warren has written to Citigroup and Apollo asking for details about loans to Kushner Companies just after Jared Kushner joined the White House. (Politico)\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen being a big health insurer isn\u2019t enough\n\nBehind Cigna\u2019s $67 billion (with debt) acquisition of Express Scripts is the idea that health insurance on its own is a challenged business. The C.E.O.s of the two companies said the union would help lower costs. But it\u2019s also meant to help Cigna counter both UnitedHealth, the giant of the industry, and a combined CVS and Aetna.\n\nThere\u2019s skepticism: Cigna\u2019s shares fell 11 percent yesterday. Matthew Borsch of BMO Capital Markets said that investors had hoped the insurer would buy something other than a business \u201cunder pressure, under scrutiny and to some degree in decline.\u201d\n\nAbout that pressure: The F.D.A. has shown interest in lack of competition among drug benefits managers. David Balto, an antitrust expert, told the NYT, \u201cHistory has shown where there are multiple mergers going on in a single industry, the Justice Department goes on high alert.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCritics\u2019 corner: Charley Grant of Heard on the Street writes, \u201cCigna has increased its vulnerability to industry changes rather than reduced it.\u201d And Lex says of Express Scripts\u2019 industry, \u201cLike Seth Rogen comedies, they are a U.S. institution whose utility eludes other nations.\u201d\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Toys \u201cR\u201d Us, yet to find a buyer, is preparing to liquidate its U.S. operations, unnamed sources say. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Shell and the Blackstone Group are in talks to make a $10 billion bid for BHP Billiton\u2019s U.S. shale assets, according to unnamed sources. (Sky News)\n\n\u2022 Atlantia of Italy and ACS of Spain are in talks over a joint bid for Abertis, avoiding a potential bidding war. (FT)\n\n\u2022 FanDuel is in talks to go public by merging with a blank-check company, Platinum Eagle Acquisition, unnamed sources say. (Axios)\n\n\u2022 McAfee is buying TunnelBear, a VPN services provider. (TechCrunch)\n\n\u2022 Before joining the White House, Jared Kushner held talks to sell the New York Observer to two big Democratic supporters, David Brock and the media mogul Haim Saban, unnamed sources say. (BuzzFeed)\n\nFalse news is your fault\n\nThat\u2019s according to an M.I.T. study that tracked the spread of both verifiably true and fake stories on Twitter, and found that \u201cfalsehood diffused significantly farther, faster, deeper, and more broadly than the truth in all categories of information.\u201d\n\nThe caveat, per Steve Lohr of the NYT:\n\n\u201cWe have to be very careful about making the inference that fake news has a big impact,\u201d said Duncan Watts, a principal researcher at Microsoft Research.\n\nElsewhere in social media: How Russian trolls slid into the private Facebook messages of Trump campaign aides. Rules to limit foreign meddling in U.S. elections may not take effect before this year\u2019s midterms. Sri Lanka is trying to block Facebook, WhatsApp and Instagram to stop anti-Muslim violence. And could Mr. Trump be obliged to mute critics on Twitter instead of blocking them?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Uber is pitching potential investors today on a $1.25 billion loan, unnamed sources say. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Meet Missouri\u2019s attorney general, Josh Hawley, who has subpoenaed Alphabet as part of an inquiry into potential violations of the state\u2019s consumer protection law. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 What happens when Bitcoin miners come to your town. (Politico)\n\n\u2022 Japan suspended trading on the exchanges FSHO and Bit Station amid concern about consumer protections. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Mr. Trump held a heated debate on whether violent video games can be connected to mass violence, but didn\u2019t indicate where he stood. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nBarack Obama may make shows for Netflix\n\nThe former president is in talks to create exclusive content for the streaming giant, though they haven\u2019t figured out how many episodes to do, according to the NYT. He\u2019s also drawn interest from Apple and Amazon.\n\nOur questions:\n\n\u2022 How much would Netflix pay? Remember that it gave the showrunner Ryan Murphy $300 million for a five-year content deal. The Obamas already signed book deals reportedly worth $60 million.\n\n\u2022 While Mr. Obama doesn\u2019t intend to take on his successor directly, will his likely choice of topics \u2014 like health care, immigration, voting rights \u2014 be seen as a counter to President Trump anyway?\n\nElsewhere in media: The actor and producer Michael B. Jordan will adopt the use of \u201cinclusion riders\u201d in his production company\u2019s projects. Disney will add a live-action \u201cStar Wars\u201d series to its forthcoming streaming service, to be directed by Jon Favreau. And Disney shareholders voted down a nonbinding endorsement of Bob Iger\u2019s pay package.\n\nPhoto\n\nInvestors are fearful. Traders are joyful.\n\nWhile the now nine-year-old bull market may still have some legs \u2014 even if it isn\u2019t likely to top last year\u2019s performance \u2014 there\u2019s more for investors be anxious of. Not so for traders.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore from Landon Thomas of the NYT:\n\n\u201cWe are seeing extreme volatility here \u2014 it is the Goldman Sachs business model,\u201d said Adam Sender, the founder of Sender Company & Partners, a hedge fund the specializes in making quick bets in up-and-down markets. \u201cThings are moving around like crazy \u2014 the opportunities are tremendous.\u201d\n\nA side note: Worried about the markets\u2019 movements? You might need a hug.\n\nAnd Peter Eavis wonders: What happens when the bond market and the Fed disagree? It\u2019s a bit like seeing the economy\u2019s parents fight, he says.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe tensions behind Dina Powell\u2019s return to Goldman\n\nBringing back the former White House adviser after her recent tour of duty in Washington, Lloyd Blankfein reckoned, would help the firm navigate the Trump presidency and win big clients worldwide.\n\nBut her forthcoming position on the management committee has rankled some senior executives, according to Bloomberg:\n\nThe decision to create a new seat on the committee for an executive whose prior experience at Goldman Sachs centered on philanthropy and related initiatives has become a topic of debate inside its hypercompetitive headquarters in Lower Manhattan.\n\nPhoto\n\nRevolving door\n\n\u2022 Tesla\u2019s chief accounting officer, Eric Branderiz, is the latest executive to leave. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Uber\u2019s head of product, Daniel Graf, is leaving. He\u2019ll be replaced by Assaf Ronen, who most recently led Amazon\u2019s voice shopping (\u201cAlexa, buy stuff\u201d) team. (Recode)\n\n\u2022 Twitter named Parag Agrawal as its chief technology officer. (CNBC)\n\n\u2022 Cory Johnson has left Bloomberg TV to become Ripple\u2019s chief market strategist. (CNBC)\n\nThe Speed Read\n\n\u2022 The N.M.E., once Britain\u2019s most important music newspaper and a taste maker on both sides of the Atlantic, has put out its last print edition after 66 years. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Institutional Shareholders Services opposed Elon Musk\u2019s $2.6 billion compensation package. (FT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The E.C.B. held interest rates steady, but dropped its promise to ramp economic stimulus back up \u201cif the outlook becomes less favorable.\u201d (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Helmut Maucher, who worked his way up from a factory job to become the C.E.O. who made Nestl\u00e9 the world\u2019s largest food company, died on Monday. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 G.M. faces the prospect of a potential $1 billion stock payout to address claims stemming from its ignition switch crisis. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Lehman Brothers caused $2.4 billion in damages to investors holding securities backed by shaky home mortgages, a New York bankruptcy judge ruled in one of the last remaining disputes in the defunct bank\u2019s nearly decade-long liquidation. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Merrill Lynch agreed Thursday to pay $1.4 million to settle S.E.C. allegations that it didn\u2019t do enough to investigate red flags at a Chinese company whose unregistered securities it sold. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Alex M. Azar II, the secretary of health and human services, said that doctors and hospitals should tell patients how much their care before treating them. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Congress is on track to order credit-reporting companies to let consumers freeze their data free of charge. (WSJ)\n\nWe\u2019d love your feedback. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Will Goldman\u2019s Blankfein Depart by the End of the Year?: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "In an administration full of men who seem to spend much of their time leaking unflattering information about one another to the press and appearing on cable news programs, Ms. Hicks was a distinctive figure. She kept her head down and knew how to manage the volatile president \u2014 mostly, it seems, by saying yes to him. She observed Mr. Trump\u2019s penchant for drama and did her best not to intrude on his one-man show, refusing to even speak to reporters for profiles about her. Instead, she was deferentially silent as Mr. Trump did the talking, and worked diligently in the background to make his life easier.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s actual daughter, Ivanka, has made this two-step between competent professional and dutiful daughter into something of an art form, enjoying the benefits of a West Wing job while insisting it\u2019s \u201cinappropriate\u201d to ask her questions about allegations of misconduct by her father \u2014 who also happens to be the man she works for. Ms. Hicks surely saw this narrow path to success under Mr. Trump and decided to walk it. The dutiful daughter strategy is one a man in her position could never have used. Mr. Trump, with his affinity for military men and mockery of male emotion would have seen such a subservient man as weak, but Ms. Hicks cannily leveraged the president\u2019s own misogyny to her advantage.\n\nIt\u2019s not the most feminist of moves, but Ms. Hicks was also in a position that many young women can recognize: working for a sexist boss who likes the women in his life, romantic and professional, to be slim variations on a very particular feminine model. Many of us have been polite in the face of boorishness and adapted hyperfeminine mannerisms in the company of chauvinists we were professionally obliged to please, putting success ahead of self-respect.\n\nBut of course, most of us weren\u2019t working to elect and then sustain Donald Trump, a man whose attitude toward women and instability affects billions of people the world over, not just those working under him. Playing nice for such a president is a different calculation than, say, a dental hygienist, lawyer or Walmart cashier might make under a similarly sexist supervisor.\n\nBeing new to working in the political world, Ms. Hicks may not have made that decision at all. If you don\u2019t see politics as a vehicle for positive change but rather as an abstraction shape-shifted into a job, and if you view the presidency as about power rather than public service, of course working to get your boss elected and then working closely with him in the White House would feel like nothing more than an exciting career opportunity. Why wouldn\u2019t Ms. Hicks use every tool in her arsenal to remain in the good graces of her volatile boss, and climb up the ladder accordingly?", "title": "Opinion | Will Hope Hicks Find Her Voice?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "And there is a good chance that President Trump\u2019s tariffs won\u2019t cause a great deal of collateral economic damage. They may end up being softer than Thursday\u2019s headlines suggest, as globalists push back. And like President Bush\u2019s tariffs, President Trump\u2019s may be quite narrow in focus and exist for a relatively short period. Investors could learn to live with those, just as they\u2019ve mostly shrugged off possible changes to the North American Free Trade Agreement.\n\nBut vulnerabilities exist right now that could magnify any negative impact of President Trump\u2019s tariffs.\n\nThe stock market is still highly valued after a searing rally that took it to an all-time high in January. The Federal Reserve expects to increase interest rates multiple times this year. Compare that with March 2002, when President Bush introduced his trade restrictions: The Fed was cutting interest rates, a policy stance that can help support the economy and the stock market; stocks were nowhere near their peak of two years earlier; and President Bush\u2019s administration was, overall, globalist in its outlook and didn\u2019t want to become isolated ahead of the Iraq war.\n\nImportantly, the United States economy is less dominant than it was 16 years ago. Last year, the United States accounted for an estimated 24 percent of the world\u2019s gross domestic product, using data from the International Monetary Fund. In 2002, the share was 32 percent. If other countries retaliate, and tariffs broaden, the United States\u2019 economy may be less resilient than some in the Trump administration may believe.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nHow business meetings cast a pall on Jared Kushner\n\nWe asked yesterday if his family\u2019s real estate business was his biggest liability. Our colleagues\u2019 latest story shows that might be the case.\n\nWhat happened\n\n\u2022 Josh Harris of Apollo Global Management, an adviser on infrastructure issues, met with Mr. Kushner several times last year. In November, Apollo lent $184 million to Kushner Companies, triple the size of the investment firm\u2019s average property loan.\n\n\u2022 Citigroup\u2019s C.E.O., Michael Corbat, met with Mr. Kushner in the spring, and shortly afterward the bank lent Kushner Companies $325 million.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Kushner, his family business, Apollo and Citi all said that nothing improper had happened. But the meetings raise questions about how the Kushner Companies is weighing down the political fortunes of President Trump\u2019s son-in-law. Mr. Kushner has already had his interim security clearance downgraded amid a feud with the White House chief of staff, John Kelly.\n\nThe WSJ editorial board writes, \u201cMr. Kushner and Ivanka have to decide if they\u2019d serve themselves and the president better by walking away from their formal White House roles.\u201d\n\nThe politics flyaround\n\n\u2022 The White House is set to announce new tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, according to unidentified sources. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Hope Hicks, the White House communications director and one of Mr. Trump\u2019s closest aides, plans to step down. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Mr. Trump publicly criticized Attorney General Jeff Sessions as \u201cDISGRACEFUL\u201d for not ordering his own investigation into the handling of the Russia inquiry. (NYT)\n\nTrump says he will impose stiff tariffs on steel and aluminum.\n\nFrom Ana Swanson of the NYT:\n\nPresident Trump said on Thursday that he will impose stiff and sweeping tariffs on imports of steel and aluminum as he moved to fulfill a key campaign promise to get tough on foreign competitors. Mr. Trump said he would formally sign the trade measures next week and promised they would be in effect \u201cfor a long period of time.\u201d The trade measures would impose tariffs of 25 percent on steel and 10 percent on aluminum. It is unclear whether those would apply to all imports or be targeted toward specific countries, like China, which have been flooding the United States with cheap metals. The announcement capped a frenetic and chaotic morning inside the White House as Mr. Trump summoned more than a dozen executives from the steel and aluminum industry to the White House, raising expectations that he would announce his long-promised tariffs. However, the legal review of the trade measure was not yet complete and, as of Thursday morning, White House advisers were still discussing various scenarios for tariff levels and which countries could be included, according to people familiar with the deliberations.\n\nU.S. stock markets slipped around the time Mr. Trump made his comments about tariffs, with declines in the industrial sector outpacing the overall market. The Standard & Poor\u2019s 500 industrial sector was down more than 2 percent, compared to the overall benchmark index which was down a bit less than 1 percent as of around 1:30 p.m. Automakers, large consumers of steel and aluminum, fell sharply. Another large consumer of those materials, aircraft maker Boeing also declined. As the country\u2019s largest exporter, Boeing would also likely be affected by rising global trade tensions if other nations responded to tariffs from the United States.\n\nThe comments also come on the same day as Bill Dudley, president of the New York Federal Reserve, said this about protectionism:\n\n\u201cThere are many approaches to dealing with the costs of globalization, but protectionism is a dead end. Trade restrictions address the symptoms and not the underlying problems, and they introduce other costs and distortions. While such measures might generate a temporary boost to growth from greater domestic production and consumption, these would likely be offset by a range of other costs. Over time, such measures would retard productivity growth and thereby shrink the economic pie.\u201d\n\nStephen Schwarzman had a good 2017.\n\nThe co-founder and chief executive of Blackstone raked in $786.5 million last year, his biggest take-home ever, according to Bloomberg.\n\nHis stake in New York-based Blackstone\u2014and the $661 million in dividends it yielded\u2014fueled much of the payout. The rest came from his cut of deal profits, salary and other compensation, according to the filing. In 2016, Schwarzman got $425 million.\n\nBy comparison\n\n\u2022 Apollo\u2019s Leon Black took home $191.3 million\n\n\u2022 Carlyle co-founders David Rubenstein, Bill Conway and Dan D\u2019Aniello divvied up a combined payout of $193 million.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 KKR\u2019s Henry Kravis and George Roberts received a combined $343 million.\n\nPhoto\n\nPowell: No signs that the economy is overheating.\n\nJerome Powell, the new chairman of the Federal Reserve, said before the Senate Banking Committee:\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t see any strong evidence yet of a decisive move up in wages. We see wages by a couple of measures trending up a little bit, but most of them continuing to grow at two and a half percent. Nothing is suggesting to me that wage inflation is at a point of accelerating. I would expect that some continued strengthening in the labor market can take place without causing inflation.\u201d\n\nContext\n\nMr. Powell said the House Financial Services Committee on Tuesday that the outlook for the United States economy had brightened in recent months. He added that the Fed expected to continue raising rates gradually and could even pick up the pace. The markets seemed to interpret the remarks as signaling the Fed would be more aggressive than expected in raising rates.\n\nBut there was more evidence Thursday morning that inflation may accelerate this year.\n\nHere are the numbers from the Commerce Department:\n\n\u2022 Consumer prices as measured by the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, rose 0.4 percent.\n\n\u2022 That was the biggest increase since September.In the 12 months through January, the PCE price index rose 1.7 percent.\n\n\u2022 So-called core PCE, which excludes food and energy, the PCE advanced 0.3 percent in January \u2014 the largest gain since January 2017.\n\n\u2022 Year-over-year core PCE, the Federal Reserve\u2019s preferred inflation measure, rose at 1.5 percent in January.\n\n\u2022 The core PCE price index has undershot the U.S. central bank\u2019s 2 percent target since mid-2012.\n\nPhoto\n\nSpotify opens its doors to all potential investors\n\nJust as the company isn\u2019t holding a traditional I.P.O., it isn\u2019t holding the usual kind of marketing road show either.\n\nOn March 15, the music streaming giant will \u2014 what else? \u2014 live-stream a presentation for potential investors. Here\u2019s what to expect, from the company\u2019s prospectus:\n\nWe will prepare an electronic presentation for this investor day, which will have content similar to a traditional roadshow presentation, and make one version of the presentation publicly available, without restriction, on a website. There can be no guarantees that the investor day and other investor education meetings will have the same impact on investor education as a traditional \u201croadshow\u201d conducted in connection with an underwritten initial public offering.\n\nSpotify adds that it will hold additional \u201cinvestor education meetings,\u201d which would likely be reserved for the most important investors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile traditional I.P.O.s generally post video versions of their road show presentations on sites like RetailRoadShow, the company looks like it\u2019s trying something different.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nWelcome to the \u201cunicorn\u201d club.\n\nDoorDash, the food delivery startup, raised $535 billion from a group of investors led by SoftBank\u2019s Vision Fund and that included Sequoia Capital and Singapore\u2019s sovereign wealth fund. The amount is almost triple what the company had raised in the last five years, Bloomberg reported and values the company at $1.4 billion.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDoorDash uses a courier model popularized by Uber, meaning that it sends independent contractors to pick up and deliver orders. The company said it has partnered with nearly 90 percent of the top 100 restaurant chains, including Wendy\u2019s, Chick-Fil-A, IHOP, PF Chang\u2019s, the Cheesecake Factory and Five Guys.\n\nPhoto\n\nWalmart joins Dick\u2019s in limiting gun sales\n\nIt was one thing for Dick\u2019s Sporting Goods to set an age requirement for firearms sales. It\u2019s another for the country\u2019s biggest gun seller to do something similar. What each is doing:\n\nWalmart: Raising the minimum age for purchases of guns or ammunition to 21, and eliminating products that look like assault-style rifles. (The company stopped selling AR-15s two years ago.)\n\nDick\u2019s: Requiring buyers to be at least 21 and dropping AR-15s from its 35 Field and Stream outlets.\n\nThe NYT notes that Walmart explicitly linked the new rules to the school shooting in Parkland, Fla. The company said in its statement, \u201cIn light of recent events, we\u2019ve taken an opportunity to review our policy on firearm sales.\u201d\n\nThe gun control debate remains a tricky one to navigate, though more C.E.O.s feel compelled to speak up. Michael Dowling of Northwell Health told the WSJ, \u201cWe are people that other people look up to.\u201d\n\nA caveat: While some capitalist activists are urging big mutual funds to sell stocks in gun companies, Stephen Gandel of Gadfly argues that such divestment campaigns don\u2019t work.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe political context: President Trump made a surprising pitch for tougher gun regulations and urged Republicans to push back against the National Rifle Association. The group called his move \u201cgreat TV\u201d but \u201cbad policy.\u201d\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Meet Martin Gilbert, whose investment fund could help decide whether the satellite broadcaster Sky sells itself to Comcast or Fox. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Bayer is willing to sell more assets to win regulatory approval of its $62.5 billion takeover of Monsanto. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Saudi Arabia\u2019s sovereign wealth fund has invested more than $200 million in Penske Media, the owner of Rolling Stone and Variety, according to an unidentified source. (NYP)\n\n\u2022 The British insurer Equitable Life has hired Goldman Sachs to examine a possible sale. (FT)\n\nPhoto\n\nEnd of an era for Bill Ackman\n\nThe hedge fund mogul finally called quits on his five-year campaign against the supplements company Herbalife, which he called a pyramid scheme and whose stock he once declared would go down to zero.\n\nA look back at the famous short bet, from Matthew Goldstein of the NYT:\n\nIn the annals of Wall Street, investors have lost more on trades. But Mr. Ackman\u2019s bearish bet on Herbalife was a signature event given how much time, effort and money he devoted to making his case \u2014 all in the hopes that the federal authorities would take action against Herbalife.\n\nHerbalife\u2019s shares closed yesterday at $92.10, a record high.\n\nMemories: Herbalife was at the center of Mr. Ackman\u2019s infamous televised debate with Carl Icahn, who was (and still is) betting on the company\u2019s ability to grow.\n\nWhere Mr. Ackman is focused now: United Technologies, the subject of rumors that the conglomerate may break itself up. Brooke Sutherland of Gadfly applauded the back-to-activism-basics bet.\n\nIn other hedge fund news: David Einhorn had a bad month. Viking Global Investors is the latest firm to wade into big-data analytics. The British retailer Whitbread is holding firm against an activist campaign by Sachem Head.\n\nPhoto\n\nCorporate America is happy with Trump, on balance\n\nDavid Rubenstein, the Carlyle Group co-founder, told CNBC at the SuperReturn conference in Berlin that, over all, businesses support the White House\u2019s economic policies:\n\n\u201cI think there are some things the administration has done that the business community will not like, but generally I think the administration has pleased the business community and other people as well.\u201d\n\nWhy? Largely the tax cuts, for which both Republicans and Democrats are compiling data to support their political arguments.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn other economic news: Liu He, Beijing\u2019s top economic adviser, met with American business leaders like Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase and David Solomon of Goldman Sachs amid heightening trade tensions between China and the U.S.\n\nhad a bad month. Viking Global Investors is the latest firm to wade into big-data analytics. The British retailer Whitbread is holding firm against an activist campaign by Sachem Head.\n\nPhoto\n\nIs the S.E.C. cracking down on I.C.O.s?\n\nThe commission has sent subpoenas to people and companies who have arranged initial coin offerings, signaling that tighter regulations may be in the offing.\n\nMore from Jean Eaglesham and Paul Vigna of the WSJ:\n\nThe S.E.C. scrutiny is focused in part on \u201csimple agreements for future tokens,\u201d or SAFTs, which are used in some of the most prominent crypto-fundraisings, according to the people familiar with the matter. The agreements allow big investors and relatively well-off individuals to buy rights to tokens ahead of their sale. The rights can be traded, or flipped for profits, even before the sale begins.\n\nThe virtual currency flyaround\n\n\u2022 How productive is spending money and natural resources on \u2026 buying digital money? (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Could your internet-connected security camera be hijacked to mine virtual currencies? (CNBC)\n\n\u2022 Bitcoin is at $10,666.90 this morning, according to CoinMarketCap.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe financial services flyaround\n\n\u2022 As Brexit looms, not everyone wants Britain\u2019s Serious Fraud Office to be completely successful in cracking down on corporate crime. (Businessweek)\n\n\u2022 A former fraud investigator for Wells Fargo said the bank fired him in retaliation for his internal complaints about mishandled inquiries. (NYT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Bank of America has fired two employees for interfering in an investigation into Omeed Malik, a former executive accused of sexual misconduct, according to unidentified sources. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Will Investors Shrug Off Trump\u2019s Tariffs?: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJames B. Comey\u2019s coming book, \u201cA Higher Loyalty: Truth, Lies, and Leadership,\u201d briefly jumped to No. 1 on Amazon\u2019s best-seller list on Sunday, about a month before its publication date of April 17. The spike in preorders occurred a couple of days after the former F.B.I. deputy director Andrew G. McCabe was fired, prompting a string of tweets by President Trump in which he said Mr. McCabe was a \u201cchoirboy\u201d next to Mr. Comey, whom he called \u201csanctimonious.\u201d\n\nThe early interest in \u201cA Higher Loyalty\u201d is comparable to the advance buzz for \u201cFire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House,\u201d Michael Wolff\u2019s expos\u00e9 of the current administration, which was published earlier this year. Mr. Wolff\u2019s book also hit the top of the Amazon best-seller list before its release, and the publishing house and book sellers were unprepared for the demand.\n\nThere appears to be an enormous appetite for books that give insight into the Trump White House. \u201cFire and Fury\u201d has sold more than a million copies across all formats, and it remains at the top of The New York Times\u2019s hardcover nonfiction best sellers list. It has been on the list for 10 weeks. Similarly, upon its release, \u201cRussian Roulette: The Inside Story of Putin\u2019s War on America and the Election of Donald Trump\u201d by Michael Isikoff and David Corn sold so quickly that Amazon temporarily shut down the buy button on the book\u2019s page, according to Twelve, an imprint of Hachette Book Group and the book\u2019s publisher, likely believing bots were manipulating the sales. It has sold 47,000 copies in its first week, and on Monday evening, it was right behind \u201cA Higher Loyalty\u201d on Amazon\u2019s politics and social sciences best-seller list.\n\nMr. Comey\u2019s book dropped to No. 2 over all on Amazon on Monday, it was replaced with \u201cA Day in the Life of Marlon Bundo,\u201d a parody book commissioned by John Oliver based on a picture book about the Pence family\u2019s real-life rabbit, which was written by Mr. Pence\u2019s daughter. Macmillan, which owns Flatiron Books, declined to comment on preorders but confirmed an initial printing of 450,000.\n\nMr. Comey stoked anticipation for \u201cA Higher Loyalty\u201d by responding to Mr. Trump\u2019s tweets on Sunday. \u201cMr. President, the American people will hear my story very soon. And they can judge for themselves who is honorable and who is not,\u201d he said. In a statement, Macmillan said the book would \u201cexplore what good, ethical leadership looks like.\u201d", "title": "Will James Comey\u2019s Book Be the Next \u2018Fire and Fury\u2019?", "authors": ["Concepci\u00f3n De Le\u00f3n"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "ROME \u2014 It happened in the United States. Then there were the Netherlands, France and Germany. One after the other, the West\u2019s leading democracies have staged national elections in which Russia is accused of using social media and fake news to try to influence the outcome.\n\nNow, Italy is holding pivotal elections on Sunday that could shake Europe \u2014 and Russian meddling is again a concern.\n\n\n\nBut the difference this time is that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia might not even need to bother, because the parties most likely to do well in Italy would probably be favored by Russia, too.\n\nMuch has changed since Russia started its online misinformation campaigns, and much of it is good for Mr. Putin.", "title": "Will Russia Meddle in Italy\u2019s Election? It May Not Have To", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "As President Trump announced sweeping trade tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, raising the specter of a possible trade war, one question has repeatedly come up: Will Americans drink less beer?\n\n\n\nMore than $100 billion in beer is sold in the United States a year, much of it in aluminum cans. And the industry has argued that proposed tariffs, up to 10 percent on aluminum, would amount to an unintended tax. It said people would lose their jobs as a result, and that higher prices for a six-pack could drive beer drinkers elsewhere for their refreshment.\n\nThe Trump administration has said that a flood of metals from other countries pose a threat to national security, and that the tariffs can help bolster domestic industries.\n\nTo help make that point, Wilbur Ross, the commerce secretary, appeared on CNBC on Friday, saying that there would be a minimal impact across industries. He had with him a series of props, including \u2014 what else? \u2014 a can of Budweiser beer.", "title": "Will Trump\u2019s Trade Policy Fit Into a Can of Beer?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Still, the Dow Jones industrial average may open sharply down on Wednesday morning. The markets were rattled in August when there were rumors that Mr. Cohn might resign. And futures markets on Tuesday evening pointed to a lower open.\n\nBut even if there is no plunge, now is a moment for investors to make up their minds about populism.\n\nFor two years, the markets have consistently shrugged off everything from Britain\u2019s departure from the European Union to the election of Mr. Trump to the rise of non-mainstream parties in Europe. Investors could look the other way because global growth was picking up, and Mr. Trump was introducing pro-business policies like tax cuts and deregulation.\n\nBut investors and populists are entwined in a way that is not obvious. Right now, economies are suffering from what could be called \u201cToxic Goldilocks Syndrome.\u201d The stimulus of central banks has delivered moderate economic growth and steady returns for investors that keep them happy. At the same time, though, the central bank\u2019s policies have struggled to solve deeper problems like income inequality and low labor market participation. As these persist, they provide fuel for populist candidates.\n\nWhat could change now?\n\nWith Mr. Cohn leaving, one of Mr. Trump\u2019s policies may end up causing real economic damage. That\u2019s a concern of investors, at least. But then much depends on how the Federal Reserve responds. If, say, Mr. Trump\u2019s tariffs dampened growth this year, the Fed might choose to raise interest rates once, rather than three times, in effect helping investors and the White House.\n\nBut there is a much brighter scenario. Despite the deeper economic problems and the tumult over trade, growth picks up to a level that causes a real bump in wages this year, and Mr. Trump decides to bask in that success, rather than aiming a wrecking ball at the international economic order.\n\nBut who\u2019s around now to make that argument?\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nWhy Cfius is worried about Broadcom\u2019s bid for Qualcomm\n\nCfius said that Broadcom\u2019s proposed deal to acquire rival chip maker Qualcomm could pose a national security risk and called for a full investigation into the hostile bid, according to a letter from a United States Treasury official.\n\nDuring the time between Qualcomm\u2019s unilateral filing and Treasury\u2019s agency filing, Cfius has been communicating with both parties to obtain additional information to inform its decision on the appropriate path forward in regards to this matter. It was during this time, and as a result of these communications and additional information, that Cfius has come to believe that Broadcom\u2019s successful hostile takeover attempt of Qualcomm, including the related stock purchase, proxy contest for the election of six directors to Qualcomm\u2019s Board as proposed and selected by Broadcom, Proposed Agreement and Plan of Merger, and any potential merger between Broadcom and Qualcomm, could pose a risk to the national security of the United States.\n\nThe letter goes on to say:\n\nCfius has identified potential national security concerns that warrant a full investigation of the proposed transaction. Articulation of the potential national security concerns, in significant part, is classified.\n\nThe move complicates an already contentious deal, increasing the likelihood that Broadcom will end its pursuit of Qualcomm. Such investigations are often death knells for corporate deals.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCfius said that the potential risk was related to Broadcom\u2019s relationships with foreign entities.\n\nA spokesman for Broadcom told DealBook in a statement, \u201cwe are fully cooperating with Cfius.\u201d\n\nMichael\u2019s take\n\nThough Cfius stressed the importance of protecting national security, relatively little of the letter focused on explaining traditional matters of national security. Though the document mentioned Broadcom\u2019s \u201crelationships with third party foreign entities,\u201d it does not go into detail about those ties.\n\nThe letter does note that descriptions of national security concerns are largely classified. But it makes no mention of Qualcomm\u2019s publicly disclosed partnerships with Huawei, the Chinese rival long considered closely tied to Beijing, on the 5G standard, either.\n\nWhat Cfius appears capable of describing publicly is concern about how Broadcom might manage Qualcomm after a successful takeover. The government panel describes Broadcom\u2019s potential approach as akin to \u201cprivate equity,\u201d referring to the company\u2019s well-known penchant for cutting costs to help drive profits.\n\nTo the government, that could pose dangers for Qualcomm\u2019s edge in advancing 5G technology. The chip maker is considered, along with Huawei, to be one of the two leading developers of the superfast wireless standard, and any potential disruption to its business could mean ceding an important advantage to the Chinese, Cfius writes.\n\n\u201cWhile the United States remains dominant in the standards-setting space currently, China would likely compete robustly to fill any void left by Qualcomm as a result of this hostile takeover. Given well-known U.S. national security concerns about Huawei and other Chinese telecommunications companies, a shift to Chinese dominance in 5G would have substantial negative national security consequences for the United States.\u201d\n\nCfius\u2019s letter also notes that Qualcomm supplies the United States government with important products, and consults on cybersecurity matters relating to 5G and the internet of things. Any disruption of that work, the panel writes, \u201ccould have a detrimental impact on national security.\u201d\n\nAnother take from a friend of DealBook\n\nHere are tweets by Steven Davidoff Solomon, long known as our colleague the Deal Professor:\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nAluminum industry group opposes Trump tariffs\n\nPresident Trump said that he is thinking of putting tariffs on imported aluminum and steel to protect the domestic metal industries. But in a letter to the White House today, the Aluminum Association said that the move would be a bad idea.\n\nFrom the group\u2019s letter, signed by its C.E.O., Heidi Brock:\n\nWe fear that the proposed tariff may do more harm than good, hurting rather than helping the 97 percent of aluminum industry jobs in mid-and-downstream production processes.\n\nIn the letter, the association says that more narrowly targeted tariffs on Chinese production \u2014 which would be more akin to what previous administrations have done \u2014 and exemptions for trading partners like Canada and the E.U. would be better.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWorth noting: The association\u2019s website says that it represents both U.S. and foreign suppliers.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPolicy flyaround\n\n\u2022 Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin tells lawmakers: \u201cWe are not looking to get into trade wars.\u201d (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Harley-Davidson is bracing for a one-two punch: President Trump\u2019s tariffs on steel and aluminum and threats of retaliation from Europe. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Goldman said President Trump \u201cwould have been better served by targeted tariffs on steel and aluminum instead of the broad, \u201cdraconian\u201d taxes he announced last week.\u201d (CNBC)\n\nPhoto\n\nBlackBerry sues Facebook.\n\nBlackBerry has filed a lawsuit against the social media giant for patent infringement. BlackBerry argues that Facebook and its Whatsapp and Instagram apps copied technology and features from BlackBerry Messenger, Reuters reports.\n\nBlackBerry said in a filing with a Los Angeles federal court.\n\n\u201cDefendants created mobile messaging applications that co-opt BlackBerry\u2019s innovations, using a number of the innovative security, user interface, and functionality enhancing features.\u201d\n\nFacebook Deputy General Counsel Paul Grewal told Reuters:\n\n\u201cBlackBerry\u2019s suit sadly reflects the current state of its messaging business. Having abandoned its efforts to innovate, Blackberry is now looking to tax the innovation of others.\u201d\n\n\u201cBlackBerry is trying to persuade other companies to pay licensing royalties to use its trove of more than 40,000 global patents on technology including operating systems, networking infrastructure, acoustics, messaging, automotive subsystems, cybersecurity and wireless communications,\u201d Reuters reports.\n\nPhoto\n\nAirbnb has named the head of its Homes business.\n\nGreg Greeley, an executive at Amazon, is joining Airbnb as president of Homes. He will oversee the company\u2019s core business, including its newly launched Airbnb Plus and Airbnb Collections programs.\n\n\u201cWords can\u2019t express how excited I am to join the Airbnb team,\u201d Mr. Greeley said. \u201cI\u2019ve used Airbnb for years, and the chance to work here and expand the positive impact its community is having around the world is a once in a lifetime opportunity.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Greeley has spent the past 18 years at Amazon. Most recently, he led Amazon Prime. Before that, he oversaw the launch of businesses in India and Brazil for the e-commerce giant and managed its European consumer businesses.\n\nContext\n\nAirbnb has been reorganizing and building out its executive ranks. Last month, Belinda Johnson, the home-rental company\u2019s chief business affairs and legal officer, was named the chief operating officer, and Laurence Tosi, Airbnb\u2019s chief financial officer, left the company to focus on his investment fund.\n\nBroadcom shows Cfius flexing its muscle\n\nEvery expert that Michael and our colleagues spoke to yesterday acknowledged that the national security panel\u2019s review of Broadcom\u2019s bid for Qualcomm was extraordinary. (One other time Cfius was involved in a contested situation, recalled by Reuters: BHP Billiton\u2019s bid for Rio Tinto in 2008.)\n\nIts move shows Washington\u2019s worries about the selling of U.S. companies to foreign counterparts \u2014 and its willingness to act. From Alan Rappeport, Cecilia Kang and Chad Bray of the NYT:\n\nWith the White House making the case for more government intervention, Cfius is expected to gain more authority. A bipartisan group of lawmakers wants to expand the panel\u2019s scope beyond mergers, giving it the power to review joint ventures and investments in start-ups.\n\nThe deal context: Qualcomm filed for a review of the proxy fight on Jan. 29, before voting on the board contest began. But as of yesterday, Broadcom looked on course to win at least four seats, with a decent chance of six. Big index funds like BlackRock and Vanguard hadn\u2019t voted yet.\n\nBonus explainer: Everything you\u2019d want to know about Cfius.\n\nIn other foreign deals: The Chicago Stock Exchange\u2019s proposed sale to Chinese investors is dead.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat BlackRock and other investors could do about guns\n\nSome institutional investors have talked about divesting their shares in gun makers like American Outdoor Brands and Vista Outdoor. (And some, like the Carlyle Group\u2019s David Rubenstein, say they will never invest in the industry.)\n\nBut, Andrew asks, what if those giants became shareholder activists to change those businesses? From his latest column:\n\nBlackRock has enormous influence over both gun makers and retailers. It could pressure them to raise the minimum age for buying AR-15-style rifles to 25 years old, and impose strict screening and background checks that go far beyond what is required by law. BlackRock could even push gun makers to stop producing such weapons altogether.\n\nThe rub: Any decision has to be anchored by financial logic, since BlackRock and others have fiduciary duties to their own investors. But then gun makers are facing costs from boycotts by both consumers and businesses like REI.\n\nElsewhere in guns: A bipartisan bill would require federal officials to notify state law enforcement within 24 hours if someone fails a national background check. And the dating app Bumble has banned gun-related images from user profiles.\n\nPhoto\n\nCould Trump\u2019s tariffs be defanged?\n\nThough President Trump insisted that the tariffs on all imported aluminum and steel are coming, there are signs that he may soften their impact.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 He left open the possibility that Canada and Mexico could be exempt if they signed a new Nafta pact.\n\n\u2022 Gary Cohn is organizing a meeting with executives from U.S. companies that would be hurt by tariffs, according to Bloomberg.\n\nWho has criticized the tariffs: House Speaker Paul Ryan, Goldman Sachs economists and the consulting firm The Trade Partnership.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Among the proponents is Randal Quarles, the Fed\u2019s vice chair for supervision. Peter Eavis notes one group grateful for the Volcker Rule: investors in banks.\n\nThe foreign bank campaign: Peter Eavis dived into how Deutsche Bank and others are trying to take advantage of a bill that would relax regulations for regional banks. In short: banks with less than $250 billion in assets would enjoy more relaxed rules, and foreign banks \u2014 which oversee less than $250 billion in assets in the U.S. \u2014 want in.\n\nElsewhere in regulations: Don\u2019t expect more disclosure under the S.E.C.\u2019s new cybersecurity rules, according to White Collar Watch.\n\nPhoto\n\nMeet Zagat\u2019s new owner\n\nMichael broke the news yesterday that a nine-year-old reviews site, The Infatuation, had bought Zagat \u2014 the \u201ciconic\u201d and quote-mark-happy restaurant guide built around contributions from readers \u2014 from Google.\n\nWhat is The Infatuation? It was founded by two former music executives and grew by embracing technology: It created the \u201c#EEEEEATS\u201d branded hashtag on Instagram and a texting-based restaurant recommendation service.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe big question: Can even a company that rose to fame with Instagram hashtags keep Zagat relevant amid a slew of younger digital competitors?\n\nPhoto\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Nordstrom rejected its founding family\u2019s latest takeover bid, valued at $8.4 billion. The online giant is talking to big banks like JPMorgan Chase and Capital One Financial about creating checking accounts for customers, unnamed sources told the WSJ.\n\nWhat\u2019s in it for Amazon: access to younger customers and those without bank accounts; lower fees to financial firms; and, of course, more customer data. (Amazon already runs a credit operation for customers in India, where it\u2019s battling powerful local rivals.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat\u2019s in it for the banks: keeping a rival close and being tied to a company that millennials love.\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Now its legal fight with Waymo is over, Uber wants to partner with its erstwhile foe once more, unnamed sources say.
