Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Will the Market\u2019s Gains Follow Cohn Out the Door?: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "There were other challenges. How does Burning Man\u2019s principle of radical participation translate to the \u201clook, don\u2019t touch\u201d propriety of museums? And will the festival learn to speak the institutional language of \u201coutreach and education\u201d?\n\nThose challenges were part of the show\u2019s appeal for both parties. Touching will be encouraged for most works, and outreach is precisely what Burning Man is after. In the process, both cultural institution and countercultural event may re-evaluate their relationships to the mainstream. \u201cThat\u2019s going to be a really cool outcome if the lines get blurred,\u201d said Kim Cook, Burning Man\u2019s director of art and civic engagement. \u201cIf we\u2019re not so far out and the museum isn\u2019t so far in.\u201d\n\nMs. Atkinson, who recently attended her first Burning Man, contrasted that experience with the frenzied marketplace of Art Basel Miami, another annual fair of similar size and duration. In Miami, art is a product; an investment. At Burning Man, art is a manifestation of communal values, like inclusion and participation, that generate playful work emphasizing interaction and feeling over economics.\n\nPhoto\n\nThose qualities make Burning Man art \u201cless attractive in the conventional world of galleries,\u201d Mr. Harvey said. \u201cBut at the same time the great potency of this is that it\u2019s a social movement.\u201d That said, some of the works are acquired after the event by cities or businesses. And Burning Man is eager to help its artists make a living beyond the desert.\n\nThe exhibition includes sculptures, art cars, light installations (including one by Leo Villareal that is part of the Renwick\u2019s permanent collection), virtual reality experiences, jewelry and costume displays, an immersive temple (one of the show\u2019s three commissioned works), and a documented history of the event organized by the Nevada Museum of Art in Reno. The Renwick also teamed up with the Golden Triangle Business Improvement District to extend the exhibition into the neighborhood, where six installations \u2014 among them, a giant bear made of pennies and a bronze head of Maya Angelou \u2014 will inhabit parks and sidewalks.\n\nPhoto\n\nBurning Man has bohemian roots and can be seen as a descendant of Dada, Allan Kaprow\u2019s Happenings and the psychedelic Merry Pranksters. Yet the Renwick is the arm of the Smithsonian dedicated to American craft, and \u201cNo Spectators\u201d celebrates Burning Man as a hub of modern maker culture. The Arts and Crafts movement was born in response to the Industrial Revolution, and Ms. Atkinson suggests that Burning Man art responds to the digital and information revolutions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEach time we take another one of these technological leaps, there needs to be a balancing humanist force that keeps us connected,\u201d she said. The link between Silicon Valley and Burning Man in both proximity and attendance is no accident, she pointed out.\n\nBut what happens when art shaped by utopian principles and intended as a civic gift to a temporary city is uprooted from its native white sands and replanted within white walls across the street from the White House, suddenly subject to the scrutiny of critics, curators and busy tourists?\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis is the heart of the experiment now,\u201d Ms. Cook said. \u201cWhen you move into another context, how much cultural integrity can you maintain and insist upon?\u201d The experiment she refers to is the expansion of Burning Man. In recent years, the organization \u2014 which has dozens of full-time, year-round employees \u2014 has been planning its long-term legacy. In 2011, it shifted from a limited liability company to a nonprofit, consolidating previously independent entities, like the Black Rock Arts Foundation, under one roof.\n\nSince the Bureau of Land Management has capped attendance at the Burning Man event at about 70,000 people, the organization is exploring new ways to spread the gospel. Museums and municipalities are potential apostles. The goal is \u201ca global movement which is not purely event-based anymore,\u201d Ms. Cook said. \u201cIt\u2019s as much about engaged citizenship and quality of interaction as it is about having a function.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBurning Man and the Smithsonian have worked closely together to ensure that values are upheld while institutional needs are met. Admission to the Smithsonian, as always, is free. A licensing agreement lets Burning Man review signage and press materials and set guidelines for merchandising and sponsorship. Nothing with the Burning Man name or logo will be sold in the gift shop; no corporate sponsors are acknowledged near the artwork, though the Renwick\u2019s exhibition is supported by Intel and the Golden Triangle\u2019s by Lyft.\n\nThe Smithsonian is also enlisting local Burners, as the festivalgoers are known, as gallery volunteers to help interpret and enhance the experience. And a docent manual that Burning Man helped develop offers suggestions for promoting deeper encounters in the Burning Man spirit: \u201cThink about facilitating interactions rather than simply sharing information.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s a look at several featured artists and collectives adapting their Burning Man art to the white-walled museum world. Ms. Bertotti noted that the work \u201ctakes on a different preciousness here.\u201d But then, adaptability is a Burning Man virtue.\n\nDavid Best\n\nPhoto\n\nThe first temple that the sculptor David Best contributed to Burning Man, in 2000, was not meant to be a memorial but turned into one when a young artist he worked with was killed in a motorcycle accident weeks before the event. The following year, he was asked to build a temple for Burning Man, which became a place to mourn losses and mark transitions. Burning Man has built a temple every year since, one of its annual traditions. It is ceremoniously burned to conclude the event. \u201cThe fire can heal and seal and protect something,\u201d Mr. Best said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis temples were an impetus for the Renwick\u2019s exhibition. \u201cI don\u2019t know if I would have done this show if I couldn\u2019t have David in it,\u201d Ms. Atkinson said. For \u201cNo Spectators,\u201d Mr. Best and his crew are transforming the second-floor Grand Salon into a sanctuary encased in ornately carved raw wood panels with a central chandelier that descends to meet an altar. \u201cI use beauty as a trap to catch the most pained person,\u201d he said. \u201cIt has to be delicate and strong at the same time.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Best, 72, has made eight temples for Burning Man and several more beyond the desert, notably in 2015 in Londonderry, Northern Ireland. \u201cWhen I turned 60, I said I\u2019m only going to work with people. I stopped showing in galleries,\u201d he said. \u201cWhen I stopped that game, that system of objects for sale, it freed me. I promised myself when I turned 70 I was only going to do priceless work.\u201d\n\nMichael Garlington and Natalia Bertotti", "title": "Will the Spirit of Burning Man Art Survive in Museums?", "authors": ["Brian Schaefer"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt isn\u2019t being twisted in any direction it\u2019s not comfortable with \u2014 it\u2019s just being given wings,\u201d Mr. Porter said in an interview during a rehearsal break in London. (The show opened at the Black Box Theater in Galway, Ireland, on March 16 and later transfers to the O\u2019Reilly Theater in Dublin.) \u201cThe minute I met Enda, I knew this was going to be no problem at all because he just gets it. He\u2019s got this weird combination of playful energy and intellectual seriousness.\u201d\n\nThe book\u2019s rights were snapped up by the esteemed experimental theater company Complicit\u00e9. They approached Mr. Walsh, who instantly thought of Mr. Murphy: the pair have worked together several times since Mr. Walsh\u2019s play \u201cDisco Pigs\u201d in 1996. Mr. Walsh said he had been sure that \u201cGrief Is the Thing With Feathers\u201d would resonate with his friend because Mr. Murphy has two young sons of his own.\n\n\u201cI read it in one go, in the bath,\u201d Mr. Murphy recalled. \u201cIt absolutely floored me emotionally\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Walsh has not rewritten the work; the show uses only words from the text. But that still left the question of how to present Crow onstage. While the production will make heavy use of audiovisual projections, the real solution is as simple as it is theatrical: Mr. Murphy will play both characters, Dad and Crow.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s my understanding of what grief is \u2014 it does feel like your mind and body are possessed,\u201d Mr. Walsh said, before joking that Mr. Porter had been expecting a CGI creature and had instead gotten \u201cCillian in a bathrobe.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not flying Crow in, it\u2019s not a Cirque du Soleil interpretation,\u201d Mr. Murphy said. Yet the character will be a flamboyant, strutting performer, he said, rather than a somber representation of sorrow. He added that he had drawn on diverse sources of inspiration for the role, from Michael Keaton\u2019s character in Tim Burton\u2019s 1988 movie \u201cBeetlejuice\u201d to Dr. Evil in \u201cAustin Powers.\u201d\n\nWatching Mr. Murphy playing the part of Crow in rehearsals, Mr. Porter said he was delighted with the way the actor had physically captured the character. Witnessing Mr. Murphy suddenly switch from the cocky Crow to the grief-soaked father is alarming, he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe audience will think \u2018Oh God, gorgeous Cillian Murphy from \u201cPeaky Blinders\u201d is in a mess, has he lost it?\u2019\u201d Mr. Porter said, referring to the BBC and Netflix show. \u201cAnd to have the control to go there, and then stop exactly on the line: That is exhilarating to watch. I knew he\u2019d be good, but he\u2019s phenomenally good.\u201d\n\nSwitching constantly between the two parts is a challenge. But the father role, at least, feels closer to home. For that character, Mr. Murphy said, he \u201ctried very much to not do anything transformative \u2014 other than growing a mustache.\u201d\n\nThe production will also feature two child actors, whose presence onstage adds a further charge. \u201cI find it on the verge of tear-jerkingly uncomfortable,\u201d Mr. Porter, himself a father of three, confessed.\n\nThat feeling is intensified by Mr. Walsh\u2019s choice to ground the production in a specific, domestic milieu: a fully realized London apartment, complete with bunk beds and period furnishings. The show begins in October 1987, when huge storms hit Britain, wreaking physical destruction outside the apartment that matches the emotional turbulence within.\n\nAlso in 1987, Mr. Porter\u2019s father died. How does it feel to have that event set so precisely, in an apartment that so deliberately recalls the one where he grew up? \u201cReally weird is the honest answer,\u201d Mr. Porter said. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot of emotion in the room: We\u2019re all making this for our children, for our dead mums and dads. And being in this close recreation of my dad\u2019s flat \u2026 I find it really tremendously moving.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Walsh said he felt a heightened sense of responsibility in directing the work \u2014 to Mr. Porter, but also to his audience. \u201cIt\u2019s so emotional; you\u2019re heartbroken in so many parts. And I\u2019ve never really put that out in a theater before,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019ve experienced theater where I feel emotionally exhausted. But at the same time, why be afraid of that \u2014 why not just throw it out into the auditorium? Don\u2019t control it. Just do it.\u201d\n\nSuch emotive material might feel exposing for an actor \u2014 but Mr. Murphy and Mr. Walsh have worked together often enough that the trust is already there. \u201cWe\u2019ve known each other for 22 years; he gave me my first-ever professional part, and changed the course of my life,\u201d said Mr. Murphy, who has not worked with any other theater director in more than a decade.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019ll always be like a little brother to me,\u201d Mr. Walsh said. \u201cWe have a similar sense of humor. We tend to exhaust one another. But he\u2019s got a tremendous energy \u2014 you just hop on his back.\u201d\n\nMr. Porter has no reservations that Mr. Murphy and Mr. Walsh are the right pair to bring his novel to life. \u201cThere is a restlessness about them that is itself Crow-like, endlessly poking around for what\u2019s interesting and beautiful,\u201d he said. \u201cThe worst thing for any adaptation would be to see it being trapped or deadened or held still. But the thing is sort of flapping its wings. I feel like Crow is among his people.\u201d", "title": "Will \u2018Grief Is the Thing With Feathers\u2019 Take Flight on the Stage?", "authors": ["Holly Williams"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "William Alexander Borders was born on Jan. 11, 1939, in St. Louis to William Alexis Borders and the former Kate Thompson. His father was a banker and chairman of Ozark Airlines and, during World War II, the chief of staff to General George S. Patton.\n\nMr. Borders\u2019 marriage in 1967 to Barbara Burkham ended in divorce in 1984. He did not remarry.\n\nBesides his son, he is survived by three grandchildren; his sisters, Carolyn Danforth and Kate Moore; and a brother, John. Another brother, Guy, died in 1975.\n\nHis son, who is known as Will, said his father\u2019s death had been unexpected. He said Mr. Borders had been to the opera on Monday night and to an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting on Tuesday morning and was last heard from, by email, on Tuesday night.\n\nAt Yale, Mr. Borders, an English major, worked on The Yale Daily News and graduated in 1960 with a bachelor of arts degree. He went on to spend his entire professional life at The Times, leaving only for a six-month stint in the Army Reserve.\n\nHe advanced from copy boy to news scriptwriter for the Times\u2019s radio station at the time, WQXR, and then to general assignment reporter before moving on to cover Connecticut.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis first foreign assignment, in 1970, was to Lagos, Nigeria, where he began reporting on the famine in the secessionist state of Biafra during the Nigerian civil war. His initiation, he recalled, was being seized by the Nigerian Army and held captive for two days without food or water.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cSomehow I had been led to believe that the life of a foreign correspondent was a glamorous one \u2014 a lot of sitting around beach cabanas with Kings, Prime Minsters, Agas and other such folk and occasionally cabling New York for money,\u201d Mr. Borders later wrote in Times Talk, an internal newsletter that was later discontinued.\n\n\u201cBut that was before my trip to Biafra,\u201d he added, \u201cand the image now seems very distant.\u201d\n\nHe sometimes doubled as a photographer, especially early in his career in remote places where fresh images were hard to come by.\n\n\u201cThe story gets better display if it has pictures,\u201d he told The Lens blog on nytimes.com in 2009, \u201cand I\u2019d often be in places where there were no other pictures.\u201d\n\nAs a foreign correspondent he covered, among other events, a military coup in Afghanistan, India\u2019s return to democracy and protests in London against nuclear weapons.\n\nHis many articles included one in 1968 on the fierce ideological jockeying between William F. Buckley Jr. and the diplomat Cyrus R. Vance for a seat on the Yale Corporation; another, in 1978, was on the sharp break with modesty in India that catapulted a titillating, or scandalizing, kiss onto the Hindi motion picture screen.\n\n\u201cHe was one of the most considerate and thoughtful people I ever knew on the New York Times staff,\u201d said Craig R. Whitney, a former foreign correspondent and editor who recruited Mr. Borders as his deputy. \u201cHe had a great sense of humor, was appreciative of good writing and did his best to make sure it survived the editing process.\u201d", "title": "William Borders, Former Times Reporter and Editor, Dies at 79", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWilliam H. T. Bush, a wealthy investor and the brother and uncle of presidents, died on Wednesday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 79.\n\nHis nephew Jeb Bush, the former governor of Florida, confirmed the death in an email to The Associated Press on Thursday. He did not give the cause.\n\nKnown as Bucky, Mr. Bush was the brother of President George H. W. Bush, the uncle of President George W. Bush and the youngest son of Sen. Prescott S. Bush of Connecticut, all Republicans.\n\nMr. Bush was also active in Republican politics, heading his nephew\u2019s presidential re-election campaign in Missouri in 2004. At the time, he would recount how he used to babysit the future 43rd president of the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Bush was a co-founder and chairman of Bush O\u2019Donnell Investment Advisers in St. Louis. Before that, he was president of Boatmen\u2019s National Bank of St. Louis.", "title": "William H.T. Bush, Brother and Uncle of Presidents, Dies at 79", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "William Pulte, who built his first house as a teenager and went on to found one of the country\u2019s largest home builders, churning out some 600,000 houses and becoming a billionaire, died on Wednesday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 85.\n\nHis family announced the death.\n\nMr. Pulte was part of a new generation of home builders who got their start when a postwar nation was building miles of new freeways and rings of expanding suburbs.\n\nThese builders dotted the landscape with manufactured subdivisions and made vast fortunes off the growth of the baby boom generation, turning what had once been a mom-and-pop industry into giant corporations that were traded on the New York Stock Exchange.\n\n\u201cBill Pulte\u2019s energy and dedication to home building helped transform the industry and helped more than half a million families across the country find a place to call their own,\u201d the philanthropist Eli Broad, a founder of the Los Angeles-based KB Home and one of Mr. Pulte\u2019s home-building contemporaries, said by email.", "title": "William Pulte, Pathbreaking Home Builder, Is Dead at 85", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Theodore Wilson Harris was born on March 24, 1921, in New Amsterdam, in what was then a British colony. Though the colony had significant poverty, his parents were middle class. His father, Theodore, was an insurer and underwriter. His mother was the former Millicent Glasford.\n\nWilson attended Queen\u2019s College, a prestigious secondary school in Georgetown, in the mid-1930s, then studied surveying, passing the surveying examination in 1942. He then joined a government surveying expedition into the Cuyuni River area in the north of Guyana, toward the border with Venezuela.\n\n\u201cThis expedition was a revelation for me,\u201d he told Bomb Magazine in 2003. \u201cMultitudinous forests I had never seen before, the whisper or sigh of a tree with a tone or rhythm I had never known.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe experience influenced the poetry he would soon begin writing, as well as his first novel, \u201cPalace of the Peacock,\u201d published in 1960, the year after he relocated to England. Rich in symbolism, that book, about a multiracial crew that ventures into the interior of Guyana, is sometimes compared to Joseph Conrad\u2019s \u201cHeart of Darkness.\u201d It was part of a grouping of Mr. Harris\u2019s works that became known as the Guyana Quartet.\n\nMr. Harris wrote 26 novels in all. He is generally included among a group of Caribbean writers (Guyana is often considered a Caribbean country because of its demographics and history) who explored themes of identity, colonialism, myth and more in lyrical, far-ranging prose.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHarris, who is of mixed African, Scottish, Amerindian and possibly East Indian ancestries, and from a region that is a cultural confluence of four continents, is a believer in what he calls \u2018cross-culturality,\u2019 \u201d the literary critic Maya Jaggi wrote of him in 2006. Mr. Harris explained his idea of cross-culturality this way:\n\n\u201cIt means one faction of humanity discovers itself in another; not losing its culture, but deepening itself. One culture gains from another; both sides benefit from opening themselves to a new universe.\u201d\n\nHis novels were sometimes described as difficult, eschewing conventional plotting in favor of multiple narrators, intermingling viewpoints, jumps in time and a free-form prose that demanded concentration of the reader.\n\n\u201cI know that the view of science tends to be that we are all genetically coded,\u201d he told Bomb by way of explaining his approach, \u201cbut I would suggest interior lives that touch nature and make us into living sculptures. Freedom therefore needs to be explored in depths beyond conventional linearities.\u201d\n\nHe maintained that experimental approach even when taking up the poisoning of more than 900 cult members in 1978 at Jonestown, a settlement in Guyana. In \u201cJonestown\u201d (1996) he addressed that horrific incident through a narrator named Francisco Bone, who slides out of reality and wanders across history and cultures as he explores the implications of the real-life event.\n\n\u201cThere is something mechanical,\u201d Kenan Malik wrote in a review in The Independent, \u201cabout the deliberate attempts to push the narrative to the edge of incomprehension \u2014 the story will be \u2018bewildering to the Western mind,\u2019 warns Bone \u2014 which diminishes Harris\u2019s ability to wring meaning from the clashes of times and cultures that he sets up.\u201d\n\nHis other books included \u201cResurrection at Sorrow Hill\u201d (1993), \u201cThe Dark Jester\u201d (2001) and \u201cThe Ghost of Memory\u201d (2006). He was knighted in 2010.\n\nMr. Harris\u2019s wife, Margaret, died in 2010. In addition to his son Nigel, his survivors include three other children, Michael, Alexis and Denise Harris; six grandchildren; and 13 great-grandchildren.\n\nAt a forum in 2014 commemorating Mr. Harris, various speakers took up the question of how best to approach his challenging work. The Caribbean-born poet Ian McDonald described how Mr. Harris would read his early material. Mr. Harris, he said, would get louder and more enthusiastic as he went along, reaching the point where he would start hitting those nearby for emphasis.\n\n\u201cAnd then at the end he\u2019d say, \u2018You see?\u2019 \u201d Mr. McDonald said. \u201cAnd I\u2019d say, \u2018Wilson, I\u2019m not sure I see, but I certainly feel.\u2019 \u201d", "title": "Wilson Harris, Guyanese Writer of Intricate Novels, Dies at 96", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Can you explain just what a recovery drive will do as opposed to a system restore point or a recovery image? How do these features differ from Reset PC? If my Windows 10 Surface Book crashes, which feature do I try first?\n\nA. Microsoft provides a slew of troubleshooting options to aid ailing Windows computers, but choosing which one to try first requires close observation of the situation. Minor glitches may be fixed by rolling back to a previous restore point, but a nonstarting computer might need more assistance.\n\nA system restore point, which Windows automatically creates once a week or before software updates and installations, is a snapshot of the computer\u2019s settings at that moment \u2014 hopefully when things were working well. If you have just installed a program, a driver or a patch and Windows is behaving erratically, it may be a problem with the new software. Reverting to a previous restore point may be enough to get your system functioning properly again.\n\nRecovery drives are USB drives you make that have Windows system files and tools installed on them. You need to create the recovery drive ahead of time, before the computer starts having problems. If Windows cannot start up properly, you can plug in the recovery drive, boot the Surface Book from it and use the tools on it to restore or reset the system.", "title": "Windows 10: When to Restore, Reset or Recover", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Still, \u201cWe\u2019re really forcing the North Koreans to jump through hoops,\u201d said Andrea Berger, a senior research associate and senior program manager at the James Martin Center for Nonproliferation Studies in Monterey, Calif.\n\n\u201cNorth Koreans are literally physically concealing the identity of ships at night and doing ship-to-ship transfers,\u201d she said. \u201cThat\u2019s not something you do unless you have to.\u201d\n\nFinancial Transactions Abroad\n\nNorth Korean firms and individuals, utilizing front companies and working with foreign citizens, have opened bank accounts around the world.\n\nThe report said some of the country\u2019s banks \u201cmaintain a network of overseas representatives who continue to move freely across borders to undertake transactions in multiple countries and to establish residences abroad.\u201d\n\nThe experts found that many banks do not scrutinize account holders closely enough. It cited a \u201cmajor European bank\u201d that failed to verify answers that a representative of the Korea Daesong Bank gave to a questionnaire to screen for money laundering and ignored the fact that the account applicant appeared in a financial-crimes database.\n\n\u2018Destabilizing\u2019 Arms Sales\n\nAs previously reported, the experts contend that North Korea has shipped supplies to the Syrian government that could be used in the production of chemical weapons. The report also detailed sales of ballistic missile systems, multiple rocket launchers and surface-to-air missiles to Myanmar.\n\nThese arms sales are concerning not only because they help the North raise money, but because of \u201cthe inherently destabilizing nature of military cooperation that looks like this,\u201d Ms. Berger said.\n\n", "title": "Wine and Diamonds: How North Korea Dodges Sanctions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 The opening ceremony of the biggest Winter Paralympics yet unfolded Friday night with a glittering performance that championed a world of coexistence where differences are embraced and understood.\n\nIn a spectacle that featured a rhythmic drum dance, projections of fish and animals coming to life and a boat symbolically powered by the equipment used in Paralympic games, a record 567 athletes paraded into the Pyeongchang Olympic Stadium to officially commence the 10-day festival that runs through March 18.\n\nA cheery mood coursed through festivities that lacked the tension of the 2014 Sochi Paralympics, when Ukraine sent only its flag-bearer to the opening ceremony to protest Russia\u2019s intervention in the Crimean Peninsula, or the undertones of the 2016 Rio Paralympics, which were stained by financial turmoil and meager ticket sales.", "title": "Winter Paralympics Open in Cheery Mood", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "(Want to get this briefing by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nGood morning.\n\n\n\nHere\u2019s what you need to know:\n\nTariffs pit Trump against his party\n\n\u2022 The issue of trade has always divided President Trump and establishment Republicans.\n\nMr. Trump says other countries have taken advantage of the U.S., while most Republican leaders say lower trade barriers have helped America build the world\u2019s leading economy.\n\nThe schism was highlighted this week when Mr. Trump said he would impose tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, and as Gary Cohn, the president\u2019s top economic adviser, announced his resignation. We fact-checked some of the president\u2019s statements.", "title": "Winter Storm, Texas, Stormy Daniels: Your Wednesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "JP Morgan announced on Feb. 21 that it would demolish its headquarters on Park Avenue, between 47th and 48th Streets, to build a 1,200-foot-tall skyscraper that, experts say, could cost as much as $4 billion.\n\nIn order to build the new headquarters, which will rise nearly 500 feet higher than its current 700-foot, 52-story building, Chase is buying about 680,000 square feet of air rights from Grand Central\u2019s owners, the executives said.\n\nDevelopers have their eye on at least four other well-known buildings in the district that they could demolish and then employ air rights to make way for new skyscrapers, according to real estate developers and city officials.\n\nThose buildings are the Grand Hyatt New York hotel, next to Grand Central on 42nd Street; the Roosevelt Hotel on 45th Street between Madison and Vanderbilt Avenues; the Pfizer World Headquarters on 42nd Street near Second Avenue; and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority headquarters on Madison Avenue.\n\n\u201cThrough the east Midtown rezoning, Chase\u2019s new headquarters has re-established Midtown as a competitor to Hudson Yards for corporate tenants,\u201d said M. Myers Mermel, chief executive of TenantWise, a real estate advisory firm. \u201cThis marks the beginning a new wave of redevelopment in this area. It\u2019s kind of a surprise it actually worked.\u201d\n\nThe $3.1 billion One Vanderbilt project, a 1,401-foot skyscraper next to Grand Central, is already under construction thanks to a related rezoning and 525,000 square feet of air rights.\n\nTo add four floors atop their modest 16-story building at 405 Park Avenue, the owners \u2014 Deutsche Bank Asset Management and MRP Realty \u2014 have turned to St. Patrick\u2019s Cathedral to buy 30,000 square feet of air rights in a deal that could top $11.5 million, according to records filed with the city\u2019s planning department and local officials.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Chase deals will generate more than $42 million for the city to improve the district\u2019s streets, sidewalks and pedestrian plazas. St. Patrick\u2019s, St. Bart\u2019s and other landmarks will also reap millions of dollars to maintain and preserve their buildings.\n\nMore than six years ago, powerful real estate forces in New York pushed for the rezoning of what is now called Midtown East. They argued that the existing zoning often prevented property owners from replacing an aging set of office buildings with the kind of tall towers that companies were now seeking.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThey also feared that a corporate migration to new oversized towers on the Far West Side would undermine the value of their properties.\n\nIn 2012, the administration of Michael R. Bloomberg began the process of \u201cupzoning\u201d the area around Grand Central to encourage development of the kind of towers now found in London, Shanghai and Hong Kong.\n\nBut local community boards complained that new towers would overwhelm an already crowded district, while the owners of Grand Central, as well as landmarks like St. Patrick\u2019s, successfully sought the right to transfer air rights across a broader swath of Midtown.\n\nAir rights, also called transferable development rights, represent the difference between an existing building and the largest structure permitted under local zoning. Los Angeles and other cities also use air rights in their zoning code, but nowhere in the world are they used as extensively as in New York.\n\nGrand Central, for instance, has more than 1.3 million square feet of air rights, while St. Patrick\u2019s has about 1.2 million. The increasing use of air rights in development in recent years has produced a generation of super towers, like the residential towers along Billionaire\u2019s Row, a stretch of 57th Street known for a $100 million penthouse.\n\nTo build taller under the Midtown East zoning plan, developers have to buy air rights within the district. Anyone selling air rights for projects there have to pay a minimum of $61.49 a square foot, or 20 percent of the sale price of air rights, whichever is greater, to fund either transit or streetside improvements.\n\nReal estate executives complained that the requirement would hobble new construction. But no one expected Chase to suddenly move to tear down its 57-year-old headquarters, even though the bank was clearly looking for a new home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn order to build a tower that would accommodate most of its employees, who are currently spread across multiple buildings on the East Side, the bank eventually went to the owners of Grand Central, TF Cornerstone, a real estate company run by K. Thomas and Fred Elghanayan, and MSD Capital, an investment firm controlled by Michael Dell of Dell Technologies.\n\nThe value of the air rights they control has been hotly debated. Andrew Penson, an investor who has a small stake in the property, has argued in the past that the rights were worth $880 per square foot. But developers and the city said that number was too high for office development. The Real Estate Board of New York argued that air rights were worth between $200 and $325 per square foot.\n\nThe bank, however, has since worked out a deal to buy about 680,000 square feet, for more than $350 per square foot, according to real estate and banking executives. St. Patrick\u2019s is asking $385 a square foot for its air rights.\n\nMr. Dell was well known to Chase, which was the lead bank in his $67 billion acquisition of the tech giant EMC. Jamie Dimon, JP Morgan\u2019s chief executive, personally assured EMC that Dell would have the money for the deal.\n\nMr. Dell and his partners stand to make more than $100 million. They must, however, set aside 5 percent of the proceeds to maintain Grand Central.", "title": "With $240 Million Deal, Floodgates Open for Air Rights in Midtown East", "authors": ["Charles V. Bagli"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The new team unites two of the most virulent opponents of the 2015 Iran deal: Mike Pompeo, the C.I.A. director who was nominated as secretary of state after Mr. Tillerson was unceremoniously fired last week, and Mr. Bolton, a former ambassador to the United Nations who famously declared two decades ago that if 10 stories of the organization\u2019s headquarters disappeared, \u201cit wouldn\u2019t make a bit of difference.\u201d\n\nEven before the announcement on Thursday night that General McMaster was leaving the White House \u2014 following months in which Mr. Trump chafed at his briefings and complained that his national security adviser was \u201cmanaging\u201d him \u2014 it seemed likely that the president would follow his instincts and abandon the Iran deal.\n\nEven the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee, said over the weekend that he expected the president would \u201cmove away from it.\u201d\n\nNow that seems inevitable.\n\nIf so, this new team of hard-liners will be cast, in their first month together, into two of the most volatile nuclear issues of the post-Cold War era. The question is whether, once in office, they will manage America\u2019s allies and adversaries by ultimatum or by diplomacy.\n\nThere is little in Mr. Bolton\u2019s past, or in Mr. Pompeo\u2019s, to indicate they have much time for the give-and-take of the diplomatic process, where to get something the United States also gives something.\n\n\u201cA president who is under political siege and faces at least two extremely sensitive situations in the world has picked the hawkish team that is most likely to turn those into conflicts,\u201d said David Rothkopf, who has written two histories of the National Security Council.\n\n\u201cWe get in trouble when the national security apparatus presents a single view, rather than a range of views,\u201d Mr. Rothkopf said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Interpreter Newsletter Understand the world with sharp insight and commentary on the major news stories of the week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe last time there was this conservative a clique around the president was 15 years ago, when Vice President Dick Cheney and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld pressed President George W. Bush to invade Iraq. At that time, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell played the role that Mr. Mattis plays now: the voice of caution about what happens when unpredictable wars start, and the unanticipated follows.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe anniversary of the beginning of the Iraq invasion was Wednesday. Many who were involved in that decision have since begun to acknowledge the flaws \u2014 not only the reliance on what turned out to be false intelligence, but false assumptions about how quickly peace and prosperity would come to Iraq.\n\nMr. Bolton continues to assert that it was the right decision and was among those who insisted, in the run-up to the war, that Saddam Hussein was on the brink of getting weapons of mass destruction. His initial instinct was to use force.\n\nIn North Korea\u2019s case, there is no debate: The country has conducted six nuclear tests, and has demonstrated that its missiles are within striking distance of American cities. If his argument for pre-emptive strikes was convincing to Mr. Bush, he can make a far more persuasive case to Mr. Trump.\n\nIt is unclear how Mr. Pompeo and Mr. Bolton will jell, or how the dynamic may be changed by another new player in the national security orbit around Mr. Trump: Gina Haspel, his nominee for director of the C.I.A.\n\nHers may be the most difficult nomination to succeed, because of her history overseeing part of the \u201cenhanced interrogation\u201d program after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks and the C.I.A. move to destroy tapes of those interrogations. A career intelligence officer, Ms. Haspel will now be joining the policymakers \u2014 though not in a policy role, if she follows the tradition of offering intelligence assessments rather than recommendations.\n\nMr. Bolton, the third national security adviser in 14 months, is taking over a National Security Council that, a year ago, leaned a lot further to the right.\n\nGeneral McMaster replaced many of the appointees left over from the 24-day tenure of Michael T. Flynn, whose instincts, especially on Iran, hewed closer to Mr. Bolton\u2019s. Mr. Flynn recently pleaded guilty to one count of lying to the F.B.I. about his contacts with Russia\u2019s ambassador to the United States during the presidential transition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNorth Korea and Iran aside, what is fascinating about Mr. Bolton\u2019s selection is that his operating style runs contrary to exactly the kind of national security adviser the Republican establishment has argued that a president who is inexperienced in foreign affairs needs.\n\nThe model, those establishment figures declare, was Brent Scowcroft, the former Air Force general who served Gerald R. Ford and George H. W. Bush. Mr. Scowcroft viewed the job as one designed to bring together views \u2014 and consensus if possible \u2014 to be sure that the president heard a variety of opinions.\n\nGeneral McMaster, a historian, seemed to follow the Scowcroft model a bit closer. He presented the president with a variety of options, often with lengthy explorations about the pros and cons of each. Mr. Trump had no patience for that kind of briefing.\n\nThe president is unlikely to get the same kind of briefings from Mr. Bolton, who in every job he has held has made his own views clear, and sometimes silenced those who disagreed.\n\nIn the coming months, that person could likely be Mr. Mattis, more so than other players left in the mix. The defense secretary has often called war on the Korean Peninsula unthinkable, given the likely casualties. He has told Congress that his advice to the president is to stay in the Iran deal, despite its imperfections, because all the alternatives are worse.\n\nHis may be a lonely view.", "title": "With Bolton, Trump Creates a Hard-Line Foreign Policy Team", "authors": ["David E. Sanger"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. \u2014 After a season in which several high-profile injuries exposed deficiencies in the medical treatment and training of players, the Mets promised an overhaul. Spring training has provided a glimpse of what they meant.\n\nEvery day, players tap an iPad to record their sleeping habits and the color of their urine, to help assess if they are drinking enough water. At the clubhouse buffet, chickpea pasta is in, but chicken fingers are out. And a new job was created to direct the staff members how to coax the best performance out of the players.\n\n\u201cEverything is a work in progress,\u201d said Jim Cavallini, 39, the Mets\u2019 director of performance and sports science, a position new for the team and relatively new across the sport. \u201cWe\u2019re going to look at anything and everything that can make our players better.\u201d\n\nThe Mets are trying to fix the faults of the past. Democrats and gun control advocates accused Republicans and the National Rifle Association of using school safety to divert attention from what they see as the real issue: the proliferation of guns that have been used in mass shootings at concerts, in movie theaters, on college campuses, in churches and at workplaces, as well as at public schools.\n\n\u201cThis time, the gun rights crowd messed with the wrong community, the wrong kids and the wrong dad,\u201d said Fred Guttenberg, whose 14-year-old daughter, Jaime, was killed at the school. Turns to \u2018School Safety\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "In an industry challenged by Airbnb and other home-sharing competitors, hotels are happy to attract local laptop tappers and cocktail crowds to their lobbies. But public popularity risks frustrating guests, who may be forced to retreat to their rooms, leading to an expansion of guest-only areas including meeting spaces, libraries, quiet rooms and bars.\n\nFor hotel operators, these private spaces are similar to the concierge-floor perks, where guests pay a premium for access to a lounge with business facilities and food, but expanded and fee-free.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s similar to when hotels offer a \u2018club level\u2019 lounge, but in this case, the \u2018club\u2019 is open to all guests,\u201d said Henry H. Harteveldt, a travel analyst and the president of Atmosphere Research Group. \u201cBusiness travelers, in particular, enjoy these facilities as they can provide a quiet place to meet, away from the hotel\u2019s public spaces.\u201d\n\nSome also function as private clubs in the Soho House mold, making amenities enjoyed by club members, such as private restaurants and meeting spaces, available to overnight guests.", "title": "With Hotels Becoming Social Spots, More Private Spaces for Guests", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Music directors might spend less than a third of the year with an ensemble but are the center of its marketing campaigns. The San Francisco Symphony is struggling to choose just the right successor to Michael Tilson Thomas, who will retire in 2020, after 25 years; that orchestra\u2019s very existence without him feels, at the least, delicate.\n\nThe centrality afforded to conductors makes them appear indispensable. It inclines institutions to look past obvious problems and try their best to make their relationships with their maestros work, at most any financial or moral cost. (The critic Justin Davidson, writing on the Vulture website, has pointed out a slew of questions regarding the Met\u2019s involvement in Mr. Levine\u2019s case that are left unanswered by the company\u2019s curt statement firing him.) The way some conductors have abused their power \u2014 Charles Dutoit, like Mr. Levine, has recently been felled amid numerous accusations of sexual misconduct \u2014 is a function of being granted so much power in the first place.\n\nPhoto\n\nActivists in any number of fields have lately renewed their calls to topple the patriarchy, but classical music is one of the few remaining areas of human endeavor in which leaders are still encouraged to think of themselves as daddies. When Jaap van Zweden, the incoming music director of the New York Philharmonic, visited The New York Times recently to speak with writers and editors, he referred without apparent irony to his role as \u201cfather\u201d of that orchestra. Mr. N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin\u2019s Twitter biography likewise describes him, abbreviating some of the ensembles he directs, as \u201cFather of Rotterdam Phil, Philadelphia Orchestra, Orchestre M\u00e9tropolitain Mtl\u201d \u2014 and \u201cFuture father of the Met.\u201d\n\nMr. van Zweden and Mr. N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin doubtlessly believe they\u2019re being sweet; they aren\u2019t not. Mr. N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin told The Times a few weeks ago that he is \u201cconsciously breaking\u201d what he called \u201cthis culture of \u2018You can\u2019t say anything to the maestro.\u2019 \u201d\n\nTheir paternal self-conception leaves them well short of Mr. Levine\u2019s or Mr. Dutoit\u2019s trespasses; most fathers, of course, aren\u2019t abusers or even unfair leaders. But in these cases, the two modes \u2014 parent figure and accused abuser \u2014 are sides of the same coin: a male-centered, star-driven structure that saps coffers, repels gender equity and leaves ensembles at a loss when a charmed leader disappears, unexpectedly or not.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe end of this story may well be happier. As classical music and opera slowly, steadily drift from mainstream culture, ticket sales that were once driven purely by the names of beloved music directors have dried up; audiences want experiences, not artists they more likely than not haven\u2019t heard of. The record companies that spent millions on advertising plumping up the celebrity-conductor complex are shadows of their former selves.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile orchestras and opera companies hold tight, for the time being, to the fading magic of the maestro, beloved of aging donors and subscribers, audiences as a whole believe the illusion less and less each year. This demystification will eventually result in a more diverse, more modest pool of leaders.\n\nThere are already examples worth following. The Cleveland Orchestra, perhaps the finest in America, has had its music director, Franz Welser-M\u00f6st, for nearly 20 years now. He\u2019s plainly guided its style and artistic choices, and yet it has stubbornly, inspiringly declined to be defined by him. This orchestra and conductor seem truly like colleagues.\n\nAnd I\u2019ve been thinking a lot, over the past few months, about Alan Gilbert, Mr. van Zweden\u2019s predecessor at the New York Philharmonic, whose up-and-down eight-year tenure ended in June, earlier than he probably would have liked. It causes me some shame, now, to look back on those years; I think I resisted Mr. Gilbert\u2019s performances, his presence \u2014 genial, bookish and curious, and utterly without glamour \u2014 because they didn\u2019t meet my sense of what a conductor was supposed to be. He acted like the Philharmonic\u2019s peer, not its papa.\n\nHe was more of a model than I recognized. The Met shouldn\u2019t want a savior to follow Mr. Levine. It should want a musician.", "title": "With James Levine Fired, Should We Rethink Maestro Worship?", "authors": ["Zachary Woolfe"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Manager Aaron Boone did not want to delve deeply into what the acquisition of Walker could mean, since it was not yet official when he spoke Monday afternoon. But when asked if it was a sign that Torres and Wade were not quite ready, Boone said: \u201cNo. I think that\u2019s reading into it a little too much.\u201d\n\nStill, in the 32-year-old Walker, the Yankees are clearly getting a proven commodity \u2014 they pursued him last season at the non-waiver trade deadline, they had repeated discussions with earlier this winter, and he posted a .801 on-base-plus slugging percentage with the Mets and Milwaukee Brewers around a stint on the disabled list with a hamstring injury.\n\nThough Walker is a switch-hitter, he has been significantly more effective as a left-handed batter \u2014 during his career and last season. He posted a .842 O.P.S. batting left-handed last season (compared to .601 hitting right-handed) and all 13 homers came from the left side. He could also spell Brandon Drury, who has hit left-handers and right-handers at about the same rate, at third base and Greg Bird at first base.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe had a really good player fall into our lap, essentially,\u201d Boone said Monday night, after the Yankees\u2019 2-1 loss to the Minnesota Twins.\n\nWalker, who had been working out recently at a camp for unsigned free agents in nearby Bradenton, Fla., will work out with the Yankees on Tuesday and Wednesday, and could play in a game as early as Thursday against the Pittsburgh Pirates, his hometown team that he came up with.\n\nThe signing of Walker \u2014 at such a discounted rate \u2014 is another sign of the depressed market for free agents this winter. Infielder Kyle Holder was reassigned to minor-league camp.", "title": "With Neil Walker Signing, Yankees Send Message to Youngsters", "authors": ["Billy Witz"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI prefer boutique fairs,\u201d said Primo Marella, director of the Primo Marella Gallery in Milan and Lugano, one of just 17 exhibitors at 1-54. \u201cThey attract fewer collectors, but they are more specific.\u201d\n\nThe Marrakesh fair attracted 4,000 visitors from Thursday through Sunday, according to the organizers, less than a third of the attendance at last year\u2019s London fair. But many were collectors with plenty of money to spend \u2014 ensuring sales.\n\nBy the end of Friday, Mr. Marella said he had sold three textile wall hangings by the Mali-based artist Abdoulaye Konat\u00e9 made specially for the fair. P riced as high as 25,000 euros each, or around $30,000, they went to collectors based in France, Morocco and Portugal.\n\nMr. Konat\u00e9\u2019s enigmatic, politically charged hangings, inspired by local textile traditions, first came to prominence in the much-exhibited Contemporary African Art Collection formed by the Italian businessman Jean Pigozzi. That collection, which still guides many buyers\u2019 incursions into contemporary African art, was formed in 1989 under the guidance of Andr\u00e9 Magnin, a French curator and dealer.\n\nMr. Magnin\u2019s Paris gallery, Magnin-A, was doing brisk business at the fair, selling 10 works by Friday afternoon for prices ranging from \u20ac2,500 to \u20ac22,000, by artists such J.P. Mika from Congo and Amadou Sanogo from Mali. The latter\u2019s wry 2017 canvas, \u201cUntitled,\u201d showing a headless figure holding a paddle, sold for \u20ac16,000.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs these price points suggest, African contemporary art tends to be more reasonably priced than equivalent works by American or European artists.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTunji Akintokun, an I.T. executive based in London, described African contemporary art as \u201cunderestimated and undervalued.\u201d He flew to Marrakesh for the fair, attracted by its North African emphasis.\n\n\u201cMost of my collection is sub-Saharan,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was an opportunity to be educated, but also to look at the potential to buy.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Akintokun said that he was negotiating to purchase two North African works for his collection, but he declined to name the artists.\n\nMr. Akintokum might have been looking, for example, at photographs by the Moroccan artist Walid Layadi-Marfouk, 22, who is based in New York. The London gallery Tiwani sold one of his photographs \u2014 of his aunt in his great-grandfather\u2019s ancestral mansion in Marrakesh \u2014 for $5,000. Others were included in a survey show of works by 40 photographers, \u201cAfrica Is No Island,\u201d at the contemporary art museum.\n\nOver 9,700 square feet of exhibition space over two floors, the museum presents the most comprehensive overview of how North African artists are responding to our times by showcasing works from the 2,000-piece collection of Alami and Othman Lazraq. Many of the artists are from Morocco. For several, plastic garbage has become the medium \u2014 and the message \u2014 of the moment.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Marrakech-based collective Zbel Manifesto, comprising Ghizlane Sahli, Katia Sahli and Othman Zine, has used \u201cdaily life garbage\u201d to create an entire dining room, complete with formal place settings for the exhibition \u201cSecond Life\u201d on the museum\u2019s upper floor. Titled \u201cUn d\u00eener en ville,\u201d or \u201cA Dinner in Town,\u201d the immersive installation is a lurid allegory of consumer excess.\n\nThe Casablanca-based artist Soukaina Aziz El Idrissi, on the other hand, takes the ugliness of plastic waste, then heats and weaves it into translucent hangings that lyrically reimagine the carpets and textiles for sale in Morocco\u2019s souks.\n\n\u201cIn Morocco, carpets were art, until Westerners came in and said they weren\u2019t,\u201d said Ms. Aziz El Idrissi, 30, who trained at Central St. Martins college, the London art and design college. Her installation of hangings, \u201cCalibrated Compositions III,\u201d is on display on the second floor. \u201cWe have too much plastic,\u201d said Ms. Idrissi, who in 2016 made a maze out of 17 tons of polyethylene bottles in Marrakesh to coincide with the COP22 climate change conference. \u201cLet\u2019s stop.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s easy enough see the disconnect between internationally minded contemporary art shown in luxury hotels and millionaires\u2019 private museums and the lives being lived in the surrounding communities. The opening last fall of the grandiose Zeitz Museum of Contemporary Art Africa in Cape Town \u2014 hailed as Africa\u2019s answer to Tate Modern \u2014 also drew attention to this issue.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Othman Lazraq, the Moroccan collector who is president of his own museum, is eager to connect with Moroccans and, possibly, to inspire more of them to become artists. The museum runs an active program of artists\u2019 workshops, talks and screenings for schools and universities. It has also started \u201cLa Chambre Claire,\u201d a biannual photography prize for emerging African artists.\n\n\u201cPhotography is the medium of my generation. It\u2019s the easiest way to see things clearly.\u201d Mr. Lazraq said, adding that he wanted his museum give African artists \u201ca platform to be proud of their roots.\u201d\n\nBut gaining wider recognition remains a challenge for African artists. Encouraging international visitors to look at their art in Africa can only help that process.", "title": "With New Museum and Fair, Marrakesh Joins the Art World Map", "authors": ["Scott Reyburn"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s kind of a handy little thing,\u201d said Cindy Hockenberry, director of tax research and government relations with the National Association of Tax Professionals. Ms. Hockenberry said she had tried the tool and found it \u201cpretty accurate\u201d for her situation.\n\nPeople who were getting a significant refund before the tax law changes should consider whether they could end up with an even larger one if they don\u2019t revise their paycheck withholdings, she said. The I.R.S. says the average refund last year was just over $2,800.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s a good chunk of money,\u201d Ms. Hockenberry said. Many people might prefer to reduce their tax withholdings, she said, and take home more cash in their paycheck for living expenses.\n\nThe I.R.S. advises that people with particularly complex tax situations \u2014 including those owing self-employment tax or the alternative minimum tax, or those who have capital gains and dividends \u2014 may need to consult Publication 505, Tax Withholding and Estimated Tax, to check their withholdings instead of using the online calculator. The publication is expected to be updated in \u201cearly spring,\u201d the I.R.S. said.\n\nIt may be wise, Mr. Walters said, for those taxpayers to consult a tax professional to make sure they are on track with proper withholdings.\n\nHere are some questions and answers about checking your paycheck withholdings:\n\nWhat documents do I need to use the I.R.S. withholding calculator?\n\nBefore you start, have handy a copy of your current pay stub and your most recent federal income tax return \u2014 ideally, your 2017 return, the I.R.S. says. That will help you answer the questions. The calculator asks questions like how often you receive paychecks, how much has been withheld in taxes already this year and whether you contribute to a 401(k) plan. (You don\u2019t have to enter your name or other personally identifiable information to use the tool, and the I.R.S. says it doesn\u2019t save the information entered on the calculator.)\n\nHow do I make changes to my paycheck withholding?\n\nFill out a new I.R.S. Form W-4, using data provided by the calculator, and give it to your payroll office or human resources department.", "title": "With New Tax Law, I.R.S. Urges Taxpayers to Review Withholdings", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "If Qualcomm and Apple can just bury the hatchet, Mr. Dodson reasons, Qualcomm\u2019s revenues would soar, and its stock price would climb well past Broadcom\u2019s offering price of $79 a share. By Mr. Dodson\u2019s reckoning, once Apple resumes paying Qualcomm, the chip maker will be worth at least $84 a share, \u201cwhich is why Broadcom\u2019s offer didn\u2019t really engage my attention,\u201d he said.\n\nThat, however, is a big \u201cif,\u201d given the intractable positions both sides have staked out.\n\nAt the heart of the dispute is the way Qualcomm calculates the licensing fee it charges customers, which is a percentage of the cost of the net selling price of the entire handset \u2014 and not the price of the chip. That means that Apple, a high-cost producer whose iPhone X sells for as much as $1,000, has paid much higher licensing fees than low-cost competitors using exactly the same chip set.\n\nApple has called the arrangement an \u201cextortion scheme.\u201d It infuriates Apple that Qualcomm has, in effect, been subsidizing its low-cost competitors, including the very Chinese companies that Mr. Trump says he is so concerned about.\n\nQualcomm has countered that its intellectual property makes many of the iPhones\u2019 distinctive features possible, features that low-cost competitors haven\u2019t replicated, and therefore Qualcomm deserves a percentage of the cost of the entire device.\n\nMr. Dodson made little immediate headway when he met with a delegation of top Qualcomm officials late last month and pressed his case for a settlement with Apple. The officials, including the chief executive, Steve Mollenkopf, and Paul Jacobs, a Qualcomm founder and, until recently, executive chairman, visited Mr. Dodson in San Francisco to make their case against the Broadcom bid.\n\nIn Mr. Dodson\u2019s account of the meeting, he urged the Qualcomm executives to settle with Apple rather than risk alienating it as a customer over the long term. But Qualcomm officials said that Apple was demanding more than they were prepared to give and that, on an engineering level, relations with Apple remained good. They assured him that eventually they would reach a settlement, revenues would normalize and Qualcomm stock would respond.\n\nStill, \u201cI\u2019d like to see them budge\u201d on the licensing issue, Mr. Dodson said. \u201cI can see Apple\u2019s point.\u201d", "title": "With One Battle Over, a Bigger One Looms for Qualcomm: Apple", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "He said that he really wanted to meet Mr. Kim and improve ties, but that there was a limit to how far he could go without progress in dismantling the North\u2019s nuclear program. He urged North Korea to talk to the Americans and said they needed to hurry so as not to lose the rare momentum from the spirit of the Olympics visits.\n\nA Family Envoy\n\nAfter the unfortunate optics from Mr. Pence\u2019s visit and what some viewed as a missed opportunity, Mr. Trump sent his daughter, Ivanka Trump, to the closing ceremony of the Games. She had dinner with Mr. Moon at the Blue House and briefed him on new sanctions her father would impose on North Korea, then made a public statement to reporters reaffirming the American strategy of \u201cmaximum pressure.\u201d\n\nShe then headed to Pyeongchang for the last two days of competition. Briefed by Mr. Pence\u2019s staff, Ms. Trump and her team were \u201cincredibly forceful,\u201d as one official put it, in going over the seating plan for the box and the timing and sequencing of arrivals to avoid any surprises.\n\nMs. Trump proffered a smiling, more open image that went over better in South Korea. She stood for the South Korean athletes, who this time entered the stadium separately from their compatriots from the North, and posed for photographs with famous Korean pop stars. But she too made a point of sending a message; for her guest in the box, she brought Gen. Vincent K. Brooks, commander of American forces in South Korea.\n\nWhen she attended a curling event, Ms. Trump\u2019s team received word that the North Koreans were on their way in what the Americans thought was an effort to make a scene or prompt her to leave in an embarrassing spectacle. Ms. Trump decided to stay, and the North Koreans in the end did not come.\n\nAll Smiles in the North\n\nWith the Olympics over, it was time for Mr. Moon to make his move. Last week, he sent two trusted aides on a two-day trip to Pyongyang: Mr. Chung, his national security adviser, and Suh Hoon, his National Intelligence Service director. Flying north, they knew that they were meeting Mr. Kim but not when.\n\nAfter landing in Pyongyang, they were taken to a riverside guesthouse where they found their rooms equipped with the internet and access to foreign television channels, including CNN. They could even surf South Korean websites, a rare privilege in the totalitarian state. As soon as they unpacked, Kim Yong-chol, a general who heads inter-Korean relations, showed up and said that they were meeting Mr. Kim that evening.", "title": "With Snap \u2018Yes\u2019 in Oval Office, Trump Gambles on North Korea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNow more than ever, the easiest answer to that pesky question \u2014 what\u2019s keeping jazz vital these days? \u2014 appears to lie in London. And much of the serious activity there runs through Shabaka Hutchings. The 33-year-old tenor saxophonist anchors a handful of his own bands and served as the musical director for \u201cWe Out Here,\u201d a Brownswood Recordings compilation with tracks from nine British groups, like a book of hours for the thriving young scene.\n\nIn January Mr. Hutchings announced that he had signed with Impulse!, an imprint of Universal, and that the label would be releasing music from his various ensembles. The first to arrive is \u201cYour Queen Is a Reptile,\u201d the third album by his quartet, Sons of Kemet, and it\u2019s an excellent place to start.\n\nThis band has a rare instrumentation \u2014 tenor saxophone, tuba, two drummers \u2014 and a relentless, jouncing sound anchored in rhythms of the Caribbean. His two other major projects are Shabaka and the Ancestors, a collaboration with young South African musicians that has a forbearing, serious mission, and the Comet Is Coming, an astro-futurist trio influenced by electronic dance music. Sons of Kemet\u2019s sound falls somewhere right between those two: It\u2019s acoustic music, but adamant and dance-driven.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe new album\u2019s title takes a shot at the British monarchy, a system that, Mr. Hutchings says, reaffirms the notion that one\u2019s birthright is enough to define class and status. He wrote each of the album\u2019s nine tunes for an alternate matriarch from the African diaspora. Their titles all have the same construction: \u201cMy Queen Is Harriet Tubman;\u201d \u201cMy Queen Is Yaa Asantewaa,\u201d for an early-20th-century Ashanti ruler; \u201cMy Queen Is Ada Eastman,\u201d for Mr. Hutchings\u2019s Barbadian great-grandmother; and so on. On some tunes the band is joined by an M.C. or a poet, spinning verses of defiance and affirmation.\n\nSons of Kemet\u2019s music reaches vastly across the diaspora, though it has increasingly gravitated toward the Antilles. The band\u2019s 2013 debut, \u201cBurn,\u201d was a restive, rangy album, stretching from slow deliquescence to scorching surrealism. Its sophomore release, \u201cLest We Forget What We Came Here to Do,\u201d pulled toward calypso and soca, toward the earth, toward a more direct energy, thanks to Mr. Hutchings\u2019s growing embrace of his own upbringing \u2014 he moved to Barbados at 6 and returned to London in high school \u2014 and to the impact of Theon Cross, a prodigious young talent who took over on tuba just before \u201cLest We Forget\u201d was recorded. His playing centers on heavy oscillations between the strong and weak beats, and never lets up on a groove.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn \u201cYour Queen Is a Reptile,\u201d the interplay between Mr. Hutchings and Mr. Cross immediately calls you to attention, but as songs progress your focus drifts to the twin drummers \u2014 Tom Skinner and Seb Rochford \u2014 as they start to shift the flow from beneath. (Mr. Rochford left the group soon after recording this album, and was replaced by Eddie Hick.) It happens on \u201cMy Queen Is Ada Eastman,\u201d the opening track: Mr. Hutchings finishes the song\u2019s melody and Mr. Cross hops up an octave to join him in unison for a brief coda. Your ear catches a spark between the drummers, and you realize they\u2019ve been sparring all along, their patterns making a big shared gesture, a half-circle, a contested zone.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Spectacular in last Saturday\u2019s trouncing of Ohio State, Hachimura, a sophomore who took up basketball at age 13, could become the second native of Japan to play in the N.B.A. (Yuta Tabuse, the first, logged all of four minutes with Phoenix.)\n\nHachimura, in his second start, accounted for 5 consecutive \u2014 and timely \u2014 points, interrupting an 11-0 run that had vaulted Florida State ahead by 16-6.\n\nBut few teams in the tournament are deeper than F.S.U., which mixes and matches 10 players. Eight of those 10 scored within the first nine minutes as the Seminoles built their lead back to 23-11. From there, F.S.U. shredded the Zags\u2019 press and finished on a roll.\n\nAfterward, Mann declared himself fully fit and did not seem impressed by his accumulation of dunks. \u201cI\u2019m sure I\u2019ve had more in a game before,\u201d he said.\n\nHis coach, Leonard Hamilton, credited the team\u2019s medical staff with Mann\u2019s preparation.\n\n\u201cWe were going to hold him out if necessary,\u201d Hamilton said. \u201cThe treatment he got obviously promoted the healing process.\u201d\n\nF.S.U. promotes its depth with T-shirts that say \u201c18 strong,\u201d a reference to the number of players on the roster.
