But it was not enough as his fellow starters missed 30 of 43 field-goal tries, and saw their tournament run come to an end.", "title": "With Terance Mann Healthy, Florida State Rolls Over Gonzaga", "authors": ["Mike Tierney"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 Diplomacy between the United States and North Korea has gone through familiar cycles of long stagnation, followed by brief bursts of hope and then inevitable disappointment, typically after North Korea reneged. President Trump\u2019s three predecessors each went through the cycle.\n\nIn October 1994, Bill Clinton concluded what was perhaps the most ambitious nuclear agreement ever reached between Washington and Pyongyang \u2014 called, appropriately, the Agreed Framework.\n\nUnder the deal, North Korea agreed to halt construction of two nuclear reactors that the United States believed would be used to produce fuel for a nuclear bomb. In return, the White House pledged to give North Korea two alternative nuclear power reactors that could not be used in a weapons program \u2014 as well as fuel to tide it over before the new reactors were ready.\n\nThe agreement headed off a threat by North Korea to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, and eased what had been one of the tensest periods on the Korean Peninsula since the armistice that ended the Korean War.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Clinton administration tried to expand the scope of the Agreed Framework after North Korea began testing ballistic missiles in 1998. That effort culminated with a trip to Pyongyang by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright in 2000, and what another American official, Wendy Sherman, later wrote were negotiations that came \u201ctantalizingly close\u201d to a broader agreement.", "title": "With U.S. and North Korea, a Repeated History of Hope and Disappointment", "authors": ["Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Jeff Levy knocked gently on an apartment door on the Lower East Side of Manhattan on Tuesday afternoon.\n\n\u201cI knock lightly because dogs can get upset if you knock loud, or with a cat, it might run under the bed,\u201d said Dr. Levy, a veterinarian who specializes in acupuncture, exclusively by house call.\n\nThis house call was for Harpo, a 10-year-old toy fox terrier with a liver tumor that was diagnosed a year ago as terminal and untreatable.\n\n\u201cThey told me to just keep him happy for his last couple of months,\u201d said Harpo\u2019s owner, Jess Caragliano, 36, who heard that Dr. Levy, 61, could help provide palliative care during Harpo\u2019s last few weeks.", "title": "With a MetroCard and Needles, a Vet Makes House Calls", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "By ending their primaries against the two senators, Mr. McDaniel and Mr. Tarkanian snuffed out what was left of Mr. Bannon\u2019s vision for remaking Congress with candidates in his populist mold. At one time, Mr. Bannon envisioned primaries in Mississippi, Nebraska, Arizona, Wyoming and Nevada.\n\nNow he has none.\n\nWith Mr. Bannon exiled by the president and Mr. Trump getting along with congressional leaders and taking counsel from largely mainstream Republicans in the post-Bannon White House, there is little political space for right-wing insurgents to oust incumbents.\n\nPerhaps no one is happier about that than Mr. McConnell, whom Mr. Bannon had once threatened to unseat. Chris Pack, the spokesman for the Senate Leadership Fund, a political action committee that Mr. McConnell helped found to ensure the re-election of incumbents, was succinct on Friday.\n\n\u201cWho is Steve Bannon?\u201d Mr. Pack asked wryly.\n\nMr. Bannon declined to comment.\n\nDemocrats said on Friday that the dynamics of the Nevada race had not changed much, and that they remained optimistic about their chances to pick up a Senate seat in a state won by Hillary Clinton. Mr. Tarkanian, party strategists said, has already caused lasting damage to Mr. Heller by forcing him into positions he will later regret in his campaign against Representative Jacky Rosen, the Democrat whose seat Mr. Tarkanian is now seeking. (Mr. Tarkanian lost to Ms. Rosen by about one percentage point in 2016.)\n\nLast year, for instance, Mr. Heller agonized for weeks over Republicans\u2019 drive to repeal the Affordable Care Act, before finally siding with party leadership and voting to undo President Barack Obama\u2019s signature health care law. Mr. Tarkanian pounced, accusing Mr. Heller of having \u201cno convictions.\u201d And Democrats are still reminding the senator of that vote.\n\n\u201cNevadans learned today what Senator Heller got for selling out their health care and putting himself and his party first,\u201d Lauren Passalacqua, spokeswoman for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, said on Friday, adding that \u201cno amount of Trump tweets\u201d could save him.\n\nWhile Mr. Trump is often described as the ultimate insurgent, he is driven far more by personal interaction and whether he feels respected than by any ideological impulses. Mr. Wicker and Mr. Heller have spent months courting the president and taking care to note, publicly and privately, that they are in his corner.", "title": "With a Nevada Senate Candidate\u2019s Exit, the Bannon Revolt Fizzles", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "King Cyrus, who is credited with allowing Jews to return to Jerusalem from exile in the Babylonian empire, represents the possibility that a nonbelieving leader and state could be used by God to reunite the chosen people and the promised land.\n\nThe prominence of the Cyrus trope has revived fears about religious influences on United States foreign policy that have swirled around Republican presidents for decades. Ronald Reagan and George W. Bush were both accused of allowing their policies toward Israel to be influenced by interpretations of the Book of Revelation that foresee a literal Battle of Armageddon.\n\nAnd encouraging presidents to take up the mantle of Cyrus is also something of an American tradition. The Chicago-based preacher William Eugene Blackstone \u2014 who described himself as God\u2019s \u201cerrand boy\u201d \u2014 visited the White House in 1891 to present President Benjamin Harrison with a petition. It called on him to use his influence to extract Palestine from the Ottoman Empire and promote a Jewish state. The petition was signed by 413 prominent citizens, including the Supreme Court\u2019s chief justice, Melville Fuller; the future president William McKinley; and the tycoons J. P. Morgan and John D. Rockefeller. Its cover letter explicitly compared the president to Cyrus, offering him a \u201cprivileged opportunity\u201d to serve as patron of the Jewish people. For this service, five years before the publication of Theodor Herzl\u2019s \u201cDer Judenstaat,\u201d Louis Brandeis reportedly described Blackstone as the real \u201cfather of Zionism.\u201d\n\nHarrison was not even the first president to be imagined as a potential successor to Cyrus. In the 1790s, the New Jersey minister David Austin suggested that the United States under John Adams might help assist the world\u2019s Jews in returning to Palestine. Austin went so far as to purchase ships and warehouses that could be used for this purpose.\n\nAustin\u2019s practical efforts for the cause were unusual. But a fellow resident of Elizabeth, N.J., Elias Boudinot, an aide to George Washington who served as president of the Continental Congress, director of the United States Mint and other important posts, wrote several books urging the new republic to act as patron to the Jews and assist in their return to the territory God promised to Abraham. In a book published in 1816, Boudinot wrote, \u201cWho knows but God has raised up these United States, in these latter days, for the very purpose of accomplishing his will in bringing his beloved people to their own land.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | With the Embassy Move to Jerusalem, a Biblical Trump?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Josh Radnor stood backstage in a Brooklyn auditorium. Breathing: audible. Expression: agonized. \u201cPlease let this not suck,\u201d he whispered.\n\nMr. Radnor, best known as the I in \u201cHow I Met Your Mother,\u201d was in character on this late December day as Lou Mazzuchelli, or Mr. Mazzu, the high school drama teacher at the center of \u201cRise,\u201d the midseason NBC show that debuts on March 13. Based on \u201cDrama High,\u201d Michael Sokolove\u2019s 2013 nonfiction book about the visionary Levittown, Pa., teacher Lou Volpe, the first 10-episode season follows the permanently rumpled Lou from the moment he lands the drama job, beating out Rosie Perez\u2019s better-qualified fellow teacher, to the opening night of his first musical: \u201cSpring Awakening.\u201d\n\nAnother man might have started out with something easier, perhaps a \u201cBye Bye Birdie\u201d or a \u201cSeussical.\u201d Not Lou. \u201cWhich part did you like best?\u201d Ms. Perez\u2019s Tracey Wolfe asks bitingly. \u201cThe abortion, the teen suicide or the incest?\u201d This goes a long way to explaining Lou\u2019s backstage prayer.\n\nGiven the high school setting, the ing\u00e9nue cast and some show tunes, you\u2019re forgiven for thinking that \u201cRise\u201d sounds a lot like \u201cGlee,\u201d the Ryan Murphy glitterbomb about a show choir that ran on Fox from 2009 to 2015. The showrunner of \u201cRise,\u201d Jason Katims (\u201cFriday Night Lights,\u201d \u201cParenthood\u201d) likes \u201cGlee.\u201d He likes \u201cHigh School Musical.\u201d He wanted to do something different.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe mantra is to always keep it as realistic and honest as possible,\u201d he said, speaking in his office above the Greenpoint soundstage where \u201cRise\u201d shoots its interiors. So is \u201cRise\u201d kin to \u201cFriday Night Lights,\u201d another show initially based on a sociological deep dive, with rehearsals in place of football practices, performances standing in for championships? \u201cThat\u2019s fair,\u201d Mr. Katims said.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cRise\u201d began when the theater producer Jeffrey Seller (\u201cHamilton\u201d), now making his first foray into series TV, read an excerpt from \u201cDrama High\u201d in The New York Times Magazine in 2013. He bought the book. It made him cry. But the rights had already been sold. A few years later, when he\u2019d joined up with the veteran producer Flody Suarez (\u201c8 Simple Rules,\u201d \u201cThe Tick\u201d), he learned that those rights were again available. \u201cI handed Flody the book and I said, \u2018This is what I want to make into a TV show,\u2019\u201d Mr. Seller recalled.", "title": "With \u2018Rise,\u2019 a \u2018Friday Night Lights\u2019 for Theater Kids", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "I think we all have to ask ourselves if there are people who have nothing else to do but push against our liberal society, who is actually defending it if we are not. If you feel an urgency and you don\u2019t act upon it, then that is the whole problem in a nutshell.\n\nIn 2016, you produced a series of posters to campaign for Britain to remain in the European Union, ahead of the referendum here. What is your view on what has happened since?\n\nThe reason I felt such urgency to rebel against Brexit has, of course, to do with my 28 years living in England and Germany, but also because I really predicted at the time that it will be all about language. It will turn into an ugly blame game, and when the promises of a glorious post-Brexit future do not turn out right, no one will say \u201cWell, maybe we got it wrong.\u201d\n\nEven though I\u2019m not campaigning in the U.K. anymore, I really think anything that could stop Brexit is a good thing. Even though it would be seen as anti-democratic, I think the pain and the antagonism in language and the sentiments of this divorce is more harmful.\n\nWhat were you most surprised by when putting together this collection?\n\nI learned how, for the last 50 years or so in the Western world, authoritarian people have been kept widely at bay. They have had to accept feminist, nonracist and L.G.B.T. progress, social justice, international cooperation and anti-nationalism. They had to accept all of that, and things in society changed for the better so dramatically because individuals believed in it and spoke up for it. So one should see it this way around: Trump being in power and Brexit succeeding is not the reason for despair, but it is really a backlash to 50 years of civil rights and liberal progress.\n\nWhat conversations do you hope the work will provoke?", "title": "Wolfgang Tillmans Explores the Role of Art in a Post-Truth World", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 If Vicki Momberg had only unleashed a high-volume tirade at the South African police officers, video of it would have been of mere passing interest. But her repeated use of a racial slur \u2014 unfamiliar to most Americans, but explosive in South Africa \u2014 made her notorious, and led to demands to make her an example.\n\nOn Wednesday, Ms. Momberg, a white woman, became the first person in South Africa to be sent to prison for using racist language against someone, according to prosecutors and legal experts. Specifically, she hurled the term \u201ckaffir,\u201d considered the most offensive racial slur in South Africa \u2014 so radioactive socially that it is often referred to as \u201cthe k-word.\u201d\n\nThe 2016 viral video of her outburst at police officers who responded to her report of thieves breaking into her car set off a national furor, and made Ms. Momberg a symbol of the racism that persists a generation after the collapse of apartheid.\n\nPartly because of that video, viewed repeatedly on social media and news sites, the parliament may take up a bill that would make prosecution for hate speech more common.", "title": "Woman Becomes First South African Imprisoned for Racist Speech", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Two women were arrested on Thursday after they recorded a video while taking things from a mosque in Arizona and insulting Islam, which the police said might be considered hate speech.\n\nIn the video, which was posted to Facebook on March 4 and shared by several accounts, the women, identified by the police as Tahnee Gonzales, 32, and Elizabeth Dauenhauer, 51, can be seen bringing three children to the Islamic Community Center in Tempe, Ariz., near Phoenix.\n\n\u201cLook at this mosque, this ugly mosque, here in our backyard in America,\u201d Ms. Gonzales said in the video, adding, \u201cThis is the infiltration of the Arabic Muslim coming in and destroying America.\u201d\n\nThe women can be seen opening an unlocked gate with a \u201cNo Trespassing\u201d sign on it, entering a courtyard, collecting pamphlets, removing items from a bulletin board and encouraging the children to do the same.", "title": "Women Arrested After Trespassing at Arizona Mosque and Mocking Islam", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "They also receive relatively little attention: National elections are Sunday, but the issues that Italian women struggle with every day \u2014 like employment support, child care and equal pay \u2014 rarely enter the national political discussion.\n\nMs. Roncetti and others like her say they might as well be invisible, even though many of the election\u2019s undecided voters are women \u2014 and their votes could be critical.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis campaign is a perfect mirror image,\u201d said Ms. Roncetti, who now cares for her two daughters and works as a freelancer. \u201cPoliticians ignore our daily lives.\u201d\n\nItaly has the second-lowest female employment rate in the European Union, according to Eurostat, ahead of only Greece. One in four Italian women do not return to work after giving birth. Those who keep working often see earnings drop more than 35 percent, according to INPS, Italy\u2019s social security institute, mostly because mothers have to reduce working hours since child care and other support is so limited.\n\nOther than Greece, Italy also has the lowest percentage of working mothers in the European Union. In Germany, 75 percent of women with two children work. In Italy, the figure is 54 percent. Yet the leading parties in the election have hardly broached these issues, instead fanning anger over immigration and security. The #MeToo movement is a distant concept.\n\nItaly has plenty of powerful interest groups. But for the most part, women are not organized to push for changes on workplace issues. \u201cThat penalizes them,\u201d said Paola Profeta, a public policy expert at Bocconi University in Milan. \u201cWorking women would need investments in day care or paternal leave, but that would imply taking resources away from another group.\u201d\n\nShe added: \u201cSome politicians would want to make reforms \u2014 but without increasing spending, which is impossible.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDuring the campaign, right-wing parties have praised mothers, but otherwise barely mentioned women. Late last month, Silvio Berlusconi, the leader of the center-right party Forza Italia and a likely power broker after the elections, proposed a minimum pension for mothers, once they reach the retirement age of 67.\n\nThe anti-establishment Five Star Movement offered bonuses to pay for diapers and day care. Left-wing parties devoted a few lines in their programs to proposals to lower the gender pay gap and to allow smoother reconciliation between work and family life.\n\nPhoto\n\nMeanwhile, the problems only deepen.\n\nEnrica Maria Martino, who conducted a study for the social security institute, cited \u201cthe rigidity of working hours, the scarcity of part-time opportunities and the inadequacy of child care provisions, together with a strong role division between men and women that still attributes women all family responsibilities\u201d as obstacles to keeping mothers in the work force.\n\nItaly does offer generous maternity leave policies, but there are few safety nets once that leave is over. In the past, networks of relatives, especially grandmothers and aunts, often provided child care support.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut now younger generations are moving away from their families to pursue work \u2014 often leaving them dependent on inadequate public institutions for support. Few employers subsidize child care, and assistance is particularly rare for women on temporary contracts.\n\n\u201cPublic kindergartens are few and badly distributed all over the country \u2014 they are very few in southern Italy,\u201d said Linda Laura Sabbadini, a social statistician and columnist at the Turin daily La Stampa. \u201cThe private ones are expensive.\u201d\n\nItaly has one of the lowest birthrates in Europe, and it hit a new low last year, less than half what it was during a baby boom in the 1960s.\n\nThe few facilities that do exist are often operated by women facing such predicaments themselves. One is L\u2019Alveare (The Beehive), the only shared work space in Rome with day care in a working-class neighborhood. The Beehive also helps mothers return to the work force. One is Lucia Roca, a 39-year old freelance movie translator and mother of two, who lives hundreds of miles from her parents.\n\n\u201cUntil my daughter was little, I worked from home with no problem, but as she was growing up, it was impossible,\u201d she said as she held her 1-year-old. \u201cI felt so isolated and lonely.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Beehive offers workstations in rooms with spacious windows overlooking a garden and a nursery next door. For a couple of months, a group of 25 mothers met there for a course on how to recalibrate their professional goals when balanced with motherhood.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI try to explain that we may as well to skip a step in Italy, as we are so behind,\u201d said Riccarda Zezza, one of the course\u2019s speakers. Ms. Zezza, a former multinational manager, founded the country\u2019s first shared work space with day care. A few years ago, Ms. Zezza presented an 83-page paper to the government, explaining what the country could do to help women. Not much happened.\n\n\u201cPoliticians know what is needed, but at best give bonuses for kindergartens or to buy diapers, abdicating to their role to find long-term solutions,\u201d Ms. Zezza said.\n\nThe problem is largely cultural, many observers say. Italy did not pass laws granting paternity leave until 2012, and those leaves are shorter and less generous than in other European countries. Not many men take advantage of them, statistics show.\n\n\u201cI am on a long-term contract, and that of course helped me a lot,\u201d said Francesca, a designer at a large Italian company, who preferred not to use her last name. \u201cBut my partner, who works in my same company and had my same position, became a manager while I had three kids.\u201d\n\n\u201cMen are praised for raising a family,\u201d she added. \u201cWomen are punished.\u201d\n\nMonica Mastroianni, a 36-year old radio journalist turned into press officer, faced the ultimate problem for any worker: the economic crisis. Two months into her maternity leave in 2013, the radio station where she and her husband were employed folded. She found herself jobless and with a toddler, while he hunted for a job. She later opted for two freelance jobs that allowed her to take care of her family.\n\nWhen she got pregnant again, she was told that women were \u201cdone\u201d once they had two children because working is impossible.\n\nMs. Mastroianni rejected that notion.\n\n\u201cI will make it,\u201d she said. \u201cI don\u2019t want my daughters to feel my same pain, or be forced to emigrate.\u201d", "title": "Women Could Decide Italy\u2019s Election, but They Feel Invisible", "authors": ["Gaia Pianigiani"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "The Coyote Ugly Saloon, the East Village bar that became an early 2000s cult film, proved it takes work to keep a wild reputation alive. On a Sunday in January, about 350 guests celebrated the bar\u2019s 25th anniversary at a party that included appearances from a contortionist, Times Square\u2019s Naked Cowboy and a performance from the rapper Justina Valentine.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the year of the woman,\u201d Ms. Valentine declared from atop the bar to the crowd of former bartenders, regulars, some who have been patrons since the 90s, and fans of the film. \u201cIt\u2019s the decade of the woman.\u201d\n\nThe owner , Liliana Lovell, was there catching up with the customers who frequented her saloon 25 years ago , when she was the one dancing on the bar. \u201cIt\u2019s like getting into an old shoe,\u201d she said about being back.\n\nA fter Ms. Valentine and two backup dancers performed a few songs from on top of the bar, a bartender slipped her a note to \u201croast the crowd ,\u201d something she\u2019s used to doing to her castmates on M.T.V.\u2019s \u201cWild \u2018N Out,\u201d a hip-hop comedy improv show.", "title": "Women Still Rule the Coyote Ugly Saloon, 25 Years Later", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWant to witness the tectonic shifts underway in American politics? Consider women and college graduates, who have flocked to the Democratic Party in recent years.\n\nA larger share of college graduates identify as or lean Democratic than at any point in the past quarter-century, according to a new Pew Research Center report based on more than 10,000 interviews with registered voters last year. The data tell a similar story for women, too.\n\nRepublicans have gained some ground, too, among older registered voters and those with a high school education or less.\n\nHere\u2019s a brief look at the findings of the Pew analysis, which was released this week.\n\nCollege graduates overwhelmingly side with Democrats\n\nAmericans are more divided along educational lines than at any point in about a quarter-century, according to Pew.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat\u2019s thanks largely to a realignment among two groups: those with only a high school diploma and those who have completed college.", "title": "Women and College Graduates Flock to the Democratic Party, Study Finds", "authors": ["Niraj Chokshi"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 The Philadelphia Museum of Art will highlight the creations of a number of women who work in varied media. An exhibition (March 24 to July 15) by Jean Shin marks the museum\u2019s first single-artist display of works by a contemporary female Korean-American artist. Ms. Shin, who works in New York, is known for the huge installations she makes by deconstructing and rebuilding everyday objects, like clothing and shoes, to tell stories about identity, society and community. In April, the museum will present two large sculptures by the German-born artist Ursula von Rydingsvard in a yearlong show that coincides with a major exhibition at the Fabric Workshop and Museum, also in Philadelphia, from April 27 to Aug. 26. On display at the art museum will be \u201cBronze Bowl With Lace,\u201d which is nearly 20 feet tall, and \u201cElegantka II.\u201d A third show will look at works by the abstract painter Agnes Martin (May 19 - August) And, finally, a new video installation by Rachel Rose (May 2 - Aug. 19) will have its premiere at the museum. The project, set in 16th-century agrarian England, examines the links between \u201creality and perception, history and coincidence.\u201d", "title": "Women in the Spotlight at Museums", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIf you\u2019ve been keeping score, you\u2019ve probably noticed: Women have been getting sweaty on New York stages lately. They punch and kick. They jab and run. They push themselves and each other to their physical limits, until someone erupts in triumph or defeat.\n\nIn Deborah Stein and Suli Holum\u2019s \u201cThe Wholehearted,\u201d at the Abrons Arts Center through April 1, a boxer wraps her hands, puts on her gloves and hits a bag as violently as she would the abusive husband who almost killed her. In January, Sarah DeLappe\u2019s Pulitzer Prize finalist \u201cThe Wolves,\u201d about teenage girls on a soccer team, ended its third New York run in two years; a month later, we could watch two high school fencers for whom friendship is a weapon as sharp as a blade in Gracie Gardner\u2019s \u201cAthena.\u201d Reaching back a few years, Ruby Rae Spiegel\u2019s harrowing \u201cDry Land\u201d was set mostly in the locker room of a girls\u2019 swim team.\n\nPhoto\n\nFootball? We got that too: Julia Brownell\u2019s \u201cAll-American\u201d explored the dynamics in a family where a daughter did not want to be her school\u2019s quarterback anymore, while Tina Satter\u2019s \u201cIn the Pony Palace/Football\u201d gleefully appropriated gridiron tropes by having women play boys. Coed plays about tennis have included Anna Ziegler\u2019s \u201cThe Last Match\u201d and Kevin Armento and Bryony Lavery\u2019s \u201cBalls,\u201d which reproduced the infamous \u201cbattle of the sexes\u201d match between Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs.\n\nThis is starting to look like a trend. But then, there should be a better term for the act of making up for decades\u2019 worth of women playing the male star\u2019s girlfriend (\u201cRocky the Musical\u201d), wife (\u201cLombardi\u201d), mother (\u201cMagic/Bird\u201d) or temptress (\u201cDamn Yankees\u201d). Telling untold stories is not merely a \u201ctrend,\u201d not 46 years after Title IX passed, forbidding sex-based discrimination in federally funded education programs or activities.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAll these new plays have been written or co-written, directed or co-directed, by women. And in most of them, sports is more than the background; rather, it is a dramatic engine for exploring socialization and self-image, femininity and power. For many women, athletics is one of the few places where it is acceptable to show ambition, where it is O.K. to want to win-win-win.\n\nPhoto\n\nTellingly, several of these new shows have focused on adolescence, a time when a girl\u2019s body is simultaneously ally (it has newfound abilities) and foe (it changes in uncontrollable ways, triggers unpredictable moods and draws attention that may or may not be welcome). Teenagers can take pleasure in their power without necessarily having it linked to notions of attractiveness.", "title": "Women on Stage Get Their Turn on the Playing Field", "authors": ["Elisabeth Vincentelli"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Chicago, now 78, lives in New Mexico with her husband. Following are excerpts from an interview with the artist, which have been edited and condensed.\n\nWhat was the Southern California art scene like in the \u201970s?\n\nIt was unbelievably macho. I went through tremendous struggles to be taken seriously as a woman artist. I really tried to fit in, both in my art-making and in my persona. After about a decade I got tired of it. I didn\u2019t realize what a radical change I was about to make when I went to Fresno, but I knew I was setting out to create two things: a feminist art practice, and a feminist art education so that young women wouldn\u2019t have to do what I had to do.\n\nImage Judy Chicago\u2019s \u201cButterfly Test Plate #2,\u201d 1973-1974. Credit 2018 Judy Chicago/Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York and Salon 94, New York; Photo: Donald Woodman\n\nWhat was the goal when you got to CalArts?\n\nThere was no women\u2019s art scene. The goal was to build one. And I knew there was a lot of hunger among women for images that related to our own experience. I taught women to step up. I trained them in what it meant to be professional artists, and to raise their consciousness, among other things. Once I gave these young women permission to make art out of their own experiences as women, it was like an explosion.\n\nHow would you describe yourself?\n\nA troublemaker. I\u2019ve never fit in. In my first decade, I didn\u2019t fit in because of my gender. Then, after I made this radical change in my art, I didn\u2019t fit in because of the kind of art I was making. Part of the problem is the art world can\u2019t fit me into one category. I\u2019ve done different subject matters and different techniques. I have tried to make art that\u2019s accessible to a broad audience, that doesn\u2019t need somebody to stand between me and the audience and explain it, and that\u2019s very out of step with the art world.\n\nWhat did people take away from Womanhouse?\n\nIn those days, women were the primary audience for feminist art. That has dramatically changed. Young men now come by themselves to see my work. There\u2019s a big shift generationally. Back then men came because their mothers, wives, girlfriends or sisters brought them. Many were uncomfortable because they didn\u2019t know how to relate.\n\nImage The cover of the exhibition catalog for the original Womanhouse exhibition with Ms. Chicago and Miriam Schapiro. The cover was designed by Sheila de Bretteville. Credit Through the Flower Archive\n\nOver the past 46 years what are the biggest changes?\n\nI\u2019d been told in the \u201960s that I couldn\u2019t be both a woman and an artist. I had to excise any hint of gender from my work in order to be taken seriously in the L.A. art scene. That has completely changed. Young women, artists of color, artists of the range of sexual orientation can now be themselves openly in their work. That\u2019s a fabulous change.\n\nWhat do you hope this new show accomplishes?\n\nI hope it kicks ass, shakes people up, and opens their eyes. That it gives them new experiences and helps them understand more about the range of women\u2019s experiences and their views.", "title": "Women, Art and the Houses They Built", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Jane Walker will take over her brother Johnny\u2019s whiskey label this month \u2014 in honor of Women\u2019s History Month, we\u2019re told \u2014 a temporary rebranding that\u2019s fueling comic riffs by Stephen Colbert and other cynical types. It might seem innocuous enough \u2014 an unsubtle attempt to lure skittish female drinkers to whiskey \u2014 but there\u2019s a back story to this relationship that\u2019s worth noting.\n\nThe liquor industry was once the most powerful opponent of granting women their civil rights. Jane Walker, in a sense, would have been an anti-suffragist. And over decades, the industry provided much of the \u201cdark money\u201d used to fight woman suffrage in Congress and in the states.\n\nTemperance was a \u201cwoman\u2019s issue\u201d in the 19th and early 20th centuries, as women and children suffered physical and emotional abuse from inebriated men, often their own husbands and fathers. Families also suffered the financial toll of salaries squandered on booze, with not much left for bread. Early feminists took up the temperance cause, not just for moral reasons (though that was a rationale for some) but also as a public health issue and as a way to protect women from domestic violence and sexual harassment on the street.\n\nBefore she was an organizer for woman suffrage, Susan B. Anthony was an organizer for the Daughters of Temperance. Frances Willard and her Women\u2019s Christian Temperance Union advocated votes for women, and there was a natural alliance between the movements: Empower women with the vote so they can protect themselves by placing legal restrictions on liquor.", "title": "Opinion | Women, Booze and the Vote", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFRIDAY PUZZLE \u2014 It\u2019s Friday, so most of us can stay up as late as we like to finish Sam Trabucco\u2019s puzzle. No school, and if you happen to work on Saturdays, sorry about that. It\u2019s worth giving up a few winks for this 68-word treat. Also, happy M.L.B. opening day to all who worship. Please celebrate responsibly.\n\nThe is a mostly clean grid with a lot of entertaining entries, and Mr. Trabucco debuts a whopping 12 words and phrases today. Of those, I really liked WELL DAMN, WELCOME TO MY LIFE (a fantastic entry, although I\u2019m not sure the clue quite gets there; I hear it as \u201cNow you see what I\u2019m going through\u201d), MEGADEAL, DON\u2019T WAIT UP FOR ME, TIGER MOM, NEVER FAILS and PLEASE STOP.\n\nI also liked MAMA BIRD, O SOLE MIO, I\u2019M A FAN, ICED COFFEE, ALLOSAURUS and AW MAN.\n\nTricky Clues\n\n1A: Hand up if you were thinking of some sort of \u201cAs Seen on TV\u201d device for the clue \u201cEgg warmer.\u201d Not today. In most bird species, the MAMA BIRD sits on and warms the eggs.\n\n9A: T.I.L. about the rutabaga\u2019s provenance, which is a sentence I never thought I\u2019d write. It\u2019s a cross between a cabbage and a TURNIP. This is why people need to solve crossword puzzles.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n38A: The \u201cUbiquitous Chinese character\u201d is not a written character in today\u2019s puzzle. Today, the ubiquitous character is MAO.", "title": "Won\u2019t Be Back Till Late", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "It was an opportune moment for Mr. Pecker to showcase his White House connections. He was considering expanding his media and events businesses into Saudi Arabia and also was hunting for moneyed partners in acquisitions.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe intersection of the tabloid publisher with the Saudis, enhanced by the White House visit, is a previously untold chapter in the long, symbiotic relationship between the president and Mr. Pecker, which was forged in the 1990s. At the time, Mr. Trump was celebrating a real estate comeback after his casino bankruptcies and was both the subject and the source of much gossip in New York.\n\nMr. Pecker, who had known Mr. Grine only for a few months, invited him to the dinner to thank him for advice he had provided about investing in the Middle East, according to someone who knew of the invitation.\n\nWord soon traveled back to Saudi Arabia about the dinner: It signaled Mr. Pecker\u2019s powerful status in Washington.\n\nTwo months later, he was in Saudi Arabia, meeting with Mr. Grine and the crown prince about business opportunities there, according to A.M.I.\n\nAnd by January, Mr. Pecker was confident enough about his growing rapport with Saudi investors that he sought their help bankrolling a possible acquisition of Time magazine, which he had long coveted, according to two people with direct knowledge of the talks. A.M.I. disputed that.\n\nThe White House did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nThe people briefed on the interactions between A.M.I. and Saudi Arabia requested anonymity because they were not authorized to speak publicly.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe outcome of Mr. Pecker\u2019s efforts to do business with the Saudis remains unclear. But he is still working to cultivate ties. This week, he and Mr. Grine both attended events in New York featuring Prince Mohammed, who is on a tour across the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAhead of that visit, A.M.I. published a 97-page glossy magazine that is essentially a promotional brochure for Saudi Arabia and the crown prince. It makes no mention of anything troubling, like the Saudi-led military campaign in Yemen, human rights concerns or the crown prince\u2019s arrest last fall of many extended royals, including Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, an influential client of Mr. Grine\u2019s.\n\nThe magazine \u2014 which refers to Saudi Arabia throughout as \u201cthe Magic Kingdom\u201d \u2014 includes an interview with Mr. Grine, accompanied by a photo of him posing with Mr. Trump in the Oval Office, taken during his visit with Mr. Pecker. It talks up the relationship between Mr. Trump and the Saudis, noting that Mr. Trump \u201cendorsed the crown prince\u2019s high profile anticorruption\u201d crackdown.\n\nA.M.I. has said it produced the magazine to \u201ccapitalize\u201d on interest in the crown prince, who is next in line to the throne, and has been careful to say it received no input or guidance from Saudi officials. That carries important legal implications: Foreign direction or control of such a purely promotional publication may require disclosure to the Justice Department. The Saudi government did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nThe magazine \u2014 200,000 copies distributed in Walmart and other outlets, with a cover price of $13.99 and no advertising \u2014 provided a unique welcome mat for the prince, whose visit comes as the Trump administration is trying to establish tighter ties with the kingdom. Both countries are touting cross-border investment opportunities, including a pledge by the Saudi government to put $20 billion into a fund that will invest in American infrastructure projects. The kingdom is also nearing a deal to buy American-made missiles and other military equipment.\n\nMr. Grine, a 30-year-old French citizen, has helped broker deals between Saudi investors and companies in France, Senegal and the United States. He and Mr. Pecker were introduced last spring by Ari Emanuel, chief executive of Endeavor, the huge talent, entertainment and sports company based in Beverly Hills, Calif.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Grine and Mr. Pecker soon had a series of discussions about the investment landscape in Saudi Arabia, according to a person briefed on the talks. Mr. Pecker extended the White House dinner invitation shortly afterward.\n\nA.M.I. would not say who else was among the \u201cselect group of friends\u201d Mr. Pecker took to the White House at the president\u2019s invitation. During the evening, the Middle East and the recent French elections came up. In a statement, A.M.I. said, \u201cThe entire conversation was social, with the exception of a couple very brief mentions of current events.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Pecker is best known for The Enquirer, but his media empire is wide-ranging. A.M.I.\u2019s titles include Men\u2019s Journal, Hers, Flex and Muscle & Fitness.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe publisher has used the company at times to protect close friends, including Mr. Trump. Karen McDougal, a former Playboy model, recently filed a lawsuit alleging that Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyer was secretly involved when A.M.I. tried to bury her story about an affair with Mr. Trump. A.M.I. bought the rights to her story during the presidential campaign for $150,000 but never published it. In the world of gossip media, such a maneuver is known as a \u201ccatch and kill\u201d operation.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s lawyer Michael D. Cohen and A.M.I. have denied the allegations. Mr. Trump\u2019s representatives say the affair never happened.\n\nDuring the campaign, The Enquirer also published scathing articles about Mr. Trump\u2019s rivals, as well as perceived antagonists like the television host Megyn Kelly. In promoting Mr. Trump, The Enquirer endorsed a candidate for the first time in its history.\n\nPhoto\n\nSince he entered the White House, A.M.I. titles have run articles alleging a \u201cdeep state\u201d plot to undermine Mr. Trump. As scandals engulfed the White House, a recent Enquirer cover blared: \u201cDonald & Melania Fight Back! Exposing the Lies, Leaks and Intimidation. How They\u2019ll Crush Their Enemies!\u201d\n\nThe support appears mutual. Mr. Trump at times has praised Mr. Pecker\u2019s stewardship of A.M.I. He once endorsed Mr. Pecker to run Time magazine, whose cover, Mr. Trump has incorrectly asserted, has featured him more than anyone else.\n\n\u201cDavid Pecker would be a brilliant choice as CEO of TIME Magazine \u2014 nobody could bring it back like David!\u201d Mr. Trump wrote in a Tweet in 2013.\n\nAsked about Mr. Pecker\u2019s interest in Time, A.M.I.\u2019s chief content officer, Dylan Howard, said, \u201cAny media executive worth his or her salt must look at any acquisition opportunity in today\u2019s media climate.\u201d\n\nA.M.I. has struggled financially. It went through a series of restructurings in the last decade, including a bankruptcy in 2010 in which the company reported up to $1 billion in debts, before being acquired four years ago by two private equity funds.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe company said in a statement that it was \u201cin an incredibly stable financial position.\u201d\n\nMr. Pecker has continued to hunt for new acquisitions. Last year, he bought Us Weekly from Wenner Media. But money remained scarce, according to A.M.I.\u2019s financial advisers. When Mr. Pecker\u2019s friend Harvey Weinstein suggested last fall that they team up to purchase Rolling Stone, Mr. Pecker expressed little interest. \u201cI can not contribute any cash,\u201d he wrote in an email obtained by The New York Times.\n\nIn that same Sept. 28 exchange, he wrote to Mr. Weinstein: \u201cI am in Saudi Arabia on business. Can\u2019t call from here.\u201d\n\nDuring the visit to Saudi Arabia, Mr. Grine arranged for himself and Mr. Pecker to meet with Prince Mohammed, who is the chairman of the kingdom\u2019s deep-pocketed Public Investment Fund. At the meeting, Mr. Pecker described his vision for expanding his events business, which includes the Mr. Olympia bodybuilding competition, into Saudi Arabia.", "title": "Wooing Saudi Business, Tabloid Mogul Had a Powerful Friend: Trump", "authors": ["Jim Rutenberg", "Kate Kelly", "Jessica Silver-Greenberg", "Mike Mcintire"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "pretentious \\ pri-\u02c8ten(t)-sh\u0259s \\ adjective\n\n1. making claim to or creating an appearance of (often undeserved) importance or distinction 2. intended to attract notice and impress others 3. (of a display) tawdry or vulgar\n\n_________\n\nThe word pretentious has appeared in 84 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 10 in \u201cIs Your Dog Ready for Instagram?\u201d by Alex Williams:", "title": "Word + Quiz: pretentious", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "_________\n\nThe word apothecary has appeared in 26 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on April 20 in the movie review \u201c\u2018The Promise\u2019 Finds a Love Triangle in Constantinople\u201d by Jeannette Catsoulis:\n\nWeighed down by the worthiness of its intentions, \u201cThe Promise\u201d is a big, barren wartime romance that approaches the Armenian genocide with too much calculation and not nearly enough heat.\n\nIt can happen all too easily. An otherwise highly competent director (in this case, Terry George) succumbs to the lure of addressing a real-life atrocity (here, the still-contested slaughter of more than a million peaceful Armenians by the Ottoman Empire during World War I). Somewhere along the way, though, the need to do justice to the slain and call out the perpetrators becomes a pillow that smothers every spark of originality. Even actors with the heft of Oscar Isaac and Christian Bale \u2014 playing an Armenian apothecary named Mikael and an American war reporter named Chris \u2014 appear muffled and indistinct.", "title": "Word + Quiz: apothecary", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "_________\n\nThe word audacious has appeared in 251 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 17 in \u201cThe WeWork Manifesto: First, Office Space. Next, the World\u201d by David Gelles:\n\nIndeed, to assess WeWork by conventional metrics is to miss the point, according to Mr. Neumann. WeWork isn\u2019t really a real estate company. It\u2019s a state of consciousness, he argues, a generation of interconnected emotionally intelligent entrepreneurs. And Mr. Neumann, with his combination of inspiration and chutzpah, wants to transform not just the way we work and live, but the very world we live in.\n\n... It\u2019s an audacious, perhaps delusional plan for a company that made its mark by building communal desks and providing refreshments. And so far, it seems to be working.", "title": "Word + Quiz: audacious", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "_________\n\nThe word conflagration has appeared in 47 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 8 in the Opinion essay \u201cDoom Season in Los Angeles\u201d by H\u00e9ctor Tobar:\n\nLast week the outdoor humidity as measured by my home weather station dropped below 10 percent. By Wednesday morning, wildfires were burning on a wide crescent of mountain ranges on the fringes of the metropolis. One of them loomed near the treasures of the Getty art museum and threatened homes on Linda Flora Drive in Bel-Air \u2014 the street where my kid sister lives.\n\n... This being Los Angeles, the conflagration enveloping my sister\u2019s neighborhood was a media event. I followed the progress of the fire that morning on five different television stations, looking for her house in every shot. Firefighters attacked the blaze with aircraft that dropped a crimson-colored rain of fire-retardant chemicals. They trudged about on foot too, pouring water onto the roofs of burning homes.", "title": "Word + Quiz: conflagration", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "_________\n\nThe word conjecture has appeared in 56 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 22 in the Opinion essay \u201cWhat Is the Future of Speculative Journalism?\u201d by Christy Wampole:\n\nWe\u2019ve really gotten ahead of ourselves. Our eagerness to know what will happen next, particularly in relation to the Trump saga, manifests itself in a hunger for conjecture in places that we once relied on to deliver fact \u2014 in particular, journalism. Reporters and editors making guesses at what might happen rather than reporting what did happen results in what is typically called speculative journalism.\n\nWhile this tendency to speculate has existed in journalism since its inception, its prevalence in recent months strikes me as peculiar at a time when all sides seem to be calling for more truth and less fake news. Because speculation is neither true nor false, it seems to work as a strange compromise, a third way that shelves for now the question of what is real and true.", "title": "Word + Quiz: conjecture", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "noun: the topmost projecting part of an entablature\n\nnoun: a molding at the corner between the ceiling and the top of a wall\n\nnoun: a decorative framework to conceal curtain fixtures at the top of a window casing\n\nverb: furnish with a cornice", "title": "Word + Quiz: cornice", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "_________\n\nThe word deplorable has appeared in 102 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 9 in \u201cFor Older Venezuelans, Fleeing Crisis Means \u2018Starting From Zero,\u2019 Even at 90\u201d by Kirk Semple:\n\nAs for the 90-year-old Ms. Abad, what she will miss about Venezuela, she said, are things already gone; she is practiced in loss.\n\n\u201cThere isn\u2019t food, there isn\u2019t medicine, there isn\u2019t anything,\u201d she said in a recent interview at her apartment building. Another persistent problem is known as bunching, buses on the same route traveling one after another, resulting in large gaps in service and aggravatingly long waits. New York also has the slowest buses of any large American city, with an average speed of about 7 miles an hour, and even slower speeds in parts of Manhattan where walking is sometimes the faster alternative.\n\nBus riders have grown increasingly exasperated by the lack of reliability. Krista Kaszycki, who lives in the Bronx and works in Chinatown in Manhattan, abandoned the subway after enduring a cascade of delays last summer, believing buses to be more reliable and safe. Discuss\u201d by A. O. Scott:\n\nWhat do you make of the homicidal misogyny of \u201cCrimes and Misdemeanors\u201d (1989), in which Martin Landau murders his inconvenient mistress, played by Anjelica Huston? (Jonathan Rhys-Meyers does the same to Scarlett Johansson more than 15 years later in \u201cMatch Point.\u201d) Does the philosophical despair that surrounds it offer an explanation or an excuse for amorality? Whose? What about the almost-romance between Mr. Allen\u2019s character in \u201cHusbands and Wives\u201d and a 21-year-old college student, the failure of which causes the man to regret ruining his marriage to a woman played by Ms. Farrow? Is the regret a pre-emptive attempt at apology? An act of denial? Completely irrelevant?\n\nThere are still those would insist on the last answer, which has been a critical shibboleth for a very long time. And so it may remain. The argument about Woody Allen is far from finished. Critical neurosis may not be curable. But it is useful to remind ourselves, via Freud, of what clinging to it can cost. Neurosis, he wrote, involves the \u201cflight from an unsatisfying reality into a more pleasurable world of fantasy.\u201d The real world, he went on, \u201cis under the sway of human society and of the institutions collectively created by it. To turn away from reality is at the same time to withdraw from the community of man.\u201d", "title": "Word + Quiz: shibboleth", "authors": ["The Learning Network", "Word Of The Day"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": ": either of the two times of the year when the sun is at its greatest distance from the celestial equator\n\n_________\n\nThe word solstice has appeared in 58 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 20 in \u201cGive Thanks for the Winter Solstice. You Might Not Be Here Without It\u201d by Shannon Hall:\n\nOn Dec. 21, or Thursday this year, the sun will hug the horizon. For those of us in the Northern Hemisphere, it will seem to barely rise \u2014 hardly peeking above a city\u2019s skyline or a forest\u2019s snow-covered evergreens \u2014 before it swiftly sets.\n\nFor months, the orb\u2019s arc across the sky has been slumping, shortening each day.\n\nIn New York City, for example, the sun will be in the sky for just over nine hours \u2014 roughly six hours less than in June at the summer solstice. The winter solstice marks the shortest day of the year, before the sun reverses course and climbs higher into the sky. (At the same time, places like Australia in the Southern Hemisphere mark the summer solstice, the longest day of the year.)", "title": "Word + Quiz: solstice", "authors": ["The Learning Network", "Word Of The Day"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "transcendence \\ tran(t) -\u02c8sen-d\u0259n(t)s \\ noun\n\n1. the state of excelling or surpassing or going beyond usual limits 2. a state of being or existence above and beyond the limits of material experience\n\n_________\n\nThe word transcendence has appeared in 62 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 29 in The Upshot infographic \u201cWhat Love and Sadness Look Like in 5 Countries, According to Their Top GIFs\u201d by Amanda Hess and Quoctrung Bui:\n\nAs we survey GIF usage around the world, what pops out is how people from different countries draw on a globalized media ecosystem to express themselves online. Minions, the nonverbal sidekicks from the animated blockbuster \u201cDespicable Me,\u201d were created by Hollywood to appeal to moviegoers worldwide. Now they\u2019ve seamlessly worked themselves into the online culture, too \u2014 they\u2019ve become a top avatar for Italian GIF users to express humor, and for Mexican users to express excitement. There\u2019s also plenty of cultural drift on display. The GIF\u2019s transcendence of language means it skips easily over national barriers. One of Mexico\u2019s favorite ways to express anger is from a viral 2010 commercial by an Egyptian dairy company called Panda Cheese that features a panda wreaking havoc on an office. Another popular GIF in Mexico was captured during the N.B.A. playoffs, when fans of the Golden State Warriors celebrated in the stands.\n\n_________", "title": "Word + Quiz: transcendence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Analysts saw Mr. Abe\u2019s language as suggesting that Japan fears that the North might define denuclearization differently from the rest of the world.\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cI think there\u2019s real concern about a deal-maker president talking one-on-one with Kim, accepting something less than\u201d verifiable and irreversible denuclearization, said Tobias Harris, a Japan analyst at Teneo Intelligence, a political risk consultancy based in New York.\n\n\u201cThe Japanese government obviously wants the North Korean threat resolved,\u201d he added, \u201cbut I don\u2019t think Japanese officials are na\u00efve about the difficulty of achieving a truly meaningful disarmament agreement under these circumstances.\u201d\n\nIn remarks released by the White House, an unnamed senior official said President Trump had spoken with Mr. Abe on Thursday night in Washington. The official added that the administration sought a verifiable deal for the permanent denuclearization of North Korea.\n\nIn Seoul, a spokeswoman for President Moon Jae-in described the invitation to talk as \u201canother great breakthrough.\u201d\n\nPresident Trump\u2019s acceptance of Mr. Kim\u2019s invitation to a summit meeting clearly marked a diplomatic victory for Mr. Moon, adding momentum to the South Korean leader\u2019s efforts to steer the nuclear crisis from talk of war toward negotiations.\n\nBut analysts quickly noted the risks for Washington and Seoul if Mr. Kim did not live up to American expectations for negotiations, or if South Korea pursued better relations with the North should Mr. Kim not take any steps toward denuclearization.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAnnouncing intention for a U.S.-North Korea summit, with so many details yet undetermined, carries risks,\u201d said Leif-Eric Easley, associate professor of international studies at Ewha Womans University in Seoul. \u201cIf the Trump-Kim meeting breaks down, both engagement and pressure campaigns could suffer.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThere was no immediate reaction from China\u2019s Foreign Ministry, but some Chinese analysts were pleased with the news.\n\n\u201cThe United States cannot resist North Korea\u2019s proposals, and Trump is grabbing at them,\u201d said Cheng Xiaohe, professor of international relations at Renmin University. \u201cThat\u2019s good.\u201d\n\nWendy R. Sherman, the lead negotiator for the Obama administration on the Iran nuclear deal, said China would be wary of a meeting between Mr. Kim and Mr. Trump even though Beijing wants dialogue between the two.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
