View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cNorth Korea is not about a rush to denuclearize,\u201d she said. \u201cThey are about dominance, respect and the reunification of the peninsula on its own terms.\u201d\n\n\u201cDoes China want Kim to determine the future of Northeast Asia?\u201d she asked. \u201cChina wants to define the future of Asia. The United States is a Pacific power and wants to protect and grow its place in Asia. However China doesn\u2019t want North Korea as a nuclear state. The United States doesn\u2019t want that. There maybe common ground there.\u201d\n\nAny talks could end up offering only a temporary reprieve, given the American readiness for military action.\n\n\u201cWhat is worth paying attention to is whether North Korea will state very clearly that they are willing to give up their nuclear weapons,\u201d said Zhang Liangui, professor of international studies at the Central Party School of the Communist Party.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIf North Korea tries to beat around the bush again this time,\u201d Mr. Zhang added, \u201cI think the U.S. is ready to resolve the problem with force.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Japan, where Mr. Abe has worked to maintain a close relationship with the American president, analysts said officials were keen to rein in Mr. Trump\u2019s impulsive tendencies.\n\nOn the same day that Mr. Trump accepted Mr. Kim\u2019s invitation, he announced tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, a move that Japan\u2019s foreign minister, Taro Kono, described as \u201cregrettable.\u201d\n\nDuring a budget hearing in parliament, Mr. Kono expressed skepticism about North Korea\u2019s intentions.\n\n\u201cAnyone can say that one has the intention to denuclearize,\u201d he said. \u201cSo far North Korea has done the same twice, to save time to develop nuclear weapons. So Japan\u2019s stance is unchanged. It\u2019s necessary for them to show concrete actions.\u201d\n\nEuan Graham, director of the international security program at the Lowy Institute in Sydney, Australia, said it was worrying that the North Koreans were dictating the pace of events.\n\n\u201cKim Jong-un is playing this very well,\u201d he said. \u201cHe\u2019s got South Korea acting as his emissary, and now an unprecedented summit with the U.S. president, all on the basis of a vague and untested commitment to denuclearization.\u201d\n\n\u201cMy concern is the U.S. is being drawn into a negotiation prematurely, without the internal coherence required to hold the North Koreans to a meaningful bargain that doesn\u2019t compromise U.S. interests, and those of its allies,\u201d he added.", "title": "Word of Trump-Kim Summit Meeting Stirs Concern in Asia", "authors": ["Motoko Rich"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "The accident caused 6 train subway service to be suspended on the Lexington lines between 138th Street in the Bronx, south to 86th Street in Manhattan in both directions. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs the subways and buses, scrambled to fill the gaps left by the service suspensions at some of the city\u2019s busiest stations.\n\nAll morning, chaotic scenes played out up and down Lexington Avenue as commuters convened on the streets outside the shut stations while transit workers on bullhorns directed them to waiting buses.\n\nJust before 9 a.m. the trains were restored but extensive delays snarled the 4, 5 and 6 trains, which continued to bypass 125th Street.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Richards-Stephens had been employed by the M.T.A. for six months, Mr. Byford said. He had been working on removing debris from the track.\n\nAn M.T.A. safety inspection team was sent to the accident site on Tuesday morning, Mr. Byford said.\n\n\u201cPeople don\u2019t come to work not to get home at night,\u201d Mr. Byford said. \u201cWe pride ourselves on running a safe service and getting our employees home safely. That tragically hasn\u2019t happened.\u201d\n\nMr. Richards-Stephens\u2019s death is the first track-worker fatality in two years. In 2016, Lewis Gray was killed after he was struck by a train while setting up safety flags on the track of the G train in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn. In 2010, James Knell, a maintenance supervisor, was electrocuted while working on the A train tracks in the Rockaways in Queens.\n\nAs Tuesday\u2019s commuters backed up all along the Lexington IRT and quickly choked the Seventh Avenue lines as riders shifted to alternate subways, the usual social media fury at the M.T.A. seemed tempered as customers learned over loud speakers about the tragic cause of the slowdown.\n\n\u201cThis is a tragedy, not just for this young man and his family, but for the entire city. While everyone else was asleep, this young man was working in a tunnel beneath Manhattan so others could get to work, or school, or wherever else they need to go to,\u201d Tony Utano, the president of Transport Workers Union Local 100, said in an email.\n\n\u201cWe will be conducting an investigation to determine exactly happened and will assist the family in every way possible.\u201d", "title": "Worker Dies After Fall in Manhattan Subway Tunnel", "authors": ["Sarah Maslin Nir"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt is clear that the consensus that the world had up until the G-20 in Germany is no longer the same,\u201d Nicolas Dujovne, Argentina\u2019s treasury minister said, referring to last year\u2019s summit meeting.\n\nBill Morneau, Canada\u2019s finance minister who has been engaged in tense negotiations with the United States to overhaul the North American Free Trade Agreement, said the Trump administration was showing little sign of being more accommodating to the trade worries that have gripped of the rest of the world.\n\n\u201cI have the continuing sense that they have a point of view, and that point of view is that the system has to work in a way that, in their estimation, benefits American businesses and American trade,\u201d Mr. Morneau said. \u201cThe ramifications of that are that we\u2019re going to have to rethink some of the rules.\u201d\n\nTrump administration officials have said that the tariffs are aimed primarily at combating cheap metals from China, which they say are flooding into the United States through other countries. The Commerce Department has ruled that those imports pose a threat to national security because they degrade the United States\u2019 industrial base.\n\nCountries including France, Argentina and South Korea pressed Mr. Mnuchin during the gathering about being freed from the metals tariffs, arguing that, as United States allies, they should not be penalized on national security grounds. Mr. Mnuchin said that decisions were being made on a case-by-case basis and that there was not a one-size-fits-all approach to deciding which countries would be exempt. The tariffs go into effect on Friday.\n\nMr. Trump has already said he would exempt Canada and Mexico from the tariffs upon a successful renegotiation of Nafta, and he has indicated that other countries could also get exemptions. But the United States has yet to detail what would qualify a country for an exemption, other than a vague reference to protecting the United States\u2019 national security and reducing bilateral trade deficits.\n\nIn an interview on the sidelines of the meeting, Mr. Mnuchin suggested exemptions to the tariffs could be announced \u201crelatively quickly.\u201d", "title": "World Economic Leaders Warn of Trade War as Mnuchin Defends Policies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Uzbekistan has freed a reporter who was incarcerated for nearly two decades on sedition charges, the longest-known prison term served by a journalist, human rights advocates said Friday.\n\nThe reporter, Yusuf Ruzimuradov, 64, who worked for a newspaper banned by the Uzbek authorities, had been held since 1999.\n\n\u201cGlad to hear that #journalist Yusuf Ruzimuradov was released from #Uzbekistan prison,\u201d the Eurasia division of the Committee to Protect Journalists, an advocacy group, said on its Twitter account. The group said he had been held \u201clonger than anybody else in the world \u2014 after being convicted on politicized charges in a quick sham trial.\u201d\n\nSteve Swerdlow, the Central Asia researcher for Human Rights Watch, said in a statement: \u201cToday, I got a Skype message I will treasure: the government of Uzbekistan has finally released journalist Yusuf Ruzimuradov after 19 long years in jail.\u201d", "title": "World\u2019s Longest-Imprisoned Journalist Is Freed in Uzbekistan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Every election cycle we say that so and so is fighting for the soul of the Democratic Party, or the soul of the Republican Party. And, of course, most of the time it\u2019s not true. Most of the time the fight is over whether the party in question should go to the left or the right on some policy issue, which is important but not really a matter of a party\u2019s soul.\n\nBut this year it actually is true. The crucial issue of this election cycle is whether the Democratic Party will retain its soul \u2014 remain an institution committed to the basic democratic norms \u2014 respect for truth, personal integrity, the capacity for deliberation and compromise, loyalty to nation above party or tribe.\n\nThese fundamental issues are on the table because Donald Trump put them there.\n\nTrump is a revolutionary figure not because he changed the G.O.P.\u2019s position on trade or international engagement. He\u2019s morally revolutionary.\n\nIn the decades before Trump, the Republican Party stood for an idea: character before policy. To Mitt Romney, John McCain, the Bushes and Ronald Reagan, personal character and moral integrity were paramount. They stood for the idea that you can\u2019t be a good leader or a good nation unless you are a good person and a good people.", "title": "Opinion | Worthy Is the Lamb", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Dowd, like any reasonably sentient person, knows there is no way that a conversation with Mr. Mueller would go well for the president. Mr. Trump doesn\u2019t have a relationship to the truth, but may at one point have had a fleeting affair with it, albeit one apparently covered by a nondisclosure agreement. He lies with pleasure and abandon, then brags about it later. Yet on Thursday, Mr. Trump, who has built his career on the belief that he can brazen his way through anything, told reporters that he \u201cwould like to\u201d testify.\n\nAt least when Mr. Dowd climbs into bed tonight, he can rest easy, knowing that he did all he possibly could for an impossible client. His last significant public comment as Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyer was to call on the Justice Department to shut down the Russia investigation \u2014 a position he attributed to Mr. Trump before backtracking and claiming it as his own.\n\nThe president\u2019s legal team appears to be falling apart just as his legal problems are mounting, both from the Russia investigation and, more recently, from women who say they\u2019ve had affairs with Mr. Trump and are seeking to be released from agreements to silence them. Before Mr. Dowd\u2019s departure, Mr. Trump had spoken to associates about firing Ty Cobb, the White House lawyer who has been advocating a cooperative approach toward Mr. Mueller. Meanwhile Mr. Trump has reached out to, and been rebuffed by, at least two legal heavyweights in the last few weeks: Emmet Flood, who represented President Bill Clinton during his impeachment process, and the conservative superstar Ted Olson.\n\nIn their stead the president has brought on Joseph diGenova, a lawyer who has argued on television that the Justice Department and the F.B.I. are framing Mr. Trump. Who else is there? Alan Dershowitz, the celebrity defense lawyer and self-described liberal from Harvard who has taken on the unlikely role of Trump defender? Or Marc Kasowitz, who previously represented Mr. Trump before leaving because he, among other things, threatened a stranger over email?\n\nThe bigger problem for Mr. Trump is that there aren\u2019t many experienced lawyers who will want to take on a client like him \u2014 save, perhaps, Michael Cohen, a longtime loyalist and Trump lawyer who may be in serious legal trouble of his own, and Roy Cohn, who is dead. Mr. Cohn, a litigious thug who helped destroy the lives of many decent people before being disbarred for \u201cparticularly reprehensible\u201d ethical violations, took a young Mr. Trump under his wing and taught him how to use the law: as a concealed weapon, brandished primarily in the service of vengeance or survival. Mr. Trump was an avid student, as evidenced by the empty threats of litigation he aims regularly at reporters or the unconscionable nondisclosure agreements he wrests from his paramours and underlings.\n\nBeyond this, Mr. Trump has shown contempt for the rule of law and its operation in a democratic society. He attacks the institutions that embody it, from the Justice Department and the F.B.I. to the federal courts and their judges. His approach is not based on any philosophy of governance, but on scorn for or fear of anyone who would hold him to account. So it is fitting that the biggest threat to Mr. Trump is coming from the courts, and from Mr. Mueller, who in many ways represents Mr. Trump\u2019s polar opposite \u2014 a man who has devoted his life to respecting and enforcing the law. And it\u2019s concerning, to say the least, that Mr. Trump is eagerly throwing off the yoke of relatively sober legal counsel just as Mr. Mueller homes in on the president and his shady family business empire.", "title": "Opinion | Would You Want to Be Donald Trump\u2019s Lawyer?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 Concern that Broadcom would sell off parts of Qualcomm to win regulatory approval, disrupting the work of the main American developer of 5G wireless technology \u2014 and therefore ceding the race for a superfast internet to China\n\nThe WSJ recently reported that members of Cfius have been examining the former point. It\u2019s an interesting issue since the panel generally doesn\u2019t get involved until a potential transaction has been submitted to it for review, and obviously, there\u2019s nothing of the sort yet. Some officials pointed out that the panel has the jurisdiction to consider board takeovers as a form of foreign acquisition, though the article said that Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin isn\u2019t sold yet on the argument.\n\nBut let\u2019s consider the second point. The WSJ reported that some Cfius members share Mr. Cornyn\u2019s concerns about a weakened or distracted Qualcomm falling behind Huawei of China in the 5G contest.\n\nBut that ignores Qualcomm\u2019s very public collaboration with Chinese tech companies on 5G. The American chip maker said in January that it has shared information on some of its hardware with Lenovo, Xiaomi and other Chinese companies.\n\nAnd last week, Qualcomm and Huawei announced that they have jointly conducted significant tests for a 5G standard. Here\u2019s what Serge Wilenegger, a Qualcomm Wireless executive, said in the news release:\n\n\u201cAs the industry works toward the goal of commercial launches of 5G NR products and networks in 2019, close collaboration among global mobile industry leaders is necessary to validate the technologies and continue to build and improve our capabilities.\u201d\n\nThe research analyst Stacy Rasgon of Bernstein isn\u2019t convinced by Mr. Cornyn\u2019s point either, arguing in an investor note that Intel can also play a role in developing 5G tech and that, more importantly, Broadcom itself is very interested in the wireless standard.\n\nBroadcom has a reputation for being a cost-cutter, which Qualcomm has argued would likely stunt its ability to keep innovating. That question hasn\u2019t been settled. But the question of whether a deal would endanger the U.S.\u2019s role in the 5G race appears to go a bit too far.\n\nA related consideration: Cfius\u2019s ability to review Broadcom\u2019s moves depends on that chip maker being considered a foreign company. But shareholders of the manufacturer are scheduled to vote on moving its legal residence to the U.S. from Singapore on May 6. It\u2019s unclear whether the panel will act before then \u2014 or if it would ultimately have to decide that it has no jurisdiction after that change in address.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nThe silver linings in President Trump\u2019s tariff plans.\n\nPresident Donald Trump\u2019s trade tariffs are unlikely to amount to effective policymaking. They target stanch allies and ignore far greater problems in the world trading system. But there may something to salvage from the wreckage.\n\nFirst, on the face of it, the president seems willing to risk a stock market plunge to pursue a policy that Wall Street opposes. Too often, the disfavor of investors is taken as evidence that a policy is terrible when it might be just inconvenient to powerful interests.\n\nSecond, Mr. Trump\u2019s tariffs have kept an important debate over trade going. One hope for Mr. Trump\u2019s administration is that its skepticism toward free trade leads to policies that help workers whose jobs are vulnerable to free trade. The proposed tariffs on steel and aluminum are unlikely to provide longer-term assistance to workers in those industries. Still, the skepticism toward free trade may now be permanent and provide future administrations with greater leeway to address its drawbacks.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nMrs. May\u2019s reasonableness may not win over Europe.\n\nBritain\u2019s Prime Minister Theresa May on Friday described the highly preferential relationship her government is seeking to establish with the European Union after it leaves the bloc next year.\n\nAnd to win over skeptics, she attempted to make Britain\u2019s goals seem as reasonable as possible. Her requests for a unique relationship will no doubt get short shrift from those who say Britain cannot be allowed to enjoy the benefits of trading with Europe without accepting most of the obligations. Mrs. May\u2019s response is that both sides can benefit under a new arrangement. She said:\n\nWe both want good access to each other\u2019s markets; we want competition between us to be fair and open; and we want reliable, transparent means of verifying we are meeting our commitments and resolving disputes. But what is clear is that for us both to meet our objectives we need to look beyond the precedents, and find a new balance.\n\nAnd Mrs. May said Britain would not, as some fear, reduce regulation to win business from the European Union and still expect a high degree of access to the bloc\u2019s markets. She said:\n\nBut in practice we are unlikely to want to reduce our standards: not least because the British public would rightly punish any government that did so at the ballot box.\n\nThe big questions:\n\nWill the European Union be willing to set up a whole new regulatory infrastructure to oversee a stand-alone trading arrangement with Britain? Why would the bloc go to such lengths when it has the clout to insist that Britain abides by its rules?\n\nWhat would Britain do if the European Union says no to most of what\u2019s in Mrs. May\u2019s speech? It would almost certainly deepen tensions within the British government between those who want a deeply entwined trading relationship with Europe and those who favor a looser one. Mrs. May, who has spent weeks trying to build a consensus in her cabinet, may then find it even harder to present a coherent position to the European Union, giving it even less reason to want to compromise.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat will it take for Gary Cohn to leave?\n\nPresident Trump\u2019s national economic adviser has threatened to quit before, most notably in the wake of the controversy over the violence in Charlottesville, Va. But now that Mr. Cohn apparently has been outplayed in the battle over trade, will he finally decide to depart?\n\nThe former Goldman Sachs president had managed to hold off trade hard-liners like the policy adviser Peter Navarro and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross during previous debates on tariffs. But an exodus of like-minded White House officials diminished Mr. Cohn\u2019s standing \u2014 and let his rivals reassert their positions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrom Damian Paletta and Josh Dawsey of the WaPo:\n\n\u201cGary got rolled and was entirely kept in the dark,\u201d a person close to the White House said of Trump\u2019s top economic adviser.\n\nOr as Mike Allen and Jonathan Swan of Axios put it:\n\nThe tariffs call was also a big middle finger to economic adviser Gary Cohn, who has fought for more than one year to kill tariffs that would provoke a trade war or higher prices for consumers, a de facto tax increase.\n\nOur colleagues Mark Landler and Maggie Haberman have reported that Mr. Cohn threatened to resign if the president followed through on the tariff threat. (That cost him standing with Mr. Trump, though he seemed to regain much of his political capital, particularly after the passage of the tax overhaul.)\n\nMr. Landler and Ms. Haberman point out that Mr. Cohn is still waiting to see if Mr. Trump actually rolls out the tariffs \u2014 a fair question, given how quickly his boss appears to switch policy positions.\n\nBut if the White House does impose tariffs on imported aluminum and steel, will Mr. Cohn finally pull the trigger?\n\nOn a related note, let\u2019s talk about the resuscitation of Mr. Ross\u2019s political fortunes:\n\n\u2022 Axios, on Jan. 21: \u201cPresident Donald Trump has put Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross out to pasture,\u201d the publication reported, noting that Mr. Ross had been criticized for falling asleep in meetings.\n\n\u2022 Axios, today: \u201cWhite House staff, most of whom were in the dark about Trump\u2019s planned tariffs announcement, are referring to Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, the victor in the policy coup, as \u2018Chief Ross.\u2019\u201d\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nThe world is girding for a potential trade war\n\nExpect today to be rough in the markets, after President Trump doubled down this morning on his threat to impose tariffs on international steel and aluminum. S. & P. 500 futures are down in premarket trading, after falling yesterday.\n\nThe current plan: A 25 percent tariff on steel and a 10 percent one on aluminum.\n\nThe winners: U.S. sellers of industrial metals, like AK Steel and U.S. Steel, whose stocks jumped yesterday; trade hard-liners like Wilbur Ross, the commerce secretary, Robert Lighthizer, the White House\u2019s top trade negotiator, and Peter Navarro, its trade policy guru.\n\nThe losers: Big metal consumers like Ford, G.M., Boeing and United Technologies; free-trade proponents like Gary Cohn, who has threatened to resign; many Republican lawmakers; Brazil; and Canada.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe world\u2019s response: China could retaliate with tariffs on some U.S. goods. The E.U. could, too. Japan and Korea are hoping that, as allies, they would be exempted \u2014 but they appear prepared to fight back.\n\nThe context: George W. Bush imposed tariffs on imported steel in 2002. He lifted them a year later.\n\nPeter Eavis\u2019s take: Mr. Trump\u2019s tariffs may be quite narrow in focus and exist for a relatively short period. Investors could learn to live with those. But the U.S. economy and stock markets have some vulnerabilities that could magnify the damage from a trade war.\n\nWhat could President Trump\u2019s planned tariffs mean for Nafta?\n\nGoldman Sachs\u2019s economists wrote that while the potential tariff\u2019s on imported steel and aluminum \u201ccould alleviate political pressure on the White House to pursue other trade restrictions in the near-term,\u201d it would increase \u201cthe probability of trade-restrictive outcomes to other pending issues.\u201d\n\nOn Nafta:\n\n\u201cWe believe the most likely outcome in the near-term is the announcement of a few small agreements on technical trade issues, but we continue to expect negotiations to stall on major issues like rules of origin and government procurement. There is a good chance that this could eventually lead the President to announce he intends to withdraw from NAFTA, but such an announcement does not appear likely in the near term, in our view.\u201d\n\nOn China\u2019s practices regarding intellectual property and technology transfer:\n\n\u201cWe expect that the Administration will ultimately announce restrictions on investment by Chinese companies in the US, and possibly broader trade restrictions, in response to its ongoing Section 301 investigation. The deadline for that decision is not until August, however, and it is not clear when an announcement in this area will be made.\u201d\n\nWilbur Ross: Potential prices increases will be \u2018no big deal.\u2019\n\nThe Commerce Secretary appeared on CNBC and downplayed the impact of President Trump\u2019s planned tariffs, using a can of Campbell Soup.\n\n\u201cIn a can of Campbell Soup, there are about 2.6 pennies worth of steel. So if that goes up by 25 percent, that\u2019s about six-tenths of one cent on the price on a can of Campbell Soup,\u201d Ross argued. \u201cI just bought this can today at a 7-Eleven ... and it priced at a $1.99. Who in the world is going to be too bothered?\u201d\n\nNot everyone agrees with that view:\n\nPhoto\n\nThe questions BlackRock is asking gun makers.\n\nBlackRock, the largest investor in the world, is doubling down on pushing gun makers to consider their responsibilities to the public. BlackRock said that in the wake of the Parkland, Fla., shootings it has been speaking with public gun manufacturers and retailers.\n\n\u201cFor manufacturers and retailers of civilian firearms, we believe that responsible policies and practices are critical to their long-term prospects. Now more so than ever. That is why, over the past week, we have reached out to the major publicly traded civilian firearms manufacturers and retailers to engage in a discussion of their business practices. We have already had constructive discussions with some, and we are continuing to pursue our engagement with them all.\u201d\n\nBlackrock said it is asking companies to answer questions like:\n\n\u2022 \u201cWhat is your strategy and process for managing the reputational, financial and litigation risk associated with manufacturing civilian firearms?\u201d\n\n\u2022 \u201cHow do you assess the financial, reputational and litigation risk of the various aspects of your product lines and how each of those products is distributed?\u201d\n\n\u2014 Andrew Ross Sorkin\n\nPhoto\n\nDid Kushner Companies seek money from Qatar\u2019s finance minister last year?\n\nAn article in The Intercept says that not only did the real estate firm \u2014 which Jared Kushner led until joining the White House \u2014 try to convince Qatar to invest in its embattled 666 Fifth Avenue property in Manhattan, but that it spoke directly with the emirate\u2019s top money man.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe meeting between Charles Kushner, Mr. Kushner\u2019s father, and Ali Sharif Al Emadi of Qatar was last April, a month before Saudi Arabia and others set up a blockade of the emirate. Mr. Kushner supported the move, while Secretary of State Rex Tillerson did not.\n\nMore from Clayton Swisher and Ryan Grim of The Intercept:\n\nThe 30-minute meeting, according to two sources in the financial industry who asked not to be named because of the sensitivity of the potential transaction, included aides to both parties, and was held at a suite at the St. Regis Hotel in New York. A follow-up meeting was held the next day in a glass-walled conference room at the Kushner property itself, though Al Emadi did not attend the second gathering in person.\n\nA Kushner Companies spokeswoman said that the company doesn\u2019t \u201cdo business with any sovereign funds.\u201d\n\nThe context: Mr. Kushner\u2019s family business has appeared to become more of a liability to his work in the White House. Remember that he held meetings with top financiers whose firms later lent money to Kushner Companies, which has aroused concerns. Or that several countries have reportedly discussed using his complicated financial ties as negotiating leverage over him.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nGrading Trump\u2019s management style\n\nMr. Trump has long thrived on chaos as an organizing principle. But how much disorder is too much?\n\nRemember that the White House has suffered from: very public infighting; off-the-cuff policy proposals by the president; a historically high 34 percent turnover rate; officials threatening to quit to win policy arguments; and an array of investigations into advisers (including Mr. Trump\u2019s daughter Ivanka) and cabinet members.\n\nJim Stewart spoke with a number of experts for their takes on how the president has been running his White House. Here\u2019s a taster:\n\n\u2022 Jeffrey Pfeffer of Stanford University, said of the White House\u2019s turnover rate, \u201cThis reflects badly on his leadership.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. I would expect that some continued strengthening in the labor market can take place without causing inflation.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut new data from the Commerce Department suggest the opposite:\n\n\u2022 Consumer prices as measured by the personal consumption expenditures price index, or PCE, rose 0.4 percent, the biggest increase since September.\n\n\u2022 So-called core PCE, which excludes food and energy, advanced 0.3 percent in January \u2014 the largest gain since January 2017.\n\n\u2022 Year-over-year core PCE, the Federal Reserve\u2019s preferred inflation measure, rose 1.5 percent in January.\n\nIn other Fed news: The White House plans to name Richard Clarida, an economist at Columbia University and an executive at Pimco, as the Fed\u2019s vice chairman, the WSJ reported, citing unidentified sources.\n\nThe policy flyaround\n\n\u2022 Mr. Trump may have switched his position on gun control again, after a meeting with the National Rifle Association. Georgia lawmakers punished Delta Air Lines for eliminating discounted fares for N.R.A. members. Kroger and L.L. Bean are the latest retailers to restrict gun sales to customers age 21 and older.\n\n\u2022 An overhaul of the Dodd-Frank financial rules that would ease regulations on regional banks is moving toward a vote next week in the Senate. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 The venture capitalist Elliott Broidy, a longtime Republican donor, was in talks to earn millions if the Justice Department dropped its corruption investigation of a Malaysian government fund. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Anthony Scaramucci publicly fretted that the White House chief of staff, John Kelly, would block the sale of his SkyBridge Capital to HNA of China. (Bloomberg)\n\nPhoto\n\nWho can show skin in Facebook ads?\n\nFacebook has drawn criticism for inconsistencies regarding which body images are allowed in ads on its platform: a man\u2019s bare chest was found acceptable, but a woman\u2019s bare back was not. (The company later said the latter should have been.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore from Sapna Maheshwari and Sheera Frenkel of the NYT:\n\nThe company has flagged a photo of a woman in a T-shirt reading in dim lighting, for example, while allowing a provocative image of a man\u2019s bare stomach for an ad from a Facebook group dedicated to \u201csteamy romance novels\u201d called Beyond 50 Shades. That image, in which the man had his thumb on the inside of his pants, was incorrectly approved, a Facebook spokeswoman recently said.\n\nElsewhere in digital ads: Procter & Gamble says that most online advertising is a waste. And News Corporation is still pushing Google and Facebook to share more ad revenue.\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Jack Dorsey admits that Twitter still hasn\u2019t done enough to address fake news and cyberbullying. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Facebook has ended an experiment in some countries that separated news from other content \u2014 and that may have led to a rise in misinformation. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Germany has blamed Russian hackers for infiltrating its government\u2019s data network. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Amazon hasn\u2019t changed much at Whole Foods \u2014 yet. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Garrett Camp, a co-founder of Uber, is starting a virtual currency. (TechCrunch)\n\n\u2022 Mark Carney of the Bank of England called for more regulation of virtual currencies. (CNBC)\n\n\u2022 Google is considering whether to hire a construction start-up like Katerra to build thousands of apartments for employees and others in the San Francisco Bay Area. (The Information)\n\n\u2022 Don\u2019t count on 4G wireless service on the moon anytime soon. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 A former Google employee is suing the company for allegedly restricting the hiring of white and Asian males for technical positions at YouTube. (WSJ)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 An additional 2.4 million Americans were affected by a cybersecurity breach at Equifax. (Axios)\n\nPhoto\n\nRegulators mine into Broadcom\u2019s bid for Qualcomm\n\nOn the U.S. front: Members of Cfius, the panel that reviews transactions for national security concerns, have debated whether it can step in before there\u2019s even a deal, the WSJ reported, citing unidentified sources. Those who say it can point to Broadcom\u2019s campaign to win a majority of seats on Qualcomm\u2019s board as effectively a change in control, which will come to a head on March 6.\n\nOn the international front: European lawmakers are concerned about the privacy of E.U. citizens, according to the FT, because NXP \u2014 a chip maker that Qualcomm has agreed to buy \u2014 makes chips for German passports.\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Dell and VMware are working out the details of a combination of the two companies, though a deal is more than a month away, unidentified sources said. (CNBC)\n\n\u2022 DoorDash has raised $535 million from SoftBank\u2019s Vision Fund, GIC of Singapore and Sequoia Capital for a $1.4 billion valuation. (Recode)\n\n\u2022 Carl Icahn has taken a stake in the Crock-Pot maker Newell Brands, amid the company\u2019s fight with fellow activist investor Starboard Value. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 The Athletic has joined ABC News and The Atlantic as finalists to buy Nate Silver\u2019s FiveThirtyEight, unidentified sources said. (The Big Lead)\n\n\u2022 GKN, a British industrial parts maker, is in talks to sell its auto components business to Dana Inc. of the U.S. to stave off a hostile takeover bid by Melrose. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Nippon Life of Japan will buy an 85 percent stake in the U.S. insurer MassMutual for $982 million. (FT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Fosun of China has bought a majority stake in the lingerie maker Wolford for 55 million euros, about $67 million. (Reuters)\n\nPhoto\n\nA deal for Weinstein Company is back from the dead\n\nAt the beginning of the week, the offer by the businesswoman Maria Contreras-Sweet and the investor Rob Burkle appeared to have dissipated. But, after a meeting between the two sides at the offices of the New York attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, there is now an agreement.\n\nWhat the deal entails, according to Brooks Barnes of the NYT:\n\n\u2022 Paying off the studio\u2019s $225 million in debt;\n\n\u2022 Investing $275 million in the new business;\n\n\u2022 Forming a $90 million fund for victims of Harvey Weinstein.\n\nIn other misconduct news: Two massage therapists have sued the casino mogul Steve Wynn in separate lawsuits, each accusing him of coercing them into sex more than a dozen times.\n\nPhoto\n\nRevolving Door\n\n\u2022 Travis Kalanick has joined the board of Kareo, a medical software start-up. (Axios)\n\n\u2022 Brian Gu, JPMorgan\u2019s chairman of Asia-Pacific investment banking, will join the Chinese electric carmaker Xiaopeng Motors as vice chairman and president. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Xavier Niel, the deputy chairman of the French telecommunications company Iliad, has joined K.K.R.\u2019s board. (K.K.R.)\n\nThe Speed Read\n\n\u2022 Four Wells Fargo directors plan to resign next month. The bank also disclosed that the Justice Department had ordered an independent investigation into misconduct allegations in its wealth-management business.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Nasdaq has sued IEX, an electronic stock exchange, for allegedly infringing on seven of its patents by hiring former employees with knowledge of the technology. (Axios)\n\n\u2022 The S.E.C. may be warming up to the idea of forced arbitration, unnamed sources said. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 According to the Hurun Report, the net worth of China\u2019s Parliament and its advisory body has grown by nearly a third, to just below Switzerland\u2019s annual economic output. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Harvard\u2019s endowment made one big miscalculation: believing its top money managers were smarter than everyone else. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Ye Jianming, who runs the conglomerate CEFC China Energy, is under investigation by the Chinese authorities, unnamed sources said. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Color forecasters at Pantone have tremendous influence over the visible elements of the global economy \u2014 the parts of it that are designed, manufactured and purchased \u2014 though their profession itself is all but invisible. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Would a Broadcom-Qualcomm Deal Really Shift the 5G race?: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Perhaps no one knows the devastating wounds inflicted by assault-style rifles better than the trauma surgeons who struggle to repair them. The doctors say they are haunted by their experiences confronting injuries so dire they struggle to find words to describe them.\n\nAt a high school in Parkland, Fla., 17 people were recently killed with just such a weapon \u2014 a semiautomatic AR-15. It was legal there for Nikolas Cruz, 19, the suspect in the shooting, to buy a civilian version of the military\u2019s standard rifle, while he would have had to be 21 to buy a less powerful and accurate handgun.\n\nMany factors determine the severity of a wound, including a bullet\u2019s mass, velocity and composition, and where it strikes. The AR-15, like the M4 and M16 rifles issued to American soldiers, shoots lightweight, high-speed bullets that can cause grievous bone and soft tissue wounds, in part by turning sideways, or \u201cyawing,\u201d when they hit a person. Surgeons say the weapons produce the same sort of horrific injuries seen on battlefields.\n\nCivilian owners of military-style weapons can also buy soft-nosed or hollow-point ammunition, often used for hunting, that lacks a full metal jacket and can expand and fragment on impact. Such bullets, which can cause wider wound channels, are proscribed in most military use.", "title": "Wounds From Military-Style Rifles? \u2018A Ghastly Thing to See\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "At the Battle of Guadalcanal during World War II, hundreds of sailors \u2014 including five from the same family \u2014 lost their lives while serving on the same ship for the United States Navy.\n\nThe ship, the cruiser Juneau, was blasted apart by a Japanese torpedo on Nov. 13, 1942. For decades it was lost, resting in pieces somewhere in the South Pacific.\n\nIt was found on Saturday when a team aboard the Petrel, a research vessel funded by the Microsoft co-founder and philanthropist Paul G. Allen, identified the wreckage about 2.6 miles underwater off the coast of the Solomon Islands.\n\nAmong the hundreds aboard the Juneau when it sank were five brothers from Waterloo, Iowa. Because they were all serving together, the sons of Thomas and Alleta Sullivan were well known even before they deployed.", "title": "Wreck of the Juneau Is Found, 76 Years After 5 Brothers Perished", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Do I have control over my iPhone\u2019s autocorrect function beyond repeatedly correcting words it mistakenly tries to use?\n\nA. The iOS keyboard\u2019s auto-correction feature, intended to be a timesaver and an aid for typing on small glass keyboards, checks spelling and automatically fixes mistakes as you enter text. Good intentions aside, the software has been known to insert incorrect words in the process, which has led to embarrassing mistakes and a few websites devoted to collecting the gaffes. However, you do not have to constantly correct the auto-correction tool.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIf you find the auto-correction feature consistently tries to change the same words that you type to the same wrong words, the keyboard\u2019s dictionary file may have saved incorrect entries. If you do not have a lot of custom words you have saved and want to start over so the auto-correction tool learns new words from scratch, you can dump the old dictionary. To do that, open the Settings app on the home screen, select General and scroll to the bottom of the list. Select Reset and then Reset Keyboard Dictionary, enter your passcode if asked and delete the old dictionary.\n\nPhoto\n\nIf you do not want to ditch the dictionary, you can turn off the auto-correction tool and make other adjustments in the iOS keyboard settings. Tap the Settings icon on the iPhone\u2019s Home screen and choose General. Scroll down the screen until you get to Keyboard and select it.\n\nYou can disable auto-correction entirely but leave the spellchecker on to highlight suspect words. The controls for automatic capitalization and a few other typing aids are also here, as is the setting for the predictive text bar on the keyboard that suggest words as you type. If you have a tendency to repeat typos in certain words or want to expand abbreviations into full phrases, tap Text Replacement to set up automatic conversions as you type.", "title": "Wrestling With Auto-Correct", "authors": ["J. D. Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "But her favorite childhood game was something she called \u201cschool.\u201d Standing at her beloved chalkboard, she taught to her large collection of stuffed animals. \u201cEveryone made outstanding academic progress in absolutely every lesson,\u201d she said.\n\nBy Thanksgiving of 2009, the college relationships of Ms. Gibes and Mr. Gac-Artigas had ended. At the Teach for America holiday party, the pair were glued to the dance floor, and at the end of the evening they giddily shared their first kiss.\n\nSoon Ms. Gibes became a regular at Mr. Gac-Artigas\u2019s apartment, where his roommates, all Harvard guys, welcomed her upbeat presence at their communal dinners. For quite a while she eschewed the label \u201cboyfriend,\u201d instead describing Mr. Gac-Artigas as her \u201coasis.\u201d\n\n\u201cMy sister is very pragmatic,\u201d said Megan Gibes of her younger sibling. \u201cShe was thrilled with Alejandro, but she is a strong woman with lots of ambition and was not afraid of being on her own.\u201d\n\nTo outsiders, the pairing was implausibly perfect. \u201cThey are entirely focused on the greater good but are also the right amount of weird for each other,\u201d said Jake Segal, a close friend to both.\n\nMs. Gibes helped to slow down Mr. Gac-Artigas, while he motivated Ms. Gibes to the next big thing. And their humor meshed and popped. They\u2019d spin out a goofy dance move anywhere and were game to don a costume anytime. In choosing get-ups, Ms. Gibes insisted on gender equity; her character had to be as empowered and recognizable as Mr. Gac-Artigas\u2019s. This led to some amusing twinning. For one party, they both dressed as Vincent Vega from \u201cPulp Fiction.\u201d Another time they were each Rocky, the boxer.", "title": "Writing Their Own Stories, Together", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "This data set can\u2019t determine whether the rising diversity is due to changing hiring practices in Hollywood or whether the academy has gotten better at nominating people of all backgrounds, or perhaps some of both. What we can test numerically is how the academy compares with its peer organizations.\n\nThe two most notable screenplay awards outside the Oscars \u2014 as well as two of the best predictors of the screenplay categories \u2014 are handed out by the British Academy of Film and Television Arts and the Writers Guild of America. By 1985, they had both switched over to the modern format \u2014 two screenplay categories, one for original and one for adapted \u2014 so we\u2019ll use data since then to compare all three organizations.\n\nThe result: all three are nearly tied: The Oscars and WGAs have both nominated about 1.5 percent more diverse screenwriters than the Baftas. The American academy can claim the lead on rewarding these storytellers: 19 Oscar winners since then have come from outside the group of non-Latino white men, compared with only 13 at the WGAs and nine at the Baftas.\n\nWinning, it turns out, is the one area in which the screenplay Oscars do not currently involve a demographic disparity. Since the Oscars shifted to original and adapted screenplay categories, white men and everyone else win 17 percent of their nominations on average.\n\nSo, while the data suggests a historical lack of opportunity for female and minority screenwriters to get invited to the Oscars, we can take heart in a couple findings: First, if a writer does get nominated, regardless of background, he or she has the same chance at winning as every other competitor. And second, the number of people who have the opportunity to tell their stories appears to be trending up.", "title": "Writing Their Way Into a Diverse Oscars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Coleman told local television stations that he often watched White Sox games while behind bars and dreamed of getting his job back. He said he could hear cheers from neighboring cells when the team won the World Series in 2005.\n\nOn Monday, the stadium as he knew it had changed. There were more lights, electronic signs and security. It had been renamed Guaranteed Rate Field. But a few former co-workers were still there and greeted him when he returned.\n\nOne of the men who met him at the field was Jerry Powe, a co-worker in 1994 and now his supervisor. Mr. Powe had testified as a character witness for Mr. Coleman at the death penalty phase of his sentencing.\n\n\u201cWe were buddies back then, but now I am his boss, so it\u2019s a little bit different now,\u201d Mr. Powe said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe judge had acknowledged that there was no evidence linking Mr. Coleman to the crime and that he did not have a criminal record, but gave him a life sentence for the murder conviction and a consecutive 30-year sentence for the sexual assault conviction, the court documents show.\n\nIn February, Mr. Coleman\u2019s lawyers filed a civil-rights complaint in district court seeking damages and a jury trial. The suit named the city of Chicago, Cook County and members of the Chicago Police Department as defendants.\n\nIt says that Mr. Coleman was coerced into confessing by detectives, and that he was punched in the face. Some of the detectives named in the suit procured confessions in more than a dozen other murder cases in which charges were dropped or the defendant was acquitted at trial, The Chicago Tribune reported in 2001.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe complaint said that in April 1994, Mr. Coleman\u2019s mother asked him to investigate a terrible smell coming from the basement of their apartment building in the Englewood neighborhood of Chicago. He and a friend went to take a look, and saw the body of a young woman, Antwinica Bridgeman. They told Mr. Coleman\u2019s mother, who called 911.\n\nMs. Bridgeman had been raped and impaled with a pipe, and a brick had been crammed into her mouth, the complaint said. Mr. Coleman and his friend voluntarily went to the police station to tell the officers how they found the body, and were released. But investigators returned to his home during the night and brought him back to the station.\n\nHe was interrogated for more than 12 hours, punched twice in the face and addressed with a racial slur, according to the complaint. Deprived of sleep, he was coerced into confessing with false promises of leniency, the complaint said.\n\nThe Cook County state\u2019s attorney\u2019s office said on Tuesday that it had no comment. Lawyers for the police department and the city did not immediately reply to requests for comment.\n\nThe state\u2019s attorney reopened the case in 2016 amid new information about police misconduct and DNA evidence from semen samples taken from Ms. Bridgeman\u2019s body and clothing. The DNA pointed to a known serial rapist who had gone on to rape three more women, the complaint said.\n\nOn Nov. 17 last year, Mr. Coleman\u2019s convictions and life sentence were vacated and he walked free, reuniting with his adult children, whom he left when they were 2 years old and 3 months old.\n\n\u201cHe must now attempt to make a life for himself outside prison without the benefit of two decades of life experiences which normally equip adults for that task,\u201d the complaint said.", "title": "Wrongfully Imprisoned for 23 Years, White Sox Employee Gets His Job Back", "authors": ["Christine Hauser"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "This video Op-Ed is by Wuilly Arteaga, 24, now famous for playing his violin in the middle of Venezuela\u2019s deadly protests last year against President Nicol\u00e1s Maduro. Once homeless, Mr. Arteaga taught himself to play the violin by watching videos online and later joined Venezuela\u2019s renowned music education program, El Sistema.\n\nAfter being jailed and tortured for his role in the protests, he left the country and found safety in New York City. He is part of the exodus that has created one of the biggest migration crises in Latin American history. According to the United Nations, the number of Venezuelan nationals seeking asylum worldwide has increased by 2,000 percent since 2014. As the crisis deepens, Mr. Arteaga implores the world to help. \u2014 By the Editors", "title": "Opinion | Wuilly Arteaga: Fighting Venezuela\u2019s Repression With My Violin", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. van der Gang also had 12 years of expertise in manufacturing instruments for the space and medical industries. Exakt Fijnmechanika, the company he founded soon after receiving his degree in precision engineering from the Instrumentmakers School in Leiden, produces precision components such as those used in ophthalmological surgery, the aerospace industry \u2014 and, these days, watchmaking.\n\nPhoto\n\nBeginning with a few Dutch clients in 1990, the company has earned an international reputation for producing superior elements for industries that require optimal accuracy and minute components.\n\nWhich was exactly what Mr. van der Gang wanted in his ideal watch. \u201cI needed a level of quality and workmanship that was higher than you find in the jewelry world,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cIn the jewelry world, if it\u2019s beautiful, if it\u2019s shiny, it\u2019s good. But companies that work in the space industry demand more. So we used the techniques from our Fijnmechanika business to make a watch.\u201d\n\nThe first watch took two years to develop. Priced at 5,600 euros (now, $6,835), the limited edition of 250 sold out, mostly through word of mouth. The prototype, made of paper with a piece of standard plastic for a crystal, is still displayed at the company\u2019s showroom, where Mr. van der Gang presented it with the pride of a young father showing photos of his newborn.\n\nAnd indeed, its creation marked the birth of Van der Gang Watches, which shares offices with Exakt Fijnmechanika in a former agricultural school, built in the 1950s. Mr. van der Gang renovated and redesigned the space himself, from the glass-walled rooms, windowed corridors and spare, laboratory-like workshops to the all-white furnishings and red glass chandeliers.\n\nA small, wiry man with wild, wiry curls, Mr. van der Gang moves with a sprite-like enthusiasm and energy, though his conversation is measured, his voice gentle and calm. If the character of Van der Gang watches lies in their details, then the same is true of their creator.\n\nPhoto\n\nDespite his emphasis on technology, there are indications of another, sentimental side. His wife, a graphic artist, helps design each watch face. A eight-foot-high photograph of his daughter as a toddler (she is now 16) fills the wall opposite his work table. He gave the first watch he ever made to his father. And although he now keeps the first and last examples of every new model for the archives, the second one still goes to Dad.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat sentimentality also fuels his creative process. \u201cI have a passion for making something beautiful and the best,\u201d Mr. van der Gang said.\n\nOn the sporty, aviation-style Vlieger 20045WW-T, for instance, the sapphire crystal, cut flat to enhance shine, rises a tenth of an inch to stand, bezel-free, above the case. No other brands, he said, produce this free-standing, faceted edge or use such thick crystals \u2014 the sapphire and the faceting process are too costly.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut profit is not Mr. van der Gang\u2019s primary goal, even though sharing office space and much of its equipment with Exakt allowed the company to begin turning a profit in 2010. The compatibility of the two concerns also allows Mr. van der Gang to produce a relatively affordable high-end watch \u2014 models now are priced from \u20ac5,900 to \u20ac22,000 \u2014 while still meeting his exacting demands.\n\nTo ensure this standard of quality, the company purchases basic Swiss-made movements, then dismantles and rebuilds them to \u201cto create something that doesn\u2019t exist,\u201d explained Roel van den Haak, co-owner of the Amsterdam Watch Company, an official Van der Gang dealer.\n\nVan der Gang creates all the complications, such as chronograph and second time-zone functions, in-house, along with all parts that connect the shaft and movement to the watch itself. Numerals are hand-placed, the cases hand-polished. A complication moon feature, one of Mr. van der Gang\u2019s favorites, shows the actual shape of phases of the moon. \u201cHe invents many of the different functions,\u201d Mr. van den Haak said. \u201cThis is part of what makes him unique.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. van der Gang\u2019s greatest pride, however, are the watch cases, which are carved rather than cast. For the steel Vlieger case, for instance, a block of steel weighing a little more than two pounds is cut down with high-voltage wires until it weighs a bit more than a half an ounce.\n\n\u201cBy milling and turning, we take material away, so you can sculpt it to any shape you want,\u201d Mr. van der Gang said. The same process is used for gold and ceramic cases, resulting in sharp, clean edges, and a modeled underside that fits comfortably against the wrist.\n\nAdditionally, transparent blue sapphire crystal casebacks \u201cshow that the inside is as beautiful as the outside,\u201d said Maaike Borstlap, the company\u2019s marketing director.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. van der Gang is building on his initial success, examining ways to expand his market beyond the Netherlands.\n\nNow, the watches are available only through two Dutch shops, on the company\u2019s websites and by phone order.\n\nStill, Mr. van der Gang has no intention of becoming a mass-market brand. The company employs eight people, two of them watchmakers, and produces 150 watches a year, each made to order. The process usually takes about four months, Mr. van der Gang said, though it can be expedited.\n\nMeantime, Mr. van der Gang is busy developing a perpetual calendar watch, a project he has been working on for several years. It could be produced now, he said, although it\u2019s not as perfect yet as he would like.\n\nBut there\u2019s time.", "title": "Wybe van der Gang Couldn\u2019t Find the Watch He Wanted. So He Built It.", "authors": ["Abigail R. Esman"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWang Qishan is one of the most important figures in Xi\u2019s inner circle, and this position allows him to retain a formal position,\u201d said Wu Qiang, a former lecturer in political science at Tsinghua University in Beijing who now works as an independent researcher.\n\n\u201cEven in the United States, the vice president is usually ceremonial, there just as backup,\u201d Mr. Wu said. \u201cBut Wang Qishan will add substance to the role of vice president. The amendment of the Constitution has raised the status of the presidency, and the vice presidency will also benefit from that.\u201d\n\nParty insiders and experts have said Mr. Xi wants Mr. Wang to act as a counselor, possibly helping to watch economic policy and anticorruption efforts and manage ties with the West, especially with the United States. President Trump has considered placing stiff trade sanctions and investment restrictions on China.\n\nMr. Wang appears likely to \u201cplay a leading role in overseeing U.S.-China relations,\u201d said Ryan Hass, a former director for China at the National Security Council who is now a fellow at the Brookings Institution. Mr. Wang will work alongside Yang Jiechi, the former Chinese Foreign Ministry official who last year was promoted to the Politburo, a council of 25 senior party members, Mr. Hass said.\n\n\u201cWang will operate at a more strategic level, in theory to help keep the relationship from going off of the rails,\u201d Mr. Hass said.\n\nBut Mr. Wang could face a potent rival within the Chinese government for influence over trade policy toward the United States: Liu He, a longtime economic adviser to Mr. Xi who is expected to be named on Monday by the National People\u2019s Congress as one of the country\u2019s four vice premiers.\n\nMr. Wang will bring longstanding bonds with American politicians and business leaders to the task. His ties to Wall Street executives include John L. Thornton, a former president of Goldman Sachs, who last year helped arrange a meeting between Mr. Wang and Stephen K. Bannon, Mr. Trump\u2019s former chief strategist. Mr. Wang also helped to steer trade and investment talks with Washington.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe is the man China\u2019s leaders look to for an understanding of the markets and the global economy,\u201d Henry M. Paulson Jr., who was Treasury secretary under President George W. Bush and knew Mr. Wang well, wrote in 2009. \u201cHe is a Chinese patriot, but he understands the U.S.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Chinese officials have felt frustrated in their attempts to negotiate with Mr. Trump\u2019s White House. There is no sure evidence that Mr. Wang can succeed, especially if Vice President Mike Pence does not emerge as his counterpart to manage tensions, Mr. Hass said.\n\n\u201cTrump really values being the person in the cockpit steering U.S.-China relations,\u201d Mr. Hass said. \u201cSo I think Wang Qishan\u2019s impact on the relationship remains an open question.\u201d\n\nWhile many National People\u2019s Congress delegates welcomed Mr. Wang\u2019s elevation, his election was also a sign of how Mr. Xi has recast political conventions so that he can consolidate power and surround himself with trusted supporters. For five years, from late 2012, Mr. Wang was in charge of the party\u2019s discipline commission, from which he pursued Mr. Xi\u2019s withering drive against corruption and political laxity.\n\nParty sources said last year that Mr. Xi had raised the idea of keeping Mr. Wang in the formal party leadership, which would have bent an unspoken rule that top officials step down if they have reached age 68 when the congress meets to appoint new leadership. Instead, Mr. Wang, now 69, left his party positions at that congress and largely disappeared from public view in the following months.\n\nBut it turned out that Mr. Xi still had plans for him. In January, Mr. Wang was named a delegate to the legislature, a sign that his career was not over.\n\n\u201cI think Wang will play an important role in determining whether Xi succeeds over the next five years and can smoothly make a transition to a third term,\u201d Mr. Wu, the analyst in Beijing, said. \u201cXi thinks there are many challenges still ahead, I believe, so Wang has been kept on as kind of a consultant.\u201d\n\nMr. Xi and Mr. Wang first met about five decades ago during the Cultural Revolution, when they were both sent from Beijing to work as \u201csent down youth\u201d in rural northwest China, a poor and dusty corner of the country. Mr. Wang lived on a commune about 50 miles from Mr. Xi, who has said Mr. Wang stopped by for a night and took away a book on economics.\n\nAfter China began to loosen controls on the economy from the late 1970s, Mr. Wang left his job as a historian in a state institute and became an expert on rural reforms, zipping around Beijing on a Japanese motorbike, then a rare sight in Beijing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Wang accumulated experience in economic policy, and from the 1990s he rose through a series of increasingly senior government jobs, defusing financial messes and getting to know financiers on Wall Street. In 2003 he was made mayor of Beijing to deal with SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, a virus that spread after officials hid the epidemic.\n\nAs deputy premier for five years from 2008, Mr. Wang was a key negotiator in trade and investment talks with the United States. After the global financial crisis erupted, Mr. Wang also took charge of a group of officials assigned with designing China\u2019s response.\n\nBut Mr. Wang is no economic liberal.\n\n\u201cYou were my teacher,\u201d Mr. Wang told Mr. Paulson, the former Treasury secretary recalled in his memoir. \u201cWe aren\u2019t sure we should be learning from you anymore.\u201d", "title": "Xi Starts New Term in China, With Trusted Deputy to Deal With Trump", "authors": ["Chris Buckley"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "HONG KONG \u2014 China\u2019s president, Xi Jinping, has handed the reins of the country\u2019s financial system to a close ally, strengthening his hold over the world\u2019s second-largest economy and sending a clear signal that companies must reduce risky borrowing.\n\nLiu He, an economic adviser to Mr. Xi and previous leaders, was appointed on Monday as vice premier overseeing financial and industrial policy after a ritual vote by China\u2019s legislature, the National People\u2019s Congress. His title comes with greater powers after a move by Mr. Xi to centralize control over the financial sector by consolidating banking and insurance regulators. Mr. Liu\u2019s closeness to Mr. Xi appears likely to enhance his influence.\n\nMr. Liu\u2019s elevation was another step toward cementing Mr. Xi\u2019s control over nearly every facet of Chinese political and economic life. The congress, which is holding its annual meeting in Beijing, voted last week to eliminate a presidential term limit on Mr. Xi, potentially extending his rule deep into the next decade and maybe much longer.\n\nBut Mr. Liu\u2019s appointment also signals that Mr. Xi has grown more serious about fixing a financial system groaning under the weight of a decade-long borrowing spree that has left it riddled with shadowy risks, economists said.", "title": "Xi Taps Harvard-Educated Adviser to Tighten Grip on China\u2019s Economy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "James Galullo, another juror, said he did not understand the outrage that the verdict had inspired on campus, among students who wrote angry opinion pieces for the campus newspaper or took to social media to denounce the outcome.\n\n\u201cI just think it\u2019s lack of experience in the world,\u201d Mr. Galullo, 61, said. \u201cThe jurors were all basically middle-aged. They were able to see their way through all the noise.\u201d\n\nAlexandra Brodsky, a lawyer at the National Women\u2019s Law Center who graduated from Yale College and Yale Law School, said, \u201cSchools have adopted consent as an educational tool, but that sometimes means we end up using words that mean different things in different contexts.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere are many forms of violence that would be condemned on campus, where a prosecutor would have trouble getting a jury to convict,\u201d she added.\n\nBut even college students disagree on the language of consent. A 2015 poll by the Kaiser Family Foundation and The Washington Post found that 47 percent of current and recent college students said that someone undressing themselves signaled agreement to further sexual activity; 49 percent said it did not.\n\nDefense lawyers did not necessarily paint a flattering picture of their client, who acknowledged having sex with the woman, despite the fact that she had been drinking to the point of vomiting several times. He also said that he had called his longtime girlfriend, with whom he had an open relationship, from the complainant\u2019s bedroom.\n\nBut Mr. Khan\u2019s lawyers pressed the woman on the witness stand about messages she had sent inviting Mr. Khan to dinner, or writing \u201clol\u201d \u2014 short for \u201claugh out loud\u201d \u2014 the morning after the alleged assault, when she woke up with bruising on her legs. Norman Pattis, one of the defense lawyers, asked if the messages indicated her interest in Mr. Khan. She replied that she spoke to everyone in that manner.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Pattis also asked about a screenshot that she had sent to Mr. Khan of a Shakespeare sonnet that seemed to imply a romantic interest. She replied that she had been joking; the screenshot was from a popular campus Facebook group, where jokes are often posted.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDan Erwin, who handled jury selection for the defense, said that they had favored \u201colder jurors, 30 to middle-age\u201d because \u201cthere was a seriousness about them insofar as none of them accepted, condoned or denied the existence of misconduct, harassment or assault, but they all seriously engaged with the need for due process.\u201d\n\nThe juror who spoke anonymously said that the panel had not focused on the banter or on Mr. Pattis\u2019s suggestion that the woman\u2019s Halloween costume had been too sexy. Instead, the jurors focused on evidence like security camera footage that showed the complainant and Mr. Khan walking back to her dorm room. The complainant had testified that the footage showed her so drunk that she was unable to support herself, her leg dragging behind her.\n\n\u201cWe looked at and we looked at and we looked at that video of them walking,\u201d the juror said. \u201cWe could not see her leg dragging. We could not see her eyes shut. We could not see what she said.\u201d\n\nMr. Galullo said the rigorous standard of proof required, coupled with the length of Mr. Khan\u2019s possible prison sentence, weighed heavily upon him.\n\n\u201cWe wanted to really be sure that he was guilty,\u201d he said. \u201cThese kids went through a lot. It was really very, very sad. You had tears in your eyes \u2014 for both of them.\u201d\n\nMr. Khan may still face a hearing at Yale. He was suspended by the university shortly before he was arrested and charged, and his lawyers said that Yale\u2019s disciplinary hearing had been delayed pending the criminal trial. That panel would only have to determine that it was \u201cmore likely than not\u201d that he was in the wrong to find him responsible.\n\nMr. Khan\u2019s lawyers are seeking to have him reinstated. A university spokesman declined to confirm or deny the existence of an internal complaint.\n\nSeveral experts agreed that the distance between campus and criminal understandings of permissible sexual conduct may continue to widen, especially as conversations about sex and power continue to evolve.\n\nWhile juries must interpret legal definitions of rape, students and administrators have increasingly sought to define \u201cethical sex,\u201d said Vanessa Grigoriadis, author of a book on campus consent policies and a contributing editor at The New York Times Magazine. Unlike criminal courts, Ms. Grigoriadis said, campus communities are quicker to denounce sexual encounters that are \u201cimmoral but not criminal.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJaclyn Friedman, a consent educator and author, said that in the end, \u201cConsent is not a legalistic construction. It gets translated into law, and should be reflected in our laws, but it is actually a moral value.\u201d", "title": "Yale Rape Verdict Shows How \u2018Yes Means Yes\u2019 Can Be Murkier in Court", "authors": ["Vivian Wang"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "That the trial was happening at all was already noteworthy. Statistics on how many college rape cases go to trial are elusive, but experts agree that the number is exceedingly low; the Department of Justice estimates that between 4 percent and 20 percent of female college students who are raped report the attack to law enforcement.\n\nBut unfolding as it did in the wake of the #MeToo movement and the fierce, unresolved debate over whether campus rape cases are best handled by universities or law enforcement, Mr. Khan\u2019s trial also took on political significance, with defense lawyers accusing Yale of making Mr. Khan a scapegoat for its own poor handling of previous sexual assault claims. Representatives from Families Advocating for Campus Equality, a group that has criticized university hearing processes as skewed in favor of accusers, attended the trial in support of Mr. Khan.\n\nIn an interview after the verdict, Norman Pattis, a lawyer for Mr. Khan, said he had tried to challenge \u201cthe outer limits of the #MeToo movement,\u201d which he called \u201ca form of mass hysteria.\u201d\n\n\u201cSex happens, especially on college campuses,\u201d he said.\n\nAfter a two-week trial, the six-member jury deliberated for about three hours before returning a verdict. In an interview afterward, a juror, Diane Urbano, said the #MeToo movement had not figured in the panel\u2019s decision.\n\n\u201cIt was not part of the case,\u201d she said. \u201cWe put it aside.\u201d\n\nInstead, she said, they considered the evidence. \u201cThere was sufficient doubt on every charge,\u201d she continued. \u201cSo we came to the verdict we did.\u201d\n\nMaura Crossin, executive director of the Victim Rights Center of Connecticut, which, along with the state\u2019s attorney\u2019s office, represented the complainant, declined to comment. A Yale spokesman also declined to comment.\n\nIn a statement after the verdict, Mr. Pattis called on Yale to reinstate Mr. Khan, accusing the university of having rushed to judgment in his suspension. Mr. Khan, a native of Afghanistan, never finished college and has been living with family.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrom the start, the case had promised to be difficult to try. The encounter had unfolded on a raucous, alcohol-fueled evening, across several off-campus and on-campus settings. Text messages between the complainant and Mr. Khan were interspersed with emojis and specific references to Yale\u2019s campus culture, which defense lawyers promoted as proof of flirtation; the complainant said they meant nothing.\n\nOn the night of the alleged assault, the complainant said, she attended an off-campus party with her friends, where she had several drinks \u2014 the first time she had ever been drunk, she said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt a performance by the student orchestra after the party, she was so intoxicated that she lost her friends. In the morning, she was naked, even though she said she remembered lying down fully clothed. She saw used condoms on the floor, and bruising on her legs.\n\nShe visited Yale\u2019s sexual harassment and assault resource center on Nov. 2, where an administrator called the police. Mr. Khan was suspended from Yale on Nov. 9, and officers arrested him on Nov. 12.\n\nMr. Khan, who testified in his own defense, offered a vastly different account of the night, one in which the complainant invited him to her room and took off her own clothes. Her apparent anger the next morning, he said, came as a shock.\n\n\u201cThis was a different demeanor,\u201d Mr. Khan said.\n\nMr. Pattis said there were glaring inconsistencies in the complainant\u2019s story, and that she remembered only the details that bolstered her allegations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhat went on in the room that night made everyone uncomfortable, but it wasn\u2019t a crime,\u201d Mr. Pattis said after the verdict.\n\nThe prosecutor, Michael Pepper, said the gaps in the alleged victim\u2019s memory were proof that she had not made up the assault.\n\n\u201cIf she wanted to do that so bad, put a nail in the coffin, wouldn\u2019t she have given you a more coherent story?\u201d he asked the jury.\n\nThe complainant insisted the same. Weinstock"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nStephanie Wiles, an expert in old masters drawings and a museum leader at Cornell University, will be the next director of the Yale University Art Gallery, the university announced on Wednesday.\n\nShe will succeed Jock Reynolds, who has run the gallery since 1998 but announced last year that he would step down at the end of this June. Ms. Wiles will take up her new post on July 1.\n\n\u201cStephanie shares my vision for integrating the arts into so much of what we do at Yale,\u201d Peter Salovey, Yale\u2019s president, said in a statement. \u201cShe is a respected leader and gifted communicator who understands that the arts can contribute to every aspect of teaching and learning on our campus.\u201d\n\nIn a phone interview, Mr. Salovey said that the transition from Mr. Reynolds\u2019s tenure to that of Ms. Wiles \u201cwill be a smooth one because Stephanie is very much an admirer of what Jock has accomplished \u2014 the two know each other and are admirers of each other \u2014 and Stephanie has been a leader now in a university and college art museum setting.\u201d\n\nAfter getting her Ph.D. in art history from the Graduate Center of the City University of New York in 2001, Ms. Wiles began her career in the department of drawings and prints at the Morgan Library and Museum. She then worked at art museums at Oberlin College and Wesleyan University, before serving as the director of the Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art at Cornell.\n\n\u201cThe formative early years I spent at the Morgan Library taught me the importance of quality, connoisseurship and deep looking,\u201d Ms. Wiles said in a statement. \u201cIt has been a joy to apply this same research and aesthetic expertise to learning about art from other cultures and contemporary arts practice in an academic setting.\u201d\n\nThe Yale Art Gallery is the oldest college art museum in the United States.
