In November, we will rend our garments about the months of early darkness to come when we fall back. In March and November alike, we lament the disruption of our circadian rhythms.\n\nOften, these complaints take the form of calls to eliminate daylight saving time altogether. But Florida wants to move in the opposite direction: permanent daylight saving time.\n\nThe Florida Senate passed the Sunshine Protection Act on Tuesday, three weeks after the state\u2019s House of Representatives, and sent it to Gov. Rick Scott for his signature or veto. (Asked on Wednesday whether Mr. Scott would sign it, and why or why not, his press secretary, Lauren Schenone, said only, \u201cThe governor will review the bill.\u201d) The margins of victory in both chambers were overwhelming \u2014 33 to 2 in the Senate and 103 to 11 in the House \u2014 and the measure has considerable public support.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe problem? Florida doesn\u2019t have the authority to adopt daylight saving time year-round.\n\nThe federal government controls the nation\u2019s time zones, as well as the start and end dates of daylight saving time. States can choose to exempt themselves from daylight saving time \u2014 Arizona and Hawaii do \u2014 but nothing in federal law allows them to exempt themselves from standard time.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n[READ MORE: Why Does Daylight Saving Time Exist?]\n\nAnd so the legislation, H.B. 1013, is written conditionally. \u201cDaylight saving time shall be the year-round standard time of the entire state and all of its political subdivisions,\u201d it says \u2014 if \u201cthe United States Congress amends 15 U.S.C. s. 260a to authorize states to observe daylight saving time year-round.\u201d", "title": "Year-Round Daylight Saving Time? Florida Says Yes, but It\u2019s Not So Simple", "authors": ["Maggie Astor"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "The vaccine, invented in the 1930s, is highly effective \u2014 one dose normally provides lifetime protection. But it is not harmless. It cannot be given to newborns or anyone with a compromised immune system. It is given to people older than 60, pregnant women, or children younger than 8 months only when the risk of infection is high.\n\nAbout one recipient in 100,000 suffers a dangerous reaction like jaundice, hepatitis or encephalitis, Dr. Marques said, and about one in a million dies. \u201cIf you vaccinate 30 million people, you\u2019ll get about 30 deaths,\u201d he said.\n\nBut if yellow fever infected 30 million people, two million could die.\n\nSo, with the disease moving rapidly forward, health authorities announced that they hoped to inoculate 95 percent of the population in 77 cities and towns in the virus\u2019s path \u2014 a total of 23 million people, including 12 million in this city alone.\n\nBut \u201cthey didn\u2019t have 12 million shots to give us,\u201d said Dr. Wilson M. Pollara, S\u00e3o Paulo\u2019s health secretary. \u201cSo we\u2019re doing it in phases \u2014 two million at a time.\u201d\n\nThe global vaccine stockpile, overseen by the World Health Organization, normally contains only six million doses, made by only four manufacturers, including the Cruz foundation.\n\nBut Brazil has scaled up its production to about 5 million doses per month and will soon be able to double that, said Dr. William Perea, the W.H.O.\u2019s epidemic control coordinator.\n\nThat should easily cover Brazil\u2019s needs for now, he said, so the global stockpile will not be drawn down. If necessary, it can be replenished; the four makers together can turn out 100 million doses a year in an emergency, he said.", "title": "Yellow Fever Circles Brazil\u2019s Huge Cities", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNo matter how much cream and honey you pour into your bowl, no matter the raisins or raspberries that dot the top, there will always be something gray and Dickensian about a bowl of morning porridge.\n\nUnless, that is, you add chocolate. Because chocolate oatmeal splits the difference between porridge and pudding: It\u2019s soft; it\u2019s custardy; and it\u2019s profoundly bittersweet.\n\nEven better, since unsweetened cocoa powder is naturally fat-free and full of antioxidants, this is one chocolate breakfast cereal that can be considered healthful \u2014 at least until you start adding on the sugar and cream.\n\nChocolate oatmeal is not something I grew up with \u2014 I only recently stumbled across a mention of it online. That recipe, made with dates and freshly toasted, ground hazelnuts, was fancier and more involved than I wanted for a weekday morning.\n\nPhoto\n\nA much simpler method is to whisk some unsweetened cocoa into your boiling water before adding the oats, then to sweeten the mixture to taste at the end. I like the ratio of one tablespoon cocoa powder to a half-cup steel-cut oats, but you can vary that, making it more or less intensely chocolaty. Dutch-processed cocoa, which has been alkalized to reduce its acidity, will give you a darker chocolate flavor, while natural cocoa powder is a bit brighter and more fruity, so use whatever you have.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn most mornings, I\u2019ll stop there. But sometimes, on the dreariest days, when I know I need something extra special to lure me out of bed, I\u2019ll toast the oats in browned butter before adding them to the pot. That touch of caramelization adds a wonderful, nutty depth.", "title": "Yes, Adults Can Have Chocolate for Breakfast. Really.", "authors": ["Melissa Clark", "A Good Appetite"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "The national security adviser is the person who makes sure the president hears the views of all the national security agencies, including the State Department and the Defense Department, and who drives policy toward a decision. It is hard to see Mr. Bolton acting as an honest broker. He is known to play a ruthless inside game as he maneuvers to win bureaucratic battles and freezes out people he thinks have crossed him. He has been such a lightning rod that he couldn\u2019t get confirmed as United Nations ambassador in 2005, so President George W. Bush gave him a recess appointment, and he stayed in the job about a year. It was considered unlikely that the Senate would confirm him as secretary of state, but the national security adviser job doesn\u2019t require confirmation.\n\nBringing on the fiery Mr. Bolton now, at a delicate moment with North Korea, is a terrible decision. While Mr. Trump has often threatened North Korea with military action, he accepted Mr. Kim\u2019s invitation to a summit meeting, brokered by South Korea\u2019s president, who is eager for a diplomatic solution to the nuclear crisis.\n\nMr. Bolton, by contrast, told Fox News earlier this month that talks would be worthless, and he has called South Korean leaders \u201cputty in North Korea\u2019s hands.\u201d On Feb. 28, he insisted in a Wall Street Journal op-ed article that \u201cit is perfectly legitimate for the United States to respond to the current \u2018necessity\u2019 posed by North Korea\u2019s nuclear weapons by striking first.\u201d Last summer he wrote in The Journal, \u201cThe U.S. should obviously seek South Korea\u2019s agreement (and Japan\u2019s) before using force, but no foreign government, even a close ally, can veto an action to protect Americans from Kim Jong Un\u2019s nuclear weapons.\u201d\n\nOn Iran, Mr. Bolton and the president are in sync, with both arguing that the United States should withdraw from the nuclear agreement by a May deadline. In March 2015, he argued in a New York Times Op-Ed opinion article that only military action like Israel\u2019s 1981 attack on Saddam Hussein\u2019s Osirak reactor in Iraq or its 2007 destruction of a Syrian reactor \u201ccan accomplish what is required.\u201d\n\nGoing to war in either of these cases would not only create unnecessary bloodshed; it would be disastrous for the United States and its allies, South Korea and Japan. The Iran deal has substantially halted the nuclear program and needs to be maintained. Negotiations between the United States and North Korea, given a new impetus by Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim, need to be tested.\n\nMr. Bolton\u2019s position on Russia, that NATO must have a strong response to the Kremlin-linked poisoning of a former Russian spy in Britain, is somewhat better than Mr. Trump\u2019s. But his rejection of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and his endorsement of a book by the anti-Muslim activist Pam Geller are unacceptable positions for a top American official.\n\nMr. Bolton is certain to accelerate American alienation from its allies and the rest of the world. Congress may not be able to stop his appointment, but it should speak out against it and reassert its responsibilities under the Constitution to authorize when the nation goes to war.", "title": "Opinion | Yes, John Bolton Really Is That Dangerous", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cEven though it\u2019s damaged, it still feels right for my body,\u201d Mr. Jaffe said of his tuba, which he could not resist playing a bit before sending it in for repairs. \u201cIt felt like a reunion.\u201d\n\nThat the massive brass instruments are even a target of theft might seem strange, given their unwieldy nature. In 2011, The Los Angeles Times reported that thieves were taking them from Southern California high schools.\n\nTony White, the coordinator of music and entertainment education at the Los Angeles Unified School District, said that roughly a dozen were stolen from three area high schools around that time. Another high school, at which he had once been band director, had also had a dozen tubas disappear over a decade, he added.\n\nThe schools never got them back; Mr. White speculates it\u2019s because some were taken to Mexico, where banda music \u2014 which features the tuba \u2014 is popular. Others may have been melted down for their metal. And a few of the thieves may have learned to play them as a part-time job.\n\n\u201cThere must be a black market out there that\u2019s encouraging people to do this,\u201d Mr. White said. \u201cThey\u2019re not giving them to a pawnshop. It\u2019s hard to hide an instrument of that size.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nStill, about a year ago, a high-end tuba was stolen out of a car in Minneapolis and taken to Woodbury, a suburb about 20 miles away, where the thief tried to sell it to two different music stores. A new tuba can cost anywhere from $3,500 to $8,000 \u2014 or more, experts said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s an expensive item they hope to turn around quickly for cash,\u201d Chief Lee Vague of the Woodbury Police Department said, calling it a \u201ccrime of opportunity.\u201d\n\nA quick-thinking employee at one of the music stores thought it odd that a person had been trying to offload an expensive tuba that the person didn\u2019t seem to know much about. So he told the second store, which had already purchased it. The police eventually got the thief to confess to the heist after the person had been arrested on something unrelated, Chief Vague said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not a great idea for a criminal enterprise,\u201d the chief said of stealing tubas.\n\nThey are a \u201cunique item that\u2019s highly traceable,\u201d he added, one that musicians often band together to search for.\n\nThat\u2019s essentially what happened in Mr. Jaffe\u2019s case. After filing a police report, the band turned to social media and put out an announcement about the missing tuba that \u201ccaught fire\u201d and turned into a \u201ccitywide campaign to recover the instrument,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cEverybody in New Orleans knows a musician,\u201d Mr. Jaffe noted, which was why he was confident he\u2019d get the tuba back.\n\nAfter it undergoes repairs, he said, he\u2019ll put the black letters back on the instrument, spelling out \u201cPRESERVATION HALL NEW ORLEANS.\u201d\n\nMr. Jaffe said he might put a tracking device on it, too.", "title": "Yes, People Actually Steal Tubas. Sometimes They Even Return Them.", "authors": ["Matt Stevens"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "One of the perplexing questions of constitutional law is what to do about a sitting president who is suspected of having committed a crime. This much is clear: A sitting president should not be required to submit to a criminal trial, an undertaking that would be incompatible with the duties of the nation\u2019s chief executive.\n\nThat should not, however, preclude a grand jury from indicting a president when the facts and the law warrant, even if the trial itself has to be postponed until he or she is no longer in office.\n\nAn indictment in this context serves a critically important purpose: Without it, the usual five-year statute of limitations for most federal crimes would elapse, forever precluding a president from being held accountable for potentially serious crimes. Thus, a president should be indictable unless he agrees to waive any future defense that the statute of limitations expired during the president\u2019s term.\n\nThere is nothing in the constitutional text or judicial precedent that provides for a categorical bar to the indictment of a sitting president. The closest the Supreme Court has come to addressing the question was in Clinton v. Jones in 1997, in which the issue was whether a president could delay until the end of his term a civil suit by a private individual. I argued Clinton v. Jones for the United States, urging the court to hold that a civil trial would unduly impair a president\u2019s ability to carry out his duties. The court unanimously rejected that position.", "title": "Opinion | Yes, You Can Indict the President", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "In 2012, an opportunity came her way. The Rijksmuseum trustees announced Rijksstudio, a program that involved photographing hundreds of thousands of artworks and putting the free images online.\n\nWith a vast collection now in the public domain, Ms. Hofman saw a chance to get playful. As the museum leadership organized competitions to encourage people to make products based on the Rijksmuseum\u2019s collection, she began stocking the works of contest winners. She also initiated a series of partnerships with local corporations so that they might use the images for new types of merchandise.\n\nToday, when visitors enter the shop, they\u2019ll find action figures by the German toy manufacturer Playmobil based on \u201cThe Milkmaid\u201d and on Rembrandt\u2019s \u201cThe Night Watch.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSilk frocks by the Dutch fashion brand LaDress, printed with museum imagery, are available by special order.\n\nThe shop even has syrups, marmalades and jellies made from ingredients depicted in classic artworks. For about six euros ($7.40) one can take home a jar of chutney based on Martinus Nellius\u2019s \u201cStill Life With Quinces, Medlars and a Glass.\u201d\n\n\u201cMuseum shops are no longer just about selling things \u2014 they are about adding a new step to the museum experience,\u201d said Diane Drubay, the chief executive of We Are Museums, a European consultancy that advises museums worldwide on marketing.\n\nAs the stores become more experimental, Ms. Drubay noted, they are evolving \u2014 as the Rijksmuseum shop has \u2014 into destinations unto themselves. \u201cIn many places,\u201d she said, \u201cthey are a point of entry to the museum. Instead of being the last place people go after a visit, it can be the first.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne retail experiment Ms. Drubay considers emblematic of this new trend is the annex shop of the Mus\u00e9e National Picasso-Paris in Paris. This shop is not in the museum itself, but occupies a four-room apartment across the street at 4 Rue de Thorigny.\n\nIt sells books about the artist and objects made in his style. The shop is a kind of Picasso-world, selling gifts and decorative items \u2014 the kinds of things he might have owned. There\u2019s a bin of hand-carved masks from West Africa, for example.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe shop itself is decorated to reflect the style of an actual Parisian flat in which Picasso once lived. In fact, the store\u2019s designers purchased chairs and decorations similar to those in photographs of the artist\u2019s home.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s designed like a living room and it\u2019s just like going to a friend\u2019s place,\u201d Ms. Drubay said. \u201cYou have this intimate and cozy feeling and you have a feeling that you can imagine an object in your home. I remember beautiful vases and coffee cups.\u201d\n\nIn some places, museum shops are playing a new role by filling a space abandoned by commercial vendors. In New York City, where high rents have made dedicated gift and design stores somewhat of a rarity, the shop of the Museum of Modern Art on West 53rd Street is the go-to place for high-concept tableware, furniture, lighting, jewelry and clothing.\n\nEvery piece offered has been approved by the museum\u2019s curatorial staff, and some of what is sold is in the MoMA permanent collection. This is where you can find an Eames chaise, an Issey Miyake scarf or a Salvador Dal\u00ed-style cuckoo clock.\n\nPhoto\n\nUptown, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art\u2019s 15,000-square-foot bookstore and gift shop, the offerings tend to echo what\u2019s being shown at the museum.\n\nDuring last winter\u2019s Michelangelo exhibit, a $185 bangle bracelet imprinted with his sketch of the Libyan Sibyl, a female figure on the Sistine Chapel ceiling in Rome, was a huge seller.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the Met shop, merchandise has often been specifically created for the store \u2014 the silk scarves styled from patterns of the pottery collection, the bracelets reproducing ancient Roman and Greek pieces, a clutch purse based on a 14th-century silk and wool tapestry.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThese are souvenirs, yes. But classy ones.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve done surveys and about a third of the people who come to the museum say that they plan to shop here,\u201d said Rich Pedott, the museum\u2019s vice president of merchandising. \u201cThey\u2019ve said they want to buy something that\u2019s a tangible memory of their visit. Part of our goal always is to give them something they couldn\u2019t get elsewhere.\u201d\n\nThe shop offers the usual art books and posters, but it\u2019s the impresive gallery on the mezzanine that sells original photography, Oriental rugs and limited edition lithographs and prints. Original pieces by Jim Dine, William Wegman and David Hockney can be purchased there. Last winter, when the museum staged a Hockney retrospective, the shop had vintage hand-signed prints by the artist for between $6,000 and $40,000 each.\n\nWhy would a collector spend that kind of money at the Met and not at a commercial art gallery?\n\n\u201cBecause they know they can trust us,\u201d said Michael Hladky, Special Collections buyer for the gallery. \u201cEverything we sell is vetted.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOn the other hand, there\u2019s at least one museum shop selling a line of merchandise that\u2019s not at all material. At the Walker Shop of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis they\u2019ve been offering \u201cIntangibles,\u201d which are described as an \u201conline collection of art objects that have no physical form.\u201d\n\nIn other words, the concept here is conceptual art.\n\nFor $5.99, a writer named Claire L. Evans will send out a PDF summary of \u201ctoday\u2019s most important science fiction visions.\u201d A hearty seller has been \u201cThe Closer,\u201d a performance piece where for $150, a buyer and a performer interact with each other for 15 minutes in a public space; $100 will buy 25 disappearing Snapchat rounds with \u201cfamed American photographer Alec Soth.\u201d\n\nMr. Soth\u2019s Intangible is no longer available. It has sold out.\n\nChristine Teel, who manages the Walker Shop, said that the idea behind \u201cIntangibles\u201d originated with her predecessors. \u201cThe concept is extremely creative,\u201d she said. \u201cThey wanted to do something outside of the box. It\u2019s the opposite of tangible books \u2026 it\u2019s more experiential than taking away a tangible product.\u201d\n\nHas the \u201cIntangibles\u201d line provided income for the Walker? After all, one purpose of most museum retailers is to provide additional funds for their institution\u2019s operating budget. In a time of uncertain government funding and sometimes declining admissions receipts, the museum shop can be a valuable revenue source.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t say that revenue was the focus of it,\u201d said Ms. Teel, adding that there were a lot of benefits to doing it. \u201cIt was something no one had done before. I always think that\u2019s good. It gave the Walker some wonderful press. When I look at \u2018Intangibles,\u2019 I really applaud it, conceptually.\u201d", "title": "You Can Take It With You, and Museums Hope You Will", "authors": ["Claudia Dreifus"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "The reasons Douglass offered in support of this conclusion reveal that unlike most libertarian thinkers, he did not accept the idea that human beings are free insofar as they are able to act without unjust interference of others. This is what philosophers like to call \u201cfreedom as noninterference,\u201d and it is at the foundation of most libertarian theories of justice. While Douglass certainly believed that it was important to protect individuals from unjust interference, he did not believe this was sufficient to make human beings free.\n\nIn the context of the post-Civil War United States, Douglass explained, negative liberty was not enough because of the significant differences in power between former slaves and their former masters. The \u201cold master class\u201d had not lost \u201cthe power of life and death\u201d over the human beings it used to claim as property, he said, because it \u201cretained the power to starve them to death.\u201d \u201cYou shall serve me,\u201d the former master was still able to say to the former slave, \u201cor starve.\u201d This was slavery by another name.\n\nIt should be clear by now that the alternative theory of liberty defended by Douglass, which philosophers often call \u201cfreedom as non-domination,\u201d poses serious problems for those wishing to defend the idea that he was a libertarian. What makes libertarians uncomfortable about \u201cfreedom as non-domination\u201d is that it opens the door to the idea that the state may have an important role to play in counteracting the power of economic elites, who left unchecked might use their power to dominate others.\n\nBut let\u2019s step down out of the clouds of theory to see the practical implications of Douglass\u2019s view. Recall that in his libertarian reading, Sandefur argues that Douglass \u201cnever joined in efforts by some leaders, including Charles Sumner, to confiscate plantation land and divide it among the former slaves.\u201d Douglass \u201cwas too well versed in the history and theory of freedom,\u201d Sandefur explains, \u201cnot to know that destabilizing property rights in such a way would in the long run harm the freedmen more.\u201d\n\nSandefur is right that in the immediate aftermath of the Civil War, Douglass did not join with Sumner and the other Radical Republicans in their call for confiscation and redistribution. Perhaps Sandefur is also right that Douglass\u2019s \u201ctheory of freedom\u201d led him to reject this path in those years. What Sandefur does not tell us, though, is that Douglass changed his mind.\n\nIn the 1880 Emancipation Day speech, Douglass said the threat to liberty presented by economic inequality was \u201cseen and felt by Thaddeus Stevens, Charles Sumner, and leading stalwart Republicans, and had their counsels prevailed, the terrible evils from which we now suffer would have been averted.\u201d It is hard to imagine Douglass stating this more clearly. By 1880, he was looking back and saying, they were right, I was wrong. His \u201ctheory of freedom\u201d had evolved.\n\nIt is worth noting that Douglass himself considered his 1880 Emancipation Day speech to be among his most important. We know this because when it came time to choose two speeches to include as appendices for his 1881 autobiography, \u201cThe Life and Times of Frederick Douglass,\u201d he chose it and his famous \u201cFreedmen\u2019s Memorial Speech\u201d about Abraham Lincoln. This speech mattered a lot to Douglass and it ought to matter to those of us who want to tell the truth about his legacy.", "title": "Opinion | You Can\u2019t Put Frederick Douglass in Chains", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Said Wright: \u201cWhen you realize you\u2019ve made it through the final eight and you\u2019re going to go, you just feel so blessed. You think, why me? You know there\u2019s a lot of great teams out there, a lot of great programs. At this point, you don\u2019t really try to figure out why. You\u2019re just soaking it in.\u201d\n\nFather Hagan\u2019s approach to support, he said, is just to be there to listen. As an associate athletic director, and a priest of the Order of St. Augustine, he lives on campus and travels with the basketball team, for which he customarily delivers a pregame prayer. But he also serves as a counselor and confidant, building relationships that have lasted well beyond the basketball court. He recently performed the wedding of the former Wildcats star Randy Foye, and has baptized the children of other former players.\n\n\u201cThey have a million people telling them what to do,\u201d Hagan said. \u201cSometimes it\u2019s nice to just be the person that gets to listen.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Sunday, Father Hagan\u2019s pregame prayer focused on humility, a theme he has repeated with the team all season. \u201cDon\u2019t drink the perfume,\u201d he said. \u201cYou don\u2019t get too high when things are going well, and you don\u2019t get too low when things aren\u2019t going so great.\u201d Several players echoed the message in their postgame interviews.\n\nFather Hagan attended Villanova and went on to law school at Widener University in nearby Chester, Pa., before serving as a lawyer for seven years. But after leaving his career to become ordained as an Augustinian in 2003, he joined the Villanova athletics department to work on compliance matters (university officials thought his law degree would help.) In 2004, he replaced the longtime basketball and football team chaplain, Rev. Bernard Lazor, who retired.\n\nAs far as Sister Jean, Father Hagan laughed at the idea of any rivalry between the spiritual leaders of teams that could ultimately meet for a national title. On the contrary, he said he loved the attention Sister Jean was bringing to her faith and her mission.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s brought a lot of awareness and enthusiasm to Loyola and to the order of the B.V.M. sisters, the work that they do, the mission, the people they serve,\u201d he said, referring to the Sisters of the Charity of the Blessed Virgin Mary. \u201cI couldn\u2019t be happier for her and her order. It\u2019s really great to see.\u201d\n\nFather Hagan does, however, have one thing he can brag about: Unlike Sister Jean, who only had her Ramblers reaching the round of 16, Father Hagan had a bit more faith in Villanova.\n\n\u201cI picked these guys all the way,\u201d he said. \u201cEvery year.\u201d", "title": "You Know Sister Jean. Meet Father Rob.", "authors": ["Zach Schonbrun"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Dogs, it seems, can inhabit very different moral habitats within the human mind and within our cultural frameworks. Extreme value, both monetary and emotional, is placed on certain individual dogs, while an entire underclass of dogs are treated as objects, as means to an end, as cogs in the wheels of human commerce and moneymaking.\n\nThe exploitation of the canine underclass is perhaps the most insidious problem with cloning. But there are other things to worry about. Two of the nation\u2019s most prominent animal advocacy organizations, the Humane Society of the United States and People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, have come out against cloning pets. They have profound concerns about the welfare of the animals involved in cloning research, but they also point out that millions of dogs are languishing in shelters, waiting for a home and often facing early death by euthanasia. We collectively, as a pet-obsessed culture, are responsible for their situation. And yet we can feel O.K. about spending tens of thousands of dollars and tremendous energy and resources to produce cloned puppies? (Ms. Streisand also adopted a rescue dog after Samantha\u2019s death.)\n\nThe moral admonition to \u201cadopt, don\u2019t shop\u201d is not only about saving the life of a homeless dog but also about moving past shaky and unsubstantiated assertions that certain dogs, usually the so-called purebreds, are somehow smarter, more athletic, more beautiful and better behaved than mongrels, and that by spending loads of money on a dog, we\u2019re going to get exactly what we want and expect. None of this is true.\n\nCloning is symptomatic of deeper problems in how our culture thinks about pet dogs. It reinforces the status of dogs as things to buy and collect, and as sentimental tokens and emotional support objects. Dogs are valued for our feelings toward them, rather than for who they are as individuals.\n\nIn 2016, a cloning company sought to partner with an animal hospice and palliative care organization on whose board I serve. We declined. Veterinary practices providing end-of-life care are an an obvious market for pet cloning services, since these veterinarians serve clients who are staring into the abyss of loss. Veterinarians might, these companies suggest, offer DNA banking or cloning to help soften a pet owner\u2019s grief, to create an emotional bridge that might help a dog owner \u201clet go\u201d so that a dog isn\u2019t made to suffer at the end of life by a distraught human trying to prolong the relationship.", "title": "Opinion | You Love Dogs? Then Don\u2019t Clone Them", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "As a general rule, convertible car seats tend to have a 10-year life span whereas infant seats last about six years. Check the registration card you received upon purchase or the seat itself to find your seat\u2019s expiration date. And when you get a new car seat, fill out the registration card and save a picture of it on your phone so it is easy to check in case of a recall.\n\nAs technology in both cars and car seats advances, older seats may not meet current standards, be well suited for current cars or protect as thoroughly as current car seat models.\n\n\u201cPeople don\u2019t hesitate or bat an eye to spend hundreds of dollars on a telephone that they switch out every two years, and yet they want to hang on to an old car seat?\u201d said Lorrie Walker, child passenger safety training manager and technical adviser for the Buckle Up program at Safe Kids Worldwide.\n\nIf you\u2019ve been in a serious car crash, dispose of your car seat\n\nAny car seat that has been involved in a moderate or serious accident should be discarded because damage to the product could weaken its future performance. The N.H.T.S.A. says you can keep using a car seat if it was in a minor crash \u2014 one in which you were able to drive the car away from the crash site; the airbags did not deploy; the door nearest the car seat was not damaged; there were no injuries to passengers and there was no visible damage to the car seat.\n\nWhen your car seat\u2019s time is up, dispose of it by removing the fabric cover and cutting the straps to render it useless to anyone else.\n\nUse the top tether\n\nAll forward-facing car seats (with the exception of booster seats) have a tether strap that connects the top of the car seat to an additional anchor point in the vehicle. \u201cToday every car has at least three tether anchors in it. Some have five,\u201d Ms. Walker said. The tether reduces how far forward a child can move during a crash. But many parents forget to use the top tether, she said.", "title": "You May Be Using Your Child\u2019s Car Seat Incorrectly", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "One reader compared my journey to that of Lida Moser, an American photographer who traversed Quebec in 1950 for Vogue and Look magazines, armed with a camera and a desire to capture its multiple identities. That is something to aspire to! I have a similar goal in mind, only my journey will be adapted to the digital age, and I will be armed with my iPhone and my Facebook, Instagram and Twitter accounts.\n\nReaders\u2019 advice was eclectic but also suffused with the nostalgia of people who had previously visited Quebec or lived there. One place that came up repeatedly was the hilly region of Charlevoix, which will play host to a meeting of the Group of 7 industrialized nations. Another suggestion was to visit Little Burgundy in Montreal, an area that has played an important role in the city\u2019s vibrant jazz scene, stretching back to the 1920s.\n\nPhoto\n\nAlas, I am constrained by time and won\u2019t be able to venture 860 miles from Montreal to the picturesque \u00celes de la Madeleine, where I hope to sample the famed lobster at another time \u2014 hopefully soon.\n\nSeveral readers stressed the importance of gender balance in whom I meet, and so I have sought out more leading women in the province. As part of my trip, I now plan to meet in Montreal with Phyllis Lambert, at 91 years old, an architect, civic leader and philanthropist known as Montreal\u2019s \u201cJoan of Architecture.\u201d\n\nMrs. Lambert famously persuaded her father, Samuel Bronfman, head of the Seagram distiller, to commission Ludwig Mies van der Rohe to build the towering Seagram headquarters in New York in the 1950s, which became an important symbol of modernism.\n\nI have also added Louise Penny, the Canadian detective novelist and a popular request by readers, to my list of interesting cultural figures I should meet.\n\nMs. Penny\u2019s Armand Gamache series features a retired homicide chief and is set in Three Pines, a community inspired by Ms. Penny\u2019s village, Knowlton, in Quebec\u2019s eastern townships, where eccentric neighbors grapple with snow and, sometimes, murder. I will be traveling to Knowlton to inquire about, among other things, the extent to which art imitates life.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Canada Letter Every week, receive a handpicked selection of news and opinion plus exclusive commentary from New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSeveral people suggested that I visit a sugar shack and sample some maple syrup, a decidedly Qu\u00e9b\u00e9cois activity. With that in mind, I am planning to make a pilgrimage to Martin Picard\u2019s Cabane A Sucre Au Pied De Cochon, in Mirabel, outside Montreal. There, Mr. Picard conjures dishes inspired by maple syrup, all washed down, of course, with a good Burgundy wine. I have been hitting the gym in preparation for enjoying his delicacies, like foie gras cake.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn getting ready for my trip, I decided to explore whether the cultural divisions between English and French Canadians \u2014 referred to as \u201cThe Two Solitudes\u201d \u2014 still existed in Montreal in 2018, some 28 years after I left Quebec, my birthplace.\n\nOne of the first things I noticed upon my return was that the old hang-ups of the past appeared to have been largely discarded by many among the younger generation. It seemed that 20-somethings across the city, while politically engaged, seemed more intent on becoming the next Qu\u00e9b\u00e9cois Steve Jobs than in fomenting revolution.\n\nPhoto\n\nYet, there were still points of separation, including divisions over language and popular culture. Some people I\u2019ve talked to warned that the proliferation of English among the younger generation, fanned by social media, threatened the future of the French language in Quebec.\n\nI also wrote about the still powerful cultural pull of Leonard Cohen in an article about Cohen mania in Montreal.\n\nMore than a year after his death, the poet and singer-song writer has become an almost sacred figure in his hometown, where people across the cultural divide adore the lyricism of his music and the poetry of his words, which were nourished by Quebec\u2019s multiple identities. One reader noted on Twitter that there was a neighborhood in Montreal called Saint-Leonard.\n\nOn Monday I hit the road! Please keep those emails coming with your suggestions for the trip and for music for my playlist. Follow me on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter, as well as on The Times\u2019s Reader Center, where I will be posting dispatches of my journey.\n\nIt\u2019s time to start this adventure!\n\nRead: In Montreal, a Berlin Wall of the Mind?\n\nRead: Is Leonard Cohen the New Secular Saint of Montreal?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTrans Canada\n\n\u2014President Trump\u2019s steep steel tariff was suspended for Canada but his move has soured many in Sault Ste. Our Quebec Road Trip Takes Shape: The Canada Letter", "authors": ["Ian Austen"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Mascara, I love the Sisley So Curl and the IT Cosmetics one that comes in a long tube \u2014 it\u2019s called Superhero. I use a lot of Nars. I\u2019ve been friends with Fran\u00e7ois Nars since my modeling years. I\u2019ve been to his island in Tahiti. Actually our birthdays are just one or two days apart, and we\u2019ve had birthday parties there together. I\u2019ve been using his Radiant Creamy Concealer and Orgasm Liquid Blush. The Cruella Velvet Matte Lip Pencil is one of my staples.\n\nI also used to work with Kevyn Aucoin. He came to me one day and said he would do every one of my amfAR appearances, and that\u2019s how we met. His birthday was on Valentine\u2019s Day, and I always think of him then. I wore the Kevyn Aucoin Molten Liquid Lipstick, a metallic high-shine gloss, on \u201cConan\u201d the other day.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI just got a beautiful new lip balm and lip powder duo from Chanel. I also use the Sarafine Liquid Lipstick by Anastasia. She really knows how to make lipstick stay put. I had it on on New Year\u2019s Eve, and I got this surprise super-fabulous kiss at midnight, and he did not walk away wearing my lipstick.\n\nI have one drawer with all my road bags. In my makeup road bag, I always have my Benefit black eye pencil. It\u2019s kohl with a smudge stick at one end; it\u2019s almost a nub now. And I have my Tweezerman and these little Colgate Wisp toothbrushes so I can brush my teeth at lunch when I\u2019m on the job.\n\nIf I\u2019m going out, I like false lashes by Red Cherry. I learned to do them myself just this year. Once you get it, it\u2019s not that hard, but you have to devote one several-hour block to figuring it out. It\u2019s really about relaxing while you do it, and you have to learn to cut them to fit your eyes. I measure them from the center of my pupil to the end of my eye, and I cut off the bigger end. I curl my lashes; I put on a light coat of mascara and a little eye pencil as close as I can to my lashes and then smudge it a bit. Then I lay the lashes on by looking directly into a magnifier mirror.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen you put the glue on, put it on the outer edge where it curls, not just on the ridge. Also, you want to blow on the glue for, like, two seconds before you set it on the skin at the top of your lashes. I use only Duo lash glue in black. And make sure your pointer finger and thumb are really dry so that when you squeeze the lashes down onto the lid and then roll your finger off, it doesn\u2019t pull the lashes with it.\n\nFragrance\n\nWhen I put on some fragrance, I like Chanel No. 5 or Kai. There\u2019s also this perfume Dange-Rose by Blumarine that\u2019s great.\n\nHair\n\nI cut my own hair. The first time was when I was with a French hairdresser years and years ago, and I had long hair. He said pull all your hair up and then just cut off the ends and you\u2019ll have all the layers you want. Every once in a while, when I get a haircut from someone else, hairdressers will complain, \u201cWho did this haircut?\u201d But the truth is no one ever likes someone else\u2019s cut.\n\nMy color is done by Kacey Welch. I love her because she\u2019s really good and really fast, and she\u2019s cool.\n\nMy hair road bag is always changing. I use Davines Nourishing Shampoo and Replumping Conditioner from its Naturaltech line. Right now, I like KMS Hairplay Playable Texture. It\u2019s weightless. And I always carry a brushable hair spray \u2014 the Sebastian one at the moment. There\u2019s also a dry shampoo by Klorane, and I have Bullfrog Molding Paste.\n\nOther Services\n\nI love to get massages when I can find the time, but I have three kids. We just remodeled our house, though, and the boys and I all got steam in our showers. It\u2019s really great.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDiet and Fitness\n\nI don\u2019t eat processed food. I don\u2019t drink caffeine, and very rarely will have a soda or alcohol. But I eat meat and dark chocolate. I sugar my tea if I feel like it. I have celiac disease, so I don\u2019t eat gluten. Otherwise, I just eat like a person \u2014 whatever I\u2019m hungry for.\n\nI do Pilates \u2014 I have a machine in my house. Or I go to a gym and circuit train depending on what mood I\u2019m in. Or I might put on music and dance my brains out. I\u2019m not the person who will get on a treadmill and stare at a wall.\n\nAlso, for me, it\u2019s more about real inner beauty. It\u2019s important to have a philosophy or way of life or faith that keeps you balanced. For me, that has been Buddhism. It\u2019s something that brings you back to center, and is really the key to serenity and beauty \u2014 an internal sense of form and elegance.", "title": "You Won\u2019t Look Like Sharon Stone at 59", "authors": ["Bee Shapiro", "Skin Deep"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Infowars, the conspiracy theory outlet headed by Alex Jones, said Tuesday that it had received a second strike in two weeks, both for videos about the Parkland shooting. (Infowars, which has more than 2.2 million YouTube subscribers, later said the second strike had been removed.) Infowars\u2019 Washington bureau chief, Jerome Corsi, said on Twitter that his YouTube channel had been terminated without notice or explanation.\n\nNews outlets including The Outline and Breitbart have pointed to more than a dozen other right-wing or right-leaning accounts that have been disciplined, claiming they have either received strikes or been banned outright in the past several weeks.\n\nThey include the violent neo-Nazi group Atomwaffen (banned for hate speech) and the YouTube star Carl Benjamin, known by his username Sargon of Akkad, who criticizes feminism and identity politics. Mr. Benjamin posted a screenshot on Facebook on Thursday that said he had been locked out of his Google account because \u201cit looked like it was being used in a way that violated Google\u2019s policies.\u201d\n\nYouTube said it was not aware of any prominent accounts that had falsely reported strikes, though it did say that Mr. Benjamin had violated its policy on copyright infringement.\n\nYouTube denied that the deletions and other actions were ideologically driven. It said accounts that had been disciplined or banned were only the most prominent, and vocal, of many across the ideological spectrum who had seen their videos taken down for violating the site\u2019s rules.\n\nBut critics said YouTube was reacting haphazardly in an attempt to purge actors who have garnered it negative attention. They questioned whether the site was prepared to substantively address the problem of the conspiracy theories that flourish on its platform.\n\nAnd some of the right-wing YouTube stars and conspiracists who were affected saw the disciplinary action as a result of what they say is left-wing ideology flourishing inside Google, of which YouTube is a subsidiary. Mr. Benjamin told Breitbart that the company was \u201criddled with a far-left ideological orthodoxy that has taken hold to a radical degree.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA YouTube spokeswoman said in a statement that its \u201creviewers remove content according to our policies, not according to politics or ideology, and we use quality control measures to ensure they are applying our policies without bias.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe company is in the middle of hiring a large influx of moderators, and it attributed some of its recent enforcement actions to a group who are still learning to apply its rules.\n\n\n\n\u201cWith the volume of videos on our platform, sometimes we make mistakes and when this is brought to our attention we reinstate videos or channels that were incorrectly removed,\u201d the company\u2019s statement said.\n\nThe moderation efforts of YouTube, like those of Facebook and Twitter, have begun to receive more attention in the last year as academics and journalists have focused on how misinformation \u2014 like that sown by Russia during the 2016 presidential election \u2014 is spread.\n\nIn a December blog post, YouTube announced it would add many people to its work force in 2018, hoping eventually to have 10,000 working to moderate or otherwise address content that has violated its rules.\n\nThe company is in the process of hiring many of those people. A spokeswoman said that applying the company\u2019s standards to any given video required training, and that new moderators were bound to make some mistakes. It said that some of the strikes that had been handed out since the Parkland shooting had been mistaken, though it did not specify which.\n\nJonathan Albright, the research director of the Tow Center for Digital Journalism and an expert on how misinformation thrives on social media, said YouTube has long been inconsistent in its enforcement of its guidelines.\n\n\u201cIf these accounts are getting deleted at the last minute because people are angry and news organizations are digging into this, should these accounts have existed in the first place?\u201d he asked.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNegative news media attention results in more users flagging videos of right-wing conspiracy theorists, leading to a feedback loop in which channels promoting those views are disciplined. The effect is that its disciplinary process is reactive, and relies on users to flag content they find troublesome.\n\nA YouTube spokeswoman said the company planned to release a transparency report in the spring that it says will show the full range of videos that have been taken down.\n\nZack Exley, a left-wing populist who runs the YouTube channel Left Right Forward, said that the bans of high-profile right-wing accounts may do more harm than good by building up the reputations of extremists among their bases.\n\n\u201cThe extreme right loves being censored,\u201d he said. \u201cThey become heroes and raise tons of money every time YouTube removes or demonetizes their videos.\u201d\n\nYouTube does not police misinformation, which, on its own, does not violate the site\u2019s guidelines. But the company says it is confident that, with its steep increase in moderators and progress in machine learning, it will be capable of enforcing its rules effectively, which will help stem the tide of objectionable videos.\n\nMr. Albright said that hiring many more people would help. But he said that those people would have to be trained to address difficult situations, applying the platform\u2019s rules to nuanced videos in which the right decision was not always clear.\n\n\u201cIt would take a group of people specifically trained in this kind of situation,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s a problem of scale. This stuff doesn\u2019t scale like algorithms. Humans don\u2019t scale.\u201d\n\n\u201cYouTube isn\u2019t in a \u2018too big to fail\u2019 situation,\u201d he added. \u201cBut they\u2019re potentially too big to moderate.\u201d", "title": "YouTube Cracks Down on Far-Right Videos as Conspiracy Theories Spread", "authors": ["Jonah Engel Bromwich"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Away from the conference stage, the responses were anything but gentle.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m genuinely curious whether YouTube management is a bunch of Pollyannas who have never watched the videos on their platforms, or a bunch of people who just don\u2019t care,\u201d Renee DiResta, a researcher and expert in online disinformation, tweeted.\n\nJustin Brookman, the director for consumer privacy and technology policy at Consumers Union, called the plan \u201ca disingenuous cop-out that will make Wikipedia\u2019s job harder.\u201d\n\nOthers noted what seemed like an obvious point: Can\u2019t anyone edit Wikipedia, including the conspiracy theorists themselves?\n\nFrom the Wikimedia Foundation, which oversees Wikipedia, the first response was confusion.\n\nYouTube is doing what?\n\nKatherine Maher, the executive director of the Wikimedia Foundation, sounded as if she wouldn\u2019t have minded a heads up. \u201cWhen the announcement came out, we were surprised that we hadn\u2019t been contacted,\u201d Ms. Maher said in an interview.\n\nShe had learned about YouTube\u2019s plans at the same time as everyone else \u2014 including Wikipedia\u2019s army of volunteer contributors, some of whom were not pleased with the idea that an internet colossus had casually declared that it would outsource one of its knottiest problems to a relatively small nonprofit organization.\n\n\u201cWikipedia is not something that just exists,\u201d Ms. Maher said. \u201cIt takes work and it requires labor.\u201d\n\nA Wikipedia editor who goes by the handle SEMMENDINGER shared a concern on a contributor discussion page, writing, \u201cMy worry is that the people viewing these sorts of videos in the first place are the same people who wholeheartedly are in agreement with the content.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother editor, Doc James, was more sanguine. \u201cI do not imagine many problems,\u201d he said. \u201cWe have lots of policies to help support those who come with good references and rebuff those without.\u201d\n\nYouTube\u2019s announcement might be chalked up to an unintentional miscommunication or a public relations misstep. But for Wikipedia, it was part of a familiar pattern.\n\nA cross between a piece of infrastructure, a public commons and an online community, Wikipedia has been a boon to some of the largest companies in the world since it started nearly two decades ago. Whatever benefit Google hopes to get from using the online encyclopedia to fact-check YouTube videos is likely to pale in comparison with the value it receives from including Wikipedia entries in its search results.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nGoogle\u2019s \u201cKnowledge Graph,\u201d which displays certain answers to search queries in separate, authoritative-looking boxes on the right side of a computer screen, draws heavily from Wikipedia. Furthermore, virtually every voice assistant, including Amazon\u2019s Echo and Apple\u2019s Siri, uses the site to give customers a wide range of answers to their questions.\n\nWikipedia has also proved invaluable to tech companies as they develop artificial intelligence and translation services \u2014 as a multilanguage corpus for researchers, it is unparalleled (and, of course, free).\n\n\u201cThe degree to which the Wikipedia data has informed computer science is pretty astonishing,\u201d said Brent Hecht, an assistant professor at Northwestern University who has studied Wikipedia\u2019s relationships with tech companies and online communities. \u201cWikipedia definitely creates massively more value for these companies than they put in.\u201d\n\nWith the YouTube announcement, Wikipedia finds itself in a predicament similar to that of a small town after it has been chosen as the site of a new Walmart: Some municipalities have said that the retail giant creates undue stress on local police forces, straining them to the breaking point with endless calls to deal with petty crimes at the super stores.\n\nWikipedia\u2019s lopsided relationships can also amplify pre-existing internal problems. Its contributors skew white and male, for example, leading to predictable outcomes \u2014 just 17 percent of the subjects of biographies on the site are women. Wikipedia is taking steps to address the issue, but the next generation of consumer tech is being built on top of it \u2014 and its gaps and biases \u2014 in the meantime.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHaving come of age in the era of desktop and laptop computers, Wikipedia is also struggling to bring itself into the smartphone era (not to mention whatever comes next).\n\n\u201cIf we have interfaces like Alexa, for example, they\u2019re using infrastructure and content generated by editors, but they\u2019re not really encouraging readers to contribute in any way,\u201d said Dariusz Jemielniak, who published a book-length ethnographic study of Wikipedia and now sits on the Wikimedia Foundation\u2019s board. \u201cThey might not even realize it\u2019s coming from Wikipedia,\u201d he added. \u201cIt would be nice if people who take also give a little bit.\u201d\n\nThe main problem with YouTube\u2019s presumptuous announcement, Mr. Jemielniak suggested, is that Wikipedia is not necessarily geared toward breaking news \u2014 and conspiracy theories tend to move at lightning speed during times of crisis.\n\nRecently, for instance, YouTube was rife with conspiracy videos about the school shooting in Parkland, Fla., and it is unclear what even a thorough and well-sourced Wikipedia article could have done to dissuade an audience intent on believing that students at the school were paid \u201ccrisis actors\u201d carrying out orders.\n\nMore to the point, Mr. Jemielniak said, if Google wanted help from Wikipedia, it could have asked.\n\nMs. Maher agreed. At the very least, she said, it would be nice to have \u201ca primary point of contact\u201d at Google and companies like it \u2014 \u201csomeone who is invested in thinking of us an entity rather than just a resource.\u201d\n\nAs it stands, no such person has that role \u2014 though YouTube has reached out to the foundation since the announcement, and the two organizations are regularly in touch in less formal ways. (Google declined to comment for this article. Ms. Maher said of their interaction this week, \u201cIt was good for a start.\u201d)\n\nThen there\u2019s the issue of money. As important as Wikipedia may be to some of the richest companies in the world, it is, in financial terms, comparatively minuscule, with a yearly budget of less than $100 million \u2014 a rounding error for big tech. (It should be noted that Google has made one-off contributions to Wikipedia in the past and includes the Wikimedia Foundation in a program through which it matches employee donations, which netted the foundation around $1 million last year.)\n\nFor now, Wikipedians \u2014 among the most central and least visible participants in this conversation \u2014 seem not overly perturbed.\n\n\u201cLooks like we have more work to do,\u201d wrote one, after the YouTube announcement. \u201cI doubt that much will change anytime soon.\u201d", "title": "YouTube May Add to the Burdens of Humble Wikipedia", "authors": ["John Herrman"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "YouTube said this week that it would tighten restrictions on some firearm videos, its latest policy announcement since coming under scrutiny after last month\u2019s mass shooting at a high school in Parkland, Fla.\n\nThe video-streaming service, which is owned by Google, said it would ban videos that promote either the construction or sale of firearms and their accessories. The new policy, developed with expert advice over the last four months, will go into effect next month, it said.\n\n\u201cWhile we\u2019ve long prohibited the sale of firearms, we recently notified creators of updates we will be making around content promoting the sale or manufacture of firearms and their accessories, specifically, items like ammunition, gatling triggers, and drop-in auto sears,\u201d YouTube said in a statement.\n\nYouTube, which described the move as part of \u201cregular changes\u201d to policy, notified users in a Monday forum post. The company had previously banned videos showing how to make firearms discharge faster, a technique used by the gunman who killed 58 people in Las Vegas last fall.", "title": "YouTube to Ban Videos Promoting Gun Sales", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Is this suspicion correct? Good data is hard to come by; Google is loath to share information with independent researchers. But we now have the first inklings of confirmation, thanks in part to a former Google engineer named Guillaume Chaslot.\n\nMr. Chaslot worked on the recommender algorithm while at YouTube. He grew alarmed at the tactics used to increase the time people spent on the site. Google fired him in 2013, citing his job performance. He maintains the real reason was that he pushed too hard for changes in how the company handles such issues.\n\nThe Wall Street Journal conducted an investigation of YouTube content with the help of Mr. Chaslot. It found that YouTube often \u201cfed far-right or far-left videos to users who watched relatively mainstream news sources,\u201d and that such extremist tendencies were evident with a wide variety of material. If you searched for information on the flu vaccine, you were recommended anti-vaccination conspiracy videos.\n\nIt is also possible that YouTube\u2019s recommender algorithm has a bias toward inflammatory content. In the run-up to the 2016 election, Mr. Chaslot created a program to keep track of YouTube\u2019s most recommended videos as well as its patterns of recommendations. He discovered that whether you started with a pro-Clinton or pro-Trump video on YouTube, you were many times more likely to end up with a pro-Trump video recommended.\n\nCombine this finding with other research showing that during the 2016 campaign, fake news, which tends toward the outrageous, included much more pro-Trump than pro-Clinton content, and YouTube\u2019s tendency toward the incendiary seems evident.\n\nYouTube has recently come under fire for recommending videos promoting the conspiracy theory that the outspoken survivors of the school shooting in Parkland, Fla., are \u201ccrisis actors\u201d masquerading as victims. Jonathan Albright, a researcher at Columbia, recently \u201cseeded\u201d a YouTube account with a search for \u201ccrisis actor\u201d and found that following the \u201cup next\u201d recommendations led to a network of some 9,000 videos promoting that and related conspiracy theories, including the claim that the 2012 school shooting in Newtown, Conn., was a hoax.\n\nWhat we are witnessing is the computational exploitation of a natural human desire: to look \u201cbehind the curtain,\u201d to dig deeper into something that engages us. As we click and click, we are carried along by the exciting sensation of uncovering more secrets and deeper truths. YouTube leads viewers down a rabbit hole of extremism, while Google racks up the ad sales.\n\nHuman beings have many natural tendencies that need to be vigilantly monitored in the context of modern life. For example, our craving for fat, salt and sugar, which served us well when food was scarce, can lead us astray in an environment in which fat, salt and sugar are all too plentiful and heavily marketed to us. So too our natural curiosity about the unknown can lead us astray on a website that leads us too much in the direction of lies, hoaxes and misinformation.", "title": "Opinion | YouTube, the Great Radicalizer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Like Fidge kicking the rabbit, lighting the lamp is Aru\u2019s mortal error, but this time the punishment involves real consequences in our realm: the rise of the Sleeper, who will bring about an end to time unless Aru can stop him.\n\nChokshi seems in her own race against time, given how much she sets to accomplish in this, the first of a planned quartet. \u201cAru Shah\u201d is also the first title of the new imprint Rick Riordan Presents, spearheaded by the author of the hugely popular Percy Jackson series. After Riordan made Greek and Norse mythology accessible to young readers, his new venture broadens its horizons to underrepresented folklore. Starting with Hindu mythology \u2014 filled with ambiguities, abstractions and contradictions \u2014 is as nervy a move as Aru lighting the lamp.\n\nBut just as her heroine learns to wield a bow and arrow, Chokshi has her own weapons: a skill for crackling prose (\u201cA sharp sound cut the air, as if someone had dropped a handful of sewing needles\u201d), and a main character who, despite her lies, is both endearingly funny and self-aware (\u201cMaybe that\u2019s why superheroes wore capes. \u2026 They weren\u2019t actually capes at all, but safety blankets. \u2026 Because honestly? Saving the world was scary\u201d).\n\nMost of all, Chokshi is wise enough to let Aru experience Hinduism, not explain it. A Karma and Sins office leads to a pool of reincarnation; Lord Hanuman pops in like Jiminy Cricket to send Aru on her way; a tourism poster for Lanka (the demon kingdom in \u201cThe Ramayana\u201d) winkingly promises \u201cmoments of gore\u201d; allusions to Indian dance, dress, deities and traditions sit alongside references to Voldemort and Spiderman. Readers learn Sanskrit numbers, and why karma might best be explained by Justin Timberlake. With Aru at the helm, this roller coaster through Hindu culture never feels forced or pedantic, but instead like a new kind of myth \u2014 where a hero takes a hammer to the world to shine a light through its cracks.\n\nImage\n\nIn Diane Magras\u2019s THE MAD WOLF\u2019S DAUGHTER (Kathy Dawson Books, 277 pp., $16.99; ages 8 to 12), 12-year-old Drest, who lives in medieval Scotland, shouldn\u2019t be on her quest either. When her father and brothers are captured by knights, her father\u2019s parting orders are clear: Save yourself and hide. But Drest is a ferocious heroine, and after finding a wounded knight left behind by the enemy, she conjures a plan to travel to Faintree Castle and exchange the knight for her family before they\u2019re hanged.\n\nUnlike Fidge or Aru, Drest comes with little self-doubt. She knows her enemy, she knows good from evil, and she knows what she\u2019s fighting for. In fact, she knows her family so well she imagines her brothers\u2019 and father\u2019s voices in her head (\u201cDrest, lass, you must do something\u201d).\n\nAt first, it makes the novel slightly staid, since Drest is so capable: What could possibly get in her way? Even Drest\u2019s disobedience feels like the prelude to her proving that fathers shouldn\u2019t underestimate their daughters. A tale well trod. But see Magras\u2019s magic trick: Drest\u2019s self-belief isn\u2019t her strength but her weakness. Her father pre-empted this quest for a reason. He knew she was blind to the truth about her family, her enemy and the reason for their capture. Together, Drest and the reader are pulled into trap after trap, until it\u2019s clear we\u2019re in the hands of a master storyteller.\n\n\u201cThe Mad Wolf\u2019s Daughter\u201d feels like an instant classic. Its warning resonates: There will always be those who start the fires and the heroes who put them out. But to find the truth, sometimes a hero has to set a fire herself.", "title": "Young Heroines Who Are Saviors, but Not Saints", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "At the core of that debate is a program, created by the Obama administration, that shields from deportation about 800,000 immigrants who came as children, most of them from Mexico. President Trump called last year for the end of the program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, and he ordered Congress to come up with an alternative solution for the program\u2019s participants.\n\nShould Congress fail to agree on a solution that would extend legal protections to those immigrants \u2014 as well as to another one million who were eligible for DACA but never signed up \u2014 they would face renewed threats of deportation.\n\nMany of the young immigrants, a group broadly known as Dreamers, have vowed to stay. But the choice may not be theirs one day. And in Mexico, those who have already returned from the United States warn: Reintegration is rarely easy.\n\nTo be sure, voluntary returnees and deportees say that landing in Mexico can have upsides. They can walk the streets without fear of deportation. They can reconnect with long-lost relatives. They can afford college.\n\nBut the positive turns can be overwhelmed by the challenges.\n\nMany arrive in a place they never knew as adults, or do not remember. Some may find themselves alone, their friends and relatives still living in the United States. Some may even wrestle with speaking Spanish.\n\nThey may struggle to continue their education, find jobs and make their experience in the United States count for something in Mexico.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTheir return can carry a stigma: the shame of a deported criminal, or a sign of utter failure.\n\n\u201cThe early days was just, like, culture shock, man,\u201d said Mr. Aguilar, who had grown up in what he called \u201ca small white Mormon town\u201d in Utah.\n\nAfter returning to Mexico, \u201cI isolated myself in my room pretty much,\u201d he said. \u201cIsolation and depression, trying to figure out what was going on, how I ended up living in Mexico.\u201d", "title": "Young Migrants\u2019 Return to Mexico Is More \u2018Exile\u2019 Than Homecoming", "authors": ["Kirk Semple"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur correspondent Dan Bilefsky, a native of Montreal, has embarked on a road trip around Quebec to rediscover the province after several decades away.\n\nOur Canadian readers have already given Dan an abundance of great ideas for what to do, whom to meet and what music to listen to. He has indulged himself at Martin Picard\u2019s temple of excess Cabane \u00e0 Sucre au Pied de Cochon in Montreal, met with the Indigenous chef Cezin Nottaway on the Kitigan Zibi Algonquin reserve and is today going ice fishing in Maniwaki.\n\nAs Dan explores, we\u2019re hoping to hear from more young people in Quebec.
