And don\u2019t forget to sign up for the Canada newsletter.", "title": "Young People in Quebec, What Makes You Tick?", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "The tumult in Slovakia has now distinguished this country from others in the region, where a loss of faith in democracy has prompted voters to turn to populist leaders offering a strong hand as a remedy.\n\nIn Hungary and Poland, those leaders have steadily embedded networks of cronies, dismantled democratic institutions and promoted what they say are traditional, national values over Western ones.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut in Slovakia, a country smaller than West Virginia with a population of around five million, people are calling for something else: a recommitment to Western democratic values and the rule of law.\n\nFor the past three Fridays \u2014 despite freezing temperatures, snow and rain \u2014 men, women and children have demonstrated in numbers unseen since the fight to break from the yoke of the Soviet Union.\n\nAs in 1989, they have jingled their keys in the air, hoping to ring in the end of the government.\n\nThey want justice for the investigative journalist, Jan Kuciak, who was looking into government corruption when he was murdered three weeks ago, along with his fianc\u00e9e, Martina Kusnirova.\n\nBut they also want a cleaning out of a government that they believe has put its self-interests and self-preservation over their future.\n\nEven as Mr. Fico announced his resignation on Thursday, he did so with a smile. As a condition, he said his deputy must be appointed, ensuring that his party, SMER, would maintain its control over key government institutions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t worry, I\u2019m not going anywhere,\u201d he said to President Andrej Kiska as he handed him his letter of resignation.\n\nThe president accepted it and authorized Peter Pellegrini, a longtime ally of Mr. Fico\u2019s, to create a new government.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI want to be an active leader of a political party,\u201d Mr. Fico said later. \u201cThe only aim of this decision is to protect this country from chaos and ensure its stability.\u201d\n\nMikul\u00e1\u0161 Dzurinda, the prime minister of Slovakia from 1998 to 2006 and now the president of the Wilfried Martens Center for European Studies, said that the transparency of Mr. Fico\u2019s move was unlikely to appease the demonstrators.\n\n\u201cThis is just a maneuver,\u201d he said. \u201cMr. Pellegrini is not only his very close collaborator, but is perceived as his puppet.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis is why in these days, in these minutes, why frustration among the freedom fighters, among people believing in shared values, this is why frustration prevails,\u201d he said.\n\nHe did not know how long people would continue to take to the streets, but he was optimistic that \u201cthe people will demonstrate that we are not stupid.\u201d\n\nMartina Cimermanova, 25, a freelance photographer living in Bratislava, first decided to join the protests after seeing how politicians responded to the outcry over the killings.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey were so arrogant,\u201d she said. \u201cThat was the last straw.\u201d\n\nOn Friday, she was incensed after watching \u201cFico basically laughing in our face.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDespite his resignation, she fears he will still call the shots. But like others calling for change, she is not blind to the dangers new elections could pose.\n\nFor all the democratic fervor of recent days, Slovakia has not been immune to the appeals of extremist politicians. In the last election, a far-right party with links to neo-Nazis won the most votes in its history.\n\n\u201cLook at what happened in Romania,\u201d she said. \u201cPeople took to the streets; they got early elections, and the same old politicians just came back.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe same could happen here, she said.\n\nFor his part, Mr. Fico may present a confident face to the public, but in a private meeting with a delegation from the European Union recently, he expressed grave concern about the growing public unrest.\n\nHe worried that the opposition could take over, the group said in a summary of the meeting, and warned of bloody clashes, which never materialized.\n\nIn fact, the protest organizers have made it a point to keep the opposition at arms length and to remind demonstrators to remain peaceful.\n\nOn Friday, the crowd in Bratislava, the capital, was perhaps the largest yet. One man stood with an 8-month-old baby strapped to his chest. On the baby\u2019s back was a sign: \u201cNine out of 10 babies recommend not to be afraid and not to steal.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOnstage, singers, actors and activists all delivered messages calling for resilience and determination, kindness and decency. \u201cThey need to fear us,\u201d was a common theme.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhereas the crowd a week ago called for the end of the Fico government, it now called for the downfall of his entire political party.\n\nThe protest organizers say they are concerned about Slovakia\u2019s democratic institutions, and for them that means seeing high-level politicians held to account.\n\nJan Budaj, 66, one of the lead organizers of the Velvet Revolution, applauded the demonstrators\u2019 efforts, but said that a lack of political alliances might make it difficult to force a lasting change.\n\nSitting in a cafe overlooking the square, joined by other comrades in arms from the fight against Communism, he said this moment was different but no less important.\n\nThat was a revolution, but this is an evolution, he said. Change at that time came from the top, with leaders like Vaclav Havel. This time, it was coming from the ground up.\n\nHe saw it as not only important for Slovakia, but also for the region \u2014 a rejection of the illiberal drift of this country\u2019s neighbors.\n\nOn Friday, as thousands of people gathered, he watched with pride.\n\n\u201cSlovakia is seeing the real birth of a political nation,\u201d he said. \u201cWhat you are seeing on the street is a nation coming closer to the West, not pulling away.\u201d\n\nThe illusions he once may have had about Western democracy \u2014 an idealized version when viewed from behind the Iron Curtain \u2014 may have been lost long ago.\n\nBut these are the moments that truly define a nation.\n\n\u201cDemocracy does not mean you will never have corrupt politicians,\u201d he said. \u201cDemocracy is what you do when you discover the mayor is stealing the people\u2019s cash.\u201d", "title": "Young Slovaks Buck a Trend, Protesting to Save Their Democracy", "authors": ["Marc Santora"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Given the sad retreat from democracy in many of their Central European neighbors, it is heartening to witness the determination of so many thousands of Slovaks who have been marching across their country \u201cfor a decent Slovakia,\u201d as they\u2019ve dubbed their protests.\n\nThe protests were prompted by the murders last month of a journalist, Jan Kuciak, and his fianc\u00e9e, Martina Kusnirova, both 27. Though the killings remain unsolved, the police said they were most likely related to Mr. Kuciak\u2019s investigation of ties between top Slovakia politicians and Italy\u2019s \u2019Ndrangheta organized crime group.\n\nThe demonstrations rapidly swelled into mass protests against the corruption and arrogance of the government, which many younger Slovaks see as betraying the struggles their parents waged against Soviet-imposed Communist rule. Under slogans like \u201cSlovakia is going the wrong way\u201d and \u201cWe want elections,\u201d tens of thousands of have marched repeatedly under sleet, snow or rain in the capital, Bratislava, and across the small country of 5.4 million.\n\nAt first, the prime minister, Robert Fico, tried to deflect the protests, firing some ministers and assailing the liberal president, Andrej Kiska, for purportedly failing to explain why he met with the American investor George Soros in September. Mr. Soros\u2019 support of democratic causes across the former Soviet empire has made him the premier target of vile conspiracy theories and denunciations, and anti-Semitism, among reactionary populists in Central Europe.", "title": "Opinion | Young Slovaks Show Extremism in Europe Can Be Defied", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "NEON IN DAYLIGHT\n\nBy Hermione Hoby\n\n282 pp. Catapult. Paper, $16.95.\n\nBeing young in New York \u2014 the romance of discovering oneself in a city whose capacity for mythologizing has been thoroughly mythologized \u2014 is an old story. But it\u2019s still a renewable one, as Hermione Hoby proves with her smart, stylish debut novel, \u201cNeon in Daylight.\u201d\n\nHoby finds a way into the formula \u2014 and changes it up \u2014 with Kate, a 25-year-old Englishwoman, whose orientation is not so much one of energetic striving but engaged drift. She\u2019s come to New York in the summer of 2012, cat-sitting in a third-floor walk-up for a family friend who\u2019s off on a post-divorce \u201cThailand et cetera\u201d trip. She has few responsibilities and only a loosening commitment to what she left in London: a law-student boyfriend, the pursuit of her Ph.D., and some idea of herself that no longer holds. She might like to be a person who is \u201cup for it\u201d and \u201cdown for it,\u201d instead of one who is \u201ctroubled, for instance, over how those two semantically opposed phrases could have come to mean, in essence, the exact same thing.\u201d\n\nImage Credit Sonny Figueroa/The New York Times\n\nAs cerebral as she is, Kate is alive to influence and sensation, and her experience of the city is not logical but dreamlike and immersive, which Hoby depicts in image-filled language that\u2019s arresting without being overwrought. There\u2019s a kinetic New York magic that Hoby taps into \u2014 whatever that mysterious force is that allows the Brooklyn rooftops, Manhattan galleries, downtown art parties and other privileged spaces of this novel somehow to be the clich\u00e9s they are and yet resist banality. It\u2019s the same magic that makes it plausible for Kate to meet \u2014 separately, randomly \u2014 Bill and Inez, born and bred New Yorkers who also happen to be father and daughter. Kate is taken with their charisma, becomes involved with each of them in different ways, and a triangle, of which none of them are initially aware, forms.\n\nBill, a well-known, dissipated writer of exactly one novel, published in his 20s and made into a hit movie, is a man who once \u201cfelt himself to be an ongoing roar.\u201d He hasn\u2019t quite accepted that he no longer is, but he\u2019s not a little proud to see his 19-year-old daughter take up that mantle. Inez, stunning and still in full possession of an adolescent bravado, works in a coffee shop, deals Adderall and answers Craigslist ads for what\u2019s euphemistically called \u201cmiscellaneous romance.\u201d They could be stock characters, but Hoby breathes life and nuance into them, in part by making them self-aware enough to know they are, to an extent, types, involved in some subtle, ongoing performance where they risk becoming parodies.", "title": "Young and Adrift in New York City", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIn addition to the nutrient supply, dirty bath water also serves as a further source of microbial seeding for the bath toys,\u201d the researchers noted.\n\nThey suggested that using a higher-quality polymer to make the rubber ducks might prevent bacterial and fungal growth.\n\nThe study, which received funding from the Swiss government, is part of broader research into bacteria on household objects.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe rubber ducks are not the only household item found to be a haven for bacteria. Last year, a study in Germany found that kitchen sponges were a hotbed for germs. More than 350 different species of bacteria were found in 14 dirty kitchen sponges taken from private households.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s the same density of bacteria you can find in human stool samples,\u201d Markus Egert, a microbiologist at Furtwangen University in Germany, said in an interview with The New York Times. \u201cThere are probably no other places on earth with such high bacterial densities.\u201d\n\nThe study also found that cleaning the sponges could make the bacteria worse because the strongest pathogenic bacteria tended to survive and fester, even if it microwaved.\n\nAnother item that harbors a lot of bacteria is one that we tend to keep the closest: the cellphone. While research has varied on the number of germs found on the average cellphone, Charles Gerba, a microbiologist at the University of Arizona, found in 2012 that the average cellphone carried 10 times more bacteria than most toilet seats.\n\nProfessor Gerba said, however, that there were far dirtier places in a home than the toilet seat.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s one of the cleanest things you\u2019ll run across in terms of micro-organisms,\u201d he told the BBC. \u201cUsually, there are about 200 times more faecal bacteria on the average cutting board than on a toilet seat.\u201d\n\nRecently, a microbiology student\u2019s photo on Facebook of the colonies of fungi and bacteria that grew in a petri dish she had opened inside a Dyson hand dryer drew alarm when the image spread online. But studies disagree on whether hand dryers are more or less hygienic than paper towels.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne study published by the Mayo Clinic in 2000 found no statistically significant hygienic difference between dryers and paper towels.", "title": "Your Cute Rubber Duck May Be a Haven for Bacteria", "authors": ["Ceylan Yeginsu"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "The idea has been around for a bit. Jaron Lanier, the tech philosopher and virtual-reality pioneer who now works for Microsoft Research, proposed it in his 2013 book, \u201cWho Owns the Future?,\u201d as a needed corrective to an online economy mostly financed by advertisers\u2019 covert manipulation of users\u2019 consumer choices.\n\nIt is being picked up in \u201cRadical Markets,\u201d a book due out shortly from Eric A. Posner of the University of Chicago Law School and E. Glen Weyl, principal researcher at Microsoft. And it is playing into European efforts to collect tax revenue from American internet giants.\n\nIn a report obtained last month by Politico, the European Commission proposes to impose a tax on the revenue of digital companies based on their users\u2019 location, on the grounds that \u201ca significant part of the value of a business is created where the users are based and data is collected and processed.\u201d\n\nUsers\u2019 data is a valuable commodity. Facebook offers advertisers precisely targeted audiences based on user profiles. YouTube, too, uses users\u2019 preferences to tailor its feed. Still, this pales in comparison with how valuable data is about to become, as the footprint of artificial intelligence extends across the economy.\n\nData is the crucial ingredient of the A.I. revolution. Training systems to perform even relatively straightforward tasks like voice translation, voice transcription or image recognition requires vast amounts of data \u2014 like tagged photos, to identify their content, or recordings with transcriptions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAmong leading A.I. teams, many can likely replicate others\u2019 software in, at most, one to two years,\u201d notes the technologist Andrew Ng. \u201cBut it is exceedingly difficult to get access to someone else\u2019s data. Thus data, rather than software, is the defensible barrier for many businesses.\u201d\n\nWe may think we get a fair deal, offering our data as the price of sharing puppy pictures. By other metrics, we are being victimized: In the largest technology companies, the share of income going to labor is only about 5 to 15 percent, Mr. Posner and Mr. Weyl write. That\u2019s way below Walmart\u2019s 80 percent. Consumer data amounts to work they get free.\n\n\u201cIf these A.I.-driven companies represent the future of broader parts of the economy,\u201d they argue, \u201cwithout something basic changing in their business model, we may be headed for a world where labor\u2019s share falls dramatically from its current roughly 70 percent to something closer to 20 to 30 percent.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs Mr. Lanier, Mr. Posner and Mr. Weyl point out, it is ironic that humans are providing free data to train the artificial-intelligence systems to replace workers across the economy. Commentators from both left and right fret over how ordinary people will put food on the table once robots take all the jobs. Perhaps a universal basic income, funded by taxes, is the answer?\n\nHow about paying people for the data they produced to train the robots? If A.I. accounted for 10 percent of the economy and the big-data companies paid two-thirds of their income for data \u2014 the same as labor\u2019s share of income across the economy \u2014 the share of income going to \u201cworkers\u201d would rise drastically. By Mr. Weyl and Mr. Posner\u2019s reckoning, the median household of four would gain $20,000 a year.\n\nA critical consideration is that if people were paid for their data, its quality and value would increase. Facebook could directly ask users to tag the puppy pictures to train the machines. It could ask translators to upload their translations. Facebook and Google could demand quality information if the value of the transaction were more transparent. Unwilling to enter in a direct quid pro quo with their users, the data titans must make do with whatever their users submit.\n\nThe transition would not be painless. We would need to figure out systems to put value on data. Your puppy pictures might turn out to be worthless, but that college translation from Serbo-Croatian could be valuable. Barred from free data, YouTube and Facebook might charge a user fee for their service \u2014 like Netflix. Alternatively, they might make their money from training A.I. systems and pay some royalty stream to the many people whose data helped train them.\n\nBut whatever the cost, the transformation seems worthwhile. Notably, it could help resolve one of the most relevant questions coming into focus in this new technological age: Who will control the data?\n\nToday, the dominant data harvesters in the business are Google and Facebook, with Amazon, Apple and Microsoft some way behind. Their dominance cannot really be challenged: Could you think of a rival search engine? Could another social network replace the one all your friends are on? This dominance might matter less if companies had to pay for their users\u2019 data.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGoogle and Facebook and Amazon would not be able to extend the network effects that cemented their place at the top of the technology ecosystem to the world of A.I. Everybody wants to be on Facebook because everybody\u2019s friends are on Facebook. But this dominance could be eroded if rivals made direct offers of money for data.\n\nCompanies with different business models might join the fray. \u201cThis is an opportunity for other companies to enter and say look, we will pay you for this data,\u201d Mr. Posner said. \u201cAll this is so new that ordinary people haven\u2019t figured out how manipulated they are by these companies.\u201d\n\nThe big question, of course, is how we get there from here. My guess is that it would be na\u00efve to expect Google and Facebook to start paying for user data of their own accord, even if that improved the quality of the information. Could policymakers step in, somewhat the way the European Commission did, demanding that technology companies compute the value of consumer data?\n\nIn any event, there is probably a better deal out there, in your future, than giving Facebook free puppy pictures.", "title": "Your Data Is Crucial to a Robotic Age. Shouldn\u2019t You Be Paid for It?", "authors": ["Eduardo Porter", "Economic Scene"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Sure, there are treatment facilities for adolescents who are hooked on devices, and psychologists use terms like \u201cproblematic media use\u201d in describing a small percentage of people who seem to prefer screens to people. But experts are split over the question of whether internet addiction is a legitimate stand-alone disorder.\n\nA Common Sense spokeswoman, Corbie Kiernan, told me, \u201cWe use the term \u2018addiction\u2019 colloquially, not diagnostically,\u201d in response to parents\u2019 concerns. Of course, only a rank apologist would deny that there is cause for concern about the role mobile devices are playing in children\u2019s and young people\u2019s lives. Media habits are shifting fast: The amount of time children 8 years old and younger spend on phones or tablets has increased tenfold in just five years, according to a 2017 study by Common Sense. The organization also found that 42 percent of children under 8 already have their own mobile device. That number was less than 1 percent in 2011.\n\nWhile those of us who grew up before smartphones can agree that these changes are jarring, the extent of the harm done to kids by more screens than we could ever have imagined is not at all clear. The real \u201ctruth about tech\u201d is that there just isn\u2019t enough research on this yet. For example, when I asked Victor C. Strasburger of the American Academy of Pediatrics how the organization arrived at its \u201cno screens before age 2\u201d recommendation, he said that later studies supported the guidance but admitted that at the time it was put into effect, \u201cthere was no evidence. None. We made it up.\u201d (The group has since changed its stance, maintaining that it\u2019s best to keep the youngest children away from screens, but making an exception for live video chat.)\n\nAn open letter in January from Apple shareholders calling for parental controls and more research into the effects of heavy use of mobile devices on youth was also based on fairly flimsy evidence. For example, the letter cited the work of a psychologist who analyzed large surveys to find that heavy electronic device use among teenagers is correlated with reports of loneliness, depression, anxiety and the increased presence of suicide risk factors. But this connection does not prove which way the causal arrow points. Perhaps teenagers who are under emotional duress gravitate toward their phones. Maybe they have parents with troubles of their own who are less capable of supervising them.\n\nThe science here is nothing like the kind that fueled the Truth campaign against cigarettes. For that reason alone, those working to make tech safer for kids can\u2019t emulate that campaign.", "title": "Opinion | Your Kid\u2019s Phone Is Not Like a Cigarette", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Bront\u00eb went on to publish a collection of poetry with her sisters Emily and Anne in 1846. Her novel \u201cJane Eyre\u201d was published the next year under the male pseudonym Currer Bell, which was based partly on the name of the man whose marriage proposal she did accept (after two tries): Arthur Bell Nicholls.\n\nChris Stanford contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. Contact us at asiabriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Your Monday Briefing: China, North Korea, Roger Bannister", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "In the last few years, Sicily and Mount Etna in particular have become well known for their red wines, particularly those made of the nerello mascalese grape, which we drank back in 2016.\n\nThis time, we will look at the white wines of Mount Etna, known as Etna Bianco. These wines are made largely, sometimes entirely, of carricante. As with so many Italian grapes, it was little known and little appreciated until the last 10 or 15 years, when winemakers began to show just how good carricante could be.\n\nWhen grown in the right soils, under proper conditions, carricante makes one of Italy\u2019s most compelling white wines, wholly different from any other. It\u2019s a wine understood not so much for its fruitiness as for its savory elements, which is true of some of the world\u2019s great whites.", "title": "Your Next Lesson: Etna Bianco", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Back in the early days of Wine School, we focused on Chianti Classico, the signature red of Tuscany. Now we head to a different part of Tuscany to drink Rosso di Montalcino.\n\nRosso di Montalcino is the younger sibling of Brunello di Montalcino. Brunello must be aged for at least four years after the vintage before it can be released. That\u2019s quite an investment of time and money, and if things do not go smoothly in certain vintages, producers may end up with little wine to sell.\n\nThat\u2019s where Rosso di Montalcino comes in. It requires only one year of aging before it can be released, which gives producers something to sell as they await the Brunello.\n\nRosso is also a way of improving the Brunello. Instead of using younger vines or vines from lesser sites in the more expensive, prestigious Brunello, which might compromise its quality, they can go into the Rosso.", "title": "Your Next Lesson: Rosso di Montalcino", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s the latest in a long-running series of tribute concerts organized by Michael Dorf, with all proceeds benefiting music education (though presumably of a different kind than the \u201cschooling\u201d that Led Zeppelin\u2019s Robert Plant sang about on 1969\u2019s \u201cWhole Lotta Love\u201d). SIMON VOZICK-LEVINSON\n\nPhoto\n\nTV: Liberation on \u2018Divorce\u2019\n\nAfter a painfully dark \u2014 some would say unflinchingly realistic \u2014 first season, viewers could be forgiven for squirming away from HBO\u2019s \u201cDivorce,\u201d starring Sarah Jessica Parker and Thomas Haden Church as Frances and Robert DuFresne, New York suburbanites putting their marriage out of its misery. But those who\u2019ve braved Round 2 have been rewarded with sunbeams through parting clouds. The papers are signed, leaving the couple free to move on to other partners (Steven Pasquale for her, Becki Newton for him) and, perhaps more important, to become the better people they somehow couldn\u2019t muster in each other\u2019s company.\n\nIt\u2019s almost enough to make you wonder if they\u2019ve been hasty in calling the whole thing off. Alas, it\u2019s not over until it\u2019s officially over. There\u2019s still no word on whether \u201cDivorce\u201d \u2014 whose flagging ratings got a midseason bump after Frances and Robert ended up, briefly, back in each other\u2019s arms \u2014 has been renewed for a third installment. But whatever the show\u2019s fate, the Season 2 finale, airing Sunday, March 4, offers a bittersweet denouement. Just \u201cdon\u2019t start dressing that carriage just yet,\u201d Mr. Church said in a Times interview. \u201cWe never know what can happen in the post-mortem of that divorce.\u201d KATHRYN SHATTUCK\n\nPhoto\n\nDance: Paul Taylor Modern\n\nMarch 6-25, ptamd.org.\n\nIn 2015 the Paul Taylor Dance Company began expanding its repertory beyond the works of its founder, ushering in a more eclectic era for a troupe historically devoted to a single artist\u2019s vision. Under the heading Paul Taylor American Modern Dance, the company returns to the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center with new works by Doug Varone and Bryan Arias; guest visits by the New York City Ballet principal Sara Mearns and the Trisha Brown Dance Company; and more than a dozen dances by Mr. Taylor, including his 147th and newest, \u201cConcertiana.\u201d\n\nThe opening week brings the premieres of Mr. Arias\u2019s \u201cThe Beauty in Gray\u201d \u2014 sharing the March 8 gala program with Mr. Taylor\u2019s \u201cArden Court\u201d and \u201cEsplanade\u201d\u2014 and Mr. Varone\u2019s \u201cHalf Life\u201d (March 10). But the most exciting offerings come later in the season: Ms. Mearns in \u201cDances of Isadora,\u201d a suite of solos by the modern dance pioneer Isadora Duncan (staged by Lori Belilove), and the Trisha Brown Dance Company in Ms. Brown\u2019s propulsive 1983 masterpiece, \u201cSet and Reset.\u201d SIOBHAN BURKE\n\nPhoto\n\nClassical: Kennedy Center Festival\n\nMarch 5 to 19; www.kennedy-center.org.\n\nUnder the direction of Deborah Rutter, the traditionalist Kennedy Center in Washington has inched into the 21st century: In recent seasons, it has engaged compelling artists like Q-Tip and Jason Moran to oversee programming across genres. The latest initiative is the new festival Direct Current, a celebration of contemporary culture that ranges from the performance artist Taylor Mac (March 6) to the hip-hop duo Shabazz Palaces (March 17).\n\nThe festival\u2019s most promising contemporary classical offerings include music by John Cage and Viet Cuong, played by the ensemble So Percussion (March 9); a survey of Philip Glass\u2019s complete \u00e9tudes by a team of pianists including Mr. Moran and Mr. Glass (March 9); Julia Wolfe\u2019s Pulitzer Prize-winning \u201cAnthracite Fields\u201d (March 13); and the environmentalist documentary \u201cThe Colorado,\u201d featuring live music from Roomful of Teeth (March 18). The biggest ticket, though, may be the National Symphony Orchestra performing John Adams\u2019s potent oratorio \u201cThe Gospel According to the Other Mary\u201d under Gianandrea Noseda, himself in the midst of a promising first season as the orchestra\u2019s music director (March 8 and 10). WILLIAM ROBIN\n\nPhoto\n\nTheater: New Plays in Louisville\n\nThrough April 8; actorstheatre.org\n\nThe annual migration is a sign of spring \u2014 theater people flocking to Kentucky for a first look at fresh work in the Humana Festival of New American Plays at Actors Theater of Louisville. A long track record of boldface names and significant plays is what makes it worth the trip. Lucas Hnath, a Tony Award nominee last spring for \u201cA Doll\u2019s House, Part 2,\u201d brought \u201cThe Christians\u201d there for its world premiere a few seasons back. Branden Jacobs-Jenkins (\u201cAn Octoroon\u201d) was there with \u201cAppropriate\u201d in 2013, a year before that play appeared Off Broadway. This year\u2019s festival, the 42nd, will be the last as artistic director for Les Waters, who is leaving Actors Theater this summer.\n\nHis directorial swan song will be Mark Schultz\u2019s \u201cEvocation to Visible Appearance,\u201d part of a program of six world premieres, including Leah Nanako Winkler\u2019s \u201cGod Said This\u201d; Deborah Stein\u2019s \u201cMarginal Loss\u201d; Mara Nelson-Greenberg\u2018s \u201cDo You Feel Anger?\u201d; Susan Soon He Stanton\u2019s \u201cwe, the invisibles\u201d; and \u201cYou Across From Me,\u201d a play with four authors (Jaclyn Backhaus, Dipika Guha, Brian Otan\u0303o and Jason Gray Platt) which, fittingly enough, explores coming to the table together. LAURA COLLINS-HUGHES", "title": "Your Week in Culture: Jennifer Lawrence, Memories of Led Zeppelin, HBO\u2019s \u2018Divorce\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "As a doctor working in the I.C.U., I knew firsthand the frustrations of searching the electronic record for notes and scanned documents. But I had no idea how common this problem was.\n\nThrough my interviews, I heard stories of patients who had been transferred to nursing facilities without their advance directives and returned to the hospital intubated when that was explicitly not what they wanted. Others told me about patients of theirs who\u2019d grown ill on vacation only to end up in a hospital they\u2019d never been to, with an entirely different electronic medical record, where no one was able to access any prior documentation. Others described situations in which last minute \u201csaves\u201d through extreme diligence or chance, such as the one I experienced, had led to a good outcome.\n\nThere are few existing regulations here, as the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Service are relatively silent on advance care planning. In contrast to the rules around allergies, which mandate that all patients have an active med allergy list, electronic records simply need to have the capacity to show whether or not a patient has an advance directive, somewhere. They don\u2019t even need to make the directive retrievable.\n\nIn the absence of nationwide standards, there\u2019s significant variability among hospitals and among electronic records. Some have worked to make end-of-life documentation more easily accessible. At my hospital, for example, clicking on an \u201cAdvance Care Planning\u201d tab will bring you to a record of all advance care planning notes, health care proxy forms, scanned directives and code status orders. This is a start, but it wasn\u2019t enough for that elderly man in the emergency room. Habits are hard to break, and without a clear set of incentives, training and ongoing education, doctors (myself included) continue to record information about end-of-life conversations in progress notes, where they are not readily available, particularly when they are urgently needed.\n\nRecently, a handful of start-ups have stepped in, trying to offer a solution to the fact that different electronic records can\u2019t communicate with each other. There\u2019s software and clever patient apps that work outside the electronic record, promising to build a repository of directives, proxy forms, even conversations. Just imagine, your E.D. doctor is fumbling to find your information in your chart, but you have an advance directive that was safely uploaded onto your smartphone. This most likely could have helped my patient that day \u2014 if he had a smartphone and was able to show it to his doctors, or if his hospital had committed to buying the necessary software.\n\nWhat could really make a meaningful difference, I heard time and time again, is standards for sharing, or \u201cinteroperability\u201d across all electronic records that would benefit every patient, everywhere. At least, all related advance care planning documentation should be in one place in the medical record and accessible with one simple click of the mouse. Beyond that, maybe all health systems could require identification of a health care proxy for all patients, so we would know who should make decisions if the patient can\u2019t. Maybe patients should be able to access their health records through a patient-facing interface, send in their own directives, or even update related notes. Ideally, the electronic record isn\u2019t just a clunky online version of a paper chart but actually a tool to help us do our jobs better.\n\nYet as it is, we\u2019re playing catch-up. Which is how my patient ended up in the hospital that night, with a team of well-meaning doctors readying to do something to him that he never would have wanted, and a resident racing down to the emergency room because he\u2019d happened upon a note.", "title": "You\u2019ve Detailed Your Last Wishes, but Doctors May Not See Them", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The first thing to remember when receiving substantial stock compensation, financial advisers say, is that no matter how stable your company, you are taking a gamble. Markets go up and down, and even the most stalwart stocks can take sudden turns.\n\nShares of General Electric climbed more or less steadily for decades until the year 2000, then tumbled. They regained some ground, but took another beating during the financial crisis. G.E. stock was climbing again in recent years, but last year began falling again.\n\n\u201cWhether founders or executives, these individuals have a different risk appetite than other W-2 earning individuals,\u201d said Jeff Schnitz, head of wealth advisory for Silicon Valley Bank\u2019s private bank. \u201cThey have the opportunity to accept risk, and to create upside opportunities for themselves.\u201d\n\nSome chief executives are taking this to new extremes. Elon Musk recently proposed a new compensation plan at Tesla. If approved, he will receive billions of dollars in compensation if he manages to double, triple and quadruple the value of the company. He will receive nothing if he does not.\n\nRick Smith, the chief executive of Axon, followed Mr. Musk\u2019s lead and proposed a nearly identical plan, albeit with smaller targets for the market valuation.", "title": "You\u2019ve Got Lots of Company Stock. Now What?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "The attack has significantly raised tensions between the West and Russia, which has denied any involvement. Days after Britain and its allies announced that they would expel more than 150 Russians, the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, said that Moscow would respond in kind: It expelled 60 diplomats from the United States and shut the American consulate in St. Petersburg.\n\nRussia has already expelled 23 Britons. The Americans were given until April 5 to leave.\n\nThe announcements came a day after the British authorities said that Ms. Skripal and her father, a former colonel for Russian military intelligence who was widely believed to have been a double agent, had been poisoned after the nerve agent was applied to the front door of their house, resolving one of the many mysteries in the case.\n\nThe BBC reported on Thursday that Ms. Skripal was \u201cconscious and talking,\u201d and that Mr. Skripal had apparently touched the nerve agent with his right hand, while his daughter did so with her left hand.\n\nThe Metropolitan Police also said on Thursday that the search for the source of the poisoning of the Skripals was now focused on the area around their home in the cathedral city of Salisbury, about 85 miles southwest of London.\n\nTo that end, the police placed a cordon around a children\u2019s play area at a park near Mr. Skripal\u2019s home, although they sought to allay fears that members of the public were at risk of being poisoned by describing the move as a precautionary measure.", "title": "Yulia Skripal, Poisoned Daughter of Ex-Spy, Is Out of Critical Condition", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nZackory Todd Burns and Kevin Xinye Liu were married March 2 at the Bel-Air Bay Club in Los Angeles. Michele Bratcher Goodwin, a friend of the couple who was ordained through American Marriage Ministries, officiated.\n\nDr. Burns (right) and Dr. Liu, both 29, met at the University of Oxford, from which each received a Doctor of Philosophy, Mr. Burns in zoology and Mr. Liu in physiology, anatomy and genetics.\n\nDr. Burns is a third-year law student at the University of California, Irvine. He graduated from Princeton, and received an M.B.A. from Smartly, an online M.B.A. program.\n\nHe is the son of Jennifer L. Burns and Richard T. Burns of Davison, Mich. His mother is the special education director at Holly Academy, a public charter school in Holly, Mich. His father is an electrician in Detroit for Chrysler.\n\nDr. Liu is a fourth-year medical student at Harvard, where he graduated summa cum laude with a degree in neurobiology. He was both a Fulbright and Clarendon Scholar at the University of Oxford.\n\nHe is a son of Jie Chen and Yunhe Liu of Sudbury, Mass. His mother is a vice president of chemistry, manufacturing and control management in Cambridge for Wuxi Biologics, a global open-access biologics technology platform company. His father retired as a senior manager of software engineering at Arris, a telecommunications equipment manufacturing company in Lowell, Mass.", "title": "Zackory Burns and Kevin Liu", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "RIYADH, Saudi Arabia \u2014 A decade and a king ago, Saudi Arabia started talking about, of all things, energy conservation, global warming and clean alternatives to oil.\n\nUnder King Abdullah, the state\u2019s oil company, Saudi Aramco, began planning for the construction of a think tank to strategize the country\u2019s oil future and economic diversification. In 2009, Aramco held a competition to design a campus in Riyadh \u2014 a state-of-the-industry architectural icon that would embody the research center\u2019s mission and double as a showcase where conferences by OPEC and others could be held while BBC cameras rolled.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe winner was the Iraq-born Zaha Hadid, the sole female architect invited into the competition and an outspoken progressive defining an image for a country that the king was cautiously changing. Her design for the King Abdullah Petroleum Studies and Research Center, unveiled to the public in the fall, was geometrically ingenious, inspired by soap bubbles and honeycombs found in nature.\n\nBut its public opening during the country\u2019s annual Saudi Design Week in October proved to be posthumous for King Abdullah as well as for Hadid. He died in 2015, to be succeeded by his half brother, the 79-year-old King Salman. Hadid died a year later, at 65, of a heart attack. She never saw one of the most singular designs of her career, the first in her portfolio to be data-driven by the demands of climate and sustainability.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMany grandly conceived Saudi projects have never fully materialized, often because new rulers lacked interest in initiatives started by, and named after, their predecessors. But construction was substantially complete by the time of King Abdullah\u2019s death, and despite the throne\u2019s passing to a rival branch of the royal family, 135 full-time researchers and support staff now occupy the offices of an operational building, with room for more experts as the institute develops over time. An independent endowment assures the research center full funding in perpetuity.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe mandate for the competition was to plan a building with a low carbon footprint for a scorching climate that necessitates air-conditioning much of the year. The 113-degree summers drove the design. Rather than just carpeting the roof with solar panels, plugging in sustainability as an afterthought, Hadid integrated energy-conserving forms into the design.", "title": "Zaha Hadid\u2019s Desert Think Tank: Environmental Beauty and Efficiency", "authors": ["Joseph Giovannini"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Zeke Upshaw, a Detroit Pistons developmental player who collapsed on the court during a N.B.A. G League game in Michigan has died.\n\nThe Grand Rapids Drive announced that the 26-year-old Upshaw died at a hospital Monday. No cause was disclosed. He collapsed Saturday night near the end of a game against the Long Island Nets.\n\nUpshaw\u2019s mother, Jewel Upshaw, released a statement thanking the team and fans. Team owner Steve Jbara says the Grand Rapids area was fortunate to enjoy Upshaw\u2019s commitment to the community, especially children.", "title": "Zeke Upshaw Dies After Collapsing During N.B.A. G League Game", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Immediately after the speech, Mr. Miller snapped at journalists who tried to pose questions. Then he was interviewed on MSNBC by Chris Matthews, who cited the about-face on Mr. Kerry and asked him to elaborate on the \u201cspitballs\u201d remark.\n\n\u201cDo you know what a metaphor is?\u201d Mr. Miller said. Quickly becoming more annoyed, he shouted, \u201cGet out of my face!\u201d\n\nMr. Matthews was actually a safe distance away; the two were communicating by microphone.\n\n\u201cI wish we lived in the day when we could challenge someone to a duel,\u201d Mr. Miller said. He later expressed regret for his outburst.\n\nThe 2004 speech was all the more remarkable in that Mr. Miller had delivered a keynote speech at the 1992 Democratic National Convention in which he excoriated President George H. W. Bush and praised the party\u2019s nominee, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who would go on to defeat Mr. Bush. Mr. Miller attributed his own rise to the achievements of the Democratic Party.\n\n\u201cI made it because Franklin Delano Roosevelt energized this nation,\u201d Mr. Miller told the convention, which was also being held at Madison Square Garden. \u201cI made it because Harry Truman fought for working families like mine. I made it because John Kennedy\u2019s rising tide lifted even our tiny boat. I made it because Lyndon Johnson showed America that people who were born poor didn\u2019t have to die poor.\u201d\n\nZell Bryan Miller was born in Young Harris on Feb. 24, 1932. His father, Stephen Grady Miller, a teacher, died 17 days later. The widowed mother, Birdie, built a home with rocks that she had hauled from a nearby stream, Zell Miller recounted later, and raised the boy and his sister, Jane.", "title": "Zell Miller, Feisty Democrat Who Sided With G.O.P., Is Dead at 86", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "In the year of his death, which was also a presidential election year, she produced her most flat-out polemical work, a 300-word anti-authoritarian statement, part manifesto, part embittered cri de coeur, demanding radical change. The original typewriter-written version, on a single sheet of onionskin paper with ink corrections, is in the retrospective. It begins: \u201cI want a dyke for president,\u201d and continues:\n\nI want someone with no\n\nhealth insurance and I want someone who grew\n\nup in a place where the earth is so saturated\n\nwith toxic waste that they didn\u2019t have a\n\nchoice about getting leukemia. I want a\n\npresident that had an abortion at sixteen and\n\nI want a candidate who isn\u2019t the lesser of two\n\nevils and I want a president who lost their\n\nlast lover to aids, who still sees that in\n\ntheir eyes every time they lay down to rest,\n\nwho held their lover in their arms and knew\n\nthey were dying.\n\nNever published, the statement circulated in various forms over the years. Basically, \u201cI Want a President\u201d was a form of participatory public art, completed by being passed from hand-to-hand. Then in 2016 it went big time. In the run-up to the election it was posted billboard-size on the High Line, not far from the Whitney, and became a social media hit.\n\nMs. Leonard\u2019s art often has a collaborative dimension. In a 1993 project with the filmmaker Cheryl Dunye, the sharing was direct. Ms. Dunye was working on a film called \u201cWatermelon Woman,\u201d partly about the life of a black lesbian Hollywood actress named Fae Richards, whose career had been thwarted by racism. Ms. Leonard created what amounted to an elaborate archival storyboard for the film, photo-documenting the actress\u2019s life.\n\nIn fact, Fae Richards is an invented character. And, although her \u201clife\u201d is more than plausible, Ms. Leonard\u2019s documentation of it, on display at the Whitney, is entirely staged. As a pictorial narrative \u2014 a film made from stills \u2014 the piece is a tour de force. It reveals this artist to be not only a gifted storyteller, but a virtuoso of photographic technology.\n\nSome of that technology became obsolete even as Ms. Leonard was using it. And the idea of obsolescence \u2014 of the present slipping irretrievably into the past \u2014 haunts her recent work. A series of pictures called \u201cThe Analogue Portfolio,\u201d dated 1998-2009 \u2014 and made with a now-discontinued dye-transfer process \u2014 records the facades of small storefront shops on the Lower East Side, and in countries she\u2019s visited: Cuba, Mexico, Uganda. Many of the New York shops she shot a decade and more ago are now gone, wiped out by high rents and globalization. Chances are their equivalents elsewhere are too.\n\nIf Ms. Leonard has strong ideas or feelings about this, they aren\u2019t spelled out in individual pictures. Her art isn\u2019t expressive that way: the opposite, really. It sometimes suggests the point-and-shoot blankness of tourist photography. Evidence of her investment tends to lie in how she returns to a subject or theme.", "title": "Zoe Leonard\u2019s Messages Strike Hard \u2014 and Cast a Spell", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Here are the steps the company is taking to address the issue:\n\n\u2022 \u201cWe will investigate all apps that had access to large amounts of information before we changed our platform to dramatically reduce data access in 2014, and we will conduct a full audit of any app with suspicious activity.\u201d\n\n\u2022 \u201cWe will restrict developers\u2019 data access even further to prevent other kinds of abuse.\u201d\n\n\u2022 \u201cWe want to make sure you understand which apps you\u2019ve allowed to access your data. In the next month, we will show everyone a tool at the top of your News Feed with the apps you\u2019ve used and an easy way to revoke those apps\u2019 permissions to your data.\u201d\n\nMr. Zuckerberg had drawn criticism for his response to how Cambridge Analytica improperly obtained data on 50 million Facebook users. In the days since the news first broke this weekend, he had not commented publicly on the crisis.\n\nThat contrasts with how other tech chief executives have addressed crises at their firms.\n\nKevin Roose and Sheera Frenkel of the NYT report:\n\nWhen a former engineer revealed a pattern of sexual harassment at Uber last year, Travis Kalanick, then the company\u2019s chief executive, said he would immediately open an investigation. When users complained about bugs and problems with the Apple Maps app in 2012, Tim Cook, the company\u2019s chief executive, released a statement that said \u201cwe fell short.\u201d And in 2011, when Netflix tried to split off its mail-order DVD business into a company called Qwikster, its chief executive, Reed Hastings, wrote a letter to the public. \u201cI messed up,\u201d he said. \u201cI owe everyone an explanation.\u201d\n\nSo why did it take so long for Mr. Zuckerberg to respond? Kate Losse, an early Facebook employee and Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s former speechwriter, told the NYT: \u201cMy guess is that what is giving Zuckerberg pause at this point is the question of how to acknowledge and explain this state of affairs while at the same time mitigating the concerns that will come from people finally understanding how this all worked.\u201d\n\n\n\nPeter Eavis\u2019s take: There was something missing from Mark Zuckerberg\u2019s response \u2013 a full explanation of why Facebook took so long to disclose the misuse of its data. As Mr. Zuckerberg noted, Facebook found out in 2015 that Aleksandr Kogan had violated company policies by sharing user data with Cambridge Analytica. Facebook users might ask why the abuse wasn\u2019t disclosed at the time. Often it has taken pressure from outsiders to get Facebook to reveal abuses of its network. An alternative approach would have been for Facebook to proactively disclose as much information as possible about the wrongdoing. Facebook users would most likely welcome a strong commitment from Mr. Zuckerberg to do just that.\n\nPhoto\n\nTakeaways from Powell\u2019s first Fed meeting.\n\nThe Federal Reserve, as widely expected, raised interest rates on Wednesday by a quarter of a percentage point. The bigger questions were about the strength of the economy and pace of future rate increases.\n\nOn those matters, the Federal Reserve has expressed more confidence in the strength of the economy.\n\nDot plot: Fed officials signaled they would raise rates at a quicker pace over the next three years. Policymakers now expect to hike rates three times this year, three times in 2019 and twice in 2020. At its December meeting, policymakers expected three rate hikes this year, but just two in 2019.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEconomic projections: Officials raised their median estimates for economic growth this year to 2.7 percent, up from 2.5 percent in December. Fed policymakers also expect inflation to run above 2 percent by 2019 and 2020.\n\nMr. Powell\u2019s news conference: The new Fed chairman expressed optimism about the current economic picture and said officials were trying to strike a balance between raising rates too slowly or too quickly. \u201cWe\u2019re trying to take that middle ground.\u201d\n\nMr. Powell left the door open to more or fewer than three increases this year, depending on economic conditions. \u201cLike any set of forecasts, those forecasts will change over time,\u201d he said. \u201cIt could change up. It could change down\u201d\n\nOn inflation, he added: \u201cThere is no sense in the data that we\u2019re on the cusp of an acceleration of inflation. We have seen moderate increases in wages and price inflation. And we seem to be seeing more of that.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWhy driverless cars are essential to Uber\u2019s future.\n\nThe answer has to do with car ownership. For years, Uber and its rivals have promoted the idea that people living in urban areas will turn to Uber to get to and from work and to run errands rather than buy a car.\n\nIf Uber can become an alternative to car ownership, that would greatly increase its potential market.\n\nA study last year from the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute, Texas A&M Transportation Institute, and Columbia University suggested that people might make the switch.\n\nBut for people give up their cars, the cost of using Uber would most likely have to fall far below current levels. The need for this drop in costs came up when Dara Khosrowshahi, the C.E.O. of Uber, recently sat down for an interview with David Solomon, president and C.O.O. of Goldman Sachs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHere\u2019s the write-up of the autonomous car portion of their conversation in a recent Goldman note to clients:\n\n\u201cUber stressed the importance not only of autonomous technology for the future of the company, but also the value it can create from developing that technology within its existing network. In order for Uber to truly become a legitimate alternative to car ownership it must take its per mile cost below the cost of car ownership, or $0.80-$0.90/mile, from the $2.50/mile it costs on average today for an UberX, according to management. While initiatives like pooling (50% of rides in some cities) and driver density can help to lower costs, autonomous is the single most transformative piece of the equation. Uber expects to partner aggressively on this front, noting that \u2018winning\u2019 is making sure every single autonomous player is plugged into its network.\u201d\n\nCalculating the fallout from the Uber self-driving car death.\n\nThe pedestrian fatality in Arizona is perhaps Dara Khosrowshahi\u2019s first major test as Uber\u2019s C.E.O., leaving him with a difficult choice: keep spending on a technology that Uber considers essential to its future, or dial back to reduce risks ahead of an I.P.O.?\n\nInvestigators are also looking into whether the victim\u2019s actions \u2014 suddenly stepping onto a darkened street \u2014 could limit Uber\u2019s liability.\n\nToyota has paused its self-driving tests; Ford and G.M. have yet to do so. Separately, Uber has hired Tammy Albarran from Covington and Burling as its deputy general counsel, replacing Angela Padilla.\n\nElsewhere in tech: The Russian cybersecurity company Kaspersky Labs has reportedly exposed a U.S. cyberespionage operation focused on ISIS. Expect a merger frenzy in lithium. Expedia\u2019s Orbitz disclosed a breach that affects about 880,000 payment cards. And Amazon has surpassed Alphabet as the second-biggest publicly traded company by market value.\n\nTesla\u2019s shareholders approve Musk\u2019s pay package.\n\nThe electric car maker\u2019s investors backed the board\u2019s proposal to grant Elon Musk, its C.E.O., stock options valued at $2.6 billion, Bloomberg reports.\n\nThe stock options won\u2019t vest unless a set of ambitious financial goals are met. \u201cMr. Musk will earn one-12th of the options every time Tesla hits a pair of goals: one tied to its market value and the other linked to either revenue or earnings excluding certain charges. For Musk to get all the options, Tesla would have to become worth $650 billion \u2014 more than Facebook Inc. \u2014 and produce more revenue than Procter & Gamble Co.,\u201d Bloomberg reports.\n\nPhoto\n\nPete Peterson is dead at 91\n\nThe billionaire \u2014 whose career highlights include being C.E.O. of a major industrial company at 36, serving in the Nixon administration, running Lehman Brothers, cofounding the Blackstone Group and doggedly arguing for reducing the U.S. deficit \u2014 died yesterday.\n\nMr. Peterson was always self-deprecating, once describing himself to the NYT as a \u201ckind of a closet, second-rate intellectual.\u201d And this is from a 2007 Lunch with the FT:\n\n\u201cLet\u2019s be honest,\u201d he says, \u201cdumb luck can play a huge role in life. It is all too easy in the 1990s for people to say I must be a genius investor because I got returns of 30 percent or whatever. If you combine a lot of leverage with a booming stock market it isn\u2019t all that difficult to make a lot of money, so I don\u2019t think we should get carried away with ourselves, frankly.\u201d\n\nWhat to expect from the forthcoming spending bill\n\nCourtesy of our colleague Tom Kaplan:\n\nBayer takes a big step toward closing its Monsanto deal\n\nEuropean antitrust regulators conditionally approved Bayer\u2019s $56 billion acquisition of its American rival, Monsanto, today, an important step for the deal as the agrochemical sector continues to consolidate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe deal is still awaiting approval from American regulators, with the German chemicals giant saying on Wednesdaythat it was \u201cworking closely\u201d with the Justice Department and other United States authorities. Bayer hopes to close the transaction by the end of the second quarter.\n\nTo win approval of European regulators, the companies said they would sell a variety of businesses, including agreeing to sell parts of Bayer\u2019s crop science business to BASF for about $7 billion in October.\n\nBayer has committed to sell its entire vegetable seeds business as part of its concessions, European regulators said in a news release on Thursday. Bayer previously said it was in exclusive talks with BASF about the sale of that business.\n\n\u2014 Chad Bray\n\nPhoto\n\nDoes Facebook need a new regulator?\n\nInvestors have sliced off $50 billion off the company\u2019s market capitalization. The Federal Trade Commission is investigating whether it has violated a privacy agreement. Britain\u2019s data protection watchdog has warned Facebook away from its Cambridge Analytica investigation. And a founder of WhatsApp urged his Twitter followers to delete their accounts.\n\nGiven all that, Paul Ford asks in Bloomberg Businessweek whether the U.S. needs a digital protection agency, comparing its potential scope to that of the Environmental Protection Agency.\n\nMark Zuckerberg, silent so far, is expected to speak about Facebook\u2019s latest scandal within the next 24 hours, according to Axios.\n\nCritics\u2019 corner\n\n\u2022 Sandy Parakilas, a former Facebook employee involved in its apps platform, writes: \u201cFacebook has systematically failed to enforce its own policies. The only solution is external oversight.\u201d (WaPo)\n\n\u2022 Shira Ovide says the damage may be permanent. (Gadfly)\n\n\u2022 Nick Thompson and Fred Vogelstein say Facebook may have taken the wrong lesson from past scandals: \u201cAll of those crises have passed with limited damage. And perhaps that\u2019s why the company appears to have underestimated the power of the storm clouds moving in.\u201d (Wired)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Google is investing $300 million to support journalism, even though it and Facebook inevitably hurt publishers to some degree. And Canada, South Korea and Australia are becoming worried about Huawei.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe race to avoid U.S. tariffs\n\nAt the Group of 20\u2019s meeting in Buenos Aires, finance ministers from France, Argentina, South Korea and elsewhere peppered Steven Mnuchin with requests for exemptions from President Trump\u2019s forthcoming tariffs on imported metal. The U.S. Treasury secretary said, \u201cThis is all about free and fair and reciprocal trade.\u201d\n\nThe problem: The White House hasn\u2019t said exactly what would qualify a country for an exemption (it has made vague references to protecting national security and reducing bilateral trade deficits).\n\nMeanwhile, the White House is ready to announce more tariffs and limits on Chinese investments as soon as tomorrow \u2014 risking a trade war that it can\u2019t win on its own, Michael Schuman argues on Bloomberg View.\n\nElsewhere in trade: The White House\u2019s efforts to renegotiate Nafta now include a bid to limit warning labels on junk food, according to the NYT.\n\nThe political flyaround\n\n\u2022 Congress continues to discuss its $1.3 trillion spending bill. Key witnesses will include Randall Stephenson of AT&T and Jeff Bewkes of Time Warner.\n\nElsewhere in media: A Fox News analyst resigned from the network, calling it Trump propaganda. Bill O\u2019Reilly is seeking dismissal of the defamation suit. And two books about Mike Pence\u2019s pet bunny are duking it out on Amazon.\n\nPhoto\n\nTravis Kalanick\u2019s next act\n\nHe\u2019s buying control of a distressed real-estate concern named Cloud Storage Systems for $150 million, and installing himself as C.E.O. In a statement, Mr. Kalanick said that part of the goal is to expand C.S.S.\u2019s expansion into kitchens and retail space for on-demand services. (The deal took about a tenth of his liquid net worth, Bloomberg notes.)\n\nMr. Kalanick\u2019s successor at Uber, Dara Khosrowshahi, congratulated him on Twitter \u2014 and suggested the two companies might work together.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nElsewhere in tech deals\n\n\u2022 Salesforce agreed to buy Mulesoft, whose software helps connect platforms and which went public only last year, for $6.5 billion in its biggest-ever acquisition. (WSJ)\n\nPhoto\n\nRevolving door\n\n\u2022 Gary Barber stepped down unexpectedly as C.E.O. of M.G.M. He recently renewed his contract there through 2022. (Hollywood Reporter)\n\n\u2022 William Voge stepped down as chairman of Latham & Watkins after disclosing sexual communications with a woman unaffiliated with the law firm. (TechCrunch)\n\nThe speed read\n\n\u2022 Michigan State University\u2019s endowment is trying to get ahead of divestment campaigns with four tests for whether to drop an investment. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 The National Institutes of Health plans a genome-sequencing and health-tracking project involving a million people; some critics say it\u2019s too big. The N.I.H. will also examine whether health officials violated federal policy when they met with alcohol companies to discuss funding a study on the benefits of moderate drinking.\n\n\u2022 James Packer, the Australian billionaire embroiled in a corruption scandal involving Israel\u2019s prime minister, has resigned as director of Crown Resorts. (NYT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The Equitable Building is getting a $50 million face-lift. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 United, which has had high-profile dog troubles, suspended its animal transport program. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Top financial supervisors for the eurozone have told banks to keep planning for a Brexit without transition arrangements. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Munich prosecutors investigating the emissions-cheating scandal searched BMW\u2019s headquarters. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Venture capital funds are returning less to investors when they sell companies than private equity funds do, as a share of money raised. (WSJ)\n\nWe\u2019d love your feedback. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Zuckerberg Breaks His Silence: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Calming employees was particularly vital because morale had sunk at the company, Facebook employees have said, especially after months of scrutiny over how the social network was used by Russian agents to influence the 2016 presidential election. Keeping workers engaged is crucial in Silicon Valley\u2019s highly competitive job market, where recruiting and retaining talent often is difficult against deep-pocketed rivals.\n\nEarlier this week, some Facebook employees had said that colleagues had started looking to transfer from the main social network product to other branches of the company, such as to messaging app WhatsApp and photo-sharing site Instagram, which have been relatively unscathed by the recent scandals.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne Facebook recruiter, who declined to be identified because of a nondisclosure agreement, said there were concerns that top talent might choose other Silicon Valley companies over Facebook.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s such a shocking difference for company employees who are used to having esteem for where they work,\u201d said Eric Schiffer, chairman of Reputation Management Consultants, a consulting firm, and who has been speaking with people at Facebook. \u201cTen years ago, Facebook was the hottest place to go out of college. This year, the best graduates are not necessarily looking at Facebook.\u201d\n\nWhen Mr. Zuckerberg did not appear at the Tuesday staff meeting hosted by the company lawyer, Mr. Grewal, his absence made headlines.\n\nWhen he spoke to workers on Wednesday, Mr. Zuckerberg focused on concrete measures that Facebook was taking following the Cambridge Analytica reports, two employees said. Staff members asked questions about how Mr. Zuckerberg planned to regain user trust, especially in light of the #DeleteFacebook campaign from users, the two employees said.\n\nMr. Zuckerberg said the social network was investigating apps like the third-party quiz app that had obtained access to \u201clarge amounts of information\u201d from the social network, which had then been used by Cambridge Analytica. He also said the company would restrict third-party developers\u2019 access and would notify users whose data had been harvested by Cambridge Analytica.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOf the #DeleteFacebook campaign, Mr. Zuckerberg told The New York Times in an interview, \u201cI think it\u2019s a clear signal that this is a major trust issue for people, and I understand that.\u201d\n\nThree Facebook employees said morale had improved following the interviews and the internal communications that Mr. Zuckerberg did on Wednesday. One of them said he had avoided a trip home to see his family last weekend because he did not want to answer questions about the company he worked for.\n\nOn Friday, Facebook\u2019s senior managers promised an open line of communication as the company continued to re-evaluate its privacy and security measures, said two employees.\n\nThere was a feeling, said one of the people, that Facebook wanted to take aggressive steps to make sure it could regain user trust. And over all, he said, confidence was up.", "title": "Zuckerberg Takes Steps to Calm Facebook Employees", "authors": ["Sheera Frenkel"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Independent researchers who have used data from Facebook said that Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s statement did not acknowledge how the gathering of user data was fundamental to the company\u2019s operations.\n\n\u201cHe avoided the big issue, which is that for many years, Facebook was basically giving away user data like it was handing out candy,\u201d said Jonathan Albright, research director at the Tow Center for Digital Journalism at Columbia University. \u201cThere is no question that handing out that data made Facebook the success it is as a company. This has to be recognized as part of their business model and not just a one-off problem.\u201d\n\nIn his statement, Mr. Zuckerberg laid out a timeline of Facebook\u2019s dealings with Cambridge Analytica. He traced the information-sharing issue to 2007, when Facebook decided to become an open platform \u2014 enabling people to use Facebook to log into other apps and share detailed personal information about themselves and their friends.\n\nIn 2013, Mr. Kogan, the Cambridge researcher, created a personality quiz app that about 300,000 people installed, Mr. Zuckerberg wrote. Because Facebook was an open platform, Mr. Kogan was able to collect data on tens of millions of friends of those users who had installed the personality quiz app.\n\nA year later, Mr. Zuckerberg said, Facebook changed its policy to limit how much data third-party apps could access. \u201cThese actions would prevent any app like Kogan\u2019s from being able to access so much data today,\u201d he wrote.\n\nBy 2015, Mr. Kogan had shared his data and findings with Cambridge Analytica, which later used the material to single out American voters. Mr. Zuckerberg said Facebook had banned Mr. Kogan\u2019s app and demanded that the researcher and Cambridge Analytica formally certify that the data had been deleted. He did not address in his post why Facebook had not already disclosed those activities to its users whose data had been harvested by Mr. Kogan and Cambridge Analytica.\n\n\u201cWhenever there\u2019s an issue where someone\u2019s data gets passed to someone who the rules of the system shouldn\u2019t have allowed it to, that\u2019s rightfully a big issue and deserves to be a big uproar,\u201d Mr. Zuckerberg said in the interview.", "title": "Zuckerberg, Facing Facebook\u2019s Worst Crisis Yet, Pledges Better Privacy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "BEIRUT, Lebanon \u2014 When pro-government forces retook her hometown from Syrian rebels, Nisrine accepted the same surrender deal the government has offered tens of thousands of Syrians: a one-way bus trip to a place she had never been \u2014 the northern, rebel-held province of Idlib.\n\nSince Syria\u2019s war began, the population of Idlib has doubled as it has taken in a motley mix of fleeing civilians, defeated rebels, hard-line jihadists and those like Nisrine who have packed up their families to ride the government surrender bus.\n\nBut as government forces wrap up a blistering campaign in eastern Ghouta, Idlib is likely to be the next target. And this time, there will be nowhere else to run.\n\n\u201cMaybe this is the last chapter of the revolution,\u201d Nisrine, 36, an Arabic teacher from the onetime tourist resort of Madaya, said in an online interview recently. \u201cSyrians are killing Syrians. Nothing matters anymore. We decided to die standing up. I\u2019m sad for the revolution, how it\u2019s gone, how people called for freedom and now it\u2019s gone.\u201d", "title": "\u20182 Bitter Options\u2019 for Syrians Trapped Between Assad and Extremists", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Paul Newman\u2019s Rolex Daytona may be one of the world\u2019s most coveted of timepieces, but a Timex Indiglo or a Sears Winnie the Pooh watch also can mean a great deal to their owners. For his book, \u201cA Man and His Watch,\u201d published by Artisan, the writer and magazine editor Matt Hranek talked with a cross section of men, from actors to NASA engineers, about how they connect with their watches. This interview was edited and condensed.\n\nThe book design is simple: close-up images of the watches on one page and the owners\u2019 stories on another.\n\nImage\n\nI just wanted people to dive into the richness of what the timepieces look like. We show all the history, patina and nuance of the watch, whether it\u2019s dirt or crud or dings and scratches. It\u2019s about the storytelling of the journey of the piece itself. Eric Ripert [the chef at Le Bernardin] has a big ding in the top left of his 1921 Vacheron Constantin. He wears that in the kitchen every day.\n\nHow did you choose your subjects?\n\nIt couldn\u2019t just be the luxury brand groups. So I knew Atom Moore, who is this great character in the watch world, had this crazy collection of Keith Haring Swatches. But I also wanted a style icon like Ralph Lauren to represent the fashion world for me.", "title": "\u2018A Man and His Watch\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Have you read the book \u201cA Wrinkle in Time\u201d? Have you seen or do you plan to see the film adaptation? If so, what do you think of the director\u2019s casting decisions and changes to the plot and characters? In your opinion, do these artistic liberties enhance or hinder the viewing experience?\n\nWhich \u2014 if any \u2014 of your favorite childhood books would you want to see made into a movie and why? Who would you choose to play the characters? Would you make any modifications for the film version? Why or why not?\n\nOr, are there any books that you loved so much that you wouldn\u2019t want them to be made into a film \u2014 maybe because you have special memories of them, you imagined your own vivid pictures of the characters and setting, or you think some books wouldn\u2019t translate well to the big screen?
