Because he is a taskmaster and a visionary and a billionaire, people in Hollywood and Silicon Valley pay close attention when he speaks.\n\nHe has so many vests from Herb Allen\u2019s Sun Valley retreats for global elites that they\u2019re taking over his closets.\n\n\u201cThere is so much fleece,\u201d says the chairman of IAC, laughing. \u201cI\u2019ve been going for 30 years.\u201d\n\nOn this rainy afternoon, by the fireplace in the Frank Lloyd Wright-inspired stone and wood living room of his dreamy mansion, Mr. Diller is all charm, with a healthy dose of self-deprecation. He\u2019s dressed in a red checked flannel shirt, a burgundy Herm\u00e8s hoodie, baggy jeans and black Tod\u2019s loafers.\n\nWe are eating cold salads and drinking hot tea, served by the butler, Victor. And we are hopscotching topics, from Silicon Valley taking over Hollywood to Jared & Ivanka & Josh & Karlie to pornography to his company\u2019s dating websites to the time Harvey Weinstein tried to throw Mr. Diller off a balcony in Cannes to how his friend Hillary Clinton is faring to the mogul\u2019s dismissal of Donald Trump (whose Secret Service code name is Mogul) as \u201ca joke\u201d and \u201cevil.\u201d", "title": "\u2018All Men Are Guilty,\u2019 Says Mega-Mogul Barry Diller", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "GILBERT, W.Va. \u2014 Home from a long day teaching English last month at Mingo Central High School, Robin Ellis told her husband the latest talk among the teachers. They were tired of low pay and costly health benefits \u2014 and they were mulling a \u201crolling strike,\u201d in which teachers in a few counties would walk out each day.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t want to do that,\u201d Donnie Ellis, her husband, said. As a veteran of strip mines and the intense labor conflicts that often came with them, he knew what made some strikes succeed and others crumble.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s got to be all-in or nothing,\u201d he said.\n\nIt has definitely been all-in in West Virginia. For seven days now, teachers have refused to work in all 55 counties, shutting down every school in the state.\n\nEvery school day since last Thursday, thousands of red- and black-clad teachers, bus drivers and cooks have descended on Charleston to fill the halls of the State Capitol, chanting and singing defiantly in one of the few statewide teachers\u2019 strikes in American history.", "title": "\u2018All-In or Nothing\u2019: West Virginia\u2019s Teacher Strike Was Months in the Making", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Over the longer term, they must straighten out the strategic incoherence surrounding Mr. Trump\u2019s approach to Russia and China, defining the meaning of the administration\u2019s policy declaration earlier this year that \u201cgreat power competition \u2014 not terrorism \u2014 is now the primary focus of U.S. national security.\u201d\n\nWashington is now consumed by a debate over whether Mr. Trump\u2019s new team plans to govern as far to the right as it talks.\n\nSo far, the incoming national security adviser, John R. Bolton, has declared that his past comments are \u201cbehind me.\u201d Hours after his selection was announced, Mr. Bolton vowed that he would find ways to execute the policies that Mr. Trump was elected on, but that he would not tolerate slow-walking and leaks from bureaucrats he dismissed as \u201cmunchkins.\u201d\n\nSome who know Mr. Bolton and his operating style predict titanic clashes.\n\nDefense Secretary Jim Mattis, the retired general who has argued for keeping the Iran deal intact and warned that military confrontation with North Korea would result in \u201cthe worst kind of fighting in most people\u2019s lifetimes,\u201d told colleagues on Friday that he did not know if he could work with Mr. Bolton. The White House chief of staff, John F. Kelly, another retired four-star general, was also unenthusiastic about Mr. Bolton\u2019s hiring.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Bolton\u2019s harshest critics \u2014 mostly Democrats, but their ranks include some members of the Bush administration \u2014 argue that the odds of taking military action will rise dramatically when he becomes the last person a volatile American president consults.\n\n\u201cJohn Bolton is not some gray bureaucrat whose views are unknown to us,\u201d said Michael McFaul, the American ambassador to Moscow under President Barack Obama, and now a Stanford professor and the director of the Freeman Spogli Institute for International Studies.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s very clear that there should be regime change in Iran and North Korea, and military force should be used to achieve those goals,\u201d Mr. McFaul said. \u201cIf you hire him, you\u2019re making a clear signal that\u2019s what you want.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut others who have worked for years with Mr. Bolton argue that Mr. Trump knows exactly what he is getting: leverage, not conflict.\n\n\u201cI think this notion everybody talks about, that the risks of war have gone up, is wrong,\u201d said Stephen J. Hadley, who was Mr. Bush\u2019s national security adviser and a major architect of the invasions of Afghanistan in 2001 and Iraq in 2003. \u201cThis is the peace-through-strength crowd who want to make clear to people that they\u2019re tough and that no one should cross them. But the reason for that is to deter war.\u201d\n\nDov Zakheim, a former senior Defense Department official who has known Mr. Bolton for 35 years, wrote on Friday that Mr. Bolton \u201cmay be a fire breather, but he is a man who cares deeply about his country,\u201d in comparison to his boss, who \u201ccares deeply about Donald Trump.\u201d\n\nWhatever Mr. Trump\u2019s motives, his selection of this team would have been hard to imagine when he first came to office declaring that the continued American presence in Iraq was a \u201cdisaster,\u201d that he was comfortable with Japan and South Korea getting their own nuclear weapons so the United States would not have to defend them, and that America would no longer be the world\u2019s policeman.\n\nMr. Bolton has come to the opposite conclusion.\n\nHe not only fervently advocated the attack on Saddam Hussein from his post at the State Department during the Bush administration, but he also defended its aftermath, and has said he remains convinced it was the right decision. Over the past three years, Mr. Bolton has advocated bombing Iran, attacking North Korea, and carving a new state out of Iraq and Syria.\n\nMike Pompeo, the nominee for secretary of state, said at the Aspen Security Conference in July that the most dangerous thing about North Korea was the fact that its young, moody and reportedly ruthless leader, Kim Jong-un, controls its weapons.\n\n\u201cSo from the administration\u2019s perspective, the most important thing we can do is separate those two. Right?\u201d said Mr. Pompeo, who at the time was months into his current job as C.I.A. director. \u201cSeparate capacity and someone who might well have intent, and break those two apart.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAssuming that Mr. Pompeo is confirmed, he and Mr. Bolton, the two most forceful, aggressive new members of the policy team, will have to decide in what order they can risk those confrontations. The Trump administration has said it is open to direct talks with Mr. Kim by May \u2014 the same month by which the president has said he will scrap the Iran nuclear accord.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEven if you are going to be a superhawk, you can\u2019t do all these at once,\u201d said Rolf Mowatt-Larssen, a former C.I.A. station chief in Moscow who later hunted down Pakistani nuclear technology as the Energy Department\u2019s chief intelligence officer. \u201cAnd if you want to go to war with Iran and North Korea, you have to expect to alienate your allies and run headlong into the Russians.\u201d\n\nWilliam J. Burns, a longtime American diplomat who was Mr. Bush\u2019s ambassador to Russia and Mr. Obama\u2019s deputy secretary of state, predicted that if the new team exits the Iran deal and confronts North Korea, the first beneficiary is likely to be President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.\n\n\u201cHe looks for splits,\u201d Mr. Burns said of Mr. Putin. \u201cHe knows he will benefit if we walk away from the Iran deal, because it will put a wedge between us and our European allies.\u201d\n\nOn North Korea, Mr. Burns said, Mr. Putin is seeking \u201csplits between the U.S. and China. We are doing his work for him.\u201d\n\nIn fact, it is in dealing with Mr. Putin that the new team is likely to run headlong into Mr. Trump\u2019s reluctance to ever say a critical word about the Russian president. As C.I.A. chief, Mr. Pompeo has embraced the intelligence community\u2019s conclusion that Russia meddled in the election, though he changes the subject quickly when asked about it.\n\nMr. Bolton, by contrast, has ranked among Mr. Putin\u2019s harshest critics. Last July, days after Mr. Trump met Mr. Putin for the first time at a summit meeting in Germany, Mr. Bolton wrote that the Russian interference in the 2016 election was \u201ca casus belli, a true act of war, and one Washington will never tolerate.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump did not view it that way.\n\nHe emerged from the meeting in Germany repeating Mr. Putin\u2019s observation that the Russians were too skilled at cyberoperations to be caught if involved. Last week, Mr. Trump called Mr. Putin to congratulate him on winning a Russian election widely viewed as a sham, making no mention of the recent nerve-agent attack that Britain concluded, with American agreement, was a covert action by Moscow.\n\nIf it was, it was being planned out as Mr. Pompeo was acting as the host to the directors of the three major Russian intelligence services in Washington earlier this month.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe unknown factor in the new mix is Gina Haspel, the career intelligence officer who has been nominated to be the first woman to run the C.I.A. Since she has spent much of her career undercover \u2014 details of which the agency is just beginning to release, in an effort to lobby for her confirmation \u2014 her foreign policy views are largely unknown.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut her record in the terrorist detentions and interrogations following 9/11 is well documented. Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who was tortured as a prisoner of war, this past week pointedly asked in a letter to Ms. Haspel, \u201cDo you believe actions like these were justified, and do you believe they produced actionable intelligence?\u201d\n\nAt a moment when Mr. Trump has sided with the economic nationalists in his administration and ordered the imposition of tariffs on China to counter its restrictions on American companies and the forced transfer of American intellectual property, Mr. Bolton has gone one further.\n\nHe has questioned whether the United States should abandon the \u201cOne China\u201d policy that has been the underpinning of relations since the two countries resumed diplomatic relations.\n\nIn 2016, Mr. Bolton wrote that confronting China \u201cmay involve modifying or even jettisoning the ambiguous \u2018One China\u2019 mantra, along with even more far-reaching initiatives to counter Beijing\u2019s rapidly accelerating political and military aggressiveness in the South and East China Seas.\u201d\n\nIt is unclear how that squares with Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign argument that the United States should pull its forces back from Asia unless South Korea and Japan pay more of the cost of keeping them there.\n\nBut the most immediate decision facing the new team will be the benefits and costs of exiting the Iran deal. Mr. Trump cited his differences with Rex W. Tillerson on Iran in firing the secretary of state.\n\nMr. Bolton and Mr. Pompeo have been among the harshest critics of the nuclear accord, but they have not said how they would manage the international backlash if Mr. Trump decides, by a May 12 legislative deadline, to resume the sanctions that the United States suspended when the deal was reached.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf Washington breaches the deal, Iran may declare it is now free to resume producing nuclear fuel in unlimited quantities \u2014 limits it agreed to, for 15 years, in return for economic normalization. If so, that could put the United States and Israel back where they were in the years before the accord was reached: threatening military action to destroy Iran\u2019s facilities, even at the risk of another Middle East war. That was the path Mr. Bolton advocated.\n\nIn August, when Mr. Tillerson and Mr. Mattis wrote a joint op-ed article in The Wall Street Journal describing the merits of building economic pressure on North Korea in a policy of \u201cstrategic accountability,\u201d Mr. Bolton said he was \u201cappalled.\u201d\n\n\u201cTime is not a neutral factor here,\u201d he said on Fox News, where he was a contributor. \u201cMore negotiation with North Korea? I think they\u2019d say \u2018bring it on.\u2019 More time to increase the size and scope of their ballistic missile and nuclear capabilities.\u201d He will now be preparing Mr. Trump for that negotiation.", "title": "\u2018America First\u2019 Bears a New Threat: Military Force", "authors": ["David E. Sanger", "Gardiner Harris"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.\n\nA retired Marine sergeant on what it\u2019s like to kill for the first time, a foreign correspondent on his kidnapping by the Taliban, a veteran\u2019s parents on the suicide of their son \u2014 all of these deeply personal firsthand accounts from America\u2019s military conflicts in the Middle East originated on At War, a somewhat rogue operation of a blog that The Times ran from 2009 to 2016.\n\nOn March 20, the 15th anniversary of the invasion of Iraq, At War officially returns. Now part of The New York Times Magazine, the new iteration will continue to tell stories of the American war experience while expanding its coverage to global conflicts and their outcomes, including the continuing refugee crises. The first essay looks back at March 20, 2003, through the eyes of a veteran Marine lieutenant who led a platoon of six tanks into Baghdad.", "title": "\u2018At War,\u2019 The Times\u2019s Renegade Blog From the Front Lines, Returns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Last season, Alfred (a.k.a. \u201cPaper Boi\u201d) stumbled toward rap relevancy while cousin Earn shrugged his way into a music manager role. They both fell haphazardly into modest fame \u2014 by way of notoriety \u2014 and it seemed possible that they\u2019d return to show off a little bit this time around. Instead, we find them stuck on the same sofas, cruising the same struggling streets and hamstrung by the same old obstacles (rap sheets and general inertia).\n\nThe only thing that\u2019s changed is Earn\u2019s kick-the-can approach to lodging has resulted in yet another bout of homelessness. He\u2019s been booted from his storage unit squat and can\u2019t even find refuge at his cousin\u2019s condo. As for Al and Darius, the roommates have bad blood brewing and no one will speak on it.\n\nDarius is the show\u2019s lone reliable source of levity, so when things aren\u2019t buzzing harmoniously on his weirdo astral plane, morale is low overall. He keeps the episode\u2019s eerie tone going when he pivoted from discussing the everyday horrors of area crime sprees to sharing the urban legend of \u201cFlorida Man.\u201d Earn laughs off Darius\u2019s accounts of the white boogeyman, a goof on the meme inspired by the state\u2019s penchant for insane headlines. But the director Hiro Murai gives the tale a dark folkloric edge that raises goose bumps.\n\nAll this bad mojo was leading up to the big showdown between Earn and his uncle Willy. Al, who\u2019s stuck at home on house arrest, tasked Earn with peacekeeping duties when he got word that Willy was holding a woman against her will. Played by comedian Katt Williams (who\u2019s no stranger to legal drama), Willy\u2019s the bitter, combative relative most of us have and would just as soon avoid. He\u2019s a robe-sporting, chain smoking, venom-spewing cautionary tale for Earn. Willy\u2019s outworn his use to those around him, but he\u2019s still living off Al\u2019s handouts, in a house that Al\u2019s paying for.\n\nDarius was right when he pulled up to the house and sensed that the vibes there were \u201cjust so intense.\u201d A dispute over $50 led to a low-key hostage situation. Oh, and while Willy\u2019s girlfriend is locked up in one room, there\u2019s a live alligator inexplicably locked in another. (Neighborhood kids call Willy \u201cAlligator Man,\u201d dropping the episode title.)\n\nWith the police waiting at the door and tensions running high, Earn and Willy get into a heated discussion.\n\n\u201cYou scared,\u201d Willy reasons. \u201cYou gotta stay on [Al\u2019s] good side now, \u2019cause he\u2019s Mr. Money Bags. I remember Uncle Jarvis used to manage Damon when he was in that group. Now, they don\u2019t even talk no more, \u2019cause you find out family is business.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNo, Earn spits back, what he\u2019s actually scared of is turning into Willy, a guy who wasted his shot and is now just a know-it-all screw-up who just lets life happen to him.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSo far, most signs point to this being Earn\u2019s destiny. He\u2019s been floating through life, wincing and sighing as his housing prospects dwindle, his criminal record racks up points and his past Ivy League laurels fade into irrelevance. He seems to feel he\u2019s above it all, even as he\u2019s drowning in it.\n\nWilly\u2019s final word of advice was simple and on point: \u201cIf you don\u2019t wanna end up like me, get rid of that chip-on-your-shoulder \u2026 It\u2019s not worth the time.\u201d\n\nWith nothing left to say, Earn agrees to hide his uncle\u2019s contraband golden gun from the cops and figured his de-escalating work there was done. But instead of Willy\u2019s expected surrender to the cops, we get that signature left-field element we\u2019d been waiting for in the form of the aforementioned reptile.\n\nTo paraphrase legendary local lyricist Big Boi, \u201cwhile the gator\u2019s creeping, crawling, oh so wicked\u201d out the front door, the cops are too distracted to notice Willy making a hasty backdoor escape in his robe and houseshoes. Though he\u2019s clearly doomed, it\u2019s hard not to wish him well. Because if there\u2019s hope for him, there may be hope for Earn, too.\n\nThe writers returned from their protracted break offering up more questions than answers. It\u2019s not clear how much time has transpired since we last left the core trio. No one knows why Darius and Al have beef at the top of the episode. Who are Uncle Jarvis and Damon, and what did Willy do to Earn\u2019s mom that\u2019s left him carrying a grudge? Will the teens in the opening robbery be relevant down the road?\n\nBut while you may leave the episode feeling fuzzy about back stories and unsure of whether certain characters will pop up again, you do at least have a clearer understanding of just why Earn\u2019s wary parents don\u2019t let him cross their threshold. It\u2019s because they\u2019ve already seen the blueprint for what he\u2019s becoming. You also see that Darius and Al share that kind of tight-knit bond that allows friends to be unspeakably angry one day, then seamlessly in sync the next. These new layers offer clues as to how these three will progress (or regress, as the case may be) going forward.\n\nA Few More Vibes\n\n\u2022 Darius is back in his chicken-printed apron again. But this time, his sour mood has affected his cooking: He\u2019s left plating unappetizing sliders. \u201dBe careful. It\u2019s very, very cold.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Earn, in an attempt to help Alfred and Darius squash their mysterious beef, sincerely tells them he loves them both. He\u2019s then roasted mercilessly because, apparently in their world, there\u2019s no funnier punch line than a man showing vulnerability and expressing his feelings.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Earn to Darius: \u201cWhat flavor is a Flamin\u2019 Hot Cheeto?\u201d Darius shrugs: \u201cHot.\u201d Earn samples another: \u201cI am tasting \u2018hot.\u2019\u201d Though hilarious in its inanity, this little exchange is juxtaposed with the sights and sounds of a crime scene just across the street.\n\n\u2022 Uncle Willy, despite being accused of kidnapping a woman, insists that Earn and Darius take off their shoes before entering his house.\n\n\u2022 \u201cLooks like an Azealia Banks Snapchat,\u201d Darius says, upon looking in on Willy\u2019s alligator to find it surrounded by chicken carcasses. (It\u2019s a rather obscure reference to the rapper-singer\u2019s 2016 video confession about her witchcraft ways.)\n\n\u2022 The lyrics to Curtis Mayfield\u2019s \u201cWhen Seasons Change\u201d \u2014 which played the episode into the closing credits \u2014 read like an outline of everything we just watched (\u201cTime makes you suffer when seasons change/Can\u2019t call no names when you got your own self to blame\u201d).", "title": "\u2018Atlanta\u2019 Season 2 Premiere: It\u2019s Robbin\u2019 Season", "authors": ["Leigh-Ann Jackson"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "The string of Fresh scenes \u2014 visually both brighter and whiter than is usual for \u201cAtlanta \u201d \u2014 jab at the fact that even as the music industry has gotten a high-tech makeover, the practice of exploiting black youth culture persists. There\u2019s the visual of a young rapper energetically performing on top of a boardroom table as executives stoically appraise him. There\u2019s the audio guy prompting Al to be \u201cmore cool\u201d and to act \u201clike you\u2019re at a party\u201d (code for \u201csound more black\u201d) as he\u2019s recording promo spots. Then there\u2019s the scene in which Earn\u2019s just mills about the office, munching Cheerios, until he realizes every other person is wordlessly watching him. Once they know he\u2019s onto them, they quickly spark back into motion.\n\nThis speaks to a feeling known all too well by those who\u2019ve experienced \u201cthe only one in the room\u201d syndrome. For those who haven\u2019t: Being the lone minority in, say, a work environment or classroom can create an unsettling sense that people are silently observing your every move, no matter how mundane. Here the episode writer Stephen Glover brings that nagging notion to life.\n\nThe visit ends when Al storms out of an excruciating Tiny Desk Concert-style performance, after most employees can\u2019t be bothered to leave their cubicles to watch him rap \u201cPaper Boi.\u201d It\u2019s his second loss in less than 24 hours, and there are more to come.\n\nBack on the illegal grind, Al tries his luck with a second plug only to have the star-struck dealer post a stealthy, potentially incriminating photo of him onto Instagram. The third is a seemingly cool hippie bro who soothes Al\u2019s nerves with a potent smoke-out session and promises of discounted pricing. Alas, everything goes left when he loops Al into a group text with his \u201cgangster\u201d girlfriend, who turns out to be one of the millions of vanilla twentysomethings hunched over a guitar, trying to go viral with an acoustic rap cover. One video clip of her chirping his eponymous single is all it takes for Al to defenestrate his cellphone and burn that bridge, too.\n\nAfter his terrible, horrible, no-good, very bad trapping day, Al retreats to his living room comfort zone. Nearly everyone he had encountered were fans \u2014 from music biz types to dealers to fellow musicians \u2014 but each compliment seemed to grate his nerves raw. Networking isn\u2019t really his jam and he\u2019s not one for schmoozing, social climbing or, interpersonal communications with anyone outside his inner-circle. So why, exactly, is such an introvert courting fame? (And is Paper Boi reflecting all or just a fraction of Donald Glover\u2019s own reported mercurial moods and ambivalence about celebrity?)\n\nIf Al\u2019s considering changing careers, now might be the time, because his manager is a liability. That dog-breeding scheme Darius concocted in Season 1 proved to be surprisingly lucrative, making Earn $4,000 richer. It\u2019s a windfall that would certainly make his daughter\u2019s mom, Van, happy and might offer a solution to his persistent lodging problem.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAlas, grown-up thoughts like these never get a chance to take root, because Al\u2019s new couch-surfing ex-con friend, Tracy, lures him into a fool\u2019s gold charge card scam. \u201cYou give me the cash and I\u2019ll double it on any gift card you want,\u201d Tracy promises. Off they traipse to the mall, where Earn\u2019s real-world responsibilities are doomed to take a back seat.\n\nThe plan has failure written all over it, of course. (It may have been viable had a visionary like Darius pitched it.) How hard did you facepalm when Earn slumped back into the apartment bearing empty pockets and only a fraction of his mall haul?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe quickly descends into the doldrums with Al, smoking weed and watching TV. But their respite is interrupted by an incredibly catchy Yoo-Hoo ad starring Clark County, the rapper who, by contrast, made all the right impressions during his overlapping visit to the Fresh offices. On the TV screen, he\u2019s filled with the kind of animated swagger that disgusted Al and left Earn awe-struck. Here again, was the kind of career-spiking opportunity that Paper Boi would\u2019ve turned down flat. He never would\u2019ve received such an offer though, because his manager isn\u2019t even savvy enough to level up from burning demos onto blank CDs.\n\nWhile those two remained in their respective ruts, Tracy made plans to move up in the world. He had a job interview and was filled with gumption, despite his ex-convict status. First things first: He had to make sure his hair was perfect.\n\nTracy\u2019s wave cap expertise is where the episode gets its name, \u201cSportin\u2019 Waves.\u201d Watching these guys sit around sharing laughs and potshots about a hair care phenomenon that\u2019s pretty unique to black men \u2014 without expounding on its nuances for the benefit of a wider audience \u2014 felt like witnessing a secret handshake.\n\nAssured that his grooming was on point, all Tracy needs is the right pair of shoes to make his interview look complete. At the mall, he doesn\u2019t even bother using his own gift card scam (which should\u2019ve been a warning to Earn), preferring to employ a brazen five-finger discount. (\u201cThey got a no-chase policy; they can\u2019t stop me.\u201d) Armed with Earn\u2019s crib notes on how to talk to \u201cwhite folks\u201d \u2014 basically, \u201cdon\u2019t call them \u2018white folks\u2019\u201d \u2014 he was ready to put his best foot, and coif, forward.\n\nThe comically exaggerated finished product was equal parts Moe Howard and early-career Brian McKnight, glistening like a unicorn mane as Tracy expertly code-switches his way through the interview. (Earn would\u2019ve been proud.) Ultimately, though, being the \u201cKing of Waves\u201d \u2014 nay, the \u201cPrince of Tides\u201d \u2014 is not enough to land him the job.\n\nWas he actually the victim of racism, as he alleges on his way out? Was he stigmatized by his record? Maybe he just lacked the appropriate qualifications (none of us ever learned what the job was, anyway). Whatever held Tracy back, it certainly wasn\u2019t those \u201cmiraculous waves.\u201d They were baked to perfection.\n\nA Few More Vibes\n\n\u2022 That pet dragon that mesmerized Al at the hippie\u2019s place is the second prominent reptile this season, for those keeping score.\n\n\u2022 Anyone else notice the TV when Earn returned from the mall? If you blinked, you might\u2019ve missed the fake Dodge Charger commercial from last season\u2019s \u201cB.A.N.\u201d episode.", "title": "\u2018Atlanta\u2019 Season 2, Episode 2: Miraculous Waves", "authors": ["Leigh-Ann Jackson"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "To be fair, they don\u2019t end up shopping for limited edition sneakers, diamond-studded jewelry or any other ostentatious status symbols. Nor are they headed someplace lavish where they can pose for the \u2018Gram. No, the couple\u2019s idea of the glamorous life is catching a movie (VIP seats, whatever that means), then seeing where else the night takes them. Not too different from any other parents with a toddler.\n\nWhile the previous episode centered around Al\u2019s failures, this week it\u2019s Earn\u2019s turn, as he learns the hard way that a guy who looks like him can\u2019t just go around spending hundred dollar bills all willy-nilly. \u201cIt\u2019s legal U.S. tender!\u201d he keeps insisting. But it\u2019s not the green people are seeing, it\u2019s the brown. After declining to break such a large bill, a white movie theater employee is even suspicious of his debit card. And when Earn tries to plead his case to a nearby white theatergoer (who\u2019s able to successfully pay with a $100 bill), all he gets is a silent, menacing flash of the man\u2019s holstered pistol.\n\nTheir luck is no better at the hookah lounge Van picked out. The black African bar owner, having apparently accepted the worst stereotypes of black Americans \u2014 one half of a commonly acknowledged two-sided culture clash \u2014 calls the cops on them, accusing Earn of using counterfeit money.\n\nInstead of the trademark \u201cAtlanta\u201d satire, we get a face-value portrayal of everyday racism at its most insidious, tedious, exhausting and altogether unsurprising. In both places, Earn is scrutinized, held suspect and shunned just for being who he is and going where he wants to go. Without the show\u2019s usual subtle allusions and abstract allegories, these scenes drag. The writer Stephen Glover seems to have intentionally chosen not to be cheeky or overly clever when addressing such a mundane, unavoidable fact of life. He makes you feel the tiring grind of it all.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going somewhere where people definitely know how to treat people with money!\u201d Earn declares. Hearing that, anyone with even cursory knowledge of Atlanta knows he aims to hit up one of the city\u2019s famed strip clubs.\n\nHe gathers his crew (yes, even Van) and heads to Onyx nightclub (yes, it\u2019s an authentic local strip joint) in a rented white stretch limo. Though he was instantly bored by the club\u2019s lascivious sights, he knew for sure that he\u2019d found the perfect place for a young black man to fully and freely indulge his spendthrift tendencies.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAh, but the Rodney Dangerfield treatment keeps coming for Earn. The M.C. clowns his clothes and his meager tips. The dancers can barely be bothered to throw a wiggle his way. Meanwhile, the bartender and waitresses show him that not only will they accept his money, they\u2019ll deftly fleece him of it.\n\n\u201cYou told me the only thing I needed to run this city is money,\u201d Earn fumes. Al corrects him, \u201cMoney is an idea, man. There\u2019s a reason that a white dude dressed just like you can walk into a bank and get a loan and you can\u2019t even spend a hundred dollar bill.\u201d To further illustrate his point about money\u2019s ephemeral nature, Darius attempts to light a bill on fire.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey both empathize with Earn\u2019s plight and ultimately hit him with some frank advice: In order to get treated like he\u2019s better than other people, he needs to start acting like he\u2019s better than them.\n\nIf their skewed version of respect is truly what Earn\u2019s after, maybe it\u2019s time for him to tap into a little Princeton panache. Or, at the very least, an age-appropriate wardrobe.\n\nSmall Bills\n\n\u2022 Clark County\u2019s back, inviting Al and Darius to hang with him in the recording studio. He doesn\u2019t drink or smoke, but he\u2019s clearly high off bottled-up hostility, which he directs at his hapless sound engineer. Talk turns to his successful Yoo-Hoo ad and his spot on the latest \u201cFast & Furious\u201d soundtrack (the very same movie Earn tried to see at the theater). The secret to Clark\u2019s success is his manager, Luke. For the second time this season, he\u2019s been pitched as a possible Earn replacement for Paper Boi. Could the third time be the charm?\n\n\u2022 In the studio, Al and Darius get their first glimpse at the \u201cTub dubs,\u201d excitedly examining a stack of newly-minted Harriet Tubman $20 bills (not yet a reality offscreen). Black folks with money, black folks on money \u2014 cash rules everything around this episode.\n\n\u2022 Al\u2019s too rough around the edges to book TV commercials, but he has been approached about his own flavor of \u201cCocaine White Cheddar\u201d chips. FYI, the brand Rap Snacks is not just another one of the show\u2019s made-up Easter eggs.\n\n\u2022 Three film titles were visible at the movie theater: \u201c56 Nights,\u201d \u201cSand Pebbles 2\u201d and \u201cYung Buck.\u201d The first is the title of a mixtape by local rapper Future and the second is a fictional sequel to a Steve McQueen war flick. Anyone out there with an \u201cAtlanta\u201d decoder ring who can explain the significance of the third?\n\n\u2022 \u201cAtlanta\u201d often suggests the city\u2019s late-night parking lot scene attracts as much action as the clubs themselves. Outside Onyx, the former NFL quarterback Michael Vick is challenging drunk clubgoers to footraces. Though he\u2019s no stranger to such competitions, the scene comes off as weirdness for the sake of being weird in an episode that is mostly played straight. Then again, the setup offers Earn a chance to shoehorn an 11th hour victory. \u201cIt\u2019s Michael Vick,\u201d Van snaps after Earn\u2019s inevitable loss, playing the Lucy to his mortified Charlie Brown.", "title": "\u2018Atlanta\u2019 Season 2, Episode 3: It\u2019s Michael Vick", "authors": ["Leigh-Ann Jackson"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The moment they arrive at the Bavarian-style hamlet, she shakes off her previous concerns and giddily dives right into all the pageantry of the fastnacht festivities. She\u2019s ready to show off her dirndl, her braided halo and her German dance moves. She excitedly schools Earn on all the cultural dos and don\u2019ts as they approach the biergarten \u2014 including a caveat about the possible presence of attendees in traditional blackface.\n\n\u201cWhen you were a kid, didn\u2019t you feel weird about that?\u201d he asks incredulously, as two elderly white women gawk at them from the window of a curio shop.\n\n\u201cI used to,\u201d she replies nonchalantly. \u201cBut I\u2019m kind of like the Serena Williams of the festival. They hate, but they can\u2019t deny the stats.\u201d\n\nIf you\u2019re baffled by the customary games and unsettlingly creepy masks that fill the hall, then you\u2019re right there on Earn\u2019s wavelength. He was stuck stunned and staring most of the day. Meanwhile, have you ever seen Van smile as much as when she was playing those party games and working that room? She was so at-ease and confident, cocky even.\n\nThat is, until Earn\u2019s visible discomfort curbed her enthusiasm. He declined to dress up in lederhosen, wasn\u2019t picking up on any of the right social cues and refused to wear a mask like many of the other men. He quickly capitulated on that last one when a handsy reveler mistook his actual face for blackface. Subsequently, he spent the rest of the night donning a Jason-esque hockey mask. If you\u2019re stranded in a horrific situation, you may as well look the part.\n\n\u201cSometimes I feel like she wants me to be lame,\u201d Earn says to Dave, the boyfriend of Christina, Van\u2019s friend and the only other biracial woman at the event. That Dave\u2019s goofily going along with the event \u2014 and doing so in full traditional garb \u2014 yet doesn\u2019t feel personally slighted by Earn\u2019s comment tells you a lot about his overeagerness. (That he keeps peppering his speech with words like \u201cdawg\u201d and \u201cthe whip\u201d says still more.) All the same, he delivers a real nugget of wisdom: \u201cThat\u2019s what girls do when they like you. They just want to twist their life up with yours, that way it\u2019s harder to disconnect.\u201d\n\nIn a last-ditch effort to find common ground in such unfamiliar territory, Earn lures Van away from the dance floor for a quiet game of Ping-Pong. \u201cIt\u2019s the only white game I know,\u201d he pleads.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHere\u2019s where things start veering off course. She easily defeats him, but does so in front of an (eerie) audience, bruising his ego. Earn doesn\u2019t typically display much of an ego in the first place and her earlier comment about his lack of confidence in the bedroom likely did him no favors.\n\nAnd then the sniping starts. Though he knows she\u2019s in her element, he dismisses the festival as stupid. She points out that she acquiesces to his plans all the time, simply to spend time with him. Take last week\u2019s strip club outing as one example and Alfred\u2019s concerts as another.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s paying your bills,\u201d he snarls.\n\n\u201cYou can be real mean,\u201d she says, and then walks away. It\u2019s not the first time she\u2019s said those words to him. But it may be the last.\n\nShe tries to salvage her night by returning to the festivities, but finds no more comfort in her friend Christina. As it turns out, they\u2019re actually more like frenemies \u2014 not unlike Jayde from last season\u2019s all-Van episode, \u201cValue.\u201d Once again, Van is face to face with a woman from her past who\u2019s chosen a different life path, a choice that\u2019s driven an unspoken wedge between them. During an introduction to a pair of Christina\u2019s white friends, Van is referred to as both \u201cLotte\u2019s mom\u201d and \u201cEarn\u2019s girl,\u201d but never as an individual in her own right. It rubs her the wrong way, and she wants to get to the bottom of it privately.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cSince we were kids, I chose white, you chose black,\u201d Christina says gingerly, trying not to anger Van but also being condescending. \u201cIt\u2019s like you needed that identity.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou literally just told me that I\u2019m going to be a \u2018baby mama\u2019 and that\u2019s O.K. because I \u2018chose black!\u2019\u201d Van snaps.\n\nBy nightfall, she\u2019s lost a friend, a man (probably) and her cellphone, thanks to some traditional German \u201cdemon thief\u201d prankster. Her favorite festival has lost its luster and Van\u2019s left wandering the streets of Helen, on a tandem phone-searching and soul-searching mission.\n\nA flirty German-speaking bartender who had been sending vibes her way earlier sidles up during the phone hunt. Instead of hitting on her (Earn is walking a few steps behind them, after all), he helps her gain some perspective. \u201cYou should start a relationship with yourself,\u201d he advises.\n\nIt\u2019s good advice: Since losing her job, Van has been floating through life the way Earn does, and we\u2019ve all seen how that\u2019s worked out for him. One of them has to be the adult for their kid\u2019s sake, if nothing else.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe breaks from the pack to relieve herself in a dark alley, where she\u2019s terrified by the sound of a clinking bottle and heavy breathing. A tall figure wearing a monstrous mask is lurking behind her. (They laid the horror tropes on thick this episode.) She decks him, finds her phone nearby and finds the courage to finally speak her truth to Earn.\n\n\u201cI want to be in a relationship where I\u2019m valued as a human being and not as an accessory,\u201d she says.\n\n\u201cThis arrangement works for me,\u201d Earn replies. Right then and there, you\u2019d think a newly emboldened Van would turn on her heels and leave. Instead, she lets a Ping-Pong rematch decide their fate. Her terms: \u201cIf I win, then you don\u2019t have to see me unless it\u2019s about Lotte or money.\u201d\n\nMuch like everything else in his life, Earn doesn\u2019t put up much of a fight. If he\u2019d shown the same gusto he did in initiating last week\u2019s race against Michael Vick, Van may have seen some proof that his heart was really in their relationship. As it was, he begrudgingly picked up the paddle, she won the best out of five games and finally accepted the truth she\u2019d been avoiding all this time.\n\nThere\u2019s a moment during that final game where Van\u2019s lips curl into a determined smirk. It seems less about scoring a point and more about starting down the road to self-satisfaction. She looks ready to disconnect.\n\nMore Weird Swag\n\n\u2022 \u201cAre black women considered brunettes?\u201d That doesn\u2019t sound like a \u201chigh question\u201d at all, Van. Answers, please.\n\n\u2022 The biergarten crowd enthusiastically chants Earn\u2019s name when he apparently wins that perplexing party game. Was their excitement sincere? The game seemed so simple, yet they seemed unbelievably impressed by his performance. Had he actually won? Or were they just making a fool of him? This was yet another scene paying homage to \u201cGet Out.\u201d\n\n\u2022 The wallpaper on Van\u2019s lock screen is an image of Eartha Kitt. What\u2019s the connection? Well, for one thing, Kitt\u2019s breakout acting role was as a character named Helen \u2026 as in Helen of Troy, and the episode\u2019s title.\n\n\u2022 Is anyone going to explain the bespectacled old man in the track jacket who very noticeably kept popping up in the background throughout the day? He was getting his life. Earn should\u2019ve taken pointers.", "title": "\u2018Atlanta\u2019 Season 2, Episode 4: Game Over?", "authors": ["Leigh-Ann Jackson"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Season 2, Episode 5, \u2018Barbershop\u2019\n\nThe \u201cblack barbershop as sacred space\u201d trope isn\u2019t new; it\u2019s made the rounds in Hollywood, the art world, academia and beyond. Unfortunately for Al, this week\u2019s visit to a no-frills strip mall spot is steeped in none of the barbershop\u2019s fabled camaraderie, current events catch-ups or stress release. When he stops in to get \u201cthe usual,\u201d what he gets instead is all the worst barbershop experiences rolled into one, then exaggerated to \u201cCurb Your Enthusiasm\u201d proportions and spun through the signature \u201cAtlanta\u201d absurdist filter.\n\nWhether you\u2019re a chair regular or a shop newbie, there are some cut day experiences that are universal. Tardiness, personal calls and mid-cut snacking are all garden variety annoyances. From the moment that cape snaps up, you expect to hear about the barber\u2019s personal life and know full well you\u2019ll be forced to watch some viral clips on a smartphone.\n\nAl\u2019s barber does all of this in only the first three minutes. Played to shifty perfection by standup comedian Robert Powell III, the fast-talking hustler Bibby traps Al in a bottle episode of sorts. They may not be bound to one specific location, but all of the action revolves around the two men making their way through a seemingly endless to-do list.\n\nBibby has barely cranked up his clippers when his phone starts ringing. His girl\u2019s making angry demands on the other end and he\u2019s quick to jump in his pickup truck to go placate her. Absurdly enough, he\u2019s successful at luring Al along on this \u201cquick\u201d detour. How could Al refuse? He has only 5 percent of a haircut, and the barber-client code stipulates that he can\u2019t just jump into another chair and let someone else finish the job. No matter how fed up you are with the guy who tends your lines and edges, there\u2019s a loyalty there that\u2019s hard to shake.", "title": "\u2018Atlanta\u2019 Season 2, Episode 5 Recap: \u2018Barbershop\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDon\u2019t blink or you\u2019ll miss one of more than a dozen superheroes featured in the new trailer for \u201cAvengers: Infinity War.\u201d\n\nMarvel\u2019s all-star adventure brings together not only Iron Man (Robert Downey Jr.), Thor (Chris Hemsworth), Captain America (Chris Evans) and Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson) from the Avengers, but also the Guardians of the Galaxy (Chris Pratt\u2019s Star-Lord, Zoe Saldana\u2019s Gamora, Bradley Cooper\u2019s Rocket and Vin Diesel\u2019s Groot) and \u2014 oh yeah \u2014 Black Panther (Chadwick Boseman), whose stand-alone movie has grossed more than half a billion dollars in the United States alone.\n\nApparently it will take these combined superpowers and more to overcome the threat of Thanos (Josh Brolin, who\u2019ll play a different character in Marvel\u2019s forthcoming \u201cDeadpool\u201d sequel). The villain is on a quest to collect the six Infinity Stones, which will allow him to wipe out half the population of the universe.\n\nDirected by the brothers Anthony and Joe Russo, who also oversaw the 2016 smash \u201cCaptain America: Civil War,\u201d the latest Avengers installment looks to incorporate some of the cheeky humor that has set Marvel titles like \u201cGuardians of the Galaxy\u201d and \u201cDeadpool\u201d apart from the more serious films of its rival, DC Comics. After Dr. Strange (Benedict Cumberbatch) introduces himself to Peter Parker (Tom Holland), the web-slinger quips, \u201cOh, we\u2019re using our made-up names? Then I am Spider-Man.\u201d (For the record, the doctor\u2019s real name is Stephen Vincent Strange.)\n\n\u201cLet\u2019s talk about this plan of yours,\u201d Star-Lord says to Iron Man. \u201cI think it\u2019s good, except it sucks.\u201d Disney and Marvel hope moviegoers will feel more positively about \u201cAvengers: Infinity War\u201d when it lands in theaters on April 27.", "title": "\u2018Avengers: Infinity War\u2019 Trailer Unites Marvel\u2019s All-Stars", "authors": ["Bruce Fretts"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThirty years after Tim Burton\u2019s \u201cBeetlejuice\u201d arrived in cinemas, a musical adaptation is taking the stage.\n\nThe theatrical division of Warner Bros. announced Wednesday that the new musical, which has been in development for eight years, would have its first production at the National Theater in Washington in October, with the goal of then transferring to Broadway.\n\nThe musical, a comedy about a ghost seeking to scare a family out of a house, is being directed by Alex Timbers (\u201cPeter and the Starcatcher,\u201d \u201cBloody Bloody Andrew Jackson\u201d). The songs are by Eddie Perfect, an Australian musician who is also writing the songs for a musical adaptation of \u201cKing Kong\u201d that is scheduled to open on Broadway this fall; the book is by Scott Brown, a former theater critic for New York magazine, and Anthony King, the former artistic director of the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Timbers, who is also currently overseeing a musical adaptation of \u201cMoulin Rouge,\u201d said that with \u201cBeetlejuice,\u201d he is seeking to translate Mr. Burton\u2019s distinctive sensibility to the stage, including what he called \u201ca handcrafted aesthetic\u201d and \u201coutrageous, edgy humor.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOne of the things we\u2019re focusing on is the emotional story of the character of Lydia, who has an interesting inverted arc \u2014 she\u2019s a living girl obsessed with death, and Betelgeuse is a dead figure obsessed with life,\u201d Mr. Timbers said. \u201cThe film is a family drama, with the two Deetzes and the two Maitlands and Lydia and Betelgeuse all in one house, and we\u2019re also seizing on the house as a character, because it\u2019s inherently emotional and theatrical and fun.\u201d\n\nThe musical has had three readings and two laboratory workshops; Alex Brightman has played the title role in workshops, but the producers have not announced casting for the production.", "title": "\u2018Beetlejuice\u2019 Musical Is Heading to Washington, Then Broadway", "authors": ["Michael Paulson"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "But we already knew. In case there was any doubt, in fact, the song \u201cThe Next Big Thing\u201d by the New York proto-punk band the Dictators accompanies Taylor\u2019s arrival at Axe Cap\u2019s new Manhattan headquarters for Taylor\u2019s first meeting with the company\u2019s analysts. It\u2019s just one of several astute music cues \u2014 I counted Garrett T. Capps\u2019s \u201cBorn in San Antone,\u201d Mink DeVille\u2019s \u201cSpanish Stroll,\u201d and Lucy Dacus\u2019s \u201cTroublemaker Doppelg\u00e4nger,\u201d and may well have missed a few \u2014 that come with few previous associations, unlike the megahits dropped on viewers by many other series. The lack of pre-existing context makes you feel as if these characters were creating their own rock-star personas out of whole cloth.\n\nBut there\u2019s a reason that \u201cBillions\u201d is the show about Wall Street whizzes that even socialists can love. The most striking \u2014 and damning \u2014 aspect of all the power plays is the ideology behind them: There isn\u2019t one.\n\nNeither Axelrod nor Chuck shows the slightest sign of believing in some higher calling or deeper purpose \u2014 not a believable one at this point, anyway (Chuck can certainly muster an impassioned speech about truth and justice when it\u2019s convenient). You might expect this from the hedge fundamentalists: Their cause is capitalism, which they see not as a political arrangement but as a force of nature they can master like wizards. But when Rhoades brings up the concept of serving justice, it\u2019s a joke \u2014 deliberate, winking misdirection from the real reason he handed the Axelrod case to his own one-time nemesis, Oliver Dake. When Chuck and his colleague Kate Sacher (Condola Rashad) conspire to revive the financial cases that the business-friendly new administration has warned them not to pursue, they seem to do so more from pique and pride than from a zeal to right wrongs.\n\nThe political scene \u201cBillions\u201d portrays is equally amoral. The New York kingmaker Black Jack Foley (portrayed by the glamorously graying actor David Strathairn) has no agenda other than to secretly be in charge of whoever is publicly in charge of the state. This mentality tracks upward to the federal level as well. \u201cYou\u2019ve got some wolf in you,\u201d Attorney General Jeffcoat says to Chuck during their meeting, \u201cwhich is why you\u2019re not gettin\u2019 fired.\u201d Neither common ground nor principled bipartisanship has anything to do with it: Jeffcoat simply wants someone he knows he can count on to bring down big game when called upon to do so.\n\nRarely has Red Sanders\u2019s maxim \u201cWinning isn\u2019t everything; it\u2019s the only thing\u201d sounded quite so appropriate.\n\nNot even family, the last refuge of a prestige-TV scoundrel, is sacred. Bobby is in the middle of a divorce, and Chuck stabbed his father (Jeffrey DeMunn) in the back just to take down Axe, a favor the old man is eager to return. And while Chuck and Wendy\u2019s marriage appears to be on the mend, they\u2019re still keeping toxic secrets. During their bondage session, she flogs him while regaling him with details of an ostensibly imaginary liaison with another man at Chuck\u2019s request. But she never admits that such a liaison actually happened, and he never tells her that his father\u2019s private investigator uncovered the truth about it for him.\n\nSo if you\u2019re looking for an indictment of our age in here, look for it in what\u2019s absent \u2014 ethics, morality, any sense that there\u2019s a better way to run things. Chuck, Bobby, Taylor, Black Jack, Jeffcoat and the rest of the two warring tribes live these hard-charging, high-flying lives simply because they can. Money, politics, the law, even love: On \u201cBillions,\u201d they all come down to what you can get away with.", "title": "\u2018Billions\u2019 Season 3 Premiere: The Next Big Thing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLOS ANGELES \u2014 Oprah Winfrey pushing hard on the promotional circuit. Pent-up demand for a PG-rated Disney film. The first movie in four years from a filmmaker heralded as a visionary. A production and marketing budget of at least $150 million.\n\n\u201cA Wrinkle in Time\u201d (Disney), directed by Ava DuVernay, the first African-American woman at the helm of a big-budget studio film, and starring a diverse ensemble cast led by Ms. Winfrey, Mindy Kaling and Reese Witherspoon, had everything going for it. But, as often happens in Hollywood, the sum added up to less than its parts. \u201cA Wrinkle in Time\u201d arrived to a lackluster $33.3 million in ticket sales at 3,980 theaters in North America over the weekend.\n\nThat turnout placed it well behind Ryan Coogler\u2019s \u201cBlack Panther\u201d (Disney), which collected about $41.1 million in its fourth weekend, for a new domestic total of $562 million, according to comScore, which compiles box office data. After a sturdy debut in China over the weekend, \u201cBlack Panther\u201d crossed the $1 billion mark worldwide, shattering a myth about the overseas viability of movies rooted in black culture.\n\nTo avoid going down as a misfire, \u201cA Wrinkle in Time\u201d \u2014 primarily aimed at children ages 8 to 14 \u2014 must attract large numbers of families in the coming weeks, when schools begin spring breaks. However, Ms. DuVernay\u2019s movie, adapted from Madeleine L\u2019Engle\u2019s novel, received mostly weak reviews from critics and a B grade from ticket buyers in CinemaScore exit polls \u2014 results that typically do not translate to strong word of mouth.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cA Wrinkle in Time\u201d collected an additional $6.3 million in limited release overseas (about 14 percent of the international marketplace), according to Disney. It will roll out later in March in important markets like Britain, Mexico, Australia and Brazil.\n\nFor the weekend in North America, \u201cStrangers: Prey at Night\u201d (Aviron), a low-budget, R-rated horror movie, arrived in third place, collecting roughly $10.5 million. Two other new wide-release movies, \u201cThe Hurricane Heist\u201d (Entertainment Studios) and \u201cGringo,\u201d an Amazon-financed movie that was distributed by STXfilms, were dead on arrival, collecting less than $3.2 million each, according to comScore.", "title": "\u2018Black Panther\u2019 Dominates \u2018Wrinkle in Time\u2019 at Box Office", "authors": ["Brooks Barnes"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn the music industry\u2019s most closely watched copyright case, a federal appeals court on Wednesday upheld a jury\u2019s finding that Robin Thicke\u2019s song \u201cBlurred Lines\u201d infringed on the copyright of Marvin Gaye\u2019s \u201cGot to Give It Up.\u201d\n\nWhen the case went to trial in 2015, it became a flash point in the music industry over the limits of copyright. The family of Gaye, who died in 1984, argued that \u201cGot to Give It Up\u201d was copied without permission, and that it had helped make \u201cBlurred Lines\u201d the biggest hit of 2013.\n\nLawyers for Mr. Thicke and Pharrell Williams, who helped write and record the song, disputed that claim, and in the wider music industry, many worried that suit went too far in trying to protect generic elements of a song\u2019s style and \u201cfeel.\u201d\n\nA victory, opponents of the case warned, could lead more litigation and have a chilling effect on creativity. Since the dispute over \u201cBlurred Lines\u201d began, there have been several prominent settlements over credit and royalties. For example, even before the \u201cBlurred Lines\u201d verdict was announced, Sam Smith willingly shared credit for his hit \u201cStay With Me\u201d after Tom Petty said it sounded like his song \u201cI Won\u2019t Back Down.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven the appeals court decision, by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, reflected the dispute over the case\u2019s ramifications.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a ruling that for the most part was concerned with procedural issues, the judges upheld most of the trial court\u2019s decision and its damages award of $5.3 million. They reversed a decision that had also assigned liability to the rapper T.I., who contributed to the song, and Interscope Records, which released it.", "title": "\u2018Blurred Lines\u2019 Verdict Upheld by Appeals Court", "authors": ["Ben Sisario"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLogic, the Maryland-born rapper who performed his anti-suicide anthem \u201c1-800-273-8255\u201d at the Grammys and the MTV Video Music Awards, now has his second No. 1 on the Billboard album chart in less than a year.\n\nLogic\u2019s latest mixtape, \u201cBobby Tarantino II\u201d (Def Jam/Visionary), opened with 123 million streams and 32,000 copies sold as a full album in the United States, according to Nielsen, giving it the equivalent of 119,000 album sales.
