View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe rapper Lil Yachty opened at No. 2 with \u201cLil Boat 2,\u201d and two very different veteran artists reached their own chart peaks. David Byrne\u2019s \u201cAmerican Utopia\u201d opened at No. 3, his highest position ever. (Even Talking Heads, his former band, never reached higher than No. 15 on the album chart \u2014 for \u201cSpeaking in Tongues,\u201d in 1983.) Judas Priest also found its highest perch with \u201cFirepower,\u201d at No. 5 \u2014 reaching one spot higher than its previous album, \u201cRedeemer of Souls,\u201d did four years ago.\n\nBoth Mr. Byrne and Judas Priest were helped by a preponderance of traditional album sales, which are weighted much greater than streams in the formulas for determining chart positions.\n\nAlso this week, the \u201cBlack Panther\u201d soundtrack fell three spots to No. 4; in its five weeks out, it has been No. 1 three times.", "title": "\u2018Bobby Tarantino II\u2019 Gives Logic His Second No. 1 in Less Than a Year", "authors": ["Ben Sisario"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "This spring\u2019s Broadway revival of \u201cCarousel\u201d is revising its program after champions of the show\u2019s original choreographer, Agnes de Mille, objected to her absence from the Playbill.\n\nMs. de Mille\u2019s work on the original production, in 1945, is considered an important development in the history of musical theater, advancing the use of narrative dance fully integrated into a show\u2019s storytelling. And before her death in 1993, she reached an agreement with the Rodgers & Hammerstein Organization, which owns the rights to her work on \u201cCarousel\u201d and \u201cOklahoma!,\u201d under which her authorship would be acknowledged in future productions.\n\nBut the current production has its own choreographer, the acclaimed ballet designer Justin Peck, who has said that he celebrates and studied Ms. de Mille\u2019s work, but who created his own dances for the new show. And the producer of the revival, Scott Rudin, said via a spokesman that he was initially unaware of any commitment to Ms. de Mille, and that all the choreography in the revival is by Mr. Peck.\n\n\u201cThe producers of \u2018Carousel\u2019 were not made aware by Rodgers & Hammerstein of any contractual obligation that R & H had to credit Agnes de Mille for her work on the original production,\u201d wrote Rick Miramontez, a spokesman for the production. \u201cOnce the producers were informed of R & H\u2019s inadvertent and accidental omission of its credit obligation to Ms. De Mille, she was provided with a credit for her original choreography that was worked out between the producers and the R & H estate.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Carousel\u2019 Revival to Credit Agnes de Mille\u2019s Original Choreography", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "The bill passed, amnesty intact, but \u201cchain migration\u201d had been repurposed. A benign academic term had been borrowed and converted into a \u201cproblem,\u201d a ready-made salvo against lax immigration policies. It didn\u2019t seem to matter that these lax policies didn\u2019t quite exist. In theory, Daub was referencing the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965, which abolished the quota system of years past and prioritized family members as new immigrants. But the rush to sponsor family members had created a huge queue for that immigration category, which had, and still has, a yearly cap. A Government Accountability Office report from 1988 found that it was native-born citizens who filed 64 percent of sponsorship requests, and that those sponsoring family members typically waited about 12 years for their arrival. Once \u201cchain migration\u201d became wedded to United States immigration anxieties, though, these kinds of nuances were quickly lost. Chain migration became a scheme, a cheat \u2014 a way to take advantage.\n\nFor the next 30 years the two branches of \u201cchain migration\u201d would coexist: Demographers and urbanists still used the term to describe any network of support, and polemicists still maintained a conspiracy to circumvent border controls. Representative Alan K. Simpson, a Wyoming Republican and the author of those mid-\u201980s bills, wrote in a 1995 Wall Street Journal op-ed that he still aimed \u201cto end the problem of \u2018chain migration\u2019 \u2014 where one immigrant can bring in 30, 40, 50 or 70 people who are in-laws.\u201d The president echoed this language when he claimed that Sayfullo Saipov, the suspect in last October\u2019s Manhattan truck attack, brought over \u201c22 to 24\u201d people. But Saipov, as a green-card holder, could only sponsor a spouse or unmarried children under 21, and did neither. On the Senate floor, Jeff Sessions of Alabama opposed the Dream Act\u2019s provisions for people brought to the United States as children: \u201cFirst they receive conditional status, then legal permanent-resident status and finally citizenship. After they are naturalized, they can then, through the chain migration process, apply to bring in their relatives.\u201d The Congressional Record doesn\u2019t indicate whether Democrats booed this statement, but even if they had, they would have been a decade late.\n\nWhen Senators Durbin and Murphy object to talk of \u201cchain migration,\u201d they are taking a stance against the implicit prejudice behind it \u2014 the way that the term, like \u201canchor baby\u201d and \u201cgreen-card marriage,\u201d dehumanizes immigrants and misrepresents the difficulty of immigrating. Likewise, when the president and attorney general use the term, they\u2019re pushing against the na\u00efvet\u00e9 that shades some blanket defenses of all immigration. But neither group furthers the immigration debate or acknowledges the actual history of chain migration.\n\nThe chain is just a pattern of movement; the immigration system is the patchwork of policies and institutions that shape that movement. Deciding how this system should work is the point of politics. We could discuss the ways that immigrants bolster key American industries, whether surplus labor stagnates wages, how ICE flouts legal arrest procedures, how to prevent terrorism, the ways that Muslims in America are unjustly and ineptly surveilled, how much securing borders would improve public safety or how expensive walls can be. We know that immigration connects these concerns. And yet we\u2019ve never been willing to address them all that honestly. \u201cChain migration\u201d is part of the tradition of cunning partisan one-upsmanship and brokering we\u2019ve had instead. It has produced many a good line. What seems more useful would be good policy.", "title": "\u2018Chain Migration\u2019 Used to Be a Benign Term. Not Anymore.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMary Poppins Returns\u201d isn\u2019t Disney\u2019s only forthcoming reboot of a beloved British period piece. The studio just released the first teaser for \u201cChristopher Robin,\u201d a hybrid of live action and animation that finds the grown-up title character (Ewan McGregor) getting a visit from his old stuffed pal, Winnie the Pooh.\n\nThe huggable bear is voiced by Jim Cummings, replacing Sterling Holloway (who died in 1992) for a second time. Mr. Cummings also took over as Kaa the Snake in \u201cThe Jungle Book 2\u201d in 2003.\n\nPooh shows up to help out Christopher when he\u2019s struggling to balance the demands of his job with his commitment to his wife (Hayley Atwell) and daughter (Bronte Carmichael).\n\nOther characters from the Hundred Acre Wood who are expected to appear in the film but are neither seen nor heard in the trailer include Tigger (Chris O\u2019Dowd), Owl (Toby Jones), Kanga (Sophie Okonedo), Piglet (Nick Mohammed) and Eeyore (Brad Garrett). The movie is directed by Marc Forster, who brought a new take to the Peter Pan tale with \u201cFinding Neverland\u201d in 2004.\n\n\u201cGoodbye Christopher Robin,\u201d a biopic of the \u201cWinnie the Pooh\u201d author A.A. Milne starring Domhnall Gleeson and Margot Robbie, didn\u2019t find much love at the box office last year. Still, Disney hopes many millions of moviegoers will say hello to \u201cChristopher Robin\u201d when it hits theaters on Aug. 3.", "title": "\u2018Christopher Robin\u2019 Teaser Gives a Peek at a New Winnie the Pooh", "authors": ["Bruce Fretts"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "We met Frederick in the western CAR town of Boda, at a hospital run by an aid group called Alima. He\u2019s 5 years old, emaciated, with ribs pressing through his flesh, and weighs just 19.6 pounds. That\u2019s less than half the weight of an average 5-year-old in America.\n\nHis mom, Tefole Raissa, explained that they had fled fighting and no longer have land. \u201cI can\u2019t farm now,\u201d she explained. She doesn\u2019t remember the last time she ate meat or eggs; the family gets by on one evening meal a day of cassava, a starchy tuber with negligible nutrition.\n\nThis country is lush, with vast areas of untilled land, and nobody should go hungry. But violence changes everything. Collette Lundi, the mother of one desperately malnourished boy fighting for his life in a hospital, said her husband had been killed by a militia and their house destroyed, leaving the family with nothing to eat but small amounts of cassava.\n\nI asked if she ever eats meat.\n\nShe nodded and explained, \u201cWe try to catch rats.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Conflict Is More Profitable Than Peace\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "at 1 hour 47 minutes 58 seconds\n\nAround the Ferris Wheel\n\nThe opening on Thursday evening of Phelim McDermott\u2019s staging of Mozart\u2019s \u201cCos\u00ec Fan Tutte\u201d at the Metropolitan Opera was in many senses more successful than I had feared. The fairground, 1950s Coney Island setting baffled me even as it lent some gorgeous imagery, not least Amanda Majeski\u2019s Fiordiligi circling on a Ferris wheel for her great aria, \u201cPer piet\u00e0.\u201d But David Robertson\u2019s conducting, the playing of the orchestra, and some of the singing at least gave the affair more of the depth and darkness that other Mozart productions at the house have lacked. For properly dignified Mozart, however \u2014 for Mozart which takes us beyond ourselves \u2014 we must go back a few decades, to Karl B\u00f6hm, the Vienna Philharmonic and the sainted Gundula Janowitz. DAVID ALLEN\n\nReview: As James Levine Sues, the Met Opera Opens a New \u2018Cos\u00ec\u2019\n\nFrom Coney Island Sideshows to an Operatic Debut at the Met\n\nAn Opera Diva and a Broadway Star Trade Places, and Advice", "title": "\u2018Cos\u00ec\u2019 at the Met: The Week\u2019s Best Classical Music Moments on YouTube", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Emmich was in many ways a natural choice to take on the challenge. A singer-songwriter and actor who published a debut novel, \u201cThe Reminders,\u201d last year, he understood the emotional nuances of songwriting and performing on stage. He also felt he could relate to the play\u2019s protagonist \u2014 an isolated teenager who suffers from anxiety \u2014 and saw the potential to capture his voice in a first-person narrative.\n\n\u201cI really connected with Evan\u2019s tortured interior life,\u201d he said.\n\nPlenty of books have been turned into captivating theater: Alison Bechdel\u2019s \u201cFun Home,\u201d Mark Haddon\u2019s \u201cThe Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time,\u201d Hilary Mantel\u2019s \u201cWolf Hall,\u201d Alice Walker\u2019s \u201cThe Color Purple\u201d and Roald Dahl\u2019s \u201cMatilda,\u201d to name a few. But it\u2019s rare for an original Broadway musical to be reverse adapted into fiction. How do you translate the emotional highs of live musical theater \u2014 where so much drama is communicated through the songs and performance \u2014 into prose?\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cDear Evan Hansen\u201d may be better suited to novelization than most musicals. The play centers on a lonely, anxious teenager, Evan Hansen, whose therapist urges him to write encouraging notes to himself every day. When one of his notes falls into the hands of a classmate who commits suicide, Evan pretends that he and the boy were close friends. Much of the story\u2019s drama is internal, as Evan struggles under the weight of his secret \u2014 a feature that lends itself to fiction.\n\nThere\u2019s likely to be a large and eager audience for the novel. The play won six Tony Awards last year, and has grossed nearly $100 million.\n\nThe show\u2019s creators began thinking about an Evan Hansen novel last year, when they noticed that the story had developed a fan base beyond people who had seen it on Broadway. When the cast recording was released in February 2017, it debuted at No. 8 on the Billboard 200, and won the Grammy Award for best musical theater album. People published fan fiction about the characters online. Some fans said the story and the music had helped them cope with their own anxiety.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe have felt a certain discomfort with the fact that it is so expensive to come see the show, we can only have 1,000 people a night, and there are so many people who can\u2019t come to New York,\u201d Mr. Levenson said. \u201cThere were people responding to the show without having even seen it, and we did feel like, what are some ways that we can get this show to more people?\u201d\n\nThe novel fills in scenes that are only alluded to in the musical, like Evan\u2019s experience as an apprentice park ranger, and fleshes out peripheral characters. Mr. Pasek and Mr. Paul sent Mr. Emmich songs that never made it into the production, and Mr. Levenson sent him scenes that were excised from the script. He reworked the material into scenes and dialogue.\n\nWhen he felt stuck, Mr. Emmich played songs from the musical to help him settle on the right tone.\n\n\u201cWhenever I was unsure of what was going on beneath the surface of a character\u2019s emotions, I could always put on the music,\u201d he said.\n\nThe collaboration was mostly smooth, though occasionally there was back and forth about how much liberty Mr. Emmich should take with the story.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt \u201cwas a learning process,\u201d Mr. Emmich said. \u201cAt first, I was incredibly faithful to the play, and then they urged me to take more chances, which I was happy to do. Then they had to reel me back in.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Dear Evan Hansen\u2019 Goes From Stage to Page", "authors": ["Alexandra Alter"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIf you\u2019re a fan of the television subgenre that pairs a gifted, impulsive, often childlike male civilian with a tough, straight-arrow, lonely female cop, then you were probably a fan of \u201cCastle,\u201d one of the most successful shows of the type. (Other recent or current examples: \u201cThe Mentalist,\u201d \u201cPerception,\u201d \u201cForever,\u201d \u201cA.P.B.,\u201d \u201cLucifer.\u201d)\n\nYou\u2019re also in luck. Maybe. Because not one but two new examples of the genre are debuting soon. \u201cDeception\u201d on ABC, arriving Sunday, pairs a magician and an F.B.I. agent. \u201cInstinct\u201d on CBS, which has its premiere on March 18, pairs a professor and a New York police detective. \u201cDeception,\u201d with its bad-boy hero, has shades of \u201cThe Mentalist,\u201d and the academic aspects of \u201cInstinct\u201d recall \u201cPerception.\u201d But both owe a primary debt to \u201cCastle.\u201d\n\nSince they\u2019re essentially the same show \u2014 harmless case-of-the-week fluff hewing closely to a particular formula \u2014 we can assess them based on said formula: Which is more like \u201cCastle\u201d?\n\nPhoto\n\nThe hero: In \u201cDeception,\u201d Jack Cutmore-Scott (\u201cCooper Barrett\u2019s Guide to Surviving Life\u201d) plays a master illusionist who works with the F.B.I. to help his wrongly jailed twin brother. In \u201cInstinct,\u201d Alan Cumming (\u201cThe Good Wife\u201d) plays a psychology professor and author of three books who works with the New York Police Department because of his expertise \u2014 like Richard Castle, a mystery novelist who had studied criminal behavior. Advantage: \u201cInstinct.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe hero, Part 2: Mr. Cumming\u2019s Prof. Dylan Reinhart is also a former C.I.A. agent who quit spying to please his husband. Mr. Cutmore-Scott\u2019s Cameron Black is a pure civilian, like Castle, and more humor is milked from the contrast between him and his gung-ho partner. Advantage: \u201cDeception.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Deception\u2019 and \u2018Instinct,\u2019 the Latest Shows Trying to Be \u2018Castle\u2019", "authors": ["Mike Hale"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "MANCHESTER, England \u2014 Some of the women have blue hair, others, purple, some long and plaited, others short and shaved on the sides. Tattoos depicting skates, roses and eagle feathers peek out from behind their elbowpads and kneepads. They wear a streak of red makeup across their face with three dots below it, symbolizing three matriarchal generations: the grandmother, the mother and the self.\n\nOne by one, they pass around a shell filled with burning sage wafting fragrant curls of smoke toward their faces, chests and over their heads. Some cry silently and others smile, catching the eye of every member in their round. They hold one another like sisters, though they met in person just days ago.\n\nThis diverse group \u2014 astronomers, lawyers, postal workers, heavy machine operators, mothers, grandmothers and wives \u2014 is made up of indigenous people from different nations. But they are united for a surprising reason: a roller derby competition. And this is how they get ready for their game.\n\nTeam Indigenous, which includes 20 athletes from indigenous communities in Canada, the United States, South America, New Zealand and elsewhere around the globe, is one of 38 competing in the 2018 Roller Derby World Cup. It is the first such team to compete, and it is one of the few teams that are not mostly white.", "title": "\u2018Decolonizing\u2019 Roller Derby? Team Indigenous Takes Up the Challenge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI was on my way home on the A train one evening when a man got on and tried to engage a young woman seated across from me in conversation.\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t I know you?\u201d he asked, pressing toward the woman.\n\nHer effort to try to ignore him was coupled with an increasing frown and furrowed eyebrows. She pulled her limbs in close, tightening into a defensive ball.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think so,\u201d she said. She did not look up.\n\n\u201cYes,\u201d he said, \u201cwe have met. I think I remember seeing you at your sister\u2019s birthday party in London last spring.\u201d\n\nThe muscles in the woman\u2019s face relaxed and she looked up slowly.\n\n\u201cYes,\u201d she said. \u201cI was at the party. There were so many people. I\u2019m sorry that I didn\u2019t remember you.\u201d\n\nThe man said he was in New York as a student and was adjusting to his new life and surroundings. The two of them engaged in small talk and some laughs. He implored the woman to greet her sister on his behalf.\n\n\u201cIsn\u2019t it amazing that I ran into you?\u201d he said, grinning.\n\nA couple of stops later, the man arrived at his destination, said goodbye and got off the train. I wondered where their paths might cross again.", "title": "\u2018Don\u2019t I Know You?\u2019", "authors": ["Jeffrey Penn", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDr. Seuss\u2019 classic children\u2019s book \u201cHow the Grinch Stole Christmas!\u201d was first adapted as an animated TV special in 1966, with Boris Karloff voicing the titular grump. Then Jim Carrey embodied the curmudgeon in a live-action 2000 version. Now Benedict Cumberbatch is bringing his own take to the crotchety, holiday-hating character in a big-screen cartoon simply titled \u201cDr. Seuss\u2019 the Grinch,\u201d which has just released its first trailer.\n\nThe film was made by Illumination, the same company behind \u201cThe Secret Life of Pets,\u201d \u201cSing\u201d and the \u201cDespicable Me\u201d franchise. The new teaser includes a sly inside joke, as the Grinch is woken up \u2014 and annoyed \u2014 when his alarm clock plays Pharrell Williams\u2019s relentlessly upbeat song \u201cHappy,\u201d the Oscar-nominated tune from \u201cDespicable Me 2.\u201d\n\nMost of the clip\u2019s footage features the Grinch and his loyal dog, Max, who fixes his boss a hot beverage with a frowny face floating on the surface. For his part, the mean green one shuts down someone trying to wish him \u201cHappy holidays\u201d at the grocery store and vomits into a jar after tasting pickles \u2014 then puts it back on the shelf.\n\nBut Christmas fights back. The \u201cnasty wasty skunk\u201d as he\u2019s called in the song \u201cYou\u2019re a Mean One, Mr. Grinch\u201d \u2014 which can be heard in a new incarnation during the trailer \u2014 gets Grinch-slapped by a giant inflatable Santa. Universal hopes \u201cThe Grinch\u201d will get a warmer reception from moviegoers when it invades theaters on Nov. 9.", "title": "\u2018Dr. Seuss\u2019 the Grinch\u2019 Trailer: Benedict Cumberbatch Stars", "authors": ["Bruce Fretts"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "AT 14 SECONDS\n\nDark Starlight\n\nRichard Strauss paints fierce, radiant starlight in a descending flash of strings as Elektra begins a simile about the \u201cfiery light\u201d that \u201cpours down from the stars.\u201d But as she finishes her comparison, the music darkens just as quickly: That starlight, she sings, will be like the \u201cblood of a hundred throats\u201d that will pour down on the grave of her father, Agamemnon, to avenge his murder. When I heard that split second of radiance deftly transformed into to a pained, foreboding cry for blood at a dress rehearsal a few days before \u201cElektra\u201d opened on Thursday at the Metropolitan Opera, it felt a little like hearing the future. The orchestra was led by Yannick N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin, the Met\u2019s next music director, and Elektra was sung by the dramatic soprano Christine Goerke, who will tackle Br\u00fcnnhilde next season at the Met when the company brings back Wagner\u2019s \u201cRing\u201d cycle. MICHAEL COOPER\n\nRead Anthony Tommasini\u2019s review of \u201cElektra.\u201d\n\nRead about Mr. N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin\u2019s recent 14-hour musical biathlon.\n\nRead about how Ms. Goerke became a great dramatic soprano.", "title": "\u2018Elektra\u2019 Returns: The Week\u2019s 8 Best Classical Music Moments on YouTube", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cArizona Pays to Push Conservative Studies\u201d (news article, Feb. 26):\n\nThe Arizona Legislature set up at its universities some schools, also known as \u201cfreedom schools,\u201d that will teach conservative values. This could already be guessed from the frequent rightist use of the word \u201cfreedom,\u201d as in the House Freedom Caucus.\n\nIt\u2019s not enough for these freedom backers like the Koch brothers that their ilk controls much of the media. They want to push free-market beliefs. They want to domesticate the university, a rare home of intelligent and honest research \u2014 or rather, balance it with dogma.\n\nYes, universities tend to be on the left, but much of the rest of society is conservative or on the right.\n\nMany Republicans hate truth and knowledge. It\u2019s no surprise that 58 percent of Republicans (or Republican-leaning) believe that colleges are a negative force.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Freedom Schools\u2019 in Arizona", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Murin is among a tiny handful of artists who have been with the musical since a first reading with actors two years ago. The initial director was fired, the set designer quit, choreographers came and went, and the actress who read for Elsa was not ultimately cast.\n\nMs. Murin hung on. (\u201cShe broke our heart every time,\u201d said Robert Lopez, one of the show\u2019s songwriters.) But for a time, she wasn\u2019t even sure she wanted the role.\n\nShortly after a late 2016 \u201cFrozen\u201d workshop, Ms. Murin, who is married to the actor Colin Donnell (NBC\u2019s \u201cChicago Med\u201d), learned that she was pregnant. She was thrilled, and surprised, and told her parents she would be having a baby instead of doing the Disney musical.\n\nBut then, at eight weeks, an ultrasound revealed that her fetus had no heartbeat. She had to medically induce contractions at home. \u201cIt was one of the most absolutely devastating times of my life \u2014 to go from \u2018we\u2019re having a baby\u2019 to mourning the loss,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat same week, Disney \u2014 which had no idea about Ms. Murin\u2019s circumstances \u2014 called. The show was arranging a \u201cmix and match\u201d \u2014 auditioning potential Annas against potential Elsas \u2014 and wanted to see Ms. Murin again. She refused. \u201cI didn\u2019t have it in me,\u201d she said. \u201cI said, \u2018You know what I can do.\u2019 If you want to offer it to me, I\u2019ll gladly think about it.\u201d\n\n\u201cMy plan was to let \u2018Frozen\u2019 do what it was going to do, and we were going to try to have a baby again,\u201d she said.\n\nBut Disney persisted. The creative team had cast Ms. Levy as Elsa and was inclined to give Ms. Murin the role of Anna but needed her to come in and read a scene with her.\n\nMs. Murin was torn. \u201cI was made to play this role,\u201d she said. But she wanted a child, and if she were to do \u201cFrozen,\u201d she would choose to put that off. She thought back to a conversation with Audra McDonald, the much-honored Broadway actress, who gave birth in 2016 at the age of 46.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018How do you do this?\u2019\u201d Ms. Murin recalled. \u201cOne thing she said really stuck with me: \u2018There\u2019s a little soul, just waiting, and that little soul is waiting for the right time.\u2019\u201d\n\nMs. McDonald also remembers the conversation. \u201cI just let her know it\u2019s going to be O.K. \u2014 if the role is going to be hers, it\u2019s hers, and the same with the pregnancy,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019d been through similar issues, and so she and I were able to commiserate.\u201d\n\nMs. Murin went in to meet Ms. Levy \u2014 they knew each other only casually \u2014 and as soon as Ms. Levy asked how she\u2019d been, she blurted out that she had just lost a pregnancy. Ms. Levy confided that she had had a similar experience.\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018I\u2019ve been there \u2014 I know what that is,\u2019 and we just held each other\u2019s hands,\u201d Ms. Levy recalled. \u201cAnd then we went in and read together.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Levy\u2019s own path to \u201cFrozen\u201d had also been complicated by her desire to be a mother. After a miscarriage, she had a difficult pregnancy in 2016, giving birth at 34 weeks to a three-pound boy by C-section. Six weeks later, she was in an audition room, belting out Elsa\u2019s power ballad \u201cLet It Go\u201d for the Disney team. She didn\u2019t get the role.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Levy, who is married to David Reiser, a professor of theater at Stockton University, focused on nurturing her son \u2014 Izaiah, now 2, and healthy \u2014 and began looking for other opportunities. But then Disney called again. A new director, Michael Grandage, was reopening the casting process. Ms. Levy returned to the audition room.\n\nMr. Grandage and Ms. Levy, who had never met, hit it off. \u201cCaissie came in and offered a layer of humanity that I had never seen in the role,\u201d he said.", "title": "\u2018Frozen\u2019 on Broadway Made Them Sisters. Heartbreak Made Them Friends.", "authors": ["Michael Paulson"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 \u201cGet Out\u201d was the big winner at a sodden, rain-swept Film Independent Spirit Awards in Santa Monica on Saturday, winning best feature and best director for Jordan Peele a day before Hollywood\u2019s biggest night of the year.\n\nTimoth\u00e9e Chalamet won best male lead for his performance in \u201cCall Me by Your Name,\u201d Allison Janney won best supporting actress for \u201cI, Tonya,\u201d and \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d yielded prizes for Sam Rockwell (best supporting actor) and Frances McDormand (best actress). Once onstage, dressed in pajamas and fuzzy slippers, Ms. McDormand expressed relief that this was one awards show she could curse at.\n\n\u201cI continue to be amazed that you let me get to the microphone. What are you crazy?\u201d she said. \u201cBut what I know about today is that I get to swear. Do you know how hard it\u2019s been not to swear over the last couple of months? Because this award convention goes on forever,\u201d she said, throwing in an f-bomb.\n\nOther winners included Greta Gerwig, who took best screenplay for \u201cLady Bird\u201d; Emily V. Gordon and Kumail Nanjiani, who won best first screenplay for \u201cThe Big Sick\u201d; \u201cA Fantastic Woman\u201d for best international film; and \u201cFaces Places,\u201d best documentary.", "title": "\u2018Get Out\u2019 Prevails at Rain-Soaked Indie Spirit Awards", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Those of us for whom existence means fending off onslaughts to our fundamental humanity can afford to not know and prepare for the latest threats. Our lives \u2014 almost always under siege in some way \u2014 also move us to protect and bond with those similarly situated, and we are obligated to protect them as they in turn inform themselves and take action to protect us. It would also be an abdication of responsibility to be a good citizen \u2014 to be informed and to work to make life better for others.\n\n\u2014 Riley Temple, Washington, D.C.\n\n\u2018I appreciate his approach.\u2019\n\nWhatever judgment I would pass on Mr. Hagerman is the same judgment I would pass on people who retreat from the world into their own political bubbles. That goes for those on the left and the right. I appreciate his approach more than any of them.\n\n\u2014 Jeff Perkins, Iowa\n\n\u2018It doesn\u2019t absolve him of responsibility in democracy.\u2019\n\nMr. Hagerman can hide from Trumpism only because he is wealthy and white. Lack of engagement might make him feel healthier, but it doesn\u2019t absolve him of responsibility in democracy. I can\u2019t think of one historical example that ended well when citizens of privilege chose to ignore politics.\n\n\u2014 Tess, San Jose, Calif.\n\n\u2018This man is totally unique and an inspiration to many.\u2019\n\nNot many people can disconnect from their phones for even just ten minutes. We have become sheep, being led around by marketers and pundits. This man is totally unique and an inspiration to many who would like to be able to do what he is doing: being his own person.\n\n\u2014 Dee, Los Angeles\n\n\u2018There are times that I wish I could do the same.\u2019\n\nHonestly, there are times that I wish I could do the same. But I can\u2019t. Being a grandfather, I am sick worried that my children and my grandson will be badly hurt from the decisions that are made in the White House. I am old enough and realistic enough to know that my views, expressed here and elsewhere, most probably won\u2019t change anyone\u2019s mind about anything. But, I see that as a way to feel that I am not alone, but connected to the rest of humanity.\n\n\u2014 Eddie B., Toronto\n\n\u2018Good for him.\u2019\n\nIf this guy is successful with his plan and ultimately donates the restored land to his local community as his own \u201cWalden Pond\u201d project, I daresay his contribution will be much more meaningful and long-lasting than if he spent his days stressed out and yelling at a TV screen. Good for him.\n\nThat said, if we all did that, this country would be in more serious trouble than it already is. But it\u2019s nice to know that there are people out there doing other things besides being held hostage by the current horrors of the daily news cycle. A reminder that life goes on, I guess, sometimes in spite of us.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 WesternMass, The Berkshires\n\n\u2018In the same situation, I don\u2019t think his neighbors would do the same.\u2019\n\nI\u2019m a native of Athens County, where Mr. Hagerman resides. On Nov. 8, 2016, I knocked on doors in the Glouster area. I might\u2019ve even knocked on his, who knows. Many of his neighbors voted for Donald Trump, while others didn\u2019t bother voting at all. Some of them didn\u2019t have rides to the church that served as their polling location (though we did offer to drive them).\n\nI don\u2019t fault them for not participating in a system that did not appear to acknowledge their existence. But I think about Mr. Hagerman, and the resources available to him. And how he chooses to squander them on personal comfort. In the same situation, I don\u2019t think his neighbors would do the same.\n\n\u2014 Emily, Columbus, Ohio\n\n\u2018Mr. Hagerman is not alone.\u2019\n\nMr. Hagerman is not alone. My wife has blockaded all political news since Election Day as well. However, she does have a vague sense of nonpolitical news.\n\nShe does follow Facebook but has several kinds of blocks on her computer to keep the content politics free. It isn\u2019t that hard to do. She just changes the subject t if politics come up.\n\nPart of her reasoning is that as a senior she may not live long enough to see things turn around. She can\u2019t fix anything so there seems to be no point in being stressed all the time.\n\n\u2014 Franklin Khedouri, Scottsdale, Ariz.", "title": "\u2018Good for Him\u2019: Readers React to the Most Ignorant Man in America", "authors": ["Marie Tae Mcdermott"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Details of a Suspect\u2019s Life\n\nI realize that reporting on pieces like the March 22 \u201cA Bomber\u2019s Rampage Exposes Racial Fault Lines\u201d article takes considerably more time than getting quotes from neighbors and classmates, but you MUST consider what good those easy quotes do. Do they tell us anything we need to know, or are you just trying to get anything out in order to take advantage of the news cycle? \u2014 Garrett Bridger Gilmore, Long Beach, Calif. I really don\u2019t care what the bomber\u2019s hobbies were, or what his grandmother thought of him, or whether he was \u201cquiet.\u201d I want to know when and where he was radicalized. I want to know how he learned to make effective killing machines and how he was able to obtain parts and send the first few bombs practically undetected. If that information is still unavailable, perhaps run 100 percent fewer human interest stories on his childhood and wait, or better yet, investigate. \u2014 Anna Holmes, Seattle\n\nMarc Lacey, National Editor: With an event of this magnitude, with consequences so horrific, The Times made the decision to give four correspondents in Austin and four others in New York one assignment: Find out anything possible about this perpetrator and help us understand how he could have committed these terrible acts.\n\nWe fanned out through his neighborhood, school, worksite and anywhere else we could identify, trying to talk to anyone we could find who knew him. We published everything we learned, as we learned it. A story that was sketchy at first was expanded as we went along, filling in new details as we learned them.\n\nWe\u2019re still working to understand this perpetrator, and as we learn more, we\u2019ll pass it along. I can assure you that there is no effort underway to portray him as anything other than what he is, a murderer.\n\nPhoto Selection\n\nI have seen pictures of Mark Conditt with the blond hair he had at the time. And holding an assault rifle. Why hasn\u2019t that one been used? \u2014 David B. Owens, Chicago The photographs used to show suspects is one of the ways that can show racial bias. For example, even in this request for questions, a Facebook photo of Mark Conditt is used rather than an image from video surveillance. In comparison, it is common to see mug shots when discussing people of color. How does The Times evaluate photo choices and is this sort of racial bias specifically considered? \u2014 Alison, Apex, N.C.\n\nCrista Chapman, National Photo Editor: The photo of the suspect that we published was the only one that was confirmed at the time by the wire services that we subscribe to. We were unable to independently confirm other photos that allegedly showed Mark Conditt holding an assault rifle, including the photo referenced by the reader.\n\nThere were also no police mug shots available of Mr. Conditt because he had not previously been arrested.\n\nWe did subsequently publish surveillance video screenshots of Mr. Conditt at the FedEx location when the photos were made available.\n\nStaff Diversity\n\nWhat is your plan to hire and promote more people of color and non-Christian reporters? \u2014 Emily Peterson, Oakland, Calif. What controls do you have in place to check for implicit bias? How many people of color do you have in supervisory/editorial positions? \u2014 Kate E, Central New York\n\nCarolyn Ryan, Assistant Managing Editor: We have aggressively pushed to recruit more people of color, and last year, more than a third of our newsroom hires were people of color, and 60 percent were women. We have also introduced changes to our interview and hiring process to make sure we are selecting people from a diverse pool of candidates and using an interview process that has been developed to eliminate bias.", "title": "\u2018He Is Not a Victim\u2019: Our Austin Bomber Coverage Explained", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "The death on Wednesday of Stephen Hawking, the iconic physicist and author, at age 76 set off tributes from Times readers. Many wrote emotionally about Dr. Hawking on social media and in our obituary\u2019s comments section, sharing personal anecdotes about meeting him and describing why his work and life mattered to them.\n\n\n\n\u201cHe will be sorely missed in the physics community. However, he will also be missed in the disabled community. He was an inspiration to others, demonstrating what could be done despite a horribly debilitating disease,\u201d B.S. in Woodland, Calif., wrote.\n\n\n\n\u201cHe lives on as all great philosophers do in his theories and writing. Generations will continue to know and appreciate him. Much gratitude to those who cared for him and supported him day to day. We all grieve with you and celebrate his life,\u201d West wrote.\n\n\u201cHere I am, at the end of my life, and Stephen Hawking died last night. I am still weeping and I do not know why. I never met the guy. I never approached his level of dignity. But when I consider his life, I am the little boy in polio braces who wanted no one's pity,\u201d Brian Prioleau in Austin, Tex., wrote.", "title": "\u2018He Lives on as All Great Philosophers Do\u2019: Readers Mourn Stephen Hawking", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Emotions also run high at the Shokrani residence. In last week\u2019s episode, Farid soothed his \u201creligious anxiety\u201d with marijuana before making an appearance at a Muslim wedding. This time, he brings his own bottle of wine to a dinner at the home of Layla\u2019s teetotaling white imam, Chuck (Michael Weaver), and picks a fight about Islam. \u201cI have a problem with Muslims,\u201d he announces, listing grievances like Sharia law and honor killings. When his harrowing experiences during the Iranian Revolution come up and Chuck suggests that he understands Farid\u2019s pain because he\u2019s studied that period, Farid snaps: \u201cYou studied it. I lived it.\u201d\n\nI\u2019m still disappointed that we\u2019ve learned practically nothing about the Shokranis beyond their religion. And the hints that Layla is growing uncomfortably close with the imam because of her husband\u2019s long-festering anger toward Islam aren\u2019t subtle. But we are getting some real insight into the role this conflict plays in their marriage. Although the dialogue in these scenes leaves much to be desired (I groaned when Layla told Farid, \u201cYou dishonored me\u201d), the revelation that she believes his embrace of reason over faith has made him spiritually bankrupt is intriguing. We don\u2019t often see this kind of marital dispute on TV.\n\nIt\u2019s also promising that Navid is finally getting his own story line. His interest in Kristen is obvious: He savors their every conversation, even when she\u2019s blowing up at him for no reason. When she visits the Shokranis\u2019 house for a class project, only to find Navid in his hijab and eye makeup, she reacts to the news that he\u2019s gender fluid by gushing, \u201cOh my God, I wish I was.\u201d Kristen is the quintessential bored teen, fresh off a humiliating sexual encounter with a cruel popular boy, and Navid\u2019s secret life instantly gets her attention. There\u2019s a lot of potential in this new friendship, especially if it blossoms into an unconventional romance.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIf only every character\u2019s story could improve so much. Duc is still begging for his dad\u2019s approval, proclaiming his celibacy and courting potential clients with all the disingenuous bravado of an infomercial pitchman. The scene in which a woman at the pool warns him, \u201cPride goeth before a fall,\u201d belongs in the on-the-nose hall of fame. Meanwhile, in keeping with the episode\u2019s theme, Ashley and Malcolm\u2019s marriage is put under the microscope. They spend the hour bickering over whose fault it is that none of the children they invited to their 4-year-old\u2019s birthday party are coming. What doesn\u2019t make much sense is that they\u2019re not concerned about why all of Hailey\u2019s friends \u2014 and their parents \u2014 want nothing to do with them.\n\nThis puzzling subplot is mostly an excuse to get all of the Bayer-Boatwrights in the same place, a park where the family celebrated birthdays when Greg and Audrey\u2019s kids were little. It\u2019s an idyllic afternoon, all bubbles and sunlight blissfully coexisting with Malcolm\u2019s drone. Since the premiere, we\u2019ve seen character after character weigh in on whether technology is enhancing or destroying modern life. Four episodes in, the answer seems to be, \u201cIt\u2019s a whole lot more complicated than that.\u201d\n\nWhich brings us, finally, to Ramon. He and Henry were just too perfect to last, weren\u2019t they? So, after an alarming conversation in which he ignores Ramon\u2019s questions about his past and a subsequent, seemingly out-of-nowhere spat about technology, the inevitable happens: Henry disappears. I knew it was coming the moment they reconciled and Henry said, \u201cI\u2019m with you.\u201d\n\nWe\u2019re left wondering not only what happened, but who \u2014 or, seeing as there are supernatural forces at work here, what \u2014 Henry even is. His speech about \u201ctechno-geeks\u201d is beyond weird: \u201cWe\u2019re all savages,\u201d he opines. \u201cAnd this is just a way to avoid scary, messy real life.\u201d Last week he was the ultimate chill, go-with-the-flow guy. Now, he\u2019s suddenly the embodiment of primal fear.\n\nLife away from his techno-geek sanctum doesn\u2019t go so well for Ramon at Hailey\u2019s party. During a game of hide-and-seek, always a harbinger of horrors, he finds an abandoned building. Inside, he starts hallucinating. This time, it\u2019s apparently his own biological mother whom he sees, in a kitchen. She calls him \u201cmijo\u201d (a Spanish contraction for \u201cson\u201d). There\u2019s a soldier. She tears at her face, just as Farid\u2019s mom did in Ramon\u2019s dream. And he runs screaming out of the building.\n\nWhatever 11:11 is supposed to mean, the phenomena presumably associated with it are starting to resemble what Freud called \u201cthe return of the repressed.\u201d If Ramon and Farid are connected by anything besides that dream, there\u2019s a good chance that it\u2019s repressed childhood trauma. And come to think of it, \u201cFarid\u201d and his Anglicized nickname, \u201cFred,\u201d both sound a bit like \u201cFreud.\u201d In a show so concerned with philosophy and mental illness, I\u2019m not sure that\u2019s a coincidence.", "title": "\u2018Here and Now\u2019 Season 1, Episode 4: A Binary Organism", "authors": ["Judy Berman", "Here"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Ramon\u2019s got 99 problems, but a lack of conviction isn\u2019t one of them. Not only is he sure that his hallucinations have a meaning beyond mental illness, but he has fallen in love with Henry extraordinarily quickly. So it\u2019s a relief to see them reunited after two days in which Henry didn\u2019t so much as call. He tells Ramon that he left in the middle of the night because his friend relapsed. I find that pretty hard to swallow, especially after Kristen and Navid spot him climbing into a homeless man\u2019s tent and speculate on whether he\u2019s sleeping with the disheveled man inside. (I can\u2019t tell you how much I wish I could unhear Navid\u2019s awful portmanteau, \u201choboning.\u201d)\n\nBut I\u2019m certain something weirder is happening. It seems important that Henry \u2014 who hates to talk about his past \u2014 grew up in Waco, Tex., and that he insists there\u2019s nothing left for him there. If, as we learn this week, he\u2019s almost 30, then he would have been around 5 years old when government forces lay siege to a Branch Davidian compound outside the city, which ended with the deaths of nearly 80 people. Could his parents have been cult members? Now that\u2019s commitment!\n\nFor the Shokranis, conversations about commitment always come back to Islam. This week, Farid confides in Layla that Ramon\u2019s visions are disturbing him \u2014 not least because his birthday is Nov. 11 and because he really did once see his mother with four gashes in her cheek. She asks if he\u2019s off his unnamed medication and says she\u2019s afraid of his becoming \u201cerratic\u201d and \u201cdisappearing\u201d around Navid; surely we\u2019ll hear more about that tendency in later episodes. But the conversation ends with their bickering about her decision to fast during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, and his taunting her with his conspicuous snacking.\n\nNavid\u2019s fasting sparks a more serious conversation about religion, as Kristen scarfs down tacos and he abstains. When she confesses that she doesn\u2019t really have any spiritual beliefs, he points out how depressing it is to believe only in what you can see in front of you when there\u2019s so much pain in the physical world. \u201cWhat\u2019s in front of us is awful,\u201d he says. \u201cThere has to be something better.\u201d At the same time, they\u2019re getting closer and closer to discussing Navid\u2019s sexuality. As she inflicts on him her feminist justification of watching gay porn, he informs her that the boy who humiliated her last week actually likes guys. You have to wonder: How does he know?\n\nKristen and Navid\u2019s talk mirrors another exchange about religion, between Ashley and Jamila (Kelly Jenrette), the mother of Haley\u2019s new, black preschool classmate. Ashley catches shade for not being part of a church congregation, as well as for working in the ostensibly vapid fashion industry, for not carrying lotion for her daughter\u2019s dry skin and for not knowing that her hometown was founded as a \u201cwhite utopia.\u201d Over dinner at Jamila\u2019s place, Malcolm mentions that Ashley\u2019s parents are white, and Jamila says, \u201cThat makes sense.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Here and Now\u2019 Season 1, Episode 5: Commitment Issues", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Season 1, Episode 6: \u2018Fight, Death\u2019\n\nIn 1972, the MIT meteorology professor Edward Lorenz introduced a concept called \u201cthe butterfly effect\u201d in his groundbreaking paper, \u201cPredictability: Does the Flap of a Butterfly\u2019s Wings in Brazil Set Off a Tornado in Texas?\u201d The term describes Lorenz\u2019s discovery that a tiny event in one part of the world could have an unpredictably enormous impact on weather thousands of miles away. The butterfly effect has since become a central tenet of chaos theory.\n\nIt has also made its way into pop culture, surfacing every once in a while as the title of a hip-hop single or an Ashton Kutcher time-travel movie. As twisted by the entertainment industry for its own sentimental purposes, the butterfly effect dictates that any small action, usually on the part of an unwitting human, can change the course of a seemingly unrelated person\u2019s life. Now, it looks as if \u201cHere and Now\u201d is determined to give us an unusually literal take on that idea.\n\nFarid has started having dreams like Ramon\u2019s. This week\u2019s episode, \u201cFight, Death,\u201d begins with the psychiatrist in a kitchen with a woman in a head scarf, who seems to be the mother who called Ramon her son in his latest vision. There\u2019s a little boy eating bow-tie pastries. Then, Farid is sharing a joint with grown-up Ramon, who utters a sentence in Spanish he can\u2019t understand. Later, we learn that it translates to, \u201cAlways you ate all the butterflies.\u201d Farid suddenly recalls his mother calling the pastries \u201cbutterflies.\u201d There are also the butterflies in Ramon\u2019s game. It even turns out that Ramon drew butterflies and a woman with four bloody streaks down her face as child.\n\nWhat will it all add up to? Plot predictions have never been my strong suit, and maybe I\u2019m underestimating this show\u2019s capacity for subtlety, but I\u2019m worried we\u2019re going to find out in the season finale that Ramon is Farid\u2019s son or that they\u2019re somehow the same person existing in two different bodies. Perhaps these seemingly supernatural occurrences are the effects of some metaphorical butterfly flapping its wings decades ago. Even if \u201cHere and Now\u201d pleasantly surprises me with an explanation for the characters\u2019 bond that isn\u2019t quite that clunky, it\u2019s bound to delve deeper into this politically and spiritually loaded variation on butterfly-effect mysticism.", "title": "\u2018Here and Now\u2019 Season 1, Episode 6: The Butterfly Effect", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Season 1, Episode 7: Wake\n\nRamon and Farid are getting into numerology. In the session that opens this week\u2019s episode, \u201cWake,\u201d Ramon announces that he is quitting work on his video game, \u201cRealms,\u201d and his doctor beseeches him to continue. \u201cI want you to think of your game \u2014 specifically, the artistry of your game \u2014 as a part of your healing process,\u201d Farid says. But he has a hidden motive: He has discovered uncanny parallels between the world Ramon is creating and his own traumatic childhood in Iran. When Farid works himself into a numerological frenzy, connecting the address of his building, the number of his office suite and the nine groups of 11 butterflies in the game to 11:11, it\u2019s clear he\u2019s at least as far gone as Ramon is.\n\nAs a low-level arithmophobic, I won\u2019t pretend to have followed Farid\u2019s every mathematical leap. But even I have caught on to a simpler numerical pattern in the first season of \u201cHere and Now\u201d: Every three episodes, toward the end of the hour, Ramon has a vision. In the premiere, it was the candles. Episode 4 closed with the sequence in the abandoned building, where he saw his birth mother. So, in Episode 7, when the sight of someone wearing a surgical mask at the game expo seems to bring on Ramon\u2019s screaming, trembling, possibly career-killing hallucination of a horde of masked, dust-covered people shuffling toward him like zombies, it fits the pattern.\n\nThe scene is somewhat novel, in that it\u2019s the first of Ramon\u2019s visions (or dreams) that isn\u2019t tied in any obvious way to his birth family, Farid\u2019s past or 11:11. There\u2019s something post-apocalyptic about the apparitions he sees, which also bring to mind the folkloric spirits known as \u201chaints\u201d that Jamila\u2019s family discusses over dinner. Even so, watching Ramon get scared out of his wits by a hallucination every time things seem to be going well for him is starting to get old.\n\nSeven episodes in, he\u2019s not the only character whose story line is becoming redundant. I know that I complain about Ashley and Duc every week, but every week it gets more frustrating to watch the show keep hammering home the same points about them. In \u201cWake,\u201d Ashley questions her marriage to a white man, meets Jamila\u2019s mom and continues to stew about her own adoptive mother\u2019s accidental, televised defense of white supremacy \u2014 all plot points that push her another few inches in the direction of some inevitable revelation about her racial identity.", "title": "\u2018Here and Now\u2019 Season 1, Episode 7: Harsh Realms", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "I suppose there are two ways of interpreting this. One is that \u201cFox & Friends\u201d runs the country and we\u2019re all gonna die. The second is that the president is nervous about his base and feels compelled to manufacture a drama in order to keep them in line. Hence the second-most interesting line in the Times\u2019s article: \u201cAmy Kremer, a Tea Party activist who helped found Women for Trump, tweeted, \u2018I\u2019m done.\u2019 \u201d\n\nGail: I really am prepared to believe he didn\u2019t know the wall wasn\u2019t in the bill. He probably didn\u2019t even ask. When his top people are sitting in the Oval Office, the conversation goes something like this:\n\nAIDE: I have some good news: The whole spending package is almost done.\n\nPRESIDENT: Did you hear what Oprah said about me?\n\nBret: Hehe.\n\nGail: The two things a Republican president is supposed to do are cut taxes and try to cut domestic spending. Which generally doesn\u2019t work, but you expect there\u2019d be an effort at least.\n\nBret: The operative phrase on right-wing blogs is always something like: \u201cThe swamp wins again. Trump surrenders.\u201d This is also known as \u201ccompromise.\u201d Republicans got a $61 billion increase in military spending, the biggest annual increase in 15 years. Democrats got some of their own priorities funded. This is more or less how things are going to work when you don\u2019t have a filibuster-proof majority in the Senate. The correct conservative response ought to be to nod, shrug and get on with life.\n\nBut it won\u2019t work that way, because right-wing ideologues have convinced themselves that they own Washington and that any policy victory that is less than 100 percent complete is a sellout to the nefarious forces of liberalism and globalism. Wouldn\u2019t it be something if Trump had gone out there and said, \u201cThis administration is prepared to take two-thirds of the loaf and that\u2019s how politics in a democracy ought to be\u201d? He can\u2019t because he is unwilling and unable to move beyond the furies of his base.\n\nGail: Now that is the kind of sensible, real-world answer I\u2019ve come to expect from you. Personally, I\u2019d love to have a fight about the defense budget, and the whole idea that we\u2019re supposed to be the world\u2019s sole policeman. A country capable of putting Donald Trump in the White House should not be trusted with that kind of responsibility, and I\u2019m tired of paying for it.\n\nBut that\u2019s a rant \u2014 please ignore. The other White House weirdness has been the ever-shifting cast of characters. I guess there\u2019s no reason for us to worry about the way his lawyers have been racing through the revolving doors, but we\u2019re only one Fox broadcast away from Judge Jeanine as attorney general. Which allows me to once again express amazement at having come to a moment in history where Jeff Sessions is a somewhat sympathetic character.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Hush Money,\u2019 Now Playing Everywhere", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Employers are now bearing the brunt of the Trump administration\u2019s wrath against California and illegal immigration more broadly; ICE\u2019s chief, Thomas D. Homan, has vowed more workplace enforcement and warned that the state had better \u201chold on tight.\u201d\n\nAt the same time, those companies now have to follow the state\u2019s Immigrant Worker Protection Act, which took effect Jan. 1. The law prohibits companies from cooperating with ICE without a subpoena, and from letting ICE agents into nonpublic areas.\n\nIt also requires them to post notices alerting workers that ICE will be reviewing records \u2014 a tip-off to those who may not be legally allowed to work. Any company found violating the law faces fines of $2,000 to $10,000.\n\nSeveral workplaces visited by ICE have lost workers, or customers, since it began targeting businesses in late January, and before the audits were even completed. Agriculture, a state economic powerhouse, has been especially hard hit.\n\nCalifornia farms are heavily dependent on immigrants to fill their physically demanding and often low-paid jobs, and it is no secret that many of those immigrants are in the country illegally.\n\nEmployers contend that they have no way of knowing when a worker submits a fake Social Security number on their I-9 forms, the federal document on which employees attest they are citizens or otherwise legal. Supporters of tougher immigration enforcement say that employers are just winking at the issue.\n\nA common way for the government to root out illegal labor is to audit companies\u2019 I-9 records. By federal law, ICE sends companies a letter before beginning an audit, and by the new state law, companies must pass that news on to their employees.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen Bee Sweet Citrus, a large grower and shipper of oranges, lemons and grapefruit in Fowler, in Central California, plastered on the wall an advisory about ICE\u2019s inspection plans, the company lost some packers, sorters and administrators, one employee said.\n\n\u201cI resigned out of fear,\u201d said the worker, Ana, who asked that her surname be withheld because she is undocumented. She said she hung on until Feb. 16, close to the deadline for the company to submit paperwork to ICE, so she could make another month\u2019s rent. (The company said it was complying with state and federal laws regarding the ICE audit, but declined to comment further.)\n\nFaith in the Valley, an advocacy group based in Fresno, said it had received a spate of calls from workers rattled after seeing the notices about audits. Manuel Cunha, the president of Nisei Farmers League, a growers\u2019 organization, said, \u201cI have never seen workers quit like this before.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThere is fear and hysteria,\u201d he said.\n\nICE has also stepped up activity in urban areas, conducting sweeps and delivering audit notices to hundreds of businesses in San Francisco, Oakland and Los Angeles.\n\nReyna Guardado, the owner of El Guanaquito Pupuseria, a restaurant in Riverside County, said that all of her workers are family members with green cards or citizenship. But the moment a pair of agents, donning flak jackets emblazoned with \u201cICE,\u201d set foot there to serve her an I-9 audit notice, her patrons dispersed. \u201cEverybody knows ICE was here,\u201d she said.\n\nAlso in a bind are law enforcement agencies prohibited by another new state law from cooperating with ICE unless the federal agency has a warrant or the case involves a major crime.\n\nEven before the law, many of the state\u2019s largest agencies, like the Los Angeles and San Francisco Police Departments, limited their work with ICE. But agencies in more conservative areas have had to change their practices.\n\nThe California State Sheriffs\u2019 Association was one of the most vocal opponents of the law. \u201cWhat used to happen is that I would hand someone off while they were in custody, ICE would escort them out and they would be gone,\u201d said Sheriff Donny Youngblood of Kern County, who was president of the association last year. \u201cNow we have to turn them loose.\u201d\n\nLast year, before the law took effect, the Orange County Sheriff\u2019s Department turned over about 370 undocumented immigrants from county custody to federal authorities, said Sheriff Sandra Hutchens.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cNow those people are going back into the community,\u201d Sheriff Hutchens said. \u201cWe haven\u2019t had any horrible incident that has occurred yet, but when that happens, the community is going to say to me, \u2018Why were they released?\u2019\u201d\n\nThe Trump administration argues that the state laws shield dangerous criminals from federal law enforcement at the expense of public safety. In his speech on Wednesday announcing his lawsuit, Mr. Sessions cited the case of a 34-year-old undocumented immigrant arrested in Ventura County on a charge of sexual abuse of a minor. The man, Jose Vaca, left jail and has disappeared, the Ventura County Sheriff\u2019s Office said, because the new state law forbids jails to turn inmates over to ICE until they have appeared before a judge. Mr. Vaca posted bail and was released before his first court appearance, the sheriff\u2019s office said.\n\nThe state\u2019s Democratic leaders have argued that their new law regarding law enforcement cooperation with ICE keeps communities safe by maintaining trust between the police and immigrant residents. After President Trump took office, the police departments in Los Angeles and other American cities said domestic violence reports from the Hispanic community dropped, which they feared was because victims who were undocumented were afraid of coming forward.\n\nThe law on employer cooperation helps immigrant workers learn their rights and seek legal help if necessary, its supporters say. \u201cThe law works first and foremost to protect Californians\u2019 privacy at the workplace,\u201d said Sarah Lovenheim, a spokeswoman for Xavier Becerra, the Democratic state attorney general. She said she could not divulge whether the office had received any complaints about companies violating the law.\n\nMr. Poindexter, the walnut processor, said he considered himself fortunate that the audit came after the harvest. But his plant operates year-round, and he is eager for ICE to finish its work so he can replace the lost workers before the fall harvest. \u201cThere is no point in hiring people with this cloud hanging over us,\u201d he said.\n\nSome business owners even wondered if California\u2019s attempts to protect undocumented immigrants were having the opposite effect.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think the state is helping employers or workers; they are making it worse,\u201d said Karen Musson, who owns Gar Tootelian, a fertilizer retailer that serves 1,500 growers in Fresno County. \u201cWe are attracting ICE agents because California drew a line in the sand.\u201d", "title": "\u2018I Am a Pawn\u2019: Trump\u2019s Immigration Fight With California Squeezes Those Caught in the Middle", "authors": ["Miriam Jordan", "Jennifer Medina"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cClearly,\u201d Mr. Katz, a Connecticut antiques dealer, said in a video filmed at the show, \u201cwe are hoping that it might go to an institution, because it really would be wonderful to share this with the public on a day-to-day basis.\u201d\n\nSo it was gratifying, Mr. Katz said in an interview, when the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford purchased the work and gave it prominent display.\n\nIn recent weeks, though, the museum has had to acknowledge that the carefully crafted secretary with the compelling story is actually an exquisite fake. And the forger has now come forward, not only to acknowledge and apologize for his sin, but also to bask a bit in how artful his deception has been.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the apotheosis of my own making,\u201d the forger, Harold Gordon, said in a recent interview. Mr. Gordon sold the piece to Mr. Katz, and in the process fooled many experts in the antiques world.\n\n\u201cI lied,\u201d said Mr. Gordon, 69. \u201cI cheated. I stole.\u201d\n\nFake antiques are far from rare, but few match the sort of ambitions and artistry as that created by Mr. Gordon, experts said. Robert Cheney, director of the Willard House & Clock Museum in North Grafton, Mass., likened this caper to that of the \u201cgreat Brewster chair,\u201d created in 1969 by a former police officer who passed it off as a rare, 350-year-old piece. It ended up in the Henry Ford Museum in Michigan.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOccasionally, museums display fakes intentionally. One of the most popular recent exhibitions at the Winterthur in Delaware was devoted to forgeries, according to Linda Eaton, co-curator of the display. It opened, appropriately, last April Fools\u2019 Day.\n\nMr. Gordon said he had no grand plan for trickery when he set out around 2010 to create his phony memorial in the workshop of his home in Templeton, about an hour outside Boston. A self-taught woodworker, he labored off and on for months as he turned a plain-looking, if old, secretary into a detailed piece rich with the patina of history.\n\nMr. Gordon, a stickler for details, said he tried to imagine how a simple, rural country craftsman in the mid-19th century would have approached such a project. \u201cWhat standards of excellence did they have?\u201d he asked himself.\n\nAmong his additions: a clock crowned by an eagle and the words \u201cThe Union Preserved\u201d near the base.\n\nBut to make it work, he said he knew it would need a story. So Mr. Gordon, a student of history, imagined the piece as an heirloom of the Binghams, a real family with Civil War ancestors.\n\nPhoto\n\nJohn Bingham and his brother Wells, both from East Haddam, were privates in the 16th Connecticut Infantry, who, as teenagers, saw their first action on Sept. 17, 1862, at the Battle of Antietam.\n\nJohn, 17, was killed there; Wells, 16, survived.\n\nMr. Gordon said he decided to describe his handiwork as a gift that had been presented on July 4, 1876, by Civil War veterans to Wells in honor of John, and then handed down to Wells\u2019 son, Edgar. He had appraised the estate of a Bingham family member, giving him insight into their ancestry.\n\nHe taped a typewritten note inside the secretary that he had dated Sept. 22, 1972. It, too, was forged, embellished with aged, yellowed tape, artful tears and typing errors. He signed it by mimicking what he imagined to be the shaky hand of an elderly Edgar M. Bingham.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThis desk made for my father Wells Anderson Bingham,\u201d the note read, in part. \u201cA tribute to his brother John killed September 17, 1862, at the battle of Antietam.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn handcrafted \u201cbarnyard bone\u201d \u2014 from a cow or horse \u2014 Mr. Gordon spelled out \u201cAntietam\u201d and \u201cSept. 17, 1862,\u201d the bloodiest day in American history, and mounted them on a front drawer.\n\nIn a crowning touch, Mr. Gordon attached a canister to the front of the secretary, and in it he placed a small scrap of a flag bearing a star. He had found a piece of period fabric, which he presented as a remnant of a flag carried by the 16th during the battle.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI was never at a point where I was doing it to show off, to show how great I was,\u201d Mr. Gordon said. \u201cIt simply became a creative process.\u201d\n\nAt first, Mr. Gordon said, he left the secretary in his living room where he occasionally entertained offers from visitors who wanted to buy it. He always declined. But then he ran into some money problems, he said, and decided to unload it to Mr. Katz in an act of desperation.\n\nThe Wadsworth, which has not disclosed what it paid for the secretary, displayed it as a powerful artifact, beautiful in its creation and meaningful in its significance to the history of Connecticut. But in late 2016, it received an anonymous tip that the piece was fake, investigated and late last year quietly removed it from public view.\n\nClayton Pennington, editor of Maine Antique Digest, was also tipped off to the problem with the secretary. He soon found a photograph that had been taken in the Gordon living room of an unadorned secretary that looked suspiciously like an image he had found online of the fully realized Bingham memorial secretary in the same spot.\n\nBut when he first spoke with the museum, a curator told him, he said, that the institution was still studying the issue of authenticity. He also called Mr. Katz and told him about his finding. Mr. Katz said he then confronted Mr. Gordon, who confessed and apologized.\n\n\u201cIt has been a humbling and difficult experience,\u201d Mr. Katz said last week, \u201cbut at least I was able to play a key role in helping to expose this masterpiece of deception.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn late February, Mr. Pennington published a lengthy report that declared the secretary a forgery. After the article appeared, the Wadsworth issued a statement, promising to \u201creview our accession process and make every effort to ensure that art we acquire is what it purports to be.\u201d\n\nMr. Katz, a dealer in American folk art since 1985, gave the museum a full refund. He said he was not ready to decide yet whether he would try to recover any losses from Mr. Gordon.\n\nMr. Gordon, an antiques dealer since the 1970s, said he figures he\u2019s a \u201cpariah\u201d in the business now because of the forgery. \u201cIt has ruined my life,\u201d he said, but he said no legal action has been taken against him.\n\nStill he exhibits a creator\u2019s pride toward the craftsmanship he displayed. \u201cThat thing,\u201d he said, \u201cshould be in a museum.\u201d\n\nOne Bingham descendant said he found the hoax amusing, even if Mr. Gordon had falsified a portion of his family\u2019s history.\n\nMichael Cone, a 64-year-old retired physician from Maryland, who has an interest in the Civil War, said he has ancestors on both sides, including the Bingham brothers. Mr. Cone, who was born in Louisiana, said he was not bothered that the brothers\u2019 history had been misappropriated.\n\n\u201cThey deserved it,\u201d he said, jokingly, \u201csince they were my Yankee cousins.\u201d", "title": "\u2018I Cheated,\u2019 Says Woodworker Who Fooled the Antiques Experts", "authors": ["John Banks"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Opening a Prada show can transform a mere model into a supermodel, acting as a gateway to casting in other major shows, glossy magazine covers and lucrative advertising campaigns. For more than 20 years, it has also been a white-women-only privilege.\n\nBut that changed in February when Anok Yai, 19, a Sudanese model raised in the United States after arriving from Egypt as a refugee in 2000, became the first black model to open a Prada runway show since Naomi Campbell in 1997. Joining her was Adut Akech, a South Sudanese immigrant to Australia who appeared in over 30 shows this season after making her runway debut in September when she closed the Saint Laurent show at the age of 17.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI feel like I am part of a great moment, something quite amazing that is happening both in and outside the fashion world,\u201d Ms. Akech said. \u201cThere has been a big increase in the number of really dark skinned girls being cast, even from last season. It feels amazing.\u201d\n\nDiversity on the catwalks (or the lack of it) in 2018 is under more scrutiny than ever. While broader representations of beauty have appeared on the runways of the four fashion cities \u2014 New York, London, Paris and Milan \u2014 in recent years, accusations of racism and colorism remain. But now, following in the footsteps of Alek Wek, one of the first African models to be embraced by fashion, over two decades ago, many young women with dark skin and natural, largely chemically untreated hair have become sought-after runway models.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAside from Ms. Yai and Ms. Akech, for example, there was Grace Bol (originally of South Sudan), who walked in Thom Browne, Givenchy and Balmain, among others; Akiima (also of South Sudanese origin), who was cast by Marc Jacobs, Jacquemus, Loewe and others; and Shanelle Nyasiase (of Kenya), who appeared at Versace, Alexander McQueen and Valentino.", "title": "\u2018I Feel Like I Am Part of a Great Moment\u2019", "authors": ["Elizabeth Paton"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Was interested in watching until I heard she supports Trump. Can you say boycott? COLIN\n\nUsed to love the old show & Roseanne Barr too. Things change. Now, not only do I dislike the woman, I\u2019ll never let my TV rest, even for a moment, on her show. I do hope it fails. The wrong side of history is no place to be. @MSANNIEREGARDS, VIA TWITTER\n\nAdmiration for Speaking Her Mind\n\nIf Roseanne is being truthful in this interview, I have new respect for her. She factually rejects the interviewer\u2019s attempt to misrepresent Mr. Trump\u2019s position on a number of issues, and she is not afraid to do so. Good for her. PAUL, WHITE PLAINS, N.Y.\n\nAs for Roseanne the actual person, she\u2019s never been afraid to shock or say whatever she wants, so I\u2019m surprised that anyone is surprised and offended. I don\u2019t require that the actors in a show or all of its characters agree with me politically in order to enjoy it. E.G., NEW YORK\n\nWhen did we become so weak that we can\u2019t even bear to hear an opinion that is different from our own? I hope that the show can help us remember that we didn\u2019t always hate the other side. LISSA ANN, VIA FACEBOOK\n\nNo Explanation for Her Political Position\n\nWas really hoping to see someone I thought was smart and articulate explain how they can support Trump \u2014 without devolving into a tirade against the left \u2014 and she completely passed on it. It was an opportunity to explain your views to an audience that needs to hear it. And you passed. For me, that calls into question whether the views are genuine, or whether they are supported by anything other than hatred and bigotry. TK, VERMONT", "title": "\u2018I Have New Respect for Her\u2019: Readers Weigh In on Roseanne Barr", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "SACRAMENTO \u2014 The Rev. Samuel Rodriguez had been summoned to the White House for an urgent meeting, and with so much at stake, he decided that he needed a blessing.\n\nHe looked out at the Latino families jammed into his evangelical church in Sacramento on a recent Sunday and called on Stephania Herrera, a youth pastor who had come to the United States illegally when she was 10 years old. Ms. Herrera has been allowed to remain in the country under a program known as DACA. But with that program coming to an end, Mr. Rodriguez was to meet with White House aides to discuss how to save people like Ms. Herrera, known as Dreamers, from deportation.\n\n\u201cFather,\u201d Ms. Herrera said in Spanish, closing her eyes, gripping the microphone with her left hand and holding her pastor\u2019s hand high with her right, \u201cYou have placed him in this place, at this time, in this hour, with a great purpose, and we unite as one believing in your purpose. We ask that you send him covered in favor \u2014 send him in power \u2014 send him with authority.\u201d\n\nThe meeting in Washington would not end in success. At President Trump\u2019s urging, Mr. Rodriguez agreed to support a deal that would allow the Dreamers to stay, in exchange for Congress authorizing funding for a border wall, cutting legal immigration and limiting family reunification. But the proposal went nowhere in Congress. And more than a month later, the long-term prospects for roughly 700,000 Dreamers remain in limbo.", "title": "\u2018I Know I Will Be Criticized\u2019: The Latino Evangelical Who Advises Trump on Immigration", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Go365 was thrown out. Of course they decided to give a freeze [on insurance rates], and I think people thought that might be enough. But we understand that this is an election year. They can freeze it right now, but what happens after the election? The feeling is, we have to get this fixed, and we have to get it fixed now.\n\nWhat compelled you to strike?\n\nI take care of the bills in my family and knew I can\u2019t afford it, I can\u2019t. I have two children, I live paycheck to paycheck. When I realized that they were taking hundreds of dollars and then they tried to tell me they were giving me a pay raise of 1 percent, I knew I can\u2019t just sit back.
