I can\u2019t be complacent, something has to change.\n\n\n\nWe went to the Capitol on Feb. 2, we stood in solidarity, and they would not talk to us.\n\nWhen we walked out of there, my husband looked at me and he said, \u201cI feel so defeated.\u201d They didn\u2019t listen to anything that we had to say.\n\nWe were just walking silently from the Capitol and one teacher said, \u201cGuys, we\u2019re really going to have to strike.\u201d At that point, I knew.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat was it like to leave your classroom?\n\nI teach seniors and 10th graders, my kids are aware of everything that\u2019s going on. I\u2019m the pep club leader at my school, the prayer club leader, on the prom committee. My first period senior class, I started crying and I said, \u201cGuys, I legitimately don\u2019t know when I will be back.\u201d I have an A.P. exam on May 9, and that is not going to change.\n\n\n\nWe have been having local rallies as well as going to the Capitol. Our son is a little confused because we\u2019ve been wearing bunny ears because the governor called us dumb bunnies. He\u2019s been telling everyone that if his mommy and daddy are dumb bunnies he\u2019s a dumb bunny, too. He insists on wearing bunny ears in public like we\u2019ve been doing at the protests.\n\n[Tuesday] was my day to be at a local rally. I was at that rally for approximately three hours. I got in the vehicle with colleagues, we drove several hours to Charleston to the Capitol. There was music playing, the crowd was singing \u201cCountry Roads.\u201d It was really amazing to see all the educators come. So many people were there. Students were there. People brought their kids.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow did you feel after the deal was announced?\n\nInitially a lot of people around me were very happy, because we thought we won. I was excited. And then the union leaders came out and talked to us and we realized really quickly we did not win anything. The crowd turned very angry very quickly. Just because the governor suggests a 5 percent pay raise doesn\u2019t mean it\u2019s going through.\n\nNow they\u2019re saying you get 5 percent and well P.E.I.A. [the public insurance offered to teachers and state employees] is still frozen. At that point the crowd starts chanting, \u201cA freeze is not a fix.\u201d Everybody was very angry, very angry that we were told to go back to the classroom when we felt like had not achieved what we set out to achieve.\n\nOur county said we would not be returning to the classroom. We did not want to go back with a promise. We wanted it signed, sealed and delivered. We wanted it to be fulfilled, not just empty words. We knew that if we went back and there were not details of a plan and a true commitment, then we could easily lose everything.\n\nWhere do you think the protest goes from here? What do you hope to achieve?\n\nThey are telling us that P.E.I.A. cannot be fixed overnight. While we understand that, simply saying there will be a task force is not enough. We need to know who is going to be on this task force. We need specific details about how this is going to be fixed.\n\nThe governor mentioned, I think, three different sources of possible revenue to fix it. Which one? How much? We feel like the plan is too ambiguous right now. We need to know.\n\nWest Virginia has a long history of protest. How does this strike fit into that?\n\nWe know that we come from these mountains and we are strong and we have pride and we love this state. We come from an area that is known for standing up for what they believe in. The union wars, they originated in the south in Mingo County.\n\nWe believe we\u2019re following in their footsteps. We believe the movement was started years ago through the mine wars. We\u2019re just reviving the movement that was started years ago.", "title": "\u2018I Live Paycheck to Paycheck\u2019: A West Virginia Teacher Explains Why She\u2019s on Strike", "authors": ["Jess Bidgood"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 Ben Carson, the secretary of housing and urban development, took responsibility on Thursday for buying a $31,000 dining room set for his office, two days after saying his wife and assistant oversaw a purchase that has jeopardized his place in President Trump\u2019s cabinet.\n\nMr. Carson faced withering criticism from Democrats on the Senate Banking Committee, which oversees the Department of Housing and Urban Development. One senator, Sherrod Brown of Ohio, suggested that he regretted being one of the few Democrats to support the secretary\u2019s nomination a year ago.\n\n\u201cI voted to confirm you,\u201d said Mr. Brown, who is up for re-election this year. \u201cFour other Democrats on this committee voted to confirm you. I\u2019m not sure I made the right decision.\u201d\n\nIn recent days, Mr. Carson\u2019s aides have repeatedly advised him to apologize for the purchase, arguing that doing so was the only way to move on, according to several people with knowledge of the situation. But Mr. Carson, who has privately fumed about what he regards as the unfairness of being singled out for criticism, resisted doing so until Thursday\u2019s hearing, when one of the panel\u2019s Republicans, Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina, gently prodded him to be more contrite.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI take responsibility,\u201d Mr. Carson said.\n\nLater, he suggested the episode had been a personal ordeal, saying that he modeled his reaction to the criticism on advice that Jesus gave in the Sermon on the Mount, which he summarized as \u201cdon\u2019t worry about what people are saying about you, and do the right thing.\u201d", "title": "\u2018I Take Responsibility,\u2019 Carson Says of $31,000 Furniture Purchase", "authors": ["Glenn Thrush"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u2014 Mark White, Seattle\n\nAs a fellow graduate of Nakesha\u2019s from Williams College, I was stunned and deeply moved to read this arresting portrait today. While I didn\u2019t know her personally (she was a few years ahead of me at school), I know several of the people mentioned and sang for a while in the same choir. But you don\u2019t need to know Nakesha personally to be wrenched by this article. It\u2019s as powerful a glimpse into the forces behind homelessness \u2014 forces able to overwhelm even the most exceptionally gifted and intelligent of people \u2014 as I\u2019ve ever read.\n\n\u2014 Alastair Moock, Boston\n\n\u2018She Certainly Made Being the New Kid in School a Lot Easier\u2019\n\nOther commenters were Ms. Williams\u2019s students at Sewickley Academy, near Pittsburgh, where she taught after graduation from Williams.\n\nThis was heartbreaking for me to read. I was a student of hers at Sewickley Academy. Ms. Williams was one of the few teachers in my youth I wasn\u2019t afraid to approach. She certainly made being the new kid in school a lot easier. I can even remember her volunteering her own time after school to help me and a few other students get extra tutoring for math when we were struggling with the content. \u2026 It breaks my heart now knowing the struggles she went through after my brief time as her student. She deserved better.\n\n\u2014 Justin Yee, Pittsburgh\n\n\u2018I Saw Her Virtually Every Morning, Rain or Shine\u2019\n\nStill other readers recognized Ms. Williams as the woman they passed on the street every day.\n\nI worked at 250 Park Ave. for five years. That is the building that this woman lived outside of and I saw her virtually every morning, rain or shine, that I came to work.\n\nThere was always something about her. She was unusually pretty and always reading or writing. I was astounded when I read the article. I wonder how many others there are like her out there.\n\n\u2014 Chayex, New York\n\nAs a young graduate of Williams College who works in Midtown, I now realize that I had walked past her hundreds of times on 46th Street and Park Avenue. To think that I would have reached out to her if I had known her story or connection to Williams and tried to help in my own little way. My heart is broken.", "title": "\u2018I Will Ask Myself More Compassionate Questions\u2019: Readers React to a Story About Homelessness", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "But the money didn\u2019t always assure the safety of Lafarge\u2019s workers or its operations. Between 2012 and the end of 2014, at least a dozen workers were kidnapped, according to testimony and witness statements of former employees, company documents and the internal review. Employees faced gun-toting militants when they went to work. And the factory \u2014 one of the biggest foreign investments in Syria \u2014 was captured anyway. It has been shuttered ever since.\n\nA panel of French judges appointed by the Paris High Court, which oversees criminal investigations, is now looking into whether Lafarge put workers at risk and violated international sanctions by paying the Islamic State and other armed groups to keep operating as war bore down. Six former top Lafarge officials, including two former chief executives, are being formally investigated under charges of financing terrorism.\n\nThe judges, who decide whether cases go to trial, are also examining a lawsuit by Sherpa, a French anti-corruption organization that pursues humanitarian abuses by corporations, on behalf of former employees alleging Lafarge was complicit in war crimes. The employees, in the lawsuit, claim that the company ignored the dangers they faced, and pressured them to keep working.\n\n\u201cLafarge acted as if it was above the law,\u201d said Marie-Laure Guislain, the head of litigation at Sherpa. \u201cBut it played a role in an armed conflict, as well as in the violation of human rights, and must be held accountable.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Sherpa lawsuit helped prompt the French investigation, as did reports on Lafarge\u2019s activities by the French newspaper Le Monde.\n\nAll of the former Lafarge executives have denied the charges against them, which could be dropped if judges find the evidence insufficient. If prosecuted, the executives could face penalties of up to 10 years in jail and fines of 225,000 euros. Authorities will also determine whether the company itself can be held liable. The activity occurred before Lafarge merged with the Swiss cement giant Holcim in 2015.\n\nThe former chief executive Eric Olsen resigned last year after the internal inquiry, although Lafarge concluded that he was not responsible for, or aware of, the activity. In the United States, the company, now called LafargeHolcim after the merger, dropped plans to supply building materials for President Trump\u2019s proposed wall on the border with Mexico amid criticism in France over the Syria affair.\n\nLafargeHolcim, in a statement to The Times, insisted that the No. 1 priority of Lafarge executives was to guarantee employee safety, and pinned the decisions on local managers who \u201cwrongly believed\u201d they were acting in the interests of the company and its employees. The company acknowledged \u201cunacceptable errors committed in Syria,\u201d and said that it \u201cdeeply regrets what happened.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIt also said that while the use of an intermediary was a \u201cserious concern,\u201d its internal review \u201ccould not establish with certainty the ultimate recipients of the funds.\u201d\n\nLafargeHolcim\u2019s chief executive, Jan Jenisch, said the company is cooperating with French authorities. \u201cI am the most interested person that truth comes out and we can close this chapter, which we are very sorry about,\u201d he said during a presentation of the company\u2019s results last week.\n\nIn its statement, LafargeHolcim added it had put in place extensive reviews and controls \u201cto ensure that LafargeHolcim today is a different company with further enhanced compliance.\u201d\n\nMr. Mohamad and the other workers, all of whom survived, are now trying to rebuild their lives. Many had to flee Syria, becoming refugees in Turkey and Europe. While some managed to get jobs, others struggled afterward.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor a while, Dr. Adham Basho, the Lafarge employee who warned Mr. Mohamad, lived with his wife, children and 18 other families in a Turkish refugee facility after leaving Syria. He has found only odd jobs to support his family. Hisham Haji Osman, an information technology specialist, made it to Germany and is still trying to land permanent work. Mr. Mohamad is living as a refugee in Turkey, unable to return home while war persists.\n\n\u2018We Kept Going\u2019\n\nWhen Lafarge bought a dilapidated factory in northern Syria in 2007, one of the biggest advantages was a local partner with ties to President Bashar al-Assad\u2019s government.\n\nThe partner, Firas Tlass, an influential tycoon, could navigate back channels in a country with murky rules and bureaucracy. He arranged an operating license and other permits for Lafarge.\n\nFounded in 1833 as a family business in France, Lafarge had a history of landing big and complicated projects. In the mid-19th century, it won a contract to build the Suez Canal in Egypt. During World War II, it helped furnish cement for the construction of a massive coastal wall of bunkers for the Nazis, known as the Atlantic Wall, that stretched from Scandinavia to the Spanish border.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Syria, Lafarge saw a new opening to the Middle East. After a three-year renovation of the \u20ac680 million plant, Lafarge Cement Syria opened in October 2010, employing hundreds of people and generating thousands of related jobs. Trucks and vans crisscrossed the desert, transporting employees, delivering Lafarge cement and bringing in fuel and raw materials from nearby quarries.\n\nAs operations ramped up, a wave of revolutionary fervor from the Arab Spring movement swept the region. Anti-government protests spread to Syria, and were brutally suppressed in March 2011 by government security forces. Soldiers from Syria\u2019s army defected and, along with civilians who took up arms, formed rebel groups to battle the government, some of them loosely organized as the Free Syrian Army. The government responded by attacking rebel-held areas, in an increasingly complex and bloody conflict that continues to batter the country.\n\nWhile the fighting took root in the south, the security around the Lafarge plant in the north slowly began to deteriorate. Free Syrian Army groups moved into the area, long controlled by Mr. Assad\u2019s government, along with the militia of the Kurdish Democratic Union Party, or PYD. By the end of 2011, the United Nations declared Syria in a state of civil war, and the European Union placed an embargo on arms and oil purchases in Syria.\n\nAfter that, Total, the French oil giant, halted its Syrian operations. Other French multinationals followed, including Bel Group, the maker of Babybel cheese, and Air Liquide, France\u2019s largest gas company.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNot Lafarge. Bruno Lafont, who was the Lafarge chief executive at the time, saw no reason to leave. Company security advisers assured bosses at headquarters in Paris that the plant was not in a combat zone and remained safe. \u201cSo we kept going,\u201d Mr. Lafont told investigators, according to the court documents. \u201cLafarge has never run away.\u201d\n\nBy summer 2012, the situation in Syria had grown increasingly uncertain, and Lafarge decided to move hundreds of foreign employees out of the country for their safety. Senior managers, including Bruno Pescheux, the chief executive of Lafarge Cement Syria at the time, relocated to Cairo to oversee operations remotely.\n\nThe Syrian employees kept working. Their job was to keep the cement flowing \u2014 and to make the factory appear occupied as a way of discouraging militants from raiding it.\n\nLafarge said it wanted to keep providing jobs for locals who eagerly wanted to work. The company relocated employees to Manbij, a town near the plant, and provided lodging for others inside the factory compound so they could keep working as road travel grew more risky, according to testimony by former executives and employees. When the civil war ended, \u201cwe\u2019d at least have an operation that could furnish cement for the reconstruction of Syria,\u201d Mr. Pescheux told French investigators.\n\nPhoto\n\nWorkers felt fortunate to be employed by a major French multinational that offered good salaries to support their families in a region with few opportunities. Yet as the situation grew starker, Lafarge\u2019s local managers, the employees said in interviews, witness accounts and testimony, turned up the pressure, threatening to dismiss or cut the pay of those who balked at the worsening safety environment.\n\n\u201cBefore the war, the management practices were very good,\u201d said Jarir Yahyaalmullaali, a former warehouse keeper. But later, he added, \u201cthey would force you to go to work and threaten to dismiss you even if there were problems and the roads were dangerous.\u201d\n\nAfter their foreign colleagues were evacuated, the Syrian employees discussed forming a union or striking to protest deteriorating work conditions. They were especially upset about being ferried in Lafarge-contracted vans through checkpoints held by a rotating cast of armed militants, the employees said in interviews, testimony and accounts submitted to the court.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cImagine the journey,\u201d said Nidal Wahbi, a former Lafarge human resources manager in Syria who is part of the lawsuit. \u201cYou could be stopped at any time, and either they let you go, or they could take you from the car for questioning.\u201d When sniper bullets grazed his vehicle one morning, \u201cI realized for the first time how unsafe it was,\u201d he said. \u201cBut the next day, you had to go through the same road, because Lafarge would ask why you didn\u2019t go to work.\u201d\n\nA Growing Threat\n\nWhen the fighting got too close, the payments to ISIS started to flow.\n\nIn mid-2012, local Lafarge executives provided the Syrian partner with a monthly budget of around $100,000. They gave him instructions to act as an intermediary with local groups to ensure safe passage around the factory, Mr. Pescheux told investigators.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe partner, Mr. Tlass, according to the law firm\u2019s review, steered large sums to the Free Syrian Army, which occupied Manbij, where Lafarge had relocated employees. More money flowed to the Kurds, who had worked with the Free Syrian Army and promised military-style protection for the factory, which they considered to be in their territory.\n\nThe payoffs didn\u2019t guarantee safety. In autumn, the Kurds kidnapped nine Lafarge employees and transferred them to local militias. Lafarge\u2019s local managers reported the kidnappings to Paris and spent around \u20ac200,000 to secure their release, according to the internal inquiry and testimony of former executives.\n\nThe troubles worsened in 2013, when the Qaeda affiliate in Syria, the Nusra Front, and other Islamic groups seized Raqqa, a strategic city about 90 kilometers south of the factory. In the ensuing months, a schism within Al Qaeda split the Nusra Front from the Islamic State group, which took control of Raqqa. ISIS began a slow but steady push toward the region around the Lafarge plant.", "title": "\u2018ISIS Is Coming!\u2019 How a French Company Pushed the Limits in War-Torn Syria", "authors": ["Liz Alderman", "Elian Peltier", "Hwaida Saad"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Some readers dinged me for not doing enough advance research: \u201cLooks like he would of had a better time if he\u2019d done his homework before hand. Some very bad planning on his trip,\u201d wrote M&M on Twitter. \u201d And a reader, Tarin Olding, asked: \u201cU don\u2019t do any research on the destination/industry before u experience it & write critically about something u put no effort into? Entire online cornucopia of boards, FB groups (including cruise specific ones), websites, podcasts & blogs to help you!\u201d\n\nGuilty as charged. But I will add that it was an intentional decision: I wanted to go into the trip as a total novice, to learn things the hard way. (For one thing, I figured it would make for a more entertaining story.) There are definitely ways to game the Disney cruise system \u2014 and we should probably do a follow-up article on that.\n\nStill others felt the piece stank of snobbery: \u201cJust curious, but did you have to pay extra on your trip to learn to look down your nose at people with differing tastes or did that come free?\u201d wrote Suzanne Claire of Pennsylvania. \u201cYou seem to think you\u2019re too sophisticated for the Disney cruise,\u201d wrote Nate Sanchez on Twitter. \u201cYou criticize the food, the help, the fanfare.\u201d (For the record, I specifically noted how great the crew was \u2014 friendly, helpful and genuinely enthusiastic.)\n\nI can certainly be a travel snob, though I also made a point of noting how many people love these cruises \u2014 there were plenty of repeat customers on ours (members of the Castaway Club, in Disney parlance). I just won\u2019t be one of them \u2014 though my daughter has other ideas.\n\nThe article also started a discussion about the place that cruises have in the travel landscape. \u201cSorry to be a downer, but I found this article disturbing and depressing,\u201d wrote Doug Hill of Philadelphia. \u201cIt confirms that the cruise experience is all about consuming, while the ocean you\u2019re cruising on and the islands you visit are all in the process of being destroyed by consumerism.\u201d", "title": "\u2018If You Can\u2019t Have Fun on a Disney Cruise ...\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Adhiambo Mitchell lost both his legs in a car accident on the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn almost 10 years ago. Nolan Ryan Trowe was partly paralyzed while cliff diving in Northern California in 2016. When they met last year, they bonded over a shared attitude toward their disabilities.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very affirming to be around someone as positive as Adhiambo,\u201d Mr. Trowe said. \u201cI have never heard him complain about anything.\u201d\n\n\u201cNolan is adventurous,\u201d Mr. Mitchell said. \u201cYou can put him in any predicament and he\u2019ll know how to maneuver. There is no cowardice in him. And he is a really good rapper.\u201d", "title": "\u2018It Was Like My Disability Became a Gift\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "None of the friends and family members who have testified so far warned Marina and Kevin Krim, the couple for whom Ms. Ortega worked as a nanny, that she seemed to be going through a crisis.\n\nMs. Ortega, 55, is charged with two counts of first-degree murder and faces life in prison. She is accused of fatally stabbing 2-year-old Leo Krim and his 6-year-old sister, Lucia, inside the bathroom of the Krims\u2019 Upper West Side apartment, before stabbing herself in the throat. Marina Krim discovered the grisly scene at about 5:30 p.m. on Oct. 25, 2012.\n\nMs. Ortega has entered a plea of not responsible by reason of mental disease or defect. If acquitted, she would be sent to a maximum security psychiatric hospital.\n\nHer lawyer, Valerie Van Leer-Greenberg, contends Ms. Ortega has experienced hallucinations and delusions since she was 16, but her illness was never treated until after her arrest. The prosecution maintains she killed the children because she was angry at their mother over her workload.\n\nMs. Ortega\u2019s sisters, Delci Ortega, 60, and Miladys Garcia, 64, both testified that Ms. Ortega professed to love the Krim children. Despite her odd behavior, they said they had no clue that she wanted to hurt them.\n\n\u201cAt no time did I think she was going to do this,\u201d Ms. Garcia said. \u201cIt was not herself that killed them. She had become something else. Something evil.\u201d\n\nHer sisters said Ms. Ortega was born and raised in Santiago de Caballeros, a city in the Dominican Republic, where their father owned a bodega. When she was 16, a younger sister, Rosa, died suddenly. Ms. Ortega slipped into a black depression, unwilling to leave the house for a year, her sisters said. Eventually her parents took her to a doctor and she recovered, Ms. Garcia said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 1985, Ms. Ortega graduated from a local university with an accounting degree and moved to New York City, where Ms. Garcia was living in an apartment at 610 Riverside Drive. Ms. Ortega found steady work at a printing company.\n\nBy 1995, she had married and given birth to a son, Jesus Alberto Frias. Four years later, she split up with her husband and took her toddler to the Dominican Republic, her family said. She gave him to Ms. Garcia, who had returned to the island, to raise, and returned to New York to seek work.\n\nThough she worked many menial jobs, her only work as a nanny was taking care of her nephew\u2019s children in Dallas for four months in late 2006 and early 2007, the children\u2019s mother, Glendalys Garcia, 38, testified.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Frias said that while he and his mother were separated, she stayed in touch, calling him every day and visiting him four or five times a year. But it was not until 2008 that she returned to the Dominican Republic for an extended period, while Miladys Garcia went back to the United States.\n\nThat year, in April, a close friend of Ms. Ortega\u2019s shot himself in the head on the balcony of her childhood home, Mr. Frias said. He said his mother became a paranoid shut-in, so fearful of crime she would not let him go to baseball practice, and so scared of intruders she made him hide under the bed every time a dog barked.\n\n\u201cShe would step outside and she would hear someone say, \u2018Go back, go back,\u2019\u201d Miladys Garcia testified. \u201cShe heard voices speaking to her.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn August, Miladys Garcia returned to take charge of Mr. Frias, and Ms. Ortega, who was gaunt and complaining of constant headaches, flew back to New York.\n\nA year and a half later, Ms. Ortega landed the job as a nanny with the Krims, through her sister, who was a nanny. She used a relative, Jacqueline Severino, as a false reference. Ms. Severino had no children, but wrote a glowing fictional review of Ms. Ortega for the Krims, according to evidence presented at trial.\n\nFor two years, Ms. Ortega thrived at the job, but then, in April 2012, she began to go to pieces emotionally, her family members testified. She quarreled with Miladys Garcia, who had the lease on the family apartment, and moved to the Bronx apartment of another relative.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat summer, she called Glendalys Garcia three or four times a day, saying she felt betrayed by her sister. \u201cShe cried every day,\u201d Glendalys Garcia recalled. \u201cShe just said \u2018pray for me.\u2019\u201d\n\nIn June, Mr. Frias, now a senior in high school, moved to the Bronx and in with his mother. The city school system had threatened to hold him back a year, so his mother took $7,500 in cash out of her savings to pay for a private Catholic school, he said.\n\nBy September, Ms. Ortega\u2019s money was running low, and she was forced to move back in with Delci Ortega, who was now living at the family apartment on Riverside Drive, the witnesses said.\n\nOver the next few weeks, Ms. Ortega complained to Delci that the Krims changed her schedule often, playing havoc with her own plans. She also complained of skin problems from detergents.\n\nOne night she woke at 4 a.m., banged her head into the wall and plucked out her hair. \u201cI want to go back to the way I was before,\u201d Delci Ortega recalled her saying.\n\nEvery night Ms. Ortega prayed aloud in her narrow room on her twin bed, with a picture of the infant Jesus, candles and an illuminated Bible. \u201cShe prayed to God to take away all the things she was feeling in her body and mind,\u201d Delci Ortega said.\n\nThe night before the murders, Ms. Ortega was \u201cvery nervous,\u201d depressed and took medication for a headache, Delci Ortega said. Then Ms. Ortega told her sister to take \u201cgood care\u201d of her son, \u201cto raise him well\u201d and let him know \u201cthat I do love him.\u201d\n\nShe described how she had been hearing voices and had seen \u201ca black man\u201d who wanted to separate the family. Ms. Ortega said she had prayed for \u201cthe black man\u201d to go away.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe next day, at 1:30 in the afternoon, Ms. Ortega visited a young neighbor in her building, Jennifer Reynosa. Ms. Ortega\u2019s eyes were darting side to side, and she said she was being followed by a \u201cblack shadow\u201d that spoke to her.\n\n\u201cIt scared me,\u201d Ms. Reynosa testified in Spanish. \u201cI looked at her and said, \u2018My God, this woman is crazy.\u2019 \u201d\n\nA short time later, Ms. Ortega left for her job at the Krims.", "title": "\u2018It Was Not Herself That Killed Them,\u2019 Sister Testifies in Nanny Trial", "authors": ["James C. Mckinley Jr.", "Jan Ransom"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Based in Omaha, the company operates the largest rail network on the continent, a conduit that provides us with cereal, lumber, car parts and pretty much everything that touches our lives. That makes the railroad a real-time barometer of the fluctuations in global trade \u2014 a physical manifestation of how President Trump\u2019s agenda to remake the rules of commerce will play out.\n\nRoughly 40 percent of the goods that Union Pacific moves touch an international border at some point in their journey, putting the railroad at the center of the global tensions that have arisen as the administration prepares to impose tariffs on goods from China and steel and aluminum from around the world. Seventy percent of rail freight between the United States and Mexico travels on Union Pacific trains, meaning the outcome of the tense renegotiations for the North American Free Trade Agreement will shape the company\u2019s future.\n\n\u201cAt its guts, a railroad like Union Pacific is built on people consuming stuff, industry consuming stuff, and trade flows,\u201d said Lance Fritz, Union Pacific\u2019s chief executive. \u201cWhen those are happening and growing, we thrive. And all of that potentially gets impacted by getting Nafta wrong or the United States exiting Nafta.\u201d", "title": "\u2018It\u2019s Factory North America,\u2019 but Trump Could Hobble It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "ALSTON MOOR, England \u2014 After a week of blizzards, freezing rain and brutal wind \u2014 some of the worst winter weather Britain has seen in decades \u2014 the sun finally emerged in northern England on Monday, piercing the thick gray storm clouds and melting layers of ice that had sent cars spinning off roads and left towns and cities paralyzed for days.\n\nFor most of England, the warmer conditions brought a thaw after a week of chaos, but for many in remote regions like some of the hills of the Pennines, the worst was far from over.\n\nThe extreme winds and snows, created by the collision of two weather systems, Storm Emma and a blast of arctic Siberian air nicknamed the Beast from the East, left several rural communities stranded for days with limited food and fuel, prompting the military to drop emergency supplies by helicopter on Monday.\n\nSnowdrifts piled up to seven feet high in the northern Pennines, leaving some residents trapped in their homes for more than 48 hours before emergency services and volunteers were able to dig them out.", "title": "\u2018I\u2019ve Never Seen Anything Like This\u2019: Snow Brings Rural U.K. to a Halt", "authors": ["Ceylan Yeginsu"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "But long before the Zurbar\u00e1n revival, Richard Trevor, a progressive and fabulously wealthy English bishop, acquired nearly the full set of biblical portraits, which had somehow turned up in a London auction house in the mid-18th century. (We\u2019re not sure how they got to England. The Frick show\u2019s robust catalog details that Zurbar\u00e1n probably painted the works for export to the New World, but they never made it there.) In 1756, Bishop Trevor hung them in Auckland Castle\u2019s dining room, where they had more than decorative impact. The bishop was a keen defender of English Jews, who were enfranchised by an act of Parliament in 1753, only to see the act repealed a year later amid anti-Semitic public protest. Diners at the bishop\u2019s table would have sat under the reproving gazes of these Old Testament figures, Jewish forefathers of the church\u2019s good fortune.\n\nJacob, the patriarch, appears in an olive-colored turban and a simple red tunic, his white beard cascading to the top of the cane over which he hunches. His 12 sons, by contrast, fill the height of each six-and-a-half-foot canvas; they pose frontally, in profile or from behind, and they wear a startling variety of crisp, supple fabrics, whose glamour or grittiness echoes Jacob\u2019s foretelling of their destinies in the Book of Genesis. (One theory about Zurbar\u00e1n\u2019s fashion fixation: His father was a haberdasher.)\n\nReuben, the eldest son, echoes Jacob by wearing a lofty turban, while Simeon has on a savage animal pelt, and Levi, his back to us, sports an embroidered robe and eye-popping boots studded with pearls. In these paintings and the others, Zurbar\u00e1n places the figures against landscapes whose horizon is slung low, so that the brothers appear to tower over the earth.\n\nJudah, son No. 4 and the ancestor of Kings David and Solomon, faces front in a fur-trimmed gown, toting a scepter and standing beside a kindly lion. (\u201cA lion\u2019s whelp,\u201d Jacob calls Judah in Genesis.) He appears far more august than the next six brothers, who are kitted out in an array of military, mercantile and peasant clothing.", "title": "\u2018Jacob and His Twelve Sons\u2019: Zurbar\u00e1n\u2019s Biblical All-Stars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "I adore opera. But James Levine is a conductor, not a god. The Met would do well to focus fund-raising efforts on educating the public and donors about the artistry, creativity and glorious musicality of opera and making opera more accessible \u2014 not creating a deity to be worshiped by New Yorkers. SGL, SETAUKET, N.Y.\n\nMaestro worship is an extension of the high self-regard held by some who patronize the arts. But as in religion and sports, we learn that the higher the fall, the bigger the splat. TONY, WEST VIRGINIA\n\nThis article inadvertently highlights another structural problem in the arts: \u201cHe made the Met\u2019s orchestra into one of the finest in the world \u2026\u201d No, the players in the Met\u2019s orchestra did that. We need to stop putting individuals like Mr. Levine on pedestals and get over the tendency to make and worship superstars, to the point where horrible acts by such individuals get ignored. Mr. Levine was never indispensable. CME, SEATTLE\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2018It doesn\u2019t detract from the beautiful music he created onstage.\u2019\n\nSome readers wondered if professional success and allegations of personal misconduct could be separated.\n\nHorrible. Just horrible. But it doesn\u2019t detract from the beautiful music he and the Met created onstage. LOGAN ANDERSON, VIA FACEBOOK\n\nThe Met, may I remind everyone, is not a church, although it may be experienced by some, myself included, as a \u201creligion.\u201d We go there to hear music. And I for one will not buy into the idea the terrible and strange stuff that went on cancels all that out. Even if someone did terrible things, should we then ignore, condemn or eradicate the good things that same person did or created? Let\u2019s put our daggers away, O.K., people? They don\u2019t look good on us. ROGER, SAN FRANCISCO\n\nThe man is probably the greatest opera conductor/interpreter of all time. Although I cannot condone the behavior, he has not fallen from my grace. RICHARD FRAUENGLASS, HUNTINGTON, N.Y.\n\n\u2018To be willfully blind is the same as being complicit.\u2019\n\nReaders said that their reactions to the news were affected by what the Met knew and for how long about Mr. Levine\u2019s alleged behavior. They asked if the Met\u2019s reputation should suffer accordingly.\n\nTo be willfully blind is the same as being complicit. TOM Q., SOUTHWICK, MASS.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow convenient for the Met to let Mr. Levine go now that he is 74 and in poor health. Why did they not have the courage to do something earlier? Before the #MeToo movement? When it was inconvenient? MOCKINGJAY, CALIFORNIA", "title": "\u2018James Levine Is a Conductor, Not a God\u2019: Readers React to His Firing", "authors": ["Lela Moore"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music\n\nBook Review \u2018Just the Funny Parts\u2019 Nell Scovell discusses her new memoir, and Joanne Lipman talks about \u201cThat\u2019s What She Said.\u201d Audio\n\nIn The New York Times Book Review, Melena Ryzik reviews Nell Scovell\u2019s \u201cJust the Funny Parts: \u2026 And a Few Hard Truths About Sneaking Into the Hollywood Boys\u2019 Club.\u201d Ryzik writes:\n\nPhoto\n\nThe bar for contemporary women-in-comedy books was set in 2011 with Tina Fey\u2019s \u201cBossypants,\u201d which managed advice that was both hilarious and accurate \u2014 no pigtails or tube tops at the office, no diet foods in meetings and cry at work if you must because \u201cit terrifies everyone.\u201d Scovell\u2019s lessons are less jokey and more emotionally bare; she even confesses a few things that our feminist foremothers have taught us to keep buttoned up \u2014 like the lines that she crossed, too \u2014 which feels freeing. Over all, though, \u201cJust the Funny Parts\u201d functions best not when Scovell is recounting some backstage encounter on \u201cThe Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour\u201d or \u201cNewhart\u201d but when she\u2019s rankled.\n\nOn this week\u2019s podcast, Scovell discusses \u201cJust the Funny Parts\u201d; Joanne Lipman talks about \u201cThat\u2019s What She Said: What Men Need to Know (and Women Need to Tell Them) About Working Together\u201d; and Parul Sehgal and Jennifer Szalai on books by women that are shaping the way we read and write fiction in the 21st century. You may want to adjust your notifications to be alerted when a new episode arrives.", "title": "\u2018Just the Funny Parts\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "The victims ranged in age from 14 to 40, including Atiqullah, 20, who had gotten married three months ago. According to Hukum Khan Dawlatzai, a local tribal elder, 29 others were arrested in the raid.\n\nNazim Jan, the commander of the local police unit in the village, confirmed that his forces had been informed by the farmers that they were going out to irrigate. It apparently made little difference that the crop was opium, which is grown extensively across the country despite more than $8 billion in American efforts to curb the industry.\n\n\u201cYes, they had informed us that they would be out watering their fields,\u201d Mr. Jan said. \u201cThe helicopters came and shot them. We saw the helicopters coming \u2014 they did it unilaterally, they killed innocent civilians.\u201d\n\nA senior security official in Nangarhar, speaking anonymously because he was not authorized to speak to the media, said the force, known as the 02 Unit, had arrived in NATO coalition helicopters and was accompanied by coalition advisers.\n\nA provincial politician said such raids are typically carried out with NATO\u2019s assistance.\n\n\u201cWhen the 02 Unit operates, it usually operates under supervision of the Americans,\u201d said Zabihullah Zmarai, a member of the Nangarhar provincial council. \u201cThey usually have American helicopters,\u201d he said, adding, \u201cEven when they come by road they have foreign advisers.\u201d\n\nOfficials from the country\u2019s intelligence agency, the National Directorate of Security, could not be reached for comment.\n\nCapt. Tom Gresback, a spokesman for the American-led NATO coalition, rejected the claims that American or coalition forces, or their helicopters, were involved in the raid.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe are aware that several Taliban were killed to include a high-value individual and more than 20 suspected Taliban were detained to include three additional high-value individuals,\u201d Captain Gresback said.\n\nPhoto\n\nProvincial officials in Nangarhar at first denied that civilians had been killed in the raid. But when villagers carried the bodies to the district center hours later, with nearly 200 protesters accompanying them and chanting, \u201cDeath to the government\u201d and \u201cDeath to America,\u201d a senior official privately acknowledged that government forces had caused the casualties.\n\nThe police guarding the district compound opened fire on the protesters, killing one and wounding two others.\n\nAfghanistan has experienced a rise in violence in recent weeks, even before the official start of what is expected to be another bloody fighting season, when violence intensifies as the cold weather relents. In two weeks, 170 security forces have been killed, according to local news reports. The government says more than 500 insurgents were killed in about the same period.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFighting has raged across the country, with some of the heaviest coming in the western province of Farah, where insurgents are once again at the gates of its capital city, and in the northern Faryab Province, where dozens of local militia fighters have surrendered to the Taliban. More than 100 advisers from the American-led NATO coalition have arrived in Faryab to help.\n\nThe increase in violence may once again test the resolve of the country\u2019s government, which recently presented an extensive peace offer to the Taliban.\n\nEven as President Ashraf Ghani and his international allies prepare for what they see as an opening for talks, and with American officials reporting signals of willingness from some Taliban leaders, Afghans are wary of another bloody year ahead.\n\nLast year, 3,438 civilians were killed and 7,015 wounded, according to the United Nations. As the war spreads across the country, often deep into populated villages, the effects are taking a heavy toll on civilians. When the violence is perpetuated by government forces, it highlights the deadly bind in which civilians find themselves.\n\nThe Afghan intelligence agency has long been accused of abuses, particularly torture and mistreatment in detention centers. Although a recent United Nations report said the government had shown commitment to improving such practices, the agency continues to draw criticism.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cBefore this incident, too, the 02 Unit has carried out multiple operations in which civilians have been killed or wounded,\u201d said Sabrina Hamidi, head of the Afghan human rights commission in the east. \u201cThis is an issue of concern for us.\u201d\n\nIn the west of the country, officials in Farah Province said the provincial capital, Farah City, remained surrounded by the Taliban.\n\n\u201cOver the last two weeks, we have lost more than 40 security forces,\u201d said Dadullah Qani, a member of the provincial council in Farah.\n\nFighting has also raged in Faryab Province. A government militia commander in the province surrendered with about 80 of his fighters to the Taliban on Friday, according to Naqibullah, a fellow militia commander in the province. But a spokesman for the Faryab police played down the episode, saying the commander had surrendered with only 15 fighters.\n\nCoalition forces have used extensive airstrikes in Faryab and in neighboring Jowzjan Province, according to Afghan officials, including B-52 bombers, a hallmark of the early years of the American-led invasion, the district governor, Baz Mohammed Dawar, said.\n\nCaptain Gresback, the coalition spokesman said, \u201cAs a result of our alignment of air power, we will maintain relentless pressure on the Taliban using a variety of aircraft to conduct daily strikes, including B-52s\u201d and other aircraft. \u201cThese strikes continue to support a capable Afghan ground force,\u201d he added.", "title": "\u2018Killed, Shovel in Hand\u2019: Afghan Farmers Are Latest Victims of a Chaotic War", "authors": ["Zabihullah Ghazi", "Mujib Mashal"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The last time \u2014 perhaps the only time \u2014 John R. Bolton inspired bipartisan agreement, it was over the shared conclusion that he was perhaps the least diplomatic personality a president could have ever picked to be an American diplomat.\n\nThat was in 2005, when Mr. Bolton was last considered for a government job. Accounts of his red-faced tirades against intelligence analysts whose findings he disagreed with so concerned members of the Senate that they refused to approve his nomination as President George W. Bush\u2019s ambassador to the United Nations.\n\nHe wound up getting the job anyway through a recess appointment by Mr. Bush, who later regretted spending the political capital on such a divisive figure, telling conservatives, \u201cI don\u2019t consider Bolton credible.\u201d\n\nThirteen years later, another president has given Mr. Bolton the far more consequential job of national security adviser. But because that post does not require Senate confirmation, the five months in 2005 that the Senate took to decide whether Mr. Bolton should go to the United Nations remain the only extensive examination of his record and his temperament.", "title": "\u2018Kiss Up, Kick Down\u2019: Those Recalling Bolton\u2019s U.N. Confirmation Process Say He Hasn\u2019t Changed", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Here are the crucial things I think Sheryl Sandberg did. First, she made women question not just what\u2019s wrong with the corporate structure, but ask themselves, \u201cHow are you holding yourself back?\u201d Because structural change in the work environment is critical \u2014 but nothing makes a difference if you\u2019re holding yourself back. Many people said, \u201cOh, she was telling women to blame themselves,\u201d but that\u2019s not it at all. (And the onus isn\u2019t only on women; she talks about men leaning in, too.)\n\nWhat\u2019s powerful about Sheryl\u2019s writing is that she\u2019s honest. It\u2019s easy to dump on her because of her privilege. But she is self-effacing and self-questioning; she was always asking herself, whenever there was a problem, \u201cWhat\u2019s my role in this?\u201d And that\u2019s what she gave us, too: She put language to some workplace issues we all know exist but don\u2019t always know how to talk about. The idea of \u201cleaning in\u201d is extremely useful. For example, when we\u2019re feeling excluded at work, when someone isn\u2019t including us in a discussion or a project, we\u2019re all so uncomfortable. That\u2019s when we want to lean back and just ignore it. And that\u2019s exactly the time to lean in.\n\nSheryl makes it very clear how we all grow through discomfort. Think about this as a parent. When I had fights with my one of my daughters when she was younger, my thoughts would drift toward sending her to boarding school. If we both went into our rooms and shut the door, nothing happened. It\u2019s when I leaned into the conflict and forced more discussion, painful as it was, that\u2019s when things got resolved.\n\nAnd you know where she was really right, even if this part of the movement got her a lot of flak? Choosing your partner, insisting on that person being supportive and participating in the home 50 percent of the time. She was so deliberate about this part of her life. And lots of people took her to task for this, because we aren\u2019t comfortable thinking so strategically about love and romance. The truth is, when a marriage is bad, work is a great refuge. I have to admit, I put my husband at the center of everything, and it was a very bad marriage, and my career took off when I got divorced.\n\nIt\u2019s interesting. What satisfies me at my age \u2014 some board representation, some women in the C suite or on the management team \u2014 does not feel like enough to my millennial daughters. We were talking about this recently, and they were like, \u201cAre you kidding me?\u201d Representation should be at least 50 percent, they say. And they\u2019re not wrong.\n\nLola Bates-Campbell, 30\n\nAssociate creative director at Frog Design (and a daughter of Sunny Bates)\n\nFive years ago, when \u201cLean In\u201d just came out, I was a very junior person at Frog Design. I never read the book. But I remember vividly when it came out, because it catalyzed a series of initiatives at the company to look at women in positions of leadership and compensation. The company\u2019s C.O.O. and president were women. I remember the first meeting we had \u2014 I was so junior that I wasn\u2019t sitting at the table, but sort of on a chair in the corner \u2014 and the conclusion was that because there were women in the C suite, the company didn\u2019t have any systemic issues, even though there were very few women in middle management. Essentially the message to us, that I thought was the \u201cLean In\u201d message, was: You have to do more. And people left that meeting kind of crestfallen. So, it\u2019s all up to us to pull ourselves up by the bootstraps? O.K., then! But it felt out of touch.\n\nBut that wasn\u2019t the end of it. Over the next three years, the company continued to look at the issue, brought in an outside consultant that allowed us to address gender and diversity issues \u2014 and ultimately there was real change. Five years later, I\u2019m one of those women in middle management now, and one of the reasons is the \u201cLean In\u201d movement. Even for those who didn\u2019t read it and make it a part of their lives in a conscious way, it had an effect.", "title": "\u2018Lean In\u2019: Five Years Later", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Polls suggest that Ms. Le Pen\u2019s underperformance in last year\u2019s election has seriously damaged the National Front. A clear majority of French now consider it a threat to democracy, according to polls published in Le Monde this month, a reversal of Ms. Le Pen\u2019s careful, yearslong effort to \u201cundemonize\u201d her party, a word used even in party circles.\n\nOn a range of questions, from Ms. Le Pen\u2019s capacity to govern to adherence to the Front\u2019s ideas, the polls indicated that the party has lost significant ground.\n\nMs. Le Pen had succeeded in pulling up the party\u2019s rankings in these areas before last year\u2019s vote, particularly before her disastrous debate performance against Mr. Macron. But no more.\n\nShe was elected to Parliament from a safe district last year, after winning only a third of the vote in the presidential election, far worse than her supporters had hoped.\n\nAnd she has been nearly silent ever since. Far from constituting the principal opposition to President Emmanuel Macron, a promise she made last year, her voice in the National Assembly is inaudible. The influence of the Front\u2019s few parliamentary deputies is negligible. The party has virtually disappeared as a national force.\n\nThe party congress this weekend in Lille was intended, in part, to reverse this. Ms. Le Pen has received authorization to change the National Front\u2019s name, still associated with the party\u2019s founder, her father, Jean-Marie Le Pen, and his years of Holocaust denial and association with Nazi collaborators.\n\nKicked out of the party by his daughter in 2015, Mr. Le Pen called a name change \u201csuicidal\u201d in a recent interview. The Taliban are now all but banished from Swat. But many Pakistanis are still deeply suspicious of Ms. Yousafzai\u2019s mission to educate girls and empower women.", "title": "\u2018Like a Dream\u2019: Malala Makes an Emotional Visit to Her Pakistani Hometown", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "The governor also was the beneficiary of a supportive statement from H\u00e9ctor Figueroa, the president of 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, released shortly after Ms. Nixon finished speaking. He lauded Mr. Cuomo\u2019s record and downplayed those who \u201cseize the most headlines\u201d through personal attacks.\n\n\u201cWe saw Cynthia Nixon\u2019s news conference,\u201d said Rachel Cohen, a union spokeswoman, when asked about the motivation for Mr. Figueroa\u2019s statement. \u201cAnd we just wanted to restate our support for the governor\u2019s record.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
