Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe stated reason for Ms. Nixon\u2019s visit to Albany was to lobby for more equitable education funding, an issue on which the actress and activist has been lobbying for years. But the event was also, of course, an opportunity to cast a broader message.\n\nMs. Nixon, 51, took a smattering of questions after her speech, keeping most of her answers brief. She expressed support for raising taxes on the rich, called the governor\u2019s 2 percent spending cap \u201cdisastrous,\u201d and demurred when asked about revelations about Mayor Bill de Blasio \u2014 an ally of hers \u2014 taking tens of thousands of dollars in donations from a Long Island restaurateur seeking better lease terms for one of his restaurants.\n\n\u201cWe just have to get big money out of politics,\u201d Ms. Nixon said, while being chased down a Hilton stairwell by the press corps. \u201cIt\u2019s completely subverting our democratic process.\u201d\n\nIn her speech, Ms. Nixon, who is trying to become the state\u2019s first female governor, seemed galled at Mr. Cuomo\u2019s failure to invite the Senate minority leader, Andrea Stewart-Cousins, the only woman in leadership in the Legislature, to help negotiate a raft of new sexual-harassment proposals in the budget. Ms. Nixon likened the situation to the governor \u201cmansplaining and lecturing women on sexual harassment.\u201d\n\nShe also attacked Mr. Cuomo for being part of \u201can old boys\u2019 club of one actual Republican and two wannabe Republicans,\u201d referring to John J. Flanagan, the Republican Senate leader, and Jeffrey D. Klein, leader of the breakaway Independent Democratic Conference, which collaborates with Mr. Flanagan to rule the Senate.\n\n\u201cIn a few days, or maybe sooner, Governor Cuomo will walk out of that room and do what he always does: promise big, get some headlines,\u201d she said, \u201cand ultimately hand all the power over to his buddies in the Republican Senate.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Mad as Hell,\u2019 Cynthia Nixon Comes Out Swinging in Albany", "authors": ["Jesse Mckinley"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Judging from the survivors, the victims of Wednesday\u2019s bombing were Sunnis, both Pashtuns and Tajiks, as well as Hazaras. Although the Sakhi shrine is mainly a Shiite institution, it had been regarded as a safe place because it was heavily guarded after the previous attacks on Hazaras. It had been a popular venue on Wednesday with many ethnic groups.\n\nNowruz is the beginning of the year on the Persian calendar, but it also serves as a celebration of the end of winter, the first day of spring and the beginning of the school year. It\u2019s associated with outdoor festivities and picnics, usually with many children present; it is also a traditional time to try on new clothes, and many dress in their finest to promenade in the city.\n\nIn the courtyard of the hospital, one family arrived to find three members among the dead: an older woman in a pink traditional Hazara dress; a young man named Sajad, already in a body bag; and a boy of about 4 or 5. The boy wore a new red shirt, and his father, wearing old clothes, lifted him in his arms. He seemed too shocked for words or tears as he laid him in an ambulance beside Sajad, his older brother.\n\nAnother relative came and shook the young man\u2019s corpse, saying, \u201cSajad, please stand up, why won\u2019t you talk to me? What will I say to your mother?\u201d\n\nA fashionably dressed young woman, about 22 years old, her hands decorated with elaborate henna tattoos, mourned an older brother; doctors lifted a corner of the sheet covering him so she could identify him. She cried so hard that she ran out of tears, and began tearing her hair and scratching her face. \u201cLala jan,\u201d she said, using the affectionate term for an older brother, \u201cI want to come with you \u2014 I don\u2019t want to be alive any longer.\u201d\n\nMany of those in the courtyard were furious, yelling at journalists to leave, and denouncing political leaders. Doctors joined in the anger, yelling for blood, for more ambulances, for medicine. Many in the crowd repeatedly chanted \u201cDeath to Hekmatyar,\u201d referring to Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, the insurgent leader who last year made peace with the government, but is widely remembered as the \u201cButcher of Kabul\u201d for his Hezb-i-Islami group\u2019s relentless shelling of Kabul in the 1990s. There is no indication that his group was involved in Wednesday\u2019s bombing.\n\nMustafa\u2019s mother spent her ire on President Ashraf Ghani, with a maternal curse: \u201cMay God kill your own son so you will understand what it means to lose one.\u201d", "title": "\u2018May God Kill Your Own Son\u2019: Bomb Rips Families Apart in Kabul", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMAASTRICHT, the Netherlands \u2014 In theory, someone selects jewelry because it is personally expressive in some way. But with \u201cMeaningful Jewels,\u201d a collection of 46 antique European pieces exhibited for the first time at the European Fine Arts Fair earlier this month, Sandra Hindman aimed to highlight what she called a \u201cmore loaded\u201d interpretation.\n\nThat is why Ms. Hindman, founder of the gallery Les Enluminures in Paris and Chicago, and her colleagues \u2014 Beatriz Chadour-Sampson, a jewelry historian, and Cynthia Hahn, a reliquary arts specialist, the authors of a book on the collection \u2014 decided to frame the exhibition with the quote: \u201cThe thing of mine I have loved the best.\u201d\n\nThe phrase came from the will of a medieval English duchess. And the \u201cthing,\u201d which Ms. Hindman, a medieval manuscript dealer, sold to a museum 25 years ago, was a two-inch-tall psalter with eight illuminated pages. She deduced that it was a talisman, something so precious that it was made to be handled and worn. Jewels, she realized, were just as moving.\n\nPhoto\n\nCompiled over 15 years, the \u201cMeaningful\u201d collection includes many crosses, representations of saints and scenes of the Annunciation and Crucifixion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Ms. Hindman noted that, despite the devotional touch points, the pieces have almost nothing to do with traditional religion, nor are they fashion items, accessories or traditional art objects. \u201cThese are personal adornment with everyday power. They\u2019re different, almost magical,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s less about a visual aesthetic than how they interacted with you as a person, on your body.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Meaningful Jewels,\u2019 on Exhibition", "authors": ["Tina Isaac-Goiz\u00e9"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "The Pew Research Center announced last week that it will define people born between 1981 and 1996 as members of the millennial generation, embracing a slightly narrower range of years than the ones used by the United States Census Bureau. It would have been better, though, if it had announced the end of what I call the \u201cgeneration game\u201d \u2014 the insistence on dividing society into groups based on birth year and imputing different characteristics to each group.\n\nYes, limited insights can be gleaned from thinking of humans in terms of generations, but this ultimately does more harm than good by obscuring the individual factors that actually shape our attitudes, politics and opportunities.\n\nTo see what\u2019s wrong with the idea, take a look at American millennials. In seemingly endless essays in recent years, they\u2019ve been derided as lazy and narcissistic or defended as creative and committed to social change. But these all sound like characteristics that the old have ascribed to the young since the dawn of time. Similar terms were applied to the \u201cslacker\u201d Generation X and before that, the baby boomers.\n\nIt\u2019s true that the current cohort (the demographic term for a group of people born around the same time) of young people is different in important ways from earlier cohorts. It\u2019s more ethnically diverse, with a smaller proportion of whites and more of most other racial and ethnic groups. But diversity is a characteristic of a population, not, in most cases, of individuals. A relatively small proportion of millennials personally embody ethnic diversity in the sense of identifying with more than one race or ethnicity.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Millennial\u2019 Means Nothing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Fred Rogers first encountered a television in 1951 during his senior year at Rollins College. He hated it.\n\n\u201cI saw people throwing pies in each other\u2019s faces, and I thought: This could be a wonderful tool for education! Why is it being used this way?\u201d Rogers said in an interview in 1999.\n\nIntrigued by the medium\u2019s potential, he told his parents that he wanted to postpone his plans to become a Presbyterian minister in order to pursue a career in television.\n\n\u201cThey said, \u2018You\u2019ve never even seen it!\u2019\u201d Rogers said. \u201cAnd I said, \u2018Well, I\u2019ve seen enough of it here that I\u2019d like to try.\u2019\u201d", "title": "\u2018Mister Rogers\u2019 Neighborhood\u2019 at 50: 5 Memorable Moments", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "The decision by the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum to rescind its human-rights award to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi is sad, and proper.\n\nFew people in modern times had evoked as much admiration and support as the courageous daughter of Myanmar\u2019s founding father when she defied the dictatorial junta in Myanmar through 15 years of house arrest. And few people have been as disappointing in their subsequent failure to act against, or even to acknowledge, the horrific persecution of the Rohingya Muslim minority in her country.\n\n\u201cWe had hoped that you \u2014 as someone we and many others have celebrated for your commitment to human dignity and universal human rights \u2014 would have done something to condemn and stop the military\u2019s brutal campaign and to express solidarity with the targeted Rohingya population,\u201d the Holocaust Museum wrote in an open letter explaining why it was taking back the Elie Wiesel Award it had presented five years earlier. Instead, the letter said, the ruling party Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi leads refused to cooperate with United Nations investigators, used \u201chateful rhetoric\u201d against the Rohingya and cracked down on journalists trying to report on the vicious suppression of the group.\n\nLike many other former admirers of Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi, the museum said it understood the pressures on her from a military establishment that still holds most of the country\u2019s power, and a Buddhist majority which regards the Rohingya as trespassers who have no historic place in Myanmar. Hundreds of thousands of Rohingya have fled to Bangladesh to escape a campaign of execution, rape and arson, which the United Nations and the United States have termed ethnic cleansing.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Never Again,\u2019 Holocaust Museum Tells Burmese Leader", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Hetzelein, 31, who used to teach in a vocational school where nine in 10 students had Turkish or Arabic backgrounds, knows about casual anti-Semitism. \u201cJew\u201d is a popular insult on some soccer fields in Berlin.\n\n\u201cIt has become harder to teach history,\u201d he said.\n\nTeaching history is a pillar of national identity in postwar Germany. That is why Sawsan Chebli, a Berlin state legislator with Palestinian heritage, recently came up with an idea that is radical even by the standards of a country that has dissected the horrors of its past like no other: make visits to Nazi concentration camps mandatory \u2014 for everyone.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis is about who we are as a country,\u201d she said in a recent conversation in Berlin. \u201cWe need to make our history relevant for everyone: Germans who no longer feel a connection to the past and immigrants who feel excluded from the present.\u201d\n\nMs. Chebli\u2019s proposal comes at a time when Germany is grappling with the creeping rise of two kinds of anti-Semitism and as the Jewish community, now numbering about 200,000, is once again nervous.\n\nNeo-Nazis have been emboldened by the arrival of Alternative for Germany, the first far-right party to break into Parliament since World War II. And there are concerns that the recent absorption of more than a million immigrants, many from the Middle East and many Muslim, has inadvertently created incubators of a different kind of anti-Semitism \u2014 one hiding behind the injustices of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict but often reverting to hateful old stereotypes, too.\n\nIt was the sight of Arab immigrants, including Palestinian-Germans like herself, burning an Israeli flag underneath the Brandenburg Gate in December while chanting \u201cDeath to Israel\u201d that moved Ms. Chebli to speak up.\n\nSince then, other disturbing stories have emerged in the German news media: an Afghan boy greeting his teacher with \u201cHeil Hitler\u201d and proclaiming that he, too, was Aryan. A group of Syrian refugees calling the Holocaust \u201ca Jewish conspiracy,\u201d explaining that they had learned that in school back home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe reaction in Berlin, where there are strict legal prohibitions of Holocaust denial and Nazi propaganda, has been swift. The government announced that it was appointing its first-ever anti-Semitism coordinator. Some in Chancellor Angela Merkel\u2019s conservative party have urged the immediate deportation of anti-Semitic Muslims.\n\nG\u00fcnter Morsch, the director of the Sachsenhausen memorial, says he does not think that is helpful. \u201cWe cannot allow this debate to create another form of racism,\u201d he said. \u201cWhat about the Germans who are anti-Semitic?\u201d\n\nNine in 10 anti-Semitic hate crimes reported in Berlin are committed by German citizens. And for all the seeming contradictions, there is a common denominator between Muslims who espouse anti-Semitic views and those on the far-right (who also hate Muslims), Mr. Morsch said.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAnti-Semitism correlates more closely with educational background than with ethnic background,\u201d he said, citing empirical studies.\n\nMs. Chebli says that visiting a concentration camp is no panacea, but that it can help. She visited one as a young woman. The experience changed her, she said.\n\n\u201cIt is a powerful way of keeping memory alive and giving meaning to our mantra of \u2018never again,\u2019 \u201d Ms. Chebli said. \u201cBut we need to get back to the essence of what this is about: It\u2019s about standing up for human rights and the rights of minorities \u2014 all minorities.\u201d\n\nMuslims, too\n\nDuring their visit to Sachsenhausen, the teenagers huddled around their guide in the vast triangular courtyard of the camp, its perimeter still dotted with watchtowers.\n\nSachsenhausen was no death camp, although tens of thousands of inmates are believed to have died here; those were built by the Nazis outside Germany. But it was the nerve center of two dozen major concentration camps run by the Nazis.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrom an inconspicuous office building in one corner of the camp, civil servants decided what kind of medical experiments would be conducted, how many executions would take place and how much Zyklon B gas would be delivered to the gas chambers in Auschwitz. \u201cDesk perpetrators,\u201d the guide, Mariana Aegerter, calls them.\n\n\u201cDoes anyone here know who was imprisoned here?\u201d she asked the class.\n\nNelson, a boy with shoulder-length hair, tentatively raised his hand. \u201cJews?\u201d\n\nThere were Jewish prisoners in Sachsenhausen. But unlike in the death camps, they were a minority. Of more than 200,000 inmates over the years, some 40,000 were Jewish. Many died here.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Nazi regime targeted many, Ms. Aegerter explained, like communists, clerics, homosexuals, Roma and the disabled. But also those considered \u201cantisocial\u201d: The homeless, the jobless, those on social welfare, and boys with long hair \u2014 Ms. Aegerter\u2019s eyes lingered on Nelson \u2014 or with too many girlfriends, or with a weakness for American music, like Jazz or swing.\n\nBy the time Sachsenhausen was liberated, she said, nine in 10 prisoners were foreigners, coming from 45 countries. There were Muslims, too.\n\n\u201cMuslims, too?\u201d Ferdous said later. \u201cI did not know that.\u201d\n\nBuilding bridges\n\nMs. Aegerter, a young historian, says her central aim during tours of the camp is to bring to life what is an empty space, to make students visualize life there, and ultimately to create a bridge between the visitor and the prisoner, between the present and the past.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cOur most powerful tool,\u201d she said, \u201cis identification.\u201d\n\nRecently, a young Syrian had asked a fellow guide, \u201cWhy do you turn your torture chambers into a museum?\u201d\n\nTo make sure we will never have torture chambers again, he had replied.\n\nThe boy had thought this over for a while. \u201cWe have torture chambers in Syria,\u201d he eventually said. \u201cMaybe, when the war is over, we should turn them into a museum, too.\u201d\n\nIt is not always easy. Once, a Palestinian schoolgirl asked Ms. Aegerter, \u201cDon\u2019t you think that what the Jews are doing with the Palestinians today is the same as what the Nazis did with the Jews?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNo, she had explained, but that did not mean one had to approve of everything the state of Israel was doing. The girl seemed unconvinced.\n\nMs. Chebli comes across this all the time, she said. \u201cI have Palestinians tell me: I had to leave my country because of the Holocaust and you want me to worry about anti-Semitism?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nShe recounted the lukewarm reaction of one young man to her concerns about growing anti-Semitism. Born and raised in Germany, he does not see himself as German because, he says, Germans do not see him as German.\n\n\u201cOf course, anti-Semitism is important,\u201d he had told her, \u201cbut what about the racism I experience every day?\u201d\n\nTo win over young Muslims for the fight against anti-Semitism, Ms. Chebli said, Germany has to fight Islamophobia, too.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s much easier for me to persuade a young Muslim of the relevance of the Holocaust if I acknowledge their own experience of discrimination and create that link,\u201d Ms. Chebli said.\n\nSometimes, creating a link with young Germans is just as tricky, Ms. Aegerter points out.\n\nNow 34, she grew up in the eastern state of Brandenburg in the 1990s. Swastikas were a common sight in her town: Scrawled on the inside of toilet cubicles. Graffitied onto walls. A boy in her class had tattooed one on his shin. It was only after she and some friends had complained that the boy had been asked to wear long trousers during sports lessons.\n\nThese days, Ms. Aegerter has teachers on the phone who share their concerns about far-right tendencies among their students.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne teacher told her before a class visit that he had planned the trip specifically because he worried about three boys drifting into neo-Nazi territory. But on the day, all three called in sick.\n\n\u201cSadly, that is no exception,\u201d Ms. Aegerter said.\n\nIn some cases, she said, it is the parents telling teachers they do not want their children to visit a concentration camp.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen students do come, it can be transformative, said Mr. Morsch, who has been director of the memorial for 25 years.\n\n\u201cIt would be na\u00efve to expect a two-hour tour to turn neo-Nazis into anti-fascists,\u201d Mr. Morsch said. \u201cBut give us a little time, and we can achieve a lot.\u201d\n\nHe recalled a recent group of students from a vocational school that had a persistent problem with neo-Nazi graffiti. They spent several weeks in Sachsenhausen renovating one part of the memorial \u2014 but also working in small groups, dissecting drawings and letters of prisoners and creating their own exhibition.\n\n\u201cAfter they spend some time with us, the problem went away,\u201d Mr. Morsch said.\n\nMr. Morsch still believes that camp visits should remain voluntary. He fears an obligation to come would take away from the learning experience.\n\nMr. Hetzelein disagrees. Whether schools or the law make the call, students rarely get a say. He grew up in Bavaria, the only German state where visiting a Nazi memorial is already required.\n\nAs a high school student, he went to Dachau, near Munich. Years later, he saw Auschwitz, the Nazi death camp in what is Poland today.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe cast-iron gates, the barbed wire and the sheer scale of it still haunt him. \u201cIt\u2019s not enough to read books about it,\u201d he said, \u201cyou need to feel it.\u201d\n\nA week after visiting Sachsenhausen, Mr. Hetzelein asked his students whether they thought their children should one day be made to visit a camp.\n\nOf 22 students, 21 agreed. Among them: Ferdous, Damian and Nelson.", "title": "\u2018Never Again\u2019: Fighting Hate in a Changing Germany With Tours of Nazi Camps", "authors": ["Katrin Bennhold"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "In an Op-Ed essay on Tuesday, the former Supreme Court justice John Paul Stevens called for the repeal of the Second Amendment. Readers debated it on social media and in the comments section of the piece. Below is a sample of some representative viewpoints, edited lightly for clarity. For more, read the essay and comments here.\n\nRetired Justice Stevens confirms the need for conservative voices on the Supreme Court. He would change the second most important amendment based solely on his emotional lack of logic, not on history. The Second Amendment was created to guarantee the eternal freedom of the citizenry from an overreaching federal government. The same argument applies today, as history proves that one of the first steps for authoritarian governments is to remove firearms from their future serfs. Then comes free speech and religion. The founding fathers were much more wise than Stevens. \u2014 Jon Galt, Tex.\n\nFrankly, in the wake of District of Columbia v. Heller, I don\u2019t see how any meaningful gun control could be enacted without a repeal of the Second Amendment. Heller elevated the right to own a gun to such a high level, it is right up there with freedom of speech and the right to due process. Even the most mild, seemingly sensible gun control measures can now be challenged on constitutional grounds, with a high probability of success. Heller created such an impregnable shield around the Second Amendment that tearing it out root and branch seems like the only way. \u2014 Dennis Fritz\n\nRight-wing talking points aside, the Second Amendment was never written to guarantee the eternal freedom of the citizenry from an overreaching federal government. It was written \u2014 long before we had a standing army \u2014 to guarantee a well-regulated militia to defend the country from being attacked. It is a relic we tolerate to maintain consensus and something resembling unity in this country. \u2014 Eric Beyer, New York", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Only the Extremists Want to Ban All Guns\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIt is one of the maddening paradoxes of New York City\u2019s recent political history that Mayor Bill de Blasio came to power with a righteous rage to ban horse-carriages in Central Park (a prohibition he ultimately failed to enact), but he has shown no fury \u2014 or any real sign of displeasure \u2014 over a much more dangerous and environmentally damaging means of vehicular tourism, sightseeing by helicopter.\n\nThe risks of the practice were clarified again on Sunday, when a chartered helicopter crashed into the East River, killing all five passengers onboard. To facilitate in-flight photography, the helicopter doors were removed, and the four men and one woman on board were strapped so tightly into their seats that they were given knives to extricate themselves in the event of an accident. On Friday, the Federal Aviation Administration finally put a stop to open-door helicopter flights. That they had been allowing passengers access to sharp objects in aircraft flying around the perimeter of major cities, when mothers of toddlers are still removing their Uggs at the airport, remains its own enduring mystery.\n\nIt has been decades now since advocates for a quieter and less polluted city have railed against the helicopter industry, which came into tragic disfavor most dramatically in 1977, when a rotor blade broke off a helicopter that had been ferrying people to Kennedy Airport from the roof of the Pan Am building in Manhattan, killing five people, one of them a woman walking down Madison Avenue. After a crash in the East River in 2011, various politicians and members of City Council called for a ban on tourist helicopters, pointing out that since 1983 there had been 28 crashes in New York with at least 19 fatalities. The ban never materialized. Instead, two years ago, the city moved to reduce the number of tourist helicopter flights around Manhattan by half \u2014 to 30,000 per year.\n\nThat\u2019s more than 80 flights every day \u2014 an astonishingly high number given that the mayor has mythologized himself as a national leader in climate change. Earlier this year, he announced that city pension funds would divest from companies profiting from the fossil-fuel business and that the city would sue five oil companies for reparations, essentially, connected to the damage fossil-fuels have inflicted on the city\u2019s ecosystem. It is as if a class-action suit were filed against Shake Shack for causing obesity while the plaintiffs were quietly deep frying slices of apple pie every morning at home for breakfast. The Airbus AS350, one of the most popular tourist helicopters \u2014 it was the model involved in Sunday\u2019s crash \u2014 produces 43 times the amount of carbon dioxide emissions per hour than the average car.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor several years now, the city has justified helicopter tourism as a vital means of revenue. Its Economic Development Corporation, which manages the downtown heliport from which tourist helicopters take off and land, has said that the economic impact to the city amounts to $50 million a year. But that figure comes directly from the Helicopter Tourism and Jobs Council, a lobbying group made up of five helicopter-tour providers. And it is a figure that takes into account the hotel and restaurant expenses that tourists accrue while they are in the city, as if to suggest that they were coming to New York solely for the purpose of flying around Manhattan in a helicopter for 15 minutes, rather than, say, to see \u201cHamilton\u2019\u2019 for the third time. Advocates of a tourist helicopter ban have long taken issue with the figure. As Adrian Benepe, the city\u2019s former parks commissioner put it to me, \u201cIt\u2019s just completely insane.\u201d\n\nThe city has also argued that the tourist-helicopter industry in New York supports more than 260 jobs, as if that were an impressive figure, outweighing the obvious downsides, in a strong economy with a local unemployment rate of just over 4 percent. The city has said that it will not make any decisions about the future of tourist helicopters until an investigation of Sunday\u2019s crash is complete. But in a more impressive show of judgment, Senator Chuck Schumer and various local congressional representatives called for a suspension of these flights at least until the causes of the accident could be understood.", "title": "\u2018Open-Door\u2019 Helicopters Are No Longer Flying Over New York City. What About Banning All Tourist Flights?", "authors": ["Ginia Bellafante", "Big City"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Deal said he supported the inclusion of the jet-fuel tax break provision that was removed from the bill, but would still sign it because of its reductions of personal and corporate tax rates.\n\n\u201cHe is a great friend to Delta,\u201d Mr. Bastian wrote. \u201cI know this action by the state legislature troubled him as it does all of us.\u201d\n\nDelta joined United Airlines and more than a dozen other companies in severing ties with the N.R.A. following the shooting at a high school in Parkland, Fla., last month. Mr. Bastian wrote that Delta made the move after hearing statements from N.R.A. representatives about the massacre, including accusations that the news media was gleefully profiting off the deaths of students.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Thursday, the families of several victims of the deadly attack at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., in 2012 sent a letter to Bass Pro Shops asking it to stop selling assault-style rifles. Earlier this week, Walmart, Dick\u2019s Sporting Goods and Kroger said they would limit firearms sales.\n\nDelta\u2019s group rate to the 2018 N.R.A. convention, which the airline said generated a total of 13 ticket sales, was interpreted by many consumers to be an implicit endorsement of the gun group. \u201cThat is not the case,\u201d Mr. Bastian wrote.\n\n\u201cOur people and our customers have a wide range of views on how to increase safety in our schools and public places, and we are not taking sides,\u201d Mr. Bastian wrote. \u201cOur objective in removing any implied affiliation with the N.R.A. was to remove Delta from this debate.\u201d\n\nHe stressed in the memo that Delta is \u201cproud and honored\u201d to be based in Atlanta and that the company supports the Second Amendment.\n\n\u201cI know it is not comfortable to be caught in a highly emotional debate, and many of you have received questions from customers,\u201d Mr. Bastian wrote to employees.\n\nHe added: \u201cOur decision was not made for economic gain and our values are not for sale.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Our Values Are Not for Sale,\u2019 Says Delta C.E.O. as Airline Considers Ending Divisive Discounts", "authors": ["Tiffany Hsu"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "It took giant robots fighting giant monsters to finally unseat \u201cBlack Panther\u201d at the top of the box office.\n\n\u201cPacific Rim Uprising,\u201d the bombastic sequel to Guillermo Del Toro\u2019s 2013 action film, grossed $28 million domestically in its first weekend according to comScore, which compiles box office data. The new film from Legendary and Universal, directed by Steven S. DeKnight (\u201cDaredevil\u201d), opened smaller than its predecessor domestically \u2014 that one made $37 million upon release \u2014 but thrived overseas, making $122.5 million internationally, with a huge reception in China. \u201cPacific Rim Uprising,\u201d shot mostly in China and Australia, cost $155 million to make, not including marketing.\n\n\u201cBlack Panther\u201d pulled in another $16 million, good for second place. The film has now made $630 million domestically; it will have to reach about $676 million in order to beat \u201cThe Avengers,\u201d from 2012, to become the biggest superhero film of all time, adjusting for inflation.", "title": "\u2018Pacific Rim Uprising\u2019 Dethrones \u2018Black Panther\u2019 at the Box Office", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 The aftermath of terrorist attacks in France has taken on a grim familiarity: political recriminations; the prosecutor of terrorism cases on the nightly news; the family photographs of the victims, their lives cut short.\n\nIn the wake of Friday\u2019s attack in the small southern town of Tr\u00e8bes, what altered this violent narrative were the extraordinary actions of an individual whose heroism gave people a way to come together, and its culmination in a supermarket, an ordinary place familiar to every Frenchman and woman \u2014 rural or urban, Christian or Muslim, young or old \u2014 so that everyone was able to imagine being there.\n\nThe hero was Lt. Col. Arnaud Beltrame of the French Gendarmerie who volunteered to exchange places with a hostage \u2014 a cashier \u2014 and was killed. He will be honored Wednesday in a ceremony at Les Invalides in Paris and eulogized by President Emmanuel Macron.\n\n\u201cOne tries to understand it, but one cannot get there,\u201d said Patricia Perderiset, 65, a retiree who had been shopping in the Tr\u00e8bes market, the Super U, for Easter eggs for her grandchildren.", "title": "\u2018Perfect Sense of Control\u2019: Tributes Flow to French Officer in Terror Attack", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "That Mr. Trump left the impression of a positive endorsement of Mr. Xi was \u201cunexpected\u201d and \u201cmatters for China,\u201d said Zhang Baohui, a professor of international relations at Lingnan University in Hong Kong.\n\n\u201cChinese leaders care very little whether Trump is seen negatively outside China,\u201d he said. \u201cThe U.S. still represents the reference point for China.\u201d\n\nThe Trump comments would be especially welcome because Mr. Xi\u2019s step toward dictatorship was a sensitive issue inside China, and one about which public discussion has been barred.\n\nMr. Trump, an admirer of strongman leadership, has prided himself on his good personal relationship with Mr. Xi, even as Washington differs with Beijing on major issues from trade to North Korea. Mr. Xi accorded Mr. Trump a lavish state visit to Beijing last November that the president has enthused about ever since.\n\nLeaders of democracies, including America\u2019s allies in Europe and Asia, have abstained from criticizing Mr. Xi, concerned in part by retaliatory economic reprisals. Authoritarian governments from Russia to Turkey have remained quiet, offering no explicit support but apparently confident of the growing acceptance of one-man rule, analysts said.\n\nChina\u2019s state-run media has given minimal coverage to the Communist Party leadership\u2019s decision to change the Constitution. The tightening of Mr. Xi\u2019s power is considered so delicate that censors have squashed online commentary of almost any kind.\n\nSimilarly, Mr. Trump\u2019s remarks were not carried on Chinese television, online or in the state-run newspapers. When CNN, which is restricted in the venues it can broadcast in China, reported Mr. Trump\u2019s comments on Sunday, censors turned television screens blank.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhat Trump said should give Xi a modest boost,\u201d said Minxin Pei, a China expert at Claremont McKenna College in California.\n\nOrdinary Chinese who support Mr. Xi are likely to latch on to Mr. Trump\u2019s validation, even though Mr. Trump is viewed by many Western observers as an embattled president, said Shen Dingli, director of the Center for American Studies at Fudan University.\n\n\u201cChinese people who really support this change will say: \u2018Look, we are great. The superpower has endorsed our way,\u2019\u201d Mr. Shen said.\n\nPhoto\n\nA nearly two-week long meeting of the national legislature, the National People\u2019s Congress, which opens in Beijing on Monday, is scheduled to formalize the changes to the Constitution and abolish the two-term limit on the presidency.\n\nAt a news conference Sunday to highlight the main events at the Congress, the spokesman for the legislature, Zhang Yesui, played down Mr. Xi\u2019s decision to scrap the two-term rule for the presidency.\n\nAsked by a Western reporter whether the amendment scrapping two term limits meant Mr. Xi would be leader for life, Mr. Zhang ducked the question.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe changes were just intended to bring the presidency in line with two other positions Mr. Xi holds: general secretary of the Communist Party and general secretary and chairman of the commission that oversees the military, Mr. Zhang said. Neither post has a term limit.\n\nThe new arrangement \u201cwill help to strengthen and improve the national leadership system,\u201d Mr. Zhang said.\n\nThe failure of Western leaders to speak out against Mr. Xi\u2019s plans for limitless power was in step with a growing acceptance among democracies of one-man rule in many countries, said Fran\u00e7ois Godement, director of the Asia and China program at the European Council on Foreign Relations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cCriticism has been confined to human rights \u2018excesses,\u2019\u201d and even those were limited, Mr. Godement said. \u201cThe mode of government is no longer addressed.\u201d\n\nDuring a visit in January, President Emmanuel Macron of France warned China that it should not create \u201cvassal states\u201d and should not act as a hegemonic power as it expanded its influence across Asia and Europe with its infrastructure program, the Belt and Road Initiative.\n\nMr. Macron was careful to limit his comments to \u201ceconomic rules of the road\u201d and not trespass into the question of governance inside China, Mr. Godement said.\n\nIn Japan, whose adversarial relations with China are growing slightly warmer, the government has so far not commented.\n\nIn Australia, where a national debate is roiling over China\u2019s meddling in the country\u2019s domestic affairs, the government has also stayed quiet.\n\nThe Australian prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, was fearful of economic consequences that would rattle its vital trade relationship with China if it spoke out, China experts said.\n\n\u201cAustralia is silent because America, the self-styled leader of the \u2018free world\u2019 after World War II, has abdicated that role under Trump,\u201d said Feng Zhang, a fellow at the Department of International Relations at the Australian National University. \u201cAustralia\u2019s accusation of Chinese interference in its domestic affairs has elicited a chilly response from Beijing. It doesn\u2019t want to make a bad situation worse.\u201d\n\nIn the United States, political observers lamented Mr. Trump\u2019s latest off-the-cuff remark.\n\n\u201cDonald Trump has the strange habit of being completely transparent about his deepest desires, despite his long track record of false or misleading statements,\u201d said Yascha Mounk, the author of \u201cThe People Vs. Democracy: Why Our Freedom Is in Danger and How to Save It,\u201d and a political scientist. \u201cWe shouldn\u2019t take his joke as a declaration of intent, but we should absolutely take it as evidence that he deeply admires dictators like Xi Jinping and would be tempted to emulate some of their repressive policies if he could.\u201d\n\nIn his remarks, Mr. Trump may have inadvertently hearkened to the emperors who ruled China until 1912.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201c\u2018President for life,\u2019 is of course, very much in the imperial tradition and this may give the notion a certain historical resonance in China,\u201d said Orville Schell, director of the Center on U.S.-China Relations at the Asia Society in New York. \u201cIn the U.S., however, the idea is an utter anathema to everything the Founding Fathers believed and the carefully crafted Constitution they bequeathed us, which was explicitly designed to limit just such a drift towards monarchy or autocracy.\u201d", "title": "\u2018President for Life\u2019? Trump\u2019s Remarks About Xi Find Fans in China", "authors": ["Jane Perlez"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "She said, \u201cI would urge our communities to be vigilant but not frightened,\u2019\u2019 adding, \u201cWe are stronger when we stand together as one and will not be divided. #WeStandTogether.\u201d\n\nSajid Javid, a member of Parliament and secretary of state for housing, said on Twitter in response to the letters: \u201cDisturbing reports of Islamophobic letters in the #Midlands - let me be clear, British Muslims should be able to live without fear of abuse and attack and we will do everything in our power to tackle those who spread hate.\u201d\n\nThe letters lash out at Britain and countries elsewhere in Europe with migrant, minority and Muslim populations.\n\n\u201cAre you a sheep like the vast majority of the population? Sheep follow orders and are easily led,\u201d it says. \u201cThey are allowing the white-majority nations of Europe and North America to become overrun by those who would like nothing more than to do us harm and to turn our democracies into sharia-led police states.\u201d\n\nMr. Ahmed, the councilor, said in an interview that his letter arrived on Friday after being posted on Feb. 7 from Yorkshire. \u201cAll it had was the number of the property, the name of the road and the ZIP code.\u201d\n\nThe residents of the area where he lives in Bradford, a historic town in northern England, are of predominantly Pakistani and Muslim heritage, he said by phone, adding, \u201cMy guess is that the letter was meant to terrorize and cause discord within the various communities.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut we tend to rise above that in Bradford; we are very, very proud,\u201d he said. \u201cI came to this country when I was 12 years old from Pakistan. I\u2019ve seen far worse.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Punish a Muslim Day\u2019 Letters Rattle U.K. Communities", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 The 20th Century Fox thriller \u201cRed Sparrow\u201d flew low at the domestic box office over the weekend, collecting an estimated $17 million and becoming the third lackluster opening in a row for Jennifer Lawrence.\n\n\u201cRed Sparrow,\u201d starring Ms. Lawrence as a Russian intelligence operative who specializes in sexual manipulation, ran into stronger-than-expected competition from \u201cBlack Panther,\u201d which remained a huge No. 1 at North American theaters in its third weekend. \u201cBlack Panther\u201d (Disney) collected about $65.7 million, for a new domestic total of $501.1 million; worldwide ticket sales now stand at roughly $900 million.\n\nBut the R-rated \u201cRed Sparrow,\u201d which cost Fox at least $100 million to make and market, divided critics and received a lukewarm B grade from ticket buyers in CinemaScore exit polls. \u201cRed Sparrow\u201d had the hardest time attracting young adults; 79 percent of its audience was over the age of 25, according to Fox.\n\nMs. Lawrence, one of Hollywood\u2019s most popular and highest-paid actresses, was last seen in Darren Aronofsky\u2019s \u201cMother!\u201d Released in the fall by Paramount, \u201cMother!\u201d failed in wide release. Before that, Ms. Lawrence co-starred with Chris Pratt in Sony\u2019s expensive \u201cPassengers,\u201d which arrived to a wobbly $14.9 million in 2016. Sony ultimately pushed \u201cPassengers\u201d to about $100 million in domestic ticket sales.", "title": "\u2018Red Sparrow\u2019 Is No Box Office Match for \u2018Black Panther\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "So, Dr. Ripple and Christopher Wolf, a postdoctoral researcher in his lab, analyzed hundreds of potential rewilding sites from a database of protected areas around the planet where large carnivores have disappeared. They focused on big places with small human footprints, available prey and buffer zones where animals may traverse safely. Their analysis revealed 130 potential sites suitable for rewilding and an additional 150 spots with little human activity to consider preserving. Their results, published Wednesday in Royal Society Open Science, suggest that with proper attention and care to ensure these carnivores\u2019 survival, rewilding programs could restore lost ecosystems worldwide.\n\nBut it won\u2019t be as simple as finding a dot on a map.\n\nTheir paper mentions just two specific reintroduction sites where rewilding would likely work out as planned. They suggest it could be possible to put gray wolves in Olympic National Park in Washington and sending endangered red wolves, which once roamed the southeast, into Everglades National Park. These places have space for reproduction and development, prey and humans who may tolerate them.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nBut for many other locations, especially in developing countries, people still hunt some animals for bushmeat or body parts used in traditional medicine. Fences limit range. Humans compete for prey or kill carnivores that threaten their lives, agriculture or livestock. Not all corridors are safe. These places may better serve as guideposts, directing researchers to spots for further investigations into what\u2019s really happening on the ground.\n\nThe biggest hurdle will be finding humans willing to live alongside and support efforts to keep big carnivores around, said Thomas Newsome, an ecologist studying human-predator interactions at the University of Sydney who was not involved in this study. That would mean supporting efforts to stop the activities that killed many large carnivores in the first place. And even for gray wolves, that hasn\u2019t been easy: Some people don\u2019t want them, and others still hunt wolves outside park boundaries in Yellowstone and in Alaska.\n\nPerhaps the solution is rethinking what it means to be humans in a natural world, said Layla AbdelRahim, an anthropologist who has studied human understanding of wilderness. We must recognize our role as partners with the environment, rather than dominators, to maintain functioning ecosystems, she said.\n\nRewilding will be a significant trend in preserving ecosystems where all species matter, said Dr. Ripple. \u201cHumans are just figuring out what the interconnectedness in nature is all about.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Rewilding\u2019 Missing Carnivores May Help Restore Some Landscapes", "authors": ["Joanna Klein"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "With one day of delayed viewing factored in, the audience for the \u201cRoseanne\u201d premiere is now up to 21.9 million viewers. Among adults under 50, the rating went up 22 percent, to a 6.2 rating. Those numbers will continue to creep upward as more people catch up on their DVRs or through on-demand viewing.\n\nThe current \u201cRoseanne\u201d season, technically the show\u2019s 10th, comprises nine episodes, seven of which have yet to air. The next season of \u201cRoseanne,\u201d which will be shown as part of ABC\u2019s 2018-19 lineup, is currently planned at 13 episodes.\n\n\u201cRoseanne,\u201d the first run of which was part of the ABC schedule from 1988 to 1997, has thrust itself into the middle of the national conversation. Ms. Barr, in real life and on the show, is a vocal supporter of President Trump, who called to congratulate her on the ratings win and mentioned her success during a rally in Ohio on Thursday. Fox News pundits have praised the show for representing people who they say are not usually major characters on network television shows.\n\nAlthough \u201cRoseanne\u201d has won generally favorable reviews from critics, some on the left have expressed feeling conflicted over supporting the show.\n\nIts early success has been a big win for ABC. \u201cRoseanne\u201d is part of a broader strategy hatched by the network\u2019s executives soon after Mr. Trump\u2019s surprise victory in 2016. The TV industry will keep a close eye on the performance of \u201cRoseanne\u201d as it moves deeper into the season: Will there be a drop in viewership, or will all the recent media attention keep the ratings relatively high? Trump\u2019s victory meant for the network\u2019s future.\n\n\u201cWe looked at each other and said, \u2018There\u2019s a lot about this country we need to learn a lot more about, here on the coasts,\u2019\u201d Ben Sherwood, the president of Disney and ABC\u2019s television group, said in an interview.\n\nThey began asking themselves which audiences they were not serving well and what they could do to better live up to the company name \u2014 the American Broadcasting Company. By the meeting\u2019s end, they had in place the beginnings of a revised strategy that led the network to reboot a past hit centered on a struggling Midwestern family, a show that had a chance to appeal to the voters who had helped put Mr. Trump in the White House.\n\nOn Tuesday night, the strategy proved more successful than the executives had hoped: \u201cRoseanne\u201d premiered to the highest ratings for any network sitcom in almost four years.", "title": "\u2018Roseanne\u2019 Reboot Sprang From ABC\u2019s Heartland Strategy After Trump\u2019s Victory", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "At least for a night, America said it really did want more \u201cRoseanne.\u201d\n\nThe revival of the vintage ABC sitcom got off to an enormously strong start on Tuesday night, drawing 18.2 million viewers and a 5.1 rating among adults under 50, according to Nielsen. The \u201cRoseanne\u201d numbers rank as the highest total of any comedy on the broadcast networks since the 2014 season premiere of \u201cThe Big Bang Theory.\u201d\n\nFor comparison\u2019s sake, NBC\u2019s reboot of \u201cWill & Grace\u201d in September drew a little over 10 million viewers and a 3.0 rating among 18- to 49-year-olds. Earlier this month, ABC\u2019s revival of \u201cAmerican Idol\u201d reached an audience of 10.3 million viewers and scored a 2.3 rating in the prize demographic. In nine seasons of this show, we\u2019ve been brought to our knees over and over by the stunning, innovative creations of much lesser queens than those assembled on this runway. Are these queens more substance than style? Have we all now arrived at the anniversary after which we cheat and let ourselves go? Is this feminism?\n\nThe Vixen\u2019s was, again inexplicably, declared the winning team, and in a shocking and senseless upset, she was named the singular winner of the maxi-challenge. I have to hand it to her: When she\u2019s angry, she is keen and shrewd. And though her talent be but little, for some reason, RuPaul thinks she is fierce.\n\nEureka was scolded for her utter failure of a lip sync in the maxi challenge, and she wept as she confessed her fear and anxiety about her ability to make the most of her comeback opportunity. Mama Ru, in one of her Drag Oprah moments, said, \u201cEureka, I wish there was a pill to make you believe in yourself as much as we do,\u201d as she sentenced both her and Kalorie to lip sync for their lives to \u201cBest of My Love,\u201d by the underrated Emotions.\n\nWhatever pill Eureka took before pulling out her paroxysmic lip sync, she should do an actual ad for it \u2014 unless the vertigo that seems to keep knocking her off her feet is its side effect \u2014 because it reuptook her to safety. Kalorie\u2019s lip sync was sweet, but comparatively empty, and she sashayed away to an unhappy ending.\n\nConflama may have financed Andy Cohen\u2019s West Village condo expansion, but it is not what we love about this show. What we love about this show is its flashes of defiant beauty, its bruises of deep courage and self-discovery, and Ross Mathews. We don\u2019t want to watch the kind of infighting among allies that infects our social media feeds, however telegenic the fighters. We don\u2019t want the next drag superstar to be an angry, vengeful villain. We want the next drag superstar to be someone who can give us the best of their love. And it is frightening to think that they may not be out there.\n\nBut take it from a real-life Tinderella: Sometimes, to find out if one of your matches is that person, you have to pretend that the past was a dream, accept the apologies of the five o\u2019clock shadows that have offended you, and give them your hands.\n\nSee you next week.", "title": "\u2018RuPaul\u2019s Drag Race\u2019 Season 10, Episode 2: Conflama Is Abuse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "She added: \u201cLook, I\u2019m always down to clown but this was sneaky, even for me. I looked into each ambulance and could see no survivors. Instead, each vehicle carried at least one long yellow zippered bag.\n\nAirline officials said they were investigating what caused the plane to miss the runway.\n\nUS-Bangla Airlines said the pilot was experienced, with 5,000 hours of flying, and that there had been no evidence of a mechanical failure.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAn airline executive said there might have been \u201csome confusion\u201d between the pilot and the airport control tower. \u201cHowever, this is a matter of investigation. The probe committee will look into it,\u201d said the executive, Mohammad Kamrul Islam, general manager of marketing support for the airline.\n\nAn audio recording was posted on YouTube on Monday night that Mr. Islam said \u201cseemed to be the last conversation between the pilot and the control tower.\u201d In the recording, the pilot requests to land but the control tower tells the pilot that there is traffic on the runway. Mr. Islam added that he could not confirm if the audio recording was authentic and that the \u201cblack box will unveil everything.\u201d\n\nAviation experts said the recording indicated that the pilot was disoriented, possibly by unclear directions from the control tower. He seemed to be heading for the wrong runway when the control tower canceled his permission to land. The pilot then tried to go around to the right runway but was flying too low and plowed into the ground.\n\nThe crash shut down the airport, with all operations grinding to a halt.\n\nThis airport can get quite busy: It is the entry point for hundreds of thousands of tourists each year. Many come to trek in the Himalayas, and on Monday afternoon, several large jetliners were sitting on the tarmac, about to take off, while arriving planes circled pending permission to land.\n\nSome were short on fuel as they waited. The airport reopened about two and a half hours later.\n\nThe posted schedule of the crashed plane identified it as Flight 211, a Bombardier Dash 8 from Dhaka, scheduled to land at 2:15 p.m., around the actual time of the crash. The plane, a twin-engine turboprop, can carry as many as 78 passengers.", "title": "\u2018Save Me, Save Me\u2019: Scores Dead in Plane Crash in Nepal", "authors": ["Jeffrey Gettleman"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSay hello to this little reunion. The 35th anniversary of Brian De Palma\u2019s \u201cScarface\u201d will be celebrated at the Tribeca Film Festival this year, organizers announced Monday. The film will play April 19, followed by a conversation with Mr. De Palma and the stars Al Pacino and Michelle Pfeiffer.\n\nAnd on April 26, the festival will hold a 25th anniversary screening of the Holocaust drama \u201cSchindler\u2019s List,\u201d including a conversation with its director, Steven Spielberg, and the actors Liam Neeson, Ben Kingsley and Embeth Davidtz.\n\nThe festival also announced its Tribeca Talks series, conversations with artists from film, television and music. Participants this year include Robert De Niro (a founder of the festival, being interviewed by Bradley Cooper), John Legend, Sarah Jessica Parker, Spike Lee and Alec Baldwin.\n\nThis year\u2019s edition runs April 18-29. For more information, go to tribecafilm.com.", "title": "\u2018Scarface\u2019 Cast Will Reunite at the Tribeca Film Festival", "authors": ["Mekado Murphy"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWith this tripwire, this changes things,\u201d Christopher H. Combs, the special agent in charge of the F.B.I.\u2019s San Antonio office, told reporters on Monday. \u201cIt\u2019s more sophisticated.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cWe don\u2019t know why the bomber is doing this. We don\u2019t know his reasons.\u201d\n\nThe alarm seemed to ease on Monday near the site of the fourth and latest explosion, as the authorities slowly opened up parts of the upscale neighborhood called Travis Country. Residents had been urged to stay indoors for hours while the area was cleared.\n\nAnd yet, there and elsewhere around Austin, people seemed to keep their eyes trained downward \u2014 looking for suspicious bags and backpacks, packages and strands of wire across sidewalks. Residents were divided over how to change their routines, or not, while the explosions were being investigated. Some resolved not to upend their lives, and to continue to order packages and to go on neighborhood walks, while others proceeded warily.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to be cautious, but I don\u2019t think you can close yourself off from life,\u201d said Charlie Cook, 73, who lives in Travis Country a few blocks from where the bomb exploded on Sunday. \u201cI don\u2019t think we\u2019ll change our lifestyle.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOther residents said they were avoiding opening packages or even answering their front doors out of fear. \u201cToday I ran to the window to make sure it was my postman dropping off the package on the doorstep before I opened the door,\u201d posted one Twitter user, Anton Queer Proseer. Another Twitter user, Lavente McCreary, posted the message, \u201cLiterally checking the shipping numbers of all my packages right now to make sure we know when they\u2019re coming. Stay safe, Austin.\u201d\n\nFor a city of 947,000 that prides itself on a hipster eccentricity and an irreverent live music scene that spawned the local motto, \u201cKeep Austin Weird,\u201d the attacks and their aftermath have been unsettling. The new, subtle fear in places far from the scene of the explosions was that nowhere was safe. The speculation that the first three attacks were hate crimes because two of the victims were black and one was Hispanic seemed to fade as word spread that the two victims on Sunday were white.\n\n\u201cThis is shocking and horrific and I share the same anxiety and anxiousness that the whole community feels,\u201d Mayor Steve Adler said. \u201cWe want this stopped.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore than 500 federal agents are assisting in the investigation, in addition to bomb technicians from the Houston and San Antonio police departments. As of Sunday, investigators were pursuing more than 435 leads that had been called in and had interviewed more than 230 people. Even before the fourth bombing, residents have been on the lookout: Austin officers have responded to 735 calls of suspicious packages since March 12, the day of two back-to-back bombings.\n\nOfficials said that at about 8:30 p.m. on Sunday, two unidentified men, aged 22 and 23, appeared to have tripped a wire in the 4800 block of Dawn Song Drive in the Travis Country neighborhood. They were either on the sidewalk or on a grassy area between the street and a fence when a device attached to the wire detonated. Both men suffered significant injuries but were in stable condition, the authorities said.\n\nThe Austin police chief, Brian Manley, said the use of the tripwire suggested \u201ca higher level of sophistication than maybe we initially thought, based on them changing their methods to a more difficult device.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOfficials said there were similarities between all four bombs, but they declined to discuss the specifics. They did say that the first three devices were made from commercially available materials and required a level of skill on the part of the bombmaker to avoid an accidental explosion while handling the devices.\n\n\u201cWe have a high degree of confidence that the same individual built all these devices,\u201d said Fred Milanowski, special agent in charge of the Houston office of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, which has made the Austin case its top national priority.\n\nLaw enforcement officials said they have had no contact with anyone tied to the bombings, despite taking the unusual step on Sunday of publicly asking the suspect or suspects to contact the authorities so they could learn more about the message behind the attacks, hours before the latest explosion.\n\nPhoto\n\nAsked whether the latest bombing was the suspect\u2019s response to that plea, Chief Manley added, \u201cWe won\u2019t know that until we have an opportunity to talk to the suspect or the suspects, whether or not that was a motive behind this.\u201d On Monday, law enforcement officials continued to ask for the suspect to contact them.\n\nAt least one expert on serial bombers and mass murderers cautioned that the suspect may have no motive beyond causing chaos.\n\n\u201cI call them vanity bombers,\u201d said Michael Rustigan, a professor emeritus of criminal justice at San Jose State University and an expert on the Unabomber case, in which a former mathematics professor dispatched a string of bombs that killed three people and injured 23 others between 1978 and 1995. \u201cHe\u2019s looking for attention. He\u2019s looking for fame. The bomber might not have a message. The bomber might not be ideological. His motive might be simply to make Austin cringe.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat is known about the construction of the bombs so far appears to be providing few concrete clues, though analysts said the police are most likely analyzing remnants of the devices for fingerprints, DNA or other clues \u2014 in addition to scrutinizing any surveillance camera footage.\n\nImprovised explosive devices such as those involved in the attacks can vary widely in size, lethality, the type of construction materials used, and means of initiation. The basics of how to make simple I.E.D.s have been in print for decades, with \u201cThe Anarchist Cookbook\u201d by William Powell being one of the first to make that information publicly available in 1971.\n\nIn recent years, similar books have been joined online with advanced bomb-making schematics and recipes for homemade explosives developed and refined by insurgents all over the world \u2014 though the bombs described by the police in Austin are not necessarily very advanced or powerful, especially when compared with the devices faced by American troops in places like Iraq, Syria and Afghanistan.\n\nThe four neighborhoods where the explosions have occurred are varied economic and demographic slices of Austin. The first three bomb scenes were in largely working- and middle-class sections of northeast and east Austin, with sizable black, Hispanic and Asian populations. Hammocks and baby swings hang from tree branches on front lawns near Haverford Drive, the site of the first bombing on March 2. The explosion on Sunday took place in a gated and sprawling planned community that is largely white. It is a hilly and wooded area near a patchwork of busy highways and parkways, a favorite among hikers, joggers and walkers.\n\nRichard Herrington, 75, a retired pharmacist who lives about a half-mile from the blast site in Travis Country, said he and his family had gone hiking Sunday afternoon near the street where the explosive went off later that evening.\n\n\u201cMy oldest granddaughter, age 7, said, \u2018Grandpa, I want to walk on the street where there\u2019s the most shade,\u2019\u201d Mr. Herrington recalled. \u201cWe could have very easily walked down that street because there is shade. We could have been on that street and maybe the tripwire was there already, I don\u2019t know.\u201d\n\nAt about 8:30 p.m. on Sunday, Mr. Herrington said, he and his wife were watching an N.C.A.A. basketball game. \u201cIf you\u2019ve been in the military and you hear a mortar round go off, it has a thump,\u201d said Mr. Herrington, who served in the Army. \u201cAnd that\u2019s how I knew it was a bomb, because it was a distinctive thump like that. I\u2019m anxious for our community because we don\u2019t know when and where it\u2019s going to happen again. I feel like it will happen again.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Serial Bomber\u2019 Is Suspected in Explosions That Have Put Austin on Edge", "authors": ["Manny Fernandez", "Caitlin Dickerson", "Dave Montgomery"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHe knew everything,\u201d Mr. Lineham wrote. \u201cIt may sound unbelievable, but he was the most reality-informed person I have ever met.\u201d\n\nBelow is a collection of responses to the article \u2014 many of which appeared as comments on the original article, and some of which were emailed to Stephen and published with the writers\u2019 permission. Some have been edited for length and clarity.\n\n\u2018I strongly recommend one or two years as a monk\u2019\n\nBrian Hogan, from Fontainebleau, France, was a Trappist novice at Gethsemani Abbey near Bardstown, Ky., from 1957 to 1959. He said he was attracted to life in the monastery after seeing how the monks were the exact opposite of the big city parish priests he was raised with.\n\n\n\nI was a Trappist novice under Thomas Merton at Gethsemani Abbey (Mepkin\u2019s mother-house) for two years after high school graduation in the late 1950s. The Trappists have changed since those days, when Trappist-Cistercian life was a lot tougher: constant obligatory silence; the use of sign language; sleeping on a straw-filled mattress in a small cell within a common dormitory; one full meal per day, and no meat, fish or eggs; no recreation or vacation; mail written to and received from family four times per year, and one annual family visit of three days; up at 2:15 a.m., in church at 2:30 a.m. to chant matins and lauds until 4:00 a.m.; a 7 p.m. bedtime; never going outside the monastic grounds. \u2026\n\nAnd yet, adjusting to life outside the monastery after I left was infinitely harder than adjusting to the monastery itself. I learned that in at least one Asian country, it is expected that a young man will become a monk for a year or two. I strongly recommend one or two years as a monk.", "title": "\u2018Silent, Yes, but Never Withdrawn\u2019: Readers Respond to a Dwindling Catholic Monastery", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "A Republican candidate for the Maine State House who disparaged two teenage survivors of the school shooting in Parkland, Fla., dropped out of the race after drawing heavy criticism and challengers from both political parties.\n\nThe candidate, Leslie Gibson, had been running to represent District 57 in central Maine unopposed, according to The Sun Journal, which first reported the comments he made on Twitter. Mr. Gibson called one Florida student, Emma Gonz\u00e1lez, a \u201cskinhead lesbian,\u201d and another, David Hogg, a \u201cmoron\u201d and a \u201cbaldfaced liar.\u201d\n\nSome state lawmakers, including at least two Republicans, were quick to condemn Mr. Gibson after his comments surfaced. Mr. Hogg issued a call on Twitter for someone to run against Mr. Gibson. But he said that he was planning to watch the coverage closely.\n\nImage Reema Samaha was 18 when she was killed in the 2007 shooting at Virginia Tech University.\n\n33 killed, 17 injured\n\nJoseph T. Samaha | Virginia Tech University\n\nReema Samaha was 18 in the spring of 2007. She was a freshman at Virginia Tech University, where she planned to major in urban planning and minor in French. She was one of 33 people killed by Seung-Hui Cho in what is still the deadliest school shooting in modern American history.\n\nHer father, Joseph, says that every shooting since rewinds the videotapes, bringing him back to 2007. Mr. Samaha, who is the president of the Virginia Tech Victims Family Outreach Foundation, says that the Stoneman Douglas students have followed a trajectory that is familiar to him.\n\nMr. Samaha favors \u201cpractical and actionable solutions.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m looking for common ground, what we can work on together without yelling and screaming at each other,\u201d he said. \u201cI personally focus on getting to the root of what the issue is and trying to resolve the problem in a nonpartisan fashion.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Something About Parkland Has Been Different\u2019: Survivors From 20 Years of Mass Shootings Speak", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDavid Chase will bring \u201cThe Sopranos\u201d to movie theaters, Warner Bros. announced on Thursday.\n\nBut don\u2019t expect him to explain the contentious ending to the celebrated mafia series he created, which ran on HBO from 1999 to 2007. Mr. Chase is going back to the beginning \u2014 way back, to the Newark riots in 1967, when Tony Soprano was still a boy.\n\n\u201cDavid is a masterful storyteller and we, along with our colleagues at HBO, are thrilled that he has decided to revisit, and enlarge, the Soprano universe in a feature film,\u201d Toby Emmerich, chairman of the Warner Bros. Picture Group, said in a statement.\n\n\u201cThe Many Saints of Newark,\u201d as Mr. Chase\u2019s prequel is tentatively called, will include some well-known characters from \u201cThe Sopranos,\u201d according to the studio. Which ones? A spokeswoman wouldn\u2019t elaborate.\n\nFans of the TV series may remember that Tony Soprano, its main character, was born in 1959. The prequel, which still has no cast, director or estimated release date, carries this official description: \u201cA prequel to \u2018The Sopranos\u2019 set in the era of the Newark riots in the \u201960s, when the African-Americans and the Italians of Newark were at each other\u2019s throats, and when among the gangsters of each group, it became especially lethal.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Chase, 72, will not direct the prequel, which will be made through Warner\u2019s smaller New Line unit, although he will help select a director. Mr. Chase will produce the film and has already written the screenplay with Lawrence Konner, whose credits include \u201cThe Sopranos\u201d and \u201cBoardwalk Empire.\u201d New Line was also responsible for bringing the HBO series \u201cSex and the City\u201d to theaters with two films that collected a combined $704 million at the worldwide box office.\n\nMr. Chase\u2019s last film, the 2012 coming-of-age story \u201cNot Fade Away,\u201d received strong reviews but fizzled at the box office, collecting less than $1 million in limited release in the United States.", "title": "\u2018Sopranos\u2019 Creator Will Bring a Prequel to Movie Screens", "authors": ["Brooks Barnes"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "The Jason Bateman-Rachel McAdams comedy \u201cGame Night\u201d has recently scored a win at the box office, earning more than $85 million worldwide so far, and now the trailer has been released for another starry, game-based farce: \u201cTag.\u201d\n\nYes, it\u2019s inspired by the childhood chase, but in this case, it\u2019s based on the true story of a group of friends who continued the game for decades into adulthood. The cast includes Jeremy Renner (who\u2019s not known for comedy, especially after his appearance in the Will Ferrell-Amy Poehler flop \u201cThe House\u201d), Ed Helms, Jon Hamm, Hannibal Buress, Isla Fisher, Rashida Jones and Leslie Bibb.", "title": "\u2018Tag\u2019 Trailer Pits Jeremy Renner Against Jon Hamm and Friends", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cBehind closed doors, we call it testilying,\u201d a New York City police officer, Pedro Serrano, said in a recent interview, echoing a word that officers coined at least 25 years ago. \u201cYou take the truth and stretch it out a little bit.\u201d\n\nAn investigation by The New York Times has found that on more than 25 occasions since January 2015, judges or prosecutors determined that a key aspect of a New York City police officer\u2019s testimony was probably untrue. The Times identified these cases \u2014 many of which are sealed \u2014 through interviews with lawyers, police officers and current and former judges.\n\n[ALSO READ: He Excelled as a Detective, Until Prosecutors Stopped Believing Him]\n\nIn these cases, officers have lied about the whereabouts of guns, putting them in suspects\u2019 hands or waistbands when they were actually hidden out of sight. They have barged into apartments and conducted searches, only to testify otherwise later. Under oath, they have given firsthand accounts of crimes or arrests that they did not in fact witness. They have falsely claimed to have watched drug deals happen, only to later recant or be shown to have lied.\n\nNo detail, seemingly, is too minor to embellish. \u201cClenched fists\u201d is how one Brooklyn officer described the hands of a man he claimed had angrily approached him and started screaming and yelling \u2014 an encounter that prosecutors later determined never occurred. Another officer, during a Bronx trial, accused a driver of recklessly crossing the double-yellow line \u2014 on a stretch of road that had no double-yellow line.\n\nIn many instances, the motive for lying was readily apparent: to skirt constitutional restrictions against unreasonable searches and stops. In other cases, the falsehoods appear aimed at convicting people \u2014 who may or may not have committed a crime \u2014 with trumped-up evidence.\n\nIn still others, the motive is not easy to discern. In October 2016, for example, a plainclothes Brooklyn officer gave a grand jury a first-person account of a gun arrest. Putting herself in the center of the action, the officer, Dornezia Agard, testified that as she approached a man to confront him for littering, he suddenly crouched behind a van, pulled from his waistband a dark object \u2014 later identified as a gun \u2014 and threw it on the ground.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cP.O. Agard testified that she heard a hard metal object hit the ground,\u201d according to a letter the Brooklyn district attorney\u2019s office wrote summarizing her testimony.\n\nBut prosecutors lost faith in her account in July 2017, after learning from other officers that she was not among the first officers on the scene. Officer Agard had arrived later as backup, according to the letter, which noted that the gun charges against the man were later dismissed. The prosecutors did not address why Officer Agard claimed to be a witness, or why the other officers present seem to have allowed her to process the arrest.\n\nPolice lying raises the likelihood that the innocent end up in jail \u2014 and that as juries and judges come to regard the police as less credible, or as cases are dismissed when the lies are discovered, the guilty will go free. Police falsehoods also impede judges\u2019 efforts to enforce constitutional limits on police searches and seizures.\n\n\u201cWe have 36,000 officers with law enforcement power, and there are a small handful of these cases every year,\u201d said J. Peter Donald, a spokesman for the Police Department, the nation\u2019s largest municipal force. \u201cThat doesn\u2019t make any of these cases any less troubling. Our goal is always, always zero. One is too many, but we have taken significant steps to combat this issue.\u201d\n\nShrouded, but Persistent\n\nThe 25 cases identified by The Times are almost certainly only a fraction of those in which officers have come under suspicion for lying in the past three years. That\u2019s because a vast majority of cases end in plea deals before an officer is ever required to take the witness stand in open court, meaning the possibility that an officer lied is seldom aired in public. And in the rare cases when an officer does testify in court \u2014 and a judge finds the testimony suspicious, leading to the dismissal of the case \u2014 the proceedings are often sealed afterward.\n\nStill, the cases identified by The Times reveal an entrenched perjury problem several decades in the making that shows little sign of fading.\n\nSo far in 2018, a Queens detective has been convicted of lying in a drug case and a Brooklyn detective has been arrested amid accusations that he fabricated the results of a photo lineup. These cases returned the phenomenon of police lying to the public eye, leaving police officials to defend the integrity of honest officers.\n\nKevin Richardson, the Police Department\u2019s top internal prosecutor, said he believed so-called testilying was nearing its end. \u201cI think it\u2019s a problem that\u2019s very much largely on its way out,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIndeed, it\u2019s tempting to think about police lying as a bygone of past eras: a form of misconduct that ran unchecked as soaring street violence left the police overwhelmed during the 1980s and early 1990s and that re-emerged as police embraced stop-and-frisk tactics and covered up constitutional violations with lies.\n\nBut false testimony by the police persists even as crime has drastically receded across the city and as the Police Department has renounced the excesses of the stop-and-frisk years.\n\nSome policing experts anticipate that the ubiquity of cameras \u2014 whether on cellphones, affixed to buildings or worn by officers \u2014 will greatly reduce police lying. For the moment, however, video seems more capable of exposing lies than vanquishing them.\n\nMemory and Manipulation\n\nIn two recent cases, The Times found, officers appear to have given false accounts about witness identifications.
