These cases are particularly troubling because erroneous identifications by witnesses have been a leading cause of wrongful convictions.\n\nAfter a 2016 mugging near a Brooklyn subway station, the police arrested a group of four people, one of whom was found to be in possession of the victim\u2019s wallet. In preparing the case, prosecutors sought to pin down a few basic facts. Had the police brought the victim, who was punched and had his wallet taken, to positively identify the four suspects after they were taken into custody? If so, what had the victim said?\n\nGetting a straight answer from the arresting officer, Chedanan Naurang, proved nearly impossible. It had been Officer Naurang\u2019s quick thinking that had made the arrest possible: Having lost the suspects at one subway station, he followed a hunch and drove one stop down the line, where he caught up with the four men after they got off the train.\n\nBut certain details Officer Naurang gave prosecutors kept shifting over the next year, according to a February 2017 letter that prosecutors wrote in which they summarized his fluid story.\n\nOfficer Naurang said at one point that the identification had occurred inside a police station when the victim passed by the holding cells, saw the men and confirmed their involvement in the crime.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n[ALSO READ: Two NYPD Officers Are Charged With Lying About Suspect]\n\nA few weeks later, he backtracked. No, the victim had actually never gotten to see the suspects at the police station, Officer Naurang explained. Instead, the victim had gotten a chance to view them on the street, shortly after their arrest. That\u2019s when the victim got out of the police vehicle in which he had been waiting, Officer Naurang said, and pointed to one of the four men, identifying him as an attacker.\n\nThis version of events, however, was at odds with the recollection of the police officer who had driven the victim to the scene of the arrest. That officer, Christopher McDonald, told prosecutors that the victim had remained in the back seat while viewing the four suspects. And Officer McDonald said that the victim couldn\u2019t say whether they were his assailants. He thought he recognized their clothing, but wasn\u2019t sure.\n\nBecause of Officer Naurang\u2019s changing story, prosecutors dropped the case against the men as part of a deal in which all four pleaded guilty to charges stemming from a second mugging they were accused of the same night.", "title": "\u2018Testilying\u2019 by Police: A Stubborn Problem", "authors": ["Joseph Goldstein"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "A different kind of inescapable evil gets an airing when Kreizler visits Cyrus in the hospital, who is recovering from a head wound inflicted by the killer. The doctor finds Cyrus\u2019s niece, Joanna Crawford (Brittany Marie Batchelder), tending to him. A reporter for The Philadelphia Tribune, she attended college courtesy of Kreizler, who paid for her schooling as a gift to Cyrus and his family. To Crawford, however, both this gift and his continued \u201cfriendship\u201d with her uncle, who entered Laszlo\u2019s service after committing a justifiable homicide, are signs of condescension and control, not generosity. Kreizler, she believes, is simply keeping Cyrus downtrodden with his courtesies and progressive ideas \u2014 \u201cmore effective than using shackles and a whip.\u201d\n\nEchoing criticisms leveled today at \u201cperformative wokeness,\u201d Joanna\u2019s assertions about Laszlo\u2019s character hit him as hard as any he\u2019s heard so far. He spends the rest of the episode attempting to make it up to not only Cyrus but also to his other servants, Stevie and Mary.\n\nIn Mary\u2019s case, his suggestion that perhaps it\u2019s time she strike out on her own is greeted with explosive indignation. So he invites her to dinner instead. When he finally reaches out to take her hand, initiating what becomes a passionate kiss, a clever bit of camerawork begins with Mary offscreen and follows Laszlo\u2019s his hand as it traverses the space between them until she is finally in the frame \u2014 a visual representation of the effort required to bridge the emotional gap.\n\nYet another speech on the evils that plague the city isn\u2019t delivered by a knowing scoundrel like Byrnes or Kelly, nor by a sharp sociopolitical analyst like Joanna. It\u2019s delivered by a man so rich and powerful that he can bend society and politics to his will and no one thinks of him as a scoundrel at all. Using Connor as muscle and employing Byrnes (and Bishop Potter) as backup, J.P. Morgan has Moore and Kreizler abducted and brought to his mansion. At first, Morgan indulges his cohorts\u2019 demands that the investigation be dropped because of the high social standing of their suspect.\n\nBut Kreizler\u2019s insistence that Willem Van Bergen isn\u2019t the killer enables Morgan to put aside upper-class solidarity and address his real concerns. New York, he says, is on the verge of becoming history\u2019s greatest economic powerhouse. But for that to happen, he says, \u201cWe need a compliant work force.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe continues: \u201cThe civil unrest caused by these murders troubles me a great deal. A great deal indeed. Perhaps even more than the murders themselves. A harsh truth, but a truth nonetheless.\u201d In other words, dead children are usually just unfortunate; when their corpses clog the flow of capital, it\u2019s a crisis.\n\nWisely, Kreizler refuses Morgan\u2019s offer of financial support for the investigation, knowing Morgan would want something in return. (\u201cWhat could a man like J.P. Morgan want from you?\u201d John asks incredulously. \u201cI don\u2019t know,\u201d Laszlo replies, \u201cbut I\u2019m most unwilling to find out.\u201d)\n\nAnd the investigation continues despite these obstacles. Changes in the killer\u2019s methods of mutilation remind Commissioner Roosevelt, who is present when the team examines the corpse, of massacres he witnessed during his time in the Dakotas. (The future president befriended Seth Bullock, the real-life basis for the \u201cDeadwood\u201d lawman, during his time out West. I smell a crossover!)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith a surprisingly low level of colonialist racism for their time, the team figures out that the killer is not actually a Native American, whose mutilations of enemy corpses are informed by a very specific spiritual logic. The killer is likely a white man who witnessed such mutilations, probably as a child, and who applies his own twisted meanings to them as he recreates them. After a harrowing visit to a mental institution, Sara Howard identifies a new suspect: a soldier, previously interned in the United States government\u2019s secret hospital for soldiers suffering from what today we would call post-traumatic stress, and other mental disorders. Thus the breadth of any potential conspiracy widens even further.\n\nOn a final note, the progress of Sara and John\u2019s romance has become nearly as compelling to track as the murder investigation because of the character insights it uncovers along the way. In fact, the couple\u2019s most intimate scene in this week\u2019s episode isn\u2019t actually romantic at all, although it does end with Miss Howard leaning against Mr. Moore in a heartfelt embrace.\n\nWhen Sara presents her breakthrough in the child-killer case to John, the vehemence of her refusal to reveal her findings to Kreizler directly is unmistakable. John knows something must have happened between them, and asks what it was with an edge of alarm in his voice.\n\n\u201cHe was right about one thing,\u201d Sara explains. \u201cGiven certain circumstances, we\u2019re all capable of violence.\u201d The actor Dakota Fanning excels at radiating shock, pain, and betrayal from behind Sara\u2019s practiced composure, and the script follows suit: She never says outright that Laszlo struck her, but she powerfully conveys the moral gravity of Kreizler\u2019s blow nonetheless.\n\n\u201cThe Alienist\u201d has often been so focused on its central murders that its other acts of violence feel like afterthoughts \u2014 most notably the sexual assault against John arranged by Captain Connor and Paul Kelly, which at least gets alluded to by Kelly during their carriage ride, but which doesn\u2019t seem to have affected John at all. It\u2019s good to see the show treat this assault \u2014 a man\u2019s hitting a woman, essentially for mouthing off to him \u2014 with due seriousness.", "title": "\u2018The Alienist\u2019 Season 1, Episode 7: A Devil\u2019s Bargain", "authors": ["Sean T. Collins", "The Alienist"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Season 1, Episode 8: \u2018Psychopathia Sexualis\u2019\n\nAlas, poor Mary. We knew her \u2026 not so well, actually.\n\nWritten by John Sayles and directed by David Petrarca, this week\u2019s episode ups the ante for its main characters considerably, in a fashion grimly familiar to fans of genre fiction: It killed off the male lead\u2019s love interest. The episode begins with Dr. Laszlo Kreizler and his mute maid Mary Palmer mooning over each other like puppy-lovesick teenagers; it ends with her twisted corpse on the floor of Kreizler\u2019s home.\n\nWhen the former Captain Connor and his minions break into the doctor\u2019s house, presumably to finish the job after a botched assassination attempt, Mary inexplicably grabs a knife and charges after the intruder. (Kreizler isn\u2019t even there, so it\u2019s not clear what she\u2019s trying to protect except the sanctity of his bedroom.) A scuffle ensues, Connor gets stabbed in the shoulder, and Mary falls from the second-floor balcony, crashing into the chandelier on her way down before breaking her neck upon the bottom stair.\n\nIt\u2019s a sorry fate for the character, who despite an expressive wordless performance by Q\u2019orianka Kilcher never truly found her voice. (No, \u201cfalling in love with a guy\u201d is not a personality trait. And don\u2019t even get me started on the character Cyrus, who seems to exist solely to get jumped, despite being played by Robert Wisdom, who carried an entire season of \u201cThe Wire,\u201d one of the greatest shows of all time.)\n\nCompare Mary\u2019s fate with John Moore\u2019s. That toffish illustrator has survived multiple run-ins with Connor, from tense staredowns and terse conversations all the way up to getting drugged and sexually assaulted at the ex-cop\u2019s behest. Last week\u2019s episode ended, rather pointlessly it turns out, with a cliffhanger in which Connor waylaid and coldcocked Moore in a skid-row alleyway.", "title": "\u2018The Alienist\u2019 Season 1, Episode 8: Home to Roost", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSeason 1, Episode 9: \u2018Requiem\u2019\n\nEver feel like you get more done when the boss isn\u2019t around? From this, a workplace truth that for many seems self-evident (unless you\u2019re the boss, naturally), \u201cThe Alienist\u201d concocts another week of investigative breakthroughs. By the end of this episode, Dr. Laszlo Kreizler\u2019s motley crew of pro-am criminologists is closer than ever to capturing its quarry, the relentless child-killer whose stylized murders have been baffling and revealing in equal measure. But there\u2019s one major difference in their pursuit this time around: Dr. Kreizler is not a participant.\n\nThe progress made by Sara Howard, John Moore, and the Isaacson brothers in the absence of their mercurial mentor is a surprise only in terms of the centrality Kreizler was given by the story before now. Considering all we\u2019ve learned about his methods and mien this season, it\u2019s more of a shock that they got anything done before. Now, with Laszlo housebound by grief, there are no angry, object-throwing outbursts to contend with, no dredging up of painful memories of drowning brothers and faithless fianc\u00e9es and suicidal fathers, no slaps to the face when someone like Sara has the temerity to suggest that healing oneself should be any physician\u2019s first order of business (or any alienist\u2019s). It\u2019s hard to believe, given the unmistakable evaporation of all that interpersonal drama, but it wasn\u2019t so long ago that Kreizler came across like the most reasonable genius in the genre, let alone the room.\n\nTo be fair, the doctor\u2019s erstwhile acolytes are working with tools he provided. As Laszlo might have done, they puzzle over the symbolic significance of the killer\u2019s pseudonym and study the Christian calendar for significant clues. But without the skills they bring to the table themselves, they never would have been able to track down the killer\u2019s apartment and confirm his identity.\n\nHe does, indeed, appear to be Japheth Dury, the abused preacher\u2019s son turned predatory census-taker and part-time leg-breaker for a local bookie. He is also, as we began to understand last week, operating under the name \u201cJohn Beecham,\u201d the surname stolen from a man who raped Japheth before he retaliated by cutting his throat and throwing him off a cliff. To ferret this out required John\u2019s rapport with street kids and his knack for sketch artistry; Sara\u2019s attention to detail and her research skills among the vast census records; and the Isaacsons\u2019 badge-flashing, lock-picking, witness-interrogating police work.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt all leads to the grimmest discovery of the season, coupled with its goriest onscreen moments. While John\u2019s young friend Joseph listens in horror, Beecham butchers one of his friends in the public baths, dragging his bloody corpse down the hall and off to whatever urban aerie will become this latest victim\u2019s chosen resting place. At the same time, in the killer\u2019s bedroom, Sara opens a heart-shaped box and discovers an actual human heart, while Marcus Isaacson uncovers a jar filled with human eyeballs \u2014 many more, it\u2019s clear, than the known victims could have provided.", "title": "\u2018The Alienist\u2019 Season 1, Episode 9: The Doctor Is Out", "authors": ["Sean T. Collins", "The Alienist"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s in those final steps of the hunt for the killer that the problems really begin. Kreizler bamboozles Roosevelt and his men so that Kreizler and Moore, already under close watch by Byrnes, could sneak away to the child-killer\u2019s new lair unnoticed. How do they know that this lair is in the Croton Reservoir? How does Sara, whom Kreizler also dupes (reasons unclear), figure out that same thing in turn, arriving at the reservoir just in time to save their lives? There\u2019s some hand-waving about interpreting the killer\u2019s map of the water and sewer systems, a change in his modus operandi, and his apparent obsession with John the Baptist. But that\u2019s all wild guess work, and New York was a really big city \u2014 on an island, no less \u2014 even during the Gilded Age. Water, water everywhere, yet they know exactly where to go.\n\nThe episode ratchets up the tension by including Byrnes and Connor as factors in the final showdown, from a poorly explained scene in which Byrnes monitors our men at the opera house to Connor\u2019s almost comically dogged pursuit of the alienist\u2019s team. But while their acute interest in the case made sense while one of their high-society patrons was under suspicion, it made considerably less sense once that patron was killed by Connor. His involvement in the murder of Laszlo\u2019s beloved Mary seems to be an open secret as well, although this, too, is poorly explained. Now Connor goes to all this trouble just because the police object to the doctor\u2019s newfangled methodology? It simply doesn\u2019t hold up as a motive.\n\nPut it all together, and it feels rushed and forced, as if the filmmakers looked at the clock, realized they were running out of time and did a speed run through the final hour of what until now had been a very meticulous, patient detective story.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnd even here, 10 episodes deep into the show\u2019s 10-episode run, those filmmakers are gilding the cruelty lily. We\u2019ve spent weeks looking at the mutilated corpses of Japheth Dury\u2019s child victims. Did we really need to watch a puddle of urine collect on the floor beneath body of his terrified kidnapping victim, or watch the killer bash a cat in a bag to death against the wall (good luck getting those sound effects out of your head), to understand he means business? Were these awful moments required to demonstrate his desire to inflict suffering on weaker creatures, human or animal, when we\u2019ve seen the box of animal bones and the jar of eyes to prove the point already?\n\nTo be clear, I am not taking some sort of principled stand against graphic, disturbing violence. On the contrary! As a longtime horror fan, I believe gore and brutality can be used to articulate the agony and terror we feel but do not have the words to express. Moreover, I applaud any show that makes an effort to make murder \u2014 whether by serial killers or soldiers \u2014 unpleasant rather than thrilling. Trauma should not be easy to digest.\n\nBut on that count, \u201cThe Alienist\u201d attempts to have its cake and eat it too. Rather predictably (if you\u2019ve seen the end of \u201cTrue Detective\u201d Season 1, which Fukunaga directed), the hunt for Japheth Dury devolves into a cat-and-mouse game through the labyrinthine, dimly lit halls of the reservoir. Bullets fly. Characters get knocked out over and over, but never killed (John\u2019s miraculous recoveries continue, this time after having his head repeatedly slammed against a brick wall). The villain lowers himself from the ceiling to waylay his pursuers like a bizarro Batman \u2014 fitting, given the genuinely bizarre visual effects that distort his face like a member of the Dark Knight\u2019s rogues gallery. And thanks in part to all those unconscious-but-not-dead characters, there are more buzzer-beating rescues and reversals on hand here than in the whole of March Madness.\n\nAt any rate, Kreizler and company get their man, or men. Captain Connor, surely the most diligent henchman a corrupt system of authority could ever ask for, trails Laszlo and John all the way to the chamber where they\u2019re confronting Japheth, mortally wounding the killer before being shot to death in turn by Sara, another last-second arrival. Connor dies quickly; Japheth dies quietly, though not before hauling himself up to the top of the reservoir in one last incomprehensible ritualistic gesture.\n\nI\u2019ll give the climax this: Kreizler\u2019s soul-deep sorrow as he realizes the man will not live to offer any insights into why he did what he did is more than moving \u2014 it\u2019s a summary of everything the man stands for. He didn\u2019t just want to stop Japheth Dury. He wanted to stop the creation of more Japheth Durys, and that quest just took a devastating blow.\n\nOf the show\u2019s three leads, Daniel Br\u00fchl was always given the most demanding and complicated material. His character, genial and insightful one minute, robotic and cruel the next, never really cohered, and neither did the performance. (It is always possible that the role could be resurrected for an adaptation of the sequel novel, \u201cThe Angel of Darkness,\u201d but there are no known plans for now.) But the sight of Kreizler strolling in his trademark hat, or smiling politely as he interacts with others in his soft, accented voice, is endearing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nClosing the show with a scene in which Laszlo visits his elderly, uncommunicative father in a sanitarium and discusses the abuse he suffered at the old man\u2019s hand was a bold and fitting choice. The hunt for the murderer may have disappointed, but the hunt for the truth, about his own mind and the minds of others, will continue. The alienist himself is \u201cThe Alienist\u201d in miniature: temperament uneven, promise unfulfilled, but rich enough beneath the surface to have made our time together feel worth the trouble.", "title": "\u2018The Alienist\u2019 Series Finale Recap: \u2018His Awful Mystery\u2019", "authors": ["Sean T. Collins", "The Alienist"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "To round out Erica\u2019s character, the show needed some paintings. \u201cBecause we just felt that if we found the right real art, the character of the artist would feel true,\u201d Mr. Weisberg said, speaking at his offices near the Gowanus soundstage where \u201cThe Americans\u201d shoots. But not any paintings would do. Elizabeth needs to discover more than nuclear secrets in Erica\u2019s home.\n\nAs fans of \u201cThe Americans\u201d know, Elizabeth keeps her emotions closer to her chest than any spyware. In this final season, the showrunners wanted to explore what would happen if Erica\u2019s art \u201cbreaks through Elizabeth\u2019s exterior and provokes her,\u201d Mr. Weisberg said. As Elizabeth sees art as a bourgeois frivolity, the paintings had to work on her unconsciously, like sleeper agents, suggesting the kinds of intense emotions that she will never let herself feel. They had to be realistic, but not too realistic, passionate, but not over the top. They had to look as though they could have been painted in the 1980s. And they had to be, as Mr. Fields said, \u201creally good art.\u201d\n\nMr. Fields and Mr. Weisberg called their friend, the gallerist Jim Kempner, with a request: Find a painter who ticks every box. Mr. Kempner returned with a shortlist. Ms. Monks\u2019s name was near the top. As soon as the showrunners saw her canvases, they wanted them.\n\nA painting of a woman slumped on a hotel bed looked like Elizabeth after a honey trap. A screaming face seemed to embody the pain she repressed.\n\n\u201cSome of the work seemed like it could literally be a representation of Elizabeth\u2019s psyche,\u201d Mr. Weisberg said. So they proposed what Mr. Fields called, \u201cthis weird creative partnership where we wanted to appropriate her real, beautiful art for our fictional character.\u201d Ms. Monks agreed.", "title": "\u2018The Americans\u2019 Goes Dark(er), With Help From a Painter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Philip has indeed quit the spy business and is a happy bourgeois, opening the power roof of his comfy car and lecturing his travel-agency employees on how to have the human touch. He appears to have plenty of free time, as a retired assassin and empty nester \u2014 Paige is in college nearby and Henry is at the private school in New Hampshire, where he\u2019s a hard-nosed hockey player with a gaggle of screaming female fans.\n\nElizabeth, on the other hand, is working harder than ever \u2014 running a honey-pot sting on one hapless American, and infiltrating the home of another by working as a health aide for his wife. The montage is a greatest-hits collection of Elizabeth personas: the frumpy glasses-and-perm working woman, the longhaired seductress, the action-figure operative in her baseball cap. The primary message, driven home throughout the episode, is that Elizabeth is exhausted, and resentful of Philip\u2019s new freedom. (He has time to drive up to New England to watch Henry play and to make small talk with an attractive hockey mom.)\n\nNo matter how depressed and rumpled Elizabeth gets, though, Moscow does not believe in tears, a point brought home a bit literally when we cut to a scene of her, Paige and Claudia watching \u201cMoscow Does Not Believe in Tears,\u201d the 1980 film that was a combination of weepy Hollywood-style women\u2019s picture and Soviet propaganda. (The Washington-based warriors of socialism are mostly women now \u2014 these three, plus Marilyn. But Norm is still around, looking unpleased.)\n\nPaige is now operational, but she\u2019s still being shielded from the nasty stuff that her mother is so good at. When a young Navy security guard hits on Paige and possibly compromises her cover, Elizabeth says it\u2019s no big deal, then tracks the guy down and shivs him in the neck. (It\u2019s the only violent moment in an otherwise quiet episode.) In her defense, he was pretty creepy, having tried to blackmail Paige into a date by keeping her college I.D. From the vantage point of 2018, it couldn\u2019t help registering as a #MeToo moment.\n\nSex, surveillance, murder AND a sudden trip to Mexico City, where Elizabeth is sent by Claudia to meet with a hard-line, anti-perestroika Soviet general. He tells her that the Soviets have developed a system called Dead Hand that will automatically nuke the United States should an American first strike wipe out the Soviet command structure. No human touch there. She\u2019s to monitor a member of the Soviet summit team and, if she learns that Gorbachev is planning to trade away Dead Hand in exchange for an end to the Star Wars missile-defense program, she\u2019s to pass it along. Gorbachev will be dead within 24 hours.", "title": "\u2018The Americans\u2019 Season 6, Episode 1 Recap: The Coldest War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "The reaction was hurtful and also surprising: American citizens were mad at her for exposing Russian spies? But she credits the show\u2019s writers for \u201cswitching people\u2019s perspective completely.\u201d\n\nGone is the 1980s perception of \u201cRussia as the bad guy,\u201d she said. \u201cYou see why they\u2019re doing what they\u2019re doing, and how they are humans.\u201d\n\nWhile Ms. Taylor was born a decade after the era chronicled in \u201cThe Americans,\u201d she\u2019s developed an appreciation for life before the iPhone. \u201cWhen they\u2019re doing all this spy stuff, Elizabeth can\u2019t just text Phil and be like, \u2018The bad guy\u2019s coming around the corner, take cover,\u2019\u201d she said.\n\nLike Paige, Ms. Taylor is close to her parents, Mark and Margaret Taylor. Originally from Britain, they were living in Nova Scotia when she was born and then moved to Wayne, N.J., when she was 3. (She has one brother, who\u2019s older.) There, they enrolled her in a dance class, and she took to it immediately. \u201cMy dream was to be on Broadway,\u201d Ms. Taylor said. \u201cMy parents didn\u2019t even know what Broadway was.\u201d\n\nThey found out. When Ms. Taylor was 11, she landed a part as a ballet student in the original Broadway production of \u201cBilly Elliot.\u201d Her parents kept her in school, and her mother commuted with her to Manhattan six days a week. \u201cThey definitely thought school was more important, but at the same time, they didn\u2019t want to ruin the opportunity for me,\u201d Ms. Taylor said. \u201cIf my grades were to ever start slacking, it would\u2019ve been like, \u2018You\u2019re out.\u2019\u201d\n\nA few years later, Ms. Taylor was cast on \u201cThe Americans,\u201d this time commuting to Brooklyn, where the show is filmed. \u201cShe just seemed like a real kid, with a natural ability to convey these complex emotions,\u201d the showrunners wrote in their email.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe largely continued to live as a \u201creal kid,\u201d even as she starred on a critically acclaimed cable drama. Her parents maintained lofty academic expectations, and she met them. (\u201cI was 4.0 G.P.A., in every single honor society and in student council,\u201d she said.) Her friends thought it was \u201ccool\u201d that she was on TV, but because it was a grown-up show, they didn\u2019t watch and often forgot that their friend was sort of famous.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s been times when I\u2019m out with them, and someone will recognize me, and they\u2019re like, \u2018Why is this lady talking to her?\u2019\u201d Ms. Taylor said.\n\nHer first seasons of playing Paige on the show were mostly unremarkable, but everything changed when she found out the family secret. After reading the script, Ms. Taylor said: \u201cI knew they couldn\u2019t just let that die. We had to see what happens. How she\u2019s going to react? Is she going to tell people? Is she going to support them?\u201d\n\nFew answers were available, she added, because the producers are \u201cvery tight-lipped.\u201d\n\n\u201cThey don\u2019t tell you anything,\u201d she added.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe truth is that nobody anticipated how pivotal a role she would eventually play. Paige\u2019s story line has become \u201cjust as central to the show as any of the marital or political drama,\u201d Mr. Fields and Mr. Weisberg said. \u201cIn many ways, it was Holly\u2019s performance that allowed us to dig so deep there.\u201d\n\nOne plot twist that Ms. Taylor didn\u2019t anticipate \u2014 or enjoy \u2014 was her puppy-love romance with Matthew Beeman (Daniel Flaherty).\n\n\u201cI hated it so much,\u201d she said. \u201cCould you imagine going to work to make out with this person while 60 men, who\u2019ve known you since you were little, stand around to watch you do it 15 times in a row at least?\u201d She watched the episode at home with her family and boyfriend, a pillow over her head.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nExpect less kissing and more punching this season, as Paige steps into her new role as defender of the motherland in the culminating stretch of both the Soviet Union and \u201cThe Americans.\u201d But with interest in Russian spycraft higher than at any time since the Cold War, could a spinoff series, starring Paige in a pre-Putin era, be a possibility?\n\nMs. Taylor said nyet: \u201cI\u2019ve asked repeatedly if there\u2019s going to be a spinoff, if there\u2019s going to be a movie after, and they\u2019re like, \u2018Nope, nope, nope,\u2019 and they constantly shoot me down. So I think it\u2019s confirmed now.\u201d\n\nIn the meantime, she continues to commute from her parents\u2019 home in Wayne to Union, N.J., where she\u2019s studying advertising at Kean University. She\u2019s also been auditioning for new TV shows, but hopes that they don\u2019t take her too far from home.\n\n\u201cI like where I\u2019m from, and I like the suburbs,\u201d she said. \u201cNew Jersey gets so much hate\u201d because of shows like \u201cJersey Shore\u201d and \u201cThe Real Housewives of New Jersey,\u201d she noted, \u201cbut it really has everything.\u201d\n\nIncluding the world\u2019s best chicken fingers.", "title": "\u2018The Americans\u2019: Will Holly Taylor Inherit the Family Business?", "authors": ["Jonathan Small"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Norman also throws Andrew a birthday party, to which Andrew invites the object of his infatuation, David. To impress him, Andrew asks his friend Jeff to impersonate the naval officer he used to be and to present Andrew with a gift of Ferragamo shoes \u2014 as a sign, Andrew says, that he is loved. (Jeff agrees, grudgingly, to present the gift but not to dress up.) The stunt backfires: Jeff and David take an immediate interest in each other, but not so much in Andrew. And we know from a previous episode that they will end up getting together, which Andrew discovers before killing them both.\n\nAndrew\u2019s pathologies are apparent to anyone who bothers to look. Norman\u2019s protective friend Gallo spots Andrew snorting drugs and confronts him. \u201cYou think Norman\u2019s the lucky one, don\u2019t you?\u201d he says. \u201cBut you\u2019re wrong: You\u2019re the lucky one.\u201d Andrew is only able to parade himself around like an equal because Norman, who has built an immensely successful company from scratch, is generous enough to want Andrew to feel that way.\n\nWhen Andrew insists that he is Norman\u2019s equal and then tries to storm off, Gallo delivers the bons mots that will prove to be an unfortunate understatement: \u201cWhat a volatile mix you are: too lazy to work and too proud to be kept.\u201d\n\nThat mismatch between Andrew\u2019s laziness and ambition comes to the forefront when he presents Norman with an ultimatum: He demands a higher living allowance; first-class flights; a Mercedes-Benz XL600; and a place in Norman\u2019s will, as his sole heir. Norman refuses. He has performed some \u201cdue diligence,\u201d he says, and has learned that Andrew is not Andrew DeSilva, Ph.D., the estranged son of New York millionaires, but Andrew Cunanan, college dropout, who was recently working at a Thrifty drugstore for $6.16 an hour and living in a cramped condo with his mother, MaryAnn.\n\nIt is an extraordinary scene. Confronted with the truth, Andrew remains in denial. When it becomes clear Norman won\u2019t relent, Andrew grabs a patio chair and smashes a glass tabletop with it \u2014 a mere hint at the serious violence to come.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAndrew\u2019s aggression also extends toward Jeff, whom he suspects of trying to steal away David, particularly after Jeff says that he is leaving San Diego to move to Minneapolis, where David lives. Ever in denial, Andrew persuades David to fly to Los Angeles, where Andrew has reserved a room at a five-star hotel and buys David an expensive suit. Andrew can\u2019t stop lying \u2014 asked what he does for a living, he suggests that he is financing a major movie \u2014 and the dinner culminates in excruciating fashion with Andrew declaring, \u201cDavid Madson, you are the only one I have ever really truly loved.\u201d\n\nDavid, the industrious son of a Wisconsin hardware-store owner, gives Andrew what amounts to a final chance, asking simply for the truth. Andrew still can\u2019t stop his prevarications. He says his father was a stockbroker at Merrill Lynch who later returned to the Philippines \u201cto run vast pineapple plantations\u201d; that his mother oversaw a literary publishing house until she retired; and that his parents adored him so much that they lavished little Andrew with the master bedroom, a credit card and an occasional lobster when the school lunch wasn\u2019t good enough.\n\nAndrew seems unaware that high-achieving people from modest backgrounds tend not to be impressed by tales of pampered childhoods.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the remainder of the episode, we learn more about Andrew\u2019s drugs and dreams. (Maureen Orth\u2019s book \u201cVulgar Favors,\u201d upon which the series is based, says that Andrew was a drug dealer, not just a drug user.)\n\nIn one bizarre scene, Andrew dreams that he has walked into a Versace boutique and is being measured for a suit by the designer himself. His self-indulgent lament:\n\nWhat could be more generous than spending everything on other people and being left with nothing? What could be more generous than finding soul mates for other people and then ending up alone? People have taken from me, and taken from me, and taken and taken from me. Now I\u2019m spent. And they say this man has nothing left to give. And a man with nothing to give is a nothing man.\n\nThe fantasy Versace replies, more than a tad sardonically, \u201cThat is very poetic, sir.\u201d Andrew tells him: \u201cThis world has wasted me. It has wasted me while it has turned you, Mr. Versace, into a star.\u201d\n\nAndrew adds: \u201cWe\u2019re the same. The only difference is you got lucky.\u201d\n\nConsumed by self-pity, delusion and addiction, Andrew hits bottom. He returns to Norman\u2019s mansion, desperate for money; Norman threatens to call the police. Finally Andrew goes home \u2014 to his mother\u2019s dingy apartment.\n\nMary Ann seems, if such a thing is possible, even more deluded than her son. She believes he has been traveling with Versace to Tokyo, Sydney, Moscow and Milan. She gives him a bath.\n\nAlthough we don\u2019t know much of her story yet, she appears simple-minded and emotionally fragile, and her hold on Andrew nonexistent. Telling her that the next stop in his glamorous life is Minneapolis, Andrew drives off to begin his murderous spree. She will never see him again.", "title": "\u2018The Assassination of Gianni Versace\u2019 Episode 6: A Nothing Man", "authors": ["Sewell Chan", "American Crime Story"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cDoes it ever bother you that the customers only know you as \u2018That Helpful Man\u2019?\u201d Andrew asks Mercado. Mercado shrugs. Later, back at his mother\u2019s apartment, Andrew reacts violently after discovering that she has bought a tub of Safeway ice cream rather than his preferred brand, H\u00e4agen-Dazs. His spite toward anything everyday \u2014 what in last week\u2019s episode he derided as \u201cordinary\u201d \u2014 is visceral and explosive. He slams the tub onto the kitchen floor, making a mess.\n\nWhen his mother asks why it matters, Andrew tells her about Reuben Mattus, the brand\u2019s founder, who made up its Danish-sounding name. It\u2019s a brief but sad moment, one that reveals how consumer abundance, or the illusion of it, has made Andrew so petulant, childish and self-indulgent that he despises his own mother.\n\nIn the gay world, we soon learn, Andrew is more Safeway than H\u00e4agen-Dazs.\n\nAt a gay bar with his handsome friend Jeff, a Navy veteran, Andrew laments that he isn\u2019t approached more by men; Jeff urges him to take the initiative, but Andrew fears rejection in the same way he fears getting his hands dirty. For him, it\u2019s existential. \u201cBeing told no is like being told I don\u2019t exist,\u201d he says. \u201cIt\u2019s like I\u2019ve disappeared or something.\u201d\n\nPeople get rejected every day, and we may never truly understand why most move on with their lives while Andrew moved on to become a killer. But we\u2019re learning more about just how pernicious his fear of invisibility is, even at this early stage. When Andrew visits an escort agency, its brusque manager wastes no time in informing Andrew about the customers\u2019 preferences \u2014 another rejection. (\u201cMy clients never ask for Asians,\u201d she says after asking him to drop his trousers. \u201cAnd they never ask for Asians with attitude.\u201d) Deciding he doesn\u2019t need help finding a sugar daddy, he browses a local newspaper, studying the arts and philanthropy pages to identify suitable targets.\n\nA target found, he stalks the La Jolla Playhouse for a performance of Marivaux\u2019s 18th-century comic play \u201cThe Triumph of Love.\u201d Just as planned, he catches the eye of Norman Blachford, a wealthy entrepreneur whose partner, as we know from last week\u2019s episode, has recently died of AIDS. Andrew ends up becoming the kept man of Lincoln Aston, a friend of Norman\u2019s.\n\nIt\u2019s on Lincoln\u2019s dime \u2014 purportedly to look into art acquisitions \u2014 that Andrew travels to San Francisco and buys a fateful drink for a handsome young man sitting alone at the bar. That man turns out to be David, the Minneapolis architect, who is visiting San Francisco for work. (Frustratingly, we never learn more about the friends with whom Andrew is dining.)", "title": "\u2018The Assassination of Gianni Versace\u2019 Episode 7: Asians With Attitude", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Andrew Cunanan\u2019s early years, we learn, were in most respects considerably more complicated.\n\nIt is 1980 and the Cunanan family \u2014 Modesto (played by a fantastic Jon Jon Briones), who is Filipino; his wife, Mary Ann; and their four children \u2014 are moving into a spacious new home in San Diego. Andrew turned 11 that summer. Modesto leads his youngest child \u2014 whom an older brother calls \u201cPrince Andrew\u201d \u2014 on a tour of the new house. He is given the master bedroom. It is clear that his parents have marked him as special, and not just in the way youngest children are often doted on.\n\nAs Andrew interviews for the Bishop\u2019s School, an elite private academy, Modesto interviews at Merrill Lynch. Modesto\u2019s charm is on full display. \u201cGentlemen, I\u2019m aware that you have a long line of eager Ivy League-educated young men queuing up to be brokers at Merrill Lynch, but ask yourself, how many of them started from nothing?\u201d he asks. When asked to discuss business, not his biography, he protests: \u201cMy life is a tale told in dollars,\u201d he tells them, which started in a small village in the Philippines and wound up in an $80,000 home.\n\n\u201cNow is that biography or business?\u201d he asks. \u201cBecause I will tell your investors that\u2019s what I plan to do with their money. I will cross oceans with it. I will take it to new lands. I\u2019m talking about growth they can\u2019t imagine.\u201d The monologue is notable because it is so much like the fantastic tales that Andrew will later tell to the many gay men he will try to impress. Modesto gets the job.\n\nYoung Andrew, meanwhile, is accepted to the Bishop\u2019s School, after telling the interviewers that his one wish is \u201cto be special.\u201d\n\nIt is a high point for the father and son, whose lives start to go down from this point.\n\nBut first we learn about the family\u2019s unusual and troubling dynamics. Modesto spoils Andrew to the point of buying a car for him, even though he is too young for a license. Even more troubling, Modesto is physically abusive to his wife, Mary Ann, whom he holds in contempt for her \u201cweak mind.\u201d And his obsession with Andrew is clearly unhealthy. In one particularly disturbing scene at bed time, there\u2019s an intimation of possible sexual abuse. The scene goes dark, and we\u2019re left to wonder. But the effect is unsettling regardless.", "title": "\u2018The Assassination of Gianni Versace\u2019 Episode 8: Prince Andrew", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "No moment manifests those qualities more than a monologue by Ronnie, a gay drifter whom Cunanan befriended as he was hiding out from the law during the two months before he killed Versace. Ronnie recognizes Versace\u2019s significance. \u201cWe all imagined what it would be like to be so rich and so powerful that it doesn\u2019t matter that you\u2019re gay,\u201d he says during a police interrogation.\n\nBut he is also angered that the authorities were slow to alert the gay community and to solicit its help in the manhunt \u2014 until, as Ronnie notes, one of the victims was famous. \u201cYou\u2019re so used to us lurking in the shadows and, you know, most of us, we oblige,\u201d he says. \u201cPeople like me, we just drift away. We get sick? Nobody cares.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut Andrew was vain,\u201d he continues, as a flicker of something almost like pride, or at least defiance, lights his eyes. \u201cHe wanted you to know about his pain, he wanted you to hear, he wanted you to know about being born a lie. Andrew is not hiding. He\u2019s trying to be seen.\u201d\n\nMaybe. But at that moment Cunanan is, in fact, hiding out on a house boat. If he had a message to communicate about his pain, he did not share it.\n\nThe series is loosely based on Maureen Orth\u2019s gossipy book \u201cVulgar Favours,\u201d but the dramatizations and embellishments are so extreme that the series appears more a flight of wishful fantasy than an act of journalistic reconstruction. Also extreme is the director Daniel Minahan\u2019s insistence on making this finale a retrospective of horrors.\n\nUntil now, the series was told in reverse chronological order. But the finale circles back to where it started, and it is bursting at the seams with tangential characters, visual cues and over-the-top emotions that leave a jumble of impressions instead of delivering a clear punch.\n\nWe pay a visit to Marilyn Miglin, a self-made cosmetics magnate who sells her wares on television and whose husband, Lee, a Chicago property developer, was the third of Cunanan\u2019s five victims. She happens to be in Tampa, Fla., while the manhunt following Versace\u2019s murder occurs. The local police urge her to return to Chicago for fear that Cunanan may be after her, but she refuses.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHer strength and resolve are admirable \u2014 and Judith Light turns in a magnificent performance \u2014 but we hardly learn anything that we didn\u2019t know from Episode 3.\n\nSimilarly repetitive is a scene in which the father of David Madson, the Minneapolis architect whom Cunanan forced to flee home before he killed him, communicates his anguish in a TV interview. We knew from Episode 4 that the father and son were both pretty decent people.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe most strange and haunting moment of this finale comes when Cunanan, desperate and reduced to eating dog food, dials his father, Modesto, a disgraced former stockbroker who fled to his native Philippines after some shady financial deals. Andrew is sobbing, a man of 27 reduced to helplessness. \u201cDad, I\u2019m in trouble,\u201d he pleas. \u201cI need help. I need you to come get me.\u201d Modesto promises Andrew that he\u2019ll drop everything and race to Miami to rescue him. \u201cI will find you and I will hug you and I will hold you in my arms,\u201d he says.\n\nOf course he doesn\u2019t. He\u2019s a hustler.\n\nThe next morning, it\u2019s clear to Andrew that Modesto isn\u2019t coming. In fact, he hasn\u2019t even tried to leave the Philippines. \u201cMy son is not and has never been a homosexual,\u201d he tells television reporters as his son watches from Florida. He adds: \u201cHe was a perfect boy, the most special child I ever saw. The idea that he could be a killer makes me angry.\u201d\n\nModesto tells the reporters that Andrew called him a night ago. Asked what they discussed, he replies: \u201cThe movie rights to his life story. I\u2019m acting as the broker, calling Hollywood from here in Manila. Andrew was very particular about the title.\u201d\n\nThe movie, he says, will be called \u201cA Name to Be Remembered.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s disturbing and nauseating, of course. But we already knew from Episode 8 that Modesto was a pretty despicable guy.\n\nThen there\u2019s a jarring shift to Milan, where Versace is honored with a ceremony akin to a state funeral. We are reminded \u2014 as we learned in Episode 2 \u2014 that his sister and de facto heir, Donatella, and his partner, Antonio D\u2019Amico, have a frosty relationship. Antonio wants to move to one of Gianni\u2019s properties, on Lake Como; Donatella says it\u2019s up to the company\u2019s board to decide. (Later, we are shown, Antonio is driven to such despair that he attempts suicide.)\n\nWatching the live broadcast of the funeral, Cunanan kneels before the television and makes a sign of the cross: a shockingly sacrilegious moment, but hardly of great emotional power since Cunanan\u2019s Catholicism hasn\u2019t really been a theme at all. A scene with Cunanan\u2019s friend Lizzie, whom we have barely heard from, is similarly lacking, as she begs him on television to turn himself in. Lizzie \u2014 a straight, older friend who asked Andrew to be the godfather to her children \u2014 has intrigued me throughout the series, but the underinvestment in her character makes her plea seem wooden.\n\nThe one time when Cunanan\u2019s eyes suggest remorse comes when he sees his fragile mother being hounded by reporters outside her California home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOtherwise, Cunanan\u2019s victims flicker on the screen like Macbeth\u2019s ghosts, and finally he is visited by one \u2014 himself, as a child of around 11. And then we have the final flashback, the \u201cRosebud\u201d moment: a scene in which we return to the San Francisco opera house where, it is imagined, Versace and Cunanan met during a 1990 production of \u201cCapriccio\u201d that Versace designed.\n\nCunanan, at that point 21, tries to kiss Versace, but the designer turns away.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not because I don\u2019t find you attractive,\u201d Versace says. \u201cI invited you here because you are a very interesting young man. I want you to be inspired by this, to be nourished by tonight. If we kissed, you may doubt it.\u201d\n\nVersace, in this telling, had some useful advice for Cunanan: Success isn\u2019t about convincing people that you\u2019re special. Success is about hard work. It is sad that Cunanan didn\u2019t learn this from his deadbeat father, but it takes us nowhere in explaining the bloodthirst that followed.\n\nHomophobia, mixed-race identity, sexual abuse, the lust for fame, the worship of celebrity \u2014 each of these themes has been brought forward and then discarded.\n\nLike many a true-crime drama, this second season of \u201cAmerican Crime Story\u201d was more interested in the journey than the destination. I get it. But in the end, like Cunanan himself, the show was a beautiful, glittery, violent, extravagant mess.", "title": "\u2018The Assassination of Gianni Versace\u2019 Finale Recap: A Perfect Boy", "authors": ["Sewell Chan", "American Crime Story"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "One of the reasons we take the story backward is because we want to make the victims the heart of the piece, and they\u2019re amazing people. Andrew was targeting people who had things that he did not, whether that be love, financial success, or moral success. I feel very privileged to have read about Versace. I think he\u2019s underwritten about, underexplored, a remarkable figure.\n\nThe same with Donatella [Donatella Versace, Gianni\u2019s sister and business partner]. They were an incredible couple. Lee Miglin is an extraordinary figure. The greatness that he achieves is from tenacity: As the youngest kid of seven or eight, he arrived in Chicago knowing no one, and he worked his way up. He was the American dream. David [David Madson, a Minneapolis-based architect] was this incredible young man, full of love and looking for love. And Jeff [Jeff Trail, a gay former naval officer] struggling with Don\u2019t Ask, Don\u2019t Tell \u2026 I felt very lucky to tell their stories. I found them very moving and very celebratory.\n\nPhoto\n\nAndrew, on the other hand, who is the central character \u2026\n\nIt\u2019s true that when you get to their deaths, Andrew is this despicable figure. But if you go further back, it\u2019s hard not to find things about young Andrew that are impressive. He was out to people when he was \u2014 how old was he, 17? He was this Oscar Wilde-like wit who would, when confronted by homophobic bullies in school, look at them and bounce it straight back at them. I mean, I could never have done that in school. I just didn\u2019t have it. There was bravery in that. And he was a good friend to many people. He would pay for things. He would be there when they needed him.\n\nThere\u2019s that loss of potential. You feel that on the victims\u2019 side \u2014 these people were ripped from the world and they were achieving so much \u2014 and you feel it also with Andrew. Why couldn\u2019t he have converted his intellect and his consideration for other people into something great? What happened there?\n\nYou don\u2019t want to reduce an actual human being to an avatar of impersonal forces at work in the world, but Andrew is in one sense the weaponization of all the obstacles that have been placed in all those people\u2019s way by homophobia. Even at Versace\u2019s funeral, the priest performing the ceremony refuses to take his partner\u2019s hand in comfort.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nYeah. All of that is real. We\u2019ve got the footage of the priest pulling his hand away from Antonio. That\u2019s not an inference \u2014 we can see it. That priest knew he was on camera, knew he was in front of thousands of people, knew he was at the funeral for this man, and still couldn\u2019t control his hatred. He still felt no need to control it. Versace was so successful he managed to overcome that, which was what was so extraordinary about him. But the whole point of Andrew\u2019s personality was that he wanted to impress people, and he\u2019s born into one of the most marginalized groups in society. That paradox \u2014 How can you impress someone when they find you disgusting intrinsically before you even open your mouth? \u2014 that\u2019s the conundrum of Andrew.\n\nI think it\u2019s tricky. The most homophobic person in this story is Andrew, by far. When he becomes this killer, he becomes a horrific homophobic bully. It\u2019s like he\u2019s soaked up everything and unleashes it on Lee and Versace. He\u2019s like, \u201cI\u2019m going to shame you. You\u2019ve achieved success and I\u2019m going to rip it down, both through physical destruction, but also through the act of scrutiny and having the world look down upon you.\u201d\n\nEven when he was younger and acting as a welcoming figure in the gay community, he was pushing his racial identity as an Asian American to the side. That\u2019s a stark contrast.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou know, he kind of did both. He wanted to change his name from Cunanan to DeSilva so he could say he\u2019s Portuguese rather than from the Philippines. Then he was saying he was Israeli. So yeah, he would push the racial thing to one side. But the sexual thing is interesting, if you look at the way his life tracks. He can\u2019t deal with anyone who might be critical. If he met someone who was homophobic and he wanted to be friends, he would say that he was straight, or that he had a wife and a daughter. He would play the audience. Eventually he went into an audience of these older men that he didn\u2019t have to play to, because he was instantly impressive. He was younger and witty and clever and appreciated. Once he lost that audience, he hit rock bottom.\n\nThere\u2019s this moment we never managed to get into the show which I\u2019ve always thought captured something about Andrew. He was at a party when his descent was really accelerating, and no one was paying attention to him; in fact, someone had already reprimanded him for being really annoying. He just went over to this table and set fire to a napkin. He needed people to run over and notice him.\n\nTo get to the core of a person as protean as Andrew, I suppose you have to identify the desire that makes him shape-shift in the first place.\n\nOn his own, he was very sad and very alone. There were often moments when he said that. If you caught him when he wasn\u2019t high and he wasn\u2019t pretending, he said: \u201cI\u2019m alone and I\u2019m depressed. I haven\u2019t achieved anything and I\u2019m miserable.\u201d He wasn\u2019t stupid. He could see himself in those moments.\n\nBut he could, for example, pretend to be a millionaire while going to a restaurant and pay $500 for a meal. Even if he only had $500 left, for those three hours, everyone at that table would think he was wealthy and successful. Those restaurants became a kind of theater where he could pretend to be a person that he wasn\u2019t. He lived for those moments. When he stopped having those moments, that\u2019s when he killed people.", "title": "\u2018The Assassination of Gianni Versace\u2019: Tom Rob Smith on Making Meaning From Pain", "authors": ["Sean T. Collins", "American Crime Story"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Her second novel, \u201cThe Chandelier,\u201d originally published in 1946, has just been translated into English for the first time, by Moser and Magdalena Edwards. The book, ignored in Lispector\u2019s time, stands out, Moser says, \u201cin a strange and difficult body of work, as perhaps her strangest and most difficult book.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nLispector was always puzzled by this reputation for difficulty. \u201cWhen I write for children, I am understood, but when I write for adults I become difficult?\u201d she once protested. It\u2019s true that her books can be best understood as a kind of cracked \u201cAlice in Wonderland\u201d \u2014 with their gnomic wordplay, obsession with naming and inexplicable punishments. (Of course, the white rabbit in Lispector is \u201ca wounded hare losing blood and running until weakly reaching the end of blood.\u201d)\n\nBut \u201cThe Chandelier\u201d is uniquely demanding \u2014 it\u2019s baggy, claggy and contentedly glacial. We get interior monologues and barometric readings of the drifting moods of a young, unhappy woman named Virginia. Paragraph breaks are few; chapter breaks are nonexistent. Plot? On Page 4, a man\u2019s hat floating down a river snags on a rock. On Page 34, a leaf comes loose from a tall tree, hovers in the air \u201cfor enormous minutes\u201d and falls to the ground.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLispector might be describing the desultory structure of the book itself when she writes of a character: \u201cThe drinks were preventing her from letting the events connect to one another by visible paths but made them follow one another in soft, oblivious, tepidly doomed jumps.\u201d\n\nDid I mention that this novel is charming? Punishing, yes, and maniacally overwritten, but a vulnerable and moving performance \u2014 with a heart-stopping payoff.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI recall the British critic Christopher Ricks once saying that in every long book lies a short one evading its responsibilities. It\u2019s a literary prejudice I share, but in \u201cThe Chandelier\u201d I sense something else: not a shorter, better book lurking, but Lispector\u2019s entire body of work, in miniature, biding its time. So many of the themes, philosophical inquiries and character types that appear here will return, honed as Lispector refines her style and hardens them into the diamond-like perfection of her final books, which are narrated in jagged aphorisms \u2014 \u201canti-literature\u201d she called them.\n\nIf the pages of \u201cThe Chandelier\u201d are so thickly lacquered with description, streams of adjectives and looping repetition, it\u2019s because Lispector is flexing, coming into her power. She\u2019s playing, she\u2019s practicing. These pages are full of finger exercises, arpeggios of thought and perception.\n\nWe see the stirring of her lifelong interest in piercing the veil of language to access existence itself. She tries to evoke this by slowing down the prose in \u201cThe Chandelier,\u201d by making the reader feel its weight. In later books, she was unafraid of posing the point directly: \u201cWhat am I doing in writing you? Trying to photograph perfume,\u201d she wrote in \u201c\u00c1gua Viva.\u201d\n\nHer books stay peaceably indifferent to any imperatives of story \u2014 \u201cThe Passion According to G.H.,\u201d regarded by some as her masterpiece, features a housewife staring into a closet for 200 pages. But with her later restraint, it was her sentences that began to have plots. With their topsy-turvy structure, they contain the drama and the surprise.\n\nA few famous examples. From \u201cThe Passion According to G.H.\u201d: \u201cI finally got up from the breakfast table, that woman.\u201d From the opening of her short story \u201cTemptation\u201d: \u201cShe was sobbing. And as if the two o\u2019clock glare weren\u2019t enough, she had red hair.\u201d From the story \u201cLove\u201d: \u201cNext to her was a lady in blue, with a face.\u201d\n\nIn each, the strangeness come from a splitting \u2014 of women experiencing themselves as subject and object. This fracturing is everywhere in Lispector, and explored intensely in \u201cThe Chandelier.\u201d Virginia, in fact, is practicing looking at everything in this particular way: \u201cShe\u2019d see things separated from the places where they lay, loose in space as in an apparition.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Chandelier\u201d might best be understood as a bridge in Lispector\u2019s work. But even so, it conveys a special charge, an undeniable quantity of genius \u2014 similar to what Virginia felt as she filled her hands with water, that she was \u201ccarrying in the palm of her hand a little bit of river.\u201d", "title": "\u2018The Chandelier\u2019 Offers an Early Glimpse of Clarice Lispector\u2019s Power", "authors": ["Parul Sehgal", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "From \u201cInsecure\u201d to \u201cAtlanta,\u201d \u201cLuke Cage\u201d to \u201cBlack Lightning,\u201d \u201cPower\u201d to \u201cThe Chi,\u201d \u201cblack-ish\u201d to \u201cgrown-ish,\u201d television is undergoing a mini-revolution in terms of African-American representation and creativity, onscreen and (to a lesser extent) behind the camera.\n\nPerhaps an even more important measure of progress is a growing variety in the ways shows approach depictions of race. For a current comparison, we can look at two of the better series around, \u201cThe Good Fight\u201d and \u201cThe Chi\u201d \u2014 one a high-gloss courtroom dramedy and the other a surprisingly traditional kitchen-sink neighborhood drama. They are worlds apart in style but both are set in Chicago and deal in a significant way with race.\n\n\u201cThe Good Fight\u201d took a character, Christine Baranski\u2019s Diane Lockhart, from a show focused on gender (\u201cThe Good Wife\u201d) and switched the emphasis to race by making her a white partner in a predominantly black law firm. But it hedged its narrative bets: The first season balanced Diane\u2019s challenges fitting in at her new firm with a story line about a Madoff-like financial scandal that didn\u2019t have a racial dimension (and in which the principal characters were mostly white).\n\nAs Season 2 opens (it begins streaming Sunday on CBS All Access), that\u2019s still the approach \u2014 two continuing story lines (outside of the legal cases of the week) that share Diane and several other characters, but are essentially separate, in their own bubbles. (And they remain segregated to some degree along racial lines, in a way that\u2019s reasonably plausible.)", "title": "\u2018The Good Fight\u2019 and \u2018The Chi,\u2019 Near Neighbors and Worlds Apart", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "She thanked \u201cevery single person in this building\u201d and her sister before asking the female nominees in the room to stand. \u201cLook around,\u201d she said. \u201cWe all have stories to tell and projects we need financed.\u201d\n\nExpected wins by Oldman and McDormand.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. McDormand\u2019s win was expected, as was Gary Oldman\u2019s (\u201cDarkest Hour\u201d) for best actor.\n\n\u201cIf I fall over, pick me up, because I\u2019ve got some things to say,\u201d Ms. McDormand said.\n\nMs. McDormand finished with, \u201cI have two words to say: inclusion rider,\u201d a reference to a practice by which stars add a clause to film contracts that insists on diversity on both sides of the camera.\n\nJodie Foster, appearing on crutches and joking that the reason was a run-in with Meryl Streep, presented best actress with Jennifer Lawrence, in lieu of last year\u2019s best-actor winner, Casey Affleck. Mr. Affleck bypassed the ceremony amid continued criticism for settling sexual harassment suits in the past.\n\nIn a halting acceptance speech, Mr. Oldman thanked the film\u2019s director and producers; Winston Churchill; his wife, Gisele Schmid; and his 99-year-old mother, who he said was home watching on the sofa. \u201cPut the kettle on,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m bringing Oscar home.\u201d\n\nIt was a democratic Oscars over all.\n\nPhoto\n\nOnly two of the nine best picture nominees went home empty-handed: \u201cLady Bird\u201d and \u201cThe Post.\u201d The other seven collected at least one award each, preventing any one film from sweeping the ceremony.\n\nWinners included legends who had never before won, among them James Ivory (\u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d) and Roger A. Deakins (\u201cBlade Runner 2049\u201d), and first-time nominees like Jordan Peele, who landed best original screenplay for \u201cGet Out,\u201d and Allison Janney, a television stalwart who won over the film academy with her supporting work in the darkly comedic Tonya Harding biopic \u201cI, Tonya.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve been at this a long time,\u201d said Mr. Deakins, a 14-time nominee. \u201cThank you. Thank you very much.\u201d He started his career in the 1970s and was first nominated in 1995, for \u201cThe Shawshank Redemption.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018I am an immigrant.\u2019\n\nMr. del Toro\u2019s best director honor was widely expected \u2014 he took the top prize at several preceding awards shows \u2014 and he was an omnipresent darling of the awards circuit, at one point bringing a case of tequila to an awards function. The win meant that Mr. del Toro had finally won the acceptance of Hollywood, after being looked down on as a horror director for much of his career.\n\n\u201cI am an immigrant,\u201d an emotional Mr. del Toro started his acceptance speech by saying, continuing to note that art has the power to \u201cerase the lines in the sand\u201d between people of different ethnicities. \u201cWe should continue doing that when the world tells us to make them deeper.\u201d\n\nThe best picture award was presented by Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway, who because of a mix-up backstage by PwC, mistakenly announced last year\u2019s best picture winner as \u201cLa La Land\u201d instead of \u201cMoonlight.\u201d\n\n\u201cI want to dedicate to every young filmmaker \u2014 the youth who are showing us how things are done,\u201d said Mr. del Toro when he accepted the award for best picture. \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d also won for Alexandre Desplat\u2019s score and Paul Denham Austerberry\u2019s production design.\n\n\u2018Get Out\u2019 and \u2018Call Me by Your Name\u2019 win screenplay awards.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Peele, who wrote and directed \u201cGet Out,\u201d received a raucous standing ovation for winning best original screenplay, signaling the Hollywood establishment\u2019s respect for his movie and also his arrival as a certified member of that elite group. He thanked his mother, who, he said, \u201cTaught me to love even in the face of hate.\u201d\n\nMr. Ivory, 89, a four-time nominee, won for best adapted screenplay for the gay romance \u201cCall Me by Your Name.\u201d All people, \u201cwhether straight or gay or somewhere in between,\u201d can understand the emotions of a first love, Mr. Ivory said, reading from notes. (Mr. Ivory was previously nominated for directing \u201cA Room With a View,\u201d \u201cHowards End\u201d and \u201cThe Remains of the Day.\u201d)\n\nA #MeToo moment.\n\nActivism and social politics were highlighted in a segment introduced by Ashley Judd, Salma Hayek and Annabella Sciorra, all of whom had gone public with allegations about enduring sexual harassment or worse at the hands of Harvey Weinstein.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe women recognized the seismic shift in Hollywood\u2019s culture in recent months with the rise of #MeToo, and Ms. Judd spoke of the voices \u201cjoining in a mighty chorus that is finally saying Time\u2019s Up.\u201d\n\nThey were followed by an emotional video featuring Mira Sorvino, Sarah Silverman, Greta Gerwig, Geena Davis and Kumail Nanjiani, who injected a note of levity by noting that the box-office lucre enjoyed by recent diverse movies should be an incentive for Hollywood. \u201cDon\u2019t do it for society and representation,\u201d he said, \u201cDo it because you get rich, right?\u201d\n\nDuring their performance of the Oscar nominated song \u201cStand Up for Something,\u201d from \u201cMarshall,\u201d Common and the singer Andra Day were joined on stage by 10 prominent activists, including Cecile Richards of Planned Parenthood; the labor leader and civil rights advocate Dolores Huerta; Bana Alabed, the 8-year-old Syrian refugee who documented the siege of Aleppo on Twitter; and Janet Mock, a transgender activist and television writer and host.\n\nPhoto\n\nDisney wins another Oscar for animated feature.\n\nKobe Bryant is now an Oscar winner: \u201cDear Basketball,\u201d which Mr. Bryant made with the former Disney animator Glen Keane, overcame questions about Mr. Bryant\u2019s past to win the trophy for best animated short \u2014 as some members of the audience exchanged incredulous looks. #MeToo activists had said that a 2003 sexual-assault case against Mr. Bryant was reason not to reward the movie. (The case was dismissed.)\n\n\u201cAs basketball players, we\u2019re supposed to shut up and dribble,\u201d Mr. Bryant said in an apparent reference to the Fox News host Laura Ingraham\u2019s recent criticism of LeBron James for speaking out against President Trump. Mr. Bryant went on to thank his wife and daughters.\n\nDisney continued its Oscars dominance, as Pixar\u2019s \u201cCoco\u201d was named best animated feature, Disney\u2019s sixth straight victory in the category. \u201cRepresentation matters!\u201d shouted its co-director, Lee Unkrich, a reference to the characters and story line of the film, which is centered on Mexico\u2019s Day of the Dead celebration.\n\n\u201cCoco\u201d also delivered the best song winner, \u201cRemember Me,\u201d written by Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez. \u201cNot only are we diverse, but we are close to 50-50 for gender representation,\u201d said Ms. Anderson-Lopez, noting her fellow song nominees. She said she looked forward to the day when \u201call the categories look like this one.\u201d\n\nEarly awards are spread around.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe first hour and a half of the Oscars ceremony honored a wide variety of films.\n\n\u201cPhantom Thread,\u201d Paul Thomas Anderson\u2019s period romance about an obsessive dressmaker, won for costume design. Best hairstyling and makeup went to the World War II drama \u201cDarkest Hour.\u201d The Oscar for production design was given to \u201cThe Shape of Water.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cDunkirk,\u201d Christopher Nolan\u2019s layered war epic, collected Oscars for sound mixing, sound editing and film editing. \u201cBlade Runner 2049\u201d proved victorious in the visual effects category.\n\nAs expected, Ms. Janney completed her awards-season winning streak.\n\n\u201cI did it all by myself,\u201d Ms. Janney said, arriving at the microphone, to prolonged applause. She then added, \u201cNothing is further from the truth,\u201d and ran through a list of names at light speed.\n\n\u201cA Fantastic Woman,\u201d from Chile, was named best foreign film. Rita Moreno, who won a supporting actress Oscar in 1962 for \u201cWest Side Story,\u201d presented the prize. In keeping with the telecast\u2019s theme of looking back at celebrated performances, a clip highlighted Ms. Moreno\u2019s performance in \u201cWest Side Story.\u201d\n\nNetflix film wins best documentary.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a surprise, the Oscar for best documentary went to \u201cIcarus,\u201d a Netflix film about systematic Russian doping at the Olympics. (Russia was banned from the recent Pyeongchang Games, though some of its athletes were still allowed to compete.) It was Netflix\u2019s first Oscar for a feature film, having won last year\u2019s prize for best documentary short, for \u201cWhite Helmets.\u201d\n\nThe expected winner had been \u201cFaces Places,\u201d a lighter, more nuanced film about Agn\u00e8s Varda \u2014 known as the grandmother of the French new wave \u2014 and the environmental photographer JR. Netflix mounted a lavish campaign for \u201cIcarus,\u201d raising eyebrows in the rather staid documentary filmmaking community.\n\nJimmy Kimmel addresses scandals as show opens.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe first Oscars of Hollywood\u2019s post-Harvey Weinstein era took care of its serious business first. As the 90th Academy Awards got underway on Sunday night, the host, Jimmy Kimmel, addressed the sexual harassment scandals that have rocked Hollywood in recent months.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s the kind of men we need more of in this town,\u201d Mr. Kimmel said, pointing to a colossal Oscar statue on the stage, noting that the figure \u201ckeeps his hands where you can see them\u201d and has \u201cno penis at all.\u201d\n\nHe then grew serious for a moment and talked about the #MeToo and Time\u2019s Up movements, which started in Hollywood after the revelations about Mr. Weinstein and have reverberated across the globe, challenging the entertainment industry to make good on its promise to reform itself. \u201cThe world is watching us,\u201d he said. \u201cWe need to set an example.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith that, the ceremony swerved into its usual piquancy, lightly teasing nominees like Ms. Streep, up for her 21st Oscar, and naming Sam Rockwell best supporting actor for his performance as a racist dimwit of a police officer in \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri.\u201d He thanked \u201ceveryone who\u2019s ever looked at a billboard.\u201d\n\nA show with a lot of ground to cover.\n\nPhoto\n\nRarely had more pressure been placed on an Oscar telecast. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences had the burden of trying to keep ratings from falling, while celebrating films that have, for the most part, not been widely seen. The ceremony was expected to acknowledge the appalling sexual harassment scandals that have engulfed Hollywood in recent months \u2014 and then go back to gazing lovingly at the history of moviemaking to mark Oscar\u2019s 90th birthday.\n\nOther conflicting pressures included poking fun at last year\u2019s envelope mix-up, which found \u201cLa La Land\u201d mistakenly named best picture instead of \u201cMoonlight,\u201d while taking the recognition of cinematic achievements like sound mixing and film editing supremely seriously.\n\nThe tonal tug-of-war between frothy self-celebration and serious discussion of the #MeToo and Time\u2019s Up movements made for some awkward red carpet moments. ABC veered from a raucous interview with Taraji P. Henson, who was asked about her recent action film \u201cProud Mary,\u201d to Mira Sorvino and Ms. Judd, both of whom came forward last year with allegations of sexual harassment against Mr. Weinstein.\n\n\u201cI want people to know that this movement isn\u2019t stopping,\u201d Ms. Sorvino said about Time\u2019s Up, an initiative started by Hollywood women and focused on fighting systemic sexual harassment across industries. Ms. Judd, who was scheduled to present an award during the ceremony, said she was grateful that women who speak out about mistreatment are no longer being \u201cdisbelieved, minimized, shamed.\u201d\n\nA minute later, the red carpet hosts were back to squealing over the gowns chosen by stars like Whoopi Goldberg and Jennifer Garner.\n\nAn uneventful red carpet.\n\nSeveral women deeply involved with Time\u2019s Up, including Ava DuVernay and Shonda Rhimes, explained why there were no overt displays from the group on the red carpet.\n\n\u201cWe are not an awards show protest group,\u201d Ms. DuVernay said at a meeting with a small group of reporters last week. \u201cWe made a conscious choice not to do that again.\u201d\n\nViewers wondered if a celebrity would turn the questions around on Ryan Seacrest, the host of E!\u2019s red carpet coverage. He has been accused of sexual harassment, claims he and his network, backed by a third-party investigation, have vigorously denied. But no such confrontation was broadcast \u2014 though Ms. Henson did fix him with a pointed stare that was widely interpreted as such \u2014 and he did not address the accusations. His interviews with celebrities stuck to the typical fare of fashion and film, though according to US Weekly, none of the best actress nominees stopped to speak with him. An article in The Hollywood Reporter on Sunday said the E! broadcast would run on a 30-second tape delay.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the two months since Time\u2019s Up officially began, the group has amassed $21 million for its legal defense fund and, said Tina Tchen, a lawyer heading that initiative, has fielded 1,700 requests for assistance from landscapers, government workers, police officers, prison guards, and hotel and catering workers. (Some 1,250 have been connected with lawyers.) A sister initiative has sprung up in Britain; a group of male allies has formed; a partnership with StoryCorps, the story-collecting organization, has been forged; and the process of making the group a nonprofit foundation has begun. \u201cWe are global at this point,\u201d Ms. Rhimes said.", "title": "\u2018The Shape of Water\u2019 Wins Best Picture as Oscars Project Diversity", "authors": ["Brooks Barnes", "Cara Buckley"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHow I Got Over,\u201d for example, is credited to the gospel artist Clara Ward; her sister Willa says that Clara wrote the song after she was taunted with racial epithets on the way to a performance. Mavis Staples recently said that the Mahalia Jackson version of the song was the first she ever heard sung by a woman. Ms. Staples would later cover the song with the Staples Singers; Aretha Franklin and the Blind Boys of Alabama have also recorded it.\n\n\u201cSitting on Top of the World\u201d was recorded in 1930 by the Mississippi Sheiks.
