The malleable song would be performed in various styles, from folk to country to bluegrass: Cream, Howlin\u2019 Wolf, Willie Nelson, Bob Dylan and Jack White all have versions.\n\nAnd Artur Schnabel\u2019s recording of Beethoven\u2019s 32 sonatas in 1932 was the first complete recording of that collection; it set a template for artists delving into complete surveys of master works, like Glenn Gould\u2019s exhaustive foray into Bach which was recently released on a new box set.", "title": "\u2018The Sound of Music,\u2019 \u2018Rumours\u2019 and More Join the National Recording Registry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cIn 2018, women are killing it.\u201d That\u2019s the opening line of the trailer for the new Mila Kunis-Kate McKinnon comedy \u201cThe Spy Who Dumped Me.\u201d While that invokes the spirit of the current feminist moment, what follows seems to play into stereotypes from an earlier time, like the one about women being bad drivers.\n\nWhen the two are drawn into a world of espionage after the ex-boyfriend (Justin Theroux) of Ms. Kunis\u2019s Audrey is revealed to be a C.I.A. agent, they struggle with a stick shift.\n\nIn the teaser, which dropped Wednesday, an operative played by the \u201cOutlander\u201d favorite Sam Heughan clues the women into the spy game and they grow more competent in their secret-agenting skills, much like Melissa McCarthy\u2019s desk jockey in the 2015 comedy \u201cSpy.\u201d Yet once they\u2019re subjected to potential torture by an enemy, they become hysterical and start spilling secrets. (\u201cAudrey shaves between her boobs,\u201d Ms. McKinnon says.)\n\nCo-written and directed by Susanna Fogel (best known for the short-lived TV drama \u201cChasing Life\u201d), \u201cThe Spy Who Dumped Me\u201d plays off James Bond films, from a title reminiscent of \u201cThe Spy Who Loved Me\u201d to the 007-style opening montage and the sexy song in the trailer: a cover of Nina Simone\u2019s \u201cFeeling Good\u201d by Michael Bubl\u00e9.\n\n\u201cThe Spy Who Dumped Me\u201d lands in theaters on Aug. 3.", "title": "\u2018The Spy Who Dumped Me\u2019 Trailer Stars Mila Kunis and Kate McKinnon", "authors": ["Bruce Fretts"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Which is what makes the real-life, would-be gate-crasher in Laurie Gwen Shapiro\u2019s \u201cThe Stowaway\u201d \u2014 17-year-old Billy Gawronski \u2014 such an incorrigible if symbolic character, a first-generation American living in 1920s New York City who wants to join the famous polar explorer Richard Byrd on his journey to Antarctica. (While Roald Amundsen was the first to reach the South Pole in 1911, Byrd\u2019s stated purpose, 17 years later, was to be the first to haul a plane there to fly over the pole.) The only problem is that Billy has zero experience with anything but his father\u2019s budding upholstery business in Brooklyn. Seeing his future in damask brocade and mohair, he wants nothing to do with it. Zilch. Meanwhile, his Polish grandmother has gazed into her actual crystal ball and seen Billy cavorting with Admiral Byrd.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe backdrop for Billy\u2019s bildungsroman is that moment when America, too, is finding itself amid great social upheaval: Consumer culture, mass entertainment and the Industrial Age are all on the rise, while Jazz Age journalism (in some ways not so different from our modern iteration of infotainment) is hungry for new heroes. Stowing away, then, becomes a means to celebrity as well, and is a bit of a cottage industry unto itself. And so Billy leaps into the Hudson River in a night move to get on board one of the three ships headed south. All goes well until Billy finds two other stowaways squirreled in the same front berth. Their eventual squabbling draws the attention of crew members who unceremoniously remove all three. Only when the press gets wind of it does Byrd himself, always looking for publicity and funding, seem to realize there might be a payoff in this stowaway game. Still, Billy\u2019s father eventually arrives to drag his son home.\n\nHere Shapiro\u2019s story, which is a bit slow to take hold, might have dead-ended, if not for Billy\u2019s determination. After trying to board the second ship, and getting caught again, Billy hitchhikes to Norfolk, Va., the next port of call, in time to wave in the party from the dock. Shapiro tells us the ship\u2019s cook is \u201ctickled by the city kid\u2019s pluck,\u201d and puts him to work in the kitchen. Byrd approves the move, and with a New York Times reporter on board to chronicle every hiccup of the expedition, including the doings of the Polish-American stowaway, they\u2019re off to see the penguins.\n\nThe tale that follows doesn\u2019t raise Billy above what he is, a bit player who in the end isn\u2019t chosen to winter with Byrd on the frozen continent, but he\u2019s not without his moments of heroism, and besides, to the consuming public at home, substance here matters less than the quixotic journey. For this brief moment, Shapiro\u2019s Billy is our Bachelor, our YouTube star. He\u2019s the kid who frees himself from destiny to forge his own, leapfrogging class, symbolizing our wanderlust and the power of imagination over expectation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUltimately, the stumbles in \u201cThe Stowaway\u201d \u2014 including the skimming quality of the prose (Billy\u2019s first wife is \u201ca spicy gal\u201d and wears \u201ctantalizing clothes that soon came off\u201d while the ship deck smells of \u201cmasculine adventure\u201d) \u2014 are overshadowed by Shapiro\u2019s hustle in resurrecting Billy, and a number of side characters, including my favorite, an African-American stowaway named Bob Lanier, who chases the expedition all the way to New Zealand. In an author\u2019s note at the end of this book, Shapiro points us to her own discovery of Billy\u2019s second wife, whom she found alive and ready to tell Billy\u2019s story. \u201cThe Stowaway,\u201d then, is like an intriguing photo album brought out from the bottom drawer: If the gaps between images sometimes frustrate, the granular detail can fascinate. It shows us who we are, and what we\u2019re trying to escape.", "title": "\u2018The Stowaway\u2019 Appeals to the Thrillseeker in All of Us", "authors": ["Michael Paterniti", "Laurie Gwen Shapiro"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Most incredibly, it does, if only for a while. Gabriel happens upon what the skeptical would deem incredible strokes of luck, first locating antibiotics next to a suicide victim\u2019s corpse and then that person\u2019s car keys. In one commendably tense set piece, Gabriel sharp-shoots a zombie off Dr. Carson with his eyes closed \u2014 a miracle, by anyone\u2019s definition. These are textbook examples of darkness in service of a greater good, and in Gabriel\u2019s estimation, they are irrefutable evidence of God\u2019s enduring love. He\u2019s too pious to gloat about being right, but when their fortunes take a turn for the better, the priest smiles and tells the doctor, \u201cI\u2019m not going to say anything.\u201d\n\nBut just as it looks as if they\u2019re out the woods, everything goes wrong and upends Gabriel\u2019s interpretation. Negan\u2019s troopers capture both men and return them to the stronghold from which they made their daring escape, the futility of it all compelling Carson to take his own life. Watching the only person with whom he had a genuine emotional connection die proves to be the last straw for Gabriel, who returns to Negan\u2019s compound a shell of himself. Whenever characters dare to open themselves up to another person on the show, they\u2019re punished not by their confidante, but by crueler forces in the universe itself. The writers wield irony like it\u2019s a dagger.\n\nHope is in awfully short supply on multiple fronts this week. Gabriel\u2019s fears that he has been abandoned by God form poetic echoes with a handful of scenes portending grim things to come. After having piked Gavin through the neck at the close of last week\u2019s episode, Henry seems worrisomely unfazed about what he has done, causing concern about the boy\u2019s empathy in Carol and Morgan. Having received a vicious dressing-down from Negan, the closet turncoat Eugene straightens out and returns to his Savior ways, coolly issuing insulting orders to those scuttling beneath him at their makeshift bullet factory.\n\nThe episode ends by mocking the very notion of hope in such bleak times, as Negan gives what would be a rousing and inspirational speech if it weren\u2019t for the content of his words. He strides before his army like General Patton, readying them to take back the day, but he\u2019s ranting about poisoning his enemies by dipping his signature bat in the zombies\u2019 toxic blood.\n\nElsewhere, gestures of humanity suggest that decency has not been completely extinguished from the world. After some pathetic begging from a contrite (and yet, no less detestable) Gregory, Maggie finds a bit of pity left in herself and allows him and his fellow captives a bit of food and time outside their pen. Dwight and Tara tromp through the woods, their conflicting affiliations keeping a distance between them. Even so, Dwight is being sincere when he tells Tara that he is sorry her lover Denise had to die the way she did. Such little passages of empathy are what have made the series worth getting invested in, though they\u2019re a bit too few and far between this season.", "title": "\u2018The Walking Dead,\u2019 Season 8, Episode 11 Recap: Test of Faith", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Rick readily joins Michonne when she decides to extinguish a burning gazebo where Carl liked to idle. She suggests her actions are a testament to Carl\u2019s memory, but when Rick has to physically drag her away before a herd of zombies can fully encircle them, it becomes clear that she\u2019s making the gesture for her own sake. It\u2019s an old writerly device \u2014 having a character obsess over some meaningless task only to arrive at the cold realization that nothing will bring back the dearly departed. In this instance, it\u2019s executed with less grace than usual.\n\nThat scene is not nearly as calamitous, however, as the inexplicable one in the landfill just before the opening titles. On paper, there shouldn\u2019t be anything odd about this story beat: Michonne and Rick hear trouble nearby and take cover amid the trash, simple as that. But because of some catastrophic misjudgment in postproduction, the final two minutes of the scene have been cut in a way that invokes the surreal incoherence that makes \u201cThe Room\u201d such a hoot. That\u2019s not a good thing.\n\nPerhaps the title cards were intended to quarantine the conflict between Jadis and Simon. Having been thoroughly dressed down by Negan, Simon scrapes up a bit of his masculinity by belittling Jadis and her Scavengers, going so far as to shoot her followers one by one, right in front of her. The show\u2019s callous streak returns stronger than ever in this massacre, which culminates in a hail of bullets that the audience doesn\u2019t see.\n\nAfter Simon shoots the first few Scavengers who look at him funny, we hear him open fire \u2014 but the scene has already moved on. That last volley lasts all of two seconds and plays out offscreen, with only the rat-a-tat sound effect making viewers aware of the widespread carnage. Depicting (or, rather, not depicting) violence in such detached terms certainly falls in line with Savior brutality, but it also makes for alienating television.\n\nNegan and his crew may be sadists, but he isn\u2019t totally unaffected by Carl\u2019s death. He spends the first half of this episode reading the Riot Act to Simon in a transparent attempt to reassert his fading authority. (While ostensibly this season\u2019s primary villain, Negan has spent most of his screen time sidelined.) When Rick radios him in the final minutes of the episode, however, Negan expresses true remorse \u2014 the quality Simon cruelly punished Jadis for not possessing a few scenes earlier. Intentional softness is a rare quantity in this post-apocalyptic war zone, and Negan reveals a kinder and more genuine side of himself as he speaks about the future he had planned for Carl. The happy, gardening Negan we glimpsed in last week\u2019s flash-forward shows himself, however fleetingly.", "title": "\u2018The Walking Dead\u2019 Season 8, Episode 10 Recap: Talking Trash", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "The bat is returned to her rightful owner by the conclusion of the episode, but not before something else comes to pass that has never happened on \u201cThe Walking Dead\u201d: Negan offers Rick leniency. Just when it looked as if the Saviors had long passed the point of reconciliation with the Hilltopper coalition, Negan offers to let Rick live freely as part of his clan. Negan being a scoundrel, he makes it clear that Rick would have a life of custodial work, but walking his staunch stance back from the death penalty is a significant shift. That change may have been spurred by his separation from Lucille, but it still signals that both Rick and Negan are capable of seeing a light at the end of this tunnel. (The warm, soft-focus light of the paradisiacal flash-forwards, perhaps?)\n\nWhether he\u2019s ready or not, Negan is headed for more upheaval on his home front. The tension between him and Simon will soon snap, as each man comes to the individual realization that they\u2019ve reached an impasse. During their altercation, an errant word from Rick alerts Negan to that fact that Simon laid waste to the Scavengers, in direct defiance of the orders Negan had issued him. Elsewhere, Simon tentatively makes his case for mutiny to Dwight, easing his potential co-conspirator into antipathy against Negan. (The agreeably sketchy Steven Ogg makes a meal out of the lines: \u201cLet\u2019s get candid. Let\u2019s get weird.\u201d)\n\nNot that it takes much easing: Dwight is all too eager to take Negan down a peg. Things don\u2019t look so positive for Negan at the conclusion of this week\u2019s episode, as Jadis holds him at gunpoint in a car with an unknown destination. But when he makes his inevitable return, there will be hell to pay.\n\nEveryone wants the same thing \u2014 an end to the hardship \u2014 but the warring factions are unbudging in their positions on how best to achieve that. Still, as time marches onward, as the list of lost lives continues to lengthen, as everyone grows more fatigued and hungry and fed up, reconciliation becomes a little more appealing. In a moment of desperation, Negan immediately compromised and offered Rick his life. It\u2019s only a matter of time until the natural downward course brings the other characters to that breaking point, where the only objective is to establish a cease-fire.\n\nFor now, however, violence can be a sufficient answer to any nagging problems. Jadis has never been one to talk out her problems, and when she comes to blows with Negan, the chances seem slim that both parties will emerge alive. The lingering question is just how bad life has to get before the territorial attitudes and grudges are dwarfed by some darker alternative. As Negan reminds Rick, Carl is barely cold in the ground. In a rare moment of actorly subtlety, Andrew Lincoln flashes a stunned, wounded look, as if wondering what could possibly be worth all this loss.", "title": "\u2018The Walking Dead\u2019 Season 8, Episode 12: Barbed Affection", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Morgan senses the futility of this enterprise, however. He knows what it is.\n\nRick knows what it is, too. He\u2019s still stunned by his son\u2019s sacrifice, unable to speak about Carl when Siddiq approaches him with a patient ear. It\u2019s been so long since the show treated a character\u2019s death with such gravity, that seeing Rick still hurting four episodes later is a welcome reprieve from the usual depravity-of-the-week showcase. The circumstances surrounding Carl and Henry\u2019s respective demises may differ, but speaking generally, the same thing happened to both of them. They are ancillary losses, caught up in the brutal riptide of combat.\n\nThis episode couldn\u2019t have ended anywhere but a graveyard, and sure enough, Carol and Rick gaze out over rows and rows of makeshift headstones in this week\u2019s final moments. Alongside them stands Maggie, who can do nothing but lament \u201cthe cost,\u201d a universal umbrella term for everything precious they\u2019ve lost. (Shades of Tony Soprano grumbling, \u201cHow could this happen?\u201d to an absent God as he sits by his comatose nephew.) Maggie wrestles with self-doubt even as she continues to lust for vengeance against Negan, afraid that staying the course may imperil more innocent lives and wondering how many more they can lose while still considering this war worth fighting.\n\nBecause it\u2019s not slowing down any time soon. Having last been seen riding shotgun with a very angry Jadis, Negan is out of sight in this episode, and hardly out of mind. Simon\u2019s ill-advised power grab among the Saviors has been built entirely around the shaky notion that everything he wants also happens to be what Negan would have wanted. Simon is a persuasive enough public speaker that this manipulation works, for the most part \u2014 though maybe it\u2019s just that commanding handlebar mustache \u2014 but that will fall apart in undoubtedly violent fashion once Negan returns.\n\nSimon cannot be entirely unaware of this, judging by the haste with which he accelerates the Savior counteroffensive. He knows enough to wield the power while he has it, and he won\u2019t let go of it without leaving a few claw marks. The show\u2019s \u201call out war\u201d arc can\u2019t last forever, and discord among the Saviors could be the resolution Rick\u2019s coalition (and the writing staff) have been looking for.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think it ends,\u201d muses Carol in the episode\u2019s most telling moment. Her words can expand to cover the entire show, from the war raging around them to the endless cycle of Pyrrhic victories and crushing defeats that has given the show\u2019s entire run an orderly shape. This episode makes the heartening suggestion that she might not be correct. Whether it\u2019s enemy infighting or a surge of energy on the home front, something has to end all the bloodshed soon. Scanning their private cemetery as if it were a D.I.Y. Arlington, they realize that it has to. They have long since given up too much.", "title": "\u2018The Walking Dead\u2019 Season 8, Episode 13 Recap: Suffer the Little Children", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "BRUSSELS \u2014 John Bolton\u2019s appointment as national security adviser seems to many around the world to represent an uninhibited President Trump, and they are trying to puzzle out what exactly that means.\n\nA fiercely intelligent man with deeply conservative, nationalistic and aggressive views about American foreign policy, Mr. Bolton may bring more consistency and predictability to President Trump\u2019s foreign policy, many suggest. But others worry that his hawkish views on Iran and North Korea, among others, may goad Mr. Trump into seeking military solutions to diplomatic problems.\n\nBut some also wonder whether Mr. Bolton, who has played the outsider even when serving as a senior American diplomat in the State Department and at the United Nations, will be able to adjust to a high-pressure job where he must be less public, less strident and more of a mediator of differing policy views.\n\nAnd it is an open question whether he will be able to manage his relationship with Mr. Trump, who seems to tire quickly of anyone outside his own family who tries to guide or restrict his behavior, his public statements or his instincts.", "title": "\u2018The Whole World Should Be Concerned\u2019: U.S. Allies React to Bolton\u2019s Appointment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOn its website, the comic book publisher Lion Forge states that it is \u201ccommitted to \u2018Comics for Everyone.\u2019\u201d It reflects a particular passion of David Steward II, the chief executive officer of Lion Forge, which is based in St. Louis. \u201cNot only is it the right thing to do, we thought the market was craving authentic characters who had appropriate representation,\u201d Mr. Steward said in a recent phone interview. The approach seems to be working. In February, the Young Adult Library Services Association named \u201cLighter Than My Shadow,\u201d a graphic novel by Katie Green about a young woman\u2019s battle with eating disorders, one of the top 10 \u201cgreat graphic novels for teens\u201d published in 2017. During our interview, Mr. Steward, 40, talked about his career path, diversity in comics, the challenges of the industry and more. These are edited excerpts from that conversation.\n\nHow did you get your start?\n\n\n\nI went to college at American University and graduated with a degree in international business marketing. Then I worked for my dad\u2019s company, World Wide Technology, and realized very quickly it was not for me. Over a dinner, my dad said, \u201cIf you\u2019re doing something you\u2019re passionate about, you\u2019ll never work a day in your life.\u201d That stuck with me and got my wheels turning about what I was really passionate about.\n\nWhat comics did you like as a kid?\n\nI had a Marvel encyclopedia. I didn\u2019t get access to real comic books until around the time Milestone, a comic publishing imprint that showcased African-American superheroes, came out. I remember it was cool to have characters that I could see myself in. When I discovered Comixology, a digital distributor of comics, I started reading again. My girlfriend at the time, who is now my wife, was an avid prose reader. We would be hanging by the pool, and she would read her books and I would read comics.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHow did you go from liking comics to wanting to create them?\n\nI knew I wanted to do something that utilized creative storytelling. Digital comics were on the forefront of all that. You could do flip books and light animation and add soundscapes. Carl Reed, a co-founder of Lion Forge, was working in animation and was looking for the next thing, too. We got together with a couple of other guys and started exploring: Who are the players? What are they doing? Is the market saturated? We wanted to use digital as the litmus test for what you should print. You could tell the retailer: \u201cThis title sold well first digitally. We think people will look for it in the store to collect.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhy did you feel the timing was right for Lion Forge\u2019s diverse heroes?\n\nThe New 52 was launching at DC, and I remember distinctly they had relaunched Static Shock, which is cool because they brought that title to the forefront, but then they didn\u2019t have any black creators on it. I remember thinking, \u201cWhat is this?\u201d It was kind of like a reflection of what someone else thinks that an African-American person is, which is different from actually having more of an authentic representation. Whatever group we are representing, we are definitely having someone of that group be a part of it.\n\nHow did you approach creating these comics and catering to the audience?\n\nI feel like for everybody to participate, you have to have representation that looks like everyone in this country. We\u2019ve been careful to make sure that it is an inclusive line of characters. Kind of like the United Colors of Benetton [laughs], but it feels natural and organic. Another thing is not only looking at core comic book readers, but how can you reach those folks interested in comics but maybe haven\u2019t been invited in? Anybody who comes to our site or our catalog of books will find something there for them. I feel I achieved that goal in the last year with \u201cLighter Than My Shadow.\u201d My wife hasn\u2019t really picked up one of our books \u2014 other than when I\u2019ve asked her to. [Laughs.] She saw \u201cLighter Than My Shadow\u201d on my bedside table and wanted to read it. I\u2019ve truly passed the last mile here.", "title": "\u2018There Are a Lot of Stories That Need to Be Told\u2019", "authors": ["George Gene Gustines"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "At times, when Mr. Trump is focused on a specific person, he has taken action \u2014 hiring Mr. Kelly to replace Reince Priebus, for instance, or empowering Mr. Kelly to expedite the departure of Stephen K. Bannon, the president\u2019s onetime chief strategist.\n\nRecently, people close to Mr. Trump say that he has begun to feel more confident that he understands the job of president. He is relying more on his own instincts, putting a premium on his personal chemistry with people and their willingness to acknowledge that his positions are ultimately administration policy, rather than on their r\u00e9sum\u00e9 or qualifications for the job.\n\nThat could explain the president\u2019s decision to replace Mr. Tillerson and his choice of successor for Mr. Cohn. If people are unwilling to do what he wants, one adviser said, Mr. Trump now believes that he can get things done himself.\n\nRight now, Mr. Trump is surrounded by cabinet officials and a chief of staff who either have caused him negative headlines, such as Mr. Carson and Mr. Shulkin, or have declined to do what he wants, such as Mr. McMaster, Mr. Kelly and Mr. Sessions.\n\nContrary to the notion that Mr. Trump is surrounded by sycophants, the president has aides who are willing to say \u201cno.\u201d But he has increasingly grown frustrated when they do.\n\nMr. Trump also grew frustrated last year with Jim Mattis, the defense secretary, for refusing to enact a ban on transgender members of the military. Mr. Mattis essentially ignored Mr. Trump for several weeks, White House officials said, until the president finally went around him and tweeted it. But Mr. Mattis appears to be safe, even when he ignores the president, in part because he is a general who in Mr. Trump\u2019s mind \u201clooks the part\u201d of a military leader.\n\nMr. Kelly has not fared as well.\n\nA few weeks ago, when the scandal surrounding Rob Porter, the staff secretary, exploded into view, Mr. Trump began working the phones to old friends, telling them that he needed his former advisers back and complaining that he was surrounded by people he did not know. He told them that Mr. Kelly had badly botched the Porter issue. (His language was saltier and unfit for publication, according to several people with knowledge of the calls.)", "title": "\u2018There Will Always Be Change,\u2019 Trump Says as More Personnel Shake-Ups Loom", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Visitors at six lakes in the San Bernardino National Forest and two California state parks come with notebooks, cameras and spotting scopes. The forest service keeps the public about a quarter mile away from nesting sites; land adjacent is closed off, so that eagles won\u2019t feel threatened and abandon their young.\n\nOn a recent cool morning here, mallards flew overhead, pelicans swam on the lake, coots picked bugs out of the mud, and a lone doe sauntered through tall grass. A half dozen birders looked on as a pair of nesting eagles traded places before stretching their wings over the misty waters, snagging a fish.\n\nAt nearby Big Bear Lake, elementary students and skiers and snowboarders often turn up for the count. Workshops and slide shows mix education with entertainment, and participants get a chance to assist in the field.\n\nThis year, 15 bald eagles were spotted: 10 adults, three juveniles and two chicks, month-old youngsters who hatched live on a webcam in February. While 15 eagles may not sound like a lot, this species has been a surprising conservation success in a state suffering droughts and sprawling metropolises.\n\nPhoto\n\nFifteen years ago, most bald eagles were winter residents, arriving inland during the January through August mating seasons, eagles follow the paths of migratory waterfowl.\n\nBut lately, eagle numbers are a bit down. \u201cIn a typical winter, I usually see three to four eagles between my house and work,\u201d said Robin Eliason, the forest service biologist who has led the overall program since 1989. But lately, \u201cI haven\u2019t seen any of those eagles.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe decline could be due to warmer winters, she added. Eagles find more prey on these lakes when it\u2019s colder. An onslaught of severe weather hasn\u2019t helped, either: the state has suffered a long drought sandwiched between torrential rain and inland flooding, plus the worst wildfires in California\u2019s 167-year-history.\n\nBald eagles are historically more Californian than most Hollywood stars. They were brought to the brink of extinction in the 1970s, victims of the pesticide DDT, which killed thousands of birds.\n\nCalifornia\u2019s population hung on in the Channel Islands, a rocky archipelago off the coast of Los Angeles, where dozens were relocated for breeding and release programs throughout the 1980s. Nesting pairs have since spread across the state. In 1977, bald eagles nested in eight of the state\u2019s 58 counties. Today, they are found in 41 counties.", "title": "\u2018These Eagles Are More Than Just a Symbol\u2019", "authors": ["Adam Popescu"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "By Claudia Dean\n\nThey grew up in the water.\n\nIn primary school they\u2019d go when school was out and guitar lessons were over. Splashing and kicking until her mum had to leave town for home.\n\nThere was a grated gateway that they would have to cross to get to the creek. She was always scared of the empty ground beneath her and how her skinny legs could slip through the metal bars, scrape up her shin, trap her thighs.\n\nShe never told him she was scared. They\u2019d sit under the little concrete bridge in the shallow water and emerge at the rumble of an overhead car.", "title": "\u2018They Grew Up in the Water\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Sharing plates at the dinner table creates connection and encourages idea sharing! As a proudly efficient (fast) eater, I find that sharing inevitably results in a more democratic meal pace. Seriously, spare your friends and family the self-righteous indignation and enjoy your meal \u2014 together! FOODSNOOT, BROOKLYN, N.Y.\n\nThis is how much of the world eats every meal. I work with refugees, and most of the time there are communal platters of food. They offer me a plate, and occasionally will have a bowl for soup, but usually all eat from platters. They usually use a piece of a flat bread like pita or bigger ones to pick up food. Sharing probably precedes cooking. KATHLEEN, TUCSON\n\n\u2018I don\u2019t want to be distracted by watching to see who\u2019s licking her fingers\u2019\n\nSome readers complained they found food-sharing unsanitary.\n\nHygiene. That\u2019s my chief objection. Even with designated serving utensils, there are opportunities for sharing bacteria and viruses. I don\u2019t want to be distracted by watching to see who\u2019s licking her fingers, who\u2019s touched his phone. (Everyone knows where that phone has been.) H.L., DALLAS\n\nThat\u2019s all a restaurant needs \u2014 a table full of guests who get the flu or some other infectious disease from eating from each other\u2019s plate. JOAN IN CALIFORNIA, CALIFORNIA\n\n\u2018I have finally left the table with back spasms and nausea, feeling as if I\u2019ve fled a Roman orgy\u2019\n\nOther readers said allergies, dietary concerns and other health issues discouraged them from participating in shared meals.\n\nI am not a heavy eater, and I have chronic back pain that gets worse and worse as the banquet goes on. Some servers refuse to take no for an answer if I ask to skip a course, and, unless I\u2019m alone, I still have to wait for everyone else to finish. Several times, including one birthday dinner, I have finally left the table with back spasms and nausea, feeling as if I\u2019ve fled a Roman orgy where the participants were encouraged to vomit so they could continue to eat and drink all night. This is not my idea of fun. SUSAN SETTLEMYRE WILLIAMS, RICHMOND, VA.\n\nI have food allergies and there are some cuisines that I just do not enjoy. Being forced to share a meal that I carefully choose based on likes and limitations is sometimes quite challenge to me. HOPE, MCLEAN, VA.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs a vegetarian in a mostly not-veggie society, sharing has other downsides. Even if there are some other veg-heads in attendance, the risk of a dead animal tainted serving spoon winding up in the wrong place turns my stomach, as does the inevitable idiot who doesn\u2019t use the serving utensil and dips right in with their fork. B. DAWSON, WEST VIRGINIA\n\n\u2018A nice meal is not a game of Go Fish\u2019\n\nThe pacing of shared meals was a concern for several readers, as it was for the author.\n\nA nice meal is not a game of Go Fish. Give me a plate of separate foods: classically meat, a vegetable and a starch. Then I can enjoy the use of my fork and knife to mindfully consume my meal at my own pace with dignity. JOSEPH MURPHY, PORTLAND, ORE.\n\nWhat is lost when an exquisitely prepared meal of several courses is consumed like a communal basket of chili fries? BOBMEINETZ, LOS ANGELES\n\nSmall plates are an excuse for the kitchen to serve in any order, with any timing. They\u2019re designed for pictures and not for a well-paced, well-designed dinner experiences. MHM, NEW YORK\n\n\u2018Four people or less, very similar palates and/or food sensitivities and an ability to not be selfish.\u2019\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnd while some readers felt that communal dining has its advantages, most agreed that certain rules should be followed.\n\nBasically small plates require rules: Four people or less, very similar palates and/or food sensitivities and an ability to not be selfish. MJ, BROOKLYN, N.Y.\n\nI believe in a well-composed meal where ingredients work together, not against each other. PERSON OF INTEREST, SEATTLE\n\nWhat really annoys me is restaurants that encourage sharing but create dishes that are impossible to divide. I was at one recently that served a single piece of crostini that, when we tried to cut it, cracked into bits and flew off the plate. At another place, we were two people, and they served three croquettes. So we each had one, then tried to split the third, only to have it fall apart and ooze all its cheese filling onto the plate. How hard would it have been to serve four croquettes? ELIZABETH, NEW YORK\n\nA distinction should be made between a communal meal, where small plates are drawn from large platters, and are shared \u201cfamily style,\u201d and the format where a dish you order specifically is passed around randomly to all. The \u201ctasting menu\u201d version, where \u201cChef\u201d decides the timing and order of the delivery, is very much part of the new cruelty. And it\u2019s getting old. SERA, NEW YORK\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018Old Man Yells at Cloud\u2019\n\nAnd finally, one disgruntled reader had enough.\n\nThe headline for this article, but more so the comment section, should be \u201cOld Man Yells at Cloud.\u201d ANONYMOUS, NEW YORK", "title": "\u2018This Is How Much of the World Eats\u2019: Readers React to Food Sharing at Restaurants", "authors": ["Lela Moore"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "School gun violence and the terror it creates have riveted America again since a gunman shot and killed 17 last month at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla. The public outrage has produced a new wave of protests, including walkouts in schools across the country on Wednesday.\n\nBut acts of violence aren\u2019t the only source of school terror.\n\nFor each heinous attack successfully carried out, there have been many more scores of threats in schools across the country. And while thankfully no one dies because of a threat, fake or foiled attacks can be terrifying, too.\n\nAfter the Parkland attack, we reached out to students across the country, asking them to tell us about threats their schools have received. We heard from more than 100 teenagers, some describing hiding in dark closets and classrooms, sometimes for hours, as they braced for an attack.\n\nIn the five months from August to December 2017, there were at least 671 bomb or gun threats \u2014 or both \u2014 directed at American schools, according to the Educators School Safety Network, a nonprofit that provides school safety training. In the past month, since the Parkland shooting, there have been more than 465 bomb or gun threats or both.", "title": "\u2018This Is Not a Drill\u2019: 11 Students on the Terror of Lockdowns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "The return of a blockbuster action franchise couldn\u2019t bump \u201cBlack Panther\u201d from the top of the box office this week. The Marvel movie earned another $27 million for its fifth straight week at No. 1, leaving \u201cTomb Raider\u201d to settle for second place.\n\n\u201cBlack Panther\u201d has now made $605 million domestically, making it the second-fastest movie to reach $600 million behind \u201cStar Wars: The Force Awakens.\u201d Globally, it has made $1.2 billion and sits in 14th place all time. But ticket sales fell steeply in its second weekend in China, where audiences complained about \u201cpolitical correctness.\u201d\n\nThe rebooted \u201cTomb Raider\u201d earned $23.5 million in its first weekend, according to comScore, which compiles box office data. The Warner Bros. and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer movie, which cost about $94 million to make, stars the Oscar-winning Alicia Vikander as the grim and acrobatic action hero Lara Croft. It barely performed better at the box office than 2003\u2019s \u201cTomb Raider: Cradle of Life,\u201d which starred Angelina Jolie and closed that era of the franchise. The reboot received tepid reviews and a B grade from ticket buyers in CinemaScore exit polls.\n\nThe surprise hit of the week was Roadside Attractions\u2019 \u201cI Can Only Imagine,\u201d which opened to a strong $17 million in just 1,629 locations (compared to 3,854 for \u201cBlack Panther\u201d), easily making back its budget. The film stars Dennis Quaid and depicts the back story behind the song of the same name by the Christian band MercyMe. The marketing team made a strong push on Christian radio and at church events, resulting in a large audience driven by women and moviegoers over 35; the film received an A+ CinemaScore grade, suggesting it may continue to thrive from word of mouth.", "title": "\u2018Tomb Raider\u2019 Can\u2019t Topple \u2018Black Panther\u2019 at Box Office", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Their efforts led to a nationwide survey of 31,000 university students in which 51 percent said they were sexually harassed at least once in 2016. Advocates said the actual figure might be even higher; in most cases, neither the victims nor bystanders report the episodes \u2014 often because they feel nothing will be done.\n\nMany Australian women a generation removed said it was at least as bad or worse during their student days. And, they said, the culture of student politics did not help.\n\nEach of Australia\u2019s main political parties has an active youth wing \u2014 the Young Liberals promote themselves to anyone ages 16 to 31; Young Labor focuses on anyone under 26 \u2014 and their efforts often overlap with on-campus campaigns.\n\nMany lawmakers started out in this milieu, with student bodies or union boards, before moving to staffing roles, party offices or legislatures. Three of Australia\u2019s five most recent prime ministers \u2014 Malcolm Turnbull, Tony Abbott and John Howard \u2014 began their political careers as students at the University of Sydney.\n\nThe dynamics of power in these groups have not been equal. Women make up only 29 percent of the Young Liberals membership, according to the group\u2019s website. Student leaders say men tend to dominate the senior ranks across parties and campuses.\n\nRegular gatherings of young people in politics \u2014 like the annual National Union of Students conference in December \u2014 are also notorious for alcohol-fueled inappropriate behavior.\n\n\u201cAt one of them, a Queensland Labor man threatened to rape me as I was walking back to my room,\u201d said Tammy Franks, a Greens member of the South Australian Legislative Council, who was active in student politics in the \u201990s. \u201cI was on the sexual harassment and grievance committee, and there was a lot of that type of behavior.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Toxic Culture\u2019 Stymies Australian Politics\u2019 #MeToo Moment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "But back to that barbecue fork: The opening scene takes place at a Hollywood estate, where Pink Floyd is playing \u201cMoney\u201d on a sun-drenched lawn in front of swim-suited, dancing guests. Meanwhile, George \u2014 Getty\u2019s oldest son by his first wife and the heir apparent to Getty Oil \u2014 seems to be having a psychotic break from what we later learn is a cocktail of booze, amphetamines and \u201cvarious barbiturates,\u201d and he locks himself in a small garage. Women peer in, pounding at the windows, begging George to let them in.\n\nGeorge, crazed, sets his sights on the fork and, after a brief pause, thrusts it into his stomach. There\u2019s an audible puncture. The women, previously screaming, fall silent in horror. They watched the whole thing.\n\nIf this were a run-of-the-mill family, a run-of-the-mill father would be devastated. But Getty appears not to be. We meet him the next morning at his manor outside London (a practical location for doing business all around the world), where his hired security specialist, James Fletcher (Brendan Fraser), informs Getty that his son\u2019s death was self-inflicted: And if the barbecue fork hadn\u2019t killed him, he adds, the drugs surely would have.\n\nGetty, standing by a spit bowl held by his butler, toothpaste flying from his mouth, barks back, \u201cI will not have suicide!\u201d He shows no sadness over losing a son, but he is irate at the possibility of bringing shame to the family name. In this telling (which FX notes is \u201cinspired by actual events\u201d), Getty is not what you would call a happy man.\n\nBut it would be too easy to call him a bad one. One of the most promising aspects of this series is the attempt one assumes it will make to understand the psychology of this outwardly unfeeling billionaire. Why would the man once called the wealthiest private citizen in the world show no visible sadness at the death of a son? Or refuse to pay a ransom he can easily afford? Why would he install a pay phone at his mansion just to stop guests from freeloading long-distance calls?\n\nOn the day of George\u2019s funeral, he delivers a Shakespearean monologue that starts to gets at the heart of it. One of his mistresses walks into a room where Getty sits alone, lamenting his \u201cfeckless progeny.\u201d (The writing here by Simon Beaufoy gets particularly rich.) Panic-stricken, he compares his family dynasty to the Rockefellers, the Vanderbilts, the Hearsts, and even \u201cthe Kennedys, Irish peasants for God\u2019s sake.\u201d\n\nHe adds: \u201cDo you think that bastard Joe Kennedy would have countenanced simpering idle wasters for children? No Sir!\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWe don\u2019t know it from this episode, but Getty\u2019s own father, who also made a fortune from oil, didn\u2019t just fork over wealth to his son. He paid Getty $100 each month to live and buy oil leases for cheap: If oil sprung, Getty profited 30 percent and his dad got the rest. Not a deal exactly. But by age 23, Getty had made his first million. And when his dad died, he inherited only a fraction of his father\u2019s fortune \u2014 his father was said to disapprove of Getty\u2019s lifestyle and failed marriages (ultimately, there were five, harem not included).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow a father himself, J. Paul Getty disapproves of his own sons, but for slightly different reasons: He was given comparatively little from his father, but he succeeded; Getty\u2019s sons were given opportunities but failed. What seems to matter most is that both his father and his sons disrespected Getty the tycoon. None have given him the appreciation that likely would have validated \u2014 and maybe softened \u2014 Getty the man.\n\nAnd so, with his surviving sons mentally axed from the future of the business, Getty needs a business heir to save the family name. Enter the young John Paul Getty III, direct from Rome, in bell bottoms, a T-shirt and long, disheveled curls on the day of George\u2019s funeral. Getty is turned off by the sight of Paul, but then he catches wind of Paul\u2019s knowledge of art history; art collecting is Getty\u2019s great tax-deductible weakness. The clouds part. Getty sees an answer to the family failings.\n\nOne quick helicopter ride to a deepwater oil rig later, and Getty is explaining the mechanics of the family business to his grandson as ocean spray wets their faces. Paul, who has really showed up to ask for money, sees a problem: The system is a closed loop of investments. \u201cThere\u2019s no drawing from the trust?\u201d he asks Getty. \u201cUgh, God, I can always tell when one of my brood wants money,\u201d Getty says. He\u2019s seen this before.\n\nGetty asks how much Paul needs. Paul says $6,000. Getty wants to know if any of the trouble came from drugs; Paul denies it. \u201cWomen?\u201d Paul nods. \u201cWell, that\u2019s a great Getty weakness.\u201d It\u2019s a bonding moment, and one of the funnier in the episode. Getty\u2019s momentary doubt has been restored through their shared interest in sex.\n\nIn the end, though, Getty is a businessman, and he proposes a deal. He will give Paul his $6,000, and the grandson will work an oil rig for six months. \u201cCash up front?\u201d Paul asks, his sights set solely on getting out of England to sort out some unknown trouble he and his girlfriend are in back in Rome. \u201cNever,\u201d says his grandfather, \u201cbut I\u2019ll write you a check.\u201d Soon he has announced to the family at dinner that Paul \u2014 and not Paul\u2019s father \u2014 is being groomed to take over the business.\n\nThis is as close as Paul will get to being in his grandfather\u2019s good graces. Paul\u2019s father, in a rage at being skipped over, shows Getty a magazine spread that Paul appears in, nude, partying and making sport of the family name. This turns out to be a trespass Getty cannot abide \u2014 another Getty damaging his legacy. His brief hopes for the future have been dashed.\n\nWith that, Getty buys Paul a plane ticket back to Rome, sans check, just before he welcomes his mistress into his study for some pharmacologically enhanced sex. Perhaps it\u2019s the closest thing to feeling love that he can get.\n\nSpare Change:\n\n\u2022 \u201cTrust\u201d puts a notable twist on the actual kidnapping. In the final moments of this episode we see the Italian gangsters approach Paul, and they hand him a sack. Paul places it over his own head, playing into the theory that he faked the whole thing to extract money from his grandfather. Next week, we\u2019ll see in whom Getty places his trust.\n\n\u2022 The use of \u201cMoney\u201d in the opening scene is a little hokey, but the song came out the same year as the kidnapping \u2014 it\u2019s not a stretch to believe that the real Pink Floyd might have played a Getty pool party. It\u2019s anyone\u2019s guess who in the live band was supposed to be making the money-changing sound effects that open the song. (The standard album version was used to score the scene.)", "title": "\u2018Trust\u2019 Series Premiere Recap: Feckless Progeny", "authors": ["Natalie Rinn"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 Thirty years after Gao Chengyong embarked on a succession of 11 rape-murders of women in northwest China, a court sentenced him to death on Friday, following an investigation that involved sifting through 230,000 fingerprints.\n\nThe sentence by a court in Baiyin, a small city in Gansu Province, was not unexpected in China, which executes more prisoners than any other. But the verdict against Mr. Gao, 53, a farmer, itinerant worker and shopkeeper, was widely reported, and applauded, in China, where the killings drew intense attention.\n\n\u201cThe motives for the defendant Gao Chengyong\u2019s crimes were utterly despicable, the means were utterly vicious, the nature of the crimes utterly vile,\u201d the court\u2019s verdict stated, according to the China News Service, an official agency.\n\nThe court found that Mr. Gao had killed 11 women, whom he usually followed to their homes. He murdered all but one around Baiyin; another woman was killed in Baotou, a city in the north Chinese region of Inner Mongolia. In many cases, he molested the women and dismembered their bodies. Besides homicide, he also was found guilty of rape and of defiling corpses. She said she had been imprisoned and beaten, and could no longer bear the torment. She said she wanted to escape and join Ms. Choi in South Korea.\n\nShe said she would carry poison, to kill herself if she were captured.\n\nFor Ms. Choi, 63, a grandmother with large brown eyes and a steely fortitude, getting the rest of her family to South Korea was the most important thing left in life. She had fled North Korea herself 10 years ago. Her son had made it out too, as had her sister\u2019s daughter, now a hairdresser living near her in Seoul, the South\u2019s flashy capital.\n\nMs. Choi longed to be reunited with the sister, a 50-year-old dressmaker with her own home business, and also the nephew she had left behind. She wanted to get them to safety, out of the reach of the government that had arrested her husband, her brother-in-law and her son-in-law on suspicions of helping people leave. They had been targeted as enemies of the state and were never seen again.\n\n\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\n\nShe said she would carry poison, to kill herself if captured.\n\n\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\n\nOne evening this past summer, Ms. Choi got the news she had been waiting for.\n\nAs she opened her apartment door, her niece, 25, shouted: \u201cMy brother called. He accepted a post as ambassador to Canada last September, saying his role as first vice president was \u201cmore about protocol than about executive action.\u201d He arrived in Lima, the capital, shortly after midnight on Friday to assume the presidency, one day after turning 55.\n\nHe told reporters waiting at the airport that they should have \u201cfaith and optimism\u201d and that \u201cPeru always comes first.\u201d But he has been mostly silent in the past few weeks as Mr. Kuczynski\u2019s administration unraveled.\n\nSeveral lawmakers have spoken highly of him in recent days and reiterated his need for a supportive legislature.\n\n\u201cWe need to give Mart\u00edn Vizcarra room to govern, just like we did before with Mr. Kuczynski,\u201d said Congressman H\u00e9ctor Becerril of the Popular Force party.\n\nStill, he may have a hard time finding unwavering political allies. []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "SANTIAGO, Chile \u2014 Latin American leaders braced for the worst last year as they watched President Trump take office, with his vows to protect Americans \u201cfrom the ravages of other countries making our products, stealing our companies and destroying our jobs.\u201d\n\nThen something remarkable happened.\n\nGovernments across the hemisphere began forging closer commercial ties with one another and paring back some of their own protectionist policies, embarking on a course reminiscent of what the United States itself had proposed in the 1990s but which failed to materialize: a free trade area reaching from Canada to Chile.\n\nWashington\u2019s protectionist stance comes as leaders in the region are increasingly looking to Asia, and China in particular, to expand trade, obtain loans and finance infrastructure projects.\n\n\u201cTrump has inadvertently done more for commercial integration in Latin America than many Latin American leaders managed to accomplish,\u201d said Patricio Navia, a political scientist at New York University.", "title": "\u2018World Upside Down\u2019: As Trump Pushes Tariffs, Latin ties to the Trump team, had kept contemporaneous memos about his interactions with the president. (Mr. Comey also kept memos.)\n\n\u201cSpent very little time with Andrew McCabe, but he never took notes when he was with me,\u201d Mr. Trump wrote. \u201cI don\u2019t believe he made memos except to help his own agenda, probably at a later date. Same with lying James Comey. Can we call them Fake Memos?\u201d\n\nJeremy Bash, who served as chief of staff to Leon E. Panetta in his roles as C.I.A. director and defense secretary during the Obama administration, said in an interview that current and former officials were alarmed to see a president so intent on eroding the public\u2019s trust in the F.B.I. They are keenly aware, Mr. Bash said, that Mr. Trump\u2019s insults have a way of making it to TV, and vice versa.\n\n\u201cIt seems to be a very short distance between the president\u2019s Twitter device and the megaphone of Fox News and other allies on Capitol Hill,\u201d Mr. Bash said. \u201cI think most professionals I speak with think he will ultimately fail, but they worry we are a few Fox News segments away from more and more people in that conspiracy theory echo chamber.\u201d\n\nSome experts question the decision of Mr. Comey and others to publicly hit back at the president. Mike German, a former F.B.I. agent who is now at the Brennan Center, a public policy and law institute, said the public exchanges were further proof of an eroding of trust between the head of the executive branch and its traditionally apolitical civil servants.\n\nHe said the former officials\u2019 willingness to speak out against the president could spell problems for Mr. Mueller.\n\n\u201cI would imagine from Bob Mueller\u2019s point of view having potential witnesses tweeting back and forth with the president is the last thing you want,\u201d Mr. German said. \u201cThe credibility of everyone involved is being torn to tatters in broad daylight.\u201d", "title": "\u2018You Will Not Destroy America\u2019: A Trump Battle Is No Longer One-Sided", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Ortega, 55, is charged with first-degree murder and second-degree murder, and her trial, in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, is expected to last several weeks. Ms. Ortega, who has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity, faces life in prison if convicted; if acquitted on an insanity defense, she could be committed to a psychiatric facility.\n\nIn opening statements on Thursday, prosecutors said that Ms. Ortega resented Ms. Krim and that the children were killed as a calculated act of spite against her.\n\nOn Thursday, in her first day of testimony, Ms. Krim recounted how she had discovered the horrific scene in the family\u2019s apartment on West 75th Street after learning that Lulu had never made it to dance class. She found her children stacked in a bathtub with their eyes open and blood all over their bodies, then watched in horror with her 3-year-old daughter, Nessie, as Ms. Ortega plunged a knife into her own neck.\n\nOn Friday, Thomas Brown, a security guard who was working in the Krims\u2019 apartment building, said that Ms. Ortega had never spoken to him before the day she killed the children.\n\nThat day, as he was preparing for his shift to end at 4 p.m., she approached his desk in the lobby and asked in broken English whether Ms. Krim was home. He told her that he had just seen Ms. Krim leave with Nessie. Ms. Ortega then went to the elevator with Lulu and Leo in tow, and he never saw them again.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt was a shock to me that she said anything,\u201d he said.\n\nMs. Krim returned to the apartment around 5:10 p.m. and searched for her children. Glenn Looby, who had replaced Mr. Thomas, was in the lobby when she called from a landing outside the family\u2019s apartment, asking if he had seen her children. When he said he had not, she went back up to the apartment. A few minutes later, he said, she came out screaming about her children being murdered and he called 9-1-1.\n\nOver the two and a half years that Ms. Ortega worked for the family, Ms. Krim said on Friday, there were other times when she thought Ms. Ortega was acting oddly. She had considered firing the nanny, but ultimately decided against it.\n\n\u201cThere was nothing to fire her over,\u201d she said. \u201cShe was on time every day. She was interacting with the kids. She was doing most of her job.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter the cross-examination had concluded, Stuart Silberg, an assistant district attorney, asked Ms. Krim if she thought she had missed any warning signs. Ms. Krim asked for a break.\n\nShe returned, and finished her testimony describing how Ms. Ortega had reacted to a pregnancy that ended in miscarriage. When Ms. Van Leer-Greenberg objected to Ms. Krim\u2019s testimony about the miscarriage, Ms. Krim shouted, \u201cLet me finish telling my story!\u201d Ms. Ortega, she said, had been jubilant when told the Krims were expecting a fourth child. But when she was told of the miscarriage months later, she showed no sympathy.\n\n\u201cShe didn\u2019t say anything,\u201d Ms. Krim said. \u201cShe didn\u2019t give me a hug. She gave me no emotion at all. She actually looked mad at me.\u201d\n\nAs Ms. Krim spoke, Ms. Ortega, sitting a few feet away, looked down at her lap and shook her head.\n\nSoon, Ms. Krim told Mr. Silberg that she had enough. As she left the witness stand, escorted by court officers, she raged at Ms. Ortega.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re evil!\u201d she shouted. \u201cYou\u2019re evil! And you like this. You\u2019re getting pleasure.\u201d\n\nJustice Gregory Carro reminded jurors that the mother\u2019s outburst was not evidence.", "title": "\u2018You\u2019re Evil!\u2019: Mother Rages at Nanny During Murder Trial", "authors": ["Ashley Southall"]}
